column2: ALBANY, Jan. 30--Use of shortterm bonds to finance the proposed $400,000,000 State bonus to veterans of the second World War received strong support today but a companion proposal to couple bonus payment with levying additional special taxes was received with caution.

DETROIT, Jan. 30--The legal gates were thrown wide open in Federal District Court today by Judge Frank A. Picard in his effort to define for the United States Supreme Court the line at which travel time of a worker exceeds "a trifle."

Cats can be as "up-stage as people," Paul Gallico, author, declared yesterday at the annual meeting of the New York Women's League for Animals at the home of Mrs. S. Sloan Colt, 740 Park Avenue. He spoke in gratitude at the meeting, Mr. Gallico said, because the league, which maintains the Ellin Prince Speyer Hospital for animals at 300 Lafayette Street, "saved the lives of my two cats, Chin and Chilla."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--Department store sales in the week ended Jan. 25 were 17 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1946:

CHICAGO, Jan. 30--A resolution urging building trade unions to end restrictive practices as a step toward greater efficiency and economy in construction work was adopted today by the Associated General Contractors of America.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (U.P.)-- The report on newsprint made public today by Senator James E. Murray, Democrat, of Montana, former Chairman of the Senate Small Business Committee, was compiled by the Federal Trade Commission in 1939 at the request of the then Attorney General, Homer S. Cummings.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Jan. 30--Hans Fritzsche, the most influential wartime voice of the German radio, concluded his defense before a German denazification tribunal today, declaring: "It is my misfortune that, with the best of intentions, I harmed Germany."

A newcomer to the middleweight division's "big time" will be presented at Madison Square Garden tonight in the person of Pete Mead. Mead, who bills himself out of Grand Rapids, Mich., will appear in the main bout of ten rounds against Harold (Red) Green, hardpunching battler from the Brownsville section of Brooklyn.

Because of the sudden indisposition of Fritz Busch, originally scheduled to direct last night's performance of Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde," he was replaced by Wolfgang Martin, who made his first appearance on the Metropolitan podium.

WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 30-- Earl Bunting, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, told the Wilmington Chamber of Commerce tonight that better human relations and team work between labor and management, as well as reforms in labor legislation, are essential to industrial peace.

Trans World Airline maintenance crews' faulty installation of the mechanism governing vital instruments on the pilots' control panel was established yesterday as a major cause of the crash of a TWA Constellation near Shannon Airport, Ireland, last Dec. 28.

The strides being made by the American National Theatre and Academy augurs well for the future of the non-profit, Federalchartered organization. Besides going all-out to bring into being the Experimental Theatre and aiding the tottering American Repertory Theatre, ANTA is spearheading a series of events in a campaign to spread its credo at a dinner and reception tonight in Philadelphia under the auspices of that city's Art Alliance.

Ways to overcome weather hazards in flying were outlined yesterday by Dr. V.K. Zworykin, experimenter in electronics at the Radio Corporation of America's Princeton Laboratories. He addressed the Institute of Aeronautical Sciences yesterday at the Hotel Astor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--President Truman, in a new approach to broad national problems of nonpartisan character, has decided to take a poll of opinion among the various State Governors before determining on a course of action. He hopes in this way to give greater effect to the Jeffersonian concept of the Federal Union as one of delegated powers received from the sovereign States.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--President Truman appealed tonight, on the sixty-fifth birthday anniversary of President Roosevelt, for all Americans to enlist in the "continuing fight against the scourge of infantile paralysis."

ATLANTA, Jan. 30--The Georgia Senate Judiciary Committee today ordered public hearings on the Talmadge-sponsored white primary measure, which was approved yesterday by the House. The hearing's were scheduled for Monday through Thursday of next week.

Developing of new means for producing man-made snow was reported yesterday before the meeting of the American Physical Society at Columbia University. The report was presented by Dr. Irving Langmuir, Nobel Prize winner; Vincent J. Schaefer and Dr. Bernard Vonnegut of the General Electric research laboratory, Schenectady.

"THE trouble with such books," said the professor, "detective stories, mysteries, spy stories and such, is that they deal with the greatest crises possible in human lives and leave all the meaning and emotion out. What is interesting about a murder is not to guess who did it, but to know why he did it, what desperate spiritual forces drove him to the crime, and how he felt about it afterward.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP)-- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation today approved a $12,500,000 loan to the Lustron Corporation to be used in financing production of prefabricated veterans' housing. The announcement said the Chicago firm is to spend $3,500,000 of its own money before drawing on the RFC loan.
LITTLE AMERICA, Jan. 30 -- Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd arrived here today by an unprecedented flight over the Ross ice pack from the airplane carrier Philippine Sea.
The old Fordham Flash will Be right back where he started when the bell rings to open the National League season--with the New York Giants.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Jan. 30 The United States cannot, in sincerity, call upon other nations to open their gates to Europe's displaced persons while our own remain closed, Governor Dewey of New York declared today. He called for an adjustment of the country's immigration laws "to give refuge to our proper share of displaced persons, whether they be Christians or Jews."

STUART, Fla., Jan. 30--No angler would ever have an opportunity to get bored in this fishing resort, for if you get tired of reef fishing or offshore fishing you can fish inside the inlet, and if this palls you can go up the river or to one of the many lakes and fish for the over-size large-mouth black bass and tremendous crappies.

ATHENS, Jan. 30--The first meeting of the Security Council's Balkan Inquiry Commission took place this afternoon in a closed session in the Hotel Acropole. It ended in an undeniable atmosphere of suspicion and ill will.

Australia's post-war plan to reduce interest on $130,000,000 of callable dollar bond debt was advanced to a third stage yesterday, with the registration of $45,000,000 of fifteen-year bonds to bear interest of 3 3/8 per cent. Announcement of the step was made at the Australian Consulate here by Ambassador Norman J.O. Makin at the same time that the issue was formally registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
LONDON, Jan. 30--Conditions in the stock markets today generally were cheerful although paint shares were a weak exception in the industrials.

William A. Lockwood was honored yesterday by officials of the New York Curb Exchange on the occasion of his twenty-fifth anniversary as the Curb's general counsel. Edwin Posner, chairman of the board and president pro tem, was host at a luncheon held at the Lawyers Club.

Morris Raphael Cohen, long before his death on Wednesday, had become an almost legendary figure in American philosophy, education, and the liberal tradition. He had written wise and scholarly works well known not only to professional philosophers but to lawyers and judges, men such as Justices Holmes and Brandeis and Cardozo, whom he counted among his intimate friends.

OTTAWA, Jan. 30--As soon as the formalities of opening the new session of Parliament was completed this afternoon the Canadian Government laid on the table of the House of commons the text of its proposals on the German peace settlement. Later Louis St. Laurent, Secretary of State for External Affairs, gave an account of the situation that has arisen in London between the Canadian Government and deputies of the Council of Foreign Ministers.

ALBANY, Jan. 30--In a new move to protect the public against news leaking out of grand jury investigations, Senator MacNeil Mitchell of Manhattan and Assemblyman Harry A. Reoux of Warren County offered a bill today to require witnesses before a grand jury to take an oath of secrecy.

A decline in the cost of living during the closing half of this year was predicted unanimously by eleven leading economists in appraising the 1947 business outlook at a meeting of the Conference Board Economic Forum, it was announced yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.
Responding to bitter complaints from commuters who do not play cards, the Long Island Rail Road will forbid the reserving of seats in crowded trains for those who do, it was learned yesterday.

MOSCOW, Jan. 30--The Russians have opened a combined restaurant and night club rivaling anything to western Europe. It is lavishly decorated, stocked with the best food and wines and equipped with two bars, two bands and a floor show.

We commend the Board of Estimate most heartily for its unanimous action yesterday that clears the way for construction of a $17,500,000 union bus terminal west of Eighth Avenue between Fortieth and Forty-first Streets. This is probably the most constructive piece of work that the board has turned in for a good many months and Mayor O'Dwyer deserves much of the credit for bringing it about.

TOKYO, Jan. 30--Japan's highest law enforcement official, Morita Fukui, Public Procurator General, tonight warned the Government and Public Office Workers Union that the general strike planned to begin at midnight Friday was illegal and "may endanger the occupation aims of the Allied forces."

Presenting the case of Austria yesterday before the deputies of the BigFour Foreign Ministers, Chancellor Figl requested them in effect to draw up a peace treaty that would be a "Magna Carta" for his country instead of a death warrant, such as the present Allied regime is rapidly becoming.

Two West Pointers, Glenn Davis and Felix (Doc) Blanchard, more familiarly known as Mr. Outside and Mr. Inside, who hogged the headlines during the football season, had the full glare of the spotlight on them again yesterday when they were the center of attraction at the annual meeting of the All-America Football Conference, nearing its close at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel.

Sheila Gitkin, 13 years old, and Thomas Kneitel, 14, were graduated from elementary school yesterday. Sheila had her corsage, red roses with silver ribbon, and Tommy had his special suit--but there wasn't any graduation march.

OTTAWA, Jan. 30 -- Viscount Alexander of Tunis, Governor General of Canada, and Lady Alexander will be the guests of the President and Mrs. Truman at the White House on Tuesday and will visit New York on Friday and Saturday next week.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30--The Citizens Committee on Displaced Persons will direct a campaign to get the present session of Congress to adopt legislation which would permit 400,000 European displaced persons to enter America during the next four years, it was announced today by Dr. Earl G. Harrison, committee chairman.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--Senate members of the joint Congressional Atomic Energy Committee expressed concern today that the new United States Atomic Energy Commission might divulge the secret of the atomic bomb before the security of the United States had been assured by some effective international control.

Unless granted relief in the form of higher passenger fares and more favorable interim mail rates, most of the nation's airlines are threatened with financial troubles for the first six months of this year that may lead to several bankruptcy cases, C. Bedell Monro, president of Pennsylvania-Central (Capital) Airlines, declared yesterday.

Wings for Trifles In the annals of air travel there is one recurrent episode which the newspaper reader is sure to meet several times a year. It has to do with a fugitive from justice whom the law has finally run down after a country-wide search.

Two Army privates who spent a day and a half hiding in an abandoned building on Governors Island a stone's throw from the historic military prison from which they had escaped with three others in the pre-dawn hours of Wednesday, again were in custody last night.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 30 --The official representatives of seventeen governments have agreed that without quick expansion in production and consumption, the world will head straight into its severest economic collapse.

Something more than tax concessions will be needed to make tenement rehabilitation attractive to investors, Robert F. Wagner, City Commissioner of Housing and Buildings, warned yesterday. Mr. Wagner conferred on the subject with forty representatives of veterans, real estate, contracting, architectural and other organizations.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 30 (AP)--Gustave Ring's Argentine colt, Lord Grillo, survived a nose finish and a foul claim today to capture the featured seven-furlong Matecumba Purse at Hialeah Park.

The Department of Justice filed a civil suit in Federal Court yesterday charging four corporations with a conspiracy to monopolize and restrain trade in the high tension electrical cable industry in violation of the anti-trust laws.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--The House seized the portal-to-portal back pay issue with such determined vigor today as to suggest that the first measure to quash these claims might well emerge there, despite the fact that the Senate already has been long engaged on the subject.

Commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System, continued to expand last week, increasing $35,000,000 to a new high of $3,883,000,000, it was disclosed yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: During the last few years of his life Sidney Hillman came to Tucson at frequent intervals for rest and I came to know him intimately enough to enjoy his confidence.

Eugene L. Larkin of the Wykagyl Country Club was elected president of the Westchester County Golf Association yesterday at the annual meeting in the Roosevelt Hotel. Mr. Larkin succeeds Earl A. Ross of the Westcheater Country Club, who had held the post five years.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Jan. 30-- Sir Leonard Lyle, head of the sugar combine, Tate Lyle, Ltd., told a press conference today he believed Imperial preferences would continue for a generation at least, despite United States pressure for their scaling down or abolition.

A member of the Dutch resistance movement described here yesterday his efforts to help rebuild the Jewish community of Rotterdam by building a school for Jewish youths brought in with visas from western and eastern European countries.

CHAMBERSBURG, Pa., Jan. 30 --Letterkenny Ordnance Depot, a 20,575-acre Army reservation four miles from here, is an example of what Maj. Gen. Everett S. Hughes, Army Chief of Ordnance, meant when he declared last week that the Army should obtain proper storage facilities for its reserve equipment, or dump a lot of it, which otherwise will rust, on the scrap piles.

Establishment of nine new highranking positions in the Police Department was approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate at the request of Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander, with a new $8,850 post of Chief of Detectives leading the list.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 30-- David O. Selznick announced today that his next production, "Portrait of Jenny," with Jennifer Jones and Joseph Cotten, would be filmed entirely in New York, starting on Feb. 10. Ninety per cent of the picture will be photographed on exterior locations, and the producer has engaged stage space for interiors at the Pathe Studio in New York.
ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- Governor Dewey approved today the Desmond bill, providing $2,500,000 of State funds to continue the school luncheon program for the rest of the school year.

A total of 11,152 Brooklyn mothers received care last year through the Visiting Nurse Association of Brooklyn, it was reported yesterday at the twenty-eighth annual meeting of its Maternity Center Division at the association's headquarters, 138 South Oxford Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30--The Securities and Exchange Commission announced here today that it will apply tomorrow before Federal Judge Robert A. Inch in Brooklyn for the appointment of an independent trustee for Cosmo Records, Inc., of New York City and its three subsidiaries.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 30 --A meeting of the United Nations Security Council has been called tomorrow at 3 P. M. to mark retirement from the presidency of Norman J.O. Makin of Australia under the rotation policy, which requires designation of a new chairman every month.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 30 (AP)-- British soldiers and police rounded up several hundred Jews in hastily erected screening pens in the Montefiore quarter of Jerusalem and ancient Jewish tombs today in a relentless hunt for kidnappers who seized two British hostages, then set them free.

The Johns-Manville Corporation, in its annual statement issued to stockholders yesterday, reported a new peacetime sales record of $92,049,044 for last year, an increase of $6,055,368 over the 1945 volume of $85,993,676.

Trade quarters here indicated yesterday they were reconciled to continuance of the wartime excise levies on furs, jewelry, cosmetics, handbags and other items in the so-called "luxury" category, as foreshadowed in the House vote pegging the taxes at the current 20 per cent level.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--The committee for reciprocity information, concluding tariff hearings, will inform the State Department that the pressure for high tariffs is noticeably less now than it was in 1938 when similar hearings were held.

BREMEN, Germany, Jan. 29 (Delayed)--Although apathy to all forms of politics is a distinguishing feature among the population of this newly created Land [state] in the United States zone, the public will be called to the polls at least twice in the next few months, Military Government civil administration officials said today.

A cloud of confusion hung over the City Hall hearing on the choice of an agency to proceed with construction and long-term operation of the New York City airports. An effort seemed to be under way for a time to make a whipping boy of the airlines and blame them somehow for the financial plight into which the city has got itself over these fields.

Although there is no skiing close to metropolitan New York, some of the best sport of the season appears to be in store in the Adirondacks, the Green and White Mountins and the Laurentians of Eastern Canada. New snow has been reported in many of the popular areas.

Contributions and pledges totaling $12,225,000 were reported yesterday by Louis M. Loeb, chairman of the campaign of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, for $12,000,000 to maintain 116 affiliated health and welfare agencies. The final report on the funds raised during the drive was made by Mr. Loeb at a luncheon meeting in the Hotel Plaza.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 (AP)--Fifteen European opera stars will put on a one-night benefit performance next week to earn enough money for boat fare home because financial and union difficulties have stymied their plans for a five-week opera season.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 31--At least 1,500,000 Jews must remain in Europe and be integrated into its economy, the Jewish Labor Committee in convention here was told today by its executive secretary, Jacob Pat of New York.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Jan. 31-- The Episcopal Church of St. James the Less was the scene of the marriage here today of Miss Marguerite Aubert Eshleman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. I. Stauffer Eshleman of this community, to Gordon Miller Henderson, son of Thomas A. Henderson of New Haven, Conn., and the late Mrs. Henderson.
Realty brokers and property owners expressed surprise yesterday at the size of the increase in assessed valuations tentatively set for the coming fiscal year.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31--Local lung rest therapy brought six out of fourteen sufferers from advanced tuberculosis back to health, Dr. Alvin L. Barach of Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, reported here tonight before the Chicago Tuberculosis Society.

LINDEN, N.J., Jan. 31--A jurisdictional dispute involving union laborers and carpenters employed on the new $8,000,000 laboratory project of the Standard Oil Development Company here, was marked today by a melee in which 100 laborers massed two picket lines in front of the East Linden Avenue entrance to the project and barred the carpenters and others from going to work.

With charges and countercharges of gambling "fixes" enveloping several professional sports, major league baseball, which hasn't had even the hint of a scandal in more than a score of years, lost no time yesterday in taking steps to assure keeping its house clean as owners of the National and American Leagues met in separate sessions at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Mary Canberg, young violinist from Grand Rapids, Mich., gave her debut New York recital last nighi at Town Hall. In a long and exacting program she showed herself a gracious and graceful player, with a fine feeling for the music, notably for that of Brahms.

The necessity for community action to combat racial and religious bias and the importance of handling such matters with tact to reduce the "sharpness of issues" was stressed yesterday by speakers at a meeting under the auspices of the State Commission Against Discrimination at 270 Broadway.

New York's first major attraction of the indoor track season, the fortieth annual games of the Millrose Athletic Association, will draw an illustrious turnout of athletes and a capacity crowd of 15,000 to Madison Square Garden tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--The Senate's campaign investigating Committee recommended today that the Corrupt Practices and Hatch "clean politics" acts be repealed outright and supplanted, before 1948, by a new and more effective law.
MOSCOW, Jan. 31--The system of teaching literature in teachers' colleges and universities was sharply censured today for following the lines of estheticism and political aloofness.

Two ex-convicts on parole, charged with taking part in a $4,000 hold-up in a Brooklyn bar and grill yesterday, were caught after a short chase in which the victims, police and passersby took part. A third man escaped with the loot.

HARRISON, N.Y., Jan. 31-- Forty-five pupils of the Kohut School for Boys here, waiting this afternoon for a train of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad to take them to New York for a two-day vacation, saw one of their teachers become trapped on the tracks and flung to his death by a locomotive.
PORTSMOUTH, England, Saturday, Feb. 1--Britain's royal family sailed for South Africa today on the Vanguard, the nation's largest and newest battleship.

The stock market showed again yesterday no inclination to venture beyond the levels of last September as profit-taking stemmed a fresh forward push on the Stock Exchange. Gains which ranged to 2 points in some of the heavy industrials were reduced to fractions and in some cases eliminated by a last-hour assault.

BERLIN, Jan. 31--In a seven-and-a-half hour session today the Allied Kommandatura failed to agree on the procedure for the election of officials of the Free German Trade Union. As a result the trade union's thirty-man central committee is expected to be dissolved on Feb. 3.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--The possibility of applying nuclear energy to the propulsion of aircraft and to a number of other peacetime uses were among the current studies reported to Congress today by the United States Atomic Energy Commission.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31--The Philadelphia Record, last of this city's crusading newspapers, and The Morning Post and The Evening Courier, only dailies in Camden, N.J., were sold today along with the Philadelphia radio Station WCAU to The Bulletin Company, publisher of The Philadelphia Evening Bulletin.
Shelby York has been appointed record sales manager for Majestic Records, Inc., with headquarters in Elgin, Ill.

Flood control is an important and worth-while project in New York, as in other States. The creation of cheap hydroelectric power is also, of itself, a commendable objective. We should be cautious, however, in approving projects toward these worth-while ends which threaten the integrity of the forest preserve, especially the Adirondack State Park, which has been set aside as inviolable under the State Constitution.

A campaign to encourage the development of new apartments in existing Queens County buildings was announced yesterday. The venture is led by Queens Borough President James A. Burke, with the cooperation of the American Legion and other organizations, and Daniel E. McAvoy, Federal Housing Expediter for New York City and Long Island.

The marriage of Miss Janet Gregory Cleveland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robertson L. Cleveland of 45 East Eighty-fifth Street, to Thomas E. Falvey Jr., son of Thomas E. Falvey, also of this city, and the late Mrs. Falvey took place here yesterday in the Chapel of the Beloved Disciple of the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest.

After listening to the pleas of spokesmen for eighty-one of the city's 109 departments, Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson predicted yesterday that the tentative expense budget for the 1947-48 fiscal year may reach a total of $1,150,000,000, the highest in the city's history.

Short supplies of better quality rayon goods have slowed spring dress deliveries, according to market sources yesterday. Deliveries to date are considerably behind those of a year ago, it was reported.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- A special Senate committee to investigate the national petroleum resources declared today that if large-scale war came again this country could not meet its essential military and civilian requirements from the continental reserves now known.

BERNARDSVILLE, N.J., Jan. 31--Mr. and Mrs. Catesby ap L. Jones of this place have announced the engagement of Mr. Jones' daughter, Marion Evelyn, to Wilmer Hoffman Kingsford, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving B. Kingsford, also of Bernardsville.

A coordinated hunt by four police agencies was pressed last night for the four youths who kidnapped, robbed and attacked Mrs. Phoebe Hill, ballet dancer and second wife of Max Hill, author and radio commentator.

Although smaller than in the preceding month, flotations of new bonds in January were the largest for that month since 1945. The total of $262,652,000 for thirty-nine issues compared with $269,642,000 for twenty-four issues in the preceding month and $69,755,000 in twenty-six issues in January, 1946.

Aviation displays the breadth of its field by the many sciences upon which it touches. This was well shown this week at the annual Honors Night of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences. Some of the awards then made fell within the narrower confines of aeronautics itself, but many paid tribute to the correlated sciences which are vital to the development of flight.

PARIS, Jan. 31--When negotiations are resumed with Viet Nam they should be on a new basis, with all previous agreements considered dead as a result of the attack on the French in December, in the opinion of officials in close touch with the Indo-China situation.
The flailing, thudding fists of Harold Green, Brooklyn middleweight, put at least a temporary check to the title chase of Pete Mead, Grand Rapids, Mich., boxer, in Madison Square Garden last night.

In the highest annual rise in nineteen years, the tentative assessed valuation of taxable real estate and special franchises in New York City was increased $1,141,146,406 for the fiscal year 1947-48, topping increases since 1928, it was disclosed yesterday.

WITH TASK FORCE WILLIWAW on Adak Island, Jan. 31-- The weather of this strategically important island of the Aleutian chain today lived up to its reputation for changing quickly and often as reporters observed the beginning of the final phase of maneuvers of the 919 officeers and men in this Task Force commanded by Colonel Joseph D. Raney.

PARIS, Jan. 31--A French memorandum on the Ruhr, to be delivered to the Big Three powers tomorrow, will propose that the coal and steel industries there become the property of those nations signing the peace treaty with Germany.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Jan. 31--In a sentence handed down today the Bavarian denazification tribunal sentenced Hans Fritzsche, the German Government's principal radio spokesman during the war, to nine years at hard labor in a labor camp, confiscation of all his property not needed for minimum subsistence and the permanent loss of his civil rights.

Witnesses at yesterday's hearing before the Public Service Commission in the investigation of the rate structure of the Consolidated Edison Company testified that the company has a $101,934,000 construction budget for 1947 for its electric plant and that the company needs a rate return of not less than 6.5 per cent.

Under circumstances as mysterious as those attendant upon his disappearance last Monday when he dropped out of sight while presumably under the closest police surveillance, David (Pete) Krakauer surrendered yesterday in the Paris football bribe case.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--Moscow's alleged design to combine German technical discipline with Russian manpower would, if successful, destroy "the last chance of saving liberal democratic civilization," according to a statement issued today by Senator Styles Bridges, New Hampshire, Republican.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--Drastic action to eradicate the hoof and mouth disease in Mexico was urged in a report made today by a Mexican -United States commission of veterinarians to Secretary of State Marshall.
ALBANY, Jan. 31--For the third successive week increases of capital featured the weekly bulletin of the State Banking Department made public today.
Specially trained searchers employed on the United States Customs enforcement division have made 100 marijuana seizures in the Port of New York in the last two months, it was disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)-- Despite an attack of laryngitis, President Truman left the White House tonight to join in a tribute to Democratic minority leader Sam Rayburn of Texas.

The clans gathered last night to the music of 200 bagpipers as the United Scottish Clans of New York and New Jersey held its first indoor festival. The event, which honored the memory of Scotland's patriot bard, Robert Burns, was held at the Ninth Regiment Armory, 125 West Fourteenth Street.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Two scientists reported today a development of a new radiation method which preserves foods in one - millionth of a second and "eliminates" some cancer in animals.

A visit to a displaced persons' camp in Germany is a painful experience for any human being. These rootlesssettlements of uprooted citizens are the saddest waiting rooms in the world-- and the most shameful as the aftermath of a war fought to re-establish the rights and dignity of man.

The Maritime Commission announced yesterday an agreement with the Isbrandtsen Steamship Company, Inc., returning to its operation the twenty vessels whose charters were canceled on Jan. 9. The cancellations followed a hearing by the commission wherein it was determined that the company had violated its obligations under the fleet charter.

Three of the outstanding players in the major leagues -- Stan Musial, of the world champion Cardinals, Pete Reiser of the Brooklyn Dodgers, and Hank Greenberg, recent acquisition of the Pittsburgh Pirates--have yet to agree to terms for the 1947 reason.
Mrs. Genevieve Rivera, 33-yearold divorced mother of two children, will spend the next year in the House of Detention for Women for contributing to the delinquency of her 14-year-old son.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 31 (AP)--Warren Wright's Faultless, who might become Calumet Farm's main reliance in the big stakes for 3-yearolds, today inaugurated his 1947 campaign with a popular triumph in the six-furlong Sea Gull Purse at Hialeah.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--Examiners Howard Hosmer and O.G. Barber of the Interstate Commerce Commission recommended today that the ICC approve a proposal of forty-six Class I railroads to pool the earnings involved in operation of sleeping car service of the Pullman Company under the ownership of those railroads.

Beset With Doubts How, said the announcer in the course of a brief commercial chat over this column's favorite radio station the other night, how can we hope to get at the truth in the conflict of news reports and opinion now coming out of Asia without some background information of our own?
The "Iron Curtain" definitely does not apply to Czechoslovakia, Laurence A. Steinhardt, United States Ambassador to the central European Republic declared yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 31-- Twentieth Century-Fox announced today that Rex Harrison has postponed his projected trip to England and will play the leading male role in the screen adaptation of "The Foxes of Harrow" after he completes his current engagement in "The Ghost and Mrs. Muir."
WARSAW, Jan. 31--The victorious Government bloc has decided upon a broad political amnesty in a major move to bring about internal peace in Poland, it was learned today.

Reflecting a covering movement in near months, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned strong yesterday and closed 13 to 35 points net higher, with the March, 1947, position leading the advance.

The All-America Football Conference's dream of getting Army's Glenn Davis and Felix (Doc) Blanchard for its San Francisco team collapsed yesterday as Secretary of War Patterson turned thumbs down on their application and that of Barney Poole for leave in order that they might play professional football.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--H. Parker Sharp, general counsel of the Jones Laughlin Steel Company, asserted today that not only were there moral and practical reasons for opposing Government protection of foremen's unions but that only a person desiring to change the American way of doing business would promote such a revolutionary undertaking."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--The International Emergency Food Council today voted immediate and longrange measures to help meet what it termed a "rising crisis" of world food shortages.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month was the smallest since last August and the dullest for a January since 1944. Sales exceeded the million-share mark in only six sessions, the largest of which was 1,590,720 shares on Jan. 13.

An arrangement with the British Government to provide for importation of women's shoes into the United Kingdom was announced yesterday by L.L. Horch, regional director, the Department of Commerce. Each American producer of women's shoes will be permitted to ship during 1947 an amount not to exceed 50 per cent of the value of his average annual shipments to the United Kingdom during the years 1936, 1937 and 1938.

MOSCOW, Jan. 31--Extensive improvements are to be made and production increased at the huge Magnitogorsk metallurgical combine in the southern Urals, which already is described as "unequaled in Europe."

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31 -- Southwestern Public Service Company of Dallas, Tex., and the York Corporation of York, Pa., filed registration statements today with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering 180,000 shares of preferred and 64,438 shares of common stocks.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: "Science and engineering," said Secretary Harriman in a recent address on the future of free enterprise, "directed only to production, will not solve our social problems. * * * Surely if we apply the genius that has created our productive capacities also to the goal of economic stability * * * much can be accomplished.

A Polka Ball was given last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria as the fourteenth annual entertainment of the kosciuszko Foundation, which for more than a decade has presented a series of colorful benefit fetes here and in other cities to foster cultural and intellectual relations between the United States and Poland.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Permit me to congratulate you on your editorials on smoke abatement. You are performing a splendid public service and one which is necessary.
The success story of wartime experiments to find new cures for the age-old disease of malaria emerged yesterday in reports from a local hospital and from a prison in Stateville, Ill.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Col. James McCormack Jr., 36-year-old member of the War Department General Staff, was appointed today by the United States Atomic Energy Commission to the important position of director of its division of military application.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The newly constituted Senate War Investigating Committee struck out today, even before the formal selection of its Democratic membership, into the preliminaries of its promised grand-scale inquiry into the war spending of the Roosevelt and Truman Administrations.
Kuhn, Loeb Co., banking firm prominent in the development and reorganization of railroad systems here since before the turn of the century, is celebrating today its eightieth, anniversary.

PALM BEACH, Jan. 31--Blasting at the Association of American Railroads for its failure to accomplish the objective of improving service, Robert R. Young today charged that at the present rate it would take twenty years to modernize the railroads and that by that time the present new cars would be obsolete.

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- France played her traditional role in foreign affairs today and stepped in with a compromise proposal for procedure on the German peace treaty. She offered a plan to solve the primary conflict of the Foreign Ministers deputies who are facing insistent demands from the smaller powers for greater participation in the treaty making.

The United States should so adjust its immigration laws as "to give refuge to our proper share of displaced persons, whether they be Christians or Jews." Writing in these terms to the first post-war convention of the Jewish Labor Committee at Atlantic City on Thursday, Governor Dewey aligned himself warmly with the humane policy which President Truman has been urging for more than a year.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 31--Devious are the ways in which California couturiers gradually accustom the eye to descending waistlines. Beltless princess dresses, with the design centered at the hipline, and small self cords replacing belts, suggest or stress a lowering line.

TOKYO, Jan. 31--Five hours after Gen. Douglas MacArthur, acting in his capacity as Supreme Commander of Allied forces in Japan, had forbidden the threatened general strike by Japanese Government workers and affiliated public utility unions, labor leaders formally bowed to his edict.

Concluding the hearings which it has held in recent weeks, the Committee for Reciprocity Information will inform the State Department that the pressure for high tariffs is noticeably less today than it was in 1938, when similar hearings were held. There are various reasons, in our judgment, why this should be true.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 31--The Yugoslav Government announced tonight that it had sent two notes to the Vatican Secretariat of State protesting (1) against the issuing of visas for and the financing of voyages to South America of "known war criminals" and (2) against the harboring of "known war criminals" in Vatican territory.

WARSAW, Jan. 31--The Polish Government rebuked the United States today for misunderstanding conditions here, and bitterly denounced the British Broadcasting Corporation's Polish-language broadcasts as an incitement to murder in Poland.
SECURITY COUNCIL Met in brief session and decided to wait a few days for reply from Albania on British complaint on mining of Corfu Channel.

TOKYO, Jan. 31--Premier Shigeru Yoshida late this afternoon completed reconstruction of the Japanese Government, ousting three members of his Cabinet and the head of the Economic Stabilization Board. At the same time he redistributed ministerial posts among those who remained in office.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 31--Faced with the challenge of world leadership, this country finds itself unqualified in attitude and personnel to carry out this role, James Reston, diplomatic correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, asserted here tonight.
The urgent need of Christianity is a single Church of Christ, the Right Rev. Henry Knox Sherrill, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States, said last night.

The nation's farmers regard food research by manufacturers as their most valuable contribution to building markets for farm crops, according to a survey just completed by Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc. The survey, which will be followed by others, is the first effort of its Kind to get a highly selective consensus of farmer opinion on their relations with other members of the food industry, it was stated.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Surplus goods are now competing with private industry as industrial reconversion is about ended, Robert M. Littlejohn, War Assets Administrator, stated today in a report to Congress on the activities of the War Assets Administration during the last three months.

BOSTON, Jan. 31--The business of trying to analyze snow conditions, a practice this correspondent initiated back in the early 30's, when the word "ski" was still foreign to American ears, becomes increasingly difficult as the winter moves along.

"CHILDREN OF VIENNA,"* Toy Robert Neumann, is a dramatic parable of the desperate youngsters living in the ruins of Europe. It is perhaps too theatrically arranged to be wholly convincing as a story, but its details and its episodes inexorably bring home to us the tragedy of a generation barely existing, with little to eat, little to wear, little to hope.

The annual report of the New York Curb Exchange issued yesterday shows a net increase to surplus for the year 1946 of $347,579, compared with the increase to surplus of $317,163 the year before. The consolidated income statement of the Exchange includes its operating affiliates, the New York Curb Exchange Realty Associates, Inc., and the New York Curb Exchange Securities Clearing Corporation.

This is the time when sleeping Earth stirs with the first restlessness of a new season. When February's sun sends sharper-angled rays to hills and fields there's a mellowness on quiet sunny days that foretells the closing era of winter. The second month has something in common with the eleventh.

Robert Grant 3d and Clarence C. Pell Jr., national racquets doubles champions, went down in defeat yesterday as the international team match between England and the United States started at the Racquet and Tennis Club.
Reconciliation between the Russian Orthodox Church in the United States and the patriarchal church in the Soviet Union is imminent, it was learned here yesterday.

John Street Church, 44 John Street the "Cradle of American Methodism," will hold a reopening service tomorrow at 11 A.M. The meeting house that was built 106 years ago has been closed for all public services for several months while structural repairs were made.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Joint Congressional Committee on the Economic Report joined President Truman today in expressing the hope that business would reduce prices; that labor would refrain from excessive wage demands, and that both would strive to increase productivity.

ATLANTA, Jan. 31--Former Gov. Ellis Arnall said today that he was not among Governors replying to an inquiry from President Truman during the coal strike because he received no such communication from the Chief Executive.
Small apartment buildings in scattered sections of Manhattan formed the bulk of properties passing to new ownerships in deals reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Republican members of the House Ways and Means Committee held a secret meeting today on the reciprocal -trade question and were reported later to have shown little sympathy toward possible compromise with the Administration.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 31-- This week's meetings of the Indian Princes in New Delhi appear to have emphasized some deep-seated fears among them regarding their position in an independent India-- and some opposition within and outside the princely ranks.

HAMBURG, Germany, Jan. 31-- On the eve of the verdicts in the Ravensbruck trial, the official Soviet observer, Col. V. Vassiliev, declared today that he was informing Moscow of his dissatisfaction with the way the trial has been conducted.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31--Beginning tomorrow the name of the Trade Development Corporation, advertising agency here, will be Swaney, Drake and Bement, Inc., it was announced today. No change in the structure or operation of the corporation has been made and the new name has been adopted purely for better identification.
Keen Johnson, Under-Secretary of Labor, warned last night against the reintroduction of wartime labor-management controls which "in peacetime run counter to our democratic traditions."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--A further realignment of House Republicans' official policy on fiscal matters was in prospect today. This would make any income tax reduction in 1947 dependent upon ability to apply a substantial amount, possibly as much as $5,000,000,000, to retirement of the public debt.
TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 31 (AP)-- Herman Keiser, setting a new course record of 62, moved into the lead in the 72-hole $10,000 Tucson open golf tournament with a half-way total of 129 today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 31-- The United Nations Securtiy Council convened twenty minutes late today, debated briefly for less than sixty minutes and then adjourned in some discomfiture as the Russian representatives scornfully berated the practice of calling "useless" sessions to solve nothing.

Governor Dewey urged that the benefit of legal counsel be extended to an increased number of persons Who lack funds to hire counsel, in giving his endorsement yesterday to the campaign of the Legal Aid Society of New York for $200,000 to meet these needs.

The Holland - America Line's Veendam, now fully reconditioned and repaired, was turned over to her owners yesterday at Rotterdam by the Netherlands Dock Shipbuilding Company, of Amsterdam, according to word received here by Frederick R. Wierdsma, the line's general manager for the United States and Canada.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)--A program for improving safe flying on commercial lines was laid before the House Commerce Committee today by David L. Behncke, president of the Air Line Pilots Association.

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- Apart from South African gold-mining shares, which suffered from late profittaking, the stock markets here were generally cheerful today. The slump in the gold issues followed the rise in prices caused by details of a rich bore-hole strike at Western ultra deep levels.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--Any plan for settling displaced persons from the Baltic states and Poland in Alaska has been deferred in the absence of immigration laws which would make it possible, it was said today.
In a setting that had all the outward trappings of a judicial proceeding, the State Athletic Commission yesterday put off until Tuesday the Rocky Graziano $100,000 bribe hearing.

If all promises and plans hold, Broadway first-nighters will have a busy calendar this month. At least twelve openings are listed for the next twenty-eight days and three or four more may come in if booking arrangements can be concluded.

The National Maritime Union, CIO, and the negotiation committee for thirty-nine steamship companies and agents on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts have agreed to accept Paul Kleinsorge, Stanford University professor, as arbitrator in their wage dispute, it was announced yesterday.

Guns have been shot at the sky to make rain and explosives have been detonated against hailstorms, but no dramatic success has been scored. Smudge pots have warmed frost-threatened orchards and thus saved citrus fruit. During the war fog was burned away from airports, so that fighters and bombers could come and go in safety.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)-- Three West Point football greats-- Felix (Doc) Blanchard, Glenn Davis and Barney Poole--were thrown for a big monetary loss today when the War Department flatly rejected their requests for leave to play pro football.

A jury of eleven men and one woman found yesterday that Frank Costello, slot-machine figure, was the rightful owner of the $27,200 he had left in a taxicab more than two years ago. Costello had testified that the money was to have been used in a real estate deal and did not represent proceeds from gambling, as the city authorities contended.

DETROIT, Jan. 31--The charge was made today in the Federal District Court that "a terrific row" had developed between the Department of Justice and the Wages and Hours Administration regarding the validity of across-the-board portal-to-portal and "make-ready" pay claims.
ROME, Jan. 31 (AP)--The Allies tonight abolished, effective at midnight, the Allied Control Commission set up shortly before the Italian armistice to advise and supervise the Italian Government.
STUART, Fla., Jan. 31--Sailfishing, we are convinced, is not so much "where you find it" as "how you find it," and today we found it rough going.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 31 (U.P.)--England lost tour wickets for 239 runs today in the first day's play of the fourth test match in the cricket series with Australia after a first-wicket stand of 137 runs by Cyril Washbrook and Leonard Hutton.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 31 --Economists from fifteen countries recommended today that the United Nations should have the right to prod nations that did not develop their backward regions.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 31--In the most drastic and dramatic step yet taken to combat terrorism, Lieut. Gen. Sir Alan G. Cunningham, the High Commissioner, ordered today the evacuation of British women and children from Palestine.

Sharply changed in tone from last year, when military exhibits demonstrating the lethal powers of aircraft dominated the scene, the annual New York Aviation Show will open today at Grand Central Palace. The keynote this year will be the low horsepower engine for airplanes designed for personal and business use.
DENVER, Jan. 31 (AP) -- An Army plane bucked rough flying weather tonight with its load of vaccine for about 14,000 soldiers quarantined at Lowry Field by an epidemic of respiratory disease.
Man-made shooting stars traveling at speeds of six miles a second were described yesterday by Prof. R.W. Wood of Johns Hopkins at he meeting of the American Physical Society at Columbia University.
In the first reversal of the upward trend of milk prices for three and one-half years, metropolitan milk dealers will reduce their charge 1 cent a quart today.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 31--The American Federation of Labor called upon the Congress of Industrial Organizations today for a real, organic unification of the labor movement to meet the challenge of those who seek to curb its power.

New Capital Market Offerings aggregating $44,691,000 in bonds and $18,3O6,3O4 in stocks were funneled this week into a public market that was generally receptive. Of six bond offerings, three, totaling $14,691,000, were municipal; one, for $25,000,000, was an industrial; one, for $3,000,000, a railroad equipment trust issue, and the other, for $2,000,000, was for a finance company.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, Director of the Office of Temporary Controls, accepted responsibility today for ordering, without Presidential approval, the general 10 per cent rent increase countermanded by the White House at the last minute.

SALISBURY, Conn., Jan. 31-- After 206 years of unlighted streets this village has gone strongly light-conscious. It would seem that while the men are doing all the planning the women are responsible for the crusade which has become one of the main subjects of conversation here today.

Four children received their grammar school diplomas yesterday from Public School 401, located in the orthopedic ward of Bellevue Hospital. Two of the graduating class were wheeled into the room to receive their diplomas and another hobbled in on crutches.

While greatly handicapped by tight foreign exchange restrictions and shortages of basic materials, France is regaining confidence and slowly moving toward economic recovery. Henri R. Hirsch, director of the Societe Parisienne de Confection, a subsidiary of the Galeries Lafayette, well known retail organization operating five stores in France and one in London, in an interview here yesterday, outlined extent of France's steady comeback.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--John J. McCloy, former Assistant Secretary of War and New York attorney, conferred with the executive directors of the International Bank today on an offer to him of the presidency of the bank, but still reserved his decision, on acceptance.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 31 --The United States intends to recommend on Tuesday that the United Nations Security Council immediately begin consideration of international atomic control but establish at the same time a committee of the whole to determine the terms of reference for a commission that would later take up general disarmament.
Photographic studies of lightning indicate that airplanes must climb to a height of about four miles to avoid the hazards of electrical storms, engineering experts reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--Three devices designed to provide for the safety of aircraft in landing and three new methods for the further utilization of natural and synthetic rubber are among the 279 inventions for which patents were issued this week by the United States Patent Office.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--The White House said today that whenever some future crisis "made it desirable," President Truman "conceivably" would seek the opinion of State Governors before deciding on a course of action, but added that he had not sought their views on his policy decision to force a show-down with John L. Lewis, as stated in a Washington dispatch published in this newspaper today.

NANKING, Jan. 31--The Central Daily News, official organ of the Kuomintang [Government party] today opposed Russian participation in mediating the Chinese civil war. The newspaper said "patience and time" would settle the Communist problem.

New York University does not know what it means to lose to Brooklyn College in basketball. The Violets defeated the Kingsmen for the eleventh time in as many meetings last night. They piled it on relentlessly before a crowd of 4,529 at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory.

LONDON, Jan. 31--The appointment of William John McKell, 56year-old Labor Premier of New South Wales, a former boxer and boilermaker, as Governor General of Australia in succession to the Duke of Gloucester was officially announced tonight.
A flash fire enveloped a Brooklyn trolley car in flames and smoke last night, trapping forty passengers inside. Unable to open the doors and stifled by acrid smoke the passengers broke into a panic.

Albert Idell has broken the continuity of his trilogy about the Rogers family, which began with "Centennial Summer" and continued with "The Bridge to Brooklyn," to write a new novel, "The Sea Is Woman." The story is based on his own experiences in the Merchant Marine, although the characters are fictitious.

Although its request for Governor Dewey to hold a public hearing on education "falls" on deaf ears," the Teachers Salary Conference will go ahead with its plans to hold a meeting in Albany on Feb. 12.

ATHENS, Jan. 31--United Nations representatives on the Security Council's Investigation Commission heard both Yugoslav liaison officer Josip Djerdja and his Bulgarian colleague Georgi Kulishev reverse today most of the charges brought by Greece against her northern neighbors.

While much of the Middle West was digging out from under a blanket of snow and sections of the South were assessing damage to life and property caused tornadoes, New York City continued yesterday to enjoy unseasonably high temperatures.

A training program to teach skills to 10,000 displaced persons in the American zone of Germany to prepare them for resettlement in other countries was announced yesterday by Dr. David Lvovitch, vice president of the World ORT Union.

Marisa Regules, Argentine pianist, was heard in a recital last night at Carnegie Hall. The gifted young artist has a natural aptitude for the keyboard, but at this latest appearance here the entire first half of her program was devoted to compositions asking more than she was ready to give from the interpretive angle.

LONDON, Jan. 31--Winston Churchill urged the Government today to hand over to the United Nations the responsibility for Palestine. The discharge of this responsibility "is covering us with blood and shame," he said.

Banks here are studying the possibility of obtaining legislative relief from the effects of the recent decision of Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein, restricting their discount rates on installment paper purchased from individuals, it was made known yesterday.
ALBANY, Jan. 31--Senator James J. Crawford, Brooklyn Democrat, reintroduced today his bill to legalize off-the-track betting on horse racing in New York State.

Distributors of supplies and equipment and industrial buyers have reacted most favorably to the firm price policy recently announced by Worthington Pump and Machinery Corporation, C.E. Searle, president, disclosed here yesterday.

Trade Average Seen 5% Higher Retail trade here was active this week, but comparison with a year ago was affected by the high rate of gain in the 1946 week, which was confined chiefly to a few department stores. This one-sided increase leveled off in the current week and estimates put the composite sales of department stores here at about 5 per cent over last year.
Frank Shaughnessy, president of the International League, announced after his loop's meeting yesterday, several moves to combat the menace of gambling.

PARIS -- The Normandy beaches where Allied soldiers landed on D-day (June 6, 1944) and the many American cemeteries that mark the route of the invasion are to become French national parks and monuments.

ASIDE from last week's sundry alarums and excursions, including the drive to steer the American Repertory Theatre from the shoals (more by Miss Margaret Webster on Page 3), this desk wishes to call attention to a proposed survey that may throw some light on current theatrical matters.
A continued investment demand for prime real estate, if price levels are not too high in relation to present income, is predicted for 1947 by Leonard S. Gans of the Leonard S. Gans Company.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 31 (Delayed) (AP) -- King Ibn Saud of Saudi Arabia told reporters today that he was pleased with the new arrangements for developing the ArabianAmerican Oil Company.

Sixteen artists whose brushes recorded on canvas the horrors and glory in the various theatres of World War II will have their most recent work exhibited Tuesday in the International Salon of the Chrysler Building.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 1--Sixteen persons were killed and one man survived today when a French passenger plane en route from Paris to Lisbon crashed into a peak as it approached the airport here. The plane fell in flames near the ancient royal mountain resort of Cintra, on Portugal's seacoast, twelve miles northwest of Lisbon.

Schools of higher learning in the U.S.S.R. turned out more than 70,000 qualified graduates last year, an increase of 150 per cent over 1945, a report contained in the U.S.S.R. Information Bulletin released by the Soviet Embassy in Washington, D.C., reveals. The past year saw the size of the student body of the colleges and universities reach the pre-war level of 560,000 students.

TOKYO, Feb. 1--Since the passage of the new religious law, which removed temples and shrines from the Government's control, Buddhism has been falling apart. Scarcely a single sect has been spared major schisms and hundreds of individual temples have severed relations with their sects.
DATES have been set for the thirty - first International Flower Show at Grand Central Palace. They are March 17 through 22.

"SPAIN today needs Sancho Panza rather than Don Quixote * * * The ordinary Spaniard regards the Government, be it monarchist, republican or military, as his chief enemy, while the Government in its turn regards him as a potential criminal to be watched and controlled with unceasing vigilance."

ALONG our scrub-pine-bordered street in West Harwich on Cape Cod, there lived, when I was a boy, a handful of seafaring men and women who had rounded Cape Horn in fullrigged vessels, had braved storms and sometimes mutinies, and who had seen the wonders of China and Singapore and India.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--Carroll Reece, chairman of the Republican National Committee, assured Americans today of a "substantial" cut in their income taxes.

JOSIAH WHITE, according to Miss Morton, belongs "to the category of Fitch, Evans, Baldwin, Whitney, McCormick, Edison and two brothers named Wright." That is putting her hero in pretty high-class company, where he doesn't belong as an inventor but where he would be at home as an industrial pioneer.

IT IS a narrow, special world that English novelist Norah Hoult has the reader enter in her latest, smoothly written novel. But once one is within the tightening confines of that world (an aged literary lady's deteriorating mind) one finds it intense and hypnotic enough.
"The Jewish people will not yield to the continuing war of nerves being waged against them," Rabbi Louis I. Newman said in a sermon in Temple Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street, yesterday.

Retail trade gains here for the week ended Feb. 1 were considerably narrower than in preceding weeks. The composite sales of department stores here were estimated at about 5 per cent higher than for the corresponding week of 1946.

TEN years ago venereal diseases were top public health problems largely because prudish censorship denied the people the facts. Today venereal diseases are still top public health problems largely because people know too much--too much that isn't so.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 1 -- The Democratic party in Georgia, sharply divided over the rival Governorship claims of Herman Talmadge and Melvin E. Thompson, is equally at odds over the Talmadgesponsored proposal to repeal all State primary laws and establish a party-controlled Democratic white primary system.

THE author of this volume-- who has a way of throwing out disconcerting generalizations --remarks that "the United States was conceived and firmly established by the radicals of 1776," and that "there have always been radicals because society has never been free of inequality and oppression."

TWENTY years ago, when the Wales Bill became law, this city's legitimate theatre became subject to a form of censorship that has provoked controversies of such bitterness that basic issues have frequently been obscured by impassioned prose and legalistic hair-splitting.
Municipal purchasing agents have started a drive through the National Institute of Governmental Purchasing, Washington, to obtain their fair share of War Assets Administration surplus products.

DETROIT, Feb. 1 (AP)--Scoring two goals within 28 seconds in the final 10 minutes, the Boston Bruins played the Detroit Red Wings a rough 2-all tie tonight before 12,678 fans in their third National Hockey League meeting within a week.

WE ARE living through an epoch of history in which the foundations of civilization, of economic life and of social relationships have been shaken. We do not know yet what repercussions and adjustments will take place in response to these shocks.

ROEBLING, N.J., Feb. 1--A majority of the occupants of the 752 "company houses" in this village of 3,000 met today's deadline with offers to purchase the homes they or their parents have lived in for forty years as employes of the John A. Roebling's Sons Company, wire manufacturers.

A FLOCK of vocal records of many schools, styles and epochs is at hand. Two of the best albums present Marian Anderson in Bach Arias (Victor, three twelve-inch records) and Isabel French and Olympia di Napoli in Twelve Songs by Faure (Technichord, three twelve-inch vinylite records).

EMPHASIZING that motor vehicle fatalities among high - school - age students have increased 90 per cent in twelve years and continue to increase, John F. Creamer, a member of the Society of Automotive Engineers and president of the National Wheel and Rim Association with headquarters in Detroit, is urging an effort to curb this "wholesale slaughter" through better driver training.

THAT the mass evacuation of 110,000 persons of Japanese ancestry from the three West Coast States--persons two-thirds of whom were citizens of the United States--was the most important single blunder that we made during: the war, from the point of view of furthering a democratic strategy, is a conclusion overwhelmingly fortified by this scholarly, objective, thoroughly documented study.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 1 --China Is the only great power that has accepted without reserve the new United States proposal that the United Nations Security Council take up immediately the report of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission, and prospects for acceptance of the proposal are doubtful, it was learned today.

A rare and baffling disease, apparently unknown to the outside world, is threatening the production program of an area 150 miles southwest of Yenan by disabling the peasants, reports John Roderick of The Associated Press. It is known only as "the limping sickness."

--A BUSY LAND A traveler roaming through this great, rich country tells us of a pleasant sight he sees from the train window. Wherever he goes he sees factory parking lots, acres wide, cram-full of workers' cars, and smoke rising from factory chimneys past counting.

ALBANY, Feb. 1--Under Governor Dewey's budget, submitted to the Legislature today, New York City will receive upward of $191,800,000 in State aid during the State's next fiscal year, an increase of $42,300,000 over the amounts provided in the current budget.

ALBANY, Feb. 1--Following is the text of Governor Dewey's budget message: Feb. 1, 1947. To the Legislature: This budget, like the budget of last year, is designed to meet the exigencies of a complex post-war period in which conflicting economic trends make the tasks of management both in business and in government most difficult.

Recent purchases of 309,500 shares of the New York Central Railroad by the Alleghany Corporation have brought up the question of the possibility of the control of that carrier passing to interests identified with Robert R. Young, chairman of both the Aleghany and the Chesapeake Ohio Railway.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--In advance of Monday's conference of the International Emergency Food Council of thirty nations, the House Agriculture Committee unanimously "insisted" today on a sharp increase of sugar for the American public.

GIAN-CARLO MENOTTI has written a new opera--a thirty-minute comedy for two characters called "The Telephone," with a secondary title "L'Amour a Trois." It will be presented for the first time on Feb. 15 as a curtain-raiser for the Ballet Society's revival of "The Medium," the full-length tragic opera Mr. Menotti wrote last year on commission from the Alice M. Ditson Fund of Columbia University.

APPEARING at a time when the United Nations organization has weathered its first day of life with all the world's leaders busy congratulating themselves on having failed to kill it, Mr. Cohn's record of a voyage he made has a larger value than it might otherwise. It becomes as of today its own kind of "One World."

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 (AP)--Profittaking toward the close erased a large part of early advances that had extended to around 2 cents a bushel in wheat on the Board of Trade today. Corn and oats, strong early, also fell back under the weight of week-end offerings.

DUBLIN, Feb. 1--In the midst of its acute fuel difficulties welcome news has just reached Dublin that Eire's efforts to obtain coal from the United States are meeting with success. The first order for 9,000 tons has been placed with the Fire Creek Colliery of Pennsylvania, and the coal will probably be taken to Ireland in a United States Liberty ship, since Eire's own ships at present are booked up for some weeks.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 1 (AP)-- E.O. Stice Sons' On Trust, third choice in a field of eleven 3-year-olds, today won the $50,000 added Santa Maria Stakes before 52,000 spectators at Santa Anita Park. Louis B. Mayer's Stepfather ran second, three-quarters of a length back. Owners Choice, the 5-to-2 favorite, finished third.

After some irregularity in the first hour of trading, the share market on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday turned active and strong under the leadership of the railroad issues. Final prices generally were at the test levels of the year and for the current movement.

BERLIN, Feb. 1--The cases of artists, actors and musicians cleared by German denazification tribunals are no longer subject to 1 view by United States authorities, according to an order recently issued by Lieut. Gen. Lucius D. Clay, deputy military governor.

The strengthening of American democracy against totalitarian forces suspected of activity in the United States will be the objective of a newly formed group of clergy and laymen to be known as the National Religious Council of Common Cause, it was announced yesterday.

WILL radio ever develop its own valid literature? The question is asked and tentatively answered by Richard Hughes in the current Virginia Quarterly Review. Mr. Hughes, an English novelist best known here as the author of "The Innocent Voyage," wrote, in 1924, the first play written directly for radio presentation.

Favorable industrial earnings and improved management and labor relations were given more attention by financial circles last week than the varied predictions of economists on the possibility of a depression this year. The buoyant tone of the stock market indicated no great concern over a likely setback in business.

THROUGH no fault of its own, the American motion picture industry finds itself in the strange position of helping to provide financial backing for all of the conflicting political interests in Hungary. This involuntary aid, it was learned from a responsible representative of the American industry, stems from the fact that film exhibition in Hungary is politically dominated.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 1--The vote counting ended late this morning in this city and in almost every State. The results throughout the country indicate a common pattern: the democratic forces allowed the Communist party to help and thereby helped the Communists.

IF she had to depend on auditions, Nanette Fabray would be washing dishes for a living instead of starring on Broadway. Take as a sample what happened to her when she stepped onstage to try out for the role vacated by Constance Moore in "By Jupiter."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP)-- President Truman promised today to give Congress his views on how to curb the withdrawal of Government documents by retiring officials, as talk arose of military secrets being endangered by officers turned author.

The postponed negotiations between the United States Steel Corporation and the CIO United Steelworkers of America, scheduled to begin in Pittsburgh next Thursday, are fraught with the greatest significance, not only to labor and management, but also to everybody in the United States and, in fact, in the entire world.
LONDON. Feb. 1--The possibility of a Big Three meeting in Washington in the near future is definitely discounted in London.

The net expenditures for the fiscal year 1947-48 that Governor Dewey proposes are, at $663,000,000, the largest appropriations from current funds in the history of New York State. For support of State functions the Governor suggests appropriations of about $300,000,000 (which is well under a third of the $970,000,000 over-all expense budget proposed a few days ago by Mayor O'Dwyer for the City of New York).

Avenging a previous setback, the Squadron A trio staved off a galant last-period rush to beat the New York Athletic Club side, 12 to 11, in the star match of the indoor polo double-header at the Squadron A Armory last night. The curtain-raiser saw the Squadron A Falcons turn back the Ramapo Gauchos, 11--8.

IT has to be said: these plays make dull reading even to the comparative few who, like myself, are in the habit of reading plays. It is conceivable that such a play as Marshal's "Twelve Months" (1940) would make pleasant reading in the original Russian.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--President Truman disclosed today that a labor-management agreement had been made for the voluntary settlement of disputes in the building and construction industry.

The Committee on Legislation of the Citizens Union announced yesterday its opposition to the election bill introduced by Senator Pliny W. Williamson. The bill would amend the election law by increasing from 12,000 to 25,000 the number of signatures to petitions nominating independent candidates for State-wide office and requiring 150 signatures from each county instead of fifty.

IN one of her earlier books, "Serve It Forth," published in 1937, Mary Frances (Kennedy) Parrish, who writes under the pseudonym of M.F.K. Fisher, put forth in highly entertaining fashion the thesis that there are three types of gastronomic literature.

Prompt declaration, by all Government agencies of all excessive stocks of steel sheet, plate, bar, strip, tubing and pipe as surplus is necessary to prevent a recession for small metalworking plants, the Association of Steel Distributors, Inc., disclosed here yesterday.

ED GARDNER is not so much a person as a human symbol variously associated with Brooklyn, Hell's Kitchen or First Avenue. This husky mat with the rugged features and aggressive manner provokes the feeling that pretty soon someone will belabor the floor with a cue stick and shout: "Rack 'em up.'

"ONE WORLD FLIGHT," the latest contribution from Norman Corwin's one-man theatre, is an uneven piece. At best it is a stimulating synthesis of idea, word and mood which is effective radio; at worst it is an example of the pretentious confusion so typical of radio's impersonal and clinical approach to life outside the studio.

DENMARK, Feb. 1 -- Experimental flights with a Dakota plane whose elevator was locked showed today that the aircraft reacted exactly as had the Dakota transport that crashed here last Sunday, killing all twenty-two persons aboard.
WHEN I came home from the opening of the musical version of Elmer Rice's "Street Scene," late as it was, I dug into the files to get out the Elmer-Riceana and indulged in an orgy of reminiscence.

CABLEGRAMS from Moscow received by J. H. Stolow say that the U.S.S.R. is issuing 30-kopecs gray and 60k grayish blue stamps to commemorate the birth of N.E. Zhukovsky, scientist, a century ago, and 30k dark green and 50k dark gray to mark the centenary of the birth of A.P. Karpinsky, geologist. Both men enter philately's gallery for the first time.

LONDON, Feb. 1 (Reuters)-- Snow-covered grounds and frigid weather caused postponement of many big league soccer matches in England and Scotland today and sent attendance figures to a new low for the season. Less than 650,000 witnessed English League games, against Saturday afternoon crowds of nearly a million.

AMERICANS who were in Europe during and shortly after World War II will find the setting of Robert Neumann's new novel, "Children of Vienna," not unfamiliar. It is a cellar on top of which a whole house has collapsed.
TO THE EDITOR: EVERYONE in uniform knew Kilroy, the subject of the contest referred to in your story, "Who Is 'Kilroy'?", and GT's in the British Isles met his counterpart.
In the first sale this week at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, more books from the library of the late Fred W. Allsopp of Little Rock, Ark., will be auctioned.

John A. Dunbar and H. Thornley Martin, salesmen of Cushman Wakefield, Inc., have won jointly the award of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company for negotiating "the most ingenious realty transaction of 1946," among members of the Real Estate Board of New York.

With victory being decided in the last bout of the last match of a full day of fencing, the Eastern District High School team yesterday won the Castello Trophy in New York University's twelfth annual interscholastic fencing tournament.

SWEET peas have been the delight or despair of gardener for years. They flourish like weeds in some sections of the country, but shrivel and die in others. Any new strain that promises better performance is good news, and such a strain is the Cuthbertson sweet pea.

A strong and active real estate market not only for 1947 but for many more years is seen by Stewart Forshay, president of Byrne Bowman Forshay, Inc. Mr. Forshay reported that 1946 was one of the firm's most active years in real estate.

"ALL Indians," said the traveler, "walk in single file." "How do you know?" he was asked. "Well, the one I saw did." So we know, with equal validity, that Mexicans are stupid, Negroes shiftless, Japanese sly and Jews either bankers and/or Reds.

COULD it be that in our habitual yearning for some vaguely defined thing that we call the American ballet we are focusing our eyes too far on the distant clouds? If somebody were to come along and point out something quite close at hand and familiar and say to us: "Look, here is your American ballet," would we look down our noses and reply: "What, that old thing?" It is more than possible.

DAVOS PLATZ, Switzerland, Feb. 1--Charming 3,000 spectators with one of the most graceful performances ever seen on continental ice, Miss Barbara Ann Scott of Ottawa today sailed through a free-figures competition to win the European figure skating championship.

MOSCOW, Feb. 1--The Western plans for the federalization or division of Germany were emphatically rejected today in an editorial in The New Times, influential review of foreign affairs. The editorial declared that the economic and political unity of Germany must be preserved.

Tojo Company For nine months, Hideki Tojo, wartime Premier of Japan, has sat eight to ten hours a day in a grim Tokyo courtroom in the War Ministry Building from which he directed the war effort. With twenty-five other Japanese war leaders, he has heard the prosecution pile up a vast store of evidence against him.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 1--The general philosophy of "freer world trade" won the support of West Coast ocean shipping yesterday. The annual meeting of the Pacific American Steamship Association went on record against any broad program of tariff increases such as those which, it stated, "shut us out of world markets" following passage of the smoot-Hawley Bill in 1930.
