A SCORE of one-man shows opening in the galleries last week brought out a wide diversity of work both by wellknown artists and by newcomers. Switching the spotlight rapidly from one to another, here are some brief verdicts: Carl Sprinchorn, at Macbeth's, employs strength comparable to that in some of the late Marsden Hartley's canvases.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--Following is the text of the arbitration agreement between the Associated General Contractors of America and the Building and Construction Trades Department, American Federation of Labor: National Joint Conference Committee, Building and Construction Trades Department, AFL, and Associated General Contractors of America, Inc.

MONTREAL, Feb. 1--In a freeskating, free-swinging game that kept 11,383 spectators at the Forum on the edges of their seats, the Montreal Canadians defeated the New York Rangers, 2--1, tonight. By outlucking, though not outplaying, the scrappy Blue Shirts, who carried the play to the world champions virtually throughout the sixty minutes, the Habitants wrested first place in the National Hockey League from the Toronto Maple Leafs by one point.

SAIGON, French Indo-China, Jan. 31 (Delayed)--The first important reinforcement of the French troops in Indo-China now has been effected with the arriva today of the Ile de France. Military secrecy, which has been tightened since the outbreak of hostilities in Hanoi on Dec. 19, prevents details of troop movements but it has already been published that the liner is bringing at least 8,000 men.

The United Seamen's Service announced yesterday a program under which its facilities for seamen will be maintained in nineteen overseas and ten domestic ports as part of a move designed to offer world-wide services for American seamen at the most effective peacetime level.

THE sensitive and adroit editorial touch of M.A. de Wolfe Howe has been most agreeably employed in selecting, arranging and annotating these passages from the papers of his late wife's family. The Josiah Quincy that J.R. Lowell described in one of the best of his essays as "a great public character" had two sons and five daughters, all of whom not only admired, but really liked their father.

If there is sunshine today, says the legend, there will be more winter in the weeks to come. And if cloud or overcast such that the groundhog cannot see his shadow, then the worst of the winter is past. Why one day's sun or shadow should forecast weeks of weather, even in superstition, is beyond understanding.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--Backstage developments, which during the week brought House Republicans and Democrats to the brink of common ground on the question of personal income tax reductions, entered, the final phase today. Prospects were that the rapprochement soon would be complete.

To the Drama Editor: I READ with great interest the different articles in THE NEW YORK TIMES on the experimental theatre. * * * The use of the words "experimental" and "commercial" seem to me utterly confusing. * * *

As the principal hearings before the Committee for Reciprocity Information drew to a close in Washington last week it became clear that the numerous organizations and associations supporting the reciprocal trade agreements program of the Government had generally adopted a policy of watchful waiting, according to trade leaders in New York.

TWO authors make their initial appearances as artists with current shows. At the New Art Circle, Clifford Odets is the exhibitor and admirers of his "Waiting for Lefty" and other plays will be hard put to it to explain any connection between the Odets drama and the Odets paintings.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 1--As the British administration cleared the decks for action by speeding preparations for the evacuation of civilians from Palestine, a dramatic eleventh-hour appeal was made tonight by the chief rabbi to spare the life of a condemned man whose fate is the immediate cause of most of the tension.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 1 (AP)--Mrs. Babe Zaharias, out to make a "grand slam" of women's golf events this year, handily won the fifteenth annual Helen Lee Doherty tournament today by routing Miss Margaret Gunther of Memphis, Tennessee State champion, 12 and 10, in the 36-hole final.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 1-- The insignificant volume of German industrial equipment distributed by the Interallied Reparations Agency has become the source of such concern to the delegates of eighteen nations assembled here that they have addressed a note to Big Four Foreign Ministers requesting a voice at the Moscow conference in March.

CONGRESSIONAL hearings on airplane accidents brought out last week a widespread opinion among aviation experts that installation of the Ground Control Approach system for bad-weather landings would be the most effective way of preventing further disasters.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1--Don Casey's foul toss and Chink Crossin's field goal in the last twentyseven seconds enabled the University of Pennsylvania basketball team to spike a brilliant Army rally and gain a hard-earned 64-59 victory before 4,500 at the Palestra tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The State Department decided today that there were ample private facilities available for any United States citizens who wished to leave Palestine voluntarily and that no special measures or an organized evacuation program were necessary.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP)--L. B. Bolt Jr., a former Tennessee Valley Authority employe, testified today that Gordon R. Clapp has been known in the TVA "as a good friend of the Communist element."

MANILA, Feb. 1 (AP)--A compromise agreement on the establishment of American military bases in the Philippines was reported to be near today after more than five weeks of negotiations, in which the Americans startled the Filipinos by offering to withdraw all their forces.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 1-- Editorial demands for indoctrination of personnel of the United States Immigration Service in "minimum requirements" of "courtesy and humane consideration" were made on the West Coast this week in connection with the handling of incoming Chinese at the Port of San Francisco.

TORONTO, Feb. 1 (AP)--The lastplace Chicago Black Hawks came from, behind at Maple Leaf Gardens tonight and defeated Toronto, 5--4, to knock the injury-riddle Leafs out of first place in the National Hockey League.

FOR several weeks now this observer--along with a few million others hereabouts-- has been watching a celestial apparition of the strangest and most disturbing sort. Every few nights what seems a bright star has appeared on the blurred horizon, accompanied by a distant and peculiarly ominous drone.

TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 1 (AP)--Defending champion Jimmy Demaret of Houston, Tex., ringing up his second consecutive 66, went into the lead for the 72-hole $10,000 Tucson open golf tournament today with a three-round total of 199.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--When the chairman of the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee bluntly demanded this week a concrete program to improve aviation safety, Federal air officials promptly dumped the problem into his lap.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 1-Seizures of United States shrimping boats by the Mexican Navy in Mexican waters have directed the attention of this port to a question of jurisdiction over territorial waters.

To the contrary, the Circuit Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, Judge L. Hand, dissenting, (Commissioner V. Ickelheimer, 132 F. (2d) 660) held that sales of bonds listed on the New York Stock Exchange, followed by purchases of like securities by members of the family of the seller, are neither direct nor indirect sales "between members of the family," thus allowing the loss as a deduction.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 1--Ch. Rip, of Blue Bar, belonging to C.N. Myers of Hanover, Pa., went to the top among English setters tonight to provide a highlight of the breed judging that opened the Maryland Kennel Club's thirty-fourth annual all-breed show.

The most elaborate and complicated pension program ever undertaken by a professional sport was adopted yesterday when the National and American Leagues, sitting in joint session in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel, agreed to a plan assuring veteran baseball players an income ranging from $50 to $100 a month on reaching fifty years of age.

DO WE want, a repertory theatre in America or don't we? Can we or can't we have it ? If we can have it, on what terms? These are questions which are currently engaging the attention of the professional theatre world, and enlisting the active interest of an unprecedented number of its component parts.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1--Efforts to have the daily editions of The Philadelphia Record and The Camden (N.J.) Courier and Post newspapers resume publication under "independent ownership are under way," Robert McLean, president of The Philadelphia Evening Bulletin, said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- If President Truman succeeds in curbing the removal of state papers by departing members of his own and future official families he will end a custom begun by Washington and his Cabinet and continued since.

BOTH the bookstores and magazinestands are well loaded these days with material which by exhortation, inspiration or information purports to help the reader make a better man of himself. Most of this literature is either obvious but dull, or sensational but dubious.

Gilbert Dodds can move up to wo miles any time. The Flying Parson is in a class by himself in he mile. If this required any further proof, it was supplied in overwhelming measure at Madison Square Garden last night as the front-running minister made a romp of the Wanamake Mile in 4:09.2.

FOR a biographer this is a well-nigh perfect subject. The Bonapartes are an inexhaustible field, and of them there is none more tempting to the pen than Pauline. The whole clan was an Italian family on the make and as such they were greedy, quarrelsome, irritable, vain and touchy.

LONDON, Feb. 1--Further data in support of its charges that the National Socialist party is reorganizing for a return to power in Germany were issued today by the International Committee for the Study of European Questions.
LONDON, Feb. 1--One of the familiar phrases in history is "Vae Victis"--woe to the defeated.

With the aid of two canes John Crown yesterday came down the two steps from his new home, which is in a Quonset hut at Ulmer Park, Brooklyn. His left side, from the waist down, is paralyzed. The steps are a problem that he is conquering, as he has overcome others.

There was an increase of 19 per cent during January for New York and Brooklyn department stores, compared with the comparable month a year ago, according to the monthly survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The largest increase of 41,2 per cent was made by a store in the volume category above $20,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--A "Declaration of Human Rights," drafted by a committee appointed by the National Catholic Welfare Conference, was made public here today as copies were sent to the United Nations Committee on Human Rights, of which Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt is chairman.

SEEING Bucky Harris and Charlie Dressen together last week during a rehearsal for the Baseball Writers' show brought home an instantaneous thought. The new Yankee Brain Trust, despite its rather innocent outward appearance, is undoubtedly as larcenous a combination as baseball has had in many a moon. Their larceny is strictly legal, of course, since this pair doesn't steal anything except the other fellow's signals.

Surprised in an East Side flat since a few days after they broke but of Brooklyn City Prison, Edmund Godfrey and William Duffy were seized at 5:40 P.M. yesterday before they had a chance to reach for two pistols secreted under the pillows of a bed on which they stretched.

MOSCOW, Feb. 1 -- A British and American Combined Chiefs of Staff committee is occupied with work on some future joint AngloAmerican operations and with the distribution of the armed forces of the two powers according to new strategic plans, Maj. Gen. Galaktionov, noted Soviet military writer, said in an article on "The AngloAmerican Military Alliance" in the international review, The New Times.

Dr. Luther H. Evans, librarian of Congress who headed this nation's delegation at the signing of the Inter - American Copyright Convention in Washington last June, urged yesterday Senate ratification of the treaty which, he declared, "gives the United States author or owner of protected works an advantageous position within Latin-American countries."

DR. MORRIS R. COHEN: On Jan. 29, at Washington, age 66. For many years Professor of Philosophy at New York's City College. Prolific and widely read author of books on philosophy, science, literature and autobiography; last published work was "The Faith of a Liberal."

"AREN'T you ashamed of yourself, maltreating a fellow-human being like this?" Count Leo Tolstoy once indignantly asked a brother officer whom he saw brutally strike a soldier who had fallen out from the ranks: "Haven't you read the Gospels?" But the officer calmly replied: "And haven't you read Army Orders?"

BY looking carefully on these winter evenings you can possibly identify bits of Victor Herbert's "Sweethearts" on the stage of the Shubert. But the little puffs of comic steam that very nearly obscure that ancient operetta are our old friend Bobby Clark, the celebrated mountebank, who is blessing New York with its grandest evening of merriment.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 1--The snowladen winds that have been scouring the north dwindled down, to a warm zephyr by the time they reached here, and the off-shore anglers have been bringing in a wide variety of Gulf Stream scrappers, including a few fish that may establish new records.

Hank Greenberg will discuss his contract with Col. Frank McKinney, directing owner of the Pittsburgh Pirates, next week-end, probably in Pittsburgh and it is assumed will sign with the Buccaneers for at least $55,000.

ALBANY, Feb. 1--Appropriations for current purposes amounting to $671,439,557, a record high, were proposed today by Governor Dewey in submitting his budget for the State's next fiscal year to the Legislature. He said they could be financed without increasing present tax rates.
Ten thousand persons streamed into Grand Central Palace yesterday for the opening of the 1947 Aviation Show.

HEREWITH is another ticket for that fascinating fiction train--Hollywood bound, and loaded to the lounge car with stars and their agents. These latter, and indeed the entire book, are not so broad as Benny Greenspan nor so loud as "The Hucksters," but they are well met in the cold white light of satire.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 (AP)--Today's report of the liveestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable cattle. 500 head (estimated); total not not given. Compared with week ago: All weights and grades, barrows and gilts. 50 to 75 cents higher: sows, mostly 75c higher.
The first international racquets match between England and the United States since 1930 resulted in victory for the British yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

NORTH CONWAY, N.H., Feb. 1 -- Recreational and competitive skiers--more than 2,500 in all-- were out in full force today at Cranmore Mountain, getting in a lot of skiing in daylight and several hours more of the sport under brilliant floodlights and a starlit sky.

The Air Defense Command, one of the three major operational commands of the United States Army Air Forces, is slowly bridging the difficult gap from war to peace and is helping to organize on a nation-wide basis the new Air National Guard and Air Reserve.

Broad window spaces and architectural stone spandrels will be featured in the exterior design of the two story office, showroom and store building which Frederick Brown will build at 4 West Fiftyeighth Street under plans already filed with the Department of Housing and Buildings.

NUREMBERG, Feb. 1--The theory that German industrialists and financiers were the men who pulled the strings behind the Nazi regime, brought it to power, profited by it and were fundamentally responsible for its aggressions and other crimes will be put to judicial test in trials which, after some delay, are now due to begin in March and will last throughout the year if not longer.

Declaring it had received reports that some babies have been placed for adoption upon payment by the adoptive parents of sums as high as $1,500 for a boy and $1,200 for a girl, the New York Committee on Adoptions recommended yesterday that proposed State legislation to govern voluntary adoptions seek to prevent placements of children for profit by penalties or other measures.
The faculty situation is "the real bottleneck in higher education today," Dr. Edmund Ezra Day, president of Cornell University, charged yesterday.

TOWARD the end of the war in the Pacific, the Navy appointed James A. Michener Senior Historical Officer for the area, from New Guinea to Tahiti. Strangely enough, Mr. Michener --a trouble-shooter in aviation maintenance at the time -- had already written most of the manuscript of this book.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--Strong Democratic opposition to limiting the Presidential tenure shaped up today, with the minority whip, Representative John W. McCormack, of Massachusetts, scheduled to open the fight Monday before a Judiciary subcommittee.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development is risking a further serious blow to its prestige and prospects through the possibility that a move will develop to remove its securities from the "legal list" in this State.

" To tax and to please, no more than to love and be wise, is not given to men." --Edmund Burke. " Tax A to favor B. If A complains, tax C to make it up with A. If C complains, tax B to favor C. If any of them still complain, begin all over again. Tax them as long as anybody complains, or anybody wants anything."--William Graham Sumner.

Toward Labor Peace To the recent signs of growing harmony between labor and management there was added yesterday a new and encouraging note. President Truman announced the conclusion of a "nostrike" agreement in the nation's basic construction industry.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 1--The Minneapolis contingent virtually took over today's events in the national outdoor speed skating championships with but a sprinkling of skaters from other cities winning places in the sixteen events in which finals were run off.

HOLLYWOOD. ROBERT TAYLOR checked out of the Navy in November, 1945, went to work in "Undercurrent" in February, finished up in April, and has been idle ever since. He is a victim of the same situation worrying most of the other ex-service men swarming around Hollywood these days.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP)--The United States has told Britain to avoid repeating what this country regards as a violation of the agreement by which Britain got a $3,750,000,000 loan.

LOS ANGELES -- California, which traditionally boasts of having everything, now offers the spectacle of the hotel and resort industry clapping its hands because business is lighter. The initial weeks of the winter season have produced definite indications that the wartime travel avalanche finally has subsided.

LONDON (By Wireless). SURROUNDED by the medieval trappings of feudalism and chivalry, King George VI recently urged Parliament to hasten the Labor Government's socialistic program. That may seem a strange anomaly to a good many Americans but not so to the British, who over the centuries have evolved a political system that preserves ancient forms but gives them the substance of an advanced democracy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--Following are President Truman's statement on the construction trades agreement, his letter to management and labor and their joint letter to him: The President's Statement I have an important statement for you this morning concerning labor management relations.

HOLLYWOOD. BENJAMIN GLAZER, producer, and Nat W. Finston, musical director, who formed Symphony Films last year as an independent company, have begun work on their much discussed project, "Tragic Symphony," a screen biography of Peter Ilich Tchaikovsky, under the sponsorship of Allied Artists, a producing subsidiary of Monogram Pictures.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 1--The decision taken by the civil and military authorities of Palestine to let nothing hamper their efforts to suppress political violence and restore order brought a dramatic surprise this week-end.

IRVIE PEASE is a blatant, shocking little egotist, a tremendous mass of extroversion compressed into a small, hard star of pride. Clustered around his bright light, following it like planets, are his parents, his relatives and his friends.

Dr. Samuel Proger and Dr. Dekaneas, respectively, of Tufts Medical College and the Pratt Diagnostic Hospital of Boston, Mass., report in Science that they have obtained promising results in cases of angina pectoris, a painful heart disease, by injecting a nonpoisonous chemical called cytochrome C, a protein normally present in all living tissues, animal or plant.

LISBON FALLS, Me. THE song runs, "Oh, what fun it is to ride in a one-horse open sleigh." I object to that, because it is not fun to ride in a one-horse open sleigh at all. but it is a cruel, inhuman torture far more unpleasant than hiking the same distance through the snow barefooted.

PARIS, Feb. 1--The French note proposing international ownership and control of the basic industries of the Ruhr was delivered to the Big Three powers today. It marked a notable change in French policy.

TACITURN CLAM-- During the war sonar operators on submarines and other ships were troubled by a persistent crackling. Dr. Martin W. Johnson, Associate Professor of Marine Biology in the University of California, tracked it to tiny pistol shrimps which have a way of snapping their oversized claws.

RECENTLY the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System lifted most of the wartime controls on installment buying and all of the restrictions on retail charge accounts. From now on an increasing number of people will be putting their purchases on the books and paying for them by the easypayment plan.

To the Screen Editor: AS a filmgoer who likes to choose films (as opposed to taking-in-the-face-whateveris-thrown-upon-anyscreen) may I try this means of cheering in print for "It's a Wonderful Life," James Stewart's first post-war film? The heart-warming quality of this film, embarrassing as it may be at the beginning and the end, is something of which both Mr. Stewart and Mr. Frank Capra can be justifiably proud.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--President Truman, in the wake of widespread confusion on rent ceilings, repeated today that he opposes a general increase in present levels.

NANKING, Feb. 1--Closing of Executive Headquarters and American withdrawal from the Committee of Three represent the final steps taken this week in the termination of American efforts to mediate China's civil war.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP)-- Layers of blazing heat have been found in the upper atmosphere, scientists announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--Nothing could illustrate more clearly the vicissitudes of Congressional life than the picture of Democrats in the House of Representatives passing the hat to buy an automobile for their colleague, Sam Rayburn of Texas.
The biggest single factor in the residential real estate market today is the disproportion which exists between supply and demand, according to C.T.S. Keep, president of Previews, Inc.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 1 --American Jews, who raised over $140,000,000 in 1946, $105,000,000 of it through the United Jewish Appeal, will be asked to give more than ever before in history to "meet unprecedented needs overseas and at home," Stanley C. Myers of Miami, president of the Council of Jewish Federations and Welfare Funds, declared today.

THERE seemed to be agreement last week that labor relations had entered a stage of more common sense on the part of both parties. The demands of the steel workers were met by counter proposals of the leading steel producer without either party getting too excited.
PARIS, Feb. 1--Augusto Barcia, former Minister of Finance in the Spanish Exile Government, tonight accepted the task of forming a new Cabinet. He is a moderate.

LIBERALISM in the United States is in transition. Some of its fervor and enthusiasm has waned. The impact of the war upon American habits of thought was less, perhaps, than most Americans believe, but the war served to focus American eyes upon goals other than domestic affairs; and, because liberalism is a realistic political faith, it tends to concentrate its efforts upon the domestic front.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Feb. 1 (U.P.)--England scored 460 runs all out in its first innings in the fourth cricket test match today. Australia, going in for its first innings, lost two wickets for 24 runs before the close of play.

PROFESSOR DOUGLAS MOORE of the Music Department of Columbia University complains in The Saturday Review of the hard lot and the alleged neglect, in favor of foreign music and musicians, of the American composer.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 1-- Speed and experience paid big dividends for Yale University today as the clever Eli sextet overwhelmed Army, 9 to 1, before a capacity crowd of 3,000 at Smith Rink.

FOR three centuries the New World has been an object of interest and of curiosity to the Old, and for half that time the United States has been called upon to point a moral or adorn a tale edifying to Europeans. It is well to be reminded that the Old World has, similarly, been an object of interest and of curiosity to the New, and that interpretation has been mutually edifying.
Fifth of a series of ten articles on recent developments in contract bridge bidding methods.

The Prudential Insurance Company's new post-war housing project for East Orange, N.J., moved a step nearer to realization yesterday with the announcement of the appointment of Emil A. Schmidlin, architect, to design and supervise the plans.

The concert of the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra, under Charles Muench, last night in Carnegie Hall was principally devoted to modern French compositions. These consisted of Debussy's "La Mer," and two works by Albert Roussel, the Symphony in G minor, No. 3, and the "Bacchus and Ariadne" Suite, No. 2, which was new in the organization's repertoire.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--President Truman turned a cold shoulder to suggestions of another meeting of the Big Three in response to questions at his news conference today.

Fordham's basketball team put on an eight-point scoring spree in a five-minute overtime session to defeat St. Francis, 55--47, in the Rose Hill gymnasium last night before 3,500 fans. The hard-won victory ran the Rams' winning streak to eight straight and gave them a record of eleven triumphs in twelve contests.

TODAY, as never before, the world spotlight is on the fourteen men who make up Russia's Politburo, for it is the decisions of these men which determine Russia's international position. Nowhere mentioned in the Soviet Constitution, the Politburo has nevertheless been called the most powerful body of men in the world.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--Secretary of State George C. Marshall will have the assistance of a delegation of 100 at the Moscow peace conference next month, the State Department announced today. The delegation will include official advisers, technical experts, secretaries, clerks and other aides.

Stressing the importance of American history in the development of intelligent citizens, the seventeenth annual yearbook of the National Council for the Social Studies outlines methods by which the elementary and secondary school teacher can improve the teaching of history in the classroom.

IN Elizabeth Seifert's latest novel she manages, as always, to Introduce you to a group of folksy people living in a small town that has a bit of every town in it. Then she starts making her characters do things, resulting in a story-line that is forced beyond credulity.

FOR those who would be relieved of travel responsibilities, the New Haven Railroad is now running a series of all-expense tours of from three to ten days to the winter playgrounds of New England and the Laurentians.

The Protestant Episcopal Church has taken an option on the Herbert L. Satterlee estate in Greenwich, Conn., in a move to establish a permanent headquarters for the denomination and a residence for the Presiding Bishop, it was learned yesterday.

The United Fruit Company will be back in the passenger business by spring, with three vessels operating to "banana ports" out of New York and an equal number sailing from New Orleans, it was disclosed yesterday. Passenger service from the Gulf port, however, will be resumed first.

TO THE EDITOR: Justice Jacob Panken's views on the "Real Delinquent--the Parent," should receive wide attention, particularly among those who are most concerned about doing something constructive for the delinquent.

THE International Salon of Nature Photography, held annually at the Museum of Science in Buffalo, will hang its ninth exhibition from May 30 through June 16, under the sponsorship of Hobbies, the museum's publication.

CONVINCED that it will be merely a matter of time before rocket developments expose the United States to direct transoceanic attack, Mr. Borden, former Air Force pilot, has written down his thoughts on the strategic implications of the atomic and rocket age.

On or before April 1, as required by the City Charter, Mayor O'Dwyer will submit to the Board of Estimate an executive budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 1947. The budget, the Mayor told the City Council last week, will total about $970,812,000, by far the largest in the city's history.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I was astounded to read the following passage from the brilliant speech delivered on Jan. 17 to the National Publisher Association by John Foster Dulles:

TOKYO, Feb. 1--The unions of Japanese Government employes, who yesterday were ordered by General MacArthur to call off their general strike, today appealed to the Supreme Allied Command to compel the Government to grant their demands for a 300 per cent wage increase and a new legislative program.
MOSCOW, Feb. 1--The sloppy sentimentality over the agonies of a pair of lovers who were forbidden to kiss in the park, and such like nonsense, is out of tune for Soviet popular songs.

In line with Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander's drive to cut down juvenile crime, a 40-yearold Harlem repairman will face a heavy fine and jail penalty when he appears for sentencing Tuesday in the Children's Court Division of Domestic Relations Court.

Additional proof of the rapid resumption of travel activities was furnished yesterday with the announcement of the opening here of a new office of the Bergen Steamship Company, Inc., representatives of Det Bergenske Dampskibsselskab of Bergen, Norway.

LONDON, Feb. 1--The Soviets would like even closer ties with Britain than are provided by the Anglo-Russian treaty at present. That is the apparent meaning of Marshal Stalin's reference to "reservations" which weaken "the significance" of the pact in the postwar period.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 1--At least 270,000 new members have been enrolled in the American Federation of Labor's Southern organizing campaign, according to a report submitted to the AFL executive council in session here.

Declaring the country will face further inflation and then a big depression unless the hugs supply of money due to wartime financing is reduced, Thomas I. Parkinson, president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, called upon the Federal Government last night to adopt policies that will cut sharply the $172,000,000,000 now in the country.

THERE was a time when the average homemaker had a pretty good idea of what she would have to pay for a new rug, a new mattress or draperies for the living room. She knew there was practically no limit to what these things could cost if she were blessed with a bottomless pocketbook and went in for custom design, precious materials and all hand workmanship.

Any general strike is a political strike. A general strike in a conquered country takes on the nature of a revolt. General MacArthur acted on that assumption in forbidding the threatened walkout of 2,600,000 Government workers in Japan. It is not likely that he will yield to further pressure by politically inspired Japanese labor leaders.

PANAMA, R.P. -- Another Inter-American Lightplane Cavalcade led by Col. John C.L. Adams, pioneer of the route, will arrive in Panama in February in time for the annual Mardi Gras carnival. The cavalcade will leave Brownsville, Tex., on Feb. 8 for a leisurely trip through Mexico and Central America.
JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 1--State Democratic leaders are reputed to be alarmed over the large number of Negroes who have paid poll taxes and have registered to vote.

A cosmic entity pulsating on the borderline of space and time, constantly being created and destroyed within the nuclei of atoms, which has a "lifetime" of only one one-hundredth of a sextillionth of a second, was offered yesterday as a possible solution to one of the fundamental secrets of the universe.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 --The Congress of Industrial Organizations will unqualifiedly accept the American Federation's proposal to form a united front to combat labor restrictive legislation, but will with equal emphasis reject the Federation's invitation to discuss "organic unity," it was indicated in informed quarters today.
Britain Clears Decks After years of controversy and months of terror a showdown in Palestine now seems at hand.

Fiscal Worries New Yorkers last week got a forecast of what it will cost to run their city and State governments during the coming fiscal year that begins July 1. The official figures contemplate a combined expenditure by city and State of more than $1,612,000,000-- of which the city's share would be about three-fifths.

With retailers appearing to have overcome their earlier timidity, reorders were placed with more confidence last week, according to a market report prepared' especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc. Merchandise continued to become more readily available in numerous categories.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 1 --Representatives of the State and War Departments declared here today that the real solution of the problem of displaced persons was resettlement in other countries.

THE photographs of Henri CartierBresson, which go on exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art this Tuesday, have a triple interest. Primarily, they are pictures of human incidents caught during a historical epoch (roughly the last decade), which are so intensely observed and masterfully photographed that they can serve among the chief pictorial symbols of their time.

Steps aimed at closer retailer-manufacturer cooperation are beginning to take form and undoubtedly will be strongly marked as greater balance between production and distribution permit both new and war-deferred plans of retailers to be put into operation.

BRATISLAVA, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 1--There is evidence today of a marked increase tly in the number of persons who wish to leave the good prospects in orderly and increasingly prosperous Czechoslovakia for an uncertain future as immigrants overseas.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 1--Floridaowned Frere Jacques, something of a champion on the grass, set a track record as he captured the $10,000 added, mile and three-sixteenth Bougainvillea Handicap at Hialeah Park today. Flying the silks of Jacob Sher, the Jack High gelding scored by four lengths in 1:57 2/5, two full seconds better than the turf course mark set three years ago by Miami Springs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--The Senate and the House, both controlled by the Republicans, are not coordinating very well on methods or subjects in legislative areas where coordination should not be difficult to attain. Observers, noting that the House is proceeding one way and the Senate another on such matters as tax reduction, labor legislation and other major issues, are disposed to attribute this to these causes: 1. Presidential nomination politics, with several candidates in Congress itself.

LONDON, Feb. 1--The Arab States delegations have stiffened their attitude of opposition to a Jewish national state in Palestine and will tell Foreign Secretary Bevin so on Tuesday, when the Palestine conference is expected to reconvene.

After an irregular opening the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned strong yesterday and closed at the best levels of the day, 6 to 22 points net higher, with the near months continuing to show strength.

That the steel industry, hub of the nation's industrial activity, has finally generated the momentum needed to relieve quickly the stunted operations of many important manufacturing lines became apparent last week with the release of steel company earnings for 1946.

WE may suppose the committee that selected the paintings now on view at the Whitney Museum to have been well qualified to give us a rounded report on the current aspect of the Ecole de Paris. Serving on this committee, besides representatives of the Association Francaise d'Action Artistique, were two curators each from the Louvre and the Musee National d'Art Moderne, the director of Arts and an art critic.

ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Human Rights Commission -- Argued inconclusively whether the United Nations Secretariat should receive power to draft an international bill of rights, and decided to study the question further.

NOTRE DAME--Medieval Study Eight diversified subjects comprise the curriculum of the newly established Medieval Institute at the University of Notre Dame. Included in the studies for the first semester are medieval history, theology, philosophy, languages and literatures, Latin palaeography and art history.

GROWING as large a variety of vegetables as possible is one way to secure the greatest usefulness from the vegetable plot. In general, it is well to avoid the untried novelties and specialties, but it is good practice to try some of the standard but neglected crops.

MOSCOW, Feb. 1--United States expansion in the Arctic is a step on the highway to world domination, even though this may entail direct attacks and infringement of the sovereignty of Denmark, Iceland and Greenland, it is claimed here.

RICHMOND, Feb. 1--Virginia has joined five other States of the Union having anti-closed shop laws. Governor William M. Tuck, who submitted the measure to an extraordinary session of the General Assembly this month, saw it passed by large majorities in both houses, and has signed it, to become effective late in April.
" The week that the diagramless puzzles appear I am furious because I can't work them. What is the method of working them? There must be some simple rules that would help me."

TAMAZUNCHALE, Mexico-- It cost 15 cents to cross the International Bridge to Mexico and 60 cents for a Mexican auto permit. Contrary to rumor, Mexican officials neither expected nor demanded tips for rushing our bags through a brisk inspection.

The sale of the Stern newspapers in Philadelphia and Camden would threaten grave hardship to hundreds of the employes were it not for the action and encouraging words of Robert McLean, publisher of The Bulletin, who bought the properties. Mr. VcLean made it clear that he agreed to purchase only after the suspension of the newspapers had been determined upon.

THIS novel begins with promise. Written in the first person, the first few chapters unfold with elusive, nostalgic overtones as Camilla Lejonstedt tells her story. She is an American girl married to a Swedish man of solid and substantial background.

WITH H.M.S. VANGUARD, at Sea, Feb. 1 (AP)--This British warship, bearing the royal family on a three-month visit to South Africa, steamed tonight into choppy seas and the prospect of a gale the first night out.

New York will not be acclaimed as a model city until it eliminates slums, establishes higher standards of cleanliness and improves its system of transportation, according to pupils who participated yesterday in the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast over Station WQXR.

HAVING completed a series on "Man and His Government," "invitation to Learning" (CBS, Sunday, 12-12:30 P.M.), beginning this afternoon, will embark on a thirtythree-week series of discussions under the general topic of "Pursuit of Happiness." Talks will survey the different ways in which man has pursued that elusive quality as exemplified in the world's great literature. Today's initial discussion will be on the "Analects" of Confucius.

ATHENS, Greece, Feb. 1--Alexis Kyrou, Greek liaison officer, today handed the chairman of the United Nations investigation commission, John D. Hood, a sharp note of protest against the efforts made by Josip Djerdja, liaison officer for the Yugoslav delegation, to "vilify" Greece.
Celebrations of the hundredth anniversary of the birth of Thomas A. Edison, the inventor, will begin this week. He was born on Feb. 11, 1847, in Milan, Ohio.

ROBERT M. MacIVER, Professor of Political Philosophy and Sociology of Columbia University, has written a wise and provocative book. It is also an ambitious book. It covers the whole history of government, from its family origins through the forms it has taken in differing cultures, the way it has been transformed and has grown, the relations of state to state, and finally the future of those relations --the approach to the international order.

Wherever there is life there is protein. The protein need not be alive itself, but it is always associated with life. Examples are milk and meat. Bacteria, the viruses, bacteriophage ("bacteria eater"), genes--not one of these would be possible without protein. This juggests to Dr. Dorothy Wrinch (Smith College) that the virus diseases will be truly conquered when more is known about the structure of the protein molecule.

LITTLE AMERICA, Jan. 31 (Delayed) -- Little America will be evacuated by the last of the Navy's Antarctic expedition force about March 1, Rear Admiral Richard H. Cruzen, task force commander, announced tonight.

IT is perhaps the ultimate expression of labor's rise to respectability that a publisher should bring forth this record of the lives and attainments of 7,500 men and women who lead unions or represent government agencies that deal with them.

New York's Police Department was strengthened yesterday by 633 former service men who were sworn in as probationary patrolmen at Police Headquarters. When these men end a six-month training course the force will number 17,494, or about 1,500 less than the quota recently established.

MATAGALPA, Nicaragua, Jan. 31 (Delayed)--Under the guns of about 4,200 members of the Guardia Nacional, more than 200,000 Nicaragua voters will go to the polls Sunday to elect a successor to President Anastasio Somoza.

HOLLYWOOD. ACCORDING to the pundits of the cinema, the Western picture constitutes the fullest realization, of the screen as a dramatic medium. Buddy Adler, who cannot bear to see a Western if he can help it, has become a minor theatrical magnate on the West Coast by accepting the dictum of the esoteric critics.
BERLIN, Feb. 1--Peter Dattel is alive and is going to America.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 1-- Hopes for a peaceful settlement of the Indian political impasse seem at their lowest ebb tonight.

Jan Cherniavsky, pianist, and Mischel Cherniavsky, 'cellist, gave a joint recital yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. The brothers, who were members of the former Cherniavsky Trio, could be commended for the musicianship, sincerity and refinement of their performances.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1--In this metropolis, citadel of Al Capone's underworld empire during the Prohibition era, the crime syndicate which the late scarfaced gang leader "fashioned with blood and bribery" has "flourished to this day."

His account of the discussions which preceded the use of the atomic bomb at Hiroshima and Nagasaki is not a mere memoir. It represents a stage in an evolving national foreign policy, in which Mr. Stimson, twice Secretary of War.

THE world of Nelson Algren's "The Neon Wilderness" is like James T. Farrell's, one he never made. It is not the same world as Farrell's, however, despite the fact that all but eight of these twenty-four brutal, pitiful and piteous stories occur in Chicago, among the streets and alleyways where Studs Lonigan and Danny O'Neill traced their wayward patterns.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 --The State Department announced tonight that its International Broadcasting Division would begin a daily series of broadcasts in Russian to the Soviet Union on Feb. 17.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 1 (AP) -- Francis Tyler, a former Olympic bobsled driver, piloted his Lake Placid Club Sno-Birds to a half-second triumph over Bill Linney's Republic Miners today in a four-man, half-mile race down the Mt. Van Hoevenberg Run.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 1--The first effort at international coordination of working conditions and living standards among production and refining workers in the petroleum industry of a dozen nations will be made when the International Labor Office's new petroleum industry committee meets here on Monday for a nineday session.

What were the best gags heard on the radio last month? This question was put to the most popular comedy and variety shows, judged by radio surveys, and here is their collective answer. Each show picked what it considered its funniest lines in January.

CHILDREN need space. Not nearly enough is being said about this, Cornelia Goldsmith has been telling us. She points out that children need space to move freely, to run and jump, swing and slide and climb, and she finds reason to be concerned about the effect on young children of crowded apartments and family doubling up.

To the Radio Editor: RADIO'S place is in the home, a recent visit to a supper club convinced me. One night a group of us were playing gin rummy. Just as I went eleven-card gin, my partner jumped up saying, "Time for the 11 o'clock news."

PARIS. BY midafternoon every day the offices of Modern Times (Les Temps Modernes), the Existentialist monthly on the rue Sebastien-Bottin, start filling up. There are students from the Sorbonne, wearing full beards and threadbare overcoats; literary ladies who bring along their knitting; a sprinkling of notorious Left Bank dead beats, bent on borrowing a few hundred francs; journalists looking for interviews; visitors from abroad, speaking French with a variety of accents--Anglo-Saxon, Scandinavian, Balkan.

Joe Fulks, the former Murray State Teachers star who has been setting a blistering pace in the Basketball Association of America race for the Philadelphia Warriors, turned in another of his scintillating performances last night.

THOUGH the rest of the world may think highly of Ben Grauer because of his outstanding achievement as a radio announcer, and of Rube Goldberg for his cartoons, it's on the merit of their culinary accomplishments that these gentlemen are judged by fellowmembers of the Society of Amateur Chefs, an organization of famous men who cook for a hobby.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1 (AP)-- Fast breaking St. Joseph's College of Philadelphia made up a sevenpoint first-half deficit tonight to defeat the Redmen of St. John's College of Brooklyn, N.Y., 55 to 48, in the feature game of a college basketball double-header at Convention Hall.

Interest among motor boat folks centers for the next three days on Hollywood, Fla., where many of the 101 unit branches of the United States Power Squadrons will have representatives for the thirty-third anniversary of the U.S.P.S. founders' day.

IT is not often that writers of fiction present convincingly the young artist. A few have done it; most of those who make the attempt fail. And unfortunately it is among the many failures that "Darkling" must be classed.

Hope that we are entering upon an era of industrial peace was strengthened yesterday by President Truman's announcement of an agreement for the friendly settlement of disputes between the Associated General Contractors of America and the A.F.L. Construction Trades Department.
An amendment to the Ives-Quinn law to permit the filing of charges of bias by an interested organization was proposed yesterday by the Citizens Union, 41 Park Avenue.

Hedy Spielter is one piano teacher who believes, in putting her talented pupils before the public when they are young. Four years ago she presented Richard Korbel, aged 8; two years ago she introduced Toba Brill, aged 14; and yesterday afternoon at Town Hall she brought forward Denise Dubs, aged 10.

LONDON THE big star news of the month is Jean Simmons, a 17-year-old Rank property who is tipped as the hottest favorite discovered over here in seasons. Little Miss Simmons smashed through just before Christmas in an almost terrifyingly mature performance as the young Estella in "Great Expectations," and pulled off another smart trick in "Hungry Hill" a couple of weeks ago.

THE week of Feb. 2 to 8 has been designated by Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson as National Garden Planning Week. In selecting these days, the Department of Agriculture thus underlines the advisability of working out on paper the arrangement of crops while the seed order is being made out.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : On Dec. 23, 1946 THE NEW YORK TIMES, under the headline "South Reverses Tradition, Asks Tariff Protection." carried a story credited as Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES which read, in part, as follows:
The nationwide campaign of the Greek War Relief Association to raise $12,000,000, of which the New York City quota is $2,500,000, opened last night with the dedication of a booth in Times Square.
BOSTON, Feb. 1--It's townmeeting' time in New England and reports filtering in indicate that the "perfect exercise of self-government" has lost none of its vigor.

JERICHO, Kansas, was created by Paul Wellman for an earlier novel, and he turns naturally to the prepared site for this story of the short-grass country--a tale which (he says) might just as well have been placed in Rhode Island or California.

BERLIN, Feb. 1 -- Maj. Gen. Frank A. Keating, United States representative on the Berlin Kommandatura, assailed today Maj. Gen. Alexander G. Kotikov, Russian representative, for having brought a Kommandatura dispute to the attention of the German people contrary to an Allied Control Council law.

LONG recognized as a favorite technique of the pictorialist the paper negative process of making photographic prints has become through association a symbol of pictorialist ideology. Those who employ the process, with the facility it affords for altering details of the original negative, are said to belong to the "control" school of photography.

NORTH CONWAY, N. H., Feb. 2--Chunky Toni Matt, former twotime national ruler, and Miss Paula Kann, present women's downhill champion, showed potential Olympic prospects by sweeping the men's and women's phases, respectively, of the Gibson giant slalom today on lightning-fast Arlberg trail.
STUTTGART, Germany, Feb. 2--A dark-eyed Jewish woman, smiling away her tears, told today the story of the first German general to win freedom from United States imprisonment --her husband.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2--Chicago's first eye bank, a laboratory devoted to preserving eye corneas taken from dead persons until they can be transplanted into the living blind, will be established in Chicago by the Sisters of Mercy.

Questioning the right of the United States Commercial Company to undertake a promotional campaign for silk, Matthew H. O'Brien, counsel and secretary of the Rayon Tarn Producers Group has protested the use of Government funds for this purpose.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Feb. 2 --Charles P. Taft, chairman of the State Department's advisory committee on voluntary foreign aid, said here today that private relief agencies probably would be called upon for at least five years to continue their present high rate of aid to Europeans.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP)-- Peace moves by labor and industry met a mixed reception from Congress members today but most of those interviewed maintained that the drive to enact union controls would go ahead.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 2--The top command of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, one of the "big three" unions in the American Federation of Labor, is warning its members that it intends to combat unauthorized strikes with stern disciplinary action.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Feb. 2-- Edward H. Ahrens, president and chairman of the board of the Ahrens Publishing Company, 71 Vanderbilt Avenue, New York, died here yesterday in his home at 60 Prescott Street, after a long illness. His age was 62.

With famine already on the march in China and the food supply in Britain more limited than it was during the U-boat campaign, Europe and Asia are paying the price for the most destructive war in history.

A boycott of British goods to impress the Government of Great Britain with the earnestness of American demands for the opening of Palestine to European Jews was suggested yesterday by Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz.

Two five-story apartment houses, occupying a plot 100 by 100 feet at 198 to 204 Brown Place, in the Bronx, were sold by 200 Brown Place, Inc., Estelle Kuttner, treasurer, to an Investing client of Louis Schrag, Inc., broker. They are at the corner of 137th Street and are assessed for $92,000.
Thomas I. Parkinson, president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, will head the national advisory committee of the American Heart Association, which will begin National Heart Week next Sunday.

The Young Men's Board of Trade of New York, 291 Broad-way, acting as coordinator of the efforts of business and industry, lists the following free services to aid veterans in career-planning and employment:
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 29 --The average Swedish man consumes about 2,700 calories daily. If he wants more he can easily get as there is plenty of unrationed food in Sweden.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Feb. 2-- Competent authorities on finance in Italy agree that after the failure of the 3 1/2 per cent national reconstruction loan offered at 97 1/2, exempt from all present or future taxation, none but measures of unprecedented rigor could avert a national disaster.

ATHENS, Jan. 30--The destruction of overland communications wrought by the enemy, especially in Greece's only productive areas of Macedonia and Thrace, have made the distribution of food hazardous and in many cases impossible.

SINING, China, Feb. 2--Sining, the bleak and dusty little uplands capital of China's Far Western Chinghai Province, is soon to become the first city in the slab of territory stretching 2,000 miles across Central Asia to have a piped municipal water supply.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations has submitted to the Governments of the world a list of basic items designed to serve as the starting point for a 1950 world census of agriculture.

When the spiked shoe brigade charges back to town two weeks hence for the New York Athletic Club games the mile may not be the prime attraction. But at least it will be a race, rather than another of the solo exhibitions staged by the peerless Gilbert Dodds.

The wholesale markets last week were quiet, with few out-of-town buyers in attendance, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. A few re orders for ready-to-wear also were noted.

BOSTON, Feb. 2--The Boston fishing industry, it was disclosed today, is keeping a close watch on the Atlantic Fishermen's Union, AFL, to see whether it will try to limit the size of catches in face of a sudden drop of nearly 50 per cent in the boatside price of fish.

BRATISLAVA, Czechoslovakia, Jan. 29--Czechoslovakia is faced with a serious grain shortage and lack of fats. Bohemia and Moravia also are short of winter storage fruits. The food situation, in general, is superior to that of the surrounding countries.

LANSING, Mich., Feb. 2--Gov. Kim Sigler of Michigan was served today with a demand from the American Youth for Democracy that an investigation of alleged communistic activities of members of the organization on the Michigan State College campus at East Lansing be dropped.
PEIPING, China, Feb. 2 (AP)-- Nearly 2,000 Americans got set today to run a hazardous 115-mile Chinese gantlet to the sea.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2--Prices of corn futures moved up steadily last week on the Board of Trade as the result of enlarged buying by cash and commission houses, The March sold at the highest price since mid-December and within about 1 cent of a new high since last October, or about the time the new crop started to move in volume.

ALBANY, Feb. 2--At the request of Mayor William O'Dwyer Democratic legislators will introduce bills this week to provide for a $90,000,000 to $100,000,000 increase in State aid to New York City and for a wide expansion of the State's housing program, chiefly for the benefit of New York City.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Jan. 31--The well disciplined public in the Netherlands has learned to understand what the Government is doing to improve its daily diet, and generally approves the result.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Feb. 2 (AP)--A couple of newcomers to bobsled competition rode to victory today for the Lake Placid Bobsled Club in an open two-man half-mile race down the Mount Van Hoevenberg run that saw one minor crack-up.

Arthur Christmann, gifted young American conductor, directed an orchestra of thirty-six musicians in a concert given last night al Town Hall. Herbert Blayman, clarinetist, and Frederick Loadwich, tenor, were the soloists on a program containing compositions by Bach, Cimarosa, Mozart, Beethoven and Walter Piston.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 31 --Marshal Tito told the Yugoslav people during the election campaign that no one would starve. There is little question among all observers that he has lived up to that campaigns promise.

The Senate War Investigating Committee, reconstituted by an almost solid party vote, is settling down for what promises to be a prolonged inquiry into "excessive profits, fraud, corruption, waste, extravagance, mismanagement, incompetence and inefficiency" in the home front conduct of the second World War.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--The International Bank, through its long search for a president and because of conjecture over loans it may make, has become a famous name denoting one of the least understood arms of the organization clustered under the United Nations.

ROME, Jan. 31--The Italian food situation, though still tight, is not so bad as it was several weeks ago, when stocks were almost totally exhausted and a reduction of the bread ration seemed unavoidable.

The Ven. Kenneth J. F. Bickersteth, Canon of Christ Church Cathedral in Canterbury, England, yesterday praised the charitable work of New York City's hospitals and churches but warned against the danger of mistaking humanitarianism for Christianity.
MEXICO CITY, Feb. 2--Mexican organized labor gave another demonstration last week of its apparent determination to weaken itself.

To the editor op the new York times: Walter Reuther's letter published in your issue of Jan. 24 is inaccurate. In the first place, neither in my Milwaukee speech, which he criticizes, nor in your account of the speech, did I say that either Mr. Reuther or Mr. Murray was a "threat." What I did say was: "The attack upon capitalism -upon profits to employers-by the Phil Hurrays and the Reuthers is insistent and vicious."

The more than two score of art events scheduled for this week icre include two annual exhibitions, the forty-seventh by the American Society of Miniature Painters, opening to the public on Wednesday, at Portraits, Inc., and the eightieth by members of the American Water-Color Society, opening on Friday in the galleries of the National Academy.

PARIS, Feb. 2--Acting through the American Chamber of Commerce here, American business men living in France will ask the United States Senate to reject the pending taxation treaty between the United States and France, which is expected to come before the Foreign Relations Committee soon.

MONTREAL, Feb. 2 (Canadian Press)--The cost of living in the United States was 48 per cent higher at the end of November, 1946, than in 1937, the international Labor Office said today in a survey of seventeen nations.

The New York Chapter of the Baseball Writers Association irreverently produced an opus, "Mexican Pay Ride," or "Who's Owin' Owen?" This was the sock and buskin trade at its worst--and the emphasis was on the sock infinitely more than on the buskin.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 2--A coal bin that will hold sixty tons of coal, a fourteen-car garage and ten bathrooms all with built-in showers are among the features of the Herbert L. Satterlee estate here on which the Protestant Episcopal Church has taken an option in a move to establish a lodging center and a residence for the Presiding Bishop.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Feb. 2-- This city is expected to be on a near-normal basis tomorrow for the first time in four days, after digging out from under the most paralyzing snowstorm in its history. The storm, which smothered the city in 18.1 inches of snow during a twenty-four-hour fall beginning last Wednesday night, accounted for at least five deaths, three of them by freezing, about thirty miles west of the city.
BRUSSELS, Jan. 31 -- Among the countries hard hit by the war Belgium is unquestionably the best fed now, and people here see no reason why this comforting state of affairs should change.

With flotations of new equity capital at minimums typical of the first weeks of the new year, interest in the capital market here centers upon the degree of success achieved by current transactions deriving from the recapitalization or divestment of public utility companies at the direction of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--Proposals to abandon priorities in the distribution of the Government's surplus property were attacked today by Albert Pleydell, Commissioner of Purchase of the City of New York, as spokesmen for public purchasing agents.

A special service marking the reopening of the John Street Church, known as the "Mother Church of American Methodism," 44 John Street, in the downtown financial district, was held yesterday morning. The meeting house, which serves the oldest Methodist congregation, in the United States, had been closed for ten months while extensive structural repairs were being made.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 2-- Fred MacMurray has been signed by Universal-International to star in "Singapore," a photo-play by Seton I. Miller dealing with pearl smuggling. The Miller photo-play was purchased recently by the studio in completed form from the author and the picture is scheduled to go before the cameras Feb. 24. A director and a producer will be assigned to the project this week according to U-I.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- It is now clear that the division between the Soviet Union and the other members of the Big Four on how far Germany should be allowed to develop a strong central administration of her economic and political affairs is reflected perfectly in the views of the small powers.
LONDON, Feb. 1--The food situation in Britain this winter is pretty much the same old story.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 2--Delegates to the Pan-African Congress on Pre-History have returned to Nairobi after an examination in Tanganyika of rock paintings whose age is measured not in centuries but in millennia.
A Touch of Sea Air One of our scouts, with long conditioning to the sidewalks of New York and the city air above and below them, reports on a week-end excursion to Long Island.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Feb. 2 (Reuters)-French troops in a surprise counter-attack this afternoon hurled back Viet Nam forces which earlier had penetrated French defenses ringing the encircled town of Namdinh, fifty miles southeast of Hanoi, a French news agency dispatch from Hanoi reported.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Feb. 2-- In the face of some post-election disorder in the capital tonight, President Anastasio Somoza claimed victory for his Liberal party on the basis of early and fragmentary returns from today's elections.
A nearly perfect record in the prosecution of criminal cases in 1946 was shown yesterday in the j annual report of John F. X. McGohey, United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York.

To the editor of the new york times: As an American equally of Northern and Southern origins I was glad to see your editorial upon the Segregation Number of The Survey. That which I find of immediate personal concern, however, is not the Negro problem in the South, bad as that is.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--J. A. Krug, Secretary of the Interior, today recommended a $1,000,000,000 survey of mineral resources to determine this country's dependency on foreign supply.

A memorial service for the late Prince Gustaf Adolf, second in line of succession to the Swedish throne, who was killed Jan. 26 in an airplane crash in Copenhagen, Denmark, was held yesterday in the Gustavus Adolphus Lutheran Church, 151 East Twenty-second Street.

Harry Adaskin, Canadian violinist, who had been heard here as a member of the Hart String Quartet, had his New York solo debut last night at Times Hall in a program of unusual distinction and integrity.

LITTLE AMERICA, Feb. 1 (Delayed) (AP)--An Antarctic storm paced by wind gusts ranging up to fifty miles an hour raged across Little America and the Ross Sea tonight, slowing the final unloading of the Navy expedition's ships and the construction of an emergency camp.

January witnessed the heaviest post-Christmas return flow of currency from circulation ever recorded, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York states in its monthly review of credit and business conditions released for publication today.

A 16-year-old boy who said he believed he had been accused unjustly of a theft admitted last night that he had started a spectacular fire earlier in the evening that had swept through the lumber yard of Joseph H. Benzing, Inc., at 45 Williams Place in the East New York section of Brooklyn.

Expenditure by the State of an additional $500,000,000 to finance and subsidize low-rent housing was proposed yesterday by the Liberal party as part of its legislative program sent to members of the Legislature by Joseph V. O'Leary, State secretary, and Ben Davidson, executive director.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 2--A boxer that already was top-heavy with best-in-show victories but wore them lightly, Ch. El Wendie of Rockland from the Rye Top Kennels of Harrison, N. Y., got one more to cap the two-day show of the Maryland Kennel Club tonight

With traffic greatly increased during 1946, the five bridges operated by the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority showed a net profit of $4,171,209 last year, George E. Spargo, general manager and secretary, declared yesterday in his annual report.

WEEK ENDED FEB. 1, 1947 Heavy buying of the Canadian free dollar last week carried that unit to 96 cents, highest since Dec. 11, last. The advance was steady from the outset of trading when 95.06 cents was made on Monday

A national sale of $500,000 worth of telephone and telegraph equipment is included among new mail-order offerings and six special cycles of location sales for commercial buyers of surplus property totaling approximately $27,000,000 in original inventory, Carl P. Malmstrom, regional director of the War Assets Administration, announced over the week-end.

The New York Rovers were in no mood to be tampered with yesterday in their Eastern League battle with the Boston Olympics. The league-leading Red Shirts, beaten only twice on home ice this season, stopped the Hub skaters, 7-1, before 11,564 fans in the feature of the amateur hockey twinshowing at Madison Square Garden.

"Einstein: His Life and Times," by Philipp Frank, has been scheduled for publication by Knopf on Feb. 20. Dr. Frank, a scientist who long has known Dr. Einstein, gives an exposition of his scientific, philosophical and social principles.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2--An active demand for cash lard combined with strength in edible oils and a falling off in receipts of hogs due to unfavorable weather conditions sent July and September lard to new seasonal high prices on the Board of Trade last week.

WARSAW, Jan. 31--The overriding factor in Poland's economy today is the approaching end of the program of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration. UNRRA has poured nearly $500,000,000 worth of supplies into Poland, enabling her to maintain a fairly comfortable food ration.

BERLIN, Jan. 29--The average German is in the position of a hungry man looking in the window of a locked restaurant and hearing the owner beside him promise to open it in a couple of days. On paper, the German is due to eat better shortly.
Return of the church to the everyday, materialise life of man was advocated yesterday by the Rev. Dr. George F. MacLeod, leader of Scotland's Iona movement.

Following is a summary of what is being done on an international basis for the relief of war-damaged countries: International Refugee Organization--This is being organized by the United Nations, but no international help in supplying food and other essentials to war-devasted countries will be available through the organization after the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration stops its work around July 1.

George Abbott and Richard Aldrich, joining forces for the first time in their long theatrical careers as managers, will present tonight at the Biltmore Theatre "It Takes Two," a comedy by Virginia Faulkner and Dana Suesse. Martha Scott, who made her last appearance on the Broadway stage in "The Voice of the Turtle," is starred. The curtain will rise promptly at 8 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--Col. John S. Sensenbrenner, General Staff Corps, has been appointed War Department representative on the War Contracts Price Adjustment Board by the Secretary of War, Robert Patterson, it was announced here yesterday.

MADRID, Jan. 30--The benefits of peace and neutrality in the World War arena are not so apparent to the average Spaniard. A Spanish workman cannot be upset by the fact that defeated Germans struggle along on 1,500 calories daily, because if he is lucky enough himself to have work his own diet averages 1,400 to 1,600 calories, according to his job and the number of children he must feed.
VIENNA, Jan. 28--No country in Europe is living on a lower food ration than Austria and for no country are the 1947 food prospects more uncertain.

The National Association of Manufacturers said yesterday that a survey of sixty-four companies sued for back portal-to-portal pay showed that claims filed averaged $6 for every $1 which the companies made in net earnings last year.
CHICAGO, Feb. 2--Grain markets were on the upgrade on the Board of Trade last week. March and September wheat were at new seasonal highes and March corn went to a new high since midDecember.

Once more, as it has done for several years past, the Interstate Commerce Commission, in its annual report just made public, recommends that Congress enact legislation permitting the railroads to act jointly, under commission supervision, to establish rates and fares.

TOKYO, Jan. 30--The Japanese food situation has vastly improved since last summer's critical days through last fall's bumper rice crop of 9,000,000 metric tons, approaching the pre-war average. Although the nation is still unable to feed itself without outside assistance, releases of Allied foodstuffs to the Japanese Government have been reduced about two thirds and are now running about 50,000 metric tons monthly, compared with 150,000 at the peak of last summer.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--The Foreign Policy Association asserted today that the Soviet Union, lacking large-scale money credits from the United States, would have to continue getting its imports by barter.

Baseball's current "indoor" season closed on a hilarious, historical and at times slightly hysterical note last night as more than 1,200 guests, including virtually all of the game's outstanding bigwigs, attended the twenty-fourth annual dinner and frolic of the New York Chapter of the Baseball Writers Association at the Waldorf-Astoria.
A record number of police officers will be promoted at a ceremony at Headquarters on Wednesday at noon, Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander announced yesterday.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Feb. 2-- lasting a shadow over the fleet of sailing dinghies on this Groundhog Day, Arthur Knapp's painfullamed boat Agony did not duck back even from the ice flake-freezing cold, but stayed out there and made a top score in the racing at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 26 --The most striking feature of Hungary's food situation is that in this former granary of Europe the shortest items are bread and flour. After Feb. 1 the bread ration is to be reduced for workers from twenty-five dekkars [slightly more than half a pound] to twenty and for ordinary consumers to fifteen dekkars.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 2 (AP) --Nikolai V. Novikov, Soviet Ambassador to the United States, expressed "deep confidence" here tonight that "the shadow that has lately been darkening our relations is not the reflection of the real state of affairs between the two peoples."

PARIS, Feb. 2--French infantry, supported by tanks, field artillery and aircraft, today cleared the entire circular road near Hanoi from the northern end of the Great Lake to the Red River, according to tonight's communique from IndoChina.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 2--steel output last week reached a new post-war high when the industry was able to push production up a point to 93 per cent of rated capacity. Indications are, according to steel sources here, that this rate will be maintained for some time despite the situation in scrap and pig iron.

A new type of adaptable folding screen, in which Venetian blind slats are used vertically, is now being made by four painters who have combined their decorative talents for the furniture venture. The wood slats may be painted to match wall colors, or stained and rubbed to blend with furniture and flooring, and then hand-painted in large designs.

One day each February some people start worrying about groundhogs. Then they get other people stirred up and pretty soon the Weather Man's phone rings and Boy Scouts start scampering around parks and suburbs looking for the animals.

ATLANTA, Feb. 2--After three weeks of turmoil legal lines were being formed today for Georgia's "Battle of the Governors" in the courts this week, when hearings are scheduled in three of six pending suits.

For the first time since before the war food costs for a low-income family of five in New York have declined, according to a citywide survey by the New York Budget Council, released yesterday. The decline amounts to 7 1/2 per cent since last September, due mainly to the wider availability of low-cost foods that were either scarce or nonexistent a few months ago.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2--Production of coin-operated vending machines will be back to normal by the end of the year, spokesmen for the industry predicted, provided steel needs can be met by that time. One industry bottleneck, a shortage of aluminum castings, is now in the process of clearing up.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Feb. 2--Col. Edward J. Glavin, new chief of the Army's information and education program, expressed concern today that Congress would restrict the program's funds "when we are still, passing through a critical twilight period from the combat into the post-war phase."
ROME, Feb. 2--Premier Alcide de Gasperi announced today that he had formed a Cabinet based on a coalition of Christian Democrats, Communists and Socialists and two independents.

The National Home Demonstration Council has joined the Women's Action Committee for Lasting Peace, Mrs. Norman de R. Whitehouse, national president of the committee, announced yesterday at group headquarters, 1 East Fifty-seventh Street.

William H. Hastie, Governor of the Virgin Islands, declared here yesterday that "the people of the Islands have demonstrated a real capacity for self-government" since enactment of the Organic Act of 1936.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 29--The midwinter outlook for food in the Middle East is unchanged from normal, which means a marginal subsistence level for the vast majority of people in these barren, fruitless lands.

Prices of cotton, in the domestic market last week registered the largest net gains for a week since mid-December. At the close of trading on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net advances for the week of 93 to 161 points, with the greatest improvement in the near months.

A survey to determine if it is possible to set aside additional parking space on the fringes of the downtown financial and commercial areas, in parts of which rigid enforcement of the ban on daytime parKing starts today, will be made hand-in-hand with the drive to clear the sector, it was made known last night.

TOKYO, Feb. 2--Almost 50 per cent of the Japanese people now oppose the Government of Premier Shigeru Yoshida, it was indicated today in a nation-wide poll taken by the newspaper Asahi through its branch offices in all parts of the country.

MOSCOW, Feb. 2--The American report on control of atomic energy does not stand a chance of success when it comes before the Security Council of the United Nations this week, according to today's Pravda, official organ of the central committee of the Communist party.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Feb. 2 --Gen. George C. Marshall, Secretary of State, said today it was the policy of the United States to join with other nations for speedy resettlement of the displaced persons of Europe.

LONDON, Feb. 2--Dr. Chaim Weizman, former chairman of the executive board of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, warned tonight that Zionist terrorism might destroy everything the Zionists had built. He urged them to work for the restoration of normal relations between the agency and the British Government.

The experts are still grinding or "shaping" the two-hundred-inch mirror that is to be carried up Palomar Mountain, where it will become part of a large telescope on which the Rockefeller Foundation alone has spent over six million dollars. By the end of the year space should be pierced for a distance of a thousand million lightyears. Astronomers and astrophysicists need the Great Eye for its enormous light-gathering power.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--An immediate, full scale study of the newsprint shortage was proposed today by Senator James Murray, Democrat, of Montana.
MOSCOW, Jan. 31--Midwinter and early spring will be the most difficult period of the year for food supplies in the Soviet Union.
MANILA, Jan. 31--The Philippines has sufficient reserve grains and imported foods to ward off famine when UNRRA aid ceases, probably in midsummer.

Jere McMahon, who has danced hereabouts in various musicals and light clubs, last night presented himself and several other artists in a program at the Belasco Theatre under the title of "No Cover Charge." As this would suggest, it was essentially a night-club show, but lacking the conviviality and especially the informality of the night club atmosphere, it cannot be said to have been altogether effective.
