To the editor of the new york times: On Jan. 23 you reported a speech by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler in which he is stated to have said that in the summer of 1921 he was invited by the late David Lloyd George to a meeting of the Prime Ministers of the British dominions at which "Canada, Australia and New Zealand threatened to seced from the empire unless they obtained greater regional autonomy and independence."
PARIS, Jan. 26--In the midst of another cold wave in the second post-war winter, Paris and other large cities are suffering from scarcities of food and fuel to the almost same extent as in wartime.

NANKING, Feb. 2--The Communist Yenan radio reacted today for the first time to the American decision to close Executive Headquarters at Peiping and withdraw the United States Marines from North China. The Communist station indicated some satisfaction with the decision, but made it clear that Yenan felt that the United States had not gone far enough.
More Bible reading was urged upon Catholics by the Rev. Michael J. Deacy of St. Patrick's Cathedral in a sermon at a solemn mass there yesterday.

MOSCOW, Feb. 2--Izvestia, Government newspaper, said today that the Soviet people must understand that there is definite United States and British policy against carrying out denazification in Germany as directed by the Potsdam Agreement.
Two hundred and elghty-four officers and men of the Turkish merchant marine who arrived here on Saturday will man seven ships recently acquired in this country by Turkey.

DENVER, Feb. 2 (AP)--An erudite plumber fixed a faulty stopper in Randolph Churchill's hotel bathroom here and engaged him in debate almost as heated as the visitor's father, Winston Churchill, encounters in the House of Commons.
NANKING, Feb. 2--Chinese Government troops have recaptured Tancheng, twenty-eight miles south of the Communist New Fourth Army headquarters at Linyi, it was reported today.
LONDON, Feb. 2--Great Britain must try to reduce the economic burdens arising out of her international commitments, Hugh Dalton, Chancellor of the Exchequer, said today.

The post-war era "has ushered us into a time of moral confusion," the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, said in his sermon yesterday. With a half million divorces in the United States in one year, widespread juvenile delinquency involving children between the ages of 10 and 14 and "a marked decline in sexual morality, the sickness of our society is plainly revealed," he said.
The United States needs leaders of proved ability, training and a knowledge of spiritual value if Western civilization is to be saved from chaos, the Rev. Joseph T. O'Callahan declared yesterday.

Declaring that New York City was giving away $76,000,000 each year in "free subway rides" because the 5-cent fare was insufficient to meet operating expenses, the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York called upon the city administration yesterday to establish a 10-cent fare without delay.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--Simplification of the tariff system on watches and clocks, with proper regard for our trade agreement with Switzerland, was urged today by the United States Tariff Commission.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--Representative Harold Knutson of Minnesota, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, renewed his stand today for a flat 20 per cent income tax cut for everyone amid a Republican family argument on whether the measure should give more relief to the poor than to the rich.

Because of greatly expanded activities, the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, after nine years of association with, the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, will set up on its own by mutual agreement, it was announced over the week-end by Thomas Jefferson Miley, secretary of the association.
NANKING, Feb. 1--Famine in China is certain to take a heavy toll again this year. Some experts on the Chinese food situation fear that conditions in 1947 may be even worse than last year.
The carving of ham has special pertinency now, because this meat is plentiful and, on the word of the Department of Agriculture, thriftily priced in relation to wholesale costs.

Britain s new 42,500-ton battleship, the Vanguard, steaming past the Isle of Wight on Saturday, passed within two miles of one of those floating mines which still infest the world's chief seaways. This was not a particularly close call. The incident was noted, however, because the Vanguard had on board the reigning house of Britainthe King, the Queen, the Princess Elizabeth and the Princess Margaret Rose.

TORRINGTON, Conn., Feb. 2-- A meeting to vote on secession of the Torrington local from the International Union of Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers, CIO, broke up in disorder today after the local president, Michael Ricci, had called on the police to eject the national president, Reid Robinson.

The Long Island Rail Road seems to have become the rope in a tug of war between our subway civilization and an earlier and more leisurely culture. On the one hand is the amorphous but determined mass of humanity we call society, with the first-come-firstserved dictum so indigenous to our metropolis.
Dr. Winton I. Patnode, chemist of the General Electric Research Laboratory in Schenectady, has been placed in charge of the laboratory's branch at the Hanford Engineer Works, Richland, Washington.

KERRVILLE, Tex., Feb. 2 (AP)-- Liberalization of the substitution rule to make possible insertion of a player when the ball is dead although the clock is still running and banning the so-called running shift, the use of which had brought bitter protests from some sections, were among seven rules changes and clarifications announced today by the National Collegiate Athletic Association football rules committee.

BREMEN, Feb. 2--As a result of the drop in the United States price of cotton, German textile mills are re-entering the world market, offering finished place goods instead of gray goods, it was learned today. The program, which got under way with initial shipments from the American zone to Bremen, for eventual shipment to Sweden, envisages a weekly production of 500 tons of finished goods.
There has been no agreement between Sam Breadon, president and owner of the Cardinals, and his star player, Stan Musial, on the terms of the latter's 1947 contract.

The quandary of the British Government in sacrificing nearly everything to recover export markets is not unlike the thirty-year-old dilemma of the Soviet Government in its merciless campaign for industrialization. The British have every incentive but one to produce more than they ever produced before.

Twelve thousand women and children clicked through turnstiles to see the Aviation Show in Grand Central Palace yesterday, with an unexpectedly large number of actual airplane purchasers among them. Almost all the twenty-odd exhibitors of personal airplanes reported sales and all said prospects demanded flight demonstrations.

TOKYO, Feb. 2--Japanese Christianity, handicapped by militaristic suspicion and suppression throughout the war, has been making little progress since the surrender. It has been hindered by the official yen-dollar exchange rate, fifteen yen to one dollar, which prevents American aid from reaching the struggling congregations.

BERLIN, Feb. 2--The Arbeitsgemeinschaft Schmierstoff Verteilung, one of several oil cartels organized by the Germans during the war to monopolize the sale of petroleum products, was dissolved on Dec. 31 by joint British-American action, it was disclosed today in an unusual manner.

The New Friends of Music, which was founded in 1936, gave its 200th concert yesterday afternoon in Town Hall at 5:30 o'clock, the hour which it has made its own and which lovers of chamber music have come to know as the time when they can hear good performances of the sort of music they prefer.

WINFIELD PARK, N. J., Feb. 2 --The Federal Government may soon be out of the headaching business of owning this town--the warborn Winfield Park housing development, where 700 families now live and many more would be living if quarters were available.

The refusal of unions in seven building crafts to accept a lengthening in their basic work day from seven hours to eight has jeopardized the no-strike agreement covering 200,000 building trades workers in this city, the Building Trades Employers Association warned its members yesterday.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 2 (AP)-- Ken Bartholomew of Minneapolis put on a two-lap spurt in the final race to win a first place and enough points today to dethrone his fellow townsman, defending champion Bob Fitzgerald, in the senior men's national outdoor speed skating championships.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2 (AP)--The Chicago Black Hawks, tail-end club of the National Hockey League, defeated the third place Boston Bruins, 3-1, tonight to fashion a two-game winning streak before 17,998 rabid followers in Chicago Stadium.

TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 2 (AP)-- Jimmy Demaret successfully defended his Tucson open tournament title today when he posted a record-breaking 264 to win first money in the seventy-two-hole $10,000 golf event.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP)-- The American Red Cross disclosed today that $350,000 was the amount of the contribution from the motion picture industry which it rejected on the ground it was raised along with other charity funds.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 2 (AP)-- Ken Bartholomew of Minneapolis put on a two-lap spurt in the final race to win a first place and enough points today to dethrone his fellow townsman, defending champion Bob Fitzgerald, in the senior men's national outdoor speed skating championships.
PARIS, Feb. 2--The outstanding silhouette in spring hats shows a sidewise movement. Brims are much wider on either side than in front or back, and trimming accentuates this tendency.
ALBANY, Feb. 2--Child-care centers operated at present under the jurisdiction of the State Youth Commission will be continued, it was learned today from an authoritative source.
MOSCOW, Feb. 2--Slandering the Soviet Union has now become a family business for Brooks and Oriana Atkinson, according to The Literary Gazette.
Cleaning women of New York united yesterday in announcing their opposition to cleaning cuspidors, relics of the days when men were men and proved it by chewing tobacco.

Launches World Trade Drive The Advertising Council has launched a nation-wide campaign on the basic economics of world trade through distribution to advertising agencies and advertisers of 10,000 campaign guides developed by it, it 'was announced over the week-end.

LONDON, Feb. 2--The stock markets here have settled down to a more calm atmosphere, with a noticeably smaller turnover since the recent shake-up caused by the publication of the Government's white paper on the economic situation.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 2--An incomplete tabulation of ballots indicates that members of the Marine Firemen, Oilers and Watertenders, an independent union, have voted overwhelmingly against formal affiliation with the Committee for Maritime Unity.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2 (AP)--The Chicago Black Hawks, tail-end club of the National Hockey League, defeated the third place Boston Bruins, 3-1, tonight to fashion a two-game winning streak before 17,998 rabid followers in Chicago Stadium.

Three players who are slated to play a prominent part in the Dodgers' bid for a 1947 pennant have come to terms with Branch Rickey, the head of the Brooklyn club announced yesterday at one of his dramatically planned press conferences.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 3 -- The ambitious road building program that will bring the United States and Mexico City many highway miles closer to each other is being pushed as rapidly as possible by the Ministry of Communications and Public Works.

A record attendance of buyers placed substantial orders yesterday at the opening of the convention and merchandise exhibit of the National Sporting Goods Association at the Hotel New Yorker. Many dealers, however, were inclined to be cautious because of the high level of prices compared with a year ago, and easing supplies in a number of lines.

MOSCOW, Feb. 3 -- Out back of beyond, where the red stone hills of Nemegetu Range knuckle into the black wastes of the Gobi Desert, Soviet scientists have discovered a huge graveyard of prehistoric monsters.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Feb. 3 -- Manilal Gandhi, a resident of Natal, called on the Indian community today to observe a day of mourning when the British royal family reaches Durban on March 20 on its South African tour.

Opening two weeks earlier than last year, summer dress lines brought an excellent buying response yesterday, according to a survey of member houses of the Fashion Originators Guild. Eight manufacturers opened their lines yesterday, five will do so today and the rest will open in the next two weeks.

Vigorous international competition for transatlantic air traffic this spring and summer, together with the possible entry of the British Overseas Airway Corporation into air traffic between New York and San Francisco, was indicated yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- A proclamation limiting imports into the United States of harsh, or rough, cotton of less than three-quarterinch staple to 70,000,000 pounds a year was issued by President Truman today. The quota will apply to the year ending Sept. 19, 1947, and each subsequent year ending on Sept. 19.
PARIS, Feb. 3 -- Plans for the launching of the second stage of former premier Leon Blum's experiment in price reduction by "shock treatment" were discussed tonight by the inner Cabinet.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Almost fifteen years after he was convicted as a murderer and sentenced to life imprisonment, the Supreme Court today unanimously ordered a new trial for Rene de Meerleer of Michigan. In a terse opinion, the court explained that de Meerleer, then only 17 years old, was hurried through his trial in one day, was without a lawyer, and was never advised of his right to counsel.

An exhibition called "Significant War Scenes by Battlefront Artists" opened with a preview yesterday afternoon in the International Salon of the Chrysler Building, 405 Lexington Avenue. It opens to the public today and will continue (9 to 6 daily, except Sundays) through March 1.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 3 -- Protests against a recent resolution that singled out only the World Federation of Trade Unions by name, were voiced in the United Nations Social Commission here today by members of the American Federation of Labor and the International Cooperative Alliance.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (U.P.) -- President Truman was urged today to convene a "Big Four" conference to attempt a settlement of China's civil war that would permit speedy unification of that country.

OSAWATOMIE, Kan., Feb. 3 (U.P.) -- A middle-aged Negro who had shot and killed Chief of Police Mike Churchill, was dragged by officers today from an infuriated mob, members of which already had thrown a rope around his neck and started to lynch him.
There was a bull movement in Wall Street yesterday as the police ban on parking in the downtown financial and commercial areas moved into high gear.

Silver Prices The London and New York silver markets were brought virtually in balance yesterday when the price of the metal in London was reduced from 55 1/2d an ounce to 44d. The new price is equivalent to 73.88 cents in United States currency at the present official rate of exchange, compared with the previous price of 93.19 cents an ounce.

SAIGON, French Indo-China, Feb. 3 -- French forces in IndoChina, already re-inforced yesterday by 6,800 veteran infantrymen, will receive 1,000 more paratroops in about a week, it was learned reliably today.

"John Loves Mary," a comedy by Norman Krasna, who contributed the successful "Dear Ruth" of two seasons ago, has its Broadway premiere this evening at the Booth Theatre. The producing auspices are Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d in association with Joshua Logan.
CHICAGO, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Today's report of the live-stock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Manufacturers of children's and infants' wear can maintain their peak business only by paying close attention to quality and price, Joseph Gleitsman, president of the United Infants' and Children's Wear Association, declared yesterday.

OTTAWA, Feb. 3 -- Amid applause from all sections of the House of Commons this evening, Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King asserted Canada had "fought to prevent two countries from dominating the world, and we do not wish to see any one, two or three or four countries dominating the peace."

BERKELEY, Calif., Feb. 3 (AP) -- Herbert O. (Fritz) Crisler of Michigan, No. 1 prospect to become athletic director and head football coach at the University of California, arrived today to talk terms with California officials.

Perhaps you've noticed chestnut vendors on street corners this winter, roasting their wares in full view of pedestrians, their portable stoves sending up puffs of steam that are warming to look at on a brisk day.

PARIS, Feb. 3 -- Clean-up operations to the south of the Circular Road and to the east of the Mandarin Road near Hanoi were continued today. All villages within a radius of two miles of the city in this section were freed from Viet Nam forces, which, at several points, made strong resistance, according to the French millitary communique.

A smoke-abatement program was started yesterday at a meeting at City Hall of representatives of municipal agencies, civic organizations, medical societies and industrial groups in the metropolitan area as well as from surrounding communities.
Sydenham Hospital, the interracial institution at Manhattan Avenue and 124th Street, has overcome its temporary financial difficulties, it was announced yesterday.
Butter prices went up 4 1/2 cents a pound at wholesale yesterday, foreshadowing a similar rise today in most retail stores in this city.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- President Truman asked Congress today to extend for another year some of his war powers in the interest of "the effective completion of reconversion." The extended authority would cover a limited list of foods, including sugar, grain, rice and fats and oils, allocation of freight cars and regulation of a few imports and exports.

Senator George announces that he will submit to the Joint Congressional Committee on the Budget a plan to cut 500,000 Government employes off the Federal payroll by July 1. Chairman Taber of the House Appropriations Committee has already suggested a figure twice as large.

Benjamin Brodie, head of the corporation that operated the Miami Theatre, Forty-sixth Street and Avenue of the Americas, until its license was revoked last spring for showing the film "Guilty Parents," was exonerated of all charges in connection with the case yesterday in Special Sessions.

The huge red bow on the white facade of the new ten-story Lane Bryant store on Fifth Avenue at Fortieth Street was untied yesterday, with all the ceremony due the first major fashion store opening on the Avenue in fifteen years.

A jury in Federal Court found two real estate agents guilty yesterday afternoon on all four counts of an indictment charging that they had demanded a year's advance rent and a $9,500 bonus as conditions for the rental of an apartment at 935 Perk Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The War Assets Administration apparently was free today to continue plans to dispose of the $146,000,000 Big Inch and Little Inch pipelines for either oil or gas use after efforts to delay their sale were nullified in Congress.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations, urging" the maintenance of the existing rent control structure, intimated today that modification would markedly affect the present delicate state of collective bargaining negotiations.

SECURITY COUNCIL Meets today at 11 A.M. to discuss disarmament and atomic control. (Open.) economic and social council Social Commission-Began consideration of its draft report. Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 2:45 P.M.

The New York State Senate last night approved the proposition for a constitutional amendment to pay a $400,000,000 bonus to war veterans in this State. The vote for such a bonus, of $50 to $250, was unanimous in both chambers last March on its first submission, and if approval is given by the Assembly the question will go to the people in a referendum next November.

Four prefabricated metal barracks, originally destined for occupation duty in Japan, have been set up in the middle of the Columbia University campus to facilitate handling veteran students' affairs. Finished in time for spring session registration, which ended yesterday, their use reduced ex-servicemen's registration time to an average of twenty-two minutes.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- An outline of the extent to which Britain is prepared to go to meet Zionist demands for an independent state in Palestine will be submitted to leaders of the Jewish Agency for Palestine tomorrow, Foreign Secretary Bevin told the agency's spokesmen here today.

While many travelers remember Mexico City as a blend of the old Spanish and the native Indian, recent visitors have been bringing back reports of new architecture and a new type of decor that is unpretentiously modern. Arbitrary color schemes and elaborate window treatments, they say, have given way to the airiness of transparent curtains and a simple lack of clutter.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 3 (AP) -- After three straight favorites had scored, form players in the crowd of 16,538 at Hialeah Park today wagered with confidence on Warren Wright's Pep Well in the featured Key West Purse, expecting him to duplicate the victory of his Calumet stablemate Pad Lock in the previous race.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I cannot agree with the letter of G.P.B. of Wilmington, Del., demanding the abolition of the capital gains tax and lifting the so-called double taxation on dividends.

MARATHON KEY, Fla., Feb. 3 -- Sometime during the past five years, apparently when no one was looking, the Florida keys have thrown aside their Greenwich Village simplicity and assumed a Park Avenue exterior with an undercurrent of Broadway glitter, and along with others who knew the keys "when," we are not quite certain the change has been for the better.

ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- The need for the St. Lawrence seaway project has been demonstrated "by every engineering and economic test," the State Power Authority declared today in calling for prompt action by Congress to authorize development of this international waterway.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Supreme Court approved today for the second time a reorganization plan of the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad and ruled that the Circuit Court had improperly ordered the plan stayed.

LONDON, Feb. 3 --If any such idea ever really existed, the Soviet Union appears to have abandoned any thought of seeking to establish a continuous Slav population bloc between the Baltic and the Adriatic that would isolate Hungary and Rumania within a sea of Slavs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Bernard M. Baruch was reliably reported tonight to have told the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy that Russia evidently had tapped United States atomic bomb secrets.

In the First World War most emergency Government controls were authorized for the war period or until six months afterward. This created a good deal of ambiguity and operated generally to make the gradual abandonment of controls difficult. In the case of the Second World War many wartime laws carried definite time limits; others were to be terminated by Presidential proclamation or by concurrent resolution of Congress.

Dr. Francis T. Spaulding, New York State Commissioner of Education, reported last night that the school system was applying "a very large majority" of 935 recommendations made in 1938 after a study known as the Regents Inquiry Into the Character and Cost of Public Education in the State.
PARIS, Feb. 3 -- The French Government will ask that the peace treaty with Germany embody an international economic regime for the Ruhr and that it establish a fixed basis for...

HASBROUCK HEIGHTS, N.J., Feb. 3 -- New Jersey's first allcivilian amputee rehabilitation clinic was started by Hasbrouck Heights Hospital today with fiftyphysicians, surgeons and makers of artificial limbs attending.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 3 -- This year $300,000,000 will be required for Jewish philanthropy here and overseas, the National Council of Jewish Federations and Welfare Funds was told today at the final session of its four-day annual general assembly.

A 15-year-old blind Negro boy who was graduated from elementary school as an honor student was one of four winners of memorial prizes presented yesterday at a ceremony in the office of Superintendent of Schools John E. Wade.

MONTREAL, Feb. 3 -- The uniform collection and analysis of air-transport accident reports and arrangements for the payment for accident investigations as between the nation whose plane is involved and the country in Which the accident occurs will be recommended by the Accident Investigation Division of the Provisional International Civil Aviation Organization when it meets here tomorrow.

The possibility of having a unified system of public school and higher education in New York City, with an integrated high school and college curriculum, is being investigated by a committee consisting of representatives of New York high schools and of the four city colleges, it was learned yesterday.

The signed contract of Orben (Spec) Sanders, outstanding back of the New York Yankees of the All-America Football Conference, was announced as received by Dan Topping yesterday. It was a twoyear agreement.

January marked the fourth successive month of recovery in the real estate bond market with an advance of 1.5 per cent, according to the Amptt-Baker realty bond price averages based on an index of 200 Eastern issues. This brought the average price of a $1,000 bond at the end of January up to $741, which was only 1.6 per cent of the all-time high of $753 on June 30, 1946.

CONCORD, N.H., Feb. 3 -- It was back in 1933 when this correspondent made his first ski tour of New Hampshire and discovered, without too much surprise, serene villages and towns hibernating during the winter months.

NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 3 -- Grief at the death of Admiral Marc A. Mitscher cast its shadow today over the ceremonies marking the formal opening of the Armed Forces Staff College, where highranking colleagues of the admiral paid warm tribute to him as a tactician and friend.
LONDON, Feb 1 (AP) -- A turnabout silhouette, trim and unexaggerated for day wear, soft and flowing for after dark, is London's fashion bid for spring.
Mayor O'Dwyer came to grips yesterday with the problem of a higher transit fare, an issue that all previous administrations have dodged as politically unhealthy.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- The British Government considers that the Polish and Rumanian elections were neither free nor fair but, since the Russian Government feels differently, Britain does not intend to try do anything further about either, the House of Commons was told today.

The initial step in the recentlydrafted financing program of Transcontinental Western Air, Inc., was completed yesterday with sale of $5,000,000 of convertible notes to the Hughes Tool Company of Texas, main enterprise of Howard Hughes, TWA's principal stockholder.

DETROIT, Feb. 3 -- Only a pedometer was lacking today in Federal District Court as Judge Frank A. Picard heard from witnesses in the Mount Clemens (Mich.) Pottery Company cases testimony designed to show how rapidly a man walked to and from his job.

HOLLYWOOD. Calif., Feb. 3 -- Twentieth Century-Fox today announced the purchase of screen rights to Richard Sherman's forthcoming novel, "Not So Long Ago," at a reported price of $310,000. The property has been assigned to William Perlberg for production in the fall.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- A House Judiciary Subcommittee today approved a constitutional amendment that would prevent any President from serving more than eight years.

The Yankees in their bid for another 2,000,000 attendance season at the Stadium next summer will have at their disposal twelve Sunday and an equal number of Saturday home dates to offer to their fans in addition to their already allotted quota of fourteen night games.
BOSTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Slugging Ted Williams today signed his own ticket to play left field for the Red Sox this coming season and the chit is figured to call for $75,000.

A buyer's market in passenger cars is still far off, K.T. Keller, president of the Chrysler Corporation, said yesterday while visiting the art salon in the Chrysler Building. He estimated, however, that in a year a motorist would be able to walk into a showroom and buy a vehicle as in pre-war days.

OTTAWA, Feb. 3 -- Unsubstantiated allegations, such as that made today by Bernard M. Baruch and others before the Congressional Atomic Energy Committee, that information leaks might be occurring in Canada are resented here as harmful to harmonious work.

ATHENS, Feb. 3 -- Half the British forces in Greece will leave as soon as it is possible to withdraw them, according to a statement issued today at the British Embassy. The Greek Government has been advised of this and reminded that a part withdrawal had been planned some time ago.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 3 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, chairman of the United Nations Human Rights Commission, and other officers, will have the primary responsibility for writing the first draft of an international bill of rights, it was decided here today.
HAMBURG, Germany, Feb. 3 -- The Ravensbrueck concentration camp trial ended today with the sentencing to death by hanging of five women and six men of the staff of the Nazis' women's prison.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The newly constituted Senate War Investigating Committee set out today to ascertain whether Government departments or agencies were destroying records pertinent to future inquiries, and, if so, under what legal authority.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- A demand that the Supreme Court withdraw the master portal-to-portal suit from Federal District Judge Frank A. Picard and state more clearly its own views on the issue was made today at House hearings on bills to quash backpay claims of the type involved in the case.

Raymond Tese, 27 years old, was arrested yesterday in his law office, 217 Broadway, on an indictment that accused him of having gone through a bogus marriage ceremony in 1945 with an unidentified young woman who had been substituted for a client with whom he had obtained the marriage license two months earlier.

Donna Grescoe, 19-year-old violinist from Winnipeg, Canada, gave her first New York recital last night at Town Hall. Her wellwishers in the audience included Garnet Coulter, the Mayor of Winnipeg, and Ralph Maybank, representative of Winnipeg in the Canadian House of Commons.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 3 -- The Jewish Agency for Palestine received an ultimatum today from the Government to cooperate with the police and bring terrorists to justice within seven days. The order was sent by the chief secretary, Sir Henry Gurney, on behalf of the High Commissioner and replied to the agency's refusal yesterday to cooperate if, it said, Jews had to be informers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Supreme Court, splitting 5 to 4, ruled today that it is legal for the owner of a patented invention to require the user who licenses it to assign back all patentable improvements discovered during its use.

The stock market yesterday broke through the previous resistance level and moved ahead to new high ground for 1947. Confirmation by the rails of the strength exhibited last week imparted a technical lift to prices which left the composite rate higher on the day by about 3/4 point, with the industrials up more than a point.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 --The United States proved itself better able to assay the requirements of victory in the war and to mobilize its full resources than either of its major enemies, despite their long plans for conquest, according to conclusions reached by an official study group which has just made public the first comprehensive report on the war program of this country.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- The Russians proposed at today's meeting of the Foreign Ministers' deputies for Austria that Germans be banned from becoming naturalized citizens of the new Austria by a clause in the treaty of peace.

THESE seem to be historical times in which we live. Also, perhaps, a little on the hysterical side as well. Particularly among those with a penchant for viewing all things with alarm and who take an almost ghoulish delight in forecasting the decadence of mankind, if not its entire destruction, whenever certain shady operations in professional sports are uncovered and the rascals laid by the heels.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3 (U.P.) -- A new cold wave, accompanied by gales that whipped up dust storms, hit the snow-burdened North Central States today. Forecasters warned that the cold would spread to the Ohio Valley and Eastern States tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Railroads that under a 1940 act of Congress were allowed to charge the Government full rates, forfeited their claims to public lands, the Supreme Court decided in a unanimous opinion written by Justice Hugo L. Black today.

Push Weekly Rating Program The American Weekly Newspaper Publishers Council has completed evaluation of all Maine and Rhode Island weeklies and will shortly submit its findings to advertisers, Bennett Fishier, publisher of the Ridgewood, (N.J.) Herald News and council chairman, announced yesterday.

Varying Atomic Tempos On the one hand, there is the meson. It is a particle inside the nucleus of the atom as envisaged in a theory put forward by Prof. J. Robert Oppenheimer, who was in charge of the atomb bomb at Los Alamos.
Construction of under-street electric wire conduits in Manhattan and the Bronx was halted yesterday by a sympathy strike of American Federation of Labor building unions.

WELLESLEY Mass., Feb. 3 (AP) -- Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr., of the House said tonight that President Truman's $37,000,000,000 budget "must be cut and cut deeply" with the savings being distributed between "debt reduction and tax reduction."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- President Truman asked Congress for a limited extension of the Second War Powers Act, imposed a quota on imports of short staple cotton, asked Congress for $2,169,144,500 for the Veterans Administration and nominated Lawrence Clayton to be a governor of the Federal Reserve Board and Herman P. Baruch to be Ambassador to the Netherlands.

Artur Rodzinski, who has been musical director of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra since 1943, resigned last night, effective Oct. 1, after delivering an indictment of the orchestra's management before an afternoon meeting of the executive committee of the Philharmonic's board of directors.

PARIS, Feb. 3 -- In Agnes' collection the cascades of fabric that hang over one shoulder are original in that they are knotted toward the end, looped up and pinned to the lapel of suits. Striped faille, printed cretonne and wool mouseline contrast with straw or felt on hats that have rather wide crowns but minute brims.

How practical and good-looking garments can be fashioned from utilitarian blankets was demonstrated yesterday morning in the office of the New York Dress Institute by CARE, Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe. Those attending the meeting viewed a sample blanket package and its contents as well as the clothes designed by some of New York's leading designers, Claire McCardell, Mme. Eta and Emily Wilkens.

NANKING, Feb. 3 -- A radical policy of land redistribution through the forced subdividing of large holdings has given land to 60,000,000 peasants in the Communist areas of North China and Manchuria, according to figures based on Yenan estimates and released by Communist Headquarters here.

MOSCOW, Feb. 3 -- American and British capital is pouring into western Germany in contravention of the Potsdam agreement, paving the way for Germany's economic vassalage, a Soviet journalist charged today.

Public officials and Army officers joined yesterday in the cornerstone laying of a $200,000 swimming pool at the Bronx Veterans Hospital in honor of four Army chaplains who died four years ago when the transport Dorchester was torpedoed off Greenland.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 3 -- New pleas for State control of commercial rents in Westchester caused the county Board of Supervisors this afternoon to order a public hearing for consideration of control bills that it could send to Albany for adoption.

Adelaide Abbot, coloratura, soprano, gave a recital last night at Times Hall, where she was warmly received by a large audience. The program was made up of numbers by Gretry, Leroux, Dachelet, Hue, Delibes, Rossini, Paradies, Mozart and Haydn in French, Italian and English, with a closing contemporary group in English.

PEIPING, China, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The Chinese Government reinforced its Tientsin and Peiping garrisons today and promised drastic steps to keep the Communists away from the Peiping-Tientsin railway over which nearly 2,000 American personnel are expected to be evacuated.
A gallant little band of commuting pinochle, gin rummy and bridge enthusiasts grinned defiance at the Long Island Rail Road last night when they trooped aboard the 5:33 to Far Rockaway.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The intra-party Republican dispute over income tax reduction was carried to the House floor today. The brief and occasionally bitter debate was touched off by an appeal to all conservatives to support "across the board" cuts.
The establishment of a free evening school for deaf and hardof-hearing adults is expected to be approved by the Board of Education at its scheduled meeting tomorrow afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The House Labor Committee which had planned to open hearings on a sheaf of labor bills on Wednesday will, instead, devote its first public session to in investigation of disputes between newspaper publishers and their employes.

The food situation in six of twenty countries covered in a survey published in this newspaper yesterday is very bad. This is true of Austria, Greece, Hungary, Italy, Poland, Yugoslavia and China. In Germany, Spain and Western Russia it is not good. In France there are serious shortages.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 3 -- Prosecutor Mathew F. Melko summoned police officials of this city and South Plainfield to his office today, demanding that they explain alleged laxity in permitting gambling to flourish in their communities. The move followed a demand by Attorney General Walter D. Van Riper that the Middlesex County grand jury be convened immediately for an inquiry.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 35 to 58 points net lower yesterday, after making small gains early in the day.

Plans for a six-story building, at an estimated cost of $2,500,000, to house the natural history exhibits of the American Museum of Natural History were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings. The new building will adjoin the present structures on the plot known as Manhattan Square, bounded by Central Park West, Seventy-seventh Street, Columbus Avenue and Eighty-first Street.

OWOSSO, Mich., Feb. 3 -- America must rededicate itself to the religious principles of the Declaration of Independence to eliminate present economic, racial and religious tensions, the Rev. John J. Cavanaugh, president of the University of Notre Dame, said tonight at a testimonial dinner in his honor in the city of his birth.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- President Truman dipped into the silver Davis Cup today and came up with the order of play in 1947 for the tennis trophy, and a play on words as well.

Store Sales Here Up 8% Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores increased 8 per cent for the week ended Feb.1, according to the "Flash report" issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the four weeks ended on that date the increase was 20 per cent.

Two producers and two authors put on a comedy entitled "It Takes Two" at the Biltmore last evening. That is the most amusing thing about it. The two producers are George Abbott and Richard Aidrich, who are practically grown up by now, and the two authors are Virginia Faulkner and Dana Suesse, who can probably develop over the years.

BERLIN, Feb. 3 -- In an unprecedented action, the American military government appealed directly today to the entire German press for a hearing on its side of the Kommandatura dispute with the Russians.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- Argentine rail stocks were the feature today in an otherwise dull stock market. They soared in anticipation of an announcement that an agreement had been reached with the Argentine Government for its purchase of the lines.
Four steamship lines with terminals in New York are now considering acceptance of a city plan to reconstruct piers at their own expense.

ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- Without a single dissenting vote, the State Senate approved tonight the constitutional amendment authorizing a $400,000,000 bond issue to pay bonuses ranging from $50 to $250 to veterans of World War II.
TRENTON, Feb. 3 -- New Jersey legislative leaders of both major parties were in general accord today with Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll's plan to modernize the State Constitution this year.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 3 -- The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation today broke off wage negotiations with the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, for about 50,000 employes as the result of a wildcat strike by intraplant railroad workers at the Aliquippa, Pa., works.

Sidney Reiter, twice-decorated veteran of the recent war, will go on trial tonight before General Duffy Post, American Legion, in the post headquarters, Twenty-third Street and Second Avenue, on charges seeking his expulsion from the Legion on the ground that he is an avowed Communist.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- If a perspective of the past with ability to apply it to the present and the future are, as many think, prerequistes of a Foreign Minister, whatever his proved capacity in direct action, then all material which will clarify that perspective is invaluable to a Foreign Minister engaged in peace-making.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 3 -- The Talmadge forces in the State House of Representatives today sought passage of two resolutions which would compel public officials, banks and taxpayers to recognize Herman Talmadge as Governor and give him authority of the Great Seal of Georgia.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 3 -- The trial of Bernard M. McFeely, Mayor of Hoboken, and ten other Hoboken officials who have been indicted for conspiracy to oppress "rebel" police officers who sought changes in working conditions, was postponed today until May 19, six days after Mr. McFeely comes up for re-election.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Feb. 3 -- The paradoxes of the United States' Latin-American policy as well as the hemispheric effect of the Argentine issue were pointed up by yesterday's election in Nicaragua.
Battle lines were being drawn yesterday for a fight between two curiously unwarlike forces.

LOS ANGELES. Feb. 3 -- An expression of hope that the nations of the world might contrive some system of distribution of the world's oil resources to eliminate them as a source of international discord today opened the first meeting of the International Labor Organization's twelve-nation petroleum industry committee.

Two veterans, both paralyzed from the waist down, left the Bronx Veterans Hospital yesterday to begin an automobile trip to Chicago, where they will attend the convention of the Paralyzed Veterans Association. The veterans are Alex Michaochyk of 102 Clinton Place, Yonkers, N.Y., and Walter Suchanof of Rlchland, N.J.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- In four sections, the bizarre air-borne trial of Col. Jack W. Durant, accused of stealing the $1,500,000 Hesse royal family jewels, moved across the Atlantic today for resumption in Washington and Chicago.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3 -- Wheat and corn held strong on the Board of Trade today, and, although there was a sharp decline in sympathy with cotton and on profit-taking at one time, renewed buying entered the market on the break. Wheat then rallied to close about the top, with gains of 1 1/8 to 2 3/8 cents a bushel, the new crop months showing the most strength.

Admiral Marc Andrew Mitscher used to ride the bridge of his flagship facing aft. "I'm an old man now," he would explain; "I spent my youth looking ahead." He was only 60 when he died yesterday at the Norfolk Naval Hospital, and not an old man by today's standards.

Current inheritance tax rates, which may amount to as much as 77 per cent for estates in the higher brackets, cast "an almost obliterating shadow upon the institution of inheritance," Evans Woollen Jr., president of the Trust Division of the American Bankers Association, declared yesterday.

TOKYO, Feb. 3 -- About onequarter of the elections held in December to choose village commissions to administer the rural land reform have proved unsatisfactory, in the opinion of occupation and Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry officials.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Vice Admiral William H.P. Blandy, who commanded the Joint ArmyNavy Task Force which conducted the atomic bomb tests at Bikini last summer, will succeed the late Admiral Marc A. Mitscher as commander, Atlantic Fleet, the Navy announced today.

The resignation of Louis A. (Red) Gebhard as football coach at City College was accepted yesterday by Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of the college. Gebhard, who was head football mentor for two years, did not give any reasons for his action, but said "I intend to go on teaching and coaching football, although I have not formed any definite plans for the future."

"LEARNING has Its price, which is occasional pedantry," writes D.W. Brogan in "French Personalities and Problems."* No better example of apt and unintentional selfcriticism could well be imagined. Mr. Brogan, whose learning is astounding, is sadly pedantic in this tedious and disappointing volume. It isn't as if Mr. Brogan doesn't know any better.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- President Truman today conferred for the second time with Republican and Democratic Congressional leaders in what Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Republican of Michigan, termed a "congenial meeting."

A spouting whale cruising five miles outside of New York Harbor came within 100 feet of the Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth as the ship arrived yesterday from Southampton with 2,283 passengers.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Feb. 3 -- Retribution caught up with the University of North Carolina basketball team as a vengeful New York University five gained a 60-47 triumph tonight, successfully opening its Southern trip before 7,000 fans in Woolen Gymnasium.

NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 3 -- Admiral Marc A. Mitscher, Commander in Chief of the United States Atlantic Fleet and wartime chief of famed carrier task force 58, died in the Norfolk Naval Station Hospital at 1:30 A.M. today of a heart attack suffered a week ago.

Food supply lines which were clogged up at the year-end by high inventories are now opening up because of increased consumer buying, Paul S. Willis, president, Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., told the Grocery Manufacturers Representatives, New York, Inc., at a luncheon meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3 -- Richard Smith, counsel for the United Corporation, told the Securities and Exchange Commission at a hearing today that United will have more than $50,000,000 to use for the benefit of its common stockholders under its proposed plans to operate as an investment company.

Facing a possible twenty-year prison term, Teodoro Erdmann Lau, 44-year-old citizen of Argentina, will be arraigned for stentencing, as a German spy this morning before Federal Judge Edward A. Conger.

The President's proposals for the budget, "precariously balanced at the enormous total" of $37,500,000,000, has come as "a shock and heavy disappointment," the National City Bank of New York declares in its monthly letter, released yesterday.

WARSAW, Poland, Feb. 3 -- In a move to strengthen its hand for the impending struggle for survival, the Polish Socialist party decided today to name 35-year-old Jozef Cyrankiewicz its secretary, as Premier in the new Government to replace Edward B. OsubkaMorawski.

Martha Graham and her dance company will take advantage of the availability of the Ziegfeld Theatre, pending the arrival of "Brigadoon" next month, to give a limited season there from Feb. 24 through March 2.

ADELAIDE, South Australia, Feb. 3 (Reuters) -- Arthur Morris and Lindsay Hassett took their third wicket partnership to 189 on the third day of the fourth test cricket match here today to retrieve the position for Australia and at the close the Aussies had made 293 runs for the loss of four wickets in reply to England's first innings total of 460.
LONDON, Feb. 3 -- Britain's production drive was bogging down today as a result of a shortage of fuel, a surplus of snow and a continuing cold wave.

A detective shot and seriously wounded one suspect and captured a second at 8:25 o'clock last night during the attempted hold-up of David Schwartz' liquor store at 841 Lexington Avenue, at Sixtyfourth Street.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 3 -- The United Nations Security Council will go back to work tomorrow on its two biggest problems -- arms and the atom -- with the United States ready to make another determined campaign to get quick action on plans for international atomic control.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 27, Czechoslovak Ambassador Slavik explains the position of his Government on the current deportation of the Hungarian minority from Slovakia to the Sudeten area as reported by your correspondent, Mr. Albion Ross.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Feb. 3 -- The decline in the average age and educational level of the occupation soldier since the end of the war, combined with his manifold contacts with the German people and what he says and does in their presence, makes the Army's Information and Education program of growing interest to the military government.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 3 -- The American Federation of Labor's executive council, beginning a systematic examination of labor legislation, likened the Ball-TaftSmith bill today to "an executioner's knife held at the throat of every worker and every union in our country."

Mrs. Elinor S. Gimbel, American delegate to the meeting of the executive council of the Women's International Democratic Federation set for Feb. 20 to 27 in Prague, is among the 2,220 passengers scheduled to sail today from Pier 90, North River, for Southampton on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth.

IT wasn't so many years ago that the Football Rules Committee was the favorite whipping boy of sports. No stand-patters, the overlords of the intercollegiate code were ever chasing rainbows seeking perfection. Annually their clinical session resulted in one or more innovations.

NANKING, Feb. 4 -- The post-war migration tide has turned in China. Many persons are pulling up stakes in the economically hard hit eastern Provinces and are seeking a livelihood in the western and southwestern areas that in wartime were known as "Free China."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Overseas Writers, an organization which has been in existence here for the last twenty-five years, altered its constitution today in such a manner as to exclude from active membership American citizens who serve foreign newspapers, agencies, or radio networks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Pressure of international problems at their posts in the Senate will prevent Senators Arthur H. Vandenberg and Tom Connally, Congressional advisers to the Secretary of State, from going with the delegation to the Foreign Ministers' conference in Moscow next month.

British Foreign Minister Ernest Bevin was asked last night by officials of the American Jewish Committee to "take immediate measures for the amelioration of conditions" in Palestine. The request was contained in a cable signed by Joseph M. Proskauer, president of the committee, and Jacob Blaustein, chairman of the organization's executive committee.

Though we may recognize that the fine flavor of coffee that has been freshly ground before brewing cannot be equaled, we are likely to regard coffee mills as out-of-date appliances requiring too much work to be useful. The Cory Corporation has overcome this difficulty by eliminating the old-fashioned "by-hand" method in the electric grinder that it is now introducing.

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- New British proposals for a solution of the Palestine problem along lines already rejected by both Arab and Zionist leaders are to be submitted to the two groups here within two days.

A vacancy caused by the death of Judge Mandelbaum has existed for more than two months in the Federal District Court for the Southern District of New York. The business of this Court encompasses a great variety of important legal controversies, civil as well as criminal. Judge Knox, the senior District Judge, has stated that the Court has been seriously handicapped by failure to fill the vacancy.
PARIS, Feb. 4 -- The first elements of advancing Foreign Legion forces today established contact with the French garrison at Hue, it was reported officially.

Legislative relief for commercial bankers, whose consumer credit discounting activities were curtailed recently by a ruling of Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein, now appears likely at an early date, it was learned yesterday. Special legislation bearing

Something new has been added to the St. Agnes branch of the New York Public Library at 444 Amsterdam Avenue -- a reading and recreation lounge for teen-agers. Although not scheduled to open until Feb. 13, advance reports of the new venture have created much interest among teachers, parents and teen-agers themselves from West Seventy-second to West Ninetieth Street.

Claims that Argentina won most of the benefits of the recent commercial treaty between Argentina and Chile are disproved by the terms of the agreement, as revised, according to Alfonso Grez, consul general of Chile, who announced them yesterday.
LONDON, Feb. 4 -- Continuing reports of a slowdown in production due to the coal shortage checked buying in the stock markets today and contributed to the quiet and rather irregular tone.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: President Peron's "purge" of the democratic elements in Argentina's six national universities has been resumed. In the past few months Peron has caused to be dismissed and suspended literally hundreds of professors and employes in the universities.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Accused of being a leftist and of harboring Communists, David E. Lilienthal affirmed today his belief in American principles in a way that cast a spell of solemnity over the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy and a room filled with spectators.
Dreams of a fortune in ambergris went glimmering yesterday for the crew of the Robert K. Call.

The Winter Ball, first in a series of gala fetes planned to be given annually henceforth under the auspices of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association, took place last night in the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria. Drawing a capacity throng of members of society, civic and artistic circles, the event was one of the largest benefit entertainments of the winter season.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The Administration has decided to adopt a new procedure for negotiating and amending reciprocal trade agreements in an effort to avoid a partisan fight over the nation's economic foreign policy, it was learned today.

The board of directors of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society accepted yesterday Artur Rodzinski's resignation as musical director but made it effective immediately, instead of in October, as Mr. Rodzinski had specified.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Feb. 4 (U.P.) -- Australia, with 487 runs all out, led England by 27 runs at the close of the first innings in the fourth cricket test match today. Leonard Hutton and Cyril Washbrook, opening England's second innings, made a stand for 96 runs not out and with two days of play remaining the prospect was for a draw.
MOSCOW, Feb. 4 -- Industrial personnel who are delaying an increase in the tempo of production until the end of the present fiveyear plan have been severely criticized here.

A serious slump in sales has hit some major machine tool builders, industry spokesmen disclosed here yesterday. Principal lines affected include those now being actively pushed by the War Assets Administration surplus sales campaign, they said.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Secretary of State George C. Marshall is expected to announce tomorrow that the core of the State Department, including his own office, will he moved to the new War Department Building in Virginia Avenue, several blocks from the present State Department Building, which stands on the west side of the White House.
As a result of complaints, the Surface Transportation System, operator of the new Broadway buses, has made changes in the equipment to improve passenger comfort, it was disclosed yesterday.

The American system of private enterprise is being curtailed because it "has within it weaknesses that ought to be eradicated," William, A. Irwin, economist of the American Bankers Association, declared yesterday. He spoke to members of the group at their twenty-eighth midwinter trust conference in the Hotel WaldorfAstoria.

SARAFAND, Palestine, Feb. 4 -- Tragedy, comedy and pathos Mingled here today at this largest of army camps in Palestine as more than 1,000 British wives and children, being sent to the United Kingdom because they are considered in danger, arrived at this assembly point.

ATLANTA, Feb. 4 -- Amid charges that efforts were being made to put pressure on the courts in Georgia's Governorship dispute by repeated moves in the Legislature to back up its election of Herman Talmadge as the chief executive, the anti-Talmadge faction won its first roll call victory today in the House of Representatives.

The boxing future of Rocky Graziano, East Side middleweight who is the outstanding challenger for the world title, still was in doubt last night. The opening session, of the first full-scale inquiry by the State Athletic Commission into the boxer's failure to report a bribe of $100,000 reportedly offered him to fix a fight scheduled for last Dec. 27 between Graziano and Cowboy Ruben Shank in Madison Square Garden ended yesterday.

Development of community recreation programs by the Athletic Institute is creating a greatly enlarged national market for sporting goods for manufacturers, wholesalers and dealers, Theodore P. Bank, president of the institute, told more than 800 dealers attending the annual convention of the industry at Hotel New Yorker yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The Democrats in Congress, who in 1928 were overwhelmingly in favor of limiting White House tenure to two terms, gave more votes against than for a similar proposal adopted by the House Judiciary Committee today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Thomas W. Lamont has given $500,000 toward the fund for restoring the centuries-old Canterbury Cathedral which was damaged by German bombs on May 31, 1942,...

Point-of-Purchase Tests Set A comprehensive three-point research program to determine effectiveness of point-of-purchase advertising shortly will be submitted for sponsorship to the Advertising Research Foundation by the Point-of-Purchase Advertising Institute, Norman McKean, executive secretary, disclosed yesterday following a board meeting in the Biltmore Hotel.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Many Lands, a Detroit Stable sprinter, took the featured sixfurlong New Roads purse at the Fair Grounds today, winning by four lengths over the favored Whitchtack, owned by A.L. Colby. Many Lands' time was 1:12 2-5.
A $50,000,000 building program, a revised curriculum and increased empasis on leadership mark the new chapter now opening in the long and honorable history of the United States Military Academy.

Redemptions of United States Savings Bonds, principally Series E, although including a small volume of Series A to B, declined to a daily average in this district during January of 41,000 pieces, the lowest level since January, 1945, it was disclosed yesterday.

Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Eduard C. Lindeman of 235 East Twenty-second Street of the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Jean, to William Benton Sanford, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur H. Sanford of Mamaroneck, N.Y. The wedding will take place in this city in June.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The Postoffice Department today asked the Civil Aeronautics Board to set a special reduced rate for the shipment by air mail of newspapers and newsmagazines to foreign countries.

LONDON, Feb. 4 (U.P.) -- Molyneux, the soldier-turned-designer who captivated the world of fashion after World War I, today gave London's colorful style season an exclusive showing of symphonic elegance featuring traditional British modes.

The Board of Superintendents decided yesterday that Howard Fast's best-selling historical novel, "Citizen Tom Paine," was undesirable as reading matter for children and recommended that it be removed from the New York City public school libraries.

The value of radar on the navigational bridge of a ship like the Queen Elizabeth was described here yesterday by Sir Robert Alexander Watson-Watt, British scientist, who said that n-a recent Atlantic crossing the ship in one day saved more than the cost of its entire radar equipment by maintaining its scheduled run of 720 mile sthrough dense fog.

If the phrase "farce-comedy" is still in the theatre's lexicon, this department asks your permission to apply it to Norman Krasna's "John Loves Mary," which was put on at the Booth last evening. It describes a comedy that is just the least bit hard to believe.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4 -- Accidents in 1946 cost this country 100,000 dead, 10,400,000 injured and $5,600,000,000, the National Safety Council reported today. This toll was 4 per cent greater than that of 1945, which claimed 95,918 lives.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 29 the Federal Reserve Board announced today. An increase of $291,000,000 in loans, decreases of $535,000,000 in holding of United States Government obligations and $554,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks and an increase of $164,000,000 in borrowings.

An exhibition of 200 woodcuts and engravings taken from illustrated weeklies published from 1850 to 1900 entitled "News Artists to the American People," was opened last night at the New York Historical Society, Central Park West and Seventy-seventh Street, with a private view to the members.

Buying in the motors gave the stock market a further lift yesterday, although the rails lost ground and profit-taking in the final hour reduced early gains. Restoration of the 75-cent dividend by General Motors was generally interpreted as a bullish gesture and moat automotives issues shared in the lift given to this issue.

GRASSY KEY, Fla., Feb. 4 -- Only an optimist would allocate one day to bonefishing and expect to get a bonefish, but as we had "One a Day" Dick Warner for a guide we had more optimism than most bonefishermen.

The need for United States products and technology by the Soviet Union within the next ten years will be unprecedented, J. Anthony Marcus, executive director, Institute of Foreign Trade, stated yesterday. The basic problem, he said, will not be how this trade can be paid for, but how it can be established on a working basis.

Trial of Sidney Reiter, a member, on American Legion charges that he is an avowed Communist and concealed such affiliation when he took the Legion oath, was adjourned for two weeks last night at General Duffy Post, 389 Second Avenue.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 4 -- Organized labor's efforts to unionize Southern workers "is a battle for democracy in industry, for the welfare of the millions who labor for wages, for the man before the dollar," the Southern Religion and Labor Conference was told here today.

Buyers' Total Higher Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,575 against 1,464 in the preceding week and 1,524 in the similar week last year, according to listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 4 -- The American Federation of Labor is collecting a per capita tax on an alltime record total of 7,505,446 union members, George Meany, secretary -treasurer, informed the executive council today. This figure, as of Feb. 1, represents a gain of more than 255,000 since last September.

NANKING, Feb. 4 -- Reorganization of the present one-party Chinese Government to include outside "liberals" is proving to be no easy task. Although the Kuomintang [Government party] is still trying to broaden the governmental base without Communist participation, the two available parties have not fallen into line readily.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The United States Treasury is potentially richer by more than $2,000,000,000 of tax revenues as a consequence of an intensified drive against evasion during the last eighteen months, Secretary John W. Snyder reported today.

The largest seizure of narcotics in nine years was reported here yesterday after a customs agent found heroin on a seaman and went on to uncover a shipboard cache valued in the illicit market at $250,000.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 4 -- Doug Burckett, the new president of the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association, today at the organization's headquarters made a plea on behalf of raising money to send a representative American ski team to the winter Olympic games in St. Moritz in 1948.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 4 -- A jury before Judge Thomas F. Meaney in Federal Court today found three men guilty of selling a house to a war veteran for $1,500 above the $9,000 ceiling price put on it by the Federal Housing Administration.

After trailing virtually throughout, St. Francis College of Brooklyn nipped Manhattan College, 53 -- 52, at the Jaspers' Riverdale Gymnasium last night when Jack Zeitler netted a foul shot with less than a minute remaining. The Terriers froze the ball for the remaining seconds.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Warren C. Kendall, director of car service for the Association of American Railroads, said today "we cannot increase the boxcars going to the Midwest without unduly taking them away from shippers in other parts of the country."

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 4 -- The Iowa-Illinois Gas and Electric Company filed an application with the Securities and Exchange Commission today seeking authorization to sell, competitively, $22,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, due in 1977.

More than 25,000 child lives have been saved in the last ten years as a result of safety education in the schools of this country, Dr. Herbert J. Stack, director of the Center for Safety Education at New York University, declared yesterday. He said 1,000 children had been spared from traffic accident deaths in New York City.

Tommy Quinn, Leslie MacMitchell and the other milers have it in their power to shape the future course of Gilbert Dodds. It was revealed yesterday that developments in Saturday's Hunter Mile at the Boston A.A. games will decide whether the Flying Parson is to run the Baxter Mile or the Toussaint Two-Mile in the New York A.C. meet here on Feb. 15.

The Board of Transportation has in progress a total of sixty-six contracts for construction, equipment, rehabilitation and acquisition of rolling stock, aggregating $74,421,312, the board announced yesterday through its publication, Contracts.

The concert of the Philadelphia Orchestra under Eugene Ormandy's baton last night in Carnegie Hall began with due propriety, and proceeded with exceptional demonstrations by the audience. Mr. Ormandy commenced with his own transcription of a Bach choraleprelude, scored and performed in perfectly respectable fashion.

FRESNO, Calif., Feb. 4 -- The crack Southern Pacific train, San Joaquin Daylight, crashed into a gasoline tank truck-trailer at Kingsburg at 3:25 P.M., Pacific standard time, today and at least three persons were killed and an undetermined number injured as flames swiftly engulfed the fourteen -car streamliner.

Brisk purchasing of items which have made a slow recovery during the reconversion period marked the second day of the National Notion and Novelty Show at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday. New York and out-of-town buyers indicated a willingness to place orders with the majority of the 100 exhibitors for immediate promotions and replenishment of notion and houseware department stocks.

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- Winsto Churchill's cigars and Hollywood films figured in a discussion in the House of Commons today on the large amounts of dollars the British are spending out of their Ame ican loan. Tobacco and films, was pointed out, amount to about 40 per cent of the total British imports from the United State.

New York department store sales, postal receipts, savings bank deposits and average weekly earnings of factory workers reached all-time highs last year, according to an analysis issued yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., Feb. 4 -- Title to two of New Jersey's historic shrines passed to the State today with the filing of deeds to the Wallace House, headquarters of General Washington during the winter of 1778-79, and the Old Dutch Parsonage here, in the office of County Clerk Robert B. Bergen.

Federal and city law enforcement officials and local health authorities met yesterday at Police Headquarters to consider a plan to compel drug addicts to submit to a cure with the alternative of a jail sentence.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Removal of rent controls on new construction would be unfair to veteans, the Senate Banking and Currency Committee was told today by Ivan Carson, rent administrator in the Office of Temporary Controls.

With undisputed leadership of the Eastern League at stake, Columbia's basketball team, playing its first game in three weeks, will clash with Princeton on the Morningside Heights court tonight. The game will start at 8:30.

BERLIN, Feb. 4 -- A flat statement that the General Electric Company and unidentified British capital are negotiating for the outright purchase of the big Siemens electrical equipment manufacturing company is featured as the lead story in today's Vorwaerts.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4 -- Wheat showed a strong undertone on the Board of Trade in early trading today, all deliveries except May selling at a new seasonal high. March, at $2.19 1/4, was up 1 1/2 cents a bushel, and at a new high since 1920.

Features on the program of the Music Festival organized by the Jewish Music Council and sponsored by the National Jewish Welfare Board, to run from Friday to March 6, were announced yesterday by Mrs. Frank Cohen, chairman of the council's executive committee.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 9,000 head; total, 15,000; market Irregular; weights from 240 pounds down opened steady; closing weak to 25 cents lower: heavier weights moderately active, fully

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The Port of New York Authority filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission objections to recommendations by an ICC examiner covering motor carrier rates in New England. The Port Authority said the proposed revisions would discriminate against the New York district and its shippers on domestic trade and import and export traffic handled by motor carriers.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Feb. 4 -- Representatives of petroleum production and refining employers of ten nations, meeting here as part of the International Labor Organization's petroleum industry committee, today endorsed unanimously three fundamental policies regarding labor, including tacit approval of the open shop.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 4 -- Low-priced furniture and floor coverings are still practically nonexistent and most household appliance prices are too high, it was said here last night by Roscoe R. Rau, executive vice president of the National Retail Furniture Association, who warned retailers that "somehow or other you must get for consumers merchandise in lower-priced lines."

Gerhart Eisler, who has been described as the "brains" behind the Communist party in the United States, was arrested at his home here yesterday and sent to Ellis Island for detention as an enemy alien.

Thirty-three players were named yesterday by Manager Bucky Harris as the Caribbean contingent of the Yankees. This group, which will assemble in San Juan, Puerto Rico, on Feb. 15, is scheduled to play fourteen games in three countries on a baseball training tour that will close in Havana on March 10.

Published complaints by commercial enterprises and unions that the ban on parking in midtown and downtown streets made it impossible for companies servicing heating and air-conditioning equipment to make emergency repair calls were discounted yesterday by high police officials.

A touching picture of a suppliant Mayor O'Dwyer going to Albany to seek a fairer share of State funds for New York City from a Republican-controlled Legislature was drawn at yesterday's City Council meeting by Joseph T. Sharkey, majority leader.

SOUTH : END, Ind., Feb. 4 (AP) -- Notre Dame will play a ninegame football schedule in 1947, featuring Army's first visit to the Irish Campus on Nov. 8 -- a clash that temporarily will end the Notre Dame-cadet gridiron relationship.
THE two Russian sailors were chipping away old paint.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UP) -- The text of David E. Lilienthal's statement to the Congressional Atomic Committee answering the charge of Senator McKellar of Tennessee that he has Communistic leanings: This I do carry in my head, Senator.

L.L. Horch, New York regional director of the United States Department of Commerce, announced yesterday removal of approximately fifty additional items from the list of commodities subject to export control. They include certain classes of rubber products, some chemicals and leather processing materials, several forest products and cambric and muslin for electrical insulation.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif, Feb. 4 -- The signing of an agreement whereby at least two George Bernard Shaw plays will be filmed in Hollywood was announced today by Gabriel Pascal, Shaw's film interpreter, and Artists Alliance, the Lester Cowan Mary Pickford producing company, which holds a releasing contract with United Artists.

HARTFORD, Feb. 4 -- Governor James L. McConaughy today delivered his budget message to a joint session of the General Assembly and urged adoption of a State sales tax and an increase of corporation and liquor taxes to balance income and expenditures.

An intensified program of rehabilitation through vocational training for Europe's surviving Jews became a certainty yesterday with an announcement that the Joint Distribution Committee and the World ORT Union would unify their activities in this field during 1947.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The Army, weary of the fact that too often its messes are just that, today decreed that cooking is to become a career job.

MONTREAL, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Max Bentley, Chicago Black Hawk center and the National Hockey League's leading point-getter last season, is closing in on the Montreal Canadiens' Maurice Richard, who currently leads the circuit in scoring.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- With virtualy no discussion, the Assembly approved unanimously today proposed Constitutional amendment to provide for a $400,000,000 State bonus to veterans of World War II and to streamline the procedure for removing or retiring corrupt, dissolute or incapacitated judges.
The Robotham family of Gourock, Scotland, will finally get together again this week-end after nineteen years apart. The reunion will take place in Petaluma, Calif.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 4 -- Russian Communist, British Socialist and American democratic members of the United Nations Human Rights Commission today argued inconclusively which rights of man should be embodied in an international bill of rights.
The Day's Record Diaries have been written before this by men who participated in Cabinet conferences in Washington, including at least two men who sat at the head of the table.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- House Republicans, with some significant help from conservative Democrats, brought to the verge of floor action today proposals for a constitutional amendment to limit the Presidential tenure to two terms.

WARSAW, Jan. 4 -- The United States and British Ambassadors to Warsaw ignored today the colorful opening of the first post-war Polish Parliament. It will ratify the results of the election that both Washington and London have condemned as unfair.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 4 -- The severely restricted size of modern Swedish apartments exerts a primary influence on exhibits in the Swedish Home Decoration Exposition, opened yesterday in Stockholm under the auspices of the National Artcraft Association.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Representative Leo E. Allen of Illinois, a key member of the House Republican leadership, stepped into a party policy breach over income tax reduction today with a compromise proposal.

Two exhibitions are opening to the public today at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fiftythird Street: the large group of extraordinary photographs by Henri Cartier-Bresson and a small show addressed to the architecture of Henry Hobson Richardson.

There is urgent need to tone down some of the romance in blended textile fibers to avoid exaggerated claims which have been made for them, Andrew J. Sokol of J.P. Stevens Company, Inc., pointed out yesterday.

NANKING, Feb. 4 (AP) -- President Chiang Kai-shek today made his second flight in three days to an important war front. There was immediate speculation that he had ordered a full-scale offensive to drive Chinese Communists from key areas.

Parents make a mistake in trying to teach good manners to very young children, Miss Cornelia Goldsmith, director of the daycare unit of the New York City Department of Health, Bureau of Child Hygiene, declared yesterday.

A blinding snowstorm, whipping winds and rapidly falling temperatures sent New York City last night into the grip of a new cold wave, expected by the Weather Bureau to last at least two days and to be the most uncomfortable of the winter.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 4 -- Four Greek men and an orphan boy who were to die today at dawn were saved from the firing squad with only hours to spare last night by the United Nations in the person of Mark Ethridge of Kentucky and Col. A. Roscher Lund of Norway.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Feb. 4 -- The pro-Government newspaper Ultima Hora today issued the threat that the Government might expel foreigners involved directly or indirectly in local politics. A number of wealthy opposition supporters hold foreign passports.
A call for formation of a permanent agency to provide entertainment in veterans' hospitals was sounded yesterday by Abe Lastfogel, president of United Service Organizations-Camp Shows.

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- The sharpest clash yet between the United States and the Soviet Union marked today's meeting of the Foreign Ministers' deputies for the Austrian peace treaty. General Mark W.
