Clark and Fedor T. Gusev argued acidly during almost the entire session over the proposed treaty clause on war criminals.
The third annual fashion show by students of the Fashion Institute of Technology was held last night at the Needle Trades High School, 225 West Twenty-fourth Street.

Reversing Monday's trend, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned strong yesterday and closed 44 to 59 points net higher on the day, with the near months again showing the most strength.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- President Truman, in receiving the new Ambassador of Poland today, told him bluntly that Warsaw had violated its pledge to hold a free election.

Abraham Green has been appointed divisional merchandise manager of women's ready-to-wear in the basement store of Abraham Straus. He formerly was divisional merchandise manager of ready-to-wear at Hovey's, Boston.
LITTLE AMERICA, Feb. 3 (Delayed) -- Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd today revisited the camp from which he made his historic flight over the South Pole seventeen years ago.

There have been more than a few intimations from Washington that some of the Republicans who are most eager to cut expenditures and then cut taxes look with a longing eye at an item in the President's budget labeled "International Affairs and Finance." It is a large item, amounting to $3,510,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Revisions of the Wage-Hour Act going far beyond the single current issue of portal-to-portal suits for back pay were asked of Congress today by representatives of retail businessmen.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Franz von Papen was dramatically arrested in the middle of his denazification trial today. He was charged with giving false testimony about the reported will of the late President Paul von Hindenburg and was thrown into a German jail.

PARIS, Feb. 4 -- The French Government's memorandum to the Big Three powers on the future of the Ruhr, the text of which is published for the first time in this issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES outlines what must be the most ambitious project for an international economic authority ever proposed by a government.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The United States Government closed its books on the seventh month of its current fiscal year today with a surplus of $685,498,000.

Fortunately, the hoof-and-mouth disease which is ravaging the cattle herds of Mexico has not yet crossed the border into the United States. However, unless some positive action is taken soon by our Government to cooperate with Mexico in stamping out the disease it is feared that it will be only a short time before it will be prevalent in the United States.

Theatre Incorporated, established two years ago as a non -profit organization, announced yesterday plans for modification of its policy of non-profit so far as the production of new plays is concerned. According to a spokesman for the group which has sponsored "Pygmalion," with Gertrude Lawrence, the Old Vie Players and, most recently, "The Playboy of the Western World," new plays will be produced on "a commercial basis."

Instead of sentencing the parents of juvenile delinquents to jail, judges should sentence them to guidance clinics to take courses in learning how to assume the responsibilities of parenthood, Edward Carey, director of children and youth activities for the Eastern District of the Salvation Army, suggested yesterday.

A stubby, swarthy man, dressed in a dark double-breasted suit, stood coolly yesterday afternoon before Federal Judge Edward A. Conger. During an hour and a half of talk by attorneys, which seemed of no interest to him, he alternately clasped his hands behind him and folded his arms across his chest.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 4 -- An Australian proposal for an unofficial meeting tomorrow of representatives of the five nations that had submitted draft resolutions on the control of atomic energy and armaments was adopted unanimously by the United Nations Security Council here today.

Maintenance of the high standards of this country's merchant marine and its assistance in the development of foreign trade are dependent in a large measure upon the continued use of Americanflag vessels by American shippers, Frank J. Taylor, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute, declared yesterday.

Of a total of $1,500,000 sought by City College in a drive for funds to improve extra-curricular activities at the college and to construct a war memorial building, $545,000 already has been pledged, it was announced last night at a special gifts dinner in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel, for which the college's Centennial Fund was sponsor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- A change in Senate rules that would make it possible for a minority of twenty-five members to invoke closure, or limited debate in the Upper Chamber, was endorsed today by the National Maritime Union, CIO, through Hoyt S. Haddock, its legislative representative.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Six witnesses from Industry urged the Senate Labor and Welfare Committee today to approve bills for curbing what they called monopoly among labor unions while one, a labor lawyer, maintained that the monopoly charge could not be applied to labor unions since "they deal with human life."

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- Bills enabling banks of the State to go on the five-day week all year were reported favorably today by the Banking Committee of the Senate and the General Laws Committee of the Assembly.

TOKYO, Feb. 4 -- Considerable regrouping in the ranks of Japanese labor, as well as a thorough national reconsideration of the obligations and privileges that labor received when the Allies permitted freedom of unionization more than a year ago, appeared likely today in view of Gen. Douglas MacArthur's order of Jan. 31 forbidding a paralyzing general strike.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Carroll Reece, Republican National Chairman, today reminded members of his party of the importance of this year's local elections and warned them against arguments "that the abilities and character of the individual candidate are more important than his party label."

Instead of sentencing the parents of juvenile delinquents to jail, judges should sentence them to guidance clinics to take courses in learning how to assume the responsibilities of parenthood, Edward Carey, director of children and youth activities for the Eastern District of the Salvation Army, suggested yesterday.

A stubby, swarthy man, dressed in a dark double-breasted suit, stood coolly yesterday afternoon before Federal Judge Edward A. Conger. During an hour and a half of talk by attorneys, which seemed of no interest to him, he alternately clasped his hands behind him and folded his arms across his chest.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 4 -- An Australian proposal for an unofficial meeting tomorrow of representatives of the five nations that had submitted draft resolutions on the control of atomic energy and armaments was adopted unanimously by the United Nations Security Council here today.

Maintenance of the high standards of this country's merchant marine and its assistance in the development of foreign trade are dependent in a large measure upon the continued use of Americanflag vessels by American shippers, Frank J. Taylor, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute, declared yesterday.

Of a total of $1,500,000 sought by City College in a drive for funds to improve extra-curricular activities at the college and to construct a war memorial building, $545,000 already has been pledged, it was announced last night at a special gifts dinner in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel, for which the college's Centennial Fund was sponsor.
TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 4 (AP) -- New Jersey will offer $15,000,000 of bonds beginning on Feb. 25, State Treasurer Robert C. Hendrickson announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- President Truman was host tonight at the first Army and Navy reception since Feb. 11, 1941, at the White House. More than 1,800 were on the guest list, including high-ranking military men. Resplendent decorations and smart evening gowns were the rule.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Feb. 4 -- More and stronger subversive activity must be expected in Germany now that transport and communications have been re-established, Lieut. Gen. Lucius D. Clay, American deputy military governor, said today after a meeting with the German council of states of the American zone.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 4 -- Uncertainty continued to dominate the Indian political picture today. The British may take some time to ascertain their position as the result of the Moslem League's refusal to participate in their proposed machinery for setting up an independent India.

Maria Mendoza, soprano, gave a recital last night before a large and cordial audience at Times Hall. She sang numbers by Bach, Brahms, Strauss, Marx, Bellini, Debussy, Turina, John Duke, Courtland Palmer and Wintter Watts.
The number of veterans receiving city relief has doubled in the last year, James J. Rafter, director of veteran assistance for the Department of Welfare, announced yesterday.

DETROIT, Feb. 4 -- The Department of Justice will seek to intervene tomorrow as a full participant in the portal-to-portal pay case involving the workers and the management of the Mount Clemens (Mich.) Pottery Company.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 4 -- The marriage of Miss Christina Higginbotham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry E. Higginbotham of this community, to Grosvenor Andersen Blood, son of Mr. and Mrs. Grosvenor T. Blood of East Orange, and Edgartown, Mass., will take place here on the afternoon of Feb. 15 in St. Andrew's Episcopal Church.

RANGOON, Burma (London Times Dispatch), Feb. 4 -- The working committee of the AntiFascist. Peoples Freedom League (Burma's majority party, led by U Aung San) has now unanimously accepted the terms of the recent London agreement on Burmese independence.
TOKYO, Feb. 4 -- Shinto, Japan's religion of blood and iron before the war, is the focus for extreme nationalism's reverting toward the crude superstitions from which it sprang.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 4 (AP) -- Pot o' Luck, Warren Wright's former star of the distance classics, that frequently disappointed last year after bowing a tendon in the spring, captured today's Cocoanuts Purse for his second straight triumph and completed a triple for Jockey Doug Dodson at Hialeah Park today.

Six 100-million candlepower searchlights, throwing beams twelve miles across the New York skyline from Central Park from 7:30 to 11 P.M. next Tuesday, will be one of the more spectacular features marking the international celebration of the centennial of Thomas Alva Edison's birth, the Edison Centennial Committee announced yesterday.

BERLIN, Feb. 4 -- The German Labor unions have voiced a strong demand for representation on the German Bi-zonal Economic Committee, but to date they have been ignored. Manpower officials, both American and British, strongly favor such representation, but the United States Deputy Military Governor, Lieut. Gen. Lucius D. Clay, has not approved.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 4 (AP) -- Bob Fitzgerald of Minneapolis went all out in his final trial of the day to turn in a time of 0:44.5 seconds in the 500-meter event, despite a high wind, to win first place on the United States Olympic skating team.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Jewish leaders studied a British ultimatum giving them seven days to cooperate in "locating and bringing to justice members of terrorist groups."

Maintaining that basic laws cannot be enforced without the constant cooperation of the public, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan assailed last night a public attitude that brands as "informer" any individual who seeks to aid in law enforcement.

Mayor O'Dwyer promised yesterday day that he and the Board of Estimate would make a prompt decision on a higher transit fare once the "facts" had been submitted at the series of public hearings that will start Monday morning at City Hall.

Plans of Robert R. Young to acquire, through the Alleghany Corporation, control of the New York Central System and other railroads to build a transcontinental system produced yesterday repercussions in legislative and railroad circles.
Frederick G. Blackburn of Pittsburgh has made known here the engagement of his daughter, Harriet Elizabeth, to Moses Taylor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald B. Taylor of Buffalo.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 4 -- The dominant Communist party is beginning to regard this country's increasing trade with the western nations as an alarming sign and to protest that something must be done to correct the situation.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 4 (AP) -- The Pennsylvania General Assembly abandoned today as "futile" an effort to have Congress delay sale of the $146,000,000 big and little inch pipe lines for six months.

Grace Castagnetta, who played Last night at Town Hall, is a clever improviser, but when she gives a recital she does not rely on her improvisational gifts to carry her through. She always presents a carefully prepared program, proving she is first and foremost a serious pianist.

Industrial executives and architects supervising new plant construction in four major industries disclosed here yesterday that they are seriously concerned over delays caused by shortages of materials and jurisdictional disputes in the building trades.

New York City's public school system will experiment with camp education in June to determine whether some things can be learned more effectively and quickly in the outdoor world than in the classroom.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5--Senator Kenneth McKellar of Tennessee proposed in the Senate today that any one Senator's opposition vote should be sufficient to prohibit confirmation of appointees to the United States Atomic Energy Commission.

Other Russian Prices The price in human life which Russia paid for her Revolution of thirty years ago would seem to be one and a half times as great as the price exacted by her war of defense against Hitler.

The United States and Russia were unable to reach full agreement yesterday, at a six-and-ahalf-hour closed meeting, in which representatives of four other nations also participated, on the procedure to be followed by the United Nations in seeking to regulate atomic energy and armaments.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5--Republican proposals for legislation based on the portal-to-portal issue of back pay were attacked today by union witnesses as striking at one of the basic labor reforms of the Roosevelt Administration.
Time, Inc., in a step designed to assure living quarters for employes and their families, has leased five small apartment buildings at 1737-45 York Avenue, it was announced yesterday.

Theodore G. Pilalis' boasted code of "impenetrable" Greek symbols with which he recorded policy gambling bets was shattered yesterday in the Gamblers Court by a police code expert. Magistrate Eugene R. Canudo promptly found Pilalis guilty as a policy "collector."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP)-- Chairman Fred Bradley, Republican, of Michigan, of the House Merchant Marine Committee said today records of the Maritime Commission "are so involved and so deep and dark" that it might take 200 auditors six months to find the truth about them."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- An optimistic view of the first year's operation of the United Nations was given to Congress by President Truman today, although he warned that the hopes engendered by its progress "can be betrayed and lost."

Responding to charges of persistent contract violation by leftwing department store locals in this city, Philip Murray, national president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, has assured store executives that the CIO is determined that contract obligations will be observed faithfully, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5--President Truman renewed today his recommendation to Congress for legislation which would, in effect, put Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., Republican, of Massachusetts, next in line for the Presidency. Mr. Martin is Speaker of the House.

Net profit of the Dow Chemical Company for the six months ended with last November amounted to $6,099,205, or close to double the $3,721,909 profit shown in the corresponding period of 1945, according to the report issued yesterday.

At least 2,460,000 Chinese have been aided through the Church World Service's American Activities Committee in China, Dr. Robert T. Henry, director of the committee, reported yesterday at service headquarters, 37 East Thirtysixth Street.
LANSING, Mich., Feb. 5 (U.P)-- Gov. Kim Sigler said today he intended to "investigate Communist and subversive activities in every phase of Michigan life."

MOSCOW, Feb. 5 -- Moscow papers announced today the details of the new agreement under which Finland is to pay the Soviet Union 6,000,000,000 Finnish marks in goods, territory, services and foreign exchange. The sum involved represents German funds in Finland at the end of the war, which were assigned to the Soviet Union at the Potsdam conference, according to today's press announcements.
ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- Republican legislative leaders served notice on New York City today that Mayor William O'Dwyer's program for getting $102,000,000 additional from the State was "as good as dead."

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 5--Czechoslovakia is putting into operation a foreign trade plan and program of control that is calculated to bring the country's foreign trade into complete subjection to the Government's economic policy--and if necessary, its political aims.

A suave international impostor, who was able to obtain $125,000 from two experienced business men with a fantastic story of hoarded millions, pleaded guilty in Federal Court yesterday to transporting stolen property and was ordered to prison for three years by Judge Edward A. Conger.

The heavy snowstorm that blew in from the West accompanied by a cold wave starting Tuesday night brought untold delight to thousands of skiing enthusiasts in this part of the country. For it means the best period of sport for the snow-famished devotees this weekend.

The rehabilitated and municipally supported Baltimore Symphony Orchestra, under its conductor, Reginald Stewart, who also is director of the Peabody Conservatory of Music, gave its first concert in New York last night in Carnegie Hall.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Feb. 5 (AP)--Residents of this city of 150,000 were reported today to be "getting aroused and angry" over a dispute that has closed four daily newspapers here for five months.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14, a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP)-- Benjamin F. Fields was convicted of contempt of the House Surplus Property Committee today for failure to furnish information which the committee demanded about a deal in surplus bronze screen wire.

Robert L. MacGregor, formerly general manager of the mortgage loan and real estate investment department of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, has been appointed director of housing for the company. In his new position he will have charge of the company's housing projects, the first of which to get under way is the recently reported development in East Orange, N.J.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 5 --The names of twenty-six architects, including some of the world's top-ranking designers, have been submitted to the United Nations as candidates for the board of design consultants that is to help design the projected world capital along the East River.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 9 to 32 points higher yesterday, led by strength in the March and May contracts.

The nation's gasoline stocks last week were increased an additional 778,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the close of the week, they amounted to 100,579,000 barrels, against 99,801,000 a week earlier and 102,574,000 a year ago.
Lester and Allen Cummings, the second seeded team, won their match the squash racquets open doubles tournament last night as play started on the courts of the Heights Casino in Brooklyn.

Sharp division over an increased transit fare in New York City was noted yesterday among civic and political groups as they lined up for the full-dress public hearing on the question that is to begin before the Board of Estimate Monday morning.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5--The House Education and Labor Committee began today an extended study of the problem of industrial unrest. Starting its hearings two weeks after its Senatorial counterpart, the committee gave first attention to bills by House members to revise the National Labor Relations Act.

The International Emergency Food Council, successor to the wartime Combined Food Board, whose strategy of economic warfare had to be kept secret, has just issued its first massive report, a sixty-four-page document of self-revelation. As an example of how world cooperation works at a down-toearth level of day-to-day give-and-take, it la probably unparalleled.

NEWARK, N.J. Feb. 5 (UP)-- Tami Mauriello, one of the nation's top-ranking heavyweights, got up from a nine-count knockdown in the second round tonight to score a close decision over Freddie Schott, Paterson (N.J.) veteran, in a ten-round bout at the Newark Armory.
Bennett S. Chappie Jr. has been appointed assistant vice president of sales, U.S. Steel Corporation of Delaware.
LONDON, Feb. 5--Great Britain's Labor Government reached out to Africa today for a means of cutting the country's bills for imported foodstuffs by $40,000,000 a year.

A group of printed fabrics by Ben Rose of Chicago, a comparatively new designer in the field, was presented for the first time in New York in an exhibit that opened yesterday in the gallery of America House, 485 Madison Avenue.

MOSCOW, Feb. 5 (AP)--Yuri Zhukov, writing in Pravda, described New York today as a city where a merchant would do anything to get a customer's dollar and in which the housing shortage could be relieved by the simple expedient of removing rent controls.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 5 -- Reporting an acute crisis in New Jersey higher education because of inadequate facilities, Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of Rutgers University, today announced that the university was exploring the possibility of borrowing funds from private sources to finance a long-range construction program.

LONDON, Feb. 5--The report from Johannesburg that a new rich strike has been made on the Geduld 679 farm which is being drilled jointly by Western Holdings and Blinkpoort Gold Syndicate brought a blaze of activity in Orange Free State gold shares on the stock markets here today. Apart from gold shares the markets were generally quiet.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5--Republican members of the House Ways and Means Committee agreed today on a full-dress investigation of the Administration's reciprocal trade program, and Chairman Harold Knutson of Minnesota set Feb. 24 for the opening of hearings.
Unseasonable weather this fall and winter has probably destroyed many plants, amateur gardeners were warned yesterday by Dorothy Jenkins, garden editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your cogent editorial of Jan. 27, "We Grow Older," is stimulating to thought and action.

LONDON, Feb. 5--The Foreign Ministers' deputies for Austria and for Germany completed today the preliminary phase of their London labors and cleared the way for the next steps in framing the peace treaties.

LONDON, Feb. 5--The unexpectedly violent reaction of the Arab League's delegates to any suggestions of a partition of Palestine has shaken Foreign Secretary Bevin and other top officials of the Foreign and Colonial Offices, it was learned today.

The St. Louis Bombers, western division leaders in the Basketball Association of America, easily beat New York's Knickerbockers, 71--46, last night in a league contest at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory.

SCHENECTADY, Feb. 5--Infrared photographs are being used successfully to detect forgeries or prove the authenticity of paintings of the old masters, Murray Pease of New York, associate curator in the Metropolitan Museum, of Art, said tonight.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5 -- Liberal profit-taking sales developed in grain futures on the Board of Trade today and prices averaged lower, wheat being off around 2 cents a bushel at one time. The finish was well above the bottom on the nearby deliveries of that grain, with the close off 1/2 to 1 5/8 cents net and new-crop months weakest.

LONDON, Feb. 5--A statesponsored "marriage welfare service" was recommended in the final report of a committee on divorces appointed by the Labor Government. The report was issued in the form of a White Paper today.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 5 -- The Jewish national council rejected tonight a British ultimatum giving official Jewry until Tuesday to join in stamping out Palestine terrorism. The Irgun Zvai Leumi, an "underground" group, asserted it would "fight to the last breath" against British authority.

Mass advertising, through bill boards, match boxes, car cards, newspapers and radio, to prevent the break-up of the family system before the end of She century was advocated here yesterday by Dr. Carle Clark Zimmerman.

More Shirt Fabrics Available Larger quantities of staple fabrics for men's shirts are being offered, market sources said yesterday. Limited offerings are being made for deliveries early in the third quarter, it was pointed out. Price levels are regarded as too high by cutters, but no easing is anticipated.
ALLENTOWN, Pa., Feb. 5-- Muhlenberg College scored a 55-53 victory tonight over the Long Island University basketball team in one of the most gripping games of the year.

An invitation preview of the loan exhibition of oil paintings, watercolors and drawings of Winslow Homer will take place the night of Feb. 18 at the Wildenstein Galleries, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street, where the exhibition will be on public display from Feb. 19 to March 22.

THERE may be nothing really spectacularly new in "An American Dynasty,"* John Tebbel's valiant appraisal of the McCormicks, the Medills, the Pattersons and their newspapers. The record of their singularly varied contributions to America in war and peace is, you might say, pretty widely known. But Mr. Tebbel has brought together a very large hatful of widely scattered material to make an informing guide to their somewhat restless careers.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 5--The American Federation of Labor Executive Council summed up its official attitude on proposed labor legislation today with a sweeping rejection of any proposal which "disturbs, menaces or destroys its free status."

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- The severe situation in the British zone of Germany this winter once again formed the subject of a long, earnest, frank debate in the House of Commons today. However, the upshot of it all was simply that the Government was doing its best.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5 (AP)--The New York Rangers went into a thirdplace tie with the Boston Bruins tonight when they defeated the Chicago Black Hawks, 3--2, in a national Hockey League game played before 15,441 fans.

The experience of Sweden, the only country to stabilize its economy successfully during the world economic depression of the thirties, is that fixing interest rates that discourage saving and allowing wage rates to reduce profits may prolong or intensify unemployment, Dr. Bertil Ohlin declared last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- High United States naval officers testified today that Russia had an advantage over her war allies in building new submarines because any exchange of information with her was on a "one-way street."

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 5--Col. William Roy Hodgson, Australian Minister to France, fought vigorously today to persuade the United Nations Human Rights Commission to set up a world court of human rights to enforce an international bill of rights.

SECURITY COUNCIL Representatives of five nations discussed procedure for control of atomic energy and armaments. No agreement reached as main point of contention was American insistence that terms of reference specify that new disarmament commission must not encroach on Atomic Energy Commission.

"We Americans of all others can never forget that in the darkest days of 1940 and 1941 it was only British courage and the blind faith of free men, undismayed by disaster, that saved the world from the evil of the Teutonic onslaught." These are the words of Thomas W. Lamont in making a gift of $500,000 toward the restoration of Canterbury Cathedral.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 5--Herman Talmadge told the Georgia Senate's judiciary committee today that he would not oppose Negroes' participation in elections "if they would vote individually but I know they would vote in blocs."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5--Secretary of State George C. Marshall today placed continuation by the United States of international relief in the wake of the expiring United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration as first on a list of twenty-seven "urgent" proposals the State Department is sending to the new Congress.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 5-- Evidence that the Russians are still teaching their school children that world conflict between communism and capitalism is inevitable and the fact that the Soviet espionage system is active constitute major threats to world peace, Dr. Karl T. Compton, president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5--President Truman recommended to the Senate today that twenty-four general officers be promoted to permanent generals in the Regular Army and that twenty-three others have temporary promotions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5--For the next few months The Congressional Record will become a textbook of American history if the debates on three current legislative proposals are worthy of the subjects. These are Presidential succession, Presidential tenure and the tariff.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5--The Soviet Union and Britain have declined to approve the United States' terms of trusteeship over the Japanese-mandated islands in the Pacific at this time, it was learned today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 5 --Britain became today the eleventh nation to join the International Refugee Organization formally --and the first to accept unconditionally its $22,281,424 quota for the first year of operations. Sir Alexander Cadogan, British delegate to the United Nations, signed the IRO's constitution this morning.
The State Liquor Authority probably will decide today whether the Longchamps restaurant chain's liquor licenses will be renewed. They expire Feb. 28.

NANKING, Feb. 5--Premier T.V. Soong announced today that the Government would grant a 100 per cent bonus" to exporters as a means of lending an "immediate stimulus" to China's meager export trade. The subsidy plan is part of a sustained effort by the Government to improve its deteriorating foreign exchange position under a program that already includes import licensing and exchange control.

Preferred stock financing for both refunding and new money purposes will be undertaken here today by underwriting managers for an Eastern public utility company and a Middle West department store enterprise, as follows: New York State Electric Gas Corporation--150,000 shares of 3 3/4 per cent $100 par value cumulative preferred stock at $102 a share, by Harriman Ripley Co., Inc.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Feb. 5 (U.P.)--A stonewall stand by Dennis Compton saved England from a virtual batting collapse today in the second innings of the fourth cricket test match. England took its second innings score to 274 runs for eight wickets.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I deeply appreciate your splendid editorials on the immigration of Displaced Persons. The 800,000 men, women and children now confined in Displaced Persons camps, of whom threefourths are Christians and one-fourth are Jews, represent a heavy burden upon our Federal budget.

The eightieth annual exhibition of the American Water Color Society has been set up in the galleries of the National Academy, 1083 Fifth Avenue, where a preview will be held from 3 to 7 this afternoon. The show opens to the public tomorrow and will continue through March 2, daily, including Sundays.
ALBANY, Feb. 5--Senator Seymour Halpern, Queens Republican, proposed today that State aid be extended to the localities to permit expanded psychiatric care of the mentally ill.
recommended today in a report to the advisory board of the Office of War Mobilization and Reconversion. The report was submitted by Murray Latimer, former head of the Railroad Retirement Board.

The War Veterans Bar Association announced yesterday that it opposed payment of a New York State bonus to veterans of World War II and had sent letters to Governor Dewey and to the Speaker of the State Assembly expressing its view.

Americans should be galvanized into action by the record of the National Safety Council which shows that accidents last year killed 100,000 persons in this country and injured 10,400,000 persons, or one out of every thirteen inhabitants. The most important classifications of accidents all showed rises as compared with 1945.

A banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co. submitted the high bid yesterday for $1,000,000 of State of New Mexico highway bonds coming due on Feb. and Aug. 1 in each of the years 1957 and 1958. The bid was 100.155 for 1 1/2 s.

The inflationary threat inherent in the nation's huge money supply can be checked effectively only through the reduction of bank holdings of Government securities, the main source of this currency, the Committee on Public Debt Policy states in a special study released yesterday.

"It Takes Two," the George Abbott-Richard Aldrich production, will take down its shingle at the Biltmore Theatre after Saturday night's performance. The Virginia Faulkner-Dana Suesse comedy, starring Martha Scott, will have chalked up a total of eight performances.

The chairmanship of the Manhattan Employe Gifts Committee for the Red Cross 1947 Fund Campaign of Greater New York has been accepted by Mrs. George J. Harding, it was announced yesterday by James M. Cecil, general chairman.

The Truman Administration's opposition to any labor legislation that would create a new mediation board and outlaw industry-wide bargaining and the closed shop was expressed here yesterday by David A. Morse, Assistant Secretary of Labor.

Columbia attained undisputed leadership of the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League by turning back Princeton, 57 to 49, before a capacity crowd of 2,000 at the Morningside Heights gymnasium last night. The Lions clearly deminstrated their superiority over the Tigers, with whom they had been deadlocked.
MOSCOW, Feb. 5--The Soviet Union has taken two vital steps toward victory in its nation-wide battle for a good harvest and the abolition of rationing.
LONDON, Feb. 5--Gales, blizzards and freezing weather over Britain and her coastlines presented an industrial and health crisis to the nation today.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 5-- One hundred and fifty members of seven different classes, ranging from the class of 1942 to the class of 1947, received degrees from Princeton University at its 211th graduation exercises this afternoon in Alexander Hall.

The United Nations has become so familiar a feature of the post-war scene that the President's first annual report to Congress on its activities and the part played in them by the United States comes as a surprising reminder that only fifteen months have passed since its Charter came into force.

Pointing out that in a matter of months nylon output will be sufficient to meet requirements of all manufacturers of hosiery, Warren A. Beh, director of nylon sales of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., warned yesterday that there was a need to appraise the effect of unlimited increased production.

Sir Alexander Cadogan, the British delegate to the United Nations Security Council, voiced disappointment yesterday over the "Iamentable lack of progress" by the Military Staff Committee, the five-nation body set up almost a year ago to plan for a world police force.

Richard Bonelli, the Metropolitan baritone, gave his first New York recital last night at Town Hall, where he was heard by a large and responsive audience. From the first, Mr. Bonelli has had a distinguished career in the opera house.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP)-- Foreseeing 500 miles an hour as outine airline speeds within five years, two aircraft manufacturers urged today that Congress keep airports and ground facilities abreast of aircraft design.

The Seatrain Lines announced yesterday that its new terminal at Edgewater, N.J., would be completed in time for resumption on March 12 of the company's warinterrupted coastwise service between New York, Texas City and New Orleans.

Retailers of hand-woven imported oriental rugs face serious inroads in sales volume if they increase prices, already at record levels even for a "class" market, W.J. Taber, general merchandise manager of W. J. Sloane, warned yesterday.

BERLIN, Feb. 5--While the western zones argue about decartelization, the Russians in SaxonyAnhalt have substituted a new state-owned cartel, covering 41 per cent of all industry, for the old privately owned combines.

The first clear though still incomplete picture of what is happening in Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania since these three Baltic states disappeared behind Russia's iron curtain is provided in a report in The Economist of London. This report is based primarily on information furnished by the Russian press and radio themselves, and it appears in a reliable journal not unfriendly to the Soviets.

The battle between the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society and its musical director of three and a half years, Artur Rodzinski, flared again yesterday when friends of the board of directors told its side of the story and charged the conductor with failing to act in good faith.

WORD that the Poughkeepsie regatta is to be resumed this year will warm the heart cockles of every oarsman who ever pulled a sweep or handled the tiller-ropes during one of those nerve-tingling rowing classics on the Hudson.

Youngsters probably give and go to more parties in February than at any other time with the possible exception of Christmas and New Year's. Valentine's Day, with its hearts and cupids, and Washington's Birthday, which has come to be symbolized by hatchets and cherries are excuses enough for children to get together.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Some years ago THE TIMES received nation-wide attention for a series of articles on the ignorance of American history revealed by the students in our schools. The conclusion appeared to be that such ignorance of our national background, traditions and ways of life jeopardized good citizenship.

A sharp warning against overextension of credit in foreign trade without careful appraisal of the particular market and the individual company concerned was voiced yesterday by members of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau in its round table conference at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

EL SEGUNDO, Calif., Feb. 5-- The first jet plane designed as a "flying laboratory" in the noman's-land of trans-sonic speeds, the D-558 Skystreak was unveiled by the Navy at the Douglas Aircraft Company's plant here today.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 5 (AP)--It seemed only appropriate when Imperator, flying the Canadian-owned silks of R.S. McLaughlin, captured the Bahamas Handicap with the Duke and Duchess of Windsor honored guests at Hialeah Park today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AB) -- President Truman's letter transmitting his first annual report to Congress on the United Nations: To the Congress of the United States: In accordance with the provisions of the United Nations Participation Act of 1945 I submit herewith my first annual report to the Congress on the activities of the United Nations and the participation of the United States therein.

Roswell Magill, former Under Secretary of the Treasury, urged yesterday that the Federal budget be reduced to a "more reasonable figure," emphasizing that the proposed one was based upon the highest tax rate in the nation's history applied to the highest national income.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Senate was told by Senator Claude Pepper, Democrat, of Florida today that the Republican party leadership in and out of Congress was stepping away from bipartisan foreign policy and setting out to smash the Potsdam Agreement for making Germany incapable of waging further wars.

BERLIN, Feb. 5--The occupation powers are making joint efforts to relieve the stress of the heavy winter here. Their latest action was an order by the Kommandatura to the German administration to begin immediate payments of special unemployment relief pending the final decision on the ultimate amount to be distributed this winter.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP)-- Rear Admiral W.W. Smith, chairman of the Maritime Commission, testified today that his agency had recommended that the United States "seek the immediate return" of 306 merchant ships now being operated by the British Government.

From the "sitting ducks" of World War I--the balloon observers-- to former Lieut. Gen. James H. Doolittle's Tokyo raiders and veterans of the German" and Pacific bombings, the men who have had to make parachute jumps to save their lives attended an organization meeting of the New York chapter of the Caterpillar Club here last night.
LITTLE AMERICA, Feb. 5 -- Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd revealed today details of the Navy's recent discoveries that turn the present maps of Antarctica into waste paper.

WARSAW, Poland, Feb. 5-- Boleslaw Bierut, 54-year-old son of a landless peasant, was elected fifth President of Poland today. The Parliamentary vote for M. Bierut, the only candidate, who had been President of the Provisional Government, was 408 to 24.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- An early showdown on income-tax reduction was charted by Republican members of the Ways and Means Committee today at a strategy conference.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5--In the fourth of a series of conferences with various interested groups, the Securities and Exchange Commission and its staff today discussed the commission's proposed program for streamlining the securities acts with the executive committee of the National Association of Securities Administrators.

Although President Truman has asked Congress to extend authority for the Government's operation of ocean shipping beyond Feb. 28, the expiration date, the Maritime Commission yesterday notified all its general agents in the domestic trades to advertise no sailings and accept no cargo bookings after that date.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 5--Rutgers University snapped Fordham's eight-game winning streak tonight by downing the Rams, 69--55, in a wide open basketball contest. The Scarlet held a 35-31 advantage at the intermission, after seizing an early 6-4 lead.

Publication of worth-while books, especially non-fiction, is being choked off by the rising costs of printing materials and labor, according to Dr. Henry Seidel Canby, author and editor, in an analysis released yesterday.

William J. Powell, Commissioner of Sanitation, told Thomas J. Patterson, budget director, yesterday that the Sanitation Department would need $12,717,809 more than last year to operate efficiently in the coming fiscal year. Mr. Powell also said he needed 2,000 more employes and wished to replace much equipment.

DETROIT, Mich, Feb. 5--President Truman entered the portalpay contest today by lending his full support to a plea by the Department of Justice for the right to intervene as a participant in the Mount Clemens Pottery Company case.

Trading Rule Revised Additional evidence that trading in securities is being freed of certain restraints that have come to be looked upon as onerous and detrimental to market liquidity and stability was brought to light yesterday when governors of the New York Stock Exchange liberalized a regulation covering the operations of floor members.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 5-- Setting a torrid pace throughout, Army's basketball team regained its winning ways by downing previously unbeaten Washington and Jefferson, 52 to 40, in the academy field house today.

The motor issues again led the stock market to higher ground yesterday although the pace of trading slackened and gains elsewhere in the list were selective. The textile, along with the store stocks, shared some of the gains but the composite rate showed an increase of only about 1/2 point, against a rise of a point for the industrials.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5--Gen. Robert E. Wood, chairman of Sears, Roebuck Co., asserted today readjustment of supply to demand, accompanied by price declines and a return of competitive selling, will be a gradual process which will continue through this year and probably into 1948.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5--Legislation to terminate rent control and all other operations of the Office of Price Administration by April 30 was introduced today in the Senate.

NANKING, Feb. 5--The Chinese Communists have formally proclaimed invalid all the Chinese Government's agreements with foreign nations "which disgrace the country and strip away its rights" and have not been ratified by the Political Consultation Conference or otherwise approved by the parties and groups that participated in last year's P.C.C.

An open competition is being conducted for a sketch to be used on a new brochure by the Village Presbyterian Church, 143 West Thirteenth Street. The sketch should be a line drawing of the Village House, Greenwich Mews, and a portion of the Village Presbyterian Church.

The Italian liner Saturnia, hastily reconditioned in Genoa after serving throughout the war as an American hospital ship, docked here yesterday on her first post-war voyage, carrying 1,560 passengers, the largest number to come from the Mediterranean since 1940.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 5 (AP)-- Two more skaters were added to this country's 1948 Olympics team today when Del Lamb, Milwaukee fireman, skated the 1,500-meter event in the best time for the twenty-one contestants and the final tryout mmittee selected John Werket of Minneapolis on the basis of his performance that included the second best time of the day.

Two radio policemen, an agent of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals and the crew of a police launch tried yesterday morning to rescue two white swans in Spuyten Duyvil, in spite of the frigid weather, the disdainful glances of the swans and a flock of sea gulls that were marooned with them on an ice floe.
A demand for loft buildings was indicated by reports on the East Side yesterday.

An appeal to the American people to "renounce the pattern of segregation, especially within our churches," was made yesterday by the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America in proclaiming next Sunday as the twentyfifth annual Race Relations Sunday.

The last gaps in the Police Department's highest ranks were filled yesterday by ninety-five pronotions. This set a record for ligh-rating promotions on any given day. These advancements, at he same time, exhausted the captain's list for the first time.
LONDON, Feb. 5 (U.P) -- Colonial
Admiral Thomas C. Kinkaid, commander of the Eastern Sea Frontier, warned yesterday against the "school of thought" that favors disarming before attempting to solve problems of international politics.

New York University moves up into the football picture a little more prominently today with the selection of Edward Everett (Hooks) Mylin as new head coach. Announcement of his appointment, under a three-year contract, was made last night by Graduate Manager Albert B. Nixon.

EXETER, N.H., Feb. 5 (AP)-- Thomas W. Lament, president of Phillips Exeter Academy's trustees, upheld the faculty today for making Latin and Greek elective instead of compulsory subjects, but expressed regret fewer students were studying the classics.
MOSCOW, Feb. 5--Sweden will deliver 200,000,000 crowns worth of mining and ore refining equipment to the Soviet Union under the Soviet-Swedish credit agreement.

PARIS, Feb. 5--Foreign Minister Georges Bidault indicated today that Britain and France might sign their projected pact of alliance before the Council of Foreign Ministers met in Moscow next month. He also told the Foreign Affairs Committee of the Assembly that the alliance might develop into a three-power pact by including the Soviet Union.

LONDON, Feb. 5--A new directive, in effect canceling the famous Order 1067 of the Joint Chiefs of Staff to guide the United States Military Government in Germany, has been approved in principle by the State and War Departments in Washington, responsible sources said today.

ROME, Feb. 5--The Italian Communist party accused the United States and Britain today of artificially fanning anti-Yugoslav feeling among the citizens of Pola, Istrian city assigned to Yugoslavia in the Italian treaty.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5--Charles E. Wilson, president of the General Motors Corporation, offered the Senate Committee on Labor and Public Welfare today a ten-point program for industrial peace.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 5--The annual Silver Sailfish Derby, sponsored by the West Palm Beach Fishing Club, is at its peak, and although there usually a last-minute surprise entry in one of the classes, the eight foot nine and one half inch sail taken by John MacNeil of Philadelphia is going to be a hard one to beat.

The mailman staggered into the Montague Street offices of the Brooklyn Baseball Club under a heavy load yesterday. After his underlings had done their duty with letter-openers, Branch Rickey, the Dodgers president, was able to announce the signing of six more players.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP)--The men who teamed with Admiral Marc A. Mitscher to win the war gathered from around the world today to help bury the fighting airman beside other heroes in Arlington National Cemetery.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 5-- United California Productions, an independent company formed by Robert Cummings, Philip Yourdan and Eugene Frenke, announced today their first picture will be "Joe MacBeth," a modern melodrama of Chicago, which Yourdan has written as a vehicle for Cummings.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 5--Gertrude Lawrence opened a week's engagement here last night in the Theatre Incorporated production of "Pygmalion" before an audience more notable for its distinction than for its size.

Contradictions in the testimony of two witnesses from the District Attorney's office developed yesterday in the second day's hearing of the State Athletic Commission's inquiry into the $100,000 bribe reportedly offered to Rocky Graziano to "fix" a bout scheduled for last Dec. 27 against Cowboy Ruben Shank.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5--The Office of Temporary Controls said today that the first ten-pound sugar stamp will become effective on April 1. The current stamps call for five pounds.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5--Earl Bunting, present of the National Association of Manufacturers, submitted to Congress today an analysis of President Truman's 1948 budget, in which, he declared that the Administration had failed to make promised economies and had lost control of Government spending.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5--Great Britain has assured this Government that there will be no repetition of provisions in its future trade pacts which violate terms of the British loan, John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, stated today.

PARIS, Feb. 5--The Robert Piguet opening yesterday carries one back to the "middle Twenties" in lines and in many subtle things, such as that gesture of holding a loose coat closed across the front, long ropes of pearls and sleeveless V-neck evening gowns.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5--The International Association of Machinists (independent) announced today that it had resumed its affiliation with the International Metal Trades Federation on condition that the latter organization refrain from becoming part of "the Communist-dominated World Federation of Trade Unions."

It is a very old person in this country whose youth was not acquainted with the Young Women's Christian Association. This year that organization is eighty-nine years old. Now in 435 communities in the United States it provides housing, companionship and recreation for young women who are leaving their homes and families to work in the cities.

Advertising in all New York newspapers during January totaled 10,718,210 lines, or a gain of 21.06 per cent, compared with the corresponding month last year, according to a compilation of Media Records figures. Financial was the only classification to show a loss-- 8.32 per cent.

Labeling it as an open invitation to the Jews of Palestine to become "informists and spies," Dr. Abba Hillel Silver, chairman of the American Zionist Emergency Council, condemned yesterday the British ultimatum of Feb. 3, which called on the Jewish Agency for Palestine to cooperate with the police and bring terrorists to justice within seven days.

The attempts of Senator McKellar of Tennessee to block the confirmation of David E. Lilienthal as chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission are an absurd and pitiful waste of time. But Mr. McKellar did unwittingly render a public service when he drew from Mr. Lilienthal one of the most movingly eloquent definitions of democracy that had been heard on Capitol Hill in many a year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (U.P.) -- Following is the text of the letter dated Oct. 16, 1946, on Gerhart Eisler from J. Edgar Hoover, Chief of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, as read today into the record of the House Un-American Activities Committee:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The Committee on Reciprocity Infer station heard in its closing session today a plea by Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association, for extension of the reciprocal trade treaty program as an essential element in the future welfare of this country.
LONDON, Feb. 6 -- In a sudden spurt of progress the Foreign Ministers' deputies for Austria succeeded today in reaching agreement on several minor clauses of the peace treaty.

After an early slump, cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 1 point higher to 20 points lower than on Wednesday, with the near months again showing relatively greater strength than distant months.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- President Truman announced the appointment of Joseph K. Carson, former Mayor of Portland, Ore., to the Maritime Commission, and expressed his sorrow at the death of Ambassador O. Max Gardner.

In East Harlem an important program of social work among people of many races and religions goes on daily and throughout the year under the auspices of the Good Neighbor Federation. This agency, with a full-time staff of eleven, of whom nine are professional social workers, has a record of more than forty years' service.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The House adopted today a resolution proposing a Constitutional amendment to limit the Presidential tenure to two terms. The vote was 285 to 121.

A durable structure of peace among the nations of the world is dependent upon the contribution of America in the field of international organization, Dr. Oswaldo Aranha, Brazilian representative on the Security Council of the United Nations, declared yesterday to an assemblage of leaders of international commerce, industry, the church, military and naval affairs.
By a unanimous vote, the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York registered its approval yesterday of the self - sustaining - subway - fare resolution presented at its monthly meeting.
President Truman praised Scouting in a message to the Boy Scouts of America on their thirty-seventh anniversary being marked by Boy Scout Week opening today and ending next Thursday.

ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- Faced with suspension of unemployment insurance tax rebates this year, employer groups are exerting strong pressure on the Legislature for changes in the State's modified merit-rating law so that these can be continued.

Fordham's Joe Nowicki will go after Ms third Halpin Half Mile triumph in the seventy-ninth anniversary New York Athletic Club games at Madison Square Garden on Feb. 15 it was announced yesterday by Manager Paul Pilgrim. It was also disclosed that Bill McGuire Jr. of the Sixty-ninth Regiment A. A., Bill Atkinson of Manhattan, Stanton Callender of New York University and Roscoe Browne of the Pioneer Club would be hr the field.

TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 7 (U.P.) -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur today instructed the Japanese Government to begin making preparations to hold a general election "as soon as practicable" after the end of the present Diet session.

DETROIT, Feb. 6 -- After allowing the Department of Justice to enter the portal pay case against the Mt. Clemens Pottery Company, Judge Frank A. Picard, in Federal District Court, retired today to the privacy of his chambers in the Federal Building.

Good to excellent skiing is the general outlook for the coming week-end, with the areas near New York City and, oddly enough, the New Hamphshire resorts, sending in the only discouraging reports. The recent snow storm and cold wave have given Vermont and the upper New York State Skilands their best sport of the winter.
LONDON, Feb. 6 -- The stock markets took a more cautious view today of dealings in gold shares and in the late trading the picture was stolen by Argentine rails with a new rise.

The Board of Superintendents' recommended ban of Howard Fast's historical novel, "Citizen Tom Paine," because of "vulgar" expressions, was indirectly a result of a high school teacher's advice to her pupils that they buy another of the author's novels, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Senator Taft sniffed auspiciously yesterday when the President repeated his call for a new law on Presidential succession. And probably so did nearly every other Republican, except Speaker Martin, who has been mentioned as eligible to the party's nomination for President or Vice President next year.

The time has come to realize that the sellers' market of the war years is fast vanishing, that in some lines a buyers' market is here, and in others it is just around the corner, Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, said last night.

The United States Rubber Company established last year new high records in consolidated net sales and net income, F. B. Davis Jr., board chairman, and Herbert E. Smith, president, reported yesterday in the fifty-fifth annual statement to stockholders.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Gordon R. Clapp, nominee for Director of the Tennessee Valley Authority, testified today that Senator Kenneth McKellar, Democrat, of Tennessee, once wrote TVA asking "best consideration" for an employe the Senator now says had Communist sympathies.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 6 (London Times dispatch) -- At the closing plenary session of the South Pacific Conference, representatives of Great Britain, the United States, France, the Netherlands, Australia and New Zealand signed an agreement tonight constituting the South Pacific Commission.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Department store sales in the week ended Feb. 2 were 10 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1946:

The strongest argument to be made against a constitutional prohibition of a third term for an American President is that in some grave future national emergency it might tie the hands of the electorate and prevent it from exercising a free choice in its own best interest.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- An appeal by Ambassador W. Bedell Smith in Moscow to Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov for negotiations to settle Russia's $11,260,000,000 lend-lease account has brought no result, the Senate Appropriations Committee learned today.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6 -- The city of Montreal, Canada, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $77,811,000 (United States currency) of 1947 refunding issue debentures, due serially on each Oct. 15 to 1967.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 6 (U.P.) -- A former lance corporal in the British Army is the pivotal figure in that army's expected showdown with the Zionist underground in Palestine.

MONTREAL, Feb. 6 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadiens, National Hockey League leaders, trounced the second-place Toronto Maple Leafs, 8-2, tonight and went five points ahead of the Leafs in the loop standings. A crowd of 12,341 witnessed the game.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Feb. 1 were 835,051 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 13,087 cars or 1.6 per cent more than for the preceding week; 111,750 cars or 15.4 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 95,495 cars or 12.9 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Legislation designed to hold labor and management to "full responsibility" for their contracts, especially in industries involving public health and safety, was demanded tonight toy Speaker Martin.

The American Iron and Steel Institute, announced yesterday that total capacity for the production of steel ingots and castings in the United States on Jan. 1 was 91,241,250 net tons, a decline of less than 1 per cent from the capacity of 91,890,560 net tons a year earlier.

NUTLEY, N.J., Feb. 6 -- Miss Ethel Calvert Phillips, writer of children's books, died here today in her home at 54 Wayne Place. In 1919 she wrote "Wee Ann," which attained great popularity. Others of her more successful works were "The Lively Adventures of Johnny Ping Wing," "Ride-the-Wind," "Peter Peppercorn" and "Brian's Victory."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Dr. Vannevar Bush, wartime chief of Government research, described David E. Lilienthal today as "a great American" and former Representative Joe Starnes, Alabama Democrat, termed him "a man of character, vision and realism."
PARIS, Feb. 6 -- The Communist party of France today formally declared Itself opposed to the official French policy of seeking an early treaty of alliance with Great Britain.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 6 -- Belgium is prepared to offer a substantial long-term loan to the United States and British occupation authorities in Germany to recover for Belgian ports valuable transit traffic now being diverted through Hamburg and Bremen.

The Boston Symphony Orchestra will give twelve concerts at next summer's Berkshire Festival at Tanglewood, Lenox, Mass. The greater part of the festival will be led by Serge Koussevitzky, who has invited Leonard Bernstein and Robert Shaw, both of the Berkshire Music Center's faculty, to appear as guest conductors.

Architectural models, model interiors and a significant collection of new furniture combined in one big exhibit for home planners will have top billing in Bloomingdale's seventy-fifth anniversary celebration next week. With many finishing touches still lacking, this array of exhibits was unveiled yesterday in a preview.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 6 (AP) -- British military traffic echoed ominously tonight throughout all Palestine.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Feb. 6 (U.P.) -- England forced a draw in the fourth cricket test match today, declaring for 340 runs with eight wickets down in the second innings after an all-morning stand by Dennis Compton and Tom Evans. Australia, going in after lunch, batted strongly and made 215 runs for one wicket.

RALEIGH, N.C., Feb. 6 -- New fork University's basketball team split its two-game Southern tour by dropping a fast and rough contest to North Carolina State, 47 -- 43, tonight before 3,000 fans in Thompson Gymnasium.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 6 -- "Whispering Smith," a 1906 Western novel by Frank H. Spearman, will be filmed for the first time by Paramount, with Alan Ladd in the leading role, the studio announced today. The story has reached the screen in two silent versions, the first in 1906 and the second in 1926, with H.B. Warner in the title role.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The House-approved bill to peg excise taxes on liquor, jewelry, furs and other luxuries at present wartime rates was reported out by the Senate Finance Committee today without amendment.

Continued borrowings, principally by tobacco companies, flour millers, finance organizations and oil companies, pushed the total volume of commercial, industrial and agricultural loans, an additional $30,000,000 higher last week, according to the statement of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System.

The Y.W.C.A. sought last night to stimulate a world-wide campaign to rehabilitate association work in Europe, Asia and the Pacific area. Mrs. Maurice T. Moore, chairman of the Round-theWorld Y.W.C.A., asked the meeting, at the Central Branch, 610 Lexington Avenue, for $2,100,000 for the reconstruction program.

Although erected five years ago, a shortage of personnel trained in psychiatry prevented until yesterday the opening of the modern seven-story psychiatric pavilion of Kings County Hospital in Brooklyn.
WARSAW, Friday, Feb. 7 -- The new Polish Cabinet was announced early today. Headed by Socialist Premier Josef Cyrankiewicz, it consists of twenty-one Ministers, two without portfolio.

ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- The joint legislative committee on housing and multiple dwellings proposed today that savings banks be permitted for another year to invest in the construction and ownership of group housing projects.
Democratic National Chairman Robert E. Hannegan served notice last night that President Truman would be called upon to accept the party's designation as Presidential standard bearer in 1948.

Three of the season's debutantes will serve as models at the Fiftieth Anniversary Luncheon and Fashion Show for the benefit of the Winifred Wheeler Day Nursery of the West Side House Settlement, to be given Feb. 18 in the clubhouse of the New York Junior League.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- John R. Steelman, assistant to President Truman, warned American business men today that the Government will not pay exorbitant prices for supplies under guise of protecting the "Buy American" program. In cases of exaggerated prices, he intimated, foreign goods win be bought to meet Government needs.

Recent declines in the prices of milk, poultry and other important foods represent the first significant reversal of the large rise since the start of the war. The decline in food costs is reflected not only in these lower prices but in the greater diversity of lowerpriced foods available.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The United States Chamber of Commerce offered a comprehensive program of labor legislation, including outlawing of the closed shop, to the Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6 -- The first post-war built train for transcon tinental service made an exhibition run of about 200 miles on the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Rail road today. Aboard were a large number of railroad executives as well as several railroad labor leaders.

In connection with its drive to round up souvenir weapons brought back to the United States by former service men the Internal Revenue Service of the Treasury Department unveiled yesterday for a week's showing a window display of foreign arms at Macy's.

Rocky Graziano, East Side middleweight boxer, who has been under inquiry by the State Athletic Commission after investigation by the District Attorney's office of an alleged attempt to bribe the boxer, will know his fate today.

The Columbia Theatre Associates of Columbia University presented the Columbia Opera Workshop in two one-act operas by Etienne Mehul last night at Brander Matthews Hall. The works performed, "Stratonice" and "L'Irato, ou L'Emporte," were sharply contrasted in character, forming an excellent double-bill and one exceedingly welcome, since it afforded a rare opportunity to hear once-popular creations of a leading French composer, whose output is largely unfamiliar today because of unmerited neglect.

SAN ANTONIO, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Ben Hogan of Hershey, Pa., favorite to win the twenty-first Texas open which starts tomorrow over the Brackenridge Park course here, laid down a 6-under-par 65 today to tie Herman Barron of White Plains, N.Y., for top money in the 18-hole pro-amateur event, forerunner of the $10,000 golf tourney.

A comprehensive group buying plan to improve quality of upholstered furniture has been approved unanimously by the board of directors of the Upholstered Furniture Manufacturers Association, comprising seventy local producers with an annual volume of $50,000,000, Irving R. Kass, counsel, announced yesterday.
As February is the time when supplies of broilers and fryers reach their peak, a decline in prices for most poultry this weekend was reported by the City Department of Markets.
FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Feb. 6 -- Gen. Joseph T. McNarney said today that he did not think there was "any other feasible solution but Palestine" for the 165,000 Jews in the American zone.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I was much gratified to see your recent editorial comment on the Lawrence bill to stop construction of the Higley Mountain dam and reservoir. It has been estimated that this reservoir with its companion reservoir at Panther Mountain would provide nearly eight times the capacity needed for flood control on the Black River.

Just before boarding his private plane for a hop to Pensacola, Fla., yesterday morning, Branch Rickey, the Mahatma of the Dodgers, left Word that he had four more contented Dodgers signed and sealed for delivery at Havana on Feb. 20.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- A number of recommendations have been drafted in official discussions in Mexico City for tightening control over migration of Mexican workers into the United States, the State Department made known tonight.

Taylor Adopts Firm Prices Escalator clauses are being withdrawn from sales contracts and firm prices are being re-established by the Taylor Instrument Companies, officials disclosed here yesterday. Wholesale, retail and industrial customers of the company are being notified that firm price policies on domestic Taylor products become effective today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities "threw the book" today at Gerhart Eisler, reputed Soviet mastermind in the United States, charging him with conspiracy to overthrow the Government, contempt of Congress, perjury, income tax evasion and falsification of passport.
LITTLE AMERICA, Feb. 6 -- This base was ready today to launch a flight that may answer what Rear "Admiral Richard E. Byrd calls the world's greatest unsolved geographical problem.

NANKING, Feb. 6 -- Lieut. Gen. Hisao Tani, commander of the Japanese Twenty-sixth Division, went on trial here today before a military tribunal as an alleged leading culprit in the "rape of Nanking." Nine years after the event, three gunnysacks of human bones were introduced as evidence of the two-month holocaust, which was said to have resulted in the slaying of more than 40,000.

More than a 10 per cent increase in output of critically scarce pipe fittings will mark 1947 if production schedules are not interrupted in the thirty-six plants in the industry. R. L. Stewart, president of the Pipe Fitting Manufacturers Association, made the forecast for the year following the annual meeting at the Biltmore yesterday.
ROME, Friday, Feb. 7 -- Indications here early this morning were that some hitch had developed in Government circles over whether Italy should sign the peace treaty in Paris Monday.

Pro and Con There is one advantage that we believe the newspaper is fully entitled to claim over the radio. The newspaper, working in space instead of time, gives its audience the opportunity to ponder and to compare.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- A treaty of alliance between France and Great Britain, which has been in process of negotiation for more than two years, will be signed within three weeks unless something untoward happens, it was learned today from completely responsible quarters.

John G. Winant, former Ambassador to Great Britain, asserted yesterday that Americans must take the lead in acquainting people with the "vital quality" of democracy. As general chairman of the American Brotherhood Week, Feb. 16-23, he announced the names of leaders in the press, radio, films, magazines and advertising fields, who will help the nation-wide observance sponsored by the National Conference of Christians and Jews.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission and its staff discussed today the agency's proposed program for revising the securities acts with representatives of the American Institute of Accountants.
CHICAGO. Feb. 6 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows.

Asserting that the complete story behind the resignation of Dr. Allan T. Newman as dean of New York University's College of Dentistry had not been given, Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase denied in an interview published yesterday in the NYU Alumni Bulletin that any question of racial or religious discrimination had been involved.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 6 -- Local 49 of the stereotypers and Electrotypers Union and members of the Rochester Mailers Union Local 66, of the International typographical Union, came to terms today with the management of the Gannett newspapers, according to Charles M. Lyons, international representative of the mailers.

PEIPING, China, Feb. 6 -- The United States branch of Executive Headquarters -- a unique chapter in American foreign policy -- breathed its last today when identical letters from Lieut. Sen. Alvin C. Gillem Jr., United States Commissioner, were handed to the Nationalist and Communist Commissioners informing them of the evacuation of the American component, effective at 4 P.M.
A 99 per cent increase last year over 1945 in the number of labor cases arbitrated in New York City alone was reported yesterday by the American Arbitration Association at its annual meeting.

Margin Loans Despite the relaxation of margin requirements, effective Feb. 1, total loans to brokers, dealers and others, for purchasing or carrying securities, as listed yesterday by the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System, showed a decline from the previous week's levels.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Widespread adoption of guaranteed annual wage plans by management-labor compacts was described as "dreamy-eyed star-gazing" in the first reactions today from organized business spokesmen to the report of the annual wage study group to the advisory board of the Office of War Mobilization and Reconversion.

LONDON, Feb. 6 (U.P.) -- The British Lawn Tennis Association, which has been delegated by the United States to manage the European zone play in the 1947 Davis Cup competition, today fixed the dates for the matches which will determine the European representative by July 15.

JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 6 -- Although Negroes have just completed an all-time record for payment of poll taxes in this State, it appears unlikely that a special session of the Legislature will be called this year in a stop-gap move to rescind all primary statutes and thus transform political parties into private clubs that could bar Negroes from voting in the summer primaries.

The true function of public relations for American business and industry should be not merely to get publicity or sell goods but to sell ideas in support of the American economic system and to help shape those ideas so that they will be acceptable to the public and win operate for the public good.

The P.E.N., the international association of writers, editors and publishers with members in fortynine countries, intends to ask for fuller representation for authors in the United Nations' Department of Public Information.

The smug bearing of three Harlem men, indicted as leaders of a $1,000,000 international narcotics ring, vanished yesterday in General Sessions when the prosecutor revealed at the opening of their trial how Federal agents and detectives had trapped them in an automobile last Dec. 12.

Emily Wilkens, until now pet of the teen-agers, is "growing up," speaking from the fashion angle. For some time she has been talking about doing a more sophisticated type of dress; that at last she has realized her ambition was evident in the collection of her clothes presented by Bonwit Teller yesterday morning.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- During the week ended Feb. 5 member bank reserve balances decreased $29,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Possession of Alva E. Belmont House, the headquarters on Capitol Hill of the National Woman's Party, and of the treasury and trust funds of the organization, is requested in a suit started here against the incumbent officers by dissident members.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 6 -- Leaders of the Congress party were reported tonight to have lodged a demand with the Viceroy, viscount Wavell, for the removal of the Moslem League from the interim popular ministry unless the Moslem group agreed to join the Constitution-making assembly.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 6 -- Considerable debate has been stirred up here by the decision of the Czechoslovak Government not to contribute an available $1,950,000 worth of potatoes and sugar to the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration except under far-reaching conditions.

PARIS, Feb. 6 --The French High Command reported today that the French garrison besieged at Hue, Indo-China, had been relieved yesterday by an advance that freed the European part of the town from the enemy. At the same time, the Viet Nam delegation in Paris today issued an appeal for a truce and for negotiations on the basis of agreements signed last year.

PARIS, Feb. 6 -- Lanvin's ruches, ruffles, jabots said fichus, featured it the spring and summer showings here, capture some of the charm of the eighteenth century, of the Watteau period. A black organdy blouse, with a deep ruffled jabot and cuffs that fall over the hands, gives this touch to a white shantung tailored suit.
LONDON, Feb. 6 -- Zionist leaders and Arab League delegates were forced to mark time again today, awaiting the British Government's proposed solution to the Palestine impasse.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6 -- James F. Burns Jr., president of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms of New York City, asserted here today that the Federal Reserve Board had exercised "arbitrary control over credit" in the purchasing of listed securities and in their carrying by banks, to the detriment of industry and employment.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Lower prices for foods offset price advances in most other commodity groups during the week ended on Feb. 1, with the general level of primary market prices unchanged, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
John L. Lenker, formerly director of retail merchandising and training for the Gulf Oil Corporation, has been promoted to assistant manager of the New York sales division.

LEESBURG, Fla., Feb. 6 -- Big bass but not as many of them, seems to be the moan of the largemouth bass addicts who concentrate in this area, which at one time produced some of the finest bass fishing to be found in this country.

MILWAUKEE, Feb. 6 -- A telegraphed invitation from Local 248 of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, for a resumption of bargaining negotiations tomorrow in the 285-day-old strike at the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing "Company's plant near here, was declined today by E.F.
