Orhman, chairman of the company's negotiating committee.

LONDON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- The Cabinet was split tonight on a solution to the Palestine problem, authoritative sources said. Mr. Bevin and Mr. Jones were reported at odds over the formula, but Government sources said the two Ministers were now ready to convey "many agreed aspects" of a compromise to Jewish Agency leaders.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 6 (AP) -- Once again there was an international flavor to the racing today at Hialeah Park, where a South American colt, Gustave Ring's Lord Grillo, romped to an easy triumph in the seven-furlong Rock Harbor Purse.

ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- Republicans, who control both the State Senate and Assembly by large margins, today manifested coolness towards suggestions that organized labor be given representation on the Board of Regents, governing body of the State education system.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- The House of Commons debated today the report of the Preparatory Commission on world food proposals and heard one Conservative party leader call it "a sellout to the United States Government."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 6 (AP) -- When Paul O. Bixler resigned today, Ohio State University set out for the fourth time in six years on a hunt for a new head football coach. Officials said Bixler's decision had caught them "sort of flat-footed," but Buckeye followers immediately produced a list of possible successors and even the State Legislature sprang into action.

MOSCOW, Feb. 6 -- The theme of crime and punishment has received more attention than usual in the Moscow press this week. Dispatches in the last three days report the sentencing of five criminals to be shot and one to be hanged.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- Prime Minister Clement Attlee and Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin voiced tonight the British Government's grief and regret at the death of O. Max Gardner, American Ambassador to London, in messages to President Truman and Secretary of State George C. Marshall.

A confederation of German states of the "pre-Bismarck" type, with Austria free to join or remain independent, was recommended yesterday by former Austrian Chancellor Kurt von Schuschnigg, as a good way to settle Germany's political future.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 6 -- The United Nations Transport and Communications Commission today heard representatives of France, the United States and the United Kingdom express their belief that the commission should assume the task of acting as conciliator in disputes concerning international transport and communications.

Following upon New York University's appointment on Wednesday of Hooks Mylin, word was received yesterday from Hamilton, N.Y., of the selection of Paul O. Bixler of Ohio State University as the new football coach of Colgate University.

PARIS, Feb. 6 -- Premier Paul Ramadler's five-party coalition Government had reached a critical stage tonight resulting from a split on five major issues. All these deadlocks revert to the party controversies that developed during the formation of the Cabinet and are now preventing the Government from action on the economic program of recovery started under former Premier Leon Blum.

James J. Caffrey, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Com mission, appealed yesterday to the managements of corporations to help keep the public holders of securities of corporations fully informed about company affairs and to implement such information "by the application of decent standards to proxy solicitation."

The fourth annual "Paintings of the Year" competition will be held in the galleries of the National Academy some time next autumn. As usual, this competition will be open to "all artists throughout the United States of America and its possessions," according to announcement just sent out by Walter S. Mack Jr., president of the Pepsi-Cola Company, the sponsors, and Roland McKinney, who directs the annual competitions.
The complicated labor dispute that grew out of the transfer of Macy's delivery staff to United Parcel Service seven months ago had an echo yesterday in an inter-union fight for control of funds.

A medical career was suggested yesterday for William E. Zimmerman, 27 years old, during ceremonies which marked his passage as the 10,000th veteran to go through the Testing and Advisement Center of New York University.

SECURITY COUNCIL Five-nation, meeting on disarmamen and atomic control still failed to result In agreement., Though some concessions were made, United States and Russia unable to reach accord oh relation of new Disarmament Commission to Atomic Energy Commission.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The support of an influential bloc of right wing House Democrats for Republican efforts to recast American labor policy through material restrictions in the Wagner Act was pledged today.

The first of several expected changes in the management of Transcontinental Western Air, Inc., appeared yesterday with the announcement that T. B. Wilson has resigned as chairman of the airline's board of directors, effective Feb. 15.
The current cold wave will end this morning, but will be followed later in the day by a second frigid spell, equally intense and charted to last through Sunday, weather-men predicted yesterday.

Reconsideration of their action in lowering or eliminating traditional trade discount terms has been asked by the National Retail Dry Goods Association in a letter to manufacturers who have made such moves, it was made known here yesterday.

It is encouraging to read that saner counsels have prevailed in Republican Congressional ranks, and that, at least for the moment, proposals of hightariff advocates to wreck the Reciprocal Trade Agreements program have been effectively sidetracked.

Lifting by the Argentine Government yesterday of its export ban on steer hides will have no effect on the domestic hide market, which took an upward turn this week from the lows of last Friday, market sources said.

VIENNA, Feb. 6 -- Unanimously, but also with unanimous reluctance, the Austrian Parliament approved today a law for the registration and punishment of Austrian Nazis to which the Allied Council had added fifty amendments.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 5 (U.P.) -- The four-motored Cuban air liner Ruta de Colon crashed in the mountains west of Madrid today and all eleven persons aboard were killed, including five American crew members, an airport announcement said tonight.

Boys make better cooks than girls, a contest among nearly 100 entries from the Children's Aid Society's cooking classes indicated yesterday when results were in at its West Side Center, 419 West Thirty-eighth Street. Even though girls predominated in the cooking classes, boys captured the first two places, with a girl finally getting in on third.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Official Washington was deeply shocked early today by the White House announcement of the sudden death of Ambassador O. Max Gardner. The news spread by word of mouth as government officials reached their offices and members of Congress gathered on Capitol Hill.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 6 (AP) -- Ken Bartholomew, Minneapolis speed skater who last Sunday won the national outdoor senior men's championship, today turned in the best time of a field of 16 in the first of two 5,000-meter trials in the final tryouts for the U.S. Olympic team.

A three-year program at an expenditure of $500,000 for the musical training and entertainment of hospitalized service men was announced yesterday by the Musicians Emergency Fund, 113 West Fifty-seventh Street.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 6 -- Col. Edward J. Murray, under arrest for smuggling more than $210,000 worth of diamonds and other precious stones into the country from Japan, said today that he regarded them as "legitimate souvenirs" and prepared to fly back to Tokyo within the next six days to try to clear himself with his superior officers.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- Home Secretary James Chuter Ede, although tone deaf by his own admission, had to defend the granting of a British visa to Beniamino Gigli, the Italian tenor, in the House of Commons today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The long-awaited liberalized provisions to relieve the plight of landlords undergoing economic hardship under existing rent controls were announced today by the Office of Temporary Controls. The changes will become effective on Feb. 15.

As Mayor O'Dwyer provided additional seating in City Hall yesterday in expectation of a record crowd of speakers at Monday's public hearing on raising the transit fare, the newly organized Citizens Committee to Save the Five Cent Fare asked that the hearing be held in an armory to provide sufficient seating space.

The local premiere of "The Story of Mary Surratt," slated to take place this evening at Henry Miller's Theatre, has been delayed until tomorrow night because of the weather conditions, it was announced yesterday by the show's spokesman.

Magistrates courts had an unprecedented increase of cases and income from fines in 1946, according to the annual report submitted to Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday by Edgar Bromberger, Chief City Magistrate. Nearly 1,000,000 docketed cases, summonses and warrants were handled and $4,201,586 in fines and penalties was collected.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Agreement on a new contract raising wages three cents an hour was announced tonight by the CIO Glass, Ceramic and Silica Sand Workers of America and the Libbey-Owens-Ford and Pittsburgh Plate Glass Companies.

As the first indication of the line of policy to be expected from the new Secretary of State, the list of proposals Secretary Marshall has sent to Congress for prompt action is important news. His course is a matter of intense interest to the whole world. We may be sure that his first recommendations to the Foreign Relations Committee, and the order in which he places them, will be studied carefully in many capitals.

The deadlock between Soviet Russia and the United States in the United Nations discussions over the method whereby the projected Disarmament Commission would be prohibited from encroaching on the province of the Atomic Energy Commission remained unbroken last night.

SOMETIMES the most careful, subtle and even beautiful writing comes to no good end. The writer becomes so preoccupied with polishing small facets of his work, with laborious refinements of inconsequential minutiae, that his finished story seems only an instrument for his private pleasure. Alis de Sola, gifted as she undoubtedly is, is such a writer.

What Mr. Muench did recently at a Philharmonic-Symphony concert for Berlioz of the "Symphonic fantastique" Bruno Walter did last night, on the same podium, in Carnegie Hall, with Mahler's Fifth symphony. The hour-long symphony made the first half of a notable program completed by the performance of Chopin's E minor concerto by a master pianist, Artur Rubinstein.

ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- Unless the highway accident rate in the State is reduced soon, there is a possibility of restrictive laws that will affect automobiles and driver Clifford J. Fletcher, Commissioner of the Motor Vehicle Bureau, told a meeting of the New York State Automobile Association and New York State Highway Users Conference here today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Two Republican Senators at key posts will take into the open tomorrow their fight for peace in a controversy over tariff policy which threatens to split the new Congressional majorities into warring camps.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Feb. 6 -- As a sequel to a hitherto undisclosed incident two weeks ago in which Polish displaced persons mauled seven Polish Government liaison officers in the Wildflecken United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration camp near Fulda, a conference between Zonal UNRRA Chief Paul B. Edwards, Gen. Joseph T. McNarney, United States Military Governor, and other officers today brought to a climax a long-standing conflict over repatriation policy.

TOKYO, Feb. 6 -- Pressure is mounting behind the demand on the Japanese Government to do something definite and drastic to break the present economic impasse. The occupation authorities are shouting for action, the people obviously are impatient and today industrial and labor leaders formed an Economic Rehabilitation Council, with Mosaburo Suzuki, Socialist party economist, as chairman, to try to solve the problem where the Government has failed.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial in the issue of Feb. 5 praised Mayor O'Dwyer for calling a public hearing to discuss all phases of the subway fare problem, and I agree with you that this program is both courageous and sound.

ATLANTA, Feb. 6 -- The Georgia State Treasurer, George B. Hamilton, was directed today by the Fulton (Atlanta) County Superior Court to accept checks representing tax collection funds from the Talmadge-appointed state Revenue Commissioner, Charles D. Redwine.

BERLIN, Feb. 6 -- The German governments in the Russian zone were revealed today to be alarmingly overcrowded with unpurged former Nazis and an extensive house-cleaning is now in process by Russian order. The great majority of those being belatedly removed are understood to be members of the Socialist Unity party, created by the Russians last year in an attempt to merge the Communists and the Social Democrats.

The stock market weathered yesterday morning a fairly steady assault against prices and managed a partiaL recovery in the afternoon, which left the composite rate off about 1/4 point on the day. Emphasis shifted from the motors to specialties such as the films, electronics and textiles.

THERE was a picture in the paper the other day of some people standing around a table and President Truman was reaching his hand inside a big silver bowl. He wasn't helping himself to a cup of punch. He was just fishing for a slip of paper.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6 -- March and May wheat sold today on the Board of Trade here at new seasonal high prices as the result of heavy buying, which brokers attributed to short covering for eastern account, combined with buying regarded as removal of hedges by mills against sales of flour to the Government.

ALBANY, Feb. 7 -- The State Congress of Industrial Organizations called upon Governor Dewey, Lieutenant Governor Hanley and legislative leaders today to recommend the election of two CIO members to existing vacancies on the State Board of Regents.

The strengthening of American free enterprise against the worldwide attacks of communism and socialism requires an aggressive public relations policy on the part of business and industry to prove by both word and deed that it can continue to give American workers and consumers greater benefits than any other social and economic system.

ROME, Feb. 7 -- The Italian Government decided today to sign the Italian peace treaty. However certain express reservations will be made by the Italian plenipotentiary at the moment when he signs the treaty on behalf of his Government.
DETROIT, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Federal Judge Frank A. Picard received a notice of appeal today from his order permitting the Government to be a party to the Mount Clemens Pottery Company portal-pay suit.
BERLIN, Feb. 7 -- The British Military Government announced today a new law for its zone, which it described as "the final solution of the problem of the destruction of nazism and militarism."

LONDON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The British Cabinet was asked today to approve a compromise plan on Palestine calling for admission of 100,000 European Jews into a semiautonomous Jewish province in the Holy Land, a reliable informant said.

In a highly jovial mood, Babe Ruth celebrated his birthday yesterday in French Hospital with three visitors -- his wife, his daughter and "Pal," his huge brown dog who didn't hesitate in the least to violate the decorum of the hospital and throw himself across the Babe's bed.

ATHENS, Feb. 7 -- Defying police orders, a crowd estimated at about 1,000 gathered today outside the Akropole Palace Hotel, where the United Nations investigation commission is holding its sessions. Unarmed police reinforcements kept order, and few instances of violence were reported.
IN "The Lincoln Reader"* -- "a biography written by sixty-five authors" -- Paul M. Angle has produced what seems to be something new under the vast Lincolnian sun.

Edward E. Oelsner of the University Club and Richard S. Rothschild of the Downtown A.C., battled it out last night in the final of the metropolitan squash racquets singles championship in the Harvard Club, Rothschild winning out in five games, 15 -- 6, 15 -- 7, 12 -- 15, 8 -- 15, 17 -- 15.

The thirty-seventh anniversary of the founding of the Boy Scouts of America and the twenty-fifth anniversary of the setting aside of the second Sunday in February as Race Relations Sunday will be celebrated nationally tomorrow. Many sermons will deal with the life of Abraham Lincoln.

BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y., Feb. 7 -- Dr. Robert Brian Archibald, 46 years old, president of the Westchester County Medical Society and for many years a leading medical practitioner in Northern Westchester, committed suicide here today by jabbing a hypodermic needle containing a lethal dose of morphine into his thigh, according to Dr. Edwin H. Huntington, acting County Medical Examiner.
Seven hundred stowaways have arrived in New York in the last eighteen months, W. Frank Watkins, district director of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, said yesterday.

Cardinal Spellman called on American women yesterday to make their country strong through creating healthy, holy and happy homes. He spoke at the convention of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs in the Astor Hotel.

While the New York Philharmonic -Symphony Society was making arrangements to fill some of the time left vacant by the resignation of Artur Rodzinski, it was announced yesterday in Chicago that Mr. Rodzinski had been appointed musical director and conductor of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, starting with the 1947-48 season.
LONDON, Feb. 7 -- The latest news of the effects of the coal shortage on industry restricted business in the stock markets today, although quotations generally remained remarkably firm.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The War Department will ask Congress to consider means of appropriating funds for military research and development that would allow longrange planning on a five-year basis, instead of the present yearto-year system, Kenneth C. Royall, Under-Secretary of War said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- A bill to continue rent control without an increase for another year beyond its expiration on June 30 was introduced today by Senators James E. Murray of Montana and Robert F. Wagner of New York, Democrats.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 7 (U.P.) -- Joe Louis and Arturo Godoy, waving 14-ounce gloves at each other, danced through a ten-round nontitle exhibition here tonight in which the heavyweight champion won an unofficial decision.
NANKING, Feb. 7 -- Thirty witnesses gave today first-hand accounts of the "rape of Nanking." They described how victims had been raped, shot and "smoked to death" over fires by Japanese troops.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 7 -- The $4,000 White Caps Purse was the main event at Hialeah Park today, an while it was restricted to horse in Grade D it provided a sizzling Grade A finish--four heads on to wire at the end of six furlongs.
LONDON, Feb. 7 -- Beginning Monday, the electrical power supplying industries in a large part of England, including the London area, will be entirely cut off for at least three or four days.

The energy with which Health Commissioner Weinstein is laying the foundations for a rounded attack on the smoke and soot problem in New York City gives promise that we are at last on the way to substantial abatement of this nuisance. The Commissioner is receiving spirited cooperation from representatives of civic groups and selected lines of business and industry affected.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Representative Alvin F. Weichel, Republican, of Ohio, chairman of a House Merchant Marine Subcommittee called today for full disclosure, through subpoenaing Secretary of State Marshall, if necessary, of how Russia replied to futile efforts by the United States to get back ninety-five lend-lease ships.
In a brief ceremony on the fourth floor of the Empire State Building, an Army veteran and a former Wave yesterday received certified checks for $1,479 and $2,300, respectively.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 7 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has concluded an agreement with Irving Berlin under which the studio will produce a Berlin musical film to be titled "Easter Parade," it was learned today. Berlin will write the musical score for the picture and will contribute established songs of his own composition in addition to "The Easter Parade," from which the title of the picture will be derived.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 7 -- Continuation of child care centers, which in some areas have enrollments almost as large as in the war years, now is assured in California until June 30, and the Legislature, following a recess, is expected to act on proposals to make the centers a part of the State's pre-school training system under direction of the State Board of Education.

Bringing to a close the public auction phase of its Japanese silk program, the United States Commercial Company yesterday disposed of 5,380 bales at well over $3,000,000. Of this total, 4,500 bales were sold to dealers in package lots of 300 bales of grades from AA to E at a discount of 25 cents per pound, and the balance on open bids which ranged from $3.95 for Grade G to $11.60 for grade special AAA.

Rainwear manufacturers, concerned over the drop in wholesale volume, are intensifying efforts to have department and specialty stores establish separate rainwear departments to boost sales, William Klothe, Weathercraft Manufacturing Company, disclosed yesterday.

The revocation of Rocky Graziano's license as a boxer by the State Athletic Commission yesterday transformed the Twentieth Century S.C. into a beehive of activity as measures were taken meet this disruption to what had been a smooth boxing schedule.
A new snow storm accompanied by thunder and lightning hit New York City early this morning, after a previously forecast cold wave had been sidetracked to the south.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Senator Kenneth D. McKellar of Tennessee demanded today that Senators turn out in greater numbers to hear his witnesses oppose confirmation of David E. Lilienthal as chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission.

BERLIN, Feb. 7 -- The increasing frequency of terroristic acts in widely separated parts of Germany is causing concern to the United States Military Government though it still insists there is neither the evidence nor the likelihood of a nationwide organization.

LONDON, Feb. 7 -- Industrial equipment from the western zones of Germany, as well as other sections, was demanded today to help satisfy a 285,000,000,000-ruble reparations bill presented by the Ukraine to the Foreign Ministers' deputies.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Stories of union terrorism which one employer, Jack Klein, testified had driven him to the point of contemplated suicide, were given under oath today to the House Labor Committee by Philadelphia produce distributors.

Dr. Sigmund L. Friedman, who became director of Sydenham Hospital last Monday after a dispute between the board of directors and the previous administrator, said in a statement yesterday that the institution would continue to be operated on a voluntary interracial basis.

The Navy will issue soon a clarification of its new procurement policy, according to M.L. Toulme, executive vice president, NationalAmerican Wholesale Grocers Association. Following discussions between Navy officials and the NAWGA, the wholesalers were told that they will be able to compete for Navy business on the same basis as other suppliers.

Government leaders of the ten Latin-American countries visited recently by Trygve Lie "look to the United Nations for leadership and assistance," the Secretary General declared last night in a broadcast over the Columbia Broadcasting System.

DUBLIN, Feb. 7 -- The news from Britain that all shipments of coal to Ireland would be stopped temporarily created consternation here. Tonight the state's main railway company declared that it might be necessary to suspend train service on short notice or, in some instances, without notice.

Bill Van Breda Kolff and Lee Knorek will make their debut with the New York Knickerbockers against the Toronto Huskies at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory tonight. The Yonkers Rockets will engage the Brooklyn Flashes at 7:30 P.M. in a preliminary to the Basketball Association of America contest.

The Right Rev. William T. Manning, with his wife and daughter, Miss Prances Van A. Manning, will move from "Bishop's House" within the close of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue near 110th Street, to 8 Washington Mews, the present residence of the Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert.

Dorothy Gish, who distinguished herself last year as Mrs. Holmes in "The Magnificent Yankee," returns to Broadway this evening in another historical drama, "The Story of Mary Surratt." The new play by John Patrick, remembered for "The Hasty Heart," opens at Henry Miller's Theatre under the auspices of Russell Lewis and Howard Young, Los Angeles producers, presently represented hereabouts by the revival of "Lady Windermere's Fan."
Thinking of home, occupation troops of the Eighty-eighth Infantry Division in cold-swept Venezia Giulia and Trieste have donated an average of $4.62 each to the 1947 March of Dimes.

Bernard M. Baruch, 76-year-old elder statesman, called yesterday upon American youth to reject "soft and beguiling" philosophies and to cling instead to the doctrines that have made this country the citadel of individual liberties.

Now and then, in the course of the tales of a Thousand and One Nights, one comes across a passage, or formula, which goes as follows: "The stranger, entering my tent, and improvising in a mode I knew not, sang" -- We thought of this at the concert given by Alan Hovhaness, the American composer of Armenian descent, who conducted a concert of his own works last night in Carnegie Hall.
WARSAW, Feb. 7 -- An analysis of the new Polish Government, which will be presented to Parliament tomorrow, indicates that the Communist party has strengthened its position in the country.

ABOARD MOUNT OLYMPUS in Ross Sea, Feb. 7 -- Three thinskinned ships of the Navy's Antarctic expedition sailed from Little America last night, seeking safe passage through the formidable Ross Sea ice pack. Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd and 197 men were left behind for a three-week stay in the tent town of Little America on the windswept barrier ice.

Everyone seems to love a bear hunter but the bear, and since we ran a story on the chicken-robbing bears of Plymouth, N.C., the number of bear tales, tall and short, that have arrived in this office would make a good-sized volume.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The setting up of a $35,000,000 tideover food relief fund for neediest nations from the expiring resources of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration was announced today by Maj. Gen. Lowell W. Rooks, Director General.

TOKYO, Feb. 7 -- Today's order by Gen. Douglas MacArthur to the Japanese Government to hold a new general election "as soon as practicable" was the second major directive that the Supreme Allied Commander has issued within a week.

The Rockefeller Foundation, in the interest of keeping open the sole avenue of the interchange of scientific data and thought between American and Russian scientists, made a grant on July 1 last of $25,000 to the American-Soviet Science Society, it became known yesterday.

Local collegiate fives will face a busy session tonight with Columbia, Fordham, City College and St. John's among the teams slated to see action. The most important contest on the agenda will bring together Fordham and Columbia in the latter's Morningside Heights gymnasium.

Again featured by a strong nearmonth situation, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 9 to 45 points net higher than on Thursday. Starting unchanged to 5 points up, it rose to the best levels of the day at the close.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Harold E. Stassen of Minnesota and Senator Robert A. Taf t of Ohio, two Republican Presidential aspirants, clashed repeatedly today on methods of bettering labor-management relations. At one point the Ohioan called a proposal by the Minnesotan "trivial."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: One of your editorials says, "Too often it is only the fanatics who go to the trouble of telling public servants what they think is wrong." How often would be just often enough to leave everything to the fanatics? Am I finical in asking that question?

A new electric iron tapered at both ends so it can be used backward as well as forward will be offered through several stores beginning Monday. The Tru-Heat automatic iron is the first in a series of home appliances to be introduced by General Mills.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 -- Edward L. Ryerson, president of the orchestral association, announced today that Artur Rodzinski would assume his new duties starting with the 1947-1948 season, succeeding Desire Defauw, who recently had submitted his resignation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Arthur Bliss Lane, American Ambassador to Poland, will return to the United States for consultations on recent developments, including the elections of Jan. 19, Secretary of State Marshall announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads reported today that the nation's Class 1 carriers last year showed an average return on investment (after depreciation) of 2.74 per cent, compared with 3.64 per cent in 1945.

Col. William H. Kendall, newly appointed chief of the Army Exchange Service, announced yesterday that AES policy does not prohibit either manufacturers or wholesalers from selling merchandise direct to post exchanges for resale.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Over Democratic opposition, the House Ways and Means Committee voted today to exclude the public from hearings on income tax reduction and to limit witnesses to Treasury and Congressional staff experts.

SAIGON, Cochin China, Feb. 4 (Delayed) -- This once rich colony of France has become a seething cauldron of highly organized unrest. Resistance movements are numberless and their tentacles reach everywhere. Even the French, who have not distinguished themselves for perspicacity here, are beginning to realize that they are up against something big.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Feb. 7 (AP) -- James Newton Demaret, singing master of the fairways, fired a record-equaling 30, 32 -- 62 today to take the lead in the first round of the $10,000 Texas open golf tournament.

Most department stores close on Saturday nights or if they keep open welcome only customers. Not, however, two of the four Sachs Quality Stores. They welcome girls and boys between the ages of 13 and 17 and don't want them to buy a thing.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 7 -- While a Superior Court judge heard allday arguments at McDonough on the rival Governorship claims of M.E. Thompson and Herman Talmadge, a Floyd County Superior Court judge at Rome ruled today that Mr. Talmadge's election by the General Assembly last month was invalid.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Already "nominated" by Robert E. Hannegan, Democratic National Chairman, for a second term in the White House, President Truman is being urged by some associates to pursue a more independent course as head of his party than that indicated by his Congressional cooperation program.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Amendment by Congress of the law which requires the Western Union Telegraph Company to dispose of its transatlantic cables, or enactment of new legislation providing for a merger of international carriers to which the cables may be transferred for operation, was recommended by the Senate Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 7 -- The general executive board of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, CIO, today bitterly attacked anti-labor legislators in Congress and warned "reactionaries in the Republican party" that the 1948 Presidential outcome will surprise them unpleasantly.

ALBANY, Feb. 7 -- A proposal to replace the three-member commission that now runs the State Civil Service with a trained administrator, who would be an expert in the field, is receiving serious consideration from Governor Dewey, it became known today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In our letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES, published Dec. 28, we demanded the termination of any United States representation at the Vatican and the cancellation of the status of the Papal Delegate at Washington, D. C.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- President Truman met with the Cabiinet, renewed his request to Congress for authority to continue rubber controls, asked Congress to abolish Federal taxes of gifts to the United Nations, nominated Joseph K. Carson to the Maritime Commission and named forty-eight high-ranking officers for promotion in the Army Reserve Corps.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 7 (AP) -- A Federal investigation into the war contracts of Andrew J. Higgins, who built more than 20,000 small boats for the United States armed forces, was ended today and the United States attorney said the grand jury had "concluded there is no basis for criminal prosecution."

JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 7 -- The impact of the war on the social life of this capital city and the question of increased aid for Negro education appear to be the principal factors in recent Negro efforts toward greater participation in the political life of this State.

If the French and British sign their long-debated treaty of alliance before the Moscow Conference, the pact will have a decided influence on the negotiations of the Foreign Ministers. Since it was first discussed in the ChurchillEden visit to Paris in November, 1944, the agreement between the former allies has been held up for two main reasons.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Attempts in Congress to legislate the Administration's reciprocal trade agreements program into temporary or permanent suspension this year appeared today to face almost certain failure.

Increased cooperation among mills, manufacturers and retailers to achieve better service for the consumer was seen as vital yesterday at a meeting of twenty representatives of leading ready-to-wear manufacturers and retailers, held in the offices of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- A new wave-signal translating system having secrecy features especially designed to safeguard the exchange of messages in code was one of the 329 inventions registered by the United States Patent Office.

Maxie Shapiro, veteran, lightweight from the East Side, scored a surprise victory over Phil Terranova of the Bronx in the main bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. Calling on all his ring generalship against his younger foeman, the East Side warrior succeeded in gaining the votes of two of the three officials to capture the decision.
LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 7 -- All set to lay the moral framework for the United Nations by writing an international bill of rights, the Human Rights Commission was stopped today for lack of money.
MOSCOW, Feb. 7 -- The United States military activity in the Arctic threatens the interests of peace, according to the viewpoint advanced in an article in the Government newspaper Izvestia.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (U.P.) -- Americans will receive only ninety pounds of sugar per person this year in the face of a serious shortage that will continue until the 1947 crops are harvested, the Senate was told today.

The greatest outpouring of skiers since the Christmas holiday period can be expected today and tomorrow in the North Country as new snows added to accumulations to provide superb conditions in general. Even such popular retreats in New Hampshire as Pinkham Notch, North Conway's Cranmore Mountain, Francoma's Cannon Mountain, Plymouth and Waterville Valley, all on the poor side Thursday, are now covered with white blankets upward to six inches in depth.

ALBANY, Feb. 7 -- New York City proposed today in new legislation that it be reimbursed by the State to the extent of 80 per cent of the full cost of its welfare expenditures, including administrative costs.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 7 -- Vassili Dendramis, permanent Greek representative in the United Nations, has complained to Secretary General Trygve Lie of "unheard of" insults against his Government by a Yugoslav official working in Athens.

LONDON, Feb. 7 -- The possibility of requesting the United Nations Security Council to appoint a permanent international commission to supervise the Greek frontier after the present Allied investigating committee has completed its work is being considered seriously here.

Canada Wire and Cable Directors of the Canada Wire and Cable Company, Ltd., at a meeting held yesterday at Toronto, decided to take no action on the class A and B common dividends at this time. Declaration of regular quarterly dividend of $1 on class A would normally have come now.

Mrs. Carol King, attorney for Gerhart Eisler, obtained a writ of habeas corpus in Federal Court yesterday to test the legality of Eister's arrest and detention on a warrant charging that he is a dangerous enemy alien.

The first post-war shipment of Dutch Edam cheese came into New York this week, and the first store to offer it is Alan Berry, 676 Madison Avenue, which is putting it on sale today for 89 cents a pound. The loaves are the old familiar cannon balls in shape, bright red on the exterior and weighing about four pounds each.
TOKYO, Feb. 7 -- Further food imports are needed if Japan is to escape starvation in 1947, Gen. Douglas MacArthur declared la e statement today.

By far, the greatest single cause of strikes in New York State during 1946 was labor's demand for higher wages, according to preliminary statistics of the State Mediation Board obtained yesterday. If union recognition in various forms be added to wages as a principal issue, 80 per cent of the year's strikes are accounted for.

Popular sentiment in Tammany Hall districts throughout the city is overwhelmingly opposed to any increase in city transit fares, it was learned yesterday as the list of organizations and individuals expecting to be heard on the issue at City Hall on Monday swelled to 105.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 7 (U.P.) -- Hundreds of men of the Jewish underground army Haganah roared south in a truck convoy today and founded three new Jewish settlements near the Egyptian border.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Two quarts of diamonds and a third quart jar containing $28,000 cash were dug up beside a Virginia highway in the recovery of the $1,500,000 Hesse crown jewels, the Army disclosed today.

All raw materials required by valve manufacturers are scarce and metal prices have gone up from a minimum of 18 per cent to a maximum of 93 per cent and are still rising, W.B. Holton Jr., president of the Valve Manufacturers Association, disclosed here yesterday.

The Senate members of the joint Atomic Energy Committee will approve and the Senate will sustain the appointments of David E. Lilienthal, Lewis L. Strauss, William Wesley Waymack, Robert Fox Bacher and Sumner T. Pike to be members of the Atomic Energy Commission and of Carroll Wilson to be its general manager.

DETROIT, Feb. 7 -- The 1947 line of passenger cars, comprising eleven models in three series, the specially styled Fleetline, deluxe Fleetmaster and the Stylemaster, was presented today by the Chevrolet motor division, General Motors Corporation.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 7 -- The Yale Daily News disclosed today that a number of students had been expelled from the university, following the continued disappearance of books from Sterling Memorial Library.

LONDON, Feb. 7--Britain tonight was believed to have made a bid for a five-year "breathing spell" on the Palestine problem by submitting a compromise version of the Morrison plan to the delegates of the Arab League and representatives of the Zionists.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Fleet Admiral Chester W. Nimitz today told a YWCA luncheon called for the purpose of starting a $2,000,000 Round-the-World Reconstruction Drive that this nation must never again disarm in the hope that other countries would then follow our example.

PARIS, Feb. 7 -- Schiaparelli's amusing and stimulating collection is replete with novel ideas. With black tailored suits there appear light-as-air hats in white or pastel horsehair, shirred or fluted, on which pose roses or wings.

The New York City public school system will experiment this semester with a new course for training students to establish and operate their own businesses, in an effort to develop individual initiative and to instil America's traditional principles of free economic enterprise.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Metropolitan Chicago would send three more Representatives to Congress under a redistricting plan approved today by the Illinois Congressional delegation.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 7 --Regulations to prevent "uneconomic competition" between North Sea and English Channel ports will have to be established and a special agency may be required to administer them, Sir Osborne Mance, British delegate to the United Nations Transport and Communications Commission, declared today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Please allow me to congratulate you upon your splendid editorial of Feb. 4 advocating that New York State spend $400,000,000 for low-rental housing for veterans instead of spending it on a bonus. I heard much favorable comment on the editorial in our office, and our national administrative committee at its regular meeting Tuesday night unanimously passed a resolution commending THE TIMES for this clearsighted and constructive proposal.

While a declining price trend in this country may cut American purchases of some types of merchandise abroad, it will have little effect on European markets, where lack of production and shortages will maintain prices there at a high level, according to Samuel Shapiro, president of the Smart Set Glove Company.

On the heaviest volume of business since early last December, the stock market broke through yesterday to new high levels of the current upswing as prices moved forward from 1 to approximately 4 points. The return of motors and steels as the prime instruments of strength, and a fresh surge in the rails produced a lively final hour when one-third of the day's volume took place.

The local FM (Frequency Modulation) radio broadcasting station whose signal was reported to have interfered with radio reception in commercial airliners using La Guardia Field was identified yesterday by the Civil Aeronautics Administration as station WGYN, in lower Manhattan.

Weather Checks Trade Here Bad weather proved a major handicap to retail trade here this week. Estimates, however, put volume at somewhat above last year, with a gain of 5 to 10 per cent held likely for department stores.

It will be three strikes and out for the rest of the milers if Gilbert Dodds runs away from the pack again in the Boston A.A.'s Hunter Mile at the Boston Garden tonight. With another romp by the Flying Parson he -- and the spotlight -- probably will shift to two and three-mile races in forthcoming meets.

Reflecting both increased sales and a larger margin of profits, the net income of the American Woolen Company, Inc., and its subsidiary rose last year to $20,098,178 from $8,301,140 earned in 1945, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

A new plan whereby the banks, factors and contract holders directly involved in the reorganization of Motty Eitingon, Inc., will supply between $1,000,000 and $1,500,000 in funds was presented yesterday at the meeting of creditors held at the United States Court House.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Fortyeight generals who served with distinction in World War II were nominated today by President Truman as general officers in the Officer Reserve Corps.

Asserting that the diverse elements that elected Franklin D. Roosevelt President had split and that the Democratic party was without national leadership, Thomas J. Curran, Secretary of State of New York, declared last night that what the American people needed was a President with executive ability to bring order out of chaos in Washington.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- President Truman recommended to Congress today that Federal revenue laws be amended to include the United Nations among approved entities to which benificences could be given without making the donor liable to a gift tax.

PEIPING, China, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Escorted by two United States Marine planes and with twenty Marbie guards aboard the train, the first party of Americans from, the disbanding executive headquarters safely reached the sea today and boarded ship for home.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Real disarmament cannot be accomplished until the international control of atomic energy and the great issues of peace-making have been solved, Secretary of State George C. Marshall warned today in his first news conference since he took office.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- As a demonstration against the increase in divorce and marital infidelity, hundreds of thousands of Roman Catholics throughout the country plan to renew their nuptial vows on March 12, it was made known here today.

Unless educators turn their attention to the task of educating America's adults in internationalism within the next ten or fifteen years, this nation faces a debacle in its civilization, Dr. Alain Locke, Professor of Philosophy at Howard University, declared yesterday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 -- Heavy buying continued on the Board of Trade today with all deliveries of wheat and lard selling at new seasonal high marks, the March delivery of wheat and No. 2 hard winter selling at new highs since 1920.

LITTLE AMERICA, Feb. 6 (Delayed) (AP) -- A Mariner plane of the expedition's Western Group has discovered a new bay in an exploratory flight over the Knox Coast area of Wilkes Land, nearly 2,000 miles west of Little America, Admiral Byrd announced today.

Alfred Hirsch, Palestine industrialist and refugee from Nazi Germany, died on Thursday night of a cerebral hemorrhage in his room in the Hotel Mayflower. His death occurred after he had received news that his residence on Mount Carmel, Haifa, had been seized by British soldiers who evicted his son and daughter, according to his brother-in-law's wife, Mrs. Kurt M. Stern, 815 Park Avenue.

PARIS, Feb. 7 -- At a meeting of the inner cabinet tonight, there was a discussion of the second step in the campaign for lower prices, which Premier Paul Ramadier is expected to explain in a broadcast to the nation after a meeting of the full Cabinet tomorrow morning.

Efforts to reconcile the divergent attitudes of the United States and the Soviet Union on the conditions under which a United Nations Disarmament Commission should be established collapsed yesterday, thereby dealing a serious blow to the prospects for international regulation and reduction of armaments, and control of atomic energy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- National security demands preservation of a synthetic rubber industry in the United States, President Truman told Congress today. He asked for a year's continuance of existing controls on allocations of rubber, as well as legislation in the present session of Congress to maintain the synthetic industry.
MOSCOW, Feb. 7 -- The violation of labor laws, including thousands of hours of unregistered overtime, was charged today in Trud, labor union newspaper.

Greeted as a soldier, as a statesman and reminded at almost every turn of his Irish birth, Field Marshal Viscount Alexander, Governor General of Canada, received yesterday a civic, military and cultural welcome to the City of New York.

Consumer Credit Legislation Now that the bill to permit banks an interest rate of 12 per cent or a flat fee of $5 on the discounting on individual dealers' commercial paper has been introduced in the State Senate, as well as in the Assembly, bankers here expect the legislation will be approved finally within two weeks.

Documents from German naval archives which have been released simultaneously by our Navy Department and the British Admiralty show that in January, 1943, when the German retreats had begun on all fronts, Hitler signed a directive ordering the decommissioning of the heavy surface ships of the German Navy, and on Feb. 13 a decommissioning schedule for thirteen ships was issued.

Charity will share in 40 per cent of the $3,000,000 estate left by Otto Sussman, chairman of the board of the American Metals Company, Ltd., who died last Monday, according to his will, which was filed for probate yesterday.

Modern Heavy Villain Even after the newspaper PM's change of heart on the subject of advertising, the world apparently must continue to reckon with that well-known social menace, that hideous manifestation of human nature at its worst, the advertiser.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 7 (AP) -- An official announcement said today the British Army had completed the compulsory evacuation of British women and children from Palestine.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Feb. 7 -- Citing him for "outstanding service to higher education," the northeast district of the American College Public Relations Association presented its annual Fair banks award to Governor Dewey today.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 7 -- When the tariff bargaining conference of United Nations' projected International Trade Organization assembles in Geneva in April, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg will be represented by a single delegation, it was learned today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 7 -- An "almost clean sweep by anti-Communist forces" in the election conducted by the Marine Firemen, Oilers, Watertenders and Wipers Association, an independent union, was forecast today by Vincent J. Malone, president, on the basis of a count of 2,450 of the 4,444 ballots cast.

Ruling that Rocky Graziano, East Side middleweight and the outstanding challenger for the championship in his class, "was guilty of an act detrimental to the interests of boxing" when he failed to report $100,000 offers to fix two bouts, the State Athletic Commission yesterday revoked Graziano's license as a fighter, effective immediately.

Stores to Increase Ad Budgets Department and specialty stores will increase expenditures for business promotion this year, it was predicted yesterday by Howard P. Abrahams, manager of the sales promotion division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department reported today that the cold wave which hit the South this week damaged truck crops and citrus fruits in Florida.

Schocken Books reports that Max Brod has prepared the complete works of Franz Kafka for publication in ten volumes, the first five in the original German and the others in English. The German version is now off the press. Volume I, containing all the short stories that Kafka published, is being translated by Edwin Muri and will be issued in the fall.

PARIS, Feb. 7 -- Vice Admiral Georges Thierry d'Argenlieu, High Commissioner for Indo-China, was believed tonight to have tendered his resignation to the French Government which has called him back to Paris to report.

Efforts of commercial bankers to formulate a "model credit schedule" as a substitute for consumer credit Regulation W have now been discontinued, it was learned yesterday. The banks, it is understood, are planning to make no move until the matter comes before Congress, at which time, request will be made for a hearing so that arguments against continuance of the regulation may be presented.
Dr. Abraham Stone, a pioneer in the field of birth control and planned parenthood, called yesterday for increased marital counseling services and intensified research into marriage problems.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 7 -- The first report of the secretariat of the Inter-Allied Reparations Agency was made public here today. In it Nigel Sutton, secretarygeneral, has written sharply: "There seems to be no overruling reason why the practical provisions of the Potsdam Declaration relating to reparations should be discarded in their entirety pending attainment of the objective of German economic unity."

ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. 7 (AP) -- With last year's winners on the sidelines, the heavily favored team of Mrs. Mildred Didrikson Zaharias and Gerald Walker led the way today into the semi-finals of the Florida mixed two-ball open golf tournament.

For two months the question of portal-to-portal pay has been a major factor in labor-management relations, owing to the filing of portal-pay suits totaling nearly $5,000,000,000 by various unions. Yesterday in Detroit Federal Court a decision was handed down that may have decisive effect on the portal problem.

It is to be assumed that the weather was responsible yesterday afternoon for the comparatively small audience that heard the performance at Town Hall by the Mendelssohn Club of Philadelphia, Harold W. Gilbert director, of Gabriel Pierne's oratorio, "La Croisade des Enfants."

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 8 (AP)-- Syracuse University enhanced its chances tonight for the Allie Seelbach Trophy, emblematic of upState New York basketball supremacy, with a 45-to-40 victory over Canisius.

Arguments for and against a ten-cent fare will be expressed by 285 speakers before the Board of Estimate in City Hall beginning at 10:30 A.M. tomorrow, Mrs. Hilda Schwartz, secretary of the board, announced yesterday.
MANCHESTER, Vt., Feb. 8-- Ideal conditions brought thousands of skiers today to this historic Vermont ski-land, the slopes and trails of Big Bromley and Snow Valley.

In a thrilling game with the outcome in doubt until the last precious second was ticked off Fordham's sterling basketball team defeated Columbia, leader in the Eastern Intercollegiate League, 56 to 55, before a packed audience in the Lions' gymnasium last night.

The Department of Parks has been carrying on confidential negotiations with a group of saddle horse owners with a view to erecting a stable in Central Park to accommodate 300 horses at a cost of $2,166 a stall, it became known yesterday.

ATHENS, Feb. 8 -- Panayotis Canellopoulos, acting Minister of Public Order, advised army and police chiefs in Athens today that the Government had banned all demonstrations for tomorrow. The Leftist Eam had previously declared it would hold mass meetings despite any possible ban, but later statements indicated it had reversed its decision.

To the Drama Editor: WHILE I was general manager and director of the municipal theatres at Leipzig and Frankfort, I produced all the more important plays by Eugene O'Neill. My production of "Strange Interlude," which is surely a very long play, became-- owing to the cuts I made--a regular evening's performance.

GARDENERS who dream of strolling along behind a power lawn mower this summer, while a green sward sleek as velvet is turned out under foot, may have to prolong their aspirations a bit. Power mowers are as difficult to obtain as new cars.

Secretary General Trygve Lie used his powers as chief officer of the United Nations yesterday in a direct appeal to a ruffled Greek Government for postponement of the execution of a group of convicted guerrillas.

PARIS, Feb. 8--Negotiations in London between French, British, Netherland and American oil companies, with regard to a proposed accord regarding oil operations in Saudi Arabia, have encountered important difficulties, according to well-informed sources here.

The incorporation at wartime safety developments has planned an important role in the reconversion of the Moore-McCormack liner Argentina to peacetime status, it was disclosed yesterday by officials of the Bethlehem Steel Company's shipbuilding division, which is handling the work.

THE frosting and trimmings of this novel are excellently done. Mrs. Birch dissects a certain segment of society composed of landed gentry and London flat dweller with considerable skill. Her pictures of week-end house parties at the home of a woman who collects "china -- distinguished authors and promising young men who promised almost anything" are satiric and successful.

"THE QUARRY" is obviously not a first novel. Working her way through six previously published works, Mildred Walker has eliminated verbal clutter to such an extent that "The Quarry" reads without a jar, a roll or a quiver.

FEW of the more memorable war souvenirs are still in the hands of hunters, having found their way into museums beside the important war documents. The original copies of the German and Japanese surrender documents, for example, are safely ensconced in the National Archives, and the Japanese surrender chair, table and cloth are on "indefinite loan" to the Naval Academy Museum, Annapolis, Md.

Approval of three rental housing projects for Dumont, N.J., was announced yesterday by Warren J. Lockwood, New Jersey State director of the Federal Housing Administration, which will insure the mortgages. The three projects are designed to accommodate 150 war veterans and their families.

The stock market in the short session yesterday extended the gains established on Friday, with prices generally at the highest levels since last September. Trading on the Stock Exchange expanded to the largest volume for any Saturday since Feb. 16, last year.

THOUGH Mrs. Tim isn't blessed with as engaging a name as Miss Buncle, she belongs definitely to the same school of Stevenson characters. She is right as a trivet on all fundamentals, but pleasantly feather-headed and gay about trivialities.

ROME, Feb. 8 -- The imminent signature of the Italian peace treaty in Paris gave rise to great demonstrations in the Constituent Assembly today in favor of the retention of Trieste and the restoration of the Italian Army, Navy and Air Force.

HAWTHORNE, Calif., Feb. 8-- The power of one of the Army's biggest bombers, the tailless Flying Wing, designed to carry five tons of bombs ten thousand miles, is being nearly tripled by the application of jet propulsion, the Northrop Aircraft Company and the Air Forces disclosed today.

LONDON, Feb. 8--A charge that United States authorities in Germany were permitting a White Russian committee of Fascists to carry on subversive activities was made today before Foreign Ministers deputies for Germany.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, IndoChina, Feb. 6 (Delayed)--A successor to the sacred white elephant of the God Indra has been found. This is a more important event in this ancient kingdom of Cambodia today than the bloody fighting raging elsewhere in French Indo-China.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 8--El Lobo, a field horse, ran to a wellraced victory over sixteen rivals today in the $50,000 added San Antonio Handicap and established himself as a strong contender for the $100,000 Santa Anita Handicap.

The stock market managed last week to by-pass the previous resistance level--an area in which the list had been befogged more than a month. The character of the leadership in terms of issues was outstanding, particularly in the motors, but trading nevertheless remained almost purely professional in that the change-over from an all-cash basis of dealings to a 75 per cent marginal rule failed to attract public participation.

Trust institutions are planning to intensify their efforts to obtain wider adoption of the "prudentman rule" for investments, plus broader powers of distribution, according to informed banking spokesmen. Because of current uncertainties regarding the purchasing power of the dollar, the project was a principal topic of discussion among executives attending the Mid-Winter Trust Conference of the American Bankers Association, which held its sessions here last week.

DETROIT, Feb. 8 -- Federal Judge Frank A. Picard dismissed in their entirety today the claims of employes of the Mount Clemens Pottery Company to walking time and make - ready - for - work pay. His decision struck hard at portalto-portal pay suits totaling about $5,000,000,000 filed against American industry.

Not even the largest cyclotron, which weighs 5,000 tons, can compete with the cosmic rays in splitting atoms. But it is hard to harness the cosmic rays. By the time they reach the earth they are so weak that, though they can be detected at the bottom of a deep lake or a deep mine, it is rarely that they smash atoms.

THE popular edition of the staff of life--the sliced loaf of soft white bread you find at the grocer's--has been under fire from divers quarters lately as being anything but a sustainer of strength or supplier of satisfaction.
LONDON. "WHAT fun it is," somebody said to me when the curtain fell on the first-night performance of "Born Yesterday" at the Garrick Theatre, "to see a really good American comedy again."

ALBANY, Feb. 8--Mayor William O'Dwyer's fight with Gov. Thomas E. Dewey to get more State money for the operation of New York City's government, which reaches its first climactic stage next week, is a renewal of a long-standing conflict between city and State.

BERLIN, Feb. 8--Students of Berlin University have just concluded the election of a student council in an atmosphere reminiscent of similar elections in the United States in the early Thirties. The results were a strong slap in the face for the Soviet-controlled faculty administration.

The annual report of J.I. Kislak, Inc., Jersey City realty company, emphasizes the continued high level of activity in the realty market in that area, with all branches of the business setting new high marks during the past year.

THE happy statement in these columns a few weeks ago that the opening of the spring season was gradually being moved farther and farther forward in order to avoid congestion now appears to have been embarrassingly naive.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 8 (AP)-- J.O. Hart's consistent gelding Angle Bar won the featured Reserve Purse at the Fair Grounds today. With Jockey Don West aboard, Angle Bar withstood a late bid by H. Forrest's Plover Brand, who finished strong in second place, Mrs. J.S. Letellier's Uncle Mac was third.

LAUGHTER and wisdom rise from these folktales from West Africa, skillfully retold by a specialist in folklore and an anthropologist. Those who know the Negro's rich humor will not, of course, be surprised by this, but they will be amazed at the ease with which primitive people spin parables on such abstractions as time and sleep, or juggle possibility and probability against certainty as in "The Messenger to Maftam."

NANKING, China, Feb. 8--Lieut. Gen. Hisao Tani protested in court today that he was not receiving a fair trial on charges resulting from the infamous Japanese "rape of Nanking." He accused the six-man Chinese military tribunal of intentionally linking general evidence of atrocities with the specific South Gate area that his division garrisoned for one week.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 8--Herman Talmadge alleged today that Judge Claude Porter of the Superior Court, in yesterday's decision holding that Mr. Talmadge's election to the governorship was invalid, violated all "existing legal precedents"; that it was written in advance of a hearing, and that the suit upon which the decision was based was "patently collusive."
ROME, Feb. 8--An editorial today in L'Osservatore Romano termed the treaties with Axis satellites as unjust, illogical and lacking in common sense.

IT is clear that the growing pains of our justly famous American orchestras, even the oldest of them, the New York Philharmonic-Symphony, are not at an end. The unfortunate altercation between Dr. Rodzinski and the management and directors of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society, which has resulted in the sudden and complete severance of their relations, points up this fact.

TO THE EDITOR: Under the heading "Personalities" you recently ran a photograph showing Prince Michael and "a clown" dressed as a hobo during a performance of London's Olympia Circus. Such anonymity is depressing, a fabulous error of omission, a gargantuan display of indifference, an unbespangled and uncaparisoned blot on your reportorial escutcheon.

Miss Maureen Ruttle, 23-yearold British girl golf champion, who is also the current French titlist, tees off tomorrow in the 18-hole qualifying round for the championship of Palm Beach over the historic course of the Palm Beach Golf Club.

A unique bid by a labor leader for public favor was made yesterday by James C. Petrillo, head of the musicians, with an announcement that his entire canned music fund, now over the $2,000,000 mark, would be used to promote musical culture.

NEW YORK'S human elect were once numbered at Four Hundred. The Dogs' Social Register, which is the American Kennel Club's list, admits more than a hundred different breeds to aristocratic standing and these will be represented by 2,500odd individual aristocrats when the Westminster Kennel Club's Seventy-first Annual Show takes over Madison Square Garden on Wednesday and Thursday of this week.

NOW that flying to and from Europe has become almost commonplace, the time is ripe to evaluate the sociological and cultural aspects of such travel. The following facts were elicited from a study made by Pan American World Airways after ferrying 32,000 passengers across the Atlantic since October, 1945:

TORONTO, Feb. 8 (AP)--The Toronto Maple Leafs jumped into an early 3-0 lead and then matched goals with Boston the rest of the way to trounce the Bruins 5--2 tonight in a National Hockey League contest. The triumph, largely engineered by rookies, snapped a seven-game Toronto losing streak and enabled the second -place Leafs to stay within five points of Montreal.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Feb. 8 --Urging a minimum annual salary of $2,400 for all teachers, speakers at the closing session of the district conference of the American College Public Relations Association, agreed that demands from teachers and college instructors for higher pay were justified.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP)-- Senator Kenneth McKellar, Democrat, of Tennessee, presented two witnesses today who testified that David E. Lilienthal campaigned actively for the chairmanship of the Atomic Energy Commission despite his avowal that he did his "damnedest" to avoid the assignment.

EAST LANSING, Mien., Feb. 8 (AP)--A. record 517-man field of the nation's finest college track and field stars rewrote the books in the twenty-fifth Michigan State relays tonight by eclipsing twelve records in the big indoor carnival's eighteen events.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8--Housewives may expect higher retail prices for some meats soon as a result of advanced wholesale prices and higher costs of livestock because of bad weather, stockyards spokesmen said today.

The thirty-ninth running of the Paumonok Handicap will feature the opening day of the Metropolitan Jockey Club's meeting at Jamaica on Saturday, April 5, according to the stake schedule released yesterday by SecretaryHandicapper John B. Campbell.

The Legislature has suceeded in knitting together the 14,000,000 people of the State into a modified united nations because the Government has sought to fulfill their aspirations, Oswald D. Heck. Speaker of the State Assembly, told the Albany Society of New York last night.

IN "Juno and the Paycock" it was old Captain Boyle who intermittently would say, "The world is in a state of chassis." It might have been the architect, Frederick J. Kiesler. For, Mr. Kiesler believes, after a catastrophic event such as the one we recently have been through, the condition of man is in a state of chassis--that is, in a state of chaos, confusion and mobility.

The deep woods, with their fish and game, Indians, guides and "sports" will crowd Grand Central Palace once more, for the tenth annual Sportsmen's Show will open its doors at noon next Saturday for a nine-day run.

FOR Lincoln scholarship the present year has unusual significance. The Lincoln papers in the Library of Congress, long withheld from investigators, are to be opened in July, 1947. These papers constitute a voluminous collection; there are more than a hundred cases of them.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 8-- Harvard's basketball team avenged an early season loss to Princeton tonight, downing the Tigers, 50--40, in Baker Rink before a capacity crowd of 3,000.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Feb. 9 (AP) --Fala, the black Scottie who was Franklin D. Roosevelt's inseparable companion, has contributed to the Roosevelt library the "Fala Papers," a whimsical collection of letters, Christmas cards and gifts sent to the dog while his address was the White House, Washington, D.C.

WASHINGTON -- For the first time since the end of the war passports to Europe will be granted to tourists who are solely on pleasure bent, according to a State Department ruling. The 1947 traveler need no longer prove to the Passport Division that he is going abroad for business reasons or is planning to visit relatives.

WITH BYRD EXPEDITION in Antarcticia, Feb. 8--Four Thousand Americans, of whom a large percentage will intimately be associated with the defense of this nation for many years to come, have been going to a unique school.

Private builders throughout the nation will erect 1,000,000 homes this year if materials are available in sufficient quantities and the supply of skilled labor remains adequate, according to the National Association of Home Builders.

PUBLIC interest in color photography and its use of the medium increased sharply during the past year, reports Glenn E. Matthews, technical editor, Kodak Research Laboratories, in the leading article of the first issue of the newly revised and enlarged PSA Journal, official publication of the Photographic Society of America.

CLAUDE JARMAN JR. was still "in school" when the reporter called on the young movie star the other afternoon. The teacher declared a recess to permit the introduction and, as the reporter went off into a corner of the hotel room to quietly while away the next ten minutes of school, Claude and his teacher turned to a new arithmetical problem.
RECITALS of various styles are on the week's calendar, and the Ballet Rusee de Monte Carlo opens its season at the City Center next Sunday evening. The complete schedule follows: Today
LONDON, Feb 8 (AP)--Western Europe dug out of a long blizzard tonight, but in Britain the paralyzing storms continued with new snow and in Moscow sub-zero temperatures prevailed.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Our present national income is estimated at nearly three times the national income immediately after World War I. In the face of the huge national debt no effort should be spared to maintain the present national income in order to carry the debt burden.

LONDON, Feb. 8 (Reuters) -- Sharply-cut attendance figures, cancellation of some pools because of the unusually large number of postponed games, and players sliding and slithering on treacherous snow-frozen grounds combined to make this the bleakest professional soccer schedule in nearly a decade.

This is the biggest dog show week of the year, in some ways the biggest in several years. The Westminster Kennal Club show in Madison Square Garden Wednesday and Thursday dominates everything, of course, as it always does, but it just can't get any bigger because of one important factor --space.

BOSTON, Feb. 8--It was, and yet was not, a runaway for Gilbert Dodds tonight. The Flying Parson, in another fast-time race, won the Hunter Mile to lead a parade of favorites in the fifty-eighth annual indoor track and field games of the Boston Athletic Association.

PARIS, Feb. 8--The French National Assembly has called for financial statements from all nationalized enterprises--an action seen in certain business and industrial circles today as an indication that the nationalization program has run into its first definite snag.

Offsetting complaints to motorists' organizations that passengercar brakes had been frozen during cold weather in this area was a report yesterday by the Society of Automotive Engineers on brake fluids. The S.A.E. predicted that motor vehicles would benefit from liquids more adaptable to operating conditions and compounded with greater resistance to corrosion and temperature changes ranging from 60 degrees below zero to 140 above.

Soviet authorities are returning so many gift parcels here because they do not conform to conditions laid down for their entry that Postmaster Albert Goldman announced yesterday procedures governing their acceptance in the future.

VIENNA, Feb. 8--The Allied Council for Austria agreed early this morning to disagree on the draft of the report requested by the Foreign Ministers' deputies in London on displaced persons in Austria and Austria's demilitarization. This meeting followed a session of the Council's executive committee, which sat until 3:15 o'clock Wednesday morning seeking, with a similar lack of success, to achieve unanimity.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8 (U.P.)--The American Football League, a minor affiliate of the National League, plans to expand from eight to fourteen teams for the 1947 season, President Joe Rosentover of Clifton, N.J., said today after a oneday meeting with Secretary Robert Ross of Jersey City.

LONDON, Feb. 8--The economic crisis confronting Britain has created a dilemma for the Labor Government. It is hard to see how its difficulties are to be resolved without creating a split in the Cabinet itself and widening the difference between the Government and the trade unions which are its principal support--except by a decision to avoid a decision.

THE Last of the major football coaching vacancies in the East have been filled with the signing of Paul Bixler by Colgate and of Hooks Mylin by New York University. The only big college posts now untenanted are at Ohio State, where Bixler pulled tip stakes, and California.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 8 --The new law for mobilization of Czechoslovak labor will contain a definite provision for the punishment of those who will not work on the jobs assigned to them, a study of the measure disclosed today. The bill received Cabinet approval yesterday.

A large-scale housing program designed to end the problems of the white collar worker in New York State and institute a program that will be followed in other States will be presented to the Legislature within the next thirty days. This was revealed yesterday by State Senator MacNeil Mitchell, chairman of the joint Legislative Committee on Housing and Multiple Dwellings.

More than 2,500 new singlefamily houses and 4,000 additional rentable apartment units will be needed throughout Eastern Suffolk County this year, according to a survey made by E.P. Dalmasse of Patchogue, real estate economist and appraiser, and his associated brokers.

It is typical of any winter that there should be a mixture of weather, bright days and dark ones, snow and ice and thaws, warmth as well as cold. And spring is always slow in coming, and seems even slower. That is the price we pay for living in a latitude with four well-marked seasons.

I HOPE this letter finds you in whatever Elysium has been reserved for your sprightly shade You will be delighted to hear that although fashions in crime have changed, reactions to your raffish crew of characters have not.

Until the statute of limitations runs against the filing of claims for relief under the excess profits tax law., which tax was repealed in 1946, there will be a keen interest in new rulings and tax court decisions under Section 722 of the Internal Revenue Code.

THE only sculpture exhibition of the week was of portraits by Ethel Hood at the Argent Gallery. Miss Hood's work has been frequently singled out in group shows and the dozen examples currently on view bear out the excellent impression made by her occasional pieces.
DOUBLE ACE-- Ten years to the day after he shot a hole-in-one at a Great Barrington, Mass., golf course, George R. McCormick went out on the same course and shot a hole-in-one on the same hole.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Feb. 8-- Big blond Harry Todd of Dallas emerged from the gathering dusk today with a par-shattering 34, 29--63 to take the lead at the halfway mark in the $10,000 Texas open golf tournament with a thirty -six-hole total of 129 strokes.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 8--The fight between two American labor organizations for world-wide supremacy will be intensified as the result of a program worked out by leaders of the American Federation of Labor who met here last week.

The United Nations Human Rights Commission, after some brisk exchanges of views, has set up a committee to write the draft of an international Bill of Rights, and report next June. The Commission's discussions during the past few days have shown how difficult it is, not only to reconcile the policies of Western-style and Communist or Eastern-style societies but to determine just how international action can define and protect individual freedom.
To the Drama Editor: MURRAY SCHUMACH's excellent article, "Censorship Battle Is On Now," in last Sunday's TIMES, was both timely and vital.

ARTHUR JUDSON, one of the central figures in the dispute between the Philharmonic -Symphony Society and Artur Rodzinski, is a man the public knows little about, despite the fact that he has been one of the leading figures in the music business since he became manager of the Philadelphia Orchestra in 1915.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--After three years of preoccupation elsewhere, our military leaders have again become interested in Alaska. Here it is that the Army is conducting high-priority experiments in Arctic warfare. Here it is that the Navy plans to spend millions to strengthen its bases.
WARSAW, Feb. 8--A Polish spokesman revealed to the United States and Britain today the terms on which they could have a full understanding and friendship with this country.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (Science Service) -- Another light metal, titanium, may soon join aluminum and magnesium in the construction field.

ABOARD MOUNT OLYMPUS, in the Ross Sea, Feb. 7 (Delayed) --Radio communication facilities at the Little America airstrip have been completed and five of the Douglas transports are ready for exploratory flights as soon as weather permits, a report to this ship said tonight.

BERLIN. IN spite--or perhaps because --of the grimness of life in Germany these days, there exists a sort of heavy humor focused almost exclusively on the economic and political condition in which Germans, to their still considerable surprise, find themselves.

FIGURES coming through on operations for the first month of the year, which has been so widely advertised as likely to parallel 1920, do not throw too much light on probable developments. Prices have continued to recede on foods, inventories in general are still rising and industrial purchasing agents have become more conservative.

The proposed International Trade Organization carries within its preliminary Charter a code of international statutes that may govern the conduct of international traders for many years to come, foreign trade leaders pointed out last week.

ROME, Feb. 8--Premier Aloide de Gasperi's third Cabinet, announced on Sunday, suffers from the same weakness as his two preceding ones, namely, that it contains such fundamentally hostile elements as Communists and Christian Democrats.

New York Adverse weather affected retail trade here adversely last week. It was held probable, however, that dollar volume was somewhat ahead of last year. The increase for department stores for the week ended Feb. 8 was put at 5 to 10 per cent, which would mean a drop in unit turnover of merchandise.
