PROBABLY the most widely practiced bidding convention in contract bridge has been the takeout double. It was originally developed in auction bridge about thirty-five years ago, for the same purpose it serves in contract bridge; to show a strong hand after an opponent has opened the bidding, and to force partner to bid his best suit in response.

JAN CIECHANOWSKI, the Polish Ambassador in Washington from 1941 to 1945, has written a quick and bitter memoir about Poland's relations with the Big Three during the war. It has the striking and poignant title of "Defeat in Victory," and the title accurately sums up the author's point of view.

With many millions of dollars in a "protective discount cushion" at stake, retailers are strongly pushing their fight against the reduction or elimination of traditional trade discounts by action of manufacturers. Close to 100 leading manufacturers have now changed their discount terms, a move which got under way during the war period and has increased since.

THE eleven-day period beginning with Lincoln's Birthday, Wednesday, Feb. 12, and extending through Washington's Birthday, Saturday, Feb. 22, again this year will be devoted to WNYC's eighth annual American Music Festival.

William Williams, New York lawyer, who was a former United States Commissioner of Immigration at Ellis Island, died yesterday afternoon in his room in the University Club, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street, where he had lived since 1899.

ON March 3, the 100th anniversary of enactment by Congress of legislation authorizing the use of postage stamps, the Postoffice Department will disclose details regarding the special postal paper to be issued in connection with the Centenary International Philatelic Exhibition which will be held in the Grand Central Palace here on May 17-25.

EVERYTHING with the Amercan Water Color Society appears to be going on as usual. The eightieth annual is a large show, filling all of the galleries at the National Academy. It contains close to 350 papers, slightly more than half of them by members, the rest having been admitted by a huge jury on which fourteen artists served.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 8 (AP)--The Seton Hall College basketball team went down to its second defeat within six days tonight as Holy Cross came from behind within three and one-half minutes of the final whistle to whip the Pirates, 44--43, before a capacity crowd of 5,000.

IN "The Color of the Country" Barbara Webster has written a warm, sensitive book about life and living. It is essentially a book of sketches about living in the country, but it might be classified as a loose narrative dealing with the lives of three people, Mady, Nick, her husband, and T, their small son.

With large reserves of surplus funds still available for suitable investment outlets and with a lower return offered by Government bonds and other prime securities, mortgage money is flowing into Manhattan real estate in increasing amounts at attractive rates.
Harold L. Ickes, former Secretary of the Interior, called last night for a more liberalized immigration policy by the United States.

Act II in a comedy of errors was played out in the absence of an audience yesterday as immigration agents took into custody stowaway number eleven from the Italian liner Saturnia. The scene took place in front of the Criminal Courts Building, 100 Centre Street.

THE official motto of the State of Georgia is "wisdom, justice, moderation." It seems to be subject to occasional repeal, but the lapses are regarded by Georgians with a tolerant philosophy based on long experience.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 8 (AP)--J. Vincent Reardon, 58, and 13-year-old Michael A. D'Arcy were dead tonight as a result of a series of tragic circumstances involving Mr. Reardon's 14-year-old daughter, Mary.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Many thoughtful citizens are considerably disturbed over certain aspects of the present movement for world government, by which term is meant a "real" government like our own for the whole world, with executive, legislative and judicial authorities elected by the people, or appointed, its laws being applicable to the individual.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska -- The airplane is throwing a lot of Alaskan dog teams and their drivers out of work. In time it may reduce them to the status of museum pieces and put them alongside the sidewheeler of the Mississippi and Ohio Rivers and the covered wagon.

Cognizant of the trend toward a revival of store brands, manufacturers of nationally advertised hosiery girded themselves for the forthcoming battle to maintain their position in the competitive picture, it was learned last week. Not only will they be faced with the private brand moves of large buying groups, it was indicated, but with the expressed desire of independent retailers to resume sales of products carrying their own private labels.

COLGATE--Public Welfare Featuring field trips to selected agencies in Albany and central New York, "Problems in Public Welfare" will be introduced into the Colgate University curriculum with the cooperation of the State Department of Public Welfare during the second semester Just starting.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 8--The main residential areas of Jerusalem were converted into fortresses today. No one was allowed to leave or enter without a special pass.

Appendix 3 of the First Report of the U.N. Atomic Commission indicates roughly how we spent more than two billions up to January, 1946, on the atomic bomb--the first statement of account that has thus far been presented to the nation and the world. Oak Ridge, with its three U-235 plants, cost about a billion, Hanford about $362,000,000 and the bomb laboratory at Los Alamos what seems by comparison a paltry $60,000,000.

THE United States Army continues to provide musical opportunities in Europe for young American conductors in uniform of a type they cannot get in their own country in civilian clothes. Tech. Sgt. Gibson Morrissey, a veteran of the Thirtyfourth Infantry Division and a former Juilliard student, is the latest case in point.

TOKYO, Feb. 8--Gen. Douglas MacArthur moved this week to provide a parliamentary safety valve for political unrest in Japan which has been boiling steadily since last fall with a series of strikes, demonstrations and abortive attempts to remake the Government of Premier Shigeru Yoshida.

Assistant Professor of History, Princeton University. EVER since the end of the war, frantic attempts have been made by the most inveterate opponents of the policies of President Roosevelt to propagate a new mythology.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--Few contests for the Presidency will have enjoyed so conspicuous and so extended a preliminary warmup as that to be decided in 1948. Historians of the period must record that the race began in earnest on Nov. 5, 1946, in the first palpitant flush of the Republicans' astonishing off-year victory.

As the membership of the United States Power Squadrons skyrockets to new record heights, there is one small fly in the ointment. The women-folk increase their complaints in direct ratio to the increase in these yachting activities.

IN all the myriad books about Abraham Lincoln none has ever dramatized so clearly as this the fact that Lincoln as a man, a character, a person, an individual is more interesting than Lincoln as the moat awesomely epochal of American Presidents. That fact, of course, is inherent in Carl Sandburg's six-volume life of Lincoln.

TOLEDO, Feb. 8--The decision in the Mount Clemens Pottery Company case will be appealed to the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals at Cincinnati, Edward Lamb, attorney for the Mount Clemens workers, said today.

THE confluence of good people and bad people, thrown together and lacking all possible avenues of understanding, common language, common reasoning, common dreams and desires, always brings about a condition of accelerated reaction.

A few weeks ago we mentioned that a bill would be introduced in Washington calling for the, registration of all firearms other than shotguns and .22 caliber rifles. This bill, tagged "S 332," was put in the national mill on Jan. 24 by Senator Wiley of Wisconsin.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 8--Wes Fesler, who lifted the University of Pittsburgh's football out of the doldrums last fall, today was officially offered the job as head gridiron coach at Ohio State, whece he won All-America honors at end in 1929 and 1930.

To the Screen Editor: WILL you please tell me if the Barbara StanwyckRobert Cummings portrayal of American parenthood in the picture "The Bride Wore Boots" is intended to inspire admiration for the home life of the American in the hearts of the British public.

The Labor Government's order temporarily shutting off electricity to most of industrial England has brought Britain to the gravest domestic crisis she has faced in the last twenty years. Four million men will be thrown out of work. Imports vital to the daily life of the people will sag dangerously.

DETROIT, Feb. 8 (AP)--Following is the text of the opinion handed down today by Judge FranK A. Picard in the Mount Clemens Pottery Company portalto-portal pay case: Because of the interest and discussion that this case has stimulated, we deem it advisable to give a brief history of its developments which finally resulted in necessity for this court's present determination.

Like the Assyrians, Egyptians, Greeks and Romans, the ancient Mayans of Central America developed a series of cultures. One of the oldest is found in Guatemala, specifically at Zaculeu in Guatemala. Here, with the support of the Government of Guatemala and the United Fruit Company, John Dimick, aided by archaeologists Dr. A.V. Kidder, a Carnegie Institution of Washington expert, and Stanley H. Boggs has directed excavations and restorations with exciting results.
GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Feb. 8 (AP)--Young David Louis Ruge, his humiliating "ape face" a thing of the distasteful past, is setting out confidently look the world in the eye.

Secretary of State George C. Marshall culminated on Friday a week of deadlock in the United Nations "disarmament" discussions by re-emphasizing that political security and control of atomic energy are necessary precedents to reduction of armaments.

MADRID, Feb. 8--Spanish political circles have been watching with keen interest the latest trends in United States relations with Argentina. American Ambassador George S. Messersmith's return to Buenos Aires and his cordial reception there have aroused a little apprehension in Madrid, lest more amity between Argentina and the United States weaken Argentina's vigorous support of the Franco regime.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--The Congress has been asked to establish a "Veterans' Reconstruction Finance Corporation" as a part of the national housing and employment program, Louis E. Starr, Commander in Chief, Veterans of Foreign Wars of the United States, stated yesterday.

An idle remark by a burglary suspect set the police on the trail of the slayers of Detective James Burke, shot in a hold-up of a Bronx liquor store Dec. 13, District Attorney Samuel J. Foley said yesterday.

In an actiion-jammed match that saw the winners rattle nine goals off the backboard in the second half, A1 Parsells' Ramapo Polo Club of Tallmans, N. Y., staged a great comeback to defeat the 15goal New York Athletic Club trio, 13 to 11, in the main attraction of the indoor double-header at the Squadron A Armory last night.

With the Moscow Conference one month off, it is apparent now that it will be a difficult affair, sure to involve issues of national politics and international ideology on a large scale. It is not to be expected that, even taking into account the preliminary work of the Big Four Foreign Ministers' deputies, it will write a German treaty. Those who are optimists hope that it will make a good beginning.

IN May of 1942, Little, Brown published a volume of ten stories by Miss Mary Lavin, an American-born writer (the author of "The House in Clewe Street") who lives at Bective, an estate in County Meath. One of these stories was called "At Sallygap," the title story of the book under review, just published by Little, Brown.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Feb. 8 --Thomas Alva Edison's roll-top office desk, sealed after he died on Oct. 18, 1931, was opened in his Lakeside Avenue library here this afternoon before members of his family and distinguished friends and co-workers.

People in Austria, Poland and Greece are too hungry to wait through the transition period between the end of UNRRA operations and the negotiation of the unilateral relief loans which will be the American substitute. This is the gist of the statement made in Washington on Friday by Maj. Gen. Lowell W. Rooks, UNRRA's present head.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8--Snow storms and the cold wave again reduced department stores sales as volume for the current week declined to last year's levels, estimates in the Chicago area indicated. Clearance sales continued in women's wear and accessories, while special promotions in men's items were limited mainly to hats and overcoats.

WASHINGTON. THE premise of this article is that freedom and prosperity in other parts of the world are essential to our own prosperity and to peace; that idle and hungry men are not the allies of democracy but the instruments of tyranny; that the economic peace is inseparable from the political peace; and that while almost everybody agrees with all this in theory, there is considerable opposition to putting it into practice.

In an analysis of housing measures introduced in the current session of the State Legislature, the committee on housing of the Community Service Society announced yesterday that it had approved seventeen of the measures and was opposing five others.

The peak has been reached in farm prices, which now are on the way down, according to V.A. Miehls, vice president of the Strout Realty Agency, who bases his conclusions on information received from about 550 associates of the company in thirty States.

IN reading "Detour," it becomes evident all over again that this was the war which the largest number of women in our history didn't sit out at home. This was the first one in which they followed the armed forces as far as they could, shared the physical as well as the emotional disruption of the men in the camps and talked the same idiom.

The philosophy of Abraham Lincoln is needed to effect a "rebirth of freedom in a nation under God," Rabbi Samuel M. Segal said in a sermon in Mount Neboh Temple, 130 West Seventy-ninth Street, yesterday.
MANHATTAN, Kan., Feb. 8 (AP) --President Milton Eisenhower today announced the appointment of Sam Francis, former Nebraska

PARENTS have come in for an awful beating since the advent of the "new psychology," according to Nina Ridenour, Ph.D. "Parents to Blame for Children's Behavior," "Parents, Not Children, Are Delinquent; Should Be in Jail," are examples of headlines this psychologist quotes in a paper just published in the New York State Journal of Medicine.
LONDON, Feb. 8--The industrial paralysis that the coal cuts are forcing will last fully a week instead of the three or four days hoped for yesterday.

Croft, president of the National Foremen's Institute, disclosed in an interview last week.

A Nassau County tract of land fronting on the new Bethpage State Parkway, near Farmingdale, L.I., has been purchased by the Hempstead Land Improvement Corporation, Jerry Leibowitz, president, for improvement with about 200 new homes, it was announced yesterday.

"THE Greatest Story Ever Told" is a program of extraordinary beauty and reverence, which without reservation may be listed as one of the most significant ethereal achievements in recent years. Each Sunday evening at 6:30 over the American Network (WJZ) it tells the parables of the New Testament and reasserts the eternal truths with a dignity and humility which make listening to the radio a genuine privilege.

THE urge to band together is one of the deepest instincts of gregarious man. Inevitably this urge must produce some uncommon manifestations, such as the organization in Great Britain not long ago of the Society for the Suppression of Family Interference.

SET in what seems to be an imaginary independent state, on the west coast of what is now Mexico, during the nineteenth century. "The Rod and the Staff" deals with an ambitious and profound theme: armed uprising versus passive resistance as a weapon against exploitation.

DARMSTADT, Germany, Feb. 8 (AP)--Queen Victoria's great grandson ate a meal of watery soup from a tin pail today and counted himself luckier than most of the 11,240 former Nazis in a prison camp here.

PARIS. TO the post-war newcomer Europe one of the most amazing things is the f comeback that music made. Concerts were being ganized almost before the last g had cooled, and even today recovery of musical life in western Europe seems to be several steps ahead of general reconstruction.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Feb. 8 (AP)--Following is the text of Senator Vandenberg's address tonight before the Michigan Republican Convention: I am happy to greet the militant, forward-looking, forwardmarching Republicans of Michigan at a moment of both triumph and dedication.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 8-- Belgium is still ahead in the wildest poker game in Europe.

THERE is something in angling which provokes a host of its partisans and practitioners to write about it. Most of them write very badly indeed, with enthusiasm running lengths ahead of talent. Only rarely does marked literary skill combine with sound knowledge and rich experience to produce a really good angling book, but Roderick Haig-Brown's "A River Never Sleeps" is just that.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed strong yesterday with prices 22 to 45 points higher than on Friday. Starting 8 to 19 points up, it pressed into new high ground for the current move. The advance was spurred by commission house buying in all months and continued buying of near months by trade shorts.

School study of historical backgrounds and customs of racial and religious groups, if carried to the home and community, would help to eliminate prejudices in these fields, according to pupils who participated yesterday in the Youth Forum, sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast over Station WQXR.

HOLLYWOOD, recently a fallow area for independent film producing companies, has sprouted another addition to that producing crop, it was learned last week. The newcomer is Marshall Grant Productions, of which Marshall Grant and Charles Haas are president and vice president, respectively, with William D. Saltiel, a Chicago attorney, as chairman of the board.

Recognizing the importance of sound labor-management relations in the economic life of this country, increasing numbers of colleges and universities throughout the United States now offer a wide variety of courses in workers' education on the undergraduate and graduate levels.
MOSCOW, Feb. 8--Complete independence is the only solution for the Palestine problem, Izvestia, the Government newspaper, asserted today.

GAINESVILLE, Fla., Feb. 8-- Universal support of liberals and the United Nations as the means of opposing the doctrines of the Fascist, and particularly the clerical Fascist, was called for here today by Morris S. Lazaron, Rabbi Emeritus of the Baltimore Hebrew Congregation.

THE other day this department was told of a well-known American poet -- I am not at liberty to use his name -- who recently wrote in a letter to a friend that he has decided to abandon poetry; first, because it seems to him to have no place in a world dominated by science, and, second, because contemporary critics have failed to set up standards as guideposts.

GARDENERS who anticipate spring by starting seed indoors, or in hotbeds and coldframes, find that the market offers numerous devices to make this work easier. Several of the newer items are worth using, both from the standpoint of convenience and for the production of healthier and sturdier seedlings.

SUPPLEMENTING the Hogarth -Constable-Turner exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum, the John Nicholson Gallery is exhibiting landscapes by Constable, Gainsborough, Bonington and others--examples recently obtained from English private collections by Mr. Nicholson.

FOR an analysis of the political situation in Georgia you had better not bother to read further here. But one thing we can tell you is that all that internecine politics isn't hurting the sales of Ellis G. Arnall's book, "The Shore Dimly Seen."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--Documents showing that Adolf Hitler plotted wars of aggression at least as early as November, 1937, almost two years before the attack on Poland, were published tonight by the War Department. These were contained in the sixth of an eightvolume series containing evidence collected by the United States and British prosecuting staffs in Nuremberg.
BOSTON, Feb 8--The political revolt in Central Falls, R.I., which stemmed from four veterans who came back from the war to help make their post-war world a brighter place, has proved to be no fluke.

CERTAIN general equipment is essential for the making of any garden, whether the space is to be planted largely with flowers or vegetables or divided fairly evenly between them. A few tools are indispensable and certain accessories also fall into this class.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 8-- Navy played a brilliant second-half game to beat Rutgers in basketball, 61--48, but the visitors from New Brunswick showed spectacular strength in swimming to defeat the Middle tankmen, 57--18, today.

"WHAT was China really like?" That conventional greeting to returned travelers, has cooled many a friendship. Travelers wearily play the worn record; listeners, eyes glazed, often wish they had never asked in the first place.

A program to stimulate interest in classical studies among high school graduates is being undertaken by Radcliffe College with the distribution to secondary school students, teachers and principals of a booklet describing the advantages of a classical education.

SO little is known about so much of Russia that Mr. Lauterbach's travel notes take on the color of adventure and exploration. By emphasizing strikes and shortages instead of the new production miracle America has achieved in the post-war period, some correspondents of European newspapers in the United States are giving Europe a distorted picture of this country, Dr. B Ohlin, chief Opposition leader of the Swedish Parliament, said yesterday.

Seventy-two houses now under construction or planned soon will mark the completion of the Clarendon Hills community at River Edge, N.J., Charles H. Reis, the builder, announced yesterday. About twenty of these dwellings, now open for inspection, are scheduled to be ready for occupancy by March 1 or April 1 and the remainder will be completed later in the spring.

HEARING FLAWS-- H.E. Van ValKenburgh, General Electric engineer, has made it possible to "see" through metal with sounds so high in pitch that they cannot be heard. Thus it becomes possible to detect internal flaws in some cases even more effectively than with X-rays.

THE desire to take off for a short holiday at the fag end of the winter season accounts for considerable travel activity at present. While cruise ships are fewer than formerly, there are still many trips that can be made by boat.

READERS of "We Ride a White Donkey" know that George Panetta has a talent for verbal caricatures and a mimic's command of Italianized English. His compatriots in Bleecker Street, along with Irish and Jewish people, are in for it again in this extravaganza about a little boy's utter confusion in a crazy world.

MONTREAL. PLANS for the development of a motion picture industry in Canada have been gathering momentum in recent months. The chief developments are the establishment of three major motion picture companies: Quebec Productions Corporation, Montreal; Dominion Productions Ltd., Toronto, and an as yet unnamed company set up under the direction of Joseph De Seve, head of Renaissance Film locally.

TONIGHT another brave idea will be launched--the Experimental Theatre, which gets going in the little Princess playshop on Thirty-ninth Street just off the Avenue of the Americas. In the light of what has been happening to brave ideas lately it can be hopefully observed that at press time virtually all of the 1,500 subscriptions had been taken, thereby insuring this initial season's program of five plays.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Feb. 8-- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, president pro tempore of the Senate and chairman of its Foreign Relations Committee, told the Republican State Convention in its keynote address here today that the United States will not make concessions on the atomic bomb until a foolproof system of control is in operation.

With a heavy arrival of out-oftown buyers expected tomorrow, summer ready-to-wear lines were opened last week, according to a market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.

Fielding Wright should convene a special session of the Legislature to rescind all State primary statutes and thus transform political parties into private clubs that could bar Negroes from primary voting.

Ives warned last night against a partisan approach to labor legislation by Congress.

H.D.G. Crerar, Commander in Chief of the Canadian Army during the recent war, in a speech delivered this evening to the Canadian Artillery Association.

The American Heart Association will open National Heart Week tomorrow, mindful that St. Valentine's Day falls within the week, to emphasize the fight the association is making through research and education against the nation's number one killer--heart disease.

Todd Shipyards Corporation's Brooklyn Division is rebuilding the Spanish Line's Habana as a passenger vessel in accordance with the highest American standards of safety, rather than along the more ornate, tile-mosaic style of conventional Spanish design, John D. Reilly, president, disclosed yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 8--While the Columbiana Handicap, with its $10,000 in added money, had the place of honor on Hialeah Park's program today, the big attraction for the crowd of 20,067 that bet $1,299,221 was a $5,000 overnight race in which the Calumet Farm's great Armed made his second 1947 start.
Plans for the construction of a new wing to the Museum of Modern Art were announced yesterday by John Hay Whitney, chairman of the board of trustees.

ONE of the few reassuring aspects of post-war Europe is the resurgence of Italian intellectual and cultural activity. That activity combines the Renaissance and the Risorgimento --the quest for new forms of expression with the search for freedom, political and economic.

THURLOW WEED, the most powerful State boss New York politics ever produced, was the first American to put lobbying on a scientific basis. A man of strong views, one of the founders of the Republican party, he never permitted principle to stand in the way of personal advantage or party fortune.

THROUGH the eyes of scores of Army Air Forces combat correspondents, who managed to stay articulate in an atmosphere that numbed, here is a report on what it was like around the "atoll circuit" of the Central Pacific. The subtitle calls it a saga, hinting at glorious deeds.

In spite of apparently "irreconcilable" differences between the United States and Russia concerning an international program for disarmament and atomic control, the nations of the world are now nearer to real security and disarmament "than we have ever been before," Warren R. Austin, United States representative to the United Nations, declared here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Congressional proponents of legislation to prohibit or drastically restrict portal-to-portal wage suits reiterated their determination to push their bills today, despite Judge Frank A. Picard's dismissal of the Mount Clemens case.

Columbia graduates will hold their fortieth annual Alumni Day reunion on Wednesday on the Morningside Heights campus of the university, Walter D. Fletcher, chairman of the alumni day commitee, announced yesterday.

O. MAX GARDNER: On Feb. 6, in New York, age 65. Lawyer, manufacturer, adviser to Presidents. Native of North Carolina, he became Governor of the State and later was Undersecretary of the Treasury. He died a few hours before he was to board the S.S. America on his way to take up his new post as Ambassador to the Court of St. James's.

PARIS, Feb. 8--French officials announced today that the Big Four had ruled out any declarations by delegations during the signing of the five Axis satellite treaties Monday. This ruling changed the plans of former enemy delegates who had prepared to read statements of protest before they signed and also of several other countries that have faults to find with the treaty texts.

NEWARK, N. J., Feb. 8--The Bethpage Polo Club of Long Island captured the New York Athletic Club's first post-war polo tournament tonight by defeating the Essex Troop of Newark, 12 to 8, in a bristling final contest at Essex Troop Armory.

Heart diseases are the leading cause of death. And the deaths have increased 400 per cent since 1900. Despite such statistics there has never been enough money available for scientific research and education--the only hope of holding the mounting toll in check.

Frederick W. Logan, a baseball clubhouse custodian who spent fifty-seven years working for the New York Giants and New York Yankees, died in his home here yesterday after a long illness. His age was 67.

CHRISTIANITY today in its many churches is united for the building of a better world for all peoples. The papers in this book, prepared at the request of the Joint Commission on Social Reconstruction of the Protestant Episcopal Church, are another indication that this is so.

Prints and drawings of European and American schools, Part Two of the collection of Mrs. George Martin of Cleveland, now on exhibition at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, will be auctioned tomorrow and Tuesday evenings.

MOSCOW, Feb. 8--The United States Embassy has sent an official note to the Soviet Ministry of Foreign Affairs asking for a considerable increase in the original Soviet quota by which twenty American correspondents will be admitted to Moscow to cover the March meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 8--A fourmonth battle by American Federation of Labor teamsters to gain control of a Western Pennsylvania segment of the United Brewery Workers, Congress of Industrial Organizations, punctuated with thirteen bombings, has branched out into four new phases.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--Howard C. Petersen, Assistant Secretary of War, in a broadcast tonight over a National Broadcasting Company network said that the indictment of the five German industrialists "marks our first step to bring to justice German industrial and financial leaders." He added that "they are indicted for inhumane treatment that violated The Hague Regulations, the Geneva Convention and the laws and customs of war."

MILWAUKEE, Feb. 8--Local 248, United Auto Workers, CIO, gained a majority today in a recount of ballots cast Jan. 26 in a State election on bargaining agent for the strikebound Allis-Chalmers plant in West Allis.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--Republican policy on tariffs and taxes was further rent today as Senator Robert A. Taft, voiced disagreement with other leaders on both subjects.
HERE is a novel strangely like a letter from home telling what has happened to neighbors whom one has never met. It makes no effort to attract the reader, whose concern is taken for granted.

Words, Words, Words The trouble in the New York Philharmonic Orchestra comes as a fresh reminder of how badly the English language needs an adjective to describe a man who has resigned a high office, or for that matter any job whatever.

WELL - INTENTIONED and sincere, Mr. Bowker is handing out, for civilians who haven't caught on, the real word on what makes the veteran tick. Formerly a guiding hand in Army Orientation, the author has all the answers.

HOLLYWOOD. HOLLYWOOD'S long-standing desire to import the plays of George Bernard Shaw for film purposes was fulfilled last week when Gabriel Pascal, Shaw's official cinematic interpreter, closed a deal to make two Shaw films here in conjunction with Artists Alliance, the Mary Pickford-Lester Cowan producing company, which will release the pictures through United Artists.

New Yorkers, commuters and visiting firemen drop nickels into the city's transit system's turnstiles at the rate of 2,500,000,000 ($125,000,000) a year. This is triple the passenger volume of all other American railroads combined. Yet the rapid transit system (240 miles of subways and Els) has been running deeper and deeper into the red--this year the deficit is $76,000,000.

PONCHIELLI'S "La Gioconda," which will be presented at the Metropolitan Opera House on Wednesday night, will be the twenty-fifth work this season. Unless another work is given unexpectedly, it will be the last opera to be added to the repertoire for the current season, which has only five more weeks to run.

ANNUALS classed as tender, or those requiring a long season between seed and garden-sized plant, can be started indoors this month. Some are difficult to find at the florist's at planting time. Others are quite expensive if large numbers are needed.

PARIS, Feb. 8--French officials have paid due attention to the advice of The Times of London to negotiate with President Ho Chi Minh of the Viet Nam Republic-- which has all along been the advice of the French Communist party--and to the statement of Secretary of State George C. Marshall yesterday that he hoped for early settlement in Indo-China.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Feb. 8-- Officials at Notre Dame University announced today that sale of tickets for the Notre Dame-Army football game at South Bend Nov. 8 will be restricted to certain groups.

THE third program in the series, "Flowers for Your Garden," given at Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, will be held on Wednesday at 2:30 P.M. and again at 8 P.M. "Bulbs for Radiant Bloom" is the subject, and Harvey Gray and Margaret Herbst are the speakers.

After dropping five decisions in a row, the New York Knickerbockers last night easily defeated the Toronto Huskies, 69--46, in a Basketball Association of America contest at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory before 3,559.

THE State is . . ., the State was . . ., the State is becoming . . ., the State will be . . ., the State won't be . . ., the State ought to be. Such are the problems that are treated by fifty-four twentiethcentury writers, representative of nine different countries, "physicians assembled here in clinic" with "faith in an ultimate redemption of the institutional State."
WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 8-- Fighting off Yale's dangerous second-half rally, the Army basketball team defeated the Elis, 48--43, today for its eighth victory in ten starts.

THE Greeks invented the saga of the labyrinth, the cleverly arranged maze in which intruders got lost and were eaten, in the end, by a monster god, the Minotaur. If memory serves, the hero of the Greek version, Theseus, was given a thread by Ariadne, killed the Minotaur and finally found his way out.

The initial announcement of the first drive for funds to cover a full calendar year's need will be mailed this week by the Protestant Fund of Greater New York, Inc., to 12,000 previous contributors to its constituents plus an added list of from 5,000 to 8,000 business prospects, according to an announcement yesterday.

TAIYUAN, Shansi, China, Feb. 3 (Delayed)--In the Province of Shansi today the last of the oldstyle warlords, "model" Gov. Yen Hsi-shan is fighting a unique but losing war against the Communists on the one hand and against the encroaching power of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's Central Government on the other.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: An interesting feature of the armed forces unification proposal which has been sponsored by President Truman is its impact upon the Presidential Succession Act of 1886.
The heaviest snowfall of the year coated the metropolitan area yesterday with a white blanket ranging from 6.1 inches here to ten inches at Dobbs Ferry.
PARIS, Feb. 8 -- The Government's control of credit will be used against merchants who hoard stocks and thus prevent a drop in prices, Premier Paul Ramadier told the French in a radio speech tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--A recommendation was reached tentatively at a meeting today of a committee of the press with Michael J. McDermott, press relations representative of the State Department, that priority be granted to American newspapers desiring to assign correspondents to the peace conference of the Council of Foreign Ministers in Moscow next month on the basis of the coverage they gave the peace conferences of the Council in New York and Paris last year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--The task of slashing President Truman's $37,500,000,000 budget sufficiently to permit a 20 per cent reduction in personal income taxes looms increasingly large in the eyes of many responsible Republicans in Congress.

JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 8--Projection of the doctrine of increased rights for the Negro in the South, which has impinged explosively upon the political life of this State in recent weeks, can be seen in many daily incidents reflecting varying degrees of support.

New York City was confronted yesterday with the threat of a strike by Local 46 of the Metallic Lathers, American Federation of Labor, which may halt or seriously cripple most major building activity on and after Feb. 17.

A RECENT traffic accident, in which two pedestrians were injured when a motorist in New York City suffered a heart attack and died at the wheel of his car, has caused representatives of the National Safety Council and the National Conservation Bureau to stress anew the need for periodic physical examination of drivers.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 8--Ken Henry, a smooth-stroking 18-yearold speed skater from Chicago, today qualified for a place on the 1948 United States Olympics skating team by touring his second 5,000-meter trial in 9 minutes 33.6 seconds to lead a field of fifteen.

Financiers here believe that the investment market will absorb a "prudent aggregate" of dollar bond borrowings of Western European nations if the borrowers can show that they have lived up to their financial obligations in the past and that they are now perceptibly restoring national economies to peace-time equilibrium.
LONDON, Feb. 8--The Arab delegates to the Palestine conference met today and rejected in toto Britain's proposal for a compromise of the Arab-Zionist problem in the Holy Land.

AMINIATURE camera combining both the reflex and the eye-level principles of subject-finder, the Swissmade Bolsey 35mm Reflex is now available. Believed to be the only miniature camera permitting both ground glass, waist-level focusing and range-finder focusing, the Bolsey incorporates a number of novel features.

BOTH in subject-matter and in method there could hardly have been wider divergence in the water-colors shown last week. Mane-Katz has returned from Palestine and is showing recent gouaches--still expressionist but more controlled than of yore --at the American British Art Center.

GARDEN tools are more plentiful in the stores than they have been for five years. Not only are most of the old kinds of tools back again in quantity but also some new inplements are on the shelves, and there begin to be signs of new trends in tools.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 8--Bets were being laid on the West Coast this week as to whether those Toonerville Trolleys, which have been climbing over San Francisco's hills since the Eighteen Seventies, really would be junked during the next few years.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Feb. 8--Friedrich Flick, largest private German iron and steel manufacturer, and four associates were indicted today by the United States Military Government for war crimes and crimes against humanity on "a vast scale."

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Feb. 8 (AP) -- Charles P. Brinton, national squash champion and top-seeded player, advanced to the semi-final round of the first invitational squash racquets tournament today at the Plainfield Country Club.

FIFTEEN years ago this week in this Review: Out on P. 1 was a review of "The Germans," by George N. Shuster, who "does not let his readers forget that the struggle of the Reich for its soul is no matter of indifference to the rest of the world."

OF the established popular writer of our time--the writers, that is, whose main contributions are to the big magazines and to the movies--MacKinlay Kantor is surely one of the most attractive. Never pretending to be more than he is-- a gifted and practiced storyteller --he has knowingly produced his full share of that artful blend of sentiment and melodrama which makes up the large part of our popular fiction.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP)-- Evidence that Communist schools are operating in Detroit and other large cities has been obtained by the House Committee on UnAmerican Activities from a former Communist party organizer.

Nearly $9,000,000 worth of men's shoes including about 1,750,000 pairs of unused fine black calf Navy oxfords priced from $3.25 to $4.05 per pair, will be offered concurrently to priority, commercial and export buyers Feb. 17 through the New York office of the War Assets Administration.

John Haynes Holmes, in a sermon celebrating his fortieth year as minister to one congregation, said yesterday that he had survived for so long a period because of the "loyalty and forbearance" of that congregation, which supported him during two world wars despite his well-known pacifist views.

Wilson Brothers, manufacturers of men's wear, had in 1946 the highest earnings in twenty years, according to the annual report for last year just issued by Eugene J. Hynes, chairman, and George C. Layman, president.

ATHENS, Feb. 9--The execution of three guerrillas on Friday night, which was officially announced today, is interpreted by the Left-Wing press as the Government's defiance of the Security Council's orders and its contravention of the wishes of the United Nations' Commission of Inquiry.

SYOSSET, L.I., Feb. 9 -- The North Shore is to have a summer theatre again, the first since the war, if plans of Miss Kosalie Dill Jones, owner of the Farm and Barn that would be used, and Miss Kathryn Lambert, who is to produce the ten weeks of plays, are carried out.

Allen B. Gellman, president of the Illinois Watch Case Company, announced yesterday that a milliondollar advertising campaign for "Elgin American" compacts, cigarette cases and dresser sets will be launched immediately. An extensive color advertising campaign in the leading national magazines is being supplemented with large-space newspaper ads in all major marketing areas.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Permit me to refer briefly to the letter of Aladar Szegedy Maszak, the Minister of Hungary, published on Feb. 4 as a reply to my letter which appeared in your issue of Jan. 27.

PARIS, Feb. 9--The two famous salons of the Quai d'Orsay will be opened together for the peace treaty signing ceremonies tomorrow. These ceremonies are expected to continue until well into the evening.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 9 (AP)-- The United States speed-skating team for the 1948 Olympics was completed today when Ray Blum of Nutley, N.J., won the 10,000meter trial and three other skaters, who failed to win qualifying races, were named to the team by the final tryout committee.

Until official reports of the Army Ground Forces are available, probably some months hence, it is impossible to make any flat, definitive statement about the cold weather tests of men and equipment now being concluded in Alaska and the Aleutian Islands beyond observing that the weather is extremely cold.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9--In a preliminary report, a committee of the Association of Stock Exchange firms said today it will recommend a change in the "outmoded and inequitable" schedule of commissions on securities transactions. A four-day meeting of the group closed yesterday.

In a statement issued at the close of last week Republican Senators Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan and Eugene D. Millikin of Colorado announced terms for a proposed truce between the Administration, on the one hand, and their high-tariff colleagues on the other, in the impending war over the reciprocal trade treaties.

MANCHESTER, Vt., Feb. 9-- Flashing the same dynamic style that in the late Nineteen Thirties made him one of the nation's foremost skiers, Charley McLane of the Dartmouth O.C. of New York showed his steel edges to a field of thirty-three in the annual New York City Ski Council's inter-club championship downhill race today.

The first Metropolitan League indoor high-goal polo tournament to be held since 1941 will start Saturday night at Squadron A Armory, Madison Avenue and Ninety-fourth Street, with the Squadron A Black Knights facing Red Bank, it was announced yesterday by Joseph Olmsted of Squadron A and John Clements of Essex Troop.

ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. 9 (U.P.)-- Mrs. Babe Didrikson Zaharias and Gerald Walker, playing the morning round in sleet, outdrove and outputted Miss Polly Riley and Joe Ezar today to win the Florida mixed two-ball golf tournament today, 5 and 4.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9--Grain markets moved up rapidly last week, with wheat in the lead, all deliveries of that grain selling at new seasonal high prices on the Board of Trade. The nearby futures of corn and oats, meanwhile, were at the highest levels since late last October.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Feb. 9 (AP) -- Ed (Porky) Oliver ripped Brackenridge Park's rugged course for seven strokes under par on the final thirty-six holes today to capture the $10,000 Texas open with a total of 265--just one over the record set last year by Ben Hogan.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 9--The Central Trade-Union Council has taken the stand that wage increases now woud be contrary to the workers' interests.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 9 --The about face by Yugoslavia on the signing of the Italian treaty was caused by several factors.

HAIFA, Palestine, Feb. 9--Six hundred and fifty Jewish unauthorized immigrants, less those taken to hospitals, were transhipped tonight from the tiny overcrowded sailing ship in which they had come to Palestine to the ferry Empire Heywood for transfer to Cyprus tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--The Chambers of Commerce throughout the United States are reorganizing this year on a greatly expanded scale a program of personal contact with members of Congress.

Bad weather conditions which prevailed in most of the country last week had little effect on retail business, and buyers visiting in the New York market in great numbers appeared to be optimistic as to business in the near future, according to the reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

Down Our Alleys In its native French or English an alley is defined as a narrow passageway. In many of our older cities it runs through the middle of a block and takes care of the baser sort of persons and traffic that uses the back door.

Acting Police Captain Emanuel Kline, recently appointed to head the juvenile delinquency work for the Four-A and Sixth detective precincts, which include east and west Harlem, said yesterday that "calling these kids, even the guntoters, 'organized gangsters' is still a little ahead of the game."
VIENNA, Feb. 9--What to do with the child refugees from Yugoslavia and Poland in Austria has become a lively issue.

James Forrestal, Secretary of the Navy, and William H. Hastie, Governor of the Virgin Islands, were cited yesterday, together with sixteen other individuals and groups, for outstanding contributions last year to the improvement of race relations in America.
Senator Irving M. Ives declared yesterday that he was "strongly" in favor of a Federal act to prevent discrimination in employment.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Feb. 8 (Delayed) -- The resumption of business with the merged AngloAmerican zone of Germany has become a practical possibility subject to conditions stipulated in an announcement issued this week from headquarters of the AngloAmerican export-import agency in Minden.

DETROIT, Feb. 9 (AP)--Although their late train from Montreal didn't arrive until three hours before game time, a tired Detroit Red Wing hockey team punched in three goals in the first eleven minutes tonight and went ahead to take a National League decision from the New York Rangers, 5 to 2, as 12,953 fans watched Referee George Hayes call sixteen penalties in the rough contest.

BERLIN, Feb. 9--A masquerade ball became a deadly holocaust last night when an estimated 100 to 150 masked merrymakers were burned or trampled to death in a flash fire that swiftly engulfed the Karlslust Dance Hall in the British zone of Berlin.
LONDON, Feb. 9 -- The stock markets here are paying, due attention to the serious economic conditions, with a generally dull tone and restriction of business.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--Scrapping of the National Labor Relations Board in favor of a judicial agency and prohibition of industrywide collective bargaining was recommended today in a study by the Brookings Institution.

For the second time within a fortnight Broadway has received a play of worthy content and interest. By John Patrick, who gave us the poignant comedy, "The Hasty Heart," two winters back, it is "The Story of Mary Surratt," which the Messrs. Russell Lewis and Howard Young brought to Henry Miller's theatre Saturday evening.

The Yong Men's Board of Trade of New York, 291 Broadway, acting as coordinator of the efforts of business and industry, lists the following free services to aid veterans in career-planning and employment.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--President Truman was commended today by Americans for Democratic Action for his stand against rent increases and was urged to veto any bill calling for a rise.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 9--On the basis of revised capacity figures released by the American Iron and Steel Institute, steel ingot output in the country last week remained unchanged from the week before at 93.5 per cent of rated capacity. Had it not been for the gas shortage here and an "outlaw" strike at Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation's Aliquippa plant, the rate might have been slightly higher, it was said.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP)--A State Department plan to send to Russia $35,000,000 of American industrial equipment without requiring actual payment of shipping charges stipulated by Congress came to light today.

PARIS, Feb. 9--Bulgaria, Hungary, Rumania and Finland are not satisfied with the treaties. Diplomats of these nations said in almost every instance that they would continue to seek changes in the conditions brought about by the treaties.

Jacques de Menasce, pianist and composer, and Angel Reyes, violinist, joined forces to present a program of contemporary sonatas at Times Hall last night under the auspices of the League of Composers. The evening's-oldest sonata, written in 1917, was Darius Milhaud's Second for this combination.

The Federal Power Commission received a rebuff at the hand of the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio recently when the latter body handed down what utility circles described as an all-out rate-base victory in favor of the Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company.

ALBANY, Feb. 9--At the request of Mayor William O'Dwyer, bills will be introduced tomorrow to empower New York City to pay into various pension funds the contributions due from veterans of World War II for the period of their war service.

Confusion, discouragement and a sense of doom currently reign in the nation's shipbuilding industry. Governmental economies in original shipbuilding plans, demands for additional taxes and the lack of a definite construction policy for peacetime are contributing to the fast demise of the important industry.

On top of Thomas A. Edison's desk in his Lakeside, N.J., library sits a chestnut-faced electric clock with its hands pointing forever to 3:27. Former Gov. Charles Edison, the inventor's eldest son, who unsealed the desk Saturday, says it stopped on Oct. 18, 1931, at the moment of the morning his father died.

Gilbert Dodds, who has expressed an ardent longing for a crack at Greg Rice's indoor twomile record, will get that opportunity in the New York Athletic Club meet at Madison Square Garden next Saturday. He left it up to Paul Pilgrim to pick his event and the manager of the Winged Foot games reached a decision yesterday.

Final preparation of their arguments for and against the proposed 10-cent transit fare was completed yesterday by more than 300 speakers who expect to appear before the Board of Estimate in public hearings starting at 10:30 o'clock this morning in City Hall.
LONDON, Feb. 9--The coal crisis that has brought Britain to her present critical situation is the result of a long accumulation of unfavorable factors.

SHANGHAI, Monday, Feb. 10-- An anti-American rally winding up in a riot brought one death today and left nine injured in hospitals. The fight highlighted China's grave economic crisis--a crisis that inspired predictions of prompt Government reorganization.

The remaining question in the Mount Clemens Pottery Company case is whether Judge Picard's decision, if upheld by the United States Supreme Court, will reduce the multi-billiondollar flood of so-called portal-to-portal suits to a tolerable and perhaps justifiable trickle.

Following is the text of the statement from Charles P. Gross, chairman of the Board of Transportation, to the Board of Estimate, regarding transit fares: The following statement is submitted for consideration in your hearings to determine action on an increased transit fare.

In the belief that no change in the leadership of Tammany is imminent, despite Mayor O'Dwyer's efforts to put Frank J. Sampson in that post, supporters of Edward V. Loughlin, the present leader, Bert Stand, secretary, and Clarence H. Neal Jr., chairman of the elections committee, are preparing for a series of contests for Assembly district leaderships at the primary election to be held in late August or early September.

The marriage of Miss Betty Augusta Reitman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank H. Reitman of Elizabeth, N.J., to Dr. Ned Weissberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Phylipp Weissberg of Brooklyn, took place here last evening in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Toscanini's performance of the first half of Berlioz's "dramatic symphony," so-called, "Romeo and Juliet," yesterday afternoon in Radio City, added an event of the first artistic magnitude to the annals of the present music season.

For several years a revolution in agriculture has been under way in the Southern States. Its economic and social implications have profound meaning not only for a region but for the nation as a whole. The change began in the years before the war and picked up momentum during the emergency when cotton, tobacco and foodstuffs were urgently needed.

A service of fellowship in observance of Race Relations Sunday was held yesterday in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Attended by 3,000 persons, it was sponsored by the Interracial Fellowship of Greater New York in cooperation with the department of race relations of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America and the Protestant Council of the City of New York.

Behind a front of deceptive elegance, a rare amount of workaday functionalism is concealed in the new Dunbar furniture designed by Edward J. Wormley, which is exhibited this week at Bloomingdale's. A special group of room settings planned by the designer, to be known as the Dunbar Gallery, has been reserved for this collection.

A comparative newcomer to the show ring, Morsel's Bonnie Mae, owned by Morton Rousuck of Cleveland and shown by Walter Key of Indianapolis, was named best of breed at the thirty-ninth annual specialty show of the Boston Terrier Club of New York at the Hotel McAlpin yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The fallacy of Robert Nathan's conclusion that a general 25 per cent wage increase could be granted without increase in prices is best exemplified by the railroad industry.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : In the newspaper reports of the sentencing of a mother for contributing to the delinquency of a 14-year-old son, emphasis is put on the penalty that the Children's Court Act imposes on a parent for neglect in care of a child.

Two forthcoming productions have won what is becoming Broadway's most coveted prize--a theatre to play in. John Gielgud and his British troupe will move into the Royale with "The Importance of Being Earnest" the week of March 3, replacing tour-bound "The Fatal Weakness."

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 9 (AP)-- The Evening Bulletin, which will be 100 years old April 12, published today its first Sunday edition, working only nine days in preparation and overcoming such mechanical difficulties as a pressroom fire.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9--Announcement that Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Pictures and subsidiaries and distributors of Zenith Radio Corporation will enter the recorded music business brought the disclosure today that other movie companies and some publishing houses are considering entering this highly competitive field.

ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein has recommended that State control over insurance rates and policies be broadened and implemented to avert the intervention of the Federal Government into the field of insurance regulations, it was announced today.

LONDON, Monday, Feb. 10--The blackout of power in more than half of industrial England and Wales began at one minute past midnight this morning. As a result, several million British workers must remain idle at least through this week.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 9 --The deadlocked debate on disarmament and atomic control is expected to be temporarily sidestepped this week when the Security Council, in a brief "coolingoff" period, turns to the less contentious issues of Greek guerrillas and Albanian mines.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9 (U.P.)--Max Bentley and Capt. Red Hamill led the Chicago Black Hawks to a hard-fought victory over the Boston Bruins tonight, 6--4, before 19,526 fans, the second largest crowd of the season.

BERLIN, Feb. 9 (U.P)--Paul Markgraft, Police President of Berlin, said tonight that eightyone bodies, including those of eight British soldiers, had been recovered from the Spandau dance hall fire. He said there were bodies in the wreckage and embers, but the weather was near zero and he did not expect more to be dug out tonight.

An unidentified pigeon, apparently disgruntled over the cancellation of a race it had been training for, took to the rafters in the gymnasium of the Madison Square Boys Club, 301 East Twenty-ninth Street, yesterday afternoon and upset the orderly finale of the club's twenty-fifth annual pet show.
The champion Baltimore Americans defeated the Brookhattan F.C., 4--2, in an American Soccer League game at Sterling Oval, the Bronx, yesterday. The visitors led by 1--0 at the change of ends.

Two or three times a winter the clouds drop deep blankets of heavy moist snow. One can almost smell the storm approaching as the gathering stratus and cirrus clouds stitch a gray canvas over the pale blue sky. The thin clouds quickly condense to blackstreaked nimbus and in a matter of hours the large, sticky flakes begin dropping on the waiting land.

With his confidence unimpaired, Mr. Austin, the American delegate to the United Nations, declares that the world is now nearer to real security and disarmament than ever before, that the heart of agreement on both issues as between the East and the West has been reached, and that ultimate agreement is largely a matter of time.
MOSCOW, Feb. 9 -- The vast complicated machinery of the Soviet election system was turned on today to elect candidates of the official "Communist and nonparty people's bloc."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP)-- Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican, of Wisconsin, proposed today a "push-button" emergency government to function by television in case "one atomic flash" should exterminate the President, his Cabinet and Congress.

PARIS, Feb. 9--Legroux breaks away from the current mode of wearing a hat straight on the head. In her collection of extreme elegance, shown this week, hats tilt way up on one side, down on the other. Flat brims widen on the side that tilts upward.
LONDON, Feb. 9--London's subway, bus and trolley fares were increased today, adding u5,800,000 (slightly more than $23,000,000) to the city's bill for public transportation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP)-- Senator Styles Bridges, Republican, of New Hampshire, called today for Senate rejection of David E. Lilienthal as chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, terming the nominee an "extreme leftwinger" and "appeaser of Russia."

A host confronted with a standing rib roast of beef, a porterhouse steak or an arm or round-bone pot roast will find those cuts far simpler to deal with than, say, a leg of lamb or breast of veal. But before their serving is explained, a bit about their preparation.

A TWELVE-YEAR-OLD boy dreaming of the future when he can be his own master and all doors will be open to him knows that he can never be another Henry Morgan, D'Artagnan or Daniel Boone. Piracy, dueling and Indian fighting are no longer practical callings. But adventure and romance are still just as alluring. The airplane is the current symbol for both, and foreign parts still seem glamorous compared with the stale familiarity of home.

PARIS, Feb. 9--The signing in Paris tomorrow of the five treaties that are the first step toward restoring peace after the second World War will mark the first stage of the most laborious settlement in history.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $57,368,158,693. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates on indebtedness, bills and notes as follows: Feb. 18--Discount bills......... $1,313,712,000
Charles Simon has been appointed a vice president of Hearn Wholesale Corporation, subsidiary of Hearn Department Stores, Inc.

Selected paintings by Picasso from the years 1922-37 will be shown at Paul Rosenberg's Gallery beginning today. Other events today include an exhibition of sculpture by Robert Laurent at the Kraushaar Gallery; a show of terra cotta figurines by the versatile dance-mime, Angna Enters, at the Newhouse Gallery; and a show of paintings by Benjamin Kopman at the A.C.A. Gallery.

Costume jewelry prices which have dropped about 25 per cent at wholesale in the last year will level off with the return of white metal to the industry, it was learned yesterday. Manufacturers said, however, that they could not hazard a guess as to when white metal would be released by the Office of Temporary Controls for use in jewelry although various predictions placed the time anywhere from six weeks to six months.

The nickel fare is as old as the city subway system. Its tie-up with municipal and State politics is almost as old. Political reputations have been made and broken on the issue of the fare, and for years it was a political axiom that tinkering with the fare, in New York City, was much more dangerous than larceny.

MOSCOW, Feb. 9--Soviet sources claimed today that the United States and Britain already had taken more than $10,000,000,000 in reparations out of Germany, a sum exceeding the Soviet Union's reparations demands.

The feature of the five treaties scheduled to be signed in Paris today by the ex-enemy states is that they are almost as unsatisfactory to the victors as they are to the vanquished. All the signatories have reservations which they will not be permitted to express at today's ceremony--but so had the drafters when they signed.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (U.P.)-- More than $1,000,000 had dribbled into the Treasury tonight from persons troubled by their conscience, or acting on the legal advice of a lawyer.

After early weakness cotton prices in the domestic market last week turned firmer to close the period at substantially higher levels. At the close on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains for the week of 22 to 115 points, with the greatest gains in the current crop months.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 9--A natural gas crisis, caused by the most severe and prolonged cold wave of the winter, has created one of the worst industrial unemployment situations in this area since the steel strike a year ago.

ALBANY, Feb. 9--Under pressure from the Republican leadership to wind up the current session within the next five weeks, the Legislature is scheduled to take up the question of increasing State aid to municipalities and a number of other controversial subjects this week.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 9 (AP)--The Saranac Lake Bobsled Club, with the veteran Tuffy Latour, a former undertaker, driving, won the senior two-man A.A.U. championship for the second straight year today over the mile course on Mount Van Hoevenberg.

KATONAH, N.Y., Feb. 9--In a sylvan setting at a resort hotel near here on Route 22, fifty-two employes of the Shell Oil Company will start today a three weeks' "basic" training course in the petroleum products business. They will be followed by similar groups every three weeks until the end of the year.
PARIS, Feb. 9--Dr. Rodolfo Llopis tonight announced the formation of a union Cabinet including a wide representation of parties in the new Spanish Government in Exile here.

With 2,000,000 items contributed by 250 exhibitors from all parts of the country, the tenth annual American Hobby Show will open at noon today in Hearn's Auditorium, Fourteenth Street and Fifth Avenue. The show, sponsored by the American Hobby Federation, will continue daily, except Sunday, through Feb. 21. Admission is free.

Three well-organized Harlem gangs and two individuals whose depredations ranged through every major felony classification, according to the police, were in custody last night after a series of raids on poolrooms, bars and hideouts in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Manhattan.

Confronted by the most acute teacher shortage in the history of American education, the nation's public school system faces a serious breakdown. One of every seven teachers today is serving on an emergency, substandard certificate.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Every citizen interested in the position of the United States in world affairs recognizes the importance of reciprocal trade agreements as essential to economic international relations. This program, a flexible and effective instrument by which our tariffs are reduced in return for corresponding concessions from other countries, is presently under strong attack.

Decorative fabric printers in the United States have captured world leadership and their product is in heavy demand in all countries, including those which dominated export markets before the war, it was pointed out last week.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Feb. 5 (Delayed)--Ho Chi Minh, President of the Viet Nam Republic, has stated that his Government would appeal to the United Nations for arbitration if France could not settle the present conflict by peaceful means.

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 9--A milestone in the financial restoration of the Netherlands will be reached on April 1 when trading on the Amsterdam Stock Exchange will be freed from existing fetters by which 50 per cent of the yield of sold domestic securities and 40 per cent of that of foreign securities have been blocked.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--Those who expected the Republican majority of the Eightieth Congress to come out of its corner punching when the bell rang early in January have instead been treated to five weeks of sparring in the center of the ring.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 9-- RKO has signed Loretta Young and borrowed Dana Andrews from Samuel Goldwyn for the leading roles in "Memory of Love," a photoplay which Harriet Parsons will produce and John Cromwell will direct.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls during the period Feb. 1 to 7 are given in the appended tabulation: The House On the Joint Resolution providing

The United States Senate should not ratify the already drafted treaty of peace with Italy "until the other treaties embodying the European settlement, particularly those with Austria and Germany, are negotiated and are placed before the Senate and the American people," Adolf A. Berle Jr., former Assistant Secretary of State, declared in a critique released yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 9-- Virus diseases cannot be adequately controlled until scientists have formulated a better understanding of latent or hidden, infections, says Dr. Karl F. Meyer, epidemiologist at the University of California.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 9-- Negotiators for the Indian Princes and the Constitutent Assembly reached a "general understanding" today on controversial points. This points to the probability that the Princely rulers are prepared to enter the constitution-making process eventually.

The shortage of natural gas in Rockland County reached the critical stage yesterday. More than 2,000 families with gas heat were notified to be prepared to evacuate their homes on a half-hour's notice.

St. Valentine's Day came to the Children's Cardiac Ward at Bellevue yesterday--a bit early but welcome. For an hour seven appreciative boys and two girls munched candy, ate ice cream and talked to their parents. The youngest was 4 and the oldest 12.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 9--The High Commissioner, Lieut. Gen. Sir Alan Cunningham, intimated today to two members of the executive of the Jewish Agency for Palestine that the British administration did not intend to impose martial law on any section of the population now.
Establishment of a provisional government for a Hebrew Republic of Palestine was advocated yesterday by the American League for a Free Palestine.
Despite the reduction by Congress of Maritime Commission appropriations, the Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, L.I., is expected to continue in operation, it was learned yesterday.

The pianist who can present in a single program works of such variety and dimensions as the BachBusoni Toccata in C, the Schubert A flat Impromptu, Op. 90, the Liszt R minor sonata and the Chopin Ballade in G minor, with works by other composers, including his own "Touchpiece"--that is to say, Toccata--has gone far toward the knowledge and technical mastery of certain of the most representative works in piano literature.

The decline in commercial airline passenger revenue that started last fall continued last month, and on the basis of available figures it appears that January, 1947, was one of the worst months, in terms of revenue, in the recent history of commercial aviation.

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 9--Considerable interest has centered in last week's reported fall of the gold stock of the Netherlands Bank by 53,000,000 guilders to a total of 646,000,000 guilders. Both the bank and the Finance Minister refused to explain the cause of this withdrawal.

DETROIT, Feb. 9--Many misapprehensions "growing out of the scarcity of new American automobiles" had to be cleared up during his 50,000 miles of air travel in South America, Europe and the Near East, Serge Daniloff, regional manager-at-large for the Packard Motors Export Corporation, said today on his return.

WITH the pro golfers moving cross country, back to the East Coast, the time is not far off when one of the main events of the entire year will be under way. This is the Masters tournament which will be held at the famous Augusta National Club in Georgia, April 3 to 6.
The genius of Thomas A. Edison was memorialized yesterday, two days before the centenary of his birth.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--Following Judge Frank A. Picard's decision Saturday dismissing the claims of employes in the Mount Clemens Pottery Company case, now classed as the original portal pay suit, the Republican leaders of Congress decided today to give priority to consideration of steps for limiting portal pay actions.
The combination of strong westerly winds and low temperatures kept most New Yorkers close to their firesides yesterday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9--A broad export demand for corn, both from the regular trade and for the Government, combined with a letup in the movement due to unfavorable weather conditions, resulted last week in a rapid advance in that grain on the Board of Trade with futures closing yesterday at gains of 2 1/4 to 2 3/8 cents a bushel for the week.

LONDON, Feb. 9 (AP)--British sports columnist John Batson said today that the United States pulled a fast one on British golfer Dai Rees by substituting Ben Hogan for Byron Nelson in a challenge match in California.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 9 (AP)-- Yvonne Sherman of New York won the senior women's title and Wilhelm Junker of Boston the senior men's crown in the Eastern sectional figure skating meet.

TAIYUAN, Shansi, China, Feb. 4 (Delayed)--Taiyuan is probably the last city in China where one can see a uniformed Japanese officer striding down the street with a Samurai sword on his hip. The streets here are filled with Japanese troops in Chinese uniform and conversely with Chinese soldiers wearing Japanese winter attire.

Unable to buy a rifle because of their youth, nineteen members of a gang called the Rockets obtained the weapon through an adult, it was brought out yesterday in Bronx Magistrate's Court at the arraignment of two of the juvenile gang for the fatal shooting Saturday of a boy, 13 years old.

Hank Greenberg virtually closed out his brilliant baseball-playing career yesterday, The Associated Press said, with an announcement that he had informed the Pittsburgh Pirates that he "was considering retirement from the active playing ranks."

Dr. Frank Aydelotte, a member of the Anglo-American Committee of Inquiry on Palestine, appealed yesterday for the United States to take its share of responsibility in solving the Arab-Zionist problem in the Holy Land.

TRIESTE, Italy, Feb. 9--A tense atmosphere prevailed tonight in Venezia Giulia--most bitterly contested of the world territorial transfers after World War II--on the eve of the Italian peace treaty's signature in Paris.

A long-range program, known as "The University Development Plan," designed "to provide suitably" for Columbia University's present activities and for further growth "commensurate with the widening areas of learning and knowledge," was announced yesterday by Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, acting president of Columbia.

Dissolution of the Committee for Maritime Unity, an alliance of sea unions that represented 214,000 workers when it was formed last May, has been recommended by the organization's executive board, it was announced here yesterday.

Ch. Warlord of Mazelaine, one of the best-known boxers in the United States, added another victory to an impressive list last night when he won the big annual specialty show of the American Boxer Club at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory.

PARIS, Monday, Feb. 10-- Stanoje Simitch, Marshal Tito's Foreign Minister, told this correspondent last night that Yugoslavia would sign the Italian peace treaty today. Thus he dispelled an agitated doubt that had prevailed in the world ever since the final draft was approved in New York.

BROOKFIELD CENTER, Conn., Feb. 9--Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Anne Popenoe, daughter of Mrs. Charles Wyatt Smythe of this community, formerly of Montclair, N.J., and the late Charles Broadwell Popenoe, to David Wainwright Avery, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Byron Ayery Jr. of Aurora, N.Y.

ALBANY, Feb. 10--Roger W. Straus, president of the American Smelting and Refining Company and close personal friend of Governor Dewey, tonight was reported slated for election to one of three vacancies on the Board of Regents, top governing body of the New York State educational system.

Professor of Russian at the University of Chicago, was requested tonight to close its booth at the International Sportsman's Show at the Coliseum here after complaints had been received from some of those attending the show.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10--The Department of Justice was urged today to take "long overdue" action to crack down on what was described as "the Moscow-directed fifth column" operating in the United States.

WALTHAM. Mass., Feb. 10-- Plans for the opening of Brandeis University in the fall of 1948 with a college of liberal arts as a nucleus and with a student body of about 1,000 students were disclosed today during an inspection of the site here.

ATLANTA, Feb. 10--Georgia's Governorship dispute reached the State Supreme Court today in an appeal from a Superior Court judge's ruling that Herman Talmadge was illegally elected by the General Assembly and that the office belongs to Lieut. Gov. M. E. Thompson.

Former Deputy Chief Inspector James F. McGoey died yesterday in Kings County Hospital as the result of injuries received on the night of Feb. 3. when a car operated by a. hit-and-run driver struck him at Avenue M and Twentyninth Street, Brooklyn.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 (AP)--Governor Dewey asked the Senate tonight to confirm reappointment of Secretary of Commerce W. Averell Harriman to the Palisades Interstate Park Commission and appointment of Merritt W. Baldwin, of New York City, to the Veterans Affairs Commission.

BERLIN, Feb. 10 (U.P.)--The toll of dead and missing stood at ninety-one today as police resumed their search for more victims in the ice-covered ruins of the Loebal nightclub which was destroyed by a flash fire Saturday.

A test case to determine the status of veterans under State civil service laws will be instituted in the near future, H. Elliott Kaplan, executive secretary of the Civil Service Reform Association, said yesterday. He spoke at a luncheon meeting of the Women's City Club in the New Weston Hotel, Madison Avenue and Fiftieth Street.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Feb. 10-Two young men were drowned here tonight while skating on Interlaken Lake. They were Norman Robins, 23 years old, 96 Grandview Avenue, Mount Vernpn, a student at New York University and son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph R.Robins, and Leonard Alpert, 22, 180 Wilmot Road, New Rochelle, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry A. Alpert.

Random Notes. There will be some trick shooting at the Sportsmen's Show, which begins its nine-day run at Grand Central Palace on Saturday, but the gun cranks will be gathered at the Fourteenth Regiment Armory in Brooklyn to see some accurate rather than fancy shooting.

When the steamship Marine Porch docks today at Pier 84, North River, with 721 displaced persons aboard, a new life will begin for one of them, Bencyen Szerman, Polish survivor of a Nazi concentration camp.

PARIS, Feb. 10-Revisionism, the avoidance of which has been the express aim of long and complicated diplomatic negotiations, developed today simultaneously with the signing of the treaties with Italy, Rumania, Bulgaria, Hungary and Finland.

Traffic accidents and injuries in the city last week were slightly above a year ago and the number of traffic deaths decreased by thirteen, according to statistics released yesterday by the Safety Bureau of the Police Department. The figures follow:

The stock market was unable yesterday to maintain the forward pace of late last week and lost an average of a point as a result of absorbed profit taking. It was the severest setback to the market in three weeks wilth inroads in key industrial issues of 2 points.
