TO THE EDITOR OF NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial "A Shocking Accident Record" undoubtedly surprised many readers with its revelations of the magnitude of the "traffic accident problem." Let us hope that your call for prompt remedial action will bring good results.

TRIESTE, Feb. 10--The woman who shot Brig. Gen. R. W. M. de Winten, commander of the British Thirteenth Infantry Brigade, in Pola today said she had been enraged by the award of her native city to Yugoslavia under the peace treaty.

Unemployment caused by the shortage of natural gas topped the 200,000 mark yesterday as additional factories were forced to curtail production to make gas available for heating and cooking in States in the East and Middle West.

HERFORD, Germany, Feb. 10-- A careful suvey conducted among the former German prisoners of war recently returned from Britain reveals that 57 per cent of them do not believe that English-type democracy can be introduced successfully into Germany.

A new crisis in the dispute between the New York PhilharmonicSymphony Society and Artur Rodzinski, its resigned musical director, developed last night, and it became almost a certainty that the issue would be fought out in the courts.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 10 --The United Nations may soon adopt a program of wages and allowances based on the somewhat revolutionary principle of "equal standards of living for equal work" instead of "equal pay for equal work." it was learned today.

MOSCOW, Feb. 10--Consultation with the German people on the future organization of the German state and their participation in its creation was called for here today. Exactly one month before the opening of the Council of Foreign Ministers' meeting to discuss the German problem, New Times, influential international review, presented what was by far the most important statement yet to appear here on the solution of that problem.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 10 --A United States resolution instructing the United Nations Balkan Investigation Commission that it was not empowered to ask the Governments of four Balkan countries to postpone the execution of death sentences unless the individuals involved were prospective witnesses before it was adopted by the Security Council here this afternoon.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 10Sylvester Gardiner, 22, Harvard junior and son of former .Governor William Tudor Gardiner of Maine, has been missing since Jan. 23, it was disclosed today as his family asked for a police search.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Feb. 10-- Labor leaders in this Southern industrial center, which estimates its union strength at 30,000 to 50,000 members and serves as a beacon for organized' labor throughout the vast Delta country, are preparing to battle this week in the State Legislature against two pending anti-labor bills that they believe were "slipped over."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10-The most closely guarded secret in the United States after the atomic bomb apparently is the great, sealed deposit of Abraham Lincoln papers in the Library of Congress. At least, that was the conclusion of a prying reporter today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The Government received today an offer of nearly the full original coat of the big inch and little inch pipelines -- a $143,127,000 cash bid by the Texas Eastern Transmission Company of Houston.

Manufacturers of wash dresses, forced to pay at least 50 per cent more for cotton goods, are victims of shortages beyond the control of mill sources, according to Worth Street commission men yesterday.

YONKERS, N. Y. Feb. 10-A bus of the North Broadway- line, while avoiding collision with a moving automobile at Quincy Place, swerved into two parked cars at 5:05 6'clock tonight, damaging all three vehicles and injuring nine persons.

The, spring collection of custommade millinery by Tatiana du Plessix was presented yesterday by Saks Fifth Avenue at the St. Regis. It featured a group of sideslanted sailors with brims of uneven width that dipped shoulderward.

"Operation Crossroads: The Official Pictorial Record," by the Office of the Historian, Joint Task Force 1, has been scheduled for publication by William H. Wise on Saturday. The picture story of the atomic bomb experiment at the Bikini Atoll has a foreword by Admiral W. H. P. Blandy.

LAKE SUCCESS. N. Y., Feb. 10 --"The whole cause of human rights has been advanced" at the first session of the United Nations Human Rights Commission, concluded here today, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, chairman, declared.

CHICAGO. Feb. 10 (AP)-Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follow: HOGS Salable hogs 9.000 head. total 13.500; weights 260 pounds and down steady to 25 cents lower than Friday's average; heavier weights and sows steady: closing moderately active; good

Corporations must present facts and figures on management-labor problems to their local communities, H. G. Batcheller, president, Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation, told the National Association of Dairy Equipment Manufacturers at the Commodore Hotel yesterday.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 10 OF Abraham Teichman, father of Arthur Murray, dancing instructor, died here today at a hotel where he was spending the winter. His age was 83.

LONDON, Feb. 10--Taking the protective measures usual in times of crisis and uncertainty, such as the industrial shutdown now in effect, jobbers marked down share prices substantially in the stock markets today. When it was seen, however, that little actual selling was taking place many of the leaders finished the day above the lowest levels.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- Whether Foreign Secretary Bevin will discuss the standardization of military equipment between Britain and the Soviet Union while he is in Moscow for the Foreign Ministers' conference next month is up to Premier Stalin, the House of Commons was told today.

Donation of a recreation hall to the Police Athletic League's summer camp for boys at Fox Lair in the Adirondacks by Bloomingdale's was announced last night. The department store opened a monthlong celebration of its seventyfifth anniversary at a dinner for 1,000 guests in the store.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 10 --A United States resolution calling for a world conference to establish an intergovernmental shipping organization, to be convened in Europe this autumn, was adopted today without dissent by the United Nations Transport and Communications Commission.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10-- President Truman received the blessing of Greek Orthodox Archbishop Athenagoras and received a certificate for 1,000 trees comprising the Harry S. Truman Grove in the Children's Memorial Forest in Palestine.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10--Adoption by the Federal Communications Commission, at this time, of commercial standards for color television was opposed as premature at the opening here today of hearings before the FCC following the demonstration in New York by the Columbia Broadcasting System of its sequential video system for which it has petitioned immediate commercialization.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP)-- Senator William F. KnoWland, Republican, of California, urged today a Senatorial investigation of surplus property disposal abroad, asserting that goods had been sold to Britain at about one-tenth, of their cost.

Many leading domestic dinnerware manufacturers have notified retailers that prices will be in creased 10 per cent effective with next allotments, buyers disclosed yesterday. The advance, following a "hidden" increase of 18 per cent effected by introduction of new patterns soon after, decontrol, it not resented by most retailers who point out that suppliers were caught in a definite "squeeze" during the entire control period.

Unequivocal support was given in Federal Court yesterday to the contention of Dr. Karl von Klecakowski, Austrian citizen and former German spy, that he furnished valuable information during the war to the United States and in return received a promise of sanctuary in this country.

BERLIN, Feb. 10--A combined report on demilitarization, denazification and other primary objectives of the occupation will be made by the Big Four occupation authorities to the Moscow conference next month, despite earlier reports to the contrary.

Local Promotion for Industry A considerable increase in the amount of space in local newspapers devoted to emphasizing the bond between local industry and the community is noted in a survey on industry's community relations, released yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

PARIS, Feb. 10--Addressing the delegates gathered in the historic Salle de l'Horloge (Clock Room) of the Quai d'Orsay to sign the peace treaties, Foreign Minister) Georges Bidault of France expressed today the hope that the former enemy nations would take their places in a world "forever delivered from war."
The appointment of George S. deMerell as port director of the Charleston facilities of the South Carolina State Ports Authority was announced yesterday by Arthur St. J. Simons, Authority chairman.

Throwing punches from all angles in tireless fashion through ten rounds of slam-bang slugging, Georgie Kochan, Akron, Ohio, heavyweight, last night furnished one of the biggest upsets of recent boxing history when he hammered out a decision over Johnny Colan, Astoria light-heavyweight, in the feature bout at the St. Nicholas Arena.

Open Market Committee Elects As was scarcely unexpected, directors of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York have re-elected Allan Sproul, president of the bank, as a representative of the Federal Reserve Banks on the Federal Open Market Committee, for the year beginning on March 1.

Unorganized New Yorkers virtually ignored the Board of Estimate hearing yesterday at City Hall on the proposed ten-cent subway fare. While representatives of interested groups crowded into the hearing room to express their opinions, the man in the street paid little attention.

A little light has been shed on a darkening picture by the decision of the Indian Princes to negotiate with Congress party leaders on joining the deliberations of the Constituent Assembly. Should they agree to help draft a national Constitution, the Moslems alone would be left in opposition.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Since the cost of the transit system is being given public hearing, might it not be well to consider the other forms of transportation which are subsidized by the city?

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10--The National Power and Light Company and its subsidiary, the Lehigh Valley Transit Company, filed a plan today with the Securities and Exchange Commission designed to rearrange Transit's capital structure and provide, among other things, for the simplification and strengthening of its capital structure and a fair and equitable distribution of voting power among security holders.
BOSTON. Feb. 10 (AP)-Signed contracts of utility infielder Eddie Pellagrini and Rookie Outfielder Sam Mele were received today by the Red Sox.

Bernard Greenhouse, a young cellist of exceptional acquirements and fine musicianship and sincerity, gave his second New York recital last night in Town Hall. Mr. Greenhouse had a large and attentive audience, in which there were many cellists, and he won the approval of this audience by the most substantial means.

Finnish and Swedish-made furniture designed by Alvar Aalto and said to be the first imported here in almost eight years was presented yesterday at the opening of Finsven, Inc., in a small secondfloor showroom at 925 Madison Avenue.

TOKYO, Feb. 10--The prospect of a general election has brought about a series of efforts to force consolidation of the nation's party set-up. This, in effect, will divide the electorate formally into the already existing conservative and radical groups.

Solution of many of the country's reconversion problems can be found by taking a leaf from Thomas A. Edison's biography, Frank M. Tait, who began working for the inventor in 1893, told more than 1,000 representatives from the electric and gas industry yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP)-- Mrs. Martha Evans told a military court today she received some of the Hesse crown jewels from Col. Jack W. Durant in a London hotel while working for the United Nations and brought them into the United States for him under her diplomatic immunity from customs examination.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 - County Judge J. Gordon Flannery of Dutchess County was nominated tonight by Governor Dewey for the Supreme Court vacancy in the Ninth Judicial District resulting from the death of Raymond E. Aldrich of Poughkeepsie. Judge Flannery has been county judge of Dutchess since 1931.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10--Terroristic activities of the Polish underground movement have been totally inspired by the belief that war is imminent between the Soviet Union and the Western Allies, said Josef Winiewicz, the new Polish Ambassador, at his first press conference here today. As this belief has shrunk, following the progress of the United Nations and other pacific factors, he said, the underground in Poland has dwindled.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 10-Under colors for the first time since last November at Jamaica-and with the weather here not a great deal warmer than it was there thenWalter S. Home's 4-year-old gelding: Skylighter scored a nose victory today in the $4,000 Flagler purse at Hialeah Park.

A ten-cent subway fare would aid materially in avoiding the annual financial crises that "have so bad an effect upon the city's credit and the market for its securities," it was argued on behalf of a higher subway fare yesterday before the Board of Estimate.
ALBANY, Feb. 10-A proposal to outlaw discrimination in mortgage financing because of race, religion, color, national , origin or ancestry was put before the New York State Legislature tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10--The Supreme Court in two separate cases upheld today the Hatch act's prohibitions on political activity by Federal employes and by State employes whose salaries come out of Federal funds.
TAIYUAN, Shansi, China, Feb. 5 (Delayed)-Disturbed economic, political and social conditions in Shansi Province offer a situation favorable to the spread of communism.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP)The War Department announced today that it had been informed that all rail and bus lines were canceling special furlough fares, for service personnel effective Friday, Feb. 28.

Sharp competitive pricing to induce reluctant buyers to place orders for bedspreads, curtains, bath mats, fancy towels, tablecloths and other household linens was clearly evident at the Domestics and Linen Show which opened yesterday in the Hotel New Yorker.

Kurt von Schuschnigg, Chancellor of Austria from 1934 to 1938 and a controversial figure on the world political stage, made his first public appearance in the United States yesterday with a lecture at Town Hall and received a mixed and stormy reception both inside and outside the packed auditorium.
The average American school teacher receives $37 a week. Rural teachers get less than $30 weekly. Despite the inflationary prices, 10,000 teachers get $12 a week! Another 200,000 get $25 weekly.
LONDON, Feb. 10--The text of the British Government's proposals to the Arabs and Zionists for a solution of the Palestine problem:

ALBANY, Feb. 10-Overriding objections from Mayor William O'Dwyer, the Senate approved tonight, by a vote of 3& to 16, a bill giving the State Commerce Department supervision and control of Federal grants for airport construction in all parts of the State.

Gross operating revenues of the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company last year were the largest in the history of the company. The $27,676,174 figure was 15.31 percent above the $24,002,101 reported in 1945, the annual statement to stockholders disclosed yesterday.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 10--Doubt is being raised here about the advisability of Egypt's pursuing her intention to appeal to the United Nations against Britain, but the Government of Premier Mahmoud Fahiny Mokrashy Pasha showed no sign today of changing its plans.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today that thirteen new directors have been elected to the board of Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Mr. Lilienthal and Mr. Baruch have declared that the Smyth report on atomic energy revealed secrets. It did indeed, but it makes little difference for the future. The greatest secret was given Away at Hiroshima; namely, that an atomic bomb is possible and that it is a decisive weapon.

SECURITY COUNCIL Adopted United States resolution restricting right of Balkan inquiry commission to ask for postponement of death sentences on political prisoners in Balkan countries. Meets today at 3 P. M. (Open).

BALTIMORE, Feb. 10 (AP)President Bob Rodenberg of the Baltimore Colts of the All-America Football Conference announced today he had signed Cecil Isbell of Purdue as coach on a five-year contract. No figure was announced but Isbell said the terms were "highly satisfactory," attractive enough, in fact, to induce him to leave his head coaching job at Purdue, where he has been "very content."

ROME, Feb. 10-- Violence resulting in the death of a British general and the wounding of an Italian demonstrator in the Yugoslav Legation punctuated Italy's mourning for the signing of the peace treaty today.

Nearly two years after the end of hostilities in Europe, the first five peace treaties to follow the Second World War were formally signed yesterday in the "Hall of Peace" in Paris. It should have been, as presiding Foreign Minister Bidault suggested, a day of hope rejoicing and reconciliation. Instead it was a day of disappointments and resentments, and the expected protests which the Big Four had barred from the chamber were promptly voiced outside.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10--Violation of the Commodity Exchange Act was charged in a complaint served today by the United States Department of Agriculture against Zenith-Godley Company, Inc., New York City butter and egg brokerage concern, and its president, John McClay Jr.
The index is based on spot market prices. Most of the twenty-eight commodities are basic raw materials.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was nervous yesterday. Alter an early sharp rise futures lost part of the gains and closed 3 to 27 points net higher than Saturday's final prices on active months.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- Britain's problem of the administration of Palestine appeared tonight to be headed for submission to the United Nations as both the Zionists and the Arabs let it be known that the Government's compromise plan was unacceptable.

PARIS, Feb. 10--In Maggy Rouffs brilliant collection of spring and summer couture, an outstanding new trend is her draping of skirts with softly crushed scarves. Dipping down almost to the hem on one side, they are carried up to the opposite hip, knotted, and the ends allowed to cascade.
INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 10 (U.P)The twenty-ninth national convention of the American Legion will be held in New York Aug. 29 to Sept. 1, Legion national headquarters said today.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, Feb. 10--Capetown went without bread today because of a bakers' strike. The stoppage in the Witwatersrand gold mines entered its third week.

In a broadcast formally opening: the first National Heart Week, Dr. Thomas Parran, Surgeon General Of the United States Public Health Service, appealed yesterday for support of the fight against heart disease.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 10--James H. Sheldon of New York administrative chairman of the Anti-Nazi league, declared today that the anti-Jewish, anti-Negro organization calling itself the Columbians planned to enlist members in other states and that they had "financial and moral support" of other hatebreeding organizations in the United States.

Agrarian Reforms, Promotion of Native Enterprise Seen as Their Aim TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As an American journalist who has just completed a tour of Latin America, somewhat similar ir scope to that of your William H. Lawrence, I believe that his recent articles were most unfortunate for American relations with our southern neighbors.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Upward revisions of minimum wage rates affecting 500,000 women in eleven States and the District of Columbia since V-J Day were summarized today by the Women's Bureau.

LONDON, Feb. 10-Great Britain plans to return 129 Liberty ships now under charter from the United States at the rate of ten a month, beginning in June. In zil, Britain has 229 of that class vessel chartered from the United States and has offered to purchase 100 of the ships for her own merchant marine.

The mile, 600 and 1,000-yard runs in the fifth Metropolitan Intercollegiate Athletic Association indoor track and field championships tomorrow night on the floor of the Twenty-second Regiment Armory, 168th Street and Broadway, are figured to produce the keenest kind of competition.

BERLIN, Feb. 10--Thousands of parcels sent through the Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe and an unspecified volume of parcel post are piling up in Bremen as a result of the acute shortage of coal for railroads.

If there existed even the faintes suspicion the matrimonial complications in which Leo Duroche finds himself out Hpllywood way might jeopardize his job as manager of the Dodgers, it was diapelled yesterday - and by non other than Branch Rickey, thclub's president.

While not out of the woods yet, the raw fur industry is showing a better feeling than at any time during the last five months, it was reported here yesterday. Signs of greater activity and price firmness on several important furs were cited in well-informed quarters as suggesting that the industry, after its long and precipitous price decline, may be at or close to bottom, with the turn already reached for some domestic furs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10--Anybody interested in how we negotiate agreements with the Soviet Union and how they keep the agreements after they are negotiated will find interesting material in the arrangements made for the forthcoming Big Four Foreign Ministers' meeting in Moscow.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10--Five long-term convicts, one of them a killer, escaped from the Philadelphia County Prison at Holmesburg this morning by scaling a wall thirty -five feeet high. Three of them were soon recaptured.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10-- In a decision of far-flung interest the Supreme Court by 5 to 4 ruled today that New Jersey public school funds raised by taxation can be used to pay for transportation of children to Catholic parochial schools.
NANKING, Feb. 10--Premier T. V. Soong and his advisers met throughout most of the day today to consider measures to combat China's growing economic crisis.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP)-- Secretary of State Marshall, in a new move to tighten administration of the State Department, has ordered scattered research and intelligence units pulled together into a single organization.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 10-- RKO today announced the purchase of screen rights to "Mr. Blandings Builds His Dream House," a new novel by Eric Hodgins, for $200,000. The story is designed as a vehicle for Myrna Loy and Cary Grant, according to the studio, and a deal for their services in the picture is in negotiation.

S PORTS news never remains static, it moves quickly and constantly, refusing to wait, for instance, while the conductor of this column spends a week wrestling with a strep germ. Before this reporter has had a chance to get over the shock of Hank Greenberg's announced retirement, another news item of importance muscles its way to attention.

The Mugg detests Mankind. Yesterday he brooded in the enshadowed girders under the roof of Pier 5 on the Bush Docks in Brooklyn. He shivered in the winter blast and his protruding eyes glittered with loathing for the longshore crews and other men who labored on the windswept concrete, fifty feet below.

Forrest Haring would like to try his hand at independent producing this season, something he has not done since he put on "Apring Strings" back in the Thirties. For the purpose, he has bought "Mister Caesar," the work of Nina Anton and John Lloyd, and promises early action.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP)-- The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that workers who strike in violation of a nostrike pledge in their union contracts can be discharged without the protection of the Wagner Act.

BERLIN, Feb. 10--German tradeunion leaders representing 6,500,000 organized workers throughout the country opened a three-day inter -zonal convention today. Although the sessions were closed individual labor leaders disclosed in off-the-record conversations, that they were seeking to work out a unification of trade unions.

TRENTON, N. J., Feb. 10-Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll submitted to the Legislature today a record budget of $155,802,317, but pointed out that were it not for recommended increases in State aid to municipalities, the new budget would be $1,000,000 less than the current one.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 10-- Field Marshal Viscount Alexander, Governor General or Canada, satisfield a personal desire he has held for thirty-one years when he visited the United States Military "Academy today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP)-- Senator Kenneth S. Wherry of Nebraska, the Republican whip, added his voice today to a swelling chorus of bipartisan opposition to President Truman's appointment of David E. Lilienthal to head the Atomic Energy Commission.

A timely scream routed two bandits who at 4:30 P. M. yesterday invaded the office of Louis E. Stoddard, polo player and manufacturer, at 1 East Fifty-seventh Street. The scream came from Miss Mary Widmayer of 34 East Fifty-eighth Street, manager of Mr. Stoddard's estate, and caused the men to flee.

Fresh attempts to unify maritime labor groups of the nation are expected as an aftermath of the impending dissolution of the Committee for Maritime Unity. Approval by member unions of the vote for dissolution by the CMU executive board, meeting here over the last week-end, is regarded in maritime circles as little more than a formality.

Patrolman Vincent Conroy, 36 years old, of 136-31 243d Street, Rosedale, Queens, was shot in the chest at 3:30 A. M. yesterday by one of three bandits he had surprised in the North Shore Bus Company garage at South and Merrick Roads, Jamaica. The bandits escaped.

The peak supplies of small chickens, mentioned here last week, give point to a leaflet called "Fryer Chicken," which the Poultry and Egg National Board is issuing" to consumers on receipt of a stamped, self-addressed envelope, sent to its local office at 6 Harrison Street, New York City 13.

Eight Italian opera singers who came to this country last December to join a new company that later suspended operations because of financial reverses sailed yesterday for Italy aboard the Italian liner Saturnia.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP)--A. Federal grand jury today indicted Kenneth Romney, Sergeant - atArms of the House for fifteen years, on a charge of seeking to "cheat, swindle or defraud the Government" to conceal a $143,863 shortage in his accounts.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 10 AP)The whirlwind effort to hire Wesley E. Fesler as Ohio State football coach was slowed down today.

Whether Rocky Graziano, East Side middleweight, will undertake court action to upset the revocation of his license as a boxer in this State, is expected to be decided today. Graziano's license was revoked last Friday by the State Athletic Commission, for "conduct detrimental to boxing," after the commission, following a hearing", ruled Rocky was derelict in not reporting a proffered $100,000 bribe.

MANCHESTER, Vt., Feb. 10With winter finally here and skiing the best of the season, an interesting competitive program has been carded for next Week-end. The calendar of tournaments includes divisional, sectional and national title events and most important of all.

LITTLE AMERICA, Feb. 9 (Delayed)From its base here, the Navy expedition sent up two planes today for the first exploratory flight, to try and learn if the Antarctic continent is split by a strait under the ice cap between the Ross and Weddell Seas. But the planes, one carrying Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd, turned back after they were an hour out when one developed a gasoline leak.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 10-- A military court sentenced three Palestine terrorists tonight to be hanged and a fourth to life imprisonment. The underground had already announced that it would no longer await the confirmation of death sentences but would act at once.

MOSCOW, Feb. 10--One of the best known persons in the Soviet Union today is a young foreman at the Paris commune shoe factory in Moscow named Vassily Matrosov. He is hailed in the press and over the radio as a sort of combination of Charles Bedaux and Henry Ford, who by a number of "amazing" changes in his shop has increased its output.

Harold E. Stassen of Minnesota, Republican Presidential aspirant, will be the principal speaker at the sixty-first annual Lincoln Day dinner of the National Republican Club tomorrow at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

ALBANY, N. Y., Feb. 10 (AP)The Republican - controlled Assembly tonight blocked a Democratic bid for a legislative investigation of the recent rigging of the New York City butter market for which the Dairymen's League Cooperative Association was fined $29,000 in Federal Court.

Peter Truesdale of the Short Hills Club upset the sixth-seeded entrant, W. E. Clapham of the Montclair Athletic Club, 7-15, 15-12,15-12, 15-10, in a secondround match in the Metropolitan Class C squash racquets singles championship tournament on the courts of the Downtown Athletic Club last night.

Temporary suspension of certification procedure under the British token import plan was announced yesterday by L. L. Horch, New York regional director, Department of Commerce. The plan was suspended, it was said, because some applicants have overestimated the amount of their exports in the base period.

LONDON, Feb. 10 --The Labor Government fought its way through a great political storm in the House of Commons today over the coal and power crisis. There will be no coalition government, no general election and--for the present --no resignations, not even of Emanuel Shinwell, the muchcriticized Minister of Fuel and Power.

YONKERS, N. Y., Feb. 10Dense smoke in the basement of a six-family apartment house at 413 Prescott Street here this afternoon took the life of Leo Podeswa, 44 years old, a city fireman. His captain, Salvatore Fierro, 45, likewise was overcome by the fumes but was revived.

The fight over Communist influence in the Congress of Industrial Organizations took a new turn last night when the general executive board of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers revoked the charter of its General Electric local in Bridgeport, Conn., for expelling twenty-seven members on charges of communism.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Feb. 10 --Describing the British Commonwealth of Nations as "one of the great forces for liberty, peace and progress in the world," Lord Inverchapel, British Ambassador to the United States, declared here today that the Commonwealth gave "a living example of how the first venture towards a United Nations "can succeed if there is the will to make it so."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 1OProf. Millar Burrows of the Yale Divinity School, who is president of the American Schools of Oriental Research at Jerusalem and Baghdad, has received a leave of absence for the academic year 1947-48 to serve as director of the Jerusalem branch of the schools. Another Yale faculty member, Prof. Albrecht Goetze, has received similar leave to accept the post of annual professor at the school in Bagtidad.

Why should a traveler on a holiday trip into the United States be suspected of being an ex-convict or a polygamist, was the question propounded yesterday by Arthur Dunscombe Alien, general secretary of the Automobile Association of Great Britain, at an American Automobile Association luncheon in the Hotel Roosevelt.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10--John Foster Dulles, foreign policy adviser to the Republican patty and a member of the United States delegation to the United Nations General Assembly, offered a six-point program today to meet the challenge of the Soviet Union's "dynamism" in world affairs.

A program for economy and efficiency in Federal spending make possible significant relief for payers of individual income taxi was urged yesterday in the fin report of the Committee on Pos war Tax Policy.
PARIS, Feb. 10-- The first treaties of peace following World War II were signed today. They will formally terminate the state of war between the Allies and Germany's five European satellites.

CHICAGO. Feb. 10--Mill and cash house buying sent all deliveries of wheat to new seasonal highs on the Board of Trade today. March also went to a new twentyseven-year top and July was up to the highest price known for that delivery in February.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 10 (U.P)--Miss Peggy Kirk of Findlay, Ohio, shot a ,three-overwomen's-par 75 today to take medalist honors in the qualifying rounds of the West Palm Beach women's golf tournament.

Improvement of steel warehouse management will pay large dividends to industrial purchasing agents during the coming year, members of the American Steel Warehouse Association disclosed here yesterday. Following the regular chapter meeting of the New York steel warehouse group, it was disclosed that a nation-wide effort is being made by warehouses to raise post-war sales above pre-war records in the percentage of total steel sales handled by warehouses compared to direct selling by mills.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 10 -Westchester County's struggle to collect ten-cent tolls on the Saw Mill River and Hufehinson River Parkways burst into the open again today with statements from William J. Gottlieb, president of the State Automobile Association and the New York Automobile' Club, and Herbert C. Gerlach, county executive of Westchester. They agreed on few points.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10 -- The Philadelphia Company, Pittsburgh, declared today that its utilities system cannot be dismembered by the Securities and Exchange Commission and challenged the power of the SEC to order dissolution of the company and a split-up of its properties.

The Rev. Robert Bracewell Appleyard, assistant to the dean of Union Theological Seminary, was ordained as a priest by Bishop Angus Dun of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Washington yesterday morning at ceremonies in Grace Episcopal Church, Broadway and Tenth Street.
LONDON, Feb. 10--In a number of Pall Mall's exclusive clubs, where conservative sentiment abounds, harsh things were said today about the Labor Government's electricity curtailment program.

Europe's orphaned children who have survived the Nazi terror possess stamina and pluck but show "tremendous need" for affection and human understanding, a sixmonth study of their psychological needs reveals.

An exhibition of 200 old valentines will be opened at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street, at 2 P. M today with a preview to museum members. Beginning tomorrow the display will be open to the public from 10 A. M. to 5 P. M. daily, Sundays from 1 to 5 P. M. It will be closed on Mondays.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 10 UPt Pirate fandom expressed mild indignation today at Hank Greenberg's failure to sign a Pittsburgh contract and his decision to "consider" withdrawing from baseball. The audience at the annual sports writers' dinner here last night-where the Greenberg development was announced-sat in glum silence as they learned the thundering bat of the mighty American League hitter may not be available at Forbes Field this spring.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10 (AP)A large quantity of drugs-including streptomycin and penicillin anesthetics and blood plasma-is on the way to Italy as the gift of a Philadelphia doctor to help overcome what he describes as medical shortages in some of the hospitals and clinics in that country. Dr.Max Strumia, a member of the staff of Bryn Mawr and.Uhiversity of Pennsylvania hospitals, said he visited Italy. recently and saw a great need for the drugs.

Although Mayor O'Dwyer had promised, the day after he announced a Board of Estimate hearing on the question of a higher subway fare, that "my mind will be open until the end of the hearings," it seemed obvious as soon as those hearings began yesterday that the Mayor's mind was pretty well made up.

A survey among 15,000 physicians throughout the nation showed that an overwhelming majority of them favor birth control, it was reported last night at a dinner of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America at the Hotel Plaza. The dinner, one of 100 throughout the United States opened a campaign to raise $2,000,000.

Twelve contributions amounting to $182 were received yesterday for the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund sponsored by the new york times, increasing the total of the thirty-fifth annual appeal to $397,612.31. Among the gifts was a contribution of $100 from Christine E. HalL The list of gifts follows:

MIAMI, Feb. 10 (AP)--The second half of Miami's 120-day horseracing season began today with figures for tote and turnstile showing that New York is not alone in its tailing-off turf trend. For the first sixty days of the current stand, comprising Tropical Park's forty-day session and the initial half of Hialeah's term, 712,824 fans wagered $48,595,792, drops of 92,471 and $5,808,468 from a similar period last winter.

With the avowed purpose of Presenting plays generally beyond the realm of the Broadway box-office, the American National Theatre and Academy inaugurated its Experimental Theatre on Sunday evening at the Princess. For its first offering it chose "The Wanhope Building," by John Finch, and obviously it has stuck close to plan.
San Antonio, Tex., announced yesterday that it would offer for sale on Thursday public improvement bonds aggregating $5,700,000 on Which bidding last year was twice postponed because of litigation.

Molly Picon, Mary Small, Henny Youngman, David Collyer, Regina Resnik, Richard Tucker, Norman Cordon, Polyna Stoska, Anne Jeffreys and Brian Sullivan have been added to the list of entertainers for the annual all-star show of the Israel Orphan Asylum on Feb. 25 at Madison Square Garden, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Gustave Hartman, president of the home.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10--Appointment of Katharine F. Lenroot, chief of the Children's Bureau of the Federal Security Agency, as United States member of the executive board of the International Children's Emergency Fund was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10--The vigor with which four justices of the Supreme Court today dissented from the legal reasoning, historical interpretation and final conclusion of the other five in the New Jersey case concerning publicly paid transportation of children to Catholic parochial schools suggests that, like the portal-to-portal issue, this is only the beginning of a grave judicial controversy.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 10 --Charging unfair discrimination in the distribution of State aid for education, the Westchester County Board of Supervisors asked today that Governor Dewey and the Legislature create a new formula.

One cannot claim with any degree of confidence that Noah had February in mind when he defined cantankerous; exhibiting ill nature; perverse; contentious. It sometimes seems the Weather Man uses the second month to display his repertoire of tricks and prove his right to contrariness.

Led by Henry Epstein, former Solicitor General of New York State, and Councilman Walter R. Hart, opponents of an increased transit fare delivered a slashing attack on the city's real estate interests yesterday and charged they had tried to shift the real estate tax burden to the backs of subway riders.

LONDON, Feb. 10--The brawl between a Communist Member of Parliament, Philip Piratin, and a press reporter became a closed incident tonight with the House of Commons accepting without a division a motion of Parliamentary Committee of Privileges expressing "the high displeasure of the House."

BERLIN, Feb. 10--The Norsk Aluminium Company of Oslo, which recently bought a large quantity of bauxitie from the bizonal export-import agency, is an old Norwegian concern with no connection with I. G. Farben or the Nazis' atomic energy research.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 --An assertion that J. David Stern, the publisher, was ridden by a "neurosis" that prevented collective bargaining was made today in the inquiry by the House Committee on Education and Labor into the sale and suspension of Mr. Stern's strike-bound newspapers at Philadelphia, and Camden, N. J.

Mayor O'Dwyer and Controller Lazarus Joseph gave marked indiations that they favored retention if the five-cent transit fare yeserday at a public hearing before he Board of Estimate in City Hall m the higher-fare issue.

Thomas A. Edison was born in Milan, Ohio, a hundred years ago today. The occasion is to be celebrated all over the country, and for good reason's. With the exception of Leonardo, Edison was probably the most brilliant inventor in history, judged by the quality and the number of his inventions.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- Britons struggled and shivered today through the first day of the nationwide power cut-off, and were informed by the Government that further cuts were coming. A longterm policy of restriction is now under consideration.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP)-- Production of all citrus fruit for the 1946-47 season was estimated at 204,000,000 boxes by the Department of Agriculture today. This would be 11 per cent more than production last season and 53 per cent above the 1935-44 average.

Financing transactions involving public and preferential offerings of public utility and airline securities will be undertaken here today by underwriting managers, as follows: Nebraska Public Power District -- Public offering of $10,000,000 of revenue bonds maturing from 1953 to 1977, at prices to yield from 1.30 per cent to 2.40 per cent, by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., subject to formal award.

Representative Vito Marcantonio obtained from Supreme Court Justice William C. Hecht Jr. yesterday an order requiring Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander to show cause Friday at 10 A. M. why he should not be restrained from imposing a curfew law on East Harlem social clubs, which he put into effect last December.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10-The House granted to two of its committees today special powers of investigation beyond those allowed in the 1946 Congressional Reorganization Act. It was the first departure by the House from the streamlining of Congressional procedures adopted last session.

ALBANY, Feb. 10. (AP)--Restoration of State income taxes to twothirds of former levels, if necessary, was advocated today by the State Teachers Association to finance permanent salary increases for teachers.

Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, Commissioner of Hospitals, and Dr. A. Goodwin Distler, president of the Queens County Medical Society, visited last night the free cancer detection and prevention clinic at Queens-General Hospital, Jamaica. They saw the start of a new section of the clinic, restricted to doctors and nurses.

The Board of Health is now seeking stricter control of dogs rather than compulsory vaccination against rabies, it appeared yesterday. The board did not rule at its February meeting yesterday on its own proposal to amend the Sanitary Code making vaccination of all 600,000 dogs in New York mandatory.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11 (AP)-- Miss Jane Austin, 19-year-old Cynwyd, Pa., player, advanced to the second round of the women's national squash racquets tournament today, after scoring a minor upset over Mrs. Ellwood I. Beatty Jr., Cynwyd, Pa., 9--15, 15--13, 15--11, 15--10, at the Merion Cricket Club.

LONDON, Feb. 11--Gen. Mark W. Clark of the United States and Fedor T. Gusev of Russia engaged in a verbal sparring match at today's meeting of the Foreign Ministers' deputies, with General Clark declaring that freedom of speech did not exist in Russia and Mr. Gusev protesting the "allegations."

With production unimpeded by labor troubles and only slightly hampered by a scarcity of scrap metal, the nation's steel industry in January turned out 7,234,187 net tons of steel ingots and castings, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

People Had Plans An advocate of planned economy who preceded Joseph Stalin by more than 130 years was Alexander Hamilton. Looking about him for ways to strengthen the new Federal Union, he bethought himself, among other things, of industrialization.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11--Maurice Pate, executive director of the International Children's Emergency Fund, said today in a joint press conference with Katharine F. Lenroot, United States member, that unilateral loans for the neediest nations were a prerequisite to supplemental work for children planned through the fund.
For the second consecutive day the public ignored the Board of Estimate hearing on the subway fare yesterday at City Hall.

Beaunit Mills, Inc.--Nine months to Dec. 31: Net income, $4,925,212, equal to $5.19 a share on 948,820 shares of capital stock giving effect to four-for-one stock split in March, 1946. This compares with $1,076,238, or $1.14 a share, for the nine months to Dec. 31, 1945.

Artur Rodzinski said yesterday that he would "hate" to have to go to court to settle the financial side of his differences with the PhilharmonicSymphony Society of New York. He revealed that he had written a letter to the society saying that whether the matter was settled or taken to court depended on the organization's board of directors.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11--The Social Security Board's eleventh annual report to Congress today recommended extension of Federal old-age and survivors' insurance to all gainful workers, increases in benefit amounts, and expansion of the program to include permanent total disability insurance.

Announcement that the Museum of Modern Art plans to enlarge its building in West Fifty-third Street will come as welcome news indeed to that institution's thousands of friends. Mr. Rockefeller's gift of adjacent property fronting on Fifty-fourth Street makes this project possible, and the museum has started a fund-raising campaign, the goal set at $3,650,000.

Purebred dogs were pouring into New York yesterday from all parts of the country for the seventyfirst annual show of the Westminster Kennel Club in Madison Square Garden. Most of the 2,598 that were entered will be on their benches when judging starts at 10 o'clock this morning.

MOSCOW, Feb. 11--The food situation in the Ukraine and White Russia is arousing grave concern among United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation officials in the two republics. At the same time reports reaching the capital indicate that in a number of districts the farmers are short of seed for the all-important spring sowing.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11-Southern Democrats opened today their fight against measures which seek to end filibusters in the Senate. They predicted that they would receive material aid from other Democrats and from Republicans. The filibuster, they argued, was not just a Southern institution.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11--The Senate War Investigating Committee, in its first session under Republican leadership, sought today to find out what had happened to a five-year-old wartime project, in which the Government had invested $18,000,000 and which was still unfinished.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange recovered yesterday from an early break and closed strong 5 to 20 points higher than on Monday on active months.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11--Soundings of Senate sentiment today indicated that the decision on confirmation of David E. Lilienthal as Chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission might as easily go against him as for him.

Of interest to all who sympathetically studied this newspaper's survey last week of the starvation existing everywhere abroad is the announcement of a new food package assembled by the Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe.
WARSAW, Feb. 11--It is unlikely that Arthur Bliss Lane will return to Poland as United States Ambassador after he leaves here shortly to report to Secretary of State Marshall.

ABOARD MOUNT OLYMPUS, in the Antarctic, Feb. 11--The discovery on the frozen South Polar continent of a remarkable inland "oasis" of muddy pea-green lakes dotted with tall, dark brown mounds of apparently bare earth was announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11--The Middle West Corporation applied today to the Securities and Exchange Commission for permission to contribute $1,500,000 to the common stock capital of its subsidiary, Kentucky Utilities Company, to enable the latter to carry out a $6,000,000 construction program.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The State Department, encouraged by indications that while the Republican majority in Congress may modify the reciprocal trade treaty program it will not jettison the program, has almost completed plans for representation at the eighteen-nation trade treaty conference scheduled to open in Geneva on April 8.
CHICAGO, Feb. 11--Prices of grains broke rapidly early today on the Board of Trade, but rallied similarly in the later trading, resulting in an irregular close.

HAVANA, Feb. 11-The InterAmerican Academy of Comparative and International Law announced that it had reached the conclusion that "diplomatic protection of nationals abroad should be incorporated in a general international system for the defense of the rights of man."

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 11--For a time it looked as if the 3-to-2 favorite wouldn't make it after turning wide into the stretch, but through the closing yards Chancegain responded to the lashing of Herb Lindberg's whip and charged to a head decision in the $4,000 Bouquet Purse at Hialeah Park today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11--The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 5, the Federal Reserve Board reported today: Decreases of $185,000,000 in loans and $478,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted, and an increase of $140,000,000 in United States Government deposits.

VIENNA, Austria, Feb. 11--A mixed Austro-American commission left Vienna for Berlin last night to negotiate with the Allied Control Commission in Berlin regarding the amount of electric power to be supplied by Austria to Germany and the rates to be charged for it.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- J. David Stern told Congress today that he retired "at heavy personal loss" from the newspaper business to warn the nation of his view that the American Newspaper Guild was menacing a free press.

ALBANY, Feb. 11--Senator Seymour Halpern and Assemblyman Fred W. Preller, Queens Republicans, proposed today the creation of a bipartisan joint legislative committee to conduct an inquiry into New York City's recurring budgetary crises.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11--The development of a "push-button" signal system of air traffic control, based on the most advanced railroad signal controls and designed to prevent air traffic jams, was disclosed here tonight by Capt. Sam P. Saint.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Those who greeted the lifting of price controls without reference to any local conditions, including, I am sorry to say, THE NEW YORK TIMES, should ponder seriously one phase of the current price situation in New York City: garage rents.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 11 --Mrs. Hamid Ali, Indian representative, told the United Nations' Commission on the Status of Women today that she felt women should not be satisfied with a demand for rights "equal" to men's.

Research Firm Reorganized A complete change in ownership and management was announced yesterday by the Ross-Federal Research Corporation. William P. Reed, formerly vice president of the Institute of Public Relations, Inc., succeeds Clifford B. Ross as president and Barry J. Holloway, director of public relations for Stephens College, Columbia, Mo., becomes vice president. S.W. Sheetz continues as vice president.

In her collection presented yesterday at Stein Blaine's Harriette Harra demonstrated that she is a designer with ideas and no fear of expressing them. She approves of longer daytime hemlines --in some models, they seemed a bare ten inches off the floor--the long torso look and emphasis on the hips.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 11-- The projected musical version of "Ramona," Helen Hunt Jackson's 1885 novel about Indian life in California, which Twentieth CenturyFox has had on schedule for a year and a half, will be made this spring with Jeanne Grain in the title role, the studio announced today.

The vast majority of waterfront labor in this port is honest but a well-organized minority is responsible for most of the pilferage on piers, James B. Young, president of the Bureau for the Suppression of Theft and Pilferage, Inc., declared yesterday.

Consideration of the $143,127,OOC bid submitted by the Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation to the War Assets Administration for the "Big Inch" and "Little Big Inch" pipelines indicated yesterday that the Eastern area of the United States, embracing the New YorkNew Jersey-Pennsylvania section and the New England States, which latter never have had natural gas, will become one of the largest gasconsuming areas in the country within two years.

ATLANTA, Feb. 11--The antiJewish, anti-Negro Columbians "zoned" Atlanta to exclude Negroes from certain neighborhoods and plotted world domination by "white gentiles," a Fulton County jury was told today by Solicitor General E.E. Andrews.

LONDON, Feb. 11--Selling was on a larger scale in stock markets today and prices again fell sharply in some sections. The fact that this was the last day of the account was responsible for part of the selling, but there also were indications of more general offerings by investors.
Sewanee, Tennessee's University of the South, opened last night a nation-wide $5,000,000 building and endowment fund campaign at its annual meeting and dinner for New York alumni.

Buyers' Arrivals Higher Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 2,005 compared with 1,575 last week and 1,856 in the corresponding week of 1946, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES.
A five-year immigration ban was advocated yesterday by Senator Elmer Thomas of Oklahoma in a forum discussion of the question, "Do Immigration Quotas Meet Today's Needs?"

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 11 --An international sports and recreation "city," including a theatre and outdoor skating rink, will probably be constructed on the site of the world capital along the East River, according to preliminary plans disclosed here today.

HONOLULU, Feb. 11--Contending that the whole question of Land Court titles in the Territory of Hawaii is at issue, the office of the Territorial Attorney General, Nils Tavars, today filed a petition as "a friend of the court" in the United States Supreme Court.
ATLANTA, Feb. 11--The Georgia Senate today heard the Talmadge-sponsored white primary bill branded as a measure "to legalize the stealing of each and every future election in Georgia."

Insecurity among adults is the greatest cause of insecurity in children, Dr. Robert K. Speer, Professor of Education at New York University, told 200 parents and teachers yesterday at a meeting of the Child Study Association of America, 221 West Fifty-seventh Street.

LONDON, Feb. 11 (AP)--Britain's great electric power system, a prewar world model of efficiency, is too war-strained to meet the assaults of a coal shortage, unusually severe weather and an all-out production drive.

The spot delivery market for sheet steel and strip is rapidly getting "out of hand," Thomas J. Smith Jr., executive vice president of the Pressed Metal Institute, Cleveland, disclosed here yesterday. Legitimate steel makers and steel warehouses are not involved in these "shady" spot markets as far as any definite connection can be traced, he said.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11--Extension to all States of the "community property" principle for payment of personal income taxes appeared today to have the support of many members of both parties in Congress, but the possibility of action this year was considered remote.

Senator Wherry of Nebraska, who has become majority whip in the upper branch of Congress by virtue of his party's victory in the last election, has announced that he will vote against confirming the President's appointment of David E. Lilienthal as chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission.

A 22-year-old former Polish theological student, who was offered home in this country by a Philadelphia couple because of his reported resemblance to their son, killed in action in Europe, arrived here yesterday from Bremerhaven on the transport Marine Perch.

BERLIN, Feb. 11 -- The Allies agreed today on the election procedure for Berlin trade unions, thus settling a controversy that had flared into bitter denunciations between American and Russian Military Government officials through the German press.

It is a sure instinct which makes this nation's thoughts turn every Feb. 12 to Abraham Lincoln as they turn toward no other man in our history. Pondering the Lincoln literature we may think there are many Lincolns: Hay's and Nicolay's, Barton's, Beveridge's, Angle's, Ida Tarbell's, Sandburg's, Randall's.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 10,000 head, total 18,000; generally 25 to 50 cents lower than Monday's average: weights 230 pounds and down showing most decline: good and choice 180-240 pounds.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- Election bills designed to make the continuance of so-called splinter parties difficult, if not impossible, met with overwhelming opposition today at a public hearing conducted by the Joint Legislative Committee on Election Law.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11--Administration Argonauts, led by National Chairman Robert E. Hannegan, will start this year's quest for golden fleece at a Jefferson Jubilee dinner in Miami Beach, Fla., for which a thousand paying guests will contribute $250 a plate.

A last-hour spurt in the stock market yesterday rescued a sagging list and lifted some of the key units as much as 3 points. Chrysler in particular gave the market its best argument for a recovery while some of the rubbers assisted in the change of sentiment during the day.

PARIS, Feb. 11 -- The French Government would like to see an alliance between this country and the United States within the overall framework of the United Nations, thus completing the French scheme of big-power pacts represented by the French-Soviet alliance and France's imminent accord with Britain.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11--The arrangement by which Senator Vandenberg of Michigan was supposed to assume the leadership of his party in foreign affairs, and Senator Taft of Ohio was to give the lead to Republicans on domestic affairs is not working as smoothly as either might desire.
LONDON, Feb. 11--Service distributing trades without frills must be the motto of the British for some time to come, Sir Stafford Cripps, President of the Board of Trade, said here today.
The President of the united States and the man in the street took part yesterday in memorial tributes marking the 100th anniversary of the birth of America's outstanding inventor, Thomas Alva Edison.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 11 --The case of Hysni Kapo, the missing Albanian, took shape tonight as the United Nations' first diplomatic mystery.

The Chesapeake Ohio Railway announced yesterday that it has acquired voting trust certificates for 315,400 shares of the capital stock of the New York Central Railroad at a total cost of $5,875,057, or an average of $18.63 a share.

Dr. Karl von Kleczkowski, a former German counter-intelligence agent who deserted to the Allied cause in Turkey in 1943, told in Federal court yesterday his version of the commitments made by American officials to provide him with a refuge in the United States.

The City Council adopted yesterday a resolution calling upon the State Legislature to give more financial aid to New York City. The resolution, sponsored by the Democratic majority headed by Vice Chairman Joseph T. Sharkey, was carried by a vote of 19 to 3.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11--Senator Homer Ferguson told the Senate today that sufficient law already existed to force the prompt return to the Treasury Department of the material making up the 900-volume "diary" of former Secretary Henry Morgenthau Jr.

The valuable site formerly occupied by the Hippodrome, in the east blockfront of Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue) from Forty-third to Forty-fourth Street, will be improved with a three-story garage and store structure under plans filed yesterday by Voorhees, Walker, Foley Smith, architects.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 11--The flight from depreciating Chinese currency attained dizzy proportions today. The price of ten-ounce gold bars skyrocketed to $9,100,000, Chinese, and the open market exchange rate closed at a record 17,500 Chinese dollars to one United States dollar.

Business men with interests in France may be deprived of their constitutional rights under the French-American Tax Treaty that has recently been negotiated unless some modification is made before ratification, according to Felix Dayton, chairman, tax committee, National Foreign Trade Council, Inc., and controller, International General Electric Company.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 11 (AP)--The veteran Stormy Weather, fivetime winner of the 184-mile Miamito-Nassau race, pushed into the lead tonight as fourteen trim yachts passed Great Isaac Light, fifty-nine miles east of Miami. The Coast Guard reported that the jibheaded yawl, flying the burgee of the Toledo (Ohio) Yacht Club and skippered by Fred M. Temple, had moved up from third position five hours after the start.

The slaying of a 16-year-old youth last Sunday in the basement of a Brooklyn tenement led yesterday to the arrest of another youth who confessed to the fatal shooting, the police said, and sixteen other members of a Brooklyn gang known as the "Socialistic Gents."

International efforts to stabilize food prices and increase consumption, rather than to restrict production, were cited here yesterday as the aims of the Bruce Commission report, an outgrowth of proposals by Sir John Orr to the United Nations for a World Food Board.

A BASKETBALL Rip Van Winkle, who had been dozing for the past dozen or so years, would get the impression that nothing had changed during his snooze. Fordham plays St. John's at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory this afternoon and Rip would think that perfectly proper and normal. The major college games in our town always were staged in armories because the average gymnasium was much too small to accommodate the eager customers.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Feb. 11-- Labor leaders throughout the State were starting tonight to converge on the Capitol at Nashville to wage a battle against two pending anti-labor bills. Word was received this morning that the hearings would begin at 2 P.M. Thursday.

ALBANY, Feb. 11--Fate of the child care centers in New York State hung in doubt today despite final passage by the Senate of the Young-Schulman bill continuing the State Youth Commission for another three years.

The first Brazilian bank that fails may collapse the whole house of cards built on the country's inflated economy, Oliver E. Zimmerman, regional export manager, General Poods Corporation, declared yesterday. Addressing the Export Manag-ers Club at the Hotel Pennsylvania, he said once Brazil has gone.through the deflation spiral, it will be the outstanding trading country of Latin America.

A 16-year-old high school student, son of a well-to-do Tuxedo Park, N.Y., lawyer, was arraigned yesterday on charges of grand larceny and violating the Sullivan Law after the police said they found him and a 17-year-old boy in a woman's apartment.

Three books of the writings of Henry James are on the 1947 lists. Knopf will issue on Feb. 20 "The American Novels and Stories of Henry James," edited with an introduction by F.O. Matthiessen. Mr. Matthiessen also has edited, With Kenneth Murdoch, "The Notebooks of Henry James," which Oxford University Press will release in the fall.

August and Nettie Marrone worked last night in their home at 1228 Colgate Avenue in The Bronx on written appeals to President Truman and to the Navy. Department to save Scout, a K-9 veteran, from the gas chamber.

The week's only opening takes place this evening at the Playhouse, where Gant Gaither will revive George Kelly's Pulitzer Prize play, "Craig's Wife." Judith Evelyn, remembered for her successful portrayal of Bella Manningham in "Angel Street," is starred in the role of Harriet Craig and Philip Ober will be featured as her husband.

BERLIN, Feb. 11--The first major step toward the economic disarmament of Germany was announced today when the United States Military Government promulgated a law designed to break up huge cartels. A similar law was announced simultaneously by the British Military Government, and both will become effective tomorrow.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Feb. 11-- Anti-Communist officers of the General Electric local union here announced tonight their intention of resisting revocation of the union's charter by the general executive board of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, CIO.

PARIS, Feb. 11--A member of the United States delegation to the 1946 Paris peace conference promised the Bulgarians to help them obtain changes in the wording of the Bulgarian treaty and did not keep his word, Kimon Georgiev, Bulgarian Foreign Minister, said today.

Columbia's basketball team, leading the Eastern Intercollegiate League with three victories and no defeats, will clash with its toughest opponent to date, Pennsylvania, in the feature event of an Alumni Day sports program on the Morningside Heights campus today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11--The new home building program this year will probably fall short of reaching early predictions of completed units, due to material shortages and high prices, John D. McCarthy, secretary-treasurer of the Illinois Lumber and Material Dealers Association, Inc., declared between sessions of the organization's annual meeting here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11--Representatives of the principal newspaper, radio and periodical correspondents' associations in Washington told Secretary of State Marshall today that an allocation twenty American correspondents for the forthcoming Moscow conference was "shockingly inadequate."

ALBANY, Feb. 11--Companion bills to prohibit all unfair practices in the insurance business and to outlaw-monopolies and restraints of competition in insurance were introduced today in the Senate and Assembly at the request of Robert E. Dineen, State Superintendent of Insurance.
Clarence (Buddy) Young faces a year of suspension from amateur competition before he can launch his announced campaign to win a place on the 1948 Olympic team as a sprinter.
Leo L. Helterline Jr., formerly senior project engineer, has been appointed chief engineer for Sorensen Co., Inc., Stamford, Conn., producers of special electronic equipment.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 11 --Following are excerpts from the speech of Warren R. Austin, United States representative to the United Nations Security Council: We could hardly go forward with a part of this resolution and leave out that part which we consider absolutely essential in the effort toward abolition of war.

POLA, Istrian Peninsula, Feb. 11--Dry-eyed, cold and calculating, 34-year-old Maria Pasquinelli sat in a damp jail here today and told British investigators that she did not regret having assassinated Brig. Robin de Winten, commander of the British garrison in Pola, since she had come here with that express intent.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 11 --A permanent regional organization to deal with almost all branches of European inland travel --road, rail and water--is required to cope with the complex Continental transport, problem, the United Nations Transport and Communications Commission agreed today.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 11 (AP)--Eighteen individuals and five business concerns were indicted by the Hudson County grand jury today on charges of conspiring to defraud the Western Electric Company of $1,235,000.

The Board of Estimate closed two days of public hearings on a higher transit fare at City Hall last evening with Mayor O'Dwyer declaring that there would be no increase without a referendum and higher fare advocates charging that the Board had prejudged the issue in favor of the five-cent rate.

On the ground that a new biography of him is libelous and violates his privacy, Serge Koussevitzky, Boston Symphony Orchestra conductor, won a court order yesterday restraining publication restraining publication and distribution of the book.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 11 (AP) --Mrs. Mildred Didrikson Zaharias of Denver, national amateur women's champion, today led the way into the second round of the annual Palm Beach women's golf championship with a 4-and-2 victory over Miss Mary Agnes Wall of Menominee, Mich.

The full measure of the benefits that Thomas Alva Edison's inventions afford mankind wait upon the solution of the problems of the machine and mass production age, Dr. Oliver C. Carmichael, president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, declared last night.

ST. CLAIRSVILLE, Ohio, Feb. 11--A new portal, four miles closer to the place where coal is dug and equipped with comfort and restaurant facilities comparable with those of a modern hotel, has been opened at the Willow Grove Mine.

New York University's balanced power and overwhelming strength in the field events establishes Coach Emil Von Elling's Violet squad as team favorite in the metropolitan intercollegiate track and field championships at the Twenty-second Engineers Armory, 168th Street and Broadway, tonight.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Feb. 11--The Dutch have found a new cause for worry in what they regard as Allied mishandling of German economic problems, in the British plans to nationalize the basic industries of the Ruhr and Rhineland.
All weekday games at the Yankee Stadium this season will start at 2 o'clock instead of 2:30, last year's time.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- V.J. Malone, president of the Marine Firemen, an independent union, announced today the results of a ballot which he called a "clean sweep by the anti-Communist forces."

America's schools today employ 125,000 teachers on emergency or substandard licenses. One out of every seven teachers--15 per cent of the total teaching body cannot meet even the minimum requirements of her State.

A month ago in England people were saying that conditions could not be worse than they were. They could see the winter through, they said, because they were certain this must be the last of short rations and austerity clothes, of queueing up in the streets and doubling up at home.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 11 (U.P.) --A new Panama Canal which would resist the shocks of earthquakes or atomic-powered weapons of war is being planned in Harvard University's engineering laboratories.

Authorities on heart disease, mankind's No. 1 killer, are confident that the problem of its control can be solved with adequate public support, the New York Heart Association was told last night by two of the world's outstanding leaders in the field.

Youthful off-the-face hats, marked by an easy wearability, were shown yesterday by Peg Fischer in a collection of spring millinery at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel. They were never overdone, but designed with simplicity and young, flattering lines.

Retail percentage sales gains have narrowed steadily since the first of the year, but this does not justify the conclusion on the basis of figures so far available that retail volume has now turned definitely downward, retail spokesmen here said yesterday.

The British people are fighting at the moment what has been aptly characterized as the Second Battle of Britain, in which their immediate enemy is the coldest weather in half a century. But it is clear that they face a far more formidable foe than weather, and that they will have to wage a long and arduous fight to overcome it.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 11 --Warren R. Austin, United States delegate, told the United Nations Security Council here this afternoon that the disarmament resolution favored by the Soviet Union would enable the projected Disarmament Commission to seek information about atomic weapons.

SECURITY COUNCIL Warren R. Austin, United States representative, declared disarmament resolution favored by Russia would enable projected commission to seek information about atomic weapons and that this country opposed such a step.

TOKYO, Feb. 11--Arrangements have been completed under which the Occupation will buy 120,000 bales "of burry topmaking" wool from Australia at L25 per bale. Final signature is needed but Occupation officials expect the first shipment of 30,000 bales to arrive before the end of March in Australian bottoms.

Hank Greenberg stated last night that he had withheld announcement of his planned retirement from baseball at the request of the Pittsburgh club management immediately after he had been sold by the Tigers. He said at no time had he indicated to the Pittsburgh management that he would sign with the Pirates.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: One of the strongest arguments advanced against the increase in the subway fare at the hearings before the Mayor was the fact that the increase would free real estate owners completely from any participation in the financing of subway operations while placing the entire responsibility on the subway riders, and that this would be exceedingly unfair.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11--It is becoming apparent to the leaders of both the major parties in Congress and to the Administration that the enduring issues over world policy between the United States and the Soviet Union are at the base of most of the official cleavages here.

Champion Karach of Khanhasset, handsome red dog with a pretty dark mask, owned by Mrs. Leah P. McConaha of Great Neck and shown by Harry Hill of Darien, Conn., was named best in show at the first specialty event of the Afghan Hound Club of America at the McAlpin Hotel yesterday.

Holiday The New York Stock and Curb exchanges, and other leading commodity and financial markets of the nation will be closed today in observance of Lincoln's Birthday. Canadian and London stock exchanges and the Winnipeg grain market will be open as usual.

PARIS, Feb. 11--Asymmetrical tunics and fantasy of detail distinguish the collection of Marcel Rochas. All the street frocks, whether in black and white shepherd's check, plain gray, or prints of luggage and burnt sienna tones have tunics that flare, tunics that cling to a narrow underskirt, dipping way down to one side and draping up to the opposite hip.

ATHENS, Feb. 11--The United Nations commission investigating the Greek frontier unanimously agreed in a secret session tonight to make a preliminary inquiry on an appeal by the Left-Wing Eam that it intercede with the Greek Government in behalf of five Greek guerrillas under sentence of death.

Thirty widely traveled explorers sat down in the cafeteria of the Museum of Natural History yesterday afternoon to sample a new combat food ration devised by the Army. It included bread a year old. Most of the explorers, who have memories of choking down such "foods" as pemmican, a standby of early Arctic expeditions, licked their platters clean.

PEIPING, China, Feb. 11--The last two days have shown that the Communists are already beginning to strike closer and closer to Peiping itself. This is taking place even as the American branch of Executive Headquarters is packing up and preparing to sail from Tangku, port of Tientsin, within thirty days.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The Senate-House Budget subcommittee voted today for a $6,000,000,000 slash in President Truman's $37,500,000,000 spending program for the 1948 fiscal year.
YONKERS, N.Y., Feb. 11--Another fugitive from a Brooklyn institution gave himself up here today.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 11--The delegates to the initial meeting of the International Labor Organization's new twelve-nation petroleumindustry committee, after eight days of confeernces, have drawn nine broad recommendations for the improvement of labor and social conditions in the industry internationally.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11--Ship operators urged the Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee today not to outlaw industry-wide bargaining lest it result in "utter chaos in collective bargaining" and lead to innumberable jurisdictional disputes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The Joint Conference Committee on Public Relations for the Baptists of the United States formally deplored today the Supreme Court ruling yesterday upholding the use of tax funds by a New Jersey Jersey school board for transporting pupils to Catholic parochial schools.

LONDON, Feb. 11--The refusal of the executive of the Jewish Agency for Palestine to consider the British proposals for a solution of the Palestine problem "might well be their last word on the subject unless the British change their minds," Moshe Shertok, head of the agency's political department, said today.

Mansfield, Ohio, City School District yesterday announced that it would receive bids Feb. 27 for $2,011,000 of bonds dated April 1, 1947, and due April and Oct. 1 from 1948 to 1967. Interest must not exceed 2 per cent.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I wish to congratulate you upon the survey of the world relief needs which appeared in THE TIMES Feb. 3. It gives a clear presentation of the facts to the American people. I should like to point out the challenge which this situation presents to the voluntary relief organizations.

ROME, Feb. 11-The immediate problem confronting all those who seek to alleviate the lot of European Jews is to evacuate 235,000 Jews from Germany, Austria, and Italy, Rabbi Barnett R. Brickne of Cleveland, one of the honorary chairmen of the United Jewish Appeal, said today at the conclusion of a fact-finding tour of Europeon behalf of his organization.

Herbert H. Lehman, first Director General of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, appealed yesterday to the White House for immediate, largescale shipments of coal to Britain as a humanitarian measure.

Realty owners ousted from their properties by large post-war housing projects in Manhattan gradually are finding new locations to carry on their activities. Two such deals involving displaced holders of properties within building sites on the lower East Side were reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11--Forney Johnston of Birmingham, Ala., on behalf of the National Coal Association, today warned Congress that this country is threatened not only with another nation-wide coal strike soon, but with "a series of strikes in industry of disastrous proportions," if unions are permitted to seek welfare funds from employers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11--Neglected rural areas and minority groups are slated for priorities in regulations governing the nationwide hospital construction program, issued today by Surgeon General Thomas Parran of the Public Health Service.

LONDON, Feb. 11--The conflict between the United States and the Soviet Union that has persistently marked the meetings of the Foreign Ministers' deputies for Austria flared up today to a new height of oral violence.
