Supreme Court Justice Bernard Botein has approved a cash offer of $975,000 made by the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, as trustee of the William Waldorf Astor estate, for the fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 1070 Park Avenue, on a plot 100.8 by 145 feet at the southwest corner of Eighty-eighth Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11--In a proxy statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the United Corporation disclosed today that it proposes to employ its capital in "special situations" after it has ceased to be a holding company in compliance with an SEC order.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11--The Securities and Exchange Commission in supplemental findings and opinion today announced approval of an alternative plan for recapitalization of the New England Gas and Electric Association and settlement of intercompany claims.

Efficient, clear writing and reading and use of books for investigation were named yesterday as the major, ideal goals of higher education for women by the dean-elect of Barnard College, Columbia University.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Feb. 11 --The first session of the Preparatory Commission for the International Refugee Organization opened here today. The delegates were welcomed by Sir Rafael Cilento, chief of the refugee section of the United Nations, who in a short speech outlined the organization's problems.

A demand for a complete investigation of the New York City public school system on the ground that it is "chaotic" and that it dispenses "a form of pseudo education" was made yesterday by the Businessman's and Taxpayers Association of Corona, Queens.

ALBANY, Feb. 11--Brushing aside the claims of organized labor and the Democrats for representation on the Board of Regents, the Senate and Assembly, meeting separately, today nominated Roger W. Straus of New York, Mrs. Frank E. Gannett of Rochester and Welles V. Moot of Buffalo for three existing vacancies.
LONDON, Feb. 11--Britain was fighting a losing battle today against the coal crisis. All signs point to still greater restrictions in the use of electricity.

Winter temperatures were moderate in the East and Midwest yesterday but in parts of the "sunny South" the mercury still was flirting with freezing weather, and fruit and vegetable crops were threatened in spite of a wide use of smudge pots.

BOSTON, Feb. 11 (AP)--Sparked by George Hauptfuhrer and Captain Saul Mariaschin, Harvard outclassed Dartmouth, 58--45, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game at Boston Garden tonight. The Crimson was ahead at the intermission, 26--18.

TOKYO, Feb. 11--Based on Jan. 1 prices the average monthly living cost of a family of five members is 1,486 yen, which is 198 yen above that of Nov. 1, according to the Government Price Board. The figures are roughly nineteen times the pre-war level.

Champion Twin Ponds Belle, Welsh terrier owned by Mrs. Edward P. Alker of Great Neck, L.I., was one of the winners to attract most attention at the Associated Terrier Clubs' big all-terrier carnival at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory yesterday.

PARIS, Feb. 11--On the insistence of Robert Schuman, Finance Minister, the Cabinet agreed today that, pending the approval of the "extraordinary" budget by Parliament, only 60 per cent of the expenditures under it would be permitted.

Some years ago a few tackle manufacturers, outdoor magazines, resort towns and fishing clubs with too few members decided something would have to be done to stimulate interest in fishing, so they decided to conduct fishing contests.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP)-- Senator Harry F. Byrd of Virginia said today that the end of hostilities in the second World War had brought "little reduction in the tremendous war expansion of the Government." He asserted that it was apparent that Federal executive agencies were trying to perpetuate themselves in office.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 11 (AP)-- Bomb-hurling Zionist extremists fought anti-terrorist Zionists in the heart of Tel Aviv tonight in a battle in which at least a dozen persons were injured, reliable private sources said.

ROME, Feb. 11 (AP)--Foreign Minister Count Carlo Sforza called today for a revision of the Italian peace treaty signed yesterday in Paris, and declared that an Italy stripped of her colonies and some of her homeland "cannot possibly nourish" her 45,000,000 inhabitants.

Gray goods price charts refute claims of mill men that cotton goods prices are equal to or below price ceilings, Max J. Lovell, directorcounsel of the House Dress Institute, asserted yesterday in a statement to the press.

NANKING, Feb. 11--The crumbling economic situation today confronted the Chinese Government with the gravest crisis that it has experienced since the low ebb of its fortunes in the autumn of 1894 in the first war with Japan.

The Hatch Act, adopted seven years ago, was a laudable effort "to prevent pernicious political activities." There is a growing feeling in Congress that neither it nor the corrupt practices statute goes far enough, and that both must be replaced by stronger legislation if campaign expenditures are to be kept within proper limits.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11-William Benton, Assistant Secretary of State in charge of the information division, said today that his department was "exploring the possibilities of a program of bilateral negotiations with foreign countries" to implement various international declarations and our own firm policy of world freedom of information as a safeguard against aggressive war.

The Governments of the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg, reporting tourist accommodations more than 75 per cent restored since the end of the war, announced yesterday the opening of a Joint promotion campaign for travel and joint action to eliminate travel barriers.

Judicial and Objective Mr. Dooley's version of the Dreyfus trial procedure just about half a century ago may have stirred memories here and there at the beginning of the City Hall subway fare hearing.

Twice refused permission by city authorities to burn their draft cards on crowded Fourteenth Street in protest against "continuation of wartime conscription," members of the "Break With Conscription Committee" last night settled for an incinerator in Greenwich Village where they disposed of sixty-three draft cards and substitutes.

A rally in the value of China's wildly plunging currency suggests that complete financial collapse in that unhappy nation may not be as near at hand as it has seemed to be in recent weeks. The recovery may be only temporary. But not even a momentary stabilization could have occurred unless the Chinese people still retained some faith in their Government's assurances that the crisis can and will be controlled.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 12--The drastic measures recently taken in Palestine were intended primarily to influence British opinion and not necessarily directed against terrorists. It is a question of policy, probably long-term.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12--Win or lose, President Truman intends to press his nomination of David E. Lilienthal for chairmanship of the United States Atomic Energy Commission to a voting showdown in the Senate, it was learned authoritatively tonight.

ALBANY, Feb. 12--Seeking to curb portal-to-portal pay suits, now totaling more than $9,000,000,000 nationally, Assemblyman Justin C. Morgan, Buffalo Republican, asked today for a new definition of overtime.

Sales and earnings of the Jewel Tea Company, Inc., last year were the highest in the history of the company, according to the thirtyfirst annual report released for publication today. Total sales of $88,237,518 were 39.3 per cent above the 1945 volume of $63,364,000.

Sales of leading mail and chain store companies in January showed a rise of 22.4 per cent over the same month in 1946, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. Grocery chain volume led with a grain of 33 per cent, with mail order companies second with an increase of 27.2 per cent.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Feb. 12--Signs that large sections of the German people are progressively exhausting their savings are focussing the attention of economists on the divergence between controlled prices of the official economy and the black market rates.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, IndoChina, Feb. 11 (Delayed)--King Norodom Sihanouk, 26-year-old bachelor, who is god as well as monarch to most of the 3,000,000 Cambodians, declared in an interview today that his country must remain under the protection of France for practical reasons, although his personal sentiments would favor complete independence.

Many ready-to-wear buyers plan weekly visits to the market here to check up on deliveries of apparel in view of the short six weeks' selling period now remaining before Easter, it was reported here yesterday. Estimates were that orders placed thus far for spring apparel range around 60 per cent of probable needs and the buyers will be here to seek the new styles which beoome available to round out stocks.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12--The United States will consider sympathetically any appeal from Britain for the diversion of coal to the United Kingdom during the present fuel emergency, it was learned today.
An American labor delegation returned from Argentina yesterday, impressed by the relatively high living standards of Argentine workers but disturbed by some phases of the Peron regime's labor policy.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Feb. 12 -- A labor feud with sanguinary potentialities has developed in the deep South, as a result of the tenmonth-old organizing campaign rivalry between the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organization.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 12--A break in a major natural gas line in West Virginia at 10 A.M. today crippled production of 152 industries in the Pittsburgh district, and curtailed supplies to the industrial plants in West Virginia and eastern Ohio.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 12 (AP)-- Two points awarded to Navy when West Virginia's Eddie Beach touched the middle goal enabled the Navy's "mighty mites" to topple the towering Mountaineers from basketball's undefeated ranks today, 57--55.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12--Secretaries Robert P. Patterson and James Forrestal stepped into a swelling Congressional dispute over proposed cuts in Federal spending today with expressions of alarm over their effect on the country's security.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12--Lessing J. Rosenwald, president of the American Council for Judaism, charged today that the rosy pictures that have been painted of Palestine as a solution to the problem of the Jews were a product of "imaginative phantasy" and urged that the entire question be placed before the United Nations.

LONDON, Feb. 12--The opening of the new account in the stock market today was accompanied by further falls in British Government stocks and industrials. Prices began to slip as soon as the markets opened and jobbers had to absorb a steady stream of selling orders.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Feb. 12 (AP)--Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, differing with some of his Republican colleagues on taxes and tariffs, tonight outlined a program to promote a "balanced" economy and called for a special Senate study of labor-management relations.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 12--Mohammed Nimer al Huwari, stocky, belligerent leader of Najada, the older and larger of the Palestine Arabs' two semi-military organizations, declared today that his army would be ready at any moment that Arab political leaders "call on us to start our career of action."

WARSAW, Feb. 12-- President Boleslaw Bierut told the foreign press today that a Government amnesty would free "an overwhelming majority" of the Poles in prison and enable "nearly everyone" to leave the underground and rejoin Polish society.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 12 -- Sam Bischoff has purchased "Intrigue," a screen story by George Slavin, as a vehicle for George Raft, with whom Bischoff has formed a producing partnership. "Intrigue," will follow "Pitfall" on Bischoff's schedule as the second of four films he has contracted to produce for United Artists release.
A militant program to mobilize American women in support of the United Jewish Appeal's drive for funds to rehabilitate Europe's displaced persons was announced here yesterday by Mrs. David M. Levy.

Fashions in fabric and silhouette were combined in a well-coordinated showing that took place yesterday in the Cottage of Hampshire House. The fabrics were John Walther's woolens; the styles were by many of New York's leading coat and suit designers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12--The United States and Canada agreed today to continue the wartime collaboration of their national defense establishments in the post-war period "for peacetime joint security purposes.'

Unlike the war years, profits in 1946 were normal in relation to the national income and in line with long-term ratios for active peacetime years, it was declared in a survey released yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

A hearing set for 10 A.M. today in Washington before the House Committee on the Merchant Marine and Fisheries probably will decide before nightfall whether the Maritime Commission is to continue as the operator of Governmentowned shipping.

Prices of industrial supplies and equipment have advanced an average of about 20 per cent since last November, industrial purchasing spokesmen disclosed here yesterday. They said the test will come in the next sixty days, during which continued high production is expected to provide the stabilizing influence to check further advances.

MOSCOW, Feb. 12--An article by M. Marinin in Pravda today charged that United States and British policy in Germany was pushing that country toward an economic collapse to ease the task of taking over German industry and forming a western German state under United States and British control.

One of last year's group winners, the boxer champion Warlord of Mazelaine, triumphed in his breed last night to become eligible for further conquests and another, the English setter champion, Prune's Own Palmer, was beaten in the judging that opened the seventy-first Westminster Kennel Club show.

PARIS, Feb. 12--In a detailed report to the National Assembly's Finance Committee today, Robert Schuman, Minister of Finance, estimated the total charges on the Treasury for 1947 at approximately 600,000,000,000 francs.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 12 (AP)--The Coast Guard reported tonight it had been advised by radio from the cutter Pandora that the yacht Stormy Weather was due to cross the finish line at Nassau at 10:30 P.M. (Eastern Standard Time) in the Miami-to-Nassau sailing event.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12 (AP)-- The United States Women's Squash Racquets Association today voted to invite England to send a team to the United States next year to resume competition for the WolfeNoel Cup, suspended in 1939. England leads in the series, 4 to 2.

TOKYO, Feb. 12--Gen. Douglas MacArthur's two orders banning general strikes in Japan and directing that an election be held next spring as a safety valve for political unrest have apparently brought to an end, at least temporarily, the wave of work stoppages that had been sweeping the country since last fall.

BERLIN, Feb. 12--In a remarkably forthright report of the United States Military Government for Berlin, the Soviet Union is officially described as "most distasteful" to the population here. Part of the reason for this, it is officially declared, is that "the city was taken by the Russians, whose destruction and poor conduct engendered a bitter hatred."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 12 -- The mounting behind-thescenes row over the failure of the United Nations Military Staff Commmittee to get on with its job of planning an international police force received its first public Security Council airing today.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The editorial section of THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 5, 1947, contains a map showing the distribution of displaced persons in Europe. The number of displaced persons in Austria is recorded as 80,000, of whom 50,000 are listed as non-Jews.
LONDON, Feb. 12--Foreign Secretary Bevin disclosed today that he was ready to seek the United Nations' help in the Palestine impasse.

Music is completely a psychological thing.The fact is nowhere more evident than in the wholly invisible relations which exist between a conductor, the music he interprets and the orchestra which he endeavors to infuse with his interpretation.

Denouncing any increase in the five-cent transit fare as "a harsh and unbearable tax on the city's low-income families, Mayor O'Dwyer broadcast the Board of Estimate's opposition to a higher fare by radio from City Hall last night.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 12 -- A showdown on the right of the American Federation of Labor and its locals to maintain closed-shop contracts with employers was started today with a filing of a civil action in Maricopa County Superior Court testing the constitutionality of Arizona's anti-closedshop law.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12--A program for the merger of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers and the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen, which together represent more than 200,000 engineers, firemen and hostlers, was outlined today by the Consolidation Committee of Enginemen, a new organization.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12--The State Department declared tonight that Gerhard Eisler, the alleged Comintern representative in this country who has been cited for contempt of Congress after refusing to testify before the House Committee on Un-American Activities, had been prevented at its insistence from sailing for Russia last October on the Soviet vessel Kozma Minov.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 12--Premier Tito issued a sweeping demobilization order on Feb. 4, it was announced today. The order provides that demobilization be completed by April 10.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Professor F.W. Foerster's letter, published in THE TIMES on Jan. 16, deals with a highly complex problem and contains so much truth that it deserves for this reason alone the widest distribution.

ALBANY, Feb. 12--Gov. Thomas E. Dewey in an address at the Lincoln Day dinner of the Albany County Republican Committee declared tonight that the Republican party is the only one offering the State and country responsible government in the Lincoln tradition.

Tenants of more than a hundred Manhattan apartment houses have been warned by the owners of the buildings that they cannot use television receivers in their homes at present because of complications in erecting suitable aerials for the sets, it became known yesterday.

Columbia maintained its lead in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League race by defeating Pennsylvania, 66 to 50, in the Morningside Heights gymnasium last night. The game was part of the Lions' Alumni Day celebration.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (U.P.)-- Lumber costs are in a "chaotic situation," the Commerce Department reported today with the warning that lumber dealers will lose markets unless prices come down.

BOSTON, Feb. 12 -- Abraham Lincoln's philosophy of no compromise with any force which would undermine or destroy the Union was urged upon Republicans tonight by Senator Kenneth S. Wherry, the Republican whip, at the Lincoln's Day dinner of the Middlesex Club.

PARIS, Feb. 12--There is a comfortable, easy look about Jacques Heim's top coats, with their deep, unpressed, box pleating in back and wide three-quarter sleeves. All in soft tweeds, the colors belong to the violet family, mauves, cyclamen, fuchsia, lilac, with some yellows and greens.
Establishment of a permanent minority to organize a State university system was urged yesterday by the Public Education Association and the Union for Democratic Action.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12--In a brief ceremony, President Truman visited the Lincoln Memorial here today and watched Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan, his military aide, carry his wreath of white flowers up the long steps to the foot of the statue and deposit it among the many tributes that were left there all day long.

The first critical test in the disarmament discussions of the Security Council was successfully met last night when the Council passed by a vote of 9 to 0 the Russian proposal for a new commission to study armament reduction but with the American proviso that it should deal only with conventional arms and not with those already being dealt with by the Atomic Energy Commission.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 12 (AP) --Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. said here tonight that partisan poltics in this country "stops at the water's edge."

LONDON, Feb. 12--The Soviet Union submitted today to the Foreign Ministers' deputies for Germany new procedural proposals admitting the principle of smallpower participation in the preparation of the peace treaty.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: May I as a visiting British journalist draw attention to an interesting aspect of the proposed future of the blitzed Coventry Cathedral?

Floyd (Bill) Bevens, Manager Bucky Harris' No. 2 pitcher, reached New York yesterday, went into a short huddle with President Larry MacPhail and emerged a signed Yankee. Beveins is the forty-fifth Yank to indicate he is satisfied.

James M. Cecil, general chairman of the Red Cross 1947 Fund Drive for $60,000,000 opening on March 1, and a group of Red Cross officials made an inspection yesterday of the Veterans Administration Hospital at 130 West Kingsbridge Road, Bronx.
LONDON, Feb. 12 -- Electricity restrictions were spread today to the whole of England, Scotland and Wales as the Government announced that the coal situation "remains dangerously critical."

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Feb. 12--The United States Military Government "authorized and directed" the Cabinets of Bavaria, Wuerttemberg-Baden and Greater Hesse today to enact identical laws granting Germans expelled from the Sudetenland and other areas the same civic rights and duties as other Germans.

The Theatre Guild yesterday confirmed the closing on March 15 of "The Iceman Cometh" at the Martin Beck, and almost at the same time the office of George Abbott announced that its new musical comedy, "Barefoot Boy With Cheek," will take up residence at that playhouse the evening of April 3.
Formation of a joint public relations committee of the alumni of the four city colleges to assist the Board of Higher Education was advocated yesterday by Dr. Ordway Tead, president of the board.

Sons of two of the most famous players in the history of racquets, Clarence C. Pell Jr. of Roslyn and Stanley G. Mortimer Jr. of Tuxedo, met in the national amateur championship yesterday as the tournament started at the Racquet and Tennis Club.
A city fireman's quick action yesterday saved two small boys from drowning in the frigid Bronx River.

Representatives of the principal newspaper, radio and periodical correspondents' associations in Washington have reported to Secretary of State Marshall that they regard Russia's proposals for American news coverage of the forthcoming Moscow conference as "shockingly inadequate."
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Feb. 12--In at least one respect the Allies' refusal to let Netherland officials and business men into Germany is hitting directly at American interests.

The second round of the battle to save the life of Scout, a K-9 veteran of the Bronx, doomed to die for biting three persons, two of them children, was fought yesterday. A letter went out from his owners to President Truman appealing for his aid in saving the life of their pet, and two former Coast Guardsmen, one of them his trainer, the other his detrainer, came to the dog's defense.

Five major objectives in the field of city finances were advanced yesterday for the current year by the Citizens Budget Commission. The commission, which has been active in the field of municipal finances for fourteen years, made public its annual report.
LACHMONT, N.Y., Feb. 12-- Off a snow-piled shore the dinghy sailors at the Larchmont Yacht Club set forth on the frigid briny today.

Low-end dress manufacturers seeking to tighten their operations in the face of increased costs and consumer resistance, have informed mills selling them finished rayon goods that they cannot countenance any shortening of credit terms.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12--One of the first changes in the organization of the State Department that Secretary Marshall made was to unify its intelligence unit, known as "Research and Analysis." This step, the effect of which was to take control of departmental information away from minor officials with a personal stake in what to do with it, restores the plan advocated unsuccessfully by Col. Alfred McCormack of New York City during the regime of Secretary Byrnes.

Back in 1926 George Kelly's "Craig's Wife," the penetrating study of a selfish, narrow woman, won him the Pulitzer Prize. Since then Harriet Craig has come to life in a couple of movies, has been heard on the radio and has been somewhat of a staple of little theatres throughout the land.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- "If there is a third World War," said Gen. H.H. Arnold before he retired as head of the Army Air Forces, "its strategic center will be the North Pole."

BOSTON, Feb. 12 (AP)--Inspired by tributes paid to Dit Clapper, their coach, for his twenty years of service in the National Hockey League, the Boston Bruins regained undisputed possession of third place by overwhelming the New Tork Rangers, 10--1, tonight at the Boston Garden.

PARIS, Feb. 12--The first offer by an Allied nation to enter into treaty negotiations with a defeated Axis state now that the peace has been signed came today from Czechoslovak Foreign Minister Jan. Masaryk.

Lincoln's Birthday Trade Active With weather conditions favorable, Lincoln's Birthday trade was active here yesterday. Business was well distributed among main floor and home furnishings departments, with fur promotions doing well.

Mark Twain's statement that everyone talks about the weather but nobody does anything about it appeared headed for contradiction yesterday with an announcement by the Weather Bureau that beginning about March 1 it will offer to all who want it a twenty-fourhour city-wide weather teletype service.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 12--The plane riding 5-year-olds, Buzfuz and Lets Dance, who a month ago had been running in California, had things all to themselves in the $10,000 added Seminole Handicap at Hialeah Park today. Buzfuz was first, his stablemate was second and the others in the field of seven were up the stretch at the end of the seven furlongs.

Conrad Cardinal von Preysing, Bishop of Berlin, left Germany by plane yesterday and is expected to arrive here today for a month's visit in this country as the guest of the Roman Catholic hierarchy in the United States, it was announced last night by the Chancery Office of the New York Catholic Archdiocese, 477 Madison Avenue.

The kale that the Department of Agriculture has just announced will be plentiful in our markets during March already is in excellent supply, according to Mrs. Frances Foley Gannon, head of the consumers' service bureau of the City Department of Markets.

Following is the text of Mayor O'Dwyer'a radio speech last night upholding the five-cent fare, with the text of a statement by Borough President Cornelius A. Hall of Staten Island explaining why he refrained from voting with other Board of Estimate members for the five-cent fare:
Patrolman Robert Smith, 41 years old, was on the critical list in Wyckoff Heights Hospital in Brooklyn last night, a .38-caliber bullet from his own service revolver lodged near his heart.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12.--Proposed changes in the rent control structure to localize eviction proceedings and to facilitate the provision of relief to landlords undergoing economic hardship were prepared today by Senator Albert W. Hawkes, Republican, of New Jersey.

Three hundred delegates of the Eastern Regional Conference of Conservative Baptists, meeting at Baptist Temple, Third Avenue and Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn, voted approval last night of a plan to organize a national association.
Inadequate tenure protection, poor retirement laws and community restrictions keep thousands of competent men and women from entering the teaching profession.

Persons who have visited the bedding shop at Lord Taylor liked the mock beds for displaying mattreses so much that the pieces have now been made into fullfledged studio, twin-size and double beds. They are included in the new bedroom settings that went on view yesterday on the eighth floor.
OTTAWA, Ont., Feb. 12 (AP) -- Graham F. Towers, governor of the Bank of Canada, warned in his annual report today that Canada cannot continue indefinitely to sell on credit in overseas markets.

Harold E. Stassen, former Governor of Minnesota and avowed candidate for the nomination for President in 1948, last night called upon the Republican party to abandon its traditional high tariff policies and support continuance of the reciprocal trade program developed under the late Franklin D. Roosevelt.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12--A proposal to exempt, in effect, all furtrimmed coats less than $135 in value from excise taxes appeared today to be gathering strength in the Senate.

LONDON, Feb. 12--The British Government announced tonight it had decided to recognize formally the Bulgarian Government. The decision was made known in a note that reiterated the British censure of the methods used by the Bulgarian regime to consolidate its power.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- A "major step" toward creation of competition in the aluminum industry has been taken by selling surplus plants to competitors of the Aluminum Company of America, the War Assets Administration stated today.
Joe Lapchick's St. John's basketball team continued its mastery over local teams when it added Fordham to its victims yesterday at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory, outscoring the Rams, 60--36.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

Matching its virtuosity in the field events with peak performances in the foot races, New York University's well-balanced squad rolled up 77 points to take the team title in the fifth metropolitan intercollegiate indoor track and field championships at the Twenty-second Engineers Armory last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12--Authorization by the Federal Communications Commission for commercial operation of the Columbia Broadcasting System's sequential color television service was urged at today's FCC hearing by Adrian Murphy, vice president of CBS.

Sharp criticism of military interference with economic affairs in Germany was expressed yesterday by some business men with investments in that country as a result of the decartelization laws announced in the combined BritishAmerican zones.

The Riverside Museum reports that 5,115 visitors attended the exhibition of the La Tausca 1947 art competetion, which closed Sunday. Paintings by Byron Browne, Philip Ebergood, Lily Harmon, Yasuo Kuniyoshi, Abraham Rattner, Felix Ruvolo and Jack Levine were sold.

BERLIN, Feb. 12 -- The Russians are seizing Germans released from United States prisoner-ofwar camps and taking them to Moscow, it was definitely established today. The positive evidence confirms rumors long circulating here, but hitherto lacking proof.

NANKING, Feb. 12--Government leaders promised drastic steps today to deal with economic conditions in China. At the same time the outward manifestations of the crisis became less evident and Chinese currency recovered somewhat.

ALBANY, Feb. 12 -- New and stringent penalties for public employes who engage in strikes were proposed today with the support of the Republican legislative leadership as 1,000 teachers staged a mass demonstration here for higher wage scales and additional State aid for education.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12--Earl F. Reed, counsel for the Weirton Steel Company in its thirteen-year litigation with the Government on labor matters, today proposed that the Wagner Act be amended. He asked that the change be made so that employers be allowed to discharge strikers who remain away from their jobs for more than sixty days "as a test of economic strength in a demand for higher wages or shorter hours or better working conditions."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP)-- Following is the text of a CanadianUnited States announcement on joint defense measures: Announcement was made in Ottawa and Washington today of the results of discussions which have taken place in the Permanent Joint Board on Defense on the extent to which the wartime cooperation between the armed forces of the two countries should be maintained in this post-war period.

LONDON, Feb. 12 (AP)--Representatives of the private enterprise merchant marines of fourteen countries today decided to demand a hearing before the United Nations equally with a proposed intergovernmental shipping advisory group.
ST., PAUL, Minn., Feb. 12 -- Wholesale resignation of St. Paul, Minn., teachers if increased wage demands are not met was predicted tonight by James E. Marshall, Superintendent of Schools.

Mayor O'Dwyer went into the hearings on transit in favor of the fivecent fare. He comes out the same way. That is the gist of his speech last night, a result well discounted but nevertheless thoroughly disappointing. The Board of Estimate stands with him, with the exception of the Borough President of Richmond, in being unconvinced that the subway rider, rich or poor, resident or visitor, should pay more than half-fare for a ten-cent ride.

The great bulb industry in the Netherlands survived the war and many new bulb varieties are available to American gardeners, Margaret Herbst of the Associated Bulb Growers of Holland said yesterday. Miss Herbst spoke at the third session of "Flowers for Your Garden," presented by THE NEW YORK TIMES at Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12 (AP)--Today's report at the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 8,000 head, total 16,000: market Irregular; opened steady to 25 cents higher; midsession trade mostly steady; closed 25 cents lower on weights 270 pounds and up; sows

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 12-- Yale maintained its complete mastery of Princeton in major sports since 1942 by downing the Tigers at basketball, 49-36, in the Payne Whitney gym and at hockey, 5-1, in the arena tonight.

The four-story building at 564 East Fourth Street, Brooklyn, containing six stores and twenty-four apartments, has been sold by David Rosenber and Ira Suval to the Nomark Realty Corporation. Philip Lipshitz and Morris Wollman were the brokers and the City Title Insurance Company insured the title.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan, it was learned yesterday, is about to investigate charges of underworld control of professional prizefighters. This inquiry will follow the barring of Rocky Graziano for failure to report a $100,000 bribe offer.

A minimum of $15,500,000 in additional State aid is needed by the New York City public school system to provide for increases in the salaries of teachers and supervisors, according to Andrew G. Clauson Jr., president of the Board of Education.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 12 --The United States version of the bitterly disputed paragraph governing the relations of the projected Disarmament Commission with the Atomic Energy Commission was adopted by the United Nations Security Council this evening by a vote of 9 to 0.

Before the war thousands of American students and teachers spent their summers abroad, combining serious academic work with pleasant travel. Many teachers gained more through their visits than they learned from a dozen textbooks. Their classroom work frequently improved as a result of their first-hand contact with other peoples.

SECURITY COUNCIL American version of disputed paragraph governing relations of projected disarmament commission with Atomic Energy Commission adopted, 9 to 0, Russia and Poland abstaining. Military Staff Committee delays aired in debate for first time.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 12--Contradicting a decision of another Superior Court jurist, Judge Walter Hendrix ruled in the Henry County Superior Court at McDonough today that Herman Talmadge was Georgia's legally chosen Governor.
Leaders of patriotic organizations and troops of Boy Scouts joined yesterday in special ceremonies in Manhattan commemorating the 138th anniversary of the birth of Abraham Lincoln.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12--An intensive Democratic organization drive in key States looking to 1948 was foreshadowed with the appointment today of Gael Sullivan as executive director of the Democratic National Committee under Robert E. Hannegan, chairman.

CRUGERS, N.Y., Feb. 12--On a plateau here overlooking the Hudson Valley, bulldozers began felling trees today and steam shovels started cutting vast gashes in the sodden earth to make space for the Government's newest venture in the care of neuropsychiatric veterans of the war--the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Veterans Hospital.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The House Labor Committee has determined to bring no labor reform bill to the floor until it has had the most binding evidence of what the Taft leadership in the Senate will do on the matter.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12--The teacher shortage in elementary schools constitutes one of the most critical situations ever encountered by this country, John W. Studebaker, Federal Education Commissioner, said in his annual report issued today.

This is the season when most hunters and fishermen are confronted with only three ways of putting in their time: hunting foxes, fishing through the ice or attending club dinners. According to the mail, the dinner form of diversion seems to be the most popular.

In his Lincoln Day address in this city last night Harold E. Stassen declared that the Republican party "can best honor Lincoln today, and best serve the people, by facing in a frank and forthright manner the great issues of the day. And," he added, "chief among these is our world economic policy."

TOLEDO, Feb. 12--Considerable success in connection with LibbeyOwens-Ford Glass Company's newspaper advertisements tied to community relations was reported here today by James M. Ashley, director of public relations. A survey following the campaign revealed that an average of 52 per cent of the public recognized the advertisements, and of these, 74 per cent labeled the campaign "good" and one which should be duplicated by other companies.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 12-- Fashion editors of magazines and newspapers throughout the country witnessed today a bit of local color in the grand manner at a luncheon fashion showing sponsored by D.H. Holmes Company, Ltd., at the Roosevelt Hotel.

Considerably bolstered by the addition of 6-foot 7-inch Lee Knorek at center, the New York Knickerbockers raced to a 76 to 72 victory over the league-leading Washington Capitols before 5,174 fans last night at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory.

Andrei A. Gromyko reiterated with force yesterday the view of the Soviet Union that the principle of the veto must be maintained as an integral part of any international convention on the control of atomic energy.

ALBANY, Feb. 12--On the eve of Mayor O'Dwyer's scheduled appeal for enlarged State aid for New York City, existence of a Democratic proposal to mandate upon the city new jobs and pay increases totaling $154,240 annually was disclosed today.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Feb. 12-- Dr. Moses Gomberg, one of the world's foremost authorities on organic chemistry, and retired chairman of the University of Michigan's chemistry department, died of a heart ailment today, just four days after his eighty-first birthday.

FORT BELVOIR, Va., Feb. 12-- This Army post in the Virginia hills--recently redesignated the engineer center of the Army--is the heart of an ambitious development program embracing everything from infra-red-ray "sniperscopes" to 150-ton military bridges.

BERLIN, Feb. 12--Gen. Ivan Sosonovitsh Kolesnitschenko, Military Governor of Thuringia, in the Soviet zone, told high functionaries of the German civil government of his province that he expected them to assume a greater degree of freedom and responsibility, it was reported here tonight by the Soviet news bureau.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 12 (AP)--Bud Washbond and Adrian Aubin rode to a slender lead in the Olympic bobsled tryouts today by capturing the opening heats of the two-man sled trials. Washbond, son of a 1936 Olympic winner, drove down Mount Van Hoevenberg's tortuous, ice-coated mile chute to two-heat time of 2.33:44 with Aubin as the brake.

LONDON, Feb. 12 (AP)--A British Treasury spokesman said today that the purchase of British-owned railways by Argentina would wipe out Argentina's sterling balances here and solve Britain's problem of how to dispose of war-accumulated funds in accordance with conditions of the United States loan agreement.

Ponchielli's "La Gioconda," which was presented last night at the Metropolitan Opera House for the first time this season, is an oldfashioned opera, filled with arias and concerted numbers for a good many principal singers, with rousing choruses and sure-fire ballet.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12--A review today of a month of intensive study by Congressional committees, Federal agencies and the aviation industry demonstrated that immediate responsibility for improving air safety rests primarily with the Federal Government, particularly in Congress.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., Feb. 13-- Lehigh University's basketball team avenged an early season defeat and won its first Middle Three game tonight by subduing Rutgers, 65 to 51.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP)-- War Department plans for a reduction of almost 200,000 in the size of the regular Army and establishment of an "M-Day" force of 1,750,000 trained troops were disclosed today by members of the House Armed Services Committee.

Bernard M. Baruch of the class of '89 of City College told 2,250 alumni yesterday afternoon that he "would not have been able to go to college had it not been for the free College of the City of New York."

An immediate reduction of 10 per cent in Federal taxes on personal and corporate income, as a means of safeguarding prosperity and protecting revenue, was urged yesterday by Russell C. Leffingwell, chairman of the executive committee of J.P. Morgan Co., Inc.

JULES VERNE once wrote a book, "Around the World in Eighty Days." He undoubtedly had Larry MacPhail in mind. The Rover Boy of the baseball profession hasn't quite achieved that lofty ambition as yet since he's only beginning to flex his muscles. Just give him time, though, and he'll do it eventually.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12 (AP)--A disputed goal in the last second of the first period tonight enabled the Montreal Canadiens to tie the Chicago Black Hawks, 1-all, in a National League hockey game before 18,627 persons in the Stadium.

PARIS, Feb. 12--After a mild effort to induce the National Assembly's Foreign Affairs Committee to subordinate the pact with Britain to the prior settlement of French-British differences over Germany, the Communists abandoned this stand today and accepted a compromise.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13--President Truman resolutely pronounced David B. Lilienthal thoroughly equipped for the chairmanship of the United States Atomic Energy Commission today, and served notice that he would stay with his nominee straight through.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 13 --A new Commission on Conventional Armaments was created by the United Nations Security Council today and charged with the momentous task of preparing within three months a plan for the general regulation and reduction of armaments and armed forces, with practical and effective safeguards for the nations of the world.

ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- Mayor O'Dwyer denied today that he had approved the proposal to provide new mandatory jobs and pay increases in the offices of the five District Attorneys in New York City. They would cost $154,240 a year.

City Financing An overnight markdown in New York City bonds of from 1/2 point to a full point was the response of municipal bond traders yesterday to the turn taken by the issues stemming from the subway fare and other City Hall headaches.

Behind Three Curtains The visitor said he had just read with great interest the first of a series of articles in one of the big national magazines on why the American people have found it impossible to understand Russia, thus unwittingly doing our share to encourage dangerous international tensions.

L.E. Waterman Company, makers of Waterman's pens and ink, will begin tomorrow the most intensive spring advertising and promotion campaign it has ever undertaken, it was announced yesterday by Frank D. Waterman Jr., president.
For the first time in the history of this country school teachers in substantial numbers have gone out on strike or are threatening to strike.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13--Americans have provided their own Social Security to the extent of about $305,000,000,000 amassed through savings, investments and insurance, the Research Council for Economic Security at Chicago, said today. The estimate was made after a study of what people were doing to provide for their own disabilities and old age.

LANSFORD, Pa., Feb. 13--Completing the first twenty-four hours of a sitdown strike 600 feet underground, fourteen Lansford miners tonight were passing the time playing cards and reading by the flickering lights on their caps.

A tightening up of the labor market virtually has wiped out jobs for boys and girls under 18 years old, according to the annual report, issued yesterday, of the Kennedy Employment Service of the Community Service Society.
BUFFALO, Feb. 13 (U.P.)--Canisius College's in-and-out basketball team was hot tonight, crushing highly regarded New York University, 61-54, before a crowd of 4,317.

One of the season's most exciting and refreshing collections of millinery was presented by B. Altman Co. yesterday in the showing of Henri de Chatillon hats. This designer, a citizen of the world, being French and British by birth and working in Mexico, Paris and New York, believes that a truly charming hat will be as eye-compelling on one side of the Atlantic as the other.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13--Declaring that "the integrity and good faith" of Henry Morgenthau Jr., former Secretary of the Treasury, "have never been questioned," Secretary John W. Snyder, announced tonight a settlement of the controversy over Mr. Morgenthau's use of Treasury Department material in his 900-volume "diary," now being edited for publication.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 13 (AP)--Tuffield (Tuffy) Latour bid for a berth on the 1948 United States Olympic bobsled team today by driving to a split-second victory in the two-man sled Olympic trials for his second major triumph in five days.

ALBANY, Feb. 13--Bitter exchanges over Governor Dewey's policies, in which Senator Benjamin F. Feinberg pitted himself against Dr. Abraham Lefkowitz, veteran teacher representative, nearly broke up today's legislative hearing on the State budget.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13--The detailed story of how the Russians, during the war, commandeered American B-29 Superfortresses-- at that time our most secret aircraft-- that had been forced to land on Soviet soil, and interned the American crews under austere living conditions, was uncovered here today.

LITTLE AMERICA, Feb. 12 (Delayed) -- Waving through open windows atop their tanklike vehicles seven members of the Navy's expedition set forth just after 11 o'clock this morning on one of the longest projected mechanized journeys in the history of Antarctic exploration.

The song of the "ski" will be heard throughout the North Country this week-end. With the exception of Bear Mountain Park, Fahnestock Memorial Park and the Catskills, where conditions ranged from no skiing to fair, all the areas report good to excellent running conditions.

Economic conditions in Brazil indicate that inflation has reached its peak and there is every likelihood that the national economy soon will begin to return to normal, Clarence C. Brooks, Counselor of the Embassy for Economic Affairs, American Embassy, Rio de Janeiro, declared yesterday.

Judge Picard's decision in the Mount Clemens Pottery Company case has not killed off all pending portal-to-portal suits, nor has it diminished the need for Federal legislation to keep such demands from reaching fantastic limits. But the effect has been wholesome. Existing law, subject to confirmation by the Supreme Court, has been clarified.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13--President Truman refused today to be labeled as an active candidate for another term in the White House and said he would continue to conduct his high office as an agent of the American people "without regard to my personal political fortunes."

In the first sale of the property in eighty years, the two-story building at 567-69 East 184th Street, the Bronx, has been acquired by Carmine Lucia, who has been conducting the St. Lucia Funeral Home on the premises for many years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13--Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Feb. 8, was 767,481 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 67,570 cars or 8.1 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 54,241 cars or 7.6 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year and 11,649 cars or 1.5 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Subpoenas for two leading prizefight managers were issued yesterday by the New York County Grand Jury soon after James Plumeri, alias Jimmy Doyle, also a manager, had undergone an hour's questioning by the jurors.

Bruno Walter, 70-year-old conductor of international reputation, has been named "musical adviser" and principal conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society for next season, it was announced yesterday after a meeting of the society's board of directors.
LONDON, Feb. 13--Gen. Mark W. Clark and Fedor T. Gusev, Soviet deputy, clashed again today in the meeting of the Foreign Ministers' deputies for Austria over the issue of freedom of speech.
The State Liquor Authority disapproved yesterday the applications for renewal of liquor licenses for nine Longchamps restaurants. They expire Feb. 28.

Floyd B. Odlum, president of the Atlas Corporation, announced yesterday that the indicated asset value of the investment comapany's common stock increased to approximately $36.06 a share on Dec. 31, 1946, compared with $34.14 a year earlier.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 13--Authority to delist the $1-par-value common stock of the Standard Silver Lead Mining Company of Spokane, Wash., was granted to the New York Curb Exchange today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
LONDON, Feb. 13 (AP)--Britain wisecracked, as well as worked and worried through the coal crisis today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- A warning to Congress that a general increase in rent ceilings would react in demands for higher wages and stimulate industrial unrest was presented today by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor.

Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle notified the members of the Fire Department last night that they would not be permitted to sell tickets for their social affairs and that disciplinary action would be taken against anyone violating the rule.

The absence of any legal obstruction to covenants restricting real estate on racial grounds was cited in a decision yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Jacob H. Livingston. The court, on the basis of such a covenant, granted an injunction forbidding sale of a home at 112-03 177th Street, in Addisleigh Park, St. Albans, Queens, to a Negro.

Virtual elimination of any prospect of a widespread Southern textile strike this year was reported yesterday by the Textile Workers Union, CIO. The union based its forecast on the signing of contracts providing a 10 per cent wage increase for 15,000 employes of the Dan River Cotton Mills at Danville, Va., and the Marshall Field Mills at Spray, Leaksville and Draper, N.C.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 13--Business in the Pittsburgh district last week showed the first significant decline in 1947, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. The setback was indicated in the preceding week, when announcement was made that most of the gas ordinarily used by industry would be diverted to domestic uses during the exceedingly cold weather.

Fall Lines to Open Early Members of the Fashion Originators Guild will open their fall 1947 lines beginning May 19, it was announced yesterday by Leonard W. Gendler, executive secretary. This year's openings are the earliest in the sixteen years' history of the guild, he pointed out and should aid marketing efficiency of manufacturers and retailers.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 13--The Communists' desire to push nationalization farther is creating new trouble for Czechoslovakia's somewhat shaky coalition Government. The Socialist press warns, in effect, today that the differences have gone about far enough.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13--The House Labor Committee resolved today to reach out into an unprecedented investigation, perhaps foreshadowing others, of an alleged breakdown of local law enforcement in a labor dispute.

Construction will start soon on a new brick edifice for St. Adalbert's Roman Catholic Church, facing Eighty-third Street near Grand Avenue, Elmhurst, Queens, and running through the block to Eighty-fourth Street, it was announced yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 13--Following is the text of Mayor William O'Dwyer's statement before the Legislative fiscal committees today, together with a digest of Controller Lazarus Joseph's statement and a memorandum submitted to the committee by John E. Burton, director of the State budget:

A banking group headed by the National City Bank won yesterday the award of $5,700,000 City of San Antonio, Texas, bonds, with a bid for a combination of interest coupons representing a net interest cost of 2.042 per cent. Four other bids ranged in interest cost from 2.084 per cent to 2.11 per cent.

A boxer that has been knocking at the door of greatness for a long while achieved it last night when Champion Warlord of Mazelaine was named best in show at the seventy-first Westminster Kennel Club exhibition in Madison Square Garden.

ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- Mayor O'Dwyer was notified by legislative leaders today that he would be required to justify personally legislation he is requesting to ease New York City's financial crisis. The notice came as he completed a plea for $102,000,000 in additional State aid at a hearing on Governor Dewey's $671,000,000 budget.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 13--An emergency bill to allow the Government to take over industries when a strike becomes a threat to the entire country was proposed tonight by Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio.

A further increase of 1,126,000 barrels last week in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the end of the week stocks were 101,705,000 barrels, against 100,579,000 a week earlier and 103,853,000 on Feb. 9, 1946.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 13-- Sir Alexander Korda's Hollywood representative announced today that Korda has signed Vivien Leigh to appear in an English film version of Tolstoy's "Anna Karenina," which will go before the cameras on April 15 at Korda's London Studios.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Recently I attended a dinner to arouse more interest in help for Europe's suffering children. A bewildering variety of rich foods was served in lavish extravagance. I am glad that our friends in Europe and Asia do not know how we live in this country. If they did they would never forgive us.

GENEVA, Feb. 13 (London Times Dispatch)--Though the preparatory commission of the International Refugees Organization succeeded in adopting its redrafted agenda today, delegates found that little progress could be made in the absence of more precise knowledge of the financial resources that will be available.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Feb. 13-- Rockwell Kent, 46 years old, a vice president of the Bank of the Manhattan Company in New York, committed suicide here today in his home at 360 Pondfield Road by taking an overdose of sleeping medicine, according to Dr. Edwin H. Huntington, acting County Medical Examiner.

PARIS, Feb. 13--The French draft proposal for an alliance with Britain will be submitted to the Cabinet tomorrow when the same party differences are expected to appear as in the meeting of the Foreign Affairs Committee of the Assembly yesterday.

The arbitration of a wage dispute between the National Maritime Union, CIO, and thirty-nine Atlantic and Gulf Coast steamship operators is scheduled to start at 2 P.M. today in a meeting room of the American Arbitration Association, 9 Rockefeller Plaza.

A pair of welterweights from New Jersey will head the boxing bill at Madison Square Garden tonight when Tippy Larkin, veteran campaigner from Garfield, opposes Charley Fusari, undefeated youngster from Irvington. The battle has "caught on" with Jersey fans and local boxing followers alike, with the result that a near capacity house and gross receipts of $100,000 are expected by the Twentieth Century Sporting Club.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 13 -- After having receded to a morning low of $6,100,000 Chinese, the price of ten-ounce gold bars climbed back and closed again tonight at $7,000,000 Chinese on the uncertain open money market here. The exchange rate leveled off at 13,800 Chinese dollars to one United States dollar.

An unpaid water bill turned up yesterday as the latest "misunderstanding" between the Russian occupants of the mansion at 6 East Eighty-seventh Street and their landlords. The building is used as a school for about seventy children of Russian representatives here, and has been partly converted to living quarters for some of the teachers.

Lumber prices will register an over-all drop of 10 per cent before the end of the first quarter, Fred W. Ritter, secretary-manager of the New York Lumber Trades Association, predicted yesterday. He declared that the reduction will be forced because yards all over the country propose to stock substitute materials rather than pay "unreasonable" mill prices.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13--The possibility that Senator John W. Bricker may yet contest Senator Robert A. Taft's claim on the Ohio "favorite son" designation to the Republican National Convention loomed large in, political speculation today as the principals ignored their best opportunity to date to announce agreement on the issue.

Nine persons were injured and fifty made homeless when three fires swept dwelling's in Brooklyn and lower Manhattan early yesterday. In addition, the two Manhattan fires, occurring only a few blocks apart and within a short time of each other, snarled the heavy truck traffic in the downtown area and caused the Police Department to assign additional traffic patrolmen for indefinite periods to direct the flow of vehicles.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- John J. McCloy, former Assistant Secretary of War and an attorney in New York City, was reported in informed circles here today to have decided to accept the presidency of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, popularly known as the World Bank.

Underwriting managers will place on the market today railroad and industrial securities as follows: Norwich Worcester Railroad Company--$1,800,000 of first mortgage bonds due in 1967 at 101, by Adams Peck. Wheeling Lake Erie Railway --$1,680,000 of serial equipment trust certificates maturing from Sept. 1, 1947, to March 1, 1957, at prices to yield from 0.90 per cent to 1.75 per cent, by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.

PARIS, Feb. 13 -- Bitterly denouncing Viet Nam ''atrocities," Premier Paul Ramadier today refused to take seriously bids for peace negotiations made indirectly in the name of President Ho Chi Minh. He was speaking at a press conference.

Conrad Cardinal van Preysing, Bishop of Berlin and enemy of Nazi doctrine, arrived by plane yesterday from Germany to thank the American people for helping displaced persons and sending relief supplies to his country.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13--A return to private sales of large quantities of raw cotton to Germany by late summer or early fall and to Japan a few months later is planned by the Government as part of its program for swift restoration of private trade with former enemy countries, it was learned today.

John Pawle, British titleholder, was eliminated from the national amateur racquets championship yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club. In the most notable victory of his career, Clarence C. Pell Jr. of Roslyn, L.I., defeated the young English stylist to gain the semi-final round of the tournament.

The recent North American Wildlife Conference devoted a good part of its program to the present waterfowl situation, and although papers were read by a number of learned biologists and waterfowl experts the net result seems to have been: "The situation is terrible, but what can we do?"
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP)--A four-months' extension of the Maritime Commission's authority to operate as a water carrier won unanimous approval today from the House Merchant Marine Committee.

Five New York City newspaper women from four newspapers received last night awards for outstanding work in their fields during 1946 at the twenty-fifth anniversary dinner of the New York Newspaper Women's Club.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 13--Nationalist military authorities in Honan Province have blocked an agreement under which the Central Government promised to deliver $5,000,000,000 Chinese to the Communists for the repair of dikes in that part of Red Shantung Province where the Yellow River is scheduled to be rediverted.

DETROIT, Feb. 13 -- Keen interest was shown by Midwestern Republicans tonight in the reunion which will be held tomorrow by Michigan industrialists and civic leaders with their Congressional delegation because of its possible bearing on the 1948 Presidential race.

A last-hour assault, succeeding a four-hour stretch of irregularity, produced yesterday the widest losses on the share market on the Stock Exchange in a month and several key units closed more than 2 points off on the day. This abrupt change, characteristic of several recent sessions, was not accompanied by unusual volume, but it did develop a marked broadening of trading.

The wholesale produce market presents a dismal picture this week-end, the United States Department of Agriculture reported yesterday, with many items considerably higher than they were a week ago. The general advance results from the recent freezing weather in Florida, which damaged snap beans, celery, citrus fruits and several other things.

Despite terrific handicaps European agriculture is staging a remarkable comeback even though food shortages are still the number one problem of the Continent. This is indicated in estimates of European beet-sugar production, a good indicator of agricultural productivity, released yesterday.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Feb. 13--The curtain will soon descend on one of the most remarkable financial dramas of the liberation period.

When President Truman was trying to find a competent chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission he turned to Chairman David E. Lilienthal of the Tennessee Valley Authority. His reasoning was sound. TVA was the biggest civilian peacetime enterprise the Federal Government had ever undertaken.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 13--Dr. Chaim Weizmann, former president of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, has just perfected a new process of chemical extraction that promises to have important effect on the plastics industry.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 13 -- Miss Sarry Neidlinger, one of the two skiing sisters from Hanover, N.H., defeated a more famous and favored pair of skiing sisters from Canada--the Wurtele twins of Montreal--to win first place in the downhill race opening event today in the Lake Placid Club's annual United States versus Canada women's ski meet for the Kate Smith trophy.

Full support of the proposed International Trade Organisation will be presented by W. H. Lukens, president, the Overseas Automotive Club, at the hearings to be held in New York, it was announced yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the club at the Hotel Woodstock.

The resumption by the Canadian Pacific Steamships, Ltd., of the role of big-time transatlantic ship operator is set for mid-May, when the liner Empress of Canada will complete her refitting and sail from Liverpool for the St. Lawrence ports of Quebec and Montreal, company officials announced yesterday.
PARIS, Feb. 13--Jean Patou presents a collection based on the week-end theme, demonstrated by his beach clothes and sports ensembles suitable for an informal holiday.

HENRY WALLACE undoubtedly would approve the entry list for the Baxter Mile at the New York A.C. meet in Madison Square Garden tomorrow night. It has been dedicated to the "Common Man." Gilbert Dodds so dedicated it when he decided to switch his own running efforts to the two-mile distance. The Perambulating Parson, who would wince visibly at the description, is our mile aristocrat, the lord of all he surveys.

While forty women who said they were her victims looked on yesterday in the Youth Term of the Felony Court, Elaine Pollack, 18 years old, of 1071 Failes Street, the Bronx, waived examination before Magistrate Raphael R. Murphy on complaints that she had stolen their pocketbooks after striking up conversations with eight of the women near Pennsylvania Station or Grand Central Terminal.

The concert given by the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra last night at Carnegie Hall was directed by Bruno Walter with masterly skill. For the event the conductor had arranged a well-devised program consisting of Wagner's "Faust" Overture, Vaughan Williams' Fifth Symphony and the Seventh Symphony of Beethoven.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 13-- The unionized workers of Tennessee carried to the floor of the Legislature this afternoon their fight against an "open shop" bill after marching 2,500-strong on the Capitol in a rare demonstration for this region.

Except perhaps for Tommy Quinn, who sincerely believes he can catch Gilbert Dodds if he chases him long enough, the milers unanimously wish the Iron Deacon happy hunting in his quest of Greg Rice's indoor two-mile record at the New York Athletic Club meet in Madison Square Garden tomorrow night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP)-- Secretary of State George C. Marshall reported to Congress today that the United States has collected $10,000,000 from sales of surplus combat equipment to foreign Governments.

Frederick H. Ecker, chairman of the board of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, told field representatives in convention yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel that 1947 should be a year of sustained business activity and one in which new investments could be made at a more favorable rate than in 1946.

From all points of the country, the Yankees poured into town yesterday to prepare for their imminent flying tour to various points in the Caribbean. Manager Bucky Harris and most of the leading lights of the Stadium squad are slated to take off this morning for Puerto Rico, first stop on their spring training junket.

Cementing anew the close friendship which has united them for more than a century, the United States and Canada have agreed to continue the wartime cooperation of their armed forces in order to promote their own joint security and world peace within the framework of the United Nations.

Total loans and investments of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System were reduced $165,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday to $18,279,000,000, the lowest level since June, 1944, according to the report released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

The President's declaration that the American Government stands ready to do everything in its power to relieve the plight of the British people is not, as he says, in response to any appeal for aid. The British have not asked for help in the emergency that has put the whole nation back on a war footing.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13--President Truman declared today the United States Government was ready to do everything in its power to relieve the fuel emergency in Great Britain. He added that no request for assistance had been received from the British Government.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 13-- State Senator David Van Alstyne Jr., of Englewood, chairman of the Legislative Appropriations Committee, announced tonight after the committee's first session that nearly half of Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll's $155,800,000 budget had been checked and tentatively approved.

The first complete wardrobe of a "woman of fashion" to take its place in the collections of the Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum of Art was presented to the institution yesterday by Bloomingdale's at a luncheon in the Cottage of Hampshire House.

Canceling all early gains, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 20 to 39 points net lower than the day before. It started active, 3 to 10 points up, and advanced to gains of 10 to 23 points.

MOSCOW, Feb. 13--An appeal for the resignation of the Yoshida Government in Japan and diatribes against alleged "reactionary" interference by Gen. Douglas MacArthur's officers in Japanese domestic affairs feature the latest Soviet censure of the situation there.

PARIS, Feb. 13--Now that the satellite treaties have been signed and the Moscow conference on Germany and Austria is impending, a series of cautious moves are being initiated on the East European chessboard. From these are likely to emerge, perhaps sooner, perhaps later, certain important diplomatic developments.

LONDON, Feb. 13--The tide began to turn today in Britain's battle against the coal crisis, but, as Prime Minister Attlee told the House of Commons, "the situation remains critical." The weather is still bitter cold and there is no sign of thaw.

Arthur Charles Evans, a market analyst for the War Assets Administration, and Martin F. Gronachan, a machine tool dealer, were held for the Federal grand jury yesterday after their arrest by the Federal Bureau of Investigation for an alleged conspiracy to accept bribes.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your first editorial on Feb. 1 dealt with the attitude of the Republican party toward reciprocity. Of course, it included a reference to Blaine and the famous quotation from McKinley's last speech.
CHICAGO, Feb. 13 (AP)--A dentist who turned magician trying to pacify young patients has decided that nothing works as well as a businesslike approach.
Officials of the New York City public school system are studying a proposal to introduce a Russian language course in at least one high school of each borough, it was learned yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 13 --Five architects, including three of the top designers in the world, were appointed today as members of the special board that is to help draw up architectural plans for the world capital along the East River.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Feb. 13 --The Nazis' V-2 rocket was the result of American, not German, inventiveness, J. F. McAllister, who is engaged in the General Electric Company's rocket program, told a business group here today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13--During the week ended Feb. 12, according to the Federal Reserve Board, member bank reserve balances decreased $101,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13--Price advances in most commodity groups raised average primary market prices by 1 per cent during the week ended Feb. 8, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The bureau's index of commodity prices in primary markets reached 141.7 per cent of the 1926 average, 0.6 per cent above the previous post-war peak in mid-January and 32.3 per cent above early February, 1946.

Representative Wat Arnold of Missouri expressed confidence yesterday that the flammable fabrics bill, which he introduced in the House and Senator Capehart of Indiana in the Senate, would be enacted by Congress. Congressman Arnold visited the testing laboratories here of the J.C. Penney Company to view fabric flammability tests and was present at a press conference held in the offices of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, sponsor of the measure.
Sales and earnings of the National Distillers Products last year were the largest in the history of the company, according to the annual report mailed to stockholders yesterday.

Industry is turning to forgings instead of using parts made of other ferrous materials, C.E. Stone, president of the Interstate Drop Forging Company, Milwaukee, and chairman of the technical committee of the Drop Forging Association, disclosed here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13--Three moves of the past year, the Hospital Survey and Construction Act, the National Mental Health Act, and the formation of the World Health Organization were hailed by Surgeon General Thomas Parran today as great public health advances.

LONDON, Feb. 13.--A further slump in British Government stocks was a feature at the opening of the stock market today. With sellers active, declines of as much as a full point were recorded. Later a few buyers appeared and a small rally took place, but the close was dull.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 --The First National Bank of New York now has nearly $13,500,000, which is, in a Pickwickian sense, "hot money." It is earmarked "United Mine Workers Welfare and Retirement Fund."

NANKING, Feb. 13 -- The Chinese Government today continued to delay its announcement of the steps that will be taken to deal with the economic crisis as conferences continued to map out a one of action.

BERLIN, Feb. 13--The Department of Commerce is studying a series of recommendations for relaxing controls over German business. This was learned today with the fact that a personal emissary of Secretary W. Averell Harriman spent three days here last November to learn how the Commerce Department could help to rebuild German foreign trade.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 13-- The Jewish people can solve their problems better as Americans concerned with all men than as Jews concerned with Jews, speakers said today at the closing sessions of the third annual conference of the American Council for Judaism.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 13 (U.P.)-- Under-water explosions believed to have been set off by rubber-clad divers of the Irgun Zvai Leumi sank a Government-owned fishing launch and damaged a military landing craft in the Haifa harbor today.

George Long, former manager of the Pure Rock Mineral Springs Corporation of Ellenville, N. Y., testified in Federal Court yesterday that false statements in the corporation's application to the Office of Price Administration had enabled it to get double the sugar to which it was entitled.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Feb. 13 (AP) --The 45-foot yawl, Revonoc, owned by Harvey Conover of the Larchmont, N.Y., Yacht Club, today won the 184-mile Miami-toNassau yacht race on corrected time after fighting heavy seas and rain.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13--Commercialization at this time of color television was opposed today as premature by engineering experts of the Radio Corporation of America and National Broadcasting Company.

Although Governor Dewey's budget for the next fiscal year already proposes the largest appropriations in the state's history, Albany was the focus yesterday of an invading army of supplicants by the hundred who feel that the budget should be still larger. The already largely committed post-war reconstruction fund of something more than a half-billion dollars will continue to be a maddening temptation until it is spent.

As a flood of more than 11,000 letters reached City Hall yesterday with, praise for Mayor O'Dwyer's stand against an increased subway fare, Borough President Cornelius A. Hall of Staten Island proposed that the city subsidize twenty-four bus lines in his borough in the interests of better transit.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Stop waste, reduce taxes. But how? Perhaps a few suggestions relating to the Navy based upon the personal experience of one in my family circle may help.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13--Without offering any explanation, the War Department announced today that its invitation to the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra to tour occupied areas of Germany and Austria, with Leopold Stokowski as guest conductor, had been withdrawn.

SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 13 (U.P.)-- The police announced tonight that they had raided the headquarters of the South Korea Labor party and seized a letter from a Russian "education officer," ordering Korean Communists to stir up student disorders in the United States zone.

Mrs. Evelyn Smith made an unsuccessful attempt in Queens Felony Court yesterday to obtain the release of her 18-year-old son, held on a charge of felonious assault in the shooting of his father, Patrolman Robert Smith, 41, in the family home at 66-39 Seventy-first Street, Middle Village, Queens.

Two prominent physicians issued a statement yesterday, deploring the growing sale to physicians of the relatively new "miracle" drug, streptomycin, and said its efficacy in the treatment of most types of tuberculosis was questionable.
Within a fortnight an automatic "block" signal system of the air will be flight-tested between New York and Rochester, it was learned last night.
ALBANY, Feb. 13--A demand was voiced by a group of eighty working mothers at the State budget hearing today that the present State program for child care centers be continued on an expanded scale.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13--March and May wheat sold today at new seasonal high prices on the Board of Trade and March corn was highest since last October. Light offerings, short covering and buying attributed to mills were responsible for the strength in wheat, while buying by cash houses was a feature in corn.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 13 --Over objections of Russia and Yugoslavia, the United Nations Transport and Communications Commission voted today to recommend that a committee to study measures for promoting safety of life at sea be established.

ALBANY, Feb. 13--Creation of a security fund to protect automobile owners and traffic accident victims from losses that might result from the collapse of casualty insurance companies was recommended today by Robert E. Dineen, State Superintendent of Insurance.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 13 --Frederick E. Weeks Jr., chief assistant district attorney of Westchester County, asserted today that three men were held for grand jury action here a year ago after an alleged assault in Lewisboro on a Norman Dairy driver.

IPSWICH, Mass., Feb. 13--Donald Philip Mead, 22 years old, Dartmouth student and war veteran, was charged with murder today after an early morning scuffle aboard a Boston Maine Railroad train in which the conductor was killed.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13--Department store sales in the week ended Feb. 8 were 2 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of 1946, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

For the second time in as many weeks the American Theatre Wing Wax Service, Inc., has made a liberal donation to the American National Theatre and Academy, an organization chartered by Congress and devoted primarily to helping worthy theatrical projects.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Feb. 13--The Dutch seek military equipment from the United States for operations in the Netherlands Indies.
