PARIS, Feb. 13--A nation-wide newspaper strike in which mechanical unions joined office employes in demands for a 25 per cent rise in their wage scale, combined with a wave of token strikes, threatened tonight to compromise the Government's whole deflationary program based on the reduction of prices and the maintenance of present wages.

LONDON, Feb. 13--Britain will submit the Palestine problem to the United Nations "without recommendations," Mr. Bevin told Zionist representatives today. He added the qualification, however, that the Foreign Office's decision was subject to Cabinet approval tomorrow.

The Department of Justice, which is seeking to sustain an order for the deportation of Dr. Karl von Kleczkowski, former German espionage agent, and his wife Stella, indicated in Federal Court yesterday that it would try to prove that Dr. von Kleczkowski's desertion of the German cause was motivated by his belief that the Germans were losing the war.

For the second time in as many weeks the American Theatre Wing Wax Service, Inc., has made a liberal donation to the American National Theatre and Academy, an organization chartered by Congress and devoted primarily to helping worthy theatrical projects.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Feb. 13--The Dutch seek military equipment from the United States for operations in the Netherlands Indies.

LONDON, Feb. 13--Britain will submit the Palestine problem to the United Nations "without recommendations," Mr. Bevin told Zionist representatives today. He added the qualification, however, that the Foreign Office's decision was subject to Cabinet approval tomorrow.

The Department of Justice, which is seeking to sustain an order for the deportation of Dr. Karl von Kleczkowski, former German espionage agent, and his wife Stella, indicated in Federal Court yesterday that it would try to prove that Dr. von Kleczkowski's desertion of the German cause was motivated by his belief that the Germans were losing the war.

Mary T. Dowling, executive secretary of the American Association of Industrial Nurses, Inc., died yesterday in her home, 106 East Eighty-first Street. She had returned to work three weeks ago after a brief absence due to a heart attack.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Feb. 14 (AP)--The Caledonians of New York, seeking their third straight victory in the Grand National Curling Matches for the Gordon Medal, reached the semi-finals today by defeating the Farmington, Conn., rink, 16--11.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 14-- Both branches of the Legislature took a "holiday" today on the controversial bills to outlaw the closed shop, and supporters on both sides of the issue met in corridor caucus to prepare for the bitter floor battle expected on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14--An investigation of the efficacy of Federal agencies in enforcement of the so-called Hobbs Anti-Racketeering Law was started today by a subcommittee of the House Committee on Expenditures in the Executive Department.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14--Secretary of State Marshall said today that the question of obtaining Soviet permission for more American correspondents to go to Moscow for the Foreign Ministers' Conference beginning March 10 was now being discussed with the Soviet Foreign Office by Ambassador W. Bedell Smith.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The House of Representatives has approved by more than the necessary two-thirds majority--285 to 121--constitutional amendment limiting Presidential tenure to two terms. The proposal is now before the Senate.
The Television Broadcasters Association appealed to apartment house owners yesterday to reconsider their ban on installation of individual aerials for tenants wanting to buy video receivers.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 14 --Following are excerpts from the speech by Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet representative, before the United Nations Security Council today: The past work of the Atomic Energy Commission has been useful in the sense that it has made it possible to clarify the attitude of individual states on this question.
The defending American champion followed the British titleholder out of the national amateur racquets tournament yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 14--The Yankees, following a hasty and frosty assembly with the crack of dawn in New York, arrived here this afternoon in their chartered Constellation plane on the first leg of their Caribbean exhibition tour that ushers in the 1947 spring training campaign.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14--Cecil B. DeMille, Hollywood motion picture producer, made an uncompromising plea to Congress today to outlaw the closed shop because, he said, it is "monopolistic," "a grotesque departure from democracy" and represents "collective absolutism."

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 14--Randel Shake, assistant national child welfare director of the American Legion at Indianapolis, predicted today that the need throughout the country for public aid will increase this year.

ABOARD MOUNT OYMPUS, Feb. 13 (Delayed) --Dispatches from the Navy Antarctic expedition's Western group said a Mariner seaplane had landed yesterday in the newly discovered inland lake region in the western reaches of Wilkes Land.

BOSTON, Feb. 14--Llanover, the home of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Henderson in South Lincoln, Mass., was the setting tonight for the marriage of Mrs. Anne Osborne Crane of Buffalo, widow of Capt. William Gratwick Crane, 108th Infantry, AUS, to Irving Hanson Chase of Boston, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard V. Chase of Worcester.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 14--The board of directors of the Pennsylvania Company for Insurances on Lives and Granting Annuities today endorsed unanimously a proposal to purchase the assets of the Kensington National Bank and to merge with the Germantown Trust Company.

MAXVILLE, Fla., Feb. 14 (AP)-- Seven cars of the Seaboard Air Line's northbound "Orange Blossom Special," Miami to New York, were derailed on the main line about a mile south of here tonight, injuring an estimated fifty persons.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 14 --The United Nations Transport and Communications Commission yesterday adopted a compromise proposal recommending that countries belonging to the United Nations be invited to two forthcoming telecommunications conferences in Washington even if they are not members of the International Communications Union.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The Federal Communications Commission has under consideration an application from Press Wireless Inc., for amendment of its license to include a "press administrative service" to its press and radio clients.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 14 --The United Nations received today its first detailed picture of devastation in the Far East and was warned that only a "whole battery" of international aids could lift the area to a sound economic and social level.
LONDON, Feb. 14--The days of great empires ruled by European nations is finished, Sir John Boyd Orr, Director General of the Food and Agricultural Organization of the United Nations, declared today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14--The Joint Committee on the Legislative Budget issued tonight the following report setting forth its procedure in dealing with the President's budget for the fiscal year 1947-48 and its recommendation, concerning it:

Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey was asked to decide yesterday whether Gerhart Eisler, avowed Communist, is a citizen of Austria exempt from the provision of the Enemy Alien Act or whether, as the Government contends, he is an enemy alien dangerous to the peace and safety of the United States by virtue of his birth in Germany.

The inimitable Gilbert Dodds will be on display for twenty-two whirls around the Madison Square Garden track, instead of the usual eleven, at the seventy-ninth anniversary games of the New York Athletic Club tonight.

Several correspondents have recently taken exception to an editorial in which we concluded that the "Wagner Act, in its present form, has tended to increase and prolong" strikes. Their objections to this conclusion rest on a distinction they say the Board makes between strikes caused by unfair labor practices and "economic" strikes.

Russell Lewis and Howard Young, the Los Angeles producers who brought over from the West Coast "The Story of Mary Surratt," decided yesterday to close down the attraction after tonight's performance at Henry Miller's Theatre. Which means that the list of outgoing productions this evening has been increased to three, the other two being "Bloomer Girl" and "Toplitzky of Notre Dame."

BOSTON, Feb. 14--The Rev. Dr. Norman Burdett Nash was consecrated as Bishop Coadjutor of the Episcopal Diocese of Massachusetts today at a ceremony attended by 2,000 members of the clergy and laity at Trinity Church.

LONDON, Feb. 14--The stock markets opened cautiously today, but as news of the slightly improved fuel position, together with forecasts of a break in the wintry weather, became known, selling dried up and most sections made a good finish to a very difficult week.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--The roll call of the Senate-House budgetary committee on cutting $6,000,000,000 from President Truman's $37,500,000,000 budget: FOR THE REDUCTION--50 Republicans--43 SENATORS

The doors of Grand Central Palace will open wide at noon today, and the preview we had yesterday convinced us that the 1947 Sportsmen's Show is the one for which thousands of hunters and fishermen have been waiting since 1941.
PEIPING, China, Feb. 14--A United States Marine was shot in the back and killed in a dark alley under mysterious circumstances here last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP)--A House Merchant Marine subcommittee approved today legislation authorizing the Army to operate until Dec. 31, 1947, troopships that do not comply with marine safety standards.

The Affiliated Young Democrats, through Harold R. Moskovit, State president, sent a letter last night to David H. Knott, chairman of the New York County Democratic Committee, asking him to call a meeting of the committee to change the party rules to provide for but one leader and one coleader in each of Manhattan's sixteen assembly districts.

Dr. Julius E. Lips, anthropologist, author and a professor at the New School for Social Research, has completed a new book, "The Origin of Things," scheduled for publication in the spring by A.A. Wyn. He traces the origin and development of many aspects of our civilization, demonstrating that there is nothing new under the sun.

Completely automatic landings through the use of improved radar devices is the goal of Army Air Forces experiments now being conducted on the West Coast, Maj. Gen. Harold M. McClelland, chief of the Airways and Air Communications Service, announced yesterday.

Charley Fusari's strength and youth proved too much for Tippy Larkin's skill and experience in the transplanted "battle of New Jersey" at Madison Square Garden last night when the Irvington welterweight, 2-to-1 underdog in pre-fight calculations, knocked out his Garfield rival in 2:49 of the ninth of their scheduled 10-round event.

Activation in the National Guard of the Twenty enth and Fortysecond Infantry Divisions and a number of major units of the Fifty-second Fighter Wing as well as setting up State headquarters has been authorized by the War Department, it was announced here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14--The Office of Vocational Rehabilitation reported to Congress today it was urging the States to set their sights so that 500,000 vocationally handicapped civilians would be started toward successful employment by the end of 1948.

William B. Benjamin, 37-yearold former head of a war-production corporation, who pleaded guilty in December to frauds totaling $493,000, was sentenced yesterday by Judge John A. Mullen in General Sessions Court to the maximum prison term of ten to twenty years.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 14--"The political importance of this declaration lies mainly in the fact that France as a Western and Czechoslovakia as an Eastern neighbor of Germany are vitally interested in seeing that the control of Germany and the security of both their countries are insured during the forthcoming negotiations concerning the peace treaty with Germany."

VIENNA, Feb. 14--The Soviet Union's insistence on extraterritoriality in its zone of Austria and the desire of its representatives here to support the Soviet attitude in the London discussions of the Austrian peace treaty prevented the Allied Council from reaching agreement today on most of the subjects on its agenda.

LONDON, Feb. 14--Formal announcement that Britain had failed in her attempts to find a solution of the Palestine problem and had decided to carry the case to the United Nations was made today by Foreign Secretary Bevin.
CHICAGO, Feb. 14--The eighteenth anniversary of the St. Valentine's Day massacre of seven hoodlums in Chicago was marked today by another typical gangland assassination.

IN Richmond, toward the end of the Civil War, the bill for a good breakfast for three people was $141. The price of beef was $10 a pound, if you could find it, and a man paid $250 for a single ham or a side of bacon.

No individual citizen can expect to reach his goal in life by depending solely upon his own efforts, Dr. Charles Spurgeon Johnson, the sixth and first Negro president of Fisk University, said last night. He was honored by a dinner at the Hotel Pennsylvania sponsored by friends, the trustees and alumni.

PARIS, Feb. 14--Paris policemen, public utility workers and other Government employes walked out today in a token strike against the Government's refusal to grant a general wage increase. The walkout crippled Paris for four hours.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14--Secretary of State George C. Marshall and Secretary of the Navy James V. Forrestal spoke today of the paralyzing effects they said the budget cuts proposed by Congressional committees would have on activities within their scope.

PARIS, Feb. 14--That Yugoslavia and Bulgaria are working toward the unification of their two countries into one large state-- linking the Black and the Adriatic Seas--was confirmed today by Alexander Obbov, Vice Premier of the Sofia Government.

Lili Marlene was the sort of girl back home who would appeal to the heart of any soldier--even, alas, a faithless one. Her sweetheart might be wounded, captured, dead. He might be gallivanting around with some bewitching foreigner far away. Never mind--Lili remained true to him.

Dr. Karl von Kleczkowski, former German espionage agent in Turkey who turned to the Allied cause in 1943, testified in Federal court yesterday that he signed untruthful statements in Cairo, Egypt, under duress.
Scout, a 4-year-old spaniel and an honorably discharged K-9 veteran of the war, was assured of a new temporary lease of life yesterday.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 14-- Chairman Clifford Hope of the House Agriculture Committee as serted here today that there probably would be no need for Congress to pass farm bills this year.

The New York State Athletic Commission yesterday reserved decision in its investigation of a bribe offer reputedly made to Ray Robinson, world welterweight champion. After listening to the testimony of the boxer, whose real name is Walter Smith, and to his manager, George Gainford, the two-man board, headed by Eddie Eagan, announced that it would make known its findings on Monday.

SECURITY COUNCIL Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet delegate, declared his country believed violators of a ban on atomic weapons should be punished, but added they should be punished by the Council, within framework of United Nations Charter.

CANTON, N.Y., Feb. 14--With statistics on the jumping competition incomplete and the crosscountry to be run tomorrow, three teams battled today for St. Lawrence University's winter carnival ski title. St. Lawrence, Cornell and Syracuse were bunched in that order within four points of one another.

Miss Jane Remsen Darlington, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Gilbert Darlington of 925 Park Avenue, was married yesterday afternoon to Lieut. Charles J. Irwin Jr., USMC, in the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest by her uncle, the Rev. Dr. Henry Darlington, the rector.

Two policemen, off duty and in civilian clothes, were beaten early yesterday morning by five Negroes while on their way home. Three suspects were captured at the scene. The others escaped although six shots were fired at them.

TOKYO, Feb. 14--With the collapse of its extra-parliamentary campaign to overthrow the Yoshida Government following Gen. Douglas MacArthur's prohibition of a Japanese general strike, the Japanese Communist party has now decided to take a vigorous part in the forthcoming general election and the local elections for Prefectural Governors and municipal officials.

The story of Joseph Kremenetz and Murray Solomon is a story of Brooklyn, a small town with a big population. Born a few days apart in October, 1925, they lived on the same Brooklyn street, entered the Army about the same time, and were seriously wounded after equal terms of service.

ATHENS, Feb. 14 (AP)--Yugoslavia admitted officially for the first time today that armed bands opposed to Marshal Tito's leadership existed inside the country, and charged that they were being financed by "Greek imperialists."

Tidy Central Park went Hollywood on a seven-hour day yesterday, and New Yorkers learned that a large section of the Fifty-ninth Street pond was out of bounds for them. It was all part of the campaign to convince movie producers that this city would make an attractive film capital.

Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag denied yesterday a motion to vacate an interim stay he signed last Tuesday, restraining the publication and delivery of a biographical book entitled "Koussevitzky." The book was written by Moses Smith, former Boston music critic, and was scheduled for release today by the publishing concern of Allen, Towne Heath, Inc.

Fifty thousand migrant farm workers, most of whom follow the seasonal crops along the Atlantic seaboard, have been left jobless and virtually penniless by Florida's recent record cold spell, it was reported yesterday by the Home Missions Council, 297 Fourth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14--Secretary of State Marshall through a statement today appealed to the moderate elements of both the Right and Center and to all loyal parties in Greece to unite in the cause of orderly, stable government.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 14--More fuel was added to Palestine's smoldering fire tonight with the official announcement that the death sentences imposed on three terrorists had been confirmed by Lieut. Gen. Sir Evelyn Barker. A fourth sentence of life imprisonment was also confirmed.

Rough, but a Friend On the balance of accounts the weather has not been Britain's enemy, even with the news what it is today. If the reporters are moved by the present critical situation to recall Dunkerque, then it is well to remember how kindly were the weather gods to Britain at Dunkerque in providing a calm sea for that huge fleet of small craft to save the stranded army on the Channel beaches.
LONDON, Feb. 14 (AP)--Britons, urged by their Government to expand exports to 175 per cent of 1938, learned today that exports for 1946 were slightly below those of that year.

The marriage of Mrs. Frances Auchincloss Armitage, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Hugh Auchincloss of 1158 Fifth Avenue, to Felix Augustine Mulgrew 3d, son of Mrs. John F. Mulgrew of 4 East Eightyeighth Street, took place yesterday afternoon in the home of the bride at 1060 Park Avenue.

Despite depression, total war and the difficulties of reconversion, the investments made by Metropolitan Life Insurance Company since 1940 on behalf of its 32,000,000 policy holders have shown a substantial net profit, Frederic W. Ecker, financial vice president, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14--Clinton P. Anderson, Secretary of Agriculture, will be one of a group of United States officials who will go overseas soon to meet with European food officials, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The Joint Congressional Committee on the Budget recommended today a $6,000,000,000 reduction in President Truman's $37,500,000,000 budget for the fiscal year 1948. The action overrode repeated bipartisan efforts to moderate the cut.
Cotton futures fluctuated over a wide range on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and final prices were 28 points higher to 11 points lower than the day before.

Contending that the city should have protected Mrs. Olga Ruocco against injury as a rider on the subway system, attorneys for the woman filed a claim for $200,000 to compensate her for the loss of her left leg when she was wounded by a shotgun blast in the Times Square subway station last New Year's Eve, it became known yesterday.

Commercial testing laboratories have encountered serious competition from quasi-public tax-exempt research institutes and are taking steps to promote sales for tax-paying laboratories, A.J. Nydick, counsel and executive secretary of the American Council of Commercial Laboratories, disclosed here yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 14 --Britain's move to hand over the Palestine problem to the United Nations may for the first time call into being an international force of the Big Five to maintain order in the Holy Land, according to official observers here.

LONDON, Feb. 14 -- Despite heavy pressure for an easing of Britain's commitments, the British Government is determined that "the fruits of seven years of intense war effort should not be thrown away by an ill-considered jettisoning of defense responsibility," the Labor Cabinet says in a White Paper on defense, issued today.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 14--Aside from the fact that the customers got a few good looks at the sun, the big news from Hialeah Park today is that thirteen have been named to oppose Armed in the $25,000 added McLennan Handicap tomorrow.

Carroll Glenn, who made her New York debut as a concert violinist nine years ago while she was in her teens, has passed out of the prodigy stage and must compete in the open market as a public performer with other grown-up fiddlers.

Despite increasing opposition from individuals and groups operating as check cashers, the State Banking Department is determined to obtain enactment of its program curtailing the activities of such agencies, it was learned yesterday.
PARIS, Feb. 12 (Delayed) -- In the reopened and refurbished Elysees Palace -- the French White House--there are today among the Gobelins and gilt what is rare in France: sizzling radiators.

Macy's taster, the man who passes judgment on every food and beverage that is to be sold in the world's largest department store is celebrating his fiftieth year with that company tomorrow. Pursuing his career as a gourmet for a half century not only has brought William Titon a vast knowledge of his subject, but it has led to wide travel in foreign lands, where he has been sent to select delicacies for Americans.
Never before has the morale of the teaching staff been as low as it is today. Everywhere teachers are discontented, dissatisfied with their profession, almost ashamed to be teachers.

Data on shoe sales at retail are being closely watched for further evidences of a decline in the number of pairs sold, together with indications that shoe volume may follow the general pattern of department store sales if the latter turn downward.

The post-war problem of wiping out Nazi indoctrination in German can be solved without much difficulty, Cardinal von Preysing, Bishop of Berlin, said yesterday. He was interviewed at a press reception in the Empire State Club arranged by the War Relief Services of the National Catholic Welfare Conference.

Representatives of the construction industry and building trades unions failed yesterday in a prolonged afternoon session to head off the strike threatened on Monday morning by the Metallic Lathers Union, Local 46, AFL.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In connection with recent discussions of what constitute official papers held by United States officials, it is interesting to note a practice as to the subject prevailing in the British Foreign Office prior to the First World War. It was encountered by Charles Francis Adams Jr. when engaged in historical research in England in 1915.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 14 (U.P.) --The Ohio State Athletic Board tonight named Wes Fesler of Pittsburgh as its new head football coach for a five-year term. He succeeds Paul Bixler, who resigned to take over as coach at Colgate.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Senator Warren G. Magnuson, Democrat, of Washington, today introduced a bill to authorize the United States Maritime Commission to enter into a contract with private steamship operators for deep water service to Alaska.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 14--Uncertainty in American fiscal stability can be expected to continue unless revenue and expenditure estimates are formulated in Washington for a number of years, not merely for the coming fiscal year, Dr. Harold G. Moulton, president of Brookings Institution, asserted here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- A method for the production of high quality Diesel fuel from virgin gas oils or any other gas oils having a similar make-up was one of 403 inventions for which patents were issued this week by the United States Patent Office.

The weight of offerings of shares diminished somewhat yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, but the market lost further ground as the list backed down about 1/2 point in the averages with losses up to 2 points in pivotal industrial issues.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14--A fourth Southern Democrat, Senator John H. Overton of Louisiana, announced today that he would vote against the confirmation of David E. Lilienthal as Chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 14--Despite an unexpected thaw that made heavy clothing unnecessary, the thirty-seventh annual Dartmouth winter carnival started on schedule this morning. By nightfall three events representing half the point-scoring program had been completed and Dartmouth, the host school, was in control.

The Geigy Company, Inc., has launched for the second year an extensive advertising campaign to make its name as well known in the insecticide industry as it is in the dyestuff field, it was announced yesterday. This year, efforts will be directed principally at acquainting consumers with Cesarol and Neocid DDT insecticides.

SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 14. (U.P)-- Ho Hun, 62-year-old leader of the South Korea Labor party, said today that a purported letter from a Russian officer "ordering" him to stir up trouble among students in the American zone of Korea was a "childish plot."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 14 -- The long-delayed screen version of "Voice of the Turtle" will go before the cameras at Warner Brothers in two weeks, with Eleanor Parker, Ronald Reagan and Eve Arden heading the cast and Irving Rapper directing, the studio announced today.

Wellsville, N.Y., awarded yesterday issues of water works and electric light system bonds aggregating $275,000 and maturing on Aug. 15 from 1948 to 1966 to J.G. White Co. and Sherwood Co. at a bid of 100.029 for 1.30s.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The Communists have turned against the American Merchant Marine "the spearhead of their drive in the United States," Almon E. Roth, a spokesman for the industry, asserted today.

PARIS, Feb. 14--The French proposal for an alliance pact with Great Britain was read today to the Cabinet, which was officially said to have approved it unanimously. If so, the Communist members joined in so doing.

The Board of Higher Education, which is responsible for the operation of four city colleges, asked Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson yesterday for $18,522,290 of city funds for the coming fiscal year. This estimate was $4,589,398 more than the amount for the 1946-47 budget year.

The threat of a cessation of bus service on twenty-four Staten Island lines serving 60,000 commuters, scheduled for midnight tonight, was postponed for one week yesterday after the Board of Estimate hurriedly convened in executive session at City Hall in an effort to solve the problem.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14--The Hughes Tool Company of Houston, Tex., has offered to make its 46 per cent stock interest in Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., available as security in a voting trust, in a move to secure a $40,000,000 loan for the airline from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, it was revealed today.

LONDON, Feb. 14 (London Times Dispatch)--A strongly worded telegram was sent today by the Preparatory Commission of the International Refugee Organization to Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, stressing the urgent need for the widest possible financial support of its activities.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14--A resolution designed to perfect the reorganization of Congressional machinery in the interest of fiscal economies was introduced in the Senate today by Senators Harry F. Byrd, Democrat, of Virginia, and Hugh Butler, Republican, of Nebraska.

Notable advances toward worldwide cooperation in public health have been made in the past twelve months, according to a report of progress made public yesterday by the United Nations World Health Organization's interim commission.

Production plans for new model machine tools were held up because of a tool builders' agreement, reached through their national association, to defer experimental work during the war, industry spokesmen disclosed here yesterday. Shortages of materials, electric motors, control apparatus and parts are now easing, however, and new models are reaching the market, they said.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 14 --A formidable Canadian contingent, led again by the Wurtele twins, Rhona and Rhoda, swept the second half of its international series with an Eastern United States women's ski team today to retain the Kate Smith Trophy.

There are 3,000 known narcotic addicts in New York who spend about $25,000,000 yearly to obtain drugs, Col. Garland H. Williams, district supervisor of the United States Bureau of Narcotics, declared yesterday. He expressed approval of a narcotic bill to be introduced next week in the State Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14--The War Assets Administration today proposed the sale of the Big Inch and Little Big Inch pipelines at $143,127,000, for shipment of natural gas from Texas to the New YorkPhiladelphia areas of the Atlantic Seaboard.

STOCKHOLM, Feb. 14 (AP)-- Richard Button, United States figure -skating champion, won the most points with a brilliant freeskating exhibition tonight, but the judges' decision gave the world championship to Hans Gerschweiler of Switzerland.
LONDON, Feb. 14--Yugoslavia and Austria debated the Carinthian frontier issue today before the Foreign Ministers' deputies on the Austrian peace treaty.

One of the bitterest reproaches against the British Labor Government has been that, in flat contradiction to its pre-election pledges, it was forcing a reactionary settlement in Palestine. A more friendly interpretation of its activities there was that it fell heir to an impossible situation.

Clever ways to disguise beds in small rooms are shown in the "Boudoir Bandbox" settings currently on view at Macy's ninth floor. Chair-beds, cots that roll away, and double divans are dressed in bright slipcovers to improve their appearance.

The Federal Government, now trustee of the $25,000,000 Longchamps restaurant chain, asked the State Liquor Authority last Nov. 14 to consider that discontinuance of the business would deprive the Government from collecting $3,000,000 in taxes owed, it was learned yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 14-- An absorbing topic of conversation here these days -- more absorbing even than India's perennial politics or the British fuel shortage -- is the forthcoming wedding of Miss Felicity Ann Wavell, daughter of the Viceroy, and Capt. Peter Longmore of the Royal Artillery, Feb. 20.

BOSTON, Feb. 14 -- The public trustees of the Boston Elevated Railway have voted to default on the payment of about $1,000,000 interest on some $20,000,000 in railway bonds held by the Boston Metropolitan District.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 14--At an unprecedented meeting in the Ministry of Finance last night, the Government told the nation's greatest potential taxpayers that wholesale evasions had to stop. The Government also warned that future evasions would result in imprisonment.

ALBANY, Feb. 14--The Public Service Commission sought authority today to direct the recapitalization or reorganization of public utilities whose outstanding obligations, including preferred stock at par value with accrued dividends, exceeded assets.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 14--The British evacuation of one of Egypt's two principal cities was completed today when Fort Kom el-Dick, a relic of Napoleon's invasion, was surrendered to the Egyptian authorities in Alexandria.

Today is the deadline for the submission to Congress of the new Legislative Budget provided for under the Reorganization Act of 1946. On Tuesday a Congressional subcommittee of twenty members made its report. Its plans called for cutting the budget submitted by President Truman from $37.5 billions to $31.5 billions -- or a reduction of $6 billions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14-- mander Charles Wayne, U.S.N., who for two and one-half months was "mayor" of the Russian internment camp for United States airmen at Tashkent, said today that the principal mistake of the Russians in their treatment of the Americans was in not allowing them freedom of communications with American officials in Russia.

U.S. NAVAL AIR TEST CENTER, Patuxent River, Md., Feb. 14 --A radar-controlled 20 mm. turret automatically laid, aimed and fired, 8,000-pound bombs, new rockets and high-speed torpedoes are some of the new weapons the Navy is prepared to use with carrier-based planes, an inspection of this air station reveals.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Official Washington honored today the memory of O. Max Gardner, who died Feb. 6 on the day he was to sail for England as American Ambassador.

The second public concert of WNYC's eighth American Music Festival was given yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Participants included Susan Reed, folksinger; the Margaret Dodd Mastersingers, directed by Margaret Dodd; the Sagul Trio, composed of Edith Sagul, flutist; Maryjane Thomas, 'cellist, and Geraldine Winnett, pianist; and the Chamber Orchestra of New York, conducted by Will Lorin.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 14 (AP)-- The Cities Service Company, in an attempt to meet objections of minority stockholders, today amended its simplification plan by offering increased amounts in retirement of its three classes of preferred stocks.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14--Prime Minister Attlee declined with thanks today President Truman's offer to divert loaded colliers now in European waters to the relief of Britain's coal crisis.

New York's Philharmonic-Symphony Society, faced with the necessity of a sudden change of conductors, has made a brilliant choice of leaders for next season. Bruno Walter, whose eminence and idealism in his art are unquestioned, will be musical advisor of the organization.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Feb. 14--With 2,100 Mennonites from the Soviet Union nearing Paraguay, United States officials disclosed today a dispute that had preceded their departure from Germany.

LONDON, Feb. 14--The British Government is willing to employ foreign labor and is anxious to recruit a labor force from all sources, Arthur Greenwood, Lord Privy Seal, told members of Parliament today. The Members urged the Government to decide now to admit thousands of skilled displaced persons from the British zone of Germany.

LANSFORD, Pa., Feb. 14-- Ignoring the advice of United Mine Workers' leaders, thirteen hard coal miners tonight carried into its third day their sitdown strike 300 feet below the surface in Colliery No. 6 of the Lehigh Navigation Coal Company.

A construction program involving nine new motorships and one tanker as partial replacement for twenty-two vessels lost in the war, was announced yesterday by Dag Klaveness, head of the Klaveness Steamship Line of Norway.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14--Defeated again today by a Federal Court decision which might destroy the whole system of sugar rationing, the Office of Price Administration said that the question would be appealed to the Supreme Court.

Good news for tea drinkers! The Tea Tasters will meet at 10 A.M. on Monday in the offices of the Supervising United States Tea Examiner, 201 Varick Street, to take part in the first tea-tasting session of the Board of Tea Experts since February, 1942.

Treasury Financing The United States Treasury's decision to redeem $1,000,000,000 of the $3,133,000,000 of certificates which will mature on March 1 is indicative of the high rate at which tax collections are continuing in advance of Treasury estimates, financial observers noted yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14--A proposal to maintain rent control to the end of the year with a general increase of 10 per cent in ceilings was introduced in the Senate today by Senator C. Douglass Buck, Republican, of Delaware.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14--Secretary of State Marshall held a press conference in Room 464 at the State Department today and a brief description of the room and the man may indicate why changes are being made on Pennsylvania Avenue.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 14 --The Soviet Union believes the violators of a ban on atomic weapons should be punished, Andrei A. Gromyko told the Security Council today. The Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister added, however, that the Security Council should be the agency to take effective measures for atomic control and that it should act within the framework of the United Nations Charter.

Trade Here Up 20-25% Retail trade here recovered sharply this week under the influence of favorable weather and excellent volume on Lincoln's Birthday. Department store sales were estimated at between 20 and 25 per cent ahead of last year.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 14 (U.P.)--Official circles were surprised and shocked today to learn that the big underground army of Haganah, which has been inactive for months, had taken responsibility for the Haifa ship bombings. The attack, in which a fishing launch was sunk and a landing craft damaged, previously had been attributed to the Irgun Zvai Leumi.
Retirement applications of ninetysix members of the Police Department will come before the board of trustees of the Police Pension Fund Monday, it was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14--Prices of grains moved up rapidly today on the Board of Trade, and business was estimated by brokers to have been the largest in six weeks or more. March wheat sold at a new twenty-seven-year peak at $2.26 1/2 a bushel, up 3 3/4 cents from yesterday, and May and July went to new seasonal highs.
The New York Public Library is operating with a turnover in its staff that has now reached 44 per cent a year. Morris Hadley, president, disclosed yesterday.

On Ash Wednesday, which occurs next week, the larger Protestsmt bodies in the United States will open a cooperative Lenten appeal for special gifts from the public to aid war sufferers overseas. The goal for 1947 is 512,000,000, in addition to 23,000,000 pounds of clothing.
LONDON, Feb. 14--Great Britain, fighting as grimly as in the dark days of 1940, successfully continued today her long uphill battle against the coal crisis.

DETROIT, Feb. 14 -- The new 1947 Hudson models are being introduced in the showrooms of Hudson dealers throughout the country, the Hudson Motor Car Company stated today. Two lines, the super series and the Commodore series, are offered, with a choice of 102 horsepower super six and 128 horsepower super eight engines.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14--Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, after being designated by Gov. Kim Sigler of Michigan as the choice of Republican partisans in that State for the nomination for the Presidency next year, criticized the Soviet Union tonight for its failure to acknowledge more promptly diplomatic inquiries.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 14--Registration statements covering $22,000,000 of bonds, 3,000 shares of preferred stock and 100,000 shares of common stock were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by two companies.

General fund receipts for the reduction of taxation in the fiscal year 1947-48 were estimated at $335,383,482 yesterday by Controller Lazarus Joseph in a tentative report to the Board of Estimate and the City Council.

Table accessories, some of them generations old, were combined with artful flower arrangements in a series of period tables demonstrated yesterday at the Horticultural Society of New York, 598 Madison Avenue. There were five settings ranging from the days of gourds and other primitive vessels to contemporary times.

Dr. Alfred Meyer and his wife, Annie Nathan Meyer, will celebrate their sixtieth wedding anniversary this afternoon at a reception in the Women's Faculty Club of Columbia University, 410 West 117th Street.

TOKYO, Feb. 14--Complete revision of the Japanese income-tax system is being planned, according to Japanese Government sources. The new program would include compulsory tax returns, extension of the present pay-as-yougo plan and a scale that would make the income levy provide more than half the Government's tax revenue.

Production of cotton duck which is running 30 per cent over the 1939 rate of output, hardly fills the needs of all users, despite the many thousands of yards sold as Government surplus, according to trade sources yesterday. Duck manufacturers have been unable to build inventories, it was reported, although demand for heavy duck from foreign users has fallen off.

Four expert skiers, members of the first Norwegian team to visit this country since 1932, arrived on the Norwegian American liner Stavangerfjord yesterday for a series of meets during the next six weeks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14--Secretary of State Marshall told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that "the world is in a very critical condition" politically. Speaking and answering questions at an hour-and-ahalf closed session with the Senate group, his first since taking his new post, the Secretary figuratively took the legislators to many troubled areas abroad.

PARIS, Feb. 14--Christian Dior presented an exhibit today in a stately old house on Avenue Montaigne. Although the dominant colors were navy, gray, greige and black, M. Dior's own special tone was a pastel khaki named royal khaki.

There have been no serious labor stoppages in France since the liberation, but the French live in the shadow of an always-impending labor crisis. The country is haunted by the dread of a general strike. In any talk of the future, Frenchmen never fail to mention that the Communists, in their complete control of the General Confederation of Labor, possess the power to paralyze public services and industrial production whenever they choose.

Burns Company, brokers.
MACON, Ga., Feb. 14 (AP)--The wreckage of an Army passenger plane, the bodies of its seven occupants burned beyond recognition, was found today in the heart of a middle Georgia swamp.

Joad's book, "The Babbitt Warren," intended as a blast against American life, was pummeled about no little bit by Elmer Davis, who wrote: "Mr. Joad's ignorance of America is no mere negative quality; it is * * * a Platonic ignorance, the knowledge of things that are not.
Charles Gurinowich, one of the nine men who escaped from Brooklyn City Prison on Jan. 2, and two companions were convicted last Friday night of the robbery for which Gurinowich had been jailed.

MOSCOW, Feb. 15 -- The primary conflict on Germany to be resolved by the Council of Foreign Ministers here next month is between the Russian idea of an economically and politically unified Germany and what is felt here to be the Anglo-American idea of a German federation -- in which the western half of Germany would be a vassal of the United States and Britain.

Hjoerdis Schymberg, Swedish soprano, who had not sung before in this country, made her Metropolitan debut as Susanna in last night's performance of Mozart's "The Marriage of Figaro." All of the other members of the cast were familiar in their respective roles, except Martha Lipton, who assumed the part of Cherubino for the first time, replacing Rise Stevens, originally slated but indisposed.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 15 -- Associates of the Mufti of Jerusalem, Haj Amin el Husseini, said today that representatives of the Palestine Arab Higher Committee in London would ask the British Government to halt Jewish immigration to Palestine and suppress terrorism pending adjudication of the Palestine question by the United Nations.

The current position of the Bank for International Reconstruction and Development, markedly, lowered by reason of the long delay in the naming of a president, has led to a revival of proposals among banking authorities that the bank be combined with the International Monetary Fund.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 15 -- Indian National Congress party leaders awaited today some kind of response from London to their reiterated demand for the removal of the Moslem League from the Interim Popular Ministry in the current deadlock between India's two main political factions.
Builders broke ground or started structural operations in January which will add 2,180 new family units to New York's short supply of residential space.

IN his heyday what a tale H.G. Wells could have told of the last days of man, smitten by some strange malady of the mind! Or of his extinction in some unfelt storm of radio-activity that his bungling statement blindly let loose! What a tale he did tell of the world's peril from the mechanized men of the war god's own planet! But that tale had a happy ending.

The majority of college students do not consider the teaching profession a good risk. More than two-thirds of them look upon teaching as being less desirable than the other professions, such as medicine, law or engineering.

GRANDVIEW, Mo., Feb. 15 -- President Truman paid an unannounced visit here today to visit his mother, Mrs. Martha E. Truman, who suffered a fractured hip in a fall Thursday night. He found her comfortable, after having passed a good night.

St. Francis defeated a stubborn Brooklyn College quintet, 46 -- 42, in a thriller on the Kingsmen's court last night. Staving off a brilliant second-half rally that shaved a 17-point advantage to 4 points the Butler Street crew succeeded in registering their eleventh victory in sixteen starts.
LONDON, Feb. 15 -- Great Britain is making slow but "real and steady" progress in her hard battle for fuel.

With the announcement last week of a further cut of $1,000,000,000 in the national debt, effective March 1, the Government rounds put the biggest year of debt retirement in its history and the first reduction in the warswollen debt figures since 1930.

The gravest internal problem facing France today is inflation. Last December, Leon Blum, then Premier of France, pushed through a program of deflation by cutting prices and pegging wages. Many workers were dissatisfied and demanded pay increases. Last Friday the demand took dramatic shape when 5,000,000 Government employes staged a token strike.
Rebellion of the consumer against poor quality apparel, which has seriously affected the retailer and manufacturer, is now causing turmoil among fabric sellers, according to trade sources last week.

ALTHOUGH overcoats and scarfs became general issue recently on Florida's west coast, replacing shorts and seersucker suits, winter vacationists were cheered by reports of how much colder it was back home.

Although retail stocks remain high, shortages developed last week in some items of apparel where purchasing had been scarce, according to a market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc.

STOCKHOLM, Feb. 15 (U.P.) -- Miss Barbara Ann Scott of Ottawa, Ont., virtually clinched the women's world figure skating championship today by piling up a 78point lead with only the free skating competition to go.

MEXICO CITY. A BRAND new producing enterprise known as Teatro Americano is off to a good start at the Iris here with a list of shows that would be impressive in any American city outside of New York. To say that it's impressive here would be understatement.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 15 -- Tennesseans are preponderantly in favor of the Tennessee Valley Authority. Lately, their elder statesman, Senator Kenneth D. McKellar, has been badgering the former TVA chief, David E. Lilienthal, with accusations that Communists are not only under the TVA bed but also on the payroll.
ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- The proposal to appropriate $2,000,000 for State aid to the public libraries is as good as dead, it was learned today.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange continued its upward course yesterday and closed with net gains of 20 to 40 points. The near months again led the advance.

PANAMA CANAL -- Samples of soil and rock from the Isthmus of Panama will be brought to Harvard University's engineering laboratories to be tested in connection with proposals for new canal faculties. With the wating lines stretching several blocks and increasing every moment, sponsors of the National Sportsmen's Show decided to open the doors at 11:15 A.M. yesterday rather than wait for noon, so Perry Duryea, New York State Conservation Commissioner, cut the tape and officially opened the show.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Wheat soared for grains exceeding 9 cents a bushel at times today in an active market on the Board of Trade that saw previous short sellers rushing to cover their commitments. March wheat ran up to a new twenty-seven-year peak.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The Inter-American Defense Board took the secret label today off plans under which standardized land, sea and air forces of the Americas would move swiftly to repel any would-be attacker of the Western Hemisphere.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 15 -- If Nick Etten is ever to regain his former high estate as the Yankees' regular first baseman he will never want for a better opportunity to re-establish himself than he will receive this spring.

THE pleasure-travel graph on the chart shows an abrupt upward bulge on or about George Washington's Birthday every year. The travel authorities are vague as to why this happens. All they say is that there it is February after February -- a sudden rush of people going places, going away for no great length of time, perhaps, yet going.

PARIS. AMERICAN Literature in France: The debate about the influence -- regenerative or degrading -- of the American novel continues to animate cafe conversation. "What do you think about American literature?"

ROME, Feb. 15 -- An investigation conducted by the Como police has proved that the "Mussolini treasure," variously estimated at between scores of millions and 10,000,000,000 lire, has been seized by the Italian Communist party, the Milan correspondent of the Bisorgimento Liberate said today in a dispatch.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15 -- This nation's best insurance against the calamity of another war is to maintain military strength, Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson declared tonight in a strong plea for universal military training. He spoke at Temple University's annual Founders Day dinner.

Henry Ward Beecher Jr., a great-grandson of the famous preacher, left here yesterday for Budapest, where he will be a vice consul. He was among 144 passengers leaving from Pier 61, North River, on the Unites States liner Washington.

PAINTINGS by artists of the San Francisco Bay region are being shown at the Riverside Museum, sponsored by Dr. Grace Morley, director of the San Francisco Museum, who has supplied a foreword to the catalogue.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The decision of the Supreme Court of the United States in the A.J. Tower Company case seems to me to go beyond any former pronouncement of he court in the direction of modifying the right guaranteed to employes under Section 7 of the National Labor Relations Act "to bargain collectively through representatives of their own choosing."

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Feb. 13 (Delayed) -- So far as anyone knows, nothing very nice has happened for a long time to the people who live four and five to a room in the half-smashed houses on the Rohmerplatz in Bockenheim.

PAUL I. WELLMAN, whose novel "The Walls of Jericho" was published by Lippincott a fortnight ago and is this month's Literary Guild pick, is an old hand at a newspaper -- he wrote six books while on the city desk. HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 15 -- Supreme in five of the six events, Dartmouth's well-balanced ski team romped off with, the thirtyseventh annual Dartmouth winter carnival today. In achieving their fifteenth team triumph in the history of the carnival, the Indians amassed 588.5 points, as compared with the total of 569 notched by runner-up Miidlebury.

ATLANTA, Feb. 15 -- Homer L. Loomis Jr., secretary of the antiNegro, anti-Jewish Columbians, Inc., was convicted today of incitement to riot in a case which stemmed from the beating of a Negro passing through a white residential section.

ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- Governor Dewey's reputed aspirations for a second Presidential nomination and Mayor William O'Dwyer's reluctance to accept the political onus of further increasing municipal taxes are deeply involved in the present fight for more State aid to New York City.

CANADA'S Postoffice Department made available last week a photograph of the 4-cent stamp, color not yet announced, which will be issued on March 3 to mark the centenary of the birth of Alexander Graham Bell.
The British Government has begun conferences in London to draw up its proposals for world disarmament, it was disclosed yesterday.

Small business in the United States is much better off than the public has been led to believe, according to findings of a two-year study reported yesterday at the first sessions of a two-day meeting of the Research and Policy Committee of the Committee for Economic Development at the Waldorf -Astoria Hotel.

NANKING, China, Feb. 15 -- Government troops today captured Lani, headquarters in South Shantung of the Communist New Fourth Army. The little city was one of the main initial objectives of the Government campaign on Shantung and its occupation is the first important success scored by the Government forces since the offensive was launched nearly a month ago.

HOLLYWOOD. THE screen version of Eugene O'Neill's "Mourning Become Electra," which RKO has been contemplating for nearly a year, will be ready for the cameras in five weeks. Dudley Nichols, who will produce and direct the film, is now doing a final editing job on the screen play, which he wrote after conference with O'Neill in New York.

NANKING, Feb. 15 -- The United States decision to withhold further armaments and credits from the Chinese Government is blamed by President Chiang Kaishek for prolonging the civil war, which he is determined to end by smashing the Chinese Communist armies, sources closest to the Chinese leader declared today.
LONDON, Feb. 15 -- A plan for using German manpower and raw materials to help Allied countries restore their "shattered economies" was published in London today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Representative Gerald W. Landis, Republican, of Indiana, said today that "it's a cinch" the House Labor Committee would approve nine major labor Jaw changes including some curbs on strikes and picketing.

Quietly and without the public attention frequently given philanthropic endeavors, The Commonwealth Fund, founded in 1918 by Mrs. Stephen V. Harkness "to do something for the welfare of mankind," recently issued its twentyeighth annual report.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 15 -- Wendell (Chummy) Broomhall, 27-year-old milkman from Rumford, Me., did plenty of delivering today on his hickory wings to win the national ten-mile cross-country championship, held in conjunction with the Olympic tryouts.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 15 -- Scholars of seven nations will meet here on Wednesday as guests of Princeton University for a threeday conference on "The University and Its World Responsibilities." The conference is the tenth in a series celebrating the university's bicentennial.

Net sales and other operating revenues of the Owens-Illinois Glass Company last year reached a new high of $196,259,500 despite continuing shortage of raw materials and transportation facilities limiting production in the last six months, the annual report to stockholders showed yesterday.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 15 -- Herman Talmadge won another Superior Court victory today but Judge Bond Almand, who upheld him, asserted critically that the State constitutional provision under which he was elected Governor by the General Assembly, "was adopted by the people living in the stage-coach era" and "remains without change in this, the Atomic Age."

Bertram Lebhar of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Preston Ellett of this city were leading last night in the life masters individual and senior masters individual cahmpionship contract bridge contests as the third session of play started at the Park Central Hotel.

Sportsmen's Show highlights. Fishermen who have tried spinning but found the complexities of the old type spinning reel too much for them will want to try the new Humphreys stationary spool reel. They have one rigged up with a seven-foot spinning rod at the Clark and Pinney display, and no matter how many thumbs you have on one hand you should be able to do wonders after four or five casts.

PARIS. FRANCE'S social structure is solid but her political history reveals a singular instability. She has had all kinds of regimes, from monarchy to republic and empire, and has held to none of them. She is still seeking the Constitution which is best adapted to her needs, without being very sure that the one she has just chosen is the right one.

WEATHER conditions over the last several weeks have made it difficult to judge whether the slackening in trade is a significant trend or not. Local business snapped back from a small margin over last year to an increase of 20 to 25 per cent last week, while the country-wide gain for department stores for the week ended Feb. 8 was only 2 per cent.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., Feb. 15 -- Compared to the rudimentary sheds in which aircraft were built in this region before the war, or with the echoing emptiness of some of the abandoned war plants, Republic Aviation Corporation's modern, tooled factory here presents a startling contrast.

ARTHUR Murphy may thank Dr. Johnson for conferring on him whatever immortality he continues to enjoy. For Murphy had the misfortune to be a minor playwright in an age that produced few playwrights of consequence, all of whom are now overshadowed by Sheridan.

The Committee on Post-war Tax Policy has released its second and final report, entitled "A Tax Program for a Solvent America." Together these volumes comprise four hundred pages of text, tables and statistics, with particular reference to taxation and fiscal affairs of the Federal Government.
White-haired United Spanish American War veterans "remembered the Maine" last night at forty-ninth anniversary ceremonies during which the need for future military preparedness was stressed.

An early rush in the renting of seasonal property on the Rockaway peninsula has already resulted in the posting of a number of "no vacancy" signs by apartment and bungalow owners, according to George Wolpert, executive secretary of the Chamber of Commerce of the Rockaways.

THIS first novel is the work of an artist, written with power, honesty and courage; it carries its own conviction on every page. Its complete realism may shock the tender-minded; yet few of those who read "End As a Man" are ever likely to forget it.

James Farley, former Postmaster General, told members of the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks at their seventy-ninth anniversary dinner at the Hotel Commodore last night that an alert and strong America must prevent another war.

ONE way to plan a perennial border so that there will be a lavish display of flowers is to pick kinds that bloom over a long period of time. They will not be wanted exclusively, for the border will be mediocre without iris, peonies, chrysanthemums, delphiniums and some of the other outstanding perennials that flower for short intervals.

AN exhibition of paintings by James N. Rosenberg is current at the Wildenstein Galleries. Most of the canvases are Adirondack landscapes, including "Maytime Storm," lent by the Boston Museum; the spacious "Adirondacks," lent by the Smithsonian Institution, and "Abandoned Farms," lent by the Metropolitan Museum.

The Association of New York Scientists expressed yesterday its strong support of the nomination of David E. Lilienthal as chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission. The organization has a membership of 850 in the metropolitan area.

Department and large specialty stores, faced with the necessity of improving customer service to combat declining sales, are concentrating on comprehensive instruction of both selling and non-selling executives in job methods, George Plant, manager of the personnel and store management groups of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, said in an interview last week.

FOR the second time in a fornight Picasso comes forward as an art world headliner, with a one-man show that opened on Monday at the Rosenberg Gallery. The sensational Picasso show at the Kootz Gallery has been extended and will now run through Feb. 22.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- In the few weeks it has been in session, the Eightieth Congress has been "needled" from several directions to do something about the growing problem of business giantism in America, a problem admittedly aggravated by all-out production policies during the war.

DON CARNEY brought to an end his series of children's programs on WOR with last Friday's broadcast. He had been heard Monday through Friday at 4:30 P.M. Known to his audience as "Uncle Don," Mr. Carney started his program twenty years ago on WOR and is credited with being the first of the radio "uncles."

Both the invited and the uninvited came to the sixtieth wedding anniversary party of Dr. Alfred Meyer and his wife, Annie Nathan Meyer, yesterday afternoon in the Women's Faculty Club of Columbia University, 410 West 117th Street.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Southpaw Max Lanier, who jumped the St. Louis Cardinals last year to play in the Mexican baseball league, now is a holdout because he has been asked to take a 50 per cent cut from the $14,000 he was reported to have received in 1946.

PARIS, Feb. 15 -- From the point of view that peace is indivisible, there is as yet no such thing in Europe, although this week five treaties were signed proclaiming the existence of a state of peace among the nations that stopped shooting at each other more than two years ago.

THIS is a handbook on skulduggery. In it Mr. George, who was football player, law clerk, stockbroker, airplane salesman before he turned Treasury Department agent, lets the reader in on how he operated against Nazi agents, bootleggers, narcotic agents, saboteurs, kidnappers and how he got evidence for the OSS against the Germans tried at Nuremberg.

Two heavyweights are to the ring dancing around each other, striking out when an opening presents itself. "Kill him," shouts a corporation president who is the personification of dignity in his office. The throng is vicariously in the ring, participating in a fight which is to decide who is the heavyweight champion of the world.

THE Bach Circle, which gives its second concert of the season, tomorrow night, will on that occasion utilize the effete modern piano as well as the eighteenth century harpsichord, hitherto deemed sacrosanct for its offerings. The piano will be played by Yella Pessl in Mozart's rarely heard trio for clarinet, viola and piano.

Daily hotel rates, while remaining stationary in some cases, jumped as high as 80 per cent in at least one place here as rent controls covering transient guests were scrapped yesterday by the Office of Price Administration. In many instances the new minimum rates rose 33 1/3 per cent but it was expected that the general average would remain around 11 per cent.
NANKING, China, Feb. 15 -- The consequences of ten years' exhausting warfare and the weak and unsound pattern of economic development became manifest in acute form in China this week.

A renewed activity in the purchase of building plots in New Jersey is noted by the Alexander Summer Company of Teaneck, which reports it has sold seventeen in Teaneck, Englewood, Hackensack, River Edge and Cresskill. since the first of the year.

The Italian Government has set a goal of $1,950,000,000 worth of imports during the current year, and $1,000,000,000 in exports, it was learned last week from ItalianAmerican trade sources. Italy will seek to double her imports and triple her exports.

CHANGE within science and technology always means social change, and the more revolutionary the discovery or invention the more revolutionary is the social change. Can the social changes that follow scientific and technologic change be predicted? Professor Ogburn thinks so.

Leonard Bernstein appeared as guest conductor at the concert given by the Boston Symphony Orchestra yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. The program, which made severe demands on the youthful leader's directorial powers, consisted of Mozart's Symphony in C major (K. 425); Beethoven's Seventh Symphony, and the Hindemith Violin Concerto, with Ruth Posselt as soloist.

Seeking to raise the standards of graduate work in Southern universities, the Southern Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools has approved in principle a program of accreditation for master's degrees based on recommended minimum requirements.

Dr. C. Ward Crampton, former chairman on preventive medicine of the New York County Medical Society, recently told the Joint Legislative Committee of the State of New York that whether a man at 60 will be as vigorous as the average man at 40 or decrepit and miserable as the average octogenarian depends largely on diet.
FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Feb. 15 -- One of the big questions troubling Europe generally and the American Army in Germany particularly is: "After UNRRA, what?"
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The State Department announced today the granting of a credit of $15,000,000 to Hungary for the purchase of surplus property that is about to become available in Germany.

PHILADELPHIA. SIX girls, aged 14 to 16, were put on probation in the Juvenile Court for frequenting a neighborhood unlicensed juke-box dance joint. I became acquainted with the case when it reached the criminal court where the proprietor was on trial before me and a jury, charged with contributing to the delinquency of these minors.

THE "Flowers for Your Garden" series, given at Times Hall, 244 West Forty-fourth Street, will be concluded with a lecture this Wednesday. Mary Deputy Lamson will speak on "Plans for a Picture Garden" at 2:30 P.M. and repeat her talk at 8 P.M.

THIS revision of Michael Sadleir's "Trollope: a Commentary" with its new gleamings will flutter the dovecotes of the Trollopians. These Sadleir humors, while he devotes himself mainly to establishing Trollope's rightful place in the tradition of the English novel.

To the Drama Editor: JOSE FERRER has indeed performed a service for the actors in the cast of "Cyrano" by his matinees of the play given by the understudies. Not only that, he has stimulated the minds of the theatre-going public toward a better understanding of the job of understudy beyond the old legend of "Understudy-To-Star-InOne-Night."

RANGES are still onorder appliances, their availability depending on the dealer's allocation, on the type desired and on the community (electric stoves are more popular in Philadelphia than in New York, for example, so more of that variety are assigned to the Quaker City).

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 15 -- Playing his last hockey game for Dartmouth, Captain Ralph Warburton netted the winning goal and scored an assist on the clincher to break a 5-5 deadlock and give the undefeated Pentagonal League leaders a 7-to-5 victory over Harvard today.

PASSENGER car output this year may reach only about 3,200,000 units, according to the Automobile Manufacturers Association. Since 3,000,000 passenger vehicles are likely to be retired from service in 1947, only a slight gain will be made in the number of cars on the road this year.

Plans for a new large scale privately sponsored housing project for Brooklyn were announced yesterday by Thomas G. Grace, New York State director of the Federal Housing Administration, which will insure the mortgage under the amended Section 608 of the National Housing Act.

MISS FERBER'S short stories (her blurbist informs us solemnly) are required reading in schools and colleges. For once, it is pleasant to agree with the publicity department. Selected by the author herself from over a hundred published items, the stories in this volume will repay the closest study of the fledgling who would go and do likewise.

OTTAWA, Feb. 15 -- Just how Canada can best do her share in defending the Arctic gateway to this continent has heen under close review in Parliament this week. This followed the announcement on Wednesday that the Joint Defense Board would continue to operate and that the principles on which Canada and the United States would collaborate were restated.

Accelerated growth for Long Island communities and a heavy influx of new families will require construction of a large number of small homes in the years just ahead, according to George M. Gross, president of the Gross-Morton Company.

BY the time these words are published the PhilharmonicSymphony Society will have announced its conductors for next season, and Dr. Rodzinski, following his suddenly proffered resignation as leader of New York's famous orchestra, and its quick acceptance by the directors of the same, will prepare to lead the Chicago Orchestra next season.

With suit and millinery departments particularly active, department store sales were high last week, according to a survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Also busy were dress, teenage, yard goods and notion departments.

Walter St. Denis, widely known as a sports editor and boxing publicity man, died yesterday in the Polyclinic Hospital after suffering a stroke Friday afternoon. He would have been 70 years old on March 19.

LONDON, Feb. 15 -- Yugoslavia's claim to a large part of the Austrian province of Carinthia was rejected today by United States, British and French deputies at a meeting of the group drafting the treaty for Austria.

LACK of recognition no longer hampers our appreciation of Vincent van Gogh's paintings. In our decade he has been exhibited widely and critics have wallowed in lavish, often indiscriminate, praise of him. His career has been romanticized and its more melodramatic episodes played up -- from the grinding poverty to the searing messianic passion that made living with him impossible and his own life untenable at the end.

THIS is a book about big game hunting. And not, as is so prevalent of late years, with flash-bulbs and cameras -- but with Mannlicher rifles and Mauser 404's and 400-grain bullets; with ingenuous native gun-bearers and jungle-scarred "white hunter" guides; with tethered heifers staked out as bait for Royal tigers, and hungry vultures hanging in the sky.
Thousands of prospective American sea travelers are doomed to disappointment this year, as far as North Atlantic travel is concerned.

HOUSTON, Tex., Feb. 15 (AP) -- The Texas Eastern Transmission Company of Houston plans to spend $40,000,000 on the Big and Little Inch pipelines for compressors and other equipment to increase the amount of natural gas moved from Texas fields to Eastern consumers to 425,000,000 cubic feet daily.

LONDON, Feb. 15 (Reuters) -- Britain's worst winter in fifty years closed down on the football field today, wiping out twenty-one English League games and ten in Scotland for perhaps the biggest cancellation list in soccer history.

A schedule of two summer services between Boston and the Canadian Maritime Provinces of Nova Scotia and New Brunswick were announced here yesterday by Alton B. Sharp, president of the Eastern Steamship Lines. One service will operate between Boston and Yarmouth, N.S., and the other between Boston and St. John, N.B.

Department store sales by reserve districts, as reported by the Federal Reserve Board, are listed in the following table which give percentage comparisons with a year ago: 4 Weeks Year One Week Ended Ended to

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 15 -- Overcoming a Princeton half-time lead of 21 -- 18, Army's basketball team downed the Tigers, 45 -- 39, in Baker Rink this afternoon for their ninth victory in twelve starts this season.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 15 -- Pat Geile of Indianapolis, assistant director of national child welfare of the American Legion, said today that present conditions made it impossible for many married veterans to take advantage of the educational opportunities offered under the GI Bill of Rights.

Last June at Basle the League of Nations voted itself out of existence and willed its documents and some of its headaches to the United Nations, Last week the U.N. was about to fall heir to one of the most perplexing problems of the League's legacy -- the problem of the Holy Land.

The United States is repeating a previous post-war error of overextending its international charge account, leaders in the foreign trade field said last week. Unless business men and the Government accept the fact that the United States has worked itself into a position of being a permanent creditor nation, it was emphasized, the elaborate international economic machinery that is being set up will be of little use.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Feb. 15 -- Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr. of the House of Representatives tonight reaffirmed intentions of the Republican Congress "to cut taxes to the bone" and to enact labor legislation which would hold labor and management equally responsible.

PEIPING (By Wireless). MANCHURIA has long been called "the cradle of conflict" because of her age-old record of war, blood and conquest. Today that historic term takes on new significance in view of Washington's decision to end mediation efforts in China's civil war.

WASHINGTON. ONE fall evening in 1944, a sergeant driving away from The Pentagon passed a tall, thin young officer. "Can I give you a lift, Lieutenant?" he sang out. The "lieutenant" smiled; he was 36-year-old Lauris Norstad.

MEXICO CITY. SINCE John Ford came down here some weeks ago to make a movie there have been any number of rumors going around that the noted director was doing a bit of pioneering. In a way, the rumors stood up under investigation, though the "pioneering" turned out to be less startling than we had anticipated.

MOSCOW, Feb. 15 -- An article in The New Times said today that the United States and Britain already had taken from Germany the richest war booty ever obtained by victorious powers. This claim was made as the tide of criticism of United States and British policy in Germany that has flooded the Soviet press prior to the opening of the Council of Foreign Ministers' meeting on the German settlement here next month rolled forward.

PARIS, Feb. 15 -- French troops supported by airplanes succeeded in occupying and holding a section of the Chinese-Annamese quarter of Hanoi in a surprise attack yesterday. The French forces met sharp resistance and all day today were reducing nests of resistance in the section occupied, which extends to the market place.

WHEN young Charles M. Blackford rode off to the wars he and his wife agreed to keep their letters for posterity. Hence a book that portrays the misery the Civil War brought to one family, both at home and in the field.

EVER since Milo of Crotona threw the bull for the edification of a packed amphitheatre, there has been, an entente cordiale between the world of sports and the world of acting. Under the aegis of the lares and penates of the box office, which they share, athletes have been accustomed since the dawn of history to step from the gladiator's sawdust pit to the actor's buskined board; and Hollywood is no exception.

At a time when many home owners are worried over the possibility that lumber which was not fully seasoned or contained too much moisture may have been used in their new dwellings -- with consequent shrinkage of doors, warping of floors or cracking of walls -- they have shown much interest in a new device that acts as a check against "green" lumber.

PARIS, Feb. 15 -- Paris policemen were back on their beats today and the Gardes Mobiles, called out suddenly yesterday to guard Government buildings during the four-hour police strike, were back in their barracks. But this "token" walkout of the armed guardians of Paris, along with Government office workers and postoffice employes, alarmed the authorities and placed the wage issue in the forefront of the urgent problems with which the Government is struggling.
LONDON, Feb. 15 -- The coal crisis in Britain is an uncannily accurate symbol of the present plight of the British Empire. In both cases the underlying problem is one of power.

Immediate passage of a State law on the lines of the AustinMahoney bill, which would prevent schools from refusing to admit an otherwise qualified student because of his race, creed or national ancestry, was advocated yesterday by various rabbis in sermons.

RIO DE JANEIRO. MANY cities have been known for their carnivals, but the most famed -- at least in modern times -- takes place in Rio de Janeiro. Older than New Orleans Mardi Gras and even more colorful than the preLenten celebration in Nice, the carnival in Rio brings out the entire population for four days of frenzy on a grand scale.

NOW that many of the 1947 catalogues have arrived, choosing seeds of annual flowers is once again in order. The lithographic masterpieces of fabulous bloom lure the gardener into mentally selecting enough seed to plant the State of Texas.
LONDON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Britons and northern Europeans heard an old story from weather forecasters tonight: "Continued cold, with slight snow."

Various aspects of the housing problem will be discussed at the annual convention and exposition of the National Association of Home Builders in Chicago during the five days starting Feb. 23, when efforts will be made to devise workable policies to relieve the acute shortage of living quarters.

Sale of homes for occupancy by the buyers instead of by lessees, conversion of residential space to commercial uses as a result of rent controls, and dwelling units deliberately held off the market by the owners are blamed by the National Association of Real Estate Boards for what it estimates to be a reduction of nearly 2,000,000 units in the number of rented homes and apartments in the country.

TOKYO, Feb. 15 -- Members of the War Department's special reparations mission to Japan have indicated a realistic approach to their problem, according to officials of Supreme Headquarters who have talked with them.

THE periodic reports on the progress of the war which the heads of the Army, Navy and Air Forces made to the Secretaries of War and Navy have been gathered here for the first time in book form. Although each of these reports has been made public from time to time since General Marshall's first report in 1939, they have been read mostly in abbreviated or summarized versions in newspapers or magazines.
