TORONTO, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Maurice (The Rocket) Richard, Montreal's league-leading scorer, tallied three goals and assisted in a fourth tonight but it wasn't enough to give the Canadiens a victory over Toronto. The Leafs matched the Montreal attack goal for goal for a 4-4 tie.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 15 -- In the feature event of the fifteenth annual Yale swimming carnival tonight in Payne Whitney pool, Joe Verdeur of La Salle College, Philadelplhia, set a world record of 2:35 for the 200-meter breast-stroke distance.

FREEZING as a means of preserving surplus crops for out-of-season use becomes more popular every year among home gardeners. Their peculiar problems have been the core of considerable research by State experiment stations.

The Aconcagua, a war-built C-2 Cargo vessel converted to combination cargo-passenger status for the Chilean Line at the Bethlehem Steel Company's Hoboken yard, will leave here Tuesday on her maiden voyage to the west coast of South America, Agustin Huneeus, general manager of the line, announced yesterday.

PHYLLIS McGINLEY meets all the requirements of light verse. Her subject-matter is New York and its suburbs, the flora, fauna and foolishness thereof She is a cartoonist in words. She sketches with unerring but not merciless lines such scenes as "Country Club Sunday," "Heat Wave" or "Lady Selecting Her Christmas Cards."

CHICAGO, Feb. 15 -- Stabilized prices in, hardwoods will develop some time during the first half of this year, John W. McClure, executive secretary of the National Hardwood Lumber Association, predicted today. In the meantime, with present price uncertainties indicating a conservative inventory policy, he revealed hardwood buyers were faced with a difficult decision as a result of the freight car shortage.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The possibility of causing the withdrawal of David E. Lilienthal's appointment as Chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission has been discussed and dropped, it was reliably reported today.

TAMAULIPAS, Mexico -- This 231-year-old ranch in the Sierra Madre foothills of northern Mexico, Hacienda Santa Engracia, isn't a dollar-aday paradise. You pay $10 a day for delicious food, a huge SpanishColonial bedroom, an ultra-modern bath, and peace disturbed only by an occasional ox-cart rumbling by the poinsettia-covered veranda.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Feb. 15 -- Gov. and Mrs. Thomas E. Dewey were among the 600 persons attending a funeral service for Kenneth C. Hogate, chairman of the board of Dow, Jones Co., publishers of The Wall Street Journal, this afternoon in the Episcopal Church of St. James the Less here.

IN response to the growing demand for color-slide projectors taking 2 1/4 inches square and larger transparencies, two such devices have just been produced. One is the Star D Projector, made by the Davidson Manufacturing Company of Los Angeles the other the Emde projector of the Emde Products Company in the same city.

DETROIT, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Hammering five goals past Chicago's rookie goalie Emil (The Cat) Francis in the first two periods, the Detroit Red Wings beat the Black Hawks, 5 to 1, tonight to keep Chicago in the National Hockey League basement. A crowd of 13,206 fans watched the cellar struggle.

Forty championship regattas, the largest number by far ever held, are on a program to be laid next month before the club delegates to the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound. They are in addition to the class races which will precede and follow them, making two more months of the summer season.

Urban mortgage financing activity throughout the nation continued its upward trend during 1946 with approximately $10,400,000,000 in "non-farm" mortgages recorded, according to a report yesterday by the Federal Home Loan Bank Administration. This amount represented "a new high" and was 85 per cent greater than 1945.

New York last year maintained by a commanding margin its prewar position as the leading United States port of entry for Brazilian coffee, according to the port development department of the Port of New York Authority. Figures given showed New York accounting for 51.5 per cent of the total volume of arrivals here as compared with an average of 45.8 per cent prior to World War II.

HAZLETON, Pa., Feb. 15 -- Casting aside long-established procedure in dealing with anthracite coal strikes not authorized by the United Mine Workers, the Lehigh Navigation Coal Company yielded today to the demands of thirteen miners who began a sit-down strike Wednesday night 800 feet underground at the Lansford No. 6 Mine.

THE broadcasting in full last week of the Board of Estimate hearing on the New York City subway fare demonstrated the tremendous part which radio can play in making the solution of government issues of direct concern to the individual citizen.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 15. (AP) -- Two slayings, a kidnapping, one arson attempt and other violence marked the traditionally quiet Jewish Sabbath today in the Holy Land.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 15 -- Because of the important place maritime affairs traditionally hold in its economy, the West Coast speculated this week as to future moves by waterfront and seagoing labor organizations.

Poldi Mildner, Viennese pianist who swept her first audience off its feet when she made her debut here as a prodigy fifteen years ago, gave a recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The pianist has been playing extensively in South America and this was her first New York appearance in nine years.

The American-Soviet Music Society last night at Times Hall presented the first in a series of three concerts of music by composers of the two countries it is seeking to bring together in closer cultural understanding. The program consisted of contemporary chamber music.

BERLIN, Feb. 15 -- The recruiting of 50,000 able-bodied men in the United States zone for work in the Ruhr mines has begun in earnest, according to a United States official just returned from a field trip to the zone. He added, however, that there were many difficulties, not the least of which is a lack of enthusiasm on the part of the German officials.
BROADWAY'S theatrical season is at its peak -- and the "first night," with its names and its neons, gleams more brightly than at any other time of the year.
CANTON, N.Y., Feb. 15 -- Cornell University's ski team surprised today by winning the St. Lawrence University Winter Carnival twoday ski meet, edging Syracuse by 7.7 points. St. Lawrence was third.
ANDRE KOSTELANETZ, who has already commissioned works from Aaron Copland, Jerome Kern and Virgil Thomson, has another commission up his sleeve. He wants a symphony dedicated to the United Nations.

Train schedules throughout the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad system were disrupted yesterday after a fast freight train jumped the tracks near Stamford, Conn., cutting off all main-line traffic in and out of New York City.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Politics, in its most primitive form, appeared to be swirling about the Senate this week as one influential member after another indicated, either on or off the record, that he would vote to bar David E. Lilienthal from the chairmanship of the United States Atomic Energy Commission.

OMAHA, Feb. 15 -- Activity in tha Midwest farm belt had an unusually heavy political flavor this week. Some of the oratory aimed at farm audiences came from the Republican Lincoln Day dinners throughout the area. Much of the remainder stemmed from a number of technical farm meeting's which could not avoid political angles on rural problems.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- President Truman plans to declare the national emergency ended before July 31, a high official disclosed today, erasing most of the 105 wartime laws then or sis months later.

AARON COPLAND'S Lincoln Portrait comes as close as any orchestral work, and there have been quite a few, to evoking the quality of Lincoln the man and his legend. Mr. Copland has come closer to success because he has not aimed too high and because he has written simply and unpretentiously.

HERE is a booK on the history of heavyweight championship fighting, from Jim Figg and the bare-knuckle days of the Seventeen Hundreds in England to the most recent title defense of Joe Louis, that will brief any follower of pugilism for the eternal arguments that cause hasty telephone calls to sports editors.
ROME, Feb. 15 -- Pope Pius XII received former President Herbert Hoover today for a discussion of European food problems.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 15 -- Preliminary discussions between British and Indian Government representatives on a settlement of India's sterling credit equal to almost $5,000,000,000, which was amassed during the war, were concluded today.

When Fabien Sevitzky brought the Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra last night to Carnegie Hall he conducted, among other works, two American scores composed in honor of his tenth season with the organization, which he has led and developed in that period.

LONDON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The text of the Moscow broadcast, as recorded here by the Soviet Monitor: On Feb. 10, 1947, when the Senate of the U.S.A. examined the question of the appointment of Mr. Lilienthal for the post of Chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, Senator McKellar took the liberty of asking:

THE Ingham family sat in their home in Washington, D.C., just before the convening of the Forty-sixth Congress (Papa was a staunch Republican member from Michigan) and wondered why Papa's bill to establish Rural Free Delivery in these United States had failed to pass previous sessions.
LITTLE AMERICA, Feb. 14 (Delayed) -- Douglas transport planes made today the first successful, major exploratory flights from this base of the Navy's Antarctic expedition.

HONOLULU, Feb. 15 -- At midnight Tuesday Pearl Harbor and toe rest of the military installations that make Oahu a mid-Pacific defense bastion were completing preparations for solving a major tactical problem of defense. Somewhere off the islands the big carrier Tarawa, escorted by two destroyers, was cruising with 101 F-4U Corsair fighters, T-B-M Torpedo bombers and SB-2C dive bombers.
MYSTERY writers, and their characters, are getting more mysterious all the time. Perhaps "bewildering" would be a better word.

-- PERILS Our Professor Ensykle has a concern lest the news of the numerous crashes, collisions and crimes of the day should engender a great, benumbing fear in the hearts of the people. Accordingly, he has dashed off a poem, from which we quote a few lines:

ONE of the featured items in a great many seed and nursery catalogues this spring is tuberous-rooted begonias. They are finally coming into their own, out of the class of "tricky things to grow" into the ranks of first-rate garden flowers.

NEW YORK'S subway -- currently the focus of hot words over the 5-cent fare vs. the 10-cent fare -- is not so old as those of London or Budapest (or even Boston). But, like certain other things in New York, it is the biggest, busiest and costliest thing of its kind in the world.

The world faces "the worst of all religious wars" unless it achieves the "international understanding and respect upon which alone peace can be built," Archibald MacLeish, former Assistant Secretary of State, said yesterday. He addressed 750 guests at a luncheon of the Foreign Policy Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Seven Democrats voted Friday in committee for the six-billion-dollar cut to the President's budget. Four Republicans voted against the cut. Senator Brewster of Maine, who voted for it "because it was that or no reduction at all" but who will "oppose it on the Senate floor," may represent a considerable group of Republicans.

ALTHOUGH it is scarcely true that "little of a biographical nature" has been written about Thackeray (there are studies by Elwin, Trollope, "Lewis Melville," N.W. Stephenson, Ellis and others, not to speak of collections of letters and reminiscence), Mr. Stevenson's book is the most detailed biography yet to appear.

EDGEWOOD ARSENAL, Md., Feb. 11 (Delayed) -- Experiments in and development of new war gases, some far more toxic than any hitherto known to man, are producing implements not only of war but also of peace.

In one of the fastest professional games played here this season, the Cleveland Rebels defeated the New York Knickerbockers, 90 -- 84, in a Basketball Association of America contest before 5,124 persons at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night.

Showing all kinds of pluck after the losers had drawn even at 11all early in the fourth period, the Squadron A Black Knights, helped by a six-goal handicap, turned back Buddy Combs' Essex Troop trio, 13 to 11, in the opening match in the Metropolitan League indoor high-goal championship polo tournament at the Squadron A Armory last night.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 15 -- Cadet Tom Hazard pounded out a decision over Intercollegiate Welterweight Champion Clarence Tannell of the Coast Guard Academy in the feature bout of a sixfight card, highlighting Army's five-sport program at the Military Academy today.

Room 1114 in French Hospital was vacated yesterday when Babe Ruth, perceptibly grayer, a little weak on his feet and weighing 189 pounds, thirty-six under the figure at which he entered the hospital, went home.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 15 -- Armed did what was expected of him today -- and did it in his usual handsome style.
A practical demonstration of the fine art of safe cracking was balked yesterday with the arrest of a master craftsman and two pickpockets to whom he was teaching the trade.

TEN-YEAR-OLD Helen was ashamed of her squalid home and her untidy clothes, but she wasn't taking any jeers about her mother's shortcomings and she lashed back with tongue and fists. Jerry, a 9year-old twirp, was one of five boys picked up by the police for petty thefts from a department store.

N.Y. UNIVERSITY -- Conference Advanced practices in junior high school curricula, administration and teaching will be analyzed in special sessions of New York University's twentieth annual Junior High School Conference to be held March 20 to 22. More than 1,000 administrators and teachers from schools in the Eastern area are expected to attend the conference, which is sponsored by the university's School of Education.

Although the colleges and universities of this country are crowded far beyond capacity, averaging a 50 per cent increase over their peacetime records, the teachers colleges have not made any similar comeback.

REACHING deep into her experience, which included responsible copywriting posts through the nation, Mrs. Stein has written a primer for the novitiate who sees in retail copywriting the hand of destiny. The book is not so much a directive on how to write copy as how to prepare oneself to write it.

TO write a familiar essay today, a man must be either a pure fool, or a convinced traditionalist, or a true stylist. Perhaps, in spite of himself, he must be a combination of all three. He is foolish to start with, for the temper of our times is impatient.

IN the faint suspicion that what our bookshelves need is another anthology, one Dave Stanley now comes up with "A Treasury of Sports Humor." Spattered on the tome's jacket are the names of some thirtyfive contributors, among them such current, deceased or reformed sports writers as Ring Lardner, Dan Parker, Damon Runyon, Paul Gallico, Tom O'Reilly, Charles Van Loan and Jimmy Cannon.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The letter of Dr. Alfred Cohn, published in THE TIMES of Dec. 29, 1946, appeared at an inopportune moment for those interested in the legislation of a National Science Foundation. On the date of Dr. Cohn's letter an informal committee composed of representatives of interested scientific groups met in Boston to discuss plans for the enactment of a National Science Foundation by the Eightieth Congress.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 15 -- Sherry Marshall, diminutive guard, ran Cornell ragged in the second half, scored a total of 17 points, and led Columbia to its fifth straight Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League victory today. The score was 41-27.

Following a breakdown in negotiations with employer groups, 1,000 metal lath workers will go on strike tomorrow morning, it was announced last night by officials of Local 46, Metal Lathers Union, AFL. The walkout will have a serious effect on city construction and hamper needed housing developments if long continued.

An intensified interest in the construction of rental housing under the Federal Housing Administration's revised loan-insurance program is reported by Raymond M. Foley, NHA Administrator, as the result of a series of meetings being held with leaders in the building industry throughout the country.

IN this collection of lyrics by the Ecuadorean poet, Jorge Carrera Andrade, his poems are offered us in translation; but the English versions are juxtaposed to the Spanish, so that the reader with the smallest knowledge of that tongue may discover something of the quality of the rich originals.

THE island of Cuba was one of the earliest way stations and staging areas in the Spanish conquest of Caribbean lands and the vaster areas to the south. Ambitious, if by no means laborious, men from all stations of Spanish life settled there, fanning out gradually from Havana along the northern coast.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 15 -- A splendid white borzoi with cream markings, Champion Vigow O.V.F. of Romanoff, gained his fifth best in show victory tonight in the eighteenth annual event of the First Company Governor's Foot Guard, first of the post-Westminster dog competitions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The resignation, effective May 1, of Wendell Berge as Assistant Attorney General in charge of the AntiTrust Division of the Department of Justice was announced today by Attorney General Tom C. Clark.

The ostensible issue in the French labor crisis, of which the Paris token strike was a manifestation, is the demand of Government workers for a minimum wage of 7,500 francs a month. This would only amount to about $62. To us it seems a reasonable enough demand. But the Government reply is that it cannot be met without raising prices.

Favored by better weather conditions, retail trade here recovered sharply week ended Feb. 15. Volume gains ranging from 20 to 25 per cent were estimated for department stores, against a rise of 2 per cent in the previous week. The week, however, had six selling days, against five last year when the large stores here were closed on Lincoln's Birthday because of the fuel shortage.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Senator James E. Murray, Democrat, of Montana announced tonight that he would reoffer the Wagner-Murray-Dingell bill for compulsory health insurance which aroused a storm in the preceding session of Congress but never reached a vote.

WHATEVER else the year 1947 brings to the commercial airlines of the United States, it should at least give tentative answers to two major questions that none of them can answer with certainty now: (1) Were they over-optimistic in estimating the post-war increase in passenger traffic and the rate of speed at which it would increase? (2) Have they all overbought in terms of airplanes?

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, now the leading private builder of apartments in New York, announced yesterday that it was ready to take applications for tenancy in Peter Cooper Village, another of its vast housing projects on the lower East Side.
Observance of American Brotherhood Week, sponsored by the National Conference of Christians and Jews, 381 Fourth Avenue, will begin today. The slogan this year is "Brotherhood -- Pattern for Peace."

THE greatest hitter in baseball undoubtedly is Theodore Samuel Williams, a good-looking, laughing youngster who has all the charm in the world when lie wants to use it. But Williams is a man of paradoxes with a rather mercurial temperament. He also has a fierce pride which can be rather childish at times. In a way he's almost a little boy who never grew up.

THE THOROUGHBRED RECORD, a publication concerned with the breeding of thoroughbred horses, recently ran a cartoon of a bespectacled race horse sitting on a stool by a floor lamp in his stable, reading one of a pile of books.

ON a sultry June Sunday seventy -one years ago, Private Charles Windolph followed the guidon of Troop H, Seventh Cavalry, out of the parched hills to the east and down into the valley of a clear, winding stream. That stream was about to be lifted to a permanent place in American history and legend.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 15 -- Returns still are coming in, but the early figures indicate definitely that New Orleans bounced back to the position of second port in the United States in 1946 in at least one respect.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The Russian protest brought swift support for Under-Secretary Acheson tonight from three members of the Senate Atomic Energy Committee.

The stock market showed little disposition yesterday to alter the closing level of Friday, and in the dullest and narrowest trading in three weeks it showed mixed changes as it closed. The list drifted narrowly throughout the two-hour session and brought to an end a week which witnessed the worst assault on quotations so far this year.

Both labor and management now realize that more is to be gained through harmony arising from analysis of mutual problems, than through strife, according to a survey just completed, the American Management Association announced here yesterday.

RALEIGH, N.C., Feb. 15 -- Russia, a reckless national fiscal policy in the United States, and ruthless labor leaders in America were named as major dangers threatening America, in the political last will find testament of the late Josiah W. Bailey, Senator from North Carolina, made public here today.

JERUSALEM (By Wireless). THE one constant factor in Palestine's long-standing perplexities is that its Jewish and Arab populations must continue to live together, no matter what ultimate political solution is hammered out. Whatever new constitution is framed, there will still be two peoples domiciled alongside each other in a land whose very smallness makes cooperative existence necessary and indeed inescapable in the long run.

WASHINGTON. THE War Assets Administration can help at least a few of those myriads of Americans who have selected the book, the phonograph record and the girl they'd like on that isolationist's dreamland -- the desert, or deserted, isle.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 15 -- The fears evoked by the very mention of the Bureau of Investigation and Statistics, the mild official name for China's secret police, have acted as an opiate on the Shanghai financial market and a stimulant to rice merchants who have been hoarding the staple foodstuff.

MOSCOW. THE American press, which is not precisely popular here, will be even less popular once Konstantin Simonov's new play, "The Russian Question," finishes rehearsals and is presented at the Drama Theatre.
HOLLYWOOD. NUNNALLY JOHNSON, Tobacco Road's other gift to Thespis, is not mad at Broadway -- not even terribly, terribly hurt. Just tired of it.

Setting seven days apart as Brotherhood Week might be like setting one day a week apart for living up to one's religion. At least it would be so if that were all. But it is a good thing for us to be especially reminded and instructed as to the practical significance of the ideal of brotherhood for all the fifty -two weeks.

The stock market has reached one of those climactic stages where surface opinion sways easily and price changes prove to be exaggerated. For approximately a month, the share list on the New York Stock Exchange enjoyed a seldom interrupted rising spiral, but last week difficulties were encountered that belied explanation in most Wall Street quarters.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 15 -- The monumental task of promoting, developing and improving world statistics has been notably advanced by the eight delegates to the Statistical Commission of the United Nations, which has closed its two-week session here with an enviable record of international agreement.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 15 -- California -bred Hubble Bubble was declared winner of the $50,000 San Vicente Handicap today when movie magnate Louis B. Mayer's favored Stepfather was disqualified and ruled out of the money in one of the wildest finales seen at Santa Anita Park.

THE dance has been ritual, spectacle, the entertainment of kings and courts, folk art and recreation; it has been so many things to so many peoples as far as memory can pierce that it has become a favored field for historians. There have been imposing -- and less imposing -- histories of the art, enough to fill all present needs and climaxed by Curt Sachs' fine "World History of the Dance."
Appears in the Capital Although the 1948 Presidential election is still twenty-one months away, it cast a long shadow last week over national and international affairs.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 15 (AP) -- All members of the New York Giants' spring training baseball squad are expected to arrive by tomorrow night, ready to take part in the squad's first workout which Manager Mel Ott has scheduled for Monday morning.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Ira Mosher, chairman of the executive committee of the National Association of Manufacturers, declared today his organization's opposition to the establishment of a Federal Mediation Board as provided by the Ball-Taft-Smith bill.

FOR THIS WEEK: Start gloxinias, one to a four-inch pot filled with a mixture of one part loam, one part leaf mold, one part sand and onehalf well rotted manure. Tubers are barely covered. . . . Sow seed of the slow-growing stock in order to have flowers before frost. . . . If they have not been sent, orders for rose bushes and fruit trees should be made out without delay.

MOST cogent criticism of American radio networks' treatment of fine music is leveled at what some have called the excessively commercial attitude adopted by the chains. It is reasonably clear that because of this attitude many a superior radio concert is put on at an unfavorable listening time, as good evening hours must be reserved for programs that are known to have huge audiences.

LONDON. MAKING the British public laugh last week was a grim and sometimes an impossible task for the BBC. Grim because the temperature hovered between 10 and 30 degrees below freezing point; impossible when electric power cuts suddenly faded out 99 per cent of receivers in London and reduced the audience to pioneer earphone numbers.

The Fordham basketball team added another metropolitan rival to its list of victims by defeating Manhattan College, one of its oldtime enemies, 60 to 53, before a capacity crowd of 3,800 in the Rams' gymnasium last night.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 15 -- In a ding-dong basketball game that wasn't decided until the last three minutes, Dartmouth outpointed Yale, 53 -- 50, tonight to climax the thirty-seventh winter carnival festivities. Aud Brindley, playing his final intercollegiate game, contributed 18 points to lead the Indians to their second Eastern Intercollegiate League triumph.

The number of stewards was increased from seven to nine, proposed by-laws to the constitution were adopted and a method of rotation on the board of stewards was put into effect at the regular monthly meeting of the Jockey Club last week.

Ground will be broken soon for a new housing development in Bayside, Flushing Gardens, Queens, where plans have been filed for the erection of thirty one-family units on the west side of 205th Street between Fifty-sixth and Fiftyeighth Avenues.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The United States squash racquets team took the Grant Trophy from Canada, 9 to 2, for the third straight time today in the third annual doubles matches.

The Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo opened what used to be known as its spring season well in advance of spring last night at the City Center. The company, which is an extremely agreeable one on the feminine side of the roster, was in good form, the program began strictly on time and the evening moved with speed and spirit.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP)-- The Army's universal military training experimental unit has conducted its first test of a "GI courtmartial" system.

Came a Saturday morning on an early winter day when Father said after breakfast, "Why don't you hitch the team to the big sled and get new shoes for the mares today? Likely to be ice any time now. You can bring back half a dozen bags of cottonseed meal when you come."

LITTLE SILVER, N.J., Feb. 16 --Three members of a Saturday night foursome were drowned in the South Shrewsbury River at 1:30 A.M. today when a car skidded off the ice-flecked Gooseneck Point drawbridge along Seven Bridge Road near here.

The Senate section of the Congressional Joint Atomic Energy Committee begins today its fourth week of hearings on the President's appointment of former TVA Chairman David E. Lilienthal and four other outstanding men to the United States Atomic Energy Commission.

Councilman Eugene P. Connolly, American Labor party member from Manhattan, yesterday called Governor Dewey's attention to a bill reported out of committee in the State Assembly that he said would permit pre-censorship of all film advertising.

By establishing their first cell in Georgia the brown-shirted Columbians thought they were casting their seeds of race hatred on fertile soil. They were mistaken. The conviction in Atlanta of Homer Loomis Jr., for incitement to riot, reveals that even in the realm of the Talmadgres American justice gags at such perversion of democracy as these bigots preached.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 16-- The Afghan, Champion Karach of Khanhasset, gained best in show tonight in an event that for class ranked with the best in the country, the twenty-fifth annual allbreed competition of the Elm City Kennel Club.
Edwin W. Ross has been appointed general manager of the Los Angeles branch of National Silver Company.

A new group of dramatic decorative fabrics styled in California and offered in New York to bring to Eastern homes the livelier, overscaled designs popular on the West Coast is available at Wanamaker's. The patterns are among new hand prints made by the Barret Textile Company on either rayon faille, American linen, sail cloth, a rayontextured fabric or "nubflax," a heavy combination of tire cord rayon and linen for draperies.

The Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert, Bishop-elect of the Protestant Episcopal diocese of New York, administered the rite of confirmation to nine persons yesterday at the morning service of the Episcopal Church of St. Matthew and St. Timothy, 26 West Eighty-fourth Street.

Barter has been used successfully on a national basis by Lyon Metal Products, Inc., Aurora, Ill., to obtain hard-to-get supplies of sheet steel, both hot and cold rolled, from New York sources as well as from stocks in other industrial regions, it was learned here last week.

Thousands of sportsmen from New York and adjoining States, most of them accompanied by their families, thronged the National Sportsmen's Show at Grand Central Palace yesterday, constituting the largest attendance in the history of the exposition, according to the show sponsors.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 16--President Truman, who is due to arrive here on an unprecedented visit on March 3, will in any case be regarded by throngs of Mexicans as a distinguished guest who has chosen to confer a signal honor on a neighboring republic.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16--Country offering of cash corn were fairly liberal last week, but there was relatively little hedging pressure as the Commodity Credit Corporation purchased an estimated $6,000,000 bushels or more from the private grain trade, paying 18 cents a bushel over March, delivered at Baltimore, Md., and about the same figure for delivery at Galveston, Texas.

STOCKHOLM, Feb. 16 (AP)-- Miss Barbara Ann Scott, 18-yearold Canadian star from Ottawa, today won the women's world figure skating championship. Miss Daphne Walker of England was second and Miss Gretchen Merrill of Boston, the United States champion, third.

NAVAL PROVING GROUND, DAHLGREN, Va., Feb. 14 (Delayed) --Guns and armor are still important elements to the postwar Navy and there is no present indication that the age of guided missiles and atomic bombs will eliminate them.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 16--The production of 4,000,000 new autos in 1947, barring any unforeseen labor stoppages, was predicted today by W.L. Mallon of Newark, president of the National Automobile Dealers Association.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 16-- Thirty-six Giants were comfortably billeted in Spanish-type bungalows at Autopia Lodge, a modern auto court, tonight, ready for tomorrow's take-off on the drive to lift the club out of the National League dead-end.

Complaining that only 19,000,000 bushels of grain had been exported through the Port of New York last year, against 100,000,000 a year before World War II, Mayor O'Dwyer has asked Clinton P. Anderson, Secretary of Agriculture, to route more grain shipments through New York, it was announced yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 16 (U.P.)--Temperatures plunged to far below the freezing point across the Continent today. The mercury dropped to 13 degrees Fahrenheit in Berlin, where seven more deaths raised the toll from cold this winter to 156.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 16--President Eduard Benes has warned Josef Lettrich, chairman of the Slovak National Council, and a delegation of Slovaks that because of the presence of Russians on the other side of the Carpathians all plans for any central European federation must be abandoned.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP)-- Three Democratic Senators threw their support behind David E. Lilienthal for chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission today and representatives of twenty-one national organizations gave him backing in a statement.

What could be better for a midwinter dinner than a crisply crusted pork roast, its odor stimulating appetites already sharpened by a brisk wind? Probably the most popular cut of fresh pork for roasting is the loin, which is easy to cook and, if a few principles are observed, easy to carve, too.

EIGHT years ago John Steinbeck's "The Grapes of Wrath" established its author as one of the most powerful and interesting of living American writers. Since then Mr. Steinbeck has written nothing worthy of comparison with his one major triumph. None of his earlier books has anything like its stature either. Is it possible that Mr. Steinbeck is a one-book author

Cotton prices in the domestic market last week displayed a firm undertone and rallied easily from all setbacks. At the close of the period, active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net advances ranging from 8 to 50 points.

LONDON, Feb. 16--London's reaction to the industrial crisis caused by the fuel famine has been no worse than might have been expected, considering the almost panicky manner in which the Government suddenly confronted the country with the seriousness of the situation.

Karl R. Free, an artist and former associate curator of the Whitney Museum of American Art, 10 West Eighth Street, committed suicide last night by gas in his two-room apartment at 649 Second Avenue, according to the police of the East Thirty-fifth Street station.

BOSTON, Feb. 16--Mr. Treadway, a campaigner for high tariffs, was bitterly opposed to the New Deal and President Franklin D. Roosevelt's policies, often ridiculing the "Roosevelt brain trust." In 1936, he called for the impeachment of Henry Wallace, then Secretary of Agriculture, after the latter had described as a "legalized steal" the Supreme Court decision abolishing the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.

MOSCOW, Feb. 16--A bitter attack on the plan recently proposed in New York by John Foster Dulles, Republican adviser on international affairs, appeared today as the latest expression of mounting Soviet concern and dissatisfaction with American policy and policy makers.

PARIS, Feb. 16--While Premier Paul Ramadier spoke today of a new price cut within a few days and warned against the effect of new wage increases, he and his Government were equally disturbed by the threat to France's financial stability that is feared unless a break in the cold spell in the next ten days permits the replanting of a major portion of the wheat crop.

The New York Rangers discovered another "cousin from Canada" at Madison Square Garden last night. Surprisingly successful against the Canadiens of Montreal in the current National Hockey League season, the Blue Shirts showed that they also had the number of the other Dominion entry in the circuit by skating through to a 6-to-2 triumph over the Toronto Maple Leafs.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 16--Despite such obstacles as scarcity of scrap metal, higher scrap prices, shortages of fuel and adverse weather conditions, the steel industry last week was able to maintain its operating rate of 93.5 per cent of capacity, unchanged from the week before.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 16 --Diminutive Ralph Townsend, who confounded Army doctors in returning to active ski competition after receiving a serious shoulder injury in the Italian Apennines, today won both the national championship and the Olympic combined classic tryouts under the sponsorship of the Lake Placid Club Sno Birds.

When the Security Council meets tomorrow, it will formally embark on the momentous task of setting up an international system for the elimination of the atomic bomb from national armaments and for the effective control of atomic energy to insure its use only for peaceful purposes.

The program of chamber music given by the New Friends of Music yesterday afternoon in Town Hall indicated a concert that first would advance characteristic music of the ninteenth century romantic school, in works by Schumann and Tchaikovsky--and end with the score of the man who became a formalist sometimes to the point of a musical abstractionist in his last period--the late Bela Bartok, the Hungarian.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Feb. 16--On borrowed now, the ski clubs of Greater New York staged their annual jumping jamboree here today. A total of fifty-one stars competed for honors.

Apparel, footwear, hand tools and industrial supplies are the major lines of current surplus offered this week by the War Assets Administration, Carl P. Malmstrom, regional director, announced over the week-end. The $9,000,000 acquisition cost black oxford shoes scheduled for sale today will not be marketed until Wednesday, Feb. 26, he said.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 16--Col. Earle L. Johnson, national commander of the Civil Air Patrol, was killed today when a twinengined Army C-45 plane which he was piloting crashed at suburban North Royalton a few seconds after taking off from Cleveland Airport, Army officials reported.

Activity in ready-to-wear markets, both wholesale and retail, continued brisk last week, with buyers in town placing orders on the new summer lines, and Easter fill-in merchandise, according to the reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.
CHICAGO, Feb. 16--A bull market was on in grains on the Chicago Board of Trade last week.

TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 17 (AP) --United States Army authorities, announcing detention of five American soldiers on murder charges, said today that the soldiers, using clubs of firewood, had killed five Japanese and injured twenty others in the town of Hachioji, fourteen miles west of Tokyo, on Jan. 31.

"Heyday," a romantic comedy by Donald Richardson, will go into rehearsal today under Howard Lang's auspices, with a cast headed by Roscoe Karns, John Craven, Timothy Lynn Kearse and Augusta Roeland. The production, which will be directed by the author, is scheduled to reach Broadway early in April, after out-of-town engagements starting the week of March 10.
This is a warning to the small fry of Greenlane, a post-borough of Montgomery County, Pa., fortythree miles north-northwest of Philadelphia.
Mayor O'Dwyer appealed for good-will and understanding among all peoples in a radio broadcast over Station WOR yesterday morning marking the start of the annual observance of Brotherhood Week.
PARIS, Feb. 16--The question who will control French newspapers is scheduled to come before the National Assembly's press committee this week.

YONKERS, N.Y., Feb. 16--To the dwellers of New York City, who take their weather lore in scientific capsules over the telephone, today was rather mild for February with the mecury hitting the 40s. But up here it was an occasion for amateur naturalists to take stock and call newspapers on their findings.
Two young hold-up men demonstrated a new technique in crime last night when they entered a Bronx drug store and forced their victims, at pistol point, to swallow a quantity of sleeping pills.
LUXEMBOURG, Feb. 16--This nation, one of the smallest on the earth, stands in danger of having her economic life crushed out by United States action against the German cartels, it is contended here.

A proposal to ordain women to the ministry in the Presbyterian Church "is absolutely contrary to the Bible and to common sense," the Rev. Dr. John H. McComb, pastor of the Broadway Presbyterian Church at 114th Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

BERKELEY, Calif., Feb. 16 (AP) --Lynn Waldorf, 44, Northwestern University football coach, today was named head football mentor at the University of California, Brutus Hamilton, acting general manager of the Associated Students of California, announced.
Is the so-called family-size farm passing from the American scene? Or is it just getting larger than it used to be?

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The International Bank of Reconstruction and Development--as contrasted with the International Monetary Fund--is endowed with the capacity to render exceptionally profitable services to the world economy, but as yet this world bank has granted no loans, and now finds itself without a president.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16--The long delay by the World Bank in getting into lending operations--a delay for which numerous compelling reasons are advanced--has focused new attention on the question whether the bank was not conceived as an organization to do too much too quickly.

PARIS, Feb. 16--Sophisticated gowns, each with its special wrap, are an important element of the elaborate evening scene at Worth's. A shell pink corduroy coat with a court mantle swung from the shoulders has huge elbow sleeves in platinum fox and is worn with a turquoise crepe gown.

Peruvian International Airways announced yesterday signing of a contract for its main operational and maintenance base at Bradley Field, Conn., between Hartford and Springfield, Mass. The field was formerly the main operating base of the Atlantic Wing of the Air Transport Command.

ALBANY, Feb. 16--In a memorandum filed with the Legislature, Mayor O'Dwyer said today that New York City is opposed to proposed changes in the election law that would increase the pay of its election inspectors by about $400,000 a year. He added that the city would withdraw its objections if the bill is changed to limit the cost to $75,000.

FOR the past several years the Thoroughbred Racing Associations have been issuing weekly bulletins to the press. These have contained an odd assortment of facts and John I. Day, who wrote most of them, has combined with Tom Underwood to publish the best of the lot under the title of "Call Me Horse,'" published by Coward McCann.

The thrill of holding records in track events can never surpass the "greater thrill" of knowing, God, Gilbert Dodds, track star and ministerial student, declared yesterday in a sermon at the Central Park Baptist Church, 235 East Eighty-third Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP)-- A majority of the Senate Labor Committee opposes pending legislation to outlaw the closed shop and industry-wide bargaining, a survey showed today, as union leaders prepared to ask Congress to junk the controversial proposals.

Putting Them On Ice The chief of staff activities of the United Nations thinks it would be a good idea to incorporate a skating rink in the U.N. group on our East River. It is an idea suggested, perhaps, by the ice pond in the heart of Rockefeller Center which invites the attention of so many spectators.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 16-- There was a fellow wearing a number "3" on his uniform who seemed to be attracting considerable attention as the Yankees swung into their second day of training under a blistering tropical sun today.
CHICAGO, Feb. 16--Short covering dominated the action of the oats market last week on the Board of Trade, with strength in
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The Czechoslovak Government needs the economic help of both Western and Eastern powers, a report of the Foreign Policy Association stated today.

City Fireman Christopher Fitzgerald went to work yesterday morning in the customary Sunday quiet. Shortly after 10 o'clock he and other members of Hook and Ladder 137,116th Street and Rockaway Beach, Queens, were called when the second alarm signal sounded for a fire in the area.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 16--Police search parties penetrated a deep ravine today and found the fifty-three charred mangled bodies of the passengers and crew members of a Colombian Avianca airliner who perished yesterday in commercial aviation's greatest disaster.
Bad news for the milers! Gilbert Dodds yesterday "guessed" that he will be back in the mile at the National A.A.U. track championships at Madison Square Garden next Saturday.

The United States will place its trusteeship plan for the 650 Japanese -mandated islands in the Pacific before the United Nations Security Council today and will ask full power to build bases and administer the islands as militarily strategic areas.
Why are there so many airline accidents ? The answer is so obvious that it is easily overlooked: Because there is much more flying on airlines.

Advertising's role in changing the peacetime attitude of Americans toward their regular Army is lauded by Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson, in a communication to James W. Young, chairman of the Advertising Council, Inc., it was revealed over the week-end.

Four thousand employes in mills directed by I. Rogosin, textile manufacturer, found themselves unexpectedly advanced from the status of workers to part owners yesterday, under a plan by which he will distribute an estimated $500,000 in stock to make them shareholders.

ALBANY, Feb. 16--Republican legislative leaders reported to Governor Dewey at a conference in the Executive Mansion tonight that his budget would be approved by the Legislature this week without substantial change despite the attacks made on it last week by Mayor William O'Dwyer, teachers and civil service employes.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Just a word of heartfelt appreciation for your splendid editorial on the Baltic states in the Feb. 6 issue. We who have friends and relatives among the refugees in Europe and imprisoned in Siberia know that there wasn't a single word of exaggeration as to the Russian version of the good-neighbor policy toward the three helpless nations.

THOMASVILLE, N.C., Feb. 16 --Van A. Bittner of Atlanta, Ga., national director of organization for the Congress of Industrial Organizations, told a conference of CIO furniture workers here today that "I am praying" that the North Carolina and other legislatures would not enact anti-labor laws.

Sooner or later most harpsichordists seem, to turn impresarios. Sylvia Marlowe is the latest to take the step, and yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Chamber Music Hall she presented the first concert of the Early Music Group that she has organized.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 16 (U.P.)-- Don Piccard, 21-year-old son of Dr. Jean Piccard, the stratosphere explorer, landed successfully twentyfive miles northeast of here today after a free-balloon solo flight of two hours and ten minutes to test equipment which his father and he developed.

New York players led two groups of contract bridge masters into the final of five rounds for the life masters' and senior masters' championships last night in the tournament of the American Contract Bridge League at the Park Central Hotel.

William J. Slocum, author of two forthcoming books, has resigned as director of special events for the Columbia Broadcasting System and has gone to Sarasota, Fla., to begin work on a book about the experineces of Elmer Irey, former head of the Treasury Department's law enforcement agency.

Surrounded by American priests who were his classmates, Konrad Cardinal von Preysing, Bishop of Berlin, was present at solemn mas in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesteday. Cardinal Spellman presided at the mass, which was attended by a congregation of 4,500.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16--The group attitude of conservative Southern Senators and of the Republican leadership was regarded by observers today as the still clouded determining factor in the bitter fight over confirmation of David E. Lilienthal as chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16--President Truman returned to the White House tonight after a flying weekend trip to the bedside of his mother in Grand View, Mo.

Luise Vosgerchian, young American pianist of Armenian parentage, gave her first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Her playing was wholesome, sane and individual. It also was alive, intelligent and imaginative.
LONDON, Feb. 16--The terms of the agreement for the purchase of British-owned railways by the Argentine Government have been received here with mixed feelings.
The Rev. Louis W. Pitt Jr. declared in his first serman here that "a broken Christendom and a broken Episcopal Church need personal consecration to save themselves from, destruction."

After investigating reports that some newspapers, both daily and weekly, have been threatened with suspension for lack of a regular newsprint supply, the American Newspaper Publishers Association reported yesterday that as far as it can find out there are now no instances of such distress where the publishers and the mills deal directly.

Dreyfus, Jacquin Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange and successors to Lewisohn Co., announced yesterday that Elias D. Davidson has joined the firm as a registered representative at the branch office, 37 Wall Street.

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 16--Widespread interest and comment have been provoked by the annual report of Holland's largest private bank, the Rotterdamsche Bankvereeniging, in which unusually sharp criticism is leveled against the Government's financial policy.
The Chase National Bank has been appointed registrar of the 3.75 per cent cumulative preferred stock, $100 par value, of New York State Electric and Gas Corporation.
CHICAGO, Feb. 16 (AP)--Fifty years ago tomorrow a small group of women meeting in Washington founded an organization to do something for America's school children.

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 16--The prolonged severe wintry weather, the shortage of fuel and the difficulties of transport are hampering the economic recovery of the Netherlands. Rivers and canals are frozen and all transport is confined to railway and road.

ALBANY, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The Prison Association of New York called today for a State study to draft plans for what it termed "a coordinated correctional policy" and more effective use of penal facilities for various types of inmates.

BOSTON, Feb. 16 (U.P.) -- The Boston Bruins staged a brilliant third-period rally to gain a 2-to-2 tie with the league-leading Montreal Canadiens tonight in a National Hockey League game before a capacity throng of 13,900 fans at the Garden.

Mayor O'Dwyer was warned last night that the strike of 1,000 metal lathers, scheduled for 8 o'clock this morning, would force an immediate suspension of work on half the construction projects in this city and that all would have to shut down within a few days if the strike continued.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 16 (AP)--Chief Engineer August Heps of Miami told tonight how he and five other survivors of the shipwrecked Shiawassee III battled mountainous waves in a tiny lifeboat for nearly six hours before being picked up off the Florida coast early today.

Obviously fatigued from their rugged tie with the Boston Olympics on Saturday night, the frontrunning New York Rovers dropped a 4-2 decision to the Washington Lions in the Eastern Hockey League battle featuring the amateur double-header at Madison Square Garden yesterday before 15,125 fans.
America's vast system of teacher training is in need of drastic revision. The preparation that many teachers receive today is entirely inadequate.

NANKING, Feb. 18--Drastic and sweeping measures for dealing with China's economic crisis were announced by the Chinese Government here today. They call for the return of the Government-controlled areas of China to the basis of wartime stringency.

Anniversary and benefit exhibitions are notable among the week's many art events. City College opened over the week-end an exhibition of paintings, sculpture and graphic work by sixty-five artist alumni, as part of the institution's centennial observation, the exhibition being installed in the auditorium of Townsend Harris Hall, Amsterdam Avenue and 139th Street, to continue through June.

Passenger service on the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad was slowly returning to normal last night, and officials were confident that by this morning delays caused when thirty derailed freight cars blocked the line above Stamford, Conn., Saturday, would hardly be noticeable.

ROME, Feb. 16--Dwindling of wheat supplies has obliged the Italian Government to reduce the amount of wheat in rations for the period of Feb. 20 to the end of this month, it was made known today. By March 1, it is hoped, importations from Argentina and other sources will have re-established the situation.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 16-- William Holden, Glenn Ford and Ellen Drew will play the leading roles in "The Man From Colorado," a photoplay by Robert E. Andrews, dealing with the post Civil War westward expansion, which Columbia will put before the cameras on Wednesday.

MONTERBY, Calif., Feb. 16-- An expanded program for dealing with potentially explosive minorities problems of this State at the "grass roots" leven was projected at a meeting of the year-old California Council for Civic Unity held this week-end at Asilomar, near here.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Feb. 16-- Out in frigid water which even fish had shunned, twenty-three sailing dinghies today wound up their winter session of racing at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

Brooklyn, whose baseball team, private homes and churches are so proudly hailed by its residents, proved to be a sad disappointment yesterday to ten teen-age boys and girls--from other boroughs--on a chartered trolley tour.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 16--While politicians throughout the world talk about the desirability of greater economic integration in western Europe, the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg are discovering some of its practical difficulties.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The challenge in the Senate to the confirmation of Mr. Lilienthal as chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission is a challenge to the American people to make their influence felt if they believe in good government and if they want to live in a peaceful world.

BRATTLEBORO, Vt., Feb. 16-- Showing his heels to a field that included a team of Norwegians newly arrived in this country, Merrill (Mezzy) Barber today won the open invitation ski jumping meet conducted by the Brattleboro Outing Club.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The State Department reported tonight that it was ready to negotiate agreements with fifteen countries to send additional hundreds of Americans to study and teach in foreign universities.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16--Strength in the cash lard market with a broad domestic and foreign demand, combined with further upturns in the price of edible oils, sent all deliveries of lard futures to new seasonal high marks last week on the Board of Trade here.
LONDON, Feb. 16--Thousands of Britain's miners gave up their traditional Sunday holiday today to swell the slender supplies of coal.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Feb. 16--Tonight this city is packed with people who have streamed in steadily for days past to witness tomorrow morning's ceremonial landing of King George VI, first reigning sovereign to visit South Africa.

LONDON, Feb. 16--The dreams of children about queens and princesses and Hollywood's richest fancies are realized in the wardrobes that the royal family has taken to South Africa. Pearls and diamonds, cloth of gold, endless yards of material, interminable work by dozens and dozens of seamstresses, have gone into the most sumptuous clothes that British royalty has worn for generations.

RIBOLOVO, U.S.S.R., Feb. 16-- Out here, in the heart of the silent whiteness, lies the Boretz, or Fighter, collective farm, whose men and women are confidently preparing for another battle in their long struggle against nature for bread.

The startling aspect in the Congressional Joint Committee's proposal to cut six billion dollars out of the Federal budget is not the sum itself so much as it is the method by which it was arrived at. As nineteen Democratic members of the committee's minority stated on Saturday, this is a proposal "to cut without knowing what is to be cut, how much is to be cut, or where the cut is to be made."

DETROIT, Feb. 16--Walter P. Reuther, president of the CIO United Auto Workers, today lashed back at R.J. Thomas, union vice president, for "false, malicious and irresponsible charges" made in the quarrel over the Allis-Chalmers strike.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Feb. 16-- Representatives of German textile industries who met informally in Hamburg last week saw no reason why the difficulties inherent in the practical application of the AngloAmerican export-import agency's plan for making the merged Anglo -American zone of Germany self-supporting by 1950 should be insurmountable under certain conditions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP)-- President Truman has lent his personal plane, the Sacred Cow, for the homeward trip of Emir Saud, Crown Prince of Saudi Arabia, who has been on a three weeks' air tour of the United States.

WARSAW, Feb. 16--The longer one is in Poland the more one becomes impressed with the work of the American Relief for Poland. This war relief agency has created an enormous amount of goodwill for the United States through its efforts to alleviate suffering in this wartorn country.

The Young Men's Board of Trade of New York, 291 Broadway, acting as coordinator of the efforts of business and industry, lists the following free services to aid veterans in career-planning and employment.

A collection of 400 dolls, representing almost every country in the world, was donated yesterday to the Israel Orphan Asylum, 2550 Beach Channel Drive, Far Rockaway, Queens, by Mrs. Grace Perlberg, of 50 Riverside Drive, a member of the asylum's sisterhood.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 16--The first American plane comparable to Great Britain's Lancastrian, with both jet and reciprocating engines, was announced here today by the Glenn L. Martin Corporation in conjunction with the Navy Department.

KINGS PARK, L.I., Feb. 16-- Forty to fifty persons were injured, eight of them hospitalized, when a Long Island Rail Road train was derailed here today after hitting an open switch. Five of the injured were in serious condition.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16--State Department officials, it was learned today, have informed Senators that the United States must ship Russia some $25,000,000 worth of goods ordered originally under lend-lease or violate "agreements made in good faith."

Leo Durocher, manager of the Brooklyn Dodgers, who is presently involved in a divorce tangle with a California court over his marriage to movie actress Laraine Day, arrived at La Guardia Field yesterday aboard a Trans World Airlines' plane from Los Angeles.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $57,365,427,693. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

JERUSALEM, Monday, Feb. 17 (U.P)--Several unauthorized Jewish immigrants were wounded and two jumped overboard yesterday when the refugee ship Herouth, carrying 800 to 950 immigrants, was boarded by sailors from three British destroyers off Bat Yam, six miles south of Tel Aviv.

American farmer "prosperity hit its peak in 1946, according to an analysis of the outlook for agriculture for the coming year released yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board. Lower prices for 1947 are predicted officially and unofficially despite heavy domestic and foreign demand and short supplies, it said.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16--Some legislative momentum is expected in Congress this week, when both houses consider the joint committee's recommendation that spending for the next fiscal year be reduced $6,000,000,000 from President Truman's budget estimate of $37,500,000,000.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16 (U.P.)--In the wildest, most bruising game of the season the Chicago Black Hawks scored a last-minute goal to defeat the Detroit Red Wings, 3-2, tonight before 19,338 rabid fans at the Chicago Stadium.

With the opening yesterday of a new reading room in City College's Army Hall extension, 1560 Amsterdam Avenue, the college's library has begun to put back in use some of the 60,000 volumes, nearly one-quarter of the school's total, that have been stored for several years beyond the reach of students because of a shortage of shelf space and building facilities, Prof. James K. Wilcox, librarian at the college, announced yesterday.

Domestic automotive and construction industries benefited most from sharply increased shipments of steel in October, according to the monthly report of the American Iron and Steel Institute. Shipments aggregated 5,246,544 tons, compared with 4,569,402 the month before.

The American Can Company and its Canadian subsidiaries had net sales last year of $258,065,461, the highest for any year except 1941, according to the annual report mailed to shareholders yesterday. They represent an increase of 6.5 per cent over the 1945 volume of $242,351,862.

Woodrow Wilson led the United States into the First World War to "make the world safe for democracy." Franklin Roosevelt called the Second World War the "war for survival." For Americans these slogans mean the same thing, for without government by the people what this country stands for and lives by would be no more.

Under the impetus of record consumer demand and a pressing need to rebuild inventories of aging whiskies, major units of the distilling industry are obtaining and utilizing the most extensive bank credits ever made available to them.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 17 -- Although Congress will materially revise existing labor laws at this session, no drastic all-out steps will be taken, Representative Charles A. Halleck, majority leader of the House, predicted here today. He spoke at the opening session of the thirtieth annual convention of the National Automobile Dealers Association, held in the Municipal Auditorium here.

Ninety agencies have used the facilities of the Willkie Memorial Building for meetings in the last year, it was announced in the first joint yearly report, released for today, for the seven national and local organizations maintaining headquarters there.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- With the slow but steady improvement in the fuel situation the stock market today, after a cautious opening, staged a further recovery -- the only prominent exception being the gilt-edge group.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange ended 10 to 28 points net higher yesterday after moving irregularly during the day.

It would have been a proud hour for Cecil Rhodes, the Empire Builder, if he could have looked down on Capetown yesterday from his memorial on Table Mountain. The first reigning British monarch ever to visit South Africa was landing in Britain's youngest dominion.

The Salvation Army has raised $570,433 in its 1947 annual maintenance appeal for $1,000,000, Edward J. Noble, chairman of the appeal, reported yesterday to 250 Salvation Army representatives at the Fifty-eighth Street Theatre.

Twenty-six antique clocks, mostly of eighteenth and nineteenth century make, shared honors with a collection of modern timepieces in an exhibition that opened yesterday at Lambert Brothers Jewelers, Lexington Avenue at Sixtieth Street.
RIBOLOVO, U.S.S.R., Feb. 17 -- Although the deep snow and cold have physically isolated this village, there is a wide and urgent interest here in the world outside, especially the United States.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 7,000 head; total 9,500; generally 50 to 75 cents higher; most advance on weights 260 pounds and down; good and choice 180 to 250 pound $26.50 to $27.00: top $27.00; 250

LEO ERNEST DUROCHER, who presumably manages the Dodgers in his spars time, will follow his Ferocious Gentlemen in the direction of the sunny Southland tomorrow, with his preliminary destination being Havana and his eventual destination being the National League pennant. He's a lead-pipe cinch to reach the first one.

Beneath the Plan A few desultory remarks in this column several days ago were concerned with one aspect of a sizable subject -- nothing less than this great debate of our times between planned and unplanned economy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The House, by a voice vote, passed and sent to the Senate today legislation continuing until July 1 the authority of the Maritime Commission to maintain shipping operations. The authority is scheduled to expire March 1.
LONDON, Feb. 17 -- In the face of unrelenting weather, some improvement in the coal crisis was registered today as Britain continued her slow, precarious struggle to overcome the fuel stringency.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Although it is expected they will be backed by upward of 40 per cent American funds, bonds of the new International Bank for Reconstruction and Development must be registered in Ohio on the same basis as any commercial issue, the State Securities Division announced today.
BERLIN, Feb. 17 -- The chairmen of three German political parties decided today to beseech the Russian Military Government to "go easy" on denazification.

The American Government has now submitted formally to the Security Council its previously published proposal for putting the Japanese-mandated islands in the Pacific under the trusteeship of the United Nations. The plan calls for designating the United States as administrator, under conditions which would grant us exclusive military, naval, air and economic rights and make the islands "an integral part of the United States."

The United States Government is anxious to obtain expressions of opinion from business men on how it may best develop the American position at the international trade conference which is scheduled for April 8 in Geneva, Willard L. Thorp, Assistant Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, stated yesterday.

Trains on the Long Island Rail Road passing through Kings Park, L.I., were back on schedule yesterday after repair crews had worked through the night restoring tracks that had been torn up in Sunday's derailment.

The Government should desist from a farm price support program that tends to create wasteful surpluses, leaders of the nation's potato industry said yesterday. Potato growers do not believe taxpayers should be forced to pay more than $100,000,000 a year to maintain an artificial level of potato production, they said.

Henry J. Kaiser submitted yesterday a brief to the Interstate Commerce Commission protesting a proposed reduction in freight rates for the Geneva Steel Company of Provo, Utah, a subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation. He asked the commission to suspend the change in rate, which is to become effective on March 1, and to make an investigation.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 17 -- A conference to study and discuss how the church and the individual Christian can make Christian principles a more potent factor in easing tensions in economic life will open here tomorrow. Convened by the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, the conference of 370 delegates will have as chairman Charles P. Taft, president of the council.

ATHENS, Feb. 17 -- The United Nations Commission inquiring into Greek border troubles heard today the Greek Government spokesman, Alexis Kyrou, charge that Yugoslavia, Bulgaria and Albania were carrying on "a war of nerves" against Greece "in league with our local extremists."
The maritime unions of the country are becoming increasingly uneasy over the number of privately owned American merchant vessels being transferred to foreignflag registry, it was learned yesterday.

Most New York garment manufacturers will have salesmen back on the road with lines of dresses, coats and suits by the fall of the year, it was learned yesterday in a survey of the market. Major outof-town selling efforts, however, will not revert to store-to-store canvassing which was customary prior to the war, but will be concentrated in apparel salesmen's group showings in market centers throughout the country.

A special dispatch to this newspaper yesterday from the Russian capital reported "that as the opening of the Moscow conference approaches, SovietUnited States relations have worsened and that the possibilities of an accord on the problem of Germany have diminished."

ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- The decision of Republican legislative leaders to bar the public from Senate and Assembly galleries tomorrow when the State budget comes up for passage met with immediate challenge tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 17 (AP) -- A twenty-eight-word letter written and signed by former President Herbert Hoover brought $550 today in a public auction. The price topped those paid for autographs of George Washington and other Presidents.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The House Labor Committee was reported at the point of final agreement today on seven restrictions upon union power. It is believed almost certain, however, that the committee will reject all demands for an end to industry-wide bargaining as practiced in coal by John L. Lewis' United Mine Workers.
ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 17 -- Supporters of Herman Talmadge in the State Senate today defeated a proposal to submit the white primary measure to a vote by the people.

Donald Wolfit and his British repertory company will open a limited engagement this evening at the Century Theatre under the auspices of Hall Shelton, by arrangement with the Advance Players Association, Ltd. "King Lear" will serve as the opening bill of a planned five-play schedule.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The National Labor Relations Board threw out today an unfair labor practice charge of the St. Petersburg (Fla.) Typographical Union, American Federation of Labor, against The Times, Evening Independent and News Printing, Inc., in a decision which reversed its own trial examiner and expounded some noteworthy board doctrine.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 -- Wheat futures resumed their upward course today after an early break on the Board of Trade. May wheat, at the top, was 7 1/4 cents above the early low, selling at $2.24 1/2, the highest price for that delivery since April, 1917.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 17 -- Housing prospects for Mr. and Mrs. I.C. Davids, whose only son was killed in the war, appeared to be better today after the couple had appealed to President Truman for aid.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Margaret Truman, showered by presents on her twenty-third birthday, topped off the occasion by inviting the President and Mrs. Truman to the theatre tonight.

MOSCOW, Feb. 17 -- Lieut. Gen. W. Bedell Smith, United States Ambassador, several Ministers and First Secretaries of foreign missions, correspondents and Russians gathered around radios tonight to hear the first State Department broadcast to Russia.

TRENTON, N. J., Feb. 17 -- Governor Alfred E. Driscoll today signed the legislation to set up a public referendum on constitutional reform and provide for election of convention delegates for the redrafting task.

LITTLE AMERICA, Feb. 16 (Delayed) -- Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd, the only man to fly over both Poles, again flew over the South Pole today and beyond it, riding one of two planes on an exploration flight from here.

ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- Major crimes increased 10.8 per cent in New York State during 1946, John A. Lyons, Commissioner of the Department of Correction stated tonight in his annual report to the Legislature.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 17 -- The final report of the United Nations Transport and Communications Commission, embodying an American resolution that a conference be convened in Europe this autumn to establish an inter-governmental shipping agency, is scheduled for consideration in the commission tomorrow.

The National Society of Mural Painters is holding its first post-war exhibition at the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street. It opened with a preview yesterday afternoon and will continue through Feb. 28.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The Senate passed by a voice vote today the House-approved bill to continue indefinitely the wartime excise tax rates on jewelry, liquor, cabarets, toilet articles and other "luxury" items, but it made concessions on fur-trimmed garments and travel abroad.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 17 -- A group of young men whose names are scarcely known outside Arab nationalist circles is meeting daily here to plan a campaign for the liberation of the western part of North Africa from French and Spanish control.

Abraham H. Feller, general counsel and director of the legal department of the United Nations, interpreted yesterday the bigpower veto in the Security Council as a sign that most of the nations of the world have relinquished an important part of their sovereignty.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Charging British "faithlessness" to the mandate of Palestine, the American Zionist Conference, in an emergency session today, called on the United Nations to repudiate imperial restrictions on Jewish immigration and settlement in the country as violations of the organic grant.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 17 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today an amended plan of recapitalization filed by the American Water Works and Electric Company, Inc., New York. The plan is part of a program that eventually will result in dissolution of the company and transfer of substantially all its water properties to a new concern, the Water Works Holding Company.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 17 -- Seeking new sources of income to relieve real estate of part of its tax burden, the Westchester County Board of Supervisors petitioned the State Legislature today to expand the tax levies on pari-mutuel horse-race bets in a manner that would permit the county to collect an estimated $5,000,000 a year from the Empire City Racing Association.

The responsibility of hotels and private clubs in conserving food supplies to assist the Government's program of feeding peoples abroad and needy American families was stressed yesterday by John L. Hennessy, chairman of the board of the Hotel Statler Company, Inc.

WIESBADEN, Germany, Feb. 17 -- Plans for a bi-zonal directorate of experts through which Germans of the American and British zones may, when asked by the Military Government, express their views on problems of the peace settlement and gather pertinent information were worked out here today at a meeting of the six Minister Presidents of the two zones and the Mayor of Bremen.

The Bach Circle gave a program of eighteenth-century chamber music, from Quantz to Mozart, last night in Town Hall. At this concert the piano as well as the sainted harpsichord was played by Yella Pessl, who is the motivating spirit of this excellent organization.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 -- Widespread delays in the national postwar highway construction program with resultant danger to thousands of motorists were attributed to Communist activities by Representative Paul Cunningham of Iowa, today at the opening of the convention of the American Road Builders Association.

Ray Robinson, Harlem boxer who holds the welterweight championship of the world, was fined $500 and suspended for thirty days, by the New York State Athletic Commission yesterday. The fighter was set down because of his failure to report a bribe of $25,000, made in connection with his scheduled -- and then canceled -- fight with Marty Servo for the 147-pound title last Sept. 6.
Forty-four teams of contract bridge stars began play at the Hotel Pierre last night in the first round of the national team-of-four tournament, played annually for the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup.

The Port of New York Authority urged yesterday that the Civil Aeronautics Board permit qualified applicants to carry air freight without obtaining certificates of public convenience and necessity. The Authority said air freight was in its infancy and needed, the greatest possible flexibility to develop an efficient service.

Following is a translation of the first broadcast, made yesterday, in the regular Russian-language program to be beamed to the Soviet Union by the State Department: Announcer 1: Hello! This is New York calling. You are listening to "The Voice of the United States of America."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 17 -- Two major issues will be taken up before the United Nations Security Council tomorrow. In the morning Sir Alexander Cadogan will present the United Kingdom's complaint against Albania; in the afternoon the Russian and Polish counter-proposals on atomic energy will be presented.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 17 -- With forty-one of his playing squad on hand and in uniform, a hot sun beating down upon a transformed playing field and a crowd of close to 1,000 natives and tourists looking on back of police lines on either side of the field, Manager Mel Ott put his Giants through their first working day of the 1947 campaign today.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 17 (AP) -- Henry Wortzel, Commander of Newark Post 302, American Legion, pleaded guilty to a charge of contempt and was fined $250 and costs today by Vice Chancellor Alfred A. Stein.

ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- New York State never was a more healthful place to live than it was last year, the State Health Department disclosed today in reporting that the death rate was "actually the lowest ever experienced," while births were at a record high.
Two real estate agents accused of rent gouging were sentenced yesterday by Federal Judge Harry B. Watkins to nine months in jail and fines of $4,000.

An issue of $773,913 of street improvement bonds will be offered on March 4 by Meridian, Miss., it was announced yesterday. The bonds, on which bidders are to name the rate of interest, will be dated Apri 1, 1947, and will be due on each April 1 from 1948 to 1957.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 17 -- On the eve of the expected legislative approval of a bill outlawing the closed shop in this State, violence flared this morning in a Congress of Industrial Organizations struck factory in the town of Dickson, forty miles west of here.

A strike of 500 metal lathers slowed work yesterday on $100,000,000 in public and private housing projects here. The walkout forced the layoff of 2,000 carpenters, laborers and foundation workers and threatened to make at least 50,000 other building trades mechanics idle if it continued more than a week.

VIENNA, Feb. 17 -- Recent allegations of anti-Semitism in Austria, published in New York, have made the authorities of Austria and Vienna disturbed and resentful.
