A report by Arthur Greenfeich of the American Jewish Committee that Jews' property was not being restored, anti-Semitism was getting the upper hand and "bloody anti-Jewish riots" had occurred at the University of Vienna was cabled back here over the week-end.

There were six voices on yesterday's Russian-language broadcast from the State Department's studios at 224 West Fifty-seventh Street. All are those of American citizens whose mother-tongue is Russian.

The United States could assume unquestioned leadership in the United Nations if it knew what it wanted and felt strongly about it, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said yesterday. She spoke at a tea given by the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom in the home of Mrs. A.B. Danzig, 29 Washington Square West.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 17 -- The early days of a spring training campaign always provide their share of rookies who somehow command immediate attention and the Yankees, toiling away under a sizzling sun, already have unearthed a fair quota.

There was nothing in Leo Durocher's demeanor suggesting that the dapper blue suit he wore reflected his mood. He was reserved and modest as he met with baseball writers at the Montague Street offices of the Dodgers yesterday and discussed the 1947 prospects of his Brooks.

PARIS, Feb. 17 -- Pickets occupying the telephone switchboard room of the Communist party's newspaper, I'Humanite, were thrown out today by a crowd of Communists mobilized by the paper's management. Officers of the striking Union of Newspaper Employes denounced the Communists as strike-breakers and expressed regret at such action by "a newspaper claiming to represent the working class."

TOKYO, Feb. 17 -- The Japanese Government decided at a special cabinet meeting today to hold the general election ordered by Gen. Douglas MacArthur on April 25. The series of local elections, long planned and frequently postponed, will be held between April 5 and May 2.

MADRID, Feb. 17 -- Spain is intensifying the campaign to build up her ports and merchant marine on the basis of a ten-year program. The latest step is the announcement that the city of Seville is about to launch a 25,000,000peseta loan as part of 90,000,000 pesetas worth of improvements scheduled to get under way in the near future.

Sportsmen's Show sidelights. Elmore Wallace, the genial Sea and Shore Fisheries warden, known to every tuna angler who ever fished out of Bailey Island, Me., will be found perched on a lobster pot at the Maine display. Wallace is one of the few people in this world who has a job he really likes, with the result that everyone he encounters on the job ends up liking him.

STOCKHOLM, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The Belgian pair of Michelin Lannoy and Clair Baugniet tonight were named the world champions of pair-skating by the referees although their point total was below that of Karol and Michael Kennedy of Seattle, Wash.

A return contest, pitting Long Island University against Canisius, and N.Y.U. against Manhattan, will feature the first college basketball double-header in a month tonight at Madison Square Garden. The intracity encounter is slated to open the program at 8 P.M.

Jacques Thibaud, French violinist, who, after a fifteen-year absence, returned to play here this season, gave a recital last night at Carnegie Hall. His admirers, including Fritz Kreisler, turned out in goodly numbers to admire his art, to enjoy his music and to pay tribute to him as a man.

A capacity crowd of 18,833 fans watched the Golden Gloves amateur boxing finals at Madison Square Garden last night. The tourney, the twenty-first annual one, was presented by the News Welfare Association with the sanction of the Metropolitan Association of the A. A. U. Proceeds of the show will be applied to Catholic, Jewish and Protestant charities and to the Red Cross.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 17 -- Skiing good-will between Norway, the parent of the sport, and the United States was emphasized today in an announcement by Roger Langley, president of the National Ski Association of America.

TORONTO, Feb. 17 (Canadian Press) -- Representing one of the oldest curling clubs in the United States, Fred Parkinson's Utica, N.Y., quartet today eliminated the strong Hamilton Victoria's rink skipped by Dr. A.E. Walkey, 7-5, in the first round of the twentieth annual Ontario bonspiel.

Practical nurses experienced with small children are needed for the new Infant Care Center of the Protestant Children's Service at 1761 Stillwell Avenue, the Bronx, Miss Helen Ruth Hagan, director of the center, said yesterday. The center has been open a week.

ROME, Feb. 17 -- Italian circles foresaw today that Trieste's economy would be linked with that of Italy as a result of the visit to Rome of representatives of the Foreign Ministers' economic commission of investigation for the Free Territory.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The State Department announced today that an official reply to Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov's complaints regarding Under-Secretary of State Dean Acheson's testimony before the Senate Atomic Energy Committee had been forwarded to Lieut. Gen. W. Bedell Smith, United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union, for transmission to the Kremlin.

Opponents of David B. Lilienthal's confirmation to be head of the Atomic Energy Commission have failed to show that he is sympathetic with communism; that his administration of TVA has not been superbly efficient; or that anything is lacking in his experience, his abilities or his character.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 17 -- The Central Bank fixed the official price of gold at $480,000, Chinese, an ounce ($40, U.S.) as Premier T.V. Soong arrived here today with a retinue of advisers to implement the sweeping economic controls adopted by the Chinese Government.

Controller Lazarus Joseph predicted last night that the basic tax rate on real estate would be increased to $2.95 for each $100 of assessed valuation from the present $2.70 if the Legislature continued to refuse additional financial aid to the city.

LANSFORD, Pa., Feb. 17 -- The end of a sixty-hour underground sitdown strike by thirteen Lansford miners on Saturday failed to bring about a resumption of work in the rich Panther Valley area today, as about 6,000 coal diggers remained away from the pits.

Beginning with a nocturnal flight over New York, the Tide Water Associated oil Company will take to the air Thursday to advertise its products, weather permitting. An ex-Navy blimp, 253 feet long, one of the largest animated advertisements in the world, carrying 11,500 electric bulbs, will flash messages concerning the oil company's products.

BERLIN, Feb. 17 -- The Russians' dramatic promise to rush coal to Berlin to keep the population from freezing to death is somewhat less generous than it seemed when made last Thursday, it was officially disclosed today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 17 -- "Rupert of Hentzau," Anthony Hope's romantic novel, first published in 1897, will be brought to the screen for the third time with Alida Valli, Italian actress, and Louis Jourdan, French actor, in the leading roles, David Selznick, who will produce the film, announced today.

This week, at 201 Varick Street, seven middle-aged gentlemen are bending over a table with a rotating top determining with much solemn sniffing and sipping what sort of tea we Americans will be drinking in the coming year. The United States Board of Tea Experts, as this dignified body is called, is gathering in the offices of the United States Tea Examiner, Charles F. Hutchinson, for its first annual meeting since February, 1942.

It all depends in what part of the United States you are born whether you will get a decent public school education. Many sections of the country are providing totally inadequate school programs for their children.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The editorial "Guaranteeing Bank Loans" in your issue of Jan. 31 raises objections to the bill recently introduced by Senator Charles W. Tobey of New Hampshire, chairman of the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency.

The half-million-dollar estate willed by Mrs. Mary Sheldon Lyon, 85-year-old recluse, to two "heavens" of Father Divine, Negro cultist, included a half interest in a $100,000 dormitory at Ithaca, N.Y., tenanted for more than a quarter of a century by Cornell students, it was disclosed yesterday.

The problem of how to meet demands for cemetery expansion was presented to Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday when he held a formal hearing on a local law to permit St. John's Cemetery in Glendale, Queens, to use for cemetery purposes eighteen additional acres it now owns.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The House Appropriations Committee emphasized today the Congressional economy mood by trimming by more than half a request by President Truman for deficiency funds for some agencies.

Unhappy, impatient and disillusioned spouses, who with shallow claims beat a, "well traveled pathway to the halls of justice" to obtain release from their matrimonial bonds, were condemned yesterday by former Supreme Court Justice Nathan D. Lapham.
Ash Wednesday, the first day of Lent, will be widely observed in New York City churches tomorrow. The forty days of the penitential season will culminate on Easter Sunday, April 6.
Three hundred boys and girls from the public schools gathered yesterday morning in the great hall of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York to observe the opening of Bill of Rights Week.

PICKENS, S.C., Feb. 17 (AP) -- The body of a 25-year-old Negro, punctured with knife and shot wounds, was found today at dawn sprawled on a frosty roadside less than two hours after an armed mob marched him from a cell in Pickens County jail.

PARIS, Feb. 17 -- A serious famine said to be threatening death to tens of thousands of persons now is in full sway in Rumania, according to diplomatic reports received here. [President Truman announced that sufficient United States Army food to aid 500,000 was being rushed to Moldavia, in northern Rumania.]
Charles L. Gallo, formerly general manager for TACA Airways, Inc., in Central America, has been appointed director of traffic for the international division of Trans World Airline.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- All seven women members of Congress were present today at a press conference announcing the introduction of a new bill on the legal status of women.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 -- Expanded world markets are essential to the continued high level of industrial and agricultural production in the United States, Secretary of Commerce W. Averell Harriman told the Chicago World Trade Conference today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Senator Kenneth McKellar, Democrat of Tennessee, dean of the Senate and formerly its president pro tempore, invoked the name of God today in a hope that the "United States would never obtain a workable agreement for the international control of atomic energy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Attorney General Clark announced today that a consent judgment had been entered at Cleveland, "eliminating restraints in the manufacture and sale of lecithin," a soybean and corn oil extract having a wide variety of industrial uses.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- A proposed constitutional amendment limiting Presidents to nine years in office, at the most, was approved 9 to 1 today by the Senate Judiciary Committee. Senator Kilgore, Democrat, of West Virginia, was the only opponent among seven Republicans and three Democrats voting.

Store Sales Here Up 25% Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 25 per cent last week over the comparative week of last year. The week, however, had six selling days against five last year, when department stores here were closed on Lincoln's Birthday because of the fuel shortage.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 17 (U.P.) -- Sweden defeated the United States today in the world amateur hockey championships, 4 to 1, and became co-favorite with Czechoslovakia to win the title.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 17 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission hopes to have open meetings in this city, in Philadelphia "or other large centers" where "those interested" may "candidly present their views" for improvement in the Securities Act of 1933 and the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, James J. Caffrey, chairman of the SEC, told the San Francisco Bond Club today.

SECURITY COUNCIL Committee of Experts -- Continued discussion of the draft statutes and rules of procedure of the Military Staff Committee. Council meets at 11 A.M. and 3 P.M. today to take up British complaints against Albania and to resume discussion of atomic report. (Open).

PEIPING, China, Feb. 17 -- Word of an American humanitarian gesture that has saved the lives of ten members of the Soviet community of Harbin -- including several women and children -- has just been received here today via the last of the planes evacuating the United States Executive Headquarters to leave Harbin.

The Macy-Gimbel price battle on Reynolds ball pens has resulted in the Reynolds Pen Company "writing business of nearly $5,000,000 in five days," Milton Reynolds, chairman of the board, said yesterday in an interview at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Commercial Paper Volume Up The volume of commercial paper outstanding at the end of January was the greatest since November, 1942, just before a decline developed because of conversion to war activity, according to information released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 17 -- Henry Ford 2d, president of the Ford Motor Company, invited California manufacturers today to help him cut the cost of automobiles and offered them an opportunity to supply an additional $50,000,000 worth of parts every year.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- After five weeks' work and with only one more week left before the Feb. 25 deadline, the Foreign Ministers' Deputies completed today the preamble for the draft of the Austrian peace treaty -- and they did not agree even about that.

QUANTICO, Va., Feb. 17 -- Quantico, "home" of the Marine Corps, which has trained many generations of "leathernecks" in the art of marine combat, is analyzing the lessons of past battles and groping toward the new technique of future war.

One of the most serious shortcomings in recent policy-making on New York City's expense budget is the niggardly attitude shown toward the support of public libraries, and we believe that the time has come to adopt a whole new attitude.

For the first time since 1930 a new Young Men's Christian Association building will be erected in New York City. Ground for it was broken yesterday at Seventy-second Street and the Hudson River, in the West Side freight terminal of the New York Central Railroad.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The International Association of Machinists today charged that a subcommittee of the House Appropriations Committee was planning to "wreck" the Department of Labor by slashing its budget by about $10,800,000.

Eighty-five school children invaded the teen-age lounge that opened yesterday in the St. Agnes branch of the New York Public Library, 444 Amsterdam Avenue. A dozen were in line before 3 P.M., official opening time, their arms filled with reference and copy books.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Investigators who climbed to the summit of rocky El Tablazo said today that the transport plane that crashed on Saturday, killing fiftythree persons, had missed clearing the peak by less than six feet.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Justice Robert H. Jackson denounced the Supreme Court today for disregarding the customs and contracts of industry when deciding wagehour cases and, on the other hand, using the wage-hour law to "put industry and labor into a straitjacket of our own design."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- In order to answer the Soviet Union's protest against Under-Secretary of State Dean Acheson's statement that Russia's foreign policy is "aggressive and expansionist," our officials, in their careful way, have been consulting the Congressional records, the dictionaries, the current maps of Eurasia and numerous statements and remarks by Soviet functionaries.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- An explanation of the structure of government in the United States, along with a few tips on its practical politics, and a news summary were included in the State Department's first broadcast to the Soviet Union today.

Steel distributors have rejected the War Assets Administration claim that present surplus steel inventories are unsuitable for sale through their outlets. Maurey I. Cohen, president, Association of Steel Distributors, Inc., and president of Harry Harris Co., Kearny, N.J., flatly contradicted the WAA opinion yesterday, in a telegram to the Eastern headquarters of the association sent from the West Coast where he is consulting with distributing officials.

The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company established a new record for peace-time sales last year, while net earnings, which more than doubled those of 1945, were the largest in the history of the company, P.W. Litchfield, chairman of the board, reported yesterday after a directors' meeting.

The stock market was left to its own devices yesterday and prices improved selectively and closed irregularly higher. There was no disposition on the part of market followers to take more than a casual interest in the day's proceedings. Transfers on the Stock Exchange totaled only 870,000 shares, smallest turnover since Jan.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, Feb. 17 -- George VI, Queen Elizabeth and the two Princesses landed on South African soil this morning. By nightfall they had endeared themselves to Capetown, the mother city.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- There is a basis for the resistance of some Senators to the confirmation of David E. Lilienthal as chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission which was created long ago and cannot fairly be discredited as a manifestation of prejudice, corporate greed, partisanship, personal spite or any form of reaction.

A demand by the Teachers Union, CIO, for an immediate strike poll of New York City's 30,000 public school teachers was disavowed yesterday by the Teachers Salary Conference, which directly and indirectly represents virtually all the teachers in the city.

ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- Republican legislative leaders, obviously with Governor Dewey's full approval, today slammed shut the door on Mayor O'Dwyer's plea for $102,000,000 more in State aid for New York City.
Airline experts of six nations will meet here today to discuss international uniformity of airports, routes, ground aids and other safety measures.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Baldish Walter S. (Mike) Milligan, 42, became Pitt's head football coach today. Line coach last season under Wes Fesler, he succeeds his former boss who shifted to Ohio State.

Decision was reserved yesterday by Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind after attorneys had completed arguments in the proceedings for a writ of habeas corpus brought by Dr. Karl von Kleczkowski, former German espionage agent, and his wife, Stella.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 17 -- The Governments of India and France have agreed to exchange embassies for the purpose of "maintaining and further strengthening friendly relations" between the two countries, it was officially announced today.

Members of the New York City Committee of the State Commission Against Discrimination were asked yesterday at their first meeting to go about their work without sentimentality. Charles H. Tuttle, who will serve as vice chairman, said that "great expressions we have learned to revere" must be converted into reality if the nation is to be served.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The Swedish Government declared tonight that Russia, then a non-belligerent, had backed Sweden's hand when she refused during the spring of 1940 to transport Nazi arms to German forces in Norway.

Reporting on last year's operations of the Western Electric Company, Clarence G. Stoll, the president, informed stockholders in a statement for release today that sales of $610,356,000 were $250,357,000 less than in 1945 but $180,887,000 above the former peacetime record.

MIAMI, Fla., Fen. 17 -- Calumet Farm, which has won more than twice as many races as any other stable engaged in the Hialeah Park scrimmaging, scored its fifteenth success of the meeting today when Pep Well charged under the wire the winner of the first division of the $4,000 Manatee Purse.
Marshall Field Co. reported yesterday net profit of $11,548,649 for 1946, equal to $5.61 a share on the common, stock. This contrasted with net profit of $5,210,093, or $2.35 a share, in 1945.

TOKYO, Feb. 17 -- A virtual reversal of present reparations policies regarding Japan will be recommended by the War Department's mission headed by Clifford Strike, which has completed its work and will start for Washington tomorrow.

Charles Triller, chairman of the Philharmonic Symphony Society of New York announced last night that "all financial matters" between the organization and Artur Rodzinski, who resigned as its musical director, had been "amicably and equitably adjusted."

Scientific methods, if applied to world problems, could solve them in a generation, James B. Sumner, Professor of Biochemistry at Cornell University, asserted last night. He spoke at a dinner honoring five Nobel Prize winners among Cornell's faculty and alumni.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Feb. 17 (U.P.) -- Nonunion supervisory workers today published The Springfield Daily News for the first time in 144 days, ending the news blackout due to a strike.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 (AP) -- American scientists were "dumfounded" by the publication of industrial aspects of the atomic bomb project in the Army-approved Smyth Report in 1945, the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists asserted today.

Scoring almost at will most of the way, the Fordham basketball team notched its fifteenth victory last night by routing the New York State Maritime Academy, 69 to 41, before a crowd of 1,000 in the Rose Hill gymnasium.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--Gerhart Eisler, described as "commissar of Communist activities" in this country, was cited for contempt by the House of Representatives today by a vote of 370 to 1.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 18 (AP)--Jerusalem was battened down completely and virtually all movement was halted. Officers in charge of road-blocks leading to the newly created "residential security compounds" stood with drawn sidearms. The compounds, taken over from Jewish residents and barricaded with barbed wire, now house British citizens.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--The Senate Republican Conference decided today to hold the Senate in session day and night twice a week, on Mondays and Wednesdays, as soon as legislation begins piling up. Two weeks' notice will be given for members to arrange their affairs and engagements.

The State Administrative Board of Michigan announced yesterday that it would offer on March 4 an issue of $200,000,000 of veterans' bonus bonds maturing from 1948 to 1965 and callable in 1952. It is part of the $270,000,000 bonus issue authorized at a referendum last November.

Show business, whose people have always been in the forefront in aiding worth-while causes, has once more demonstrated its willingness to render invaluable assistance in time of need. Through the offices of the American National Theatre and Academy, the Congress chartered nonprofit organization, numerous theatrical outfits and individual performers have managed to raise to date about $20,000 to help the American Repertory Company through its present crisis.

LONDON, Feb. 18--The Labor Government bill to allow legal proceedings to be taken against the Crown was published today. Under its terms the historic premise that "the King can do no wrong" no longer would be upheld in British courts of law and, with certain reservations, the state would have the same legal liability as a private individual.

MOSCOW, Feb. 18--Lieut. Gen. W. Bedell Smith, United States Ambassador, has sent a letter to Foreign Minister Molotov drawing his attention to nine American proposals to establish closer cultural and scientific relations between the United States and the Soviet Union.

LONDON, Feb. 18--The deputies of the Council of Foreign Ministers, working on the German and Austrian peace treaties, went smoothly forward today by the well-known process of agreeing to non-controversial clauses and leaving controversial ones for the Foreign Ministers' meeting in Moscow.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--Senator Bourke B. Hickenlooper, Republican, of Iowa, chairman of the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy, tonight knocked the props from under the case of communism that Senator Kenneth McKellar, Democrat, of Tennessee, has been trying for three weeks to build up against David E. Lilienthal, chairman-designate of the United States Atomic Energy Commission.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 18 --With the adoption of its final report and recommendations to the United Nations Economic and Social Council, the Transport and Communications Commission completed today a highly successful first session.

Not a punch was thrown at Madison Square Garden last night as Long Island University and Canisius, principals in a recent fracas at Buffalo, crossed paths for the second time. Nevertheless a crowd of 18,461 witnessed a spirited contest as the L. I. U. five romped to a 68-52 victory.
Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle ordered the transfer yesterday of a deputy chief and four firemen. His only comment was that the changes were made "for the good of the service."

When Critics Clash It would be a pity if Moscow should detect the cloven hoof of propaganda sticking out at one point in the State Department's first broadcast to the Russian people. This would be the few lines in the general news of the day devoted to the mixed reception which John Steinbeck's new book has met at the hands of New York book reviewers.
MOSCOW, Feb. 18--Canada and her army have now been turned over to the United States for the preparation of aggression, Izvestia said today.

Thirty pre-school children between the ages of 3 and 6 presented their own version of Americanism and brotherhood yesterday at the Children's Aid Society's West Side center, 419 West Thirty -eighth Street, in celebration of National Brotherhood Week.

NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 18-Operating subsidies allowed to shipowners under the Merchant Marine Act of 1936 have cost the Government less than $3,000,000 a year for the last ten years. Senator A. Willis Robertson, Democrat, of Virginia, said here tonight.

A courtship should be neither too short nor too long, Msgr. Joseph F. Flannelly, administrator of St. Patrick's Cathedral, declared yesterday in Lenten instructions to his parishioners. He inserted his exhortations on courtship and marriage among the special Lenten rules.
A campaign to construct parking terminals to serve the needs of the midtown shopping area was started yesterday by the Fifth Avenue Association.

BIRMINGHAM, England, Feb. 18--In nearing the end of its second week of industrial paralysis, Britain's Midland region is still in a slightly dazed condition, without much idea of what the near future holds.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 18--A memorial forest named for the late Maj. Gen. Orde Charles Wingate of Britain was planted in Palestine today.

Ninety-eight refugee children, one of the largest groups to be brought here recently, arrived yesterday on the steamship Ernie Pyle. The ship, operated by the United States Line for the Government, arrived at Pier 86 North River, after a thirteen-day voyage from Bremerhaven.

A 50 per cent reduction in the rate of air express could bring about an increase of possibly 300 per cent in the volume of air freight transportation, Kinsey N. Merritt, vice president in charge of traffic of the Railway Express Agency, declared yesterday.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation took the initiative yesterday in its negotiations with the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, demanding that any new contract exclude any provision for "compulsory union membership" and guarantee foremen against union organization.

ALBANY, Feb. 18--Barred from legislative chambers today by Republican leaders who professed fear of disorders, 1,000 persons; seeking expanded public housing and continued rent controls, crowded into Chancellor's hall to voice their demands.

Buyers' Total Lower Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,247, against 2,005 last week and 1,713 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 550 arrivals yesterday, compared with 779 last Tuesday.

Four members of the "Old Timers" Club of the Ninety-second Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association received citations last night for service to the community that was distinguished by "love of democracy and devotion to Jewish cultural ideas."
PARIS, Feb. 18--Mme. Gres has introduced interesting variations in the short, flared daytime clothes and Greek-draped evening silhouettes that mark her collection of fashions.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 18-- Price and income distortions in the economy are slowly but surely bringing the change from a sellers' to a buyers' market, Q. Forrest Walker, economist of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., said here today at the dinner meeting of the Northeastern Dairy Conference.

A hearing on demands by the National Maritime Union, CIO, for increases of 25 per cent in basic wage and overtime rates closed here yesterday afternoon. Representatives of thirty-nine steamship companies on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts argued that such rises were not justified.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 18 (AP)--Four veteran racers were injured today in a crack-up during the four-man team United States Olympic bobsled trials in which Joe Meconi, Ausable Forks tavernkeeper, piloted his sled to a halfway -mark lead.

LONDON, Feb. 18--Foreign Secretary Bevin told the House of Commons today that the Government had decided to refer the Palestine problem to the United Nations General Assembly without any recommendations.
ATLANTA, Feb. 18--The Georgia Legislature moved to regulate labor union activities today as the State Senate unanimously approved anti-closed shop, anti-check-off and anti-picketing measures.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 18--The most active fellow in the Giants' training camp on the second working day was Jack Lohrke, rookie infielder who seems destined to solve Manager Mel Ott's third base problem.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 18--An electrically detonated road mine operated by terrorists in a field 100 yards away blew up a British army truck tonight and injured four soldiers, one seriously.
TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 18--The Republican State Committee today studied the new law that provides a method for revising the New Jersey Constitution.

An amusing and felicitous little "opera buffa," "The Telephone," by Gian-Carlo Menotti, receive its premiere last night in the Heckscher Theatre and was coupled with "The Medium," by the same composer, in a double bill. "The Medium," first heard here in May of last year, has had some effective revisions and introduced a superb new contralto, Marie Powers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--A proposed international wheat agreement, made public here today in anticipation of a conference in London on March 18, would guarantee to American growers an export market of about 80,000,000 bushels a year for the next four or five years at farm prices ranging approximately from $1 to $1.30 a bushel.

Meatless dishes for the Lenten season that starts today will not present much of a problem to the housewife who had to concept satisfactory substitutes for the nonexistent T-bone steak, lamb chops and ham shoulders during the war. Plentiful supplies of eggs, cheese and both fresh and canned fish make the present-day task a comparatively simple one.

Favorable dividend news and earnings reports provided yesterday a basis for a price rise in selected stocks, but the list generally was irregular and the composite rate showed a small loss at the close. Again faced with a mixed news picture, domestic items being preponderantly favorable while foreign items were somewhat disturbing, the general run of market followers showed no disposition to change current commitments.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Feb. 18-- The public must be made aware of the deplorable social and economic status of the nation's teachers, a panel of five experts agreed here today on THE NEW YORK TIMES radio forum "What's On Your Mind?"

BERLIN, Feb. 18--A BritishAmerican plan to establish a bizonal network of commercial airlines with or without Russian approval was disclosed today by Maj. Gen. Robert W. Harper, head of the Armed Forces Division of the United States Military Government.

ALBANY, Feb. 18--Uniformed State troopers with night sticks and sidearms barred members of a New York City delegation demonstrating for housing and rent control legislation from the Senate and Assembly chambers today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 18-- George Brent and Turhan Bey were announced today by Eagle Lion to replace James Craig and Richard Basehart, respectively, in "Out of the Blue," a comedy mystery by Vera Caspary, which will go before the cameras next week with Leigh Jason directing.

BERLIN, Feb. 18--The United States Military Government has requested an "absolute minimum" appropriation for the next fiscal year and will be unable to do a proper job unless it gets the requested funds, Lieut. Gen. Lucius D. Clay, Deputy Military Governor, said today.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Feb. 18--King George, Queen Elizabeth and the Princesses have been on South African soil for two days in the present tropical heat, with scant opportunity for rest. Pleas were being made tonight in various quarters that the royal family should not be killed by kindness.

The New York City budget for 1947-48 "can be balanced without any additional State aid and without any increase in the current real estate tax rate," Henry J. Amy, executive director of the Citizens Budget Commission, Inc., declared in a statement yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--The Legion of Merit, in the degree of Chief Commander, was conferred by President Truman today on Abdul Aziz Ibn Abdur Rahman Al Faisal Al Saud, King of Saudi Arabia, for services to the Allied cause in World War II.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP)-- Secretary of State Marshall reviewed the world's "sore spots" with the House Foreign Affairs Committee today, and members reported him "optimistic on the whole" over maintaining peace.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--Leading off the presentation of organized labor's views on current labor bills in the Senate William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, today flatly rejected all proposals. He told members of the Senate's Labor and Public Welfare Committee not only that the bills were "ill-considered in the extreme," but that their enactment "would produce such great industrial confusion as to seriously undermine the present world position of the United States."

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development is planning to begin making loans, if necessary, without waiting to obtain an administrative head, it was learned yesterday. Although the appointment of John J. McCloy, former Assistant Secretary of War, as president of the bank is still a possibility, the bank's directors, it is understood, are prepared to face the prospect that he may finally decline.

The Port of New York lacks a large-scale program of pier development and is in danger of remaining antiquated as the rest of the world modernizes its ports, according to Lewis D. Parmelee, president of the Atlantic, Gulf and West Indies Steamship Lines, and national president of the Propeller Club of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--Plans under which President Truman will be absent from the national capital during most of March were announced at the White House today. The Chief Executive will pay a state visit to Mexico, witness fleet maneuvers off Puerto Rico, inspect the naval base at Guantanamo, Cuba, and pay courtesy visits to the Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico.

NANKING, Feb. 18--The thousand -odd official and non-official Americans here are beginning to wonder how sharp a change in their way of life will be caused by the new Chinese economic regulations banning transactions in American currency.

The complete cooperation and backing of all segments of this city's maritime industry in the recently declared war on dock thieves was called for last night by James B. Young, vice president of the Barber Steamship Lines and president of the Bureau for the Suppression of Theft and Pilferage, Inc.

Herbie Kronowitz, 160, Coney Island, outpointed Larry Fontana, 159 3/4, Bensonhurst, in the hardfought eight-round feature at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn, last night. In the semi-final of eight, Paddy De Marco, 136 1/4, Brooklyn, beat Pedro Biesca, 134 3/4, Mexico.

The twenty-eighth annual fundraising campaign of the New York Catholic Charities will be opened today with a meeting of the special gifts committee of the Cardinal's Committee of the Laity in the Empire State Club, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--Secretary of State Marshall, in a note whose contents were made public today, rejected the protest of Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov against remarks made by Under-Secretary of State Dean Acheson before the Senate Atomic Energy Committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--The annual wage is a goal which should be kept in sight, but its imposition upon all industry or key industries would tend to reduce the real income of both labor and capital, in the opinion of Dr. A.D.K. Kaplan, who conducted a study of the subject at the Brookings Institution.

One little-publicized but significant aspect of the relations of the Soviet Union with its satellites is underscored by the news of famine in Rumania. In all the hunger stories and appeals for relief that have come out of Europe in two years of unprecedented human misery, nothing has been said about Rumania.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--The Senate Republican Conference voted today to settle for a $4.5 billion reduction in President Truman's $37.5 billion budget for the fiscal year 1948.

STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 18-- Ira Mosher, chairman of the executive committee of the National Association of Manufacturers, said tonight that labor-management cooperation, as well as new labor legislation, were essential for industrial peace.

BERLIN, Feb. 18--The lack of a central German government does not constitute a serious barrier to conclusion of the German peace treaty, according to Lieut. Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Deputy Military Governor in Germany.

HAWTHORNE, N.J., Wednesday, Feb. 19--Henry H. Struck, president of the Hawthorne School Board, announced at 12:45 o'clock this morning that the board, at an executive session, had acceded to the demands of eighty-one striking school teachers and principals for a flat salary increase of $500 a year effective Sept. 1 for all teachers.

The second program of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the City Center last night was a rather discouraging one, containing as it did both those old warhorses, "Swan Lake" and "Scheherazade," with only Balanchine's "Night Shadow" to touch a note of contemporary style.

A fictionalized biography of Andrew Johnson, entitled "Storm Center," by J. Walker McSpadden, has been scheduled for publication by Dodd, Mead on Monday. The book covers Andrew Johnson from his boyhood through his Presidency and impeachment trial.

A cool million dollars in prize money will be dangled before owners of trotters and pacers by Roosevelt Raceway this season, according to word just received from officials of the Westbury (L.I.) track. The plans call for a 125night program of harness racing, beginning May 23 and running through Oct. 18.

If Chuck Rayner's twisted knee does not respond to treatment, Jim Henry will guard the nets for the Rangers tonight, when the local six opposes the Boston Bruins in an important National Hockey League encounter at Madison Square Garden.

Napkins and guest towels made from a non-woven fabric developed by the Chicopee Sales Corporation were among the newest of the home furnishings products displayed yesterday at the studio of A.K. Bartholomew, 124 East Thirtieth Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--Congressional failure to provide operating funds for the Office of Price Administration would mean the termination of rent control and sugar rationing in a matter of days, Max McCullough, chief of the agency, declared today.

An increase in the value of the Swiss franc in terms of the American dollar would aid the economy of Switzerland and facilitate an increase into that country of badly needed imports, it was stated yesterday by Gottlieb Duttweiler, national councilor of the Swiss Republic and head of the Federation of Migros Cooperatives, Inc., large Swiss retail cooperative.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 18-- With only three of the five City Commissioners present to vote, this city's 1947 budget was adopted on final reading today after a stormy ninety-minute hearing. The budget calls for the highest tax rate in the city's history, $72.75 on each $1,000 of assessed property valuation, an increase of $6.88 over last year's rate.

WIESBADEN, Germany, Feb. 18 --The hour of instruction to which children of the State of Greater Hesse are held while classrooms remain icy was devoted today to commemoration of two student martyrs of the resistance against nazism.

Though the city needs at least 200,000 new apartments right now, housing production is virtually at a standstill because private building is uneconomic and public building has committed all its funds. Edmond Borgia Butler, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, declared last night before the Women's City Club.

Albert O. Williams, Commissioner of Correction, yesterday ended the practice of farming out prisoners to city hospitals for work as orderlies. It is believed the order was the outgrowth of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's inquiry, which disclosed that Harvey Stemmer, a convicted briber, had the use of a telephone at Bellevue Hospital to make bets on college basketball games.

A sharp increase in fire losses in the nation during January was reported yesterday by the National Board of Fire Underwriters, 85 John Street. The estimated losses for the month totaled $57,180,000, an increase of 14.8 per cent over the same month of 1946.

Faris el Khouri, head of the Syrian delegation to the United Nations Security Council and a leading Arab spokesman, advocated yesterday the immediate suppression by the British of Jewish terrorists in Palestine.

Formation of a new nation-wide advertising organization known as the National Society of Art Directors has been completed, it was announced yesterday by Gordon C. Aymar, the society's first president and past president of the Art Directors Club of New York.

Chiang Kai-shek's broadcast to the Chinese people yesterday had the ring of similar appeals made at the height of the war. It is, indeed, a war he is now conducting on three fronts: economic, political and military. He cannot win that war without the help of his countrymen.

The Metropolitan Opera Association signed a five-year contract yesterday morning with the Columbia Recording Corporation for the recording of two complete operas a year from the stage of the Metropolitan. The first one will be made before the company breaks up this spring, and probably will be Mozart's "The Marriage of Figaro."
LONDON, Feb. 18--Great Britain appeared today to have surmounted her immediate coal crisis. More coal is being mined, stocks are mounting and transport conditions are improving.

DETROIT, Feb. 18--Cutbacks in automobile and truck production and a drop in employment in the second quarter are threatened as a result of the shortage of pig iron, George W. Mason, president, Automobile Manufacturers Association, told the Office of Temporary Controls today.

A syndicate of seventy-seven underwriters headed by Morgan Stanley Co. will place on the market today $45,000,000 of Commonwealth of Australia fifteen-year 3 3/8 per cent bonds at 99 to yield 3.46 per cent. The issue marks the third refunding of Commonwealth dollar obligations since last August, when a ten-year issue of 3 1/4 per cent bonds was marketed at par.

Mrs. Mary cammill, 70 years old, blind and ill, sat alone yesterday in her four-room flat on the sixth floor of 338 East Sixtyseventh Street. Her daughter, May, 35, jobless since Nov. 1, was out looking for work.

A block just around the corner from Brooklyn Headquarters-- Dean Street, between Sixth and Carlton Avenues--was branded yesterday as "probably the worst in Brooklyn" from the standpoint of producing juvenile delinquents.

A court order has been served an the American Legion and General Duffy Post 1141 to show cause why they should not be restrained from taking any action to expel a member on the ground that he is a member of the Communist party.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Feb. 18--As the Yankees took the field today for their fourth successive training session they became more than mildly intrigued with a couple of geometric designs drawn with marking lime on the diamond.

Czechoslovakia is anxious to rebuild trade with the United States to the pre-war level and intends to send only high-quality shoes, instead of its former export of cheap footwear, George Kubelik, general manager of the rubber and leather industries of Czechoslovakia declared yesterday in an interview at the Essex House.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--The first principle for the maintenance of an effective foreign policy, it is generally conceded, is that in the present state of world affairs a nation's power must be kept in balance with its commitments.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18--A gloomy summary of parking stringency and traffic congestion in cities throughout the country was presented today by George M. Shepard, chairman of the Traffic Committee, Municipal Division, American Road Builders Association.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--A request by the Chinese Government for permission to sell $200,000,000 worth of UNRRA supplies on the "open" or "black" market is being considered by the relief agency. It may be acted upon at the next meeting of its central committee, a spokesman for the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration said tonight.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There is an inaccurate implication in the letter from Dr. Mohamed AboulAhrass, secretary of the Committee for the Freedom of North Africa, which was published in your issue of Dec. 30, 1946, just now received in Cairo.

MADRID, Feb. 18--More than 3,000 wildly cheering monarchists greeted Prince Jaime, elder brother of the pretender, Don Juan, when he arrived today with his sister, Princess Cristina, at the Madrid airfield en route from Lisbon to Italy.

OTTAWA, Ont., Feb. 18--Soviet military and press representatives, among others, will have an opportunity to visit Canada's joint experimental station in Churchill, Manitoba, and to find how little foundation there is for veiled charges about what is being done there, Defense Minister Brooke Claxton declared today.

With a holiday in New Orleans, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was somewhat quieter yesterday, and prices at the close were irregular, 15 points higher to 7 points lower than the day before.

There is a great deal of competition these days for access both to the business world and graduate professional schools, but there are still several fields open that are particularly suited to women, Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve of Barnard College told the class of 1949 yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--International dealings in American cotton for future delivery are so small that they have "no great importance" on the price of that commodity in United States markets, the Department of Agriculture reported here today on the basis of a comprehensive survey of this type of hedging and speculation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--Since the path of retrenchment is thorny and lonesome, and the road of spending is a wide boulevard flanked by cheering thousands, the advocates of true economy in government are neither numerous nor popular among those who in one way or another receive public funds.

ALTOONA, Pa., Feb. 18 (AP) -- Following is the list of the Pennsylvania train wreck dead as identified by the railroad and County Coroner Daniel M. Replogle, and those from the metropolitan area who were seriously injured.

Rank and file Republicans throughout the country should make clear to the party's leaders that the adoption or a conservative instead of a progressive legislative program will mean the party's repudiation in 1948, Senator Wayne Morse of Oregon declared last night.

With Branch Rickey and Leo Durocher waving a proud farewell, Brooklyn's pennant-conscious Dodgers headed south yesterday. All hands were present or accounted for, Bruce Edwards, Joe Hatten and Carl Furillo, the last three recalcitrants, having come to terms before the squad's departure from Pennsylvania Station at 2:50 P.M.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 18 -- Full employment, full production and better distribution are economic problems about which the church should rightly concern itself, discussion groups decided here today at the opening of the National Study Conference on the church and economic life.

Justice Henry H. Curran, sitting yesterday in Special Sessions, came to the rescue of a fellow jurist in the latter's effort to rid legal terminology of the phrase "peremptory" on the grounds that another word easier to pronounce, spell and understand would serve as well.

On Trading Hours Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, let it be known yesterday it may be many months before the Big Board takes final action on proposals for a five-day week the year around. He indicated that the Exchange's board of governors would not quickly follow the lead of the New York State banks which plan to start Saturday closings on April 5, asserting that the problems involved were "vastly different.'

War veterans who are in need of rehabilitation should tie treated on the same basis as civilians and not be considered "in a special category," Brig. Gen. Arthur V. McDermott, counsel to the State Division of Veterans Affairs, declared yesterday in advocating the extension of rehabilitation as "a community proposition."

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 18-- More than 5,000 members of the National Automobile Dealers Association urged today that automobile producers meet their representatives in order to work out current trends in the industry which the retailers claim will threaten their security if continued.
Men in the armed forces need Red Cross services now as much as they did during wartime, Admiral William F. Halsey and Gen. Courtney H. Hodges, commander of the First Army, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--The House Judiciary Committee forecast today its approval, possibly tomorrow, for the first legislation restricting labor's privileges that will come to the floor of the Republican Congress.

A set of ten principles to help parents make psychologically "good" homes for their children was outlined yesterday by Dr. Mary Fisher Langmuir, chairman of the Department of Child Study at Vassar College. She spoke at the sixth of a series of eight lectures on child development held at the Barbizon Plaza, Hotel under sponsorship of Ivriah.

TOKYO, Feb. 18--No proposals to reduce Japan's textile industry are contained in the report of the War Department's special reparations mission, Clifford S. Strike, its chairman, told a press conference this afternoon.

The sixteen-story Hyde Park Hotel at the northwest corner of Madison Avenue and Seventyseventh Street, which was acquired by the Hyde Park Hotel Corporation, George W. Warnecke, president, last September in a deal approved by Supreme Court Justice William C. Hecht, has been resold.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes, for the week ended Feb. 12: An increase of $173,000,000 in loans and decreases of $442,000,000 in holdings of United States Government obligations and $297,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 18--In a dramatic recital Sir Alexander Cadogan presented to the Security Council today Britain's charge that mines laid illegally by Albania in the Corfu Channel damaged two British destroyers last October and killed forty-four sailors.

Gordon T. Broad, 59 years old, Deputy Commissioner of Hospitals, died of a cerebral hemorrhage on Monday night in his home, 600 Albany Avenue, Brooklyn, a few hours after Mayor O'Dwyer had privately informed him he was to become City Commissioner of Purchase.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--Capt. Granville Conway, Coordinator of Export Programs in President Truman's office, said today that the principal reason that most of United States export grain has been routed through Baltimore and Philadelphia was an average one cent per bushel lower freight rate to the two lower ports than to New York.

LITTLE AMERICA, Feb. 18--A Navy exploration plane circled the vapor-shrouded cone of the Antarctic's only known active volcano. Mount Erebus, last night after a flight through the unknown "back yard" of the high mountain range that studs the western shore of the Ross Sea.

The International Bar Association, a newly formed organization of lawyers from twenty-two nations, took preliminary steps yesterday toward affiliation with the United Nations in a consultative capacity.

Goal of the United Fresh Fruit and Vegetable Association is to have 25 per cent of total retail store sales consist of fresh fruits and vegetables, C.W. Kitchen, executive vice president of the organization said yesterday. Speaking at the first general session of the convention at the Hotel New Yorker, he emphasized members must work more closely with retailers to demonstrate how to make green grocery departments pay.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Allow me to congratulate you on your recent editorial urging that facilities be made available to admit refugees into this country, even if only in limited numbers. However, I wish to make some observations not included in your editorial.
The "sentimental" plea that a group of artists be allowed to remain in their big, unheated studios on Washington Square received a warm response yesterday at the Office of Price Administration.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 18 --Twelve amendments and additions to the general findings and recommendations of the Atomic Energy Commission were submitted to the United Nations Security Council here this afternoon by Andrei A. Gromyko, delegate of the Soviet Union.
The final qualifying session for the twentieth annual Vanderbilt Cup-Team of Four Tournament ended last night in the Hotel Pierre with the defending champions toppled from their thrones.

A 100-acre tract in the Ardsleyon-Hudson and Irvington area of Westchester County has been sold by the town of Greenburgh to a client of John A. Bolles, attorney, who plans to divide the property for two-acre and five-acre estates. The property is assessed at $106,000.

After five weeks of effort to prepare preliminary working drafts of peace treaties with Germany and Austria, the deputies of the Foreign Ministers meeting in London are still so deadlocked on all issues of both substance and procedure that there is slim chance of their accomplishing anything worth while during the remaining week before the deadline for their report.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 18--A survey has disclosed that although one-half of this city's junior and senior high school students were free of evidences of mental disturbances, the other half showed anxieties, allergies, stuttering, dietary disorders or sleep difficulties that may be linked to mental problems.

Audley Brindley, the high scorer from Dartmouth, is slated to make his debut with the New York Knickerbockers tonight against the Providence Steamrollers at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory. This Basketball Association of America contest will be preceded by a Metropolitan Girls League game between the Knickerettes and St. Helena, starting at 7:30 P.M.
LONDON, Feb. 18--Continued strength of South American railway stocks was the outstanding feature in a generally cheerful stock market today.

Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane disclosed yesterday that 1946 net income made available to its eighty-one partners before income taxes was $6,216,649, compared with $8,834,063 in 1945. Income from operations, however, rose from the $28,091,992 in 1945 to $29,523,668 in 1946. Offsetting these record earnings were operating expenses totaling $20,554,559 last year, in contrast to $16,486,458 in 1945.

The North American Scientific Laboratories has leased the twostory building at 42-17 Twentyseventh Street, Long Island City, Queens, for a long term of years through the Roman-Caswell Company, broker. The lessee will use the building for offices, preparations of biological specimens and as a clinical laboratory to serve educational institutions.

Most of the headline news from Britain during the past ten days has centered upon the fuel shortage in that country and its critical effects on industrial and civilian life. Less spectacular, but equally important and equally pessimistic in its economic implications, was the report of the British Board of Trade on the results during the past year of Britain's export drive.

Adolph Stuber, a vice president of the Eastman Kodak Company, and Marion B. Folsom, its treasurer, were elected directors of the company at a board meeting held yesterday in Rochester, N.Y. Mr. Stuber was chosen to fill a vacancy caused by the retirement last November of Herman C. Sievers, former vice chairman of the board.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 18 --Below are the texts of the amendments and additions submitted by the Soviet Union to modify the first report of the Atomic Energy Commission to the Security Council. (The recommendations of the commission's report were printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 31, 1946.)

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--The Chamber of Commerce of the United States declared today that national security demanded prompt action to remove Communists from Government posts. A Congressional investigation of "outside interference" in this country's foreign policy also was urged, along with a demand to make public "the secret story of Yalta and Teheran."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--The United States reopened today the list of products on which reciprocal trade treaties will be negotiated at Geneva in April to add about a score of new items to the thousands already subject to negotiation.

A large loan exhibition of work in various media by Winslow Homer opened with a preview last evening at the Wildenstein Galleries, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street. It has been arranged as a benefit for the New York Botanical Garden. Tickets for the preview were $6, and beginning today the admission fee will be 50 cents plus tax.

SECURITY COUNCIL Great Britain formally presented her case against Albania, charging illegal minelaying in the Corfu Channel. The Council later heard Andrei A. Gromyko. Soviet delegate, present twelve amendments and additions to the findings and recommendations of the Atomic Energy Commission.

ALBANY, Feb. 18--Governor Dewey's record $671,970,737 budget was enacted today in an atmosphere supercharged with tension and under circumstances that may lead to a constitutional test of its validity.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 18--The result guaranteed to provide the greatest amount of satisfaction to the greatest number of racegoers --victory for an odds-on favorite-- was recorded at Hialeah Park today when the Clinton Farm's 4year-old colt Sea Wolf romped home in the $4,000 Coral Way Purse.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--Witnesses interested in agriculture joined before the House Committee on Education and Labor today a long line of critics of union practices.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 18 (AP)-- Blaming "Government regulation," the Pennsylvania Railroad announced today that in 1946, for the first time in its 100-year history, it operated at a loss. At the same time, America's largest railroad in its annual statement reported it transported more freight and passengers than in any previous peacetime year.

LONDON, Feb. 18--All indications tonight are that Britain is about to cut the Gordian knot of India and break loose from her great eastern empire as she is now breaking loose from Palestine. And Britain is apparently prepared to set a definite time limit for the process.
PARIS, Feb. 18--French troops today began an important operation to the west of Haiphong. Official dispatches said tonight that it was proceeding favorably.

Pacific Mills, textile manufacturer, had a net profit in 1946 of $9,502,891, an increase to almost five times the 51,996,070 net earned in 1945, according to the preliminary report issued to shareholders yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--The Congress of Industrial Organizations appointed a five-man committee today to meet an American Federation of Labor committee, but insisted on its original position of making labor legislation, rather than organic unity, the primary order of business.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 18--All the difficulties of the post-war remarriage of Czechs and Slovaks in the second Czechoslovak Republic have been brought into the open Again by the reaction to President Eduard Benes' recent warning to Slovakia that another split in the republic would bring Slovakia not independence but Russian rule.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: David Lilienthal's statement in support of personal freedom, recently submitted to a Senate committee, might well have been lifted from Herbert Spencer, the great enemy of the state. If these words had been uttered with conviction during the heyday of the New Deal they would have earned for their author the derision then leveled at rugged individualists.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 18--Leo T. Crowley, president and chairman of the board of directors of the Standard Gas and Electric Company, disclosed today that the board would consider liquidation of the company at a meeting this week.

ALTOONA, Pa., Feb. 18--Twenty -five persons met death on a jagged mountainside in the predawn darkness today and 124 others were injured when a crack Pennsylvania Railroad passenger train plunged over a 150-foot embankment.

J.T. Dalton, formerly manager of distribution, has been appointed general sales manager for radio and television of the Bendix radio division of Bendix Aviation Corporation. He succeeds L.C. Truesdell, who has resigned.

Ten million American children, living in rural areas or in farm communities, are receiving a second class education. Even though the urban communities suffer educational problems today, the plight of the rural schools is infinitely worse.
PARIS, Feb. 18--Premier Paul Ramadier called today for a law preventing police strikes such as occurred here for four hours last Friday.

Although we love our brothers across the sea, they must not abuse us. Donald Wolfit and his London Company, as they are billed, must not take us back thirty-five years to road-company Shakespeare. After a brisk tour in Canada, Mr. Wolfit and his thespians turned up at the Century last evening with a production of "King Lear."

PARIS, Feb. 18--France is expected to sign a cultural accord with the Polish Government tomorrow. This agreement, which will provide for an exchange of teachers and propagandists in limited numbers, is in itself of no special importance.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18--Grain markets fluctuated nervously on the Board of Trade today, operations being featured by back spreading Between May and July wheat, which had a tendency to hold down the former and advance the new crop months.

The strike of 500 metal lathers that had threatened to halt all construction in this city was ended last night through the efforts of a five-man committee appointed by Mayor O'Dwyer. The striking union instructed its members to return to work this morning on housing and commercial projects all over the metropolitan area.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 18-- The Senate, as expected, approved today a rural-sponsored bill outlawing the closed shop in Tennessee. The vote was 26 to 7.

There seems to be no question about it; when better decoys are made, the shavings will emerge under Charles "Shang" Wheeler's knife, for his decoys "stole" the National Decoy Contest at the National Sportsman's Show.

The eyes of the ski world will be focused this week-end on "Suicide Hill" at Ishpemming, Mich., the birthplace in 1904 of the National Ski Association. The foremost ski jumpers of the country will join the invading Norweigians in the national title competition.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 18 (AP)--The United States Circuit Court of Appeals upheld yesterday the Federal Trade Commission in its finding on April 17, 1944, that sixteen manufacturers of insulation materials had violated the Federal Trade Commission Act in alleged pricefixing in the sale of their products.

The cast iron scrap shortage is the moat critical in the history of the industry, scrap industry spokesmen disclosed here yesterday. In their opinion it is doubtful there will be any relief in the foreseeable future. Production in many foundries is held back in consequence, they said.

Because of ignorance and apathy on the part of the general public, this nation is dodging the real test of internationalism--its part in the economic peace, which is just as important, "if not more important," than the political peace, Lester Markel, Sunday Editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- Cheered by the immediate reaction to their refusal to admit a delegation of demonstrators to the Senate and Assembly chambers, Republicans are planning to exploit it into a major political issue that will emphasize Democratic alliances with left-wing groups.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 19 -- Staving off a determined bid in the waning minutes after having relinquished a comfortable 17 point lead, the Columbia basketball team defeated Army, 52 to 50, in the Field House today.

The Russian Government has now submitted formally to the Security Council, its own plan for dealing with the atomic bomb. This plan is presented in the form of amendments to the report made to the Council by the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission, and these amendments more than justify the worst misgivings aroused by previous Russian statements.
Henry Ford 2d, president of the Ford Motor Company, attributed the nation's achievements yesterday to "a very high degree of human freedom and opportunity," rather than "any race, creed or color."

HAWTHORNE, N.J., Feb. 19 -- After a one-day "non-appearance" that closed five public schools here yesterday and gave 2,000 students a vacation, eighty-one striking teachers returned to their classrooms this morning and by this afternoon conditions were nearly normal.

BIRMINGHAM, England, Feb. 19 -- Within an hour after Prime Minister Attlee's announcement in the House of Commons today of the decision to resume the power supply to the Midlands industries, officials and plant managers in the Birmingham area had started getting ready for work.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- Foreign Secretary Bevin rode out a heated discussion of his Palestine proposals at a caucus of Labor members of Parliament today and emerged with an endorsement of the Government's decision to leave the solution to the United Nations.

The need for additional foster homes for child care this year was reported yesterday by officials in this field at the annual meeting of the Sheltering Arms Children's Service, held in the headquarters of the organization at 122 East Twenty-ninth Street.

Dr. Emanuel Neumann, vice president of the Zionist Organization of America and member of the World Zionist Executive, assailed last night an announcement by British Foreign Minister Ernest Bevin that continues to limit Jewish immigration into Palestine pending action by the United Nations.

In a game marked by eleven ties and eight changes of the lead, the Providence Steamrollers defeated the New York Knickerbockers, 69 -- 62, at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night before 3,149 spectators.

Random House has announced two novels for which it has great expectations. They are "Kingsblood Royal," by Sinclair Lewis, and Budd Schulberg's "The Harder They Fall." Mr. Lewis' book, a Literary Guild selection for June, is centered about the race problem.
HAVANA, Feb. 19 -- The Dodgers captured the Cuban capital tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 19 -- The life and career of the late President Franklin Delano Roosevelt will be brought to the screen under the terms of an agreement announced today by James Roosevelt, his eldest son, and Jay Richard Kennedy, financier and independent film producer.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- The resignation of the Viceroy of India, Viscount Wavell, is expected in well-informed quarters in London tonight. In all likelihood this announcement will be made tomorrow in Parliament when the British Labor Government makes an important statement declaring its intention to quit India within the next year or fifteen months.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The growth of a social economy, paternally framed by government, that reached its high point under the New Deal is a large factor in the problem before Congress of how to cut down the Federal budget without crippling national defense and failing to provide fully for our international commitments.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (U.P.) -- Inspired partly by the wartime manpower shortage, some States have erased many "lingering discriminatory laws" against women, the Women's Bureau of the Labor Department reported tonight.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14, a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.
The 100th anniversary of the birth of Alexander Graham Bell, inventor of the telephone, will be observed on March 3 with special programs here and throughout the nation.

The Public Service Commission announced yesterday that it would approve the Consolidated Edison Company's plan for the issuance of $290,000,000 of refunding bonds in three series, provided the first flotation of $100,000,000 is limited to a thirty-five-year maturity rather than 100 years, as proposed by the company.

The American Merchant Marine Staff Officers Association, an AFL affiliate, has decisively defeated the National Maritime Union, CIO, in two elections to determine a bargaining agency for pursers, it was announced yesterday.

Two little girls forced to beg food in restaurants and a boy of 10 who lived with his mother in subway stations were among the 7,800 children aided during 1946 by the New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children. Their cases were described yesterday in a report presented by John F. Smithers, general manager, at the group's seventy-second annual meeting, held at headquarters, 2 East-105th Street.

Backing of the city Department of Markets for the plea of local egg dealers for a change in the Government's egg price-support program was indicated yesterday by Deputy Markets Commissioner Arthur Dunaif. Mr. Dunaif told fifty egg merchants at a meeting in the New York Mercantile Exchange that the city would seek modification of any program that meant artificially high egg prices for New York consumers.
OTTAWA, Feb. 19 -- Although the freight - car situation throughout Canada remains serious, it is hoped that by tomorrow it will be possible to give assurance that the crisis has passed its peak.

The first basic proposal yet advanced for settling the bitter jurisdictional battle that has hampered telephone installation on dozens of new buildings in recent years and has blocked progress on the Idlewild airport for twenty months was put forward yesterday by the United Telephone Organizations, an independent union representing 12,000 telephone workers in this city.
A group of transplanted local youngsters and a group of strangers from afar are tonight's visitors in a college basketball doubleheader at Madison Square Garden.

It has seemed at times during recent weeks that the federal budget must exercise some sort of hypnotic influence over many members of Congress, an influence under whose spell the process of reasoning appears to become strangely inverted, causing its victims, as it were, to put last things first and first things last.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 19 -- Riskolater won first money of $8,800 in the Everglades Handicap at Hialeah Park today -- but to 17,4672 onlookers this was a memorable afternoon at the races not because of the Circle M Farm colt's four-length triumph but because of what occurred in the first two contests.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Feb. 19 -- Although five days may seem to offer a short period for hall players to become acquainted with a new manager and vica versa, there is evidence already that some revolutionary changes in spring training tactics are in order for the Yankees, who continued their drilling under the new leadership of manager Bucky Harris today.

Weather Now Apparel Factor Estimates in buying circles yesterday were that retailers will receive around 75 per cent of medium price spring apparel by March 10 to 15, when stores would like to peak their stocks. The size of inventories around that time, it was pointed out yesterday, will depend to considerable extent on weather conditions during the next few weeks.
IWO, Feb. 19 (AP) -- A grateful United States Army today raised the American flag on Mount Suribachi -- symbol of one of the United States Marines' greatest victories of the Pacific war.

The United States must "come out of its corner fighting" and confront Russia "precisely where she is weak," William F. Russell, Dean of Teachers College, Columbia University, declared yesterday in his annual report.

An enlarged program for the improvement of land surrounding the six-block world capital site along the East River was announced yesterday by the City Planning Commission at a meeting in City Hall. A public hearing on the revised suggestions has been called for March 5.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- President Truman recommended to Congress today a sweeping revision of legislation under which the Executive Branch of the Government has been exercising extraordinary powers pursuant to declarations of a state of emergency by President Roosevelt in 1939 and in 1941.

Legal List Extended Securities totaling $71,391,000 in par value were added yesterday to the list of securities legal for investment by savings banks and trusts. Of this amount, according to the announcement by Elliott V. Bell, Superintendent of Banks, $25,000,000 is accounted for by Firestone Tire and Rubber Company 25-year 2 5/8 per cent debentures and $27,000,000 by Gulf States Utilities Company first mortgage 2 5/8 per cent bonds.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 19 -- Cornell moved back into second place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League before 4,500 tonight by crushing Princeton, 53 to 30. It was Cornell's fifth victory in eight league starts.

New York's four municipal colleges face the danger of "a significant loss in the quality of their staffs" because of the resignations of able teachers to take better-paying jobs, inability to recruit bestqualified young personnel and obstacles encountered by instructors who want to engage in research, according to a report prepared by the Legislative Conference of the Four City Colleges, it was learned yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 19 -- Efforts to debate the closed shop as unChristian and to get a vote on a proposal that wages ought to be set in terms of purchasing power necessary for a prosperous economy failed in a session that discussed responsibilities of the churches at the Conference on the Church and Economic Life.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 19 -- Paramount today named Betty Hutton for the leading role in the projected screen version of Elmer Rice's 1945 Broadway play, "Dream Girl," in which Betty Field starred on Broadway. The studio acquired screen rights to the play in a pre-production deal, which involved $60,000 for financing the Broadway production plus $300,000 for the prospective film version.

It was an evening of "old favorites" at the City Center last night, for the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo made up its program of Fokine's "Les Sylphides" and "Scheherazade," with Ivanov's "The Nutcracker" sandwiched between.

Several thousand passengers were delayed yesterday when a fire at the Seventy-second Street station tied up traffic on the West Side IRT subway between Fortysecond and Ninety-sixth Streets. Service between these points was interrupted for thirty-five minutes beginning at 11:38 A. M., but conditions quickly returned to normal, since this is a period of light travel, compared to that of the morning rush-hour.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 19 -- Rehabilitation work on Bill Voiselle got under way in earnest today at Giant training quarters. Determined to make every effort to restore the confidence and the pitching strength which once made the Giant from Ninety-six, S.C., one of his aces, Manager Mel Ott turned Voiselle over to Coach Hank Gowdy.

PARIS, Feb. 19 (AP) -- An Air France Constellation, with seventeen persons aboard, landed safely at Casablanca tonight after its crew had jettisoned part of its cargo when one engine failed during a transatlantic flight, headquarters of the airline announced.

The stock market was subjected yesterday to one of the worst selling waves so far this year and, although it was of short duration, it reduced prices from 1 to 3 points. A creeping recovery in the afternoon helped to mimize some of the inroads, but the composite rate was down about a point at the close, with wider losses in the industrials.

A goal of at least $1,000,000, or $150,000 more than was obtained exclusively in special gifts last year, was fixed yesterday by John S. Burke, chairman of the Cardinal's Committee of the Laity, at a meeting held in the Empire State Club to open the twenty-eighth annual fund-raising campaign of New York Catholic Charities.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange showed independent strength yesterday and ended 5 to 22 points net higher.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Feb. 19 -- As far as Cape Province is concerned, the royal tour reached its spectacular climax tonight when King George, Queen Elizabeth and the Princesses watched the dazzling sight presented by a ball for the "colored community" attended by 4,000 persons.
A severe storm that started In the Gulf of Mexico and swept north and eastward lashed at North Atlantic shipping yesterday, delaying some passenger liners from two to three days.

Mrs. Cecelia Scottoriggio, widow of the Republican election captain who was fatally beaten on his way to the polls Nov. 5, joined the women's auxiliary of the New York County Republican Committee yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- A bill that would enable Mayor O'Dwyer to omit any provision for meeting next year's prospective transit operating deficit was submitted to the Senate today by Senator James Crawford, Brooklyn Democrat. It is a vital part of the city's legislative program.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- To foster safety in air travel, the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee recommended today in a preliminary report appropriating increased operating funds to Government aeronautic agencies.
