WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Congressional advocates of a $1,750,000,000 cut in the defense budget will find little aid and comfort in certain budget statistics that became available today.

Barring strikes and adverse weather, the entire Fifth Avenue facade of St. Patrick's Cathedral should be free of scaffolding by Easter, simultaneously with completion of work on a new rose window recently donated to the cathedral.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Feb. 19 -- After a somewhat heated discussion the Preparatory Commission of the International Refugee Organization, by unanimous resolution, authorized its chairman today to send a further urgent telegram to Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, requesting an advance of $250,000.

Increased production and sales of the West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company in the quarter ended on Jan. 31 resulted in a net income of $2,210,622, equal to $2.45 a share of common stock, David L. Luke Jr., president, reported to stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The mass starvation in Moldavia Province of Rumania was described as "the worst catastrophe in this part of Europe in the past fifty years" by Fred G. Sigerest, American Red Cross representative in Bucharest, in a message to Red Cross headquarters here today.

Construction of housing projects and skyscraper office buildings moved full speed ahead yesterday as 500 striking metal lathers returned to work after a two-day walkout. Other mechanics who had been forced into idleness by the stoppage were recalled to their jobs and contractors predicted that there would be no delay in the completion of major projects.
American colleges and universities, jammed beyond capacity, are planning an unprecedented expansion and building program that will cost more than two billion dollars in the next ten years.

BUFFALO, Feb. 19 -- Production of the new "Playboy" automobile will be started here by the Midget Motor Car Manufacturing Corporation May 1, it was announced today. According to Charles D. Thomas, vice president of the company, the car will be the first presented for public sale incorporating rear engine rear drive, full four-wheel independent suspension and "aut-o-matic" drive, no clutch pedal and no gear shifting.

MOSCOW, Feb. 19 -- Western Europe was sternly warned today against dangers of various economic and political attacks allegedly launched by the United States and Britain in the most exhaustive indictment of American and British policy toward the Continent yet to appear here.

Stripped of the national amateur and the American open crowns, Robert Grant 3d started out in quest of the Pell Cup yesterday as the invitation racquets tournament for amateurs and professionals began at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

Special awards were presented last evening to 118 young people in the Second Brooklyn Scholastic High School art exhibition to be held at Abraham and Straus. Two scholarships to Pratt Institute, fourteen gift certificates for art supplies and 118 gold achievement keys were given to the top winners in the arts awards contest.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 19 -- The United Nations' three-month search for a man to fill the "toughest job in the world" -- the governorship of Trieste -- has picked up speed with the elimination of candidates from the Big Four, it was reported today.

THE AMERICAN NOVELS AND STORIES OF HENRY JAMES, edited with an introduction by F. O. Matthiessen (Knopf, $5). A collection of nine stories and four novels, The Europeans, Washington Square, The Bostonians and The Ivory Tower.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The Army Air Force has admitted somewhat red-facedly, in a letter to a former Navy lieutenant which came to light today, that it was 1,250 miles off in its report of how far the Pacusan Dreamboat flew last October.

The Rachmaninoff Fund will hold a second piano contest during the season of 1947-48, it was announced yesterday by Vladimir Horowitz, president. The decision to follow the fund's first piano contest, for which regional auditions recently were concluded, by a second contest was made to allow wider regional representation in the national finals.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Senator Bourke B. Hickenlooper, Republican, of Iowa, declared today that he would try to stop this week the one-man war being waged by Senator Kenneth McKellar, Democrat, of Tennessee, against the confirmation of David E. Lilienthal as chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 19 -- The appointment of Byron Price, who was director of the United States Office of Censorship during the war, as Assistant Secretary General of the United Nations for Administrative and Financial Affairs, was announced today by Trygve Lie, the Secretary General.

The National Boxing Association, through its president, Abe J. Greene, announced yesterday that would not sustain the New York state Athletic Commission in its recent revocation of the boxing cense of Rocky Graziano, middleweight contender.

TOKYO, Feb. 19 -- Simple citizens of Tokyo who are afraid to go home at night lest they meet "pants burglars," who hold them up and rob them of their clothing -- one of the most valuable items on the flourishing black market -- now have a new problem to meet.
Pierre Etchebaster, world open court tennis champion since 1928, defeated James Dear of London, British professional champion, in a special exhibition match yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

An improved automatic washer, using an agitator similar to those in conventional non-automatic machines, will be in New York stores Monday, it was announced yesterday. It is the first of its type to be offered since the war. The machine differs from other automatic ones in that it has a three-bladed cast aluminum agitator to clean clothes, a device considered by many to be more effective than a cylinder construction.

CHICAGO. Feb. 19 -- Liberty of the press is in peril as soon as the Government tries to compel what is to go into a newspaper, and any judge or official who undertook to displace the editorial staff and write a newspaper would do a miserable job even if the First Amendment to the Constitution did not forbid him to try.

Devastated Europe, locked in the worst winter of fifty years, is suffering hardships beyond the conception of abundant America. Through the waste and ruin of a continent, hunger, misery and despair are spreading steadily. Meanwhile the sources of relief which kept at least some hope alive are drying up.
BOSTON, Feb. 19 -- Harvard defeated Princeton, 9 to 2, in an Ivy League hockey game at the arena tonight.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 19 -- Navy defeated the University of Pennsylvania today in a thrilling basketball game, 55 to 53, for its twelfth straight victory. Navy trailed, 22 to 29, at half-time, when it seemed that Penn was en route to an upset victory.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- A joint resolution authorizing the President to conclude the Great Lakes-St. Lawrence agreement with Canada and proceed with the construction of the Seaway was introduced today by Representative John A. Blatnick, Democrat, of Minnesota.

Thwarted nine times in its attempt to win the Polar Bear track meet, Penn turned the trick yesterday by nosing out Columbia, 49 -- 48, on Columbia's South Field. The third entry, Princeton, finished third with only 20 points in the thirteen-event meet.

Sixteen teams entered the first knockout round of the national contract bridge team-of-four tournament for the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup at the Hotel Pierre last night, survivors of a forty-four team field that started play on Monday night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Maj. Gen. Lowell W. Rooks, Director General of the United Nations relief and Rehabilitation Administration, today issued a statemen denying any black market implications in a proposal made yesterday by the Chinese Government that the $200,000,000 program yet to be shipped to China be converted from durable to consumer goods, chiefly cotton and wheat.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 19 -- A growing tendency on the part of scientists to take posts in large, well-endowed universities, leaving the smaller and less wealthy schools, was noted here today by Prof. William E. Rappard, director of the Graduate Institute of International Studies at the University of Geneva.
The only reason why this country has not taken action on the Palestine problem is that the people have not told Congress what they want done, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt declared yesterday.

Friends Too Nervous? Perhaps, after all, they are not Britain's best friends who express their admiration for the spirit in which the British people are facing their present "ominous" crisis; or who feel confident that Britain will emerge from her "second Dunkerque" as successfully as she did from her first.

The lack of properly located and adequately designed and equipped small airports for private planes "threatens to stifle the normal development of civil aviation in the New York region and other large population centers of the country," the Regional Plan Association, Inc., warned yesterday.

WASHINGTON Feb. 19 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, scrapped his prepared manuscript today and made an extemporaneous appeal to the Senate Committee on Labor and Public Welfare not to "reward" labor's patriotic war services by "punitive" legislation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- House Republicans at a closed-door party conference lined up solidly today behind the proposed $6,000,000,000 reduction in President Truman's $37,500,000,000 budget for the fiscal year 1948.

United States Customs agents, acting on a tip from an annoyed pier visitor, quietly placed the pier of the Queen Elizabeth under surveillance Tuesday afternoon and nipped a new waterfront racket. Four men accused of selling pier passes at from $1 to $5 each were in custody.

PEIPING, China, Feb. 19 -- Reports circulating among Chinese military circles here indicate that widespread dissatisfaction already exists and is growing daily in the Chinese Air Force throughout China. According to well-informed quarters this present dissatisfaction and low morale may soon bring concrete remedial measures by the Central Government.

Miss Kate de Forest Jennings, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Brewster Jennings of 770 Park Avenue and Windward, Glen Head, L. I., whose marriage to Harry Havemeyer Webb will take place on the afternoon of March 1 in St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, has chosen her sister, Miss Mary Brewster Jennings for her maid of honor.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- The establishment of a production priorities board to direct European production along the lines most needed for reconstruction is under close study by the Emergency Economic Committee for Europe, Eric Wyndham White, its British secretary general, disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The foot and mouth disease in cattle, which has complicated commercial relations with other countries for many years, has become for the first time a matter of joint emergency action with next-door neighbor Mexico.

The Board of Education's Committee on Instructional Affairs voted yesterday to support the Board of Superintendents' recent recommendation banning Howard Fast's historical novel "Citizen Tom Paine" from the city's public school libraries.

PARIS, Feb. 19 -- Informal inquiries were recently made in Washington regarding the possibility of a kind of regional economic organization of French, British and Netherland territories in southeast Asia.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Two bills to establish universal military training were introduced today by Chairman Chan Gurney of the Senate Armed Services Committee.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 19 -- the first photograph ever transmitted by wirephoto from Cuba to the United States was received in the Miami Bureau of The Associated Press today.

Governor Dewey's stand against referendum this year on additional funds for public housing was sharply criticized last night at a rum discussion at the Association of the Bar of the City of New York. This brought from Herman Stichman, State Housing Commissioner, a revision downward by 00,000,000 of the Governor's estiate of funds available for the purpose.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Dissension among Republican leaders ove rtax reductions, the budget and foreign affairs flared in Congress today with a warning from Senator George D. Aiken of Vermont that his party's chances of electing a President in 1948 were being jeopardized by the perfomrance of its chief spokesmen.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19. (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks rose out of the National Hockey League cellar into a tie with the Detroit Red Wings for fifth place tonight with a 5-to-3 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs before 17,628 fans.

Bach, Beethoven, Mendelssohn and Hindemith are the composers chosen for representation on the programs of the sixteen concerts to be presented Sunday afternoons next season, by the New Friends of Music at Town Hall, it was announced yesterday by Ira A. Hirschmann, president.

Leonard Shure, pianist, gave a recital last night at Carnegie Hall. A highly intelligent artist, Mr. Shure had decidedly positive ideas as to his intentions in all the music he presented. He possessed, as well, the technical skill and the control of color to bring these ideas to complete realization in a series of interpretations that taken as a whole, had much of interest to offer.

A price cut of 20 per cent on its leading portable radio model was announced yesterday by the Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation bringing its price down to $39.95 from $49.95. The portable is an AC-DC battery set with seven tubes and three-gang condenser.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- As a combination by - product of the Army-Navy merger controversy and the efforts to trim the Federal budget, the Navy finds itself vested with responsibility for operating long-range, anti-submarine air patrols, but without the $78,000,000 it requested to pay for the planes necessary for this work.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- A proposal to bar landlords from being allowed to increase rents unless they improve their rental accommodations by redecoration, renovation or similar services was introduced in the Senate today by Senator William Langer, Republican, of North Dakota.
A priest's description of Dean Street between Sixth and Carlton Avenues as "probably the worst in Brooklyn" in developing juvenile delinquents, was both defended and attacked yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- Differences between the United States and the Soviet Union flared up into a sharp oral conflict today when the deputies of the Council of Foreign Ministers discussed the thorny question of German assets in Austria.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 19 -- The Albanian Government did not plant the mines that damaged two British destroyers in Corfu Channel last October, Hysni Kapo, Albania's special representative, told the United Nations Security Council today.

Enactment of the law permitting Saturday closing of banks on a year - round basis, recently approved by both houses of the State Legislature, is being delayed by "mechanical difficulties," it was learned yesterday. The bill, it was disclosed, has not yet been presented to the Governor because of inability of a hard-pressed State printing office to complete its final preparation of the bill for submission to the executive.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 19 -- Alexander Weinstein, nationally prominent industrial engineer and former member of the New York State Board of Mediation, died today at the Cedars of Lebanon Hospital after a brief illness. His age was 55.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The first open fundamental conflict in the new Congress in action on labor legislation developed today, with the Republican majority and right-wing Democrats joining in overwhelming force against other Democrats.

Beech Aircraft Walter H. Beech, president and chairman of the board of the Beech Aircraft Corporation, told stockholders yesterday that gross business for the fiscal year ended with last September was $21,304,958, or about eight times that of 1940, the last full year of peacetime production.

LONDON, Feb. 19 (Canadian Press) -- The House of Lords today heard warnings from Opposition members that a food crisis might follow the fuel crisis and Viscount Addison, Dominion Affairs Secretary and chief Government spokesman, said their predictions might be justified.
A drive to establish on-the-job training for 6,000 veterans was started yesterday by the Federation Employment Service.

An advertising campaign directed against the "Lies of the Drys" was recommended to the board of directors of Licensed Beverage Industries yesterday by Walter M. Swertfager of the advertising agency bearing his name, which has been appointed by the organization.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- R.V. Fletcher, president of the Association of American Railroads said in a formal statement today that the nation's rail carriers "must seek a return commensurate with the earnings of other industries."

The report of the Pennsylvania Railroad for 1946 reveals a deficit of $10.8 millions, compared with a net income the previous year of $49 millions. For many roads this would be an old story, but not so with the Pennsylvania. Never before in its 100-year history has that system, the largest in the nation, lost money.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 19 -- Over strong objections by the Soviet Union and White Russian delegates, the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women today again voted down a bid by the Women's International Democratic Federation for special consultative status.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 -- Grain markets on the Board of Trade developed today a decidedly nervous undertone within a fairly wide range of prices with July and September wheat selling at new seasonal high prices. Spreading between the various deliveries of wheat and commission-house selling of March and May resulted in the close ranging from 2 cents lower to 3 1/8 cents higher than yesterday the former on March while September showed the most strength.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 -- Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, administrator, Federal Works Agency, said today that three-lane highways were "death traps." He urged wider traffic arteries in an address to the American Road Builders Association.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's message to Congress today recommending repeal of a large number of wartime laws: During the year and a half that have elapsed since the defeat of our last enemy in battle, we have progressively eliminated the great majority of emergency controls over the nation's economy.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- The feature of the stock markets here today was a marked trend in favor of dominion and other overseas industrial equities. The South African group was active, Canadian dollar securities made fresh headway, Rhodesian copper and foreign oil shares had big followings and speculators were in the market for South American railway stocks.

ALBERT EINSTEIN was once asked: "What is the speed of sound?" Without batting an eye he answered cheerfully: "I don't know. I don't burden my memory with such facts that I can easily find in any textbook." Well, what is good enough as a reply for the greatest living scientist is good enough for us. We'll even go further.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, called last night upon the United States Government to admit between 400,000 and 600,000 refugees from Europe to this country to set an example to Great Britain and the world in the handling of the displaced persons problem.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 19 -- A bill outlawing the closed shop in this State successfully completed its bitterly contested course through the Legislature today when the House voted in its favor 64 to 25, with one abstention.
SHANGHAI, Feb. 19 -- China's request for permission to sell UNRRA cotton and cereals worth $200,000,000 in the open market encountered strong opposition today in the China office of UNRRA.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 19 (AP) -- With Cyrus S. Eaton as mediator, directors of the Cliffs Corporation made peace today with minority interests backed by Robert R. Young; suspended their plan to dissolve their corporation and voted to merge it with an ore and coal subsidiary, the Cleveland Cliffs Iron Company, into a new $90,000,000 concern.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- United in a determination to curb the smoke nuisance in Queens, 200 home owners came to Albany today to ask enactment of legislation barring the Long Island Railroad from using coal - burning locomotives within city limits.

Donald Wolfit's Shakespearean company submits "As You Like It" at the Century Theatre this afternoon as its second repertory offering. The British troupe opened a limited engagement on Tuesday evening under the auspices of Hall Shelton and the Advance Players Association, Ltd. Today Mr. Wolfit will play the minor comedy part of Touchstone.

NANKING, Feb. 19 -- A sweeping Government advance into southern Shantung along a 200-mile front is claimed in reports from Government sources on the hostilities against the Communists during the last week.

Thousands of devout Christians attended yesterday Ash Wednesday services marking the opening of the annual penitential season of Lent. Ashes were put on the brows of worshipers at all Roman Catholic and many Episcopal churches.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- F.N. Bard, Chicago industrialist who has been seeking tax relief for owners of unincorporated businesses, asserted today that "Congressional prima donnas have gotten together behind an iron curtain" to postpone this type of legislation until next year.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial of Feb. 18, "King George in Africa," discerningly characterizes the royal visit to South Africa as a major undertaking by the British Government in cooperation with Prime Minister Smuts, having as its fundamental purpose "to keep this key to a continent firmly within the Commonwealth * * * (and) to transfer to Africa the power and prestige she (Britain) has lost in Asia."

Supporters of David Dubinsky president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL, scored an overwhelming victory early yesterday morning in the first of a series of elections to be held among 175,000 ILGWU members in this city between now and March 15.
A black market in taxicab licenses that has compelled some veterans to pay $2,500 for aluminum medallions issued for $10 by the city, appeared yesterday to be entrenched behind existing laws.

An increase last week of 1,343,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the end of the period they amounted to 103,048,000 barrels, compared with 101,705,000 a week earlier and 105,297,000 on Feb. 16, 1946.
ATLANTA, Feb. 19 -- Legislative action was completed today on Georgia's White Primary Bill and the measure was sent to the Assembly -elected Governor, Herman Talmadge, for his signature.
A spring millinery preview took place yesterday at the luncheon our in the Serf Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The occasion was Milgrim's presentation of ats. It was a sizable collection.
Sportsmen's Show sidelights. After four days of the show we thought we had seen just about everything in the way of fishing gadgets, but this afternoon we came across some more.

Because of increased services contemplated by the Health Department, the agency yesterday asked Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson for $11,167,646 for expenses during the coming fiscal year, an increase of $3,229,315.

PARIS, Feb. 19 -- The United States Government has been considering, according to diplomatic circles here, a plan under which it would not accept its share of the portion of the Italian Fleet that is to be divided among the Big Four powers.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 19 (AP) -- Jim Bickford drove to a one-second victory today in the combined four-man United States Olympic bobsled trials and national senior Amateur Athletic Union championship.

Pointing out that industry has entered 1947 with a large backlog of orders in all lines, Percy C. Magnus, president of Magnus, Mabee Reynard, Inc., declared yesterday that predictions of a recession this year have no basis in fact.

ROME, Feb. 19 -- Pope Pius XII today broadcast an appeal to the well-fed and sheltered Catholic school children of the United States to help the starving, homeless children of Europe and Asia. He spoke in English. It was the first time he had delivered an address directly to the Catholic children of America, and there were two reasons of very great importance to him why he did.

Chuck Rayner got even with the Bruins last night for what they had done to him in the Hub a week ago. On that occasion Boston sent ten shots past the New York Ranger goalie while Frankie Brimsek was beaten only once.
BERLIN, Feb. 19 -- The potential strength of Germany's industrial revival is indicated in official statistics to be published soon. They reveal the growing robustness of heavy industry, chiefly coal.

AUBREY (DIT) CLAPPER holds many distinctions in the National Hockey League, not the least of which is the fact that he once put the slug on the president of the circuit, Clarence S. Campbell. But the present coach of the Boston Bruins didn't walk into Campbell's office and assault him. It happened in a Stanley Cup play-off some years ago when Campbell was serving as a referee.

Spring millinery bloomed yesterday at the Hotel Pierre in a showing by Russeks of a collection from its Pink Room. There were crisp whites, pastel pinks, a tawny caramel tone in straw braids and sheer blacks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- A Supreme Court pledge to review a test case involving the fate of billions of dollars' worth of alien property seized during World War II was carried in formal notices prepared today for dispatch to interested parties

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 19 -- Hollywood motion picture production has fallen off 25 per cent in the last few weeks, and both labor and management sources estimate the resultant lay-off of workers at a comparable proportion of the studios' labor force -- possibly more than 5,000 people.

It's a sound idea to serve cherries at this time of year, not just because they're a tradition for Washington's Birthday, but because supplies of both the canned and frozen fruit are greater than they have been since before the war. In some cases the packs are record ones.

Josef Raieff, who gave three piano recitals at Town Hall between his debut in 1938 and his induction into the Army, played there again last night for the first time since his discharge from the service. His program included Bach's Chromatic Fantasy and Fugue, Beethoven's D major Sonata, Op. 28, a Russian group and six Chopin selections.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- A Congressional witness, Representative Frederick C. Smith, Republican, of Ohio, asked the House Labor Committee today to recommend repeal of both the Wagner and the Norris-La Guardia Acts.

Five men and two women, suspected members of a gang of mail box thieves and check forgers who netted $25,000 in the last year and a half, were in the Federal House of Detention last night after their arrest late Tuesday by postal inspectors and New York detectives.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 19 -- Egyptians began to learn today how much it was going to cost them to provide for their own national defense after they severed their military alliance with Britain.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Feb. 6, citing Mr. Lilienthal's enlightening passage on democracy described it as "one of the most movingly eloquent definitions of democracy."

The American people are impelled to work for a solution of the Negro problem "because it is part of our heritage and because it is right that we should do so," Henry R. Luce, publisher of life and Time magazines, said yesterday in accepting the chairmanship of the 1947 campaign of the National Urban League.

Current statistics give absoutely no indication of a depression in the immediate future, Dr. Virgil Reed, associate director of research, J. Walter Thompson Company, told a luncheon meeting of the United Fresh Fruit and Vegetable Association yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker.

Construction of a fourth major airport in the metropolitan area will be necessary within a few years, W.E. Cullinan Jr., superintendent of the airports branch of Region 1 of the Civil Aeronautics Administration, declared last night.

"Rigolotto" was the opera last night at the Metropolitan with the new Swedish soprano Hjoerdis Schymberg making her first appearance on this stage as Gilda. She is young, comely and intelligent. The voice has the requisite range and flexibility, but had a tendency to the metallic at the top, while intonation was not at all times secure.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19 -- Standard Power and Light Corporation's application for authority to sell 1,160,000 shares of common stock of the Standard Gas and Electric Company was turned aside today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which twice, in 1944, had held that the stock had no value.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- The first break in the electricity cuts that have been crippling British industry since Feb. 10 was announced by Prime Minister Attlee in the House of Commons today. Starting Monday, the Midlands will be allowed 30 per cent of the allocations of coal that were in force last month.

A resolution to protest alleged discrimination against American exporters to Palestine with the Department of State was adopted yesterday by the American Office Supply Exporters meeting in the Hotel New Yorker. Agents in Palestine have reported, they said, that a virtual boycott has been imposed by authorities there on American goods.

This newspaper would like to give its readers a full report of the proceedings of the forthcoming Moscow conference. As matters stand, it will be greatly handicapped, in this effort by an arbitrary decision of the Russian Government, which will limit our representation at the conference to a single correspondent, Cyrus Sulzberger, in addition to our regular correspondent in Moscow, Drew Middleton.

Succession of bloom is the most important feature of any picture garden, Mary Deputy Lamson, landscape architect, told the final meeting of THE NEW YORK TIMES garden course at Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Commodore H.C. Sheppard, the Coast Guard's marine safety chief, said today that it may be necessary to operate unsafe ships indefinitely under Government foreign programs.

BERLIN, Feb. 19 -- Charges of the distribution of American relief parcels to SS men in internment camps and other flagrant abuses have resulted in a thorough housecleaning of the Red Cross in the United States zone. However, the reduction of Military Government personnel prevents proper field supervision and facilitates the continuation of such abuses by former German Army nurses and volunteer workers, United States officials said today.

With Leopold Stokowski back as guest conductor, last night's New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra concert at Carnegie Hall might have been expected to be full of surprises and excitements. There was, however, only one surprise, and that was the conventional program, which was played with over-all modesty and restraint.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--President Truman predicted without reservation today that the Senate would approve David E. Lilienthal as Chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission.

PEIPING, China, Feb. 20 -- A survey of opinion in the American community in Peiping today revealed that an overwhelming majority of the United States citizens questioned are flatly opposed to the much-discussed $500,000,000 loan to China unless the loan is allocated project by project and is spent under strict United States supervision.

Counsel for Frank Costello, the gambler, collected from frank Leuci, Police Department property clerk, yesterday, the $27,200 Costello lost in a taxicab on June 14, 1944. Before the lawyer left the property clerk's office, though, this sum had melted down to $121.65.

Eight contract bridge teams, survivors of a field of forty-four teams that started play Monday night, entered the quarter-final round of the contest for the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup at the Hotel Pierre last night. The winners, who will be decided in a final match Saturday, will be team-offour champions of the American Contract Bridge League, which conducts the tournament.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--Recommendations for overhauling the Army military justice system will be submitted shortly to Congress, and the Navy also is considering revisions, Secretaries Robert P. Patterson and James Forrestal disclosed today.

Mayor O'Dwyer and the other members of the Board of Estimate must have begun to wonder anew yesterday, as they agreed unanimously to start subsidizing the operation of buses on Staten Island, to what end the folly of the five-cent fare would finally bring them. Staten Island has no subways.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 20--A Protestant statement placing grave responsibility upon hcurches and members to take direct, active part in easing and reconciling economic tensions and injustices through Christian principles was adopted here today at the close of a threeday conference by representatives of twenty-eight denominations in the United States and Canada.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--While fresh charges of interference with independent unions were launched today against the National Labor Relations Board, the board categorically denied serious accusations made against it last week by counsel for the Weirton Steel Company.

Federal and city officials will meet at City Hall Monday to explore the possibility of ending the protracted jurisdictional dispute between telephone and electrical workers on a basis already accepted by both sides in a similar dispute in Maryland.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP)--A conference of industrialists and Government officials was called today for next Wednesday in an attempt to work out a plan for obtaining 10,000 new boxcars a month to relieve the critical shortage.

The eighth district nursing office of the Community Service Society's department of educational nursing will be dedicated Thursday at 24 Pell Street, it was disclosed in the annual report of the society's health promotion and educational service made public yesterday.

Hot and Cold King George, or someone among his travel companions, may have been reminded in recent days of what a British writer said almost exactly fifty years ago in a poem called "The Recessional," about Britain holding "dominion over palm and pine."

Having put its worst foot forward with "King Lear" on Tuesday, Mr. Wolfit's London Company brought forward a better-shod foot yesterday afternoon. They added to their repertory a pleasantly Informal production of Shakespeare's "As You Like It," at the Century Theatre.

Prayers for better interracial, international and interdenominational relations will be offered today by Christian women around the world under the auspices of women's missionary societies. In this city the leaders with a very few exceptions will be women.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 20-- An agreement opening the way for trade between Germany and Belgium was signed here today. It marks, in a sense, a resumption of normal relations, yet in the opinion of Belgians the advance will be little more than a timid first step.
LONDON, Feb. 20--The British Government announced to Parliament today its intention to quit India by June, 1948.

Skiers in record number are expected to visit the popular snowlands throughout the North Country on the holiday week-end. Indications point to some of the finest sport of the season with the heavy coastal snowstorm moving up from Alabama expected to leave from four to eight inches of powder covers in most of the Northeastern United States.

The air-transport issues won unusual support yesterday on the stock market and helped materially in halting a further deterioration in prices of the whole list. Earnings reports and increased dividend announcements received only a token nod in the day's proceedings, with a slight list to the higher side at the close in terms of the number of stocks to show gains in the session, although the composite rate declined slightly.

TOKYO, Feb. 20--Occupation officials are frankly worried over the prospect that the current economy drive in the United States may seriously reduce the amounts needed to finance-Japan's continuing foreign trade deficit.

Elimination of export quotas or cattle hides and a request for a conference on the question early next week were urged in a telegram to Government officials by the Popular Price Shoe Retailers Association, made public here yesterday.
BERLIN, Feb. 20--The British Military Government told 70,000 displaced persons today that they must work if they remained in Germany.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Feb. 20 (U.P.)--Forty Williams College students will form a picket line tomorrow to boycott a local barbershop which is alleged to have tried to charge a Negro undergraduate $3 for a $1 haircut.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--Two explanations of the reason that impelled the Soviet rulers to send the note of protest about Under-Secretary of State Acheson are made in official circles here, and they are not in conflict: they supplement each other. One is that, since Russian diplomats are trained never to say anything directly, they are astonished as well as resentful when the spokesmen of other nations do on a matter that concerns the Soviet Union.

Arrangement by banks of ship, rail, or air passenger accommodations, where a fee is involved, is not "necessary" to the exercise of banking powers, Attorney General Nathan L. Goldstein ruled in a formal opinion made public yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 20--A threatened strike of 15,000 oil refinery workers in five far Western States was averted today by a wage increase agreement between the International Oil Workers Union, CIO, and the Standard Oil Company of California.

The Public Service Commission cleared the way yesterday for what was described as the largest public utility financial operation in the history of this State. It authorized the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., to seek public bids by March 20 on $100,000,000 of first mortgage refunding bonds as the initial step in a series of three to pay off more than $320,000,000 of its outstanding debt.

HAVANA, Feb. 20 (U.P.) -- The battle of words between Cuban maritime workers unions and United States Representative Fred Bradley, Republican, of Michigan, continued unabated today after a week of charges and countercharges.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 20-- Inflation rather than deflation is the dominant economic problem of the immediate future, according to a consensus of analyses of the transition economy by six economists who played leading roles in planning reconversion policy.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: You have recently printed two letters objecting to the use of "too" in such locutions as "too often" and "too many." The "too" is not in the sense of "very," but in a sense dictionaries record as one of its main and oldest meanings: in Webster's words, "to such a degree as to be regrettable."

TRENTON, N. J., Feb. 20--Tax valuations for 1945 on the terminal and main lines of the New Jersey Central Railroad in Jersey City and Bayonne were sustained today by the State Division of Tax Appeals.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--The Government moved today to bar almost immediately further imports of automobiles, jeeps, trucks and various other equipment from surplus stocks abroad.

Reduction of the individual income tax burden as the Republicans plan it is needed to stimulate business and preserve consumer spending against a downturn in business this year, according to Representative Carl T. Curtis. Republican, of Nebraska.

In his letter of transmittal to Congress with the Maritime Commission's annual report, Vice Admiral William W. Smith, chairman, complained of "a distressing lack of knowledge and understanding by the public of the nation's merchant marine policy and problems.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Feb. 15 were 799,977 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 32,496 cars or 4.2 far cent more than for the preceding week, 92,923 cars or 13.1 per cent more than for the corresponding week of last year and 15,274 cars or 1.9 per cent more than during the corresponding weak two ysars ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--President Truman served notice today that he would renew his appeal for legislation authorizing universal military training as soon as he has heard from a special committee of prominent educators, clergymen and business leaders who are studying the subject.

A decision to press for adoption of the Democratic legislative program was reached yesterday at a conference between Irwin Steingut, minority leader of the Assembly, and representatives of the Democratic State Committee and the city administration at Democratic State headquarters in the Hotel Biltmore.

By June 30, every important plant in the American occupied area of Germany will have given up its industrial secrets to American investigators. John Green, director of the Office of Technical Services of the Department of Commerce, disclosed this fact yesterday to 150 members of the New York chapter of the Society for the Advancement of Management during a meeting at the WaldorfAstoria.
LITTLE AMERICA, Feb. 19 (Delayed)--The Navy-Byrd expedition's mechanized trail party churned into camp today after having covered 245 miles.

Advocating retrenchment in Government spending to reduce the public debt, Senator Chapman Revercomb, Republican, of West Virginia, urged yesterday that "need, public benefit and monetary return" be the guiding factors in any future public works.

ALBANY, Feb. 20--An enlargement of New York City's special taxing powers and the granting of special taxing powers to counties and the larger up-State cities are being contemplated by Gov. Thomas E. Dewey as a means of partly financing permanent pay increases for teachers, it was disclosed today.

HAVANA, Feb. 20--Leo Durocher took his Dodgers into Havana's new ball park, Grand Stadium, and worked them out so briskly for the first time today that one athlete wound up in the hospital. Lou Ruchser, one of the two native Brooklynites on the squad and a leading first base candidate, was hit on the left side of the face and felled by a line drive from the bat of Marvin Rackley, rookie outfielder.

MOSCOW, Feb. 20--The Soviet Union has slashed its expenditure for armed forces in 1947 by just over 5,600,000,000 rubles, Minister of Finance A. G. Zverev announced before the Supreme Soviet of the U.S.S.R. tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- A Sikorsky helicopter, operating off the carrier Franklin D. Roosevelt during the current fleet exercises, has rescued six naval airmen from the water during the last ten days, the Navy revealed today.

LONDON, Feb. 20--The American, British and French deputies of the Council of Foreign Ministers have virtually abandoned hope of reaching agreement in London on a procedure for framing the German peace treaty.

Making its bid for expanded export trade, the women's apparel industry has filed a brief with the Reciprocity Committee urging tariff reductions in all of the seventeen foreign countries participating in the proposed International Trade Organization, it was disclosed yesterday by Dr. N.I. Stone.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 20--One of the worst explosions in Los Angeles history shattered a downtown electroplating plant and near-by industrial and residential buildings at 9:45 A.M. today, killing at least fifteen persons and injuring more than one hundred.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 20 Britain and France proposed today that the United Nations Security Council ask the Atomic Energy Commission to go ahead with phases of international atomic control on which there is agreement, leaving controversial questions like abolition of the veto on punishment to be dealt with later.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Feb. 20--Although they have been less than a week in camp, preliminary training of the Yankees already is beginning to take definite shape, so much so, in fact, that today Manager Bucky Harris sketched out a line-up for the opening game of the exhibition campaign against a local team on Saturday.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 20--Manager Mel Ott removed the shackles from his Giants today. Responding to what amounted to a public clamor, Mel let the boys do some hitting for the first time.

BIRMINGHAM, England, Feb. 20--The country is freezing and British industry is disrupted more seriously than during the worst days of the blitz for lack of coal. Still the miners in the Midland district are not working full time.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--The two senior Republicans on the House Labor Committee, Chairman Fred A. Hartley, Jr. of New Jersey and Representative Gerald W. Landis of Indiana, suggested today that it was ready to recommend dual controls hitting directly at strikes.

Boost Orders for Repair Parts Industrial plants have increased their orders for repair and replacement parts for machinery and tools, New York machine tool distributors disclosed here yesterday. During the war, when repair parts were scarce, plants stripped some tools to obtain parts for replacement use on others.

Acting at the Board of Estimate's direction, the Board of Transportation prepared yesterday to take over the operation of twenty-four Staten Island bus lines, serving 60,000 commuters, at midnight tomorrow.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 20-- Prime Minister Attlee's announcement that Great Britain would transfer power to Indian hands by June, 1948, coupled with the disclosure that Rear Admiral Viscount Mountbatten would succeed Viscount Wavell as Viceroy next month appeared destined to create a profound impression in this capital.

ITS quite obvious that Abe Greene, the president of the National Boxing Association, never studied how to win friends and influence people. Despite his pious protestations that the New York State Athletic Commission and the N.B.A. should always work in harmony, he certainly hasn't taken advantage of the kiss-andmake-up technique.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 20 -- Two sections of the final report of the Conference on the Church and Economic Life, convened by the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, were as follows:

After hearing arguments for and against demolition of the Aquarium building in Battery Park, the Board of Estimate deferred action on the demolition yesterday until April 10, with a faint hope that the Federal Government might appropriate funds meanwhile to restore it as old Fort Clinton.

LONDON, Feb. 20--The Cabinet, which approved last week the plan to refer the Palestine problem to the United Nations, will wait until after Tuesday's parliamentary debate on the subject before it attempts to set an interim policy for regulating immigration into the Holy Land, it was reliably reported tonight.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20--All major cities in this country are suffering from hardening of the traffic arteries which is jeopardizing the economic future of urban business and rapidly getting worse, according to a report today by the Highway Terminals Committee of the American Road Builders Association.

In an effort to suit the individual requirements of steamship companies wishing to purchase C-3 type vessels to be built in the next fiscal year, and to minimize the cost of construction, the Maritime Commission yesterday offered a list of improvements that will be available for this type of ship.

The closed shop was assailed as "a deeply illiberal device" and defended as vitally necessary to the growth and health of the American labor movement in a discussion at Town Hall last night, with Senator Joseph H. Ball of Minnesota and Senator Warren G. Magnuson of Washington taking part.

ALBANY, Feb. 20 -- Recalling the constant demands made on the State for new services and further aid to localities, Governor Dewey told 1,000 members of the Association of Towns tonight that his administration sought to give "balanced government within the limits of their pocketbooks."

ABOARD MOUNT OLYMPUS, Feb. 20--The forty-five-year-old camp of Capt. Robert Scott, England's premier polar explorer, was inspected today by a surveying party of the United States Navy Antarctic expedition.

There was nothing unusual about the Flatbush Avenue subway train when it left Van Cortlandt Park station of the IRT yesterday. It bumped along just like any other subway train until it reached Chambers Street, at 1:25 A.M.

BOSTON, Feb. 20 (AP)--Lenten season fish catches withheld from the market for higher prices rose close to 2,000,000 pounds today as crews of six arriving vessels joined nineteen others in refusing to unload, and prices fell even lower than yesterday's.

MONTREAL, Feb. 20--The fight for control of the St. Lawrence Corporation, Ltd., and its three subsidiaries, St. Lawrence Paper Mills Company, Ltd., Lake St. John Power and Paper Company and Brompton Pulp and Paper Company, Ltd., is believed to be nearing a showdown.

When Byron Price retired as wartime director of censorship he was formally honored by newspaper men in Washington. He had completed a task as thankless as any could ever be and had emerged not only respected tout admired. Trained in the gathering and dissemination of news, he had had to reverse his ingrained habit of mind in the interest of national security.
ATLANTA, Feb. 20 (AP)--Emory Burke, 31 years old, president of Columbians, Inc., was convicted today of usurping police authority with his brown-shirted troopers.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 20--Secnav, the Mill River stable's chief hope for honors among the 3-year-olds, gave another convincing demonstration of his sprinting ability at Hialeah Park today when he dashed to a six-length victory is the $4,000 Palmetto Purse.

Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson bluntly warned yesterday that the proposed cuts of $1,500,000,000 in the War Department's appropriation would leave the Army too weak to carry out its duties and might compel abandonment of the occupation of Germany and Japan.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--With the Republican leadership firmly in control, the House voted 239 to 159 today for a $6,000,000,000 reduction in President Truman's budget for the fiscal year 1948.

Nash-Kelvinator The Nash-Kelvinator Corporation announced a dividend of 25 cents a share on its capital stock, payable on March 28. Previous payments were 12 1/2 cents a share. The company said that both its automobile and refrigerator and appliance divisions "contributed substantially to current earnings."

Shaggy cotton rugs have inspired a new twist in ensembles for room schemes. Textured upholstery fabrics in the same looped effect as that used for matching carpeting are now available to home decorators through Edward Fields Company, Inc., 509 Madison Avenue.
ALBANY, Feb. 20--Governor Dewey's Administration reached an agreement today with the State Civil Service Employes Association on amendments to two budget bills affecting State workers.

Last night's program by the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the City Center was quite the best of its season thus far, which is not surprising, since it consisted in the main of Balanchine's "Ballet Imperial" and Ruth Page's and Bentley Stone's "Frankie and Johnny," two of its most distinguished works.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 20--The Irgun Zvai Leumi made a mortar and machine-gun attack on a Royal Air Force installation near Hadera and cut oil pipelines in two places last night and early today. Later a woman member of this terrorist group telephoned correspondents to claim the "credit" for the organization.

Municipal Pricing With the general market atmosphere still short of reassuring, underwriting houses had reason for being satisfied yesterday with the pricing formulas that spelled speedy distribution for the Detroit transit and the Louisiana highway bonds.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 (Science Service)--Babies doomed to blindness because they are born with the eye disease, glaucoma, are being given a chance to see by an operation devised by Dr. Otto Barkan of San Francisco.
LONDON, Feb. 20 (AP)--A greatgrandson of the first Empress of India, Queen Victoria, was chosen today to close out British rule over the vast subcontinent she annexed to the Crown.

Dr. Frank B. Jewett once remarked in an address delivered at New York University that he had often thought "how infinitesimally small would have been the chance of any man or group of men, except the one who actually had the idea, planning to invent the common zipper."

MOSCOW, Feb. 20 -- Twenty American press and radio correspondents will be enough to cover the news arising from the Council of Foreign Ministers' meeting here next month, since conditions for reporting will not differ from those in London, Paris and New York at earlier meetings.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The reluctance of Russia to admit Americans generally to attend the Moscow conference is a reflection of a controversy which has existed between the two countries for more than 100 years.
LONDON, Feb. 20 -- Freezing weather and heavy snows threatened new perilous setbacks tonight in Britain's fight to overcome the fuel crisis that has disrupted the national economy for eleven days.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--Another emergency agency, the Wage Stabilization Board, will leave the Washington scene tomorrow, marking the end of an experiment in tripartite governmental administration.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--Department store sales in the week ended Feb. 15 were 18 per cent above sales in the corresponding week last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1947:

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 20 (AP)--A plumber's helper and a bartender teamed today to win the North American two-man bobsled championships and possibly berths on the 1948 United States Olympic team. Fred Fortune Jr., 25, Lake Placid plumber's assistant, and Schuyler Carron, 276-pound bartender from Ausable Forks, thundered down Mt. Van Hoevenberg's one-mile course in four lightning descents to outdistance a four-team field.

American education is facing a serious situation. With the publication today of the last of twelve articles citing the results of THE TIMES nationwide school survey we can measure the deterioration that has taken place since Pearl Harbor. Of the 865,000 teachers in this country, 125,000 are on emergency licenses--or one out of every seven.

TOKYO, Feb. 20 -- A proposal that the Allies reverse their announced plan of collecting reparations from Japan by removing industrial plants and other facilities as a lump-sum payment, and instead accept Japanese produce over a period of years, was made today in the upper House of the Diet.
In her first collection to include evening fashions, presented yesterday at Arnold Constable, Dorothy O'Hara showed those talents that have made her one of the West Coast's well-known designers.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 20-- Scholars representing leading schools and educational foundations throughout the Western Hemisphere found themselves in almost perfect agreement today with the statement that the teaching of United States history in American schools had reached a stage of dangerous overemphasis.

The State of New York was revealed yesterday in the role of a landlord that is making comfortable conditions pleasanter, with the dual purpose of accommodating present tenants and attracting new ones.

LONDON, Feb. 20 (AP)--Following is the text of Prime Minister Attlee's statement on India: It has long been the policy of successive British Governments to work towards the realization of self-government in India. In pursuance of this policy, an increasing measure of responsibility has been devolved on Indians and today the civil administration and the Indian armed forces rely to a very large extent on Indian civilians and officers.

Mrs. Jessie Cuthbert MacPherson, 70-year-old widow of William L. MacPherson, author and New York Herald Tribune editorial writer, was found dead yesterday in her apartment at 108 East Thirty-eighth Street of fumes from a "faulty refrigerator."

Sportsmen's Show notes. The finals in the Surfcasterversus-Swimmer contest will be run off tonight, and the competition is scheduled to come under the heading of "heated." In this event the surfcaster, using regulation surf tackle with fifteen-thread line, "plays" a swimmer in the big tank.

PARIS, Feb. 20--M. Ramadier seemed to accept the minimum wage demanded by the General Confederation of Labor today. He said that it was "urgent to reestablish the idea of a minimum wage," and he added that the request of the miners' federation for a wage increase to at least 7,000 francs a month was "sane and reasonable."

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission stressed today, in its twelfth annual report to Congress, that it is endeavoring to carry out the policies of the laws administered by it with a "minimum of interference with the normal operations of the facilities of securities distribution and trading."

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20--Two Companies--the Cory Corporation of Chicago and the Moore-Handley Hardware Company, Inc., of Birmingham, Ala.--filed registration statements today with the Securities and Exchange Commission. while a third--the Atlantic Refining Company of Philadelphia-- withdrew a registration filed on Oct. 29, last.

ALBANY, Feb. 20--A permanent 3 per cent tax exemption on all new low-cost housing built by private capital for low-income families was proposed today as a means of alleviating the present critical housing shortage.

Underwriting managers will place on the market here today new issues of securities as follows: Maine Turnpike Authority-- $5,000,000 of 2 3/4 per cent turnpike revenue bonds maturing Feb. 1, 1976, at 98 1/2, by Tripp Co., Inc., and Stifel, Nicolaus Co., Inc.

"Colorless colors" took the center of the stage at Macy's spring fashion presentation yesterday morning. They carried off the honors with distinction. Amy Fagan, fashion councilor for the store, insisted upon the beige tones, from off-white to sunkissedsand, throughout.

America's system of public school education needs immediate assistance. The public must take a greater interest in the schools if conditions are to be improved. The downward spiral may be checked in 1947 if the public appreciates what is happening to education.

That the Musicians Emergency Fund should be national was the contention of Guy Marriner, Director of Music of the Franklin Institute, Philadelphia; Lecturer in Music at the University of Pennsylvania, and former music liaison officer between the Surgeon General's Office and the Special Services Division of the United States Army, who made an address at the meeting of that organization yesterday at the Colony Club.

Any reduction in trade discounts on sporting goods would place these departments further in the red, Jay D. Runkle charged yesterday. Even in normal times they constitute "loss departments," Mr. Runkle, chairman of the board of the National Retail Dry Goods Association and vice president and general manager of Crowley, Milner Co., Detroit, maintained at a meeting of a group of retailers with sporting goods manufacturers in the NRDGA offices.

In the hope that the methods that have helped minimize labor strife in New York City will prove beneficial in other parts of the country, thirty-two jurists, industrialists and labor leaders joined yesterday in sponsoring publication of a sixteen-page brochure entitled "The O'Dwyer Plan for Industrial Peace."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--President Truman expressed the view today that the Office of Price Administration, administering rent control, would not be allowed to die through Congressional failure to appropriate necessary operating funds.

Not only Sunday dinner but also a menu for Washington's Birthday will be included in the shopping plans of housewives who'll be doing most of their week-end marketing today in view of the holiday tomorrow. Whether they buy a roast that will last all week-end or provide variety by serving a slice of ham steak for one main meal and broilers for another, they will find ample supplies in the stores.

Reductions of borrowings by finance, sugar, cotton and tobacco companies accounted for a decline of $32,000,000 last week in the commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System.
NANKING, Feb. 20--Yenan has ordered the Communist personnel maintaining the present Communist offices in Nanking, Shanghai and Chungking to remain at their posts.
PARIS, Feb. 20--The British Cabinet, in a step that may widen the abyss between British and French policy, has decided to put a German trustee in charge of the collieries and steel works in the Ruhr.
LONDON, Feb. 20--The Earl of Halifax, former British Ambassador to the United States, rejected today the idea of an Anglo-American alliance.

Beau Jack, former locker room boy at the Augusta National Golf Club who became world's lightweight boxing champion, will make his first appearance in Madison Square Garden in several months tonight when he faces Tony Janiro, Youngstown (Ohio) welterweight, in the feature bout scheduled for ten rounds.

The State of Louisiana awarded yesterday to a syndicate of sixtyfive banking houses headed by Blyth Co., Inc., and Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., three series of highway bonds aggregating $19,000,000 and maturing from 1951 to 1965 at a bid representing a net interest cost of 2.749 per cent.
Leaders in the field of public information reported yesterday that the idea of Brotherhood Week had stimulated unprecedented interest among the American people.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--During the week ended Feb. 19, member bank reserve balances decreased $224,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.
New York City experienced the winter's record snowstorm early today with a fall of 7.4 inches reported at 1 A.M. by the Weather Bureau at the Battery. The previous high mark was 6.1 inches on Feb. 8.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP)-- Complaints charging illegal price fixing were announced tonight by the Federal Trade Commission against thirty-five manufacturers of vitrified sewer pipe and two trade associations.

Life insurance protection provided by the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States last year passed the ten billion dollar mark for the first time in the company's history, Thomas I. Parkinson, president, reported yesterday at the annual meeting of the directors.

Elimination or modification of existing laws restricting the use of sugar in the home processing and use of fresh fruits was urged yesterday in the final resolutions of the United Fresh Fruit and Vegetable Association at the closing session of its Forty-third annual meeting.

Chairman Bourke B. Hickenlooper of the Congressional Joint Committee on Atomic Energy said a little less than he may have felt yesterday when he observed that the "field of investigation" in the current Senate hearings on David E. Lilienthal and other AEC nominees seemed to him "about complete."

DETROIT, Feb. 20 (AP)--A plan whereby salaried and supervisory employes may purchase new automobiles at a 10 per cent discount is being developed by General Motors Corporation, C. E. Wilson, president, announced today. No mention was made of hourly rated workers in the announcement.
John Pawle, amateur racquets champion of England, escaped defeat by a stroke yesterday in the open tournament for the Pell Cup at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

Within several weeks the Main Stem will experience one of the most extensive theatrical turnovers of the season. According to announcements made yesterday, three attractions have decided to end local engagements to make way for incoming offering's.

The text of an address by Robert P. Patterson, Secretary of War, at ceremonies at City Hall yesterday marking the activation of three units of the Army's Organized Reserve, follows: Every old soldier enjoys a reunion with his former outfit.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 20 (AP)--The terrorists claimed they had cut the pipeline in four places. The breaks reported by the Government were just outside the installations of the giant Consolidated Refineries, Ltd., at Haifa Bay, and in the vicinity of the village of Indur, near Afule, twenty-three miles southeast of Haifa.

City College's hopes for a postseason tournament bid received a severe jolt last night at Madison Square Garden, where the Beavers dropped a 60-54 decision to Niagara of Buffalo. It was the fourth setback of the basketball campaign for Nat Holman's men, whose performance sorely disappointed 17,925 fans.

UNITED STATES ARMY PROVING GROUNDS, White Sands, N.M., Feb. 20--The highest parachute "jump" in history took place here today when Army experts installed one of the new "ribbon" canopies in the nose of a V-2 rocket that soared to a height of sixtyeight miles.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE NEW YORK TIMES reports that Representative James W. Wadsworth has proposed statutory legislation and a commission to study the legal status of women. The bill provides that Federal agencies will call upon the States for cooperation in reviewing discrimination based on sex, recommending legislation, etc.

One in every five schools in Greece has been destroyed, Sophia Tournakis of the Greek Ministry of Education reported yesterday. Those left are stripped of equipment. Children must write in sand, on slates or on whitewashed walls, she said in speaking at a luncheon given by the Greek War Relief Association at the St. Moritz Hotel.
New York City plans to spend $20,000,000 in the next ten years for bigger and brighter street lights, it was disclosed yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 20 --Evidence of extensive horserace bookmaking activity in Westchester County during the last year was assembled here today by District Attorney George M. Fanelli. The identity of ringleaders was not determined at once but clues to at least twenty "top bookmakers" alleged to operate throughout Westchester and in other parts of New York were discovered, he declared.

FIRST novels are traditionally autobiographical. Frequently they are mediums for the expression of youthful indignation, all the pent-up fury and frustration inspired in young writers by their home towns, their first jobs and their families. A few become famous as literary landmarks, such as Thomas Wolfe's "Look Homeward Angel"; scores pass unnoticed every year.

LONDON, Feb. 20 -- Although lifting of the power ban in the Midlands beginning Monday, and the 30 per cent solid fuel allocation were not up to best expectations in the city, the stock markets here held firm today.
Despite the unsettled conditions, organized sports activities of all kinds are continuing in Palestine, according to Leib Sirkin, a director of the National Hapoel Sports Federation of Palestine.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 20--A geological investigation has established that the Tatung coal mines in Shansi Province, with an estimated reserve of 40,000,000,000 tons, are by far the richest coal fields in either China proper or Manchuria.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 20--A secret "little Nathan report," dealing exclusively with the United States Steel Corporation and prepared for the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, states that the concern can grant a 21-cent hourly wage increase, according to authoritative sources here.
MADISON, Wis., Feb. 20 (AP)-- Dr. Clement C. Williams, former president of Lehigh University, died today in a hospital here. He would have been 65 years old tomorrow.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 20--A suggestion that higher education be made "as free as elementary education is in this country" was advanced and defended here today before the annual meeting of the National Association of Junior Colleges.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--Higher prices for agricultural commodities were primarily responsible for an advance of 1 per cent in primary market prices during the week ended Feb. 15, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

Prime Minister Attlee announces that Great Britain proposes to terminate her two-hundred-year-old rule in India by June, 1948, and to turn over this rich and populous part of the British Empire to whatever government or governments the Indians themselves may be able to establish by that date.

Alexander Duncan Chiquoine Jr., senior vice president and a director of Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., will retire next month, he announced yesterday. He said he will divide his time among several fields related to advertising.
The 215th anniversary of the birth of George Washington will be observed tomorrow by patriotic, civic and religious organizations.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP)-- Commodore H.C. Shepheard told the House Merchant Marine Committee today that safety regulations were waived for the S.S. Washington although it is as "hazardous" as its sister ship, the S.S. Manhattan, which burned at sea.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 20-- "The Long Tunnel," a screen melodrama by Robert Labatt dealing with political underground activities in Europe during the war years, has been purchased by RKO and assigned to Herman Schlom for production this year.

ATLANTA, Feb. 20 -- Georgia's white primary bill was signed today by Herman Talmadge, Assembly -elected Governor, who denied the measure represented "an unfriendly attitude toward our Negro population."

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 20--The Essex County District Council of Carpenters, AFL, representing seven carpenters' locals with a membership of over 3,000 in the county, was suspended today from the Essex County Building and Construction Trades Council for failing to abide by AFL regulations on jurisdictional issues, it was announced today by Frazer L. Holzlohner, council president.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--A bill to knock out portal-to-portal back pay claims now officially put at $5,785,204,606, but shorn of two provisions opposed by labor in a pending House measure, was brought out today by a Senate Judiciary subcommittee.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 6 to 18 points net lower than the day before.

ARDMORE, Okla., Feb. 20 -- American Airlines has invested here several million dollars in pedagogic and psychological experiment which, it believes, may go far to eliminate, for itself an other foreign and domestic airlines, that "pilot error" which for years has been the most fertile cause of air accidents.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Twenty-nine air reserve training bases are the latest casualties of the rapidly dwindling Army Air Forces because of budget cuts, the AAF said today.

The Welfare Council of New York City created a central coordinating committee yesterday to make a more flexible and democratic organization. The action was taken by the directors of the council at its monthly meeting at the Gramercy Park Hotel, 52 Gramercy Park North.
LEWES, Del., Feb. 21 (AP) -- It takes more than a storm, Joss of a tender and a disabled rudder to stop Harold C. Lazze of Halifax, N.S.

ATLANTA, Feb. 21 -- Emory C. Burke, president of Columbians, Inc., the self-proclaimed anti-Jewish, anti-Negro organization, was sentenced in Superior Court today to three years in prison on charges of usurping police powers.

HOUSTON, Tex., Feb. 21 (AP) -- Johnny Dawson, defending champion from Los Angeles and pretournament favorite for the twenty-ninth annual Houston Country Club invitation golf title, had to come from behind today to defeat Ken Rogers, Oklahoma City, in a 19-hole struggle.

One of the largest and most concentrated newspaper campaigns ever undertaken, for a single product has been launched for "G B Bread" by General Bakeries, Ltd., Toronto, the Bureau of Advertising, ANPA, revealed yesterday. The campaign, devised by McConnell, Eastman Co., Ltd. also Toronto consists of four series of daily 525-line advertisements, with ten advertisements in each series.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 21 -- Czechoslovakia's proposals for compensating United States owners of nationalized property here are likely to run afoul of a United States Constitutional provision that all citizens are equal.

Columbia University conferred honorary degrees of Doctor of Laws upon eleven of the nation's foremost World War II military leaders -- two of them in absentia -- at a special convocation yesterday afternoon.

MOSCOW, Feb. 21 -- Soviet soldiera and sailors received today a stern warning to maintain the strictest vigilance against "enemy" secret service men within the Soviet Union and abroad since, it was said, "incendiaries" of a new war, like Winston Churchill "and his friends in Britain and the United States" are continuing their efforts.

Balked last week in his plea for $102,000,000 in additional State aid for New York City, Mayor O'Dwyer asked the State yesterday to double its $300,000,000 housing program because of emergency conditions in New York City.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, leader and strategist in the Republican high command, announced today that he would vote against approval of David E. Lilienthal as chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission.

BERLIN, Feb. 21 -- Gen. Joseph T. McNarney, retiring United States Military Governor of Germany, said today at his last press conference that the Allied Control Council as it now operated was not a sufficient instrument to govern Germany.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Bulldozers delved today into the rubble of the O'Connor electroplating plant, searching for additional bodies in Los Angeles' worst explosion in thirty-seven years, a blast that killed at least fifteen, left two missing and injured hundreds and caused property damage of more than $1,500,000.

Here in New York the European style of candy -- molded chocolates with bittersweet coating -- have become so popular that we sometimes forget the deliciousness of confections that are what might be called typically American. Such things as penuche and fudge and peanut brittle are in a temporary state of eclipse in this sophisticated city.

The informal atmosphere of subways during the early morning hours was bound to seep into the service. For years the city's night workers -- waiters, musicians, cab drivers, newspaper men -- have taken for granted a rather folksy manner seldom known during "business hours."

The Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo last night gave the season's first presentations of George Balanchine's "Concerto Barocco" and of the revival by Alexandra Danilova and Mr. Balanchine of the old Petipa "Raymonda" at the City Center.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- Approval of the State Banking Department to an increase of capital stock of the Huguenot Trust Company of New Rochelle was announced today in the department's weekly bulletin. The increase is from $329,200 to $355,600.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- President Truman urged Congress in a special message today to appropriate $350,000,000 for the relief of destitution in liberated countries abroad. He proposed that distribution of the supplies provided by the fund be controlled directly by the United States, instead of by an international agency.

SAIGON, French Indo-China, Feb. 20 (Delayed) -- A Cochin Chinese army of 7,800 men under French commissioned and noncommissioned officers has been formed to "pacify" this strife-ridden colony, the richest province in French Indo-China, according to the semiofficial newspaper Journal de Saigon.

A jury in Kings County Court yesterday took ten minutes to decide that Alfred Minutolo, 35 years old, a former inmate of Alcatraz, was guilty of escaping from the Brooklyn City Prison. He was one of nine men who fled from the institution last Jan. 2.

Federal Judge Frank A. Picard of Detroit sentenced yesterday two men convicted of black market meat operations to five years in jail and fined them, and two corporations they own, a total of $370,000.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- As bitter weather intensified its grip on all Britain tonight, authorities issued warnings that further efforts must be made to conserve fuel. The Ministry of Fuel and Power told the public that yesterday's coal economies from the restrictions on light, heat and power had been only 31,600 tons -- 15 per cent below the figure for the corresponding day last week.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 21 -- Sentiment strongly favoring the infusion of former enemy countries n the work of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization was expressed here today at the closing session of Princeton University's Bicentennial Conference on Higher Education.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- An unexpected series of full-dress speeches prevented Senate action today on the House-approved proposal for a $6,000,000,000 reduction in President Truman's $37,500,000,000 budget for the 1948 fiscal year.
A drive to encourage homeowners and landlords to rent rooms and apartments to veterans will be conducted next week by the American Veterans Committee, it was announced yesterday.

They carried a good fighter out of the ring on a stretcher at Madison Square Garden last night. Beau Jack, the ex-bootblack from Augusta, Ga., who twice held the lightweight championship of the world, was technically knocked out by Tony Janiro, doughty battler from Youngstown, Ohio, in the fourth round of the scheduled ten-round star bout.

Coastal States from Maine to the Carolinas were shaking themselves free last night of the heaviest snowfall they had experienced since March 7-9, 1941. New York City's share of the snow bonus was 11.6 inches.

Uniform standards for the operation, construction and maintenance of school buses and for the adequate marking of highways were recommended yesterday at the close of a two-day conference sponsored by the New York State Joint Legislative Committee on Interstate Cooperation.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 21 -- Education's role in bringing about the kind of thinking held essential to world peace, and the means by which our educational institutions can join with war-devastated sister schools abroad to foster the resurgence of education in this role, were expounded here today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Unless Congress acts to restrict nation power, the national strike weapon used by John L. Lewis in the coal fields will be grasped by the metal miners and smelter workers, an industrial witness predicted today before the House Labor Committee.

Breeze Corporations, Inc. -- For 1946: Net loss, $320,397, contrasted with net income in 1945 of $743,540, equal to $2.86 a share; sales, $2,735,948, compared with $36,295,429. Loss for 1946 is after giving effect to estimated tax carry-back credit.

Lack of realism in liquor laws and lack of stringent enforcement by liquor control officials are a serious problem for both the American public and the liquor industry itself, John J. Sullivan, former deputy police commissioner, declared yesterday.

As early as 1890 George Eastman was selling his kodak by telling the world, "You press the button, we do the rest." Since then "the rest" has come to mean some shop to which the film is taken for transmission to a developing and fixing establishment. It was the taking and not the making of pictures in the chemical sense that Eastman so greatly improved.

Uncertainty as to the course of retail trade has produced some "jitteriness" on the part of retail buyers in several wholesale markets, it was reported here yesterday. Basically, the trouble was said to be "buyers are scared, but they don't know whether they are justified in being scared or not."
