LONDON, Feb. 21 -- An oral clash between Ambassador Robert D. Murphy of the United States and Fedor T. Gusev of the Soviet Union enlivened today's session of the Foreign Ministers' deputies struggling with the draft of a German peace treaty.

Settlement of the month-old controversy between David O. Selznick and Mary Pickford and Charles Chaplin, owners of the United Artists Corporation, over control of the Motion Picture Distributing Company was completed yesterday and Mr. Selznick will drop his $13,000,000 court action against the partners, it was learned last night.

Commonwealth and Southern Directors of the Commonwealth, and Southern Corporation declared yesterday a dividend of $3 a share on the $6 preferred stock, subject to approval of the Securities and Exchange Commission. The payment is proposed to be made twenty-eight days after date of the commission's order to holders of preferred stock at the close of business on the fourteenth day after date of such order.

The 28-eight-year-old Brooklyn High School for Specialty Trades, one of the oldest of its kind in the city, was renamed the George Westinghouse Vocational High School yesterday at a ceremony in the institution's annex, Public School 5, Brooklyn.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovaia, Feb. 21 -- Eleanor Gimbel, addressing the opening session of the Council of the Women's International Democratic Federation, said that the group she represents in the United States is undertaking to attain the type of world that President Roosevelt had hoped for.

A $25,000,000 order for twenty of the forty-passenger, 440-milean-hour Republic Rainbow transport planed was canceled yesterday by American Airlines and the Republic Aviation Corporation of Farzningdale, L.I. A joint statement issued by the airline and the manufacturing company said the contract had been "terminated by mutual agreement."

DETROIT, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Hal Newhouser, whose strong south-paw pitching arm bears much of the weight of the Tigers' flag hopes, settled his contract troubles today by accepting a 1947 salary of more than $50,000 and possibly as much as $60,000.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- The text of President Truman's message to Congress asking $350,000,000 to assist in the relief of liberated countries:

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Feb. 21 -- More than 500 delegates and observers from, sixteen organizations, coming from twenty-four States of the United States, convened here today for the first national congress of world government organizations.

Parents, educators and members of social agencies that operate child day care centers set out yesterday to raise funds for their continuation. Today working mothers will mark Washington's Birthday with appeals for signatures on petitions in their communities.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 21 -- Sharp protests concerning transfer of American ships to Panamanian registry came today from two powerful maritime unions.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Feb. 21 -- German political parties will soon be permitted by the United States Military Government to foster German youth organizations, it was reliably learned today.

Statistics that deal with the lives of people in trouble can hardly be dry, especially when they have to do with unhappy children and involved family situations. Therefore the twenty-eighth appeal for funds of the New York Catholic Charities, which is now under way, is bound to give meaning to figures that bespeak a need for human sympathy and understanding.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 21 -- Publication of the details of new $880,000 fund to which all Palestine Arabs are expected to contribute and the reported emergence from exile of an Arab military commander pointed today to preparations for fighting.

Some of the recent commercial airline crashes could have been avoided if more navigational aids such as ILS (Instrument Landing System) and GCA (Ground Controlled Approach) equipment had been available and installed at airports, Carl Kneisel, chairman of a technical subcommittee of the International Air Transport Association, said here yesterday.

HAVANA, Feb. 21 -- Senor Jorge Pasquel, big money man of Mexican, baseball, and Branch Rickey, boss of all the Dodgers, arrived in Havana within a few hours of each other, but haven't met socially or otherwise. Nor is there any indication that they will.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- Setting its 1947 export target at 140 per cent of pre-war volume, the British Government today placed before Parliament and the people its grim economic plan for attaining this essential rate by year's end.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The House Judiciary Committee overwhelmingly approved today a bill to quash portal-to-portal back pay suits but going far beyond that single issue to sharply restrict the future liabilities of employers under all three Federal minimum wage laws.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- An instrument flying trainer attachment, designed to improve the training of student pilots, was patented this week by Leland S. Marshall of Dayton, Ohio, and made available by him, royalty free, for manufacture and use by or for the Government.
LONDON, Saturday, Feb. 22 -- The British Labor Government's economic White Paper had a strongly unfavorable reception in the predominantly Conservative London press today.

To bring children who have managed to survive life in concentration camps back to a normal way of living one must, first of all, love them, according to Gaby Ernestine Wolff, who has been helping to care for such youngsters in France ever since liberation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Following is the text of the statement by Jack Frye on his resignation as president of TWA.

Alexander Lavrowsky, president of Bridevel, Inc., manufacturers of bridal veils and accessories, has also joined Advanced Bridal Fashions, Inc., 62 West Thirty-sixth Street, a new firm specializing in making bridal gowns in the higher-price range.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 21 -- Armed, who hopped to fifth place on the world money-winning list last Saturday, has the opportunity of advancing a couple of more notches tomorrow when he goes after his fourth successive victory of the year in Hialeah Park's $66,500 Widener Handicap.

The 215th anniversary of the, birth of George Washington will be celebrated today in churches throughout the city and by fraternal, patriotic, and civic organizations. However, many of the traditional parades comemmorating the first President's birthday had to be canceled because of yesterday's heavy snowfall.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 21 -- In a candid discussion of Britain's post-war problems, particularly in the domestic field, Lord Inverchapel tonight expressed confidence in the destiny of the United States and Great Britain, and deplored the "gloomy, defeatist talk" prevalent today.

Sportsmen's Show notes: The deep-sea boys should make it a point to drop in George Dumond's booth and look over the new reel he is showing. It took Dumond several years of trial and error and a lot of experimenting to work out a principle that is not new mechanically but represents a real innovation on reels.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (U.P.) -- After a year of silence and six vain efforts by the United States to bring up the subject, Russia finally has agreed to "look into the matter" of her $10,298,000,000 lend-lease account, it was learned today.

A growing awareness of the problems of multiple sclerosis, the mysterious malady that attacks with crippling effects the nervous system of thousands of middle-aged, was noted last night at a dinner meeting of the newly organized Association for Advancement of Research on Multiple Sclerosis, Inc., in the New York Academy of Medicine, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street.

A broken wheel that caused the derailment yesterday of a two-car baggage train near, the Rosedale station of the Long Island Rail Road snarled rush-hour traffic on the road's Atlantic and Montauk branches.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21 -- Operations in grain futures were somewhat reduced today on the Board of Trade, but price changes were rapid. Wheat had a range of 3 1/2 to 4 1/4 cents a bushel, reacting after an early advance only to rally later and finish with March and May unchanged and the new crop months up 1 5/8 to 1 3/4 cents net.

Olga Coelho, Brazilian soprano and guitarist, gave a recital last night at Town Hall. Her interesting program was, as usual, largely devoted to South American folk-songs, but also contained some examples of folklore from Spain and Italy, as well as early classics by Scarlatti and Pergolesi.

KANSAS CITY, Feb. 21 -- The Howard Hughes interests assumed complete control of Transcontinental Western Air today in a managerial shake-up that brought the resignation of Jack Frye, TWA's president since 1934.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 21 -- The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc.; the Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company of Cleveland and the Delaware Power and Light Company of Wilmington filed registration statements today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (UP) -- The text of a statement by Senate; Robert A. Taft announcing his opposition to confirmation of the appointment of David E. Lilienthal as chairman of the United Statet Atomic Energy Commission and of a letter from Dr. Karl T. Compton, president of, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, to Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg endorsing the appointment:

ISHPEMING, Mich., Feb. 21 -- The greatest collection of "riders" seen in this country since the 1932 Olmpic winter games at Lake Placid gathered tonight in this snow-bound northern peninsula iron-mine town, awaiting the national ski jumping championships tomorrow and Sunday.

Eastern ski devotees, many of whom have experienced a disappointing season because of the scarcity of snow until now, look forward to a favorable weekend. Reports from all sectors are highly enthusiastic with conditions ideal from as near by as Manhattan's Central Park to as far off as the Canadian Laurentians.

Gilbert Dodds is a clear favorite in the mile, but there are few other definite stand-outs in the thirteen individual events and three relays of the fifty-ninth annual National A.A.U. indoor track and championships at Madison Square Garden tonight.

The New York Chamber Orchestra, conducted by Charles Adler, gave a concert of eighteenth and early nineteenth century music last night in Carnegie Hall, with an orchestra of forty-three players from the Philharmonic-Symphony and with Artur Schnabel and his son, Karl Ulrich Schnabel, as soloists.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, Congress of Industrial Organizations, clashed today with members of the Senate Labor and Welfare Committee on prices, profits, free enterprise, socialism and "basic freedoms."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 21 -- The United States has submitted to the United Nations Security Council a list of five citizens of small countries for consideration as Governor of the Free Territory of Trieste, it was learned tonight.

Columbus, Ohio Columbus, Ohio, announced yesterday that it would receive bids on March 18 on an issue of $1,200,000 of City School District bonds bearing interest of not more than 2 percent, dated April 1, 1947, and due April 1 from 1949 to 1968.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Feb. 21 -- Almost all of 1,097 Latin Americans in the displaced persons camps in the United States zone were ordered evicted today on instructions from the State Department.

PARIS, Feb 21 -- A last-minute decision by the French Cabinet prevented rival demonstrations tonight by the Communists and their Rightist enemies that the Government feared would lead to a political riot like the sanguinary clash in Place de la Concorde Feb. 6, 1934, that overthrew the Government and bitterly divided France.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: When THE NEW YORK TIMES fails to get the true picture of a public question, there is small hope for the rest of the country as it tries to make our representative American system of government work.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21 -- George A. Eastwood, president of Armour Co. since 1939, was elected today chairman of the board of the meatpacking concern at a meeting of directors which followed the company's annual stockholders' meeting.

BERLIN, Feb. 21 -- Consolidation and partial demilitarization of the United States Military Government was announced today by Lieut. Gen. Lucius D. Clay, Deputy Military Governor. All changes take effect March 15, when General Clay takes over the top authority from Gen. Joseph T. McNarney.

Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania's stay in Havana, Cuba, may be cut short. As long as the one-time vice over-lord remains there Cuba will not receive our shipments of legitimate narcotic drugs, Col. Garland Williams, director of narcotic enforcement in New York for the Treasury Department, declared yesterday.

Milk will drop 1 cent a quart in price here next Saturday, it was indicated yesterday. The cut, coming after a similar reduction on the first of this month, will bring the price to 17 cents a quart in retail stores and 20 cents a quart for home-delivered milk.
To the probable discomfiturs of National League pitchers, Hank Greenberg will wield his big bat for Pittsburgh after all.

The United States Steel Corporation and the Consolidated Steel Corporation have obtained the contract for supplying the pipe for the construction of a pipeline to be built across Arabia by the Trans-Arabian Pipe Line Company, owned by the Arabian American Oil Company, operator of the Saudi Arabian oil concession.

A revolutionary new camera, which turns out a finished picture one minute after the shutter is snapped, was demonstrated last night in the Hotel Pennsylvania at the winter meeting of the Optical Society of America by its inventor, Edwin H. Land, president and director of research of the Polaroid Corporation.

SAIGON, French Indo-China, Feb. 19 (Delayed) -- Press correspondents in Saigon have appealed to Maj. Gen. Jean Valluy, commander of the French forces in the Far East, for amelioration of a censorship that is so drastic and erratic that some correspondents have ceased attempting to file any significant news from Indo-China.

Cotton tufted bedspreads offering geometric patterns in modern color combinations, as well as new versions of colonial designs, will go on display Monday at Macy's. Made by Fieldcrest, they will be shown in bedroom settings in the newly redecorated Plan-A-Home Row on the seventh floor.
With a moderate volume of activity, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 6 to 22 points net higher than the day before, again led by the near months.

Brazil's national economy is moving rapidly forward with no hint of a potential collapse due to inflationary conditions, Pedro Luiz Corres e Casto, Brazilian minister of finance, said in a statement answering charges that Brazil faces financial and economic trouble in the near future.
Earnest pleas for brotherhood and tolerance were broadcast over Station WQXR yesterday and channeled into the city's schools by arrangement with the Board of Education.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- The chances were regarded as slightly better than even here tonight that the British Government would ease the Jewish immigrant quota to Palestine while waiting for the United Nations to rule on the Holy Land's future.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, Feb. 21 -- King George VI made history today, becoming the first British sovereign to open Parliament in any Dominion.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The House, by a voice vote, unanimously approved today a measure authorizing the Secretary of Agriculture to cooperate with the Mexican Government in the control and eradication of foot-and-mouth disease.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- The proposal that new local taxes be authorized to pay a large share of the cost of permanent teacher salary increases was denounced today by the New York State Teachers Association as "the worst piece of chicanery ever played upon the taxpayers, children and teachers."

The State Capital has been a lively spot in the last ten days as Governor Dewey's budget withstood strenuous attacks on it from many sides, and political issues were laid on the line. New York City's Mayor and chief fiscal officer were prominent among the visiting delegates and the target as well as the deliverers of hot charges of "bad faith."

Charging that exporters and better dress manufacturers had bid up rayon piece goods prices more than 250 per cent over former ceilings, low-end and popular price dress manufacturers declared yesterday that they were helpless in meeting consumer demand for quality garments at low prices.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21 (U.P.) -- Consumer resistance against high prices was credited with cutting retail liquor sales by 25 per cent since Jan. 1, but spokesmen said the industry has no plans for a return to pre-war price levels.

LEXINGTON, Va., Feb. 21 (AP) -- One hundred and forty-eight years after his death, a bequest by George Washington still pays about $3 a year toward the tuition fee of each student at Washington and Lee University.

Technical considerations played an important role yesterday in the share market on the New York Stock Exchange when prices made a further recovery effort with liberal help from the airline issues. Some substantial grains were made by a few of the key units, the composite rate managed to rise, although slightly less than a point, and the industrial price average was enlarged almost 1 1/2 points.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 21 -- The after-effects of the profound impact with which Prime Minister Attlee's announcement that by June, 1948, British rule would pass from India struck this capital linger on. Generally, however, his pronouncement seems to have cleared the political atmosphere of numerous abstract arguments and suspicions.

THERE is something rather reassuring about the idea of a novel set in the year 1997. It suggests that there really will be people on this planet half a century from now. That's the stuff you want to hear when the prophets of atomic doom sing their sad songs. But the kind of people H.F. Heard foresees in this futuristic novel, "Doppelgangers,"* are something else again.
LAKE SUCCESS. Feb. 21 -- Except for that of the Commission on the Status of Women, yesterday's meetings of United Nations agencies, including the Security Council, were canceled because of the snow.

Theatregoers will have a busy calendar this week-end. At the Century Theatre this afternoon Donald Wolfit's company will turn to its third production, "The Merchant of Venice," while at the Princess Theatre tomorrow evening the Experimental Theatre will offer "O'Daniel."

By the time Department of Sanitation workers finish battling with New York's biggest snowfall since 1941, they will have hauled away or stuffed down sewe more than three million cubic yards of snow. The total is twice the volume of the 102-story Empire State Building.

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- The crucial problem in Britain's economic crisis, as set forth in the Government White Paper published today, is how to get enough dollars to pay for imports from the United States and other hard-currency countries in the Western Hemisphere.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 21 -- A motorcade and moving-van parade of forty veterans and their families, leaving the homes of their in-laws or other improvised residences for brand-new homes of their own, today marked the rising crescendo of Henry Kaiser's mass-production attack on the housing shortage.

Duell, Sloan Pearce will release "The Official Pictorial History of the AAF," by the Historical Office of the Army Air Forces, on Monday. Containing 600 photographs and full-color illustrations, the volume covers the Air Forces' expansion from the first balloons used in the Civil War to the latest planes and engines.

The International Ice Patrol and the Ice Observation Service will be resumed for 1947 with the sailing of the Coast Guard cutter Mendota within the next few days. The cutter is now being outfitted in Boston.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 21 -- President Truman will be enabled to gratify a personal whim on the morning of Wednesday, March 5, when, as the guest of President Miguel Alemarn, he will fly over Paricutin, Mexico's latter-day volcano which surged up in a corn field four years ago this month
LONDON, Feb. 21 -- The Government's White Paper on the economic domestic position, the Indian crisis and the continued bad weather combined to unsettle the stock markets here today.

Holiday Closings New York's Stock and Curb Exchanges will be closed today in observance of Washington's Birthday. Other financial exchanges and commodity markets of the nation also will suspend trading. The various livestock reports will be issued by the Department of Agriculture.

ROME, Feb. 21 -- Italy took the first step today toward organizing emigration on a rational plan. Rome signed an agreement with the Argentine Government to encourage the steady flow of Italian workers, artisans and technicians to River Plata.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- The International Emergency Food Council announced today world allocations of cocoa beans which will give the United States 258,300 tons for the marketing year ending Sept. 30.

NANKING, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Government dispatches claimed victories or long advances today along a ragged 230-mile front stretching across southern Shantung and into eastern Honan Province in the growing offensive against the Communists.

Prominent Indian Authors Three of Britain's greatest writers of the nineteenth century are closely connected with the India from which the British Government is all set to withdraw after two centuries of domination.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 21 -- A spate of communiques was spread across the columns of the Egyptian press today to reassure domestic and foreign business interests about the government's intentions after the proposed termination of its alliance with Great Britain.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 21 -- The Yankees today concluded a week of preliminary exercises preparatory to the start of their arduous forty-three-game exhibition schedule tomorrow. And only one problem seemed to be puzzling Manager Bucky Harris.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 21 -- President Truman will be enabled to gratify a personal whim on the morning of Wednesday, March 5, when, as the guest of President Miguel Alemarn, he will fly over Paricutin, Mexico's latter-day volcano which surged up in a corn field four years ago this month
LONDON, Feb. 21 -- The Government's White Paper on the economic domestic position, the Indian crisis and the continued bad weather combined to unsettle the stock markets here today.

Holiday Closings New York's Stock and Curb Exchanges will be closed today in observance of Washington's Birthday. Other financial exchanges and commodity markets of the nation also will suspend trading. The various livestock reports will be issued by the Department of Agriculture.

ROME, Feb. 21 -- Italy took the first step today toward organizing emigration on a rational plan. Rome signed an agreement with the Argentine Government to encourage the steady flow of Italian workers, artisans and technicians to River Plata.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- The International Emergency Food Council announced today world allocations of cocoa beans which will give the United States 258,300 tons for the marketing year ending Sept. 30.

NANKING, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Government dispatches claimed victories or long advances today along a ragged 230-mile front stretching across southern Shantung and into eastern Honan Province in the growing offensive against the Communists.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 21 -- Maureen O'Sullivan, absent from the screen since 1942, will resume her career next month as the leading woman in Paramount's "The Big Clock," with Ray Milland and Charles Laughton, the studio announced today. Miss O'Sullivan's last picture was "Tarzan's New York Adventure," produced by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer in 1942, in which she played Jane opposite Johnny Weissmuller's Tarzan; she had previously appeared in five other Tarzan films with Weissmuller.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 21 -- United States proposals to place the former Japanese man-dated islands under United Nations trusteeship will be presented to the Security Council at a special meeting Wednesday afternoon, it was disclosed today.
Pyramiding effects of the worst shortage of boxcars in twenty years have caused slashes in manufacturing output and employment, and brought rationing of space by many daily newspapers.

There is in many sections of this country a growing tendency to ignore the principle that it is improper for the civil service worker to strike against his employer, the people. There is even an effort in some quarters to defend this right to strike. It is argued on one side that civil service law, at least in New York State, forbids the strike and makes it illegal.

Dr. Albert Russell Mann, educator, agricultural economist and a special representative of the War Department, collapsed early last night and died In a corridor of the Hotel Commodore. He had returned earlier in the day aboard the S.S. America from Cherbourg, France.
Yesterday's storm meant different things to skiers, merchants, pedestrians and commuters but the stork had one of the toughest times of all.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21 (AP) -- The United States Circuit Court of Appeals today ordered the Federal District Court to confirm the plan of reorganization of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad Company, which went into bankruptcy June 7, 1933.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The International Emergency Food Council, distributing the limited world supply of sugar for 1947, allocated tonight to the United States a substantially greater amount than it received in 1946.

Carefully avoiding any comment on the recent charge that Dean Street, between Sixth and Carlton Avenues, was "the worst block in Brooklyn," Sixth Deputy Police Commissioner James B. Nolan reported yesterday on conditions there and measures in force to curb juvenile delinquency.

Storm Cuts Retail Volume The snowstorm checked retail trade here this week. Department store volume will show practically no change, compared with a year ago, according to estimates yesterday. Until the blizzard on Thursday, a major selling day of the week, volume had been running ahead by 12 to 13 per cent for several large stores.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 21 -- The Giants are still in the market for a slugging outfielder and a starting pitcher.

A newly acquired portrait of George Washington by Gilbert Stuart occupies the place of honor today in the Entrance Hall of the Brooklyn Museum in celebration both of the first President's birth and the museum's fiftieth anniversary at its present location.

The reconversion of the former Navy attack transport Wayne to a C-2 combination cargo-passenger vessel is scheduled for completion on Monday at Todd Shipyards Corporation's Hoboken division, it was announced yesterday. The ship, renamed the Beauregard, is the second of four similar reconversions to be completed at the Hoboken yard.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your series of articles on the travails of American education seems to be on its way to a high point in journalism.

"A PET he must have, and if the family does not permit a dog he may even resort to a snake. * * * Probably he has started a collection of some kind. * * * He is healthy, busy, full of energy and never looks tidy."

TO THE EDITOR: Governor Arnall won the respect of all who understand the true meaning of government by democracy in his insistence upon constitutional processes in the struggle over the Governorship of Georgia.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- More widespread acceptance of voluntary arbitration as "a substitute for economic force is foreseen by industrial relations experts with the establishment of a panel of 150 arbitrators who have been cleared for competence and impartiality by representatives of labor and management.

BOSTON, Feb. 22 -- The Eastern Dog Club's thirty-fourth show, Boston's smaller counterpart of Westminster, began in Mechanics Building today with several dogs that had been cutting a figure in this month's series of events coming through to breed awards.

HILDA LAWRENCES mystery stories are something to write home about -- if there is a mystery fan in the home who insists on top-drawer stuff. "Blood Upon the Snow" was her first; "Death of a Doll" is the latest and perhaps the best.

FERTILIZER listings are usually relegated to the back pages of the seed and plant catalogues that are arriving in every mail. Much less fascinating to read than the pages about flowers and vegetables, they are nevertheless something the gardener must consider.

MANY people in the United States, in an unemotional and inarticulate way, to be sure, thought the Nazi trials at Nuremberg important. Of course the trials didn't get the play in some papers that the Hall-Mills case did, nor were they pictured as being exotic and exciting as was the Lonergan trial.
CHICAGO, Feb. 22 -- Lawmakers of Central Western States have apparently reached the conclusion that the time has come to make it harder to obtain divorces or harder to remarry following divorce.
OMAHA, Feb. 22 -- Atomic energy is about to go into a new type of harness, this time for the peaceful purpose of improving the Midwest's corn crops.

HAVANA, Feb. 22 -- Adding something to his manifold talents as a baseball player, Dixie Walker has become an inventor. Manager Leo Durocher predicted today that the device created by Walker will be in use throughout the National League this year.

IN his first real one-man show in a decade, Vaclav Vytlacil establishes himself as one of the outstanding exponents of truly contemporary American painting. Along with Nordfeldt, Cowles, Davis, Knaths and others, Vytlacil always starts from nature; always keeps in view the artist's primary problem of deep space organization; always bases his semiabstract compositions on tangible reality.

All records for peacetime transatlantic passenger traffic on American-flag merchant vessels were shattered last year when 1,236,707 military and civilian passengers were carried on Maritime Commission vessels between United States North Atlantic ports and foreign countries, according to a commission report released yesterday.

The first American attempt -- and probably the first attempt anywhere in the world -- to apply atomic energy as a propulsive force for aircraft was formally but quietly started in this country last July and is now well under way, it was learned yesterday.

MORE BIRTHS -- Provisional reports received by the U.S. Public Health Service and the Federal Security Agency indicate that a total of 3,260,000 births were registered in the United States in 1946. The previous high was 2,934,860, recorded in 1943.

LAKE PLACED, N.Y., Feb. 22 (AP) -- Joe Meconi and his Ausable Forks, N.Y., team rode to a split- second halfway-mark lead, today in the North American four-man bobsledding championships. The 36-year-old tavern-keeper drove down the one-mile Mount Van Hoevenberg course in 2 minutes 19 and 22/100 seconds for two heats.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Moscow took most American diplomats somewhat by surprise tonight in pressing its complaint on Under- Secretary of State Acheson's statement that Soviet diplomatic policy is "aggressive and expanding."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Though the supply of fertilizer that will be available in this country will be "unprecedented," it will not be large enough to satisfy all domestic demands, John R. Sttelman, assistant to the President, said tonight in a report on the Government's inter-agency fertilizer program.

An almost untapped market exists in Latin America for American exporters of machinery, construction materials, hardware and electrical equipment, according to an annual survey covering approximately 6,000 trade inquiries which has just been completed by the Council for Inter-American Cooperation.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 22 -- Jamal el Husseini, chairman of the Palestine Arab Higher Committee, stated today that the committee would cooperate with the Arab League in sending joint delegations to the United States to propagate tha Arab viewpoint on Palestine before the future of the country is taken under consideration by the United Nations.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Feb. 22 -- On the second day of their three- day convention here delegates of six citizens groups in the United States which believe that peace can be preserved only by a world Federalist government agreed unanimously today on a name for the new organization they propose and on a statement of beliefs and purposes for the organization.

THE soil, sand, flower pots, labels and assorted paraphernalia that accumulate at this indoor seed-starting season make quite a collection. Sooner or later the gardener begins to think that his hobby rates a email room or, at least, a well- equipped corner.

SHRUBS, small trees or vines that hold their berries into these spring-will-never-come weeks are gay patches of color in gardens, parks and along highways. The showy fruits may be red, orange, bright blue or black, but all seem effective and desirable.

Senator Taft may have waited a little too long before he fired his Friday- night blast at David E. Lilienthal, Presidential nominee to be chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission. The testimony, if it can be called that, which Senator McKellar had produced against Mr. Lilienthal had made the gentleman from Tennessee a national laughing stock.

TEMPERAMENTAL flowers are like their human counterpart. They are likely to be the most interesting of our acquaintances, well worth cultivating, but unpredictable and a bit difficult to live with. Gardeners choosing perennials from the new catalogues ought to be warned about this characteristic.

DETROIT, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Piling up their highest single game score against Bill Durnan in his four seasons as Montreal's netminder, the Detroit Red Wings plastered the National Hockey League's leading Canadiens, 7 to 3, at Olympia tonight to climb within 4 points of fourth place.

President Truman's recommendation that Congress appropriate $350,000,000 to relieve starvation in the liberated countries of Europe lights a hope that was beginning to flicker out. It is notice to the world that the United States will not default the high trust it assumed with victory.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 22 -- In just 2 minutes 1 3/5 seconds of magnificent running -- time that smashed the Hialeah Park record for one mile and a quarter -- the Calumet Farm's great gelding Armed added $43,900 to his earnings in the Widener Handicap today and thus elevated himself from fifth to third place on the world list of money-winning thoroughbreds.

PARIS, Feb. 22 -- Although not many taxes are headed downward in France in these days of financial stringency, the Finance Ministry is considering reducing luxury taxes on restaurants as the only way to get prices down to a point consistent with the hope of an influx of tourists this summer.

IN this short novel by a war veteran, the device of throwing together an oddly assorted group of people, most of them strangers to each other, is used as a means of depicting some of the confusions of the times. Pop McCarthy, a vigorous lecher of 76, runs a roadside tourist camp on the northeast Florida shore.

MANY of the insects that can reduce the vitality of fruit and shade trees can be effectively reduced by a dormant spray within the next six weeks. This treatment is one applied before the buds start to open. Neither the insects nor their larvae are usually obvious at this season of inactive growth but they may be concealed in bark, along twigs or around buds.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: So far, public discussion of the control of armaments has teen absorbed with questions of procedure and method. In an editorial on Feb. 10 THE TIMES brought forward the underlying point of substance: the necessity of some sort of confidence that agreements formally entered into will be carried out in practice.

IT was revealed in the 'papers the other day that Alexis Thompson, the bob-sled driver, had been so thoughtless as to try to go down Lake Placid's Mount Van Hoe enberg chute without his sled. Possibly that's much too cold-blooded and heartless a method saying that Lex and his sled parted company at the treacherous Zig-Zag turn during the Olympic tryouts.

SHERIDAN, the dramatist, is authority for the melancholy fact that "your easy writing's curst hard reading." Stevenson, the stylist, put it another way when he suggested that both the art, and the trick, of successful writing is not merely to affect the reader, but to affect him precisely as you wish.

A few weeks ago the County Commissioners of Allegheny County, Pa., were nonplussed when several residents of the county who were obviously not indigent began to request permission for admittance to Woodville, the County Home, eight miles from Pittsburgh.
IN THE AGE group between 25 and 29, 39 per cent of the men in the United States are unmarried; in Eire, 80 per cent of the men in this group are unmarried.

YENAN, China, Feb. 22 (U.P.) -- Gen. Chou En-lai, who occupies a position in Red China comparable to that of Foreign Minister, said today that the Communists from now on were working out their own problems without any foreign mediation -- from Russia, Britain, the United States or any other country.

WHAT appears to be a marked sponsor reaction against the high budgeted radio package show seems to be in the making with a number of advertisers already serving notice that they will not renew sponsorship after the end of the current season.

Queens College conferred baccalaureate degrees last night on 180 graduates, representing the classes of September, 1946, and February, 1947, at commencement exercises in the Hunter College auditorium, 695 Park Avenue. Fifteen hundred persons witnessed the ceremonies, which were held at Hunter College because of limited auditorium space at Queens College, 65-30 Kissena Boulevard, Flushing.

TO THE EDITOR: I read with interest the debate, "Closed Shop or Open Shop," until I came to William Green's statement that the trade union movement is always open to new recruits, and that sometimes attempts are made to confuse the public mind by representing the closed shop as a closed union, which bars new members.
MOSCOW, Feb. 22 -- The first drops of information were sprinkled this week by the "Voice of America" broadcasts to the Soviet Union.
TOPEKA, Kan., Feb. 22 (U.P) -- Mayor William O'Dwyer of New York told Kansas Democrats tonight that the success of the United Nations was the first problem of this country.

Construction of the first three buildings of the proposed New York University-Bellevue Medical Center will not start until the beginning of 1948 at the earliest, Currier McEwen, dean of the university's College of Medicine, said yesterday in announcing that $4,500,000 of the $15,000,000 goal had been raised.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 22 -- Winning six of the twelve events contested, and gaining a tie in another, the favored Harvard University track team defeated Yale, 55 to 45, in an indoor meet at the Coxe Memorial Cage here today.
Government regulations continue to favor production of small homes which are offered for sale, while the prime need of the moment is more apartments or rental housing in the moderate price range.
The Veterans Administration is developing a code of minimum construction standards to help appraisers in their work of protecting veterans against bad housing investments, it became known yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 22 -- Architectural plans for the future world capital along the East River in New York have developed so rapidly, it was learned today, that United Nations officials profess to believe that they may be able to hold the 1948 sessions of the General Assembly in the skyscraper headquarters.
XOCHIMILCO, Mexico, Feb. 22 -- For the first time since the Aztec queens wielded plumed scepter, two women were entrusted today with running municipal governments in Mexico.

Maurice Wilk, violinist of this city, gave a recital last night at Town Hall. His exacting program comprised Bach's Prelude in C minor in Mr. Wilk's own arrangement; Schumann's Sonata in A minor; the Sonata by Ernest Bloch; Ysaye's unaccompanied "Ballade;" Op. 27, No. 3; Alan Shulman's "Suite on American Folk Themes," and the Seguidilla and Gypsy Dance from Sarasate's "Carmen Fantasie."

APRIL 10 will be the centenary of the birth of Joseph Pulitzer, Hungarian-born American newspaper editor and proprietor, and it was announced by Postmaster General Robert E. Hannegan last week that a commemorative 3-cent stamp will be released on that date in recognition of Pulitzer's contribution to "freedom of expression and freedom of thought in America."

KEY WEST, Fla. -- This city of 20,000, midway between the Atlantic Ocean and the Gulf of Mexico at the end of the, 160-mile overseas highway, is waiting for manana. That will be about August or September, when the Key West-Havana car ferry service, closed since pre-war days, is resumed by the Carib Queen, a converted landing ship that will carry 250 automobiles and trucks and 900 passengers on the ninety-mile international run to Cuba.

Although a difference of opinion is reputed to be required for the running of a horse race, it has accomplished very little toward bringing about a solution of the problems encountered in the restocking of game birds.

MEXICO CITY -- Mexico is winding up an excellent winter season from the standpoint of both the throngs of Americans who have converged on the capital, and of the hotels, restaurants, gift shops and tourist agencies who profit from their coming.

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- Political opposition to the British Government's one-year plan for increasing exports and industrial production began to take shape today, with Conservatives and Liberals, and even some Left-Wing Laborites, attacking the scheme.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Continuing anti-Semitism and the failure to restore Nazi-confiscated property to its former owners has seriously aggravated the condition of European Jews, Henry Morgenthau Jr. declared tonight in announcing the campaign of the United Jewish Appeal to raise $170,000,000.

HOLLYWOOD. MEMO to the boys on Dream Street: A considerable number of Hollywood citizens, not discernibly employed, have managed to keep their names in print since Free Money came to town by announcing a series of independent motion picture productions variously described as certain to revolutionize the industry, elevate the culture of the world and send old-line studio producers hastily into the crying towel business.

I WANT to make a testimonial, unblushing and unsolicited, a public avowal of the rightness of the Experimental Theatre. My testimonial comes fresh from the four weeks of hectic labor that went into the first Experimental Theatre production.

ATLANTA, Feb. 22 -- Georgia's white primary law was denounced today by the interdenominational Atlanta Christian Council as a violation of the "American principle of no taxation without representation."

SAIGON, Cochin China, Indo- China, Feb. 22 -- While the Viet Namese reject the possibility of a military surrender, Ho Chi Minh's rebel government is ready to consider peace with France "on terms of mutual justice," an Annamese underground resistance leader in Saigon said today.

HERFORD, Germany, Feb. 22 -- Spurred by an official report that described one of every ten Germans in the British zone as an "unregenerate Nazi," high British Military Government authorities are studying a new propaganda campaign to shock the German people into the realization that they are responsible for the conditions under which they are now living.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Three plant foremen argued today against unionization of supervisory employes, while a shopworker asked Congress to outlaw requirements for union membership generally.

Admiral Thomas C. Kinkaid, Commander of the Eastern Sea Frontier, said last night that the future security of the United States is dependent upon adequate armed forces, workable plans for immediate mobilization, an intensive scientific research and development program and a sensitive intelligence system.
BERLIN, Feb. 22 -- Nine United States educators have arrived here to assist the Germans in revamping their educational system.

Home financing by member savings and loan associations of the Federal Home Loan Bank System rose to approximately $3,322,000,000 in 1946, Harold Lee, governor of the system, reported yesterday. This amount was 90 per cent more than in 1945 and above the amount loaned during the three pre-war years of 1939, 1940 and 1941 combined.

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- Generalissimo Stalin called on the Soviet Army tonight to intensify its political education as well as military training. He said this was demanded "for the sake of insuring the security of our Motherland."

WEST VIRGINIA -- Veterans' Town West Virginia University's settlement for more than 200 student-veterans, their wives and children is soon to have its own grocery store, recreation hall and nursery. One of two Army Quonset huts received this month from the Federal Works Agency will be used for the thriving GI community.

O VIDEO, reporter of his day, writing to Charles V of Spain in 1526, in connection with a visit to the New World, said: "There are pears which are unlike pears, similar to butter and very good eating and of good taste."
On Jan. 10 President Truman sent to Congress his budget for the fiscal year 1947-48. It called for expenditures of $37.5 billion, divided into these broad categories:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Pro- Communists in the Congress of Industrial Organizations are being pushed back, but they are not in full retreat.

The new Ellerman's Wilson Line freighter Marengo has been launched at Walker-on-Tyne, England, and should be ready for service between New York and England in May, according to cable advices received by the company's New York agents.

An alarming deterioration of the "will to peace" in this country was noted here yesterday by Archibald MacLeish, United States representative on the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.
The season in racquets ended yesterday with another cup going to England.

TWENTY-FIVE years ago a fierce and protracted controversy was raging over the revision of American historical texts. The first World War had called attention to the bias and inaccuracy of many widely used books; Owen Wister had made his memorable appeal for replacing ancient grudges by "a straight deal"; and authors were striving for a new objectivity. Their work, appearing at a time when the League battle had stimulated nationalist feeling, aroused instant antagonism.

Far Rockaway High School's rifle team recaptured its metropolitan title in the third annual Public High School rifle tournament yesterday at the City College range. The Long Island school was awarded trophies by the C.G.N.Y. Reserve Officers Training Corps and the Greater New York Marine Corps League, joint sponsors of the shoot.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 21 (Delayed) -- A Yugoslav Parliament member who has switched his allegiance from the National Front of which he was secretary was badly beaten eight days ago by what friends termed a "Communist youth group," it was learned tonight.

Sharp, gusty winds that churned unshoveled snow into new drifts and freezing temperatures that turned partly cleared surfaces to brittle ice added yesterday to New York's troubles following the season's heaviest snow fall.

The refusal of the country's top labor leaders, in testifying last week before the Senate committee on labor matters, to make any compromise with the public demand for reforms, has raised anew the question of what, in addition to new legislation, the Government can do to promote labor-management cooperation for industrial peace.

HOLLYWOOD. BARBARA BEL GEDDES, erstwhile habitue of Walgreen's drug store and other clots of Broadway theatrical frustration, is basking in the anticlimactic serenity of one who has just succeeded in balancing fifteen beer bottles on top of each other.

KRYPTAR, a new panchromatic -type rollfilm, is announced by Technifinish Laboratory, Inc., Rochester. The film, available in sizes 127, 620, 120, 616 and 116, has an exposure index of 50, with a tungsten rating of 32.
Approval of the State's program for building additional low-cost public housing to the extent of $300,000,000 was expressed by the Citizens Union yesterday through its committee on legislation.

TOPEKA, Kan., Feb. 22 (AP) -- Mayor William O'Dwyer of New York expressed "unalterable opposition" to restrictive labor legislation in a speech tonight before Kansas Democrats at the party's annual Washington Day dinner.

Wages of virtually all French workers, including Government employes, are fixed by governmental decree. The latest rates were established last summer, covered 20,390,000 persons, raised incomes an average 18 per cent. Wages are still inadequate in France because living costs over the last nine years have risen almost twice as fast as salaries.

The prospect of substantial replenishment of the supply of State and municipal bonds through the marketing of bonus issues for soldiers and the financing of long- deferred local government improvements is bringing into play a new influence in the bond market.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 22 -- In a hotly contested basketball engagement which saw the lead change hands eight times, Yale kept its three-year mastery over Princeton in major sports by downing the Tiger quintet, 57 -- 54, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game before 4,000 fans in Baker Rink this afternoon.

OTTAWA. To most Americans the people who live north of the Forty-ninth Parallel are fellow-Americans who, oddly, and to some irritatingly, are still subjects of the King of England. Canada puzzles them. They think it should be "free ," by which they frequently mean that it should cut all its ties with Europe and link its fortunes solely to this continent.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 22 -- Balance. Deeper Resourcefulness. Speed. These are the potentials Mel Ott sees in his Giants' squad under training here as he starts his sixth year at the helm of New York's National League club. They are the things with which he is seeking to pull out of the doldrums the club on which he is starting his twenty - second consecutive year.

Nearly 500 mortgage and commercial bankers, realty men, insurance executives, builders and title and trust company officials from all parts of the country are expected to attend the "clinic and forum" of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America to be held on Friday and Saturday at the Drake Hotel, in Chicago.

LITTLE AMERICA, Feb. 22 -- A few men of the Navy Antarctic party here crawled out of the snow tunnels from their tents before midnight last night to see curling clouds redden in the north and the sun dip briefly below the southern horizon for the first time in 1947.
Renewing the fight for Federal aid to education, members of Congress have introduced ten important bills designed to help the schools and raise teachers' salaries. More bills are on the way.

With Charlie Slade, 19-year-old Negro, capturing four firsts, and Phil Thigpen, crack distance star, triumphing in two, Seton Hail Prep's trackmen, of South Orange, N.J., easily carried off top honors in the prep school division of the National A.A.U. schoolboy track and field championships at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Unlike the chain reaction that started the atomic age, the operation of the United States Atomic Energy Commission these days is not what might be called sustained. David E. Lilienthal and his four fellow Commissioners have a decidedly fitful business schedule while their fitness is being debated on Capitol Hill.

The New York Academy of Medicine will observe its 100th anniversary with a series of meetings during the next two months. The celebration will start with a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on March 6 at which Dr. John A. Ryle, Professor of Social Medicine of Oxford University, will discuss "Social Pathology and the New Era in Medicine."

In these tumultuous latter days change sweeps in almost melodramatic pageantry over that world-straddling institution which Winston Churchill refuses to call by any other name than the British Empire. A great-grandson of Queen and Empress Victoria is named to be the last Viceroy before Britain relinquishes domination over India.

ROCKFORD, Ill., Feb. 22 -- Dr. Enrico Fermi, famous nuclear physicist of the University of Chicago, warned today the United States atomic research was almost at a standstill and said he did not think the nation could pay the price of further delay in the choice of a chairman for the Atomic Energy Commission.

If the steel industry can operate throughout 1947 at the high rate accomplished in the first seven weeks of this year, consumers will receive as much as 16 per cent more finished steel than was shipped in 1941, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

The worst boxcar shortage in twenty years slowly tightened its throttling grip on American industry yesterday as representatives of the nation's railroads, steel companies, rail car builders and Government agencies sought some solution to the critical situation.

THERE is a minor strain of mystery and fantasy running through Robert Briffault's "New Life of Mr. Martin." But the strain is only minor, and the novel remains in the tradition Mr. Briffault began in 1935 with "Europa" -- a novel concerned with the decline of European civilization, the hypocrisy of national and international politics, and the dolorous state of the relations between man and woman.

PRAGUE, Feb. 22 -- The Amateur Hockey Association of the United States was admitted to membership in the Ligue Internationale de Hockey sur Glace and the A.A.U. was voted out today after a bitter five-hour debate that may affect United States participation in the winter Olympic games next year.

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- Neither the chill and discomforts nor the long period of involuntary idleness forced upon the average Briton by the fuel crisis of the last two weeks have swerved his loyalty to the Labor Government, in the opinion of leaders of the Labor party here today.

TO THE EDITOR: RECENTLY while reading the Magazine article, "Swastikas on the Scrap Heap," about the conversion of Nazi uniforms, pennants, medallions, etc., to peacetime, democratic uses, it occurred to me that you might be interested in the story of a young woman I know.

IF there is one "greatest difference" between the strong bridge game and the average bridge game, it is in the use and frequency of penalty doubles. In the average game, moderate overbidding is seldom punished. The average player almost never doubles a low contract, seldom doubles anything on a weak-looking hand, but is apt to double a high contract on "general principles."

The world's first supersonic laboratory equipment to duplicate conditions that prevail 100 miles above the earth is now under construction at the University of California with the financial aid of the Office of Naval Research.
BERLIN, Feb. 22 -- The pro- Nazi underground movement again is harassing the Allied Military Governments despite the common belief that it does not exist on a national basis.

Some reorders were received on coats, suits and handbags, but generally mail orders were light and buying slow last week, according to a market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.

FURTHER to complicate the already complicated problem of the spring ballet season, another company has now entered the field. This is the Ballets des Champs-Elysees, which Michael Todd is bringing over from Paris.

ISHPEMING, Mich., Feb. 22 -- A driving northwest wind that threatened to blow the "riders" off the mountainside forced the postponement today of the national senior and junior ski jumping championships. It was the first time since the title games were instituted here in 1904 that such action had to be taken.

PERHAPS the New York Botanical Garden might more appropriately have arranged as its benefit a big group exhibition of paintings of flowers, running the full gamut from literal representation to abstraction. It would have been interesting thematically and instructive from the point of view of artists' approaches and methods.

In one of the closest contests in the 20 years of the Vanderbilt Cup bridge tournament, the team of four led by Harry Fishbein of Net York won last night at the Hotel Pierre with a leader of 1,510 points in a fifty-six-board final round.

EIGHTY-EIGHT years ago a man named Drake appeared in Titusville, Pa., with the odd notion that he could extract oil from rock. The drill bit into the earth, the farmers snickered, and one day in 1859 there poured from Drake's first well a slimy green liquid that has changed the face of America, powered a world war, and written ugly history in places far removed from Titusville, Pa.

ATHENS, Feb. 22 -- A special team of the United Nations Inquiry Commission visiting the island of Syra examined a representative group of refugees from the northern neighbor countries accused by Greece of fomenting internal strife, a report said today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Housing Expediter Frank R. Creedon predicted tonight the 1947 housing effort would find building costs lower but might hit a "major bottleneck" in a shortage of labor.

CHICAGO, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 500 head (estimated): total not given. Compared with week ago: Barrows and gilts, $1 to $1.50 higher; weights above 260 pounds up most; sows, $2 higher.

Prompted by urgent needs for production materials, informal conversations have been held by industrial executives here on launching a "National Metals Recovery Drive" to stimulate the flow of copper, steel and iron scrap to melting furnaces.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The cut in funds for the Office of Price Administration and the Civilian Production Administration, voted Wednesday by the House, would end the administration of rent control and sugar rationing if finally enacted, Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming said today.

Harold E. Stasaen, former Governor of Minnesota and avowed candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1948, left La Guardia Field last night aboard a Pan American World Airways clipper for Brussels, Belgium, the first stop on a two-month tour of Europe.

Billy Rand's superb near-side shot with one minute left enabled the Squadron A regulars to top Al Parsells' favored Ramapo Polo Club side, 10 to 9, in the main match of the indoor double-header at the Squadron A Armory last night.

IN a previous Sunday music column there was discussion of a question raised by Prof. Douglas Moore in an issue of The Saturday Review claiming in substance that American composers were not given equal opportunity on orchestral and other programs with composers of other nations and that "foreign" conductors of leading American orchestras were not congenitally disposed to give works by native composers a proportionate showing with their audiences.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 22 -- Outclassing Army's basketball team from beginning to end, Fordham earned a decisive victory in the West Point Field House today, 69 to 52. The cadets suffered their worst defeat of the season.
A 1,000-POUND COW inhales approximately 7,000 bushels, or three and a half tons, of air a day.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 22 -- Dr. Robert P. Knight of Topeka, Kan., has been named medical director of the Austen Riggs Foundation here, Ernest Stauffen Jr., chairman of the board of trustees, announced today. The foundation maintains a voluntary hospital and clinic for the study and treatment of psychoneuroses and the training of psychiatrists.
PARIS, Feb. 22 -- The Viet Nam radio today declared that the Viet Nam Government would refuse to deal with an "imperialist clique" in France.

ALBANY, Feb. 22 -- Dr. Arvie Eldred, executive secretary of the New York State Teachers Association, said today that he has "a strong hunch" that the threatened strike of Buffalo teachers for higher salaries will be averted.

CHICAGO. ALTHOUGH the Chicago play reviewers paid many a fine compliment to Louis Calhern after his opening in "The Magnificent Yankee" at the Erlanger, they said so many cutting things about the play itself that Producer Arthur Hopkins was moved to remark, "The Chicago critics are the Gromykos of the American, theatre."

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 22 -- The Communist party's wish, to destroy the roots of the old European class society has brought a victory to advocates here of the American public school system after a struggle of twenty-five years.

Of timely interest to engineers and others who have started a movement against air pollution in New York City were a number of suggestions on smoke abatement made by Professor Raymond R. Tucker, head of the School of Mechanical Engineering of Washington University, St. Louis, at a meeting here last week of the New York Chapter of the American Society of Heating and Ventilating Engineers.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22 -- For the first time since 1942 Temple defeated New York University at Convention Hall tonight, 70 -- 67, in the second game of the final basketball doubleheader here before 6,231 cheering fans.

The new home center sponsored by Rossbach Homes, Inc., in the blocks bounded by Seventy-first and Seventy-fifth Avenues, 161st and 166th Streets, in Kew Gardens, Queens, continues to expand and work soon will be pressed on the fourth unit of thirty-eight attached houses for which plans have just been filed with the Department of Housing and Buildings.

ALTHOUGH the American Repertory Theatre had to abandon its repertory schedule after last night's performance of "Androcles and the Lion," it has achieved something unprecedented in New York. It has aroused a feeling of responsibility throughout the theatrical profession, as well as among its friends.

MARTHA GRAHAM and her company open their engagement of eight performances at the Ziegfeld Theatre tomorrow evening. May O'Donnell, Pearl Lang and Erick Hawkins are featured dancers, and Louis Horst conducts the orchestra as usual.

CHICAGO -- Never before in the history of the country has the need for improvement and expansion of the national highway system been so urgent as at the present time, Commissioner Thomas H. MacDonald, United States Public Roads Administration, told the American Road Builders Association convention here last week.

BOSTON, Feb. 22 -- After long wartime service for the Federal Government, radio station WRUL of the World Wide Broadcasting Foundation, Inc., will be rededicated to educational endeavor next week. It also will lend its services to the United Nations for programs from Lake Success, N.Y.

Approval of seven measures termed "vital to improving housing conditions in New York City," has been voted by the committee on housing of the Community Service Society following an analysis of forty additional housing measures introduced during the last two weeks in the State Legislature, it was announced yesterday.

THE nuclear fission season opened formally on the screen last week when Metro elaborately landed the biggest film on the subject yet, its atomic Loch Ness monster, "The Beginning or the End." For months, this prodigious creation had been swirling in that studio's inland a, enclosed by the most profound attendance and the most intriguing of official hush-hush.

BOSTON. OPERA in "American," in an unstilted, idiomatic English familiar to American ears, is filling Jordan Hall here with audiences whose traditional conservatism has made this city a testing place of theatrical enterprise.

QUEBEC -- Winter sports enthusiasts who spend their vacations and week-ends in this Old World city get a double holiday -- they can enjoy excellent skiing and they can make a typical tourist's sightseeing tour on the same trip.

ABOARD THE ROYAL TRAIN, South Africa, Feb. 22 -- The first day of King George VT's trip through the rural sections of South Africa indicated that the journey would be a homey and familiar one. By April 20 he will have visited some thirty-five townships and covered 5,000 miles by rail.

More than 6,000 home builders and community planners, real estate men and home-equipment manufacturers will attend the annual convention of the National Association of Home Builders, being held this week at the Stevens Hotel in Chicago.

Heavy backlogs of orders and favorable production prospects point to a good volume of business through the first half of the year, members of the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents disclosed in their monthly summary released today.
Goucher College, the oldest accredited college for women south, of the Mason and Dixon Line, is rushing plans to move from its campus in Baltimore to a 421-acre site seven miles north of the city.

To the Screen Editor: THE difficulties of the public in trying to obtain reservations for film showings at the Museum of Modern Art have been experienced by my wife and myself who are members of the museum.

City College's eleventh triumph of the season was a topheavy 76-57 rout of Manhattan College before a turnout of 2,500 persons on the neutral Fordham University gymnasium floor last night. Following the mediocre showing that the Beavers made against Niagara in their last start, the victors enjoyed smooth sailing against the out- manned Jaspers.

JUST how much cooperation from show business Actors Equity will be able to count on in its campaign to rectify the discrimination situation in Washington's National Theatre should be clarified this week.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 22 -- Original wooden models of an improved plow invented by Thomas Jefferson at the end of the eighteenth century have been discovered in Paris, it was announced here today. The Jefferson plow has been described as "the last great fundamental development" before the advent of the metal plow about 1840.

HOLLYWOOD. THE existence of a serious slump in motion picture production was recognized last week by both management spokesmen and labor representatives. The business agent for the local teamsters union gauged the present over-all unemployment in the industry at 6,000, while the film laboratory technicians' business agent estimated recent layoffs at 4,000.

Recognizing New York City's problem in absorption of the large number of Puerto Ricans arriving here daily, the Puerto Rican insular government is planning to show graphically to would-be migrators that New York may not be the "port of opportunity" that they expect, Leonard Sussman, director of information in New York for Puerto Rico, reported yesterday.

The blizzard which hit New Tork Thursday afternoon checked trade expansion here last week. Department store sales, it was estimated, would show practically no change from last year's levels. Prior to the storm, however, volume had been running better than 10 to 12 per cent ahead for the week.

UNDER title of "Social Art Today" an exhibition at the A.C.A. Gallery groups work by sixteen painters and sculptors. Herman Baron, director, declares in a foreword to the catalogue -- and the show bears him out -- that social painting has undergone a sea change since the depression, with protest and propaganda turning to true esthetic concept to make its point effectively.

JOHN P. MOLLOY is one of the few men in town who get paid for backseat driving, who cut the wheel to the right when their vehicles make left turns, stop traffic anywhere in Times Square and ignore red lights with police approval.

AN absorbing study of what makes a criminal is the theme of an unusual and, by radio standards, courageous series of programs now being offered at 7:30 P.M. Sunday evenings over WQXR and, out of town, on Thursday nights over the Mutual network.

HAVANA, Feb. 22 -- Cuban secret police today arrested Charles "Lucky" Luciano, former New York vice overlord, soon after he left his luxurious home in the Miramar residential area with two bodyguards.

CAIRO, Feb. 22 -- Great Britain and the rest of the world should not labor under the delusion that referring the Palestine problem to the United Nations is synonymous with obtaining a prompt and effective settlement of it. There is no such belief in the Middle East.

SEVERAL weeks ago Jose Ferrer, star and producer of "Cyrano de Bergerac," set aside two performances of the Rostand classic in which he and his principals exchanged places with their understudies. The beau geste, without exact parallel, was designed to give understudies a chance to perform not only for the public but also for the people on whom their careers depend -- managers, agents, talent scouts, directors and critics.

Message to the Russians Moscow listeners to our first State Department broadcasts are reported to have found the program a bit on the highbrow side. It sounds odd at first to have Moscow detect too much intellectualism in American publicity, considering the very solid, not to say ponderous, character of Soviet newspapers, magazines and radio discussions.

TO THE EDITOR: John Gould's reaction to "Jingle Bells" in " 'Oh, What Fun It Is' -- Oh Yeah?" is pessimistic for good and sufficient reasons. As he tells it, the one- horse open sleigh experience was limited to the small boy when the grim necessity of restocking the family larder necessitated stirring and hazardous trips to town regardless of the weather.

Zone delivered price systems came under renewed attack from the Federal Trade Commission last week when the commission issued two complaints against manufacturers of vitrified sewer pipe. This action was taken by the Federal Trade Commission, despite a recent unfavorable decision from the United States Court of Appeals on the cement case.
THE bird feeding stations are humming these days, especially in sections where natural food is scarce. Among the most numerous visitors are sparrows.

IN 1940, when the third and last volume of selections from the mid-Victorian diary of the Rev. Francis Kilvert was printed in England, there was full critical agreement that his name could be listed in the exalted company of Evelyn and Pepys, the Woodfordes, Fanny Burney anrt Dorothy Wordsworth.

Mail order companies, with a 53.1 per cent rise in sales, led in percentage gains in retail trade last year, according to analysis of more complete figures recently available on distribution volume. Department stores, as a major classification, ranked second, with a rise of about 33 per cent.

MILWAUKEE, Feb. 22 -- Michael J. Cleary, president of the Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company, a member of the Board of Regents of the University of Wisconsin and of the Board of Governors of Marquette University, died here today of a heart attack in his home, 3032 N. Summit Avenue.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 22 (AP) -- Monsoon, C.V. Whitney's stretch- running gray mare, ran away from a crack field in the final furlong to breeze to a three-length triumph today in the $50,000 added mile and one-sixteenth Santa Margarita Handicap.

Even before World War II Europe -- from the rich black-soil belt of the Ukraine to the orchards of France -- was not able to produce enough food for all its needs. The area as a whole was abbut 89 per cent self-sufficient.

THE dry air of overheated apartments limits most city gardeners to a choice of cacti and succulents for plant decoration. But when circumstances ruled that Mr. and Mrs. Louis J. Kuester exchange their successful suburban garden for the window sills of a New York apartment, they were determined they wouldn't live in a miniature Sahara.

TOWARD the further alerting of the public to the social responsibilities of the screen -- a most urgent consideration in this critical day and age -- Ruth A. Inglis, the research assistant to the director of the Commission on Freedom of the Press, has made a valued contribution in her eagerly awaited report, "Freedom of the Movies," which deserves careful reading and thought.

The Greater New York Fund, which aids 423 local hospitals, health and welfare organizations, will initiate its tenth annual campaign under the chairmanship of Frederick M. Warburg at a dinner in the Hotel Astor on April 29, it was announced yesterday. The campaign will continue through May.

The National Sportsmen's Show will conclude its nine-day run at Grand Central Palace tonight, after running up the largest attendance, record in the history of the exposition. By tomorrow morning truckloads of animals, fish, birds, guides and Indians will be moving toward Albany.

THANKS to shortages and the whims of fashion, vests may be headed for Valhalla. Style-conscious young men partial to pullover sweaters started the trend before the war, and in 1942 the War Production Board abetted the decline of waistcoats by forbidding their manufacture with double-breasted suits (which comprise 43 per cent of all suits manufactured).

Article III, Section 10 of the New York State Constitution nays of the Legislature: "The doors of both Houses shall be kept open, except when the public welfare shall require secrecy." In Albany last week this sentence figured in a bitter political dispute.

New York business men will have their first opportunity this week to present their views on the proposed International Trade Organization which is being planned as part of the United Nations organization for the purpose of smoothing out the difficulties and guiding the future course of international trade.

JOHN GART is what one might title an emotional pied piper. The hour seldom passes when the musical mood doesn't hang heavy over him. He has been known to come out of deep slumber to reach for pen and paper to scrawl theme and improvisation -- without benefit of piano.

AN outstanding quality of this volume is an evident effort of John Tebbel to resist the temptation that besets liberal writers when dealing with Col. Robert R. McCormick of Chicago, Mrs. Eleanor Patterson of Washington and the late Joseph Medill Patterson of New York, and the newspapers which they have dominated for many years.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Strikers cannot expect the Wagner Act to save their jobs when the purpose of their strike is to force an employer to violate the act.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 22 -- Leading by 6 -- 2 going into the final period, the Yale sextet had to hold off a determined Dartmouth rally in the final session to win, 6 -- 5, before a capacity crowd at the arena tonight.

"IS popcorn here to stay?" That's the $64 question being bounced back and forth by the nation's motion- picture theatre operators at the moment. Some say yes, some say no and some say maybe. But whether popcorn stays or goes, the fact is that the sale of the crunchy stuff in movie houses has reached astronomical proportions.

JUST twenty-five years ago this week in this Review: Page 1 carries the head, "Keep the Pot A-Boiling," and the article is written by an anonymous author who signs himself "A. Pot- Boiler Maker." Seems the potboiler maker was a soldier, lawyer, professional ball player and real estate man, and a pretty hard-headed fellow to boot.

ALMOST 132 years ago the Emperor Napoleon, first of those two modern conquerors who sought to unite all of Europe under the hegemony of a master race, met his final defeat upon the plain near Waterloo; whereupon his empire, which also was to have lasted 1,000 years, dissolved amid the acrid smell of gunpowder, and vanished without many traces.

IMPRESSIVE for its size, the twenty-second annual convention and trade show of the Master Photo Dealers and Finishers Association, held recently in Cleveland, had significance chiefly because of the evidence it gave of a vital, inventive and enthusiastic industry, and of its unbounded confidence in the future.

IT is time we faced the fact that we do not really live in the Temperate Zone. Our gardens are subject to every variety of climate -- to sudden assaults, now arctic, now tropic -- and to alternating conditions of desert and swamp.

The completion of 58,000 new permanent homes in December, which was more than for any other month in 1946, brought the total number completed during the year to approximately 454,000, the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the United States Department of Labor, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The lend-lease program advanced slightly toward a practical ending last week when the Soviet Union was reported to have promised to "look into" the question of casting up its accounts.

MANILA, Feb. 21 -- President Manuel Roxas and his Liberal party this week launched the most intensive political campaign since last year's Presidential elections to convince Filipino voters that they must change the Constitution in the national plebiscite on March 11 to give Americans equal rights in the development of Philippine resources and the operation of public utilities.

Efficiency of production in the textile industry up to now has been underrated as a factor to offset high labor, material and overhead costs, according to textile engineers last week. In a survey of the extent of plant modernizations, the engineers reported that more than 5300,000,000 will be spent in the next few years to improve textile output.

IF you use the telephone just for conversation, you don't know what you're missing. Your nickel also can bring you lullabies, eye-openers, sermons, hyena laughs and a variety of miscellaneous items ranging from the whereabouts of Frank Sinatra to the proper place to buy blackberries when they're green.

TORONTO, Feb. 22 -- Toronto's scrappy young team was forced to the limit tonight to score a 2-0 victory over the roisterous New York Rangers in a National Hockey League battle that concluded with nine minor penalties and three majors being handed but in the last period at Maple Leaf Gardens.

BUFFALO, Feb. 22 -- Neither Buffalo nor the State made a move today to avert the proposed teachers' strike Monday under auspices of the Buffalo Teachers Federation, and tonight its president, Raymond J. Ast, said that the "teachers are firmly determined to absent themselves from duty to seek a living wage."

Yale defeated Columbia's swimming team, 66 to 9, and the fencing team, 14 to 13, at Morningside Heights yesterday. The triumph was the ninth this year for Yale's undefeated swimmers, while the swordsmen's victory was their first in four attempts.

MANY times in his thirty-odd years Toru Matsumoto has experienced the bitter meaning of the old Japanese proverb he took as the title for his autobiography. As a student in Japan he was imprisoned and beaten by the police (to this day his hearing is impaired) because they suspected him of communism.

TO review a book that encompasses so many thousands of other books, a work of reference which ought to be tested by actual use, presupposes omniscience and leisure -- two blessings which this particular reviewer can only covet.

PNOM-PENH, Cambodia, Indo- China, Feb. 16 (Delayed) -- Both French and Cambodian officials interviewed here regard the present unrest in Cambodia as a continuation of the war with Siam. This has been going on almost constantly for thirteen centuries.

RICHMOND, Feb. 22 -- The violent and all-too-familiar tragedy of "lynch law" was re-enacted in the South this week, giving the country its first lynching in 1947 and causing worry among many officials.
