BRUSSELS, Feb. 22 -- Famine in all its hideousness has not yet spread over Europe and probably will not. Made wise by unhappy experiences of the past, the world prepared for a food crisis long before the war had ended.

The New York Stock Exchange and its member firms, having disposed of the vexatious matter of permissive incorporation for the nonce at least, are preparing to tackle two equally delicate issues -- proposals to revise rates of commissions and to change trading hours.

HERE is a first novel which measures up fully to its author's own specifications; it turns out to be exactly what Mr. Mitchell declares in advance it is to be. Furthermore, it is a piece of brilliantly sustained prose, a very beautiful, keen, perceptive rendering of human beings engaged in the ordinary yet profoundly -- almost mysteriously -- meaningful drama of every day.

THE only woman reporter on Hungary's largest newspaper, Magyarorszag, was assigned to America in April, 1939, as World's Fair correspondent. In January of the following year she was invited by the late Erno Rapee, Hungarian-born conductor of the Radio City Music Hall orchestra, to attend his Sunday noon radio concert so she could describe for Budapest readers how music was made for an audience of millions of invisible listeners by one of their own countrymen.

America may soon be moving mountains on cross-country conveyor belts -- coal and iron ore to steel furnaces; dirt for earth-fill dams; sand, gravel and cement to other construction jobs; almost anything in large tonnages, from hot coke to fruits and vegetables -- according to The Associated Press.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- While interest in labor legislation generally appears to be focused on Congress, organized labor actually is fighting defensive battles in most of the States, too.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 22 -- The Mediterranean will be crowded with unauthorized immigrant ships unless something is done immediately to relieve the situation of displaced persons now in Europe, according to Rabbi Barnett R. Brickner of Cleveland, who has just completed a tour of displaced persons camps.

LONDON, Feb. 22 (Reuters) -- Snow was brushed from scores of British football fields to entertain crowds up to 35,000 today, but continuation of bitter winter postponed many games and threw the English championships into confusion.

A committee of sixteen leaders of ten Christian churches and five church-allied organizations approved unanimously yesterday a statement that "the supreme moral test of Christians of our time is in their thoughts and works in the field of Soviet-American relations."

Autograph letters, manuscripts and documents from the collection of Charles Calmer Hart on exhibition at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, will be auctioned on Tuesday evening.

THERE is no doubt that critics, in an excess of analytic zeal, sometimes credit writers with more conscious artistry than they practice. They will tell you precisely how this or that effect was achieved, often much to the astonishment of the pleased but somewhat bewildered writer, who had not realized how clever he was being.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 22 -- Notre Dame defeated Canisius, 45 to 39, tonight for its sixteenth basketball victory in nineteen games. A crowd of 11,029, an all- time record for Buffalo, saw the contest in Memorial Auditorium.

EVERYONE interested in modern drama, modern literature, or modern ideas might well read this book. For all the talk about French Existentialism, it is the first book by the leader of the movement to appear in America.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 22 -- Senator Robert A. Taft told 1,200 Yale graduates assembled here today that "it will be possible to achieve a 20 per cent cut in the personal income tax" and still reduce the Federal debt by several billion dollars.

Barbara Troxell, soprano, who was a finalist in the Metropolitan Auditions of the Air two years ago, was presented as a "debut" artist ate yesterday afternoon at Town Hall by Debut and Encore Concerts.
Without ceremony, the city Board of Transportation last night took over operation of the twenty- four bus lines of the Isle Transportation Corporation on Staten Island.

DESPITE frequent predictions that it has run its course, the historical novel is still riding high. It has developed, by now, its pattern and its conventions. First of all, at least a handful of actual persons out of the past must move easily and naturally across the pages.

JOAN CHARLES has chosen two themes to develop in her new novel -- a girl's growing up and a plain daughter's reaction to a beautiful and narcissistic mother. A third and concomitant theme was apparently wished on her, though not quite unawares, by the demands of her characters.

DETROIT, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Chevrolet division of General Motors Corporation has approximately 25 per cent more unfilled orders on hand now than it had a year ago and the number is mounting faster than deliveries can be made, according to T.H. Keating, the division's general sales manager.

DR. NYGAARD brings to his first novel a bounding enthusiasm that all but makes up for its didactic shortcomings. He has created a vivid ethnological report of a little-known racial group that makes for interesting reading.

SANTA FE -- Starting in February and continuing throughout the year, the Pueblo Indians of the Southwest maintain an almost continuous schedule of ceremonials and tribal dances in their villages and reservations. While a majority of these festivals take place in New Mexico, two of the most outstanding are celebrated in Arizona during the last half of August.

A CREDIT plan will be introduced by thirty-five leading railroads on April 1 under which cards issued to a traveler by any of these railroads will be good for the purchase of coach, Pullman and parlor car tickets on all participating lines.

Small offerings of Long Island waterfront land are rapidly disappearing from the market and development of this type of property appears to be approaching the saturation point, according to J.L. Rettaliata of Farriss Rettaliata of Babylon.
For U.S. and U.S.S.R. The problem of Russian-American relations -- the dumber One problem of the world -- was highlighted last week in several areas and its urgency again emphasized.

THIS book," begins editor James R. Aswell's foreword, "rounds up some of the most telling examples of the American sense of humor during our age of great laughter -- from Revolutionary times when its voice began to burst out clearly, through the turmoil of the Frontier and Cavil War periods when it was its most exuberant, to the Eighteen Nineties when it was in danger of prattling itself into whimsey and commercial jokesmithing."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 22 -- In a sharp note of protest directed to the Allied Council in Austria, the Yugoslav Government charged today that British border patrols and Austrian gendarmerie "tolerated" invasions of Yugoslav territory by armed Austrian bands.

CARVILLE, La., Feb. 21 (AP) -- Dr. G.H. Faget, medical director of the United States Marine Hospital (leprosarium) here reports in The Star, official publication of the hospital, that nineteen patients have been discharged after being treated with promin, one of the sulfone drugs.

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- The deputies of the Council of Foreign Ministers completed today the work on the military clauses of the Austrian treaty. They reached an agreement on the withdrawal of all occupying troops within ninety days after the treaty becomes effective and on the size of Austria's air force.
The climax came last week in the bitter controversy over the appointment of David E. Lilienthal to head the powerful United States Atomic Energy Commission.

What would be the reaction of the nation if across the front pages of the country there was spread tomorrow morning the dire news that a thriving city of 100,000 had been totally destroyed by earthquake or fire or flood? One can imagine all too readily the shock and the immediate rallying of sympathy and of measures of relief over the whole land.

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- An economic crisis that will shake the entire capitalist world is brewing in the United States, William Z. Foster, general secretary of the Communist party of the United States, said today at the nineteenth national congress of Britain's Communist party.

VERNAL, UTAH. "GOLLY, the music they play is certainly pretty, and they all play together so well," reported Genevieve Taylor, on hearing her first concert by a symphony orchestra. Dark-eyed, pigtailed and pretty, 12-year-old Genny is an Indian girl, one of 1,250 youngsters of assorted ages brought recently by school-bus to this tiny town for one of a pair of concerts given by the pioneering Utah Symphony Orchestra.

The report of the investigation made by the trading and exchange division of the Securities and Exchange Commission of the break in prices of stocks on the New York Stock Exchange on Sept. 3, last, is nearing completion and is expected to be made public in March, it was learned last week.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 22 -- Keeping its position as undefeated Eastern Intercollegiate League leader, the Columbia basketball team edged out Dartmouth tonight in a 52-47 victory that was touch- and-go till the final whistle.

RIPLEY, ENGLAND (By Wireless). RIPLEY is a typical mining town in the Midlands of England. There deep in the earth men dig the coal that Britain must have to keep the wheels of industry moving. Ripley has suffered, as all towns and cities have suffered, from the bitterest cold spell that has gripped Britain in nearly 100 years.

If the United States Department of Agriculture has its way a stout fence will be built along the Mexican-United States border to facilitate the enforcement of quarantine regulations designed to keep out diseased cattle. Segments of such a fence have been erected, but they are too short to be of much use.

NANKING, China, Feb. 22 -- A banking system that devotes itself mainly to the needs of commerce, gives only secondary attention to industry and largely ignores the requirements of the country's vast agricultural areas is one of the chief causes of the present Chinese economic crisis, in the opinion of Dr. Chen Li-fu, organizational chief of the Kuomintang [Government party] and head of the party's Economic Research Committee.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The American people are doing some sober thinking about the relative rights of organized labor and of the unorganized public. They are now more concerned about that problem than about the relative rights of labor and capital. While in this mood it may be well to reconsider certain conclusions which have hitherto been all but universally accepted as beyond the realm of disussion.

With, early spring promotions in dresses, coats, suits and millinery receiving enthusiastic response, store activity was generally good last week, according to a survey prepared especially for the NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

From time to time the statement is made that many people have been using up their wartime savings as the result of such factors as higher living costs and loss of income attending strikes. The Treasury has made a nation-wide survey to determine the facts concerning bond redemptions during the first seven months of 1946 -- a period when a number of major strikes occurred.
ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 22 -- Authorities are convinced that the anti-Jewish, anti-Negro Columbians, Inc., are through in Georgia.

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- "Emergency restrictions on the use of gas, similar to those in force on use of electric power, became a threatening possibility for Britain tonight as the snow, driven before high winds, hampered transport by land and water.

A survey of the attitudes of 1,000 companies that have some form of the closed shop disclosed yesterday that only 14.6 per cent believed that union security clauses had worsened management-labor relations in their plants.

A camera that turns out a finished picture one minute after the shutter is snapped was demonstrated last week at the winter meeting of the Optical Society of America by its inventor. Edwin H. Land. At the turn of a knob a permanent positive print came out.

ONE fact underlined by the clash between Artur Rodzinski and the Philharmonic- Symphony Society was that Arthur Judson, besides being manager of the Philharmonic and president of Columbia Concerts, was also personal representative for most of the conductors in this country.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Feb. 22 -- Kyrre Tokle, Norway Ski Club veteran and brother of the late ski champion, Torger Tokle, won the Stevens Trophy today. The jumping event took place last Sunday and although Tokle placed second to Thorolf Wikborg Jr., a club mate in today's men downhill race, his higher point score in the jump raised his average.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 22 -- Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, leader of the Congress party bloc in the Interim Ministry, tonight characterized as "wise and courageous" Britain's decision to give India her independence by June, 1948.
THE Metropolitan Opera is making plans now for what could be the beginning of a new operatic era in this country. It could be, that is, if the plans go beyond brick and mortar.

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov has informed Secretary of State Marshall that the United States' reply to the Soviet protest against the statement on Russian foreign policy by Dean Acheson, Under-Secretary of State, is "not convincing," the Moscow radio said tonight.

HONOLULU -- Hawaii, with an apprehensive eye cocked on its capital isle of Oahu -- which seems about to burst at the seams -- has laid down the welcome mat again at this gateway to the Paradise of the Pacific.

TAKING things that go places is the latest trend in larceny. In Pennsylvania, where the most popular vehicle is the trolley car, a sentimental Philadelphia ex-motorman commandeered a car while its operator was getting a cup of coffee and ran it five miles before being arrested.

IT Is cause for rejoicing when one encounters a novel which achieves a rich variety of meaning on many levels, which is written in a style both virile and poetic, which possesses profundity of insight, which is, in short, literature.

MOSCOW, Feb. 22 -- Prospects for an early solution of the problems of the future of Germany and Austria have worsened considerably within the last three weeks as the opening of the meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers approaches.

BY any yardstick World War II was the greatest conflict in history. It was the greatest air war, the largest land war, the most immense industrial and propaganda struggle -- the biggest naval and maritime war in which fleets ever have engaged. It ended a little over eighteen months ago; today not all the dead are gathered; wounds are still unhealed and grief is yet green.

A pat on the back in a hilarious, noisy, happy and sincere fashion was bestowed last night upon Commodore George T. Merrick at the South Shore Y.C. in recognition of his last two years as chief flag officer of this busy Freeport, L.I., outfit.

BUDGET proposals moved forward in the new Congress last week but they did not appear to be on much more solid ground than the labor legislation on which, hearings have been proceeding. The storm at the close of the week had the usual effect upon trade and interfered with manufacturing operations.

PARIS, Feb. 22 -- In a statement by Premier Paul Ramadier and in a formal communique that professed to express the unanimous view of the French Cabinet, it was reiterated this week that the purpose of the Government was to press on with the program that former Premier Leon Blum inaugurated in January -- steady reduction of prices and resistance to any general wage Increases.

The British Empire -- greatest of all time -- covers 13,332,054 square miles (a quarter of the earth's land surface) and includes 556,282,000 people (more than a quarter of the human race). There is the core of the empire -- the United Kingdom of 48,000,000 persons.

IT was a couple of years ago that Arthur Miller fell to talking with a midwestern lady who told him of a war profiteer whose daughter, though she loved her father, exposed him and then ran away from home.

SOME young coniferous evergreens, like certain kinds of puppies, grow into disconcertingly mammoth specimens. At this time of year, from now until growth starts, it is possible to give the plant, if not the dog, better proportions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Complaints that a $6,000,000,000 reduction in President Truman's $37,500,000,000 budget would cripple national defense were branded by Representative John Taber, Republican, of New York, today as "nothing but a camouflage to cover up pork barreling."

The best way of honoring the memory of George Washington is by practicing the principles of brotherhood which he proclaimed, Rabbi Israel Goldstein said in a sermon in Temple B'nai Jeshurun, Eighty-eighth Street near Broadway, yesterday.
NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 22 -- The only military school of its kind in the United States, and perhaps in the world, has opened here and is offering its first five-month course of instruction.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (U.P.) -- Harry Auslinger, head of the narcotics bureau, said tonight that the ban on shipment of drugs to Cuba would be lifted only when Charles Luciano was out of that country. He added that the bureau would not act until it was convinced that no possibility remained that exported narcotics would get back into this country for illicit purposes.
SHEFFIELD, England, Feb. 22 -- The industrial collapse of the past two weeks has given a severe blow to the convictions, prejudices and hopes of the workers in Britain's industrial Midlands.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 22 -- Manager Bucky Harris today got his first glimpse of the Yankees he will direct personally this year and what he saw must have made him wonder whatever possessed Joe McCarthy to walk out on the job.
BOSTON, Feb. 22 -- The opening shots in the Battle of Boston Common were fired this week.
Costs of construction on the whole are not likely to advance beyond their present high levels in the immediate future in the opinion of Myron L. Matthews, vice president of the Dow Service.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Feb. 22 -- Turning in a subpar performance, America's Ben Hogan outstroked England's Dai Rees today and at the half-way mark of their $5,000 international golf match held a 3-up lead.

WASHINGTON. AN American invasion of Germany which started even before V-E Day is now at the peak of operations, with its mission approximately half completed. It is made up of business men, scholars, researchers and technical experts, military and civilian, who have been ferreting out German secrets of science and industry, particularly Nazi wartime developments.

Out of a welter of confusion and tattered reputations New York University emerged as team winner in the fifty-ninth annual National Amateur Athletic Union indoor track and field championships at Madison Square Garden last night.

A COOKING method which means less time in the kitchen for the housewife, and at the same time means better meals, is a method to investigate immediately and well. Pressure cooking is fast becoming the only acceptable way for women who are anxious to retain the most in nutrition and flavor in the dishes that they serve.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Congressional proponents of David E. Lilienthal believed today that he would be confirmed as chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, despite the declared opposition of Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, provided that Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Republican, of Michigan, threw his weight behind him.

ALBERT EINSTEIN is undoubtedly the only living man who has been recognized for more than a quarter-century as a genius of the first rank. It is correspondingly difficult to do justice to the man and his work in a biography.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 22 -- Emergency aid by Congress in "sharing the cost of permanent building program" of colleges, universities and junior colleges was asked here today in a resolution unanimously adopted by the American Association of Junior Colleges as it closed its annual meeting.

DR. DU NOUY, who is a former associate of the late Dr. Alexis Carrel, and who is best known in this country for his remarkable book, "Biological Time," attacks materialism and enthrones man as a goal that creation, specifically evolution, sought to achieve.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 22 (AP) -- William G. Helis' Earshot won the $25,000 added New Orleans Handicap today in a driving finish, beating Mrs. J.S. Letellier's Jack S.L. to the wire by half a length.

PARIS, Feb. 22 -- The minimum wage subcommittee of the joint Government Labor Committee of Wages and Prices agreed today to recommend the fixing of the living wage at 7,800 francs a month. The General Confederation of Labor had asked that it be fixed at 7,000 francs a month.

METRO-GOLDWYN-MAYER, which, has donated bushels of specie these past three years to winners of its annual prize novel contest, is preparing to raise its handsome ante and make the affair a semi-annual event, it was learned last week.
A former United States Army transport, renamed the EI Sudan and flying the colors of Egypt, arrived yesterday at Pier 84, North River, with 733 passengers from Alexandria, Haifa and Beirut.

Station WOR, New York, key outlet of the Mutual Broadcasting System, observed its twenty-fifth anniversary yesterday in two special two-hour broadcasts during which stars representing all branches of the amusement world were heard and congratulatory messages from prominent persons were read.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The possibility that the Senate may not confirm the appointment of Mr. Lilienthal as chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission is deeply disturbing to the scientists who have worked in the field of nuclear physics during the war.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 22 -- Charles F. Nicholson, assistant to the publisher of The Newark News and vice president of North Jersey Radio, Inc., the newspaper's radio affiliate, died after a heart attack yesterday afternoon in his home at 346 Parker Street. His age was 68.

Thirty-five members of the American Internees Committee met yesterday in Essex House and formed a subcommittee of ten persons that will ask Congress to enact legislation, now pending, to utilize Japanese property seized by this country to pay claims of civilian internees.

Days lengthen, but the nights are still bright with the winter, stars, frosty and sharp in the darkness. The Big Bear, the Dipper, swing to the east in early evening, and the Little Bear walks across the sky, his upright tail tipped with the Pole Star. The Twins and the Charioteer are almost overhead, and the Pleiades ride high, toward the southwest.
LONDON, Feb. 22 -- For Britons this is a time that calls for stout hearts and fortitude. An Englishman these days must feel, in the words of Job, "full of trouble."
NEWBURGH, N.Y., Feb. 22 -- The people of this city today dedicated to the living their finest war memorial, a completely furnished home for one of their disabled war veterans.

ACCORDING to a foreword by J. Leighton Stuart, "The Illustrious Emperor" should help us appreciate democracy. It is a novel about the reign of Ming Huang in China 1,200 years ago, when democracy was hardly a gleam in anybody's eye.

THE first of these three books is slight almost to the point of disappearance -- a tenuous essay in didactic platitude. "On These I Stand" -- An Anthology of the Best Poems of Countee Cullen, Selected by Himself and Including Six New Poems Never Before Published -- has a certain nostalgic appeal and considerable dexterity; it may concern us more.

OVER at Macy's the other afternoon a lot of kids ascended to the fifth floor, attracted there by an occasion not unconnected with "The Yearling" (film and book), to get a look at their newest matinee idol and his friend: respectively.
TOKYO, Feb. 22 -- Hiroo Wada, appointed yesterday to the directorship of the Economic Stabilization Board, recently vacated by Kienosuke Zen, faces a confused and rapidly changing situation.

Among the relief provisions enacted in 1942, designed to alleviate some of the harsh effects of the excess profits tax, was one applicable to corporate dealers in personal property who generally sell on the installment or deferred payment plan, and particularly to those who were availing themselves of the installment basis of making income tax returns.
The thirty-third President of the United States led the nation yesterday in honoring the memory of the country's first President on the 215th anniversary of George Washington's birth.
The role of parents in juvenile delinquency was discussed yesterday by school children from the metropolitan area in the weekly Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast by WQXR.

PEIPING, China, Feb. 22 -- Reports from North China Government Military Headquarters here indicate that for the first time since the Communists started their attacks against the northern sector of the Peiping-Hankow railway six months ago Government forces have been able to meet and defeat a major Communist force before the latter could make its escape into the mountains west of the railway.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A letter of A. Barr Comstock in your Feb. 9 issue suggests that World Federalists desist their efforts to establish a World Government because their activities may destroy the United Nations.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 22 -- Secretary of State George C. Marshall chose the college campus of Woodrow Wilson today for a warning to the American people against growing indifference to "long-time dangers to the nation's security."

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Feb. 23 -- The spring series of sailing dinghy racing was started today at the Larchmont Yacht Club, in what might be called an ice bowl, for while the harbor water was icefree despite the low temperature, the snow heaps on shore made it a picturesque setting.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Dr. Anslow has put me in his debt by his letter to you published Feb. 16. He gives me still another chance to state the views I hold on science legislation.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 23 (AP) -- A damaged track forced the North American four-man bobsledding champioships to be called off today after one heat, with Joe Meconi and his Ausable Forks, N.Y., team holding a slight lead.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (U.P.) -- Dr. Roscoe R. Spencer, director of the National Cancer Institute, said tonight that chemo-therapy offers "one of the most hopeful" approaches to the cure of cancer.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 23 -- The second annual convention of the New Jersey Council of the American Veterans Committee classed the Communist party with the Columbians here today and repudiated both groups as "diametrically opposed to our aims, ideals, and the purpose of our organization."

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Feb. 23 -- The first national congress of six American organizations, which believe that peace can be preserved only through formation of a federal world government, concluded its three-day session here today by merging into the United World Federalists.
Labor unions will probably pledge a "100 per cent guarantee" against strikes and other work stoppages to assure quick construction of the East River world capital, it was learned yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 23 -- As negotiations for the 1947 wage pact move along, the steel industry has injected a demand that the United Steel Workers of America, CIO, suffer penalties for any unauthorized strikes, it was learned today.

Net sales of the National Biscuit Company last year reached new high marks in ooth dollars and tonnage, despite shortages of raw material and other obstacles, George H. Coppers, president, declared in the forty-ninth annual report issued to stockholders today.

MONTREAL, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Kenny Reardon's goal in the last few seconds of play enabled the first-place Montreal Canadiens to tie the Toronto Maple Leafs, 2 -- 2, tonight and protected their fivepoint National Hockey League lead over the runner-up Leafs.

This is for city folk who have to learn about animals from the zoo, hearsay and stories they read to their children. As for the others, they may go along for the ride, checking the nature lore furnished by people who like to telephone newspaper offices on quiet Sunday afternoons.

Lent is a time for all Christians to renew their belief in the Passion as "the supremest act in all history," the Rev. Dr. Ralph H. Long, executive director of the National Lutheran Council, declared yesterday. He spoke in the Evangelical Lutheran Church of the Holy Trinity, Central Park West and Sixtyfifth Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (U.P.) -- Labor unions were warned tonight by one of their own economists against using any part of union health and welfare funds "even in the most critical labor-management dispute."
TOKYO, Feb. 23 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur today appealed directly to the United States Congress for food that he said was needed to make our victory over Japan complete.

LADD FIELD, Fairbanks, Alaska, Feb. 23 -- A B-29 Superfortress, down since early Friday morning in the far Arctic, has been located 200 miles northwest of Thule in Greenland, its crew of eleven apparently safe. Search planes from here have already dropped food for them to last two weeks.

Condemnation of old building in the heart of Manhattan and replacing them with subsurface parking garages below self-liquidating stores, and offices was advocated yesterday by the New York Board of Trade as a solution to the city's parking problem.

BERLIN, Feb. 23 -- With commitments to feed the starving British zone threatened by Bavarian non-cooperation, Lieut. Gen. Lucius D. Clay, American Deputy Military Governor, laid down the law today to the Minister-Presidents of the four States under American control.

Jobless workers in this State will begin receiving their State unemployment insurance checks every two weeks, instead of weekly, unless a Congressional committee authorizes additional funds for the division of placement and unemployment insurance of the State Labor Department, it was reported yesterday.

One of the cherished items in this department's files is a letter to the editor clipped from The Times of London of July 31, 1942. The communication bears the signature of L.P. Jacks (Oxford), and its subject is The Profit Motive. There is space here to reproduce little more than its flavor.

Another chapter in the collegiate basketball rivalry that captured the fancy of New York fandom years ago will be presented at Madison Square Garden tonight when Notre Dame University's Fighting Irish clash with the Violets of N.Y.U.

Abraham Madee, a Newark investor who recently acquired the first mortgage on the fifty-family apartment house at 110-16 Glenwood Avenue, Jersey City, N.J., from the Hoboken Bank for Savings, has purchased the property from Herbert Leinwander and Edward Robinson New York operators.

Harold Rubens, 25-year-old pianist from Cardiff, Wales, now a resident of this city, gave a recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, at which he made a deep impression by his remarkable command of the instrument, and the musicianship of his performances.

As the victors of the Second World War prepare to meet in Moscow to decide the fate of their main enemy, Germany, there are being heard from that country the recurrent rumblings of a still smoldering volcano which has repeatedly exploded in the past with devastating effects and whose continued existence presents a grave warning to the Moscow Conference.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Feb. 23 (AP) -- The second annual women's international four-ball golf championship still was undecided tonight after the finalists battled to a tie at the end of thirty-five holes, when darkness enveloped the Orange Brook course.

Two suspects of eight seized in a week-end-burglary attempt gave a novel excuse for their actions but one that had police slightly miffed yesterday. They had joined the others, they said, when promised 75 cents an hour for as long as the "job" took.
MIAMI, Feb. 23 -- Ocean cruises to Havana and Nassau are back on the list of Florida's diversions for winter visitors.

A new schedule of higher payments to hospitals for the care of infantile paralysis patients was announced yesterday by the Greater New York Chapter of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis. The new rates, established in recognition of increased hospital costs, will go into effect on Saturday.

LITTLE AMERICA, Feb. 22 (Delayed) -- Admiral Byrd discussed today the outstanding work of the expedition's Western Group, commanded by Capt. Charles Bond Admiral Byrd said the newly discovered warm-water lake area on the continental rim, inland from the Shackleton-Shelf, at about Long.

GOETTINGEN, Germany, Feb. 23 -- Dr. Werner Heisenberg, foremost German atomic scientist, disclosed today that Russia had made a standing offer of 6,000 rubles a month to any German atomic expert who would engage in research for the Soviet Government.

Synthetic rubber should continue to be produced in the most efficient plants from a standpoint of both national security and economic protection. Harvey S. Firestone Jr., president, Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, said yesterday. Under present market conditions, he also pointed out, there is no justification for the Government to continue to monopolize the purchase of natural rubber in the international market.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, opening a drive to raise $170,000,000 for the relief of European Jews, declared today that "mutual confidence" is a primary need of groups, classes and nations of the world.

Reid Nibley, pianist, gave his first New York recital last night at Town Hall. The program he presented comprised two sonatas by Scarlatti: Mozart's Sonata in G major (K.283); Brahms' "Variations on a Theme by Handel"; Leroy Robertson's Etude in G minor; Bloch's "In the Night"; Menasce's "Perpetum Mobile," and a Chopin group composed of the "Berceuse," two etudes and the "Scherzo" in B flat minor.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 23 -- The steel industry last week eliminated all old peacetime records and raised its operating rate one point to 94.5 per cent of national rated capacity. Officials here indicated that this was especially unusual in view of weather conditions, prices of scrap metal and difficulties of production which are faced when operations approach close to maximum capacity.

The American tanker fleet continues to grow both in size and in importance as a vital factor in the national economy, according to a survey report issued yesterday by the American Merchant Marine Institute.

An unusually interesting program of chamber music by two South American composers, Camargo Guarnieri of Brazil and Alberto Ginastera of Argentina, was given under the auspices of the League of Composers yesterday afternoon in the New York Public Library.

Samuel Auchmuty Tucker, chemical adviser to the War Industries Board in the first World War and a prominent figure in education, died yesterday at his home, 136 East Seventy-ninth Street. His age was 77.

Six girls from the University of California, Los Angeles, on a three-month tour of the United States to study interracial and intercultural problems, arrived in New York yesterday. They were accompanied by Dr. G. Byron Done of the university's sociology department, and a chaperone, Miss Edith Peckham.

The Navy's Operation Highjump in the Antarctic is racing against time to complete its explorations before the South Polar winter should freeze in men and equipment, dispatches from the expedition said yesterday.

TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Japan was portrayed as a "misunderstood" nation and former Premier Hideki Tojo and the twentyfive other wartime leaders on trial were depicted as patriots in the opening defense argument before the International War Crimes Tribunal today.

HAVANA, Feb. 23 -- Maybe it was the hot Cuban sun, which was bearing down hard today, or maybe it was just that Leo Durocher was wearing his rose-colored glasses, but after completing only four days of spring training the Dodger skipper was overflowing with optimism about several of his 1947 operatives.

MOSCOW, Feb. 22 (Delayed) -- During the past week there have been strong indications that the Soviet planners would seek to boost production this year by raising the production quotas or "norms" for individual workers.

Still weakened by injuries to key players and still seeking a victory after losing five of their last six games, the New York Rovers again finished on the short end of the count yesterday afternoon, dropping a 4-3 decision to the Shawinigan Falls six of the Quebec Senior League at Madison Square Garden.

New art exhibitions this week are almost exclusively one-man shows. The exception is an exhibition of contemporary Chinese paintings which is opening at the National Arts Club. Other events today include recent paintings by Iver Rose at the Kraushaar Gallery; oils and water-colors by Darrel Austin at the Perls Gallery; recent paintings by Romare Bearden at the Kootz Gallery and pen drawings interpreting the Old and New Testaments, by Josef Scharl, at Nierendorf's.

Charles Evans Hughes Jr., chairman of the Mayor's Committee on Unity, received yesterday the first annual Brotherhood Day award of the Men's Club of Temple B'nai Jeshurun. Two hundred persons attended the ceremony at a luncheon in the temple's community center, 270 West Eighty-ninth Street.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 -- An apparently almost unlimited world demand for wheat and wheat flour, coupled with inability of country shippers to move large supplies of the grain to terminal markets and heavy short-covering, advanced all deliveries of wheat futures to a new seasonal high level on the Board of Trade last week.

The New York Rangers twice had to come from behind in their National Hockey League game with the Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square last night. So doing, the local outfit was able to gain a 2-2 tie with the revived crew from the Automobile City.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 23 -- Fawzy el Kawukji, who commanded the Arab military forces against the British in Palestine in 1936 and 1939 and in Iraq in 1941, before fleeing to Germany, declared today that he was once again "at the disposition of the Arab nation."

ALBANY, Feb. 23--Mayor William O'Dwyer's legislative program for New York City, apart from his efforts to get $102,000,000 more in State aid, showed signs today of being stymied for lack of home-rule requests for action from the New York City Council.

Almost no good news comes out of China these days. The retiring flood of Japanese imperialism has left behind the blights of civil strife, disrupted communications, broken-down industries, corruption, hunger and disease. Eight days ago the Nationalist Government had to recognize the seriousness of the situation by cutting the volume of the Chinese dollar almost to the black market level.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Feb. 23 -- Warehouse occupancy will continue at capacity levels throughout this year, it was predicted today by the merchandise division of the American Warehousemen's Association. Warehouse occupancy and turnover, it was pointed out, provide an excellent general business barometer, with virtually all goods passing through merchandise warehouses on their way from manufacturer to consumer.
LONDON, Feb. 23 -- A slight improvement in the weather failed today to remove the threat that Britain's fuel crisis would be intensified by drastic restrictions on the use of gas.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 23 -- The current mission of Henry Ford 2d and a group of associates to the Pacific Coast to place orders for $50,000,000 of automobile parts has yielded ample evidence of being far more than merely adroit promotion, it was said here today.

WHEN Cesare Borgia's sinister shadow darkened the skies of Italy and Niccolo Machiavelli pondered the nature of men and politics a youth named Giacomo Orso, well known to both men, swam desperately against the current of Italian history. Giacomo was a peasant boy from the Romagna. He had been educated by a saintly priest and taught to expect that a savior would come who would unify distraught Italy and bring it order, justice and peace.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 23 -- According to those whose business it is to follow such developments, there is as yet no international atomic armaments "race" to build up stockpiles of fissionable materials.
This is the sixth in a series of articles on the cooking and carving of large cuts of meat. The final article win appear next Monday.
The rapid development of the West Coast as an important industrial center is seen in the recent battles among the large steel companies that service the district.

A defense of taxicab owners who demand "bonus" prices for old cabs because the city license is transferable to the purchaser was offered yesterday by the United Taxi Council of Greater New York. The owners' group has sent to the City Council a memorandum opposing Councilman Charles Keegan's bill to eliminate such payments by making the licenses non-transferable.

The sharp increase in the volume of bank loans during 1946 may be ascribed primarily to the accumulation of semi-finished goods and of inventories not ready for sale to ultimate consumers, according to a bulletin, The Means of Payment and Debt Management, just issued by Dean John T. Madden, director of the Institute of International Finance, New York University.
ATHENS, Feb. 23 -- All who within a month abandon the struggle against the State and deposit their arms will receive amnesty, according to a new law announced today.

With a majority of the city's main thoroughfares cleared of last Thursday's heavy snowfall, Sanitation Commissioner William J. Powell said last night that traffic would move freely in business sections today.

ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. 23 (AP) -- Burglars looted the night depository vault of the First National Bank over the holiday week-end and escaped with loot estimated at up to $50,000. It was the first bank robbery in the city's history.
IN FLIGHT OVER ANTARCTICA, Feb. 20 (Delayed) -- This plane, on a flight east of Little America, is conducting what is probably the first aerial magnetic survey in the Southern Hemisphere.
AMSTERDAM, Feb. 23 -- The severe weather is retarding industrial production in the Netherlands seriously, and output in many industries is well below that for November -- a peak month.

Great Britain's momentous decision to withdraw completely from India not later than June, 1948, does not chart the dark future of India. It does precipitate a crisis of responsibility on India herself and may compel a drastic realignment of her forces of division.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 23 -- Three masked gunmen took jewelry and cash valued at $73,000, including $48,000 worth of jewelry belonging to Sophie Tucker, the singer, from the office of the Beachcomber Night Club early today, Detective Sgt. C.W. Pierce reported.

Warning that "we have in America a most wonderful opportunity to move into an economic isolationism far worse than that in the past," the Right Rev. Donald B. Aldrich, dean-elect of the Princeton University Chapel, asked yesterday for unstinting aid for the less fortunate people of the world.
LITTLE AMERICA, Feb. 23 -- Exploration from this base is over for this year. Late yesterday the camp began packing to go home.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- A group of ten educators urged tonight that school redirect their activities with new programs aimed at "strengthening, improving and unifying American life" for the atomic age.

BUFFALO, Feb. 28 -- Judge Victor B. Wylegala of the Erie County Children's Court, in submitting his annual report to the Board of Supervisors this week-end, noted that while juvenile delinquency case increased slightly during the last year, fewer adult appeared before him and that many among the young wrongdoers were of high mentality.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 23 -- Merle Oberon has signed with RKO to play the leading feminine role in "Memory of Love," replacing Loretta Young, whose services the studio relinquished to Samuel Goldwyn last week for "The Bishop's Wife."
Staten Island bus commuters joined officials of the Board of Transportation last night in calling the city's first day of operation of twenty-four island bus lines a success.

TEPEXPAM, Mexico, Feb. 22 (Delayed) -- The skull of what was believed to be the oldest human resident of Mexico, and possibly of North America, was dug up in a dusty field here this morning. It was found just outside the walls of a hospital for incurables.
New York "is still in a pioneering stage," complacent in facing its social and health needs, W. Flowland Shaw, president of the Welfare Council of New York City, charged yesterday.

Too much importance has been attached to the therapeutic use of radioactive elements and not enough to their use in the development of biochemistry, Dr. Elise S. L'Esperance, Assistant Professor of Preventive Medicine at Cornell University, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- In the nave of the unfinished Washington Cathedral, President and Mrs. Truman today attended an Episcopal service for the unveiling of a statue of George Washington.

Price adjustments which 1946 brought to the municipal bond market after the upward sweep of prices from 1933 to 1945 are shown in the annual price and yield survey of the municipal market just released by the Chemical Bank and Trust Company.

BOSTON, Feb. 23 -- There has never been a time in the history of the United States when the country was better able to pay for higher education, but a paradoxical situation exists in that higher education is going through a financial crisis, Summer Slichter, Harvard economist, told the American Association of University professors today.

The barring of "rent marchers" from the Legislature in Albany last Tuesday was likened at a protest meeting yesterday to the first infringements of liberty by fascism in Europe. The 200 persons present at the meeting in the Hotel Commodore, called under the auspices of the Progressive Citizens of America, pledged themselves to send telegrams of protest and demands for retention of rent ceilings and additional public housing to their State and national legislative representatives.

Active functioning of the Fashion Council of Boys and Students Clothing is now under way, with editorial material being sent monthly to school magazines of 235 high schools throughout the country. The copy, which is furnished gratis for a column called "Here's Looking at You," is designed to promote clothing consciousness, combat sloppy dress and encourage neatness among high school students, according to Harry A. Cobrin, secretary.
The Rev. Dr. Robert James McCracken, pastor of the Riverside Church, declared at the morning service yesterday that the world was probably more irreligious now than at any time in the Christian era.

LADD FIELD, Fairbanks, Alaska, Feb. 23 (AP) -- A rescue team of three Army transports and a troop glider left Ladd Field today for Thule, Greenland, to establish a base for evacuation of the eleven marooned fliers, who were listed as follows:

Twenty-five editors and writers from American newspapers from coast to coast will attend a threeweek seminar on municipal affairs arranged by Columbia University's American Press Institute, beginning on March 10, Floyd Taylor, director of the institute, announced yesterday.

Having been dropped from membership in the Ligue Internationale de Hockey sur Glace in favor of the Amateur Hockey Association of the United States, the Amateur Athletic Union yesterday marshaled its battle lines against the international controlling body.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 -- The Government withdrew from the grain market as a buyer of cash corn last week, but is expected to resume purchases shortly, especially if the cash wheat situation remains tight. Elevator interests took advantage of the situation to purchase large amounts of the cash article for deferred shipment from the country to cover previous sales for export, with the result that hedging pressure was relatively light.

ALPINE, N.J., Feb. 23 -- With a demonstration of arctic snow maneuvers, the 725-acre Alpine Scout Camp was formally dedicated today to mark a new era of outdoor training for Boy Scouts of the Greater New York Councils.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- A Federal spending ceiling, the nomination of David E. Lilienthal to head the Atomic Energy Commission, portal pay legislation and the various bills aimed at curbing labor strife will again occupy Congress and its committees this week.

For some time there have been reports that radios would be the first durable goods to be subject to sharp price cuts. Now one company has announced a 20 per cent decline in the price of its leading portable model. In addition, it is reported that many distributors have been lowering the prices of lesser known brands of table sets.
Retailers have begun to make headway on what is perhaps the broadest program of retailer-manufacturer relationships that has marked the post-war merchandising period.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins moved into a thirdplace tie with New York in the National Hockey League tonight by defeating the Chicago Black Hawks, 9 to 4, before 20,004 persons -- a new attendance record for the Chicago stadium.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The United States Chamber of Commerce invited today 6,000 local chambers, trade associations and business firms to join in a countrywide observance of World Trade Week from May 18 to 24.

The Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo in its five week-end performances at the City Center occupied itself busily with season premieres. Bronislava Nijinska's "Snow Maiden," George Balanchine's "Baiser de la Fee" and Leonide Massine's "Beau Danube" bowed in on Saturday, and Agnes de Mille's "Rodeo" and Sergueff's reconstruction of "Coppelia" (after Petipa's version) were yesterday's entries.
MOSCOW, Feb. 23 -- The Soviet claim to a share in the control of the Ruhr, Germany's most important industrial area, was made clear in a bitter attack today on the British plan for the Ruhr's future.

New offerings bring the total current sales programs of the War Assets Administration to $163,000,000 in original cost, represented by 177 programs in this region, Carl P. Malmstrom, regional director, announced over the week-end.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 -- Removal of the 4-cent-a-pound import excise tax on foreign copper will do little to add to the potential supply of the metal during the second quarter of the year, a large manufacturer of electrical products declared here last week.

PARIS, Feb. 23 -- Maurice Thorez, Communist Vice Premier, addressed 30,000 workers in Toulon today, reviewing internal and foreign problems in a manner conforming to a nicety with the Cabinet's compromise positions.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 23 -- A group of five American engineering companies whose representatives are now here has received a contract for the construction of the Saudi Arabian sector of the pipeline from the Arabian oilfields to the Mediterranean coast, it was disclosed today.

That not all fine early American furniture was made in dignified mahogany is demonstrated by a gaily lacquered settee and several matching chairs now on display at the Brooklyn Museum. This group is outstanding among the new acquisitions comprising the decorative arts section of the museum's Fiftieth Anniversary Exhibition.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $57,363,780,693. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

With athletes of quality again available in quantity, a new era of wide-open competition is dawning in track and field. The pay-off was on performances, rather than reputations in the national A.A.U. championships. With titles at stake again next Saturday in the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. meet, another mad scramble is in prospect.

Charged with violating the law against employment of unlicensed barbers, 265 barber shop owners face disciplinary action by the city when a four-day series of hearings begins today before License Commissioner Benjamin Fielding.

SHEFFIELD, England, Feb. 23 -- Nothing but an early and profound change in the attitude of the British people toward the problem of national survival can prevent the present crisis from becoming a steady slide into conditions of poverty unknown in the Western world in modern times.

ISHPEMING, Mich., Feb. 23 -- Misfortune continued to pursue the fortieth running of the National Ski Association's annual jumping championships today as gale-like winds and a driving snowstorm forced postponement for the second successive day.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The public should be advised of a situation in which they can assist President Truman by arousing public sentiment in getting people to write to the President and to their Senators and Representatives.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Feb. 23 -- Several hundred organizers of underground Nazi movements, including one that boasted possession of a secret bacteriological weapon, were arrested by intelligence agents of the United States and British zones today.

An interesting bill which merits careful examination has been introduced in the House of Representatives by Congressman Canfield. It provides that henceforth all ex-Presidents be made Senators-at-Large with corresponding rights, privileges, salaries and allowances, but without a vote.

THE Notre Dame and New York University basketball teams will collide head-on at Madison Square Garden tonight. In the opening game of the double-header -- Whoops! What opening game? It seems that there just isn't any on this occasion. Nope. The boys are going at it in the single-o fashion for the first time in the history of the intercollegiate court pastime at Ned Irish's pavilion.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 23 -- In the drive to give the Polo Grounds a better ball club this year, manager Mel Ott has lifted a page from Giant history of greater days. Coaching has played an important role in the preliminary training of the Giants through the week just ended.

Although the sharply curtailed Maritime Commission training-program for seamen probably will result in the closing of most of the nation's sea schools, authoritative sources indicated yesterday that two important schools would continue.
NANKING, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Chinese dispatches from Manchuria today said that Communists had resumed an offensive along the Sungari River north of Tunghwa, which is 125 miles east of Mukden.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- David E. Lilienthal has a substantial -- but not conclusive -- margin of Senate support for confirmation as chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, an Associated Press poll showed today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The American Red Cross announced today that it had enrolled the active support of the country's top labor leaders in the drive to raise a 1947 fund of $60,000,000, beginning March 1.

MILAN, Italy, Feb. 23 (U.P.) -- Whether the management of the La Scala Theatre would resign en masse apparently depended today upon Arturo Toscanini's answer to a cable, asking him to clarify his reason for failing to open the Milan opera season last Dec. 26, as scheduled.

Modern man is "frustrated" and seeks escape in totalitarianism, dictatorships and, in the United States, alcoholism, because he is estranged from God and has therefor "lost his purpose," Msgr. Fulton J. Sheen, Professor of Philosophy at the Catholic University of America, declared yesterday in the first in a series of Lenten sermons at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. Cardinal Spellman presided in the sanctuary.

MILAN, Italy, Feb. 23 (U.P.) -- Whether the management of the La Scala Theatre would resign en masse apparently depended today upon Arturo Toscanini's answer to a cable, asking him to clarify his reason for failing to open the Milan opera season last Dec. 26, as scheduled.

Modern man is "frustrated" and seeks escape in totalitarianism, dictatorships and, in the United States, alcoholism, because he is estranged from God and has therefor "lost his purpose," Msgr. Fulton J. Sheen, Professor of Philosophy at the Catholic University of America, declared yesterday in the first in a series of Lenten sermons at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. Cardinal Spellman presided in the sanctuary.

In the first price-cut by a major movie house of the Times Square amusement zone, the Paramount Theatre announced yesterday a sharp reduction from wartime levels in admissions to morning performances, and lesser cuts for afternoon and evening programs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Virtual scrapping of the program for Federal aid to airports was recommended today by a Senate subcommittee to permit throwing of its $45,000,000 appropriation into a $54,540,000 air safety program.

A further request for government action to meet the continued rise in prices of cotton finished goods was submitted yesterday in a letter to John R. Steelman, special assistant to the President, by Max J. Lovell, director-counsel of the House Dress Institute.
BUNDE, Germany, Feb. 23 -- Hundreds of diehard Nazis were rounded up by British intelligence forces today.

For some twenty years this State has had a law under which motionpicture films may be refused a license if all of them or any part of them is found to be "obscene, indecent, immoral, inhuman, sacrilegious or of such character that its exhibition would tend to corrupt morals or incite to crime."

The Young Men's Board of Trade of New York, 291 Broadway, acting as coordinator of the efforts of business and industry, lists the following free services to aid veterans in career-planning and employment.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- With the passing of the first shock of the industrial crisis in Britain, caused by the fuel famine, and with a partial resumption of work decreed by the Government to start tomorrow, the stock markets staged a considerable recovery last week.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 -- New seasonal high prices for lard futures were established last week on the Board of Trade as hogs advanced to $27.50 a hundredweight to equal the highest price on record on the livestock markets while the daily average price of hogs on Thursday is estimated to have reached a new high record at $26.60.

ABOARD MOUNT OLYMPUS, Feb. 23 -- Mariner seaplanes of the Navy-Byrd Expedition's Western Group, which has circled halfway around the Antarctic continent, have penetrated again into little known areas. One flight found many mountains colored reddish brown with some peaks black, in the area of Queen Maud Land, south of Africa.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Feb. 23 -- Seven Coast Guardsmen and a commercial fisherman were killed and two Coast Guard air crewmen survived when a Martin Mariner flying boat crashed against the cliff side of a butte in Lower California last night.

More than 20,000,000 persons in Eastern Europe have been expelled from their homes since the end of the war or now are threatened with such expulsion, according to a protest made public yesterday by the Committee Against Mass Expulsions, 112 East Nineteenth Street.

BUFFALO, Feb. 23 -- Despite all last-minute efforts, Buffalo teachers are scheduled to go out on strike tomorrow morning in what will be the biggest school walkout in the history of the United States.

Broadway's first production of "Volpone" in the original Ben Jonson text will go on view this evening as the fourth of five Elizabethan offerings by Donald Wolfit and his London Company. The curtain at the Century is scheduled to rise at 8:15 o'clock.
Squalls on the North Atlantic delayed three ships that were due to arrive here yesterday with passengers from European and African ports.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 23 -- The Yankees today won their second straight game of this novel Caribbean venture as they toppled the Caguas by a score of 6 to 4, but before Manager Bucky Harris and his charges achieved this lofty feat they did a deal of sweating that was not all caused by the tropical heat.

Except for a slight setback on Thursday, the cotton futures market last week continued to move upward moderately. At the close of trading on Friday prices on the New York Cotton Exchange were 25 to 42 points above the preceding week, when net gains of 8 to 50 points were registered.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 -- The National Association of Home Builders, whose members have embarked on what many persons believe will be the biggest year of residential construction activity the country ever has known, started its annual convention here this afternoon with the opening of what was described as a "milliondollar exhibit" of new and improved materials and household equipment.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Feb. 23 (U.P.) -- P.G.A. champion Ben Hogan today won a $5,000 jackpot by defeating Dai Rees, leading British money winner last year, 6 and 4, in their 36-hole international golf duel.

Like seasoned troupers, Mr. Wolfit and his colleagues stage an intelligible and interesting "The Merchant of Venice," which they added to their repertory at the Century Theatre on Saturday. Since "The Merchant" is rarely played in Gotham and has been played brilliantly only once in the last quarter of a century, people who want to supplement their reading knowledge with an acted performance are directed to Mr. Wolfit's competent production.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Feb. 23 -- Methods now used to "sterilize" gold accumulating in Switzerland, with the aim of preventing inflationary effects, are noted in the report for 1946 of the National Bank of Switzerland, just issued.

ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- Governor Dewey will send a special message to the Legislature tomorrow urging the imposition of $45,000,000 a year in new taxes to finance the prospective $400,000,000 State bonus to veterans of World War II, it was announced tonight.

A local union of the Congress of industrial Organizations came to the defense of the principle of free enterprise yesterday and upheld the right of taxicab owners to a "reasonable profit" if they sell their business.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 24 -- Calumet Farm's great gelding Armed was winging toward California tonight, with Saturday's $100,000 added Santa Anita Handicap the next objective in his quest for racing's golden crown as the top money-winning thoroughbred of all time.

ABOARD MOUNT OLYMPUS, Feb. 23 (Delayed) -- The Mount Olympus steamed southward through a thick fog toward the ice-pack late today to scout the edge of the formidable belt as an aid for the outbound Burton Island.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 24 -- It was "bunt one, hit three fair, run on the fourth one regardless" today in the training camp of the Giants. The wraps were off. The first four-ply workout was in full swing. The athletes, particularly those infielders and outfielders who previously had been able to sneak an almost surreptitious swing at the ball, took full advantage of it.
LAFAYETTE, Ind., Feb. 24 (AP) -- A new bleacher section collapsed tonight in Purdue University field-house, killing at least two students and injuring more than 200 other spectators.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have read your editorial of Feb. 4 advocating that New York State spend $400,000,000 for low-rental housing for veterans and I have studied letters received by you from members of the American Veterans Committee congratulating you on your suggestion.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The Federation for Railway Progress, an organization for the purpose of restoring "courtesy, efficiency and earning power to the American railroads," was launched here today by Robert R. Young, chairman of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway and the Alleghany Corporation.

Wallpapers simulating the designs of handwoven fabrics are believed by United Wallpaper, Inc., to be the best answer yet to the background requirements of modern interiors, Adele Whitfield, interior decorator for the company, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 --The Committee for Economic Development, making public today the findings of an eight-month study by its Research and Policy Committee, proposed "ground rules" for effective collective bargaining.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 24 -- In an implied warning to America not to feel that the atom bomb alone guaranteed its safety, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Army Chief of Staff, said here tonight that he deplored "loose and sometimes gloating talk about the degree of security implicit in a weapon that might destroy millions over night."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The American Retail Federation met in an atmosphere of optimism today as industry spokesmen promised more and better consumer goods for the retail counters in 1947, and Congressional leaders pledged action on tax reduction, lower Federal budgets and labor legislation.

Sales Off 5% in First Drop Marking the first decline this year, sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores were 5 per cent under the same week of 1946, according to the "flash report" issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Random notes. Right now is the time to scan your fly rods and check them for loose glides, bad wrappings, worn tip guides or loose ferrules. Shops that do rod repairs are going to be very busy, and if you wait until a week before opening day you are going to find yourself on the stream with unsatisfactory tackle.
A drive for an increased rate of fare in New York City has been started by individual taxicab owners, who at present comprise 43 per cent of the business, it was learned yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 24 -- Miss Mary Sutherland, British delegate to the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women, criticized as disappointing the work of the Commission's first session, which ended today.

MELBOURNE, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Adrian Quist, 34-year-old veteran, was dropped from the Australian Davis Cup team today as this tennis-conscious nation began preparations to bring back the huge international trophy the all-victorious United States team lifted last December.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 24--Michael Curtiz Productions today announced the purchase of screen rights to "Sugarfoot," a 1942 novel by Clarence Buddington Kelland, dealing with lawlessness in Arizona in the late nineteenth century.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The Senate Judiciary Committee finally approved today a bill to knock out portal-to-portal back-pay claims. The friends and foes of a far more restrictive House measure were arranging the order of battle on that side of the Capitol.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- United States military planners disclosed today two important steps which are being taken toward achieving a high degree of peacetime efficiency in the fields of industrial mobilization and scientific research and development.

BUFFALO, Feb. 24 -- In the greatest strike of teachers in the nation's history, 2,400 Buffalo teachers left their classes today, paralyzing the city's school system. Eighty of the ninety-eight schools were closed. Fewer than 10,000 pupils of the total enrollment of 72,000 were in their classes.

TOKYO, Feb. 24 -- Although Toyohiko Kagawa, Christian leader, has announced that he would be a candidate for the House of Councilors, he is still under suspension by the occupation, Brig. Gen. Courtney Whitney, Chief of the Supreme Command's Government Section, said today.

A well-restrained simplicity marked the showing of custommade fashions by Alice Orovan of 785 Fifth Avenue yesterday at the St. Regis Hotel. Miss Orovan displayed a preference for long, slim lines, adapting them to her suits as well as dresses.
All the tenants but one left the old four-story brownstone house at 146 East Thirty-fifth Street before yesterday, the deadline set by the owner for vacating the building.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 24 -- Austria's hockey team has won a first-class diplomatic victory for the Vienna Government. The sudden nation-wide enthusiasm here for Austria undoubtedly constitutes, at least for the moment, a political factor of some significance.

Most of the public school teachers in Buffalo "absented" themselves from their classrooms yesterday and made a mockery of what they have taught their students of the citizen's responsibility to the state, of the wisdom of pursuing reform through orderly process rather than revolution, and of the public servant's duty to uphold law and order.

What Nobel Prize winner Dr. Werner Heisenberg has revealed about German efforts to develop atomic energy will be taken at its face value by the many scientists here who know him. As a director of German research in nuclear energy physics he knows exactly what plans had been made and how far they had been carried out.

A syndicate of 102 underwriters headed by the First Boston Corporation will offer today to investors $77,811,000 of City of Montreal serial refunding debentures. The offering will be concurrent with sale in Canada of $31,948,000 of Canadian dollar debentures and will represent the largest offering of Canadian municipal securities ever made in this market.

Mayor O'Dwyer and Edward C. Maguire, director of the City Labor Relations Division, conferred yesterday with Commissioner J.R. Mandelbaum of the United States Conciliation Service on the possibility of settling the protracted controversy between telephone and electrical unions over the pulling of telephone wire through conduits on new construction projects.

Foreign purchasers of silk who have bought directly in Japan have received no price advantage that would prove detrimental to American weavers or knitters, it was learned yesterday from trade sources. Foreign buyers have had the opportunity to make such purchases for the last four or five months, it was pointed out, and prices paid have been equal to or above those set by the United States Commercial Company for purchasers here.

The stock market yesterday went through a moderate reaction Which produced substantial losses in some of the pivotal issues and left the composite rate approximately a half point off at the close. The list was heavily weighted on the lower side as only 214 out of the 942 issues dealt in managed to show additions while 539 declined.

Five jurors were selected yesterday in the first day of the General Sessions trial of three men alleged to be the "masterminds" behind Alvin J. Paris' attempted bribe of two members of the football Giants to throw the professional championship game with the Chicago Bears last Dec. 15.

Faulty traffic lights on Eighth (Avenue resulted at 6:30 A.M., yesterday, in a collision between an interurban and an Eighth Avenue bus at the Forty-fourth Street intersection, injuring sixteen persons, two seriously.

VIENNA, Feb. 24 -- The Soviet oil administration today paid the Socony Vacuum and Shell Oil Companies 5,000,000 schillings as the first installment of the nearly 40,000,000 schillings it owed them for oil taken from their fields and refineries in Austria.

WHAT is the rise of reading about human suffering when there's nothing that I can do about it? Why should I harrow myself with horrible accounts of misery and injustice which are already ancient history, although only a few years old? So much has happened since and the worst may be yet to come.

Elisabeth Bergner's double bill -- the two-act drama by Strindberg, "Miss Julie," and Chekhov's comedy, "The Proposal" -- is again on its way to the Main Stem. The production closed in New Haven on Feb. 15 for recasting and revisions and for a while its future appeared uncertain.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Feb. 24 -- Following is the text of the address delivered tonight by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower at the civic reception held here in his honor: Through this historic city flowed the pioneer energy that expanded the nation beyond the plains and mountains to the Pacific.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 24 -- Several influential members of the United Nations Security Council said today that they would welcome an appeal by Norway against a threat by the Franco regime to bar Norwegian shipping from Spanish ports.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 24 -- One of the Arab states will be asked to raise the question of independence of French and Spanish North Africa before the United Nations, it was announced today at the close of the conference held here by Nationalists from four North African territories.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- The strike of the school teachers at Buffalo, an event without precedent in the annals of New York State, posed several knotty questions today for which there was no immediate answer.
John Kramer and Miss Pauline Betz, national champions from California, were seeded first in the men's and women's singles yesterday in the draw for the combined national indoor tennis tournament.

Covering by shippers and mills thrust the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday into new high levels for the current move. Net gains of 52 to 67 points on active months were shown.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- The text of Governor Dewey's special message to the Legislature on the State bonus to veterans follows: In the face of many demands from all quarters for new and large expenditures by the State, it is necessary that we face up to the fact that the present revenue structure of the State will not support any increased expenditures.
The eleven members of the crew of the Kee Bird, safe and sound but still battling an Arctic storm, were on their way today from northern Greenland to Westover Field, Chicopee Falls, Mass.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 24 -- A new method of distributing food relief supplies to millions of European children under an international "trusteeship" system was placed before United Nations members here today by Maurice Pate, executive director of the International Children's Emergency Fund.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Feb. 24 -- A series of night fires in the Saigon-Cholon area has made 18,720 persons homeless and has destroyed more than $800,000 worth of property in the past month, a committee representing Chinese victims declared today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- After reporting to President Truman at the White House today, Laeut. Gen. John R. Hodge, United States com mander in Korea, said that reports that the Russians were organizing an army of 500,000 Koreans in northern Korea appeared to be true.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 24 -- Governor Alfred E. Driscoll expressed hope today that delegates to the proposed State constitutional reform convention would make no commitments that would hamper free discussion of controversial issues.

For the second time in two weeks 2,500 residents of Rockland County face the prospect of unheated homes. Representatives of Rockland's utility companies warned yesterday that only the advent of warmer weather or a substantial additional supply of gas from outside sources would prevent the shut-off today of all gas for heating.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 24 (AP) -- A bomb wrecked the studios of the pro-Government Radio Libertad tonight a few minutes after President Juan D. Peron had broadcast an address from the Colon Theatre. Two girl performers rehearsing in a near-by building were injured by flying glass.

Columbia University will voluntarily remove questions relating to race, religion and nationality from the application blanks used by its employment office, the American Jewish Congress announced yesterday. A spokesman for the university, however, would neither confirm nor deny the report.

Assets of the New York Life Insurance Company rose last year to $4,026,689,280, it was disclosed yesterday in the company's 102d statement issued by George L. Harrison, president. Sales of new life insurance reached a new high of $832,484,000, which was $268,303,900, or 47.5 per cent above the 1945 volume.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the column "Topics of the Times" recently the statement was made that "air travel is still considerably more expensive than the train."
NUREMBERG, Germany, Feb. 24 -- A German denazification tribunal classified Franz von Papen as a major offender today and sentenced him to eight years in a labor camp.

Faulkner Heads Paper Group Advertising is being called upon more and more to do many jobs never considered in its traditional role, Cy Norton, of the Association of National Advertisers said yesterday, before the annual luncheon of the Paper Makers' Advertising Association, at the Lexington Hotel.

LONDON, Feb. 24--For the first time since 1939 British companies were authorized today to enter into direct negotiations with German business men for the purchase of German products. The same privilege will be extended to American business men on March 4, according to H. A. Marquand, Secretary for Overseas Trade.

Three works for solo 'cello and symphony orchestra were on the bill at Carnegie Hall last night, with Marcel Hubert as the soloist and Thomas Scherman conducting the orchestra. For good measure there was Bach's Brandenburg Concerto No. 2, which had four competent soloists -- Julius Schulman, violin; Bernard Goldberg, flute; Bruno Labate, oboe, and Murray Karpilowski, trumpet.

TOKYO, Feb. 24 -- All contentions advanced by Japanese apologists before and after Pearl Harbor will again come forth, in the war crimes trial. The defense will try to show that the conflict was forced upon Japan through military encirclement and economic aggression by the Western powers, it is now evident.
CHICAGO, Feb. 24 -- Grain markets were on the upgrade today on the Board of Trade. July and September wheat and corn and September oats went to new seasonal high ground.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The Republican majority of the House Ways and Means Committee decided today to start work on the proposed 20 per cent reduction of personal income taxes as soon as the ceiling for expenditures has been established finally in the legislative budget.

Bernard Milofsky, New York violist, who has appeared as assisting soloist with the New Friends of Music, gave his first local recital last night at Town Hall. His program consisted of modern works, with the exception of the first of the two sonatas Brahms wrote interchangeably for viola or clarinet.

The Bronx Zoo, it seems, is having less trouble with its animals than with the spelling of their names. Take the case of the kadiak bear, which made its formal debut there yesterday. The zoo people insist its correct name is "kadiak." The dictionary, however, says it is okay for the public to continue calling the animal "kodiak."

The National Maritime Union, CIO, one of the sea labor organizations that has denounced transfer of American ships to foreign registry, listed yesterday 101 vessels said to have changed to Panamanian and Honduran colors in eighteen months.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24--The Senate rejected efforts today to postpone further consideration of a ceiling on Federal expenditures for the 1948 fiscal year. Instead, it moved toward a showdown on the issue by agreeing to curb debate.
CHICAGO, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Small receipts and strong consumer demand lifted prices of hog to a record high of $29 a hundredweight today, up $1.50 from the previous peak.

BERLIN, Feb. 24 -- The major details of the Allied Control Council's report on economics to the Conference of Foreign Ministers in Moscow were described today by a non-American source. The report was completed Saturday for the signatures of the four zonal commanders after a record twenty-six-hour meeting of the quadripartite economics directorate.
PEIPING, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The Yellow River has thwarted an effort to divert it to its prewar channel, United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration officials reported today.
