WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Attorney General Clark announced today that the Department of Justice had filed suit in Wilmington, Del., to enjoin Columbia Steel Company of San Francisco from purchasing the Consolidated Steel Corporation of Los Angeles.

COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Feb. 24 (U.P.) -- Homer Norton of Texas A. and M. College has been offered one year's pay -- $10,000 in cash -- to quit his job as athletic director and football coach immediately, The United Press learned tonight on reliable authority.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 24 -- Maryland University's basketball team gained a ten-point half-time advantage, then staved off a spirited Army rally to hand the cadets their third straight setback of the season, 57 to 54, today. Ben Carnevale, Navy's coach, was among those in the field house.

The annual report of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company for 1946, being released today, shows a net income for the Bell System of $208,551,507, compared with $177,057,840 in 1945. Net income of A. T. T. last year amounted to $191,932,110, or $9.42 a share, against $171,640,228, or $8.66 a share, a year earlier.

Rental housing can be produced most efficiently through community action, including the allocation of suitable desirable sites for apartments, Federal housing expediters were told yesterday. Expediters from thirty-five cities met at the opening of a three-day conference at 2 Park Avenue, called by Charles S. Ascher, Regional Housing Expediter.
ATLANTA, Feb. 24 -- A constitutional amendment to forbid the closed shop in Georgia was approved by the State Senate today by a vote of 40 to 1.

Ungainly and crude was the brand of basketball Notre Dame and N.Y.U. exhibited in their anual court clash last night in Madison Square Garden. At times the contest developed into a comedy of errors, but at no time did it lack excitement, and in the end the Fighting Irish of Notre Dame had a 64-60 victory, its seventeenth the campaign.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- Increases in the gasoline, cigarette, utility, liquor and personal income taxes were listed tonight by Governor Dewey as potential sources of $45,000,000 in new State revenues, an amount which he said was needed to finance the proposed $400,000,000 bonus to veterans of World War II.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 24 -- Rural legislators responsible for the recent enactment of this State's "white primary" law, though still stating their conviction that they were carrying out the wishes of their constituents, are in many instances reported to be "troubled" at the bitter party cleavage resulting from their decisions.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24 -- David L. Behncke, bead of the Air Lone Pilots Association since its origin in October, 1931, was re-elected today for another two-year term as president and virtual boss over some 7,000 men who make up flight crews for all this country's air carriers, national and international.

ISHPEMING, Mich., Feb. 24 -- Heavy snows and high winds today showed no signs of diminishing and officials were forced to postpone the national ski jumping championships at Suicide Hill for the third straight day.
SHEFFIELD, England, Feb. 24 -- Labor leaders in the Midlands are worried about the attitude of workers' wives toward the Labor Government.

LONDON, Feb. 24 -- Green Britain gained a respite from the threatened restrictions on the use of illuminating gas for heating and cooking today. It was announced the Government had decided, for the moment, not to impose on gas consumption the same rules that have curtailed the use of electricity.

Housewives planning to purchase electrical appliances would have enjoyed strolling around the Jade Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday, where Landers, Frary Clark presented a preview of the company's post-war models.

In a move to match the streamlining of the Police Department, Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle yesterday ordered thirty-one members of the department who are 70 years old or will reach that age by July 1 to submit applications for retirement.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- President Truman urged Congress today to authorize United States participation in the International Refugee Organization in recognition of our moral responsibility for the victims of Axis tyranny.

BUFFALO, Feb. 24 -- For many teachers who went on strike today the picket line was an experience that they had never expected to undergo. Stamping their feet in the snow to keep warm, and with scarfs and upturned coat collars shielding them from the bitter wind, they spent most of the morning in front of the few schools that were open.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 24 -- Dinner Hour, the Brookmeade Stable's 3-year-old that finished third and was placed fourth when the judges booted one last week, caused some more commotion in the officials' stand at Hialeah Park today.
A turn-out of thirty-five candidates -- the largest he has ever had -- greeted Jack Coffey yesterday afternoon at the Fordham gymnasium as he launched his twenty-fifth year as Ram baseball coach.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee ended today the gathering of testimony on the rent control structure and prepared to draft a rent bill.

The hotel room situation has eased so far from wartime pressures that it is now possible over the week-end to obtain accommodations in the city's hostelries without advance reservation. This was reported yesterday by the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, Inc., after it had completed a survey of hotel occupancies.

On Saturday, Feb. 15, the United States Embassy in Moscow requested the Russian Government to permit fifty-two American correspondents to cover the Foreign Ministers' conference on Germany which is scheduled to begin in that city on March 10. This number compares with the seventy-three correspondents who originally applied for visas to visit Moscow for that purpose, and with the twenty who, as matters stand, will actually be permitted by Russia to attend.

PARIS, Feb, 24 -- Premier Paul Ramadier announced in a broadcast tonight the launching of the second stage in former Premier Leon Blum's price-reduction program and declared it would be made effective on Wednesday.

The Right Rev. Henry Knox Sherrill, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, accompanied by the Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert, Bishop-elect of the New York diocese, made a tour yesterday of the antiquated buildings of St. Barnabas House, temporary shelter for women and children, at 304 Mulberry Street.

Efforts of the Railway Express Agency to enter the air freight as well as the air express field were questioned by other air freight forwarders and by public counsel for the Civil Aeronautics Board at a hearing yesterday before J. Earl Cox, examiner of the board, in the offices of the New York State Chamber of Commerce, 65 Liberty Street.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24 -- Most top managements are fumbling the ball in the field of human relations, the most important and most difficult of all management problems today, according to speakers at the annual midwinter personnel conference of the American Management Association.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- Companion bills that would make possible the rebate this year of almost $100,000,000 in unemployment insurance taxes to employers were introduced in the Senate and Assembly tonight by Senator Fred A. Young and Assemblyman Benjamin H. Demo, Lewis County Republicans.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24--President Truman ordered heads of Federal Government agencies today to discharge inefficient workers in an effort to make the handling of Government business more effective.

HE may be the next heavyweight champion of the world. That, however, would be in the distant future. His more immediate destiny appears to be his prompt ascension to the light-heavyweight throne, an objective which seemingly lurks just around the corner because he meets Gus Lesnevich, the defender, in the Madison Square Garden ring on Friday.
The former Presidential yacht, the Mayflower, is expected to be ready the end of this month to enter service as an Arctic seal carrier, it was reported yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 24 -- The Westchester Board of Supervisors asked today for State rehabilitation of habitual alcoholics (and after long debate sidestepped action on commercial rent control for the county.

Severe storms and frigid temperatures in the last few weeks have frozen over large areas of the Skagerrak and choked Scandinavian ports with the largest accumulation of ice in many years, according to Capt. John Nordlander, master of the Swedish American liner Drottningholm.

ABOARD THE ICEBREAKER BURTON ISLAND, in Ross Sea, Feb. 24 -- At a shouted command from the bridge last night, two young seamen hauled out the big wooden pins that held the mooring lines of this ship to the Bay at Whales ice shelf and raced to the gangway.
Wrong New Homes This is not a time, one would imagine, for people to be super-finicky about new housing if once the basic standards of utility, safety and cost are met. But such is not human nature.

LONDON, Feb. 24 (Reuters) -- Britain's import program for 1947 includes: Tobacco, u50,000,000 ($200,000,000); petroleum products, u55,000,000; machinery and equipment (including' ships) ,u60,000,000, and net film remittances u18,000,000.
A joint plan for the largest domestic crude oil pipeline ever constructed with private capital was described yesterday by the Texas Pipe Line Company and the Shell Pipe Line Corporation.

Lunch in New York and breakfast in London -- and vice versa -- will become an actuality on Saturday when American Overseas Airlines starts daily non-stop service from New York to Shannon, Eire. Harold R. Harris, vice president and general manager, announced yesterday that planes leaving La Guardia Field at 2:30 P.M. would arrive at Shannon at 1:40 A.M., New York time, or 6:40 A.M., Irish time, without a stop at Gander, Nfld.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- A reporter's testimony today caused the Senate Atomic Energy Committee to consider possible perjury action against a witness called by Senator Kenneth McKellar of Tennessee in his fight against confirmation of David E. Lilienthal as chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24 -- Home builders of the nation were warned today that mounting costs of labor and materials were threatening to force them to price their product out of the broad market now available to them.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Feb. 24 -- International cooperation in a planned economy of scientific effort, if supported vigorously by the United States, could be a vital step toward lasting world peace, professor W. Albert Noyes Jr., president of the American Chemical Society and chairman of the Department of Chemistry at the University of Rochester, told more than 700 representatives of the scientific world tonight.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- Cooperation by the Labor Department and State Police in the prosecution of growers who "persistently and flagrantly" defy the law pertaining to the employment of children on farms was recommended today by Governor Dewey's committee on migrant camps.

A large part of the Federal Trade Commission's activities will be "witch hunting" if the test of "bigness" is to be the determining factor in seeking monopolies, it was declared yesterday by the National Association of Manufacturers.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 24 -- The specialized aid of a social agency in making psychological adjustment is needed by adopting parents as well as by unmarried mothers giving up their babies, Julia Ann Bishop, director of Casework Children's Home Society of Virginia told today the Eastern Regional Conference, Child Welfare League of America.

BUFFALO, Feb. 24 -- Buffalo is in the rather anomalous position of having a Mayor and City Council willing to increase the salary level of its teachers and municipal workers by rather substantial amounts to meet increased living costs, but of having only $31,000 available under a State restricted budget with which to pay for the boosts.

Election of Rowland Burnstan, president since 1943 of the Lawrance Aeronautical Corporation, as executive director of the State Charities Aid Association, 105 East Twenty-second Street, was announced yesterday by Winthrop W. Aldrich, president of the association, effective March 1.

New Jersey and Michigan Bond houses hummed yesterday with talk of the relationship between today's scheduled sale of $15,000,000 of State of New Jersey highway and emergency housing bonds to Michigan's $200,000,000 veterans' bonus issue, which will come to market a week hence.

HAVANA, Feb. 24 -- Branch Rickey was the busiest man in Havana today, much busier than any of the Dodgers, whose workout was limited to an hour of running and ball tossing because a heavy rain had soaked the infield of Grand Stadium.

HERFORD, Germany, Feb. 24 -- As operations against what had been described as the largest postwar network of subversion in Germany proceeded into their third day, British intelligence officers reported today that more than 80 per cent of the key figures of the organization had been arrested.

LONDON, Feb. 24 -- The deputies of the Council of Foreign Ministers wound up their work in London today by completing a halfagreed draft of the Austrian treaty and registering their disagreement on the procedure for framing the treaty with Germany.

AMRITSAR, India, Feb. 24 (Reuters) -- British troops were called out today in Amritsar, communal nerve center of the Punjab, as clashes in several important cities marked "National Struggle Day," climax of a month's Moslem League resistance to the non-Moslem coalition Government ban on processions and meetings.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 24 -- The expected signature of the Anglo-French treaty of alliance is a matter of particular importance and satisfaction to Belgium. This country looks forward to eventual discussions with both Paris and London leading to the conclusion o similar pacts.

De Kalb County, Ga. De Kalb County, Ga., announced yesterday that it would receive bids on Feb. 25 on $1,350,000 of various purpose bonds bearing interest of 2 per cent, dated Jan. 1, 1947, and due Jan. 1 from 1949 to 1977.

Thanks to the industrious Experimental Theatre, an interesting drama has appeared on the cozy stage of the Princess Theatre, where the first of the five performances was staged on Sunday evening. It is "O'Daniel" by Glendon Swarthout and John Savacool.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24 -- Seven Chicagoans were arrested today on Federal warrants charging them with participating in a gang alleged to be responsible for diverting an estimated 5,000,000 pounds of sugar into the black market.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24 -- The House of Delegates of the American Bar Association, at its mid-winter meeting today, empowered the association's Special Committee on the Judiciary to promote the nomination and confirmation as Federal judges of persons the committee found "competent" upon investigation, and to oppose the elevation of those it found "unfit or not sufficiently qualified."

A buyers' market already is here in many merchandise items, with prices softening, manufacturers more anxious to do business and quality improving, C. Carver, district manager of the 25 cent to $1 division in Atlantic Seaboard stores of the S. S. Kresge Company, said here yesterday.
LONDON, Feb. 24 -- The most notable reaction to the Government's economic White Paper in the stock markets today was a drop in tobacco shares.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- President Truman has gone so far in efforts to meet the requests of responsible Republican leadership on the handling of reciprocal trade treaties that there appeared today to be no remaining doubt that he had saved the treaty program for this year at least.

Martha Graham, and her dance company opened a week's engagement at the Ziegfeld Theatre last night and proved themselves to be in remarkably fine shape for a stimulating season. There were no novelties on the program, if by that is meant premieres of new works, but "Dark Meadow," which was new last season, is still enough of a novelty to function as such for quite a while.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The text of President Truman's message to Congress recommending United States participation in the International Refugee Organization: To the Congress of the United States of America: I recommend that the Congress authorize the United States to participate as a member of the International Refugee Organization.

The public Service Commission ordered the Westcheater Street Transportation Company, Inc., yesterday to reduce fares for county bus commuters. It is expected that Westchester residents will save $100,000 annually as a result.
CHICAGO, Feb. 24 (AP) -- New record prices for pork-on-the-hoof today highlighted an upward surge in prices that spread throughout the nation's commodity markets.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 24 -- The United States lined up behind Britain today to support her charges that the Government of Albania had laid mines in the Corfu Channel that cost the lives of forty-four British seamen.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 24 -- Clarence A. Clough, former Mayor of Englewood and Closter, N.J., who was president of the Book Paper Association for many years, died here at his home this afternoon. His age was 64.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The Senate got notice today that, beginning March 10, it would be in day and night session two days a week, on Mondays and Wednesdays. The day shift, it was announced by Senator Robert A. Taft, majority Policy Committee chairman, is to start at noon and continue to around 5 P.M. The evening sittings will be from 7 o'clock to about 10, at least on an experimental basis.

LONDON, Feb. 24 -- The Government's supporters, as well as opposition members of Parliament, arc expected to insist that Britain increase the quota for Jewish immigration into Palestine when the full-scale debate on the Palestine problem comes up in the House of Commons tomorrow.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- The Stephens bill authorizing banks to close on Saturdays on a year around basis became law today with Governor Dewey's signature. It makes no requirement that banks remain closed on Saturdays but permits them to do so if they desire.

Substantial return to competitive pricing and exhibition on a large scale of quality merchandise marked the opening yesterday of the thirty-second semi-annual local Gift Show at the New Yorker and Pennsylvania Hotels. Buyers and exhibitors agreed that the development is a result of "the dismal failure" of the show held in Chicago last month, at which orders were few and far between because of retailer refusal to purchase shoddy, overpriced merchandise.

West Virginia, with a 15-and-1 record for the current campaign, has accepted a bid to participate in the tenth annual national invitation college basketball tournament which starts at Madison Square Garden on the night of March 15.

Benjamin F. Fairless, president of the United States Steel Corporation, denied here yesterday the Justice Department's allegation that the proposed acquisition of the Consolidated Steel Corporation of Los Angeles by the Columbia Steel Company, a subsidiary of United States Steel, would violate the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 24 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission will begin a hearing tomorrow on corporate simplification proceedings that it instituted last Dec. 5 against the Philadelphia Company, of Pittsburgh, Pa.

SECURITY COUNCIL The United States supported British charges that Albania had sown the Corfu Channel with mines that cost the lives of fortyfour British seamen, but favored a proposal for a fact-finding committee to examine evidence from both sides.

Paper has successfully invaded other fields of application during the war and can hold these gains if mill chemists and engineers develop a sales point of view, John W. Crosson of the Mead Sales Company told 1,500 paper industry technicians here yesterday.

Returning yesterday after speaking Saturday night in Topeka, Kan., Mayor O'Dwyer was confronted with a stir in the field of city welfare raised by the Welfare Council, which taxed his administration on Sunday with failure to meet the ctiy's most pressing welfare problems.

President Truman's message yesterday recommending that Congress authorize this country to join the International Refugee Organization must have had a particular interest for U. N. Secretary-General Trygve Lie. Mr. Lie has in his files a telegram from the IRO Preparatory Commission, in session at Geneva.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The House, spurred by reports that newsprint supplies in cities over the country had dropped to levels described as "critical" and "desperate," will vote on Wednesday on a resolution to establish a special committee to look into the paper situation.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As a free citizen and a thinking daughter of democracy I am moved to speak my mind in the present conflict between light and darkness symbolized by the conscienceless campaign of political goring and tossing against David E. Lilienthal.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Feb. 24 (AP) --Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Zaharias, irked because a play-off was called to decide the second women's international four-ball golf tournament, was badly off in her play today but won, 3 and 2, because of smooth work by her partner, Miss Peggy Kirk of Findlay, Ohio, against the defending champions, Miss Louise Sugg's of Lithia Springs, Ga., and Miss Jean Hopkins of Lakewood, Ohio.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The Moslem League's newspaper Dawn declared today the British Cabinet mission plan for giving India independence was "dead and cannot be revived," but expressed willingness to cooperate with the Congress party "in spheres that admit of common endeavor."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, promised speedy action today to implement American participation in the International Relief Organization, which was requested by President Truman yesterday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Purdue University officials will make the final decision on whether the school's basketball game with Wisconsin will be replayed, Kenneth L. Wilson, Western Conference commissioner, said today.

In a cash transaction, the Highway Improvement and Repair Company, Inc., sold the one and two-story office building and garage, frame sheds, concrete hoppers and other buildings used for manufacturing asphalt at Varick and Messerole Streets, Brooklyn, to the Albert Pipe Supply Company.

There were brilliant offerings at the concert of the Philadelphia Orchestra under Eugene Ormandy's direction last night in Carnegie Hall. Paul Creston's Second Symphony, heard for the second time in this city and the first at the Philadelphia Orchestra's concerts, had a remarkable success.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Feb. 25 -- Just before the Yankees took the field today to step into another inelegant trimming, this time at the hands of a Puerto Rican all-star team in twelve innings by a 7-to-6 score, Joe DiMaggio, who seems to be giving more prominence to the human heel than it has received since the days of Achilles, again moved into the spotlight.
LONDON, Feb. 25 -- The national need for larger newspapers in Britain was stressed here today by Lord Layton, chairman of the rationing committee of the Newsprint Supply Company.

Ribbon prices should continue at current levels for the balance of the year, it was indicated yesterday in a trade survey. Increased costs of raw materials appear to justify an increase in prices, but the counter-acting factor is a heavy decline in volume in some apparel trades which consume sizable quantities of ribbons.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25--President Truman, by executive order, gave substantial effect today to the Vandenberg-Millikin compromise to protect the reciprocal trade agreements program from piecemeal scuttling in Congress and to make "doubly sure that American interests will be safeguarded."

LONDON, Feb. 25 -- The possibility of breaking the deadlock over the British-Egyptian treaty without recourse to the United Nations Security Council was revived today. It was officially announced that the British Government welcomed the mediation offer by Syria and Lebanon.

The only way the Polar regions can be conquered is through the air. All other pathways into those forbidden wastes are frozen fast. But the air is an open ocean through which they may be reached. How rapidly that conquest is proceeding is emphasized both by the circling flights of Admiral Byrd's airmen in the Antarctic and the spectacular rescue of eleven downed Army fliers from the northwest tip of Greenland.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- A denunciation of every major restriction on labor now proposed in the Republican Congress was delivered today by one of the half-dozen most powerful union leaders in the United States, A.F. Whitney of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Lieut. Sen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, under whose direction the new United States central intelligence group has made such strides that it now is taking over intelligence activities from the Federal Bureau of Investigation in Latin America, is slated to leave the intelligence post in the near future.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 (U.P.) -- Robert W. Voigts, Cleveland Browns line coach, tonight was appointed head football coach of Northwestern University, succeeding his old mentor, Lynn Waldorf, under whose tutelage he became an AllAmerica tackle.
LONDON, Feb. 25 -- The last day of the account saw the stock markets today on the bright side, with many industrials closing higher.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- The Republican leadership of the Legislature rejected today a Democratic proposal that State rent controls become operative, with rentals frozen at existing levels, in the event Congress votes to relax Federal controls.

Frederick Brown has acquired from Benjamin H. Namm, Brooklyn department store owner, the entire square block bounded by Queens Boulevard, Van Dam Street, Skillman Avenue and Thirty-second Place in Long Island City, Queens, through Joseph M. May and David Lind, brokers.

The Cunard White Star liner Parthia, a 14,000-ton combination passenger and cargo ship especially designed for the North Atlantic trade, was launched in the Harland Wolff's shipyard, Belfast, Northern Ireland, at noon yesterday, it was announced here by the company.

The ready-to-wear division of the Fashion Group, Inc., met at luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore to hear a report on Paris and London fashions by Harriet Wilinsky, who has just returned from the fashion openings there. Miss Wilinsky, who was introduced by Kay Sullivan, president of the Fashion Group, is director of fashion promotion at Filene's in Boston and regional director of the Fashion Group in Boston.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 25 -- At this moment, according to its secretary general, Edgar Lalmand, the Belgian Communist party is following a very restrained line, including the temporary support of the constitutional monarchy, the insurance of the country's security and insistence on full reparations for the people's war sufferings.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 25 -- Mental health service to children on a world-wide basis, even including record forms which every country would agree to use, was presented as a possibility at tonight's dinner session of the Eastern regional conference of the Child Welfare League of America.

WESTBURY, L.I., Feb., 25 -- One GI Joe and his wife and dog are enjoying the comforts of a home to themselves after having been huddled in with six other persons ever since their marriage in 1943, and they have their own foresight and the cooperation of the Long Island Railroad to thank for what some folks might not call an ideal dwelling place.

The second phase of the two-way exchange of skiing a bassadors beween Norway, home of the sport, and the United States, comparative infant in the pastime, was completed yesterday when Walter Bietila of Iron Mountain, Mich., and Merrill (Mezzy) Barber, Brattleboro, Vt., left aboard a Scandinavian airliner DC-4 for Oslo to participate in the fiftieth annual Holmenkollen ski jump on Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- A penitent former Communist summoned by Senator Kenneth D. McKellar, Democrat, of Tennessee, as an opposition witness today surprised the Congressional Atomic Energy Committee by pleading for confirmation of David E. Lalienthal as chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- The Assembly Ways and Means Committee approved today a bill authorizing New York City to issue budget notes to finance the Christmas Eve pay increases it voted city employes for the remainder of the city's fiscal year.

Donald Wolfit's London company completes its cycle of five repertory plays this evening with the presentation of "Hamlet" at the Century Theatre. The curtain will rise on the Shakespearean drama at 8:15 P.M. The British actor-manager will essay the role of the Melancholy Dane and Rosalind Iden will be seen as Ophelia.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 19: Decreases of $201,000,000 in holdings of United States Government obligations, $168,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, and $357,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted.

New Jersey awarded yesterday an issue of $15,000,000 of highway and emergency housing serial bonds maturing from 1949 to 1982 to a banking syndicate headed by J.P. Morgan Co., Inc.; Drexel Co. and Shields Co., whose bid, representing an average interest cost of slightly less than 1.65 per cent, was the lowest of five submitted.
Leaders of the Protestant, Catholic and Jewish clergy joined the Citizens Housing Council yesterday in urging the public to force Government action to overcome the housing shortage.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Feb. 25 -- James Rendall Haden, manager of the merchandising department of the Richfield Oil Corporation of New York, 19 West Fiftieth Street, Manhattan, died here today at his home, 112 Fonda Road, of a heart attack.

Mrs. Olga Trapani Rocco, victim of a murder plot concocted by her husband, Alphonse, was discharged yesterday from Roosevelt Hospital, where her left leg was amputated. She was sent to the home of her parents, 1434 Fifty-seventh Street, Brooklyn, in an ambulance.

Fifteen charitable, educational or religious institutions are to share in the estate of Miss Mary Thurston Cockcroft, daughter of Jacob H.V. Cockcroft, who died Dec. 11, 1945, leaving a gross estate of $1,583,706 and a net of $1,452,379, according to a transfer tax appraisal approved yesterday by Charles W. Ferry, Deputy Estate Tax Appraiser.
LONDON, Feb. 25 -- Stocks of coal at British power stations continued to rise today, but at a discouragingly slow rate.

Korea's emergence in the headlines at the moment when Secretary Marshall and his advisers are working overtime on the formulation of American views on the German problem is no more irrelevant to the main issue of the Moscow conference than is the dark threat of economic collapse in Britain.

TOKYO, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Secretary of the Interior Julius A. Krug and Gen. Douglas MacArthur today advocated a speed-up of democratization processes for American-controlled islands of the Pacific and for Japan.

ROBERT PAYNE, that extraordinarily gifted young English writer who soared to fame with his magnificent "Forever China" a year and a half ago, is one of the most remarkable of living writers. He is a scholar steeped in both Western and Oriental literatures. He is an adventurer, a linguist, a teacher, a novelist and a poet.

The highest peacetime sales in the seventy-six-year history of the B.F. Goodrich Company and earnings more than double those of the year before were reported in the annual statement mailed to stockholders yesterday.
A labor dispute involving charges of anti-Negro discrimination delayed a ship due to leave here last night with twelve passengers on her first voyage in a new service to the Far East.

MOSCOW, Feb. 25 -- The automobile industry of the Soviet Union did not fulfill its production plan for 1946 and lost 140,000,000 rubles more than the "planned losses," according to S.S. Akopov, Minister for Industry in the Soviet Union.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 25 -- When the Soviet Union argues that other nations are wrong and inconsistent, that is an unfortunate but not unusual situation. When, however, it proclaims its own inconsistency, that is a new and abnormal development.

A nominating committee of the National Republican Club turned down last night W. Kingsland Macy for a third-term nomination as president of the club, and nominated instead Edward Rager, the recording secretary.

The United States would be required to give up its atomic energy plants at Oak Ridge, Tenn., and Hanford, Wash., before international safeguards were put into operation, if the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission accepted Russian proposals on international control, it was charged yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- Republican legislative leaders indicated today that a bill outlawing discrimination in institutions of higher learning because of race, religion, color or national origin, would be passed before the Legislature adjourns.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Feb. 25 -- Dr. Robert M.W. Kempner, who prosecuted Wilhelm Frick, member of the Nazis Inner War Council, before the International Military Tribunal, returned to Nuremberg from the United States today to take charge of the prosecution in the "ministries" cases to be tried by the Military Government Court.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The Soviet Government has consented to the American plan for a United Nations trusteeship over the former Japanese-mandated islands in the Pacific, with the United States exercising strategic control.

LAHORE, Punjab, India, Feb. 25 -- India's political issues in their most drastic form are projected into this predominantly Moslem Province. The cleavage between communities -- Moslems on one side and Sikhs and Hindus on the other -- seems to be growing daily.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 -- Frank R. Creedon, National Housing Expediter, announced today important upward revisions in rent limitations on prospective new apartment projects in the New York and Chicago areas.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- House Republican leaders were disclosed today to be working frantically to avert what they fear may be a disastrous party split over income tax reduction.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 25 -- President Truman's first peacetime visit of state to a foreign capital will be to a country that is on record as wanting financial aid and is hopeful of getting it. The events of the past week pointed to both the need for help and the new Administration's continuing efforts to justify it.

It is a "two-to-one bet" that the United States will not have to resort to war with Russia to solve the controversial issues between them, Edwin L. James, managing editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared yesterday.

Buyers' Total Lower Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 861 compared with 1,247 last week and 1,457 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 427 arrivals yesterday against 550 last Tuesday.

Mrs. William Ayres Gray Jr. of Hingham, Mass., has announced here the engagement of her daughter, Edith Stevens, to Roger Rushmore Earle, son of Mr. and Mrs. Horace B. Earle of West Dover, Vt., formerly of Plainfield, N.J. The wedding will take place in the late summer.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25 -- The Michigan Consolidated Gas Company, a subsidiary of the American Light and Traction Company, applied today to the Securities and Exchange Commission for authority to issue and sell $6,000,000 of first mortgage bonds at competitive bidding.

The situation in Korea, as pictured by General Hodge, United States commander in that area, has become so disturbing that the American Government cannot fail to take action to keep Korea from becoming another Poland and as such a threat to our occupation forces in Japan.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The $350,000,000 sought by the Truman Administration to fight starvation and economic retrogression in liberated countries would be dispensed under strict safeguards against its use for purposes other than the saving of lives, William L. Clayton, Under - Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, said today.

Mayor O'Dwyer moved suddenly yesterday to terminate the New York City Housing Authority's present board of five unpaid, parttime members, and to replace it by a three-member agency responsible directly to the Mayor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- A Senate Banking subcommittee, studying new rent-control proposals, came out today for continued control to the end of the year, a general 10 per cent increase in ceilings and the removal of rent administration from the Office of Price Adminstration.
Thomas C. Gibney and Edward Ferro have been elected president and first national vice president of the United States ImmigrationNaturalization Officers Association, it was announced here yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 25 -- Following is the text of the United States resolution submitted to the Security Council today: The Security Council, having received and considered the first report of the Atomic Energy Commission dated 31 December 1946, together with its letter of transmittal of the same date.

Securities priced at $5,480,000 will be offered to the public today by underwriting managers here, as follows: Southwestern Public Service Company -- 20,000 shares of 3.90 per cent preferred stock at $102 a share, by Dillon, Read Co., Inc.

Now in the heart of winter, when the earth is locked in sleep and the voice of the North Wind is heard moaning around the corners of the farmhouse at night, there is a stillness over the countryside. On days when high, filmy cirrus clouds make a veil between the sun and earth thin gray shadows run on the snow from barelimbed trees and from the tall silos by the barns.
Hubert L. Williams has been appointed assistant to the president and general manager of the American Plastics Corporation, Bainbridge, N.Y., manufacturers of casein. plastics.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 25 -- Jean Arthur, who has been absent from the screen since 1944, was signed today by Paramount to play the leading role in "The Hon. Phoebe Plummer," a photoplay which Billy Wilder and Robert Harari are writing.

Net profits after all charges, but before payment of dividends, during 1946, for all member banks in the Second Federal Reserve District, averaged 11.2 per cent of capital funds, compared with the peak of 11.6 per cent set in 1945, Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, announced yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 25 -- Bitterly attacked in a hostile House of Lords on its decision to quit India by June of next year, Britain's Labor Government defended itself today by asserting, "There is no satisfactory alternative to this policy."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Labor unity overtures bogged down further today. A letter from William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, to Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, indicated that unity of any kind is remote.

Maj. Gen. Graves B. Erskine, USMC, administrator of the Retraining and Re-employment Administration of the United States Department of Labor, recommended last night a comprehensive program for production and distribution of artificial limbs.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 -- The House of Delegates of the American Bar Association, after going on record in support of the United Nations in strong terms, asked today at its midwinter meeting that our Government remove a reservation from our adherence to a UN agency, the International Court of Justice.

A large-scale advertising campaign was started yesterday for the new automatic electric iron, called the Dream, a private brand of the Associated Merchandising Corporation, group buying office for twenty-five department stores. In development for more than a year, it is now coming off the production line at the Hartford Conn., plant of the Hartford Products Company.

Action by the Port of New York to meet growing competition from other harbors was urged yesterday by Louis W. Byrne, chief of the Port Promotion Bureau of the Port of New York Authority. He spoke at a luncheon of the Brooklyn Kiwanis Club in the Towers Hotel.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 25 -- Little Job Dean Jessop was the big man in today's activities at Hialeah Park, where he won with three of his four mounts, topping off the afternoon's chores with a triumph on Mrs. M.E. Whitney's Gustaf in the second division of the $4,000 East Coast Purse.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 25 -- Limited restoration of German industry under international control is necessary for world economic recovery and for the sake of future peace, a panel of five speakers agreed here today in a discussion of "Should German Industry Be Restored?"
Harold H. Spink has been appointed manager of the municipal department of Dempsey Co., members of the Chicago Stock Exchange. Earle J. Woodward has joined the firm's municipal department.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 25 -- Restitution to Jews whom the Germans robbed has made very limited headway here, although it soon will be two years since Czechoslovakia was liberated.
Willie Thompson, Florida chaingang fugitive, was identified yesterday by a 25-year-old actress as the man who attacked her in a taxicab last Thursday at Sixtysecond Street and Central Park West.

The Plymouth Garage at 234238 East Eighty-fifth Street has been purchased by the 154 East Eighty-seventh Street Garage, Inc., Emanuel Ornstein, president, which plans to take over the operation of the property as a public garage upon the expiration of the present tenant's occupancy.

The University of Kentucky, last year's winner, yesterday accepted bid to compete in the tenth annual national invitation intercollegiate basketball tournament, which will be staged in Madison Square Garden on March 15, 17, 19 and 21.
After making new highs for the move, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange went into a tail-spin yesterday and broke to net losses of 34 to 56 points on active months.

A trend toward simple pottery dinnerware, light in color and light in weight, is evident in new sets being shown this week to store buyers at the New York Gift Show in the Hotel New Yorker and Hotel Pennsylvania. In contrast to the usual rustic type of American pottery destined only for barbecues or midnight snacks, the new sets are colored and styled to blend with modern table settings.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- Senator Harold I. Panken, Manhattan Democrat, failed today in an attempt to force a floor vote on his resolution to investigate the State Liquor Authority, but created a decided stir with a charge of graft in the issuance of licenses.

Net profit of Cluett, Peabody Co., Inc., for 1946 amounted to $5,204,670 after all charges, including $3,438,634 provision for taxes, compared with $2,155,210 earned in 1945, when $1,576,665 was provided for taxes, the annual report showed yesterday.
HAVANA, Feb. 25 -- Branch Rickey was angered when he learned today of Jorge Pasquel's conference with forty Dodger players in the Hotel Nacional lobby late last night.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 25 (AP) -- C.V. Whitney's Burra Sahib won today's $5,000 feature race at Santa Anita, but a 5-year-old gelding, Valdina Gaylad, captured the sixth race and paid $82.80 to win.

Rocco Rossano of Brooklyn won a split decision over Bobby Ruffin of Astoria in the main clash of eight rounds at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn, last night. It was the eleventh straight victory for Rossano, who weighed 146. Ruffin, the favorite, weighed 140 1/2.
ALBANY, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Governor Dewey had no comment on Mr. Bevin's statements. He has frequently advocated opening Palestine to more Jews.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 25 -- Amid signs of growing tension, the public schools here remained crippled today in the worst teacher strike ever experienced in the United States.

LONDON, Feb. 25 -- The deputies of the Council of Foreign Ministers adopted today their reports on the German and Austrian treaties and ended their six weeks of hard work with the conviction that London was tough but Moscow was going to be even tougher.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 25 -- The Greek Government will ask the International Children's Emergency Fund to provide supplementary food for its entire child population, it was learned today.

Bertha Melnik, Hartford pianist who has been heard here only as an accompanist, last night gave a recital of her own at Town Hall. Her program included Bach's Italian Concerto, two Brahms' Intermezzi, Hindemith's Second Sonata and Mozart's F major Sonata, K. 332.

More than a thousand leaders of government, banking and finance are scheduled to attend the 1947 edition of "Financial Follies" on Saturday in the Astor Hotel, it was announced yesterday by Franklyn B. Dezendorf, president of the New York Financial Writers Association, Inc.

Most post-war plant expansion financing was made possible through the use of accumulated liquid assets and hot through the issuance of new stock or incurring new debts, according to an analysis of post-war corporate finance, released yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

LONDON, Feb. 25 -- American politics wrecked the possibility of an amicable solution of the Palestinian problem, Foreign Secretary Bevin charged today when he opened the debate on Palestine in the House of Commons.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The advisory board of the Office of War Mobilization and Reconversion told President Truman today that the adoption of guaranteed wage plans should not be the subject of legislative action, but should be referred to free collective bargaining.

Trustees of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., voted yesterday to redeem on April 1, $55,000,000 of first lien and refunding mortgage bonds, 3 1/4 per cent, Series D, due Oct. 1, 1965, and $30,000,000 of Series E bonds, due April 1, 1966, of the New York Edison Comapny, Inc.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25 -- Two smaller manufacturers of cigars announced here today price reductions on some of their most popular brands. Grabowsky Brothers, producers of the Royalist line have lowered queen and duke sizes from 16 to 15 cents, imperial size from 18 cents straight to three for 50 cents, and introduced a new 10cent size under the name of Regent.

The stock market reverted yesterday to the previous low levels for the month under a final-hour selling wave which carried prices back from 1 to 3 points and more. More than half of the day's business was crowded into the closing period when an onrush of selling forced the ticker tape to lag behind actual floor transactions.

General Mark W. Clark and Ambassador Robert Murphy, United States Deputies on the Council of Foreign Ministers, have placed before the representatives of Britain, France and Russia proposals submitted by the American Jewish Committee for inclusion in the peace treaties with Austria and Germany, the committee announced last night.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 25 (AP) -- Armed, America's handicap king, apparently unconcerned by a 2,500mile flight from Miami, settled down in royal style at Santa Anita Park today and made ready for another conquest of the turf in the $100,000 added Santa Anita Handicap Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25--John Foster Dulles of New York, Republican foreign policy expert, will accompany Secretary of State Marshall to the Moscow conference of the Big Four Foreign Ministers next month as special adviser.

PARIS, Feb. 25 -- Andre Philip, Minister of National Economy, author of the price-reduction decree issued today for application on March 1, and chief Cabinet apostle of a strictly planned economy outlined today his ambitious scheme of price controls.

New York State's battle to protect the beaches of Long Island from encroachment by the sea is outlined in a report to be submitted to the Legislature today by Assemblyman Edmund R. Lupton, chairman of a joint legislative committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Dr. Edwin G. Nourse, chairman of President Truman's Council of Economic Advisers, urged the nation's retailers today to use their "collective bargaining power" to obtain better prices and improved products from their suppliers in an effort to maintain high levels of production and sales.
Dr. T. Tertius Noble, the organist and composer who has been associated with St. Thomas Episcopal Church since 1913, will give his final organ recital there tonight at 8:30 o'clock.
The Friends of Democracy, Inc., liberal organization headed by L.M. Birkhead, offered a formula yesterday for identifying an American Communist.

California Has Paradoxes The capitalist system certainly does exhibit some startling contradictions, even if they are not always the big "inner contradictions" from which, according to the Marxians, capitalism must ultimately perish.

Miss Janice Marjorie Heistad, daughter of Mrs. Edward Castano of Garden City, L.I., and Alton M. Heistad of Manhasset, L.I., was married last night to Vernon Craggs, son of Mrs. Ross Vernon Craggs of Baltimore and the late Mr. Craggs, in St. Mark's Methodist Church in Brooklyn by the Rev. Dr. Ralph Emerson Davis.

The conviction by the police Hack License Bureau of a taxi driver on a complaint that he attempted to "load up" his cab was challenged yesterday by the City Wide Taxi Workers Union, which said it would make of it a test case in its campaign against alleged corruption and "gestapo tactics" in the Police Department.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 -- Present interest rates on home mortgages are likely to hold during 1947, and proposals for reductions on some types of private rental-housing loans are inadvisable, John H. Fahey, Commissioner of the Federal Home Loan Bank Administration, declared today.

ROME, Feb. 25 -- Premier Alcide de Gasperi's third Government obtained its first vote of confidence in the Constituent Assembly by a vote of 292 to 107 tonight at the end of a long, exhausting session.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 25 -- Libels calling for the seizure of more than 400,000 pounds of fish were filed in Federal court today in an unprecedented move. Such action usually follows the tracing of commodities through interstate commerce.

WESTOVER FIELD, Mass., Feb. 25 -- The eleven United States Army airmen whose B-29 crashed on Greenland's barren ice cap last Friday were flown here today by Lieut. Bobbie Joe Cavnar, 22 years old, in a C-54 transport plane.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 25 -- Proficiency in the almost forgotten art of hit-and-run plays an important role in the reconversion of the Giants, now in full-scale operation on the sun-flooded Municipal Stadium field here.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 -- All deliveries of grain, except May wheat and March corn and oats, sold at new seasonal high prices in the early trading on the Board of Trade today. Wheat reacted violently in the late trading, July receding 6 1/2 cents a bushel from the top, of which 5 cents came in the last fifteen minutes of trading.

Overwhelming sentiment in favor of a strike poll was indicated yesterday in eighteen New York City public schools when teachers voted on the question at faculty meetings. The results were announced last night by the Teachers Union, CIO, which has been urging that such a poll be taken among the city's 30,000 teachers.

MOSCOW, Feb. 25 -- Foreign diplomats here believe that Poland's western and northern frontiers and the United States' desire to place them under review will be one of the questions that Joseph Cyrankiewicz, new Premier of Poland, will discuss during his stay in the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The six crew members of the big fourengined "Red Tailed Raider" of the Army Transport Command, heroes of a dramatic and daring rescue of a stranded crew of a wrecked B-29 on Greenland, received air honors and warm congratulations today from Gen. Carl Spaatz, commanding general of the Army Air Forces.

Rising temperatures, a favorable five-day regional forecast, increased supplies of natural gas and ice-breaking operations on the Hudson River, signaled the release yesterday for most of the New York area from the discomfort and threatened suffering of the recent cold wave.

For the second performance of her series at the Ziegfeld Theatre last night, Martha Graham elected to present "Deaths and Entrances" and "Punch and the Judy," and to repeat "Appalachian Spring" from the opening program. It was a stunning performance all told, even though there have been several replacements in the company and some of them are perhaps not quite up to their predecessors in certain roles.

Mill prices of northern hardwoods in all grades have advanced from 10 to 15 per cent within the last thirty days despite continuing yard and industrial consumer resistance, manufacturers and wholesalers reported yesterday. It was emphasized that the advances apply not only to Northeastern hardwoods but also to lake States stock.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Prices for pork on the hoof ran wild today. Continued good demand, plus the fact that not enough pigs are coming to market these days to meet the supply, forced prices on the hog market here to a new record of $30 a hundredweight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission recommended to the Export Screw Association of the United States, Providence, R.I., and its members today that they readjust their business "to eliminate practices found to be violative of anti-trust Jawa."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States and the Twentieth Century Fund's committee on foreign relations headed an important group of organizations which endorsed in principle the International Trade Organization in testimony today before a Government panel.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- New wage and working demands will be served on the country's railroads in thirty to sixty days.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: "Record of Soviet Expansion Seems to Uphold Acheson: Maps, Russian Data Affirm Persistent Growth" -- so runs the heading of a Washington dispatch by James Reston in your issue of Feb. 18, embodying a detailed "record of territories taken over by the Soviet Union since the beginning of the second World War."

Secretary of the Navy James Forrestal defended the Navy's proposed $4,300,000,000 budget for 1947-48 in an address last night at a dinner of the Economic Club of New York in the Hotel Astor as a "drastically-pruned" national insurance premium.

The future world capital on the East River will be centered on a forty-story skyscraper scheduled for completion in time to move the entire United Nations from Lake Success, N.Y., to Manhattan by October of next year, according to official plans made public here yesterday for accelerating the work.

Condemning the present American intelligence set-up as inadequate for national defense, Maj. Gen. William J. Donovan, wartime head of the Office of Strategic Services, last night outlined for a capacity audience of fellow-lawyers and their guests his views on how the United States should operate in this field.
CLEVELAND, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft made some candid answers today as thirtytwo representatives of Cleveland's high school newspapers interviewed him at breakfast.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Feb. 25 -- Alfred Wesley Ingalls, 64 years old, a Boston lawyer, and his wife were charged by Federal authorities today with violating antislavery laws in their treatment for twenty-seven years of a Negro servant, Dora L. Jones, 57.

IF you are in the market for a horse, you'd better hop in an airplane fast and scoot out to Santa Anita where you will be privileged to bid for a passel of nags now owned by Louis B. Mayer. Since the movie magnate is a Hollywood character, the disposal sale of his racing division tomorrow night will be in the true Hollywood tradition -- colossal and super-colossal.
PEIPING, Feb. 25 -- The Kuomintang secret police have arrested 1,687 persons since last Tuesday in their hunt for all suspected of being even remotely connected with communism.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 25 -- The United States proposed today that the United Nations Security Council refer the entire question of international atomic control back to the Atomic Energy Commission, which approved the basic principles of the Baruch plan on Dec. 30.

Sweden has discovered that it is impossible to avoid regulating its foreign trade and its internal economy in a world of state trading nations, Ingvar Svennilson, director of the Swedish Institute of Industrial Research, told a luncheon meeting of the Export Managers Club at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.

The duck hunters who sat in their shirtsleeves in the blinds last fall and watched a bright sun gleam on their decoys will not be surprised to learn that they were not the only ones to be confused as a result of the bluebird weather.

RENO, Nev., Feb. 25 (AP) -- The Rev. Edmund Boyle's physician said today that the 30-year-old Reno priest, who six weeks ago underwent an operation involving the use of an eye taken from an executed murderer, had regained perfect vision.

Both spot and future hide prices softened here yesterday, reversing the upward trend of the last three weeks. The decline was accompanied by reports that the March export quota on domestic hides had been cut 25 per cent to 45,000 hides, against 60,000 in February.

New Jersey 1 3/4s New Jersey's four-hour delay yesterday in formally awarding its $15,000,000 bond issue to the banking syndicate that offered the lowest interest cost reflected Trenton's disappointment that 1 3/4 per cent interest had been designated and that the net cost, afer allowing for bidding premiums, just shaded 1.65 per cent.

Beno, who makes the custommade fashions for the Tailored Woman, has good taste in fabrics and a sense of the dramatic. Both were evident in the showing held by the Fifth Avenue specialty store in the white and gold suite of the Plaza Hotel yesterday afternoon.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 25 -- Harry William Croft, chairman of the board and a former president of the Harbison-Walker Refractories Company of Pittsburgh, with New York offices at 68 William Street, died here today at his home on Clapboard Ridge Road.

ORMOND BEACH, Fla., Feb. 25 (AP) -- Miss Mary Agnes Wall of Menominee, Mich., outstroked a field of top-ranking women golfers today to post the low medal score in the qualifying round of the South Atlantic tournament.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25--Labor witnesses said today that pending labor legislation aimed 'a body blow at our democracy."

The Girl Scout troop gives girls "an excellent opportunity to apply their religious instruction to everyday living," according to a declaration issued yesterday at the national headquarters of the organization, 155 East Forty-fourth Street.

Pulpwood scarcities were foremost among discussions at meetings of the pulp and paper manufacturers conventions at the Waldorf -Astoria and the Commodore Hotels yesterday. There are just two unexplored reservoirs of supply of pulping species of wood, E.W. Tinker, executive secretary, the American Paper and Pulp Association, revealed at the Tissue Association annual meeting.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 25 -- The Belgian Government has deliberately sacrificed the comfort and perhaps the welfare of some of its people in withholding coal from them in favor of the nation's industry.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 2 -- Every day for four months, the Russian shortwave-listening public has been getting a steady diet of impartial United Nations news -- complete, from controversies to personalities -- and first indication are that they like it and are ready for more.

The Appellate Division, after More than two hours of argument, reserved decision yesterday on a petition by the Longchamps restaurant chain to compel the State Liquor Authority to renew nine liquor licenses due to expire on Friday.

Unbeaten in their last seven home games, the New York Rangers tackle the Chicago Black Hawks in a National Hockey League game tonight on Madison Square Garden ice with high hopes of widening the margin between themselves and the Detroit Red Wings in the race for a place in the Stanley Cup play-offs.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial article, "Which Way Republicans?" is replete with evidence of the same misconceptions of the socalled reciprocal trade agreements program of the New Deal held by many as a result of intensive propaganda.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Secretary of State Marshall in a statement today expressed the profound hope that Indian political leadership would accept the "clear-cut challenge" of the British plan for independence and "proceed to break the impasse" between the Congress party and the Moslem League.

PARIS, Feb. 25 -- Paul Baudoin, who was former Marshal HenriPhilippe Petain's first Foreign Minister, was en route to the United States when he was arrested at the Spanish frontier a year ago, he told the High Court of Justice at his trial today.

Opening of wage negotiations covering 125,000 General Electric workers was delayed yesterday by a National Labor Relations Board hearing on charges of unfair labor practice growing out of a nineweek strike against the company last year.

Willard K. Rice, Harvard Club entrant, led the way into the second round by winning in straight games in the annual National Squash Tennis Association singles championship tournament that opened yesterday on the courts of the Columbia University Club.

Arthur W. Macmahon of the faculty of Columbia University announced yesterday that a statement favoring the appointment of David Lilienthal as chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, and signed by individual members of departments of political science in a number of colleges and universities throughout the country, had been sent to Senator Bourke B. Hickenlooper, Republican, of Iowa, chairman of the Senate Section, Committee on Atomic Energy.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The resolution introduced by Senator Desmond for a Commission on the Aged and the Aging in New York State merits widespread public support.

A mistrial was declared yesterday afternoon by General Sessions Judge Saul S. Streit on the second day of the football "fix" trial when a talesman unwittingly referred to the previous conviction of one defendant for bribing college basketball players.

BERLIN, Feb. 25--At a solemn two-and-a-half-hour session of the Allied Control Council today, representatives of the four occupation powers in Germany considered and approved their report to the Council of Foreign Ministers, which will meet on March 10 in Moscow to take up the problem of the defeated Reich.

PASSAIC, N.J., Feb. 25 -- Hundreds of persons lined the shores of the Passaic River this afternoon and watched three 10-year-old boys drown despite heroic efforts by policemen and civilians to effect a rescue. Two of the bodies were recovered within two hours.

Attendance which averaged more than 1,000 daily, with a high point one day of 1,860, at the show of "Significant War Scenes" at the International Salon in the Chrysler Building, has caused the closing of the exhibition to be postponed until March 15.
In many households the pressure cooker is as recent an enthusiasm as "Open the Door, Richard," but to Bradshaw Crandell it's an "oldie," dating back almost a decade.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 -- Fowler McCormick, chairman of the board of the International Harvester Company, told the American Management Association tonight, that the human relations business and industry will determine, in the long run, whether the American people will keep free enterprise or turn to some other economic system.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 25 -- Speaking at the sixty-fifth annual dinner of The Yale Daily News here tonight, Lord Inverchapel, British Ambassador to the United States, declared that it was one of his principal projects as envoy to this country to clear up a "wide and deep misunderstanding of the role which the British Commonwealth and Empire play in the world today.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25 -- Fred A. Hartley Jr. of New Jersey, chairman of the House Committee on Education and Labor, said here today that his committee would "write some equity into the labor laws." Its bills, he declared, would restore the right of free speech to employers, outlaw jurisdictional strikes and equalize the provisions concerning coercion and unfair labor practices.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 26 --When an American or a Russian joins the Secretariat of the United Nations he is supposed to put aside all national sentiment, which is difficult, and become an international servant without any political bias, which is probably impossible.

Half a dozen of the most talented textile designers of this country and Europe are represented in the collection of new fabrics introduced yesterday by Knoll Associates, Inc., as the Knoll International Group. The showing was held at 31 1/2 East Sixty-fifth Street where the concern has opened a decorators' showroom for its new textile division, headed by the former English designer Arundell Clarke.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--The House Rules Committee cleared today for floor debate tomorrow a bill to knock out portal-to-portal back pay claims and to limit the possible future liabilities of employers under all minimum wage laws.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--The American Federation of Labor softened its position today to concede the desirability of some alteration of the Wagner Act, but warned Congress that "a bitter hatred" was rising against the more far-reaching labor restrictions contained in pending bills.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26--Application of anti-trust laws to organized labor as well as industry to keep industry-wide bargaining from jeopardizing the public interest was urged here today by Cyrus S. Ching, director of industrial and public relations of the United States Rubber Company.

Ricardo G. Hill, former Mexican Consul General at New York, and Albert G. Lomas, who has been convicted twice of black market deals, were named yesterday in two Federal indictments involving illegal operations in textiles. In a third indictment Lomas is alleged to have made an illegal profit of $32,000 in the sale of over 200,000 yards of textiles at over-ceiling prices.

The American Repertory Theatre, temporarily abandoning its policy of strict repertory, will revive "Yellow Jack" beginning tonight at the International Theatre for a limited engagement of four weeks. The new scheme of things, actuated by the high costs of repertory production, is expected to effect a saving of about $3,000 a week for the company.

Ernest Bloch's string quartet was heard for the first time in public performance in this city at the concert given by the Griller Quartet last night in Town Hall. This highly modern and profoundly individual composition had as a background another novelty, and a beauty, resuscitated from the seventeenth century--the D minor quartet, or, historically speaking, the "consort in ffoure parts"--of Matthew Locke, a great master of his period.

Catering as a career was far from the mind of Tino Vasquez when he came here ten years ago from his native Cuba to study design and interior decorating, but today this talented young man has found a satisfying way of expressing his artistry through the preparation of food that's as beautiful to look at as it is to eat.

Dangers of the sellers' market for pulp and paper products include over-expansion, over-pricing and excessive wage structures, Reuben B. Robertson, president, American Paper and Pulp Association, warned more than 500 members of the industry yesterday at their luncheon meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria.
Leading educators of New York City's most important teacher training institutions were divided yesterday in their opinions regarding the right of teachers to strike.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 26 --Sir Alexander Cadogan, chief British delegate to the United Nations, conferred with Mr. Lie today to explore the chances of putting the Palestine controversy in the United Nations' hands before the Assembly meets in September.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--Representatives of two large groups of American producers of commodities, cotton and petroleum, registered today strong objection to projected establishment of production quotas and price agreements under the International Trade Organization, at hearings on the provisional charter for ITO.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Governor Dewey states in his special message to the Legislature on the State bonus to veterans that the bonus arises from the tenderest sentiments of gratitude and loyalty among our people. He then proposes possible tax increases for the next ten years to pay for the bonus.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 26--The Communist daily newspaper Borba charged today, that United States Ambassador Richard C. Patterson Jr. had "inaccurately and maliciously" misinformed the American public in regard to Yugoslavia.

LONDON, Feb. 26--It was authoritatively learned today that the Government had taken up with the United Nations' Secretariat in New York the possibility that the Palestine issue might be carried to the organization before September, when the General Assembly is scheduled to meet.

EVER since Abe Greene, president of the National Boxing Association, declared that the NBA would not recognize the suspensions that the New York State Athletic Commission had meted out to Rocky Graziano and Ray Robinson but that they could do their leathertossing in NBA States, the repercussions have been violent.
ALBANY, Feb. 26--A constitutional amendment to provide a four-year term for State Senators was rejected by the Assembly today. The final vote was 41 to 86.

John A. Coleman announced yesterday his intention of retiring as chairman of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange at the conclusion of his fourth term in May. Prior to assuming the chairmanship he had served five years as a governor.

Gregor Piatigorsky's recital last night at Carnegie Hall was an exhibition of 'cello playing in its highest estate, and also evidenced the eminent artist's gift as a program -maker. The interesting and comprehensive schedule consisted of classic, romantic and contemporary offerings, and in each of these categories he found worthwhile works to present that were off the beaten track.

The stock market experienced yesterday its second sharp reversal of the week, which, in effect, completed the cancellation of the January -February upturn. Losses of 1 to 3 points again were sprinkled liberally through the list, the composite rate declining more than a point.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 26-- Pennsylvania captured its fifth Eastern intercollegiate basketball victory of the season tonight by downing Princeton, 49 to 37, before 3,300 fans.

Details of the new plan whereby the banks and factors directly concerned will furnish $1,500,000 in new capital and will continue Motty Eitingon Co., fur dealers and processors, as a "going concern" were presented and endorsed by representatives of all types of creditors at the meeting held yesterday in the United States Court House.

It would be a tragedy if Congress did not promptly vote the $350,000,000 which President Truman asks to stave off starvation. In Europe and China. It would be hardly less tragic if members who are seeking economy in the wrong places should succeed in scaling down the amount of the appropriation.

YONKERS, N.Y., Feb. 26--The blast that awoke hundreds of families here early this morning and set them to shivering over imagined calamities ranging from burglary to an atomic attack was still a mystery to local officials late today.

Uncertainty settled over the city's financial district yesterday. Wall Street observers were at no loss to explain the situation. The Trinity Church clock, guardian of Wall Street punctuality, had stopped.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--The Federal Air Coordinating Committee informed President Truman today that use of Arctic air routes would shorten flights between the United States and Northern Europe and Asia but additional communications and navigation aids are necessary for safe civil air operations in that region.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP)-- The House Committee on unAmerican Activities proposed today to create a Federal Loyalty Commission with power to discharge Federal employes whose loyalty to the United States is in doubt.

The 1946 annual report of the Radio Corporation of America, being released today to the company's 215,000 stockholders, shows a net income of $10,985,053, equal to 56.4 cents a common share, compared with $11,317,068, or 58.8 cents a share in 1945.

ALBANY, Feb. 26--In a letter sent yesterday to Republican and Democratic legislative leaders the New York State Catholic Welfare Committee asked for the defeat of the pending Austin-Mahoney bill designed to eliminate racial and religious discrimination in institutions of higher learning.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26--Federal Government support of fundamental scientific research is the "logical ultimate procedure" because of the tremendous investment required and the unpredictability of results, Dr. Karl T. Compton, president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, asserted here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--The International Fund, which becomes operative Saturday as the planned over-all stabilizing influence in international exchange, will apply strict tests to applications by member countries for loans to tide over exchange difficulties, Camille Gutt, executive director of the fund, asserted here today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP)-- R.V. Fletcher, president of the Association of American Railroads, said today that the announced objectives of the newly formed Federation for Railway Progress, sponsored by Robert R. Young of the Chesapeake Ohio, "offer no material area for conflict" with his organization.

MEADOWMERE PARK, L.I., Feb. 26--Two 3-year-old boys, cousins, were rescued today from the ice-filled waters of a Jamaica Bay inlet by the mother of one of the boys and the father of the other. The parents plunged into the bay after the boys as they struggled in water over their heads.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: At the end of hostilities there was a tremendous cry against the retention of any controls on building. Many pretended that the abolition of ceiling prices and priorities would create a wave of residential construction and that the private developer would then come into his own and give the nation the housing it needs.

Several steamship lines with permanent terminals in the Port of New York have had pier rental increases since the end of the war, and they are worried by indications that the city plans further rises affecting their operating costs, it was learned yesterday.

TORONTO, Feb. 26 (AP)--The front-running Montreal Canadiens defeated the runner-up Toronto Maple Leafs, 1-0, tonight in a National Hockey League contest that featured a goal tenders' duel between Montreal's Bill Durnan and Toronto's Turk Broda.

ALBANY, Feb. 26--New York State was asked today to supervise all security transactions not now under jurisdiction of the Securities and Exchange Commission in a bill introduced by Assemblyman William E. Clancy, Queens Democrat.

LONDON, Feb. 26--Hard pressed in the House of Lords by a savage Opposition attack on its decision to leave India, the British Government revealed today that the strategic basis of its new policy was the desperate hope of retaining a major share in the defense of an independent India.
ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 26--A rival Democratic party movement was launched in Georgia today to oppose the faction headed by Assembly -elected Gov. Herman Talmadge.

LONDON, Feb. 26--Britain's current difficulties have not in the slightest degree weakened the Government's support of the international effort to restore multilateral trade and reduce trade restrictions.

FORT MONROE, Va., Feb. 26-- A small staff of fewer than 1,000 officers, enlisted men and Wacs controls from this historic military post the Army's ground troops in this country. The Army Ground Forces, Gen. Jacob L. Devers, commanding, moved its headquarters to Fort Monroe from Washington some months ago.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 26--Although the guarantee of work and wages has become an important management issue, the great majority of business managers have not given it the attention it deserves, it was charged today by Prof. Joseph L. Snider of the Harvard Business School.

Lewis W. Douglas expressed his personal conviction yesterday that "of course there is a way out" of the present British economic crisis. The Ambassador-designate to the Court of St. James, in his first comment on his new task, drew a parallel between the wartime behavior of the British people and their peace-time problems.

ALBANY, Feb. 26--The Senate and Assembly, acting separately, rejected today five of the six proposals made by Mayor William O'Dwyer for increasing state aid to New York City by $102,000,000. The sixth was not pressed, for a vote because it is being amended.

The long-smoldering feud between right and left wing sections of the national council of the National Maritime Union, CIO, has flared up with the formal filing of charges by NMU President Joseph Curran against Joseph Stack, vice president, it was learned yesterday.

PEIPING, Feb. 26--The Chinese Communist party, which has flatly refused for the past eight months to permit the United States Government to send Consul General Edmund O. Clubb to his post in Communist-occupied Harbin, has given the British Government permission to set up a British consulate in Harbin in the near future, it was authoritatively learned here today.

Mayor O'Dwyer assailed last night as "unconscionable" a statement by G. Howland Shaw, president of the Welfare Council of New York City, listing various social and health needs of the city. While admitting "there may be deficiencies which require correction," the Mayor made public a point-by-point answer citing the accomplishments of his administration in health, welfare, hospital and recreation services.

The Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation, will terminate allocations on all table and portable radios some time in May, Benjamin Abrams, president, disclosed in an interview yesterday. Mr. Abrams reported that his organization has appreciably increased allocations to distributors on all but the models in heaviest demand since the first of the year.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 26 (AP)-- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll is seeking a formula to provide $2,400 minimum salaries for school teachers in the State's larger communities, an executive office source said today. A $2,000 to $2,400 minimum in smaller municipalities is also being sought, it was reported.

ISHPEMING, Mich., Feb. 26 (AP) --The weatherman was the winner for the fifth consecutive day today as strong winds swirled across Suicide Hill, spilling one trial rider so badly that he was sent to the hospital and forcing further postponement of the national ski jumping championship.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Beginning tomorrow the State Department will rearrange its program of daily broadcasts of one hour to Russia to lighten and enliven them, as a result of criticisms received in the first nine days of the operations.

The $5,000,000 building fund campaign of the New York Infirmary has passed the $1,000,000 mark, Miss Evelyn Blewett, executive director of the fund, said yesterday at the infirmary, 321 East Fifteenth Street.
