She made the announcement while greeting two women doctors from Prague, Czechoslovakia, Dr. Ludmila Brumlik and Dr. Vlasta Di Lotti, who toured the infirmary, staffed entirely by women physicians and surgeons.

The domestic wool industry was challenged today to show any injury from imported goods in a brief filed yesterday with the Committee for Reciprocity Information in Washington. America's reciprocal trade agreements program was strongly supported and further reductions in tariffs as permitted by law were urged.

The ice was full of Bentleys at Madison Square Garden last night. The fast-skating brothers --Doug and Max--who constitute whatever scoring threat there exists in the ranks of the Chicago Black Hawks, manifested the power that lurks in their sticks as the led the Windy City sextet to a 9to-7 success over the New York Rangers in the National Hockey League tussle before a crowd of 14,907 fans.

Deposits and resources of the commercial banks and trust companies chartered by New York State declined almost $4,000,000,000 during 1946, according to year-end figures made public yesterday by Elliott V. Bell, Superintendant of Banks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP)-- The Maritime Commission today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to direct the country's railroads and domestic shipping companies to settle the issues between them on rates and practices by direct negotiations.

A banking group headed by the National City Bank made offering yesterday of $1,250,000 of De Kalb County, Ga., School District 2 per cent building bonds, due Jan. 1 from 1948 to 1977 at prices to yield from 0.85 per cent to 2.20 per cent.
BUFFALO, Feb. 26--With the complete breakdown of the educational system here today, all public schools were ordered closed for the duration of the emergency.

Charles R. Haffenden, war-time intelligence officer for the Navy, said yesterday that he was unable to gauge the value of information supplied to the armed forces by the gangster, Charles (Lucky Luciana) Luciano, during World War II.

BERLIN, Feb. 26--A British military train en route from Berlin to Minden in the British zone was halted by Russian troops on the Soviet-British border early this morning. After an inspection of the entire train Russian officers ordered the last car containing German civilians detached and returned to Berlin.

"Winners and Losers" Nicholas Biel calls the first play produced by the Associated Playwrights at the Henry Street Playhouse last evening. None of us who ventured that far southeast of the Crossroads of the World in search of revolutionary talent counted ourselves among the winners.
A $1,900,000 annual increase in the rates charged to gas customers was sought yesterday by the Brooklyn Union Gas Company in an application filed with the Public Service Commission.

BALTIMORE, Md., Feb., 26-- Preventive mental health programs in American communities were strongly urged by speakers at today's final session of the Eastern Regional Conference, Child Welfare League of America.

DETROIT, Feb. 26--A more temperate approach toward contract negotiations on the part of the United Automobile Workers, resulting in large part from the danger of restrictive legislation in Congress, has been indicated plainly here in recent weeks.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Feb. 26--The Soviet Union today supported an American proposal that the United Nations Security Council accept the United States as the trustee for the former Japanese mandated islands in the Pacific without waiting for the peace treaty with Japan to be signed.

Reversing its previous position, the Russian Government has now expressed approval of the American trusteeship plan for the Japanese-mandated islands in the Pacific as "entirely fair." As stated by Mr. Gromyko in the Security Council yesterday this approval appears to be based primarily on a new Russian acknowledgment that American forces played a decisive role in the victory over Japan.

Gus Lesnevich, who risks his light heavyweight title against Billy Fox of Philadelphia at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night, concluded his training yesterday with a strenuous workout that saw him step five fast rounds. He scaled 178 pounds before the session and, according to his handlers, will have no trouble getting down to the class limit of 175 pounds.

Show 5 New Frigidaire Ranges Five new models in the 1947 electric range line of the Frigidaire division of General Motors Corporation will be in dealers' stock in the metropolitan area and portions of New Jersey within a week, J.T. Collins, district manager of the Frigidaire Sales Corporation, told 700 district dealers and salesmen yesterday at an exhibit in the Essex House.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 26-- RKO announced today that Cary Grant will play the leading role in "Weep No More," a screen melodrama by Manny Seff and Paul Yawitz which the studio has owned since 1945. The property, which has been on the shelf at RKO for more than a year, was revived by Producer Robert Sparks and has been scheduled for filming late in 1947.

BALBOA, Canal Zone, Feb. 26 (AP)--The Grace Line steamship Lookout reported tonight that she had taken aboard all the forty-one crewmen of the 10,296-ton tanker Royal Oak, which was abandoned in a sinking condition off Galera Point approximately twenty miles from Esmeraldas, Ecuador.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 26 --Yachtsmen, commercial ship operators and village officials here will have a new opportunity on March 27 to convince the War Department that extensive remodeling of Port Chester Harbor on Long Island Sound should be performed by the Federal Government, according to a notice from the department received here this afternoon.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Feb. 26--Mederic Bleau, owner of a barber shop here, was fined $50 today for charging a Negro student at Williams College $3 for a haircut that usually costs $1.
The Appellate Division voted four to one last night to uphold the State Liquor Authority in refusing to renew the liquor licenses of the nine Longchamps Restaurants. The licenses expire tomorrow.

Walter D. Hoag Jr. of the Yale Club, top-seeded player, led the way into the quarter-final round of the annual National Squash Tennis Association championship tournament last night by beating R.P. Meffert, a clubmate, 15-3, 17-16, on the Columbia University Club courts.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--The Senate voted 51 to 33 today for a $4,500,000,000 reduction in President Truman's $37,500,000,000 budget for the 1948 fiscal year.

ELMENDORF FIELD, Alaska, Feb. 26 (AP)--Search planes fanned out from this Anchorage Army air base today scanning the Alaska peninsula wilderness for an Alaska Air Command superfortress missing since yesterday with a crew of eleven.
MOSCOW, Feb. 26--The policies of the United States and the Soviet Union regarding Germany, now firmly established, are near enough in theory but poles apart in fact.

NANKING, Feb. 26--Communist New Forth Army forces under Gen. Chen Yi have achieved "the biggest victory of the war" in Shantung, according to a Yenan report made public by the Communist liaison office in Nanking. The Communists said they "annihilated" two Kuomintang armies consisting of six divisions in one area and another division in another area.

Former associates on the General Sessions bench, other jurists and political leaders joined with prominent Catholic clergy and laity yesterday in final tribute to former Judge Cornelius F. Collins, at a service in St. Stephen's Church, 149 East Twenty-eighth Street.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26 (AP)--While prices of hogs receded appreciably today from yesterday's record heights, cattle and sheep reached their highest levels in six weeks. This was attributable to higher quality rather than to unduly sharpened demands.

A dozen actresses from the stage and radio will go into training next Tuesday to become workers in a national project through which the American Theatre Wing's Hospital Committee plans to develop local recreational programs in the Veterans Administration's neuropsychiatric hospitals throughout the nation.

World Bank Announcement Disclosure yesterday by Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder that an announcement regarding the World Bank may be expected within a few days was received with considerable satisfaction by financial observers here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--Members of the Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee stated today that they favored a Governmental agency to handle jurisdictional disputes over rival work claims if the unions failed to decide these matters themselves.

A genuine couture elegance prevailed yesterday afternoon in the Elizabeth Arden Salon where Castillo's third collection of fashions made in this country was presented to an invited audience. No doubt about it, this young Paristrained, Spanish designer has ideas that he knows how to translate into good clothes.

DOVER, Del., Feb. 26 (AP)--Delaware teachers swarmed into the State Capitol today to protest a wage-increase bill which they consider inadequate, and, upon recess of the Senate, some went down from the gallery to mill about the Senators and become involved in a brief skirmish.
ORMOND BEACH, Fla., Feb. 26 (AP)--All of the favorites won their first-round matches today in the South Atlantic women's golf tournament over the Ormond Beach Club course.

PANAMA, Feb. 26--Five hundred seagoing merchantmen aggregating 2,000,000 tons are now registered in Panama, it was reported today. Of these 142 were transferred from the American flag. Numerous other small coastwise fishing and pleasure craft fly the Panama flag.
Edward J. Kelly has been appointed works manager of Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation.
The proposed Federal legislation which would have brought about the registration of firearms died in committee, sharing the fate of similar bills introduced in the past.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 26 (U.P.)-- Armed, golden gelding of the turf, took his first workout at Santa Anita Park today since flying here from Florida and horsemen agreed the Calumet Farm speedster was ready for Saturday's $100,000 added Santa Anita Handicap.
In an active session, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 33 to 47 points net higher than the day before.

ROME, Feb. 26--Two small inhabited centers in Sicily are directly threatened by a stream of incandescent lava flowing down the sides of Mount Etna, which entered into a phase of violent eruption on Monday. They are Cisterna di Collabasso, which has only a few houses, and Passo Pisciaro, which has about 300 inhabitants.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26--Representative Jesse P. Wolcott, chairman of the House Banking and Currency Committee, told the National Association of Home Builders tonight that he would introduce a measure in Congress immediately calling for virtually complete decontrol of the housing industry.

The class, business and technical press in the foreign field is developing into a powerful force to stimulates the world's march toward economic recovery, George E. Quisenberry, vice president and editorial direetor, Business Publishers International Corporation, told a luncheon meeting of the Export Advertising Association, Inc., at the Belmont-Plaza yesterday.
Former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman called upon Governor Dewey yesterday to let the people of the State decide whether new funds should be provided for low-rent public housing.

Grave danger of further automotive production cutbacks, now foreshadowed by shutting down of open hearths in steel mills, have developed from critical scrap scarcities, Albert J. Browning, vice president and director of purchases of Ford Motor Company, disclosed last night.

Five thousand service employes in 700 midtown office and loft buildings will receive wage increases of 21 1/2 cents an hour under an arbitration award made public yesterday by David Sullivan, president of Local 32-B of the Building Service Employes International Union, AFL.

Dismissal of the Federal Trade Commission complaint charging conspiracy in restraint of trade was asked yesterday by Elias Liebeman and Norman Roth, counsel for the Blouse and Waist Makers Union, Local 25.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 25 (AP)--Twenty Russian soldiers headed by a general have arrested Bela Kovacs, anti-Communist member of Parliament, and members of the dominant Smallholders party declared today that the act was a "direct intervention" in internal affairs.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Feb. 26--Hanging perilously on the brink of a third straight defeat at the hands of a curiously inspired array of Puerto Ricans, the Yankees righted themselves just in time today. They poured four runs across in the ninth inning with the help of a couple of obliging errors and with this outburst downed the San Juan All-Stars, 8 to 6.
Wearable and typically American were the custom-made fashions presented yesterday by Milgrim, 6 West Fifty-seventh Street. Street dresses measured fourteen inches from the floor.

By a vote of 6 to 1 the Board of Education yesterday banned Howard Fast's historical novel, "Citizen Tom Paine," from the public school libraries of New York City. This action, based upon allegedly vulgar passages to the book, upheld recommendations of the Board of Superintendents and the Committee on Instructional Affairs.
PARIS, Feb. 26--Some reservations were expressed today in several sectors of the economy to the Government's new price reduction effective on Saturday.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14, a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

Artists planning to submit paintings to Pepsi-Cola's fourth annual art competition, "Paintings of the Year," were reminded yesterday by Roland McKinney, director of the competition, that March 15 is the deadline for receipt of entry blanks. They must be addressed to Mr. McKinney at 9 West Fifty-seventh Street, New York 19.

With the national champions, John Kramer and Miss Pauline Betz, heading the lists, the most attractive national indoor tennis tournament held in a long spell will start today at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 26 --Traffic and parking congestion in urban areas throughout this country, with resultant widespread blight to business, has not yet reached its peak, Thomas H. MacDonald, United States Commissioner, of Public Roads, said today at the opening session of the twenty-third annual convention of the Association of Highway Officials of the North Atlantic States.

A further increase last week on 856,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end total stocks were 103,904,000 barrels, compared with 103,048,000 a week earlier and 104,921,000 on Feb. 23, 1946.

MOSCOW, Feb. 26--Restoration of Soviet grain production to its pre-war level in the next three years is the immediate major objective of Russian agriculture, according to I. A. Benediktov, Minister of Agriculture.

LONDON, Feb. 26--The worried House of Commons heard a Government spokesman propose today putting one-third of the manufacturing industry on a night shift to keep Britain's economy going in face or the long duration of the fuel and power shortage.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Feb. 26-- The American Telephone and Telegraph Company filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $200,000,000 of 35-year debentures due on April 1, 1982, while three other companies rgeistered common stock.

SAIGON, French Indo - China, Feb. 26-The Viet Nam President, Ho Chi Minh, has addressed a new personal appeal to the French Government for the cessation of hostilities in northern Indo-China, it was disclosed today. It proposes a return to the political relationship existing at the outbreak of the fighting at Hanoi on Dec. 19.

Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander called a press conference yesterday which Deputy Chief Inspector Thomas F. Berkery, in charge of the Hack License Bureau, denied that members of his staff had taken graft from taxicab drivers or used "Gestapo tactics" against them.
BRUSSELS, Feb. 26--Disorder reigned in the Belgian capital this afternoon when 50,000 discontented war veterans staged one of the worst riots this city has known for many years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--Senator Robert F. Wagner, Democrat, of New York, reappraising in a magazine article the act which bears his name, writes that he is "very proud" to have been the bill's author and that it has been successful in reducing strikes over union recognition, for which, he says, it was written.

NORWALK, Conn., Feb. 26 -- After an exhaustive study to determine what a fair and equitable salary schedule for teachers should be, a committee of three prominent educators recommended here tonight that it should range from a beginning minimum of $2,400 to more than $6,000 for "master teachers."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--A statutory yardstick for measuring injury caused domestic producers by tariff reductions was proposed in the Senate today to "implement" President Truman's Executive Order of yesterday for further safeguarding American interests in reciprocal trade agreements.

Foreign Secretary Bevin's charge that American politics prevented the solution of the Palestine problem was vehemently denied yesterday by Dr. Abba Hillel Silver chairman of the American Zionist Emergency Council.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 26--Frere Jacques had to travel too far under too much weight in the $15,000 added Miami Beach Handicap at Hialeah Park today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE NEW YORK TIMES editorial entitled "Strikes Against Government" smacks of the partisanship so characteristic of your editorials on the teachers' salary campaign. It is quite obvious that your editorial writer does not take seriously or reads hastily the columns of THE TIMES and especially the brilliant articles of Benjamin Fine which deservedly attracted nation-wide attention.

HONOLULU, Feb. 26 -- The transfer of much of the administration of the United States-controlled Pacific islands from the military to a civilian sphere as soon as possible was advocated here today by Secretary of the Interior Julius A. Krug upon his return to Hawaii for a four-day visit after a tour of the western Pacific and Japan.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--R.V. Fletcher, president of the American Association of Railroads, told a closed meeting of a subcommittee of the Senate Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee today that railroads were in dire need of freight cars but that it was impossible at this time to estimate how many they would purchase this year.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., Feb. 26--Dr. Harry D. Gideonse, president of Brooklyn College and Freedom House, today voiced hope that the forthcoming Moscow conference would be a failure and called for an immediate strengthening of a western European bloc with British-American support.

ALBANY, Feb. 26--Over objections that the action would merely add to insurance companies' profits at the expense of policy holders, the Senate passed today and sent to Governor Dewey for signature the so-called Guertin bill.

Excerpts from a statement yesterday by Warren R. Austin, United States representative, before the United Nations Security Council follow: Mr. President, the United States, like other nations adhering to the United Nations Declaration of Jan. 1, 1942, subscribed to the Atlantic Charter principle that "their countries seek no aggrandizement, territorial or otherwise."

SAIGON, French Indo-China, Feb. 18 (Delayed)--Frenchmen as well as neutrals here severely criticize the new law that drastically limits immigration and alien commercial enterprise and in effect enables the High Commissioner to expel any person, at his absolute discretion.

Pictures and Precedents Of all the pictures in the sports pages the basketball photos are beyond compare the most attractive. They are in a class by themselves. Nothing in our modern graphic art so intimately recalls the pattern on a Greek urn or temple frieze as the group clustered around the basket during the high moment of suspense before a score or a miss.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--The House approved today the creation of two special committees to deal with the problems of small business and to investigate the inadequacy of supplies of newsprint and other paper products.

Developing a master plan for hospitals and related facilities in New York City, the Hospital Council of Greater New York recommended yesterday establishment of community, regional and central hospitals for general care and to provide for medical education, training and research.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 28--Fearing that any further serious outbreaks of terrorism may bring the dissolution of the Jewish Agency For Palestine, a new "shadow" leadership is in the making. So far it is only in the discussion stage.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--President Truman sent to Congress today a draft of a proposed bill on unification of the armed forces under a new, over-all national defense establishment. It represents the compromise views of the Army, Navy and Air Forces.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--Owen D. Young, former president of the General Electric Company, volunteered today a strong testimonial for confirmation as chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission of David E. Lilienthal, a man he has regarded as an "adversary" for nearly twenty years.

Winner of its last seven games, Indiana State will shoot a starting line-up of four freshmen and a sophomore against St. John's University of Brooklyn tonight in the feature contest of the college basketball doubleheader at Madison Square Garden.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 26 (AP)-- Adm. Jonas Howard Ingram, Commander -in-Chief of the Atlantic Fleet until last September, was named today as commissioner of the All-America Football Conference.

ALBANY, Feb. 26--Several hundred representatives of organized sportsmen's group jammed into a public hearing on conservation bills today to oppose construction of the projected Higley mountain reservoir.

Never in his palmiest days as a fictional hero at Yale did Frank Merriwell accomplish for the Bulldog's what Al Vogel, Columbia's left forward, did for the Lions last night before a hysterical crowd of 2,700 that crammed the Morningside Heights gymnasium.

Domestic controversies formed the largest single category of problems presented last year to the Legal Aid Society, Whitney North Seymour, its president, reported yesterday at the seventy-first annual meeting at the Down Town Association, 60 Pine Street.

Having shown himself in the title roles of "King Lear" and "Volpone," as the Shylock of "The Merchant of Venice" and the Trouchstone of "As You Like It," Donald Wolfit came forth last night at the Century Theatre as the unhappy prince of "Hamlet," the last of his company's cycle of plays to be displayed here during the limited engagement.

LONDON, Feb, 26 (AP)--Along Europe's ice-choked waterways, engineers sought today to save bridges from rising rivers as the first signs of a major spring thaw forecast the end of one of Europe's worsts winters on record.

HAVANA, Feb. 26--Despite pronouncements only yesterday about keeping Pete Reiser out of ball games until April 1, Pistol Pete went into action today in the first intra-camp contest of the Dodgers' training campaign. In fact, with one exception, the Regulars, who beat the Yannigans, 3-1, in four and a half innings, probably presented a preview of the team that will open the season.

SALONIKA, Greece, Feb. 26 (U.P.)--The United Nations Balkan Investigating Commission has decided, over the protest of United States and British delegates, to hear the testimony of Gen. Markos Vifiades, self-styled commander in chief of the "Free Democratic Army" in Greece.

"GENTLEMEN'S AGREEMENT,"* by Laura Hobson, is bound to be one of the most discussed novels of the year. In fact, it is already one of the most discussed novels of the year. It is the story of a great impersonation with a startling difference, a courageous and penetrating study of human bigotry in terms of human lives.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--The White House, in an unprecedented statement, publicly rebuked Foreign Secretary Bevin of Britain tonight for his "unfortunate and misleading" suggestion that the American interest in Palestine and the settlement of Jews there was motivated by partisan and local politics.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26--The grain markets here fluctuated in a very nervous manner on the Board of Trade today, wheat having a range of 3 to 5 3/4 cents and at one time was off as much as 2 cents from yesterday's close. However, corn showed independent strength and late in the session started upward rapidly and caused a rally in other grains.
Those ardent believers in all good things associated with Brooklyn are at it again. Now they have banded together to form an organization called the FFB--First Families of Brooklyn.

LONDON, Feb. 26--The stock markets made a good start today to the new account. A more cheerful tone was attributed to the improving coal position, announcement of some good dividends and the prospect of a resumption of general industrial production.

Their play-off chances none too secure, the New York Knickerbockers collapsed in the face of a sizzling drive by the Washington Capitols before 4,492 disappointed fans at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night. The 84-60 beating from the Eastern division pacesetters cut New York's third-place lead over Providence to a mere length and a half.

ALBANY, Feb. 26--Dr. Francis T. Spaulding, State Commissioner of Education, said tonight that he had not yet received any letter from Mayor Bernard J. Dowd of Buffalo asking the department to intervene in the Buffalo teachers' strike.

HAVANA, Feb. 26--The withdrawal of United States Maritime Commission vessels from Cuban trade will not affect commerce between the United States and Cuba, Evaristo Ulloa, President of the Cuban Maritime Commission, said today.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 26--The Chinese Government must improve the distribution of supplies from the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration in Communist areas in thirty days, Deputy Director General R. G. A. Jackson said today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The four major points made by George H. Tichenor in his defense of the legal income tax dodging of cooperatives, as printed in Letters to THE TIMES on Jan. 11, require further clarification for the benefit of business men who fail to recognize the full implications of cooperative terminology.

VIENNA, Feb. 26 -- Guido Schmidt, last Foreign Minister in the Schuschnigg Cabinet, was accused before the People's Court here today of treasonable machinations designed to hand over Austria to Nazi, Germany. In reply he attributed Austria's situation to the appeasement policies of the western powers, whose intervention alone, he said, could have rescued her.

"The Brooklyn Industrial Home for the Blind, 520 Gates Avenue, established a record for peacetime business last year with sales of products manufactured by its clients reaching $1,004,100. In his annual report, made public yesterday, Peter J. Salmon, executive director of the industrial home, disclosed also that 1,048 blind persons had been aided by the Institute.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP)-- The Maritime Commission said today it had dropped Government cargo vessel service in the Atlantic -Gulf coastwise trades "because low competitive rail freight rates and mounting labor costs have made operation unfeasible."

Operations of the Consolidated Vultee Aircraft Corporation for the year ended Nov. 30, 1946, resulted in a net loss of $2,775,619 after tax carryback credits of $6,340,417, the company reported yesterday. This compares with net profit of $6,748,932 in the 1945 fiscal year.
A cocktail ring fell into useful employ yesterday when it became the legal property of Arthur Guarneri, 16 years old, of 1926 Third Avenue.

Strenuous objection to Governor Dewey's proposal for additional taxation of the liquor industry to finance payment of bonds for the soldiers' bonus was expressed yesterday by leaders of the liquor industry. With the current New York State tax at $1.50 a tax gallon compared with a national average of $1.20, members of the industry are protesting to the New York Legislature and beginning a nationwide fight to block new tax levies elsewhere.

Secretary of State George C. Marshall was asked yesterday to intervene in a landlord and tenant dispute between Morgan Island Estates, Inc., owner of the old J.P. Morgan home at Glen Cove and the Soviet Purchasing Commission. Attorneys for the owner asserted that the commission had not paid its February rent, was refusing to pay for damages to the property, estimated at $25,000, and was claiming diplomatic immunity.

A strike in the city's largest industry was threatened last "night after collapse of negotiations for a new wage agreement covering 80,000 unionized dressmakers. The industry has not had a major walkout in twenty years and is regarded nationally as a model of harmonious labor-management relations.

PORT ELIZABETH, South Africa, Feb. 26--Twenty thousand children greeted King George and his party here today. They were massed on the grandstands and bleachers of the city's circular sports ground and they cheered and waved flags unceasingly for a half-hour while local dignitaries were introduced and a speech was made.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--Lewis W. Douglas, former Director of the Budget, was nominated by President Truman today as Ambassador to Great Britain. The nominee has been president of the Mutual Life Insurance Company since 1940.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--A substantial increase, in sugar rations for both home and industrial users was authorized jointly today by the Office of Price Administration and Department of Agriculture.

We regret that the Senate at Albany has now joined the Assembly in refusing to consider legislation to put before the people in November the question of continuing the construction of low-rent, subsidized housing. This action means that the housing program, based on social enlightenment and liberal, humane purposes, is dead unless Governor Dewey himself has a change of heart and intervenes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--The Government-built steel plant at Geneva, Utah, recently sold to the Geneva Steel Compnay, a subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, became today the center of a freight-rate controversy involving Western railroads, Western political and industrial interests, Western and Eastern steel producers and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- The British Government will back former Secretary of State Byrnes' four-power security pact at the Moscow meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers, Foreign Secretary Bevin told the House of Commons today.

An old holding of the Gerry family in the City Hall area passed to new control yesterday when Gerry Estates, Inc., Robert L. Gerry, president, sold to Charles B. Benenson the twelve-story office, showroom and store building at 261 Broadway, northwest corner of Warren Street.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your editorial, "The Battle of Albany," justifying the state's rejection of the city's plea for greater state aid, you cite the figures of the State Budget Director that New York City, which has 55.3 per cent of the state's population, pays in 56.1 per cent of the state's revenues and gets back 53.4 per cent of the state's expenditures.
A rapid electronic method of changing the color--and in some cases the temporary value--of precious and semi-precious gems was demonstrated last night at the Museum of Natural History.

An application of the Tool Owners Union to operate in New York State was rejected yesterday by the Board of Standards and Appeals of the State Department of Labor in a severe sixteen-page opinion indicting the organization's structure and potential motives.

The Union Oil Company of California, in its annual report for 1946, to be released today, shows a net profit of $9,804,523 after taxes and all charges, equal to $1.90 each on 4,666,270 common shares outstanding among 35,000 shareholders. This compares with $9,201,123, or $1.87 a common share, earned in 1945.

OSLO, Norway, Feb. 27 -- A statement issued by the Norwegian Foreign Office today after a secret debate in the Storting [Parliament] was seen here as a retreat from this country's former stand on restricting trade with Spain.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Luis F. Gay, who was secretary of the Argentine Federation of Labor when a United States labor delegation visited Argentina last month, has disappeared, according to John Herling, who accompanied the delegation. Mr. Herling is a free-lance newspaper correspondent and formerly was associated with the Office of the Coordinator of InterAmerican Affairs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Department store sales in the week ended Feb. 22 were 2 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1946:

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Feb. 27 -- A restitution law providing for the return of property seized by the Nazis from Jews and others probably will be approved by the German Council of States in Stuttgart next Tuesday, German officials disclosed today.
Dr. Irving Fisher, Professor Emeritus of Political Economy of Yale University, long recognized as a leading economist, celebrated his eightieth birthday yesterday.

SALONIKA, Greece, Feb. 27--A captured guerrilla captain told the United Nations Security Council's Balkan Inquiry Commission today how he and other Greek leftists had been trained in Yugoslav camps and returned to Greece to battle the Government.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The House of Representatives is about to consider a bill which, if enacted, will drastically weaken and perhaps even destroy the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938, the Federal "Wage and Hour Law." The bill in question is the Gwynne bill, H. R. 584, which has been favorably reported by the House Judiciary Committee.

Any sharp price advances in raw furs at the moment or in the near future will only lead to further setbacks, the merchandise committee of the American Fur Merchants Association warned in a report issued yesterday. Reviewing the heavy gain in fur imports and other causes which brought about the decline in fur prices last year, the committee emphasized the need this year of a larger unit volume at approximately present levels.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- In the first full-dress debate on labor legislation in the new Congress the House brought near to final passage today a bill to knock out portal-to-portal suits and to limit employers' future liability under all minimum wage laws.
The "iron curtain" synonymous for most things Russian, apparently does not apply to the Soviet merchant marine, it became evident yesterday.
DETROIT, Feb. 27 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs held the playoff-hopeful Detroit Red Wings to a 3-3 tie tonight before a crowd of 14,076.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 27 -- The establishment of two economic commissions to help reconstruct the shattered economies of European and Asiatic nations will be the most important issue before the sessions of the United Nations Economic and Social Council, A.D.K. Owen, Assistant Secretary General for Economic Affairs, said today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 -- Government officials today began organization of a committee to allocate steel among freight-car manufacturers in an effort to reach by midsummer the announced production goal of 10,000 cars a month.

Federal Closing Saturdays Beginning on April 5, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, including its Buffalo branch, will observe the year-round Saturday closing schedule permitted under the recently enacted State legislation, it was announced yesterday by Allan Sproul, president.

Homemakers should get competent advice on how to install germicidal lamps designed to kill airborne bacteria, or "leave them alone," lighting experts advised last night. Other lighting problems that have bothered homemakers were tackled in the course of a program conducted by the New York Residence Lighting Forum.

Basil O'Connor, chairman of the American Red Cross, explained yesterday why the agency had not "cut back" to its pre-war scope. At the forty-second anniversary luncheon of the Brooklyn Chapter at the St. George Hotel, he told 600 officials and volunteer workers that he had been questioned repeatedly about the sum to be sought in the Red Cross national fund drive starting tomorrow.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 27 -- From 9 this morning until well after 3 this afternoon, Municipal Field was a bee-hive of activity despite an overnight rain which drenched the Giants' proving grounds.

Public utilities, finance companies and distillers were the dominant factors in a rise of $44,000,000 last week in the volume of commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System, it was disclosed yesterday.

Ernest Bevin, British Foreign Secretary, was sharply criticized last night at a conference of Zionists in the Hotel Commodore, for his recent statement in the House of Commons charging President Truman with "spoiling" Palestine negotiations by urging the immediate entry into that country of 100,000 Jews.

Dr. John N. McDonnell, formerly director of domestic sales and promotion, has been appointed vice president of the Sobering Corporation, Bloomfield, N.J., pharmaceutical products. Herman W. Leitzow, assistant director in charge of domestic sales, has been named domestic sales manager.
TOKYO, Feb. 27--The political race is on for the new government positions, both national and local, created under the new Japanese Constitution, which is effective May 1.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--A committee member's query on the Communist issue inside the CIO United Electrical and Radio Workers precipitated turbulent scenes at a hearing today of the Senate Committee on Labor and Public Welfare.

PARIS, Feb. 27--France's price reduction experiment will not conclude with the application of the second phase of the 10 per cent cut, Premier Paul Ramadier declared at a press conference today. Many prices will still be too high, he asserted, and there must be a period in which a general lowering of excessive prices must follow.

PARIS, Feb. 27 -- France's economic difficulties, the food shortage, the political instability and the uncertain struggle with inflation are encouraging former President de Gaulle's followers to discuss plans for his come-back.
LONDON, Feb. 27 -- Unprecedented conditions were seen today in the market in Argentine rails following the British-Argentine railway council's statement on the L150,000,000 ($500,000,000) share cut.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- It is not a crime to make a bet on a legalized prizefight, the Court of Appeals ruled today in a unanimous decision in the case of Samuel Solomon, who bet that Willie Pep would best Allie Stolz in a Madison Square Garden bout four years ago.

The Rev. Adrian Buisson, 84 years old, will celebrate Sunday the sixtieth anniversary of his ordination to the priesthood. The observance will begin at 10 A.M. with a high mass in the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Esperanza, 624 West 156th Street, of which he is the founder and pastor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Average primary market prices advanced again to a new post-war peak with a rise of 0.8 per cent during the week ended Feb. 22, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- During the week ended Feb. 26, member bank reserve balances increased $11,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

J. Knowles Hare, magazine and calendar illustrator, one of whose etchings, entitled "Sympathy," is reputed to have had a wider sale than any other executed by an American artist, died yesterday in his studio at the Hotel Des Artistes, 1 West Sixty-seventh Street.

Heads Distillers Institute Joseph A. Englehard, president, Glenmore Distilleries Co., Inc., was elected president of the Distilled Spirits Institute at the organization's annual board of directors meeting yesterday at the Netherlands Plaza Hotel, Cincinnati, Ohio.
Dr. Mauricio Hochschild, South American industrialist, has established a scholarship plan to bring three graduate students from Latin-American universities each year to the United States.

Nothing has happened in the last dozen years to alter the initial impression that "Yellow Jack" is an enterprising and original drama. The late Sidney Howard, who had one of the keenest minds in the modern theatre, wrote it in collaboration with Paul de Kruif to honor the heroism of the men who solved the secret of yellow fever after the Spanish-American War.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- President Truman and Secretary of State George C. Marshall have made an urgent appeal to Congressional leaders to appropriate large sums of money immediately to save Greece from economic collapse, it was learned tonight.

Herbert Hoover's report to President Truman on Conditions in the British-American Zone of occupied Germany follows: February 26, 1947 The President The White House Washington, D.C. Dear Mr. President:

Seeking to increase unit sales of millinery on a nation-wide scale, the board of directors of Millinery Promotions, Inc., unanimously approved a plan to raise its budget to $325,000 this year, it was learned yesterday. Of particular concern to the industry is the pronounced drop in volume and unit sales of hats retailing for $5 and under, according to industry spokesmen.

The Greentree Farm at Lincroft, N.J., has been purchased from Mrs. Joan S. Fayson by Mrs. Alice F. Sherman of New York and Terre Haute, Ind., who also owns the High Ground Farm, the former Samuel D. Riker estate in Middletown township.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 27--The Detroit Edison Company has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a proposal to issue 636,130 shares of $20 par value common stock to common stockholders in the ratio of one share for each ten held.

HAVANA, Feb. 27 -- Rumors and rumors of rumors surrounded the Dodgers today as Leo Durocher put them through a snappy workout in preparation for their first exhibition game with the Boston Braves under the Grand Stadium lights tomorrow night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--Senator William F, Knowland, Republican, of California, rejected new overtures for a compromise today and claimed sufficient votes for Senate adoption of his proposal to earmark $3,000,000,000 of any budget savings for retirement of the public debt.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 27 (AP)-- The $11,250,000 sale of the St. Louis (Mo.) County Gas Company by the North American Company to the Laclede Gas Light Company, also St. Louis, was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

BERLIN, Feb. 27 -- Marshal Vassily D. Sokolovsky, Soviet Military Governor, has charged the United States and Britain with trying to create a political union of their zones in Germany and split western Germany from the rest of the country. The charge was made in a 45minute speech at the meeting of the Allied Control Council Tuesday.

Fordham added another New York quintet to its list of victims last night when, before a howling crowd of more than 4,000 and with a thousand other prospective spectators locked out of the Rose Hill Gymnasium, the Rams defeated New York University 65 to 61.

IT was the night before the Preakness last May and most of the conversation in the Baltimore hotel lobbies was concentrated on Assault, the Texas-bred colt which was destined to win the Triple Crown and Horse-of-the-Year honors when the final barrier had sprung. Max Hirsch was talking and everyone was listening with the proper show of respect After all, Max was the trainer of Assault and his was the most authoritative voice in the group.

Handy Harman, local bullion dealers, yesterday advanced the price of silver 2 1/2 cents an ounce to 78 1/4 cents. This is the third price rise this week, an increase of 3 cents having been made on Monday and one of 2 cents on Tuesday.

In the first phase of the case against the blouse industry, Federal Trade Commission counsel sought to prove yesterday that employer groups had conspired to force non-union manufacturers into collective agreements with the union.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Development of a specific United States policy toward Africa, in keeping with American responsibilities under the United Nations, was asked today in a statement issued here by the African subcommittee of the Catholic Association for International Peace.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- Following is the text of the report of the Governor's committee on the State educational program dealing with permanent teachers' salaries: To His Excellency, THOMAS E. DEWEY, Governor of the State of New York:

MOSCOW, Feb. 27 -- Joseph Cyrankiewicz, Polish Premier, has received categorical assurances that the Soviet Government will defend the permanence of Poland's present western frontiers at the Council of Foreign Ministers conference, according to a reliable source.

The French Legion of Honor was received last night by ten Americans in recognition of their services with the Monuments, Fine Arts and Archives Division of the Third Army in France and Germany. The presentations were made at a reception at the French Embassy's cultural center, 934 Fifth Avenue.
ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- Legislative employes worked until late today clearing and sending to the printer a last-minute deluge of new measures as the deadline arrived for the free introduction of bills.

BERLIN, Feb. 27 -- Apparently not wanting to be outdone by the Western powers in efforts to increase the sorely retarded German food production, Marshal Vassily Sokolovsky, the Russian commander, has ordered big loans of seeds to farmers in the Russian zone, it became known tonight.
The endeavor to put greater individuality into ready-made fashions was a challenge well met by Harry Willis, designer of B. Altman's first group of originals shown yesterday at the Hotel Plaza.

The stock market repaired yesterday the damage suffered on Wednesday and closed higher by about 1 1/2 points. Trading was reported largely professional, with the rally based on technical considerations. The volume of business on the Stock Exchange fell to 970,000 shares, compared with the previous session's turnover of 1,350,000 shares.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 27 -- The Mexican Government is planning an internal bond issue of 150,000,000 pesos or more than $30,000,000, it was learned today. The funds will be used to finance projects that President Aleman considers most important to the regime in the long-term sense.

If one were to sit in the seat of Radamanthus and attempt to dispense justice, the high, the middle and the low, concerning last night's Philharmonic-Symphony concert in Carnegie Hall. there would be a whole system of weights and measurements to be consulted in the process.

Supporters of Frank J. Sampson, Mayor O'Dwyer's choice for leader of Tammany, obtained yesterday the signatures of a majority of the members of the Tamany executive committee to a petition asking Charles H. Hussey, the chairman, to call a meeting of the committee to elect Mr. Sampson leader.

Deep powder snow enthusiasts will find conditions, for skiing this week-end ideal. Heavy snows have fallen -- and in some instances still are falling -- at many of the popular regions in the North Country. In general, reports from the skilands indicate that slope and trail conditions will be the best of the winter this week-end.

Mrs. Frances A. Coover, 52 years old, of Ames, Iowa, who was struck by a man who leaped to his death from the Empire State Building on Jan. 26 while she was walking in the street below, will leave St. Vincent's Hospital for home Sunday afternoon, her husband, Merwin C. Coover, said last night.

The proposed International Trade Organization received the endorsement of New York business men and trade associations with qualifications ranging from changes in its basic functions to minor structural improvements at the informal hearings here yesterday.

His Two-Minute Plan It happened one morning, only a few days ago, that Quintus Vitellius Smith, in his regular righthand seat on his regular 8:24 train into town, put down the newspaper which he had been scanning for the past fifteen minutes and found himself mentally drafting a plan of his own. He had a name for it.

A determined group of women members of the Parent-Teacher Association of Public School 130, Brooklyn, achieved yesterday the first step in their aspirations to set up a library in the Kensington section of Flatbush for the use of school children.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Herbert Hoover warned in a report to President Truman today that survival of Western civilization in Europe depended on its survival in a chaotic Germany. He outlined a plan for Germany's rehabilitation designed to protect American taxpayers against footing the cost of the undertaking.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- C. Bedell Monro, President of Capital Airlines-PCA, accused the aviation industry tonight of "overselling" the public on the speed, reliability, luxury and safety of air travel.

Capt. Robert Du Bois Workman, district chaplain of the Third Naval District, soon will terminate his active status, headquarters of the Third Naval District announced yesterday. After his leave, Captain Workman will retire to inactive duty with the rank of rear admiral in the Chaplains Corps.

The City Council committee on State legislation adopted yesterday a favorable report on a resolution asking the Legislature to pass the pending bill to reconstitute the New York City Housing Authority as a three-man agency, all of whose members would be appointed by Mayor O'Dwyer on or after July 1.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 27 -- Too much politics and excessive overcrowding has created a crisis in Czechoslovak higher education that is rapidly becoming a general public issue.

Marking his second post-war title defense, Gus Lesnevich of Cliffside Park, N.J., puts his light - heavyweight championship on the line at Madison Square Garden tonight when he faces Billy Fox, Philadelphia youngster who possesses one of the most imposing knockout records in ring history.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Feb. 22 were 776,689 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 23,288 cars or 2.9 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 53,408 cars or 7.4 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year and 4,293 cars or 0.6 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

"WHEN will they understand that we are human?" It was the anguished cry of a Russian woman factory worker who finally collapsed into hysteria under the strain of exhausting laboc, insufficient food, constant worry about her children and the dread terror of the secret police. Her protest was useless and only worsened her fate, insuring that she would be deported to a Siberian prison camp.

TOKYO, Feb. 26 (Delayed) -- Leading educators, who have been fighting the Yoshida Cabinet desperately since early January, yesterday won their battle when the entire budget appropriation necessary to effect school system reforms was restored.

When the Governor's Committee on Education brought in its first report on teachers' salaries on Jan. 13 it had completed a good job of preliminary factfinding. It set up an emergency program for lifting minimum pay from as low as $1,200 in some schools in the state to $2,000 and provided $32,000,000 in additional state aid to cover a temporary pay rise for fifteen months.

After some irregular fluctuations yesterday, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange finished 9 to 20 points net lower than the day before. It opened with gains of 2 to 10 points, and increased them to 17 to 23 points on active months.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- The Senate Interstate Commerce Committee postponed today action on the nomination of Joseph K. Carson of Portland, Ore., to be a member of the Maritime Commission.

The first two contracts for advertising with the American Newspaper Advertising Network have been signed, it was learned yesterday. Philip Morris Co., Ltd., through the Biow Company, will use thirty network papers throughout the country, with the exception of the West Coast where newsprint is scarce.
HONOLULU, Feb. 27--The record-seeking Army Air Forces P-82 twin-engined Mustang, Betty Jo, left Hickam Field at 3.04 P.M.

WITH TASK FORCE 38 in the Central Pacific, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Fourteen combat ships of this task force headed east from Kwajalein today for an engagement with the First Task Fleet as the Navy disclosed the timetable for its first big-scale Pacific maneuvers since the war.

PORT ELIZABETH, South Africa, Feb. 27 -- Although this is "Amajuba Day," when irreconcilable Boers celebrate the crushing defeat of the British in the first Boer War of 1881, King George was acclaimed more loudly than ever on the second day of his visit here.
NANKING, Feb. 27 -- Foreign Minister Wang Shih-chieh returned here today from an air trip to Mukden that has aroused intense speculation.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 -- March and May wheat and all deliveries of corn except March sold at new seasonal high prices on the Board of Trade today as the result of persistent commission-house buying coupled with short covering that uncovered stop-loss orders.
CHICAGO, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

The seeds of religious and racial (hatreds which Hitler planted continue to sprout. It is a particularly cruel irony of the post-war world when these hatreds continue to be turned against Hitler's first and most helpless victims, the Jews of Central and Eastern Europe. The situation is illustrated in a dispatch from Prague by our correspondent, Albion Boss, printed this week.

Joseph Stack, vice president of the National Maritime Union, CIO, struck back yesterday at Joseph Curran, NMU president, calling formal charges made against him on Wednesday as "just part of a smear campaign against the majority of the union's national council."

ABOARD MOUNT OLYMPUS, Feb. 27 -- The fourth Byrd antarctic expedition has been "very much a success" both in discoveries and in polar training for the Navy, Rear Admiral Richard H. Cruzen, operations commander of the expedition, said tonight as this flagship began her long journey home over a fogveiled sea.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 27-- The engagement of Michael Redgrave for the role of Mannon, the caretaker, in "Mourning Becomes Electra" at RKO was in final stages of negotiation today, it was learned from a Redgrave representative.

AUSTRALIA, Feb. 27 (London Times dispatch)--A conference is expected to be held before the end of the year between nations interested in economic, political and social affairs of the Southwest Pacific zone.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 27 (London Times Dispatch) -- According to a report originating from one of the countries under Soviet influence, the Dardanelles issue will be raised at the Moscow conference of the Big Four Foreign Ministers.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Defense attorneys' objections that they had not been permitted to talk with their clients were overruled today as the trial of thirteen prisoners accused of plotting to overthrow the Hungarian Republic got under way.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 -- In a significant step which is expected to have broad repercussions in the construction industry, home builders of the country went "all out" today for the open shop in their business as a means of speeding up production of housing for veterans at lower cost.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations appeared to be at another crossroads on the Communist issue today as a result of the ideological division of the "liberal forces of the country."

Consolidated net profit of the Aviation Corporation for the fiscal year ended on Nov. 30 amounted to $14,235,339, equal to $2.06 a common share, according to the annual report to stockholders, issued yesterday. Comparable figures for 1945 are not available because the reports of three former associated companies were not included in the consolidated net earnings and sales for that year.

MONTREAL, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Maurice Richard scored three goals, including the winning one, to lead the National Hockey League's front-running Montreal Canadiens to a 6-5 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks tonight.

Three major teachers' organizations praised yesterday the report of the Governor's Committee on Education as a step forward. A fourth organization, the Teachers Union, CIO, termed it "a monstrosity" and said an immediate strike poll would be demanded today.
NANKING, China, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Communist offensives were reported today to have reached within ten miles of Tsinan, capital of Shantung Province, and fifteen miles of Changchun, Manchurian capital.

Louis St. Laurent, Canadian Minister for External Affairs, denied yesterday that his government had ever intended to place responsibility for the defense of any of its territory in the hands of the United States and referred to recent speculation on development of the polar regions for such purposes as "highly imaginative."

Clare Boothe Luce, former Representative in Congress and author of "The Women" and "Europe In The Spring," has signed a contract with D. Appleton-Century for a book tentatively titled "The Real Reason." It is a discussion of her conversion to Catholicism.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 27 -- Reconstruction projects necessary to eliminate accident hazards are being delayed by lack of equipment on at least 4,000 of the 14,000 miles of the New York State highway system, Charles H. Sells, State Superintendent of Public Works, declared today.

The type of education that develops world leaders who countenance Munich pacts or take their nations down the murderous road followed by Germany, wag challenged last night by Dr. Ernest O. Melby, Dean of the School of Education of New York University.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 27 -- Streamlining for beauty rather than for usefulness was scored today by two speakers at a home safety forum on "Fatigue Factor in Home Accidents," sponsored at Essex House here by the Womans Division of the Newark Safety Council.

An indeterminate sentence up to three years in the city pentitentiary was handed down in Special Sessions yesterday to Lorenzo Cruz, 40-year-old Harlem repairman, of 26 East 116th Street, who had been convicted of selling ammunition to minors.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Representative Fred Bradley of Michigan, chairman of the House Merchant Marine Committee, promptly rebuked a fellow Republican today for issuing a subpoena requiring the presence of Secretary of State Marshall at the Capitol tomorrow.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- Priority for obtaining food and new houses will be granted to Britain's miners as part of the Government's program for getting increased coal output. Prime Minister Attlee's office announced today.

Proposals to increase air fares from the present average of 4 1/2 cents a mile to 5 cents is expected to produce sharp differences of opinion tomorrow when the scheduled lines represented in the air traffic conference meet in Washington under auspices of the Air transport Association.

BUFFALO, Feb. 27 -- Chances that Buffalo's public schools would reopen soon appeared remote tonight when Raymond J. Ast, president of the Buffalo Teachers Federation, rescinded his earlier statement that the salary report of Governor Dewey's special committee on education would be acceptable to the striking teachers.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation has allocated $37,500,000 for the development of iron ore properties and facilities, chiefly in Latin America, and expects to tap these new sources for substantial amounts of raw material "some time during 1948," according to the annual report for last year, sent yesterday to stockholders.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The Army-Navy unification bill, sent to Congress yesterday by President Truman, was marking time today pending possible decision by the Senate tomorrow as to whether its Armed Services Committee or tits Committee on Executive Expenditures shall have jurisdiction over the measure.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 27 (AP) -- The 3-year-old colt Stepfather sold for the top price of $200,000 and two filly stars, Busher and Honeymoon, brought $135,000 apiece as Louis B. Mayer's racing stable of sixty-three thoroughbreds was auctioned before 5,000 persons tonight.

Martha Graham's new work, "Cave of the Heart," had its premiere last night in her dance season at the Ziegfeld Theatre. To be accurate, it is not a totally new work, but rather a revised version of an earlier piece presented last spring in the Festival of Contemporary American Music at Columbia University under the title of "Serpent Heart."

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- New teacher pay schedules that will add a mininum of $26,567,000 to school payrolls in the next six years were proposed today by Governor Dewey's committee on a state educational program as a means of attracting able new teachers and retaining those now in service.
Winter storms off the seaboard and in mid-Atlantic battered shipping yesterday, damaging several vessels and delaying a transport.

VIENNA, Feb. 27 -- The fact that he had refused Germany's invitation to Austria to become a member of the Anti-Comintern Pact was cited by Guido Schmidt today in his defense against the Government's charge that as Austrian Foreign Minister he had betrayed his country.

ROME, Feb. 27 -- The death of no less than 94 per cent of Italian war prisoners in Russian concentration camps was reported today by Defense Minister Luigi Gasparotto in a written reply to a question put to him in the Constituent Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- A strong possibility that the Army may transport up to 10,000,000 bushels of United States surplus potatoes to Germany as a result of the Hoover mission was disclosed today by the Department of Agriculture.

Sales and earnings of the Monsanto Chemical Company in 1946 were the best in its history, Edgar M. Queeny, chairman of the board, reported in the forty-fifth annual statement, which will be issued to stockholders today.

Former Secretary of State Byrnes proposed twice last year, once in May and again during the Paris Conference, a Four-Power treaty to keep Germany disarmed for twenty-five years. Now Foreign Secretary Bevin comes forward with a suggestion of a FourPower alliance to prevent a recurrence of aggression in Europe.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There was recently introduced in the New York State Legislature the Austin -Mahoney bill, which seeks to amend the education law in relation to the prevention and elimination of practices of discrimination in education because of race, religion, color, national origin or ancestry.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Secretary of State Marshall has expressed to the British Government the hope that it will explore ways and means of having the Palestine question considered by the United Nations before the General Assembly meets in September, the State Department said today.

MINDEN, Germany, Feb. 27 -- Should the Moscow conference of the Big Four Foreign Ministers fail to establish a unified Germany and a mark having an international value, American and British private interests will be permitted to finance a large part of the current export drive of the combined United States-British zone, it was learned today.

City Controller Lazarus Joseph announced yesterday the sale by the city of $35,000,000 of 0.75 per cent tax anticipation notes maturing April 21 and April 28 to twenty-six local banks on an allotment basis.

Herbert Hoover's report on food conditions in the American and British zones in Germany, made public this morning, is a characteristic combination of practical humanitarianism and humanitarian practicality. Mr. Hoover is aware of the folly as well as the cruelty of allowing hunger and hungerstimulated diseases to sweep Germany.

Federal aid is essential to the solution of the nation-wide teaching crisis, Dr. Pearl A. Wanamaker, president of the National Education Association, asserted last night. She spoke during "America's Town Meeting of the Air," over the network of the American Broadcasting Company.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- A Senate appropriations subcommittee voted 6 to 5 late today to allow the Office of Price Administration until June 30 to liquidate completely, in an orderly fashion.

London theatregoers will receive "Oklahoma!" sooner than they had anticipated. It was learned yesterday that the Theatre Guild has been promised London's historic Theatre Royal, Drury Lane, and that it will be available for the musical early in the spring. Originally "Oklahoma!" had been scheduled to open on the West End in the summer.

Random notes. The mossbunker hash will flow freely in the Mudhole this summer, for the executive committee of the United States Atlantic Tuna Tournament has announced that the last week of August or the first week in September will find fifteen clubs competing for horse mackerel honors.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Unions and employers may make twoyear contracts hereafter, regardless of custom, secure in the knowledge that their relationship cannot be disturbed prematurely by rival unions seeking bargaining rights.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Contrary to the statement of Mr. Hildreth published in the new YORK times of Feb. 21 there was no iron curtain in Czarist Russia. Every year millions of passengers crossed the frontier in both directions. In 1911 instance, 3,543,792 foreigners arrived in Russia and 7,894,711 Russians went abroad (see Statistical Yearbook of Russia for 1912, p. 11, 27).

NEW LONDON, Conn., Feb. 27 -- John. W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, inspected the seagoing part of his jurisdiction today when he visited the Coast Guard Academy, and went aboard the Eagle, a full-rigged training ship acquired from Germany as part of the World War II reparations.

PARIS, Feb. 27--A statute calculated permanently to bar reactionary influences that controlled the French press under Vichy was passed today by the National Assembly as a preliminary to repeal of the statute that has the effect of requiring Government consent to publish a newspaper.

Congress has now received the draft of the bill which President Truman has proposed for the long-awaited and greatly-to-be-desired unification of the armed forces. It provides for a new "National Defense Establishment," to be headed by a civilian Secretary of National Defense, who will be a member of the Cabinet.

Readily making the change from the turf of Australia to the board surface of the Seventh Regiment Armory, William Talbert won convincingly from Ray Palmer Jr., of New York, yesterday as the national indoor tennis championships started. The score was 6 -- 0, 6 -- 2.

Market-wise housekeepers will ignore pork in planning' this weekend's meals, because, as a result of the record high prices for hogs received on the Chicago livestock market earlier this week, retail costs are up forbiddingly in New York stores.
LONDON, Feb. 27 -- Zionist views on the interim policy to be applied pending action on the Palestine problem by the United Nations were sought by the Government tonight.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 27 -- Andys Glory, who cost Irving Gushen of New York only $5,500 as a yearling, completed the process of paying his way out -- and left a modest surplus for feed bills -- when he led home a dozen 2-year-olds, nine of them candidates for next Tuesday's Juvenile Stakes, at Hialeah Park today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Government authorities assessing the economic outlook for the United States in 1947 expressed today a "qualified optimism" based upon anticipated national production of goods worth $202,000,000,000. A decline from a current estimated annual production rate of $210,000,000,000 to a rate at the year's end below $200,000,000,000 was anticipated, but it was estimated that the country would wind up 1947 with an output $10,000,000,000 greater than in 1946.

St. John's took the measure of Indiana State in the feature game of the college basketball doubleheader at Madison Square Garden last night. The Brooklyn Redmen, in beating the Sycamores from Terre Haute, did what was expected of them, but the manner in which they turned the trick was hardly according to the script.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- In a report to Governor Dewey and the Legislature, the Unemployment Insurance Advisory Council today recommended the granting of dependency allowances , to persons drawing unemployment insurance payments.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- With hope for settlement of the Buffalo teacher strike hinging on recommendations of Governor Dewey's special committee on education, a source close to the committee revealed today that its plan assumed teachers there of nearly $500,000 in mandatory pay increments in the next six years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Testimony that the strike against the Allis-Chalmers Company at its West Allis, (Wis.) plant, locale of one of the longest strikes on record, was "Communist-inspired" was heard today by the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

The impressions carried away from a Hattie Carnegie showing yesterday afternoon are vivid. There's the remembrance of white coming close to the face in town dresses and suits, clear and pristine as the spring itself. Tailored suits slim as aspens with exquisite details placed them in the super class; those with slightly dilated hiplines at times hinted at the rounded form of a lantern.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 27 --A special committee composed of representatives of Australia, Colombia and Poland was named by the United Nations Security Council today to hear evidence on the British mine-laying charges against Albania.
BERLIN, Feb. 27 -- Lieut. Gen. Mr Brian Robertson, Deputy Britain Military Governor, today named the Germans, in large measure, for the mounting crisis in the supply of food and fuel.

PARIS, Feb. 27 -- As the National Assembly debated foreign policy for almost five hours today, it appeared doubtful, despite the optimistic statements by Premier Paul Ramadier and British Foreign Secretary Bevin, whether the FrenchBritish pact would be signed before the French diplomatic delegation to the Moscow Foreign Ministers' conference left next Tuesday or Wednesday.
AMRITSAR, India, Feb. 27 -- A pudgy little man with twinkling, blue-gray eyes, whose flowing beard gives him a resemblance to Santa Claus, talked today about civil war with the utmost of ease.

The State of Illinois is planning to market $300,000,000 of its authorized $385,000,000 veterans' bonus bond issue on or about May 1, according to reports received in municipal bond underwriting circles yesterday.

The Long Island sportsmen seem to be divided into several camps, all armed with explosive phrases and sharp pens, as a result of the proposed legislation which would limit the pheasant and quail seasons to two weeks.

World Bank Bonds New York State life insurance companies, controlling a major portion of the nation's insurance company assets, would be permitted to invest in the bonds of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development under a bill to be introduced in the New York Legislature.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28--Women who were attending the household and building equipment exposition, held here in connection with the annual convention of the National Association of Home Builders, have returned to their homes with a lot of bright ideas about shiny gadgets and step-saving devices which they hope to enjoy sooner or later to ease their drudgery.

The Teachers Salary Conference, which represents 35,000 New York City public school teachers, voted unanimously last night to reject the report of the Governor's Committee on Education. A strike poll that was to have been proposed by the Teachers Union, CIO, was not brought up officially at the closed meeting, a spokesman said.

HAVANA, Feb. 28--With Hal Gregg, Vic Lombardi and Kirby Higbe holding Billy Southworth's Braves to three hits, Leo Durocher's Dodgers tonight scored an 8-0 victory under Havana's Grand Stadium lights. A crowd of 3,500 turned out for the game, the first major league night contest ever played here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--President Truman, presenting the Wendell L. Willkie Awards for Journalism tonight, told his hearers that the American press had accepted Mr. Willkie's definition of "One World," and was doing a valiant service in educating the people of this country to the necessity of living in that single sphere.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--President Truman appealed tonight to "every home and business establishment of the land" to respond to the fund-raising efforts of the nearly 3,000,000 Volunteer workers of the 1947 Red Cross campaign.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 28 --Secretary General Trygve Lie warned the United Nations Economic and Social Council today that it must fit its program of world-wide projects to meet the limited budget of the organization.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 28--Calumet Farm, for the third successive Saturday, is expected to send out the favorite in tomorrow's stakes race at Hialeah Park, but this time the likelihood is that the bearer of the Devil's red silks will be the people's choice by only a slim margin.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 28 --Extension of the Federal emergency gasoline tax for an indefinite period, with full proceeds to go to the states, was urged today as the Association of Highway Officials of the North Atlantic States closed its convention here.

BOSTON, Feb. 28--The resignation of Maj. Gen. Clarence H. Kells as director of the Boston Port Authority, less than a year after he was appointed to the $15,000 post, was announced today in a bitter statement charging two State Senators with uttering "falsehood after falsehood" about his administration.

Many smaller furniture stores will continue to price certain types of merchandise at current reduced prices well into March and even beyond, it was learned yesterday. Trade spokesmen attribute the decision to maintain traditional February clearances after March 1 to inability to satisfactorily liquidate inventories of upholstered suites and individual pieces as well as most novelties.

ISHPEMING, Mich., Feb. 28 (AP) --Heavy-set Arnholdt Kongsgaard of the Norwegian team easily won the national ski jumping championship today on Suicide Hill with a score of 230.65--60 points of which were collected by achieving the meet's longest jumps of 239 and 230 feet and the remainder awarded on form.

The State Labor Relations Board handed down two decisions yesterday denying petitions by the Financial Employes Guild, Local 96, for recognition as collective bargaining agent in branches of two local banks.

Limitations' on the functions of the proposed International Trade Organization in order that it might operate effectively in an area of mutual agreement was suggested yesterday at the public hearings before the Executive Committee on Economic Foreign Policy at the Hotel Astor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--A roof construction plan designed to retard the spread of a fire, and by the rapid dispersal of smoke to facilitate fire-fighting, was one of the 386 inventions for which patents were issued this week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- President Truman sent to the Senate for ratification the peace treaties with Italy, Rumania, Hungary and Bulgaria and also the international sugar agreement protocol, signed the bill authorizing cooperation with Mexico in fighting hoof-anmouth disease there, and asked Congress for $145,167,630 for various Government departments and programs.

The City Affairs Committee of the City Council deferred action yesterday on a resolution sponsored by Councilman Hugh Quinn, Queens Democrat, calling on the Board of Education to permit the reading or recitation of the Lord's Prayer at all general assemblies in the public schools.

ALBANY, Feb. 28--The power of the Public Service Commission to regulate the fares of bus companies operating under New York City franchise was upheld by the Court of Appeals today in a unanimous decision. There was no opinion.

LONDON, Feb. 28--The electric power supply to industry will be restored in the London area and northwest England Monday, Prime Minister Attlee's office announced today. The same announcement said that the restrictions on the use of electricity for domestic purposes would continue.

"DESIGN FOR AGGRESSION,"* by Peter de Mendelssohn, is one of those rare books on world affairs without an introduction by Sumner Welles. It presents an inside story of Hitler's war plans, based on the huge cache of enemy documents used at the warcrimes trials to send a few--too few--of the main miscreants to the gallows. It's quite heavy going in spots.

PEIPING, Feb. 28 -- An estimated 70,000 Communist troops have driven south from positions above the Sungari River to within eight miles of Changchun, Manchurian capital, according to an observer who has just returned here.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 28 --Two Jews were killed and five other persons were wounded in a bomb explosion in Haifa today on the third floor of Barclays Bank building near the railway station in the harbor zone.

Although statistics are usually neither eloquent nor descriptive, the array of figures Mr. Hoover presents a his report to the President gives perhaps the most graphic picture yet drawn of conditions in Germany. Other reporters have tried to tell this dismal story to the unwilling listeners of the United States.

Branding Governor Dewey's proposed additional 1-cent tax on gasoline to help finance the State's $400,000,000 bonus to veterans as unfair and unjust to motorists and motor carriers, who must shoulder a large part of the burden, fifteen automotive organizations went on record yesterday as opposing the suggestion.

Reflecting a new high sales record, earnings of the American Tobacco Company and subsidiaries increased last year more than $10,000,000 over those of the year before, the annual report disclosed yesterday. The increased sales volume makes advisable an increase in the company's capital, Vincent Riggio, its president, said.
A 25-year-old former Marine, veteran of battles in the South Pacific, was held yesterday as a material witness in connection with the slaying of another war veteran, a member of the Navy.

Despite the largest flotation of foreign bonds since October, 1930, offerings of new bonds here in February were the smallest for any month since September and below the total of a year ago. The emissions last month totaled $206,237,000 for twenty issues, compared with $262,652,000 for thirtynine issues in the preceding month and $214,023,000 for twenty-three flotations in February, 1946.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP)-- Following is the text of Herbert Hoover's statement on relief before the House Foreign Affairs Committee: To this proposed appropriation of $350,000,000 [recommended by President Truman for China and five needy nations of Europe] must be added large sums for areas under the American flag in Germany and Japan and Korea.

The Eastern railroads filed a petition yesterday with the Interstate Commerce Commission seeking an increase in all classes of passenger fares.
