If the approval of the ICC is obtained, coach passenger fares on their lines will be increased to 2.5 cents a mile from the present 2.2 cents and in parlor or sleeping cars to 3.5 cents from 3.3.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Feb. 28 -- Conceding defeat in a tacit manner on the portal-to-portal pay issue, the United Rubber Workers of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, armed with an affirmative nine-to-one strike vote, put an eighteen-hour deadline today on a reply from the Big Four of the industry as to whether an immediate resumption of contract negotiations could be expected.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--Problems involving public health, education and general welfare came to the fore in the Senate today.
Stormy weather continued across a large part of the Atlantic yesterday as Coast Guard and Navy vessels and private tugs brought aid to many craft in distress.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 28 (AP)-- Twenty-two candidates, topped by the highly favored handicap champion, Armed, were named today for the Santa Anita Handicap and its guaranteed-to-the-winner $100,000 tomorrow.

Myron Sands, who was a curtain boy at the Metropolitan Opera House ten years ago, held the center of the stage himself at Town Hall last night, where he gave his first New York recital. The young baritone, who lives in Forest Hills, is a product of the Juilliard School.

Law-enforcement authorities in the city marked time yesterday in seeking to formulate a new procedure for the arrest and prosecution of common gamblers, but both Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander and District Attorney Frank S. Hogan asserted that the drive on "professionals" will be continued as before.

BUFFALO, Feb. 28--Mayor Bernard J. Dowd wrote today to the striking Buffalo Teachers Federation that he would "go the limit" to "make effective such mandates and means of financing the same as the State Legislature may authorize."

A stroke removed from a 3-0 deficit in the final set, Sidney B. Wood Jr. eked out victory over Alexander H. (Zan) Carver of Pelham yesterday in the national indoor tennis championships at the Seventh Regiment Armory.

The meager twenty-eight days allotted to February ran out yesterday. No one knows just why of all the months February was so ill used. Perhaps it was because even in Roman times February gave evidence of its cantankerous nature. At any rate, when the Roman Emperor Numa Pompilius established February he gave it only twenty-nine days.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 28 --Dr. Oswaldo Aranha, former Foreign Minister of Brazil, urged today that citizens of all American Republics join in re-establishing the aims of Pan-Americanism, which, he said, had been "set aside" in the effort to establish the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--The following is the vote by which the House today passed and sent to the Senate the portal-to-portal pay bill:

In the chapel of the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest yesterday afternoon Miss Susan Duncan Hamill, daughter of Mrs. Herbert Henry Melcher of 7 Gracie Square and James King Hamill of Tampa, Fla., was married to Nathan Green Osborne Jr., son of Mrs. Henry Sprague Sturgis of Cedarhurst, L.I., and Nathan G. Osborne of Chicago.
The annual report of Fairbanks, Morse Co. and subsidiaries, excluding the Municipal Acceptance

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., March 1 --In a sharp attacK on the use of the strike weapon by teachers a spokesman for American education warned today that walkouts would harm rather than help the teaching profession in this country.
The Red Cross 1947 appeal to New Yorkers will open today. Residents of the city are asked to contribute $6,153,600 of the $60,000,000 being sought nationally.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP)-- Barring a poor crop year, housewives and family breadwinners can look forward to a reduction this year in their grocery bills, Agriculture Department officials predicted today.

Anticipating a great expansion in the shipping industry on the Great Lakes, the Seafarers International Union, AFL, is preparing an all-out drive to organize the thousands of nonunion seamen sailing the inland waterways, it was learned yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 28-- Through his entire collection, shown this week, Adrian concentrates attention to the right by half capes, pockets, bandings, buttons, sleeve difference and handpainted motifs.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 28--Today's explosion in Haifa, although it shattered a period of peace, was routine for Palestine. What, seemed extraordinary to one visiting Palestine after a six-month absence was to see an Arab, plainly identified by his tarboosh, dining in Jerusalem's best Jewish restaurant and an Egyptian staying in an otherwise all Jewish hotel.

GALLITZIN, Pa., Feb. 28 (AP)-- The last sleeping car of the Pennsylvania Railroad's New York-toTexas "Sunshine Special" tore loose at a grade top in the Alleghenies in pre-dawn darkness today, raced wildly down the mountainside and plowed into an embankment, killing a Pullman porter and injuring eleven passengers.

For the second time in as many days, Martha Graham turned last night to Greek mythology for the inspiration of a new work. "Errand Into the Maze," which had its premiere in her season at the Ziegfeld Theatre on this occasion, is related to the slaying of the Minotaur to much the same extent that "Cave of the Heart" (added to the repertory the night before) is related to the Medea story.
SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 28 (U.P.) --England made 237 runs for six wickets today to start the fifth and final cricket test match against Australia. The Aussies already have won the series.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP)-- John B. Powell, American newspaper man who barely survived six months of brutalities in a Japanese prison camp, died of a heart attack today after warning the United States to remain strong in the Pacific.

Newspaper advertising in fiftytwo cities during January totaled 137,743,062 lines compared with 115,745,659 in the same period last year, or a gain of 19 per cent, according to Media Records. All classifications showed gains except financial, which dropped 10.1 per cent.

BATAVIA, Java, Saturday, March 1 (AP)--The Indonesian Republic, taking a preliminary step toward economic reconciliation with the Netherland Government, suggested formally today the immediate establishment of a joint Dutch-Indonesian trading organization.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--In the first powerful thrust in the new Republican Congress against New Deal labor statutes, the House passed today, 345 to 56, a bill to quash portal-to-portal pay suits and simultaneously restrict every form of pay claim under the minimum wage laws.
LONDON, Feb. 28--With business broadening in several directions, the stock markets here today ended the week on a cheerful note.

Just About Town In case some of the editorial writers on Pravda and Izvestia are still puzzling over what we mean by democracy in this country, we might call their attention to the petition signed by eight and two-thirds Tammany district leader votes out of a total of sixteen and two-thirds votes on the Tammany executive committee.

Summit Press has scheduled a series of art books by prominent painters, teachers and writers on art. The first will be a book on anatomy and proportion by M. Peter Piening, former art director of Life and Fortune magazines. Mr. Piening's analysis, as yet untitled, will cover from SixteenthCentury Vesalius to TwentiethCentury Picasso.

VIENNA, Feb. 28--Soviet authorities made it obvious at today's meeting of the Allied Council for Austria that until Austria obtained a peace treaty they would not budge from their position that virtually all large-scale industry in eastern Austria belonged to Russia under the Potsdam agreement and was not subject to Austrian law.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 28 (AP)--Jimmy Demaret, the smiling Texan who now hails from Ojai, Calif., whisked to the lead at the halfway point in the $10,000 St. Petersburg open golf tourney today with a seven-under-par 135.

A do-nothing policy prevailed yesterday on the stock market, although prices leaned slightly to the lower side at the close of business and trading contracted to the second smallest volume so far this year. With such meager interest, the day's results were considered meaningless unless they heralded a period of stagnation pending some major development in the national and world economic picture.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The New York State Catholic Welfare Committee, composed of distinguished representatives of the Roman Catholic Church, in a telegram sent to Republican and Democratic legislative leaders, asked for the defeat of the pending Austin-Mahoney fair educational practices bill.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 28 (AP) --Leaders of India's Chamber of Princes have decided not to enter the Constituent Assembly unless the Moslem League joins that body, a reliable source said today.

LEXINGTON, Mass., Feb. 28 (AP) --The Tool Owners Union, whose application for authority to operate in New York State was rejected on grounds the organization was "fascistic," announced today that it would appeal to the courts.

LONDON, Feb. 28 -- Foreign Secretary Bevin announced to a cheering House of Commons today that an agreement now had been reached on an Anglo-French treaty of alliance and that he hoped to sign it Tuesday at Dunkerque.

Skiing conditions continued to be superb in the North Country with the exodus of enthusiasts from the metropolitan area to popular points starting yesterday. The New York Central wound up a parade of enthusiasts with its special Green Mountain week-end expedition to Manchester and Rutland, Vt.
LONDON, Feb. 28--Britain's decision to force displaced persons under British protection in Germany to work in Germany was heatedly attacked by Labor members of Parliament today.

SALOKIKA, Greece, Feb. 28 (U.P.) --The United Nations Security Council's Balkan inquiry commission decided today to send a field tea mto confer with Markos Vifiades, Communist "commanding general" of Greece's newly formed guerrilla army.

VIENNA, Austria, Feb. 28-- Guido Schmidt, Kurt Schuschnigg's Foreign Minister, attempted to excuse himself today for his alleged willingness to betray his country to Hitler Germany by throwing the blame instead on the then British Prime Minister, Neville Chamberlain, and his Ministers.

After a week of tabulation, the Playwrights' Company and Dwight Deere Wiman announced yesterday the results of a three-week survey conducted at "Joan of Lorraine" and "Street Scene" to determine possible trends and audience opinion in the legitimate theatre.

BERLIN, Feb. 28--Lieut. Gen. Lucius D. Clay, deputy United States Military Governor, sharply contested today public charges by Marshal Vassily D. Sokolovsky, Soviet Military Governor, that the United States and British were conspiring to partition Germany and create a political union of their zones.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--President Truman reasserted today his endorsement of Gordon R. Clapp to be a director of the Tennessee Valley Authority on the heels of a rejection by a Senate committee of his nomination of Mr. Clapp.

Gus Lesnevich retained his lightheavyweight championship of the world in easy fashion against Billy Fox of Philadelphia last night. The veteran from Cliffside Park, N.J., knocked out his challenger in 2:19 of the tenth round of a scheduled fifteen-round encounter, after administering a complete boxing lesson and a thorough goingover.
PEIPING, Feb. 28 (AP) --The North China Pacification Conference of top Government military leaders turned today to the question of political stabilization of areas recovered from, the Communists.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. 28-- Issues are being defined and opponents are lining up in rival camps throughout this state for a political contest that promises to be one of the most colorful in the history of the South.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--The Senate voted today, 82 to 0, for a $2,600,000,000 payment on the national debt in the 1948 fiscal year, which begins next July 1.

In Atlanta and Baltimore small families may now buy bread in a new package designed to eliminate the waste that occurs so often when such households must use regular-size loaves. Called "TwinPack," the device enables a baker to present two small, individually wrapped loaves in one wax paper cover that encases both.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP)-- President Truman today asked Congress to appropriate an additional $145,187,630, divided thus: $50,000,000 to provide temporary re-use housing for veterans. $87,532,000 for airports and air navigation facilities.

In endorsing the American trusteeship plan for the Japanese-mandated islands in the Pacific, Mr. Gromyko submitted to the Security Council three amendments. Whether they are advanced as conditions for the effectiveness of the Russian endorsement is not clear.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I feel impelled to comment on a letter appearing in your issue of Feb. 10, written by Frederick C. McKee, in regard to the matter of reciprocal trade agreements.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Feb. 28--Albert Stiefel, 42 years old, an attorney and a leader in Masonic and synagogue activities here, was shot and killed this afternoon in his office at 2 Crary Avenue while conversing with a woman client.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--President Truman said today in a report on relief grain shipments abroad that the Government's goal of 400,000,000 bushels for 1946-47 would be reached two months ahead of time. However, he called for maximum deliveries after the June 30 deadline "in the interest of world stability and freedom."
Cotton futures yesterday closed steady, 19 points lower to 1 point higher than the day before, after a moderately active session on the New York Cotton Exchange.

MOSCOW, Feb. 28--A vast increase in cultivated land, the elimination of faults in agricultural production and the purging of violators of farm laws have been ordered by the Central Committee of the Communist Party.

PORT CHICAGO, Calif., Feb. 28 (AP)--The longshoremen's union today began picketing the Naval Ammunition Depot here, protesting the Navy's use of civil service employes to unload ammunition ships, but work continued with United States Marines on guard duty.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28--As the owner of 99 per cent of the Class B common stock of the Northern States Power Company of Delaware, the Standard Gas Electric Company filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a motion requesting approval of a substitute for the subsidiary's second amended liquidation and dissolution plan.

Sex crime is not a pleasant subject nor is it one to grow hysterical about. If it is to be reduced we will have to take a more scientific attitude toward offenders. This is the object of a bill prepared by City Magistrate Morris Ploscowe, endorsed by the Prison Association of New York and introduced at Albany by Senator Thomas C. Desmond of Middletown.

Urging legislation "to extirpate the criminal element from professional boxing," a New York County Grand Jury investigating the local prizefighting situation revealed in an interim report yesterday that the sport's "integrity" is jeopardized by existing conditions and abuses.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--Senator Homer E. Capehart, Republican, of Indiana, releasing an exchange of letters with John L. Lewis, said today he was fearful of another coal strike. He stated that he would request a Senate committee hearing to determine why nothing has been done to negotiate a contract and to return the mines to the operators.

Five important changes in cold storage warehousing which will improve services to consumers can be expected, William C. Crow, director of the marketing facilities branch, Department of Agriculture, disclosed during a luncheon address at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday.

A special meeting of union and employer representatives was convened last night in the Park Central Hotel by David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, in an effort to head off the threatened strike of 80,000 dressmakers set for Wednesday.

"Red Cross Sunday" will be observed tomorrow in the churches and "Red Cross Sabbath" will be observed today in the synagogues of the city. These observances will be a feature of the opening of the 1947 fund for that world-wide philanthropy.

ABOARD MOUNT OLYMPUS, Feb. 28--The Western Group of the Navy's Antarctic expedition has dispatched three exploratory flights within the last forty-eight hours over the Enderby Land coast [at about Long. 50 E.]. But results were meager because of thick weather.

Consolidated net income of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey totaled $23,841,656 last year, compared with $15,995,081 in 1945, according to the annual report which will be distributed today to stockholders.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28--Many large insurance companies and banks are refusing to make 100 per cent GI loans under provisions of the Service Men's Readjustment Act, the Mortgage Bankers Association of America was told at the opening of its loan clinic and forum here today.

PARIS, Feb. 28--The prospect of an early reopening of the warwrecked harbor of Le Havre to international shipping improved today with official endorsement of a plan to raise the liner Paris lying overturned at the quayside. The liner has obstructed the port since the disastrous fire aboard her in 1938.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 28 (U.P.)-- Petroleos Mexicanos, the Governmentcontrolled petroleum monopoly, has completed arrangements for the purchase of the properties of four of the five United Statesowned oil companies which continued operating in Mexico after the oil expropriation of 1938, it was announced tonight.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE TIMES has carried stories during the past several days concerning the resignation of the Commissioners of Welfare, Hospitals and Health and the Sixth Deputy Police Commissioner from the Welfare Council of New York City. This action was taken as a result of an interpretation of a statement made by G. Howland Shaw, its president, to a committee of the Welfare Council and released to the newspapers.

HONOLULU, Feb. 28--J. A. Krug, Secretary of the Interior, reiterated today his unqualified support of statehood for Hawaii and told a joint session of the Territorial Legislature that President Truman had assured him a few days before the Secretary left on a Pacific tour that he was firmly behind Hawaiian statehood aspirations and would do everything he could to obtain it.

When the twin-fuselage fighter "Betty Jo" set down its wheels at La Guardia Field yesterday, 14 hours 33 minutes out of Hickam Field, Hawaii, we had further proof of how rapidly the globe is shrinking. There were no comparable records to break for this newest modification of the North American Mustang.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 28 (AP) -- Hank Greenberg, the old Bronx boy, today became the first baseball player in history to arrive at spring training camp in his employer's private plane, with two pilots.

Bespectacled Harry W. Mandel, 37-year-old money order clerk for the Railway Express Agency, stood Thursday afternoon in the middle of Van Cortlandt Park. He was unmindful of the cold February wind that swept across the open field.

Mayor O'Dwyer's plan to transform the New York City Housing Authority into a three-man board after July 1 moved ahead yesterday as the City Council voted to concur in his message asking the Legislature to pass the necessary bill, now pending at Albany.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--Herbert Hoover recommended today that Congress put American relief in all foreign countries on a repayment, rather than a gift, footing. He also urged that relief be not dispensed in any country at levels higher than those he has proposed for Germany and Austria--the minimum under which health and ability to work can be sustained.

Support for the Hoover report on Germany was expressed yesterday by James W. Gerard, former United States Ambassador to Germany, as he and Mrs. Gerard sailed for Nassau aboard the Eastern Steamship liner Yarmouth.

BERLIN, Feb. 28--The Allied Kommandatura, the four-power governing body of Berlin, announced today that it had decided to abolish food ration card Number 5 which has long been under fire by the Germans as inadequate.
ALBANY, Feb. 28--Dr. Francis T. Spaulding, State Commissioner of Education, tonight ordered striking Buffalo school teachers to return to their classrooms Monday morning.

The Catholic Youth Organization of Brooklyn assailed Leo Durocher, manager of the Brooklyn baseball team, yesterday for his conduct "both on and off" the baseball diamond, and announced that its membership of 125,000 boys was withdrawing its affiliation with the Knothole Club, a group that sponsors Brooklyn baseball enthusiasm among the borough's youngsters.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28 --An aggregate of $22,550,000 of bonds, $1,500,000 of debentures, 555,650 shares of preferred stock and 1,286,104,5 shares of common stock were registered today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by companies.

ALBANY, Feb. 26--Gov. Thomas E. Dewey pledged "hearty, continued cooperation" to the United Nations today as he signed three bills clearing the way for the world peace organization to make its permanent headquarters in New York.

* * * Trade Here More Active Retail trade here picked up this week and made a more favorable comparison with a year ago than in the previous week when volume showed a decline of 6 per cent. Department store sales this week were estimated as likely to run 10 to 12 per cent higher than for the 1946 week.

When Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson finished the last of 109 hearings on the subject of the city's 1947-48 budget yesterday he concluded that the municipal expenditures for the next fiscal year would go beyond the billion dollar mark, the largest municipal expenditure in the city's history.

LONDON, Feb. 28--The British decision to seek United States financial assistance in supporting the Greek Government Army and economy marks the collapse of the Foreign Office policy for the Eastern Mediterranean.
A decisive victory for Mayor O'Dwyer in his fight to reorganize Tammany and elect Frank J. Sampson as leader in place of Edward V. Loughlin was assured yesterday when a majority ...

Despite an eleventh-hour decision barring Frank Martin, star two-miler, from the meet, New York University's field - event strength and superior balance are expected to give the Violets the edge over Manhattan in a close contest for team honors in the twenty-sixth annual Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. indoor track and field championships at Madison Square Garden tonight.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28--March and May wheat soared today 10 cents a bushel and May and July corn, 8 cents, the limits permissible for one day's trading on the Board of Trade, as the result of general buying and short covering induced by a bullish construction placed on former President Herbert C. Hoover's statement regarding food conditions abroad, and especially in Germany.
Morley B. Bursey has been appointed Trade Commissioner for Newfoundland in the United States, with headquarters at 620 Fifth Avenue.

CHARLES CITY, Iowa, Feb. 28 --A ton and a half of silver dollars --55,000 of the ordinarily scarce "cartwheels"--were started on an experimental rolling journey this afternoon by the Oliver Corporation, which used the hard money to meet its weekly payroll.

The longest non-stop flight ever made by a fighter plane was completed at 11:06 o'clock yesterday morning when the twin-engine P-82 Betty Jo of the Army Air Forces put down at La Guardia Field to end a 4,975-mile hop that had started at Hickam Field, Hawaii, 14 hours 33 minutes earlier.

Considerable emphasis is being given to the sharp increases in the prices of hogs, grains and other commodities. These increases have caused renewed fears that a new large increase in the cost of living impends. Less attention has been directed to the declines in prices of potatoes, eggs, poultry, milk, citrus fruits and certain other food products.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--John J. McCloy, 51 years old, a former Assistant Secretary of War and a New York attorney, was elected today as President of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, effective March 17.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--Without mentioning the possibility that the United States may find it necessary to shoulder British responsibilities in Greece, James Forrestal, Secretary of the Navy, and Admiral Chester W. Nimitz emphasized today the increasing role of the United States Navy in safeguarding security of the sea.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 28-- David O. Selznick today named Joseph Cotten to play the dual role of King Rudolf of Ruritania and Rudolf Rassendyll in the forthcoming remake of "Rupert of Hentsau," with Louis Jourdan and Alida Valli, which is scheduled for the cameras late this year.
The Crucible Steel Company of America disclosed details of a twoyear program of plant expansion and improvements involving $30,000,000 in its 1946 annual report sent yesterday to stockholders.

Although the volume of business on the New York Stock Exchange last month increased over the previous month, with a smaller number of trading days, sales were the smallest for a February since 1944. Trading exceeded the millionshare mark in eleven sessions, the largest of which was 1,361,580 shares, on Feb. 3.

The appointment yesterday of John J. McCloy as President of the Bank for Reconstruction and Development-- better known as the World Bank--ends on a fortunate note a stalemate of three months in the development of this new international institution.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--President Truman declared today that the United States stood ready "to assist India in its commendable plans for economic development in all appropriate ways which would prove of benefit to our two countries and to the world," in accepting the letters of credence of Asaf Ali as the first Ambassador of India to this country.

With production catching up to demand and inventories increasing, the number of lines of consumer goods in which prices are starting downward is increasing daily, Harry A. Barth, assistant to the director of merchandising of the W.T. Grant Company, said yesterday.

The Housing Department of the New York Life Insurance Company announced yesterday that it will begin next week to accept written registrations from applicants for apartments in the residential community now under construction at Fresh Meadows, Queens.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 28--The sliding pit was introduced to Giant yearlings and regulars today, just about completing the all-around routine in which Manager Mell Ott is drilling his 1947 squad. He also gave the athletes their first taste of fielding bunts off the pitching rubber.

TOKYO, Feb. 28--Repeated violations by other powers of treaties and international agreements that Japan is accused of breaking between 1928 and 1945 may make them worthless as a basis on which to try Gen. Hideki Tojo and twenty-five others charged with war crimes, defense counsel contended today before the International Military Tribunal.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Benjamin of 45 East Eighty-second Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Helen, to Robert Leo Arnstein; son of Mrs. Leo Arnstein, also of this city, and the late Mr. Arnstein. The wedding will take place in July.
NANKING, Saturday, March 1--Premier T. V. Soong resigned today and, in a farewell appearance before the Legislative Yuan, blamed China's economic woes on the Communists.

Plans for the greatest laboratory of its kind for research into the fundamental forces that hold the universe together and into the mysteries of the vital processes of life were unfolded yesterday by a group of leading atomic scientists at the first conference to be held in the Brookhaven National Laboratory for Atomic Research, Brookhaven, L.I.

Major elements in the retail credit situation continue favorable and on the constructive side, credit executives reported here yesterday. So far, at least, unsound competition in terms has not yet become a factor in installment selling. While collections on retail charge accounts have slowed up somewhat, this was said to have been expected, and chiefly reflects comparison with the high ratios noted during the period when Regulation W applied to charge accounts.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 28 --The Yankees today clicked off another leg on this extraordinary tour of the tropics.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 28 (AP)--Attorney General Tom C. Clark told Democrats at a $250-aplate Jefferson Jubilee dinner tonight that "America wants Harry Truman in 1948."

MADRID, Feb. 28--The police broke up a Monarchist effort today to stage a parade through Madrid. The parade was to have followed a mass to commemorate the fifth anniversary of the death of former King Alfonso XIII.

PARIS, Feb. 28--Premier Paul Ramadier, in a broadcast on the eve of the Government's application of the second 5 per cent price reduction, today promised temporary compensation payments of a 10 per cent supplement to low wage groups and to those least favored in family allotments.

PARIS, Feb. 28--A fifty-year treaty of alliance between France and Great Britain will be signed in Dunkerque Tuesday, Foreign Minister Georges Bidault announced today to the Assembly, which rose and applauded. At about the same hour, British Foreign Secretary Bevin told the same news to the House of Commons.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP)--The Civilian Production Administration, saying that a recession this year can be avoided, offered today a five-point formula for assuring continued high level output.
NANKING, Feb. 28--The last formality connected with moves for all-out warfare with the Communists was taken here tonight when the Government ordered Communist delegations to leave Kuomintang China.

The $25,000,000 Longchamps restaurant chain lost yesterday its right to serve liquor when the Court of Appeals in Albany unanimously upheld the State Liquor Authority's refusal to renew licenses that expired last midnight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Harvey W. Brown, president of the International Association of Machinists (independent), today vigorously defended unions from the charge of "monopoly." He was a witness before the Senate Committee on Labor and Education.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP)-- The Government ordered today RFC stocks of copper sold under a new price schedule which officials said will mean an increase of at least 1.9 cents per pound.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Feb. 28 (AP)-- The Bolivian Government speeded relief tonight to the flooded northern town of Trinidad, where crocodiles were reported seen in the streets. Residents escaping into the hills were in danger of attack "by wild animals," the Government said.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee voted today to grant to the Office of Price Administration funds to allow the agency to continue with a reduced staff, rent, price and sugar controls through June 30.

TO THE EDITOR: The letters answering Arthur Koestler's "A Trojan Horse in France" made me realize once more how little French political and social life is understood abroad. The myth of the upper classes oppressing the "little man" no longer corresponds to any reality.

A group of musicians, many of them members of the New York City Opera Company, has banded together to form a company to present operas in English at the Westchester County Center in White Plains, N.Y. Three operas will be presented this spring and eight are proposed for next autumn.

John B. Powell, hobbling painfully about on his crutches, never thought of himself as a hero. But Japanese hatred and stubborn American courage raised him inevitably to heroic stature. He died as he lived, fighting to the end for his convictions.

TWENTY-FIVE years ago Antioch College, floundering between mediocre survival and unhappy extinction, hit upon a valuable educational premise that enabled it to continue as a worthwhile institution of higher learning.

THE subtitle reads, "An Episode of the Fourth, the Psychological Revolution, 1997," and the book satisfies all the expectations which such a statement arouses. In 1997 the world is held in bondage by two dictators, Alpha, or the Bull, of the upper world, and the Mole, the superbrain of the subterranean opposition.

ALBANY, March 1--The State Board of Regents made public today a resolution unanimously approving the recommendations by Governor Dewey's Committee on the State Educational Program for a new permanent pay schedule for teachers in public schools.

BESIDES being a newspaper man, which is comparatively easy, I am also a father which, day in and out, is somewhat tougher on the frame and also very instructive. As part of my parental responsibilities I have always considered it mandatory to take the little ones to the circus in Madison Square Garden.

It is becoming increasingly apparent that the hunter or fisherman who wants to get the most put of these sports and still remain within the boundaries of a reasonable budget must resort to membership in a local hunting and fishing club.

OGDEN, Utah, March 1 (AP)--A Whirling snow dervish from the Swiss Alps and twin sisters from Canada won the national downhill ski championships today as the United States said good-by to the titles for this year.

The first duty of the United Nations is to maintain peace and to create a new world in which all people can live a decent existence regardless of their differences in race or creed, Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, said yesterday.

Essex Troop's trio, headed by the eight-goal Buddy Combs, collected ten goals in the second half to hand the Squadron A Regulars a 19-to-12 defeat in a Metropolitan League polo match, feature of the card staged at the Squadron A Armory last night.
Driving to an early lead, the New York Knickerbockers defeated the Toronto Huskies, 63 to 48, in last night's Basketball Association of America game at the Sixtyninth Regiment Armory.

SPECULATION on the significance to photography of the new Land process which turns out a finished print one minute after the film is exposed gave amateur photographers a busy week. In one step the new-type camera wipes out the darkroom processing; anyone who can point a camera, flick a shutter release, and then turn a knob and wait sixty seconds, can produce prints.

UNDERDOGS have usually been heroes to their novelists. The lost cause is nearly always the dramatic side of the pattern; the victor ends up by belonging to the spoils. Such truisms are everyday stumbling blocks in the reviewer's trade; still, it is surprising to find a former OSS officer, now turned novelist, falling so promptly into the familiar groove.

MOSCOW, March 1-- Russian dissatisfaction with American policy in the United States zone of Germany is outweighed, if anything, by the criticism directed both at Gen. Douglas MacArthur's administration in Japan and the United States policy in southern Korea.

Immediate action to exempt General Littlejohn from the rigid restrictions of the Surplus Property Act of 1944, as amended, should be taken by Congress, the Association of Steel Distributors, Inc., declared in a statement yesterday.

Recent insinuations in the Moscow press preliminary to the meeting this month of the Big Four Foreign Ministers to write the peace treaties for Germany and Austria have cast the spotlight-- and created a sentiment of pessimism here--on one of the principal economic matters to be discussed at the meeting.

WASHINGTON, March 1--House Republican policy makers were disclosed today to have mapped a noretreat fight against the Senate's action in scaling down the Houseapproved $6,000,000,000 budget cut to $4,500,000,000.

"Money does not pay for anything, never has, never will. It is an economic axiom as old as the hills that goods and services can be paid for only with goods and services; but * * * years ago this axiom vanished from everyone's reckoning, and has never reapeared.

Four youths suspected of a series of East Side hold-ups were captured yesterday by a rookie patrolman on special assignment on Park Avenue. One of the prisoners had a pistol stolen from a parked automobile, the police said, while another had a knife.

BERLIN, March 1--The United States has advocated to other occupying powers that permission be granted to representatives of the German press to attend the conference of Foreign Ministers in Moscow. The official United States stand was taken at a meeting of the Allied Control Council's political directorate, it was learned today.

From testimony given before the Aviation Subcommittee of the House of Representatives, it is evident that the attack on the problems of all-weather flying and instrument landings will be many-sided. Milton W. Arnold, vice president for operations and engineering of the Air Transport Association, told the subcommittee that no single device now under study comprises a complete landing system.

ATLANTA, March, 1 (AP)--Dead persons, nonresidents and even nonexistent persons "voted" for the late Eugene Talmadge and his son, Herman, for Governor of Georgia in the general election of 1946, The Atlanta Journal said tonight.

PHILOSOPHY, in the proper sense of the term, is not a presumptuous effort to explain the mysteries of the world by means of any superhuman insight or extraordinary cunning, but has its origin and value in an attempt to give a reasonable account of our own personal attitude toward the more serious business of life.
PITTSBURGH, March 1--Ten years ago tonight reporters from major newspapers in the East and Midwest were hurrying to Pittsburgh to cover a steel strike--or so they thought.
In a quiet house on a hilltop in the New England countryside, Mrs. Elsa de Brun, a 50-year-old grandmother, has produced thirty highly original drawings, her first work as an artist.

PARIS, March 1--In the preamble to the British-French alliance to be signed Tuesday, the two Governments express their desire for a treaty against a further German menace. All the powers competent to act on Germany would be eligible to participate.

WHETHER we like the idea or not, gardening both indoors and out is largely a mechanical process. Various jobs may be more easily, more quickly and more efficiently performed if we have at our disposal the right tool, accessory or gadget with which to accomplish each operation.

MADRID, Feb. 28--Future control of Telefonica, the national telephone company formerly Americanowned, is the cause of a bitter three-cornered fight between the Government telegraph service, the Government's National Institute of Industry and private capital represented by the big banks.

WEST POINT, N.Y., March 1-- Registering decisive victories in the swimming and pistol meets, the United States Naval Academy dominated the annual service rivalry today, limiting the cadets to a lone victory in gymnastics.

Nat Holman, veteran C.C.N.Y. mentor and Hank Iba, who led Oklahoma A. M. to the N.C.A.A. championships the last two years, have been designated as the coaches who will tutor the squads for the All-Star East-West basketball game at Madison Square Garden, Saturday, March 29, it was announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, March 1--The all-around playing of Center Jack Colberg helped Penn defeat Dartmouth at the Palestra tonight, 60--50, before 4,000 fans, as the Red and Blue avenged an earlier season set-back in Eastern Intercollegiate League competition.

NEW ORLEANS, March 1 (AP)--Treasury agents announced today the arrest of five men in connection with a cache of guns, ammunition and grenades which, it was alleged, were destined for shipment to Latin America.

LAHORE, India, March 1--Indian political leaders, startled momentarily by Britain's flat declaration of intent to quit India in fifteen months, are trying to ascertain the next step. This, all in all, has been a great week for second thoughts.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Several problems recurrently facing the American people and their Federal Government can be greatly clarified if it be emphasized that our Secretary of State holds a dual office with two virtually unrelated functions. The current Congressional concern, at Mr. Truman's instigation, about succession to the Presidency involves a recognition of this duality.
WASHINGTON, March 1--The United States was challenged this week on how far it is prepared to go to mitigate Europe's distress.
Rescue craft continued busy yesterday in scattered parts of the Atlantic assisting craft that were in distress after encountering pounding wives and high winds.

TEHERAN, Iran, March 1 (AP)-- Reports circulated in Teheran today that Mohammed Reze Pahlevi, Shah of Iran, under heavy pressure from his military advisers, was seeking a way to dismiss Premier Ahmed Ghavam before the new Majlis (Parliament) convened.

WITH NAVAL TASK FORCE 38, CENTRAL, PACIFIC, March 1 (AP)--Racing eastward for a mock battle with Task Fleet 1 from the West Coast, this force won a big initial advantage today with announcement that one of its submarines theoretically had knocked out the battleship Iowa.

LATELY returned from Hollywood, Davidson Taylor, vice president in charge of programs for the Columbia Broadcasting System, announced last week that he has put a stamp of approval on five program ideas submitted to the network and that the new shows soon would be given their initial airings.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- President Truman was the guest of honor at the 24th annual dinner of the White House Correspondents Association at the Hotel Statler tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- A pause in the seemingly endless climb in the country's cost of living was finally announced this week, but hopes by consumers for a real break in retail prices could hardly be described as satisfied.

MOSCOW, March 1--John Foster Dulles and Ambassador Robert D. Murphy, who will come to Moscow next week as two most important members of the delegation to the Council of Foreign Ministers meeting, were sharply attacked here today.

TO THE EDITOR: I feel that Raymond Daniell's article, "Can Freedom and Socialism Be Reconciled?" calls for a few criticisms. The note of hostility and suspicion with which the British Labor Government is reported in the press gives the average American a very distorted picture of the true situation.

SO you can't carry a tune, never could, and don't know any songs to sing to, or with, the children? If you could hear Mrs. Bess C. Haskell on this subject you might change your mind. In a recent interview we learned that it is well worth trying to loosen up, skip, dance and sing with the children.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 1--Amid the cheers of 11,000 fans, the Yankees lost the opener of their six-game exhibition series here today to the Vargas club, 4 to 3. The battle was lost in the last of the ninth when Cliff Mapes misjudged a fly and played it into a double.

The legendary lion chased the proverbial lamb into town as March started yesterday. Snow, which began descending over the city at 4:25 P.M. and was scheduled to leave a white cloak of 3 to 6 inches before turning to rain this morning, followed clear, sunny weather here earlier in the day.

The concert given by the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra last night at Carnegie Hall was led by Walter Hendl, assistant conductor, who directed a program featuring Rachmaninoff's Piano Concerto, No. 3, with Witold Malcuzynski as soloist.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 1-- Outside Dahlgren Hall today a snowstorm presented a pretty picture along the beautiful Severn. Inside the 40-year-old gymnasium that has served the Naval Academy so well, the picture was just is pretty.
The series of twelve articles which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES from Feb. 10-21--Based on the nation-wide survey of schools and colleges--will be printed by THE TIMES in booklet form.

TO prevent individuals or groups from by-passing legal and democratic procedures, Eugene P. Connolly of the New York City Council has proposed an amendment to the Administrative Code enjoining the License Commissioner from exercising powers of censorship.
PEIPING, March 1--Violent fighting continues near the outskirts of Changchun, Nationalistheld capital of Manchuria. Meager reports indicate that the Communist pressure there is growing.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, March 1--A battle for freedom of speech and of the printed word is under way here in committees working on the new Czechoslovak Constitution. The basis is a Soviet note of last week requesting measures to halt alleged anti-Soviet propaganda of Obzory, publication of the Catholic-oriented People's party.

BUFFALO, March 1--Taking a step that may have far-reaching consequences throughout the nation, 2,400 teachers in this city seriously crippled the public schools this week with the greatest teacher's walkout in educational history.

ABOARD MOUNT OLYMPUS, Sunday, March 2--This flagship of the Navy's Antarctic expedition has run into its first heavy seas in the same area where the expedition's cargo ship Merrick broke loose from her towline two weeks ago and drifted helplessly in a storm half a day until she was hitched again to the icebreaker North Wind.
The Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. indoor championship trophy, which has shuttled from campus to campus for twenty-six years, has finally found a permanent resting place.

BOSTON, March 1--The Yale hockey team defeated Harvard, 6 to 4, in a rough game at the Arena tonight, a pair of late goals by Gordon Ritz of Minneapolis stretching the Eli victory streak to twelve straight.

The energetic news bureau of the University of California informs htis department that Dr. J.C. Reid of the chemical department has synthesized a complex amino acid with which carbon is combined. This is of importance when the part played by the amino acids is kept in mind.
NANKING, March 1--Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek will take over the presidency of the Executive Yuan--the Premiership--vacated today by Dr. T.V. Soong, it was officially announced tonight.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 1--The United Nations Economic and Social Council attempted today to give privileged consultative status to the World Federation of Trade Unions, recommended by the General Assembly, but decided that it must first revamp its procedure in line with "contradictory" Assembly resolutions.

Paterson, N.J., March 1--Incorporated as the United Management Association, the management and employes of Stenchevers, Inc., one of the largest independent retail shoe dealers in New Jersey, tonight signed a contract under which the workers will join with the employers in the actual management of the firm's three stores in this city.

The increase in venereal disease in New York City last year took place entirely among the male population, Dr. Theodore Rosenthal, director of the Bureau of Social Hygiene of the Department of Health, declared yesterday. He announced that the number of infected men increased 47.4 per cent over 1945 while the women showed a decrease.
WASHINGTON, March 1--With a backlog of major industry disputes steadily accumulating, the threat of a country-wide telephone strike was projected into the center of the labor picture today.

IT seems that Gian-Carlo Menotti's admirable little skit in the opera buffa style, "The Telephone," has rung the bell! Never mind, never mind. This vile rejoinder to his success at the Heckscher Theatre is the composer's penalty for having, in his melodic and sparkling manner, been so amusing.

WASHINGTON, March 1--The State Department was said to have agreed in principle today to the British proposal for the United States to assume a large part of Britain's obligations in Greece. The agreement-in-principle was said to have been included in a note to British Ambassador Lord Inverchapel.

BATAVIA, Java. ON a wooden bench padded only with a straw mat and a thin quilt, in a thatched temporary building on the outskirts of Batavia, a little Indonesian girl, of perhaps 4 years old, lies crying. On the left side of her face is a white bandage that covers a raw hole in her cheek that exposed all her teeth and gums on that side.

LONDON, March 1--The Inter national Committee for the Study of European Questions, which warned the world Jan. 25 of the existence of an active Nazi underground in Germany, said today the round-up of leaders in the British and United States zones last Sunday had only scratched the surface.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 1 (AP) --Kentucky romped to its fourth straight Southeastern Conference basketball championship here tonight with a 55-38 victory over Tulane, but only after overcoming the stiffest kind of opposition from the Green Wave.

Americans can hardly pick up their newspapers these days without learning of some new demand on the resources of their country for relief abroad. They can see these demands against two sharply contrasting sets of facts. One is a proposed national budget of $37,500,000,000, from which Congress is trying to whittle something between $4,500,000,000 and $6,000,000,000.
Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of the Crestmont Country Club, tournament chairman of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association, announces completion of half the schedule of events for the coming season.

THE output of skiing literature (comparable to the post-war boom that this ancient sport of the Vikings is enjoying) continues unabated this winter. Fred Iselin's "Invitation to Skiing," with A.C. Spectorsky doing the writing, covers purchase of equipment, all aspects of skiing itself and concludes with chapters on conditioning for the sport, etiquette on trails and slopes and a glossary.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: L'affaire Lilienthal prompts me to call attention to a fallacy which has grown up apparently quite unnoticed by the public or indeed by the Congress itself which, through the language of some statutes, is largely responsible for it.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 1 (AP)--Scoring in every event the University of Missouri Tigers won the nineteenth annual Big Six Conference indoor track and field meet tonight with a total of 55 1-3 points. Nebraska was second with 46 points, followed by Kansas 27 1/2, Oklahoma 25 1/2, Kansas State 18 5-6 and Iowa State 6 5-6.

CAIRO, March 1--By 1950 more than one hundred million American dollars will have been laid out across the Arabian and Syrian deserts and the territories of four Middle East countries in the form of a pipeline from Saudi Arabia to the Mediterranean coast.

There appears to be room for reduction of cotton textile prices and these will come about shortly in competitive selling, it was predicted last week by textile industry leaders. Basically, however, the price structure is sound, they held, and those pressing for drastic price cuts on cotton goods are consciously or unconsciously asking for a ruinous type of deflation.

MEXICO CITY, March 1--Both the Communist and the oil issues have arisen again just prior to the visit of Pesident Truman to Mexico on Monday. Those issues always touch off lively discussion here even though in this case neither is the least bit likely to affect the friendly course of the Presidential call.
The notion that March is unpredictable is deep-seated but erroneous. Everybody knows what March is going to do. It's going to lead, by fits and starts and temperamental outbursts, directly to April.

THE first room to be converted was a second-floor drawing room (below). It measured 16 by 22 feet, had a thirteen-foot ceiling and characteristic trimmings --a lavishly carved marble fireplace, tall recessed windows graced by folding jalousies, and a huge double doorway. To become a one-room apartment it had to have cooking facilities, which could be accommodated easily enough in a corner space measuring approximately 4 by 7 feet.

WASHINGTON, March 1--President Truman cleared his desk late today and arranged to depart in his private plane, "The Sacred Cow," at 8 o'clock tomorrow morning for Grandview, Mo., on his way to Mexico City for a three-day official visit.

LONDON, March 1--The British Government is prepared to maintain its security forces in Greece if the United States takes over the economic and financial burden, it was learned authoritatively tonight.
"TAKE one part rum, one part hurricane, one part sex," says Mr. Williamson's hero "--and look what happens!"

CHICAGO, March 1--Both league - leading Wisconsin and runner-up Illinois lost Big Nine basketball games tonight to force the Western Conference to decide where, When and how much of the interrupted Wisconsin-Purdue game should be replayed.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 1 --Harvard's faster and more aggressive basketball team scored a 66-50 upset victory over Columbia at the Indoor Athletic Building tonight in an Eastern Intercollegiate game.

TOKYO, March 1--Although the "March crisis" threat still hangs over the nation, Japan comes to the end of the first full year since she took emergency financial measures with the knowledge that conditions are gradually improving.

THE hardest job the young novelist has to do is to write his second book. The first has been, let us say, a success, but it has been a success for reasons only partly connected with the craft of fiction. The book has been characteristically shaped out of experience so fresh in memory that the literary rendering is essentially autobiographical.

A QUICK glance this morning at the new month's schedule should give you a pretty conclusive idea that the season's final quarter promises to be both interesting and perhaps a bit exhausting. As of the moment, for instance, there are seven definite entries on the board for March in addition to two Sunday evening debuts at the Princess Theatre, where the Experimental Theatre seems to be taking good root.

CHICAGO, March 1 (AP)--Kevin O'Shea's basket in the last 40 seconds tonight gave Notre Dame a 55-to-53 victory over Northwestern, nullifying a 27-point performance by the Wildcats' Benny Schadler before more than 17,000 at Chicago Stadium.

A sharp drop in the volume of residential property sales from a year ago and a definite trend to lower prices for the first time in eight years are indicated in the forty-sixth semi-annual survey of the real estate market just completed by the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

WASHINGTON, March 1--The Navy's program for enlisted personnel "is, in general, progressive and designed to afford a worthwhile and an honorable career for those who elect to make it their life's work," a civilian advisory committee reported to James Forrestal, Secretary of the Navy, in a survey made public today.

Advances in prices of some primary market commodities to new highs last week met a frosty reception in retail circles. Merchants regarded this development as undesirable and economically unsound if it should inspire a departure from efforts to get prices and costs of finished merchandise down to levels meeting with a minimum of consumer resistance.

THE reader of "The Wild Yazoo" may have some difficulty deciding whether John M. Myers is writing a historical novel or kidding the pantaloons off those who do. As a parody the book has some claim to success, but by and large parody does not seem to be the aim.

EVER since the first lawmakers solemnly gathered together to think up the first tax, a basic canon has been "The tax shall be proportionate to the ability to pay." Every time the Amercan Congress squares away to draw up a new tax schedule this old maxim is waved in the oratorical winds.
TOMORROW is the hundredth anniversary of the birth of Alexander Graham Bell. His name was appropriate. He probably was responsible for more bell-ringing than any other man in history.

LONDON. WITH snow on the ground, ice in the air, electricity cut, and no coal in most people's cellars, the main topic of conversation in England now is fuel; even in the entertainment world, the big freeze is on, and the agents are tucked down into their overcoats, hibernating.

Eugene Rogers, 23-year-old former Columbia swimmer now with the New York A.C., won the 220 and 440-yard free-style championships to feature the New York State title meet at the Winged Foot pool last night. In each case a clubmate, Mike Priano, was second.

IN his Victory Order of the Day to the Allied Armies General Eisenhower said: "Let us have no part in the profitless quarrels in which other men will inevitably engage as to what country, what service won the European War." That was a great hope, but in vain.

WASHINGTON, March 1--The State and War Departments strongly endorsed today United States participation in the International Refugee Organization as a method of reducing the cost of American responsibilities abroad.

If continued at its present pace, erection of office building space in Manhattan may become a threat to the market, in the opinion of Lee Thompson Smith, president of the Lawyers Title Corporation of New York, who sees current high rents for such quarters setting the stage for stimulated building activity that could result in a glut of business quarters.

RICH in charm and as gay in color as azaleas, Martha Washington or Lady Washington geraniums are oldfashioned house plants. Closely allied to the favorite but more common geranium, they are a joy to grow on sunny windowsills.

LONDON, March 1--The picture of the post-crisis Britain is gradually taking shape. It will not be very much like the picture of the post-war Britain that the tired and heroic people had expected to emerge from their years of struggle against a powerful enemy.

WAYCROSS, Ga.--A small section of what the Seminole Indians used to call "Land of Trembling Earth" and what Georgians refer to simply as "The Swamp," is now a public park. It is Cowhouse Island, whose 1,200 acres just south of Waycross are only a tiny slice out of the 400,000 acres of Georgia swampland known as Okefenokee Wildlife Refuge.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 1-- Edward Bauer, register of Union County, an elective office, for twenty-nine years, a founder and vice president of the former Elmora Bank here and long a Republican leader in the county and State, died last night in his home at 31 Princeton Road, after an illness of several months.

OF the recent books on art a small volume by Aline B. Louchheim, managing editor of Art News, stoutly specifies the longest land broadest span. Its perkily ambitious title is "5,000 Years of Art." Of course, in the allotted space, and even with the Orient left out, no one could hope to handle so vast an assignment otherwise than with tabloid succinctness.

THE jacket says of this newly translated and annotated edition of the prophecies of Nostradamus that it will enable the reader "to open the door of the future." No doubt a solemn editorial conference preceded the decision to publish this work; after all, letting the general reading public in on the future is no light responsibility.

LONDON, March 1--A "fair degree" of improvement in the transport of coal was registered today as British industries, blacked out since Feb. 10, warmed up electrical instllations to resume operations Monday.

COLOR is obviously the first consideration of Iver Rose, whose recent paintings are on view at the Kraushaar Gallery. But Rose is also an observer and, too, he is capable of putting humor into his clowns, musicians and participants in a Gloucester fisher folk festival without letdown in the seriousness and dignity of his craft.

ADD another case history to the catalogue of novels subtitled Returned Veteran. Several quite sturdy variations on this theme have already been played, but that has not stopped Howard Hunt from hitting the keys of his typewriter hard and loud.

BEFORE 1939 there were plotters other than Hitler who had designs inimical to English scenery. Busy British planners, with schemes for arterial roads and civic centers, were already blue-printing the destruction of some of the most famous antiquity in the world before the Luftwaffe got under way.
ATLANTA, March 1--White and Negro leaders of Atlanta joined today in dedicating the George Washington Carver Negro Boys Club. Speakers said the project marked a new era in Atlanta community work.
WASHINGTON, March 1--The first phase of an experiment in establishing a "legislative budget" neared an end this week, and the second was already under way.

LOGICALLY enough, reams are written about the Markovas and the Danilovas in any given season, for they have won their way to stellar rank and are figures of importance. There are other figures of importance, however, who are not yet rated as stars in the billing but whose accomplishments on the stage indicate quite clearly that lights are being reserved for them on the marquee.

NEW ORLEANS, March 1--Dry Mississippi's so--called "black market" tax on liquor apparently is on the way out. The levy, called a "black market" tax because it is a legal impost for the benefit of the State against goods which cannot be sold legally in the State, probably will be eliminated at a special session of the Legislature.

NEW DELHI (By Wireless). HE was a tall, burly, rather red-faced man who in appearance resembled greatly the caricatured concept of a "Poona colonel." Now wearing tweeds, he had been retired from the Indian Army.

PHILADELPHIA, March 1-- Plans for the construction of a $25,000,000 four-lane vehicular tunnel under the Delaware River, to connect major highways in Pennsylvania and southern New Jersey, are being considered by the Delaware County (Pa.) Authority and the Gloucester County (N.J.) Tunnel Commission.
The library of Cloyd H. Marvin, president of George Washington University, will be auctioned tomorrow at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

Joseph D. Nunan Jr., Commissioner of Internal Revenue, and Charles Oliphant, assistant general counsel of the Treasury Department, conferred yesterday with John F. O'Connell, chairman of the State Liquor Authority, on means for the Federal Government to recover $3,250,000 in taxes owed by the Longchamps restaurant chain.
The threat of a strike vote among teachers in the city school system was raised several times yesterday at the annual conference of the New York Teachers Guild, AFL, in the Hotel Roosevelt.

MINDEN, Germany, March 1-- As an answer to the high prices charged by the Soviet zone for buna rubber, the British Military Government is proposing to import natural rubber for manufacturing plants in the economically merged United States and British zones.

HIGH in the mountains in the northeastern part of Jamaica, lies the Maroon village of Accompong. There, by train, automobile and mule-back, Katherine Dunham, young American Negro dancer, choreographer and anthropologist, went to study the Koromantee dances.

With the elimination of price control from all segments of the economy except for several foods and rents, there has developed an intensive drive to modify rent control. Most of the proposals suggest 10 or 15 per cent increases in rents, with some differences as to the timing of these adjustments.
MIAMI, Fla., March 1--Faultless was just that in the Flamingo Stakes today.

ANTIQUES collecting abroad used to be the privilege of aristocracy and later an activity of a climbing upper class. In this country the aristocratic-upper class phase was telescoped into a very few years, and now we find widespread feeling that antiques are fashionable, romantic and desirable.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 1--Two weeks of preliminary training for the Giants ended today under sunny skies, leaving one more week before the New Yorkers launch their spring exhibition schedule against minor and major league clubs.

LONDON--The backlog of people waiting impatiently in Europe for transport to the United States is being whittled down month by month, but not fast enough to offer a great deal of hope to the thousands of American tourists eager to visit Europe this year.

NOURATHAR is the name coined by the author from Arabic roots meaning "light" and "essence," to describe what she calls a sixth art, that of light-color-playing upon the Sarabet, an instrument of Mrs. Greenewalt's invention.

ALLIUMS are a group of plants, some three hundred strong, that are most conveniently examined during a time of rear when the garden does not demand too much attention. One or two might be potted up for winter forcing.

Prices of stocks drifted within a narrow range in yesterday's final session of the week on the Stock Exchange and closed irregularly higher in the second dullest session of the year. Commodities, however, continued to show strength. Sales on the Exchange dropped to the smallest volume since Jan. 4, on a turnover of 300,000 shares, compared with 440,000 in the previous two-hour session.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, March 1--Following close upon the exposure of the cosmic crimes of the war lords and politicians tried before the International Military Tribunal, an American Military Government Tribunal at Nuremberg is now ferreting out details of crimes committed by a part of the German medical profession so hideous that the Nazis bent every effort to keep them secret.
Hail and Farewell Any number of observers find the dissolution of the British Empire going on before our eyes. The question of time remains. How long will the liquidation process last?

VERBENAS in the new catalogues are pictured in beautiful shades of pink, lavender, blue, purple, red and white. The promise of lusciously colored, velvet-textured flowers all summer long tempts the gardener to order seeds, even though he knows these annuals are trickier than some others to grow, and must be started indoors in March.
The charge of Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin that American politics wrecked the possibility of an amicable solution of the Palestinian problem was assailed by rabbis in sermons here yesterday.

RADIO programs heard by children again have moved to the forefront of controversial subjects in broadcasting. Several parent-teacher groups in various parts of the country have indicted the "crime" shows and the hair-raising serial "thrillers" as psychological dangers to impressionable youngsters and as possible stimulants to juvenile delinquency.

Fresh, in the wake of last week's announcement that Delaware River skippers are planning a predicted log race for cruisers this summer come details of another predicted log event on the waterways of the Shrewsbury River and New York's Lower Bay.

WHEN she first saw Sgt. Michael Flannigan of the Northwest Mounted Police, Katherine Mary O'Fallon of Boston, Massachusetts, was 16 years old. It was in 1907 at her uncle's home in Calgary, Alberta, where she had gone for her health.
What were the best gags heard on the radio last month? This question was put to the most popular comedy and variety shows, judged by radio surveys, and here is their collective answer.

SALONIKA, Greece, March 1 (AP)--A Greek witness told the United Nations Investigation Commission today that he had made nineteen trips into Albania and had personally escorted numerous members of guerrilla bands into Greece.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, March 1--The Communist president of the court in Bratislava that is trying Father Tiso, former President of the Slovak State, according to the official report of the trial, appears to have engaged in what amounted to an open debate in a determined effort today to refute the evidence of a witness who was primarily for the defense.
SACRAMENTO, Calif, March 1 --Balboas of eastern industry, hearing rumors of startling population gains along the western sea frontier, are "discovering" the Pacific Coast in growing numbers.

ARCADIA, Calif., March 1 -- Mighty Armed fell from turfdom's throne today as Olhaverry, 8-yearold gray charger from Chile, scored a smashing upset victory in the $136,100 Santa Anita Handicap before a roaring record crowd of 85,500.

A YEARLY anthology of American thought is a pretty extraordinary publishing feat. The amount and variety of available material might easily dismay the hardiest entrepreneur, and as for the financial and copyright negotiations involved, the less said the better.
OCCASIONALLY in reading a book, one pauses to reread and savor a sentence or a paragraph so concisely stated that it mirrors one's own thoughts and expresses ideas that are hard to put into words.
ABSTRACT art is again, as usual, very much in evidence, even though the week just concluded was the lightest one, with respect to the number of openings, since the first of the year.

WASHINGTON, March 1--A detailed blueprint for the "radically different" commercial airways of the future was made public here today by the Air Transport Association of America, trade organization of the scheduled airlines of the United States.

Professor Edward Teller of the University of Chicago, a physicist who had much to do with the development of the atomic bomb, discusses the future of war in the Bulletin of Atomic Physsicists. He thinks that "new kinds of bombs or other methods of destruction will come as no less a surprise than did the blinding flash over Hiroshima."

NO book, certainly no novel, can settle the rights and wrongs of this nation's treatment of the racial minority represented by the Indian. The record is shameful but the sentimental admirers of Poor Lo ignore--as the author of "Blood Brother" has ignored--the fact that the Indian peoples produced numerous treaty-breakers, many able liars, and whole tribes of bloodlustful killers.

A springtime theatre party that has received a large advance subscription is that arranged for the performance of "Barefoot Boy With Cheek" on the night of April 8 at the Martin Beck Theatre. Projects of the Play Schools Association will be aided by the benefit, of which Mrs. George W. Naumburg is chairman and Mrs. Thomas J. Blake and Mrs. Russell M. Dill, co-chairmen.

IT'S a long haul from the cadences of the classic trios to the melody put out by the Three Suns, but those worthies continue to be assured that the effort is worth while by an intense fan following and a growing corps of imitators.

BECAUSE that eminent Dubliner Leopold Bloom was himself essentially an outsider and an alien, a foreigner from America, spending enough time in de Valera's Eire to feel that he knows it passingly well, is likely to become increasingly conscious of his debt to Bloom's creator.

FRANZ KAFKA, the lonely Czech writer who died in 1924 of tuberculosis at the age of 41 and whose life was a burden of suffering and humility, is slowly being recognized as one of the great figures of modern literature, to be ranked along with--or at least not far below --such writers as Joyce, Proust and Mann.

THE Metropolitan will introduce a new soprano the last week of its season. She is Danitza Ilitsch, a Yugoslav, whose debut role will be Desdemona in "Otello" on March 12. Miss Ilitsch made her first operatic appearance as Nedda in "Pagliacci" at the Berlin State Opera in 1936.

WASHINGTON, March 1--The apparent inability of the Republican leaders in Congress to agree on a legislative program and to bind their members to it has lately been a subject of growing concern to party strategists, whose hopes for a Presidential victory in 1948 are based on the GOP record on Capitol Hill.

BATAVIA, Java, Sunday, March 2 (AP)--The United States freighter Martin Behrman, escorted by a Dutch destroyer, arrived in Batavia harbor at dawn today after abandoning a plan to run a Dutch naval blockade with a multi-million dollar cargo of rubber, sugar and quinine for the United States.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the "Topics of The Times" recently, the editor gave expression to his doubts as to whether our housing problems could and should be solved by mass prefabrication of homes and "* * * whether we should be so eager to abandon the one great sector of modern existence in which the spirit of mass production has been most successfully resisted."

Two meet records were broken and one was equaled in the scholastic events held in conjunction with the afternoon trials in the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. track and field championships at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

AS usual, John Steinbeck's new novel has raised a critical tower of Babel. The differences of opinion among his critics, as this department observed when "Cannery Row" was published, seem to grow with each new book.

BEACON, N.Y., March 1-- Eight inmates of the Matteawan State Hospital, an institution for the criminal insane here, escaped this evening. Four were captured within two hours as they hiked along roadways in various directions. Several were described as "dangerous."

JOHN T.S. WADE, who recently celebrated his eightieth birthday, has been head of the domestic relations department of the Legal Aid Society almost half his life. During that time he has listened to the tales of woe of both men and women who, too poor to engage private lawyers, have turned to the society to straighten out their matrimonial tangles.

A complicated system of foreignexchange transactions through which Latin-American silver is finding a way into India in spite of British control regulations there produced last week a sharp rise in the price of the metal in the market here.

PAULSBORO, N.J., March 1-- Harold S. Ray, 31 years old, and his wife, Frances, 26, of Woodbury, were killed and five other persons injured early today in a triple auto collision on Crown Point Road, near here.

ON BOARD U.S. NAVY ICEBREAKER BURTON ISLAND, March 1--After two months of exploration, war-trained Navy pilots have filled in almost all of the Antarctic continent's coastline and have gone a long way toward putting an end to the exhilarating experience of sighting great areas heretofore unknown to man.
Mayor O'Dwyer opened the 1947 Red Cross Drive here yesterday morning at City Hall by making the initial gift in the city's campaign for $6,153,600 of the national $60,000,000 goal.

THE first roster to arrive on this desk from a major league ball club was that of the Pittsburgh Pirates. Grinning broadly from the front cover is a picture of the new Buccaneer manager, William Jennings Herman. His smile is quite understandable. Billy Herman has finally achieved his life-long ambition, the job of directing the destinies of a team on the Big Time.

THE revival of Henry James is a phenomenon as surprising to his devotees as it is to his detractors. In the last three years more of his work has been reprinted in this country than in the entire quarter of a century following his death in 1916.

CHICAGO, March 1--Mortgage lenders of the nation, who are advancing funds now at the lowest average rate on record, were advised today that ten years hence they probably would have to be content with a still smaller interest return.

Splitting of shares, a corporate practice that has enabled many companies to obtain a wider distribution of their securities, has been less frequent this year than in the early part of 1946, but with the announcement last week of the proposed splitting of the shares of one of the nation's leading railroads, interest in the subject has been revived.

ALBANY, March 1--New permanent teacher-salary schedules proposed by Governor Dewey's special committee on education represent an effort to calm unrest and dissatisfaction among the State's 77,000 public school teachers. It is hoped, too, that they will provide an economic incentive for abler high school and college graduates to enter the teaching profession.

In 1943 the Congress enacted in the Current Tax Payment Act certain relief from the payment of income taxes to the families of members of the armed forces who died while in active service of the United States or of any of the United Nations.
Heavy are the responsibilities of power, and never heavier than in this age of dissolution and decay of old values and the emergence from the dust of dead empires of a new world order.

LONDON, March 1 (Reuters)-- Charlton Athletic, Liverpool and Newcastle United reached the Football Association Cup semi-finals today while Middlesbrough and Burnley fought to a 1--1 draw in their sixth-round cup tie. More than 200,000 fans watched the four games.

A NEW work by Valerie Bettis, her first for a ballet company, is the week's most inresting event. Its title is "Virginia Sampler" and the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo will give it its first performance at the City Center on Tuesday.

MANY books explain the causes of city decay, but few suggest such practical remedies as "New City Patterns." Sanders and Rabuck present a convincing argument by which they claim cities can not only successfully wipe out their blighted areas, but actually gain a substantial sum in taxes each year, over and above all expenses incident to the work.

With retail stocks ample in most departments, purchasing at wholesale was unusually quiet last week, according to a market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc. Some orders were received for after Easter selling, but generally merchants were not inclined to place orders for large amounts of goods other than for immediate or near-term delivery.

GILFORD, N.H., March 1--Veteran Wendy Broomhall of the Chisholm Skiing and Outing Club of Rumford, Me., and Roland Chivers, Hanover Ski School instructor, each covered an approximate nine-mile course in 90 minutes and 43 seconds to wind up in a topplace tie for the Eastern crosscountry championship today.

HANDEL'S Messiah, one of the towering works of musical literature, has been recorded anew in England and released by Columbia in two large albums, one with, nine twelveinch records, the other with ten. The old Columbia version, made about fifteen years ago, has not been available in recent years, and the new recording is a worthy succesor.
ALBANY, March 1--More than 700 college students and veterans marched to the nearly deserted State Capitol today in a demonstration for passage of the AustinMahoney anti-discrimination bill.

In the face of a growing demand upon financial institutions for loans to finance homes, the savings and loan associations of the country last year increased their balances by about $1,100,000,000, an amount about $100,000,000 more than that added to accounts in 1945.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 1--Confronted with an acute teacher shortage and lowered teacher morale, public school education in the United States faces the most serious crisis in its history, educators attending the annual convention of the American Association of School Administrators warned today.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 1-- Argentina's refusal to sell wheat to Belgium has precipitated a crisis here, it was learned today. Paul Kronacker, Minister of Imports, has suddenly decided to fly to Washington tomorrow to appeal for the delivery of more grain.

ON an eight-francs red-brown stamp in an airmail series issued by French West Africa is philately's first portrait of Antoine de Saint-Exupery (1900-1944), French aviator and the author of "Night Flight," "Wind, Sand and Stars," "Flight to Arras," and other books which attracted attention in America.

The truly national character of the American Red Cross as a service organization with its roots in the community life of every city, village and farm area of the nation is demonstrated both by the scope of its activities and the number of persons who participate yearly to make such services possible.

The thirty-first all-breed show of the Providence County Kennel Club next Sunday has drawn 825 dogs, making it the biggest bench event ever slated in Rhode Island. The competition returns to the State Armory in Providence and judging starts at 1 P.M. to continue througn the afternoon and evening.
