ACCIDENTALLY or on purpose, the title of this volume, taken from its first entry, may mislead prospective readers. This story, recently filmed, is going the rounds of the grind houses: the accompanying advertising has implied that prompt medical attention is at hand should patrons be overcome.

CLEVELAND, March 1--With, the current labor contract expiring tomorrow at midnight, the rubber industry failed today to meet a noon deadline set by the United Rubber Workers of the Congress of Industrial Organizations. The union issued its so-called "ultimatum" yesterday.
OMAHA, March 1--Pork chops should remain scarce--and expensive --at least until next autumn.

Universal military training is needed for the nation's security pending the establishment of the United Nations program for peace, according to pupils who participated yesterday in the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast over Station WQXR.

TORONTO, March 1 (AP)--The Detroit Red Wings nosed out the second-place Toronto Maple Leafs, 5--4, tonight to move within two points of the fourth-place New York Rangers who were idle. Still fifth, one place below the notch necessary to make the National Hockey League's playoffs, the Wings outplayed the Leafs most of the way, but almost saw a fourgoal lead wiped out in the final period.

A warning that some coimnunities are pushing rental housing projects without proper regard to the desirability of the land sites was sounded recently by Charles S. Ascher, Federal housing expediter for the five-State Middle Atlantic region, who stressed careful selection of location as a prime factor in the success of the new developments.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 1 --The South will produce "the next great liberal movement in this country" in the opinion of Aubrey Williams who three years ago was the central figure in a New Deal controversy that revolved about his "liberal" or "radical" views on the aims and purposes of government.

The action of the House Merchant Marine Committee last week in approving legislation, which if passed by Congress, will extend for a year the war-time provision permitting employment of alien seamen on United States ships, has brought renewed hope to thousands of foreign-born seamen.

"SONS," by V.A. Smirnov, is a novel of a peasant mother. It is a rural story in which three emotional pressures bear upon the central character, Anna. The first is her primary devotion to her twin sons, whose father has died in the early battles of the Russian Revolution.
--MARCH March comes in like a reactionary, strong for the status quo, scowling at visionaries and their talk of change, their dreams of better days, their hopes of freedom for the winter- bound.

PRAGUE. THE revolutionary high hopes of the new post-liberation Prague stage have had a head-on collision with the box-office. The State, which subsidized nearly all of Prague's some twenty to twenty-two theatres last year in an outburst of enthusiasm for new, progressive, constructive culture, has announced that the cost is too high in view of the fact that audiences have been staying away from progressive, constructive performances in droves.

ATWOFOLD achievement is the aim of the Musicians Chapter of the American Veterans Committee when it presents the first public concert of the All-Veteran Symphony Orchestra Sunday afternoon, March 9, at Hunter College Assembly Hall, with veteran Walter Hendl conducting and veteran Ruggiero Ricci as violin soloist.

WASHINGTON, March 1--The War Department reported today that two United States Army officers had been seized by Chinese Communists in an area of Manchuria where heavy fighting is going on between Communists and Government troops.

The complicated problems and tensions that arise out of life in the metropolitan area are being studied firsthand by students in the Social Research Laboratory of the College of the City of New York. With 272 students, the laboratory now has the biggest enrollment in its history.
TRENTON, N.J. March 1-- Modification of labor legislation to give moderate control of union activities, rather than punitive measures, was proposed today by two leaders of New Jersey industry.

LONDON, March 1 -- "British foreign policy is a mixture of pretense and weakness--a pretense that we are still a great power on the scale that America is a great power, that we can negotiate with America as equals."
TOKYO, March 1--The Japanese Government introduced in Parliament today the largest single budget in Japanese history. About one-fourth of it is set aside for the expenses of the Allied occupation.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP)-- R.J. Thomas, vice president of the CIO United Auto Workers, told the House Labor Committee today he has been in charge of the AllisChalmers strike since November and "believe me the issue is not communism."

Gov. Thomas E. Dewey on Feb. 1 estimated New York State revenues for the fiscal year 1947-48 at $667,000,000. He noted that additional revenue would be required to finance the proposed $400,000,000 bonus for the State's 1,600,000 veterans of World War II ($50 to $250 per man) which will be put to the voters in a referendum this fall.

"ANGEL'S METAL" is the story of a Catholic college and a group of people attached to it who briefly cast the shadow of their lives against the enduring rock of the church. It is a first novel, skillfully written with sharp, sure attack and a vital, realistic style.

IT was clear to anyone who watched them work and read their stuff, from the time they went into action in the spring of 1942, that the marine combat correspondents --a group of enlisted men assigned directly to Marine Corps units in the Pacific war, to write about what they saw in and out of battle--were brave, skillful and industrious.

HOUSEWIVES sometimes sigh at the thought of cooking fish, and their families openly rebel when fish is served. But just try to get a table around the dinner hour in some of the good fish restaurants of New York City.

Financial markets last week were heavily weighted by new fears of a possible breach in the favorable labor situation as a result of the sharp rise in commodity prices, which may invite another round of wage demands. This, coupled with the consequences of the serious plight of Great Britain both at home and abroad, brought an unsettlement to the stock market.

"THE LONG WING" is not simply a novel about a St. Louis family, the Macloud sons and daughters, the inlaws, the grandchildren, the aunts and uncles. It is a genealogy, in novelette form. After ten pages, the reader finds himself as obsessed as the author with the need to classify and enumerate the Maclouds.

CABBAGE and broccoli, like other members of the Brassica clan, grow well in the cool weather of spring and fall. To have plants of good size for transferring outdoors by midApril, when they may have the advantage of a cool growing season, seed should be sown in the house or hotbed the first week in March.

BERLIN, March 1--Denazification trials by German tribunals slowed down materially in January. Action was completed on 28,323 cases in the United States zone, compared with 36,710 in December and 39,429 in November.

THIS novel about Ireland (in the benighted tenth century A.D.) should have been a blend of fantasy, pedantry, poltergeists. As it turns out, these elements are here. In addition there is, because of the author's native emerald talent for outspokenness, a mass of opinion to complicate the story.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, March 1 (AP)--Fourteen Army fliers, whose blazing B-29 crashed with "an explosison like Bikini" after they had parachuted to safety, were rescued by four daring civilian pilots yesterday from snow-covered tundra of the Alaska peninsula over which the superfortress crew had been flying in search of thirteen lost comrades.

A gallant Fordham basketball team, whose great play has been the surprise of the local season, received its worst setback yesterday from a driving City College five, 86-57, at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory. The game marked the close of the season for the losers.

A familiar figure returns to New York Harbor on Tuesday when the Holland-America liner Veendam enters the port for the first time in almost seven years. She comes back once more a Dutch passenger ship, bringing in 576 persons.

OPTIMISM is essential equipment of people engaged in the theatre-- optimism and exaggeration. Expressions of temperate appraisal bespeak a pathetic absence of fire. Plays must be great, actors wonderful, settings magnificent. Anything less is failure. The best play in years is forgotten in months.

THE Old World quarters in San Francisco and Fresno are fast becoming America's major circuses for the whims. Milla Zenovich Logan's Serbians don't have the sweetness-and-light coating of Saroyan's Armenians or the quiet faith of Esther Forbes' Norwegians, but they are a good deal funnier.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 1 (AP)-- The Right Rev. Irving Peake Johnson, retired bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Colorado, died last night at his home here after an illness of several months. He was 80 years old.

CHICAGO, March 1--An undercurrent of fear that the vast potential market for new housing might dry up at least temporarily and that buyer resistance now being encountered in some sections of the country might turn into a real "strike" for better and cheaper houses was felt throughout the convention of the National Association of Home Builders here this week.

Webb-Pomerene Associations may soon become an effective instrument of international trade, Government officials concerned with their operation indicated last week. The necessity for these associations in a world of state trading nations is generally recognized by domestic industry.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 1 (U.P.) --A newly invented machine that shoots electric vibrations through the arms of anyone who holds a set of handle bars attached to it was credited today with curing a 17-year-old high school girl who had been hiccoughing for eightytwo days.

A Crucial Debate Opens This is the big question for the United States: What role shall we play in the world? Last week that question was sharply posed by various developments, the most important of which were these:

In the grand ballroom of a big hotel in Chicago last week various speakers warned a meeting of the American Management Association that the future of the freeenterprise system depended upon business and industry improving their human relations with the public--that is, with their workers and their consumers as human beings.

GEORGE ADE was, perhaps, the most genial, most tolerant and most successful of the goodly number of American newspaper men who, during the first quarter of the twentieth century, graduated from daily journalism to become popular philosophers widely read here and abroad.

RICHMOND, March 1--A lively controversy over the relative merits of Virginia and North Carolina erupted this week when Jonathan Daniels, Raleigh editor lecturing in Richmond, termed Virginia the "cradle and grave of democracy."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 1 --Dr. Alberto Lleras Camargo, former President of Colombia and former Ambassador to Washing ton, is the most likely selection for Governor of the Free Territory of Trieste but will probably not be available because he is schedule to become Director General of the Pan American Union, it was learned today.

GETTING an air transport plane down safely at its airport of destination in weather where both ceiling and visibility are at zero is still the biggest problem and the greatest danger of commercial aviation. It is the obstacle that must be overcome if commercial airlines are to operate with regularity all year round in all kinds of weather.

THE much-put-upon movie patron, who has been complaining with righteous indignation over the seemingly unwarranted increase of film theatre prices during the last four years, apparently is not going to benefit to any great extent as a result of the downward revision in admission scales instituted by the Paramount Theatre last Wednesday.

MR. BALLARD, a specialist in this field, presents in this little book the fundamentals of the American patent system-- one of the most remarkable social inventions on record. His text is a defense of the system as it stands.

Mrs. Florence Denton, 67 years old, was found dead last night in a partly-filled bathtub in her fifteenthfloor apartntent at 45 Prospect Place, Tudor City, by her husband, Frank, a real estate dealer and retired lawyer, the police of the East Fifty-first Street station reported.

WASHINGTON. March 1 (AP)-- Representative Fred A. Hartley, Jr., Republican of New Jersey, chairman of the House Labor Committee, made public today a list of complaints against labor union practices and said many union officials would be called to reply.

THE weather-minded gardener sees many signs of spring that make him believe his longer hours of outdoor work are not too far off in spite of the deepest snow of the winter. The bittersweet and viburnum which have held their berries so long have started to lose them, as a first step toward the opening of new buds.

SCHUYLER GREEN (the hero of this Grade-A tract, which Mrs. Hobson has cleverly camouflaged as a novel) is a crusading writer for Smith's Magazine. Smith's, one soon gathers, combines the best features of Mr. Luce's Life, Mr. Hibbs' Post and Mr. Straight's New Republic:

OTTAWA, March 1--Speculation as to who will succeed Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King as next leader of the Liberal party has been filling many columns of the Canadian press during the past ten days since it became known that Mr. King had been seriously ill.

SALT LAKE CITY. HOLLYWOOD producers are once again bringing trainloads of glamour to the American hinterland. After a war-caused hiatus, caravans of stars are again being sent to spotlighted Main Street movie palaces to introduce filmland's newest wares by means of that great Institution, the "World Premiere."

John Kramer, national turf court tennis champion, had his introduction to the board courts of the Seventh Regiment Armory yesterday. The long limber Californian, who led the United States to victory against Australia, in the Davis Cup challenge round, found that the big service, volley and smash pay-off as handsomely on wood as on turf and defeated Nathan Goldstein, 6--1, 6--3, in his opening test in the National indoor championships.

BOSTON, March 1 (AP)--Erwin D. Canham, editor of The Christian Science Monitor, said today that Gen. Douglas MacArthur believed the occupation of Japan should be turned over to the United Nations "as a test case for collective security as soon as possible after the peace treaty with Tokyo comes in effect."
JERUSALEM, March 1--Answering British Foreign Secretary Bevin's words with bombs and bullets, the Jewish terrorists resumed their activity with a vengeance today.

Friday's six-to-one House vote to pull the teeth of perhaps six billion dollars' worth of portal-to-portal suits obviously reflects the emotions of legislators who have recently been thinking of six billion dollars in another connection. They are beginning to learn what that sum of money means in a Federal budget and they can guess what it might mean to American industry.

A painting of Saint Francis Xavier, which hung in the Immaculate Church in Nagasaki, Japan and survived the atomic bomb explosion late in the war, has been presented to the Church of St. Francis Xavier, West Sixteenth Street, between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas.

SINCE the middle of January an airminded American public has witnessed unwarranted sensationalism surrounding the problems of air safety. Unfortunately, the end of 1946 and the first month of 1947 produced a few spectacular air crashes, many of them abroad, which tended to obscure the really remarkable safety record compiled by United States certificated air carriers in the past year.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Feb. 28--Tax reductions totaling more than $63,000,000, which will benefit industry mainly, were announced today by Jan H. Hofmeyr, Minister of Finance. He presented the budget for 1946-47.

WHEN tree branches are bare in winter, problems of shade seem far away and unimportant. On almost every property, however, some spot presents planting difficulties because of heavy shade. There is more choice among shrubs than any other group of plants.

PRICES on New York's used car market are virtually stabilized for the spring trade, following a sharp decline during the last ninety days, according to Larry Seidman, secretarytreasurer. New York Used Car Dealers Association.

BERLIN, March 1--Disappointed in its attempts to induce the Russians to share the Berlin radio on a quadripartite basis, the United States Military Government will double the strength of its own station here, authoritative sources said last night.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 1--Dr. Kirtley F. Mather, Professor of Geology at Harvard University, in an address before the Science Conference at Vassar College, warned today that science and technology have placed in human hands the power either to destroy civilization or to construct a world of comfortable, efficient existence for all members of the human family.

As telephone company employes prepared to mark the centennial of the birth of Alexander Graham Bell throughout the nation tomorrow, an 1877 edition of The New Brunswick (N.J.) Times came to light yesterday with a report on a threehour long-distance call from New Brunswick to New York City.

JUST seven weeks short of the fifty-two years since its first performance in New York, Oscar Wilde's "The Importance of Being Earnest" comes back to town tomorrow night to show a durability that not even the most visionary of 1895's prophets would have granted it.

HAVANA, March 1--Going into reverse with such violence that they practically stripped their gears, the Dodgers today matched their three hits with as many errors and were lucky to score at all as the Braves beat them, 5--2, to even the series.

Eighty-five rabbis, graduates of the Rabbi Elchanan Theological Seminary of Yeshiva University, will be formally ordained Sunday, March 16. The clergymen, all of whom finished their course during the war, will return to their alma mater for what is known as a "S'micha" (ordination) convocation, coming from sixteen states in the United States, Canada and Palestine.

DEEP snows in New England have increased winter sports activities at Franconia Notch and Stowe, where sportsmen are making the most of the late winter weather. Manchester and Rutland are also entertaining big crowds at Big Bromley and Pico Peak.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 1-- In a thrilling game decided in the last two seconds of play, Cornell's basketball team downed Princeton in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game in Baker Rink tonight, 44--43, before 3,200 frenzied Tiger fans.

THE process that Fernando Ortiz calls "transculturation," which has taken on new forms in the last decade, numbers among its effective disciples a distinguished South American who moves by choice on a triangular course between Buenos Aires, New York and the European capitals.
LOS ANGELES, March 1--A remarkable radar mechanism with three electric "memories" which will land three airplanes simultaneously, and automatically, is being developed by engineers here.

ATER years of a seller's market, where every room clerk had two or three eager candidates for every room available, New York City's hotels are back in a buyer's market. The unprecedented demand for rooms is easing up and desk clerks, who lived for months in the center of throngs of weary guests looking for a place to sleep, have been heard to say they were getting lonely at their jobs.

Admiral Byrd's expedition is conducting the first aerial magnetic survey in the Antarctic. Walter Sullivan, NEW YORK TIMES correspondent, sent a dispatch while in flight recently and described the methods employed. "On a long cable hanging from the Douglas transport trails a sensitive instrument that detects infinitesimal variations in the magnetism of the earth beneath the Antarctic ice cap," he wrote.

Edward V. Loughlin, leader of Tammany, who is up-State on legal business, informed supporters yesterday that he would not resign but would put the issue of his leadership to a vote at the meeting of the Tammany executive committee Wednesday.

Plans for cutting up a large tract of land at Little Neck Parkway and Grand Central Parkway, adjoining the State Farm, in Queens, were announced yesterday with the purchase by Brooklyn developers of ten acres from Samuel Meltzer in a deal negotiated by the Queens Hub Realty Company.

With the problem of securing a berth, in the National Hookey League play-offs still to be solved, the New York Rangers will tackle a tough foe at Madison Square Garden tonight. The foe is Boston, the team that has been waging a fight with the New Yorkers all season for possession of third place in the loop.

MOSCOW (By Wireless) THIS is a city of people fully convinced that they won the war and equally convinced that they must not lose the peace. To them the selection of Moscow as the site of the momentous meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers in which Germany's fate will be decided seems right and natural, just as the views on Germany and American-British treatment of Germans expressed here seem right and natural.

BUFFALO, March 1--Mayor Bernard J. Dowd called together the board of education and other city officials today in a search for some way to end the teachers' strike, but the conference ended in a stalemate.

HOLLYWOOD. THE settlement of the dispute between David O. Selznick and the United Artists Distributing Company leaves Mary Pickford and Charles Chaplin sole owners of U.A. and gives Selznick $2,000,000 and a free hand to operate his own releasing organization, which he established last December.

MONTREAL, March 1 (AP)--The Boston Bruins beat the leagueleading Montreal Canadiens for the first time this season tonight in a National Hockey League game, 2 to 1. The victory enabled the Bruins to snap their third-place deadlock with the idle New York Rangers and it was their first triumph over the Flying Frenchmen in eleven tries.

Key men of finance and industry submitted last night to the free-swinging jibes of the writers who delineate their careers as more than 1,000 gathered in the Hotel Astor for the annual "Follies" of the New York Financial Writers Association.

The board of directors of the National Association of Manufacturers urged Congress yesterday to ban the closed shop and industrywide bargaining. It said both were contrary to the public interest and were largely responsible for the "near-catastrophes" in last year's strike wave.

TECHNETIUM-- From a communication in Nature it appears that Dr. Gerald Druce thinks it premature for Professors F.A. Paneth and E. Segre to call element 43 "technetium," simply because the claim to its discovery made by Dr. I. Noddack and his wife (then Ida Tacke) was at first unconfirmed.
CHICAGO, March 1 (AP)--Grains moved over a wide price range today in an extremely nervous market on the Board of Trade. The volume was large and prices moved with unusual speed.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 1--On the theme, "Working Together for a Better Home and World Community," almost 2,000,000 boys and girls in 4-H clubs in the United States, Hawaii and Puerto Rico are observing National 4-H Club Week, March 1 to 9.

The Joint Distribution Committee announced yesterday that it had appropriated $5,937,000 for overseas relief, reconstruction and emigration work during March. The allocation for March brings to $23,691,000 the total for this year and is the largest threemonth figure since the organization was founded in 1914.

SHANGHAI, March 1 -- The resignation of Dr. T.V. Soong as Premier was greeted here with satisfaction by numerous Chinese groups and with mixed sentiments by members of the American community. Among Chinese Dr. Soong had become the symbol of everything wrong in Chinese economy.

Sales of leading New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of only 9 per cent in February, compared with the same month last year, according to the monthly surrey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. Sales in the previous month showed an increase of 19 per cent over January, last year.

A FEW weeks back, readers of these columns were invited to speak up on the question of inaudibility in the theatre. The invitation touched off a veritable roar of comment. At last, still ruing its curiosity, this department has begun to emerge from the din and to grope cautiously toward a few conclusions.

MOSCOW, March 1--Basic tasks ranging from the greatly increasing of lagging coal production to the equipping of the Soviet armed forces with the most modern weapons and material, will occupy Soviet workers in 1947, the Council of Ministers of the U.S.S.R. announced today.

NEW DELHI, India, March 1 (AP)--A rift developed tonight in the Indian Chamber of Princes when Maharajahs of the larger Princely States reported that they intended to enter the Constituent Assembly without awaiting a possible Congress party-Moslem League agreement that would bring the League into the constitutiondrafting body, also.

Certain elements within the National Maritime Union, CIO, "are determined either to control the union or break it, but nobody is going to weaken or break it up without a terrific struggle," Joseph Curran, NMU president, declared yesterday.

JOHN LOMAX is America's foremost ballad hunter. Where other men collect sheet music, books, prints or dollars, he has collected the living folksong, naked on the lips of the singer. He began gathering folksongs when he was a small boy, and I dare say he's still at it out there in Dallas, Tex., at the age of 80.

Aided by the 74-point rise in the cotton parity to 27.40 cents a pound as of Feb. 15, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange opened strong yesterday but closed rather sluggish with net gains of 8 to 20 points.

SHANGHAI. FOR an old hand in Hollywood, which specializes in the "stupendous" and "colossal," Ray Nazarro's job sounds simple enough. All he has to do is hide a film camera from four million curious Chinese and restore this frenzied Shanghai winter to the relatively peaceful springtime of 1935.

Construction was started last year on almost 41,000 new dwelling units in the New York metropolitan area, the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics announced yesterday. More than 20,000, or almost half of the 40,980 units started, were in large apartment buildings, while 15,080, or 37 per cent of the total, were one-family dwellings and the remaining 5,450, or 13 per cent were in two to four family structures.

CHICAGO, March 1 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 500 head (estimated): total not given. Compared with week ago: All barrows and gilts, $2 to $2.25 higher; sows, $1.75 higher.

HAVANA, March 1 (U.P.)--The criminal branch of the Havana lower court accepted a petition for a writ of habeas corpus on behalf of Charles (Lucky) Luciano today and ordered the immigration director to produce the former New York vice racketeer on Monday for a review of his case.

LONDON, March 1--Mutual understanding between peoples must precede a world federation or a United States of Europe, Prime Minister Attlee told a rally of the World Federation of United Nations Associations here tonight.

Retail trade here beaded upward during the week ended March 1, following the decline under a year age in the preceding week. Department store volume was estimated at 10 to 12 per cent over the like week of 1946. The gain in dollars, however, was not enough to push unit sales ahead in view of the higher price level.

THE Government's unqualified dissatisfaction, with the consent decree regulating movie trade practices, handed down last Dec. 31 by a Federal Statutory Court in New York, is made clear in the appeal filed on Feb. 21 by the Department of Justice with the Supreme Court.

FINAL termination of the remnants of OPA was debated in Congress last week while in the commodity markets hog and wheat prices were attaining thirty-year highs. A year ago the fight on OPA was well launched toward its summer victory and the National Association of Manufacturers was promising that only moderate price rises would occur once controls were removed.

WILLIAM IRISH (and/or Cornell Woolrich), a topflight craftsman in the straight mystery-cum-terror field, has chosen to bill "Waltz Into Darkness" as his first novel. Written as a straight fustian chiller of the old school (with many a cinematic overtone tucked away carefully in its purpled corners) the book scarcely fits that ambitious label.

Miss Jessie Van Brunt, an artist well known as a designer of stained-glass windows, who was a member of an old Brooklyn family, died Friday night at her home, 212 Gates Avenue, after an illness of several months in her eightyfifth year.

New building operations will be encouraged by the recent announcement of Frank R. Creedon, National Housing Expediter, revising upward the rent limitations of apartments in the New York area, according to David Tishman, president of the Tishman Realty Construction Company, who believes, however, that the change does not go far enough.

WASHINGTON, March 1--As the Army-Navy-Air Force unification bill this week-end headed at long last for decision by Congress, chances seemed good for its eventual passage. Meanwhile toplevel military and naval planners were hopeful that the beginning of an era of evolutionary coordination of the three armed services was at hand.

CHOSEN on the basis of subject matter, general interest and appeal, ninety-one pictures submitted from ten States by sixty-eight photographers won a total of $1,000 in prizes in the national contest of the WJZ Amateur Farm Photo Contest.
LOVEDALE, South Africa, March 1--king George VI of Britain and his party visited Lovedale College, center of Bantu culture, today.

WHEN the enthusiastic gardener can look out upon snow scenes through windows framed with flowering vines, his impatience for the arrival of spring is eased to a slight degree. But to attain those flowering green frames takes planning.

The appointment of Eugene Black Jr., a vice president of the Chase National Bank, as United States director of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development neatly solves a problem which had threatened the bank's prospects, financial observers remarked yesterday.

THE Government's unqualified dissatisfaction, with the consent decree regulating movie trade practices, handed down last Dec. 31 by a Federal Statutory Court in New York, is made clear in the appeal filed on Feb. 21 by the Department of Justice with the Supreme Court.

FINAL termination of the remnants of OPA was debated in Congress last week while in the commodity markets hog and wheat prices were attaining thirty-year highs. A year ago the fight on OPA was well launched toward its summer victory and the National Association of Manufacturers was promising that only moderate price rises would occur once controls were removed.

WILLIAM IRISH (and/or Cornell Woolrich), a topflight craftsman in the straight mystery-cum-terror field, has chosen to bill "Waltz Into Darkness" as his first novel. Written as a straight fustian chiller of the old school (with many a cinematic overtone tucked away carefully in its purpled corners) the book scarcely fits that ambitious label.

Miss Jessie Van Brunt, an artist well known as a designer of stained-glass windows, who was a member of an old Brooklyn family, died Friday night at her home, 212 Gates Avenue, after an illness of several months in her eightyfifth year.

CHICAGO, March 1--When the Illinois State tax on cigarettes rose from 2 to 3 cents aspack last Jan. 1 --the extra penny going toward payment of the State soldiers' bonus--it became 30 cents cheaper to buy a carton of smokes in Indiana, where there is no State levy on cigarettes, than in Illinois.

LIKE all other elements of the nation's transportation system, the American railroads are still in the middle of reconversion from war service that left their equipment and manpower worn and weary. Restoration of railway operations to the smooth and dependable standards of prewar years has taken longer than was hoped.

Arthur Benline, vice chairman of the American Legion housing committee in New York County and chairman of the State committee, announced yesterday a Legion-sponsored plan for realty tax exemptions as a stimulus to housing construction.

PHILADELPHIA, March 1 -- Translation by Dr. Samuel N. Kramer, an associate curator of the University of Pennsylvania Museum, of a 4,000-year-old Sumerian epic poem has revealed that psychology, which is looked upon as a "new science," actually won a war some 5,000 years ago.

LONDON, March 2 -- The spirits of financial London have risen with the temperature in the past week. Evidence that the worst of the industrial stoppage has been seen and a batch of encouraging industrial dividend and profit statements also have helped recovery.

Patchwork of New York Of writing books about New York by newspaper men who know their New York there is no end. But New York is a patchwork place. And nobody has been able to piece the patches together so as to arrive at a pattern that gives a true picture of the city.

Rejection by the United States Senate of the draft peace treaty with Italy was urged yesterday by former Gov. Charles Poletti and Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi as spokesmen for the Committee for a Just Peace With Italy.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Domestic questions, great and small, which are before Congress appear to be overshadowed and complicated this week by the Greek issue.

SEACLIFF, L.I., March 2 -- Voters at the election on March 18 will be asked not only to elect a mayor, three trustees and a member of the school board, but to decide whether the village will wipe out the last of its so-called blue laws and permit the playing of baseball in Clifton Park on Sunday afternoons.

STE. MARGUERITE, Que., March 2 (Canadian Press) -- Displaying consistent form in each of the downhill, slalom, cross-country and jumping events, Middlebury College of Vermont yesterday won the senior Intercollegiate Ski Union championships with 566.0 points.
MOSCOW, March 2 -- Private enterprise does not exist on a large scale in a socialist state such as the Soviet Union, although it is tolerated in a minor way on the fringe of the economy.

The battleship Wisconsin left Bayonne, N.J., yesterday for a two-week training cruise in the Caribbean witn 575 Navy reservists aboard. All are volunteers from the Third and Ninth Naval Districts with previous Navy service.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 2 (AP) -- First Baseman Stan Musial of the St. Louis Cardinals ended his holdout siege today, Manager Eddie Dyer announced. This was confirmed at St. Louis by owner Sam Breadon.

New York State has had savings bank life insurance for eight years. Before that Massachusetts had had it for about thirty years, largely because of the enthusiastic support given by the late Supreme Court Justice Brandeis to this particular form of public service.

Ten years have elapsed since John Gielgud, a visiting journeyman from London, electrified Broadway with his conception of Hamlet's baffling character. To many theatregoers, including this observer, time cannot dull the sheen of that memorable portrayal.
PARIS, March 2 -- Since the war France has lived under a regime of mixed economy, with huge new doses of socialism but without the complete repudiation of private enterprise.
PARIS, March 2 -- United States and French experts will meet Tuesday to discuss France's request for a delay in the liberation of some 440,000 prisoners lent to her by the United States.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 2 -- Taking an unprecedented stand, the executive committee of the National Education Association, representing 750,000 of the nation's teachers, adopted a resolution today commending THE NEW YORK TIMES for its series of twelve articles dealing with conditions in schools and colleges.
LAHORE, India, March 2 -- Throughout the militant Punjab its people are living in an uneasy peace.
LONDON, March 2 -- As industry throughout Britain prepared to resume operations tomorrow, most of the country enjoyed the sunniest day in nearly five months.

CHICAGO, March 2 -- Near-by deliveries of lard sold at new seasonal high prices on the Board of Trade last week. Hogs brought as much as $30 a hundredweight, the highest price on record, as the result of decreased marketings and a broad demand.

Rosario and Antonio, assisted by a company of three other dancers, gave their only concert of the season at Carnegie Hall last night. They are both talented young people who have been doing the dances of their native Spain hereabouts for a number of seasons, and frankness makes it necessary to remark that they have sometimes done better by it than they did on this occasion.

TRENTON, N.J., March 2 -- The New Jersey Legislature ending a three-week recess, will resume tomorrow its attack on several controversial problems, among them a soldiers' bonus, teachers' pay rises and increased taxation of pari-mutual racing.
The Jewish Board of Guardians yesterday called upon Governor Dewey and the Legislature to support a bill for segregation of young offenders.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 1 -- Private industry in Turkey is on an extremely small scale, and it is difficult to appraise it by Western European or American standards. It is strictly confined to the lightest industry such as clothing, cotton goods, leather and other commodities and small, implements.

Water spurting through a crack in the concrete floor yesterday flooded the basement of 700 Avenue of the Americas, causing damage estimated at $10,000 to equipment owned by the Stromes Systems, Inc., industrial engineers.

A great national crisis usually turns up a scapegoat to assume the sins of the nation itself. China is in the midst of such a crisis, her most acute since the war with Japan ended. She has apparently selected Premier T.V. Soong, Chiang Kai-shek's brother-inlaw, as her scapegoat. Events he could not control have finally forced him out of office.

A plea "for the simple, unpretentious virtue of kindness" was made yesterday morning in the Riverside Church by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. Robert James McCracken, in a sermon on "Majoring in a Minor Virtue."

The New Friends of Music brought its eleventh year to a close late yesterday afternoon with its sixteenth and final concert of the season at Town Hall. Having completed the Bach and Bartok cycles, Schumann and two Slavonic masters were the composers of the program.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Two recent editorials in THE NEW YORK TIMES, "Russia's Atomic Plan" and "Covering Moscow," are interesting to me because of the interrelationship they have in connection with the answer I would give to all questions pertaining to Russian behavior.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- With the soft coal situation heading for another strike deadline on March 31, Capt. N.H. Collisson, Federal Coal Mines Administrator, declared today that there was no immediate prospect of returning the seized mines to their owners.

The Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert, Bishop-elect of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, consecrated yesterday the Church of the Heavenly Rest and its Chapel of the Beloved Disciple at Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street.

Of twenty-two nations surveyed by correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES, Canada appears to be the only one in which private enterprise can be said to be functioning today with anything like the freedom from government controls that obtains in the United States.

Cautious purchasing in both the wholesale and retail fields dominated the market last week, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. In many departments retailers had ample stocks and, with a slackening of consumer purchasing ,of those items, they were in an excellent position to be more "choosy" than ever.
AMSTERDAM, March 2 -- Despite official denials, rumors continue that very soon a Dutch loan of $25,000,000 will be floated in New York.

Snow that was expected to blanket the city to a depth of two or three inches began falling early today after rain and thawing temperatures had saved New York from an early threat of a crippling snowstorm and had begun making inroads upon the snowfall of last week.

BERLIN, March 2 -- Sentiment grows in official circles for the postponement of a formal peace treaty for Germany and the temporary substitution of a "peace statute." The purpose would be to permit some rationalization of the German impasse and a subsequent leisurely discussion of the provisions of the permanent treaty.
NANKING, March 2 (AP) -- The United States pressed through three channels today for release of two American Army officers who fell into Communist hands in Manchuria.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 2 -- Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, has been forced to agree to temporary continuance of per diem allowances on a reduced scale because of bitter complaints of lower-paid employes, it was learned today.

PITTSBURGH, March 2 -- Steel ingot production, at 94.5 percent of capacity, was unchanged last week from the week before and steel observers saw no immediate let-up in the heavy demand for practically all types of steel products.

CHICAGO, March 2 -- Expansion and modernization within the plumbing and heating industry and many others related to housing will raise, manufacturing to record levels, industry leaders declared today. They promised builders a supply of equipment and materials that will keep pace with needs.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- The Veterans Administration said today that it had asked the States to intensify their check-ups on veterans claiming unemployment payments with a view to tightening-up.

Andres Segovia, the Spanish guitarist, was heard in a recital last night at Town Hall. In spite of the rain, a large audience was on hand to welcome the eminent artist, who remains the unrivaled master of his chosen instrument. The passing years have served only to ripen his art, which never was more remarkable and compelling than at this latest of his many appearances in this city.

Cotton prices in the domestic market last week again registered a net gain for the period. At the close on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 21 to 58 points over the close of the previous week.

BERLIN, March 2 -- Fawzi el Kawukji, Arab terrorist and aide de camp of the exiled Mufti of Jerusalem, Haj Amin el Husseini, lived in the Soviet sector of this quadripartite city under the noses of the British, who have a price on his head, it was revealed today by one sympathetic to the Arab cause.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 26 -- The Swedish Social Democratic Government's post-war program is one of nationalizing big industries. This program aims at the slow but progressive absorption of the bulk of Swedish big business.

Studebaker Campaign Set Black and white copy of nine hundred, five hundred sixty, four hundred twenty and three hundred lines will run in approximately 1,700 newspapers in 1,500 leading markets, while full-page, four-color advertisements will be placed in business, news and fiction magazines and automotive trade publications in the campaign of the Studebaker Corporation for its third post-war motor car creation, the Land Cruiser.

Although rising price trends continue to be reported by industrial purchasing agents on a broad variety of materials, supplies and equipment, the most., encouraging indication of future stabilization is a wide increase in the number of firm prices quoted by suppliers, purchasing spokesmen reported here last week.

The Boston Bruins squelched the New York Rangers as a threat for third place in the National Hockey League race last night. Taking advantage of the many errors committed by the Blue Shirts-particularly by the "rover-boy" line of Church Russell, Rene Trudell and Cal Gardner -- the Boston sextet battered its way through to a 3-to-2 triumph before a crowd of 15,925 onlookers at Madison Square Garden.

David E. Duncan will succeed Richard Cukor as store manager of Macy's-Parkchester. The latter will return to Macy's New York to continue development of his plans for the organization of Macy'sJamaica, now under construction.

LONDON, March 1 -- A Colonial Office spokesman said today that the British Government regarded the handling of the situation in Palestine as entirely a matter for Palestine authorities. No other comment was forthcoming from any British official source.

Defeated for the first time this year in Eastern League competition by Harvard Saturday night, Columbia's league-leading basketball team will face second-place Cornell tonight on the Morningside Heights court in a contest that will go a long way in deciding if the Lions can recapture a title they last held in 1936.
The New York City Housing Authority, in letters sent yesterday to all members of the Legislature, declared that Mayor O'Dwyer's plan to replace the agency would inject politics into public housing.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The "expanding system of slave labor" is a "dire threat to the free workers of all countries," according to the International Labor Relations Department of the American Federation of Labor. In a pronouncement issued today the department, headed by Matthew Woll, said that "forced labor has become a postwar institution in many lands."

All types of household materials -- clothing, furniture, rugs, appliances, toys-are needed immediately by Goodwill Industries, 123 East 124th Street, for use in its rehabilitation program. Refurbished in the society's workshops by handicapped persons, the articles are sold to support the agency.
WARSAW, March 2 -- While Poland is well on the road toward complete socialism, it ia not clear how small a role private enterprise will be allowed to play in the country's economic future.

The 35,677-ton Cunard White Star liner Mauretania will re-enter passenger service between England and the United Stated on April 26, when she leaves Liverpool for New York, it was announced yesterday.

HAVANA, March 2 -- An earlymorning tropical downpour that inundated Grand Stadium field this morning washed out the final exhibition game with the Braves and made even a Dodger workout impossible today. With the exception of six players who flew, back to Miami early this morning to participate in the Braves-Brown game this afternoon, Billy Southworth's crew boarded plane at 6:40 this evening to return to their Fort Lauderdale base.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I wonder whether in your editorial comment on the teachers' strike in Buffalo you have not focused too much attention on the merits of the issues and too little attention on the lack of a procedure under which the teachers or their representatives may seek expression of their grievances in some other way than through strike.

ALBANY, March 2 -- The proposal to create a State motor vehicle security fund, which would guarantee performance on all automobile insurance written in New York State, will meet, with substantial opposition now just coming to a head, it was learned today.

The surprise triumph of Warren Halliburton in the high hurdles, the inspirational success of its twomile relay team in the clinching test and the unexpected two-point contribution by Homer Gillis in the 60-yard dash marked New York University's sitrring victory in the high-tension Intercollegiate A.A. A.A. indoor championships last Saturday night.

Of immense effect on the deliberations in Moscow is the bombshell dropped into Washington last week by the official announcement that Great Britain is no longer able to maintain without American help her military and economic foothold in Greece. The British are seeking to withdraw from Greece.

SINGAPORE, March 2 (London Times Dispatch) -- According to official reports from Kuala Lumpur, the situation in Kedah, northernmost of the Malay states where rioting among Indian laborers broke out last week on several rubber estates, is now "reassuring."
JERUSALEM, March 2 -- More than a third of Palestine's Jewish population was put under statutory martial law today.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, March 2 -- During the next two years Czechoslovakia probably will abandon most of the international spa business as a source of foreign exchange. Experience in the past year and estimates for this coming season indicate that the fashionable.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 26 -- Private industry in Czechoslovakia retains a respectable position, despite an over-all 70 per cent nationalization of industrial capacity.

Admittedly this is not the time to invest in pork, which has taken an upspurt in price. Yet no discussion of carving would tie complete without something on picnic shoulders, which is why we must devote this final column on the subject to a cut of the meat that has increased so in cost.
NANKING, March 2 -- President Chiang Kai-shek, who took over the Premiership of China just twenty-four hours ago, predicted today that China would achieve unity in six months to a year.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- While nationalization of industry is the heart of the Labor Government' program for post-war Britain, this country will continue to depend on private enterprise for the conduct of most economic activity.

LAKE SUCCJESS, N.Y., March 2--The fifty-five members of the United Nations will probably be asked to establish a special committee to study the Palestine question and report its recommendations to the General Assembly at its regular session next September, it was learned today.

As Secretary of State Marshall prepares to leave for his first peace conference, scheduled to start in Moscow a week from today, it is becoming painfully evident that he faces great tasks and difficult circumstances.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The Export-Import Bank, financed by $3,500,000,000 of United States funds, announced its intention today to stop loaning money to other countries for "emergency reconstruction."

ROME, March 2--As long ago as last August, Dr. Alcide de Gasperi, Italian Premier, declared that "Free capitalism can never rise again in Italy," and events seem to confirm the correctness of his opinion.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, March 1 -- Capitalism and private enterprise are on the way out in Hungary.

ALBANY, March 2 -- Governor Dewey is planning to send special messages to the Legislature this week endorsing the teacher-salary program recommended by his special Committee on Education and proposing that additional taxing powers be given to cities and other subdivisions of the State.

BERLIN, March 1 -- The lack of economic unification of Germany provides a distorted picture of private industry in the country. One would have to know not only the outcome of the Foreign Ministers meeting in Moscow but also the ultimate political character of a free Germany before predicting any economic trend.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 25 -- Two conflicting trends are manifest in Australia's economy.

TO the members of the Baseball Writers Association the robin is not the first sign of spring. Their harbinger is the Red Book, which the American League prints exclusively for their information, or else it's the Green Book, which the National League sends them. They always roll off the presses at this time of the year.

POPLARVTLLE, Miss., March 2 (AP) -- Senator Theodore G. Bilbo, wearing a mask to hide scars of a recent mouth operation, heard himself described as a man of vision who made possible the $100,000 Juniper Grove Baptist Church and parsonage, which were dedicated today.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 2 -- With no diverting interests such as the arresting of any more local players to distract them, the Yankees seemed to pay closer attention to what they were doing today, with the result that they defeated the Magallanes of the Venezuelan League, 5 to 4.

ALBANY, March 2 (AP) -- The population of fourteen cities and larger villages of up-State New York dropped in 1946 as compared with 1940, estimated figures on sixty-nine localities, released by the State Health Department, showed today.

Private philanthropy in the United States spends an estimated 52,706,000,000 annually, according to the Social Work Year Book for 1947, whereas in 1945, given as a sample year, Federal, state and local government expenditures for old-age assistance, aid to the blind, aid to dependent children and general assistance totaled $988,000,000.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 2 -- There is no such thing as "our problem," but there is "something that others have rendered into problems concerning points we consider vital," Premier Recep Peker stated today.

WARSAW, March 2 -- After more than two years of bitter struggle, Poland's political underground is disintegrating. The pre-election fighting apparently was its last major effort to bedevil the country's Left-Wing Administration.

PARIS, March 2 -- Peasants of France were asked to make the same sacrifice as workers and to sell at a loss to aid the pricelowering experiment in a speech addressed to them today by Premier Paul Ramadier, speaking in the small town of Bagnols-surCeze, near Nimes.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 2 -- A reminder that the conditioning process is nearing completion and that the competitive stage of training for the Giants is approaching came today as the ranks of Mel Ott's hold-outs thinned.

MEXICO CITY, March 2 -- Preparations were complete tonight for this capital's first reception to a President of the United States. Mexicans hoped President Truman would arrive on schedule at Balbuena Airport here tomorrow forenoon.

WHEN Jean Stafford's first novel, "Boston Adventure," was published, two and a half years ago, it was generally acclaimed as a work of unusual talent. Miss Stafford's emotional power, her technical facility and her mature intelligence won flattering tributes, and comparisons to Dostoievski, Marquand and Proust were rashly tossed about.
JERUSALEM, March 2 -- The British Administration issued tonight two Official Gazettes providing appropriate legislation for the statutory martial law ordered by the High Commissioner.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 24 -- In the Soviet sphere in southeastern Europe -- Rumania, Bulgaria, Yugoslavia and Albania -- private enterprise steadily if slowly is waging a losing battle, even if there is no plan to try to copy all aspects of the Soviet pattern immediately.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Carroll Reece, chairman of the Republican National Committee, lectured GOP Congress members today on the importance of "team play" and of carrying out the signals of the "duly chosen" quarterback.

MANILA, March 2 (AP) -- A higly-placed, well-informed Philippines official said today that signing of a military-base agreement with the United States was "imminent," and that these -- subject to last-minute changes -- would be the bases that American forces would man:

Unless the church of Jesus Christ can be "implemented to condition people spiritually," there is no hope for the world, Dr. Lewis E. Christian declared yesterday. He delivered his first sermon as the new minister of the Washington Square Methodist Church, 133 West Fourth Street.

MADRID, Spain, March 1 -- The declared policy of the Government is to encourage private initiative and private capital to develop industry. Nevertheless, during the eight years since the end of the Spanish civil war, the Government has continued to infiltrate into more and more, branches of activity, and it shows no signs of withdrawing.
Developments in the railroad and shipping industries in the last week threatened to create a transportation crisis.

Week Ended March 1, 1947 There was an undertone of softness in the Canadian free dollar and British pound in last week's foreign exchange market. These two currencies, which have been furnishing all of the activity of recent months, suffered principally from a drying up of buyers interest, so that at the week's close losses were not particularly large.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 2 -- The Deep South controversy on restricting registration of Negro voters, ranging from the strict interpretation of existing laws to the rescinding of all laws on the subject, is expected to develop along several lines when this State's biennial legislative session convenes in May.

The Rev. Adrian Buisson, pastor and founder of the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Esperanza, 634 West 156th Street, celebrated a solemn mass there yesterday marking the sixtieth anniversary of his ordination. Cardinal Spellman presided at the ceremony, which was attended by 3OO persons.

Three Chinese children captured an audience at Town Hall yesterday with their charm, their poise and their ability to make music ring true on the piano. The audience was won from the moment 12-year-old Sophie Vlachos-Wei stepped out on the platform and announced: "It is awfully nice to know that while we play here some other Chinese child will be learning to play music.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 2 -- The $1,300,000 Lido Beach Hotel near Long Beach, which was taken over from the Navy by the United Nations eight months ago to house delegates and Secretariat members, soon will be "reconverted" into a swank resort for public use, it was learned today.
LONDON, March 2 -- The most important international Communist gathering since the abolition of the Communist International in 1943 is now drawing to a close in London.
Although seas were rough and winds high over large areas in the Atlantic yesterday, no distress calls from ships were reported by the Coast Guard here.

Francis Adams Truslow, New York attorney, takes office today as the second salaried president of the New York Curb Exchange. He has relinquished his responsibilities as a partner in the law firm of Reed, Truslow, Crane deGive to devote full time to the affairs of the exchange. He was elected for a three-year term last December.

When the world is at peace and on a stable economic and exchange basis, international lending, it is generally agreed, should be handled predominantly through the private investment market. But however desirable this may be under normal conditions, it is a state which cannot be restored overnight when the fighting of a major war ends.

Several group exhibitions in museums and galleries are among the many art attractions opening this week. Paintings by contemporary Irish artists go on view tomorrow at the galleries of the Associated American Artists. At the Riverside Museum is an exhibition of work by members of the Associated Artists of New Jersey.

OTTAWA, Feb. 27 -- The Government's control of industry and enterprise in Canada during the war reached such a peak that private business seemed almost inevitably doomed to disappear. The Government built not only airplanes, tanks and all forms of armament, but also ships and houses.
SALONIKA, Greece, March 1 -- Industries in Greece are approaching their pre-war levels, but at a rate that is far from satisfactory.

LONDON, March 2 -- The dollar problem is one of Great Britain's worst headaches at present and much prominence was given to it in the Government's recently issued economic survey, It has become, more urgent then ever in view of the industrial plight of the country.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, March 2 -- Czechoslovakia is arriving at the point where the extension, rather than restriction, of her trade with the West is becoming important for success of the Communists' Two-Year Plan. No secret is made here of the difficulties arising from the lack of multilateral trade and the resulting barter character of Czechoslovak foreign trade.
OSLO, Norway, March 2 (AP) -- An enthusiastic crowd of 100,000 saw Norwegian ski jumpers rout foreign contenders in the famed Holmenkollen meet today.
PARIS, March 2 -- France's difficulties with Viet Nam are characterized today by continued armed clashes in Indo-China and by a vigorous propaganda war in Paris.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 26 -- Those most intimately concerned with private industry in Belgium are in the curious position of not being sure whether the conditions are good, bad or indifferent. A plausible case can be made out for any one of the three.

Support of the current $65,000,000 campaign of the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York was pledged yesterday afternoon by 2,000 representatives of Jewish fraternal and benevolent organizations at a conference in Manhattan Center, 311 West Thirtyfourth Street.

BATAVIA, Java, March 2 (U.P.) -- The American Liberty ship Martin Behrmann, seized by the Dutch Navy for allegedly taking on a cargo of rubber in an Indonesianheld port without Dutch permission, docked at Batavia harbor today.

PEIPING, China, March 2 -- Confirmation that Maj. Robert B. Rigg and Capt. John W. Collins were both captured yesterday by Communist forces while they were on an inspection tour approximately ten miles southeast of Changchun reached here today from American sources in Changchun.

BATON ROUGE, La., March 2 (AP) -- Investigation of alleged scandals in the Evangeline Baseball League which resulted in five players being declared ineligible, today was declared ended with no action pending against anyone else.

Chances of adoption of the Austin- Mahoney anti-discrimination bill at this session of the Legislature faded yesterday when Coadjutor Archbishop J. Francis A. McIntyre put the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York on record as flatly opposed to it.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 2 (AP) -- Jimmy Demaret of Ojai, Calif., won the $10,000 St. Petersburg open golf tournament today with a seventy-two-hole total of 280 and projected himself as the leading money winner of the winter golf circuit.
Employer and union representatives in the dress industry will meet with Mayor O'Dwyer at noon tomorrow in an effort to avert the strike of 80,000 New York dressmakers threatened for Wednesday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 2 -- "War Knight," a screen story by Ethel Hill about her 7-year-old horse which won the $100,000 Santa Anita Handicap in 1946, has been purchased by Liberty Films for $100,000, the producing company has announced.

CHICAGO, March 2 -- Two persons were killed and more than thirty injured in an explosion just after noon today which completely demolished a three-story brick building in the southwest corner of the Loop. The cause of the blast was undetermined tonight, but authorities speculated it might have been a gas explosion.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., March 2 (AP) -- The United States Olympic bobsled team for 1948, including two veterans of the 1936 games, was announced tonight by the Olympic Committee.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., March 2 (AP) -- The United States Olympic bobsled team for 1948, including two veterans of the 1936 games, was announced tonight by the Olympic Committee.
The tenth New York Antiques Exposition opened yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel with fifty dealers' booths arranged in the Astor Gallery and the Jade and Basildon Rooms.

TOKYO, Monday, March 3 (AP) -- The war-ravaged islands of the Ryukyu group, including Okinawa, are slowly returning to normal and the people, long dominated by the Japanese, are assuming a role in their government, Gen. Douglas MacArthur reported today.

The 1947 Red Cross drive for greater New York got off to a flying start yesterday with collections of $150,000 up to noon, it was announced by James M. Cecil, general chairman. The drive started Saturday, with a goal of $6,153,600.

The 104th annual report of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York prepared by Lewis W. Douglas, president, before his appointment last week as United States Ambassador to Great Britain, and issued for publication today, emphasized the effect of low investment yields in increasing the net cost of life insurance protection for millions of policy holders.

Continuing its efforts to prosecute the surviving defendants indicted in 1942 in the mass sedition case, the Department of Justice has appealed a United States District Court decision dismissing the indictments, it was learned here yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, March 2 -- A resolution pledging "support of the maximum resources of American Jewry" for continuance of "the stream of Jewish immigration into Palestine in defiance of the British blockade" was adopted here today at a special meeting of the National Administrative Council of the Zionist Organization of America.

CHICAGO, March 2 (U.P.) -- The Detroit Red Wings, fighting for a place in the Stanley Cup play-offs, defeated the Chicago Black Hawks tonight, 3 -- 1, to tie for fourth place in the National Hockey League. A crowd of 17,548 watched the battle.

Laws to prohibit strikes of civil service workers are "charged with the gravest danger" unless they establish the principle that government employes should enjoy higher wages and more favorable conditions than comparable workers in private industry.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., March 2 -- Condemning city and State threats against the Buffalo teachers, the powerful Tenure and Academic Freedom Committee of the National Education Association adopted a resolution today pledging its full support to any teacher who might suffer reprisals for going out on strike.

PHILADELPHIA, March 2 -- A new electronic super-calculator, said to be capable of making the Army's world-famed ENIAC look like a dunce, is under construction at the University of Pennsylvania, it was revealed tonight with the lifting of security restrictions.

Term lending, although employed most by large banks, has become widespread in this Federal Reserve district, according to the second of a series of studies of commercial bank loans published today by the federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Any day now there will be a resonant drumroll from the old Baldwins behind the barn or from the gaunt, scraggly August Sweet at the corner of the ice house. It will likely be a mellow bluesky day, with tumbled masses of white cumulus clouds overhead and drops of water from icicles playing a muffled tick-tack on the cement apron before the open barn doors.

TOKYO, Feb. 25 -- The wreckage of the war and the measures demanded by the Allies to break up the classes accused of causing it have left private industry in Japan in an extremely shaky condition with the question still to be answered whether it eventually will revive or be replaced by a system of nationalization or a sweeping state-planned economy.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (U.P.) -- Current high hog and lamb prices are expected to continue through the summer, the Agriculture Department said today.

A master plan for voluntary health agencies in New York City, designed to assure maximum service by all such agencies in cooperation with official agencies, will be worked out by a committee of the Health Council of Greater New York, it was announced yesterday.

As dissatisfaction among teachers over Governor Dewey's salary proposals moved closer to the showdown stage yesterday, the Board of Superintendents issued an open letter to all teachers cautioning them against any course of action other than the "effective professional campaign" they are now following.

ZURICH, Switzerland, March 2 -- How swiftly the economic recovery of Europe is now proceeding is clearly demonstrated by reports and balance sheets the large Swiss commercial banks presented to shareholders at annual meetings last week.

The United Nations was asked yesterday to give its members quotas for absorption of Europe's displaced persons and refugees "on an equitable, nonsectarian basis." The request was made in a resolution adopted by 1,000 delegates representing 3,000 fraternal, labor and religious organizations at the sixty-second annual convention of the Hebrew Sheltering and Immigrant Aid Society in the Hotel Astor.
A fact-finding survey of the city's $50,000,000 laundry industry, covering 4,956 licensed laundries employing 30,000 workers, was announced yesterday by License Commissioner Benjamin Fielding.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $56,361,789,693. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

MOSCOW, March 2 -- Visas for sixteen additional United States correspondents to report the Council of Foreign Ministers' meeting here will be granted by the Soviet Government, the United States Embassy announced today.

Paints, finishing materials, chemicals, lift trucks, tractors and skid platforms, steam engines, measuring instruments, office furniture, lacquers and thinners and ovens are among the new fixed price offerings included in total surplus sales in this region having an approximate cost value of $180,000,000, Carl P. Malmstrom, regional director of the War Assets Administration, reported over the week-end.

NANKING, March 2 (U.P.) -- Communist leader Gen. Chou En-lai today, telegraphed President Chiang Kai-shek requesting a twenty-fiveday extension of the order closing all Communist liaison offices in Government territory.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 2 -- President Truman, en route to Mexico City on a good-will mission, dropped out of the clouds at the Army's airport near here in his plane just before noon today after having been airborne four and a half hours from Washington.
BUFFALO, Monday, March 3 -- Buffalo's strike of public school teachers has ended and the schools will reopen on schedule this morning.

La Salle Academy, making a bid for its second straight championship, edged St. John's Prep, Brooklyn divisional title-holders, 42 -- 40, in an overtime semi-final contest of the C.H.S.A.A. city-wide basketball play-offs at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night.

NANKING, March 3 -- A Defense Ministry spokesman announced tonight that Government troops had scored a major victory below the Sungari River in Manchuria. He said they had broken the siege of Tehhwei, ended the threat to Changchun and "trapped" 60,000 Communists in a counter-attack that had "annihilated" 20,000 Reds.

LONDON, March 3 (AP) -- Prime Minister Stalin, after six years as commander of the vast Russian military organization, resigned his post as Minister of the Armed Forces today because of the "excessive pressure of his main work" and handed the job to Gen.Nikolai Alexandrovich Bulganin, the Moscow radio said tonight.

Statements allegedly made under duress at Cairo by Dr. Karl von Kleczkowski, former German, intelligence agent in Turkey, and his wife, Stella, have "their parallel only in the infamous 'confessions' of the Russian state trials," Louis Waldman, attorney for the von Kleczkowskis, declared yesterday in a brief filed with Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind.

Trailing by nine points twice during the opening period, Columbia's Ivy League pace-setters refused to succumb to Cornell's Big Red quintet last night, subsequently registered a 47-45 victory and moved a step closer to its first court crown since 1936.

The election of John J. McCloy as president of the new International Bank for Reconstruction has generally been interpreted as the go-ahead signal for that institution. That this development did not come any too soon is suggested by the semi-annual report of the Export-Import Bank, made public yesterday.

Reported discovery of a second Antarctic "oasis" by Admiral Byrd's wideranging fliers seems to confirm the fact that the south polar continent is not the continuous frozen waste that the world conceived it to be. The existence of wide stretches of open land studded with fresh-water lakes suggests the possibility of establishing permanent settlements there, from which the mineral resources of these rugged regions might be exploited for the benefit of mankind.

"Parlor Story," a comedy about a former newspaper man who strives to have himself named president of a small Midwestern university, opens tonight at the Biltmore Theatre under the auspices of Paul Streger. It is William Mc-Cleery's second script in as many years dealing with a member of the so-called fourth" estate, his first having been "Hope for the Best," which, was offered with Franchot Tone in the leading role.
The six main types of atom-smashing machines now in existence give scientists "great cause for hope" that they may force the atom nucleus to yield its secrets.

Owing to unavoidable circumstances, this department cannot solemnly swear that John Gielgud's performance of "The Importance of Being Earnest" is immeasurably superior to the original performance in 1895. Even Mr. Gielgud, wise though he is, cannot know that from personal observation.
The Seafarers International Union, AFL, announced last night that it would seek increases in wage scales to meet rising living costs.

The Appellate Division affirmed yesterday by a three-to-two vote a decision handed down last December by Supreme Court Justice James B.M. McNally, upholding the right of the city to issue and sell budget notes of approximately $18,500,000 to finance a retroactive wage increase promised to its 33,000 transit workers.

Defeat of Mayor O'Dwyer's bill to abolish the present five-member New York City Housing Authority and replace it with a three-man agency was urged upon all members of the Legislature last night by the Citizens Union.

MURRAY HILL, N.J., March 3 -- A conversation over what was said to be the longest telephone land circuit ever used, covering 10,000 miles, was part of the program originating today in the Bell Telephone Company's laboratories here in observance of the 100th anniversary of the birth of Alexander Graham Bell.

JACKSON, Miss., March 3 -- Members of the Legislature were arriving here today for a special session that convenes at noon tomorrow, with the possibility of a "white primary" law the most discussed item in this State, which, in 1890, set the pace for the South in methods to limit the registration and voting privileges of Negroes.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As chairman of the public relations committee of the New York Library Association, representing 611 libraries in New York State, may I thank you for the editorial "A New Policy on Libraries" which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The annual report of the National Gypsum Company, issued to shareholders yesterday by Melvin H. Baker, president, showed that the net profit of $4,023,952 for 1946 was four times the 1945 net of $1,000,616.

JERUSALEM, March 3 -- The Palestine Government accused Zionist authorities tonight of "deliberate misrepresentation of the facts." The charge referred to statements that the Government had steadily refused concessions while trying to obtain Zionist cooperation to suppress terrorism.

Resources of all State-supervised banks in the forty-eight States, the District of Columbia and the Territory of Hawaii aggregated $84,148,564,000 at the end of 1946, $1,842,768,000, or 2.1 per cent, below the level of June 29, 1946. They declined a total of $3,281,961,000 during the year.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 3 -- After six weeks of investigation, a public hearing and heated discussions, the Westchester Board of Supervisors rejected commercial rent control legislation for the county today by a vote of 24 to 17.

NORWICH, Conn., March 3 -- Arthur Lincoln Peale, a member of the Connecticut State Park and Forest Commission since 1926, who was an authority on wildlife and Indian history, died here on Saturday after an illness of two months. His age was 78.

TOKYO, March 3 -- Industrious and honest farmers who not only grow their required quotas of rice but also turn in their grain to the Government, denying themselves the much larger prices that can be obtained on the black market, now will be rewarded.

NEW HAVEN, March 3 -- Trailing, 37 -- 27, with five and a half minutes to play, a fighting Dartmouth five put on a sensational finish at Payne Whitney Gym tonight for a thrilling 43-41 triumph over the Yale quintet. Yale led at the half, 20 -- 17.

MADRID, March 2 -- Handbills attacking Generalissimo Francisco Franco as a demagogue and tyrant are, being circulation among Spanish troops. The pamphlets, as violent as anything the Communists have written, apparently are being distributed by Monarchist officers.

Oscar Shumsky, young; American violinist, is beginning to build up a reputation as an interpreter of modern music. Last night he added to it with an excellent performance of a Hindemith concerto with the National Orchestra Association at Carnegie Hall.

Senator Vandenberg expressed a feeling which must certainly be widely shared when he characterized Senator McKellar's questioning of David E. Lilienthal before the Senate Atomic Energy Committee yesterday as "outrageous." Senator McKellar has been allowed to conduct a personal and vindictive filibuster in a committee of which he is not even a member.

A new marine navigation system, used for the first time by the Normandy invasion fleet and employed more recently to guide coal-bearing ships up the fog-blanketed Thames River during the British coal crisis, is scheduled for introduction in this country soon, it was disclosed yesterday.

An investigation by the March Kings County grand jury into possible unethical practices by professional bondsmen, criminal lawyers and politicians in Brooklyn's criminal courts was indicated yesterday by Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz in Kings County Court.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Senate put the armed services merger legislation into the hands of its new Committee on the Armed Services today, overriding by a voice vote the bid of the Committee on Expenditures in the Executive Departments for jurisdiction.

LONDON, March 3 -- In one of the most violent and stormy debates ever held in the House of Commons Winston Churchill, leader of the Conservative Opposition, accused the Labor Government today of taking the first step in "curtailing national liberties" and of "strangulation of parliamentary democracy."

ALBANY, March 3 -- Without fanfare, the World Trade Corporation has asked the Legislature for authority to operate a produce market, it became known tonight. The market presumably would be in New York City.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Persons thronging the white marble home of the Supreme Court were disappointed when the tribunal again failed today to rule on the contempt case brought by the Federal Government against John L. Lewis, chief of the United Mine Workers.

Blustering winds, a backlash from the storm that brought snow, sleet, rain, and finally more snow to the city in a thirty-seven-hour downfall, swept and chilled New York yesterday. Velocities ran for the most part between thirty-five and forty miles an hour, with gusts of fifty-five miles an hour recorded by the Weather Bureau in mid-forenoon.

Adjournment of the Federal Trade Commission hearings on restraint of trade charges against the blouse industry was requested yesterday by counsel for the National Association of Blouse Manufacturers until an agreement can be reached for shortening the trial.

Service training has been placed ahead of sales education in the home appliance field development campaign of Bendix Home Appliances, Inc., A.A. Smith, field service supervisor, disclosed here yesterday. Service managers for eastern distributors have started first sessions of a four-day intensive instruction course at the Park Central Hotel, Mr. Smith revealed.
