WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's message to Congress on expiration of selective service, March 31:
WASHINGTON, March 3 (U.P.) -- The War Department today blamed lack of housing, and hospital facilities for its decision to return pregnant wives, of Americans from Germany to the United States.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A great deal has been said recently about Mr. Bevin's tactlessness in accusing the President of the United States of wrecking the possibility of an amicable solution of the Palestine problem. THE NEW YORK TIMES condemned the Bevin statement as "impolitic and badly timed."

The special subcommittee appointed by the United Nations Security Council to investigate the British-Albanian mine dispute put both the London and Tirana representatives through ninety minutes of questioning at the first meeting held yesterday in the Empire State Building.

Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the Port of New York Authority, said yesterday that the authority had filed a brief with the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday protesting proposed tariffs, now under suspension, that would relieve railroads of the responsibility of pick-up and delivery service where, in the opinion of the carriers, physical conditions or strike situations made this service impracticable.

PARIS, March 3 (AP) -- Leah Thall of Columbus, Ohio, one of the U.S. hopes in the women's table tennis championships, won her first match today but lost to Giselle Farkas, 21-year-old Hungarian secretary, 21 -- 15, 14 -- 21, 21 -- 14, 20 -- 22, 21 -- 18 in the second round.

ALBANY, March 3 -- In a special message to the Legislature, Governor Dewey endorsed tonight the teacher pay recommendations of his committee on a state educational program and urged their immediate enactment into law.
PHILADELPHIA, March 3 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had adopted an amendment to Rule X-12 D 2-1 under the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934.

MEXICO CITY, March 3 -- President Truman assured Mexico and the other American Republics tonight that the United States would remain faithful to its non-intervention commitments. He referred to non-intervention as the keystone of the Western Hemisphere's Good Neighbor Policy.

Land for Schools Low teachers' pay and high farmers' prices both being in the news, and the connection between the two an obvious one, there comes to mind an example of American planning which goes back into the nation's colonial history.

American business is definitely steering away from the recession widely predicted for this year, with indications now growing that "boom and bust" psychology is being replaced by a "boom and balanced economy" sequence, S.J. Flink, chairman of the Department of Economics of the Rutgers University School of Business, said yesterday.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 3 -- With the arrival of the Dodgers today this quaint metropolis nestled among towering mountain peaks beheld a curious spectacle. It looked as though two expeditionary forces of explorers had suddenly stumbled upon each other by accident and there was much handshaking all around.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, March 3 -- The United States Army Post Exchange is charged by business men here with depreciating the purchasing power of the dollar in the countries surrounding Germany by buying considerable quantities of goods every month allegedly above real prices, and accepting unsatisfactory wares.
LONDON, March 8 (AP) -- Jimmie Bruen, young Irish amateur golfer, hinks Ireland should make a threesome of the Walker Cup golf tournament, in which only Britain and the United States compete.

Any help, economic or otherwise, to China will only "aggravate the ill effects of the mistakes already made in American policy and set China further back," Nathaniel Peffer, Professor of International Relations at Columbia University, declared last night.
ALBANY, March 3 -- following is the text of Governor Dewey's special message to the Legislature on teacher pay recommendations:
PHILADELPHIA, March 3 (AP) -- The regional office of the War Assets Administration, today announced the sale of textile and other items through competitive bidding which closes March 7.

LONDON, March 3 -- The election of John McCloy as president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development is considered here a victory for Wall Street, and for British theories as to how the bank should have been organized in the first place.
The Holland-America liner Veendam, which was used by the Nazis as a training vessel for U-boat personnel during the war, will arrive here today for the first time in almost seven years.

SINCE this space already has been filled with a discussion of the Red Book, the press information booklet issued by the American League, it would be both impolite and impolitic not to devote an equal amount of embossed verbiage to the companion volume, the Green Book, which the National League has issued to the inkstained wretches of the Fourth Estate.

Jascha Bernstein, 'cellist, and Ernst Victor Wolff, pianist, joined in an evening of serious, unpretentious music-making at the Town Hall last night. It was the kind of playing that would grace a cultured home where live music by family and friends might be the accepted way of spending an occasional evening.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 3 -- To retain its leadership in the world, the United States will have to increase its expenditures for education, William Benton, Assistant Secretary of State, told the nation's leading educators today at the seventy-third annual convention of the American Association of School Administrators.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 3 (AP) -- Miss Mary Agnes Wall, diminutive star golfer of Menominee, Mich., won medal honors in the qualifying round of the nineteenth annual Florida East Coast women's golf tournament today with a score of 76.

This country must take over some of the responsibilities formerly assumed by the British Empire, Mrs. Anne O'Hare McCormick of the editorial staff of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared yesterday. She made this assertion to 170 members and friends of Sorosis, the first incorporated woman's club in this country, which awarded to her its tribute as outstanding journalist of the year at its seventy-ninth anniversary luncheon meeting at the Waldorf - Astoria Hotel.
TEL AVIV, Palestine, March 3 -- Uncertain and apprehensive, the people of Tel Aviv stood on the sidewalks. For a minute today the heart of Jewish Palestine stood still.

EAST LONDON, South Africa, March 3 -- Addressing principally the youth of south Africa, Princess Elizabeth was received with great enthusiasm today when she inaugurated a new dry-dock here named for her.

BUFFALO, March 3 -- Buffalo's ninety-eight schools reopened this morning with about 80 per cent attendance after the week-long teachers' strike. Almost immediately other city employes warned Mayor Bernard J. Dowd that their demands must also be satisfied or a new strike vote would be taken among municipal employes.

LONDON, March 3 -- An insistent demand that the Government speed the Palestine problem to the United Nations for consideration and make possible an end of "this squalid warfare" was made by Winston Churchill in the House of Commons today.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- A record $3,035,877,000 in income tax refunds for fiscal 1946 was reported today for big and little corporations, celebrities, politicians and ordinary citizens.

The Chicago Black Hawks continued their feud with the New York Rangers in the National Hockey League race before a crowd of 13,203 at Madison Square Garden last night when they lambasted the local crew by the score of 9 to 4.

The stock market was unable yesterday to generate any major trading interest as prices drifted back and forth and closed irregularly lower. The session again was one of the dullest of the year as transfers on the Stock Exchange only totaled 690,000 shares, compared with 680,000 shares on last Friday.

In the continuing struggle for freedom the United States should promulgate a positive policy and eschew a tendency to let fear direct the nation's destiny, Archibald MacLeish, United States representative on the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, asserted last night.

CHICAGO, March 3 (AP) -- Commissioner K.L. (Tug) Wilson of the Big Nine today announced that the Wisconsin-Purdue game, disrupted at halftime when a bleacher section collapsed at Lafayette, Ind., last Monday night, would be resumed at that point at Evanston;

JERUSALEM, March 3 (AP) -- Five hand grenades were hurled into a British military office in Haifa tonight. This renewal of violence came shortly after the Jewish underground organization Irgun Zvai Leumi proclaimed that "open warfare exists in Palestine."

Irresponsible persons flying private planes over the City have caused the Police Department grave concern, Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander declared yesterday at the weekly luncheon-meeting of Advertising Men's Post 209, American Legion, in the Hotel Lexington.

A sharp, rise in "open and flagrant" prostitution and venereal diseases in the United States was reported here yesterday at the opening session of a two-day conference of the American Social Hygiene Association.
LONDON, March 3 -- Influenced by the country-wide power switch-on, the stock markets were active and cheerful today.

PARIS, March 3 -- German prisoners were erecting flag poles today in front of the Subprefecture in Dunkerque in preparation for the ceremonies attendant upon the signing of the, British-French treaty tomorrow.

LOS ANGELES, March 3 -- Herbert K. Sorrell, leader of the Hollywood motion picture studio strike which has just entered its seventh month, was found badly beaten and bound by the roadside at Ridgecrest, 100 miles north of Los Angeles, last night.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Senator Wayne Morse, Republican, of Oregon, who identifies himself as a middle-of-the-road liberal, broke openly today with Carroll Reece, chairman of the Republican National Committee, "and the machine for which he speaks."

Mrs. Rose Russell, legislative representative of the Teachers Union, CIO, declared yesterday that three of the five organizations making up the executive committee of the Teachers Salary Conference were on record as favoring a strike poll of New fork City's public school teachers.

CAPE ELIZABETH, Me., March 3 -- (AP) A tremendous wave whipped up by New England's worst coastal storm of the winter snapped off the bow of the collier Oakey L. Alexander today, but her thirty-two-man crew rode a Coast Guard breeches buoy to safety across 150 yards of wild surf.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Senator Homer E. Capehart, Republican of Indiana, chairman of a newsprint subcommittee of the Senate Small Business Committee, expressed the hope today for "prompt action" to ease the newsprint shortage.

Dr. Hans Borchers, last German consul general in New York, has been returned to this country to testify as a voluntary witness for the Government in a propaganda perjury case, it was established yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The attitude of the Republican majority in the State Legislature toward the delegation of 1,000 New Yorkers who visited Albany on Feb. 18 in an attempt to inform their representatives of their feelings about rent control legislation is shocking to any citizen who believes in our democratic traditions.

De Pinna offered yesterday at the St. Regis a showing of spring fashions representing the work of some of the country's topflight designers. It included a simple classic coat in a deep ginger tone of the costly chulengo fleece priced at approximately $1,000.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 3 -- In its most decisive step since it began operating, the United Nations Economic and Social Council today set up a special commission to put European reconstruction work on a unified, continent-wide basis.

What has happened to tapioca? It used to rank with rice pudding and ice cream and cornstarch pudding among America's No. 1 desserts, but any housewife will tell you that it is a matter of years since it has been seen in groceries.

The Cincinnati Market Research Council, patterned after the New York City Market Research Council, has been formed. Rene Pepin, chairman, vice president and director of research, of Stockton, West, Burkhart, Inc., has named a nominating committee to select officers.

ALBANY, March 3 -- Six of the seven special taxes levied by the City of New York produced $74,218,097 during the first seven months of the fiscal year, only a few millions short of the $79,000,000 which had been estimated as the annual yield of the program.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 3 -- The trade winds blew on sun-flooded Municipal Stadium today. The Giants' workout, sizzling through close to four hours, attracted the attention of Walter (Dutch) Ruether, old-time pitcher of the Reds, Dodgers and Yanks, who is now a scout for the Cubs.
LONDON, March 3 -- Power cuts imposed upon household consumers enabled the still idle sections of British industry to resume operation today after their three-week shutdown.

MEXICO CITY, March 3 -- When President Truman arrived here today after a brief visit in Grandview, Mo., with his mother, who is bedfast, the first person to greet him at the United States Embassy was the mother of his Ambassador to Mexico, Mrs. John Ernest Thurston, who is barely able to be out of bed herself.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- The House Labor Committee learned today that if a telephone strike is called April 7, it would "halt communications throughout the United States and perhaps internationally.

With 80,000 dress workers in the metropolitan area scheduled to strike tomorrow, negotiators representing three employer associations and the Dress Joint Board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL, still were in conference late last night seeking to reach a wage agreement.
Jailing of parents as punishment in juvenile delinquency cases was criticized yesterday by G. Howland Shaw, president of the Welfare Council of New York City.

NEW DELHI, India, March 3 -- The Federation of the Indian Chambers of Commerce and Industry adopted a resolution today criticizing the "fresh and staggering burdens" placed on Indian trade, commerce and industry by the proposed budget.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Sir John Strachey, British Minister of Food, conferred with Clinton P. Anderson, Secretary of Agriculture today on the 1947 food export outlook.

Fifty-nine men and women out of an original panel of 250 talesmen were called yesterday in General Sessions before, a jury was completed in the second attempt to try three men alleged to be the key figures in the football "fix" plot involving Alvin J. Paris.

Random notes. A number of hunting and fishing clubs in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut began operating feeding stations for game birds about a month ago, and reports received from several points indicate that the results have been worth the effort and expenditure.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Army prepared today to release its remaining 100,000 inductees by the end of June and to intensify its recruiting activities for the future, as President Truman ordered the end of the peacetime draft.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (U.P.) -- The Supreme Court today agreed to pass on the validity of divorces obtained in States such as Florida and Nevada which have short-term residence laws.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- President Truman recommended to Congress today that Selective Service, which has inducted 10,022,367 men into the nation's armed forces since Oct. 29, 1940, be allowed to lapse on March 31. The White House sent his message to the Capitol in the Chief Executive's absence in Mexico City.

Store Sales Here Up 14% Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 14 per cent for the week ended March 1, according to the "flash report" yesterday of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

ST. LOUIS, March 3 -- Adequate quantities of high quality coffee will be available to, American consumers this year, it was unanimously concluded here today by the board of directors of the National Coffee Association. The threat of competition from foreign markets was entirely discounted at a meeting of the board in the Missouri Athletic Club.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Credit for the Soviet Union's decision to permit sixteen additional press and radio correspondents from the United States to cover the forth-coming Moscow conference of the Big Four Foreign Ministers was given, at the State Department today to Ambassador Walter Bedell Smith.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: New York City's major bar associations have recently taken the last of several progressive strides in the direction of bettering the professional service of the bar toward the public and toward its own members, all of which I feel deserve wider recognition.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- Chairman Fred Bradley of the House Merchant Marine Committee called today for prompt revision of what he described as the "short-sighted policy" of restricting entry of American steamship companies into transocean airline service.

TRENTON, N.J., March 3 -- Legislation to reorganize New Jersey health facilities and increase revenues from taxation of liquors was introduced today in the Legislature, which resumes sessions after a three-week recess. The measures are part of the Administration program of Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll.

A year ago the Red Cross planned to shut down its clubs for overseas service men, but continued at the request of the War Department it was learned yesterday. Officials had feared for the morale of thousands of teen-age occoupation troops. For this service $16,200,000 will be spent in 1947-48.

Charles Y. Freeman, chairman of the Commonwealth Edison Company of Illinois, said yesterday in the annual report to stockholders that "a substantial part" of a $1,697,900 rise in the system's consolidated net income of $26,275,646 last year was "directly attributable to the elimination of the remaining $18,594,900 of 3 1/2 per cent debentures.

Edward V. Loughlin sent to Tammany Hall yesterday a curt note of resignation, bringing to an end his ill-starred three-year tenure as leader of the Democratic organization in Manhattan. His act ended any possibility of a battle by his supporters at the meeting of the Tammany executive committee to be held tomorrow.

The challenge was offered to Sidney Wood to bring out some of his more radiant strokes yesterday as the former Wimbledon champion defeated Ladislav Hecht in the national indoor tennis tournament, 2 -- 6, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 4.

Electronics Laboratories, Inc., yesterday introduced four new radio models in a press demonstration in the Hotel Drake. Feature of the presentation were two radiophonograph consoles, one standard and the other chair height, with an electrical device which raises or lowers the top of the radio to provide easy access to the record player simply by pressing a button.

OGDEN, Utah, March 3 (AP) -- Racing skiers from Switzerland and Canada slammed the gates on a flock of America's best today in winding up the two-day battle for the United States speed championships at spruce-bordered Snow Basin.

Four Eastern collegiate basketball teams, Fordham, Boston College, Georgetown and Canisius, will see action in a benefit basketball double-header on Friday night, March 14, at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-fifth Street.

CHICAGO, March 3 -- The State Department opened public hearings in Chicago today on the preliminary draft of a Charter for the International Trade Organization, a proposed intergovernmental body for the negotiation of world trade agreements.

VENICE, Italy, March 3 (U.P.) -- Field Marshal Gen. Albert Kesselring, who directed the successful German delaying fight during the Italian campaign, asserted today that he had twice been betrayed by former King Victor Emmanuel and the Italian Government.

Eight persons, including a woman clerk for the Office of Price Administration, were arraigned yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn, charged with conspiracy in obtaining sugar by making false statements. All were released by United States Commissioner Edward E. Fay, in bail ranging from $2,000 to $4,000.

BRUSSELS, March 3 -- Belgium's bonanza is almost over, according to a formal announcement by the Government today that an "extremely grave economic crisis" will hit the country unless conditions improve quickly.

Fashion entered a new era yesterday afternoon at Bergdorf Goodman's with the showing of new spring and summer styles. Gone was all restraint in designing. The imaginations of three distinguished designers, Mary Gleason, Leslie Morris and Mark Mooring, had worked unfettered to bring the collection into being.

Consolidated net income of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation and subsidiaries in 1946 amounted to $16,072,000, compared with $8,146,000 in 1945. After preferred dividend requirements, this was equal to $1.42 a common share, compared with 60 cents the year before.

Voluntary admission by one of the partners of a misdemeanor charge and suspended sentence thirty-nine years ago cost renewal of the liquor license of Fugazy, Flaherty Greene, Inc., 570 Seventh Avenue, and closing of the package store at midnight last Friday, the State Liquor Authority reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- Congress was asked today to approve construction or improvement of 307 large airports in the country during the 1947-48 fiscal year.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 3 (AP) -- Michigan clinched undisputed fifth place in the Western Conference basketball standings tonight by defeating Ohio State, 66 to 62. It was the final game of the season for both teams.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Senate Judiciary Committee suddenly recalled from the floor today for eleventh-hour amendments the bill quashing portal-to-portal pay suits which it had brought out only last week after long study.

St. John's winner of six straight, and N.Y.U., upset in its last three contests, clash in the feature game of the college basketball doubleheader at Madison Square Garden tonight. If the Redmen prevail, the metropolitan championship will belong to them, not to mention a stronger chance for a post-season bid.
WASHINGTON, March 3--The Senate's vote today on a resolution pledging a $4,500,000,000 cut in the national budget for the 1948 fiscal year was as follows:
Austin, Texas, announced yesterday that it would accept bids until March 20 on various purpose bonds totaling $3,300,000. Dated April 1, 1947, the bonds will come due July 1 from 1951 to 1975.
PARIS, March 3 -- The High Court of Justice sentenced Paul Baudouin, former Vichy Foreign Minister, to five years in prison, national unworthiness and the confiscation of his property today.

The possibility of a nation-wide strike of telephone workers April 7 grew stronger yesterday when union representatives completed their presentation of contract demands to the long-lines department of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company without reaching agreement on any issue.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The proposed $350,000,000 authorization for relief of distress in liberated countries struck a snag today in the House Foreign Affairs Committee, which originally had planned to approve the measure promptly.

CHICAGO, March 3 -- March wheat advanced 4 1/2 cents a bushel in the early trading today on the Board of Trade to a new twenty-seven-year high at $2.64. The grain markets were much less active, however, and prices fluctuated in a nervous manner.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 3 -- Twentieth Century-Fox announced today that Rex Harrison will play the leading role in the studio's projected remake of "Lady in Ermine," which Ernst Lubitsch will produce and direct. Samson Raphaelson is writing the screnario from a European play by Rudolph Schnazer and Ernst Welisch described as a military musical comedy of mid-nineteenth century Italy.

LAKE HOPATCONG, N.J., March 3 (AP) -- A 1,600-pound jetpropelled ice boat which its sponsors say will be able to shatter all existing speed records was tested here during the week-end, but was held to a ninety-miles-an-hour maximum because of poor ice conditions.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- A small first step toward restoring normal trade relations with Germany and Japan was taken today with abolition, effective tomorrow, of the requirement of Treasury licenses under the Trading With the Enemy Act.
LONDON, March 3 -- In an atmosphere of considerable skepticism on both sides, a new effort to overcome the impasse in Anglo-Polish financial and trade relations began here today.
Continuing last week's trend, prices of copper, lead and silver moved higher yesterday.

President Truman's decision not to recommend to Congress at this time an extension of Selective Service is, by his own statement, necessarily a gamble. In order to replace personnel losses and maintain the Army and Navy at the rock-bottom minimum needed for the defense of the nation and the maintenance of occupation forces overseas, an average monthly enlistment of 30,000 volunteers is required.
MOSCOW, March 3 -- In Scandinavia, proponents of a Northern bloc plan to transform northern Europe and the Arctic into a huge airdrome for Anglo-Saxon rocket planes.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- The Supreme Court refused today to reconsider its recent decision that the United States Circuit Court in Denver incorrectly ordered a stay of reorganization proceedings for the Denver & Rio Grande Western Railroad.

MIAMI, Fla., March 3 -- The forty days of racing at Hialeah Park end tomorrow with the running of a double-feature program. No. 1 on the list of the day's activities will be the $20,000 added Black Helen Handicap, named for the late Col. E.R. Bradley's Florida Derby champion of 1935, and the supporting attraction will be the Hialeah Juvenile Stakes, which has a $10,000 endowment.
The main purpose of good day care programs for children is to help families to stay together, Alice Dashiell, national field consultant of the Child Welfare League of America, declared yesterday.
Electric lights were cut off early today in the Manhattan State Hospital on Wards Island in the East River by a small but spectacular fire in a one-story brick power house.

Earnings approximately twice as large as for any other year of the Celanese Corporation of America and a new high record in sales were reported in the annual statement for 1946 being issued to stockholders today by Dr. Camille Dreyfus, chairman.

President Truman's address in Mexico City yesterday was a welcome reaffiramation of policies long recognized in this hemisphere, with a somewhat wistful application to the rest of the world. Here, as elsewhere, "the peoples of the world have peace as a common objective."

CHICAGO, March 3 -- Organized labor must undertake the task of making democracy work, Matthew J. Burns, president of the AFL International Brotherhood of Paper Makers told the opening session today of the union's convention.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange started 2 to 21 points lower yesterday and sold off to losses of 17 to 31 points on lower stock and grain markets, but later recovered on trade support. The close was 21 points lower to 7 higher than Saturday's final levels, with distant months stronger than nears.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Nine Northern States and thirty-three Western railroads argued before the Supreme Court today that an order of the Interstate Commerce Commission equalizing "class" freight rates was arbitrary and "inconsistent with cost facts."

SALONIKA, Greece, March 3 -- The United Nations Commission of Inquiry into Greek border strife took testimony today from Greek Nationalist organizations opposed to the Left-Wing Eam. The commission also heard statements from groups associated with Eam that had not argued their cases in Athens.

Eyes on Michigan Bonds Today's scheduled competitive sale of Michigan's $200,000,000 of veterans' bonus bonds is expected to be memorable for more reasons than the mere statistical fact that the issue is the largest ever to be taken on by the municipal market.

MEXICO CITY, March 3 -- The thirty-third President of the United States met the Fifty-eighth President of Mexico in a perfect Mexican morning here today, while the snow-capped Ixtaccihuatl Volcano formed the background.

WASHINGTON, March 3--The Senate half of the Congressional Atomic Energy Committee finally decided this evening to shut off the private fight of Senator Kenneth McKellar, Democrat, of Tennessee, against the confirmation of David E. Lilienthal as chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission.
MEXICO CITY, March 3 (U.P.) -- Text of President Aleman's address of welcome to President Truman:

ALBANY, March 3 -- A series of amendments to the Austin-Mahoney bill to bar discrimination in educational institutions were submitted to the Legislature tonight in an effort to meet objections raised by Coadjutor Archbishop J. Francis A. McIntyre of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, other spokesmen for the Catholic Church and college officials.

The exhibition called "Painting in Ireland" opened officially with a preview last night at the Associated American Artists Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue. More than a dozen contemporary Irish artists "now active in the cultural and national art movement of Ireland" are represented by close to sixty oils and water-colors.

Industrial purchasing agents will soon be asked to participate in a series of panels sponsored by the New York Tool and Die Institute for the improvement of service, Henry Wikstrom, secretary, declared here yesterday.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 3 -- Mahmoud Fahmy Nokrashy Pasha, the Egyptian Premier, announced today his Government's decision to appeal to the United Nations Security Council on the issues of Egyptian sovereignty over the Sudan and the evacuation of British troops from Egypt.

SHANGHAI, March 3 (U.P.) -- A Central News Agency dispatch from Taihoku said tonight that the situation in Formosa was gradually becoming normal following Governor Chen Yi's promise to organize a joint Kuomintang-military-civilian inquiry board to investigate causes of Formosans' clashes with "outsiders."

PHILADELPHIA, March 4-- Securities registered under the Securities Act of 1933 aggregated $7,319,320,000 in 1946, 41 per cent above the previous high of $5,179,472,000 in 1936, the Securities and Exchange Commission has disclosed in its Statistical Bulletin for January.

Although official confirmation was lacking, it was learned last night from an unimpeachable source that the council of the Dramatists Guild voted yesterday afternoon to align the playwrights with Actors Equity in removing the ban against Negroes in Washington theatres.

LONDON, March 4--By issuing a joint statement expressing the hope that the Anglo-French alliance signed in Dunkerque this afternoon "will soon be completed by the conclusion of a four-power treaty," London and Paris have taken the unusual step of emphasizing that Dunkerque is essentially a stopover on the way to Moscow.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP)-- Duquesne, entering the contest as the only undefeated basketball team in the nation, lost tonight, 57 to 39, to a slow-starting Georgetown five.

The Pan-American Coffee Bureau, representing the nine leading coffeeproducing countries of Latin America and, the National Coffee Association, composed of more than 90 per cent of the coffee trade in the United States, have completed an agreement to coordinate all activities, related to the promotion of coffee in an administrative body which will be known as the Coffee Advertising Council.
LEIPZIG, Germany, March 4-- This once-medieval city, now just another example of modern bomb havoc, opened its 757th Fair this morning.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 4-- Irene Dunne, Barbara Bel Geddes and Oscar Homolka will play the leading roles in the screen version of "I Remember Mama," which RKO will put before the cameras in April with George Stevens directing and Harriet Parsons producing, the studio announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 4--Lieut. Gen. John R. Hodge, American commander in Southern Korea, in a speech delivered today at the National Press Club, modified the pessimistic views he expressed at his press conference last week concerning the hopelessness of cooperating with Soviet Russia in Korea.

In addition to towing facilities the Moran Towing and Transportation Company, Inc., of 17 Battery Place, is now in a position to offer emergency electric power to both ships and shoreside installations in New York Harbor, by means of its Diesel-electric-drive tugs, Joseph H. Moran 2d, vice president, said yesterday.

OMAHA, March 4 (AP)--Roy S. Anderson, general president of the Northwestern Union of Telephone Workers, said today the Northwestern Bell Telephone Company has rejected demands set out by the union Jan. 28 for inclusion in a new contract.

Figures Are Quoted The way to use statistics in an argument is becoming more and more standardized. A person begins by exhibiting very little respect for statistics, to put it mildly. He then goes on to prove his own case by a parade of unanswerable statistics.

WASHINGTON, March 4--A strong appeal for American assistance without delay has been made in a note from the Greek Government that was given out by the State Department late today. It followed the earlier notification by the British Government that it could no longer continue its economic assistance to Greece.

Another famous passenger ship returned to the transatlantic shipping lanes yesterday as the Holland America liner Veendam arrived at Fifth Street, Hoboken, N.J., on tier first trip here in seven years.

ALBANY, March 4--Governor Dewey will insist on passage of legislation at this session outlawing strikes by public employes, including teachers, even though some of his advisers believe it may lead to a Republican split and force a delay in the adjournment of the Legislature.

BATAVIA, March 4 (UP)--Captain Gray reported to the Isbrandtsen Steamship Company that the Dutch Navy had threatened to cut the vessel's anchor cable and tow it to port if he refused to obey the Dutch sailing order.

ALBANY, March 4--The Republican legislative leadership appeared today to be committed to the passage of a bill designed to curb further growth of the American Labor and Liberal parties by imposing restrictions on their right to endorse Democratic and Republican candidates.

Post-season basketball bids were accepted yesterday by Duquesne and Navy, the former for the national invitation tournament and the latter for the Eastern Regionals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association. Both competitions are to be held at Madison Square Garden, the invitation starting March 15 and the Eastern Regionals on March 20.

A 70-year-old woman who left her native Ireland fifty years ago and settled in France, where her underground work in World War II won for her a British citation, arrived here yesterday on the United States liner Washington.

Mrs. Loire Brophy, employment counselor, author and lecturer, with an office at 30 Rockefeller Plaza, died early yesterday in her home at 320 Park Avenue after a brief illness. In private life she was the wife of John Harrington McNeil, until recently manager of Station WJZ of the American Broadcasting Company.

MEXICO CITY, March 4--Nothing President Truman might have done to touch the Mexicans could have succeeded better than his gesture this morning when he personally changed his set schedule to pay homage at the small monument honoring the boy heroes of Chapultepec who rushed to defend the capital against United States troops a hundred years ago.

The United States reciprocal trade agreements program is of vital importance to American business and to world trade, Philip D. Reed, chairman of the board, General Electric Company, said yesterday. Speaking at a luncheon of the Sales Executive Club at the Hotel Roosevelt, he said that American business men must give their full support to the program and must let Congress know that they are behind it.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: With the Second World War, at the request of the French Government, the American Friends of France was organized under the leadership of Anne Morgan. It was called upon to help evacuate civilians from the Aisne and Ardennes, scene of the break-through in 1940.

ALBANY, March 4--By a vote of 13 to 6, the Senate Finance Committee today approved a bill to legalize and license bookmaking on horse races within New York State. The measure is sponsored by Senator James W. Crawford, Brooklyn Democrat, and would raise, it was estimated, $50,000,000 in additional revenue for the State.
The cost of treating syphilis among veterans of World War II in the next twenty-five years was estimated at $328,000,000 yesterday by a Veterans Administration official.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP)-- An attorney for several Southern states contended today in the Supreme Court of the United States that railway freight adjustments are needed to give his section of the country an even break economically.

Dissatisfied with the report of the Governor's Committee on Education, the Teachers Union, CIO, will hold a mass meeting on Sunday at Cooper Union to discuss a strike poll of New York City's 35,000 public school teachers.

LONDON, March 4--Realization of the United States' vital interest in Greece has been growing gradually since the Casablanca conference, when President Roosevelt consigned to Prime Minister Churchill control over the conduct of Allied military and political strategy in the eastern Mediterranean.

WASHINGTON, March 4--Gael Sullivan, executive director of the Democratic National Committee, today denounced the "Taft-tory" leadership of the Republican party for what he termed "leading the party into a dangerous disregard of the public debt and an even more dangerous revival of the philosophy of isolationism."

NANKING, March 4--The foreign policy and domestic policy of the Chinese Government have been geared to an all-out military drive against the Communists, with outside economic help if possible and without any help if absolutely necessary.

When Secretary of State Marshall leaves for Moscow this morning he will embark on a mission as difficult and as fraught with destiny as any ever undertaken by an American statesman. This mission is to break the diplomatic deadlock between Russia and the West and to establish a peace, with Germany its key, which will rescue the world from what he himself has characterized as a critical condition.

The Mizrachi Organization of America announced yesterday its withdrawal from the Vaad Hatzalah Relief Committee as the result of recent charges of Vaad Hatzalah discrimination against European Mizrachi members in distributing relief supplies.
BOSTON, March 4 -- Led by Capt. Saul Mariaschin, Harvard swarmed all over Pennsylvania tonight in the Boston Garden to take a 64-to-48 victory in an Ivy League basketball contest.

The basic question today is whether we can really believe that Russia has given up the idea of a world Communist federation and wants peace, James B. Reston, diplomatic correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, told 500 New York school teachers yesterday.

The fourteen-year record of labor peace in the city's largest industry was kept intact yesterday vhen representatives of 80,000 unionized dressmakers and three employer associations reached agreement on a contract calling for a 7 per cent wage increase and an employer-financed retirement fund.

PHILADELPHIA, March 4--The Upper Peninsula Power Company, a newly organized Michigan corporation, applied today to the Securities and Exchange Commission for approval of several transactions including acquisition of the assets of the Houghton County Electric Light Company, the Iron Range Light and Power Company and the Copper District Power Company.
LONDON, March 4--With business easing and a tendency to take profits becoming apparent, one or two sections in the stock markets here today were less buoyant.

JERUSALEM, March 4--Terrorist attacks on British forces continued today despite the imposition of martial law on nearly one-third of Palestine's Jewish population. Five Britons and four Arabs were injured in the last twenty-four hours, five of them critically.

To prevent the reduction of its child care services and to increase these services, if possible, the Salvation Army will extend by two weeks its campaign to raise $1,000,000 in the New York Area, Lester E. Brion, vice chairman of the campaign, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP)-- Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association, said today that Communists are "foreign agents" and asked Congress to prevent them from holding positions of leadership in labor unions.

PHILADELPHIA, March 4 -- The Automatic Firing Corporation of St. Louis filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 25,000 shares of $10 par value 6 per cent cumulative preferred stock; 25,000 shares of $1 par value Class A common stock and 100,000 shares of $1 par value Class B common stock.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- A Senate subcommittee, opening a study of the shortage of newsprint, received from its first group of witnesses today emphatic testimony as to urgent needs but few ready suggestions for alleviation of the situation.

According to reports from London, neither Britain's domestic economic difficulties nor her problems of exchange, which threaten to become worse before they improve, have weakened "in the slightest degree" the Government's support of international efforts to eliminate trade restrictions and restore multilateral commerce.

Fifty representatives of the various section of the maritime industry met yesterday afternoon in the Maritime Exchange, 80 Broad Street, to discuss organization of a local bureau for port development, it was announced last night. Those who attended included men from steamship companies, shipping organizations, maritime labor and local chambers of commerce.

WASHINGTON, March 4--Sentiment in the Congressional Atomic Energy Committee, as hearings were concluded today, appeared to be much stronger for the confirmation of David E. Lilienthal as chairman than for some of his colleagues on the Atomic Energy Commission.

ROME, March 3 (Delayed)--The American contingent of 5,000 troops that will garrison the free territory of Trieste with equal numbers of British and Yugoslav troops will assume the name of "Trust"--a contraction of "Trieste United States Troops."

CHICAGO, March 4--Grain markets had a heavy undertone today on the Board of Trade. At no time were prices more than a small fraction of a cent a bushel above Monday's finish, and the market finally broke sharply under pressure of persistent commission house profit-taking and professional selling.

OTTAWA, March 4--Nine new weather stations are to be established in the Arctic during the next three years, by the Canadian Government in cooperation with the United States, Reconstruction Minister C. D. Howe announced in the House of Commons today.

A gain of 1,021,210 members of Methodist churches in 1946 was reported here yesterday by Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam of New York area and secretary of the Council of Bishops of the Methodist Church, as the "greatest gain in any church in any year in the history of this country."
The Ninth Annual "Cawcus" of the American Crow Hunters Association is scheduled for mid-June at Grand Rapids, Ohio, at which time the national crow callingshooting championship will be decided.

WASHINGTON, March 4--The scene was laid today for what promised to be a drawn-out struggle between the House and Senate on how much President Truman's $37,500,000,000 budget for the 1948 fiscal year should be reduced.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP)-- The Agriculture Department recommended today fixing of wool import quotas and authorization for the Commodity Credit Corporation to sell its holdings below parity.

JACKSON, Miss., March 4--A bill proposing a "white primary" and a strong Gubernatorial plan for Mississippi to stand firm on state rights in defending primary voting privileges were given to the state Legislature today when it convened in extraordinary session.
To add an extra fillip to the finale of the indoor track season at Madison Square Garden Saturday, one of those celebrated Knights of Columbus "doubles" has been lined up for Gilbert Dodds.
A favorite with tennis galleries of long standing passed from the national indoor championships yesterday with the defeat of Frank Shields at the Seventh Regiment Armory.
The possibility of a complete reorganization of the world's merchant shipping communications system was outlined here yesterday by Commodore E.M. Webster, United States Coast Guard, Retired.

MOSCOW, March 4--Lazar M. Kaganovitch has been appointed first secretary of the Central Committee of the Communist party in the Ukraine, one of the largest of the Soviet Union's Republics, in a move to "strengthen the party and Soviet work in the Ukraine."

Secretary Marshall's departure for Moscow was preceded by two sessions with Congressional committees--one on Monday with the House Subcommittee on Appropriations, the other on Tuesday with the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations. The first was ostensibly to discuss the budget of the State Department, the second to urge the speedy ratification of the treaties negotiated by Mr. Byrnes for Italy, Rumania, Hungary and Bulgaria.

A panel of fifty talesmen was exhausted in Federal Court yesterday in an effort to select a jury to try Serge M. Rubinstein, international financier, and two co-defendants on charges of having made false statements to the Selective Service Board at 1109 Lexington Avenue.

DUNKERQUE, France, March 4 (AP)--The official English-language text of the fifty-year French-British treaty signed here today: His Majesty, the King of Great Britain, Ireland and the British Dominions beyond the seas, Emperor of India, and the President of the French Republic.

BATAVIA, March 4 (Aneta)-- The Netherlands Indies Government today in effect ordered the seizure of the cargo of the 9,000ton American freighter Martin Behrman, under charter to the Isbrandtsen Shipping Company of New York.

Alvin J. Paris, dapper 28-yearold convicted would-be briber of two New York Giants football stars, admitted yesterday in General Sessions that he had lied when he originally told the District Attorney's office that he had developed and executed the bribe offer "on my own."

Full of fashion interest in styling and combination of furs was the spring showing presented by Esther Dorothy yesterday at 78 East Fifty-sixth Street. Rounded natural shoulders, shawls instead of stoles, combinations of two tones and two types of fur in shawls and jackets were a few of the host of ideas carried out.

ALBANY, March 4--With New York City's request for $102,000,000 more in state aid still pending, fiscal leaders of the Legislature asked Mayor O'Dwyer today to report in detail the extent to which the city payroll, covering both civil service and exempt positions, has been increased.
BRUSSELS, March 4--Belgium has submitted concrete proposals for treaties of alliance to the British and Russian Governments within the past twenty-four hours.

ELGIN, Ill., March 4--Production of a new alloy watch mainspring, described as the greatest advance in watchmaking since the fabrication of jewels into watch bearings in 1704, was announced here today by the Elgin National Watch Company.

Frank J. Sampson, who is to be elected leader of Tammany Hall today as part of the reorganization demanded by Mayor O'Dwyer, pledged himself yesterday to the cause of civic progress and the welfare of the Democratic party. He asked for support from all quarters in carrying out that program.
Trading will be resumed this morning on the New York Cotton Exchange after a one-day shutdown caused by a strike.

MEXICO CITY, March 4--President Truman touched the heart strings of the Mexican people today, and before sundown had been hailed by President Miguel Aleman as "the new champion of solidarity and understanding among the American republics."
Don't be too sure that a child's sulking or shyness or temper tantrums represent individual "problems" until you know his home background.

A former Army mess sergeant, who was well on his way toward pyramiding a $3,000 stake into a large fortune, was arrested yesterday by United States Customs agents on a charge of bringing securities into the United States without declaring them.

DUNKERQUE, France, March 4 --With a word of assurance from Foreign Secretary Bevin to the Soviet Union to dispel possible fears that a "western bloc" was being formed against it, a fifty-year treaty of alliance between France and Britain was signed here today.

Rudolf Serkin gave one of the standout recitals of the season at Carnegie Hall last night. In a program that would have taxed the resources of any pianist, Mr. Serkin played with a triumphant command of technique, with power under scrupulous control and with soaring imagination that illuminated everything he touched.

Serge Koussevitzky, conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, lost yesterday his legal fight to enjoin the publication of the biography, "Koussevizky," written by Moses Smith, Boston music critic. Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag vacated a temporary stay and denied injunctive relief sought by the conductor to prevent publication, advertisement and distribution of the book.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 4--Demands of the Southern Federation of Telephone Workers in behalf of an estimated 40,000 employes in nine Southern States would boost the payroll costs of the Southern Bell Telephone Company by $72,000,000 annually, "far in excess of total revenues," the company charged today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Quantities of newsprint have been used up in the dissemination of views on the split in the Republican-controlled Congress, with especial reference to the tentative amount of cut from the Truman budget.

Mayor O'Dwyer is off to a good start in his reorganization of Tammany Hall. This afternoon the district leaders, seventy-two individuals sharing among them sixteen votes in the Executive Committee of the New York County Democratic Committee, will vote formally to elect Frank J. Sampson as "leader" of the Hall.

MIAMI, Fla., March 4--To Miss Grillo, 5-year-old mare from the Argentine, and Phar Mon, 2-yearold colt from the heart of old Kentucky, went the stake races at today's final session of Hialeah Park's forty-day meeting.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 4-- Secretary General Trygve Lie has proposed to the Big Five that a United Nations committee be created to study the Palestine problem and he is now awaiting replies to his proposal, it was learned today.

Air Associates, Inc.--December quarter: Net profit, $40,516 or 30 cents each on 134,905 common shares, compared with $12,207 or 9 cents a share for similar quarter of 1945, which included $143,147 tax carry-back credit, before which the operating loss was $130,940.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 4--The first intra-club game on the Giants' training schedule today gave Manager Mel Ott his first comprehensive look at his baseball material after almost three weeks of workouts.

DARIEN, Conn., March 4--Maxing music and politics is as dangerous as joining church and state, Olga Samaroff-Stokowski, pianist and musicologist, said here today in a radio forum on the topic: "What Have Music and Politics to Do With Each Other?"

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP)-- Representative Fred Bradley, Republican, of Michigan, urged Congress today to cut off all United States exports to Russia until the Soviet Government makes "a satisfactory settlement" for ninety-five American merchant ships received during the war.

WASHINGTON, March 4--Earl Bunting, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, called today on John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, to repudiate a statement by the Congress of Industrial Organizations that wealthy persons could easily evade the income tax laws.

Thousands of New Yorkers are preparing their Federal income tax returns incorrectly, thus complicating the work of employes of the Internal Revenue Bureau and delaying their own refunds, Capt. William J. Pedrick, collector of the Second New York District, said yesterday.

Mayor O'Dwyer said at City Hall last night that the information asked for by heads of the Legislative Finance Committee would be sent to Albany as soon as it could be compiled. However, he denied the Albany statement that he had promised such information in a telephone conversation the day after his appearance in Albany.

Mayor O'Dwyer's recommendation, near the end of the legislative session, that all the experienced members of the New York City Housing Authority be turned out of office and the whole agency reconstituted with his own personnel, responsible to him, seems to us to be unwise on several counts.
The remainder of the National Hockey League season should prove plenty keen, if the news disclosed at the Board of Governors meeting yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore is any criterion.

CHICAGO, March 4 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 9,000 head; total 13,000. Hogs under 240 pounds steady to 25 cents lower early with top $29.25; but these closed 50 to 75 cents lower along with heavier weights;

VIENNA, March 4--The United States forces in Austria today transferred fourteen Germanowned or partly German-owned plants and properties in the United States zone to the trusteeship of the Austrian Federal Government.
A collection of suave modern furniture by the Danish-American designer Jens Rissom is an outstanding highlight of the home planning and decoration exhibit that opened yesterday at Altman's.

For the purposes of universal contentment, William McCleery should not wrap up a rather dreary problem play in such attractive clothing. In his second drama, "Parlor Story," which was put on at the Biltmore last evening, he is demonstrating the moral value of being fearless and honest.

The additional January Kings County grand jury, dismissed aburptly last week by County Judge Franklin Taylor while it was in the midst of an investigation into the Brooklyn City Prison break of Jan. 2, described the court's action yesterday as "highhanded."

A proposal to increase the number of authorized preferred shares of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. from 3,000,000 to 4,000,000 and to raise the redemption price from $120 a share to $125, plus accumulated dividends, if redeemed by April 25, 1952, will be presented to the holders of preferred and common stock at their annual meeting on April 14, it was announced yesterday.

Retail drug sales should hold up well even if general retail trade volume should decline later this year, Edward J. Carroll, director of economic research of Sharpe Dohme, Inc., said yesterday. He addressed the mid-year convention of the Federal Wholesale Druggists Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Otto Swanson, head of the Nebraska Clothing Company, Omaha, was elected yesterday president of the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers at its annual convention at the Hotel New Yorker.

Supporters of the Stephens bill to regulate check-cashing agencies expect favorable legislation soon as a result of the State Banking Department's consent to an amendment eliminating the "uncollected items" section, it was learned yesterday.

JERUSALEM, March 4--An argument that others were trying to settle with bombs and guns was taken up by lawyers armed with affidavits, briefs and law books in the High Court of Jerusalem today. The court will decide tomorrow a case that is the Zionist legal challenge to the right of British authorities to deport unauthorized immigrants to Cyprus.
WASHINGTON, March 4--An attempt by Midwestern Republicans to cut almost in two the Adninistration's $350,000,000 program for relief of post-war distress abroad was being prepared today.
Frank C. Chaffee and Louis Friedman have joined Newburger, Loeb Co. as customer's brokers in. the firm's main office, 15 Broad Street.

Noon-Hour Mecca The Cotton Exchange on Hanover Square proved to be the chief attraction for noon-hour thousands in the Wall Street area yesterday. All day long spectators ringed the sidewalks to watch lively but orderly picket lines thrown around the two entrances of the strikebound building.

MEXICO CITY, March 4--The fiesta of native songs and dances presented this morning in honor of President Truman would have been an important event here even without the presence of a distinguished guest, since it was the first presentation of its kind by Mexico's recently created Institute of Fine Arts.

WASHINGTON, March 4--The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 26:

LONDON, March 4--Prime Minister Attlee failed to satisfy House of Commons-questioners this afternoon as to why the British Government has not sought help from the United States in overcoming the critical coal shortage.

ALBANY, March 4--Senator Walter J. Mahoney, Erie Republican, suggested today that action on the bill to bar discrimination in education, of which he is co-sponsor with Assemblyman Bernard Austin, Brooklyn Democrat, be deterred for a year.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 4--Higher educational standards, including a minimum of four years of college for all teachers, were advocated here today by key educators attending the convention of the American Association of School Administrators.

Those who have dined in Paris, or never have but hope to, will enjoy two restaurants in the city run by brothers in the best traditions of the French cafe. They are medium in size, seating from 200 to 250 at a time, offer nothing fancy in the way of decorations and are a bit on the busy, bustling side.

ALBANY, March 4--The Legislature received today the recommendation of the State Youth Commission, advanced with the support of Governor Dewey, that the State child care program be scrapped after Oct. 1.

ALBANY, March 4--The Adjutant General assigned the following officers to duty today: Walsh, Col. C. C., Jr., 27th Inf. Div., to Headquarters as Colonel. Cantaglia, Lt. Col. F. C. R., 27th Inf. Div., to Headquarters as Inspector General. Unger, Lt. Col. E. B., 27th G. M. Co., to Headquarters as Div. Q. M.

The Eastman Kodak Company, in addition to reporting record sales and earnings for 1946, announced yesterday proposals to split the common stock, five shares for one; change the shares from no par to $10 par value, and increase the number authorized.
WASHINGTON, March 4--Prompt ratification of the peace treaties with Italy, Bulgaria, Hungary and Rumania as a step toward world recovery and security was bluntly urged today by...

PITTSBURGH, March 4 (AP)--The oldest railway receivership in United States history was ended today with sale of the Pittsburgh, Shawmut Northern Railroad and its mining properties to Harry W. Findley of Carnegie Pa., a coal operator. Final sale of the properties was ordered yesterday by Federal District Judge Guy K. Bard after a day of spirited bidding.

It was obvious from start to finish that the Jay Thorps custommade collection of originals, exhibited yesterday afternoon, was keyed to wearability rather than the extremes of the new mode. Present were the fashion elements that are under discussion today, but they were handled with under rather than over statement.

Conditions in-north-central New York, where a part of the city's milk supply originates, were described by The Associated Press yesterday as the worst within the memory of residents, as a result of a three-day storm that brought forty inches of snow to some areas.

The concert of music for the lute, virginal, recorders and other old instruments given by Suzanne Bloch and her pupils and confederates last night in Times Hall was exceptionally a pleasure. Old pieces, played upon instruments for which they originally were scored, or upon instruments in common use in the period, were played by highly intelligent and accomplished musicians who gloried in their task and communicated their enthusiasm.

PARIS, March 4--The French Cabinet today discussed a report submitted to it by the Governors and High Commissioners of French Colonies. In that report those officials said that they were "disturbed" by a nationalistic campaign in Madagascar resembling that of Viet Nam in Indo-China.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP)-- S. H. Ingberg, chief of the Bureau of Standards, fire resistance section, estimated today that deaths from burns might be reduced 10 to 20 per cent through a proposed law to prohibit sale of highly flammable cloth in interstate commerce.

BALTIMORE, March 4--The steamship Yaque, first of nine new refrigerated cargo-passenger vessels being built at the BethlehemSparrows Point Shipyard for the United Fruit Company, returned here tonight from her sea trials on the Kent Island course in Chesapeake Bay.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your report of the City Council hearing on the reading of the Lord's Prayer in public schools (Quinn Resolution) omitted mention of the position of the New York Board of Rabbis. Many of your readers will want to know the view of the rabbinate on this matter.

Stagnant conditions were present again yesterday on the Stock Exchange as prices moved narrowly and with no general directive Strength cropped out in a few individual issues, but the main body of stocks only showed fractional alterations, with the composite rate off 0.13 point on the day.

Benjamin Franklin, last year's title-holders, won't be around to defend when city-wide championship day gets under way this week as the Benjays were upset by Stuyvesant, 26-21, in a P.S.A.L. elimination tourney triple-header at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, March 4--The Post Office Department today proposed higher postal rates for postcards, mail other than first class, and special postal services, in an effort to reduce an anticipated deficit of $287,679,250 for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1948.

CHICAGO, March 4--The proposed charter for the International Trade Organization is nothing more than economic appeasemen by the United States of the collectivist countries, Frederick Salditt, vice president of the Harnischfeger Corporation, Milwaukee industrial machinery manufacturer, said today.

The United States must remain at full military and economic strength to play its "decisive" role in keeping the peace, Warren R. Austin, chief American delegate to the United Nations, declared last night.

BOYD COMSTOCK has long been rated as one of America's better track coaches. He did a great job at Southern California and later with the Los Angeles A.C. Then he spent quite a few years in Italy and transformed the Italian athletes into a European power in track and field. Back in the United States now and out of the sports business, he still has a tremendous interest in the game.

How the United States submarine Tang sank 110,000 tons of Japanese shipping in a single twenty-four-hour patrol in the Pacific in 1944, then fell victim to its own last torpedo, which circled and blew up the undersea craft with a loss of seventy-eight lives, was told here yesterday fo rthe first time.

Milk for New York's metropolitan area trickled in from snowcovered up-State sections yesterday at a rate that led distributing companies to predict shortages of up to 30 per cent in today's local deliveries.

ATLANTA, March 4--Anti-labor measures, outlawing the closed shop, involuntary check-off on union dues and mass picketing, were unanimously approved by the Senate today. The vote on the bill to ban closed shops and check-off was 35--0. The anti-picketing bill was carried 40--0.

TRENTON, N. J., March 4--A direct appeal for elimination of railroad grade crossings in Passaic was made today to Gov. Alfred B. Driscoll by a man whose wife recently was killed in a crossing accident. He is Aldo Luchetti, father of four small children.

Wallace K. Harrison, director of planning for the United Nations headquarters, appealed to the city's large contractors and builders last night to mobilize their forces to put up the United Nations buildings with the greatest speed possible and to do it in the "most unselfish way you can."

The New York Telephone Company's annual report for 1946, being distributed to stockholders today, shows a net income of $39,542,081, equal to $9.39 a common share, compared with $28,916,606, or $6.86 a share in 1945.

The Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo experimented last night at the City Center with the idea of commissioning a modern dancer to create a ballet for its repertory. The dancer was the ever-adventuresome Valerie Bettis, and the ballet was "Virginia Sampler."

SECURITY COUNCIL Meets today at 3 P. M. to resume discussion of atomic question. (Open). Sub-committee on incidents in the Corfu Channel--Met at Empire State Building and continued study of British complaint against Albania.

Higher family incomes and consumers' familiarity witn credit purchasing lend an optimistic tone to the future of installment selling, A. J. Guffanti, vice president, Springfield, Mass., declared yesterday.

SYDNEY, Australia, March 4 (Reuters) --Bowlers dominated batsmen today on the fourth day of the fifth and final test match between England and Australia. Douglas Wright baffled the Australians. Taking seven wickets for 105 runs, he was mainly responsible in gaining for England a first innings lead for the first time in this series.
Commonwealth of Massachusetts The Commonwealth of Massachusetts

VERSAILLES, France, March 4 --Fernand de Brinon, accused before the High Court of Justice as a traitor and as a spy in the service of Nazi collaboration, refused today to defend himself. He announced that he would stay in his cell while the court deliberated.

Buyers' Arrivals Higher Out-of-town buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,144, compared with 861 in the preceding week and 1,576 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP)-- The Commerce Department's Lumber Survey Committee expressed belief today supplies of lumber will be adequate for the housing program this year.
LONDON, March 4--Winston Churchill protested today in the House of Commons when the Speaker accused him of "gate crashing."

A syndicate of 212 underwriters began yesterday distributing to investors an issue of $200,000,000 of State of Michigan veterans' bonus bonds--the largest single issue of either municipal or corporate bonds ever to come to market here --at prices yielding from 0.65 per cent for the first maturity, March 15, 1948, to 1.625 per cent for the last maturity, in 1965.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., March 4-- Ralph A. McClelland, 48 years old, an attorney in White Plains, committed suicide here today in his apartment at 48 Garth Road, according to Dr. Amos O. Squire, County Medical Examiner. Mr. McClelland was Scarsdale Town Supervisor since 1934 and chairman of the Westchester County Board of Supervisors in 1938-40.

Basketball at its best, certainly the finest of the local college season, was on display last night at Madison Square Garden, where St. John's, rising to the occasion, achieved a mild upset victory over New York University. Before 18,429 fans, the Brooklyn Redmen earned a 57-56 decision that defies description.

WASHINGTON, March 4--A new CARE food package containing 40,963 calories for $10, instead of the 40,000 calories offered in the former "ten in one" Army ration, was introduced at a press conference here today with the aid of twelve embassy chefs.
Brooklyn breweries already have raised 9 per cent more than their quota in the Red Cross 1947 Fund of Greater New York, it was announced yesterday at a luncheon for campaign leaders.

WASHINGTON, March 4-- Spokesmen for large professional groups appealed today to the Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee to permit professional employes to select their own bargaining agent instead of having such employes classified by the National Labor Relations Board with non-professional workers.
CARACAS, Venezuela, March 4 --Overcoming a four-run deficit, the Yankees drew first blood in the three-game Venezuelan Cup series tonight by drubbing the Dodgers, 17 to 6, before 10,000 spectators.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 4--Creation of an international inspectorate to control the Japanese narcotic drug traffic was supported here today by British and United States representatives, but vigorously opposed by Soviet Union and White Russian representatives.
WASHINGTON, March 4--On his way to the Moscow meeting of the Big Four Foreign Ministers, Secretary of State Marshall will stop in Paris to confer with President Vincent Auriol of France.

PETER DE POLNAY, a British writer of novels and radio scripts, finds in his own adventurous career the material for his superior novels. More than twenty years ago Mr. de Polnay was a sheep rancher and a cattle smuggler in Argentina. And out of that experience came his interesting novel "Two Mirrors." Not too long after that he was a farmer and big-game hunter in Kenya Colony.

Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., proposed yesterday that cooperating contractordealers consider quoting flat prices, including all costs for buying and installing gas household heating equipment. During a luncheon at the Hotel Lexington, attended by more than 100 contractor-dealers and manufacturers of gas equipment, E.F. Jeffe, vice president, said that the use of flat price quotations would be welcomed all the way around by everyone from manufacturers to home owners.
CHICAGO, March 4 (AP)--Pork prices may continue to set record levels right through April, and if they do the cost of beef will follow the upward spiral.
Paperboard production last week was 12.8 per cent above a year ago, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday. New orders were down 3.2 per cent and unfilled orders up 7.7 per cent.
HOUSTON, March 4 (AP)--Several crew members of the tanker Lyons Creek were hospitalized here today after a terrific explosion tore a hole in the ship and then set it afire.

TEL AVTV, Palestine, March 4-- Twenty-five armored cars carrying u8,000,000 ($32,000,000) in notes and coins reached Tel Aviv banks from Jerusalem today. The banks will reopen tomorrow. Thousands of depositors, in fear that the military commander may close all financial institutions under a blanket order of martial law, are hoarding cash.

PARIS, March 4--The cost of sending newspapers from New York to Paris by air freight has Been reduced from $1.25 a pound to half that sum, subject, however, to a minimum rate of $5 for any such parcel.

The Russian people today, impoverished and weary of fighting, would not go to war unless they are invaded, Richard Lauterbach, former head of the Time-Life bureau in Moscow and author of "Through Russia's Back Door," declared yesterday.

A solution is at hand for one of modern living's vexing problems. Chiefly, the late afternoon institution known as the cocktail party promises to be revolutionized. The martini sipper whose fun is often plagued by failure to remember people's names is on the brink of a new carefree era.

ABOARD MOUNT OLYMPUS, March 3 (Delayed)--After almost two weeks of frustration the eastern wing of the Navy's Antarctic expedition abandoned yesterday its attempt to reach the southern coast of the Weddell Sea, assuming that there is such a coast, and headed toward home.
LONDON, March 5--Some of Great Britain's top economic planners are attacking the Labor Government's plan for 1947.

SALONIKA, Greece, March 5 (AP)--The United Nations Investigating Commission decided tonight to ask Yugoslavia to suspend the execution of five men until it could be determined whether the prisoners had information relevant to the commission's Balkan inquiry.

The great majority of the seventy management witnesses who have appeared before the House Labor Committee urging restrictive labor legislation are employers who have been cited by the National Labor Relations Board and the courts for unfair labor practises, Representative Arthur Klein of New York charged last night.

WARSAW, March 5--Poland and Czechoslovakia have agreed on the long-awaited friendship and mutual assistance treaty, which they will sign in Warsaw Sunday, the day before the opening of the Moscow conference, the Polish Foreign Office announced today.

CHANGCHUN, Manchuria, China, March 4 (Delayed)--The climax of the Communist offensive against Changchun, capital of Manchuria, has now been reached. Government forces are pushing the Communists back to the line of the upper Sungari River, whence their offensive started on Feb. 21, Lieut. Gen. Tu Yu-ming, commander-inchief of Government forces in Manchuria, said here today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 5--To avert the danger of a worldwide economic depression, the United Kingdom has asked the United Nations to go to work with all the other intergovernmental agencies concerned to hasten international measures for full employment, it was learned today.

All Hallows Institute captured its first Catholic High School basketball championship last night when it defeated La Salle Academy, defending titleholder, 42 to 32, at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory before 4,000 spectators. In the consolation game for third place, St. John's Prep turned back St. Augustine's, 40 to 38.

SAN JUAN TEOTIHUACAN, Mexico, March 5--President Truman, after being guided around the famous archaeological site here by one of Mexico's leading experts, expressed the opinion that the ancient Indian god Quetzalcoatl was sort of a combination of Plato, Aristotle and Socrates.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned strong in the late trading yesterday after the one-day strike of employes of the Exchange and closed 37 to 70 points higher led by the strength in the March, 1947, position.
Evans, Moore Woodbridge, architects, filed plans yesterday for the Police Department for a new three-story police station house at 411-19 West 204th Street. They estimated the cost at $168,000.

MOSCOW, March 5 -- Concern over the United States-British military "alliance" continues to be expressed here, reflecting the Soviet attitude toward the policies of two of the countries whose Foreign Ministers will meet here next Monday to settle, or attempt to settle, the German problem.

Fashions in a springlike mood for both Northern and Southern wear were presented by the Tailored Woman yesterday at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel. Including ready-made models as well as others from the custom-made department, the show opened on a southbound note with a handsome cutaway suit of white tweed topped with a full-length loose boxcoat of navy tweed lined with the white of the suit.
LANCASTER, Pa., March 5 (AP) --The Armstrong Cork Company reported today to stockholders net profits of $4,184,075 on record peace-time domestic sales of $104,717,423 in 1946.
LONDON, March 5 -- Blinding snow storms, driven before icy winds last night and today, disrupted Britain's transportation system.

Issues of public utility common stock priced at $6,717,000, representing new financing for two Midwestern operating companies, will be offered to investors by underwriting managers today as follows: Oklahoma Gas and Electric Company--140,000 shares at $39.50 a share, by The First Boston Corporation.

ALBANY, March 5--Controversy over the proposal to scrap the organized child care program in the State after Oct. 1, a plan endorsed by Governor Dewey, grew in intensity today with submission of legislation implementing the proposal.

One of the best rallies in a month was made yesterday by the stock market to the accompaniment of an increase in volume. Gains of 1 to 2 points appeared in many key units, with the best performance during the final hour. The industrial and packing issues led the recovery, which pushed the composite rate forward about a point.

A syndicate of investors represented by Joshuah Sidney Shultz, attorney, bought the nine-story apartment house for thirty-eight families at 46 West Ninety-fifth Street from Walson, Inc., through Joseph H. Nassoit, Inc., and Harold M. Silverman, brokers.

The establishment of a special United Nations District, which would embrace a huge 130-block area and provide "dignified and harmonious" surroundings for the projected world capital along the East River, was strongly urged upon the City Planning Commission yesterday by civic and architectural organizations.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 5 --Republic Pictures and Charles K. Feldman, motion-picture agent and producer, have concluded a deal whereby Feldman's organization, Group Productions, will produce two films on a profit-sharing basis in conjunction with Republic, the studio announced today.

The dispatch of Lazar M. Kaganovitch, Stalin's brother-in-law and right-hand man, to the "independent" Ukraine to "strengthen the party and Soviet work" is an unmistakable demonstration that Russia is also having post-war troubles. As first Secretary of the Central Committee of the Communist party in the Ukraine, Mr. Kaganovitch will be the real boss of the country.

CHICAGO, March 5 (AP)--The New York Rangers broke their tie with Detroit and took fourth place undisputed in the National Hockey League tonight by defeating the Chicago Black Hawks, 3 to 1, before 16,033 fans at the Stadium. It was the Rangers' first victory in six games.
Independent unions representing all major classes of telephone workers in the metropolitan area put themselves in position yesterday to join a nation-wide telephone Strike threatened for April 7.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In a letter in your columns, Herbert H. Finch states that our Secretary of State has two virtually unrelated functions: as the chief officer of the Cabinet, and as our minister of foreign affairs. He suggests that we have "a Cabinet office for each of these functions, a Secretary of State and also a Secretary of Foreign Affairs."

The reconversion to peacetime status of the United Fruit Company's Antigua is rapidly nearing completion at the Todd Shipyards Corporation's Brooklyn Division and the ship should be ready for sea in the next week or ten days, Todd officials said yesterday.

The case of Gerhart Eisler, reputed Communist leader in the United States, who is under arrest here as an enemy alien, took a new turn yesterday at a hearing involving Leon Josephson, former Trenton lawyer and admitted Communist, who was described by Representative Richard Nixon, Republican of California, as a person who "is just as important as Eisler."

SYDNEY, Australia, March 5 (Reuters)--Captain Don Bradman batted for two hours today and set Australia on the path to a five-wicket victory over England in the fifth and final test cricket match. Requiring 214 runs on a sporting wicket, Australia accomplished the task with six minutes left tonight and a spare day tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- A major crime was committed in the United States on the average of once every 18.7 seconds last year. J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today.
WASHINGTON, March 5--The National Association, of Manufacturers criticized the National Labor Relations Board today for "amending" the Wagner Act "without awaiting action toy Congress."
