The New York Academy of Medicine begins this week ceremonies which mark the hundredth anniversary of its foundation and which are to continue until April in a series of scientific meetings to be attended by some of the most eminent medical authorities in the world.

ABOARD MOUNT OLYMPUS, March 5--After making fifty-nine successful mapping flights into unknown regions, all elements of the largest Antarctic expedition in history are either northbound or already in port today.

Nomination of Graham F. Towers, Governor of the Bank of Canada, as Canadian executive director of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, is under active consideration, it was learned yesterday. Under the arrangement now being studied, Mr. Towers would take a leave of absence from his present post in order to serve the World Bank on a full-time, though temporary, basis.

JACKSON, Miss., March 5 --A bill proposing repeal of the controversial "black-market" tax under which a 10 per cent levy is made on alcoholic drinks in legally dry Mississippi was approved by a vote of 31 to 15 in the State Senate today.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 5-- Peter A. Leavens, described by the police as an amateur astronomer with starry-eyed financial views, was arrested today on a charge of grand larceny in connection with an automobile sales deal.

The quarter was in the other hand yesterday when Renee Carroll celebrated her twentieth anniversary as hat-check girl at Sardi's Restaurant, 234 West Forty-fourth Street. "I decided this was my day to tip the customers," she said. And tip them she did.

ALBANY, March 5 -- Governor Dewey's committee on education agreed today to consider several amendments to its pending teacherpay bill that will safeguard the rights of administrative employes, principals, superintendents, examiners and other noninstructional employes of the New York City school system.
LONDON, March 5--The British Government was asked in the House of Commons today for assurances that British troops would not be kept in Greece "in exchange for United States money."

Vigorously opposing a trend among airlines to increase passenger fares from the present general 4.5 cents a mile, Capt. E.V. Rickenbacker, president of Eastern Air Lines, last night asserted his company was asking the Civil Aeronautics Board for permission to grant a 10 per cent round-trip reduction.

ALBANY, March 5 -- Following is the text of Governor Dewey's special message to the Legislature urging the enlargement of local taxing powers: To the Legislature: In my annual message this year I called attention to the need for conferring added taxing powers upon the municipalities of the state.

LEIPZIG, Germany, March 5-- As far as can be determined from official and unofficial sources, the average German living in the Soviet-occupied zone is better off than those in the Western zones. Most persons here do not realize this.

Frozen food men are now making plans to clean up unfavorable conditions that developed in this relatively new industry during the war boom period, spokesmen for the Eastern Frosted Food Association stated yesterday. "Quality control," is the biggest problem the prozen food business must face, they said, and leaders in the industry are now planning to do something about it.

A good idea of what florists' windows will look like around Easter was offered yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania, where the Metropolitan Retail Florists Association, Inc., held its Spring exhibit and demonstrations.

Secretary of the Interior Krug returned to Washington yesterday from the Pacific, urging speedy statehood for Hawaii. Speaking before the Territorial Legislature in Honolulu, he posed the only two basic questions that need answering in deciding whether the Hawaiian Islands should be admitted as an equal partner in the United States.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., March 5-- Women should possess jobs or some other constructive activity outside the home if they want to make doubly certain that their marriages will be successful, pupils at Sarah Lawrence College here were told today at the last session of a course on marriage and parenthood.

WASHINGTON, March 5--The Administration's program for a $350,000,000 post-war relief fund to be distributed under the State Department was in danger tonight, in some of its principal features, before the House Foreign Affairs Committee.

WASHINGTON, March 5--Dr. Dennis A. FitzGerald, secretarygeneral of the International Emergency Food Council, advocated today that relief repayments go into a revolving fund to meet future famines. Dr. FitzGerald has accompanied former President Herbert Hoover on all his food surveys after World War II.

Resolutions embodying an eightpoint program of trade and consumer relations were adopted yesterday at the concluding session of the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers in the Hotel New Yorker. The resolutions called for:

Paul Hindemith, German-born composer, has been elected to full membership in the National Institute of Arts and Letters, it was announced yesterday by Douglas Moore, president. Mr. Hindemith, who had been an honorary associate of the institute since 1943, was entitled to full membership as a result of becoming an American citizen.

WITH the major league teams already in brisk training for the coming campaign, it might seem a bit incongruous to be distracted by the doings of a minor leaguer-- except that he'll always be a major leaguer in our book. We are referring to the new manager of Sacramento in the Pacific Coast League, Dick Bartell.

LONDON, March 5--India's minorities will have to look out for themselves after June, 1948, Sir Stafford Cripps told the House of Commons today. Britain's administrative grip on India, he said, has become so weakened that a British Administration could not maintain effective control after next year.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 5--City Attorney Paul W. Ewing was under subpoena today to appear as a witness on Friday when the grand jury resumes an inquiry into professional gambling here.
Monroe, La., announced yesterday that it would receive bids on April 8 on an issue of $2,158,000 water and sewer bonds dated May 1, 1947, and due on each May 1 from 1949 to 1972.

ALBANY, March 5--Following is the text of the amendment proposed to the Condon-Wadlin bill today to meet the wishes of Governor Dewey: The Civil Service Law is hereby amended by inserting therein a new section to follow Section 22 to be Section 22-A, to read as follows:

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Had it been 1937 instead of 1947 when Messrs. Green, Murray and Reuther were appearing before the Senate Committee on Labor and Public Welfare, they would have taken quite a different position on the desirability of labor legislation.
WASHINGTON, March 5--In a note received today, the British Government promised to cooperate with the United States if we should decide to assume primary responsibility in Greece.
WASHINGTON, March 5--A break in retail prices is not expected in time to moderate the climate of wage negotiations this spring. In fact, further price rises on the average may be expected.

Efforts to "hold-the-line" and prevent a "secod round" of increases of retail prices may be wrecked by current upward spirals in materials prices, industrial purchasing agents disclosed here yesterday. New peaks in prices in copper, silver, pig iron, scrap, lead, hogs, beef, wheat and other materials and supplies may bring serious repercussions through forcing repricing of manufactured products on a new high level in both the wholesale and retail trade, they said.

Pointing out that she is looking forward to the Olympic Games in 1948, Miss Barbara Ann Scott, 18year-old Canadian star, who won the women's amateur world and European figure-skating championships in Stockholm and Davos, Switzerland, arrived here yesterday aboard the liner Queen Elizabeth.
LONDON, March 5--The Soviet Union was strongly attacked in the House of Lords today on the ground that it had violated international obligations.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The public has long been aware of the growing problems of juvenile delinquency and adolescent crime. In spite of the community's efforts the incidence of these offenses has not decreased.
As trading on the New York Cotton Exchange returned to normal after a one-day strike, new trouble clouds gathered yesterday on the Wall Street labor scene.

CHICAGO, March 5--The copper -using industry, faced by a 50 per cent shortage of copper, will have to curtail manufacturing operations drastically within a short time unless the present importexcise-tax on copper is removed or suspended soon, Frank C. Jones, president of the Okonite Co., warned today.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP)-- The United States is protesting to the Netherlands Government against export regulations in the Netherlands Indies that led to the seizure of the merchant ship Martin Behrman last Sunday.

WASHINGTON, March 5--Maj. Gen. Henry S. Aurand, director of research and development in the War Department, expressed his approval today of the manner in which the proposed Army-Navy unification bill sets up a scientific research and development board directly under civilian instead of military control.

Defense lawyers subjected Alvin J. Paris, would-be football "fixer" turned State witness, to almost six hours of continuous questioning in General Sessions yesterday attempting to knock down his story implicating three defendants as the instigators of the bribe offers.

NEW DELHI, India, March 5--Declaration of "Governor's Rule" in strife-torn Punjab Province followed an exchange of views today between the Provincial Governor, Sir Evan Jenkins, and the Viceroy, Viscount Wavell, whose approval is necessary for the suspension of popular government.

Chile's Unfinished Business Chile's dollar bonds flurried upward in New York Stock Exchange dealings yesterday within fortyeight hours of the speculative movement in Peruvian obligations on news of a new debt service resumption plan proposed by Lima.

BOSTON, March 5 (AP)--The Boston Bruins scored all except one of their tallies against shorthanded opposition while tightening their grip on the National Hockey League's third play-off berth with a 5-4 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight before a capacity crowd of 13,900 at the Boston Garden.

Charles R. Denny, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, told several thousand radio scientists here last night that while their work in the past has been productive of "technological black magic," for which they have won the world's admiration, some of the biggest tasks still lie ahead.

Civic, business and real estate organizations voiced strong protest yesterday against increased real estate taxes and "excessive" assessed valuations. Representatives of twenty-five groups, meeting at the request of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, adopted a motion from the floor supporting a legislative request that the city's finances be investigated.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 5--Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet representative on the United Nations Security Council, charged today that the United States plan for international atomic control was directed against the independence of other nations.
ALBANY, March 5--A proposed amendment to the State Constitution to permit members of the Legislature to fix their own pay by law was approved in the Senate today, 50 to 2. The present pay is $2,500.

After seven months of effort by Mayor O'Dwyer to bring about a reorganization of Tammany, the executive committee of that political body yesterday took the same number of minutes to elect Frank J. Sampson leader to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Edward V. Laughlin and clear the way for a complete reorganization.

A working woman living with her family in New York State needs $1,796.35 a year, or $34.55 a week, to support herself properly, according to the latest and tenth annual survey by the State Labor Department. This sum, figured as of last fall, is 7 per cent higher than a year before, and the cost of living has gone up still further in the six months since the survey was made.

Herman T. Stichman, State Housing Commissioner, looked back yesterday on the first year of the State's emergency housing program and found it good. At Manhattan Beach Homes, in Brooklyn, families who moved in a year ago to the first big housing project for veterans agreed with the commissioner.

WASHINGTON, March 5--The Senate's test today on a proposal to set June 30 as a deadline for winding up the Office of Price Administration came on rejection of amendment by Senator Glen H. Taylor, Democrat, of Idaho to strike a provision of that nature from an appropriation bill.
LONDON, March 5--Mixed conditions were seen today in the stock markets, where transport difficulties due to the blizzard delayed brokers and jobbers.
When it comes to conservation legislation almost anything can happen, and according to a few disconsolate falconers "it usually does."

The simple and spontaneous expression of a warm heart often does more to seal friendship between nations than all the calculated approaches of diplomacy. History abounds in examples. President Truman, placing a wreath on the tomb of "Los Ninos," the boy heroes who fought our troops to the death at Chapultepec, has just added another.

Arthur Bliss Lane, United States Ambassador to Poland, who returned to this country yesterday, disclosed that despite his insistent efforts to confer with an estimated 100 Americans held in Polish prisons, he had been allowed to talk with only one of them.

The First Methodist Chuch property at the southwest corner of Clark and Henry Streets, Brooklyn, has been sold by the New York East Conference of the Methodist Church to the Milrene Realty Corporation. The new owner plans to tear down the building, which was erected in 1889, and to build a one-story taxpayer.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 5--In one of the most sharply controversial sessions of the educational convention here, Dr. John L. Childs of Teachers College, Columbia University, attacked today the Catholic position on Federal aid to education, and by implication accused the Catholic Church of weakening the nation's public school system.

ALBANY, March 5 -- Majority members of the Joint Legislative Committee on Rents explained today in detail why they rejected the Democratic proposal to make state rent controls with ceilings pegged at current levels operative in the event that Federal regulaion was relaxed.

The course of recent events has added to the Legislative calendar at Albany one issue on which there is no escaping a decision. It is, simply stated, the question whether the public employe has a right to strike. The surrounding, eloquent circumstances are such that if the Legislature fails to act the instant assumption drawn from that silence will be that it condones such strikes.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 5 (AP)--A. thorough diagnosis of glaucoma is possible for the first time with a tiny instrument, smaller than the eye itself, the Bausch Lomb Optical Company said today.

The Harvard-Yale regatta, oldest of all intercollegiate sports rivalries, is to be resumed over the four-mile course on the Thames River, New London, Conn., on June 18, according to a joint announcement made yesterday by the Harvard and Yale athletic directors.

ALBANY, March 5--On a party vote, the Republican dominated Ways and Means Committee of the Assembly today killed the bill that would have authorized the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority to build a $20,000,000 new sports arena and exposition hall at Columbus Circle for lease to the Madison Square Garden Corporation.

PRINCETON, N.J. March 5-- Looking to the future, seventy leading architects of this country and a small group from abroad opened today a two-day conference on the topic "planning man's physical environment." The conference is being held under the auspices of Princeton University as part of its bicentennial observance.

WASHINGTON, March 5--The Congress of Industrial Organizations accused the National Association of Manufacturers today of "weeping crocodile tears" in its concern for the reputation of the Treasury Department.

The United States Government has paid at least $25,000,000 more for oil products in the Near East than was necessary, James A. Moffett, a retired executive of oil companies and former Federal Housing Administrator, charged yesterday in a statement.

JERUSALEM, March 5--Fusillades of machine-gun fire and rifle fire rattled around Jerusalem tonight after hand grenades had been thrown at a British military police vehicle on the perimeter of the martial law area in the northern part of the city.

It would be hard to trace a Consistent trend in the original wallpaper designs by twenty-three artists that went on display yesterday yesterday in the gallery of America House, 485 Madison Avenue. Lush flowers, chaste geometrics, street scenes and storybook fantasies, all presumably belong on the wall, to judge from these latest offerings from design studios.

Governor Dewey's suggested program of new taxes by which New York City could raise $24,300,000 drew vigorous protests yesterday from spokesmen for the interests involved--legitimate and motion picture theatres, restaurants, liquor dealers and bars, and automobile and truck users.

MEXICO CITY, March 5--President Truman stood among the broken ruins of a lost Toltec civilization today and warned that organized society in North America might share the same fate unless lasting world peace could be brought about.
President Truman has under consideration a plan to determine the nation's future merchant marine needs, it became known yesterday.
The Red Cross 1947 Fund of Greater New York has received $421,600 of the $6,153,000 sought this month, it was announced yesterday.

Radio distributors and retailers are bringing pressure to bear on manufacturers of standard brands to reduce list prices on table radiophonograph combinations in the $120-$125 category, it was learned yesterday. A spokesman for one of the nation's largest electrical appliance distributing organizations disclosed that representations have been made to producers who have agreed to study the matter.
MOSCOW, March 5--After more than three years of labor, the hydroelectric plant of the great Dnieprostroi dam across the Dnieper River went into partial operation on Monday.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 5--The suspicion that Jack Lohrke will make a stern battle for the thirdbase position on the Giants was strengthened today in the second intra-club game as the Rookies trounced the Regulars, 5 to 2.
A kaleidoscope of fashion swirled through the Salon Moderne at Saks Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon. It moved with unceasing rhythm, often with brilliant coloring.

CHICAGO, March 5 -- Grain markets staged a strong upturn on the Board of Trade today under the leadership of oats. The March delivery of that grain soared 6 cents a bushel, the permissible daily limit for oats, and closed at the top.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 5--Wiping out a 3-run deficit with a 5-run explosion in the ninth inning, the Dodgers defeated the Yankees tonight, 8 to 7, to tie their three-game Venezuelan Cup series at one victory apiece.

The pork market has had more ups than downs lately, and yesterday, to add to the price confusion, a livestock expert was reported as saying that prices may continue to set record levels right through April. The high cost goes back, of course, to smaller supplies, which already are being reflected at retail to some extent.

WASHINGTON, March 5-- Cleaving away from Senator Robert A. Taft, the other Republican Presidential aspirant front Ohio, Senator John W. Bricker, declared today that neither communism nor New Dealism had any bearing on the fitness of David E. Lilienthal, chairman-designate of the United States Atomic Energy Commission.

Harry Donovan, a freshman sensation last season, returns with Muhlenberg to Madison Square Garden tonight, when the Allentown Mules engage Long Island University in the feature game of the college basketball doubleheader at the Eighth Avenue Arena.

A former chief of a United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration mission to the Ukraine admitted yesterday the failure of his efforts to delay publication of a book about Russia by a former member of the mission. However, as his final shot in a two-month dispute, he asserted that he questioned the propriety of the publication at this time and also the adequacy of the textual changes that had been made at his suggestion.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 5 --Buzfuz, finishing past the center of the track after a wide entrance into the stretch, equaled the track record for six furlongs in the $10,000 added Inaugural Handicap today at Gulfstream Park, as pleasant an establishment as any horse player could ask, opened its fortyday meeting in Chamber of Commerce weather.
PARIS, March 5--The French Cabinet today approved the appointment of Emile Bollaert to succeed Vice Admiral Georges Thierry d'Argenlieu as High Commissioner for Indo-China.

A survey of retailers to determine their interest in television as in advertising medium will be conducted by the National Retail Dry Goods Association, it was announced yesterday by Howard P. Abrahams, manager of the sales promotion division of the association.

SECURITY COUNCIL Andrei A. Gromyko, Russian delegate, assailed American atomic plan as infringement on economic interests and even independence of other nations and charged it was intended to give United States monopoly on atomic developments.

LONDON, March 5--British representatives of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, the operating agency for the World Zionist Organization, leave here tomorrow for a Palestine meeting where they will help to map a technique for lobbying on a global scale.

WASHINGTON, March 5--Fleet Admiral William F. Halsey Jr., wartime commander of the famous Third Fleet whose ships and planes operated with impunity off Japan's shoreline, was retired from naval service March 1 because of physical disability, the Navy Department announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) --Speedy statehood for Hawaii and creation of civil rule for other Pacific islands were urged today by Julius A. Krug, Secretary of the Interior, on his return from a 24,000-mile tour of the Pacific.

A display of paintings by merchant seamen has opened at the Seamen's Church Institute, 25 South Street, in the Janet Roper Room, and will continue through March. Three prizes of $25, $15 and $10 will be awarded by popular vote of visitors to the exhibition.

Mounting prices and a continued shortage of the material have placed the iron and steer scrap market on the verge of chaos, according to reports from Pittsburgh, Cleveland and Chicago, the principal scrap-consuming centers of the nation.
WASHINGTON, March 5--The Senate, while granting the Office of Price Administration a limited lease on life, voted, 58 to 29, today to direct the agency to go out of business by June 30.

A warning that any "precipitate action" by teachers' groups in New York City might wreck negotiations now going on in Albany between the Teachers Salary Conference and State legislative officials was voiced last night by a delegate of the conference.

WASHINGTON, March 5--Secretary of State Marshall left today for the meeting of Foreign Ministers in Moscow, expressing hope for conclusion of a peace treaty for Austria but some doubts about the prospects of concluding at this time a treaty for Germany.
ALBANY, March 5--The Condon-Wadlin bill to outlaw strikes by public employes was amended drastically today to provide that any such employe participating in a strike shall be automatically dismissed.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP)-- Van A. Bittner, organizing director for the Congress of Industrial Organizations, told House Labor Committee members today they were not equipped to write fair labor laws and "it would be a wonderful thing for the United States if Congress met only every ten years."

Small manufacturing plants are now being established to provide jobs for displaced Jews in the American zone of Germany, it was reported here yesterday by Dr. Joseph J. Schwartz, European chairman of the Joint Distribution Committee.

Variety chains will show a smaller drop in dollar volume or units than almost any other mass distributor in the event of economic storms ahead and in the future "will be leaders in the field of distribution," Joseph Reiss, president of Reiss Advertising, said yesterday.

A further increase last week of 1,899,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the close of the week, total stocks were 105,803,000 barrels, compared with 103,904,000 a week earlier and 104,773,000 on March 2, 1946.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 5-- Wage increases of 6 per cent were awarded to about 12,000 members of three maritime unions in a decision handed down yesterday by Paul Kleinsorge, West Coast arbitrator.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 5-- Princeton Chapter No. 1 of the Save Capitalism Committee, the latest of campus movements to originate at Princeton University, is beginning a drive to form student chapters across the country.
WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP)-- President Truman is preparing a recommendation to Congress to keep disloyal persons out of Government jobs, Lawrence Malloy, Civil Service counsel, said today.

ALBANY, March 5--Governor Dewey recommended today that power be given to the State's cities and counties to raise an additional $111,000,000 a year through new special local taxes. Part of the extra revenue would be earmarked for educational purposes and the balance would be available to meet expanding costs of local government.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The House Ways and Means Committee gave its attention today to a critical shortage of copper which threatens to tie up a number of important industries. It was indicated after a day-long closed hearing that a bill to relieve the situation by a moratorium on the $80-perton import tax would be approved tomorrow.
PARIS, March 5--During the National Assembly's debate on the reconstruction budget today Premier Paul Ramadier promised that the ordinary budget would be balanced "or I shall not be Premier.
Spectators at the national indoor championships were surfeited with tennis yesterday as John Kramer, the outdoor titleholder, led the field into the semi-finals at the Seventh Regiment Armory.

NANKING, March 5--The Control Yuan, watchdog of the Chinese Treasury, issued an explosive report today denouncing the Central Bank's former open-market gold sale policy. The report declared that a probe of last month's Shanghai financial panic indicated that a number of civilian officials and Army officers had used public funds to engage in "gold profiteering."

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A recent editorial entitled "The Pay of Librarians" was very gratifying to those of us who are members of the library profession. The support of your newspaper in the fight to secure adequate salaries for public librarians is deeply appreciated.

The United Corporation, in its annual report issued yesterday, disclosed that during 1946 it received $17,137,110 from the sale of securities of various utility companies. In addition, it sold $13,000,000 of Government securities.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 5-- Columbia University's basketball team encountered little difficulty against Princeton tonight and the 50-41 decision the Lions fashioned over the Tiger quintet at the Hobey Baker Memorial rink clinched the Eastern Intercollegiate League championship for Gordon Ridings' athletes.

The Tournament of Champions boxing competition, sponsored annually by the News Welfare Association and sanctioned by the Metropolitan A.A.U., held the spotlight at Madison Square Garden last night. A capacity crowd of 18,719 fans saw the survivors of various sectional tournaments from Massachusetts to Puerto Rico battle for titles.

The help in the Hotel Seymour in Forty-fifth Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues seemed excited yesterday because their favorite tenant had broken into print. A Pennsylvania law suit had disturbed her long privacy.

Fields for the two major postseason basketball tournaments began to shape up yesterday as Wyoming accepted a bid to represent District 7 in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Western regional championship, while Utah was getting ready to enter the New York national invitation tournament.
WASHINGTON, March 5--Representatives of religious and labor publications, among the smaller users of newsprint, urged today a sharing of short supplies of paper to bring about equitable distribution.
Gerald I. Carlson, formerly chief project engineer of the Stratos Corporation, has been advanced to director of engineering.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP)-- Counsel for nine Northern States estimated before the Supreme Court today that an Interstate Commerce Commission order making regional revisions in rail-freight rates on manufactured goods would cost his part of the country $15,000,000 or more yearly.

James Sykes, pianist, who has appeared several times as a recitalist in this city, presented a program at Times Hall last night consisting of eighteenth-century classics and works of contemporary origin. Featured on the list was the new Sonata by Elliott Carter, which received its first public performance.

ABOARD THE PORT OF BEAUMONT, at Sea, March 4 (Delayed)--The Ronne Antarctic Research Expedition is moving steadily toward the Antarctic Circle so that we will arrive in the polar region of Palmer Land Peninsula before it freezes over and we can make preparations for our fourteen months' stay there.

The big Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth arrived in port yesterday flying for the first time in her commercial career the famous "Blue Ensign" indicative of her status in the Royal Naval Reserve. The ensign means that a majority of her officers are members of the reserve.

LIMA, Peru, March 4 (Delayed) --The 1946 Congress has now adjourned after holding sessions for seven months and it is not expected that a further extraordinary session will be called. The ordinary session of the 1947 Congress opens on July 28, which is the republic's national day.

ANTHOLOGIES form one possible protection against the atomic bomb that should not be overlooked. When the big firecrackers begin to drop there will probably be enough anthologies around to cover most of our vital installations. In depth--not to say density. One of the latest of these ventures in literary collectivism is "Our Fair City,"* edited by Col. Robert S. All

Small Scrap Collectors Active Current high prices for scrap are making it profitable for small collectors to resume business, industry members disclosed here yesterday. They said that increasing supplies are coming into scrap yards and that the increased flow ought to be reflected in better supplies for foundries and steel mills within thirty days.

ABOARD ROYAL TRAIN, South Africa, March 5--Great dignity mutually acknowledged characterized the meeting today between King George VI of Britain and representatives of the 1,500,000 members of the Transkei native reserve.
Sixty pickets, including two union officials, were arrested last night for a mass demonstration in front of the Central Branch of the Y.W.C.A. at 30 Third Avenue, Brooklyn.

Nature's Top Energy When in the nearer course of human events David E. Lilienthal has been confirmed as chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission he can sit back in his chair and catch his breath and look back on his life and consider how it has been his lot to be brought into contact with the problem of power in various forms.

SAN JUAN TEOTIHUACAN, Mexico, March 5 -- Standing beneath a billowing blue and white tent in the heart of Mexico's most famous archeological preserve, President Truman revealed today that he and President Miguel Aleman, finally had got around to talking business yesterday afternoon.

The metropolitan open championship, abandoned for lack of interest since 1940, will be resumed this year, according to an announcement yesterday by Theodore G. Law, chairman of the tournament committee of the Metropolitan Golf Association.

Martha Graham and her dance company last night returned to the Ziegfeld Theatre to open a supplementary season of four performances, having earned for themselves considerable glory in their sessions at the same theatre last week.

BERLIN, March 6--A thorough weeding out of Nazis holding responsible positions in United States Military Government headquarters has been ordered by Lieut. Gen. Lucius D. Clay, Deputy Military governor. General Clay acted promptly after he had been informed that more than 300 known Nazis were on the payroll in positions ranging from charwoman to secretary, interpreter and wireless operator.

PHILADELPHIA, March 6 -- Five companies filed registration statements today with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering $8,000,000 of bonds, $1,025,000 of debentures, 70,000 shares of preferred stock and 180,000 shares of common stock.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 6--The Arab League began a determined fight today to turn United Nations efforts on building up the underdeveloped countries of the Middle East and warned that they now represented a threat to world peace.

Early last December in Indo-China, when the question whether there would be peace or civil war between the French and the Viet Namese was in such delicate balance that any whisper could sway the scales, Americans were told: "If the Admiral returns, blood will flow."

The executive branch of government has been made the subject of two books. Recently published by Macmillan was James E. Pollard's "The Presidents and the Press." Coming from Knopf on March 20 will be Wilfred B. Binkley's "President and Congress," a historical analysis of the conflict between the executive and legislative branches.

By helping in the reconstruction of Europe and providing relief for war victims, Americans are working to safeguard their own peace, freedom and standard of living, Dr. Howard E. Kershner, acting vice president of the Save the Children Federation, declared yesterday.

Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag denied yesterday a motion for a temporary injunction to the fifteen East Harlem clubs seeking to restrain the police from enforcing a 10 o'clock curfew and ruled that a trial would be necessary to determine the questions involved.

PHILADELPHIA, March 6--The Consolidated Natural Gas Company filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a declaration relative to the solicitation of proxies in connection with its proposal to increase its authorized $15 par value capital stock from 2,728,359 to 3,274,031 shares.

WASHINGTON, March 6--Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on March 1, were 850,031 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 73,342 cars or 9.4 per cent more than for the preceding week, 67,634 cars or 8.6 per cent more than for the corresponding week of last year and 64,295 cars or 8.2 per cent more than during fhe corresponding week of two years ago.
ATLANTA, March 6--The authority of the courts to intervene in the General Assembly's election of Herman Talmadge as Governor was challenged today in a hearing before the Georgia Supreme Court.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: At this time, when representatives of the Allied Governments in Berlin have resolved upon the abolition of the Prussian state, it is not without interest to recall that this step was envisaged and ardently desired by Hitler. In January, 1934, continuing the policy of Bismarck, Hitler sought to abolish state sovereignty in order to accomplish the unification of the Reich.

WASHINGTON, March 6--Paul M. Herzog, chairman of the National Labor Relations Board, warned Congress today that any change in the policy of encouraging collective bargaining would have "most unhappy consequences."

PARIS, March 6--Fernand de Brinon was convicted tonight not only as a collaborationist but also as the author of the idea of collaboration, and was sentenced to death and national unworthiness. His property was confiscated.

Thomas I. Parkinson, president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, yesterday urged an immediate Congressional investigation of the Federal Reserve System, charging that its fiscal policies has contributed to inflation and continuing wage-price spirals.

PARIS, March 6--The nationalized banks are required to lend money to such nationalized enterprises as coal mines and gas and electricity companies without knowing whether they are earning or losing money, it was learned today.

John Kramer and Miss Pauline Betz, champions of the United States on turf, gained their final Brackets yesterday in the national indoor tennis tournament at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

The upward trend of cotton futures prices continued yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange and final prices were 24 to 36 points net higher than on Wednesday. The market opened unchanged to 14 points up. March led the advance.

WASHINGTON, March 6--The Supreme Court by 7 to 2 upheld today the contempt conviction of John L. Lewis and the United Mine Workers, sustained the $10,000 fine against Mr. Lewis and ordered the $3,500,000 fine levied against the union cut down to $700,000.

A piecemeal study of post-war military problems has led the country down a blind alley. Today the United States is entering a profoundly critical period in history without the benefit of any over-all military policy to guide the development of our armed forces.

TEL AVIV, Palestnie, March 6 --Dr. Chaim Weizmann, former Zionist president, announced here today at a civic-leaders' meeting that he had temporarily given up all his chemistry research and placed himself at the disposal of people in the coastal martial-law area.

WASHINGTON, March 6--The ninety-nine Americans whom Ambassador Arthur Bliss Lane could not visit in Polish prisons are not United States citizens under Polish law, according to a statement issued by the Polish Embassy here today.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, March 6--The post-war Czechoslovak cities are one place where Marie Antoinette's "let them eat cake" suggestion might work.

WASHINGTON, March 6--Here in brief is the day-byday story of the soft-coal strike and the Government's moves to end it: Oct. 31--John L. Lewis demands reopening of contract with Government on miners' wages and hours; declares it void Nov. 1 unless negotiations start by then. Oct. 24--Interior Secretary Julius A. Krug replies that the May, 1946, contract Mr. Lewis signed is valid for full period of Federal mine operation.
Serge M. Rubinstein, 38-year-old international financier, told his draft board in June, 1941, that his average weekly salary during 1940 as an "employe" of several corporations was $115 a week.

ALBANY, March 6 (AP)--Governor Dewey's proposed program, empowering localities to levy new taxes aroused unfavorable reaction today, but many municipal and county officials deferred comment pending further study.

DETROIT, March 6--The United Automobile Workers of the Congress of Industrial Organizations served notice today that it would level its full 1947 wage demands, as drafted in New York in December, upon the General Motors Corporation within a day or so of the earliest possible date, March 19.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, March 6 --The Hungarian public received first news of the United States note to Russia through a foreign broadcast tonight. There is no indication yet of the reaction of the Russian representative here to the United States demand that the Allied Control Commission investigate the Russian arrest of Mr. Kovacs.

Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday that the board of governors had decided to close the Exchange on Saturdays commencing on May 31 and continuing through June, July, August and September.

LEIPZIG, Germany, March 6-- Dr. Erich Zeigner, Lord Mayor of Leipzig, said today he foresaw for Germany a government along the lines of that of Great Britain or the United States, rather than that of the Soviet Union. Dr. Zeigner is one of the leaders of the Sovietsponsored Socialist Unity party.

JERUSALEM, March 6--Twentyfive known terrorists have been captured in Palestine in recent days, it was officially announced today in the first report of progress against underground forces since limited martial law.

An aggregate of $2,850,000 of common and preferred stock of industrial companies will be offered to investors by underwriting managers today as follows: Universal Winding Company-- 100,000 shares of 90 cents dividend, $15 par value convertible preferred stock at $16.50 a share, by Reynolds Co., G.H. Walker Co., and Harris, Hall Co., Inc.

Three "hundred men and women picketed the Central branch of the Y.W.C.A., 30 Third Avenue, Brooklyn, for an hour last night after a conference earlier in the day between union attorneys and police officials.

Although Great Britain's prospects seem dreary, it would be a great mistake to count the British out, Herbert L. Matthews, chief London correspondent for THE NEW YORK TIMES, said last night in a radio broadcast over Station WQXR.
TOKYO, Friday, March 7--Japan's Socialist party refused yesterday to enter the April elections on a "joint struggle basis" with the Communists.

De Witt Clinton, upper ManhattanBronx runner-up, defeated Andrew Jackson, South Queens titleholder, 37--26, at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon as the P.S.A.L. city-wide basketball elimination began.

WASHINGTON, March 6--The Democratic minority of the Senate indicated a readiness today to approve almost en bloc material, financial and other aid to Greece, but with two distinct reservations. One was that this aid should not be employed to further British policies in the Mediterranean.

WACO, Tex., March 6--President Truman remained off the stage of Waco Hall where he was to receive an honorary degree of Doctor of Laws until the last minute today while President Pat Neff revised the citation accompanying the award.

CHICAGO, March 6--A broad movement headed by Commission houses developed today in the grain markets on the Board of Trade, induced by prospects of continued large export clearances of grains which might continue until the 1949 European harvest unless this year's return is considerably in excess of expectations.

WASHINGTON, March 6--The current flurry in the capital over economic aid to Greece illustrates the difficulties and weaknesses in our present process of reaching major decisions on United States foreign policy.
LONDON, March. 6--Delays in transportation, due to the weather, resulted in stock markets starting sluggishly again today.

WASHINGTON, March 6--Substantial increases for agricultural commodities and continued advances for industrial goods raised average primary market prices 1.5 per cent during the week ended on March 1, 1947, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, United States Department of Labor.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP)-- Chief Justice Vinson today delivered the following majority opinion of the Supreme Court in the Governments contempt case against John L. Lewis and the United Mine Workers, footnotes to the opinion, giving legal and other references, being omitted:

WASHINGTON, March 6--The Soviet Union has been accused by the State Department of practicing "unjustified interference" in the internal affairs of Hungary. The communication, delivered in Budapest, Moscow and London, was made public today, although its substance had become known earlier.

WASHINGTON, March 6--Congress generally saluted today the Supreme Court's decision in the John L. Lewis case, but leading Republicans in the House moved at once to use the ruling to broaden rather than to narrow the scope of restrictive labor legislation.

ALBANY, March 6 (AP)--Santa Claus "Dewey" took expensive gifts away from Republicans and Democrats alike tonight but promised he would "go to town" in the 1948 Presidential year as the legislative correspondents presented their annual gridiron show.

An hour at the office of the Cultural Adviser to the French Ambassador, 934 Fifth Avenue, should prove profitable and pleasant to lovers and collectors of artistic books. Bibliophiles will linger before the perfect typesetting, equilibrium and harmony of each page encased in the glass-top tables.

PARIS, March 6--Auguste Champetier de Ribes, president of the Council of the French Republic, which replaced the Senate of the Third Republic, died in Paris today after a long illness. His age was 64. M. Champetier de Ribes was one of eighty-eight French Parliamentarians who on July 10, 1940, voted against giving power to Marshal Petain.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 6 --Having nobly executed its assignment as a Navy rehabilitation center for the past four years, Sun Valley, in the heart of the Sawtooth Mountain range of southcentral Idaho, today is back from the war on a record peacetime playtime basis.

NUREMBERG, Germany, March 6--Showing the German people the self-destructive qualities of nazism, its basic inefficiency and its responsibility for Germany's own disaster, is the purpose of the current Nuremberg trials that holds most promise of success, Brig. Gen. Telford Taylor, chief of counsel for war crimes, said today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: My attention has been called to the controversy in your columns during January regarding food and other gift parcels to Great Britain. The argument, as I understand it, arose from a criticism by Jan Struther of an article in The Saturday Evening Post written by Frank Stuart.

Budgetary appropriations already made and those contemplated for the next fiscal year ought to be adequate enough to cover the reasonable requirements of foreign nations in their current crises, W. Randolph Burgess, vice chairman of the National City Bank of New York, asserted yesterday.

PARIS, March 6--The budget's deficit total will be nearer 300,000,000,000 to 325,000,000,000 francs than the officially conceded deficit of 110,000,000,000, Pierre MandesFrance, former Minister of National Economy, told the National Assembly today.

A lively presentation of the decorative values of contemporary sculpture in contrast to Victorian bronzes and plaster Venuses was made last night at the Architectural League in a program on "Sculpture in the Home."

WASHINGTON, March 6--Following are textual excerpts of salient part of the dissenting and concurring opinions in the Supreme Court today on the John L. Lewis case: JUSTICE RUTLEDGE, DISSENTING This case became a cause celebre the moment it began.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt has urged Philip Murray, national president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, to withdraw his objections to participation by antiCommunist CIO leaders in the Americans for Democratic Action, which Mrs. Roosevelt helped organize.

WASHINGTON, March 6--Department store sales in the week ended March 1 were 10 per cent above those in the corresponding week last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1946:
Widespread police laxity and graft in the inspection of taxicabs was charged yesterday by Nathan Frankel, attorney for the CityWide Taxi Workers Union.
Adams-Mills Corporation -- For 1946: Net profit, $1,501,764 or $9.63 a share, compared with $558,487 or $3.58 a share, the year before.

OTTAWA, Ont., March 6--Graham F. Towers, governor of the Bank of Canada, has agreed to serve as executive director for Canada of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, it was officially announced here today by Finance Minister Douglas Abbott.

* * * Handbag Prices Cut 50% To stimulate continued high volume in better handbags, Deitsch Brothers, large manufacturer of reptile handbags, will lower prices about 50 per cent on a new collection of reptile bags, it was announced yesterday.

Neighbors watched interestedly yesterday, and a few grumbled, as the first family moved into a newly rehabilitated building at 220 East Ninety-fifth Street. The Yorkville neighborhood was impressed by the fact that the newcomers were five Negroes, including two Army veterans.

BOSTON, March 6 -- Massachusetts members of Congress were urged today by seventy citizens of this State to take the lead to have the national legislature adopt rules against the abuse of power by any of its committees.

A plan to bounce short radio waves off the moon to form a new transoceanic channel between the Western and Eastern Hemispheres and which may even prove to be the answer to transoceanic television was announced here yesterday.

New York City's public school teachers have a good chance of obtaining their demands in negotiations now going on with legislative leaders in Albany, Dr. Abraham Lefkowitz, legislative representative of the Teachers Guild, AFL, said last night.

A collection featuring finely tailored suits by Muriel King was shown yesterday at Stein Blaine. Miss King had an interesting way of manipulating fabrics, working with folds and seamed detail that softened even her tailored suits.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP)-- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States asserted today that employers could not "rest easy" until Congress rewrote parts of the Wagner Act to wipe out any question of the law's intent.

Following is the text of President Truman's address yesterday at Baylor University as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES: President Neff, ladies and gentlemen, members of the faculty of this great school and its pupils:

A general wage increase of 19 cents an hour and "other substantial changes" in working rules have been awarded to 4,500 mechanics and other ground personnel of Pan American Airways by a three man arbitration board, the Transport Workers Union of America, CIO, announced yesterday.

LONDON, March 6--Winston Churchill will ask the House of Commons for a vote of censure on the Labor Government at the conclusion of next week's threeday debate on economic policy, it became known today.

ALBANY, March 6 -- Gradual construction of a cluster of new State office buildings in Albany, each to house a major State department, and prompt construction of a new Executive Mansion were recommended today by the State Commission on Building and Development.

ALBANY, March 6--The Assembly Ways and Means Committee reported favorably today on the Gugino bill to provide dependency allowances, over and above present unemployment insurance benefits, for jobless workers.
NANKING, March 6 (AP)--Following their defeat in Manchuria, Communist forces in China proper began a new offensive today close to Tsingtao in Shantung.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 6-- Immediate removal of Capt. John B. Taylor as commanding officer of the United States Naval Magazine at Port Chicago, on the northern shores of San Francisco Bay, was demanded today by the CIO International Longshore and Warehousemen's Union.
Another week-end of top-flight skiing in the East is indicated by reports received yesterday. Except for Bear Mountain, where conditions were "poor to fair," the outlook appeared unusually good.

ALBANY, March 6--Gov. Thomas E. Dewey informed John E. Wade, New York City Superintendent of Schools, at a conference today that sympathetic consideration will be given requests of the New York City school authorities for amendments to the teacher-pay bills.
PARIS, March 6--The French have reached a turning-point in Indo-China, where they are now entering the "constructive phase," Premier Paul Ramadier said today.

Gene Raymond is quitting "The Greatest of These," which opened Tuesday night in Chicago. The stage and screen actor, one of the stars in the Max Wylie play dealing with troubled conditions in India, turned in his notice, effective after the performance of March 18.

The control of Federal expenditures that would bring about reductions in both debt and taxes in the Government's finance program was advocated yesterday by Arthur A. Ballantine, attorney and former Under-Secretary of the Treasury, in discussing the current "turning point" in the Federal budget.

Over the defense's repeated objections, the State yesterday placed into evidence seventeen tapped telephone talks that purportedly linked David (Pete) Krakauer, Harvey Stemmer and Jerome Zarowitz to the football "fix" deal.

WACO, Texas, March 6--President Truman asserted today that the United States must take the lead in reducing international trade barriers, or plunge the world into economic war and pave the way for future armed conflicts.

CHANGCHUN, Manchuria, March 6--Shipments of food by Chinese Communists in Northern Manchuria to Soviet Siberia started two months ago and have reached a daily average of 6,000 tons, according to a Chinese railway engineer and others who have just arrived in Changchun from Communist territory.

A plan under which New York City "will become the medical capital of the world" was outlined last night by Dr. George Baehr, president of the New York Academy of Medicine, at the dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel opening the centennial celebration of the academy.
E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., in their annual report, generally optimistic in tone, reported yesterday that operations in 1946 established a new production record, resulting in peak sales and income.
The coffers of the Red Cross 1947 Fund of Greater New York were enriched yesterday by $4.04 from boys and girls at the Children's Aid Society's Lower West Side Center, 219 Sullivan Street.

PARIS, March 6--Secretary of State Marshall's passing visit to Paris today en route to Moscow was the cause of much satisfaction in official circles. The French saw in his visit a sign of consideration for French prestige on the part of the United States Secretary of State.

A call to gifted American students and scholars to take advantage of opportunities for study in France was issued last night by the directors and members of the advisory committee of the American Institute of France, Inc.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 6-- Satisfied with the progress made in revising Clint Hartung's batting stance, Manager Mel Ott today started instructions designed to improve the defensive skill of the Giant rookie who figures so largely in the club's plans for the outfield.

The Warwick Corporation, Chicago, will extend its campaign in magazines and trade papers on Clarion radios to newspapers in 80 to 100 key cities serviced by the company's distributors by early summer. Some insertions will be made by the producer while others will be handled on a cooperative basis with distributors.

BOSTON, March 6 (AP)--Trial of Kathleen Winsor's "Forever Amber" on a charge of obscenity ended in Superior Court today with a defense lawyer arguing that the State had failed to show that moral corruption resulted from reading the novel.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: W.A. Hunton's charge that the royal tour of South Africa was instigated by the British Labor Government in furtherance of "imperial" policy doesn't appear to be soundly based.
WASHINGTON, March 6--During the week ended March 5, member bank reserve balances increased $149,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

WARSAW, March 6 -- British Foreign Secretary Bevin saw for himself today a small part of the destruction caused by the Germans in Poland. He then assured Polish newspaper men that British policy aimed at preventing "the resurgence of Germany."

MEXICO CITY, March 6--After having taken President Truman to the airport in the chilly darkness at 5 A.M. today, Mexican President Miguel Aleman tonight hailed his guest as a "noble leader in the cause of continued unity, independence and justice."

CANBERRA, March 6-Reversing the adverse vote taken late last year, the Parliamentary Labor Party decided by 33 votes to 24 today that Australia should accept the Bretton Woods agreement and seek membership in the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the International Monetary Fund, provided other members of the fund and the bank would admit her as an original member.

Random notes. Those who don't want to let their shotguns remain idle, but have been unable to get enough shells to justify burning them up at trap or skeet, might put in their spare time shooting crows.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 6--In the interest of economy the United Nations has undertaken a campaign to slash diplomatic verbiage. Its communications experts are compiling a diplomatic code book that is expected to save thousands of dollars on cable tolls daily.

Representatives of thirty-four religious, tenant, labor, consumer and civic organizations in New York City appealed yesterday to President Truman to provide the leadership necessary to save the Office of Price Administration and to beat back the proposal for a general 10 per cent increase in rent ceilings.

WASHINGTON, March 6-- The nine Supreme Court justices ruled 7 to 2 today that John L. Lewis and the United Mine Workers were guilty of contempt in the soft coal strike and should be fined, but divided 5 to 4 in holding that the NorrisLa Guardia anti-injunction act did not apply in the case.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Advocates of a $6,000,000,000 reduction in President Truman's $37,500,000,000 budget for the 1948 fiscal year began talking compromise today at a secret meeting of House and Senate Republicans.

WASHINGTON, March 6--Contentions that large publishers, through contractual relationships with mills and through past "illadvised" buying practices, had contributed substantially to the shortage of newsprint, were voiced today by representatives of Government and industry.

The Kennecott Copper Corporation yesterday reported for 1946 a consolidated net income of $23,047,255 after charges and taxes but before mine depletion, equal to $2.13 each on the 10,821,653 capital shares outstanding. This compares with $30,253,821, or $2.79 a share, in 1945.

All factors point to continuation of the quota system of burlap shipments from Calcutta for the balance of the year, according to trade sources yesterday. Importers here had hoped that a better supply would bring about an end of the system.

In an action without precedent in this State, a union got a Supreme Court order yesterday requiring the State Labor Relations Board to show cause why it should not order a collective bargaining election among supervisory employes.

Artie Levine and Herb Kronowitz, middleweight boxers whose careers have run almost parallel, will clash in the headline event of ten rounds in Madison Square Garden tonight, with Levine the 1 to 2 favorite.

JACKSON, Miss., March 6--Responding to Gov. Fielding L. Wright's warning that countrywide increased costs of living had threatened the Mississippi school system with "complete disaster" the State Senate approved unanimously today a bill appropriating an additional $5,000,000 to supplement teachers' salaries.

Commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System increased $61,000,000 last week to a new high of $4,029,000,000. According to information released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, loans to electrical manufacturers, finance and rubber companies were the principal factors in the rise during the week ended on Wednesday.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 6 (AP)--Jousting Match, claimed out of his last race for $7,500 by Mrs. M. Wood, rad with a $10,000 claiming tag in the first half of today's divided feature event at Gulfstream Park and promptly won in hollow style, paying $30.30 for $2.

ROCHESTER, March 6--A poll by The Catholic Courier-Journal, weekly newspaper of the Diocese of Rochester, revealed today that Catholic experts in the social field in the United States unanimously support the fight of public school teachers to organize into a union and believe that "in extraordinary or grave" circumstanees a teachers' strike may be morally justifiable.
An alleged cattle rustler was captured in Brooklyn yesterday under circumstances that were a far cry from the old "Wild West." The setting was the residential Hill Section of the borough.
WASHINGTON, March 6--The women's organization of the Democratic party has officially gone back to the New Deal as basis for the 1948 campaign.

Random Moscow Thoughts One plausible reason for being hopeful about the Moscow conference is the season. It is cold in the Soviet capital on March 10, When the conference begins, and it will continue cold for a good many weeks to come.

Bruno Walter conducted his last Thursday concert of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra this season last night in Carnegie Hall. The veteran conductor had reason to be gratified with the welcome the audience gave him, a token not only of admiration for the artist, but esteem for the man.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., March 6-- Recitals of bombings, beatings and threats of violence were made today to a House subcommittee which opened an investigation of the five-month-old jurisdictional war between the AFL teamsters union and the CIO brewery workers.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- The House Agriculture Committee, trying to work out a national wool program, got today a new bill--the fifth -- to provide support for a lagging industry.
LONDON, March 6--The Government announced today a general increase in the level of prices for the products of British farms for the year beginning April 1.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP)-- The John L. Lewis case is not yet out of the courts.

CHICAGO, March 6 -- Today's Supreme Court decision upholding the contempt of court conviction of John L. Lewis and the United Mine Workers, American Federation of Labor, appeared to be a reversal of the court's previous position on the use of injunctions in labor disputes, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, said here today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 6--Stressing the importance of a sound educational program in a democracy, Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, called today for immediate passage of a Federal aid bill to raise school standards in thirty-three of the nation's neediest States.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 6--The United States will continue to insist that the United Nations Security Council refer the entire question of international atomic control back to the Atomic Energy Commission, informed sources said today. Warren R. Austin, the United States representative, is expected to make this clear when the Security Council meets Monday.

A flash rally was staged yesterday by the stock market in token acknowledgment of the United States Supreme Court's decision against John L. Lewis, but best gains of 1 to 3 points failed to hold after the brief upturn. The ruling caught Wall Street by surprise since no decision had been expected until next Monday at least, but the reaction of stock prices proved quick and intense.

The models that passed in swift procession before the fashion press at Henri Bendel's yesterday morning were eloquent of two facts-- that the designers had taken into consideration the requirements of a variety of women and that the tradition of the house for magnificent fabrics had been maintained.

William C. Foley, vice president of Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc., formerly in charge of advertising, has been placed in charge of the coordination of purchasing, transportation, warehouses and manufactured inventories.

NEW DELHI, India, Friday, March 7 (U.P.)--Rioting that began three days ago in Lahore is continuing violently there and has spread throughout northern Punjab Province. Casualty estimates range from 150 to "hundreds," reports reaching here early today said.

A long step forward in the movement to unify and modernize building codes throughout the nation was taken yesterday at the first meeting of the executives of the Building Officials Foundation, held in the University Club.

Grace Moore, opera and film star, who was killed in a plane crash at Copenhagen, Denmark, on Jan. 26, left virtually all of her estate to her husband, Valentin Parera of Newton, Conn., it was shown yesterday when her will was filed in Surrogate's Court.

BATAVIA, Java, March 6 (AP)-- Rudy Gray, master of the United States liberty ship Martin Behrman, accused the Netherlands Indies Administration of "an act of piracy" today and ordered his crew to resist with force any Dutch attempt to open the ship's hatches "unless they have the gun on you first."

Steps aimed at development of a more liberal economic policy in France and increased mutual trade between that country and the United States were hailed yesterday at a luncheon honoring a delegation of twenty-two French merchants.

A dark aura of mystery surrounded the trim little Chesapeake Bay liner President Warfield as she lay in the waters of Hampton Roads yesterday awaiting a survey for damage repairs. En route across the Atlantic to a destination and a service of which her crew spoke vaguely, the small passenger craft last week entered the severe Atlantic storm area and was towed into Norfolk with seawater entering through sprung seams.

Responsibility for depriving the city of a chance to provide traffic relief in midtown Manhattan while clearing an important slum area was charged yesterday to the Republican majority in the Legislature by Robert Moses, chairman of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority.

ABOARD MOUNT OLYMPUS, March 6--Summarizing the exploratory work of the planes flying out of Little America on the Navy's Antarctic expedition, Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd said today the air crews had discovered and mapped 310,000 square miles of Antarctica previously unsighted --an area roughly equivalent to Louisiana and Texas combined.

NEWARK, N.J., March 6--Mrs. Mollie Levin, 42 years old, who operates a beauty shop at 727 Seventh Avenue, New York, was convicted today by a jury in Common Pleas Court on a charge of stealing $71,000 in jewels from the home of Mr. and Mrs. Curt Forstmann in Upper Montclair.

MIAMI, Fla., March 6 (AP)--Defending champions Ben Hogan, Hershey, Pa., and Jim Demaret, Ojai, Calif., blasted par by fourteen strokes today as they defeated Jimmy Hines of Glenview, Calif., and Jimmy Thomson of Los Angeles, 4 and 3, in the opening 36-hole round of the $20,000 Miami International Four-ball Golf Tournament.

From J.P. Morgan Co., Inc., came yesterday the first official estimate of the wealth of the late J.P. Morgan, who died March 13, 1943, at the age of 75. The appraisal for New York estate tax purposes showed that the head of the old House of Morgan had left a net estate of $4,642,791, after taxes, debts and expenses were deducted.

The first of ten new doubledeck passenger cars, each seating 134 passengers compared to seventytwo in the coaches now in use, was received and put on view at the main Jamaica station of the Long Island Rail Road yesterday. It will be placed in service next week between New York and Babylon.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 6--Although Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet representative on the United Nations Security Council, contended yesterday that the Council of the British Atomic Scientists' Association opposed international operation of atomic production plants, the association actually endorsed this provision of the Baruch Plan.

Mr. Gromyko's latest statement before the Security Council knocks into a cocked hat the notion advanced by some, and the hope entertained by others, that the only obstacle to agreement on control of atomic energy is America's insistence on the abolition of the veto.

Tammany Hall, which had begun to resemble the "deserted village" in recent months as district leaders shied away from the Loughlin leadership, resembled a full house again yesterday as Frank J. Sampson, newly elected leader, spent his first full day at the job.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 5 (delayed)--An official spokesman of the Bulgarian Embassy said tonight that no entry visas would be issued to Bulgaria-bound passengers for a tea-day period, beginning tomorrow.

Tournament-conscious Long Island University built an early lead against Muhlenberg College's basketball team from Allentown in their return meeting at Madison Square Garden last night, and it was well that the blackbirds did Most of their 17-point bulge vanished, but the Brooklynites had enough to win, 60--54.
LONDON, March 6--Britain was suffering tonight from the worst breakdown of transport and communications facilities of this already calamitous winter.

Peace and freedom are not easily achieved. They cannot be attained by force. They come from mutual understanding and cooperation, from a willingness to deal fairly with every friendly nation in all matters--political and economic.

St. John's University, aiming at a berth in the invitation basketball tournament, will seek to maintain its clean slate in intracity competition, against Brooklyn College at the Sixty-Ninth Regiment Armory tonight. The junior varsity teams of the rival schools will clash in a preliminary starting at 7:30 P.M.
An arbitration award of a 6 per cent increase in basic wage and overtime rates has been won by the National Maritime Union, CIO, it was reported here yesterday.
LONDON, March 6--The British Government's decision to quit India by June, 1948, was approved by the House of Commons tonight despite a slashing attack by Winston Churchill.

MOSCOW, March 6--A series of agreements strengthening the economic ties between Poland and the Soviet Union and providing for supply to Poland by Russia of "armaments and military supplies on credit" has been signed here.

WASHINGTON, March 6--The Supreme Court decision against John L. Lewis and the United Mine Workers today is expected to mean continued production of soft coal at least until June 30. Government possession will terminate on that date unless Congress legislates an extension.

Mr. Lewis's coal strike ended three months ago today. It ended with Mr. Lewis's belated submission to the Supreme Court as "the protector of American liberties and the rightful privileges of individual citizens." Yesterday the Court stepped out of its ordinary routine to define liberties and privileges as they apply to Mr. Lewis and the United Mine Workers.
MONTREAL, March 6 (AP)--The Detroit Red Wings stretched their unbeaten streak to seven games tonight by battling the National Hockey League's front-running Montreal Canadiens to a 1-1 tie.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP)-- The Bureau of Agricultural Economics said today forces now at work seem to indicate a business recession late in 1947 and a downturn in prices, particularly in foods.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your issue of Feb. 20 W.A. Hunton, Educational Director of the Council on African Affairs, joins those who, for reasons of their own, have been discovering political, imperialistic and other motives behind the royal visit to the Union of South Africa.

Officials of the brokerage house of A.M. Kidder Co. asserted yesterday that they were formulating their labor policy without any consultation with the New York Stock Exchange or the Association of Stock Exchange Firms.

ABOARD MOUNT OLYMPUS, March 6--When this ship and her two accompanying ice breakers, the North Wind and Burton Island, sail into Wellington, N.Z., tomorrow they will have a veritable rookery of squawking penguins aboard.

HOUSTON, Tex., March 6 (AP)-- Plans for a 1,000-mile, $55,000,000 gas line from the Houston area to West Virginia were outlined today by Gardiner Symonds, president of the Tennessee Gas and Transmission Company, in his annual report to stockholders.

Something must be done immediately to get pig iron into the hands of machinery foundries if food machinery, chemical and process equipment and other types of industrial machines are to be supplied to fill large current backorders, industry spokesmen said here yesterday.

A further step in the program to refit disabled and handicapped civilians for employment and normal living was announced yesterday by the New York UniversityBellevue Department of Rehabilitation and Physical Medicine and the Community Service Society.
PITTSBURGH, March 6--Soft coal miners who make up a major share of western Pennsylvania's economy received the Supreme Court decision in stunned silence today.

WASHINGTON, March 6--Miss Margaret Truman will make her professional debut as a radio soprano this Sunday from Detroit on the American Broadcasting Company's Sunday evening hour concert from 8 to 9 P.M., a surprise announcement from the White House revealed today.
Former Seaman George Soto earned his license yesterday to drive an automobile. Now all he needs is the car.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP)-- Comments by members of Congress on the Supreme Court's decision in the John L. Lewis case included the following: Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio--The decision will tend to clarify the legal situation and assist us in drafting labor legislation.

As part of its activities in developing cultural relations between Great Britain and other countries, the British Council has made a gift of British music to the Music Library in the Circulation Department of the New York Public Library.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 6--Playing their finest performance of the spring training campaign, the Yankees tonight vanquished the Dodgers in the third and deciding game of their cup series here by a score of 4 to 0 before a crowd of 9,000.

A National Conference on the Problem, of Germany, convoked by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and Edgar Ansel Mowrer, framed yesterday a program to implement the Yalta and Potsdam agreements. It will be sent to the American delegation at the Moscow conference and to the United States Government.

Snow storms that have caused transportation bottlenecks in the northern part of the State are held responsible for the higher prices that the housewife, doing her week-end marketing today, will notice on butter and eggs. She'll also find that many of the vegetables that may be on her shopping list are more expensive.

NORFOLK, Va., March 6-- Thirty thousand persons who assembled in murky weather heard John L. Sullivan, Under-Secretary of the Navy, dedicate the fleet's newest warship to "universal peace" today as the rapid-firing, air-conditioned heavy cruiser Newport News was named in the graving dock where she was built at the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company.

Winfield Scott (Winnie) O'Connor, one of the foremost jockeys of the early days of the century, died yesterday at the home of a friend, Dudley Duryea, at 1870 East Fifty-first Street, Brooklyn. His age was 66.

BRUSSELS, March 6--The Foreign Ministry issued the following statement today and approved, this translation: "It is inexact, as reported in a dispatch of THE NEW YORK TIMES' correspondent in Brussels, that 'Belgium has submitted in the last twenty-four hours propositions for alliances to the Governments of Britain and the Soviet Union.

Quotas on undesirable low-end bedroom suites have been terminated by many factories and wholesale salesmen still operating under factory allocations are finding it difficult to move quotas assigned to them, it was learned yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 6-- The production of the atom bomb "has been a ghastly revelation of the failure of our educational economic and political systems," Frank Lloyd Wright, the architect, told a group of the country's leading architects at a dinner at Princeton University tonight.
PARIS, March 7 (U.P.)--Verhuslav Vana of Czechoslovakia, the favorite, captured the men's world table tennis championship tonight by defeating Francois Side of Hungary, 21--10, 21--14, 21--9.
LONDON, March 7--Business in the stock markets today was quiet, with most sections showing irregular trends due to leveling up of commitments before the week-end.

The transmission of printed text and pictures by facsimile over frequency modulation stations as a regular home service for 1948 was predicted yesterday by John V.L. Hogan, president of WQXR and WQXQ.

Because of the shortage of nurses in the New York City Department of Health, 100 elementary and junior high schools here have lost public health services, Mrs. Edna Malone, district supervising nurse of the Lower East Side Health Center, declared yesterday.

The Moving Finger A very old Egyptian custom has come to life with the move in Congress to rechristen Boulder Dam with its original name, Hoover Dam. In the ancient Nile land the new Pharaoh had a habit of erasing the name of a predecessor from the monuments, especially if he held contrary views, and inscribing the new ruler's name.

The case of the United States freighter Martin Behrman, which has been forced by a Dutch destroyer to dock at Tanjong Priok, Java, with her valuable cargo of rubber, quinine and sugar, while Dutch, and Indonesian Republican leaders quarrel over ownership of the material, illustrates the economic paralysis that the political deadlock in the Netherlands Indies has imposed on that rich area of the Southwest Pacific.

A new system designed to speed up immigration clearance on its big transpacific passenger liners arriving at San Francisco was tested this week by American President Lines. The idea involves flying immigration personnel to Honolulu where the inbound liner is boarded, and the work of checking and clearing passengers is done en route to San Francisco.

ROBERT BRIFFAULT sings his songs of social significance in some of the gaudiest prose of our time. His novels--"Europa," "Europa in Limbo" and now "New Life of Mr. Martin"*--have for a dozen years been celebrating the death of European society with considerable relish. They are written in a style that is unbelievably ornate.

WASHINGTON, March 7--Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican of New York, said today in his maiden Senate speech that the British decision to turn over the Palestine problem to the United Nations General Assembly "offers little hope of a constructive solution."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 7--Msgr. Joseph A. Breslin, dean of the Catholic clergy of Westchester County and pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of St. John the Evangelist of this city, died tonight in the rectory of the church of a heart attack.

CHICAGO, March 7--A broad trade was on in the grain markets on the Board of Trade today with prices swinging wildly, wheat having a range of 5 1/4 to 6 cents a bushel, and corn, one of 4 1/4 to 4 1/2 cents.

PITTSBURGH, March 7 -- The long-expected labor bill will be sent to the floor of the House on March 25, Representative Carroll D. Kearns, Republican, of Fennsylvania, said today. He is here as a majority member of a three-man Congressional subcommittee investigating Pittsburgh's five-month beer war.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I am impelled to correct the impression given in your issue of March 1 as to my opinion of the pending bill sponsored by Mayor O'Dwyer to reorganize the New York City Housing Authority. The article to which I refer states that I said that the new Authority would be no better than the present agency and would bring politics into the field of public housing.
