The American Bible Society donated 129,234 complete Bibles, 1,665,709 Testaments and 286,456 parts of the Bible to the United States Navy and its affiliated services from 1941 through 1946, it was made known yesterday at the headquarters of the society, 450 Park Avenue.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- A Senate-House conference committee reached an agreement today on funds to be allowed to the Office of Price Administration for continued operations but reaffirmed insistence that the agency be completely out of business by June 30.
CHICAGO, March 7 (AP)--Lieut. Gen. James H. Doolittle said today that "we must subsidize the airlines until they become entirely self-supporting."

WASHINGTON, March 7--J.A. Krug, Secretary of the Interior, vigorously endorsed today the admission of the Territory of Hawaii as the forty-ninth State of the Federal Union. To the House Committee on Public Lands he said:

BUDAPEST, Hungary, March 7--The Hungarian Government has forbidden the publication here of the United States note of protest to Moscow against the recent arrest by the Russians of Bela Kovacs, former secretary general of the majority Smallholders party.

NEW LONDON, Conn., March 7 (AP)--A forecast that Congress ultimately would decree a 20 per cent across-the-board income tax cut was coupled here today with an expression of belief that, through better understanding, labor and management would find a way to avoid industrial chaos.
Vivid upholstery fabrics and dramatic new lines distinguish the season's summer furniture that is just beginning to appear in New York stores.

HIGHTSTOWN, N. J., March 7 --Three persons were killed early this morning when the car in which they were riding crashed into a tractor and trailer on Route 25, one-half mile south of Hightstown State police station. A second motorist narrowly escaped death when he crashed into the wreckage.

After the local board of appeals had refused unanimously to review his 1-A classification in the draft, Serge M. Rubinstein, 38-year old international financier, succeeded in getting a review of his draft status by the Presidential Board of Appeals through Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, national director of Selective Service, it was brought out yesterday at Rubinstein's trial in Federal Court.

PARIS, March 7--Raphael Alibert, first Minister of Justice under former Marshal Henri-Philippe Petain, who is accused of having framed Vichy's "fascist" constitution, was condemned to death in absentia by the High Court of Justice at Versailles today.

Now enjoying the peace and quiet of honorable semi-retirement, that tough old aerial warrior of the Second World War, the B-17 Flying Fortress, this week celebrated its tenth birthday. No warplane that hung a vapor trail in the sky or blasted an enemy with its fire ever claimed so many loyal and devoted supporters among Allied airmen and civilians nor so many implacable foes among Axis fliers and citizens.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 7--Secretary General Trygve Lie estimated today that the United Nations would be ready to move into its first $20,000,000 office building along the East River and vacate its headquarters here by Nov. 15, 1948.

The General Sessions trial of three men charged with attempting the football "fix" that was bungled was adjourned at 11:53 o'clock last night until 10:30 A.M. today, when Judge Saul S. Streit will charge the jury.

Gilbert Dodds, surfeited with six hollow triumphs at a mile and two miles, will tempt fate tonight by tackling both distances within an hour in the twenty-eighth annual games of the New York Chapter, Knights of Columbus, at Madison Square Garden.

Imposition of import quotas on woven fabrics and knit goods cannot aid the wool grower in the United States and is merely another attempt of woolen manufacturers to have an embargo imposed on cloth importations, according to the National Council of American Importers, Inc., yesterday.

Tomorrow evening the first night trail will lead to the Princess Theatre, 106 West Thirtyninth Street, where the Experimental Theatre, Inc., will offer the third of five productions planned for the season under the sponsorship of the American National Theatre and Academy.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., March 7 (AP)--A pair of pre-war punchers from Syracuse and a clever Coast Guardsman dominated the first night of clouting in the twentyfourth Eastern Intercollegiate Boxing Association championships tonight as Syraruse, Virginia and the defending champion Army team remained well in the running for the team title.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, March 7 -- Hungarian Foreign Minister Dr. Janos Gyoengyoesy's negotiations here concerning the exchange of Magyar and Slovak populations have broken down entirely, the Hungarians disclosed tonight. As a result, the whole Hungarian delegation will return to Budapest immediately.

John M. Hancock, partner of Lehman Brothers and one of the associates of Bernard M. Baruch in formulating the United States plan for the international control of atomic energy, warned a gathering of prominent chemists at a luncheon of the American Chemical Society at the Hotel Commodore yesterday that no plan for outlawing the use of atomic bombs will stop their use by any nation once a war had started.

A four-alarm fire swept the United States Maritime Commission's motor ship, John Ericsson, yesterday afternoon, at Pier 90. Fiftieth Street and the North River, resulting in $1,500,000 damage, me fire caused widespread confusion but no panic among several thousand visitors and passengers on board the Queen Elizabeth, berthed at the south side of the same pier.

YENAN, March 4 (delayed)-- In the opinion of Communist leaders here, the Government order for Communist personnel to leave Kuomintang territory has made the break between China's two warring factions final and complete.

Trade in Smaller Gain Here Retail trade here showed narrower increases this week. Department store volume was estimated at 5 to 10 per cent above last year. Women's wear departments failed to show the substantial gains noted at this time in 1946 when early buying for Easter was more of a factor in this merchandise than it is today.
LONDON, March 7--The strenuous efforts to unravel the dislocation in production and the movement of coal to Britain's fuelstarved industrial centers suffered fresh setbacks today.

LEAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 7--Establishment of an Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East to promote rehabilitation of the Orient was recommended today in the final report of the United Nations Temporary Subcommission on Economic Reconstruction of Devastated Areas.

Secession by any member of the United Nations would be the most serious threat to outlawing the atomic bomb and should be prevented by amendments to the United Nations Charter, Norman Cousins, editor of the Saturday Review of Literature, declared yesterday.

ALBANY, March 7--Leaders of the Democratic minority in the Legislature will meet in New York City over the week-end to decide what course they will follow with regard to the Condon-Wadlin Bill outlawing strikes by public workers.

BLOEMFONTEIN, South Africa, March 7--"Die Konig! Is hy welkom?" (The King! Is he welcome?) To this question, Bloemfontein, capital of the Orange Free State, replied today with a most decided "ja" (yes) but not quite unanimously.

WASHINGTON, March 7--John L. Lewis declared emphatically today that there was nothing that the Government could do to prevent country-wide coal strikes unless the present form of government gave way to a totalitarian system. Testifying before the Senate Committee on Labor and Public Welfare, he opposed any amendment of the Wagner Act.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 7 --Louis de Rochemont, Twentieth Century-Fox producer, will settle his contract with the studio next fall unless differences existing between him and the Fox management are ironed out, it was learned today from studio sources.
WASHINGTON, March 7--The United States and Britain have asked Yugoslavia to surrender claims to nine war-wrecked Italian vessels, including the transatlantic liner Rex.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 7 (AP) -- Keeping its average of a winner per day for the meeting which opened Wednesday, the Woolford farm of Herbert M. Woolf sent out the veteran Affiant to win the first division of the Hibiscus Purse at Gulfstream Park today.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Because of developments presumed to be connected with the question of United States aid for Greece, President Truman postponed indefinitely today the Caribbean cruise for which he was to have left the capital tomorrow.

Two armed thugs waylaid a partner in the Williamsburg Fireproof Door Company in an alleyway leading to the factory office at 86 Quay Street in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn at 2 P.M. yesterday and escaped with an $8,700 payroll.

NEW HAVEN, Conn.. March 7 --With a grand march and the traditional wooden spoon ceremony as the highlights, the Yale junior promenade was resumed in the Payne Whitney Gymnasium tonight after a wartime lapse of four years.
Repeating his victories of Forest Hills and Seabright, Robert Falkenburg of Hollywood, Calif., defeated William Talbert of Wilmington, Del., last night in the national indoor tennis championships.

The West Side waterfront in the John Ericsson fire area yesterday resembled a refugee rout. Cabs halted by police fire lines dumped passengers with baggage destined for the liner Queen Elizabeth three and four blocks from the pier and left them to shift for themselves.

An aggressive merchandising campaign directed at the travel field and the general public will be undertaken to stress the economic importance of world travel and the International Travel Exposition, which will be held at Grand Central Palace, May 5-10, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 7--The first Republican move toward a $6,000,000,000 budget cut brought a recommended reduction of $897,072,750 in Treasury-Postoffice funds today, but Democrats shouted that it was a false start, a "sham" and a "phony."

WASHINGTON, March 7--The Children's Bureau, which a few days ago urged "adequate community aid to unmarried mothers as one of the requisites to ending the black market in babies," today outlined a program for such aid.

Winners of prizes for the best notebooks submitted at this season's Young People's Concerts of the Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra will receive their awards at this morning's concert in the series, at Carnegie Hall. Rudolph Ganz, William Kroll, Leon Barzin and Constance Keene will make the presentations.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 7 -- America's foremost downhillslalom racing exponents, gathered from every corner of the nation's snow belt, were marking time tonight at this snow paradise awaiting the start of the Olympic tryouts tomorrow.

ARCADIA, Calif., March 7 (AP)-- Stepfather, Harry M. Warner's $200,000 colt, was among thirteen 3-year-olds named today to run in the $100,000 added Santa Anita Derby tomorrow, but observers, remembering the defeat of the great Armed in the Santa Anita Handicap last week, declined to go overboard on the handsome son of Beau Pere.

PARIS, March 7--Officials and economists here were delighted by President Truman's statement in his speech in Waco, Tex., yesterday that the United States could no more remain isolated economically than it could politically. Some added that they would be still more pleased if Republican leaders endorsed the same view, since Europeans cannot be sure Mr. Truman will be President two years hence.

Influenced by a weak stock market and uncertainty over foreign political conditions, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday lost 36 to 72 points, closing at or near the low marks of the day.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the Senate on Feb. 25 Senators Brewster, Taft, Barkley and Hawkes criticized severely the British policy in Palestine. They stated that it was in violation of the British pledge in the Balfour Declaration, and in general abused Foreign Minister Bevin roundly for his objection to President Truman's request, just before the 1946 Senatorial and Congressional election, that 100,000 Jews be immediately admitted into Palestine.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP)-- A new allocation of natural gas from the Big Inch and Little Big Inch pipelines for the remainder of March and for April was announced today by the Federal Power Commission.

Artie Levine, star Brownsville middleweight, made his superior weight and punching power tell in his ten-round star bout with Herbie Kronowitz of Coney Island at Madison Square Garden last night. Off to a slow start against his less experienced rival, Levine found himself as the battle wore on and succeeded in gaining the unanimous vote of Referee Arthur Donovan and Judges Charley Shortell and Jim Hagen.

BATAVIA, Java, March 7 (U.P.)-- An armed Dutch force of fiftyfive men seized the United States freighter Martin Behrman today, deposed Capt. Rudy Gray and the crew and towed the ship to a new dock to begin unloading her cargo.

Unless hide and skin prices are reduced substantially, shoe prices must advance rather than decline, the National Shoe Manufacturers Association, representing about 95 per cent of total shoe production, declared yesterday. In a statement counteracting the general impression that lower shoe prices can be expected, spokesmen for the organization indicated that shoe prices cannot decline until hide and skin prices get back somewhere nearer former price ceiling levels.
The Coast Guard Search and Rescue coordinating center, 42 Broadway, reported yesterday two ships in immediate need of aid in the North Atlantic.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 7--Confronted with British, Russian and Australian objections, the United States failed today to get immediate action on its proposals to rule the 650 Japanese mandated islands under United Nations trusteeship.

For more than ten years New Jersey sportsmen have been working to bring about the passage of a State law for the preservation of striped bass, and next Tuesday their bill will be presented to the State Senate for decision.
WASHINGTON, March 7--The Republican leadership in Congress recently the open target of members of the party's small liberal wing, went under fire from its ultra-conservative side today.

A concerted drive is under way to make fair - trade agreements effective in the liquor industry by both distilling companies and retailers, it was reported yesterday. This attention to a "floor" on prices as over-all indices point toward record highs in many commodities, it was stated, indicates the concern of the liquor industry over consumer resistance to present price levels in alcoholic beverages.

Richard Hirsch, former colonel in the Military Intelligence Division of the War Department, has written a book entitled "The Soviet Spies: A Record of Russian Espionage in North America," scheduled for publication by Duell, Sloan Pearce March 15. Mr. Hirsch for fourteen years was a special writer on crime and law enforcement problems.

LONDON, March 7 (AP)--Counsel for William S. Paley, chairman of the Columbia Broadcasting System, withdrew a libel action against the publishers of The London Daily Mail today. They advised the court that the defendants had apologized publicly and had paid an agreed sum of money, which Mr. Paley turned over to British charities.

The severest assault in four months was made yesterday to the stock market in a series of selling drives which reached their peak in the final hour and left the composite rate on the Stock Exchange reduced by 3 3/4 points. A few greater inroads were suffered by some units, and the industrial average lost more than 6 points as the result.
NANKING, March 7--Government authorities here are displaying growing concern over the spread of banditry, popular demonstrations and local uprisings in scattered parts of Nationalist China.
The assignment of three colonels to units of the Organized Reserve was announced yesterday by Gen. Courtney H. Hodges, commanding the First Army.

St. John's University enhanced prospects of a bid to the national invitation basketball tournament by delivering a stunning defeat to Brooklyn College, 82 to 52, last night in the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory.
REDWOOD CITY, Calif., March 7 (AP)--Ty Cobb, a baseball hero in the lusty days of Tris Speaker and Honus Wagner, was sued for divorce today after thirty-nine years of marriage.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 7 (AP) --Ohio State's defending champions took a 20-point lead at the halfway mark of the annual big nine swimming meet tonight after losing one of their 1946 titles.

WARSAW, March 7--Deeply resentful of what it considers the illmannered attack by Ambassador Arthur Bliss Lane, the Polish Government announced today that it had offered many months ago to allow a joint American-Polish commission to examine the imprisoned claimants to American citizenship.

NANKING, March 7 (AP)--The Government clamped a 10 P.M. curfew on Tsingtao tonight and gave the garrison unlimited search powers as a Communist offensive swept close to that important Shantung seaport.
MOSCOW, March 7 -- Seven planeloads of United States diplomats and correspondents arrived in Moscow today for the Council of Foreign Ministers conference Monday.

BERKELEY, Calif., March 7 (AP) --National figure skating champion Dick Button of Englewood, N.J., an entry of the Philadelphia Skating Club, rules favorite to repeat among four senior men finalists in the national figure skating championships being held here.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The recent letters to THE NEW YORK TIMES by F.W. Foerster, life-long opponent of German militarism and PanGermanism, and a group of politicians of the defunct Weimar Republic, should arouse great interest among Americans.

LEWISTOWN, Pa., March 7-- Formal notice that they will resign in a body May 5 was given the Derry Township school district today by the entire teaching staff in protest against refusal of the school board to grant immediate salary increases of $300.

A "careful understanding" of the relations between the United States and other nations of the Western Hemisphere is necessary before a true accord can be established between them, Victor Raul Haya de' la Torre of Peru, leader of the liberal APRA movement in Latin America, declared yesterday.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 7--The actual conditioning of his Giant squad having reached a satisfactory conclusion, Manager Mel Ott tomorrow launches the campaign which will determine the make-up of the club he hopes will be a contender for the National League pennant of 1947.

SALONIKA, Greece, March 7-- While the United Nations Inquiry Commission heard today another witness testify that Greece's northern neighbors sponsored guerrilla activity, it was disclosed that Greece intended to summon before its commission Mme. Draja Mikhailovitch, widow of the executed Yugoslav general.

TEL, AVIV, Palestine, March 7-- Satisfaction with the results so far achieved by the imposition of martial law over a large section of Palestine's central coastal area was expressed to me today by an authoritative British Army source.

PARIS, March 7--Secretary of State Marshall was acclaimed by several thousand Parisians today when he visited the Arc de Triomphe this morning. This was a reflection of French gratitude for the role that General Marshall played in French liberation.

LAHORE, Punjab, India, March 7--Using military tactics, police and British and Indian troops restored a measure of order today in this province where for three days Hindus and Sikhs battled Moslems in the shadow of India's ultimate issue--unity or partition.
PARIS, March 7--Premier Paul Ramadier appealed to Paris newspaper workers today to end the strike so that newspapers could express French public opinion to the world during the Moscow conference.

MIAMI, Fla., March 7 (AP)--Ben Hogan of Hershey, Pa., and Jimmy Demaret, Ojai, Calif., continued their magnificent play in the second round of the $10,000 international four-ball golf tournament today by trimming Jim Ferrier, Chicago, and Fred Haas Jr., New Orleans, 5 and 4.

ALBANY, March 7--Nineteen of twenty-three non-sectarian colleges in New York State are asking applicants for admission questions designed to elicit information about race, religion or national background, Rabbi Irving Miller, chairman of the executive committee of the American Jewish Congress, reported today.
HAVANA, March 7--Still leading the Dodgers by a matter of six hours, the Larry MacPhail Yankee party of fifty-one players and supernumeraries dropped down on the local airport this afternoon.

PITTSBURGH, March 7--Owing mainly to the extended cold spell, business in the Pittsburgh district last week fell to the lowest level recorded in 1947, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. Pronounced decreases were reported in industrial production and in originating shipments.

TOKYO, March 7--Yoshiki Hoshino, Japan's version of the American flagpole sitter, today became the subject of a serious protest by the Soviet Union because he had recently starved himself in a Tokyo public park in behalf of faster repatriation of Japanese.

PHILADELPHIA, March 7--The proposal of the Interstate Power Company, a subsidiary of the Ogden Corporation, to issue and sell two collateral promissory notes of $400,000 each to the Chase National Bank and the Manufacturers Trust Company of New York was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WHEELING, W.Va., March 7 (U.P.) -- A Federal district court ruled today that the Government's Coal Mines Administration had no authority to take over a private coal mine because the operator refused to comply with terms of the Government's contract with John L. Lewis and the United Mine Workers.

Church schools cannot instill religious motivations for human behaviour in rising generations until adults provide an example in leadership, it was emphasized in talks yesterday at a conference for ministers. The meeting was under the auspices of the Department of Parent Education and Family Life of the Board of Christian Education of the Protestant Council of the City of New York.

The Supreme Court decision in the case of John L. Lewis and the United Mine Workers makes repeatedly and with emphasis a clear distinction between private and governmental employes which offers some timely guidance on one of the most important issues now before the Legislature in Albany.
A meeting yesterday at the State Labor Relations Board failed to settle a strike in the National Safety Bank and Trust Company, Thirty-eighth Street and Broadway, and its three branch offices.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP)-- Republican leaders abandoned attempts today to force an immediate Senate vote on a proposal to limit the tenure of a President to nine years.

The Commonwealth of Massachusetts awarded yesterday note issues totaling $30,000,000 at competitive sale yesterday to bidding managers as follows: To National Shawmut Bank and Bankers Trust Company and associates --$10,000,000 of notes due Nov. 14 at 0.72 per cent plus a premium of $3, and $10,000,000 of notes due March 12, 1948, at 0.74 per cent, plus a premium of $3.

WASHINGTON, March 7--A stabilizer to facilitate the landing in safety of fixed-wing airplanes, has been patented by Jacob Spiegel of Philadelphia, one of 373 inventions for which patents were issued this week.

Albert Brusilow, 18-year-old Philadelphia violinist, made his recital debut at Carnegie Hall last night. The first impression, reenforced as the evening progressed, was that the young musician had chosen, the wrong forum. His tone is small, if refined, and his artistic perceptions are limited at this point in his development.

A good breakfast, and well-balanced dinner seem, to fall into natural patterns, but planning the third meal often proves baffling. This is especially true when there are children in the family, for they can't lunch--or at least, they shouldn't--on a cup of tea and some crackers, the way mother does.

Africans of the Gold Coast are only one generation removed from human sacrifice, but they have the beginnings of a free trade union movement that can and does strike against the Government, Idwel Glyndwyr Jones asserted yesterday.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 7 --The United States has insisted that Great Britain present to the United Nations a formal, clear-cut proposal for action on Palestine, it was disclosed tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 7--An undercurrent battle between proponents of rival plans for improvement of the Panama Canal has been simmering for months, and is likely to boil over into Congress before the issue is settled.

First World Bank With the recent executive reorganization of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development now apparently completed and the expectation of an early start in its operations, renewed conjecture has developed regarding the future of the old Bank for International Settlements.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, March 7--The Jewish community organization in Prague issued today an official protest against the "unlawful procedure of the district national committee and local officials in Varnsdorf against Emil Beer."

The Seafarers International Union, AFL, has served notice on all prospective ship owners and operators on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts that it will not permit such companies to sign crewing agreements with the National Maritime Union, CIO, Paul Hall, SIU port agent here, asserted yesterday.
LONDON, March 7--A storm of protest blew up in Parliament today over the high prices Great Britain has had to pay for Argentine meat this year.

Any ex-GI who puzzled in gunnery school over wind and muzzle velocity and elevation and deflection, may well marvel at the feat of Coast Guard Warrant Officer Earl B. Drinkwater, who hit the mark on his first shot with a Lyle gun.

In November, 1946, an election was held in Hungary in which the Smallholders party was put in power by an overwhelming majority of the people. The Socialists ran second and the Communists a poor third. Although the Red Army was then, as it still is, the sole occupying force, and therefore in complete control of the country, the election was completely free.

Philip Murray and other labor leaders, with, the Nathan report as a springboard, declare that corporate profits at the present time are excessive and urge that part of this excess --about $17 billions--be turned over to union labor in the form of higher wages.

The United Negro College Fund, which was organized four years ago, will seek this year to raise $1,300,000, about one-tenth of the operating expenses of its thirty-three member colleges. The funds raised will be used to improve teachers' salaries and for current expenses, plant operation, maintenance and scholarship aid.

ALBANY, March 7 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's Committee on Education is expected to reach a decision by Monday on requests made by teacher groups and Boards of Education for revision of the Administration's permanent teacher pay program.
LONDON, March 7--An Italian financial mission with the ambitious objective of persuading Great Britain to forego some of her rights under the newly signed peace treaty arrived in London tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP)-- Dr. Vannevar Bush told a Congress committee today that the Government must assume responsibility for building up a reservoir of young scientists "to maintain our proper place as the world leader in science."

An increasing interest in parent education and a demand for counseling far in excess of the supply are reflected in the annual report of the Child Study Association of America, 221 West Fifty-seventh Street.

The Artists' Gallery, Inc., which was founded in May, 1936, on Eighth Street, will open on May 15 at its new location, 61 East Fiftyseventh Street. The gallery will continue its policy of sponsoring work which appears to have outstanding merit.

A pencil, paper, and the possible knowledge of the whereabouts of a rugged 200-pound fullback will stand fifteen applicants for an important City College faculty position in good stead this afternoon at 1 o'clock. At that time, it was learned yesterday, the college will hold what may prove to be a unique test in the history of higher education--a written examination for the job of head football coach.

The National Maritime Union, CIO, is "very disappointed" oven the arbitration award that gave its seamen a wage and overtime rate increase of only six per cent, instead of the 25 per cent sought, a union spokesman asserted yesterday.

There's activity in the sugar groves Sap is flowing in the maples. Snow is still deep among the trees, but it is sugaring time and the sweet water drips from the slanting spiles into big buckets. In recent weeks countrymen have overhauled and repaired their equipment.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP)-- The Navy has created a supersensitive fire alarm from a gadget used by atomic scientists.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- An up-to-date census of business was urged today by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, in a statement supporting legislation pending in Congress to authorize a new governmental survey of this type. None has been made since 1939.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP)-- Ira Mosher, National Association of Manufacturers spokesman, told the House Labor Committee today that the Supreme Court decision in the John L. Lewis case proved "you've got to have some legislation" to protect the public.

Tammany Hall continued its reorganization yesterday under the direction of Frank J. Sampson, newlyelected leader, who spent the day conferring on organization matters with numerous district leaders at 331 Madison Avenue, the Tammany headquarters.

LONDON, March 7--The plight of British subjects divorced by their American wives or husbands under an American law but regarded by British law as still married was raised in the House of Commons today by Garry Allighan, Laborite.
Food Minister John Strachey of Great Britain, who has conferred with Government officials here on the American export food program, sailed for home last evening on the Queen Elizabeth.

After forcing the store manager, a clerk and two customers into a rear room, two armed robbers looted the Walgreen Drug Store in the Times Tower in Times Square at 4:45 A.M. yesterday. They fled with $155, the contents of a Red Cross collection box and a wrist watch.

Capt. John Allyne Gade, USNR, retired, and Mrs. Gade of 920 Fifth Avenue and St. James, L.I., have announced the engagement and forthcoming marriage of their daughter, Mrs. Allyne Gade Branch, widow of Maj. Henry Branch 2d, AAF, to Frederick Burnham Stimson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Stimson of this city and Wynnewood, Pa. Plans have been made for a wedding on May 17.

CHANGCHUN, Manchuria, March 7--Large numbers of Japanese "holdout" troops--estimated by some at 100,000--are still in remote areas of Northern Manchuria, according to Chinese military circles in Changchun.

WASHINGTON, March 7--The Senate members of the Joint Committee on Atomic Energy today postponed until 10 A.M. Monday a final committee vote on the confirmation of David E. Lilienthal as Chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission and of four other members of the commission.

JERUSALEM, March 7--Nearly 5,000 British troops and Palestine police laid siege to three Jewish communities at dawn today and combed through them for arms and terrorists. Thirty-two persons were detained and one small arms cache was discovered.

ESSEN, Germany, March 7-- For the first time in more than six months the Allied Control Council will announce an increase in the allocation of German coal for export to European countries, it was learned today. The Council has advised the European Coal Commission that 675,000 tons, the highest figure since last October, will be made available to neighbors of Germany.

Caution on mortgage lending was advised yesterday by Joseph M. Dodge, vice president of the American Bankers Association, who warned bankers that "legal restrictions on the maximum amount of mortgages a bank may carry in relation to its savings deposits frequently are too high."

Ralph Starr Butler, vice president in charge of corporate relations and research, General Foods Corporation, was presented last night with a gold medal award for his "distinguished services to advertising." The presentation was made at the annual dinner of Annual Advertising Awards, sponsored by Advertising and SellingMagazine, in the Waldorf-Astoria.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 7--J.P. Morgan made during his lifetime gifts totaling $14,810,340 to his immediate family, an inspection of the appraisal of his estate filed in Surrogate's Court here today disclosed.

Threats of a teacher strike in New York City waned yesterday with reports that delegates of the Teachers Salary Conference had reached agreements with legislative officials in Albany on a number of demands.

LEIPZIG, Germany, March 7-- The resurgent political awareness of the German people and the volatile orientation of those in the Soviet zone rarely has been so well demonstrated as at a rousing three-party rally here last night.

WASHINGTON, March 7--The Senate subcommittee investigating the newsprint shortage invited producers and large consumers today to a conference next Thursday to develop a cooperative program of distribution of supplies to assure the continued publication of smaller newspapers threatened with suspension.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., March 7 (AP) --Herb McKenley, Illinois runner from Kingston, Jamaica, tonight was clocked in 48 seconds flat at the Illinois Armory for a new American and Western Conference indoor quarter-mile record. He ran in the preliminaries of the thirty-seventh annual Big Nine track and field championships.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 7--Leonid Kamensky, White Russian delegate to the Economic and Social Council, warned the United Nations today against condoning imperialism in its promotion of "capital investments" abroad in developing backward countries.

YONKERS, N.Y., March 7-- William A. Kruppenbacher, who resigned three days ago as Chief of Police at the "suggestion" of Patrick F. O'Hara, Commissioner of Public Safety, was found dead today back of the garage of his home at 80 Seminary Avenue.

WASHINGTON, March 7--Attorney General Tom Clark asked the Supreme Court today to waive the usual waiting time and issue its mandate to John L. Lewis at once in a move to remove the threat of a soft coal strike on April 1.

To the Screen Editor: I HAVE read with great care an article by Jack Goodman in last Sunday's TIMES relative to the world premiere festivities in Salt Lake City of the motion picture "Ramrod," which I produced for Enterprise Studios.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- The House Merchant Marine Committee today reluctantly approved the waiving of ship safety requirements for another year but said "we were just plain lucky" that no disaster has occurred so far.

THE Saturday Night Hit Parade is scheduled to change networks beginning April 26. Now heard for forty-five minutes beginning at 9 o'clock on CBS, the program will be shortened to thirty minutes and will move over to NBC at the same time, in the spot now filled by the Roy Rogers Show.

THE question "What have music and politics to do with each other?" was discussed on THE NEW YORK TIMES radio program, "What's on Your Mind," broadcast from the Darien High School over Station WQXR last Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Louis R. Lautier, a Negro newspaper correspondent who earlier this week failed to obtain admission to the Congressional press galleries, called upon the Senate Rules Committee today to correct "this gross discrimination against "the Negro press."

THE veterans' organizations start in many ways, but always behind their origins has been some desire to perpetuate comradeship begun in arms and the parallel idea of protecting the interests -- moral or physical -- of these same men.
George Carson Moon, for many years a director of the American Chain and Cable Company, and former Mayor of Cranford, N.J., died yesterday in his home at 77 Park Avenue. He was 71 years old.

"I CAN'T teach you to write," a famous professor used to say, "but I think I can help you teach yourself." Courses in English Composition have been an interest of mine ever since I was in college: I even taught one for a little.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, said today it was his impression that the Democrats were making a "deliberate attempt" to delay Senate proceedings.

LETTUCE is one of the garden vegetables that lend themselves happily to succession planting. A freshly picked crop from April to December is now possible owing largely to the diverse and excellent varieties that have been developed in recent years and, since it is high time for the first planting, a careful selection must be made quickly from the catalogues.
A three-man Coast Guard board of investigation began an inquiry yesterday into the fire that swept the motor ship John Ericsson, the former Swedish American liner Kungsholm, at her pier here Friday.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- In an unprecedented move by the Navy Department, educators and historians were called upon today to help write the naval history of World War II.

LONDON, March 8 -- The British Government, following up its new "work-or-perish" campaign, will consider Tuesday whether to stop midweek sports events a ban which would affect the coming Joe Baksi-Bruce Woodcock heavyweight fight, the famed Grand National steeplechase, and might even bring about the cancellation of the time-honored all-England Wimbledon tennis championships and the international Walker Cup golf matches.
TOKYO, March 8 (U.P.) -- United States Ambassador George Atcheson, Jr., told the Japanese people today that American business interests were prepared to help Japan develop her peacetime economy.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, March 8 -- Lieut. Gen. V.P. Sviridov, Russian chairman of the Allied Control Council for Hungary, said "no" tonight to the United States note requesting an investigation of the recent Russian arrest of Bela Kovacs, former secretary of the Smallholders party.

LONDON, March 8 -- There are today approximately 3,680,000 German prisoners of war still detained outside their country and working for their conquerors. The fact that there is no recognized German Government provides legal justification under international law for their continued detention nearly two years after Germany's unconditional surrender.

CHICAGO, March 8 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United State Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salabe hogs, 500 head (estimated); total not given. Compared with week ago: Market 50 cents to $1 lower; least decline on hogs over 300 pounds and sows.
Congress in recent debates has served notice that a considerable cut in the military budget faces the armed services during the 1948 fiscal year.

Hans Heidemann pianist, gave his first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The youthful artist, who was born in Germany and came to this country in 1926, intended to appear in 1942, but had to postpone his local debut because of his induction into the armed forces.

A slight rise in reorders occurred in the ready-to-wear markets last week with emphasis on medium-priced suits, according to a market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.

THE doughnut is having its day -- its week, as a matter of fact, because manufacturers of this food, so typically American, have agreed that this is National Donut (that's the way they spell it) Week.

John L. Lewis's assertion before the Senate Labor Committee on Friday that "when the right to strike is limited or taken away from the workers in this country the form of government in America is changed" is one-half of a true statement. The other half is that if workers are able to change a law or a public policy solely by using the strike weapon the form of government is also changed.

LEIPZIG, Germany, March 8 -- Night clubs in Leipzig have been enjoying a heyday during the annual fair. But the biggest heyday of all is being enjoyed by the famed Auerbach's Keller, probably the only cabaret in Germany that is collecting real United States dollars from Americans, theoretically not supposed to have them.

BALTIMORE. AMONG the lesser known feats of H.L. Mencken is this: he wrote the play which launched the oldest "little" theatre in this country one November night thirty years ago. It was a one-acter called "The Artist" and the group of Baltimoreans who thus proclaimed rebellion against the "commercialism" of the theatre called themselves The Vagabond Players.

A large number of books on art and other literary property from the estates of the late Marie L. Russell and Hilda N. Loeb will be auctioned at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, tomorrow at 10:30 A.M. and 2 P.M. and on Tuesday at 2 P.M.

Youngsters may believe it when they are told that pussy willows appear in earliest spring simply to show off their warm fur coats. But the real reason is that Salix discolor, as the botanists call it, is a hardy shrub with early habits. It isn't as forward as the witch hazel, which blooms in the fall; but it pretty well sets the pace for all the spring shrubs.

ROCKETS -- At White Sands, N. M., nineteen V-2's, loaded with, scientists' instruments to gather data in the upper atmosphere, have been fired. Five failed to climb high over the desert in useful flights. The Germans did somewhat better at the Peenemunde Experiment Station on the Baltic.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Fiorello H. La Guardia, who co-sponsored the Norris-La Guardia AntiInjunction Act fifteen years ago, recommended to Congress today that Government power to seize and operate essential industry be continued in peacetime.

TO THE EDITOR: I read with great interest the recent letter regarding the Third Alarm Association and its activities. However, I think it would be fair to point out that the 255 Club, and not the Third Alarm Association, mans the Mobile Canteen at all

In most cities the prices of homes and the volume of sales of residences will decline this year, the National Association of Real Estate Boards reported yesterday on the basis of reports made to it in its forty-sixth semi-annual survey of the realty market.

EMMA SCHAVER, who will sing songs from displaced persons camps at the Festival of Jewish Arts at Carnegie Hall March 15, collected the songs while on a six-month tour of the American occupation zone of Germany. The tour was organized by the World Jewish Congress in collaboration with Army authorities and UNRRA officials.

Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the Committee for the Election of a Slate of Officers of the National -Republican Club Headed by W. Kingsland Macy, sent letters yesterday to members of the club urging them to support this ticket. It is opposed by a ticket headed by City Councilman Edward Rager.

MEXICO CITY -- The hills get higher closer to Mexico City. So do the prices. Smart hotels charge $8 a day minimum for a single without meals. At Ciro's a steak dinner for two with trimmings totes up to $15.
YENAN, China, March 7 (Delayed) -- With Kuomintang troops concentrating at Tchuan, fifty miles from here, Yenan is preparing for an all-out attack.

WHEN Erwin Blumenfeld was selling handbags in Holland twelve years ago, photography was his hobby. Today he is one of the highest paid fashion photographers in the United States, and his experiments with unusual techniques and new media mark him as an outstanding leader in imaginative photography.

OFFICIAL business biographies have come a long way from the sleazy glorifications of pre-1929 days, when the official historian's canvas was liberally ceated with whitewash. Today they bravely refer to past company derelictions, and although these usually manage to be of the minor-league variety, the modern business biographer can at least make a legitimate claim to objectivity.

AS an artist, Mr. Stephen Spender has always been something of a puzzle. Endowed with a richer sensibility and a purer lyric talent than most of the craftsmen of his generation, he has nevertheless emerged from among them rather as a name than as a poet: as a reputation, greatly promising, but in the event somehow disappointing.

JERUSALEM, March 8 -- In spectacular defiance of British martial law in Tel Aviv, Jewish terrorists made a concerted series of three attacks on army and police centers in the area tonight, bringing death to one British soldier and four of their own men.

SEVERAL more forecasts were made last week about the business outlook and when to expect the widely advertised recession. Satisfaction in the court victory of the Government over Mr. Lewis was short lived, and President Truman's cancellation of his vacation cruise brought back the jitters, this time from the international front.

THE Literary Life: A New York restaurant with a flossy cocktail bar, soliciting the trade of publicists for publishers who might want to give literary teas, has sent out a form letter setting forth the bistro's features (private dance floor, piped-in music) and concluding: "You're almost guaranteed favorable reviews under such chi-chi surroundings."
LONDON. THE theatre boom is over at last. There were signs, when I last wrote, that it might be ending soon, but the cold weather and the fuel crisis made its end sudden rather than protracted.

SIX months ago Scandinavian Airlines System, an airline pooling the commercial aviation resources of Norway, Sweden and Denmark, started regular passenger service between Europe and the United States. It was, admittedly, a modest start, but one which Scandinavians called an "experiment in practical internationalism" and hoped would grow to full size in time.

IF there is such a thing as viewing with a limited degree of alarm, that's what we're going to do this morning, in a round-about sort of way. And the grounds for this cautious agitation are the samples we've had of late of the misuse by movie producers of the so-called "documentary technique."

Issues concerning the Government, a large segment of the domestic steel industry and virtually all civic groups and business organizations on the West Coast are involved in two proposed curbs on activities of the United States Steel Corporation in that area coming up for argument this week.

The three defendants charged with being the "brains" behind Alvin J. Paris football bribery scheme were found guilty last night by a General Sessions jury of ten men and two women who had been deliberating nearly nine hours.

Time Fades Out Something was said in this column last Sunday about the strange fate which has over- taken the basic element, time, in our ordinary thinking. We have come so close to abolishing time. With the scientists it has been different.

THE kitchen cabinet always has a reliable, all-purpose cook book, and the basement work shop has a fix-it book, but less frequently does the home have a good reference book for the thousand and one cleaning jobs to be done in the house.

CHICAGO, March 8 -- The shortage of casting may precipitate a shutdown for some companies in the automobile industry before there is improvement in the supply, L.E. Roark, executive vice president of the National Founders Association, declared today.

KAPPA ALPHA MU, national pictorial journalism fraternity, announces its second annual Fifty Print Collegiate Photography Exhibition to which college and university students are invited to contribute. Deadline for entries is April 30.

Prayers for the Big Four Foreign Ministers Council opening tomorrow in Moscow will be offered in thousands of churches in the United States beginning today and continuing at every service while the Council remains in session.

Following an analysis of thirty additional Albany measures affecting housing in New York City that were introduced in the Legislature in the last two weeks, the committee on housing of the Community Service Society announced yesterday its endorsement of eight of these bills and opposition to seven others.

MOSCOW, March 8 -- United States radio correspondents will be able to broadcast from Moscow during the Council of Foreign Ministers Conference, which opens Monday, Michael. J. McDermott, press officer of the United States delegation announced today.

PETERSBURG, Va., March 8 (AP) -- Roberts Day ceremonies -- a tribute to the memory of Joseph Jenkins Roberts, the Virginia-born boatman and barber who became first president of the African Republic of Liberia -- will be observed here Friday night at Virginia State College in the city where he was born 138 years ago.

ARCADIA, Calif., March 8 -- On Trust captured the $100,000 added Santa Anita Derby today with a convincing victory over the $200,000 bay colt, Stepfather, and eleven other rival 3-year-olds in the tenth running before 60,000 fans.

The American Male Chorus, a group of thirty-two former service men who decided to stick together after being discharged, gave its first New York concert yesterday afternoon. Singing with skill, beauty of tone and affecting simplicity, it made an immediately favorable impression.

The United States Attorney's office for the Eastern District of New York was successful last year in the prosecution of more than 96 per cent of its criminal cases, United States Attorney J. Vincent Keogh announced yesterday in his annual report.

The Alcoa Cavalier, first of three new 14,870-displacement ton vessels being built on the Pacific Coast for the Alcoa Steamship Company, will be delivered to her owners before the middle of the week, the company officials announced here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- When B. Carroll Reece, Republican national chairman, appealed this week for party regularity among Republicans in Congress, he doubtless expected to hear from Senator Wayne Morse of Oregon. He heard.

MIAMI, Fla., March 8 (AP) --Defending champions Ben Hogan of Hershey, Fa., and Jimmy Demaret of Ojai, Calif., defeated Dick Metz, Chicago, and Chick Harbert, Detroit, 1-up on the thirty-sixth green tonight to enter the final round of the $10,000 international four-ball golf tournament.

MOSCOW, March 8 -- Generalissimo Stalin has protested against the "panegyrics" in his honor, "which grate upon the ear." It is "really uncomfortable to read them," he declared in a letter printed in the latest issue of the magazine Bolshevik.

A voluntary program of gradual and orderly price reductions now, in steps ranging from 5 to 10 per cent and involving a "squeeze" on profit margins, was urged upon manufacturers and retailers by the top executive of one of the country's outstanding stores in an interview here last week.
At the end of the first week of its campaign, the Red Cross 1947 Fund of Greater New York announced yesterday that it was approaching the $1,000,000 mark toward the New York City quota of $6,153,600.

Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, declared yesterday that "Governor Dewey sits kinglike on a huge surplus which is estimated to reach $627,000,000 by the end of the month." Despite this, he added, the Governor recommends to the Republicancontrolled Legislature two separate programs of nuisance taxes to defray the cost of the proposed soldiers' bonus of $400,000,000 and to assist the financially embarrassed cities of the State.

ST. LOUIS, March 8 (AP) -- Sweeping economies in the operation of St. Louis public schools were ordered today by the Board of Education following the defeat in a special election yesterday of three proposals designed to bolster the financial status of the school system.

Secretary of State Marshall was urged to avoid the mistakes of Yalta at the Moscow meeting of the Foreign Ministers and to support creation of "a federated Germany within a federated Europe," in a statement issued yesterday by the officers of Freedom House.

TO THE EDITOR: Congratulations to Judge Nochem S. Winnet on one of the most intelligent articles on delinquency ("The Real Delinquents -- Parents or Society?") written in many a month. We, in the United Parents Associations, have been greatly troubled by the continuous attacks on parents each time excesses are committed by young people.

JACKSON, Miss., March 8 -- Debt-free and author of a new book setting forth the creed of "white supremacy" so dear to his heart, Senator Theodore G. Bilbo is now resting at his "dream house" in Poplarville with assurances pouring in that his "popularity" in this State has increased immeasurably.

The writer of the following letter was for many years general counsel to the Port of New York Authority. Be is an authority on labor conditions and labor law, and the author of a number of books on legal and industrial problems.

ALAMOGORDO, N.M. -- White Sands National Monument, sprawling in the Tularosa Basin of southern New Mexico, will be the scene on April 12 of "the world's biggest picnic." On this second Saturday in April, following a custom begun in 1935, about 5,000 tourists will participate in a round of social and athletic activities.

Dr. Carl A. Whittaker of Emory University had as a patient a 26-year-old worker who was what the psychiatrists call a manic depressive. Everything was tried to aid the man-everything from shock therapy to land words. From Dr. Whittaker's presentation before the American Orthopsychiatric Association there was reason to believe that this was the familiar psychoanalytic case of a frightening experience in childhood.

Confident that they have shaken he slump into which they had fallen two weeks ago, the New York Rangers will skate against the Toronto Maple Leafs in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. The clash has attracted considerable attention among local fans and promises to attract a capacity crowd of almost 16,000.

"THE WORLD AND AFRICA" is the third statement of an important historical fact, voiced by the same author, in a period of thirty-two years. In 1915, after establishing a reputation as a sound historian and clear-thinking political scientist.
A three-man Coast Guard board of investigation began an inquiry yesterday into the fire that swept the motor ship John Ericsson, the former Swedish American liner Kungsholm, at her pier here Friday.

A FEW blossoms of Christmas rose (Helleborus niger) are probably still lingering under the snow or close to evergreens. The flowers of this perennial may be enjoyed any time between October and April, depending upon the whims of the individual plant.

IN her first show of oils and water-colors at the Macbeth Gallery, Dorothy Hoyt acquits herself well. This is fresh, personal, spirited work. If one or two of the larger pictures, such as "Under the Bridge," are not quite as satisfying as the smaller canvases, they nevertheless possess passages which indicate that a little more experience will bring the added integration.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 8 -- Tony Lavelli, Yale's ace marksman, went on a 32-point scoring spree to completely demoralize a favored Harvard five and pace Yale to a 60-38 triumph over the Cantabs before a prom crowd of 2,000 in the Payne Whitney gym tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee reported out a bill today to continue rationing and price control of sugar but with its operations transferred from the Office of Price Administration to the Department of Agriculture.

Joseph Curran, vice president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and head of the Greater New York CIO Council, directed a formal denunciation yesterday at the Trade Union Committee for Democracy, organized last week by delegates of Right-Wing CIO unions to oppose Communist influences.

IN the slam-bidding method of the leading players, there is one recent development which is noteworthy even though it is not particularly significant. After ten years and more in which they expressed the utmost scorn of the Blackwood and other aceshowing props to slam-bidding, the experts in general have been turning to the Blackwood convention, at least for occasional use.

Guaranteed prices for the first Six months of 1947 have withstood the test of advancing raw materials prices, H.L. Edinger, president, Barnett Foundry and Machine Company, Irvington, N.J., disclosed here yesterday. Despite recent sharp increases in prices of metal scrap and pig iron, guaranteed prices have proved to be good business, Mr. Edinger said, and he recommended his formula to other industries seeking to aid price stabilization.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 8 -- The United Nations Economic and Social Council gave its approval today to the projected International Trade Organization, which is to consult and advise member nations on the broad subject of economic development throughout the world.

SALONIKA, Greece, March 8 -- The differences within the United Nations commission of inquiry into guerrilla activities in northern Greece are multiplying. Last night's open meeting of the commission ended on a note of mutual criticism and indication, which diplomatic suavity and attempts at conciliation could not conceal.

War housing projects designed for permanent occupancy are being acquired by private interests, veterans and tenant groups in increasing numbers, according to the National Association of Housing Officials. Some deals are being made on a "cooperative" basis, but other homes are being disposed of in individual units.

RHINESTONE GULCH, as any confirmed novel-reader knows, is littered with the bones of writers who have tried to explore, and explain, its frenetic heart-beat; the casualties are highest among those novelists who insist that Broadway's heart, for all its brassy carapace, is really a heart of gold.

Edwin A. Osborne, veteran newspaper man of the Rockaways, who had been a member of THE NEW YORK TIMES staff for twenty-two years, died yesterday morning in St. Joseph's Hospital, for Rockaway, Queens, after an illness of four months.

VALERIE BETTIS is not one to run away from a challenge. Having given a number of solo recitals in the modern dance category and tried a composition or two for group in the concert field, she blossomed out earlier this season as choreographer for a Broadway musical, "Beggar's Holiday," and now has taken a leap into the field of the ballet.

JERUSALEM, March 8 -- As far as the Zionists of Palestine are cerned, there is only one way to stop terrorism: not by barbed martial law or repeated searches but by increasing Jewish immigration from Europe.

If any of City College's 32,000 students happened to be on the campus yesterday afternoon, they would probably have seen the future coach of the college's football team -- but not if he saw them first.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 8 -- A subcommittee of the United Nations Security Council is virtually deadlocked on its findings in the dispute between Britain and Albania over mines allegedly sown by Albania in Corfu Channel.

Former Senator Guy M. Gillette, president of the American League for a Free Palestine, Inc., announced last night that his organization was preparing to use "every possible appeal of statecraft and maritime law to neutralize the British action" in seizing the Jewish refugee ship Abril.
PEOPLE ask why "parent education" is needed now when earlier generations -- bringing up well adjusted children to be good citizens -- got along without it.

THE cook's handiest aids might be called her pots and pans, for the better they are in design and construction the better her performance. Since supplies of them are again becoming normal in retail stores, it may be appropriate to discuss the factors that contribute to intelligent purchasing.

IF producers Had the magical powers of leprechauns, and dramatists saw eye to eye with economists, either things would have been brighter in Glocca Morra months ago or "Finian's Rainbow" never would have appeared over Broadway's horizon.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The National Catholic Conference on Family Life has chosen Mrs. Math Lies, of Andale, Kan., as the Catholic Mother for 1947, it was announced today.
After an easier start, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange recovered yesterday and closed with net gains of 37 to 60 points.

MIAMI BEACH, March 8 -- Rip Sewell, perhaps, expressed it best. "You jes' gotta get acquainted all over again with our ball club," drawled the blooper-ball expert. The Pittsburgh Pirates have new owners, a new manager, a covey of new ball players and a new spirit. They even may be one of the most interesting teams of them all before the season has progressed very far.

TEN years ago in this Review: George Macaulay Trevelyan's "Grey of Fallodon" was the event of the week, and P.W. Wilson achieved the well-nigh incredible feat of reviewing it without quoting the Viscount's "the lights have gone out." . . .

Industrial engineering and construction volume will be greater this year than in 1946 and may even attain an all-time peak as materials become more plentiful, prices become stabilized and Government controls are relaxed, in the opinion of five executives of the H.K. Ferguson Company, industrial engineers and builders of New York, Cleveland and Houston.

ON Orleans Street, not so long ago, they used to show you Pere Antoine's date-palm and tell how it grew from the grave of a little girl -- daughter of Pere Antoine's boyhood sweetheart -- cared for by the good priest after the death of her parents.

Public Relations Director, Regional Plan Association BULLDOZERS are snorting in Middlesex County, N.J., clearing the right of way for the first section of New Jersey's first parkway. To the New Jersey-New York-Connecticut metropolitan region, start of work on this parkway system means filling a long-existing gap in the area's highways.

PHILADELPHIA, March 8 -- A survey of commercial traffic likely to use the Panama Canal up to 1985 was completed here today. It is part of a re-evaluation program to determine whether future use of the waterway will be great enough to necessitate modification of present facilities or the construction of a new canal.
CHICAGO, March 8 (AP) -- All grains advanced in a strong market on the Board of Trade today, responding to an increase in the Government's buying price for flour and to higher cash markets.
PEIPING, March 8 (AP) -- Racing the weather with a drive aimed at Communist-held Harbin, Chinese Government forces in Manchuria have crossed the frozen Sungari River in strength.

Passage of a modified version of the Hawkes bill to increase rent ceilings on residential space was predicted yesterday by the National Home and Property Owners Foundation, which claims that "a substantial majority" of members of both branches of Congress would support the Hawkes proposal, after changes are made.

PHILADELPHIA, March. 8 -- Coming with a rush in the last half, Columbia, recently crowned Eastern Intercollegiate League champions, defeated Pennsylvania at the Palestra tonight, 68-59, before 4,500 spectators, including many New Yorkers and a trio of high-spirited cheer leaders.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 8 -- Dr. Everett R. Clinchy, president of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, declared here today that for political peace, economic prosperity and personal happiness, psychological distances between the cultures of the world must be reduced.

CRISTOBAL, C.Z. -- For the perplexed American tourist who wants to travel by ship but cannot get accommodations for months in advance, the Panama Canal can solve a lot of problems. The drawback, of course, is that United States travelers have become "reservation conscious" and hesitate to start off without a good idea of where they are going and how and when they will start and when they will arrive.
The New York Knickerbockers scored a 64-61 triumph over the Detroit Falcons last night in a Basketball Association of America contest.

BERLIN, March 8 -- Secretary of State Marshall said today that the negotiation of the four-power forty-year alliance proposed by the United States was of utmost importance and should precede the attempt to write a peace treaty for Germany.

ANDREW JOHNSON'S reputation, personal and political, has enjoyed a renovation of late years by the historians, who have removed the calumny with which it was encrusted by the Radicals. Furthermore, he has gained stature as a courageous man, a sincere and consistent democrat, and a sound constitutionalist.

While the spring handicap list of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association just released contains no startling revisions, there are some changes and some omissions of top women golfers on the list of the 442 made public to date.

MR. SMITH, who has written extensively on Far Eastern affairs and was with the OWI in India during the war, is convinced that Americans have a jaundiced view of British policy in India and have not sufficiently heard the British side of the "so-called Indian problem."

NEWARK, N. J., March 8 -- Concession of a seven-goal handicap proved no barrier to the Ramapo poloists tonight as they subdued the Squadron A Black Knights, 17 to 12, in a Metropolitan Indoor Polo League match at Essex Troop Armory. The strong Ramapo trio buried its foes under a 10-2 count in the last half.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.T., March 8 -- Between 100 and 300 employes of the United Nations will be dismissed within the next five weeks, it was learned today.

CHICAGO, March 8 -- In announcing a four-point program aimed at improving the country's educational outlook, the Congress of Parents and Teachers called today for Federal aid to States for schools "on the basis of need" and higher teacher salaries.

BALTIMORE, March 8 (AP) -- A 32-year-old Negro Army veteran filed suit against the Maryland Institute of the Fine Arts today, alleging it discriminates against Negroes while receiving money from the municipal budget for the education of local students.

NEWS from Albany suggesting that there might be additional taxes to burden the box office touched off a roar of protest last week indicating that any move in that direction would meet with the stiffest kind of opposition.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- John L. Lewis is back where he started in November, from a legal, contractual point of view. His bargaining advantage and his prestige have been impaired, too. Add to that, $710,000 in fines, thousands of dollars in legal fees and millions in lost wages.

TOKYO, March 8 -- The Japanese Government decided today to introduce in the Diet next week a blanket law to permit the establishment of Government corporations authorized to handle critical materials necessary for rebuilding the national economy and the wrecked export trade.

Governor Dewey commended the broadcasting industry yesterday for its vigilance in keeping the radio free of control by government and minority groups. The result is that the American listening public is the best informed in the world, he said.

Showing a more coordinated attack, the 13-goal New York Athletic Club side scored its second victory in three Metropolitan League high-goal indoor polo starts last night by riding to a 15-10 triumph over the Squadron A regulars at the latter's armory.

The Long Island Rail Road asked the Public Service Commission in Albany yesterday to authorize increases in commutation fares and other passenger rates. A petition filed with the commission requested an investigation of "greatly increased costs of operation."

LAHORE, Punjab, India, March 8 (Reuters) -- Four hundred armed raiders, said to be Moslems, boarded the Peshawar-bound Frontier Mail train at Chaklala near the fortress city of Rawalpindi in the northern Punjab and pushed out Sikh passengers while the train was still running, it was learned here tonight.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., March 8 -- John McArdle, Syracuse heavyweight, scored his third straight knockout victory to win the team title for his university in the twenty -fourth Intercollegiate Boxing Association tourney tonight when he stopped pudgy Joe Corletto of Western Maryland in 1 minute 50 seconds of the second round.

PARIS, March 8 -- A compromise was agreed upon today to end the three-week-old Paris newspaper strike which threatened the existence of several large dailies. It was submitted to Premier Paul Ramadier's Government late this afternoon.

NANKING, March 8 -- After investigating the complicated Shanghai money market, a Control Yuan committee has issued a ten-thousand -word report taxing the former President of the Executive Yuan, T.V. Soong, with responsibility for the "gold rush" that led to the serious financial panic of last month.

To the Radio Editor: YOUR article in last Sunday's Times was most interesting to us of the United Parents Associations, because we too feel that the potentialities of better radio programming for children have not been met.

BUENOS AIRES, March 8 (U.P.) -- President Juan D. Peron today called for an all-out struggle to crush his opponents. He described them as the "enemies of Argentine economic independence -- the remnants of the oligarchy, opposition politicians, Communists and the press."

The promises of the League of Nations regarding Palestine must be kept by its successor, the United Nations, should it be called upon to act, Mrs. Moses P. Epstein, national president of Hadassah, the women's Zionist Organization of America, said last night.

THIS is the war story of a house dress, one of those comfortable and homey garments that millions of American women wear. It's a story that began in Washington in December, 1942, and ended in Budapest just a few weeks ago.

From time to time Harry Truman likes to get away from a job that entails, in the words of Thomas Jefferson, "unceasing drudgery." Last week Mr. Truman escaped from the White House drudgery for a while. He was on tour, but the tour lasted a much shorter time than he had planned.

(Originator and Producer of "The Life of Riley" on NBC.) NOBODY in his right mind is envious of the bigwigs in network radio whose function it is to keep Mr. Sponsor and Mr. Public happy at the same time.

Ground is scheduled to be broken within six weeks for a $2,000,000 community development in Teaneck, N.J., which will provide thirty stores, sixty-four offices and living quarters for 230 families. Present plans call for the project to be ready for occupancy by Oct. 1.

HOLLYWOOD. BYRON PRICE, board chairman of the Motion Picture Producers Association, who will leave the industry next week for a post with the United Nations, told a group of financial writers and editors last Tuesday that studio operating costs must be reduced to weather a prospective decline in revenue.

Faced with a rapidly deteriorating foreign situation and conflicting statements emanating from Washington, the financial community saw the stock market last week undergoing its worst break in four months. The drop coincided with President Truman's cancellation of his Caribbean cruise and the call for a meeting with Congressional leaders of both parties tomorrow to discuss international affairs; it was the fourth consecutive week of declining security prices.

DUBLIN, N.H. THE OLD FARMER'S ALMANAC warns that the weather at this time of writing will be "blustery and rough." Here in the Old Farmer's present home town, that's just what the weather is. The bus had difficulty getting up the long grade this side of Peterborough; the slopes of near-by Mount Monadnock are half hidden by snow flurries, and the mercury is close to zero.

New York's most famous storm was rehashed again yesterday when the Blizzard Men of 1888 held their eighteenth annual reunion and luncheon at the Hotel Pennsylvania to swap yarns about their experiences on that momentous March 12.

Following publication of notice by the Commissioner of Internal Revenue of the proposed Treasury regulations under the Income Tax Convention between the United States and the United Kingdom, the public has been invited to file with the commissioner objections to such regulations or comments thereon by March 24.

AT the moment this department is suffering from an acute attack of literary indigestion. It was brought on, probably, by too much indiscriminate sampling of the current printed word. I found myself reacting violently against a lot of things that get between the covers of books and into the pages of magazines.
The American Hospital Association, through its Advertising Council, said yesterday that it had started an intensive national campaign to recruit students for schools of nursing.

BERLIN, March 7 -- Male teachers in Bavaria will under no circumstances be subordinated to female principals, according to Dr. Alois Hundhammer, Bavarian Minister of Culture. At the same time he declared himself in favor of corporal punishment in the grammar grades.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- Representative Albert Gore, Democrat, of Tennessee, proposed today that Congress save $33,000,000 in the 1948 budget by cutting the interest rate on income tax refunds in two.

Now that the Senate has disposed of a question of committee jurisdiction, it is reasonable to hope for prompt action in Congress on President Truman's bill for unification of the armed forces. Certainly there is no good reason to delay matters through extensive hearings which would merely retrace all of the ground already covered.
John Kramer and Miss Pauline Betz of Los Angeles, the national champions on turf, extended their tennis dominion to the indoor realm yesterday.
The writer of the following letter was formerly editor and publisher of The North China Star, a daily Englishlanguage newspaper published in Tientsin.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., March 8 (AP) -- Illinois, grabbing five firsts, easily retained its Big Nine indoor track title as three new conference records were established and two, as well as an American indoor mark, were equalled in the league's thirty-seventh championships tonight.

THIS is the first full account of what will undoubtedly be a considerable library on the Battle for Leyte Gulf, and it is well that it is the first; for future laborers in the vineyard will now be forced to do their required reading in a volume everywhere readable, accurate and soundly constructed.

BOSTON, March 8 -- A strong sentiment has developed in New England in favor of the International Trade Organization which it is proposed to set up under the auspices of the United Nations. In general, business, industrial and civic groups approve moderate tariff concessions in the proposed ITO charter.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, March 8 -- Lieut. Gen. Lucius D. Clay's stern warning to the last session of the German Council of States that they must find means to absorb the Germans expelled from the East permanently is now filtering down to the lower echelons of German officials and to the expelled Germans.
When LeMoyne College completes its new campus, now being created on a 117-acre site outside Syracuse, it will have a well-developed course in Industrial relations.

FOR years the complaint of theatre owners was that the big producing companies dictated what pictures they could show. Now a situation has come to light wherein the theatre owners are depriving the public of the right to see a certain picture.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee reported out a bill today to continue rationing and price control of sugar but with its operations transferred from the Office of Price Administration to the Department of Agriculture.

TO THE EDITOR: The article "The Female Is Less Deadly Than the Male," by Helen Bryant, did not pursue the problem far enough. Even the psychologists missed the answer. Every woman driver has her own private pixie or gremlin who not only permits but urges her to wheel her car freely through any sort of traffic with a fine and fantastic disregard of rules, courtesy or the laws of physics without incurring the normal penalties.

"THE MEMOIRS OF DR. FELIX KERSTEN" is sure to cause a ripple among those readers who are still trying to keep abreast of the post-war documents being published in such profusion. There have been many now-it-can-be-told books by war correspondents, and by statesmen and by military men, but never before a book by Heinrich Himmler's osteopath.

Provision for competent teachers at adequate salaries is inescapable and to make it we may have to go without some of the things we now enjoy, Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican, of New York, declared yesterday.

THANKS to greatly improved varieties, the vogue of fibrous -rooted bedding begonias has increased in the last few years. The newcomers are hardier and of far more prolific growth and bloom than the oldfashioned Vernon or wax begonias of our grandmothers.

OTTAWA, March 8 -- Canadian resentment against exclusion from the Moscow conference was the subject-matter of a whole day's debate in the House of Commons this past week. No conclusion was arrived at, but the speeches indicated how strong and growing is the distrust among all parties of the approach of the big powers to the problem of making peace.

NEW DELHI, India, March 8 -- The predominantly Hindu Congress party today invited its rival, Mohammed Ali Jinnah's Moslem League, to get together with it and prepare for next year's British withdrawal from India.

The nation's retailers solidly support a proposal recently unanimously reported out by the House of Representatives Committee on Veterans Affairs which would substantially increase compensation ceilings for veterans participating in accredited on-the-job training programs under Public Law 346, an executive training director for a large nation-wide department store chain said last week.

A NOTABLE selection of work by contemporary French artists has opened at the Bignou Gallery. One piece of sculpture is included -- a late bronze torso by Maillol with all the characteristic poise and strength associated with that artist's best work.

IN a country given to striking contrasts, the strangest of all, in view of our national history, is that disclosed by our tremendous capacity for patriotism in time of war and our general indifference to public affairs in peace. In an emergency we do not hesitate to sacrifice our greatest treasure -- the younger generation -- and to mortgage our financial future for decades to come in almost prodigal expenditures for our national defense.
NEW DELHI, March 8 (AP) -- Official reports here showed today that 192 persons had been killed and 580 wounded in riots this week in Punjab Province.

NEW ORLEANS, March 8 (AP) -- B.F. Whitaker's sturdy filly, Carolyn A., slushed through, the mud at the Fair Grounds today to win the $20,000 added Louisiana Derby by three lengths from William Helis' Lady's Ace. Jobstown another Helis entry, ran third, and Mrs. M.E. Rizen's Ekard was fourth.

Just as the curtain on the Moscow Conference was about to be rung up the curtain went flown on an English geographer who probably knew as much as any man about the vast and long-term issues involved. His name was Halford John Mackinder and he was 86 years old when he died in London on Friday.

A basic design for standard health center units and a modern 256-bed hospital to be erected in Greece has been completed by Kokkins Lyras, New York architects. John Kokkins and construction engineers have already left for Greece to supervise and expedite the construction of the first twenty units.

REMEMBER the fabric shortage of 1945? Decorators, we were told, would rush to the telephone and announce breathlessly to a client: "I've found fifty yards!" Equally breathlessly, the client would reply, "Take it," never stopping to ask.
