LONDON, March 8 -- Another aspect of Britain's commitments in the Eastern Mediterranean -- those in Turkey -- is expected to be discussed officially with the United States before long, an authoritative source said today.

"DESIGN FOR AGGRESSION" presents the general objectives of German political and military plans from about 1937 until the invasion of the Low Countries in 1940, as revealed in secret German documents. When the Third Reich ceased to exist in the spring of 1945, the invading Allies recovered nearly the whole political and military archives of the German State, an event "without precedent or parallel in history."

By way of emphasizing his solitary grandeur in the distancerunning field, Gilbert Dodds rang down the curtain on New York's major indoor track and field season by registering a smashing double at one mile and two miles last night at Madison Square Garden.
LEIPZIG, Germany, March. 8 -- Some hint of the effect of Russian demobilization on the occupation forces in the Soviet zone was given today by Gen. F. Kominsky, commander in the Leipzig area.

THE twisted tongue is the occupational disease of radio broadcasting. Announcers, commentators, actors, novices and veterans alike live in terror of the verbal fluff that turns an innocent phrase into a bit of bawdy banter or comical nonsense, causing censors to sputter and listeners to guffaw.

"THE EAGLE'S BROOD," the Columbia Broadcasting System's documentary broadcast on juvenile delinquency, was an angry, tough and eloquent piece. In purest form it was a crusade against public apathy, a crusade told in the persuasive imagery of words, music and stagecraft.

NEW CANAAN, March 8 -- Leaders in labor, management, the public and the Government will take part in a symposium on "Labor Relations in the American Economy" under the auspices of the Student Association of the Yale Law School on March 21 and 22.

MOZART, Wagner and Schumann have had a goodly amount of biographical attention recently; but, oddly enough, Karl Geiringer's new book is the first full-length life and critical study of Joseph Haydn to appear in English in some forty years.

Sarkis, Katchadourian of 48 West Fifty-sixth Street, internationally known painter, died March 3 in Paris, France, where he had been invited by the French Government to exhibit his Indian frescoes and paintings, it was learned here yesterday. His age was 58.

An all-time record for buyer attendance and variety of exhibits is expected to feature the fortyfourth American Toy Fair which opens tomorrow at the McAlpin Hotel and at permanent showrooms at 200 Fifth Avenue, 1,107 Broadway, the Hotel Breslin and other buildings.

January and February provided the first test of severe cancellations on a leading durable goods industry, refrigeration equipment manufacturers disclosed here yesterday. In this industry, while cancellations have been large, far greater than anyone had expected, canceled orders have been largely replaced by new orders, thus providing a more dependable backlog of business for the balance of the year.

IN the course of Wilde's bright and endless chitchat in "The Importance of Being Earnest," one of the characters gravely declares: "In matters of grave importance, style, not sincerity, is the vital thing." No doubt Mr. Gielgud has other motives, including his own knowledge of the stage, for the immaculate and detached manner of the brilliant performance of the comedy which he brought to the Royale Theatre on Monday evening.
HOLLYWOOD. ETHEL HILL'S sale of her screen story, "War Knight," to Liberty Films for production by George Stevens was timed to coincide with the recent auction of Louis B. Mayer's racing stable.

MEXICO CITY. BALBUENA AIRPORT here, which has just given Harry Truman a chance to get both feet on the ground, has for some time been quivering under the arrival and departure of enough Hollywood performers to keep local gossip columnists in a perpetual frenzy.

"THE fundamental tenet of communism is that the state is an end in itself, and that therefore the powers which the state exercises over the individual are without any ethical standards to limit them." That is a recent observation of David Lilienthal, whom even our shrill fellow-travelers could hardly classify as a "reactionary."

Dept. of English, Cornell University THE long line of translators of Petrarch beginning with Chaucer contains many illustrious names: Spenser, Wyatt, Surrey, the Countess of Pembroke, Sir John Harington, Leigh Hunt and, in our own time, J.M. Synge, Joseph Auslander and Morris Bishop.

PLANT orders made out at this time usually are based on some mental picture of the display to be provided. Sometimes the inexperienced gardener is disappointed when the blooming season comes, to find that his plants make less of a showing than he expected, or even that they do not flower at all the first season.

LONDON, March 8 -- The Government warned again today that the restarting of industry and continued bad weather required the utmost economy in the use of gas and electricity. Railwaymen were urged to make a supreme effort to make up the arrears in the movement of coal.

Curtis, representing Richmond, and Franklin K. Lane of South Queens brought the total number of teams in the city Public High School basketball championship tournament quarter-final round up to six by winning their opening tests at the Sixty-Ninth Regiment Armory yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- James J. Maloney, chief of the Secret Service, has refused to bargain with Chinese officials for the plates used in making bogus $20 and $50 bills which have turned up in this country.

NOWADAYS arranging the transportation for a Metropolitan tour is quite a headache. In the old days the management could pack the whole company in one train and breath a sigh of relief. But now the principal artists have so many radio and concert commitments that an elaborate system of dovetailing engagements has to be worked out.

WESTFIELD, N.J., March 8 -- Local talent took a good share of the honors today in Westfield Troop's Memorial Fund Horse Show sponsored by 50th Cavalry Reconnaisance Squadron and Union County Park Commission.

MOSCOW, March 8 -- Moscow awaits the opening of the Council of Foreign Ministers meeting, confident of the wisdom of the Soviet policy toward Germany but conscious of the differences that exist between the Russian concept and the policies of the United States.

A plan unique in the history of the twelve-year-old Public Utility Holding Company Act will be presented tomorrow to the Federal Court in Boston when the New England Gas and Electric Association seeks approval of its "alternative" plan of recapitalization.

FOR THIS WEEK: Start seed of aster, calendula and Cobea scandens indoors. Outdoors scatter seeds of larkspur and poppy on the snow, where they are to flower. . . . Tuberous-rooted begonias and gloxinias are sometimes slow to sprout and even with plenty of heat may take almost two months. Then they are planted in four-inch pots with a rich soil mixture. . . .

ITHACA, N. Y., March 8 -- The Syracuse basketball team overpowered Cornell, 45 -- 30, before a record crowd of more than 9,000 tonight to close its season with nineteen victories in twenty-four games.
OMAHA, March 8 -- The Government is finding it increasingly expensive to buy in Midwestern grain markets to feed hungry peoples abroad.

CHICAGO, March 8 -- The International Harvester Company announced today it would put into effect before April 1 a series of price cuts that will save customers $20,000,000 a year. The action is being taken, said Fowler McCormick, chairman of the board, because the company feels that all industry has been caught in a "vicious circle" of progressively, rising prices, profits and wages.

MOSCOW, March 8 (U.P.) -- The steering committee of the central committee of the Communist Party in White Russia, following the lead of the Ukrainian party early this week, has voted to split the tasks of the first secretary of the central committee, the most powerful party post, and the chairmanship of the Council of Ministers, the highest Government post.

BATAVIA, Java, March 8 (AP) -- Dutch harbor authorities began unloading the $3,000,000 cargo of rubber and quinine today from the privately chartered United States liberty ship Martin Behrman seized yesterday by Dutch police and marines.

PROFESSOR WOOD'S book, a survey of Australia's resources by a team of experts, reminds us that the revolution in Australia's trade will place her in an international position comparable to that of the United States, Canada and probably Argentina.

Mayor O'Dwyer's plan to convert the New York City Housing Authority into a three-man agency, whose salaried chairman and two volunteer associates would be his own appointees, has struck a serious snag at Albany, according to reports reaching the city yesterday.

OF all the survivors of the Hitler era in Europe perhaps the most tragic and the most desperate are the "unaccompanied children" -- the orphans of the ghettos, concentration camps and slave labor forces who lost every precious thing except their lives. In the American zone of Germany, living still within a few kilometers of prison camps which now hold their old torturers, are some 6,200 of them.

LONDON, March 8 -- Greece is the great test of whether the United States is ready to take over the responsibilities that go with world leadership. That, at any rate, is the way it looks from London. Shorn of its diplomatic verbiage, the Greek problem is basically that of checking Soviet expansion toward the key strategic area of the eastern Mediterranean.

CHICAGO, March 8 -- Renewal of the campaign for enactment by the Illinois Legislature of a State fair employment practices law, which would combine the best features of the New York and Massachusetts statutes, has not only dropped a "hot potato" into the laps of the lawmakers at Springfield, but it has had repercussions in the Chicago mayoralty contest.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- After a week of shock and buffeting within Republican ranks, the party leadership was making an intensive hunt for unity over this weekend.

MUSICIANS, by and large, are justly famous for their story-telling, but not many of them make good subjects for autobiographies. Mr. Szigeti is an engaging and intelligent man, and furnishes a pleasant exception to this rule.

ON the 100th anniversary, last Monday, of enactment of legislation by Congress authorizing use of stamps to prepay postage on mail, the Postoffice Department made available the designs of the postage stamp, the souvenir sheet and the airmail stamped envelope which will be issued to commemorate the Centenary International Philatelic Exhibition at the Grand Central Palace here on May 17-25.

Retail sales gain here narrowed during the week ended March 8. Department store volume was estimated at 5 to 10 per cent over last year. At this time in 1946, consumer buying of spring ready-towear and accessories was substantially heavier than that currently reported.

Extending the decline of the previous day, the stock market ended yesterday's abbreviated session at the lowest levels since January. Prices on the Stock Exchange opened fractionally to a point lower in the broadest and most active Saturday since Feb. 8.

The Society of the Classic Guitar presented its third concert last night at Carnegie Chamber Music Hall. The artist it sponsored was Roland Valdes-Blain, who played in the same hall six years ago in a joint recital with his brother, Albert.

Complete acceptance of an international bill of rights can be achieved only by increased education among all the nations of the world, according to pupils who participated yesterday in the Youth Forum sponsored by the NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast over Station WQXR.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 8 -- Confronted by a serious educational crisis school leaders of the United States, meeting here for their first post-war conference, mapped a constructive program designed to improve the nation's schools and restore public confidence in education.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- President Truman, faced by the withdrawal of Britain from economic support of Greece, began today a crucial week-end of shaping a policy for American plans and responsibilities abroad.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- President Truman asked his council of economic advisers today to study the "economic implications" of the guaranteed annual wage as an aid to the stabilization of employment, production and purchasing power.

BUFFALO, March 8 -- Buffalo has committed itself to a general pay increase for its municipal employes -- about 10,000, including 3,000 teachers -- and in doing so has given Mayor Bernard J. Dowd an almost insuperable problem to meet before the budget deadline on March 15.

ATLANTA, March 8 -- While Georgians await the State Supreme Court's decision on the question of who is the State's legal Governor, some officials looking beyond court settlement of the controversy foresee a continuing bitter feud in the State Democratic party and the likelihood of a strong rival party movement.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Organized labor is definitely on the defensive. This is the outstanding conclusion of observers at the hearing conducted for nearly five weeks by the labor committees of both houses of Congress.

Back in 1922 it was suggested in a paper read before the State Medical Association of Texas that scopolamine, widely used in childbirth, might enable the police to drug the truth out of a criminal or a suspect Since then sedatives have been administered with considerable success in plumbing the unconscious minds of neurotics whose troubles are thus traced to Incidents which have been either forgotten or deliberately suppressed as memories.

GRAPES are one of the best small fruits for the home grounds. They can be used as fresh fruit, in jams and jellies, for grape Juice or wines. The vines can be grown over arbors that will provide a pleasant, shaded outdoor sitting room in hot weather.

EAGERLY jumping the gun, not waiting, quite, for St. Patrick's Day, the Irish have arrived, on an "exchange" basis, at the Associated American Artists Galleries. And it is indeed a good show that they offer: large, though not too large, representing an even dozen contemporary painters, most of whom are new to us.

Under New York State law teachers and other public employes who stay away from work without permission may suffer penalties ranging up to discharge. But the penalties are not mandatory, seldom are invoked.

Anyone can buy a dog: but the momentary pulse of omnipotence that most of us feel as the money changes hands is of short duration, and usually only a brief time passes before it becomes questionable as to who "acquired" whom.

HOLLYWOOD. THE current cost of production in Hollywood has reached alarming levels, as evidenced by the fact that David O. Selznick was able to spend $5,250,000 on "Duel in the Sun" before he began to advertise the picture or prepare prints for distribution.

PINKHAM NOTCH, N.H., March 8 -- Seventeen-year-old Brooks Dodge of Pinkham Notch, skiing in his own back yard today won the United States Eastern downhill championship. He covered the mile and three-tenths of the Wildcat Trail in 2 minutes 16 seconds flat, only one second off Bob Meservy's amateur record for the course, pacing a field of sixty-one starters.

With coat, suit and millinery sections crowded with pre-Easter purchasers, department store sales activity was good last week, according to a survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Also busy were women's dresses, neckwear, handbags, infants and lamp departments.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 8 -- The stormiest debates in United Nations history are expected when the organization tackles the question of Palestine.

LONDON, March 8 (Reuters) -- Winter dealth British soccer the severest blow in the history of the Football Association today when twenty-seven of forty-four games scheduled in the English league were postponed because of frozen, snowbound fields.

AFTER nineteen years of experimenting, the radio networks are still faced with the problem of how to present an admittedly "educational" music broadcast without giving it a stuffy classroom atmosphere. But now in devoting some of their best adult thought to it, they are coming close to a solution that may surpass the straight radio concert by virtue of freshness and unity of idea.

THE Indian literature of "The Winged Serpent" is preceded by two long and sensitive essays by the editor of the anthology, Mrs. Margot Astrov, a European-trained authority on the aboriginal inhabitants of North and South America.

A world-wide trend away from free enterprise and toward various forms of socialism and communism was shown in a survey published last week by THE NEW YORK TIMES. Two world wars and a world depression have broken down private capitalism virtually everywhere except in the United State's and Canada.

Scientific experiments, carried out in the stokehold of a British tramp steamer, have shown that smoke can be eliminated and coal saved by a simple and inexpensive device. British merchant ships consume about 5,000,000 tons of bunker coal a year. Though not all the coal burned produces smoke, the total saving is considerable.

TOKYO, March 8 -- Efforts of Premier Shigeru Yoshida to have Hiroo Wada, former Minister of Agriculture and Forestry, head the Empire's "Cabinet level" Economic Stabilization Board have ended in failure. Mr. Wada, whose appointment on Feb. 21 started an intense battle within the Liberal party over his "too liberal economic ideas," announced yesterday that his conditions had not been fulfilled and that he was refusing to accept the post.

NYACK is a mighty uncommon place. Situated twenty or so miles from Manhattan, it by rights should be only another bedroom to New York. Like the Westchester towns across the Hudson and the Jersey towns to the southwest, its theoretical function should be no more than providing a place for the weary commuter to rest his head.

Before a crowd of 22,181 persons, believed to be the largest turnout ever to watch an indoor schoolboy meet hereabouts, Mount St. Michael High School of the Bronx ended Bishop Loughlin's thirteen-year reign as kingpin at the twentieth track and field championships of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

AGAINST the novels written for wholesale consumption, the fantasies of Frank Baker are an unfailing delight to those who have the necessary passport to his world. Without that passport -- namely, the dreamer's disconcern with logic -- readers may find Mr. Baker's world as bewildering as Mr. Baker's own habit of dressing in the fashions of another century and composing his books by candlelight.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 8 (AP) -- Eternal Reward, stretch-running colt that astounded the turf world when he won the American Derby at Chicago's Washington Park last summer, created no surprise at Gulfstream Park today in capturing the first running of the Biscayne Bay Handicap.

CONSUMER'S GUIDE -- The Department of Commerce has published a forecast of industrial trends and trade prospects for the remaining months of 1947. On the theory that people like to know what's in store for them, we offer the following piquant digest: Enough meat to provide every American with about 150 pounds.

TO THE EDITOR: Re "The Real Delinquents -- Parents or Society?" by Judge Winnet of Philadelphia: Nowhere in my writings, or in public statements made, did I say that "fault means neglect" or that it is the fault of parents that children are delinquent. The fact is that children are delinquent because of faulty parents.

In view of the possibility of the lifting of all limitations on commercial and industrial construction work later this year, builders are being warned against the danger of creating an over-supply of new space such as plagued property owners during the depression.

HAROLD LAMB, memorable for "Genghis Khan" and "Alexander of Macedon," now offers his first full-length work of fiction. It can be said at once that the chief fault with Mr. Lamb's lush imagination is its range.

THE lady who wrote this charming book -- a sequel to her previously successful "Headhunting in the Solomon Islands" -- modestly admits to a "primitive sense of humor." That isn't the half of it. She recounts here with balance and wit an adventure that must have been, to say the least, not funny.

One hundred years ago, in the fall of 1846, a small group of medical men met at Peletier's, a popular restaurant on the southeast corner of Broadway and Prince Street, for the annual meeting of the Society for the Relief of Widows and Orphans of Medical Men.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- Oscar Schatte, a Hollywood boss carpenter who said he was endangering his life by testifying, asked the House Labor Committee today to investigate the two-year-old jurisdictional strike in the movie studios.

Entering an economic period in which efficiency of operation will spell the difference between success and failure, manufacturers in the needle trades are at last awake to the need of scientific management comparable to that in other large industries, it was pointed out last week.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 8 -- The United Nations is considering plans to broadcast its proceeding's to an audience of 225,000,000 on a permanent, world-wide and independent network.

TUCSON, Ariz., March 8 -- Before an over-flow crowd of about 4,934 on Randolph Field this afternoon the Giants opened their spring exhibition series against the Cleveland Indians with distressing consequences. They lost the ball game and the services of Willard Marshall almost in the same motion.

Edward R. Carr of Washington, D.C., the new president of the National Association of Home Builders, will be guest and chief speaker at the fifth anniversary dinner and dance of the Long Island Home Builders Institute, to be held on March 20 in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

THIS novel attempts to do for India what John Steinbeck did for America in "The Grapes of Wrath." Remarkably enough, its author is an Englishman, and it is therefore something of a literary event. The story Dennis Stoll has chosen to tell is that of an Indian peasant family that finds itself thrown into the tawdry anarchy of the cotton mill city of Randhandram.

The Supreme Court decision in the John E. Lewis case should be a warning to business and labor leaders that "a certain respect for authority must be observed, not only the authority of the Government but the authority of moral conduct," said Rabbi William F. Rosenblum in a sermon in Temple Israel, 210 West Ninety-first Street, yesterday.

A false alarm of fire resulted yesterday in serious injury to a young patrolman and the holding without bail of an attractive blonde and a Princeton University student. The latter two, strangers, were involved separately in, the incident.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 8 -- Streaking down the snow-packed mountainside at a mile-a-minute clip, Jack Reddish of the Alta S.C. of Salt Lake City today led the record-breaking assaults in the downhill phase of the Olympic try-outs.

The strike that halted trading last Tuesday on the New York Cotton Exchange appears to have been one of the more demonstrative phases in a carefully mapped plan to unionize the nation's white-collar workers.
THE three maps on these pages illustrate the complexities of the German problem which the Big Four Foreign Ministers are about to tackle in Moscow.
The Foreign Ministers of the Big Four meet tomorrow in Moscow. But the matters that are not included in the agenda of their conference are far more important than the matters that are.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (U.P.) -- Senator Homer E. Capehart, Republican, of Indiana, described tonight as "very encouraging" the response of representatives of large newspapers to the invitation of a Senate subcommittee to confer here on means of helping small papers to obtain newsprint.

WASHINGTON. EVERY attempt to make peace with Germany highlights the character and personality of some American. In and after the first World War it was Woodrow Wilson, the prophet. Before and during the second World War it was Franklin Roosevelt, the politician.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 8 -- The Yale hockey team clinched the Big Three championship and gained a tie for the Pentagonal League crown tonight with a 4-2 victory over Harvard. This thirteenth triumph in a row for the Bulldogs was witnessed by a capacity prom week-end crowd of 3,600.

BORN of her experiences as director of the experimental kindergarten class at Teacher's College, Columbia, Mrs. Sheehy's "There's Music in Children" is a pleasant helpful guide telling how to direct your child's interest in music.

THE thirty-first International Flower Show will transform Grand Central Palace, Forty -sixth Street and Lexington Avenue, into a panorama of gardens and flowers during the week of March 17. Opening at noon that day, the displays may be seen daily thereafter through Saturday from 10 A.M. until 10:30 P.M.
Leonard Bernstein, young American conductor, has been invited back to Prague to conduct the Czech Philharmonic Orchestra in May at the second International Music Festival in the Czech capital.

Menahem Begin, 37, is the leader of the Irgun Zvai Leumi (National Military Organization), Jewish underground organization in Palestine. He is a former Polish lawyer and soldier, described by Palestinians who know him as courageous, ambitious, authoritarian, anti-Socialist; a fanatic Jewish nationalist, omnivorous reader of revolutionary history.
The Liberal party, through Ben Davidson, executive director, opposed yesterday the Condon-Wadlin bill to forbid strikes by teachers and all civil service employes in all branches of government.

WHEN cars get a spring overhauling and cleaning in preparation for the touring season, motorists are going to discover that the cost of many parts and accessories has increased almost 20 per cent over pre-war levels.

DETROIT, March 8 -- The United Automobile Workers of the Congress of Industrial Organizations will demand of the General Motors Corporation a guaranteed fortyhour week regardless of the amount of time worked after an employe has been called to the plant, it was learned today.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 8 -- The seventy-third running of Kentucky's famed derby here next May 3 drew 135 nominees from American racing's top 3-year-old horses.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- It is always prudent to assume in Washington that things are never so good or so bad as they seem. In general, this goes for the current state of United States-SovietBritish relations over the atomic bomb and Greece.

BERKELEY, Calif., March 8 (AP) -- Seventeen-year-old Dick Button of Englewood, N. J., last night retained his national senior men's figure skating championship, turning back the threat of John Lettengarver of St. Paul, 1946 national junior champion. Fifteen-year-old Jimmy Crogan of Berkeley, was third.

IN "The Umbrella Thorn" Peter de Polnay has given us another of those novels upon which the sun never sets. His characters are Britishers, pioneer farmers in Kenya, East Africa, bwanas to the natives, but pukka sahibs to those of us already conditioned by Maugham.

Stricter regulations governing design and equipment of buildings to prevent the spread of fire and to permit prompt evacuation of all occupants were urged by the Building Officials Conference of America, Inc., yesterday in a report inspired by the tragic Winecoff Hotel fire in Atlanta on Dec. 7, 1946.

AFTER World War I, we had Dadaism, Joseph Wood Krutch's "The Modern Temper" and Walter Lippmann's "A Preface to Morals." After World War II, we have Existentialism, Philip Wylie's "An Essay on Morals" and Dr. Link's "The Rediscovery of Morals," described as an "American Mercury Book," a phrase which places it somewhat right of center.

GABRIEL KOHN, now residing in Paris at No. 1 Rue Joseph-Bara, a one-block street just off the Boulevard St. Germain and hard by the Church of St. Germain des Pres, is a fugitive from Hollywood. Paramount would like to have him back.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., March 8 -- Southern California appears to be reconciling itself, in some cases against its will, to the idea that war-time industrialization established a pattern here which cannot be shaken off. After building $10,000,000,000 worth of airplanes with which to fight a war, it finds itself unable to go back to being a movie capital, one of the country's richest agricultural areas and a well publicized vacation land.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- (AP) -- Republican Senators clashed today over whether spending up to $12,000,000 to import farm labor from Mexico, Jamaica and other countries would constitute an agricultural subsidy.

The successful standby stock offerings just completed for United Air Lines and the Southwestern Public Service Company are being studied closely by distributors of securities here because the transactions furnish examples of wholly dissimilar standby management techniques employed by underwriters for the first time in major newmoney financing.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- The Veterans Administration, which has paid almost $2,000,000,000 to jobless veterans, said today 217,841 former service men had exhausted their special veterans' unemployment allowances.

TORONTO, March 8 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs turned the local debut of Emile Francis, the Chicago Black Hawks' rookie goalie, into a nightmare when they crushed the National Hockey League cellar dwellers, 12 -- 4, before 13,276 fans tonight.

GODFREY BLUNDEN is a reporter who has written a book. Having done political journalism in Australia and having covered the coronation of King George VI in England in 1937, Mr. Blunden was sent to Russia for part of 1942 and 1943.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- President Truman's decision this week to end the peacetime draft focuses the spotlight on the military manpower crisis.

IT will cost more to travel in Europe this summer than it did before the war, but according to an extensive survey prepared by Thos. Cook Son, neither fare nor living expenses need be "exorbitant." Harold White, president of Cook's, puts it this way:

SAN DIEGO, March 8 -- Californians increasingly are looking upon their State as a laboratory on race relations. A State-wide tour, even if undertaken for a wholly different purpose, brings daily evidence of the seriousness with which the post-war problem of racial adjustment is being viewed and of the steps being taken to solve it.

An uneasy peace, imposed only with the aid of British troops, has settled over the Punjab after a week of vicious communal riots raging through three cities. They have already cost the lives of more than 200 Hindus, Moslems and Sikhs, wounded more than twice as many and left more than 40,000 homeless in burning Amritsar alone.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The sudden, favorable turn in relations between the United States and Mexico has given new point to the observation that, in the field of foreign affairs, men are but the creatures of their times.

Ceylon is anxious to reopen its trade with the United States and is in particular need of machinery, textiles, hardware, electrical products and general consumer goods, according to K.D. Jain Murray, trade representative of several companies in Ceylon.

Medical scientists who have been harried by the anti-vivisectionists and who have to lose valuable time every year to combat proposed legislation which, if enacted, would seripusly hamper medical research by forbidding animal experimentation, have at last taken a step that is long overdue.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- A four-point program aimed at improving the lot of teachers of the country was adopted today by the Committee on Education of the American Federation of Labor.

HAVANA, March 8 -- Five thousand Havana fans got the thrill of a lifetime in Grand Stadium today when three Dodger pitchers hurled a no-hitter for nine innings as the Brooks beat the Yankees by 1 -- 0 in the tenth.

Declaring that the shortage of dwelling space made housing the most serious problem in the State, six Episcopal Bishops asked Governor Dewey and the Legislature yesterday to authorize a referendum this year on the expenditure of $300,000,000 for housing.

THE Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo goes into its fourth week at the City Center today. Valerie Bettis' new "Virginia Sampler" is on the bill several times, and there is an "AllAmerican" evening set for Wednesday. The complete schedule is as follows:

DELAWARE -- Aid to Teachers Three types of scholarship-fellowship aids will be available to prospective teachers and to teachers in service in the State of Delaware for the year 1947-48. These aids represent a portion of the program made possible by a $50,000 grant from the Delaware School Auxiliary to the University of Delaware.

The fifth annual Alfred I. du Pont Radio Award for distinguished public service by a commentator was presented last night to Elmer Davis. Two Midwestern radio stations also were honored for their contributions to the communities they serve.

MAY we introduce Mrs. Moshica Bumbac, also known as "Coana Moashe," or Madam Midwife? Enormous of bulk, gruff, poker-faced, allknowing and, occasionally, softhearted, Moshica has brought two generations of upper-class Rumanian babies into the world.

AN interior decorator often uses a single vase, rug or picture as the basis of a color scheme, repeating some of the shades throughout the room in draperies, walls and upholstery. In our gardens we may use a similar idea for effects that are both unusual and pleasant, but, in place of the vase or picture, a flower of two or more colors provides the central motif.

BUDAPEST. THE success of Zoltan Kodaly in America, plus the fact of Hungarian artists having won three first prizes abroad, has reawakened the interest of the Hungarian public in serious music from which it turned away for a time after the war.

An audience of 2,700, composed mostly of children, crowded Carnegie Hall yesterday morning for the fifth of the Young People's Concerts of the New York Philharmonic Symphony Society. Rudolph Ganz conducted a GermanAustrian program.

THERE is an old saying that there are tricks in all trades but ours. Teachers, like butchers, bakers and candlestick makers, often cannot tell you exactly what it is they do or why they do it. Like the young lady in the song, they just keep on doing "what comes naturally."

WITHIN a few days the new Ambassador to the Court of St. James's will start for London to assume his duties. Lewis W. Douglas looks forward to his mission as "the most exciting" experience in a varied career. Moreover, he enjoys a sense of relief in being assured of a place to live.

The New York Historical Society has just placed on exhibition in its galleries in Central Park West at Seventy-seventh Street a group portrait by John Durand, called "the most important discovery to be made in the last quarter century in the field of colonial New York painting."

CHICAGO, March 9 -- Grain markets continued last week their sensational advance, which got well under way early in February. All deliveries of wheat, corn and oats except March corn sold at new seasonal high prices on the Board of Trade here and March oats equaled the twenty-seven-year peak established early last July.

MIAMI, Fla., March 9 (AP)--Ben Hogan of Hershey, Pa., and Jimmy Demaret of Ojai, Calif., won the $10,000 international four-ball golf tournament here today for the second straight year. They defeated Lloyd Mangrum of Los Angeles and Lawson Little of Cleveland, 3 and 2.

ZURICH, Switzerland, March 9 --After fluctuating unsteadily for the last few weeks, the rate of exchange of the free dollar in Zurich, which had been as low as 3.60 Swiss francs, rose last week to 3.80 francs, on the issuance of new regulations by the National Bank of Switzerland prohibiting further export of bar gold.
JERUSALEM, March 9 (AP)-- British military authorities expect fresh violence as a result of the deportations.

The Furness Bermuda liner Monarch of Bermuda, previously scheduled to re-enter the New York-Bermuda service in the summer, probably will not be ready before January, according to Sydney Foster, vice chairman of Furness Withy Co.

"Man Against Myth" by Barrows Dunham, will be published by Little, Brown on April 8. It is described as "a critical analysis of some of the social illusions which rob mankind of abundance, equality and peace." Among the notions discussed are that "you can't change human nature," that "there are superior and inferior races," and that "words will never hurt me."

LONDON, March 9--Great Britain's Labor Government will explain its economic policy at a private meeting of its own party members tomorrow before facing Parliament for the beginning of the big three-day debate on the fuel crisis.

Although Christians sincerely pray for the success of international conferences, neither the sessions of the United Nations nor the Moscow Council of Foreign Ministers will bring permanent peace, the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer, pastor of Calvary Bapist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, declared yesterday morning in his sermon.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, March 8 (Delayed) -- The Communist party has started campaigning strenuously for the elimination of the greater part of private enterprise in the wholesale trade by the establishment of a national network of nationalized wholesale houses distributing the products of nationalized industries.

Special Sessions Justice Henry H. Curran has been prodded out of epistolary retirement by an incipient rebellion at the mythical university named after him. Faced by a "strike" by his one-man faculty --Bronx Borough President James J. Lyons--and his one-man student body -- former Council President Newbold Morris -- the "chancellor" decided to take action before the postal rates were increased.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (U.P.)-- What appeared to be the unofficial Administratation viewpoint was voiced today by Senator Herbert R. O'Conor, Democrat, of Maryland, He said in a radio address (Station WBAL, Baltimore) that the issue was a test of strength between Russia and the United States with Russia ready to move into Greece if this country does not.

PITTSBURGH, March 9--Major interest in the steel industry last week was in the erratic movement of prices on the scrap metal market. In some centers such as New York, Philadelphia and Boston, quotations representing brokers' buying prices were advanced again.

Progress toward relaxation of trade barriers and elimination of discriminatory practices in international trade have followed the Anglo-American financial agreement, the international finance committee of the National Foreign Trade Council, Inc., declared yesterday.
BEERSHEBA, Palestine, March 9--"And Israel took his journey with all that he had, and came to Beersheba."--Genesis xlvi, 1.
The Seatrain Lines, which carried freight cars from New York to Gulf ports before the war, will resume service this week, it was announced here yesterday by Graham M. Brush, president of the company.

The sun shone on the delegates on their first day in Moscow. They missed the curious red fog, blurring the sharp outlines of the Kremlin towers and filling the Red Square like the smoke of a dull fire, that gives its distinctive color to the winter atmosphere. They missed the fanfare of ceremonial reception the Russians usually give to distinguished visitors.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., March 9--A helicopter, soaring above enraged pickets, established what was believed to be a precedent in picket line circumvention today by making seven hourly landings with raw materials in the yard of the Cornell-Dubilier Electric Corporation, where a wage dispute has been in progress since Thursday.

BERLIN, March (U.P.)--Gen. Joseph T. McNarney revealed today that the American taxpayer since the end of the war had spent close to half a billion dollars to nurse along the nation he had spent billions of dollars to defeat.

Backlogs of orders for automatic machinery have reached new records according to contract manufacturing executives. Those with established lines find that their delivery promises appear unreasonable to prospective buyers, and some are refusing to accept further orders.

Industrial engineering and construction volume will be higher in 1947 than in 1946 and may reach an all-time high as materials become more plentiful, prices become stabilized and Government controls are relaxed. This is the consensus resulting from a survey of executives of the H. K. Ferguson Company, industrial engineers and builders.

MOSCOW, March 9--When the Foreign Ministers of the western nations meet tomorrow at the opening session of the Council of Foreign Ministers they will find themselves confronted with specious, long Soviet plans for Germany.

Twelve decommissioned submarines with extensive wax records have been assigned to coastal ciites as training vessels, the Third Naval District Headquarters announced yesterday. They will be used for qualified veterans and non-veterans as part of a new Naval Reserve program.

YENAN, March 8 (Delayed)-- A statement by Lieut. Gen. John R. Hodge that Chinese Communist troops were participating in the training of a Korean army by the Russians in North Korea was denied by Gen. Chu Teh, commander in chief of the Chinese Communist armies, in a statement here today.

The successful completion of the first year of an interracial experiment wherein City College students and residents of the Hamilton Grange neighborhood bordering the college meet weekly to discuss local and national problems was announced yesterday by Mr. Harry M. Shulman, director of the Community Service Division at City College.

BERKELEY, Calif., March 9 (AP) --Gretchen Merrill of Boston and Dick Button of Englewood, N.J., successfully defended their senior women's and men's United States figure skating titles during three days of competition ending last night at Iceland Rink here.

Governor Dewey and the Republican majority in the Legislature were held responsible yesterday by the Citizens Housing Council and Assemblyman Irwin Steingut for failure so far to meet the housing shortage in New York State.

For her New York debut with her one-woman show, "The Mystery of Theodosia Burr," Jeanne Welty came to the stage of the National Theatre last evening with the cards stacked elaborately against her--and, of course, by her own hand.
Off his 4:07.1 mile and subsequent two-mile victory in the Knights of Columbus meet last Saturday night, the indoor mile record still must be considered fair game for Gilbert Dodds.

JERUSALEM, March 9--The first unauthorized immigrant ship known to have been sent here by the Hebrew Committee of National Liberation was in the Palestine Government's custody today. Her crew of twentythree, believed to be Americans, was arrested and will be charged in Haifa tomorrow with bringing the ship into Palestinian waters illegally.

George W. Morgan Jr., 16 years old, awaiting grand jury action on a charge of stealing four fur coats from his grandmother, was accused yesterday by his father of stealing $5,000 worth of clothing from the family home at Tuxedo Park, N.Y.

A resolution denouncing the merit promotion and salary increment phases of the teachers' pay bill sponsored by Governor Dewey was adopted yesterday by 1,500 persons attending a meeting of the Teachers Union, CIO, at Cooper Union.

The Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert, Bishop-elect of the Episcopal diocese of New York, told twenty-one newly confirmed members of Grace Episcopal Church, Broadway and Tenth Street, yesterday that "the peace and security of the world literally depended on the willingness of Christ's followers to undertake service and sacrifice for God."

ALBANY, March 9--Governor Dewey will recommend the enactment of legislation to simplify and streamline the State's income tax blanks for use in making returns in 1948, it was announced today. The changes will not apply to returns which must be filed by April 15 of this year.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 9-- Three safe robbers walked into a police trap in a downtown restaurant here early today and were shot and killed by four detectives who had hidden in a rear room.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Monday, March 10 -- Nine persons, three of them United States Army officers, were arrested in Europe today as officials of the State, Treasury and War Departments launched a world-wide crackdown on counterfeiters and unauthorized hoarders of military currency.

New York's Rovers, making their first start in the Amateur Hockey Association, of the United States play-offs, battled the rugged Boston Olympics to a 3-all tie in the feature engagement of the amateur twin-showing at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

PARIS, March 9--The French have sent emissaries to Bao Dai, former Emperor of Annam, to discuss his return to power in wartorn Viet Nam, according to persons claiming authority to speak for the Viet Nam Republic in Paris. The French Foreign Office professes to have no information about such an interview.

Unfair to Mayors A letter from a curious reader of our Manhattan meanderings has had us poking about the older inhabited part of our island East Side and West Side from the Battery to Delancey Street where the Williamsburg Bridge starts over to Brooklyn --and to further exploration of the official street directory.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 9 --Paul Lukas will play the leading role, that of an Alpine guide, in RKO's "The White Tower," which will be filmed in Switzerland, the studio has announced. Edward Dmytryk will produce and direct the picture from James Ramsey Ullman's 1945 novel dealing with the experiences of a party of mountain climbers.

Retailers expressed anxiety last week over the slowness of the ready-to-wear business and the failure of Easter trade to open up yet, according to the reports prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. As a result stocks were high and purchasing at wholesale was cut down considerably, the reports continued, adding, however, that despite this, a healthy spurt of consumer buying, particularly of Easter goods, was expected.

ATLANTA, March 9 (AP)--A brilliant rally by Fort Dix brought a 60-55 overtime victory over the Hoosier Ambassadors of Lyons, Ind., to climax today's session of the American Basketball Congress tournament. The meet's two topseeded teams were eliminated in their initial appearances.
Although leading by 2--0 at the end of the first half, the Kearny Americans were defeated by the New York Americans, 3 goals to 2, in an American Soccer League match at Sterling Oval yesterday.

Promptly at 9 o'clock tonight, a Frenchman wearing a natty tuxedo, a straw hat set at a rakish angle and an infectious grin will step forth jauntily on the stage of Henry Miller's. A renowned oneman entertainer, he will be renewing an acquaintanceship with Broadway after an elapse of more than a decade.

New designs appear in fashion as spring approaches, and so, too, do they make their bow in a homelier field of women's interests --household refrigeration. General Electric has five 1947 models that are now appearing for the first time.

MEXICO CITY, March 9--The entire structure of organized Mexican labor, more than 1,000,000 strong, is undergoing increasing stress. Four important conventions within the next eight weeks will crystallize the tensions and almost certainly lead to important changes.

Emphasizing that the current teacher shortage threatens to continue for six or eight years, Dr. Ordway Tead, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, asked yesterday for state funds to train teachers in each of the four city colleges.

CHICAGO, March 9 -- Speculative operations in corn have increased rapidly recently, especially in the last two weeks, and prices on the Chicago Board of Trade have mounted steadily. The May delivery at its high point yesterday showed an advance of more than 30 cents a bushel since Feb. 1.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 9--Native tribes in the South Sea Islands of Western Samoa submitted today through forty-six Samoan chiefs the first plea for selfgovernment to be made directly to the United Nations Trusteeship Council.

The All-Veteran Symphony Orchestra gave its first concert yesterday afternoon in Hunter College Auditorium. The event was planned to give the ex-servicemen a chance to be heard and also to raise money to buy musical instruments for veterans still in hospitals.

LONDON, March 9--The remarkable resiliency displayed by the stock markets a week ago has been followed by hesitancy owing to a fresh and serious interruption to business throughout the country by the return of extremely cold weather.

CHICAGO, March 9 (U.P.)--The Montreal Canadiens gave the downtrodden Chicago Black Hawks more headaches tonight, combining smooth passing with an overwhelming attack to defeat the National League cellarites, 4--1, before 17,336 fans.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., March 9-- Philip Dunham, 23-year-old dentist from the U.S. Naval Station at Norfolk, Va., came here today to capture the New York State ski jumping championship on the Norsemen Hill at nearby Salisbury Mills.

The nature of our economy being what it is, wages and profits, either separately or jointly, will probably be with us indefinitely as a recurrent source of controversy. But the area of that controversy has a way of changing with the times.

Back in the gay and thoughtless Nineties most Americans, if they had heard of her at all, regarded Carrie Chapman Catt as a crusading crank, misled into leadership of the hopeless cause urged by such pioneering feminists as Susan B. Anthony and Anna Howard Shaw.

Ruth Page's ballet, "The Bells," suggested by Poe's poem, had its first performance of the season by the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo on Saturday evening at the City Center. Its premiere last September was not a happy one, beset by accidents and general lack of preparation.

BOSTON, March 9 (U.P.)--The Boston Bruins, backed up by flawless goal-tending by Frankie Brimsek, shut out the Detroit Red Wings tonight, 6 to 0, to win their fifth straight National Hockey League game.

A sermon on racial tolerance, preached in the deep South by the Rev. Sam Nader of the First Methodist Church, Jennings, La., was broadcast yesterday over WOR as the "Sermon of the Week." Former Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia read Mr. Nader's plea for brotherhood as a solution of the Negro question.

The Roesch Orchestra, consisting of sixteen young women who play stringed instruments, and conducted by Clara Burling Roesch, gave a concert, refreshing alike in the unhackneyed character of the program and the spirit, also unhackneyed, of its performances, yesterday afternoon in Town Hall.

ON THE U.S.S. TACONIC IN THE CARIBBEAN SEA, March 8 (Delayed) (AP)--A powerful Navy task force, trained to scatter at the first sign of an atomic bomb attack, today raced across the Caribbean Sea to land marines on tiny Culebra Island, eighteen miles east of Puerto Rico.
Psychoanalysis in general and "Freudian" psychoanalysis in particular were attacked yesterday by Msgr. Fulton J. Sheen, Professor of Philosophy at the Catholic University of America in Washington.

RANGOON, Burma, March 9 (AP) -- The Burmese Government, moving to halt a smallpox epilemic raging in the capital, tomorrow will begin evacuating 100,000 refugees who have come to Rangoon to escape robber bands in rural areas.

Except for a sharp setback on Friday, prices of cotton in the domestic market last week continued an upward trend. At the close on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed for the week net gains of 67 to 85 points.

HAVANA, March 9--When Branch Rickey assumed control of the Brooklyn Dodgers it was said that he instantly adopted Leo Ernest Durocher as his favorite reclamation project. The Mahatma now is entitled to pat himself gently on the back. The job is completed.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Because of my long and intimate association with the field of public housing in New York City, I feel not only privileged but obligated to seek the courtesy of your columns to make some comment on Mayor O'Dwyer's current proposal.

BANGKOK, Siam, March 9-- Here in Bangkok, where the fugitive Viet Nam Government of President Ho Chi Minh has its only direct contact with the outside world, it is evident that the French position in Indo-China has suffered a grim deterioration.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 9 --A 14-year-old Eastern girl, Andrea Mead of Pico Peak, Rutland, Vt., won the women's slalom and finished second in the combined downhill-slalom Olympic tryouts which ended today at Ruud Mountain.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Beardsley Ruml, chairman of the Board of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., and former chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said today that a tax cut of $8,000,000,000 was feasible with a balanced budget.

MIAMI, Fla., March 9 (AP)--Fred Corcoran, tournament manager for the Professional Golfers Association, today announced twenty-two tournaments with prize money totaling $275,000 for the spring and summer circuit.

PEIPING, China, March 9--There is a firm conviction in the minds of experienced observers, both Chinese and foreign, in North China today that the Communist offensives in Manchuria and Central China are directly connected with the opening of the Moscow conference.

Despite the latest affirmation by John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, that the Government contemplates no changes in its interest rate policy "at this time," unfreezing of the rates on shortterm Government securities appeared to move a step nearer realization last week, financial observers declared yesterday.
ALBANY, March 9--With most of the major controversies of the legislative session still to be resolved, leaders were dubious tonight of final adjournment Saturday night as planned.

Trailing by two goals with the first period little more than half over, the Toronto Maple Leafs fought their way back to score a 4-to-2 triumph over the New York Rangers in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., March 9 --Under a north-northwest wind that was not of the March lion variety, but puffy enough at times to make matters interesting, twentysix of the Interclub class dinghies sailed through seven races today off the Larchmont Yacht Club.

North Carolina State, winner of the Southern Conference championship, became the sixth team to accept a bid to participate in the national invitation basketball tournament in Madison Square Garden, Asa Bushnell, chairman of the metropolitan selection committee announced yesterday.

Business of the Chrysler Corporation in 1946 amounted to $870,000,412, it was announced yesterday by K.T. Keller, president of the company. Net earnings were $18,889,290, before expected recovery of excess profits taxes, and $26,889,290, or 3 per cent of sales after recovery of excess profits taxes, the annual report set forth.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 9--The United States Embassy agreed today to request the International Emergency Food Council to supply 100,000 tons of grain to Yugoslavia. The need was described by an official of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration as "the worst crisis in the country since the Germans left a devastated land."

WARSAW, March 9--Premier Klement Gottwald led the Czech delegation of eight, including Foreign Minister Jan Masaryk, into Warsaw today for tomorrow's signing of a treaty of friendship and mutual assistance with Poland. It will be the pact by which the two countries will make a common front against Germany, their age-long enemy.

RACINE, Wis., March 9--Members of Local 180 of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, voted tonight to terminate their 440-day strike against the J.I. Case Company. The strike was one of the longest in the country's industrial history.

WHEN Francois, Duke de la Rochefoucauld, wrote in the seventeenth century, "We all have strength to bear our neighbor's burdens," he was writing what he called a "moral maxim." But the world has preferred another name for such epigrammatic writing and has ever since ranked Rochefoucauld as the greatest of all writers of aphorisms.

No matter what the United States Government decides to do to bolster the tottering economy of Greece, the need for private relief in that unhappy land will continue. For the last six years the Greek War Relief Association has been carrying on a work of mercy that has been one of the main factors of Greek survival since the Axis struck her down in 1941.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 9-- Champion Karach of Khanhasset, the Afghan that was best in show at the Elm City show in New Haven last month, competed successfully in another New England event when he went to the top in the thirty-first all-breed fixture of the Providence County Kennel Club tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP)-- The Department of Commerce advised business men today to get busy right away on lowering prices.

WASHINGTON, March 9--Tomorrow's meeting of Congressional leaders with President Truman on the question of aiding Greece will be a "showdown" session, it was learned tonight. Some of the fourteenmember bipartisan group are determined to request Mr. Truman to disclose exactly what he has in mind for the American course with the withdrawal of British assistance in parts of the Eastern Mediterranean.

The American labor delegation to Argentina reached the following conclusions on the basis of its three-week study of labor and economic conditions under the Peron Government: 1. There is little formal action by the Government to suppress civil liberties.
LONDON, March 9 (AP)--Sports circles counter - attacked today against a proposed Government curb on the athletic industry, declaring that all work and no play will make Jack Bull a dull boy.

A million aerosol bombs for destroying insects are among the items offered for sale in more than 100 sales schedules of surplus property worth $42,000,000 in cost value, announced over the week-end by Carl P. Malmstrom, regional director for the War Assets Administration.

The Argentine Government of President Juan D. Peron was accused yesterday of having established dictatorial rule over the Argentine Confederation of Labor through the use of armed force, political favoritism, bribery and the imprisonment or expulsion of union leaders true to the principles of freedom and democracy.

The Young Men's Board of Trade of New York, 291 Broadway, acting as coordinator of the efforts of business and industry, lists the following free services to aid veterans in career planning and employment: ADVERTISING--Job Interviews conducted by Veterans Guidance in Advertising and Selling, Inc.. 103 East Thirty-filth Street, will be held daily from 9:30 A. M. to 11:30 A. M.
LAHORE, Punjab, India, March 8 (AP) -- Airborne troop reinforcements, with orders to shoot rioters on sight, arrived today in troubled Punjab Province, as communal fighting spread out into villages.
The Whitney Museum's annual exhibition of contemporary American sculpture, water-colors and drawings, opening to the public tomorrow, is the outstanding event in a busy week in the galleries.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP)-- The National Planning Association asserted today that the United States should insist on full Russian compliance with the German reparations plan adopted in Potsdam.

Frank J. Sampson, leader of Tammany, said yesterday that he would confer with chairmen of the organization's committees early this week with a view to obtaining their resignations in his first step for reorganization. A statement by Mr. Sampson on his reorganization plans is expected today or tomorrow.

Every year, about this time, a group of congenial citizens, some of them getting along in years, meet in this city and swap yarns. This year they had their reunion and luncheon on Saturday the 8th, although the exact anniversary of the event they celebrate falls on the 12th, day after tomorrow.

Tests of Readership The first report of the continuing study of farm publications, measuring readership of the Oct. 5, 1946, issue of The Ohio Farmer, a bi-monthly, was issued over the week-end by the Advertising Research Foundation, Inc., to 2,500 advertiser, advertising agency and publisher executives.

Shoe production in the United States amounted to 528,960,000 pairs in 1946, the highest output for any year in the history of the industry, according to a week-end report by the New England Shoe and Leather Association. It exceeded the figure for 1945 by 43,000,000 pairs or 9 per cent, the report stated.

An alarm was sent out last night from Police Headquarters to all commands, and especially the harbor squad and waterfront patrols, to be on the lookout for a number of cardboard-encased glass tubes containing mustard gas that might be floating in near-by waters.

MOSCOW, March 9--The Council of Foreign Ministers will meet here tomorrow afternoon to attempt to settle the outstanding peacemaking problem of this generation --writing a peace treaty for Germany. This session will be the first Moscow meeting of the Council since December, 1945.

Beneficent currents near Scaly Rock, a pinnacle formation rising from the East River at the upper end of Hell Gate, were credited by the Queens police yesterday with saving two youthful mariners-- John Verdon, 14 years old, and John Brady, 15, crew of a rubber life raft.

CLEVELAND, March 9--Ralph H. Stone, deputy administrato of the Veterans Administration for the Ohio-Kentucky-Michigan district, announced tonight at Columbus that he would start an investigation tomorrow morning of charges made by Dr. Alan B. Adams, who resigned as chief of the neuropsychiatric service at Crile Hospital, that the neuropsychiatric department was fast becoming "a mere way station" on the road to the Veterans Administration insane asylum at Chillicothe, Ohio.

The recently-formed Bureau for the Suppression of Theft and Pilferage already has made its presence felt on the New York waterfront, according to E.E. Conroy, executive vice president. He reported yesterday a decline in losses due to theft.

Mary Ledgerwood, contralto of this city, was heard in her first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. A vocalist of experience, Miss Ledgerwood was always the intelligent artist, positive in her intentions, and sure of her effects.

WASHINGTON, March 9-- From the operations of the International Fund, now slightly more than a week old, there is expected to develop one substantial result having no connection with the main business of the fund, but of inestimable value to development of international understanding.

WASHINGTON, March 9--This will be an important week for the Eightieth Congress, but one which probably will see little accomplished in the sense of completed legislation. This is chiefly because most major bills are still in the committee stage.

JACKSON, Miss., March 9--As the State Legislature enters tomorrow its second week of extraordinary session, public interest here was focused largely on the likelihood of "white primary" laws being enacted to restrict the registration privileges of Negroes.

LONDON, March 9--The British Labor Government has been widely and seriously accused in the press this week-end of endangering Brititsh liberties. Reappearing after having been banned for two weeks to save fuel, weekly papers and magazines of all shades of political opinion accuse the Government of having played fast and loose with freedom of the press.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (Science Service) -- The once popular notion that a man could get all the nourishment he needed for a day out of a pill-sized ration of chemicals or something approaching that is debunked by latest studies of the Quartermaster Corps.

Martial law in Palestine was expected and emergency medical service was ready, Dr. Haim Yassky, director of the Hadassah Medical Organization in Jerusalem, reported yesterday to the national board of Hadassah, Women's Zionist Organization of America.

MOSCOW, March 9--For the first time in eight years--except for a brief period in 1945--foreign correspondents in Moscow can write factual dispatches on an important subject tonight without benefit of ideological censorship, which has hamstrung their work almost since the last of the great purges.

Problems of personnel, housing, promotion and organization -- the solution of which will be hampered or facilitated by the size of the defense budget--are the principal current worries of the Army and Navy, a recent trip to a number of military and naval posts and stations showed.

Greater use of all public school facilities by private agencies, especially for athletics, was advocated yesterday by the Catholic Youth Organization in the annual report, of the Youth Activities Division of Catholic Charities.

WASHINGTON, March 9--Fiorello H. Le Guardia, as chairman of a new National Fair Rent Committee, called upon Congress today to give spokesmen for tenants a chance to present fresh evidence of the need for continued rent controls.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., March 9--After being icebound for four weeks, Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's Class B dinghies and Penguins held the fourth regatta of their spring series today in a fresh northwestern. Seven races were held during the day.

Mainbocher is a poet in fashion. He endows his lines with rhythm. He treats his fabrics with a broad sweep or a restraining hand. His idiom is delicate and light when the occasion calls for it, dramatic when it suits his purpose.

Fewer than 240,000 persons of New York City's working population of 3,520,584 are unemployed, according to the latest figures of the Department of Commerce made public yesterday. The figures, covering the month of November, 1946, put unemployment at 239,760 or 62 per cent less than in the pre-war census month of March, 1940, when unemployment stood at 635,394.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Our trusteeship agreement for the Japanese mandate islands, faithless to the spirit of the Charter of United Nations, now has served an added sinister purpose, curiously unforeseen by ourselves.

YENAN, China, March 8 (Delayed) -- Gen. Chou En-lai, chief diplomatic figure of the Chinese Communists, bitterly charged today that the United States still was heavily supporting the Chiang Kai-shek Government and that American policy "has gone from bad to worse" since General Marshall became Secretary of State.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP)-- The Foreign Policy Association asserted tonight that lack of a clear United States policy toward Puerto Rico was to blame for many of the island's economic problems.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $56,361,808,693. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows: Mar. 13--Discount bills..........$1,314,809,000

American representatives at the Council of Foreign Ministers in Moscow were urged to "stand firmly for a constructive European peace settlement in accordance with American democratic ideals" in a statement yesterday by seventy-five clergymen, economists, educators, journalists and former military government officials.

The meager financial support that New York gives its public libraries doubtless originates in the fact that the city long ago got so much for nothing, and still does, through being the beneficiary of continuing and sizable private support. The Reference Department in the building at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street has endowment funds alone of more than $40,000,000.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 9-- What happened at Municipal Stadium today was strictly from the script. The gigantic Clint Hartung from Texas was pretty much the whole show in a won-in-theninth victory which gave the Giants a triumph over the Indians in the second game of their interleague exhibitions and squared the series.

The church should enter the arena of life where the people are if it is to give spiritual leadership in a changing world, the Very Rev. Eric Noel Porter Goff, provost of Portsmouth Cathedral in England, declared yesterday morning in a sermon at St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue at Fiftythird Street.

ARCADIA, Calif., March 9 (AP)-- Santa Anita Park, winter turf mecca of the Far West, entered that peculiar lull today, with the stable area quiet in one section and bustling with activity in others, following the close of the season yesterday.

Murrell J. Fischer, formerly vice president of International Furniture, Company, Chicago, was elected president to succeed P. W. Pelts, who died Feb. 26 in California, directors announced today. L. N. Lavin, secretary, was elected to the additional post of treasurer.

New York leaders of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations joined yesterday in urging support of the Red Cross drive. All union members are being urged to give a day's pay to insure realization of the city's quota of $6,153,600 in the national drive for $60,000,000.

SALONIKA, Greece, March 6 (Delayed)--Greek army authorities showed to the writer today a document that, they held, established collaboration between units of the Elas, which is the fighting arm of the Eam leftist coalition, and the German army units that controlled the Salonika area during the occupation.
LONDON, March 9 -- One-way traffic dealing in 178 named certificates of American shares will start tomorrow on the Amsterdam Stock Exchange. Official dealings were banned in July, 1941.
CHICAGO, March 9--Bread prices are rising, a survey of United States cities showed today.

BRUSSELS, March 9--The name of Foreign Minister Paul-Henri Spaak is given in usually reliable quarters as that of the next Premier of Belgium. A political crisis is expected to break soon, while a trade depression is already beginning.

ALBANY, March 9--Microchemical blood tests of an experimental group of school children, taken at the instance of the Joint Legislative Committee on Nutrition, has disclosed widespread dietary deficiencies, Senator Thomas C. Desmond, chairman of the committee, reported tonight.

SCRANTON, Pa., March 9-- Raymond B. Gibbs, secretary of the Scranton Chamber of Commerce since 1925 and former president of the National Association of Commercial Organization Secretaries, died today in his home here at the age of 63.

HONOLULU, March 10 -- Two hundred twenty "enemy" planes struck Oahu in two waves today in the final phase of the Pacific fleet's war game and preliminary reports indicated that the island's big military installations had suffered some theoretical damage.

Blocks of public utility stock priced at $10,672,475 were awarded in a competitive sale yesterday to syndicates headed by Blyth Co., Inc., which plan to make reoffering later in the week. Other underwriting managers will undertake today secondary distribution of two issues of industrial securities aggregating $2,895,000.

LOS ANGELES, March 10 (AP) -- The automobile industry should produce 3,500,000 passenger cars during 1947, according to Harlow H. Curtice, general manager of the Buick division of General Motors Corporation.

HAVANA, March 10 -- The rather strained relations between the Yankees and Dodgers reached an even more acrimonious stage today when Larry MacPhail, Bombers' president, cut loose with a vitriolic blast against the vanished Flock.

Further new lows since mid-January were recorded yesterday by the stock market in a continuation, of the downward spiral of prices that began last Friday. Modest improvement was shown by many groups during a greater part of the ' session but a final hour assault left the list well-weighted on the down side at the close.

Reporting on operations last year of the American Sugar Refining Company, Joseph F. Abbott, president, informed stockholders yesterday that while the company opposed Government price and rationing controls as a peacetime measure, the sudden elimination of the present wartime sugar control program undoubtedly would cause substantial price increases and a scramble for available supplies.

AMSTERDAM, March 10 (Aneta) -- Prices were lower in light trading on the Stock Exchange. Oil stocks led the decline, while industrials, snipping and Indies plantations issues were mixed. Bank stocks and State bonds were steady.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., March 10 -- Box kites were flown today by members of the Teamsters Union, American Federation of Labor, in a futile attempt to prevent a helicopter from ferrying raw materials into the Cornell-Dubilier Electric Corporation's plant for the second successive day.

British economic policy deliberately is crippling trade 'between Palestine and the United States, Meir Grossman, president of the United Zionists - Revisionists of America and member of the general council of the World Zionist Organization, asserted yesterday.

BOSTON, March 10 -- Kathleen Winsor's novel "Forever Amber" received a clean bill of health for Massachusetts readers today from Judge Frank J. Donahue, who ruled that while it was not obscene, indecent or impure, it was "conducive to sleep."

A sharp attack by Mayor O'Dwyer on the Condon-Wadlin bill, now before the Legislature, which would provide drastic punishment for striking civil service employes, brought into the open yesterday a rift between the Mayor and Brooklyn Borough President John Cashmore, Democratic leader of Kings County for six months.

Following is the text of Herbert Hoover's report dealing with the Austrian aspect of President Truman's economic mission to Germany and Austria: Introduction It Is impossible to make clear the economic and relief problems of Austria without a paragraph on her history.

To begin with the most profound observation, Maurice Chevalier is a nice guy. Nothing has altered that winning fact. Now that the Germans have left Paris and the shooting is over, M. Chevalier has come back to New York with a bundle of night-club songs which he sang at Henry Miller's last evening. Let's not say that nothing has changed.

"HENRY ADAMS' history of America from 1801 to 1817 is too important to be left to the scholars and the students." Convinced of this, Herbert Agar has labored manfully to abridge the original nine-volume work into a mere two volumes, which are published today as "The Formative Years: A History of the United States During the Administrations of Jefferson and Madison."

ALBANY, March 10 -- Governor Dewey vetoed today a bill granting real estate tax exemption for property acquired by the United Nations in New York City on the ground that he had signed a similar bill two weeks ago that was state-wide in effect.

The field for the tenth annual national invitation college basketball tournament, which gets under way at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night, was completed yesterday with the acceptance of bids by St. John's and Long Island University.

Installation of badly needed radar safety devices at La Guardia Field was halted yesterday by a work stoppage by a dozen members of Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, AFL.

Perriette, the homing sparrow, is back in the Bronx again. For the fourth successive March the sparrow with the instincts of a pigeon is building a neat on the fire escape outside the second-floor apartment of Mrs. Noble L. Hetherington, at 3050 Grand Concourse.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- John L. Lewis and the United Mine Workers of America today opposed the Government's request for a speed-up in the formalities in connection with the Supreme Court's decision against the union chief and his organization for civil and criminal contempt.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission will hear argument tomorrow on whether or not railroads serving Geneva, Utah, are to be permitted to make rates on iron and steel articles from Geneva and other Utah points to the West Coast about 31 per cent lower than present rates.
MOSCOW, March 10 -- Secretary of State Marshall said today that he was prepared to press for conclusion of a four-power treaty to insure the world against German aggression.

The action of a Jamestown, N.Y., furniture factory in advancing wholesale prices of solid mahogany bedroom suites 10 per cent across the board yesterday will be followed shortly by similar increases by all manufacturers offering comparable merchandise, retailers predicted yesterday.

President Truman's budgetary allotments for new ship construction in 1947 and 1948 "spell the doom of the American shipbuilding industry," according to the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO.

Because alcoholic beverages are definitely a luxury and are meeting with increasing consumer resistance, the proposed rise in the New York State tax on liquor actually will result in a drop in revenues to both the State and the National Governments, it was declared yesterday by Gerald F. Dunne, executive director, Metropolitan Package Store Association.

HAVANA, March 10 -- All during those long years he was supplying endless talent to the St. Louis Cardinals, Branch Rickey achieved the reputation of never buying ballplayers but always selling them. The going was a bit rugged in those days when the Red Birds had to compete in the open market with the rich clubs such as the Yankees, Tigers, Cubs and Giants. They couldn't afford to outbid the others for finished talent.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- Virtually all signs point to an excellent 1947 crop-producing season, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

JERUSALEM, March 10 -- Twenty-one American citizens, including a woman named Hanna Herschkowitz, as well as two Norwegians with American first papers and two French nationals, all of whom arrived aboard the unauthorized immigrant ship Abril, were remanded by a magistrate in Haifa today.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 10 -- The American Olympic Committee, through Al Sigal of California, announced today that Walter Prager, former Dartmouth coach, and Alf Engen of Sun Valley will serve as coaches of the United States ski team at St. Moritz, Switzerland, next February.

Store Sales Here Up 10% Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week showed an increase of 10 per cent over the like week of 1946, according to the "flash report" yesterday of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

The farmer who plays up to the cow's loafing instinct without curbing her freedom to come and go as she pleases is rewarded with better milk, it was reported yesterday on the basis of State-sponsored experiments conducted on sixteen New York farms.

Immigration into the United States has been paralleled in the past by increased employment rather than less and by a higher rather than lower standard of living, the National Committee on Immigration Policy asserted yesterday in a report on the economic aspects of the subject.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Supreme Court held today that it is unconstitutional for New York City to levy a general business tax on stevedoring companies handling interstate and foreign commerce within the city limits.

TOKYO, March 10 -- The Japanese Government's legislative program, including the budget, the basic labor law and proposed industrial controls, are being sabotaged by absenteeism in the Japanese Parliament.

WASHINGTON, March 10 - The Senate Committee on Atomic Energy voted today to recommend confirmation of David E. Lilienthal as chairman and five other appointees as members of the United States Atomic Energy Commission. The vote on Mr. Lilienthal was 8 to 1.
