Giving dramatic emphasis to the importance of the issue by one of his rare personal appearances before Congress, President Truman will address a joint session of both Houses tomorrow on the critical situation in the Near East in connection with the proposed $250,000,000 loan to Greece and a possible loan to Turkey.

An exhibit of toys, dolls and games is now in the process of construction at 204 Fifth Avenue and will be open to buyers, educators and the general public same time in May, it was announced yesterday by the Toy Guidance Council, Inc.
CHICAGO, March 10 (AP) -- The All-America Football Conference today launched its 1947 scheduledrafting with a bit of negative trade talk.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 10 (AP) -- Campos became the latest South American horse to win in this country when he carried F. D. Kaplan's silks to a half-length score in today's featured Key West Purse at Gulfstream Park.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- Construction of two American-flag luxury liners was proposed today by Representative Willis W. Bradley, Republican, of California, as he disclosed that the liner John Ericsson which burned Friday in New York, had received a waiver of safety requirements.

Nordics Learn Geopoiitics Halford John Mackinder, distinguished geographer and social soientist who is dead in London at the age of 86, was often described as the spiritual father of the "geopoliticians" when that school of thought was at the height of its vogue a few years ago.

OTTAWA, March 10 -- All Canadian troops were withdrawn from the occupation forces in Germany at the request of the Canadian Government and contrary to the desire of Great Britain, Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King revealed today in the House of Commons.
RAWALPINDI, Punjab, India, March 10 -- Civil strife has turned a considerable part of the northern Punjab countryside into flames.

The Pressed Steel Car Company, Inc., of Pittsburgh had a backlog of orders for freight and industrial cars and parts from domestic and export customers approximating $45,750,000 at the close of 1946, Ernest Murphy, president, informed stockholders in the annual report yesterday.

The American Jersey Cattle Club of Columbus, Ohio, has sold its former headquarters at 322-24 West Twenty-third Street to the Brooklyn Heights Realty Company, Inc., through Abbott Adams, Inc., brokers. The property, comprising a three-story building on a plot 43.9 by 98.9 feet, is assessed at $87,000.

David E. Lilienthal and his colleagues of the Atomic Energy Commission have come out of the ordeal of six weeks of Senate committee hearings with flying colors. The hullabaloo of the McKellar onslaught, the inaccurate and misleading bill of particulars presented by Senator Taft, were ineffective.

TRENTON, N.J., March 10 -- The New Jersey Legislature received tonight bills to permit municipalities to impose luxury sales taxes and to repeal the State constitutional amendment authorizing pari-mutuel betting on horse races.

Spring and sailors went hand in hand at Mary Goodfellow's showing of hats yesterday at the St. Regls. Opening the presentation with a large group of straws, she followed the theme right through the collection.

Arturo Toscanini's RCA Victor recording of Haydn's Symphony No. 98, with the NBC Symphony, and Bruno Walter's Columbia recording of Mahler's Fourth Symphony, with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony, received awards last night as the outstanding symphonic recordings of 1946.
MANILA, March 10 -- President Manuel A. Roxas narrowly escaped assassination tonight.
LONDON, March 10 (AP) -- Gus Lesnevich, the United States Walker Cup team and other foreign sports invaders can go ahead with plans to compete in Britain this summer.

An all-metropolitan college doubleheader concludes the regular basketball season at Madison Square Garden tonight, with City College opposing N.Y.U. and St. John's meeting St. Francis. Both contests are of the traditional variety and it goes without saying that more than 18,000 persons will turn out for the twin bill.

World economy is "grievously distorted" now, but existing international agencies, if used "with unusual imagination and boldness," can solve the problems presented, Lord Inverchapel, British Ambassador to the United States, said last night.
MOSCOW, March 10 -- The Council of Foreign Ministers convened today and speedily ended the brutal, bloody history of the Prussian State.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., March 10 -- The United Nations gave its backing today to a United States decision not to invite Spain to two international telecommunications conferences to be held in this country in May and July.

CINCINNATI, March 10 -- Under the Wagner National Labor Relations Act the right to strike has been exercised in such a way as to defeat the existence of other equally important rights -- the right to work and the right to engage in business, James Tanham, vice president of the Texas Corporation, New York, said here tonight.

ALBANY, March 10 -- Bills providing for special taxes to finance the proposed $400,000,000 state bonus to World War II veterans and a revised version of the Teacher Pay Bill were submitted to the Legislature tonight as leaders tried to make possible a final adjournment by Saturday of this week.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Herbert Hoover recommended today the allotment of $155,000,000 in emergency relief for Austria for April 1, 1947, to July 1, 1948. In a report, made public today, on his study of the Austrian phase of relief needs in the occupied area of Europe under American jurisdiction, he said this sum did not cover industrial rehabilitation.

The maximum penalty of thirty days in jail and a $100 fine was imposed on Mrs. Margaret Lake Hubitsen yesterday for turning in a false alarm of fire that resulted in serious injury to a young patrolman.

With twenty engagements listed against Ivy League rivals, Columbia University's baseball, tennis and track teams will see action in a total of thirty-four events this season, according to the schedules announced yesterday by Ralph Furey, director of athletics.

Although recognizing that adlittonal cars alone will not assure idequate service, the Public Servce Commission ordered the Long Island Rail Road yesterday to file by April 1 a plan for full utilization of all equipment to improve commuter conditions.

CHICAGO, March 10 -- A warning that neither industry nor the country can reach prosperity until better homes are made available for more people was sounded today by President Truman in a message to the National Public Housing Conference, which opened its annual meeting here today.
ALBANY, March 10-Prospects of Senate passage of the Crawford bill legalizing off-the-track betting virtually were snuffed out tonight as members voted to hold the measure on general orders.

WARSAW, March 10 -- The network of Slav solidarity alliances cementing the Eastern bloc was completed today when Czechoslovakia and Poland signed a twentyyear treaty of friendship and mutual assistance in "common defense" against any renewal of German aggression.

ABOARD SS. BEN HECHT, At Sea (Delayed) -- A dozen or more of the 900 Jewish refugees jammed aboard this tiny blockade-running yacht could have emigrated to the United States in comfort and safety. Instead, they chose to suffer the hardships and dangers of getting into Palestine, to strive, as they put it, "to bring justice into the world."
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- In a field day for dissents, the Supreme Court rolled eight cases off its decision list today, even though it left unsettled about forty other issues.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today refused to review a 1941 plan of reorganization for the St. Louis Southwestern Railway Company lines.

Plans for the cruise of the American Yacht Club of Rye, N.Y., were announced yesterday at a luncheon in the New York Yacht Club, at which Commodore Edward L. Richards, Race Chairman Donald Evans and Fleet Captain R.O.H. Hill were present.
MANILA, March 10 -- The consummation of a Chinese-Philippine treaty of amity, halted on the verge of signature recently by a disagreement over terms, seemed further than ever distant today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 10 -- The United Nations Security Council approved unanimously today a United States resolution to refer the entire question of international atomic control back to the Atomic Energy Commission. There is some hope that the Commission may be more successful than the Council has been in obtaining:

Two widely differing points of view on children's behavior during school agre were heard yesterday from Dr. Arnold Gesell, director of the Yale Clinic of Child Development, and from Ernst Kris, Ph. D., faculty member of the New School for Social Research, at the annual conference of the Child Study Association of America at the Hotel Roosevelt.
NEW ORLEANS, March 10 -- Dr. Paul Mazzuri, who was associated with Walter Reed in the yellow fever experiments in Cuba in 1900, died last night at Touro Infirmary here. His age was 82.

SALONIKA, Greece, March 10 (AP) -- A plan calling for United Nations sponsorship of patrols to maintain the integrity of the Greek border is being developed for inclusion in the final report of the United Nations Balkan Investigating Commission, informed sources said today.

"Carrousel for Bibliophiles: A Treasury of Tales, Narratives, Songs, Epigrams and Sundry Curious Studies Relating to a Noble Theme" is the title of a fireside companion for book lovers. It is edited by William Targ, who also does the introduction.

In a decision which turned on a 5-4 vote, the Supreme Court handed down its first ruling yesterday on the moot question of whether foremen are, or are not, "employes" for purposes of collective bargaining under the Wagner Labor Relations Act. The majority opinion, delivered by Justice Jackson, found that when foremen organize their own union the employer must bargain with that unit.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 10 -- About 1,000 United Nations employes met today in the Security Council chamber to protest against working conditions.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- A threatened defection of Republican "freshman" Senators demanding a larger voice in party legislative councils was killed with kindness tonight as the majority leadership promised the new members voteless representation on the Republican Policy Committee.

LONDON, March 10 -- Fears that further unpleasant facts may emerge from the debate on the economic situation in the House of Commons, and disappointment with the new coal allocations to industry tended to restrict movements in the stock markets today.

ROME, March 9 (Delayed) -- Whether Trieste will be able to live as an Independent state or will become part of a Slavic political economic bloc Will depend on the decision of the 'Foreign Ministers' conference, Italian political circles said today.

BATAVIA, Java, March 10 (U.P.) -- An Isbrandtsen Steamship Company official today threatened to sue the Netherlands Government for $10,000,000 damages if it failed to release the United States Liberty Ship Martin Behrmann, its cargo and crew within twenty-four hours.
A 16-year-old page boy at the New York Cotton Exchange was accused yesterday of the hold-up murder on Sunday of a Brownsville, Brooklyn, shoe store owner.

BAYONNE, N. J., March 10 -- Harassed by intra-party strife, opposed by fellow members of the City Commission and deserted by Mayor Prank Hague of Jersey City, his erstwhile supporter, Dr. Bert Daly came to the end of his political rope here today.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Democrats threw the Senate into a new fight over the Republican anti-third-term program for limiting the tenure of a President of the United States today by seeking to "simplify" and "remove discriminations" from the proposed constitutional amendment now pending.

The third annual National Antiques Show was opened yesterday morning in Madison Square Garden by Hugo E. Rogers, Borough President of Manhattan, who turned a key in an antique wrought iron door lock lent by the Yale Towne lock collection.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Legislation to permit the immigration of displaced orphans into the United States for adoption was introduced in the Senate and House today by Senator Irving M. Ives and Representative, Jacob K. Javits, Republicans, of New York.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Before returning to my native country after a month's stay in the United States, I should like to voice, through you, my deepest gratitude to President Truman, the American Government and the American people for the generous relief extended to Moldavia and other sections of Rumania recently.

After a slow start yesterday the cotton, futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange gained momentum, in the afternoon and turned strong. Active contracts closed at about the best levels of the day, 27 to 47 points net higher than Saturday's final levels.

PITTSBURGH, March 10 (AP) -- The Dubois Brewing Co. of Dubois, Pa., contended in Federal District Court today the name "Budweiser Beer" is a geographic and generic name and is not the exclusive brand name of the Anheuser-Busch Brewing Corporation of St. Louis.

LONDON, March 10 (AP) -- Text of a Soviet communique on the foreign Ministers' meeting, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor here: The Moscow session of the Council of Foreign Ministers opened today in Moscow in the House of the Aircraft Industry.

Brig. Gen. Donald Armstrong, USA retired, declared last night that "extremely serious" errors were made in the industrial mobilization of World War II and called for greater civilian participation in future mobilization plans.
Frederick V. Roberts, formerly director of labor relations at the Ford Motor Company's Edgewater (N. J.) plant, has been named industrial relations head of that plant.

Mayor O'Dwyer, who sees reporters every day at City Hall, traveled up to Columbia University yesterday to answer questions of newspaper men from twenty-six cities throughout the country. The Mayor spoke for ninety minutes at the opening:
Settlement of the long-standing controversy over how the airports of New York and Newark should be developed as an integrated systerm is in sight, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- One of the most bitterly contested disputes in labor-management relations was settled today when the Supreme Court ruled by five to four that employers must bargain collectively with unions of foremen or supervisory employes.

Fira Benenson has remained true to her fashion principles this season. She has not permitted herself to be swayed by the fanfare of many talked-of style trends. Detail is the very heart of her collection, shown yesterday morning in the Salon de Couture at Bonwit Teller's.

Dean Francis M. Crowley of Fordham University's School of Education declared yesterday that the Catholic Church was not opposed to Federal aid for public schools but that parochial schools, too, were entitled to such assistance.

Annual Reports While utility companies have made some progress in recent years in their efforts to brighten up annual reports, most of the appeal continues to be limited to attractive covers. Thus, many companies miss their yearly opportunity to engender sustained layman (investor) interest in the company's affairs, although millions of investors would welcome informative but simple and brief financial facts and some light but interesting "asides" on the company's other activities and accomplishments.
CHICAGO, March 10 -- The Roman Catholic Church and its members were held today to face a challenge In the increasing forces that make for disintegration of the family.

The five-story apartment house, also containing three stores, at 1121-23 First Avenue, has been sold by Mark W. Maclay as trustee and Frederick Johnson as substituted trustee to the Jebe Corporation for cash above a purchasemoney mortgage of $50,000.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 10 (U.P) -- Manager Eddie Dyer had his solid one-two-three pitching punch in tow today for the st. Louis Cardinals' world championship defense this season, as Murry Dickson, last of the club's holdouts, came to terms and joined the team in practice.

The second part of the Whitney Museum annual, made up of contemporary American sculpture, water colors, gouaches, pastels and drawings, opened with a private view yesterday afternoon in the museum, galleries at 10 West Eighth Street.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 10 -- The miseries jarred the peaceful calm of the Giant camp here today. Overnight Manager Mel Ott discovered an alarming number of casualties -- Montia Kennedy, Mickey Witek, Jack Lohrke, Johnny Maze and Babe Young -- on top of this the Indians came to town today and swamped the Giants, 12 to 5.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- President Truman has decided to introduce a double Russian policy. The No. 1 policy is going to be one of collaboration for peace on the basis of justice. The No. 2 policy is going to be one of economic intervention in key areas to block Soviet expansion.

LONDON, March 10 (AP) -- Silver bullion dealers said today that Indian buying of silver had stopped as the result of "reports" that the Reserve Bank of India had refused to issue import licenses for the metal.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- A challenge arose today from among the Senate's irregular Republican wing to every principal bill for labor restrictions now pending before the Senate Labor Committee. In a four-hour speech which was the first prolonged floor discussion of the whole issue in the new Congress, Senator Wayne Morse of Oregon sharply criticized proposals of three of his senior Republican colleagues on the committee, including Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, its chairman.

PEORIA, Ill., March 10 -- George P. McNear Jr., 55 years old, president of the Toledo, Peoria Western Railroad, where one of the country's longest strikes has been waged for seventeen months, was shot and killed tonight by an unknown assailant.

The Direct Mail Advertising Association, Inc., is canvassing its membership on the proposed increase of postal rates. Members are being asked what would be the percentage of decrease in the number of pieces they would mail if the minimum rate of 1 1/2c for miscellaneous printed matter mailed under 3rd class regulations was to become effective.

BRUSSELS, March 10 -- All the little business men of Belgium locked their establishments today in protest against restrictions in the form of rationing, price-fixing, taxes and the voluminous paper work imposed on them by the State.

LOS ANGELES, March 10 -- Southern California Edison Company is preparing to market the largest issue of preferred stock ever undertaken by a public utility company in this country, according to reports in investment banking circles here.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The State Department threw considerable doubt today on Yugoslavia's need for relief grain. This followed a published report from Belgrade that the United States Embassy there had requested the International Emergency Food Council to allot 100,000 tons of grain for purchase by the Yugoslav Government and by the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, March 10 -- Striking at counterfeiters and black market operators, the United States Army called in its blue and gray occupation scrip today and replaced it with a new currency printed in blue and red.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Senate Judiciary Committee approved today a new and much harsher bill knocking out portalto-portal back pay suits and restricting the future liabilities of employers under all the minimum wage laws.

CHICAGO, March 10 -- The first session of the national marketing conference of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States today brought warnings from both retailers and manufacturers that 1947 will see the return of a buyers' market and heavy public resistance to further price increases. The conference is being held in the Stevens Hotel.

Bread made the front page yesberday, with, the news of a rise in its price, and apropos, a report appeared on how women select the staff of life. The account, in the current issue of Consumer's Guide, the Department of Agriculture's monthly publication, is based on a survey of 5,000 homemakers by the American Home Economics Association.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y.,. March 10 -- The Westchester Board of Supervisors opposed unanimously today the program of Governor Dewey's Committee on Education for collecting: additional school funds. It asked also for defeat of pending State legislation that would permit uneral processions on the county's parkways.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, March 10 -- That the Hungarian Government itself might refute a statement in the recent United States note alleging Russian interference in Hungary's internal affairs emerged as a possibility today.

A young conductor, Thor Johnson, who next season will be the leader of the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, directed the youthful orchestra of the Juilliard School of Music in a program of modern compositions last night in Carnegie Hall.

Scrap shortages are responsible for the loss of 140,000 tons of steel a month which could be added to present steel production, Walter S. Tower, president, American Iron and Steel Institute, disclosed here yesterday. He told more than 100 members of the American Steel Warehouse Association at a luncheon session at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday that twenty-five more furnaces could have been operating during March except for scrap scarcities.

The first group of apartments prepared especially for paralyzed veterans was shown yesterday by Herman T. Stichman. State Commissioner of Housing. Four such units at the Maritime Base in Brooklyn, and two more at Marine Park in the same borough, form part of Governor Dewey's emergency housing program.

Early next fall Katharine Cornell will fulfill a long-time ambition. She will present and co-star herself as Cleopatra in "Antony and Cleopatra" with Godfrey Tearle as Antony. Mr. Tearle is now playing Antony in London opposite Dame Edith Evans.

CHICAGO, March 10 -- Wheat futures advanced the permissible limit of 10 cents a bushel on the Board of Trade today and closed at the top, or % cent below it, with March at $2.73%, a new 27-yeai peak. Although price changes were violent at times, each dip brought in renewed commission house buying.

CLEVELAND, March 10 - The Elisabeth Severance Prentiss Foundation, created by the late Mrs. Prentiss for the improvement of the health of the public, now has assets amounting to approximately $5,680,000, and ultimately will have a principal value of about $7,000,000, the Foundation disclosed today in its first .

Last January six AFL representatives and three from the railway brotherhoods accepted the invitation of the Peron Government and the Argentine Confederation of Labor to study conditions in Argentina. They were welcomed on Jan. 19 at a lavish reception tendered by the Department of Labor and Welfare.

A record registration of buyers marked the opening yesterday of the American Toy Fair at the Hotel McAlpin and in permanent showrooms elsewhere. The total was estimated at 2,500, a rise of some 25 per cent over the approximate figure of 2,000 for the opening day last year.

MOSCOW, March 10 -- The enormous Hotel Moskva, diagonally across from the crenelated Kremlin, is these days a hotel without parallel in the history of the Soviet Union. It probably has been equaled only in fancy fiction.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- The House Labor Committee heard five members of Congress and a Harvard professor recommend compulsory arbitration today as the "most practical and fairest" way of stopping big strikes.

Carrie Munn has fun when she is making a collection, and so does the audience assembled at her showing. This designer, often counted as one of the best-dressed women in the country, makes a gay and animated assortment of clothes.

PHILADELPHIA, March 10 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today set March 24 for a hearing on an amended application by the American Power and Light Company and two subsidiaries, the Pacific Power and Light Company and the Northwestern Electric Company.

LONDON, March 10 -- The British Government, shaken by the rapid growth of strong criticism against its economic policy within the Labor party, opened the threeday Parliamentary debate on the defensive today.

MOSCOW, March 10 -- On the assumption that there is no security in Moscow against eavesdropping and wiretapping, even inside the United States Embassy chancery and residence, the American delegation to the four-power Council meeting has established its own iron curtain.

PANAMA CITY, Canal Zone, March 10-- Eighteen Dodgers made thirteen hits today to win their opening engagement in the Canal Zone, 8 to 1. They defeated the Panama Chesterfields, obviously not named for that fellow with the fine manners, before a crowd of 6,500.

ALBANY, March 10 -- Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein informed Governor Dewey today in a special report that butter manipulations of the Dairymen's League Cooperative Association last December were "essentially an act in restraint of trade but did not violate present state law."
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The first ten-pound sugar stamp, Spare Stamp No. 11 in the family ration book, will be valid April 1, the Office of Temporary Controls announced today.

BERLIN, March 10 -- Field Horine, former chief of the Radio Control Branch of the Military Government for Bavaria, has accused United States officials of sabotaging a Military Government mission in Germany so they could win German support against the Soviet Union.

A strike of bank employes was ended yesterday through the intervention of the City Labor Relations Division, but the State Labor Relations Board refused to permit the union involved to withdraw unfair labor practice charges it filed against the bank when the strike began last Friday.

PARIS, March 10 -- Members of the Gaullist Union in Alfortville, a suburb of Paris, have hidden arms, the Communist party charged today in a leaflet circulated during the suspension of its newspaper by the strike.

Frank J. Sampson, new leader of Tammany Hall, invited yesterday the holders of all the other official posts in Tammany to meet with him at lunch today in the National Democratic Club. The meeting is to give Mr. Sampson a chance to ask for the resignations of the entire group, so he can start with a clean slate.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Chinese Embassy described tonight as a "strange and surprising move" the unexpected effort of' Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov to bring into the agenda of the meeting of the Big Four Foreign Ministers political conditions in China.

Certain Chinese import quotas for all countries listed by value in United States dollars for the period February through April this year were announced here yesterday by L. L. Horch, regional director of the Department of Commerce. The announcement was based on information received from the American Consulate General at Shanghai.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In regard to the current strike the Brooklyn Young Women's Christian Association has been facing -- and facing up to -- two problems in labor relations which are of basic importance to this country.
JERUSALEM, March 10 -- After fifty years of existence the Zionist movement does not have a unified and detailed plan for Palestine to present to the United Nations.

Although consolidated operations of the Phelps Dodge Corporation and its subsidiaries showed a loss of approximately $500,000 in the first half of last year, the consolidated net income for the full year was $14,853,360, Louis S. Gates, president, reported in the annual statement mailed yesterday to 27,335 shareholders.

JACKSON, Miss., March 10 -- Four more "white primary" bills were introduced in the State House today. At the same time, leading members of business, the bench and the Legislature were warned by Alfred Stone, Chief Tax Commissioner and 76-year-old elder statesman of Mississippi, against adopting "any new hare-brained ideas."

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The White House announced today that President Truman would address a joint session of Congress Wednesday on the Greek problem. In a message to Congress the President recommended complete liquidation of Selective Service system by March 31.

ALBANY, March 10 -- A bill designed to make it more difficult for Representatives Vito Marcantonio and Adam Clayton Powell to enter the primaries of more than one recognized party was approved by the Assembly tonight with only two dissenting votes.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- A frank Republican acknowledgment that a proposed $800,000,000 cut in Treasury funds might not save "a single dollar" marked the start of a two-day House debate today on the $12,388,029,971 TreasuryPostoffice Appropriations Bill.

ROME, March 10 (U.P.) -- Pope Pius XII presided over the second Consistory of his reign today when fifteen Cardinals approved sainthood for five beatified Europeans as sixty American sailors looked on.

ST. PETERSBURG. Fla., March 10 (AP) -- Franklin Bache Huntington, great-great-great-grandson of Benjamin Franklin, died this morning at a hospital here, less than two months after being flown to Florida from New York by air ambulance. His age was 72.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- President Truman is expected to ask authority to lend $250,000,000 to Greece and another $150,000,000 to Turkey before a joint session of Congress on Wednesday, arrangements for which were made today. The plan was adopted at a conference with thirteen Congressional leaders, of both parties, at the White House.

Charles K. Hanel, former chief clerk of Local Selective Service Board 44, testified in Federal Court yesterday that Serge M. Rubinstein, international financier, offered him 200 shares of Taylorcraft Aviation Corporation stock at a time when Rubinstein's induction for military service appeared imminent.

CHICAGO, March 10 (U.P.) -- Jay Bozeman of Vallejo, Calif., took over second place in the world championship three-cushion billiard tournament tonight, beating John Fitzpatrick of Los Angeles, 50 -- 37, in fifty-two inning's. The high runs were Bozeman, 7; Fitzpatrick, 3.

BUENOS AIRES, March 10 (AP) -- Aurelio Fernandez, secretary general of the Argentine General Labor Confederation, described today as "full of untruth" a report by the American Federation of Labor charging the administration of President Juan Peron with using organized labor as a "political instrument."

SHANGHAI, March 10 -- Formosan rebels, acting through the Committee to Settle the Feb. 28 Incident, have convoked the autonomous Assembly, to institute political reforms pending recognition of their demands by the Chinese Government, it was reported tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 10 -- Plans for the first two pictures that Joan Fontaine and her husband, William Dozier, will produce for Universal-International under the corporate name of Rampart Productions were announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- In sequel to his message of March 3 recommending that the Selective Service Act be allowed to expire March 31, President Truma urged on Congress today action to preserve the Selective Service records. His special message of today said that except for this step the Selective Service system could be liquidated.

Presbyterian women regarded with frigid silence last night a seemingly light-hearted masculine debate on the question of whether women should be ordained as ministers of the church. They uttered not a word during the ten-minute discussion period that followed expressions of opinions by clergymen.

BERLIN, March 10 -- The United States and British Military governments are creating the nucleus of a reactionary Army of Polish exiles for use in a war against Poland and the Soviet Union, it was charged by the chief of the Polish military mission here in a formal note to the Allied Control Council.

BERLIN, March 10 -- The threeday session of the "German Women's Congress for Peace" ended here with the formation of the "Democratic Women's Society of Germany." Its avowed purpose is to "make propaganda for peace." Dr. Annamarie Durand-Wever was elected chairman.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- A long-range housing bill designed to encourage construction of 15,000,000 city and rural dwellings in the next ten years was introduced today by Senators Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio; Robert F. Wagner, Democrat, of New York, and Allen J. Ellender, Democrat, of Louisiana.

Capt. Harold Milde of Newark, N.J., former master of the liner John Ericsson, told a Coast Guard Board of Investigation yesterday that the City Fire Department "was a long time responding" to the fire that swept the 20,000-ton vessel at her West Fiftieth Street pier here last Friday.

PLYMOUTH, England, March 10 (AP) -- The vicar of St. Barnabas Church, the Rev. J. S. Clarke, turned tipster today in his parish magazine and advised his flock to back Bricett in the Grand National Steeplechase.
ALBANY, March 11 -- Mayor O'Dwyer sent to fiscal leaders of the Legislature today his answers to fifteen penetrating questions they had asked a week ago on New York City finances.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, today was placed squarely "in the middle" in the internal row which has led to a secession movement among locals of the Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers Union.

Recommendations for a spring town wardrobe were cleverly made by Saks-34th Street at a showing of misses' styles yesterday afternoon. The clothes were selected with good taste and the accessories well teamed to the costumes.

Two thousand electricians and building service workers engaged in the two-year-old jurisdictional strike in the principal Hollywood film studios will return to work by the end of this week, it was predicted yesterday by Richard F. Walsh, president of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes, AFL.

A 26-year-old son who, the police said, shot and critically wounded his father as a climax to many arguments between his parents, was booked on charges of felonious assault and violation of the Sullivan Law last night at the Bath Street station, Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- President Truman today named the members of his Advisory Committee on Merchant Marine.

The wind of freedom, blowing so briskly through many lands washed by the Pacific, has swept across Samoa. But in those enchanted isles it seems to have suffered a sea change. Certainly their native petition for selfgovernment was wafted into the United Nations Trusteeship Council on the gentlest of balmy breezes.

AMSTERDAM, March 11 (Aneta)--Prices were generally firmer in increased volume of trading on the Stock Exchange. Quotations for industrials, Indies Plantations issues and banking shares registered only slight changes.

A million-dollar synagogue and a community house that would be open to use by all faiths may replace the old six-story buildings at the northwest corner of Seventh Avenue and Fortieth Street in the garment district, it became known last night.

PHILADELPHIA, March 11 -- The Standard Gas and Electric Company asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for authority to extend $13,350,410 of unpaid bank note balance due on April 10 to May 10. The participating banks, the application said, have agreed to the extension.

WASHINGTON, March 11--The House unanimously passed today a $12,388,029,971 Treasury-Post-office Supply Bill, the first appropriations measure for the 1948 fiscal year to reach the floor in the new economy-minded, Republican-controlled Congress.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- What worries President Truman's advisers at the moment is not the loan to Greece and Turkey now under discussion but the next one. They have few doubts that Congress will agree to the President's appeal tomorrow to block Russian expansion, but, they ask, what about the next tomorrow, the next strategic area threatened by Communist expansion, the next economic retreat by Britain?

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 11--No one actually did it, except mentally. And they all did that, kiss the ground of American soil as soon as we clambered out from the Yankees' chartered plane at Tampa this morning. For four long weeks the Bronx Bombers had been away from the States touring Puerto Rico, Venezuela and lastly, Cuba.

WASHINGTON, March 11-- Sava N. Kosanovitch, the Yugoslav Ambassador, declared in a statement today that his country was in need of food and that he had expressed grave concern over the situation in a memorandum to Dean Acheson, Under-Secretary of State, on Feb. 13.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP)-- The Federal Trade Commission, in a special report on business trends, informed Congress today that 1,800 companies had been swallowed up by purchase and merger since 1940.

WASHINGTON, March 11--Bipartisan support of projected political loans of $250,000,000 to Greece and $150,000,000 to Turkey was taken for granted today by Senate and House leaders on the eve of President Truman's message outlining a program of financial aid to these Near East pressure points.

NEWARK, N.J., March 11 -- Five high school boys, whose knowledge of atom fission is happily slight, were placed on informal probation by United States Attorney Edgar H. Rojsbach tonight after admitting ownership and operation of five "bootleg" short wave radio stations which they started early in January in the town of Summit on a total investment of $150.

Gastronomically, New Yorkers are lucky, because this city is the only one in the country where converted rice is about to become available regularly. Between 10,000,000 and 20,000,000 pounds have been assigned here for the next twelve months by the manufacturer, Converted Rice, Inc., of Houston.
WASHINGTON, March 11--The Senate Foreign Relations Committee unanimously approved today United States participation in the International Refugee Organization.

TOKYO, March 11--With an implied threat that the United States cannot be expected to feed Japan unless Japan first exhausts her own resources, the occupation authorities are cracking down on the food black market and enforcing rice collection quotas.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Charges that two prominent diplomats in Washington under the Nazi regime will testify against Douglas MacCollum Stewart only under duress were made today at the start of the perjury trial of Mr. Stewart, former publisher of Scribner's Commentator.

Columbia's most successful basketball team of the past eleven years will close its season tonight in the Morningside Heights gymnasium against Harvard, the only team that topped the Eastern League champions in loop competition. Starting time is 8:30.

"I DO not pretend to be a poet," said Edward FitzGerald, the author of one of the most beloved and most often quoted poems in the English language, his translation of "The Rubaiyat of Omar Khayyam." He was being overmodest, for he believed firmly in the quality of his own work. But if he could win the admiration of his distinguished friends, that was all he cared to do.

LONDON, March 11--Establishment of an international military, naval and air base, in which the United States would share, on the northern shore of Libya is being considered in London, it was learned tonight.
ALBANY, March 11--The fall primary election in Presidential years would be abolished under the terms of a bill approved by the Assembly today and sent to Gov Thomas E. Dewey.

At least twelve young children, six of them in this city, have died recently of a new drug widely prescribed by physicians throughout the country for tonsillitis and to aid recovery after tonsilectomies, it was disclosed yesterday.

Trans World Airlines and Government authorities moved yesterday to prevent a recurrence of the tragic accident in which George L. Hart was blown from his navigator's post in a Constellation 19,000 feet above the North Atlantic on Monday night.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 11--With the main detachment of Yankees bringing their Caribbean jaunt to a neat three-point landing, Manager Bucky Harris today lost no time in getting himself acquainted with the remainder of his extensive baseball family.

The State Department's policy toward post-war Germany, so far as long-term aims, occupation and a peace treaty are concerned, generally has the support of 530 community leaders in twenty-two cities from Boston to Seattle, according to a summary of a poll conducted by the Council on Foreign Relations, 58 East Sixtyeighth Street, and announced yesterday.

MOSCOW, March 11--Russian press and radio reporting of the Council of Foreign Ministers' meeting rests upon a corps of not more than a dozen veteran correspondents. They are employed by Pravda, the organ of the Central Committee of the Communist party; Izvestia, the organ of the Soviet Council of Ministers, and Tass, the official Soviet news agency.

Silver The price of silver yesterday had its sharpest drop in a single day in more than twenty-five years. The break of 5 3/4 cents an ounce brought the price of foreign-produced silver to 78 cents, compared with a recent high of 86 1/4 cents.
The prominent role of the Czechoslovak Y.M.C.A. in opposing the Germans during the war was described here yesterday by Dr. Miroslav Kohak, its president.

An unidentified man wearing a military discharge button caused a uror yesterday afternoon in Federal Court when he excoriated Gerge M. Rubinstein, international financier, as a "yellow slacker." Rubinstein is on trial with two others on charges of having made false statements to his draft board.
JERUSALEM, March 11--Several American Jews who served in the American forces during the war were among the pioneers who founded a new communal settlement in Upper Galilee today.

PALM BEACH, March 11--Ever since the perfection of the longdistance telephone the number of men active in large affairs who spend much of the winter in this region has greatly increased, and the arrival of commercial air transport has added to their ranks.

The new feeling in decorative fabrics is aptly illustrated in the exhibit opening today at the Museum of Modern Art. Patterns are shrinking from three times larger than life to a scale ranging from medium to small. Motifs are neater, crisper and more often planned to create an all-over effect.

Referee Irwin Kurtz yesterday signed an order authorizing Motty Eitingon, Inc., fur dealers and processors, to accept the offer of $1,500,000 in new capital and to operate the business under the supervision of a committee designated by the lenders, contract holders, note holders' and general creditors.

TRENTON, N.J., March 11-- Budget expenditures of the New Jersey State Administration for the 1947-48 fiscal year were fixed today by the Legislature Appropriations Committee at $155,723,345. The general appropriations bill will be prepared for introduction in the Legislature next Monday.

Marked by an attendance of some 5,000 representatives of shoe manufacturers, retailers and other leather - consuming industries, the first American leather show since 1942 was opened yesterday under auspices of the Tanners Council of America in the Hotel Commodore.

PEIPING, March 11--The State Department's cultural and information program--destined to give the peoples of the world an idea of what American democracy is like through an exchange of cultural, scientific and literary information in foreign lands--moved forward another step recently when a United States Information Service library and distribution center was opened in Changchun at the very height of the Communist offensive there.

The end of the year should bring freedom from Government controls to all branches of the construction industry, but for the present housing must receive top priority, Frank R. Creedon declared yesterday. The Housing Expediter urged investors to put their money into building now, and not to wait for reduction of costs, as these are likely to remain high for a "long, long time."

A challenge to the authority of Aristotle and Moses (Commissioner) to dictate tto the City Council, possible discrimination against some fish as tenants in the proposed aquarium at Coney Island, the housing shortage and "protocol" figured in one debate of the Council yesterday.

STUTTGART, Germany, March 11--The Council of States of the United States zone today approved, with reservations, a restitution law that would return to racial, religious and political victims of the Nazis all identifiable property of which they were wrongly deprived between Jan. 30, 1933, and May 8, 1945.

BERLIN, March 11--Although Germany's territorial boundaries are not mentioned in the Allied Control Council's report to the Conference of Foreign Ministers in Moscow, the Eastern frontier is expected to play a large role in the treaty discussions.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 11--Early demolition and excavation to make way for the projected skyscraper capital of the United Nations was assured today with formal authorization of a $1,325,000 preliminary work program for the six-block East River tract in Manhattan.

The Simmons Company, manufacturer of bedding equipment, celebrated its seventy-fifth anniversary in 1946 by handling a record dollar volume of business, foreign, including Canadian, as well as domestic, resulting in peak earnings, the pamphlet report to stockholders revealed yesterday.

SALONIKA, Greece, March 10 (Delayed)--A witness called today by the Greek Government in support of its argument that its northern neighbors aided and equipped rebellious elements inside the country appeared before the United Nations investigating commission in United States Army trousers and tunic.
CHICAGO, March 11--Economic security is essential to the family unit, Harry C. Read of the Congress of Industrial Organizations told the National Catholic Conference on Family Life today.

For the first time the Pacific Mills Worsted Division will employ large-space newspaper advertising in twenty-eight leading market centers from coast to coast to promote its products. Its theme will be "Look to the Fabric First." This advertising, handled by Williams and Saylor, Inc., will supplement the worsted division's regular program of full-page, full-color advertising to appear in leading consumer magazines this spring.

JERUSALEM, March 11--For the first time since martial law was imposed on Palestine's main industrial area around Tel Aviv, the resulting economic distress has elicited outcries from municipal and labor leaders against terrorism rather than against the Government.

WASHINGTON, March 11--William L. Clayton, Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, will head a delegation of eighty-five officials from nine departments and agencies representing the United States at the dual conference on post-war trade starting at Geneva April 10, the State Department announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (U.P.) --Acting Secretary of State Dean Acheson told Congress today that continuation of the Government's "exclusive" power to import rubber might provoke charges from other nations that the United States is "unjustifiably influencing" the world's rubber markets.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 11 -- Louis Saillant, secretary general of the World Federation of Trade Unions, today received permission for the WFTU to prevent its views on full employment and post-war reconstruction to the United Nations Economic and Social Council.

PANAMA, March 11--A dusky prototype of Bobo Newsom had a wonderful time for five innings today as he held the Dodgers hitless while the Cerveceria team maltreated Kirby Higbe to collect four runs. The temporary hero of the 2,500 fans answered to the name of Chino Melendez and left nobody in doubt about it since the back of his windbreaker was emblazoned with his name after the manner of prize fighters.

WASHINGTON, March 11-- Lewis B. Schwellenbach, Secretary of Labor, and Representative Fred A. Hartley, Republican, of New Jersey, chairman of the House Labor Committee, agreed today that the Communist party in America should be outlawed.

LONDON, March 11 (AP)--The Grand National Steeplechase tonight was rescheduled for Saturday, March 29, in the first big response to the Government's request to curtail midweek sports to aid the nation's production-forsurvival drive.
LONDON, March 11--The British Government sees the whole economic future of the world depending on the outcome of the Geneva trade conference set for April 10.

ROME, March 11--Pope Pius XII, completing the eighth year of his reign in a tempestuous world, told The Associated Press today that he was hopeful the world would achieve a just and lasting peace, but that the price might be agreements that would curtail to some degree the sovereign rights of nations.
SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 3 P.M. today to continue discussion of proposed United States trusteeship agreement for Japanese-mandated islands. (Open).

BRUSSELS, March 11--The Government will resign tomorrow after the resignations of four Communist members today in a row over the coal price. This pretext was used for dissolution after months of squabbling arising from fundamental differences of outlook.

There must be something grimly humorous to New Yorkers in the spectacle of a delegation of members of the Transport Workers Union marching on Albany today with the intention of pleading with the Legislature not to pass a bill that would forbid strikes by public employes.
ALBANY, March 11--The record vote in the State Senate on the Condon-Wadlin bill outlawing strikes by public workers follows: FOR THE BILL Republicans--35 Anderson Groben I.B. Mitchell

The 2 1/2 per cent interest rate which Peru has just set by legislation as a ceiling for resuming debt service on $82,769,000 of American dollar bonds in default since 1931 and 1932 was denounced here as unacceptable yesterday by the Foreign Bondholders Protective Council.
MOSCOW, March 11 -- Black bread and cabbage soup loom larger in the eyes of most Russians than the future state of Germany.
NANKING, March 11--Two battalions of Chinese troops have reached Taihoku, the capital of Formosa, and have gone into action against the rebels, according to word from the island today.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 11--Sixty persons, including leaders of the Woman's Suffrage and World Peace Organizations she had helped establish, attended a funeral service here this afternoon for Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt, who died of a heart attack on Sunday at the age of 88.

LAHORE, Punjab, India, March 11--A Punjab Government communique disclosed today that civil strife was continuing in the northern and western sections of the Province. In eastern Punjab the atmosphere was said to be "tense."

Martin T. Ford, former general agent of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, who died at Daytona Beach, Fla., a year ago at the age of 84, left an estate estimated at $1,000,000 to 141 employes of his company, it became known yesterday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 11 --Rapid expansion of the new program of general education to include all four college classes by next fall was announced today by Harvard. The action follows six months of successful experience with small classes in general education for freshmen and sophomores.

Notable Russian Anniversary A brief dispatch to this newspaper on Monday took note of two birthdays which occurred the day before in Moscow. On that day Foreign Secretary Bevin attained the age of 66 and Foreign Minister Molotov became 57.

WASHINGTON, March 11--It was learned today that the National Labor Relations Board, in a decision a week ago, refused to sustain an unfair labor practice charge against an employer who appealed directly to his employes during a strike and then negotiated a settlement with an independent majority of them.
CHICAGO, March 11--Prices of grain broke badly late today on the Board of Trade after an early bulge had put July wheat up 10 cents a bushel, the limit, making 20 cents in the last two days.

LADYBRAND, South Africa (Aboard the Royal Train), March 11--Queen Elizabeth made a gesture toward a colored group this morning that is likely to stand long in the history of the Union. The setting was Ladybrand Township, in the northeast of Orange Free State, near the border of Basutoland, which is directly administered by the British Crown.

WASHINGTON, March 11--The State Department announced today that it would broadcast daily reports on the meetings of the Foreign Ministers in Moscow in twenty-five languages to all parts of the world over the Voice of the United States of America of its international broadcasting division.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 11 (AP)--J.R. Steinman's Stimulist, the colt that had set the pace for six furlongs in Hialeah Park's rich Flamingo Stakes before fading to fifth, found it an easy matter to lead all the way at Gulfstream Park in today's Opa Locka Purse at one mile and seventy yards.

WASHINGTON, March 11--An accelerated program aimed at House passage of a personal income tax reduction bill before the end of this month was announced today by Chairman Harold Knutson of the Ways and Means Committee.
WASHINGTON, March 11--The Department of Justice today started an inquiry into the ambush slaying of George P. McNear Jr., president of the Toledo, Peoria Western Railroad.

The quarter-final bracket in the city-wide P.S.A.L. basketball eliminations was completed yesterday afternoon at Madison Square Garden when Stuyvesant defeated Thomas Jefferson, 45 to 35, after Commerce tripped Bryant, 49 to 40, in the opener.

In Moscow Secretary Marshall, Mr. Bevin and M. Bidault have rejected, quite properly, Mr. Molotov's proposal to discuss China's affairs in China's absence. To have done so would have been a gratuitous insult to a nation which is itself one of the Big Five and a permanent member of the Security Council of the United Nations.
LONDON, March 11 -- Preliminary discussions have begun toward the conclusion of an AngloBelgian alliance, it was learned in London today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 11 -- Two cases of willful neglect and cruelty to children appeared so flagrant today to Children's Court Judge George W. Smyth of Westchester County that he broke precedent by making details public. In one case a child was beaten, in the other a mother who had lost three children in a fire nearly lost three more under identical circumstances.

When Gladys Gooding, the organist, played "I'm Just Wild About Harry" at the conclusion of the St. John's-St. Francis game last night, she expressed the sentiment of 18,452 persons, or every man, woman and child who had witnessed the greatest one-man basketball act ever presented on the Madison Square Garden floor.

In a pistol duel at short range, Patrolman Winthrop Paris, 37 years old, of the West 152d Street Police station, shot and killed a burglary suspect in an apartment across the hall from his own at 936 Stebbins Avenue, the Bronx, yesterday and was himself mortally wounded.

The Treasury Department has just issued a warning to corporations reporting their income this week against the possibility of submitting faulty returns. This year, for the first time, corporations which have not distributed at least 70 per cent of their earnings to their stockholders must state the reasons in detail.

When President Truman goes before Congress today, undoubtedly to urge substantial loans to Greece and Turkey, he will ring down the curtain on one epoch in America's foreign policy and begin a new chapter more in keeping with the changes that have taken place in our position in the post-war world.

MEXICO CITY, March 11 (U.P.)-- The Mexican league, whose raids on major league talent had club owners talking to themselves and their lawyers in 1946, no longer will lure United States baseball stars to Mexico, it was learned tonight.
L.E. Thompson has been appointed manager of the newly created renewal parts division of the General Electric Company's air conditioning department.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, March 11--Representatives of all eleven major groups into which the Czechoslovak nationalized industry is organized expect to visit the United States soon because of the friendly, helpful attitude of American authorities and business men during his recent visit, George Kubelik reported today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 11--The United Nations' long-simmering labor troubles came to a peak tonight when Secretary General Trygve Lie faced a mass meeting of 2,000 of his staff, told them he was powerless to meet all their demands and heatedly ordered them to stop the corridor rumors that he was a hard-hearted "tyrant."

Silvio Sermoneta, 54-year-old jeweler of Bridgeport, Conn., succeeded in concealing $10,000 worth of jewelry from the Fascists and Nazis in Rome, but lost it yesterday as he allegedly attempted to leave Pier 88, North River, with the jewelry concealed in a money belt.

TRENTON, N.J., March 11-- Bergen County residents, nature lovers and public park enthusiasts divided sharply at a legislative hearing today on whether a parkway along the Palisades would improve or destroy Palisades Interstate Park.

Optimism that Great Britain will overcome her present difficulties and regret that other nations are not sufficiently willing to help her through her current crisis was voiced yesterday by two English representatives at the thirty-eighth annual meeting of the Daughters of the British Empire in the State of New York at the Biltmore Hotel.

Calling for an end to "isolationism" in Protestant philanthropies, Coverly Fischer, chairman of the Council of Affiliate Agencies of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, urged yesterday that Protestant groups cooperate closely in their charitable efforts with those of other faiths and with public welfare agencies.
Last year's campaign netted the United Hospital Fund of New York $1,756,191, a gain of $99,199 over the previous year, it was announced yesterday.

MANILA, Wednesday, March 12 --An estimated 1,500,000 Filipino electors in a national plebiscite yesterday effectively endorsed a constitutional amendment required by the Philippine Trade Act by a majority that is predicted to be about six to one. This is on the basis of incomplete returns. There will not be a full tally for another week.

PEORIA, Ill., March 11--The shotgun slaying of George P. McNear Jr., president of the strikebound Toledo, Peoria Western Railroad, on a darkened street here last night, was being investigated tonight by city, county, State and Federal authorities.

WASHINGTON, March 11--Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson today announced discontinuance of payments on 1946 cotton crop loss claims and an investigation of these losses. The reason reported was that funds available under this part of the general crop insurance program have been exhausted due to loss claims "far beyond any preliminary estimate."

Unless 54,000 Jewish refugee children in Europe are transferred to Palestine they will become an international social problem in two years, Mrs. Waitstill Hastings Sharp of Boston declared yesterday. She reported on a two-month trip to Europe and Palestine to survey problems of Jewish child refugees for Hadassah, Women's Zionist Organization of America.

WASHINGTON, March 11--The validity of arguments that there is an inequitable distribution of newsprint between large and small publishers was challenged today before a Senate subcommittee, which is studying newsprint shortages.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 11 (AP)--Ben Hogan, professional from Hershey, Pa., and Mike Phipps, amateur from Palm Beach, won the eighth annual Latham R. Reed amateur - professional tournament today at the Seminole Golf Club with, a best-ball score of 63 for eighteen holes.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, March 11 (U.P.)--The Government radio announced tonight that northern Paraguay had been declared a war zone, indicating that the revolt centered in Concepcion had erupted into full-scale civil war.
LOS ANGELES, March 11 (AP)-- Nearly nude bodies of two women, victims of violent deaths, were found today, bringing to four the number of unsolved slayings of women here since Jan. 15.

The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith announced yesterday that it had refused to recognize the Social Service Employes Union, Local 19, of the United Office and Professional Workers, CIO, as bargaining representative for its clerical employes because the union had "the well-known reputation of having a Communist-dominated leadership."

BUDAPEST, Hungary, March 11 --As a result of a new demand today by the leftist bloc that the Smallholders party purge itself of more reactionaries, it was understood that two Smallholder members of the Cabinet and five Parliamentary Deputies would be dropped.

MOSCOW, March 11--The United States drafters of the treaty for Austria won an important technical point in the first meeting of the special deputies this morning when the four powers agreed to the apopintment of a committee charged exclusively with examination of the problem of German assets in that country.

Two teams with a single thought --fourth place and the Stanley Cup berth that goes with it--will clash tonight at Madison Square Garden. The principals, the Rangers and the Detroit Red Wings, view this meeting as a vital one, since only one point separates the sextets at the moment, with the New Yorkers holding the slim margin.
STUTTGART, Germany, March 11--A provisional German Government may emerge from the Moscow conference, Lieut. Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor-designate, said today.

WASHINGTON, March 11--A new rent bill, maintaining controls to March 1, 1948, and providing for area adjustments rather than a blanket increase, was being prepared today by Senators Robert A. Taft of Ohio and Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin, both Republicans.
WASHINGTON, March 11--A "mild" recession and a "moderate" drop in prices about midyear is the Government's official forecast for the national economy in 1947.

William J. Grainger, 30-year-old unemployed elevator operator, of 2254 Cedar Avenue, the Bronx, is sorry in more ways than one that he cannot appear in Bronx Magistrates Court Tuesday to answer the charge of violation of a Park Department regulation in landing a plane in Van Cortlandt Park on Jan. 27.

WASHINGTON, March 11--The United States Government will take a further step in the next day or two as a result of the Soviet rejection of its protest against alleged Soviet interference with free government in Hungary, Dean Acheson, Acting Secretary of State, said today.

The Office of International Trade will resume the certification of shipments of specified commodities to the United Kingdom under the British Token Import Plan, L.L. Horch, New York regional director of the United States Department of Commerce, announced yesterday.

ALBANY, March 11--Dividing almost entirely on the party lines, the Republican-dominated State Senate approved tonight the CondonWadlin bill outlawing strikes by public employes and providing penalties for those who engage in them.

Substantially bettering the performance of department stores for the month, sales of leading mail order and chain store companies increased 19.9 per cent during February, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

MADISON, N.J., March 11-- Foreign Minister Molotov's proposal to put China on the agenda of the Moscow conference was described here today by Annalee Jacoby, author of "Thunder Out of China" as "a convenient red herring."

An important and highly interesting loan exhibition of fifteenthcentury German paintings has just opened at the Durlacher Gallery, 11 East Fifty-seventh Street, to remain through March 29. It contains twenty-two panels, one of the paintings, Johann Koerbecke's "Annunciation", has been transferred from the original panel to canvas.

The differences between the Civil Aeronautics Administration and Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, AFL, which halted work on the installation of blind landing equipment at La Guardia Field and Idlewild Airport on Monday, were settled yesterday and work will be resumed today.

The Prudential Insurance Company of America reporting yesterday on 1946 operations, disclosed that life insurance in force with it had reached a new high of $26,071,000,000 at the year's end, or a gain of $2,371,000,000 during the year.

JACKSON, Miss., March 11-- By the surprising margin of seventeen votes, the House today defeated a Senate-approved bill proposing repeal of the controversial "black market" tax on alcoholic drinks sold in legally dry Mississippi.

LONDON, March 11--The sober debate on the economic future of Great Britain was turned suddenly into an explosive political battle in the House of Commons tonight when Albert V. Alexander, Minister of Defense, lashed out with a denunciation of the Conservative party for having led Britain unprepared into war.

TUCSON, Ariz., March 11-- Larry Jansen, Pacific Coast League rookie on the Giants' pitching staff, was in St. Mary's Hospital here tonight under observation for a possible fracture of the skull. Hank Edwards, regular outfielder of the Indians, was in the same institution suffering from a dislocated right shoulder and a pulled muscle.

LONDON, March 11 -- Flatly contradicting a recent statement by Premier Mahmoud Fahmy Nokrashy Pasha of Egypt on the break-down of the Anglo-Egyptian treaty talks, Prime Minister Attlee told the House of Commons today that the sole cause was disagreement over the right of the Sudanese to choose their own political future.

PHILADELPHIA, March 11-- The Securities and Exchange Commission sanctioned today, in a unanimous decision, the proposal of the North American Company to sell 1,714,525 shares of the common stock of the Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company, a subsidiary, to North American's common stockholders.
First Rumania, and now Yugoslavia. For months no news comes out of these countries, and then the Iron Curtain lifts to disclose widespread hunger.

TOKYO, March 11--Belatedly recognizing the rising curse of Japanese inflation, United States authorities today set a new conversion rate between the American dollar and the Japanese yen. The latter is now valued at two cents.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 11 --Robert Montgomery's first picture under his new profit-sharing contract with Universal-International will be the screen version of "Lights Out," a 1945 story by Baynard Kendrick which the studio has purchased.

Common and preferred stocks priced at $16,370,570 and consisting of two blocks of public utility operating company common shares and stock of two industrial concerns, will be placed on the market here today by underwriting managers as follows:
PARIS, March 11--Blows were struck between Communist and Rightist Deputies in the corridors of the National Assembly today and the debate on the Government's Indo-China policy had to be suspended.

Plans for the "democratization" of Tammany Hall by making district leaders subject to direct election by the enrolled Democrats of New York County are under consideration, it was learned yesterday. The change may be made in time for the August primary election, at which county committee members and district leaders are due to be selected for two-year terms.

BALTIMORE, March 11 (AP)-- Joe DiMaggio underwent a skin grafting operation at Johns Hopkins Hospital today and inside a big bandage on his left heel was the answer to whether the Yankee slugger would miss another American League opening day on April 14.

Albert Putnam Humphreys, Fifth Avenue diamond merchant and frequenter of "cafe society," was released in $5,000 bail yesterday in General Sessions on an indictment charging him with criminally receiving stolen property.

MOSCOW, March 11--Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov denounced today the demilitarization of Germany as carried out in the United States and British zones of occupation and placed before the Council of Foreign Ministers a four-point plan to speed German disarmament.

* * * Buyers' Total Higher in Week Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,510 against 1,144 last week and 2,357 in the corresponding week of 1946, according to listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP)-- The State Department made public today the following note from the Soviet chairman of the Allied Control Commission in Hungary to the United States representative, General Weems, rejecting the American protest:

BOSTON, March 11--The Dartmouth hockey team defeated Yale, 5 to 2, in the Arena tonight before 4,398 spectators, and captured the Pentagonal League championship. By winning, the Indians gained the right to meet Toronto varsity, possibly next Sunday afternoon at the Garden, for the Alexis Thompson international trophy.

PEORIA, Ill., March 11 (AP) -- Bradley University tonight awarded its disputed basketball victory over Colorado College to the Far Western school by a score of 56 to 55. The game ended in an uproar last night when the official timepiece stopped for a time in the closing minutes and permitted Bradley to win, 57 to 56.

French ribbons were the attraction in the Laddie Northridge millinery parade that took place yesterday noon in the Oval Room of the Ritz Carlton at the luncheon hour. They were a veritable rainbow of colors ranging from the palest of ivory tints to deep blue.

ALBANY, March 11--Three bills granting Westchester County the right to take over the Westchester County Parkway Authority and to change the location of toll booths on the Hutchinson and Saw Mill River Parkways were approved in the Assembly today.

The news-hungry people of Europe, living in the dark without the information essential to arriving at correct decisions, constitute a greater peril to peace than "hunger, cold or the atom bomb," Anne O'Hare McCormick, member of THE NEW YORK TIMES editorial staff, warned yesterday.

LONDON, March 11--The British Government takes a serious view of the "disgraceful and discourteous" behavior of the Bulgarian officials and militia toward a number of foreign diplomatic missions in Sofia, it was authoritatively declared today.

PARIS, March 11--General Jean de Lattre de Tassigny, one of the three French commanders who succeeded in restoring some of the oldtime luster to French arms in the closing days of World War II, has been replaced as Chief of Staff of the French Army, it was officially announced today.

The hunter, who took a long shot at that buck last fall and has been wondering ever since how he happened to miss, will be interested in some of the slide-rule calculations of the ballistic experts, who can tell you why you missed, although they were a thousand miles away at the time.

Just a few blocks from the spot where Joseph Scottoriggio was fatally slugged last election day and in the heart of the East Harlem political domain of Representative Vito Marcantonio, a grass roots experiment in democracy is modestly under way.

A plan for self-regulation of the radio industry, involving the appointment of a virtual "czar" to administer improved standards in programming and advertising on the air, is being drafted by broadcasters, advertisers and major industrial concerns sponsoring network shows, it became known yesterday.

ROME, March 11--Pope Pius announced today the following appointments: MSGR. THOMAS McDONOUGH. St. Augustine, Fla., as Titular Bishop of Tene. MSGR. JOSEPH ELMER RITTER, as Archbishop and transferred from Indianapolis to St. Louis.
New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday that it would offer on March 19 an issue of $13,285,000 of notes dated April 17 and due Oct. 16.
NANKING, March 11--Protest, resentment and disapproval flared in Government quarters here today over the Russian proposal that the Chinese problem be discussed at the Moscow conference.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 11--The will of Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt, organizer and leader of woman's suffrage and peace organizations, was filed for probate here today in Westchester County Surrogate's Court. It gave substantial bequests to Iowa State College, other organizations and several friends and relatives.

To relieve the 100 per cent increase in work at the American Kennel Club, directors and delegates of that organization yesterday created a new office, that of executive secretary, to be held on a full-time basis and named John C. Neff of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., to the position.

A fresh selling wave struck the stock market yesterday and, although it was of limited duration, prices again fell 1 to 3 points. Losses were greater in a few thinmarket issues, but the average gave way about a point to leave the list in new low ground for the current movement.

On general principles, a season made notable by all sorts of revivals might as well include the celebrated Oscar Straus operetta, "The Chocolate Soldier," the story of which emanates from George Bernard Shaw's play "Arms and the Man."

All allocations of standard brand automatic electric irons will be terminated within sixty to ninety days, an executive of a large national distributor of appliances predicted yesterday. He said that steadily increasing production, which he estimated at 100 per cent above the 1941 level in the case of well-known producers, combined with slackening of consumer demand, will make the move possible.

Congratulatory messages from Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Mrs. Harry S. Truman and Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt to the Girl Scouts of America, which celebrates its thirty-fifth birthday anniversary today, were made public by its national headquarters yesterday.

Neither the State legislators nor child-care experts know the implications of the recommendations of the Youth Commission regarding day-care centers, Miss Charlotte Carr, executive secretary of the Citizens Committee on the Children of New York, declared yesterday.

For almost an hour and a half yesterday 1,557 passsengers who arrived at Pier 84, North River, from Mediterranean ports on the Italian liner Saturnia were unable to debark as longshoremen refused to unload the vessel.

A reduction of 85 per cent in sales and billings of the Douglas Aircraft Company in the fiscal year ended with November resulted in an operating loss of $2,019,478, according to the annual report, for publication today.

BUENOS AIRES, March 11 (AP) --The General Confederation of Commercial Employes issued a formal statement today describing as "aggressive" and "imperialistic" a report by the American Federation of Labor charging President Juan Peron's administration with using organized labor as "a political instrument."

CHICAGO, March 11--Leonard W. Trester, director of the United States Chamber of Commerce, told the closing session of the two-day national marketing conference of that organization that the four years of war gave the advertising industry its first opportunity to show "its essentiality to the nation."

WASHINGTON, March 11--The condition statement of weekly reporting banks in 101 leading cities, according to the Federal Reserve Board, shows the following principal changes for the week ended March 5: A decrease of $216,000,000 in loans; increases of $511,000,000 in holdings of United States government obligations, $409,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks, and $130,000,000 in United States government deposits; and a decrease of $149,000,000 in borrowings.

Testifying before a three-man Coast Guard Board of Investigation, which is inquiring into the fire on Friday aboard the liner John Ericsson, Acting Chief Fire Marshal Martin Scott yesterday criticized the ship's personnel for not turning in a city fire alarm promptly.
Following the trend in other commodity markets, cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 27 to 40 points net lower.

MOSCOW, March 11--The delicate topic of China, fraught with embarrassing rivalries between Soviet Russia and the United States, was omitted today from the agenda of this meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers upon the stubborn but restrained insistence of Secretary of State Marshall.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I am very much against underwriting what is left of a British policy and what is left of a Greek Government with a quarter of a billion dollars, or any other sum, and then sitting back and thinking we have been very generous.
A new parcel containing fabric, thread, needles and buttons is now available for shipment overseas, it was announced yesterday by the Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe.

SALONIKA, Greece, March 12 -- An investigating team of the United Nations Inquiry Commission left Salonika this morning with the expectation of interviewing "General" Markos Vifiades, who recently assumed command of "Greece's Democratic Army." The exact place of the meeting was not disclosed but probably will be somewhere in the mountainous area between Grevena and Kozani.

The United States team which will meet the British for the Walker Cup at St. Andrews, Scotland, next May, is scheduled to sail from New York on the Queen Elizabeth of the Cunard White Star line April 24, it was announced yesterday at the offices of the United States Golf Association.

The Detroit Red Wings skated into exclusive possession of fourth place in the National Hockey League last night at Madison Square Garden. Jack Adams' stickhandlers, facing the crippled and jittery Rangers, capitalized on the home team's overanxiousness to carve out a 4-to-2 triumph.

By its unanimous approval of the Vandenberg-Connally bill, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee has probably assured United States participation in the International Refugee Organization. In view of American sponsorship of the plan to make the care and resettlement of the homeless in Europe an international rather than a national responsibility, we cannot do less than give it full financial and moral support.
Seven leaders of opinion disagree on "group libel" laws against fomenters of racial and religious hatred, Norman Cousins, editor of The Saturday Review of Literature, reported yesterday.

Arrangements have been completed by the Celanese Corporation of America with the government of British Columbia, Canada, for the construction of a $15,000,000 plant for the production of highly purified cellulose near the Alaskan border, Harold Blancke, president of Celanese, disclosed here yesterday.

NANKING, March 12 -- Official quarters have expressed gratification over the outcome of the proposal by Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov that China be placed on the agenda of the Council of Foreign Ministers in Moscow.

TOKYO, March 12 -- The Japanese Government, it was announced today, has proposed to declare a virtual state monopoly of foreign trade and will place a program before the Parliament at the current session. If the necessary measures are approved the system will become effective by the middle of next month.

When the American Legion convenes here next Aug. 28 for a fourday session it will be the biggest convention in the organization's history and probably the biggest ever held in the United States, it was predicted yesterday.

A report recommending a program of immediate and long-range improvement of this port has been adopted by the board of directors of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, it was announnced yesterday.
H.E. Williams has been promoted to Eastern regional sales manager of the heating controls division of the Minneapolis-Honeywell Regulator Company, with headquarters in New York.
