WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission took under consideration today the question whether railroads shall be permitted to make an immediate cut in freight rates for iron and steel between Geneva, Utah, and Pacific Coast points.

Ensembles of printed silk dresses with wool coats of varying lengths highlighted a fashion show of spring costumes for women presented yesterday at Martin's in Brooklyn. The dresses were fashioned along simple lines with added smartness and slimming effect achieved through the omission of superfluous trims.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- A resolution to submit to the states a Constitutional amendment limiting the tenure of the Presidency to two terms was adopted tonight by the Senate by a vote of 59 to 23.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States issued today a study on "Communism Within the Labor Movement" with the conclusion that the elimination of such influence would lead to sounder, more peaceful labor-management relations.

LONDON, March 12 -- Weakness persisted in British Government stocks in stock markets here today, where dealers reported continued small business. With no demand prices declined from a quarter to three-quarters -- the latter in the Treasury 2 1/2 per cent, Chancellor Hugh Dalton's latest issue.

MOSCOW, March 12 -- Ernest Bevin, Britain's chunky, gravelvoiced Foreign Secretary, demanded of the Russians today an explanation of reports that they were enlisting German war veterans in the Soviet armed forces.

VIENNA, March 12 -- Austria's almost friendly attitude toward Czechoslovakia's desire to have a small corner of territory near Bratislava is probably due chiefly to the future great usefulness of the proposed Oder-Danube canal to Austria, it was explained here today.

The Very Rev. J. Hutchison Cockburn, former Moderator of The Church of Scotland and now head of the Department of Reconstruction and Interchurch Aid of the World Council of Churches, which is operating a $12,000,000 program, will come to this country in April for a speaking tour.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The chances are "a little better" that the United States will end this fiscal year, which ends June 30, with a balanced budget, John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, said today.

PEIPING, China, March 12 -- Two United States Army officers who were captured by Communists on March 1 while observing the Manchurian front are in good health and are now en route to Harbin, where they will be released, it was stated here today.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- A bill to close out the office of Price Administration by June 30 cleared Congress today and only the signature of President Truman was necessary to schedule the end of the wartime rationing and price control agency.

Members of the Board of Estimate gathered in Gracie Mansion at Mayor O'Dwyer's invitation last night for their second dinner meeting within a week in search of an operating agency for Idlewild and La Guardia Airports.

Jurisdiction of the United Nations must be enlarged and expanded and a code of international law must be agreed upon and subscribed to by all nations if peace is to be maintained, Senator Carl A. Hatch of New Mexico said last night.

Burglars entered the fifteenroom, five-story home of Roy W. Howard, publisher and editor of The New York World-Telegram, at 20 East Sixty-fourth Street late Tuesday night and escaped with several valuable items of jewelry belonging to Miss Alice Rohe, sister of Mrs. Howard.

CHICAGO, March 12 -- Grain markets fluctuated in a very nervous manner within a relatively wide range on the Board of Trade today, wheat had a range of 5 to 7 5/8 cents a bushel and finished unchanged to 1 1/2 cents down, the former on March.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, March 12 (AP) -- The Paraguayan Government announced tonight that the rebel stronghold of Concepcion had been placed under siege and that loyal troops rushed from other parts of the country had ringed the city.

All eyes were trained upon burly Walter Budko last night as the Columbia basketball team, with the Ivy League championship already clinched, ended its campaign against Harvard on the Morningside Heights floor. That the Lions conquered Harvard, 69 to 51, was of secondary interest to the capacity turnout of 2,700 persons.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 12 -- The United States insisted today that it would not allow its control over the Japanese-mandated islands in the Pacific to be tied in with any future peace treaty signed with Tokyo.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 12--President Truman arrived here tonight for a vacation which he hopes will last four days. He came by air in a five-hour trip begun after delivery of his message to Congress in the early afternoon.

Undaunted by deportation to Ecuador as an undesirable alien in October, 1943, Nelson Alfredo Lopez, 33-year-old export authority, returned to the United States nine months later at the expense of the United States Government, it was announced yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

ISDUD, Palestine, March 12--Five buses were waiting for more than 800 unauthorized Jewish immigrants whose creaking wooden ship was grounded today on a beach just out of sight of a brandnew British army camp here.

Showing increasing alarm over the plight of American merchant seafarers aboard the Liberty ship Martin Behrman, under seizure at Batavia by Dutch authorities, two maritime labor unions here yesterday called upon the State Department for immediate protective measures.

The Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company, in its annual report for 1946 issued yesterday to shareholders, showed a new high sales record of $184,660,940. This was an increase of 28 per cent over the $144,173,052 volume the year before.

WARSAW, March 12 -- The Soviet Union has agreed to release the entire Vilna division of the Polish Armja Krajowa [AK or Home Army], which was shipped to Russia when it revealed itself to the Soviet Army at the beginning of Poland's liberation in 1944, it was learned today.
PANAMA, March 12 -- Brooklyn fans may go slightly hysterical at times, but students of baseball fandom and its peculiar reactions ought to come down here to discover something new.

LAKE WORTH, Fla., March 12 -- On both sides of the roads of Florida, coastal and inland, the construction industry is busy. In this community and on the west banks of the lakes and lagoons that divide the beaches from the mainland of the peninsula, housing that costs in the neighborhood of $5,000 is diminishing the jungle at what to a traveler's snapshot eye seems a rapid rate.

A 6 per cent increase in wages and overtime rates for an estimated 30,000 seamen employed on vessels operated by twelve companies has been obtained by the Seafarers International Union, AFL, a spokesman for the organization said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- A $41,000,000 cutback in the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration's machinery and medical supplies program, to pay for the recent emergency food commitments to Austria, Greece and Poland, was announced today by Director General Lowell W. Rooks.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Senator Homer E. Capehart of Indiana, chairman of a Senate Newsprint Subcommittee, announced today that more than fifty leading publishers and newsprint producers would be here tomorrow to attend a conference to explore the possibility of a voluntary sharing program of limited supplies of newsprint.

BUDAPEST, March 12 -- By resigning for a few hours today Prime Minister Ferenc Nagy induced his followers to agree to the demand of the Leftist minority in the coalition Cabinet that the Smallholders party expel five more parliamentary Deputies and three more Cabinet Ministers.
The Department of Justice filed a final judgment in Federal court yesterday eliminating alleged restraints in foreign trade in the electrical equipment field.
TUCSON, Ariz., March 12 -- The wind blew four homers over the left-field wall at Randolph Field today but authority rode with two by the Cleveland Indians.

YENAN, China, March 8 (Delayed) -- In the one-third of all China that they control the Communists are proceeding relentlessly with their program of land division. They expect to eliminate tenantry and large landholdings and give to almost every tiller the ownership of his own plot of ground.

As a change this morning from books on Germany and on whether or not we should get tough with Russia (apparently it's all right to get tough with Britain, China, or any other ally) we have a book on what we should do about Japan. This is a novel, "Black Fountains," by Oswald Wynd. Mr. Wynd knows a good deal about Japan.
Mayor O'Dwyer's prediction in Albany of an increase in the basic city tax rate perhaps to $2.97 on each $100 valuation was received with dismay yesterday in realty circles.
WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- Six territorial legislators from Hawaii asked the House Public Lands Committee today to permit Hawaii to become the forty-ninth State.

BILIN, March 12 -- Foreign Minister Molotov's demand that all German service units be disbanded June 1 will have been satisfied this Saturday, so far as the American zone is concerned, a United States Military Government official disclosed today.

Liquor package stores will press for a comprehensive survey of the metropolitan area by the State Liquor Authority to determine precisely where new stores may be located, trade sources stated yesterday. Lack of funds and manpower, it was pointed out, have made it impossible for the SLA to make such a survey up to this time.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 12 -- In a battle involving supporters of Georgia's rival Governors, the forces of Herman Talmadge received a setback in the State House of Representatives today when they failed to muster a two-thirds majority on a proposed constitutional amendment to apply the county unit voting system to general elections.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The executive board of the Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers Union today rejected the proposal of high officials of the Congress of Industrial Organizations to permit a committee to investigate the internal row hi the smelter union and to make recommendations.

The State Senate has approved and sent to the Assembly the Condon-Wadlin bill to declare illegal strikes by public employes and to provide penalties for those who engage in such strikes. It is unfortunate that the vote in the Senate on this measure was almost entirely along party lines, with the Republicans arrayed in favor and the Democrats against.
A complete re-design of bombs and guns, bomb and gun sights, radios, and other aircraft equipment are some of the immense problems the nation's air forces face as the jet-engine age opens.

MOSCOW, March 12 -- The visiting delegates to the Moscow conference of the Big Four Foreign Ministers are impressed most by the cold weather, hard work and stiff prices as they walk about the streets of this mysterious city.

The response by sportsmen of this State to the action of the Assembly Conservation Committee in killing the license fee increase bill before it could reach the floor of the Assembly for vote was immediate, and it is increasing as the days pass.

SECURITY COUNCIL United States rejected Australian and New Zealand statements that final approval of trusteeship agreement should be part of Japanese peace treaty. Last-minute requests to be heard from India and New Zealand again prevented acceptance, at least until Monday.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 12 -- The ten major studios comprising the Association of Motion Picture Producers tonight announced a pay increase for 15,000 employes.

Mrs. Grace Hall Blashfield, widow of Edwin H. Blashfield, mural painter, bequeathed $100,000 of her estate to fourteen charitable, religious and educational groups, it was learned yesterday in Surrogate's Court, where her will was filed for probate.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- A broadened Federal investigation into the shotgun slaying of George P. McNear Jr., to include an anonymous threat reported by a member of Congress who had dined publicly with him was requested today by Chairman Fred A. Hartley Jr. of the House Labor Committee.

Harrison Abramovitz, architects, yesterday filed plans for Astoria Houses, the next of the lowrent projects of the New York City Housing Authority to enter active construction. The development will consist of twenty-three six-story buildings to house 1,104 families with low incomes.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 12 -- A new round of stormy debates in the United Nations Security Council, with the United States inevitably playing a leading role, is foreshadowed by President Truman's decision to support the Greek and Turkish Governments in an out-and-out struggle for power with the Soviet Union.

Edward P. Flynn, 40-year-old executive editor of The New York Post and The Home News, died early yesterday trying to escape from his burning apartment on the eighth floor of the Nottingham Apartments at 35 East Thirtieth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- A much-shaken Congress squared off today to meet, concededly, one of the toughest deadlines in modern history. This deadline was the providing of the financial and technical aid to Greece and Turkey that President Truman urged at the Congressional Joint Session before British commitments are withdrawn from those countries on March 31.

The Port of New York Authority has authorized a survey of Government -owned Piers 1, 2 and 3, situated along the lower Hoboken waterfront, with a view to their possible purchase and operation by the bi-State agency, it was disclosed yesterday.

With controversy at its height concerning the 1948 federal budget, the news spotlight has suddenly shifted, for the moment at least, back to the all but forgotten budget for the current fiscal year, which ends June 30, 1947.

ALBANY, March 12 -- Between $5,000,000 and $25,000,000 will be made available to the United States State Department for relief of displaced persons in Europe under the terms of legislation introduced today with the support of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey and Republican leaders.
After a rather nervous session, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 7 to 34 points net higher than the day before.
Twenty-eight boys and girls from the Queens Children's Shelter visited yesterday the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where they spent a good part of the day.

MOSCOW, March 12 (U.P.) -- First comment in Big Pour circles tonight on President Truman's speech ran from fears that it had torpedoed hope of agreement in the conference to hopes that it had cleared the air of doubt and thus had aided Secretary of State Marshall in his work here.

"The Case of Mr. Crump," by Ludwig Lewisohn, the first authorized American edition of a novel that was published in France in 1931, will be issued by Farrar, Straus on March 28. Mr. Lewisohn now is working on a massive historical novel, to be called "StarSon," about the last revolt of the Jewish people against Roman rule in 130-135 A.D.

The suggestion of Secretary of Labor Lewis B. Schwellenbach that the Communist party be outlawed was denounced yesterday by unions identified with the left wing of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

Four topnotch professional basketball teams will be seen in action tonight at Madison Square Garden, where the New York Knickerbockers clash with the St. Louis Bombers in an Association of America contest featuring the twin bill.

MASERU, Basutoland, March 12 -- Eighty thousand Basuto chests swelled with pride this morning when King George VI, great grandson of "Victoria the Good," told them that "during the recent war you came to my assistance when I was beset by many and powerful enemies."

ALBANY, March 12 -- The Republican leadership of the Assembly decided tonight to defer a final vote on the Condon-Wadlin bill outlawing strikes by public employes until tomorrow after the measure was approved at a party conference and its passage was assured.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Republican fiscal leaders in Congress gave serious attention today to the effect on proposed tax and budget reductions of the new foreign policy line as enunciated by President Truman.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 12 -- Whatever advantages tropical training may have given to the Yankees were not discernible today as the sun-bronzed Bombers opened their eight-game series with the Cardinals.

Some reduction in list prices of electric refrigerators retailing at more than $250 was forecast yesterday by retailers despite continuing acute shortages at the distributor and dealer level. They pointed out that recent reductions by the Frigidaire division of General Motors Corporation on two of its top models are far more than a good-will gesture and reflect growing consumer price resistance.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, March 12 -- Labor and management were given today a verbal spanking and a pat on the back at the final sessions of the tri-state conference of the Society for the Advancement of Management.

The United Financial Employes, AFL, which tied up trading at the New York Cotton Exchange with a one-day strike last week, will take a strike vote today among all its members in Wall Street exchanges and brokerage houses.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- President Truman's address to Congress today is being rebroadcast in the President's own voice throughout the world at the most favorable listening hours by the International Broadcasting Division of the State Department.

LONDON, March 12 (AP) -- The Soviet Union suddenly called its ambassadors home from Washington and London while the big powers were writing the future of Germany and Austria in Moscow today and just a few hours before President Truman was asking Congress for money and military advisers to combat any Communist "subjugation" of Greece and Turkey.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- President Truman gave further emphasis to the trend of the State Department to concentration on economic problems by nominating for the first time today an additional Assistant Secretary of State in the field of economic relations.

ON THE GREEK-YUGOSLAV FRONTIER, March 12 -- Yugoslav authorities barred a United Nations Investigating Commission team from entering Dragos, Yugoslavia, today. This town has been named as a supply center and station on the underground railway for Yugoslav -trained Greek guerrillas reentering Greece to resume the civil war.
WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- President Truman will go to Cleveland, Miss., May 8, to address the annual meeting of the Delta Cotton Council.
One new pool record was established in the course of the metropolitan collegiate indoor swimming championships held last night in the Brooklyn College Gymnasium pool.

Rosette Pennington presented a fashion showing yesterday at the Hotel Pierce based on the importance of navy blue for spring. Suits were shown in several variations. The box jacket version made its appearance in navy gabardine with a row of gold buttons at the youthful high collar and at each of its vertically shaped pockets.

TULSA, Okla., March 12 (AP) -- Three more oil companies have raised prices of gasoline in the wake of twenty-five cents a barrel general advance in prices of crude petroleum throughout the MidContinent and Rocky Mountain areas.

A man described by police as Spencer Brainard, 52 years old, of Branford, Conn., a former amateur golf champion who played lefthanded in many tournaments, was arrested here last night at the request of Connecticut authorities in connection with a number of thefts from golf and country clubs in that state.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 12 -- The failure of the United States to contribute to the International Children's Emergency Fund has caused other United Nations members to abopt a "wait and see" policy, Dr. Ludwig Rajchman, chairman of the executive board, asserted here today.

Dr. Koussevitzky returned last night with the Boston Symphony to Carnegie Hall. Reversing the originally planned order of his program he began his concert with Rachmaninoff's Third Symphony and ended it with a first New York performance of Lukas Foss' biblical cantata, "The Song of Songs."

May Add Shoes to Token List Office of International Trade officials and British officials are now considering including women's shoes under the British Token Import Plan, trade sources stated yesterday. The proposal is to allow importations equal to 50 per cent of the 1936, 1937 and 1938 base year period.

The Museum of Modern Art will devote two major summer exhibitions to the late Alfred Stieglitz: one to the modern paintings, sculpture, drawings and prints assembled by him during his lifetime; the other to a retrospective showing of his own photography.

ALBANY, March 12--Governor Dewey and Mayor O'Dwyer agreed today at a conference in the Governor's office that the state housing loan fund should be increased by $135,000,000 and that New York City could get along without any further financial help from the state this year.

PARIS, March 12 -- President Truman's message to Congress today constitutes a new and broadened Monroe Doctrine that seems certain to compel a showdown between the Soviet Union and the Western World, of which the United States now is the principal defender, in the opinion of some of the ablest diplomatic officials in Europe of French and other nationalities.

HALLANDALE, Fla,. March 12 (AP) -- Ariel Song, 4-year-old filly from R. Bruce Livie's Bobanet Stable of Baltimore, scored a nose victory in track record time over Hilton Dabson's favored Nance's Ace in the Suwanee River Handicap at Gulfstream Park today.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Dr. Donald Du Shane, executive secretary of the National Commission for the Defense of Democracy Through Education and president of the National Education Association in 1940-41, died last night at the age of 62.

CHICAGO, March 12 -- The National Catholic Conference on Family Life, which closed here tonight with a solemn and dramatic reaffirmation of the church doctrine on marriage and the family, in Holy Name Cathedral, heard chastening words today from a Bishop of the hierarchy.

Nothing Very Crucial It is altogether unlikely that President Peron, in identifying himself as the champion of Argentina's "shirtless" workers, was thinking of historical precedents. But in the line of garment metaphors Argentina's radical "descomichados" may call up another well-known popular nickname, the sans-culottes of the French Revolution, the "men without breeches."

Wage increases averaging 17 1/2 cents an hour were awarded yesterday to 23,000 employes of the Consolidated Edison System in the metropolitan area. The increases were made retroactive to Jan. 1 in the decision of an arbitration board set up to decide a wage dispute between the company and the Brotherhood of Consolidated Edison Employes, an affiliate of the Utility Workers Union, CIO.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- President Truman outlined a new foreign policy for the United States today. In a historic message to Congress, he proposed that this country intervene wherever necessary throughout the world to prevent the subjection of free peoples to Communist-inspired totalitarian regimes at the expense of their national integrity and importance.

PHILADELPHIA, March 12 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has directed the United Corporation to furnish to Randolph Phillips of New York, owner of 1,100 shares of United common stock, with a list of stockholders and also to address envelopes for his use in mailing out his proxy statements in connection with the corporation's annual meeting on April 9 in Wilmington, Del.

American Tobacco Stand-By While the American Tobacco Company's $50,000,000 stock financing was being registered yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission, formation of a syndicate to underwrite the offering was going ahead here.

Counsel for the National Association of Blouse Manufacturers were authorized yesterday by the board of governors of the organization to file an "admission answer" with the Federal Trade Commission covering "facts" in the trade practice portion of the FTC complaint against the association and other respondents.
STUTTGART, Germany, March 12 -- The Communist party in the western zones may become the Socialist Unity party, Otto Grotewohl of the latter party said in Munich today.

PEORIA, Ill., March 12 (U.P.) -- Roy Dailey, 36, discharged guard of the strike-bound Toledo, Peoria and Western Railroad, was taken into custody late today for questioning about the ambush slaying of George P. McNear, the railroad's president.`

The war seemed like such a disaster to so many young musicians who were just getting their start that it has been a pleasure to report on those who returned with careers unimpaired. Douglas Johnson, who gave a piano recital last night at Town Hall, is another who fits into this class.

The acquisition by the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey and the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., of a stock interest in the Arabian American Oil Company has been delayed pending the settlement of a legal action in London concerning a group agreement reached in 1928 among participants of the Iraq Petroleum Company, according to an announcement made yesterday by the three companies involved.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The tentative conclusions of responsible observers on the significance of President Truman's address today may be summarized as follows: (1) His statement was comparable in importance to the late President Roosevelt's announcement of the lend-lease program and President Monroe's warning to the European autocrats in 1823.

Health inspectors, combing the city for Analbis suppositories, a drug suspected of having caused the death of twelve small children in five States, have seized 3,044 doses of the compound since its embargo Tuesday, Health Commissioner Israel Weinstein reported yesterday.

In an address that informed the American people frankly of the gravity of the international situation created by Russo-Communist aggression, President Truman yesterday called upon this nation to meet that challenge by immediate action to support the free nations of the world in order to guard our victory and our own security.

Orders from unauthorized distributors are now being flatly refused by industrial supply and equipment manufacturers in a new drive to curb "black market" prices, spokesmen disclosed here yesterday. Immediate objective is to end unauthorized sales of metals, supplies and equipment at higher than established manufacturers' resale prices, they revealed.

A new comedy-fantasy with music, "Brigadoon," opens on Broadway this evening under the auspices of Cheryl Crawford. It will be presented at the Ziegfeld Theatre, which, oddly enough, has been unoccupied by any legitimate offering since the closing last January of "Show Boat."
Serge M. Rubinstein, international financier, told Selective Service Board 44 in June, 1941, that his total income from all sources in 1940 was $11,342.

Total business transacted by the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation last year was 5 per cent greater than in 1945 and sales of chemical products were the largest in the history of the company, F.J. Emmerich, president, reported in the annual statement for 1946 which will be distributed today to stockholders.

Charges that the manager of a State student veterans' housing project on North Brother Island in the East River had sought the eviction of a family because of its activity in a tenants' association were disclosed yesterday.

Following is the text of President Truman's message to Congress on the Mediterranean situation, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES: Mr. President, Mr. Speaker, members of the Congress of the United States: The gravity of the situation which confronts the world today necessitates my appearance before a joint session of the Congress. The foreign policy and the national security of this country are involved.

JACKSON, Miss., March 12 -- The State Legislature took its first step toward insuring "white supremacy" in Mississippi primary elections when the House approved measures late this afternoon and forwarded them directly to the Senate.
ATHENS, March 12 (AP) -- President Truman's eagerly awaited speech on financial aid to Greece was received here with the most profound satisfaction everywhere except in Communist circles.

City College and Syracuse University will engage in a play-off game tomorrow night at the Troy N.Y., Armory to determine which basketball team will represent District 2 in the Eastern Regionals of the National Collegiate A.A. tournament starting at Madison Square Garden next Thursday.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- An effort to start debate tonight on the question of confirming David E. Lilienthal, chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, and his five colleagues wound up in a parliamentary snarl and failed in the Senate's first night session.

Dave Elman, hobbyist and radio entertainer, will be master of ceremonies at an entertainment program for children 8 to 14 years old at Times Hall, 240 West Fortyfourth Street, on Saturday at 10:30 A.M. He will tell tales of his unusual and interesting hobbies and of his odd experiences with hobbyists.

The plan for a Broadcasters Advisory Council became enshrouded in confusion last night, with conflicting reports circulating as to the immediate fate of the proposed organization to lift standards of programming and advertising on the air.

Verdi's "Otello" received its final performance of the season last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. Daniza Ilitsch, Yugoslav soprano, made her debut with the company as the Desdemona of the cast, but all of the other roles were in familiar hands.

Had airline fares been increased along with the general rise of the cost of living since 1940 there would now be 7 1/2 cents a mile instead of 4.5 cents as at present or the 5.11 cents the airlines are asking the Civil Aeronautics Board to approve, C. Bedell Monro, president of Pennsylvania Central Airlines, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- The Anti-Saloon League of America reported today that dry gains in local option elections last year were twice as great as in 1945. The report said that of 3,070 counties in the United States, 978 now barred hard liuor, 887 wqine and 480 beer.

Saying that he regarded with "both alarm and disgust" the spread of Russia's power in Europe, Thomas J. Curran, New York's Secretary of State, declared last night that he wished steps could be taken to restore real freedom in Poland.
Victorious in a two-year fight for reinstatement, Charles T. Douds resumed his post yesterday as regional director of the National Labor Relations Board.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- United States companies engaged in international communications were reported today by the State Department to be unanimously opposed to mandatory legislation to merge their activities.

Bless us, if they haven't done extremely well by Oscar Straus' "The Chocolate Soldier," which was put on at the Century last evening. If there is a note of surprise in this opening statement, it is because old-fashioned operetta has become one of the more frightful hazards of the town.

ALBANY, March 12 -- Overriding a series of Democratic amendments, the Republican-controlled Senate approved today the teacher pay and bonus bills, two major items in Governor Dewey's program. Both still require Assembly action.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 12 -- "Sweet Genevieve," a screen story by Christopher Isherwood and Lesser Samuels, has been purchased by RKO as a vehicle for Barbara Bel Geddes, Dore Schary, the studio production chief, announced today.

Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey dismissed yesterday the petition for a write of habeas corpus asked by Gerhart Eisler, member of the Communist party, who has been under arrest since Feb. 4 on a warrant charging that he is an enemy alien dangerous to the peace and security of the United States.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I refer to a recent news story in THE TIMES reporting the opinion of the Friends of Democracy that the Civil Rights Congress is a "known Communist-front group" or "Communist -inspired."

LONDON, March 12 -- President Truman's momentous request for Congressional approval for the economic reinforcement of Greece and Turkey was received with gravity in today's London press which saw the move as a bold, direct challenge to the Soviet Union.

Immediate relief for the freight car shortage can be provided by reducing turn-around time at freight terminals through more systematic use of new automotivetype electric trucks to speed up unloading operations, Elmer F. Twyman, general manager of the Automatic Transportation Company, Chicago, suggested here yesterday.

Industrial users of frozen foods told members of that industry yesterday that a prosperous future for preservers, bakers and frozen food men depends to a large degree on establishment of high quality cold food packs. Speakers at a luncheon of the Eastern Frosted Foods Association, Inc., at the Hotel Pennsylvania, emphasized that higher standards alone will lead to increased volume of sales.

Relief for "hundreds of thousands of men, women and children, cold, hungry and homeless," depends upon the generosity of Roman Catholics of the United States, according to an announcement yesterday in connection with the Bishops Relief Campaign for Victims of War, to be started next Sunday.

A fashion collection designed by Hermes of Paris was presented yesterday afternoon in the Prince Matchabelli Crown Room, 711 Fifth Avenue. The presentation, consisting of twenty-five originals, was designed for the introduction of a new lipstick shade, Paris Original.

Radio has emerged as the principal advertising medium throughout Latin Ameica, Arthur Kron, executive vice president of the Gotham Advertising Company, said yesterday at a luncheon of the American Marketing Association's international markets and marketing group in the Hotel Sheraton.

LONDON, March 12 -- The British Government has determined, for the time being at least, to undertake the colossal task of pulling the country out of its worst economic crisis without wavering in its reliance on Socialist methods.

The New York City Housing Authority's refusal to permit four Negro families to occupy apartments they had rented set off a five-hour demonstration yesterday at the Authority's offices, 122 East Forty-second Street. A group of fifty persons moved into the offices after other efforts to obtain an explanation of the Authority's action had failed.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.
LONDON, March 12--Great Britain's Labor Government emerged tonight, battered but victorious, from three days of the hardest hitting political battle it had yet experienced.

The National Federation of American Shipping and the Shipbuilders Council of America endorsed President Truman's merchant marine survey plans yesterday, but the federation warned that competitive operating factors must be included in the study to make it a success.

Support of the proposal to aid Greece and Turkey was voiced yesterday by Common Cause, Inc., of 1775 Broadway. Mrs. Wales Latham, chairman, made public a telegram to President Truman, congratulating him on his address to Congress.

MOSCOW, March 12--A thoroughly prepared United States delegation to the Council of Foreign Ministers' meeting is ready to take the offensive wherever the diplomatic chess game permits. It is resolved not to be outmaneuvered into tactical positions where the United States would lose prestige, and is determined to press for four-power cooperation on a realistic basis.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The Navy air arm has thrown down the gauntlet to the Army Air Forces on the question of whether antisubmarine warfare is to be conducted with Navy aircraft designed for the purpose or with surplus Army strategic bombers.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Last September I returned from Germany, where I was attached as attorney to the War Crimes Branch, United States Army, and had the privilege of taking an active part in various war crime trials, especially the so-called "Malmedy Trial," conducted at Dachau to punish the killers of American soldiers taken prisoners in the Battle of the Bulge.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 12--The finest demonstration of slalom running in the history of North American skiing was given today as the celebrated visiting Swiss team, considered the world's best, had to go all out before turning back America's premier exponents in the open invitation race on Ruud Mountain.

The Philippine people, in voting in an overwhelming affirmation for the so-called "parity amendment" to their Constitution, giving citizens of the United States equal opportunity with the Filipinos to develop the natural resources and public utilities of the islands, have given evidence of political maturity that would do credit to any electorate.

CHICAGO, March 12 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins routed the Chicago Blackhawks tonight, 8 to 3. The game flared into fisticuffs late in the third period with referee Bill Chadwick assessing wholesale penalties -- a major and minor to McGill, a misconduct to Nattrass, a minor to Kaleta and a major to Gadsby.

TOKYO, March 12 -- Labor unions, which already control and virtually manage all Japan's leading newspapers except Yomiuri, are making a renewed effort to extend their domination over information media.

NEW DELHI, India, March 12 (U.P.) -- Rioting between Moslems and Hindus in the northern Punjab has spread into the North-West Frontier Province. Seven towns there have been placed under a curfew, a Government communique announced today.

The Koppers Company, Inc., spent $10,000,000 last year to enlarge its chemical manufacturing facilities and plans further substantial expenditures over the next several years to carry forward this program, according to the 1946 annual report issued to stockholders yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Baron Heribert von Strempel, former First Secretary of the German Embassy, identified Douglas MacCollum Stewart today as the man in whose New York hotel room he left $10,000 to $15,000 to help finance a Nazi propaganda magazine in pre-Pearl Harbor days.

Flour companies are always on the lookout for quicker baking methods, because they realize that women no longer are interested in spending much time in the kitchen. A result of one concern's experiments in "hurry-up" cooking has been the so-called "no-knead" process for breads and rolls.

MADRID, March 12 -- Three young officials were charged today by Juan Antonio Suances, Minister of Industry and Commerce, with the difficult task of balancing Spain's imports with exports to help stabilize her economy.

MOSCOW, March 12 -- Following are excerpts from the text of British Foreign Secretary Bevin's statement on German demilitarisation read to the Council of Foreign Ministers this afternoon: I have promised to give my views on this important question of demilitarization.
BRUSSELS, March 13 -- PaulHenri Spaak, Minister of Foreign Affairs, has accepted the charge to form a Government, it was announced tonight in a communique issued in the name of Prince Regent Charles.

BURBANK, Calif., March 13-- An $8,681,960 order for 134 of the improved Lockheed P-80 Shooting Star jet fighter planes was announced here today by the Army Air Forces and the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation. It is the fourth order for the P-80 that the AAF has placed since the original Lockheed jet first flew in 1944.

PARIS, March 13--Only by greater exports to the United States can France rectify her adverse balance of trade United States Ambassador Jefferson Caffery said in an address to the Comite France-Amerique today. He added that the deficit in French trade with the United States was nearly $500,000,000 out of a total French trade deficit of $1,100,000,000.

Something new in Easter parades occurred yesterday at Public School 6, Madison Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street, when a procession of costumed, gift-laden youngsters trooped in at 9 A.M. It was the first anniversary of the day the school's 1,200 pupils, ranging in age from 6 to 13, "adopted" a shattered school in Wijk, Holland, and brought nearly 6,000 useful articles to be shipped as Easter gifts to eighty pupils overseas.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 13--The supposedly better-trained Yankees, with fifteen exhibition games behind them, still were finding it difficult to display their superiority today as they dropped another decision to the more conservatively conditioned Cardinals.

The first response to President Truman's vigorous statement of American foreign policy has been encouraging. A majority of the comment in Congress, in the American press and in the foreign capitals has strongly supported his position. It is significant that few voices have been raised to challenge the President's facts or his interpretation of them.

Washington Sanitary District Washington Suburban Sanitary District, Md., announced yesterday that it would receive bids on March 26 for an issue of $1,500,000 of water and sewer bonds dated April 1, 1947, and due on each April 1 from 1948 to 1987.

JERUSALEM, March 13--Rabbi Abba Hillel Silver, leading American member of the executive of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, said on his arrival today that the United States Government "might be prepared to go a little further" in its policy on Palestine now that it was taking a greater interest in the Middle East and proposing to make large loans to Greece and Turkey.

Random notes. The average New York upland game hunter confronted with the direct query as to whether a pheasant could swim probably would come back with some biting retort to the effect that he "hadn't seen enough during the past few years to know."

ATHENS, March 13 (U.P.)--Premier Demetrios Maximos informed President Truman tonight that the Government was offering an amnesty to rebels as a unifying gesture. He added that Mr. Truman's speech was "destined to have a decisive influence on the future of the world."

ALBANY, Friday, March 14-- The Condon-Wadlin bill outlawing strikes by public employes received final legislative approval by the Assembly early today. It now goes to Governor Dewey for his approval. The vote was 92 to 54.

New home construction on Long Island--usually one of the busiest spots in the nation--has declined sharply in the face of the greatest housing shortage in history, and is threatening to dwindle to a small fraction of its normal volume as both buyers and builders resist the upward price trend, it became known yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 13 --"Ever the Beginning," an unproduced play by Lucille S. Prumbs and Sara B. Smith, has been purchased for the screen by United States Pictures as a vehicle for Lilli Palmer, the producing company announced today.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 13--The Franklin D. Roosevelt Warm Springs Memorial Commission has completed tentative plans for conversion of the late President's Little White House in Georgia and 1,000 adjoining acres into one of the country's outstanding shrines and resort areas.

MOSCOW, March 13 -- United States Secretary of State Marshall confronted Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov today with reports that the Russians were clearing former Nazis who joined the Communist - led Socialist Unity party in Germany.

The nominations to the Atomic Energy Commission have come before the Senate just as Congress prepares to face a grave decision on foreign policy. There is the more reason for not delaying action on the confirmation of David E. Lilienthal, Lewis L. Strauss, William Wesley Waymack, Dr. Robert Fox Bacher and General Manager Carroll Louis Wilson, all recommended by the Senate Atomic Energy Committee.

Anticipating a shutdown of telephone service after April 7, the date set for a national phone strike, representatives of thirteen Bell System unions in New York and New Jersey announced yesterday that they had asked the Western Union Telegraph Company to install teleprinter service between their offices in this city and the headquarters of the National Federation of Telephone Workers in Washington.

JERUSALEM, March 13 -- The Government announced tonight the arrests of seventy-eight persons, including fifteen members of the Stern gang and twelve of the Irgun Zvai Leumi, as a result of assistance from members of the Jewish community.

CHICAGO, March 13--Grain markets turned violently upward after an early break on the Board of Trade today, closing prices being about the top, with March wheat and corn within striking distance of the high reached early this week.
The testimony of a 14-year-old girl that Scout did not bite, but merely pawed and scratched her, may save the honorably discharged K-9 war veteran from the death sentence.

The Daily Worker led off editorially yesterday with an attack on President Truman's speech that was followed by various Left-Wing and Communist front organizations. The Worker declared that the President's message "marks a day of national shame for our country."

HONOLULU, March 13 (AP)-- Twelve crewmen from the tanker Fort Dearborn, which split in half during a raging Pacific storm, were missing today, and one-half of the stricken ship with eight others aboard was sinking in heavy seas.

Votes and Women Comment on the late Carrie Chapman Catt and her work for woman suffrage in another column the other day expressed the opinion that we must still wait for an answer to the question whether women have raised the standard of American politics.

WASHINGTON, March 13--The Congress of Industrial Organizations today "passed the buck" again to the American Federation of Labor in their correspondence on the problem of joint sessions to advance organized labor's cause.

PARIS, March 13--The close connection between President Truman's message yesterday and the internal political situation in France was the theme of many conversations today in the corridors of the Assembly and elsewhere in almost newspaperless Paris.

"Parsifal," which has suffered from its share of dull and soggy performances, came alive at the Metropolitan Opera House last night when it had a glowing, searching and reverential presentation. The cast, well chosen, was in the vein, and most important of all, the conductor was Fritz Stiedry.

KINGSTON, N.T., March 13-- James O. Winston of this city, a retired contractor and builder, who once estimated he had handled construction contracts totaling $100,000,000, died today of pneumonia in Kingston Hospital at the age of 82.

CHICAGO, March 13--The Investment Bankers Association's current campaign to speed information on new securities to prospective investors will be followed by an effort to obtain sweeping changes in the Federal tax structure, Edward Hopkinson Jr., president of the association, disclosed today in an address before the association's Central States Group conference.

GENOA, Italy, March 13 (AP)-- The first officer and a seaman were killed and thirteen members of the crew were injured today when two explosions wrecked the prow of the United States Liberty ship Edmund Fanning, docked at Genoa with a cargo of cotton and other goods.

Charles Luckman, president of the Lever Brothers Company, who attracted national attention recently by urging management to take a more constructive approach to cooperation with labor, indicated yesterday his ability to practice what he preaches.

Declining to comment upon President Truman's declaration of American foreign policy in the Middle East, Nikolai V. Novikov, Russian Ambassador to the United States, departed from La Guardia Field for Moscow yesterday. He said the flight had been planned for a week and was made at the request of the Russian Government.

While pounding on price may be "doing what comes naturally" for retailers during a period of price softening or a business recession, it is fundamentally "misuse of advertising," H.I. Kleinhaus, formerly general manager of the controllers congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association and now retail consultant, said yesterday.

Brass bands and bagpipes will lead the marchers in the St. Patrick's Day parade on Fifth Avenue on Monday. The procession will start at 1 P.M. at Forty-fourth Street and will entertain sidewalk crowds up to Ninety-sixth Street.

Duell, Sloan Pearce will distribute on Wednesday "Novels and Stories by Robert Louis Stevenson," selected by V.S. Pritchett. The book, published in England by Pilot Press, includes "Weir of Hermiston," "Kidnapped," "Thrawn Janet," "Travels with a Donkey" and "The Suicide Club."
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- By a unanimous voice vote, the House passed and sent to the Senate today a bill establishing a permanent Nurse Corps of the Army and the Navy.

PARIS, March 13--Tumultuous incidents today broke up the National Assembly's debate on IndoChina for the second time when the Communist Deputies, led by Vice Premier Maurice Thorez and Defense Minister Francois Billoux, walked out and refused to listen to the end of a speech by former Premier Paul Reynaud.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 13 (U.P.) -- Baseball Commissioner A.B. (Happy) Chandler suggested a cooling-off period today for Yankee President Larry MacPhail before he files charges that his old pal and ex-manager, Leo Durocher of Brooklyn, is guilty of "conduct detrimental to baseball."

Prolonged institutional care for very young children makes them impossible to educate or train for full, normal life, Dr. Lauretta Bender, assistant professor of psychiatry at New York University, declared yesterday at the opening session of the National Conference on the Blind Pre-school Child.

Starting rather slowly, the futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday turned stronger and more active in the afternoon and closed unchanged to 38 points net higher, with March and May leading the advance. It opened 7 points up to 7 points down, and was quiet most of the day.

BISBBE, Ariz., March 13--In the greatest demonstration of individual slugging the Giant training campaign has yet produced, Willard Marshall today hammered the Polo Grounders to victory over the Cleveland Indians before a gathering of 2,530 at Warren Park and pulled Mel Ott's squad even with the American League club in their exhibition series.

WASHINGTON, March 13-- Close to forty of the largest publishers in the country pledged today that they would do everything possible to assure continued publication of daily and weekly newspapers threatened with suspension because of inadequate newsprint supplies.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, March 13--Gen. Joseph T. McNarney, holding his final press conference as United States Military Governor in Germany and Commander of the European Theatre today, "completely rejected" Foreign Minister Molotov's charge in Moscow that the United States was maintaining 9,000 German troops in its zone of occupation.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 13--The United States is preparing to present to the United Nations the first detailed suggestions for the actual operation of an international atomic energy authority, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on March 8 were 805,789 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 44,242 cars, or 5.2 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week, 19,600 cars or 2.5 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 38,734 cars or 5.0 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

WASHINGTON, March 13--The debate on President Truman's antitotalitarian policy already has narrowed to two critical issues. The first is whether the United States should grant financial aid to Greece and Turkey for military supplies or restrict it to civilian aid.

Advises Tests for Pleating Reporting that several members have had complaints from manufacturers that some fabrics reveal discoloration when subject to the pleating process, the Textile Distributors' Institute, Inc., yesterday advised that the manufacturers test the fabrics for pleating before cutting.

Though spring will be here in a week, skiing enthusiasts still have plenty of opportunity to engage in their favorite sport, according to reports received from the northlands yesterday. Top conditions prevail in areas as close to New York as the northern Catskills and the Berkshires.

Two more deaths of children from Analbis suppositories, raising the total reported so far to fourteen in various parts of the country, were disclosed yesterday. City Health Commissioner Israel Weinstein received word of a child dying in Brooklyn after the drug was administered last year.

WASHINGTON, March 13--Key committees of the Senate and House moved quickly today to expedite action on President Truman's call for direct economic and indirect military aid to Greece and Turkey to fortify them against possible totalitarian aggression.

WASHINGTON, March 13--Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder listed sixteen possible tax revision fields today to which he said technical staffs of the Treasury were directing studies. They were as follows: 1-The level and structure of individual income tax exemptions.

At the turn of the present century there were two Winston Churchills who were somewhat in the news. One was a young Englishman, who had had a dashing career as a correspondent and soldier but who still had to be identified as a son of Lord Randolph Churchill.

WASHINGTON, March 13-- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, tonight wired Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York asking that he use his influence to defeat the Condon-Wadlin bill prohibiting strikes of teachers and other State Government employes.

A fascinating perspective of French music from Cesar Franck, via d'Indy and Ravel, to young Olivier Messiaen of today, was afforded at the brilliant concert given by Leopold Stokowski and the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall.

Five hundred camp directors, counselors, education authorities and recreational leaders met yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania to discuss the improvement and expansion of organized summer camps for children. It was the opening session of a three-day conference sponsored by the American Camping Association and the Association of Private Camps.

The annual rush of taxpayers to offices of the Federal income-tax collectors in New York's four districts began in earnest yesterday. The deadline for filing returns and making final payments on the 1946 income is tomorrow midnight. By then many taxpayers also must file the declaration of estimated income for 1947.

Four steamship lines, Seatrain Lines, Inc., the American Liberty Steamship Company, Inc., the Newtex Steamship Corporation and the Southern Steamship Company of Philadelphia, are re-entering coastwise shipping as private operators and thus relieving the serious situation created when the Maritime Commission withdrew from the trade last month.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP)-- Harold Ahlers, New York produce wholesaler, told the House Labor Committee today that New York City police are "restrained very definitely" from protecting his firm in a row with a labor union and "kind of look the other way" when labor "racketeering" affects food markets.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Bills providing for revision of the promotion systems for Army and Navy officers, with particularly radical changes proposed in the Army's traditional system of promotion by seniority rather than merit, were introduced today in the House.

A schoolboy, seven young men and a pretty girl in her 20's smiled with unaffected cheerfulness, yet they knew they were fatally ill. Afflicted with Hodgkin's disease, an invariably fatal malady closely related to cancer, they greeted amiably the appearance of newspaper reporters yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital, Twelfth Street at Seventh Avenue.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The appeals of small nations and small men often fail to reach important places. Therefore, through the goodwill of THE TIMES, I am trying to gain the attention of Secretary of State George C. Marshall and Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov.

CINCINNATI, March 13--With its several campuses, University of California continues as the country's largest in full-time enrollment with 40,800 students and has come up from third largest to top place with a grand total of 50,109, including part-time students.

It should not be forgotten that the President's reverberating message on Greece was immediately preceded by an almost equally forthright declaration of American policy in the note sent to the Soviet Government by Secretary Marshall on the political crisis in Hungary.

LONDON, March 13--A brighter tone seen in stock markets today was attributed to the defeat of the censure motion in Parliament last night, President Truman's proposal of loans to Greece and Turkey and to a further batch of good industrial dividends.

WARSAW, March 13--Premier Joseph Cyrankiewicz refused today to comment officially on President Truman's speech to Congress. However, in a few "remarks on the margin," he recalled that the presence of a "semi-Fascist regime" in Poland before the war had not disturbed Polish-American relations.

In the second round of a contest between the United Corporation and a minority common stockholder over the company's future as an investment concern, United late yesterday filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for its approval a "reply to certain statements in the (Randolph) Phillips attack upon us."

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 13--Whitey Kurowski stuck his head in the door of Eddie Dyer's inner sanctum just before the YankeeCardinal game today and said: "See you tomorrow, skipper. No baseball for us today. We've all decided to go fishing instead." Eddie grinned at him. "Enjoy yourselves, boys, and catch a lot of fish," he drawled in his appealing Texas fashion.

Substantial switching to freight carriers and parcel post shipments was foreseen in retail circles here yesterday if the proposed increases in express rates are granted by the Interstate Commerce Commission. Retailers normally are one of the heaviest users of express transportation for goods and would be confronted with sharp increases in costs of such transportation, it was said.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A recent news item announces that a second ice-free "oasis" has been found in the Antarctic. Perhaps this is another evidence of nuclear energy, commonly but mistakenly called "atomic energy." It may thus be connected with volcanic activity in Iceland, and the eruptions of Paricutin in Mexico and of Mount Etna in Sicily, and even with the occurrence of coal in Spitsbergen.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In his letter published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of March 8, Edward E. Lewis again tries to prove that the Balfour Declaration and the League of Nations Mandate for Palestine did not envisage the establishment of a Jewis state in that country.
The markets are in a healthy condition this week-end with supplies of many perishable foods larger than in recent weeks and prices somewhat lower as a result.

Brilliant-colored flame yesterday morning wrecked a five-story brick warehouse at 243 South Street containing valuable stocks of chemicals, medicinal products, and several tons of clothing scheduled for early shipment to Poland's destitute Jews.

WASHINGTON, March 13-- Price advances in all commodity groups, with sharp increases for agricultural products, raised average primary market prices 1.6 per cent during the week ended on March 8, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

Apparently acting to halt the current decline in the rate of growth of deposits in savings banks, which, while slight, has become increasingly noticeable in recent months, the Greater New York Savings Bank of Brooklyn announced yesterday that its dividend rate, payable on April 1, would be increased from 1 1/2 to 2 per cent.

BRUSSELS, March 13--The Tripartite Commission for the Restitution of Monetary Gold began today the distribution of a questionnaire to determine the ownership of the hoard seized by the Germans since March 12, 1938, the day the Wehrmacht marched into Austria.

Governor Dewey and Mayor O'Dwyer are to be congratulated on their agreement giving primacy to housing as the greatest need to be met among New York's problems. As a result of their sitting down together in Albany a proposition to add $135,000,000 to the largely committed $300,000,000 state loan fund for low-rent housing will go to referendum in November.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The resignation of Homer Folks as secretary of the State Charities Aid Association brings to a close an era in social work in America. He has been one of the company of great social pioneers--Jane Addams, Julia Lathrop, Graham Taylor, Florence Kelly, Edward T. Devine, and others.
Jake La Motta, hard-hitting New York middleweight, and Tommy Bell, aspiring welterweight from Youngstown, Ohio, will clash tonight in the ten-round feature bout at Madison Square Garden.
ASUNCION, Paraguay, March 13 (AP)--Paraguayan Government planes "bombed rebel military objectives" outside the insurgents' stronghold of Concepcion, a Government communique said tonight.

Production of electrical home appliances since the end of the war has proceeded at a rate far greater than anticipated and the industry expects supply to equal demand by midsummer, Brig. Gen. E.E. Jeffe, vice president in charge of sales of the Consolidated Edison Company, Inc., disclosed last night.
VIENNA, March 13--Russian authorities here have informed the municipality of Vienna that as a result of inadequate drilling, the supply of oil from the Zistersdorf wells is decreasing.

VIENNA, March 13--The Czechoslovak delegation negotiating frontier changes here has threatened to carry the whole case to Moscow and place it before the Big Four Conference. Negotiations nearly broke down today.

Re-establishment of round-theworld cruises, which were halted by the outbreak of war in 1941, was announced yesterday by the American President Lines, with the liner President Monroe scheduled to make the first trip with through passengers from New York on March 28.

MOSCOW, Friday, March 14 (AP) --Foreign delegates to the Council of Foreign Ministers read in Izvestia today a front-page editorial attack on President Truman's speech, in which the United States was accused of "new interference in the business of other states."

Lieut. Gen. James A. Doolittle, wartime commander of the Eighth Air Force, called yesterday for extensive and large-scale development of the city's airports on the ground that, to do less, would mean "a stab in the back to the security of the United States."

There must be something about Madison Square Garden that makes extra work a pleasure for the New York Knickerbockers. They made their fourth appearance for the season there last night and for the third time went into overtime, finally beating the St. Louis Bombers in a Basketball Association of America game, 78--74.

WASHINGTON, March 13-- Over the objections of the defense, Dr. Hans Thomsen, former German Charge d'Affaires in Washington, told a jury today that he authorized payment of $10,000 to $15,000 to Douglas MacCollum Stewart, now on trial for perjury.
LONDON, March 13--A delegation of twenty members of the Supreme Soviet of the Soviet Union arrived in London tonight as guests of the Houses of Parliament.

Maria Shacko, mezzo-soprano, gave her first New York recital last night at Carnegie Chamber Music Hall. With Mary Michna at the piano, Miss Shacko was heard in the aria, "Den, vieni," from Mozart's, "The Marriage of Figaro"; a group of early Italian classics; German Lieder of Schubert and Schumann, and French lyrics by Hahn, Massenet and Debussy.

A vast weather research program, designed primarily to disperse fog and clouds over airports, but that eventually may lead to the "manipulation of gigantic natural forces for the benefit of mankind everywhere," was announced here yesterday by the General Electric Company and the Army Signal Corps.

CHICAGO, March 13 (AP)--The Journal of the American Dental Association advocated today that all dentists apply diluted solutions of sodium fluoride to the teeth of their child patients as a means of diminishing tooth decay.

PHILADELPHIA, March 13 -- The United Gas Improvement Company applied today to the Securities and Exchange Commission for authority to tender, if conditions warrant, all or part of its holdings of 64,253 shares of $6 cumulative preferred stock of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation under the exchange provisions of the latter's amended plan.

Preparing for an attempt to shut down the financial exchanges and brokerage houses in Wall Street, the United Financial Employes, AFL, began yesterday afternoon taking a strike vote among its members.
DETROIT, March 13 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins unleased a sharp and accurate passing attack tonight to gain a 3-2 victory over the Detroit Red Wings in a National Hockey League battle.

A wave of complaints is being received by the Department of Commerce from cement manufacturers that they are unable to get shipping space despite heavy demands abroad, department officials revealed yesterday. Companies are reportedly unwilling to take cheap cargo during the present shortage of bottoms with better paying commodities available.

A civilian blood donor service will be started within thirty days by the New York City chapters of the American Red Cross in cooperation with the Coordinating Council of the Five County Medical Societies of Greater New York, it was announced yesterday.

The State and War Departments were accused yesterday by Matthew Woll, chairman of the International Relations Committee of the American Federation of Labor, of following a policy in conflict with President Truman's call for a check on the spread of Communist influence throughout the world.

To the growing list of major achievements on the musical stage add one more--"Brigadoon," put on at the Ziegfeld last evening. For once the modest label "musical play" has a precise meaning. For it is impossible to say where the music and dancing leave off and the story begins in this beautifully orchestrated Scotch idyll.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 13 (AP)--A hard-earned triumph for Mrs. B.F. Lister's Eternity in the Coconut Grove Purse and Jockey Job Dean Jessop's feat of winning both ends of the daily double for the second day in a row were the highlights at Gulfstream Park today.
ALBANY, March 13--The Senate passed today the Young-Demo merit rating bill under which large employers of the state will get back $118,000,000 this year from the state unemployment insurance fund.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP)-- California protested today to the Supreme Court of the United States that its people are "shocked' by the Federal Government's suit for title to submerged lands off its coast containing oil.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 13--In response to urgent requests for funds, Secretary General Trygve Lie has agreed to lend to the Preparatory Commission of the International Refugee Organization a preliminary $60,000, it was learned here today.

NANKING, March 13--Officials here believe that the Central Government's chances of obtaining American assistance to fight the Chinese Communists was greatly enhanced by President Truman's recommendation of aid for Greece and Turkey.

PARIS, March 13--German prisoners lent by the United States to France for work in French industry and agriculture will have three months to decide whether they wish to remain in this country as free contract workers or return to Germany.

The stock market moved cautiously yesterday, and price changes were mixed and narrow in the dullest trading in seven months. There was a slight leaning to the higher side, but the price index only advanced 0.01 point on the day. Timid bidding as well as meager pressure brought few major changes and the key industrials erased early gains to end with fractional decreases.

The New York City Housing Authority explained yesterday why it had refused to permit four Negro families to move into a rehabilitated tenement at 220 East Ninetyfifth Street. Four of the building's ten apartments already are occupied by Negro families and the authority said that permitting such a preponderance of Negroes would violate its policy against "Jim Crowism."

MOSCOW, March 13--Following is the statement by Secretary of State Marshall on German denazification at this afternoon's Big Four Council session: Since the beginning of the occupation of Germany, denazification has been a basic objective of the United States Military Government.

PEORIA, Ill., March 13--Roy J. Daily, discharged chief of guards of the Toledo, Peoria and Western Railroad, was released by police late today after he had submitted to a lie detector test in the investigation of the shotgun murder of George P. McNear Jr., millionaire president of the railroad.

LONDON, March 13 (AP)--Home Secretary James Chuter Ede told the House of Commons today that the Government probably would not interfere with the Wimbledon tennis championships because "it is unlikely in present circumstances that there would be large crowds there."

Cesar J. Bertheau has been elected president of Anchorage Homes, Inc., manufacturers of prefabricated houses, and will assume office in Westfield, Mass., at the end of this month, Andre de SaintPhalle, chairman, announced yesterday, Mr. Bertheau succeeds W. W. Rausch who because of ill health, will continue to serve only in a consulting capacity.

LONDON, March 13--While welcoming President Truman's message on aid to Greece and Turkey, the British Government, it was learned on good authority today, is inclined to share the fears voiced in the London press that the President may have gone too far in his sharp challenge to the Soviet Union.

MOSCOW, March 13--Discussions of the Austrian peace settlement both in this morning's deputies' meeting and in this afternoon's special committee meetings made sufficient slow but steady progress through a maze of complexities to lead a ranking member of the French delegation to predict tonight that the final treaty almost certainly would emerge before the end of the Big Four Foreign Ministers' council session.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 13 (AP)-Olivia De Havilland and Fredric March were named best actress and actor of 1946 tonight at the nineteenth annual presentation of awards by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 13-- President Truman is enjoying a popularity in Key West of which he is not yet aware. An immediate Gallup Poll among players of bolita here would put him far ahead of all possible rivals for the Presidency in 1948.

WASHINGTON, March 13--The trade treaty conference scheduled to open in Geneva on April 10 attained new importance in the view of some Administration officials today, as a result of the new foreign policy enunciated by President Truman yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 13--There is evidence of stability in general business conditions, inventories and order backlogs, the monthly survey of the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago indicated today, despite a "continuing and growing struggle between production and prices."

Costumes for the Easter parade and for spring activities were presented by Hearns in a fashion show in the store auditorium yesterday. Suits with longer jackets, short, boxy or flaring toppers in bright colors, dressier black or navy fitted full-length eoats, and feminine afternoon and after-dark dresses were featured.

LONDON, March 13--Barring unforeseen developments Great Britain will weather the coming six months without critical developments in her food supply, John Strachey, Minister of Food, said tonight upon his return from the United States and Canada.

The American Association of Scientific Workers, a unit of a world-wide federation of scientists, yesterday forwarded to Secretary of State Marshall a detailed memorandum charging political persecutions of scientists, educators and scholars in Greece, Portugal and Argentina.

ALBANY, March 13--In a turbulent session, the Assembly approved tonight Governor Dewey's sweeping program of special taxes for localities. The Vote was 124 to 18, in contrast with the 53-to-1 margin earlier in the day in the Senate.

Robert Moses, New York Construction Coordinator, warned residents of the Bronx last night that they would have to wait a long time for anticipated improvements in that borough if reliance were placed solely on the realty tax to finance any projects.

A charge by Louis F. Budenz that Soviet secret agents whom he knew personally arranged in this city the preliminaries for the murder of Leon Trotsky is contained in the forthcoming autobiography of the former Communist editor, it was learned yesterday.

The extent to which our municipal colleges have grown is made apparent in the annual report of the Board of Higher Education. Despite limited funds and with limited facilities at their disposal, the colleges have accommodated thousands of veterans. From a student body of 17,584 in 1945, the enrollment rose to 26,000 a year later.

ALBANY, March 13--The Assembly unanimously approved today two bills extending the state's residential and commercial rent control laws for another year. The Senate is expected to act on them tomorrow.

More than $500,000 has been allocated for research in heart disease this year by the Life Insurance Medical Research Fund, it was announced yesterday by M. Albert Linton, chairman of the fund. This brings the total of grants by the fund since 1945 to more than $1,000,000.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, told Congress today he was "reasonably certain" it would be impossible to reduce Federal spending sufficiently to permit tax reduction plus a "proper" payment on the public debt this year.

Surplus purchasing priorities for small business, extended through the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, have been terminated through an order unexpectedly issued by the Office of the Controller General of the United States, it was learned here yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 13--The United States plans to use half of the $250,000,000 earmarked by President Truman for the support of the Greek Government to provide guns, signal equipment, vehicles and training for the Greek Army, authoritative sources said today.

David O. Selznick, producer of "Duel in the Sun," announced yesterday that he had made "fortysix individual cuts" in the picture, which had been criticized on moral grounds by religious and civic groups after it opened in Los Angeles last December.

MOSCOW, Friday, March 14-- Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov, determined to bring the issue of China's civil strife to the fore as soon as possible, has invited British Foreign Secretary Bevin and United States Secretary of State Marshall to meet him to discuss the delicate situation in that country.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I wish to express my wholehearted agreement with the position you have taken in your recent editorial "Immigration and Labor." Indeed, one of the favorite arguments of those opposed to immigration has been that immigration results in depriving Americans of employment opportunities.

The General Electric Company, in its fifty-fifth annual report being issued today to stockholders, shows a net income of $43,039,589 for 1946, a decrease of 24 per cent from the $56,540,555 earned the year before. Last year's net is equal to $1.49 a common share, compared with $1.96 a share for 1945.

JACKSON, Miss., March 13--Efforts to insure "white control" of primary elections floundered in the Mississippi Legislature today when the Senate openly invoked the specter of party dictatorship and moved to "protect" the white electorate from restrictive measures aimed at Negroes.

William Joseph Ryan, 28-yearold ex-soldier, who married a French girl last May 20 after a two-continent courtship and many difficulties, committed suicide last night by jumping from the roof of the six-story apartment house in which he lived at 473 Columbus Avenue.

ISTANBUL, March 13 (AP)--The text of Premier Peker's statement: News agencies have not yet reported the full text of President Truman's speech, but, according to abridged versions, the President of the United States, by making his propositions for help to Turkey and Greece has not confined himself to an understanding of world-wide strategy, but has also been inspired by a point of view both fully realistic and fully humanitarian.

ALBANY, March 13--Sportsmen and conservationists were defeated today in their efforts to bar construction of a dam and reservoir on the south branch of the Moose River in Hamilton County when the Assembly rejected a bill containing such a prohibition.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Frank Creedon, National Housing Expediter, recently asserted that the raise of the rental ceiling to as high as $32 per room in New York and Chicago cannot fail but provide a profit incentive to rental building. It is difficult to see how this can be so.

Bank Closing Finalist The year-round Saturday closing schedule for banks in this area, somewhat belatedly but nonetheless finally, received yesterday the formal approval of the New York Clearing House. The Clearing House Association, whose membership includes the principal financial institutions in the city, adopted a resolution to close its doors on Saturdays, beginning on April 5, as permitted by the recent amendment to the State's General Construction Law.

Henry A. Wallace, former Vice President and Secretary of Commerce, accused President Truman last night of betraying America and promoting communism through proposals outlined on Wednesday in a foreign-policy message.

A memorial show of gouaches, water-colors and drawings by Hugo Steiner-Prag will open with a preview for invited guests tomorrow evening at the Galerie St. Etienne and to the public on Monday. The artist, one of the foremost book illustrators and exponents of the graphic art field in Europe, came to this country in 1941.

Federal Judge J.F.T. O'Connor refused yesterday to accede to a request by defense counsel to poll the jurors bearing the trial of Serge M. Rubinstein to determine whether any of them had read newspaper accounts of the outburst of a veteran at the close of Tuesday's session when Rubinstein was called a "yellow slacker."
Windows in a spacious suite of the Hotel Marguery served as backgrounds for inexpensive paper draperies shown to the press yesterday by the Clopay Corporation, whose New York office is located there.
Harold F. Bower, formerly in charge of the Truarc technical service staff, has been named sales manager of the Truarc retaining rings division, Waldes Kohinoor, Inc., Long Island City.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP)-- The Postoffice Department announced today that the new threecent stamp honoring Joseph Pulitzer would go on sale April 10 at New York City.

ROME, March 13--Pope Pius issued today an apostolic constitution termed "Provida Mater Ecclesia" -- the Providential Mother Church -- with which he founded Secular Institutes and thus gave official recognition to religious practice by laymen.
