BOSTON, March 13--A block of marble, quarried from the Judean Hills surrounding Jerusalem, became the cornerstone today for Boston University's new science building at ceremonies held in connection with the Founders Day program.

"Icetime" is nearing the end of a prosperous run at the Center. On April 12 the spectacle, which has been attracting customers from far and wide since last June 20, will conclude an engagement of 405 performances. As usual, there will be an interval during which a successor (a second edition of "Icetime") will be prepared to open around Decoration Day.

The post-season basketball jamboree will get under way tonight with a charity double-header here at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory and the play-off at Troy, N.Y., between City College and Syracuse for the District 2 berth in the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship.

On the strength of their great play on Long Island last season, Michael G. Phipps of the Meadow Brook Club and Cecil Smith, Texas star from the Austin Polo Club, have been returned to the top ranking of ten goals, it was announced yesterday by the Handicap Committee of the United States Polo Association.

East New York Vocational, coholders of the Brooklyn-Queens divisional title, routed McKee Vocational, 53--28, in a quarter-final contest of the vocational schools basketball play-offs at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon. In the opener, Bronx Vocational advanced by conquering New York Printing, 52--41.

On the heels of President Truman's request to Congress for a loan of $400,000,000 to Greece and Turkey, Senator Owen Brewster, Republican from Maine, called on the United States last night to establish a consistent foreign policy.

WASHINGTON, March 13--The Agriculture Department moved today to curb possible potato surpluses by devising a "big stick" formula whereby, if necessary, it will sell potatoes at less than the support price at which the Government acquires them.

WASHINGTON, March 13--Business and retail credit organizations are growing increasingly distressed, it was learned today, by the possibility that an economyconscious Congress may invalidate a public law, enacted last year, by failing to appropriate funds for its operation.

WASHINGTON, March 13--Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson urged today further corrective measures to prevent excess speculation on the cotton futures markets in making public his department's official report on last October's debacle.

The constitutional rights of Jehovah's Witnesses are not violated by regulations of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company that prohibit canvassing at the company's Parkchester development in the Bronx, Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora ruled yesterday.
CRISTOBAL, C.Z., March 13 --The Dodgers journeyed fifty miles across the isthmus today to beat the Canal Zone All-Stars, 8 to 4, at Mount Hope Field, but almost lost a coach.

WASHINGTON, March 13--The Senate Armed Services Committee voted overwhelmingly today, as insurance against any world crisis, to prolong the essential core of the Selective Service System, even though conscription is expiring on March 31.

AMSTERDAM, March 13 (Aneta) --Prices on the stock market were higher, due to developments in the Indies economic situation being viewed in a more favorable light. Industrials, oil, shipping and Indies plantations issues registered gains, while State bonds and banking shares were steady.

CAZENOVIA, N.Y., March 13 --Miss Phyllis Watson, 19-yearsold, of Rochester, N.Y., a student, and Mrs. Elvira Funk, 68, of Erieville, a dormitory worker, died this morning when fire destroyed two buildings of the Cazenovia Junior College, formerly Methodist Seminary.

Financing operations by the Arabian American Oil Company, consisting of $102,000,000 in bank loans accounted largely for the rise of $120,000,000 in the commercial, industrial, and agricultural loans item of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System during the week ended on Wednesday.

Joey Rao and Mike (Trigger) Coppola, one-time East Harlem gang kingpins, remained in custody last night as material witnesses in the Scottoriggio Election Day killing even though their bail $250,000 each had been reduced to $25,000 each by General Sessions Judge James G. Wallace.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, March 13--Leaders of the three Opposition parties here have drawn up statements to the United States, Great Britain, the Soviet Union, France and the United Nations accusing the Government of continuing to intimidate them after the signing of the Rumanian peace treaty.

The annual report of the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company disclosed yesterday a net profit for 1946 of $5,355,233 after offsetting the estimated net loss of $735,000 realized last year on three shipbuilding contracts by a transfer of income from a reserve of $1,000,000 provided for the purpose in 1945.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 15 (AP)--Horton Smith, veteran shotmaker from Detroit, bucked a strong south wind and fired a 4under-par 68 today to take the lead in the first round of the $10,000 Jacksonville open golf tournament.
WASHINGTON, March 13--During the week ended March 12 member bank reserve balances decreased $83,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

ROME, March 13--President Truman's message to Congress has been widely interpreted throughout Italy as a declaration of war by the Western democracies on the Slav Communist bloc. The general impression is that active hostilities will probably be avoided but that this is by no means certain and that the world finds itself again at a decisive turning point in its history.

ONCE upon a time the skeletons in family closets were kept decently hidden from public curiosity and good taste forbade that the more scandalous and deplorable goings-on of one's relatives should be broadcast from the housetop. But that circumspect age is long since past and today any literate person knows that next to grandfather's government bonds grandfather's follies and sins are to be cherished.

LONDON, March 14--In the midst of the nation's most critical fuel shortage Britain's miners today won a five-day working week. The new working schedule, which carries with it the same wage allotted for the present six days' work, was won from the Government and will go into force on the first Monday in May.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, March 14-Leaders of three Rumanian opposition parties sent a joint message today to the four Foreign Ministers in Moscow, protesting against widespread arrests during the past week of their members.

Play in the tenth annual National invitation basketball tournament will open at Madison Square Garden tonight with Bradley University of Peoria, Ill., facing West Virginia's Mountaineers in the opener and St. John's of Brooklyn meeting North Carolina State, Southern Conference titleholder, in the afterpiece.

MOSCOW, March 14 -- United States Secretary of State Marshall told Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov this afternoon what the United States meant by the word "democracy." In so doing he made probably the most revolutionary statement on the rights of man to be heard inside this city since the early days of the Bolshevik revolution.

VIENNA, March 14--Soviet representatives on the Allied Council for Austria attempted today to block one of the restitution laws essential for the return of certain property stolen from Jews by the Nazis.
TOKYO, March 14 -- Political platforms are being presented to the voters of Japan, who will have four election days in April.

WASHINGTON, March 14--The Senate Small Business subcommittee studying the current newsprint scarcity heard today a hard-pressed small publisher assail what he called the supply monopoly of large publishers.

LONDON, March 14--Praising President Truman's speech on aid to Greece as "a great event," Winston Churchill told a Conservative party conference today that "no step that I have seen taken lately has more increased the chances of maintenance of world peace and world freedom."
ALBANY, March 14--The Assembly vote early today on passage of the Condon-Wadlin bill to outlaw public employe strikes was as follows:

Trinity Episcopal Church, Broadway and Wall Street, will hold a "service in celebration of the historic relationship between Trinity and its sister and daughter churches" as a further commemoration of its 250th anniversary tomorrow at 3:30 P. M.

Consolidated net income of the Electric Storage Battery Company and subsidiaries for 1946 amounted to $3,283,510 after all charges and taxes, equal to $3.62 each on 907,810 shares of common stock outstanding, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 14 -- Seven American Federation of Labor non-operating railroad unions, representing about 500,000 workers, announced demands today for a 20- cents-an-hour-pay increase. The demands were drafted at a meeting of union leaders here and will be served on the individual railroads immediately.

Establishment of The Joint Committee for Research in the Problems of Cerebral Palsy was announced yesterday by its chairman, Dr. Philip D. Wilson, surgeon-in-chief of the Hospital for Special Surgery.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- President Truman is resting at Key West, Fla.

MOSCOW, March 14 (AP)--The text of United States Secretary of State Marshall's statement to the Council of Foreign Ministers on the democratization of Germany follows: The Berlin conference instructed the Allied Control authority "to prepare for the eventual reconstruction of German political life on a democratic basis, and for eventual peaceful cooperation in international life by Germany."

"THIS WORLD IS MINE,"* by Luigi Creatore, is an unusual first novel. It is the story of a Navy man, Victor Blake, whose mind went completely blank after a disaster- and the steps by which he regained it. There was an interval when he had no ungovernable desire to come to his senses again. The world he saw around him was not one to encourage anyone to share again in its responsibilities.

President Truman's advisory committee on the merchant marine assumes a responsibility far above the perfunctory. We must beyond a doubt decide, here and now, what we are going to do about our merchant marine. It is too easily thought of as a phase of the national economy that will, somehow, work itself out or find its level, like the water that bears it and gives it haven.

The market for shares on the New York Stock Exchange edged yesterday periously close to the low marks of the year in a furtherance of the liquidation prevalent during the past week. Prices were impaired on an average 1 1/2 points while the industrials, as measured by THE NEW YORK TIMES INDEX, dropped 2.39 points.

SALONIKA, Greece, March 14-- The permanent status of Macedonia was believed to have been the principal topic of a hastily called meeting today of the United Nations commission of inquiry on the Balkans. The session, which was closed and did not appear on the official schedule, was attended by representatives of Greece, Albania, Bulgaria, Yugoslavia, the United States and the Soviet Union.

United States trade with Russia can grow by leaps and bounds over the next twenty-five years because of that country's enormous need for American goods and technical services, J. Anthony Marcus, president, Institute of Foreign Trade, stated yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., March 14--The International Chamber of Commerce has asked the United Nations to press for the abolition of all frontier red tape passports, visas, fingerprinting and needless police examinations.

WASHINGTON, March 14--The Federal Communications Commission today announced that Press Wireless, Inc., already has authority, under its present licenses, and FCC rules and regulations, to handle for its clients such related traffic as press queries, orders and administrative messages, inclusion of which as "press messages" was requested.

New Capital Market Regardless of the dispirited cone of the secondary security markets, underwriters of new capital issues sense that their late winter weeks of hibernation are about ended and that they will soon have selling jobs on their, hands.

E. S. Diggs has been advanced by Standard Oil Company of New Jersey to assistant manager of the southern sales region with offices in New York. A. R. Martin, assistant general sales manager in New York, becomes acting manager of the West Virginia division.

WASHINGTON, March 14--The controversy over communism in the Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers Union will be investigated by a committee named today by the executive board of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

WASHINGTON, March 14--In the first Senate debate of the session on labor legislation, the Republican majority brought up today a bill knocking out portal-to-portal back pay suits and setting sharp limits to further employer liability under all minimum wage laws.

East Flatbush has changed plenty since Sam Kerschenbaum was a boy. It was only about fifteen years ago, maybe less, that goats roamed the lots in that section of Brooklyn and youngsters played baseball and football in the bumpy fields.

Here and There How true it is that language is not the fossil collection which you find in the dictionaries and among the professors. Language is the living, throbbing, growing, ever-changing daily creation of the common life!

If manufacturers do not heed consumer demands for lower prices, and overproduce many current lines of merchandise, "they will be heading for fat inventories on their own factory shelves," Howard P. Abrahams, manager of the sales promotion division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, said yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We must take issue with some of the statements in your editorial of March 2, under the caption "Rent Control," because some of those statements give a misleading impression as to the situation confronting private owners of rental housing in this city.

DETROIT, March 14--An appeal was taken today from the opinion of Judge Frank A. Picard in Federal District Court that the travel time involved in the Mount Clemens (Mich.) Pottery Company case was too trivial to warrant attention under the law.

LONDON, Saturday, March 15 (U.P.)--Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov, replying to the United States five-point democratization program for Germany, conceded today that Nazis might be holding responsible posts in the Soviet zone and pledged his Government to take action at once.

The united influences of parents teachers, doctors and the community are necessary to protect the young blind child against "the mildew of broken sense," Helen Keller, deaf and blind leader and author, told delegates to the National Conference on the Blind Pre-School Child yesterday at the Russell Sage Foundation building, 130 East Twenty-second Street.

WASHINGTON, March 14--An improvement in daylight fluorescent signaling devices, greatly extending the useful range of their employment for military and civilian purposes, has been invented by Robert C. Switzer of South Euclid, Ohio.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I do not understand how THE NEW YORK TIMES can defend its loan of sixteen tons of newsprint to The Daily Worker by quoting Voltaire.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP)-- A compromise which would permit Hawaii, under statehood, to own virtually all of its productive public lands and give the Federal Government the remainder was approved tentatively today by the House Public Lands Committee.

Four days before Serge M. Rubinstein, international financier, told his Selective Service Board that he had no means to support his many dependents if he were inducted, he offered to purchase for $800,000 the American assets of Chosen Corporation, Ltd.

BALBOA, C.Z., March 14 -- If confusion envelopes the Dodgers before they get out of the Canal Zone it should be understandable. This training trip is extraordinary. In Havana they played day and night. Here today they played a freak double-header, with one game in Balboa Stadium and the other in Panama City, two miles away.

Manhattan and New York University, which have fought it out all season long for team honors, are expected to have another close battle tonight in the revival of the Metropolitan A. A. U. junior indoor track and field championships at the Twenty-third Regiment Armory in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, March 14--The Commodity Exchange Authority of the Department of Agriculture today asked Chicago, Kansas City and Minneapolis Grain Exchanges to increase margin requirements on speculative transactions in grains to at least 25 per cent of the market price.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 14 -- There seems to be a sneaking suspicion abroad that the Florida- trained teams the Yankees are now meeting have the supposedly superior-conditioned Bombers slightly on the hip. Though not in such fine shape as our bronzed Caribbean tourists, they appear to be getting infinitely better results, and while this may be difficult to explain, the figures speak for themselves.

ALBANY, March 14--In most areas of the State, there is an acute shortage of facilities and services for the aged, handicapped, disabled and alcoholic, the Legislature was told today in a report by the subcommittee on adult institutional care of the special committee on social welfare and relief.

CHICAGO, March 14--March and May wheat and May and September corn sold today at new seasonal high prices on the Board of Trade. March wheat advanced 6 cents early to $2.84 1/2 a bushel, a new peak for futures since May, 1917, and No. 1 hard winter sold at $2.83, highest since 1920.

Canisius, bad news to New York quintets all season, added Fordham to its list of Metropolitan victims last night. The Golden Griffins from Buffalo put on a second-half drive that carried them to a 55-to-47 decision over the Rams in the feature contest of a benefit double-header at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory.

MANILA, March 14--In the festive atmosphere of a fare-well ball for Ambassador Paul V. McNutt, the United States and the Philippines tonight signed a ninety-nine-year agreement for American military and naval bases in these islands.

Possibilities of a sharp break in soaring metal prices have caused brokers to take all possible precautions against sudden inventory losses, purchasing executives for larger manufacturers reported here yesterday. With peak prices of $50 a gross ton reached locally for No. 1 cast scrap during the past week, metal traders "really are worried," the purchasing agents said.

ALBANY, March 14--The Adjutant General released today the names of these officers assigned to duty as follows: Kaufman. Lt. Col. W. F., 27th Inf. Div., to Headquarters as G-4. Reinberg. Capt. E., 71st Inf., to Headquarters as company commander. Whelan, Capt. G. J., 71st Inf., to Company F as commander.
ATHENS, March 14 (U.P.)--Athenian merchants closed their shops for two hours today as part of a thanksgiving demonstration for President Truman's effort to aid Greece.

MOSCOW, March 14--The Foreign Ministers' deputies on Austria agreed this morning that a special provision should be made in the treaty draft specifying how German assets in that country would be defined.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP)-- The Supreme Court finished hearing arguments today in the Government's claim to oil lands off the California coast and took the case under consideration.

CIO unions began distributing a million leaflets in this city yesterday urging the public, to write New York legislators demanding the defeat of anti-labor measures in Congress. The leaflet argues that another depression may result if curbs on unions reduce the nation's purchasing power.
ALBANY, March 14--The Joint Legislative Committee on Nutrition today urged the State and Federal Governments to institute a long range program of planning, education and research.

PHILADELPHIA, March 14 -- Benjamin Lieberman, a $75-a-week bookkeeper, and his wife, Jessie, were bordering on nervous collapse tonight, police reported, following their discovery of $92,800 in the basement of their modest house in south Philadelphia.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., March 14 --Still tied, 2--2, at the end of one overtime period, Toronto University of Canada and Dartmouth College were declared co-holders of the International Intercollegiate Ice Hockey Association title after their contest at the Rhode Island Auditorium tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP)-- The House Labor Committee today unanimously ordered an investigation to determine whether some witnesses lied to it during hearings on general labor legislation.

LONDON, March 14--The text of the Izvestia editorial on President Truman's speech regarding aid to Greece and Turkey, as broadcast today by the Moscow radio and recorded in London by the Soviet monitor:
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 14 -- Lloyd Gearhart today broke out with some of the distance hitting which figured in his purchase from the Atlanta ball club last year.

SHANGHAI, March 14--China has flatly rejected Russia's proposal for her participation with the United States, Britain and Russia in an informal discussion of the Chinese civil war, it was announced in Nanking tonight.

Senator Styles Bridges of New Hampshire is responsible for perhaps the least realistic comment offered thus far from a responsible source on President Truman's request that Congress appropriate $400 millions for strengthening Greece and Turkey. This was the observation that such a policy would "knock budget plans askew."

Two Broadway-bound attractions have fallen by the wayside and now are slated to be done next season-- if at all. They are "The Greatest of These" and "Heyday," closing down for repairs after performances this evening in Chicago and New Haven, respectively.

Feike Feikema collected eighteen years of detailed weather information, while working on his new book, "This Is The Year." a novel of Iowa farm life. Five years were selected that caught the spread of farm life in the prairie: 1918, 1924, 1929, 1933-34 and 1936--a good year, an indifferent year, a good year mixed with bad, a bad year and a very bad one.

Trade Gains Narrower Here Retail trade gains here narrowed this week. Department store volume was estimated at 5 to 10 per cent over a year ago. Ready- to-wear figures failed to reflect any bulge, although Easter comes two weeks earlier than was the case last year.
SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 14 --Some of the greatest skiing figures in the world are gathered tonight in this snow paradise for the seventh annual Harriman Cup races slated for this week-end.

Spring fashions for the whole family was the well-developed story presented yesterday at the St. George Hotel by Abraham Straus for the benefit of the School Settlement Association. Easter parade outfits vied with those for travel and play as manikins in children's, tenn-agers', misses' and women's styles came down the runway.

TROY, N. Y., March 14--In a contest as wild and closely fought as any ever seen here, City College of New York conquered Syracuse University, 61--59, before a capacity turnout of 5,000 at the Troy Armory tonight. The C. C. N. Y. quintet thus hurdled the last obstacle in its path to competition in the National Collegiate A. A. tournament at Madison Square Garden next week.

HONOLULU, March 14 (AP)-- The master and nine crewmen of the wrecked tanker Fort Dearborn were rescued from the severed bow section today while twenty others aboard the stern section got the engines going and headed that Dart of the ship for Honolulu under its own power.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- After a visit today to the Navy Department to get data on the plan favored by the Navy for improvement of the Panama Canal, several members of Congress predicted that the rival, and more expensive, sea-level plan was "dead."
NEW ORLEANS, March 14-- Forty-four New Orleans property owners filed a petition with the District Attorney today demanding the removal of Mayor De Lesseps S. Morrison from office.

JERSUALEM, March 14 -- A wide survey of the Zionist movement's present political position in Palestine and the world's capitals occupied the first session of the Jewish Agency Executive in an emergency meeting today.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 14 (AP)--Three lesser lights among the touring professionals left the heavy artillery of the clan behind today when they forged into a tie for the lead at the halfway mark of the $10,000 Jacksonville open golf tournament.

Sportsmen and conservationists lost another battle on Thursday when the New York State Assembly voted down their efforts to bar the construction of the proposed dam and reservoir on the South Branch of Moose River in the Adirondacks.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 14 -- The Eastern Intercollegiate Wrestling Association's forty-third annual three-ring mat show got under way in Yale's Payne Whitney Gymnasium, today, and at the end of more than six hours of at times exciting competition the squad from Lehigh University was pacing the field.

WASHINGTON, March 14--The Interstate Commerce Commission today approved acquisition of 78,145 shares of Wheeling Lake Erie Railway stock by the Nickel Plate from the Chesapeake Ohio, the price to be paid not to exceed $4,168,388, and control by the C. O. and the Alleghany Corporation, through the Nickel Plate, of the W. L. E.

VIENNA, March 14 -- Austria has hopes that the treaty negotiations in Moscow may bring recognition of her claim to about $50,000,000 worth of holdings in Hungary surrendered to the Soviet Union as alleged German property.

WASHINGTON, March 14--The House Ways and Means Committee concluded income tax reduction hearing's today with the Republican majority brushing aside the question of whether the country's new foreign policy was an obstacle to a cut.

A conference to discuss India's cultural and industrial needs will be held here next month at the Hotel Biltmore under the auspices of the India Society, Hari G. Govil, president and founder of the society, announced yesterday. With specific dates yet to be set, the conference will last three days, comprising sessions on films, press, radio, aviation and education, he explained.

ALBANY, March 14--Governor Dewey, in a special message to the Legislature, asked today for the appropriation of an additional $5,000,000 to help colleges and universities meet the housing needs of returning veterans and new high school graduates.

PATERSON, N. J., March 14 -- Parents of children in Public School 22 here conferred today with school commissioners in an effort to remove from the school special-class pupils, who they charge are responsible for a juvenile crime wave.

In an atmosphere of charges and counter-charges of discrimination against Negro workers, the Strauss Stores Corporation, distributors of automobile accessories, went into Supreme Court in Jamaica yesterday to seek determination by a jury trial whether a recent strike in fifty-six of its retail stores in the metropolitan area was justified or barred by a union contract.

JERUSALEM, March 14 -- Renewing their campaign against transport and oil supplies, the Jewish underground forces blew up another section of railway line in Palestine today after blasting an oil pipeline at Haifa.

Ground-breaking ceremonies for Junior High School 157, the first of twelve post-war school construction projects in Queens, were held yesterday in Forest Hills. Part of the Board of Education's $14,000,000 building budget allocated for the borough, the structure will cost $2,500,000.

WASHINGTON, March 14--The bipartisan campaign for urgent action toward unification of the armed forces, already forwarded by the atmosphere of crisis concerning the Mediterranean, gained powerful adherents in Congress today.

ROME, March 14--Rear Admiral Ellery W. Stone today announced that the Italian Military Affairs Section, which he has headed, would be placed directly under Allied Military Headquarters. This, he said would be in line with the policy of reduction preliminary to the expected evacuation of all Allied troops from Italy.

CHAPEL HILL, N. C., March 14 --As it celebrated its twenty-fifth anniversary today, the University of North Carolina Press was acclaimed the leader in its field in the South and one of the half dozen foremost university presses in the nation.

ALBANY, March 14--Formal requests for public hearing's on the Condon-Wadlin bill to prohibit strikes by public employes before it is signed were filed with Governor Dewey today by Democratic leaders and spokesmen for organized labor.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 14--W. Stuart Symington, Assistant Secretary of War, and Samuel I. Rosenman joined President Truman for luncheon today, but their visits were described as purely social. The President continued his vacation routine of late breakfast and sun baths.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., March 14--A preliminary program for collecting from workers in every country one days pay to help supply food, medicine and clothing to 30,000,000 needy youngsters will be submitted tomorrow to the United Nations Economic and Social Council.
PARIS, March 14--Scenes of discord between the Communists and members of other parties in the French Cabinet were repeated for the third successive session of the debate on Indo-China today.
MOSCOW, March 14 -- Soviet newspaper and radio coverage of the Council of Foreign Ministers' meeting here is expanding as the issues widen and temperatures rise in the Council.

One of the remarkable things about Mr. Truman's remarkable message is that the boldest declaration ever offered by an American President in peacetime is made by the man who a few months ago was rated timid, uncertain, and overpowered by events and responsibilities too big for him.

Age is a general guide to children's play interests, but it is not always a reliable yardstick, Clara Lambert declares in a new stud issued yesterday by the Play Schools Association, 119 West Fifty-seventh Street.
Dr. Clyde Kluckhohn, Professor of Anthropology at Harvard University, received an award of $10,000 yesterday for his "Anthropology and the World Today," which will appear in book form next fall.
PEIPING, March 14 -- Chinese Communists, with one eye on the Moscow conference, struck two hard blows for the totalitarian cause in China yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 14 --Universal - International today announced a switch in Robert Montgomery's production plans by which "Ride the Pink Horse" will be his first acting-directing venture under his new profit-sharing contract with the studio, instead of "Lights Out."
It's a wonder that in all the years, perhaps centuries, that women have been strugging over pastry, no one ever thought of inventing a gadget like the Pido lifter.

WASHINGTON, March 14-- Unique steps were taken today to see that Congress and the people were informed fully, before Congressional test votes were taken, on the facts and implications of President Truman's $400,000,000 program for Greece and Turkey.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 14 --The Liberty ships which carried millions of tons of supplies to Allied troops during the war are doomed to disappear from the seas under the stress of post-war competition.

Relief from the tension of near- month strength in the cotton futures market was evident yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange, as, with the expiration of March futures, the market eased and closed at losses of 23 to 39 points on active months.

BERLIN, March 14--The first four-zone post-war conference of any German political party began today deep in the Soviet sector of Berlin. Delegates from the various wings of the Christian Democratic Union met there for a three-day unity session.
WASHINGTON, March 14--A Congressional attempt to force the ouster of Edgar L. Warren as director of the Conciliation Service by crippling the service's budget was disclosed today.

After a year's study the Red Cross and the Coordinating Council of the five county medical societies in the metropolitan district have evolved a plan for a voluntary blood-donor service for the city. Public-spirited citizens are to give up a pint of blood free of charge, and this blood will in turn be passed on without charge to five city hospitals in the beginning and eventually to voluntary hospitals in all the boroughs.

Fulton County, Ga., announced yesterday that it would receive bids on March 27 on issues of various bonds aggregating $20,000,000. Dated Oct. 1, 1946. the bonds will come due Jan. 1 from 1948 to 1976.

LONDON, March 14--With Cape operators suffering from nervousness, South African gold-mining shares fell away sharply today in the stock markets here as successively lower quotations arrived from Johannesburg. Operators here advanced the theory that the selling was caused by uncertainty about international affairs.
MOSCOW, March 14--Approximately 800,000 German prisoners of war are still held in the Soviet Union and more than 1,000,000 have been repatriated, an authoritative Soviet source said tonight.
Kirsten Flagstad, Norwegian soprano and former Metropolitan Opera singer, returned yesterday on the United States liner America after a six-year absence.
LONDON, March 14 -- On the first full day of their visit to Great Britain as guests of the two Houses of Parliament, twenty delegates of the Supreme Soviet learned today how London is governed.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., March 14--Declaring that the United States had long considered freedom of information "one of the pillars of lasting peace," Leroy D. Stinebower today urged the United Nations to speed the creation of a subcommission on freedom of information and the press.

Trapped in the second of two night-club holdups within two hours three armed thugs shot it out early yesterday with two patrolmen at the Cafe Vienna, 50 West Seventy-seventh Street. One suspect was caught unhurt but the others, supposedly wounded, escaped.

PARIS, March 14--The mission of the Catholic Popular Republican Movement [MRP] was described at its national congress today as that of finding a middle road between capitalism and communism, both of which it has repudiated. The aim of the MRP was so defined in a long speech on doctrine by Albert Gortais, acting secretary.

Olivia De Havilland and Fredric March received well-earned "Oscars" on Thursday evening from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, but it was a new actor, an avowed one-timer, who walked off with the show. Harold Russell got a regular award for This work in "The Best Years of Our Lives," as the best supporting actor of the year in the Samuel Goldwyn film, which was adjudged the best motion picture of the year.

Members of the United Financial Employes, AFL, employed in the Stock, Curb and Cotton Exchanges and several brokerage houses voted overwhelmingly to cancel contracts in thirty days to wage a strike intended to shut down the financial district, the union announced last night.

RICHMOND, Va., March 14 (AP) -- Boyd Williams, All-Dixie Professional League center for the Richmond Rebels last season, today was sold to the Philadelphia Eagles of the National Football League. No sale price was announced by Mac McEver, owner of the Rebels.

Jake La Motta punched his way to a decision over Tommy Bell of Youngstown, Ohio, in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. The Bronx middleweight, mainly on the strength of a club-like left to the body, out-fought his lighter rival clearly enough to earn a unanimous verdict.

The management of Transcontinental Western Air, Inc., which has beeen hampered since last July by financial and operational difficulties, has canceled a $13,500,000 order for eighteen Constellations from the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation and has decided not to seek a loan of $40,000,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation at this time, it was made known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 14--Defense attorneys were overruled by Chief Justice Bolitha J. Laws when they insisted today that the Government prosecution of Douglas MacCollum Stewart for perjury should be dismissed because the Department of Justice case "was built out of the whole cloth."
Investors are prepared to build 3,500 apartments to rent at $16 or $17 a room in the Bronx and Queens, Herman T. Stichman, State Housing Commissioner, reported yesterday.

Three men, including a former Army lieutenant whose assignment during the war was to organize protection for Government property at the Brooklyn Army Base, were arraigned yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn, on a charge of receiving stolen property taken in interstate commerce.
MIAMI, Fla., March 14 (AP)-- Longshot players had a picnic at Gulfstream Park today and only in the seventh race did a favorite get home first.

SEATTLE, Wash., March 14-- Col. William H. Donaldson Jr., commander of the Seattle Port of Embarkation, said today that since last September fifty-one Japanese- manned Liberty ships have arrived in Pacific Northwest ports from Japan for decommissioning.

A 3-year-old war orphan, whose parents or nationality may never be known, arrived here yesterday aboard the Government-owned Marine Flasher. The ship, carrying 890 passengers, including displaced persons, war orphans, Belgian naval and merchant marine personnel from Bremerhaven and Antwerp, tied up at Pier 90, North River.

There should be instruction in the public schools in the fundamental values and standards common to all religions and beliefs rather than sectarian religious instruction on released time as at present, speakers declared yesterday at a panel discussion of the American Education Fellowship conference at the Hotel New Yorker.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 14-- President Truman's appeal to Congress for support on a foreign policy restricting totalitarian inroads was hailed as the "turning point in the world's history" in the Turkish press this morning.

ALBANY, March 14--By unanimous vote, the Senate gave final legislative approval today to three bills extending state residential and commercial rent controls for another year. With enactment of the program asked by Governor Dewey in his annual message, continuance of state regulation thus is assured.

The Associated Press reported yesterday from Washington that "President Truman's bid for American help for Greece and Turkey has gained such momentum in Congress that opposition seems likely to be confined to only a rear-guard action aimed at narrowing the terms."

ROME, March 14--L'Unita, Communist party newspaper, discussing President Truman's message to Congress hints at the part that "the dollars of bankers and the officials of trusts" have had in determining the American attitude.

Better style and quality in neckties at no increase in prices will be the theme of a promotional and publicity campaign to be undertaken shortly by the Men's Neckwear Manufacturers' Institute and the Tie Fabric Association, it was announced yesterday.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 14--Definitely spiking rumors of concessions or mediation concerning the stalemated Anglo-Egyptian treaty negotiations, Premier Mahmoud Fahmy Nokrashy Pasha announced without qualification today that there would be no resumption of the talks.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- A gruesome description of morbid motorists endangering lives while speeding to view results of fatal highway accidents was presented here today by Governor Millard F. Caldwell of Florida to emphasize country-wide failure to curb reckless driving.

WASHINGTON, March 14--To help relieve world shortages, short-period controls in Japan have been authorized for increasing the export of goods to areas that have suffered from Japanese aggression. This decision, made by the Far Eastern Commission, was announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 14--To help relieve world shortages, short-period controls in Japan have been authorized for increasing the export of goods to areas that have suffered from Japanese aggression. This decision, made by the Far Eastern Commission, was announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 14--The Government of Poland has asked the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization for a special study mission such as that which the United Nations group sent to Greece last year, it was learned today.

MOSCOW, March 14--Denunciation of the plan for American financial aid to Greece and Turkey set out by President Truman in his address to Congress on Wednesday as an attempt to usurp the sovereignty of those countries was the editorial theme of Izvestia today.

College professors whose minds have been dulled by the routine of academic life should reach for a hammer and a saw or take jobs as book salesmen, according to Prof. Harold Hagan of the City College Biology Department.

WARSAW, March 14--While the press here assailed President Truman's appeal for financial aid to Turkey and Greece, a Polish Government spokesman said today that the part of the speech dealing with Poland and communism would not be published here because of its possible effect on the underground.

The New Jersey State Mediation Board, acting under the new public utilities law in the State, intervened yesterday in the telephone situation as a contract covering 4,800 plant workers of the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company expired without extension.

PHILADELPHIA, March 14-- The Securities and Exchange Commission today endorsed the American Power and Light Company's proposal to lend up to $9,000,000 this year to two of its subsidiaries, the Texas Utilities Company and the Florida Power and Light Company.

New York State will institute a canvass of all camps within its borders this summer to insure that health and sanitary codes are being strictly complied with, Dr. Irwin Conroe, assistant commissioner of the State Department of Education, declared here yesterday.

Louis Kaufman is a violinist with a lively sense of his own time. His programs are never a rehash of what most other fiddlers play time and concerts without end. He seeks out living composers and gets them to write for him. He finds interesting contemporary works wherever he looks.

WASHINGTON, March 14--The first monthly report of the Advisory Committee on Voluntary Foreign Aid of the United States Government, issued today, showed that $14,084,653 worth of cash and commodities had been sent abroad by fifty-eight voluntary agencies in the month of January.

WASHINGTON, March 14-- Louis Saillant of France, head of a labor delegation that will leave tomorrow for Japan and Korea, scoffed today at a protest that the objective of the trip was to spread communism.

Rose Slatkovitz, violinist, gave a recital last night at Carnegie Chamber Music Hall. Her serious and exacting program contained Bach's Concerto in A minor, the Mendelssohn Concerto, Chausson's "Poeme," and a final group composed of Bloch's "Nigun," Szymanowski's "La Fontaine d'Arethuse," and the "Nana" and "Jota" by de-Falla.

Five hundred and seventy-four of the country's leading thoroughbreds, among them Assault, Armed. Stymie, Gallorette, Rico Monte, Talon, Cosmic Bomb, Blue Border, Better Value, Stepfather, Honeymoon. Be Faithful and W. L. Sickle, have been nominated for the seven stake events that stud the Metropolitan Jockey Club's twenty-five-day meeting which will open the New York racing season at Jamaica on April 5, it was announced yesterday.

Working for hours in the thin beams of pen-style flashlights through Thursday night, leisurely cracksmen with a knowledge of jewelry values got away with 2,000 watches, more than 100 diamond and cocktail rings, a brooch and $3,500 in cash in the fourth-floor plant of the Uris Sales Corporation, 222 Fourth Avenue.

JACKSON, Miss., March 14-- The Mississippi Legislature approved two "white primary" bills today under compromise agreements that left wide doubt as to the actual efficacy the restrictive measures would have when applied at the polls.

Holding that "the ends of justice would not be served" by sending them to jail, Magistrate Leonard H. McGee gave suspended sentences to Mr. and Mrs. August Marrone of 12 8 Colgate Avenue, the Bronx, yesterday.

PARIS, March 14--Franco-Bulgarian relations, strained as a result of a recent incident during which the French Minister in Sofia was allegedly menaced by police near his legation, underwent additional complications, it was learned today, when the Bulgarian Minister to France unexpectedly left for Sofia two days ago.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- A truce has been made between the Army Air Forces and the Navy in their dispute over how anti-submarine warfare shall be conducted. This means that arguments shall cease, officially at least, but the Navy still is left without money to procure the patrol planes it maintains are necessary.

With kidskins the brightest spot in the supply picture at the present time, the over-all leather supply for this year should be about the same as in 1945 and 1946 and should be sufficient for a production of approximately 425,000,000 pairs of leather shoes, the National Shoe Manufacturers Association estimated yesterday.

ALBANY, March 14--Teachers serving as regular substitutes in any public school district, including New York City, would become entitled to a $300-a-year rise over their June 30, 1945 pay under a bill approved today by the Assembly Rules Committee.

WASHINGTON, March 14--Britain has agreed, at the request of the United States Government, to permit the importation of limited quantities of thirty-four additional commodities under its British Token Import Plan, the Department of Commerce announced today.
WASHINGTON, March 14--The House Banking and Currency Committee reported out unanimously today a bill to continue price control and rationing of sugar until Oct. 31.

Bossism in American political life was attacked yesterday by Charles Edison, former Governor of New Jersey, as "the reverse of popular government and as a kind of domestic dictatorship absolutely irreconcilable with democracy."

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP)-- Scientists have produced a device which "reads out loud." They say it may be possible to have it read to a blind or handicapped person or to people "just too plain lazy to read."

WARSAW, March 14 (AP)--The Polish Government today ordered that, effective April 1, at least 4,000,000 persons be dropped from the rationing lists. The move was a desperate attempt to conserve supplies in a food crisis that United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration officials said would soon see the average Pole getting less to eat than the Germans.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., March 14--Action of Congress in formulating a national labor policy will determine whether there will be industrial peace or class conflict in this country, it was declared here tonight by Carroll E. French, director of the National Association of Manufacturers industrial relations department.

The New York Legislature has strengthened the foundations of government by its completion of action on the bill that forbids strikes by public employes. We consider it a reaffirmation of principles that assure the execution of the will of the people, that safeguard our welfare in times of emergency and guarantee orderly government as against chaos.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, March 14 (AP)--The Government of Paraguay, faced with an army revolt in the northern part of the country, declared tonight that troops from the Chaco region had remained loyal. In contradiction, however, rebel forces in Concepcion said in a radio broadcast that the Chaco garrison had joined the uprising.
A general revision of the Rules of Golf has been put into force, effective immediately, by the United States Golf Association, according to an announcement made by that body yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 15 (U.P.) -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur reported tonight that Japan is making both political and economic progress despite strikes, shortages and black market activities.

IN her first, published novel Josephine Eckert has chosen an oblique angle from which to tell her story. "The Practicing of Christopher" treats of a pretty run-of-the-mill tangle of adult relationship as seen, however, through the limited comprehension of a nine-year-old boy.

BUFFALO, March 15 -- Mayor Bernard J. Dowd submitted to the City Council today a budget of $48,279,600, a record high and $5,493,800 more than the appropriations for this fiscal year. The council must return an approved budget by April 1.

MEXICO CITY, March 15 -- Before dawn on the morning of April 28, 1905, a tall man and three little daughters trudged two miles through the darkness from their home in suburban Tacubaya to the monument to the child heroes of 1847 in Chapultepec Park.
CHICAGO, March 15 -- The bedding industry's return to "normalcy" has been at a rapid pace since the first of the year, a spokesman for the trade said today.
THE incomparably majestic delphinium is the king of all outdoor flowers. Every day in June and July and again in September, new spikes open their blossoms of exquisite blue, pink and white.

Building of new one-family and two-family houses in the Rockaways during 1947 will add about $3,500,000 to valuations there, according to an estimate made by William F. Brunner, chairman of the real estate committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the Rockaways.

Lewis W. Douglas, newly appointed American Ambassador to Great Britain, declared yesterday afternoon that a close relationship between the two nations "is one of the important factors in the establishment of a lasting peace." He added that President Truman's foreign policy speech was "a clear pronouncement that this time we are not going to withdraw from world affairs."

ON one side of Margaret Millar's equilateral triangle stands Martha Pearson, a young and beautiful girl with two exaggerated anxieties; her full-blown figure which she considers not quite decent, and a guilt complex which she developed as a hangover from a youthful love affair.

NINETEEN years ago in this Review: Page 1 was in the spirit of those rich, carefree days: "This Mounting Tide of Wealth" was the headline over a critique of "American Prosperity: Its Causes and Consequences," by Paul M. Mazur.
OMAHA, March 15 -- The signs and portents appear good to those Midwesterners who look toward the snow-capped mountains for precious water.

LONDON, March 15 -- Turkey and Greece have a strategic and economic importance to the United States and Britain alike. Lying at the eastern end of the Mediterranean and under western influence, they serve as bastions against Soviet Russia's ambitions in the Middle East and guard the approaches to the rich oil fields around the Persian Gulf.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was somewhat irregular yesterday, closing 10 points higner to 22 points lower than the day before.

ALTHOUGH Easter comes two weeks earlier this year and normally should be reflected at this time in heavier consumer buying of apparel and accessories, this stimulus has not been particularly evident in retail trade thus far.
Etchings and engravings by old and modern masters now on exhibition at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, will be auctioned tomorrow and Tuesday evenings at 8 o'clock.

CHICKENS are a natural supplement to a thriving garden and take a lot less time than plants. A small flock may not make a chicken farm but it does supply a family, as it did ours, with all the chickens and eggs they can use, and enable week-end guests to take home a dozen fresh eggs and occasionally a dressed chicken fresh from the freezer.

MARTHA GRAHAM'S season at the Ziegfeld Theatre was, as is usual with Graham seasons, a stimulating affair. It was not especially the new numbers and revivals that grave it its satisfactions and its recitements, though there was perhaps more than the customary quota of them, and they are certainly worth discussing when circumstances permit.

THERE is an old saying that "a well-cared-for garden is a good garden," and it follows that good gardening requires good tools and the right one for every operation. No other investment will give the gardener better dividends than a complete assortment of well-made and durable tools, supplemented by other labor-saving accessories.
PARIS, March 15 (Reuters) -- Jean Richard Bloch, who died here today, was one at the men who urged that the death sentence for Marshal Petain, Vichy head of the state, should be carried out.

Record sales of $30,836,262, which rose from the previous year's volume of $11,433,710, and an increase of $2,986,081 in earnings were reported yesterday by Bendix Home Appliances, Inc., in its annual statement for 1946.

The suggestion calling for employment of a new yardstick of efficiency in distribution, similar to the man-hour production formula in industry, made last week by Fenton B. Turck, of Turck, Hill Co., industrial engineers, was termed "challenging" in retail circles here.

MANY older varieties of chrysanthemums, in danger of being forgotten in the rush for new and improved sorts, deserve to be planted still. The merits of new kinds are undeniable, but on older lists are names that hold their own against all the innovations.

THOSE who like roses seldom let a spring go by without setting out at least one new climber or a couple of hybrid teas. All activities with roses are prompted by various signs of spring, from flower shows to forsythia bursting into bloom, and prove a relief after months of looking at colored pictures of roses in the catalogues.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, March 15 (AP) -- The Stars and Stripes, United States Army newspaper, in its supplemental edition Weekend today quoted General McNarney as having said in an interview that any lessening of United States aid to Germany would leave the Germans "ripe for organization by communism" and that "I would fear more a Communist inspiration than one from German Nationalists or Nazis."
Labor unions have come in for so much criticism in recent months that it is a genuine source of pleasure when the opportunity arises to say something of a commendatory nature.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- A White House statement issued today said that messages from Greek leaders welcoming the prospect of American assistance had been received by President Truman as assurance of the unreserved cooperation of Greece in the proposed $250,000,000 assistance.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We should consider ourselves divinely directed to grant aid to all people everywhere who need it. But the relief we send abroad must be used to help humanity live, not die. If we designate part of it for the purchase of arms by the recipient nations, we become criminals, rather than benefactors.

NO property, however small, seems complete without a fruit tree of some sort to supply both spring blossoms and a modest but satisfying harvest later in the year. Care is needed in making a selection, for in some cases trees will not set fruit without a suitable variety near by for cross-pollination.

MOSCOW, March 15 -- An official British spokesman said tonight that Foreign Secretary Bevin's delegation thoroughly agreed with the definition of democracy offered at yesterday's Council meeting by Secretary of State Marshall. He added that despite the differences between the United States and British governmental forms, the essential and philosophical understanding of that key word was the same.

DAMME, Belgium, March 15 -- Alois Danneels, a 27-year-old native of this twelfth century Flemish hamlet, returned home ten days ago after escaping from a Soviet slave camp at Relst, near Koenigsberg, where he said there were 3,000 Belgian, Dutch, French and Czechoslovak civilian prisoners.

ONE of the pleasures of this more or less literary life is the mail that comes in, this week's most fetching item being a letter addressed to Gen. Zachary Taylor, of whom a biography was reviewed a while ago in these pages.

CHICAGO, March 15 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 500 head (estimated): total not given. Compared with week ago: All weights of barrows and gilts and some sows 25 to 50 cents lower.
DAYTON, Ohio, March 15 -- Use of a revolutionary method of parachuting heavy artillery and supplies at Wright Field under the direction of the AAF's Air Materiel Command was revealed here today.

ANOTHER Heyer novel with a Regency background, this lighter-than-usual romantic period piece is (as usual) laced with ribands of mystery and intrigue. You must enter the spirit of the tale whole-heartedly to feel the proper pangs for Elinor Rochdale, the virtuous little governess.

In keeping with the custom of past years of making annual designations upon the completion of the regular campaign, the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association made known their choices yesterday. In addition to first and second all-star metropolitan teams, the writers once again picked players for the Lieut. Frank C. Haggerty and Gold Star awards.

Dominating the play at every turn the Brooklyn College basketball team defeated Yeshiva College on the former's court last night, 74 to 46. The game was the final one of the season for the teams. Brooklyn winding up with twelve victories and eight losses, and Yeshiva with six triumphs and thirteen setbacks.
ITHACA, N.Y., March 15 -- Cornell made sure of second place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League before 4,000 spectators tonight by defeating Dartmouth 51 -- 37.

IN prize-winning flower arrangements at the International Flower Show, a small bloom that looks a little like a gladiolus is to be seen. This graceful, dainty blossom that blends so well in bouquets is Gladiolus tristis. It gains in favor the more one sees it.

Organized Foremen In January, 1943, the Foremen's Association of America (40,000 members) brought action before the National Labor Relations Board against the Packard Motor Company. The issue was whether the 1,100 Packard foremen, who supervised 32,000 rankandfile workers, were entitled to bargain collectively.

MONTREAL, March 15 -- Buddy O'Connor's slick and sly goal with less than two minutes to play in the second period gave the Montreal Canadiens a 1-0 triumph over the New York Rangers tonight before a crowd of 11,965 and practically erased the New Yorkers' last hope of making the fourth

Victor Raul Haya da la Torre, leader of the Aprista party in Peru, proposed yesterday that the twentyone American Republics join in guaranteeing the liberties of their citizens against dictatorship, whether of the Right or the Left. He feels that steps to strengthen inter-American unity should be within the framework of the United Nations, but is convinced that such regional agreements will give it the strength it needs for the tasks ahead.

DETROIT, March 15 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings, firing from all angles and distances, tightened their hold on the National Hockey League's fourth place play-off spot by decisively beating the Chicago Black Hawks, 8 -- 3, before a crowd of 13,526 at the Olympia tonight.

Reports of volume business done by retail stores last week were somewhat better than generally anticipated by many store owners and merchandise men according to a market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc.

WHEN, in October of 1945, the news broke that Louis Francis Budenz, the managing editor of the Communist Daily Worker, had returned to the Roman Catholic Church after an excommunication which had lasted for thirty years, it was freely predicted that now, at last, the real story of the American Communist movement would be told.

CHICAGO, March 15 (AP) -- Wheat advanced today to the best level since 1917 and corn to the peak since 1920 in heavy buying on the Board of Trade. Mills were reported good buyers of wheat, while corn was taken by cash interests. On the upturn some short covering was noticeable.

MANY of the week's shows deserve more extended comment than space permits. Moses Soyer's recent painting's at the A.C.A. Gallery are certainly among his best. The soft, persuasive brushwork; the sympathetic depiction of young dancers and simple people; figure subjects; the portraits so well individualized -- these are in his familiar vein.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 15 -- The Boston Red Sox did not enter into the bidding. That made them very distinctive, they being the only ball club in either major league which did not make an offer to Bobby Brown. He and his father thus had fifteen teams to choose from. They picked the New York Yankees. At a price, of course.

DIFFERENT generations are hostile to different things, and ours has been singularly inhospitable to rhetoric. Nevertheless, rhetoric continues to find a haven in the Jesuit tradition, and it ought not surprise anyone, in this age of spoken gobblegrook and bumblepuppy, to learn that the president of Fordham University still knows how to turn a phrase.

GARDENERS may grow more flowers than vegetables this year, but many who discovered the excellent quality of home crops during the past few years will still grow a basic selection which the best market crops cannot equal for tenderness and flavor. Tomatoes, beans, lettuce and carrots are the choice of many of us.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 15 -- Forty-seven villages in Nassau County will go to the polls Tuesday to elect mayors or trustees, or both, and in a few cases to name police justices. Thirty-five mayors, ninety-eight trustees and seven police justices are to be elected.

BOSTON, March 15 -- An investigation into reports of bribery requests allegedly made by members of the Boston City Council in return for various kinds of permits is providing fuel for proponents of a new form of city government.

Letter From America Dear Dr. Pangloss: The most exciting things are happening in American life, not excluding the world of art. Here in New York they have been showing a good deal of sculpture in the galleries, of which two exhibits were reproduced the other day in the art columns of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

INTEREST in garden books runs high at this time of year. Almost every serious gardener is looking for just the right ones to add to his horticultural library and at the same time aid his spring planting. Many garden books have appeared recently.
HERE is a first novel which in many of its moments deserves a second reading.

To the Music Editor: THE curious unsigned article from Budapest about the revival of music in Hungary, which appeared on last Sunday's music page, is, on closer examination, a fabric of malicious insinuations and half-truths that cannot go unanswered.

VEGETABLES which have not been grown before offer, as the very least of their lures, horticultural adventures this spring. Some might turn out to be extremely good to eat and become permanent additions to the seed list.

To the Art Editor: THIS year being the hundredth anniversary of the birth of Ralph Blakelock, the Whitney Museum of American Art is forming a record of his work. A number of his important paintings are still unlocated.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- There were forecasts with the stamp of authority this week that prices would take a "moderate" drop about July 1. The "law" of supply and demand appeared to be only about a year behind schedule.

Reflecting the continued uneasiness over domestic and foreign conditions, financial markets followed an irregular course last week. Although, the contents of President Truman's message to the joint session of Congress had been anticipated, the message was well received in financial circles, where the effect of the move on the nation's economy was being weighed as the week ended.

HONOLULU, March 15 (AP) -- A Navy rescue vessel reported today that bulkheads were weakening on the stern section of the wrecked tanker Fort Dearborn. It was attempting to rescue the twenty-two crewmen on board by launching a liferaft.

MOSCOW. TO answer the question "what are Russians reading today?" I have talked to scores of Moscovites and sent questionnaires to three libraries. One was the Lenin Library, among the largest in the world.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The size of the United States military mission envisaged in the Greekaid proposal, a point that has agitated members of Congress, may not exceed thirty-five or forty officers, it was reliably reported today.

Management is engaged in an all-out campaign to promote human relations by making employes fully conscious of their social and economic importance in the traditional American system, Alvin E. Dodd, president of the American Management Association, reported in an interview last week.

THE second year of the Atomic Age, 1947, will go down in history as the beginning of a new era in the saga of the sizzling sausage, or frankfurter. The era dawned in Hollywood, where someone with pretensions of grandeur picked up a ten-cent sausage, covered it with caviar and sold the product for a dollar.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- The Senate Agricultural Committee, by a vote of 7 to 2 today, agreed to give to corn and wheat farmers a bonus variously described by Republican Senators as "only justice" and "pork barrel legislation."

IT isn't just absent-minded little old ladies who ask for "a pound of lettuce seed, please," to plant ten feet of row. If all the seeds optimistically bought in the spring were actually sown and grown, gardeners would find themselves by midsummer needing ten more acres of space.

Mrs. Le Brun Rhinelander heads the committee for the twentysixth annual New York Book Week campaign to aid the American Merchant Marine Library. The drive will open on March 24 and continue through March 29. The Duke and Duchess of Windsor have presented books to Mrs. Rhinelander to open formally the New York Book Week.
AN EGYPTIAN pharmacopoeia of the time of the Pharoahs lists 877 prescriptions, with the incantations to repeat while taking a dose.

President Truman's message to Congress last Wednesday, formulating a new foreign policy of world-wide defense of democracy against communism, gains added significance when read against the background of his Baylor University address in the preceding week.

JACKSON, Miss., March 15 -- For the first time since the Civil War the politically famous "Solid South" of the Democratic party is faced with an internal split over the question of "white primary" laws.
AT the old Murray Hill Hotel this afternoon a gathering will be held to discuss -- and do something about -- the lot of the Negro in the American arts. Discrimination will be the target.

HOLLYWOOD, March 15 -- Under pressure of charges, chiefly from Eastern writers, that it was scheming to establish a left-wing dictatorship over American writing, the Screen Writers Guild has made sweeping changes in its proposed "American Authors' Authority" to centralize the leasing, rather than outright sale of literary properties for commercial use.

DUESSELDORF, GERMANY (By Wireless). THE problem of Germany is Europe's problem. Until German industry and trade are restored the recovery of the whole Continent and especially the western half of it will be retarded. The great challenge to the statesmanship of our time is how to restore Germany's economy and at the same time prevent its ever being used again for aggression.

TORONTO, March 15 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins struck swiftly for two goals within 27 seconds of the third period tonight to earn a 5-5 tie with the Toronto Maple Leafs in a National Hockey League game before 13,607 fans.
PANAMA CITY, March 15 -- The Dodgers defeated the Panama AllStars, in eight innings today, 6 to 3, Only 4,000 fans turned out for the game which was called on account of darkness.

SPRING is the beginning of the year for gardeners. The flash of a bluebird, sap dripping from the maple trees, soft green haze over the willows -- any of these may be the signal to lift down tools, stop fingering packages of seed and start tending a patch of earth. Pinch the blossoms off strawberry plants set out in April. Alpine strawberries, grown from seed, can be allowed to set their tiny fruit.
PARIS, March 15 -- An agreement to end the month-old Paris newspaper strike was reached today and newspapers are scheduled to appear Monday, an official Government announcement said.
Increased salaries for teachers and higher certification standards are cited as being among the most important needs today for the improvement of education in the United States.

CANBERRA (Canadian Press) -- Four of Australia's six states are occupied with problem of employment of water, one of the most precious resoruces in the generally dry continent of 3,000,000 square miles, which for its size has few rivers and lakes.

AN exhibition of photographs by Walter Strate, on view through Saturday at the Norlyst Gallery, 59 West Fifty-sixth Street, reveals the latest attempt to break through the "limitations" of photography. The attempt is especially noticeable in the series of pictures called "Moods," in which river, forest, city and railroads are interpreted through the trick of printing a woman's head into the scene.

GEORGE SKLAR, a playwright turned novelist, has, I would say, shown more than angels' courage, if not brashness, in attempting his present theme. To trace the course of an affair between a 17-year-old high school boy and a sensitive, cultured married woman almost twice his age is a formidable exploration, and one which demands great delicacy and understanding.
"Tell me what a man eats, and I'll tell you what he is." -- Brillat-Savarin.

Until a treaty of peace is signed the Powers which made war on Germany have the legal right to hold German prisoners of war. Their moral right to do so is more questionable. The tragic fact that two years after the end of hostilities millions have not yet been repatriated is now under belated consideration at Moscow.

DETROIT, March 15 -- Profits reported by the Chrysler Corporation for the fourth quarter of 1946 justify union demands for a basic wage increase of 23% cents plus Social Security and old-age pension adjustments, two union officials contended today.
The major obstacle to piloted supersonic flight is the development of a suitable aircraft structure.

MEXICO CITY, March 15 -- Two weeks behind schedule because of holdout trouble and the defection of two teams, the Mexican Baseball League is now expected to open its season on Thursday, March 27, with or without "big name" players from the United States whose status is still in doubt.

THIS, like a number of Miss Allis' other novels, offers a pleasant way of absorbing some old-time Connecticut lore. While the Erie Canal was building in New York, the neighboring State caught the canal fever, too. This form of transportation spelled speed and progress to the young blood as compared to travel by muddy, dusty, snowy roads.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., March 15 -- This was home-coming day for Lucky Jack Lohrke in the baseball pasture from which he hopes to be graduated to the Giants. The Giants registered a victory over the Chicago White Sox by 6 to 3.

THE Metropolitan Opera Association has finished the most successful New York season in its history. This is significant in view of the particular problems which this organization has annually to meet, and the conditions under which it must operate.
PARIS. AS Others See Us: Everyone is putting in his oar on the subject "What do you think of American literature?" -- on which the highbrow, left-of-center daily Combat is now conducting a poll.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, March 15 (AP) -- Dr. Anselmo Jover Peralta, former Minister of Justice in the Government of Rafael Franco, Febrerista leader, has been arrested and charged with complicity in the eight-day-old Concepcion uprising.

Comments continued to come in yesterday, three days after President Truman's address urging Congress to lend material aid to Greece and Turkey lest these Mediterranean nations be engulfed by communism. Organizations and individuals here have made known their views, both pro and con.
At least eleven State Legislatures already have received housing rent control bills and Virginia has enacted such a law, according to the National Association of Housing Officials.

NANKING, China, March 15 -- The potentialities for Russo-American power politics inherent in the Chinese civil war were made plain for all to see at Moscow this week as a result of Foreign Minister Molotov's move to get the China problem placed on the agenda of the four Foreign Ministers' conference.

LONDON, March 15 (Reuters) The Wolverhampton Wanderers maintained their drive toward the English Football League championship today by stopping Charlton Athletic 2 -- 0, while Liverpool and Blackpool stayed in pursuit, 4 points behind, with victories over Portsmouth and Sheffield United.

BEFORE long the vanguard of the annual pest procession will appear in our gardens. We may look forward with apprehension to the arrival of the descendants of chinch bugs and grubs which ruined our lawns last year, or Japanese beetles that attempted to eat every green leaf and fruit on our premises.

EVERY garden year begins with firm resolutions, worthy ambitions and high hopes. We resolve to do the things we left undone last year; we promise ourselves to work harder than ever before; we look forward to superlative results from our efforts.

CLEVELAND, March 15 -- Organizations engaged in research projects on high blood pressure and arteriosclerosis need about $3,000,000 a year for effective work a committee of the American Foundation for High Blood Pressure reported today as the organization, newly formed, ended a two-day meeting.

WITH the prize-giving season in the offing, Broadway's more interested parties are up to their usual surveys and guesses. As of the moment, the ear-to-the-ground boys say that both the Pulitzer Committee and the Critics Circle are going to be torn between Eugene O'Neill's "The Iceman Cometh" and Arthur Miller's "All My Sons."

MUSIC lessons, dancing lessons, riding class. French conversation, concerts, trips, club and troop meetings -- how many of these are on your children's list after school? And how much of this is good for them, plus their school day and homework and a certain allotment of time to catch their breath?

THE eager anticipation with which we await the blossoms of our spring bulbs, as well as the expense involved in procuring them for planting, makes it worth while to choose those which will continue to produce long-lasting flowers year after year.

LOS ANGELES, March 15 -- Stating that "crime in Los Angeles has gotten out of hand," Los Angeles police in a secretly planned operation last night suddenly established quasi-military road blocks at seven major intersections on the eastern side of the city and for six hours systematically examined all passing vehicles and their occupants.

The Hopes of Men LOOKING back now more than thirty years, I can shut my eyes and see that Bull Moose convention of 1912, see their eager faces -- more than a thousand of them -- upturned, smiling hopefully, with joy beaming out that came from hearts which believed in what they were doing; its importance, its righteousness.

HOLLYWOOD. INDICATIONS are multiplying that, as inconceivable as it may be, Hollywood is arriving at an acute state of loss for words. Not, to be sure, the old tried-and-true combinations like "No -- there's nothing you can do now," and "Darling -- why didn't you tell me?"

-- SEA POLICE Two centuries have passed since James Thomson reported the guardian angels as proclaiming, "Britannia rules the waves!" Now Britannia is feeling her age and a little under the weather, and Uncle Sam will take over some of her duties of safeguarding the security of the sea.

ONLY an especially fine planting is suitable in and around so conspicuous a feature as the pool. Catalogues from nurseries that specialize in water plants are worth studying beforehand. It may prove difficult to keep the list down, for among water plants are some of the most intriguing and beautiful things to grow.

Increases in the dividend rate announced recently by savings banks in the metropolitan area are causing the savings institutions generally to re-examine their dividend structures with a view to possible adjustment, it was learned yesterday.
KOREAN hybrid chrysanthemum seeds sown before the middle of April will produce blossoms in the fall on plants hardy enough to endure the rigors of a cold winter.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Carroll Reece, chairman of the Republican National Committee, agreed with a worried freshman Senator today that "the Republicans back home are impatient," but blamed their restlessness on "a natural anxiety" for a program and lack of understanding of the "realities" in Washington.
NANKING, March 15 -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek charged the Chinese Communists today with armed rebellion, which he said the Government must quell by force.

SHANGHAI, March 15 -- A thorough purge of "wavering and corrupt" elements in the Kuomintang [Government party] was demanded here today by the Central Daily News, official party organ, as China's ruling group opened its annual meeting in Nanking to proclaim the formal end to twenty years of "political tutelage."

The American President Lines President Cleveland, largest merchant ship ever constructed on the Pacific Coast, is rapidly nearing completion at the Bethlehem Steel Company's Alameda (Calif.) shipyard, and is scheduled for delivery to her owners about July 1 for operation on the de luxe passenger service to the Orient, it was announced here yesterday.

Two welfare organizations for needy girls have consolidated their activities, so that underprivileged girls formerly cared for at the Hopewell Home, 218 Gates Avenue, Brooklyn, will be transferred to the Sevilla Home at Lafayette Avenue and Manida Street, the Bronx, according to an announcement yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, March 15 -- Secretary of the Navy James Forrestal said today that any direct assistance to Greece or Turkey by the United States Navy would consist solely "of a staff character."

BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 15 -- Negotiations now being conducted by Foreign Minister Paul-Henri Spaak for the formation of a new Government went badly today for the first time. Communist leaders have asked for terms that, it appears, the Foreign Minister cannot possibly grant.

PERHAPS the most important factor in the health and beauty of a shrub is the care it is given for the first few weeks after it comes from the nursery. Soil preparation for it, planting as soon as possible after it arrives and pruning are vital to its wellbeing.

The danger of a poorly planned slum clearance project causing a speed-up of decay in other parts of a community is stressed in a forum discussion in the current issue of Tomorrow's Town, publication of the National Committee on Housing.
IT augurs well for the esthetic future of the American home when the mentors of Art turn their attention to such mundane affairs as the slope of a chair back or the contours of a salt cellar.

A hotel construction program involving approximately $12,000,000 in fourteen cities of the Dominican Republic has been announced by Alvarez Pina, president of the Hotel Jaragua board of directors. The project, which has been approved by President Rafael L. Trujillo, calls for the erection of fourteen hotels and an addition of seventy-five rooms to the Hotel Jaragua in Ciudad Trujillo.

Abraham Lincoln, William H. Taft, Commerce and DeWitt Clinton High School quintets advanced to the semi-final round of the annual Public Schools Athletic League basketball championships yesterday afternoon before a crowd of 13,000 at Madison Square Garden.
