West Virginia had trouble with Bradley Tech, but it did not compare with the misery St. John's encountered in its first-round meeting with North Carolina State at Madison Square Garden last night. For the Mountaineers managed to survive the tenth annual national invitation college basketball tournament preliminaries, while the Brooklyn Redmen fell by the wayside.

THE story of a twentieth-century Cinderella who is more overwrought than overworked has been told by Susan Ertz in "Mary Hallam," a recent English importation. A hypersensitive girl who counts herself a failure in life and love and art, Mary is rescued from a cruel stepmother by a fairy godmother from Boston.
TO THE EDITOR: For his article, "A Plea for the Small Taxpayer," J.K. Lasser is entitled to the gratitude of all those for whom he has made an admirable appeal for fair play and justice.

THE rebellion of the meek is one of the most satisfying spectacles that either life or literature can offer. But in this leisurely, lachrymose novel of a sorely tried English spinster there is no splendid turning of the worm.

The billion-dollar life-insurance companies are exploring new and promising areas for mortgage investments in the face of a plethora of competitive "easy money" and interest rates that no longer make the yield attractive.

With the current Red Cross fund drive at the halfway point, only $1,838,150 -- or 29 per cent of the city-wide quota of $6,153,000 -- has been contributed, James M. Cecil, general chairman for the city, announced yesterday.

SALONIKA, Greece, March 15 -- Mark Ethridge, American representative on the United Nations Balkans Commission of Inquiry, has moved to extract from representatives of Yugoslavia and Bulgaria a clear answer to Greek charges that their countries are waging an undeclared war to detach the Greek Province of Macedonia, it became known today.

LONDON, March 15 -- The water supply of more than 1,000,000 of London's populace was contaminated today as snow-fed rivers and streams burst their banks and inundated thousands of acres about the city's watershed.

MOSCOW, March 15 -- The Big Four Foreign Ministers' deputies plunged into the heart of the Austrian treaty discussions today by debating what the German assets in that country were and how much the Soviet Union was entitled to claim.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 15 -- Balloting on two propositions and on an unwilling candidate for Mayor will feature Tuesday's elections in Westchester County, when twenty villages will choose local officials.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, March 15 -- It has often been said that when the Russians got around to agreeing to the unification of Germany it would be with the calculation that in sacrificing exclusive control of their part they would gain control of the whole.

HOLLAND, Mich., March 15 (AP) -- A six-week summer tour of the Netherlands, as special guests of the Dutch Government with all expenses paid, became a prospect today for three college students and three high school seniors.

DELPHINIUMS, peonies, iris, chrysanthemums and along list of other perennials have an irresistible appeal, especially when the spring catalogues come around. From a desire to grow one or two that have caught his fancy, the gardener is lured into starting that magnum opus of all flower fanciers, the perennial border.

On a 300-acre estate in the rolling hills of Sussex County thirty miles south of London, there is an unusual pioneer program for the salvaging of industry's psychological misfits that holds a singular lesson for this nation Developed during the dark days of the London blitz when Britain's wartime manpower shortage was acute, the Roffey Park Rehabilitation Center opened in June, 1944.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 15 -- Augustus and Nahm's stretchrunning Eternal Reward drove to a half-length triumph in the Broward County Handicap today for his second stakes triumph on successive Saturdays at Gulfstream Park.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The friends of Hawaiian statehood have in the last few days been accorded the most encouraging reception they've had in Washington.

Two new speedboat racing classes for 1947 were adopted as probable additions to future regatta schedules by the American Power Boat Association's national council at a meeting yesterday at the Hotel Lexington. Both categories were referred to the racing commission for the adoption of specific rules and regulations.
Professional tennis now has a commissioner, as in baseball and football.

THE appearance of these two little volumes is a sign of the times. For more than one century our information on Arab lands and life came primarily from British explorers and scholars. Of them there has been a long and brilliant line -- from Palgrave and Doughty to Lawrence and Philby.
A record high in the number of Federal income tax returns filed and payments received was reported yesterday at the offices of Collectors of Internal Revenue in this city and vicinity.

A factor in the proposal that the United States Government give aid to Greece and Turkey is the vast petroleum resources of the Middle East, which are about onehalf of the world's known supply. Continued control of the oil fields of the Persian Gulf by United States and British interests is considered necessary to the economy of Europe.
NEW ORLEANS, March 15 -- Gambling, and the influence of New York gamblers in Louisiana politics, probably will be a major issue in the campaign for Governor of this State which is getting under way.

MANY of us cherish delightful childhood memories of picking bouquets of spring beauties, violets or anemones in the woods and hurrying home to present them to a favorite member of the family. The delicate blossoms may have been a bit the worse for being clutched tightly in grubby hands, but they were as real a sign of spring as skipping ropes or tops.

Stock prices closed steadier yesterday on the Stock Exchange, with leaders fractionally mixed after opening around the lows of the year in the averages. Trading was the smallest since the first session of the month with a turnover of 370,000 shares, compared with 740,000 shares on the preceding Saturday.
JAY RICHARD KENNEDY is a name to be underscored in your memory book, for during fourteen months in Holly wood he has made the town sit up and take notice.
THE fragrance of herbs close by the kitchen doorway invites their daily use for savory salads and sauces. A small planting of culinary herbs in a convenient spot has many advantages.

"THE WOUND AND THE WEATHER" is Howard Moss' first book of poetry, although, as his publishers point out, many of the poems included have already appeared in magazines that run a gamut from The Kenyon Review to Harper's Bazaar.

ANCESTRAL, mansions have always made good heroes for English novels, even when they have had only half the extravagant history at Miss Lindop's Dimmocks -- a not quite du Maurierish house whose confused (if not dark) memories drive the last of its inheritors to the verge of suicide.

TWENTY years is no mean slice out of a lady's life, but Renee Carroll, the most publicized hat-check girl in the world, doesn't object to owning up to every day of it. Perhaps one explanation is that as taker of the tips at Sardi's Restaurant her life has been exciting and full as she has watched Broadway flourish over the years.

IN the seller's market that still predominates today -- notwithstanding a barrage of recession talk and some muchpublicized but none the less isolated price reductions -- the consumer continues to cut a pitiful figure of confusion and frustration.

IT isn't often that the same work is released by two major competing companies in the same month. Victor and Columbia have issued new versions of El Amor Brujo by Manuel de Falla, who died recently, and each album is sufficiently meritorious to be worth your attention.

LAS VEGAS, Nev. -- This sprawling desert town, where tourism is the major industry, is enjoying a springtime boom. Capacity crowds are the rule at the major resort hotels, such as El Rancho Vegas, the Hotel Last Frontier and the Nevada-Biltmore.

If Western capitalism is to help shape the future of the Orient, American citizens and American capital can join in the test unhandicapped, at least so far as the Philippine Islands are concerned. This is the meaning that the financial district is reading into the outcome of the plebiscite by which the new Philippine Republic last week accorded to American citizens rights paralleling the constitutional guarantees assured to the Filipinos themselves.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 15 (AP) -- Atomic energy, the most destructive force ever unleashed by man, has "tremendous possibilities" for peaceful applications and creates "almost limitless" tools for scientific research, scientists from seven New England colleges and universities were told here today.

TO the flood of historical novels now running, which bids fair to cover every last syllable of recorded time. Doris Ponsonby has added a full-dress eighteenthcentury romance. It reflects faithfully and enthusiastically the color, costumes and customs of England when Beau Nash ruled at Bath.

Moderate gains featured retail trade here last week. Department store sales were estimated at 5 to 10 per cent higher than a year ago. Apparel sales failed to go ahead in volume, although Easter arrives two weeks earlier than last year.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- As the result of a directive issued by President Roosevelt in October, 1943, the State Department issued tonight an annotated edition of the Treaty of Peace that was signed with Germany at Versailles on June 28, 1919.

IN the earlier Forties, when our soldiers were dreaming of a white Christmas, Ernest Nevin Dilworth, with the infantry, and his friend Walter Leuba, at home, were dreaming of a world made safe for education. "A conversation piece" based on the correspondence between Dilworth and Leuba during the war, "Smith Unbound" gives us their educational Utopia.
The return of French passenger shipping to the North Atlantic lanes was announced yesterday by Guy de Berc, general manager of the French Line.

TELEVISION, both as artform and in its commercialadvertising aspect, has undoubtedly suffered more grievously from ill-informed bombast and premature promotion than any comparable technical development. Mr. Hutchinson's work should do much to bring matters audio-visual to a truer perspective.

To the Radio Editor: I READ with much interest your article on the subject of crime broadcasts in the times of March 2. Enclosed is a copy of a report of the Section of Criminal Law of the American Bar Association, recently made to the House of Delegates of the association.

Cleaning up in the three relay events and taking three individual titles as well, Manhattan College's deeply-manned squad won the Metropolitan A.A.U. junior indoor track and field team championship at the Twenty-third Regiment Armory in Brooklyn last night.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Representatives of ten seafaring unions announced today a program on which they have agreed to cooperate as a means of improving the general welfare of employes in the maritime industry.

THE author of this down-toearth study of Japanese family life, in the years between the "China incident" and the capitulation of '45, has approached his task with a unique point of view. Born in Tokyo thirty-odd years ago, of Scottish parents, he was educated at the American School in Japan and remained in that country until he was 18.

ANYONE who enjoys a colorful human story of the good old sailing ship days when Yankee privateers and smugglers became respected merchant princes and patrons of higher learning, would do well not to overlook this tightly packed little volume.

Ella Goldstein, 20-year-old Palestinian pianist, gave her first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Almost from the opening chords of the Bach-Busoni Chaconne it was obvious that she was one of the most richly endowed of the many talented young pianists who have played here this season.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In these grave times it is important that all citizens have some part in the discussion and determination of policies which so vitally affect the well-being of each of us and the peace of the world. We cannot safely leave these great decisions entirely to public officials who are motivated by political pressure.

AMONG the young men writing short, nervous novels about young men, Gore Vidal is noteworthy for a clear style, purposeful but natural dialogue and a downright kind of story-telling. His "Williwaw," last year, was based on his experiences as a very young soldier in the Aleutians.

THERE used to be a time when every story idea that came to me had two curtains and a second act climax. Now I don't care whether I ever write another play as long as I live. It may be heresy, but I've turned in my Dramatists' Guild card for one from the Authors Guild. Sue me, if you want to, for non-performance.

The Saw Mill River Kennel Club all-breed show at the County Center in White Plain today has drawn 902 dogs, of which boxers are most numerous with sixtyfour. Cocker spaniels muster three less, Great Danes number fortyfour and Doberman pinschers fortytwo.

A GOOD lawn enhances the real value of a property. More important, perhaps, is its social value. For the leisure and enjoyment which are, after all, main purposes in improving the home grounds, the lawn is all important.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- Not so many years ago the people who spent the spring and summer months vacationing in Florida were (a) Floridians who were busy catering to Northern tourists during the winter season and (b) residents of other near-by Southern States.

TO many gardeners miniature roses are the jewels of the rose family. These exquisitely scaled, tiny replicas of larger roses are as perfectly formed in their minuteness as the finest hybrid tea blossom. It is more fascinating to grow them than any of their larger counterparts.

After listening last evening to arguments for a five-cent fare by Controller Lazarus Joseph and arguments for a ten-cent fare by Harold Riegelman, counsel of the Citizens Budget Commission, 45 per cent of a WNBC studio audience of 400 voted for the lower fare.

Russia and the World President Truman last week announced what was generally regarded as a new foreign policy for the United States -- a policy that might well be as important for America and for the world as the Monroe Doctrine of 1823 and the Roosevelt Lend Lease program of 1941.

Signed in Manila Friday night in what an Associated Press correspondent describes as "the festive atmosphere of a farewell ball for Ambassador Paul V. McNutt," the 99-year military base agreement between the United States and the Philippine Republic reflects the changed strategic situation in the Pacific.

SEASON IN HELL -- A young reveler woke up after a celebration to find himself locked in the bottom of a hot, smoke-filled smoke stack at a heating plant in East Orange, N.J. He clambered 180 feet up a narrow iron ladder to the top, found no ladder on the outside, yelled, then reluctantly climbed back down inside as police rushed to unlock the door.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, March 15 -- Gen. Joseph T. McNarney handed over his command of the United States forces in the European Theatre today to Lieut. Gen. Lucius D. Clay. In ceremonies on the steps of the Frankfort headquarters General McNarney presented to General Clay an Oak Leaf Cluster to the Distinguished Service Medal as 100 P-51's roared overhead.

Failure to take depreciation as a deduction in a taxable year of the useful life of business property is usually fatal to such deductions, except that an amended return and a claim for refund may be filed within the period of the statute of limitations.

ADMIRERS of Norman Rockwell's covers for The Saturday Evening Post and his interpretation of "The Four Freedoms" should acclaim the publication of this volume, for among its more than 500 illustrations are miniature reproductions of all of the 240 Post covers Rockwell has executed over a period of thirty years.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 15 -- The Swedish Government imposed a sweeping ban on all except the most essential imports tonight. The purpose of this action is to combat the inflation threat and arrest the rapid decline in Sweden's foreign exchange reserves.

THE stereotyped planting of window boxes with purple petunias or double salmonpink geraniums and periwinkle might lead the casual observer to suppose there were rules about such things. Actually much more variety in plant materials is possible, although the range is necessarily limited by the rigors of window-box life.

ARETROSPECTIVE exhibition of photographs by the late Alfred Stieglitz, opening June 11 at the Museum of Modern Art, was announced last week by Philip L. Goodwin, chairman of the museum's exhibitions committee.

BOGOTA, Colombia, March 15 -- President Mariano Ospina Perez appealed tonight over the radio for moderation and order in tomorrow's Congressional elections. The Minister of the Interior promised ample protection to the voters, stressing that the present Administration represented not a party but the national Government.

Four choruses, an orchestra, instrumentalists, singers and dancers participated last night in the seventh annual Festival of Jewish Arts to be presented by Jacob Weinberg at Carnegie Hall. The event drew a capacity audience.

CHICAGO, March 15 (AP) -- Willie Hope of White Plains, N.Y., who clinched his fifth world 3-cushion billiard championship last night, dropped his first game of the eleven-day tournament in his closing match tonight against Brooklyn's Art Rubin.

FOR more than thirty years Merle Armitage has been one of America's most devoted amateurs of the dance; for much of this time he has been engaged in its professional promotion. His new and beautifully designed volume. "Dance Memoranda," is a testament of his love and understanding of the art.

Legislative Record Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York began his second term in January with overwhelming Republican majorities in the 170th Legislature -- 41 to 15 in the Senate, 109 to 41 in the Assembly. Last week the Legislature approached adjournment of what may be the shortest session in fifteen years.

THE basic dilemma of those formulating United States foreign policy is that publicly they feel they must assume the best about the intentions of the Soviet Union and privately they fear the worst. They want to believe they can do business with Stalin, and they keep trying, but most of the time they fear the spread of Communist influence and devote their energies to blocking it.

Negotiations to end a strike of maintenance employes of two branches of the Brooklyn Y.W. C.A., now in its third week, were broken off yesterday between the Y.W.C.A. board of directors and the Social Service Employes Local of the United Office and Professional Workers of America, CIO.

DETROIT, March 15 (U.P.) -- Margaret Truman, the President's daughter, arrived here tonight for her second attempt to sing before an estimated nationwide radio audience of 15,000,000 listeners tomorrow night.

The United States has changed its "tactics" rather than its "policy" in China and is still ready to aid that country financially if it is inclined to become "a bastion in the Far East," Representative Michael J. Mansfield, Democrat, of Montana, declared yesterday in discussing several phases of Far Eastern policies.

A sad comment on progress in reverse has been made toy the International Chamber of Commerce in an appeal to UN's Economic and Social Council to take action against unnecessary restrictions on international travel. In 1914, the Chamber says, "a business man could decide to make a journey from one capital city to another and accomplish the journey in a matter of hours."

A goal which has been sought by Boys High School for four decades finally was realized by the Red and Black when it showed plenty of strength in the running events to capture the forty-fourth version of the indoor Public Schools Athletic League track and field championships at the Thirteenth Regiment Armory, Brooklyn, yesterday.

With the National figure skating championships a thing of the past for another year, the ice skating scene now shifts to Ottawa, Ont., where on March 28 and 29 the North American championships will be held. The Minto Skating Club, home rink of Miss Barbara Ann Scott, the defending champion, is playing host to all stars.
THE outstanding success of hybrid corn has called attention to other hybrid vegetables. Squash, onions, tomatoes, cucumbers and eggplants have now been hybridized, with more to follow.

LONDON, March 15 -- Britain's efforts to overcome its grave economic difficulties are still in the "phony war" stage. After, as before, the big three-day debate this week on the Labor Government's economic policy there was a widespread feeling in London that the real economic Battle of Britain had not even started yet.

BARMAIDS -- Although women bartenders were outlawed by the last Michigan Legislature, the present body of lawmakers is being pressured to put the ladies behind bars again. The 250-pound president of the Upper Peninsula Tavern Association in Lansing told a State liquor control committee that his wife was able to handle "the tough miners and loggers we get at our place better than I can."

MEXICO CITY -- You like some things, dislike others, in Mexico's capital. We like the rotisseries near the bullfight arena where, between mouthfuls of spitted chicken and crisp potato chips, you pick up from afficionados the fine points of Manolete's art....

Two eighteen-goal sides, the highest handicapped teams to see action in local indoor polo circles this season, will ride in the feature game of the benefit double-header Wednesday night at the Squadron A Armory. The event is for the Red Cross 1947 Fund of Greater New York, which seeks $6,153,600 in the current drive.

WASHINGTON. CARTOONISTS evolved the humorless figure we accept as Uncle Sam, but that was before they knew Jim Preston. Today every newspaper man and cartoonist who has worked in Washington long enough to earn his press gallery card knows Jim.

IT takes a special temperament to appreciate the "fragrant smoke of ox-dung and camelthorn," as Melvin Hall did. The fragrance came to him in the lovely valley of Mahal-i-Zoshk, hard by the holy city of Meshed, somewhere west of Samarkand.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The Senate Republican Policy Committee today laid down a policy line calling for investigations of President Truman's 635 appointees to postmasterships and of alleged discrimination against Negroes in the Senate press gallery and Senate restaurants.

PARIS, March 15 (Reuters) -- The French Foreign Office spokesman said today that the President of the Bulgarian National Council had cast doubt on the legality of French diplomatic funds in Bulgaria and had criticized France for having 100,000,000 leva capital, in contrast to the 35,000,000 leva held by the United States Legation and 25,000,000 leva held by the British Legation.

SMALL fruits are beginning to be grown in many a plot formerly occupied by vegetables. Other gardens, even little ones, have new rows of berry bushes coming up along boundary lines, in hedges, and in other ingenious places.

The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization represents a problem to the teachers of the world because they do not know how much they can bank on an organization not supported by Russia, Dr. Howard E. Wilson, assistant director of the division of education of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, declared yesterday.

A CLOTH house that is used for growing plants has many advantages for the average gardener. Such popular items as asters and dahlias which may have been given up because of insect pests will grow better than would seem possible under cloth.
ALMOST anyone who has watched both babies and puppies -- sprawling on the floor, plopping into sleep, gnawing on anything they can get their jaws around -- will agree the two seem much alike.

THIS is a first novel of no small merit and distinction, an absorbing, sensitive dissection of a middle-aged woman's attempt to free herself from the past and live creatively in the present. In broader strokes it is the timeless problem of the over-dominated, frustrated and genteel spirit unable to cope with the realities of the world.

FOUR weeks ago Maxwell Anderson occupied this pulpit to preach a sermon against the omnipotence of critics. "Plays now live or die by the verdict of the reviewers," he declared. He thinks that plays would have a happier experience on Broadway if the critics' opinions were not interposed between the play and the public.

NEWARK, N.J., March 15 -- Three late goals by Bobby Clark in a wild-and-wooly fourth chukker enabled the Squadron A Regulars to nose out the Squadron A Black Knights, 16 -- 15, in a metropolitan Indoor Polo League match tonight at Essex Troop Armory.

DR. JAMES E. POLLARD has compiled a tremendous record -- nearly 900 pages -- of facts concerning the relation of the Presidents and the press without ever explaining clearly what that relation is. The book, therefore, is valuable to specialists, less to general readers.
GLADIOLUS is a man's flower. I have a wonderful time hobnobbing with the many other men who grow it as a hobby and try to collect blue ribbons.
JERUSALEM, Sunday, March 16 (AP) -- A group of persons identified officially as Jewish terrorists blew up a British Army Naafi (post exchange) store near Hadera early today.

BERLIN. THE German theatre under the stimulus of the occupying powers is having an extremely interesting revival. Most of the activity centers in Berlin, where the Russians and Americans are the most active in sponsoring the revival of the German stage, which, before Hitler, was world-famous for the variety and excellence of its fare.

A sharp difference of opinion about reconversion of the liner Washington now exists among shipping men and Government officials with the result that the future of the vessel is extremely uncertain despite this country's desperate need for passenger-carrying tonnage, it was learned yesterday.
LONDON, March 15 (AP) -- Seventytwo horses are entered for the 101st running of the Grand National steeplechase March 29 -- offering fans the biggest gamble in years.

FOR the thrill of growing "something new" in perennials, the gardener searches the catalogues in spring, seeking disease-resistant and highly vigorous species and varieties, with novel and interesting colors and forms.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Last-ditch efforts to avert a rankand-file revolt over the Knutson method of cutting income taxes were mapped today by House Republican leaders.

WHETHER a new garden is made or an established one regenerated, the quality and conditions of the soil are of primary importance. Good soil is the backbone of the garden. When plants fail to respond to the labor of careful weeding, watering and feeding, a soil deficiency is usually the answer.

MOSCOW, March 15 -- The first clash in the Big Four meeting over the vital question of Germany's political future occurred today when Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky attacked the tendency toward federalization in the western zones of Germany.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- J.A. Krug, Secretary of the Interior, foresaw today eventual development of a large-scale newsprint industry in Alaska as a consequence of the Territory's extensive forest reserves.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 15 -- A special subcommittee appointed to examine evidence in the British case against Albania failed to reach any decision today in its report to the United Nations Security Council.

With the exception of Stravinsky's "Symphonic de Psaumes," the program presented by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, under Serge Koussevitzky, yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall consisted of works played here by the same forces earlier this week.
LEEDS, England, March 15 -- From the turmoil of Britain's strangest industrial crisis a new progressivism is emerging in a key section of the trade union movement.

A GARDEN should be a haven for relaxation whether it be on country hilltop or in city backyard. Although a welltended city garden is always refreshing, its individual character affects the mood of anyone who comes within its boundaries.

PARIS, March 15 -- The next two months will be decisive for the French effort to adjust internal prices to avoid further inflation. Persons in closest touch with this experiment expressed that opinion today.

Greater public recognition of the importance of education and of the teacher as a key figure in a working democracy is needed to assure education and teacher the more adequate public financial support they must have to function with full effectiveness, speakers declared yesterday at the closing session of the American Education Fellowship conference for parents and teachers.

SPOKANE, Wash., March 15 (AP) -- Invited to comment on juvenile delinquency, North Central High School students flooded the principal's office today with letters urging heavy punishment for "juvenile and adult delinquents," better recreational facilities and a clean-up of drinking and gambling spots.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 15 -- Four meet records fell by the wayside tonight as the Rutgers swimming team, undefeated in dual competition since 1944, successfully defended its Eastern Collegiate Swimming Association title by outclassing twelve rivals.

The general trend toward automatic heating was indicated in the exhibits of the latest devices and improvements in heating equipment shown at the recent exposition at the American Society of Heating and Ventilating Engineers in Cleveland.

PESHAWAR, North-West Frontier Province, India, March 15 -- The first of the Indian political discords are beginning to tell under this explosive corner, which guards the historic Khyber Pass, northwestern gateway into India's plains.

HOLLYWOOD. THE American cinema is apparently preparing to face questions of racial and religious prejudice with more forthright courage than audiences have been accustomed to expect. Two major companies, RKO and Twentieth Century-Fox, are competing over anti-Semitism as a screen subject.

MOSCOW, March 15 -- The Chinese Embassy notified Secretary of State Marshall and Foreign Secretary Bevin today that China "cannot take part in or agree to" any informal meeting of the Big Three Foreign Ministers to supply information on China.

PERHAPS we should be thankful that meteorology made no progress during the two thousand years from the time of Aristotle to that of Galileo and that it was an unpaid amateur pursuit until the last century was almost over. For if any large nation had spent on meteorology a ten-thousandth part of its expenditure on military science it might conceivably have gained the knowledge needed for some degree of control over weather and climate.

PHILADELPHIA, March 15 -- Last week in the third Federal Reserve District a 20 per cent increase in department store sales was reported as compared with a year ago. In the four weeks to March 8, dollar volume sales of these stores gained fifteen per cent over the like 1946 period.

WOODMERE, L.I., March 15 -- A man and his wife were burned to death here this morning and their daughter was seriously injured in a fire that destroyed the Cedar Point clubhouse. Damage was estimated at more than $50,000.

YALE -- Summer Students More than 850 students are expected to enroll for the summer session at Yale University. The semester, designed primarily to enable returned service men to complete their education in the shortest possible time, will open July 7 and will continue through Aug. 29.

OUTRANKED only by larcenies and burglaries, car thefts are third in the nation's categories of crime. Last year, according to J.R. Crossley, vice president of the Automobile Club of New York, more than 229,920 motor vehicles were stolen in this country, and this year the number of thefts is expected to be even higher.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 15 -- Reports from Secretary of State Marshall in Moscow to President Truman, the first two of which were received here today, indicate no official Soviet reaction to the President's Congressional message of last Wednesday.

ACCORDING to the legend beloved by ancient and medieval chroniclers. Britain owes its name and its founding to Bruttys (or Brut), the greatgrandson of Aeneas. Geoffrey of Monmouth, who was perhaps a more imaginative than scholarly historian of the twelfth century, first set down his epic wanderings on paper, and it is this version which Miss Sprague has used as the basis of her story.

Confidence that values of real estate in Westchester County will remain firm for the year 1947 was expressed yesterday by Raymond D. Porter, president of the Westchester County Realty Board, as the result of a survey just completed by the board.

The program for the seventh annual metropolitan appraisal conference of the New York State Society of Real Estate Appraisers, to be held in the Commodore Hotel on Friday, March 28, was announced yesterday by Frank S. O'Hara of Jackson Heights, chairman of the conference committee.

TAMPA, Fla.-- A tug nudges the little schooner down the Hillsborough River to Hillsborough Bay and releases her to the breezes and deep water of Tampa Bay. The schooner gets under way as tackle creaks, canvas is hoisted and the skipper points the bowsprit toward distant Egmont Key at the entrance to the Gulf of Mexico.

The lingering seriousness of the scrap metal situation -- in regard to both the short supply of the material and its abnormally inflated price quotation -- captured the concern of the entire steel industry last week as conditions became more grievous than they had been at any time since 1917.

MOSCOW, March 15 -- Pravda, Communist party organ, made a bitter, second Soviet attack today on President Truman's GreekTurkish policy. The President's program did not serve the cause of peace and security, and it "renders valueless" United States declarations of faithfulness to the United Nations, Pravda said.

CHICAGO, March 15 (AP) -- Herb McKenley, Illinois' long-striding Jamaican, set a new American indoor 440-yard record, three American marks were equaled and ten meet marks toppled in the sixteenth Illinois Tech relays at the University of Chicago field house tonight.

American business men must take the responsibility at educating foreign buyers to more precise specifications and must adapt their products to suit foreign markets if they want to sell Latin America, an export manager of a large durable goods manufacturing company stated last week.

JERUSALEM, March 15 -- One hundred and thirty-eight additional Jewish men, women and children of the remaining refugee immigrants brought to Palestine in the ship Susannah, sailed before dawn today for Cyprus aboard the British ferry Empire Shelter.

"THE Postoffice Departmemt announced last week that the 3-cent stamp to be released on April 10 to mark the centenary of the birth of Joseph Pulitzer (1847-1911), newspaper proprietor and editor, will be purple in color and of the format of the special delivery stamp.

JACQUES SINGER, 35-yearold American conductor, has been named musical director of the Vancouver Symphony Orchestra. The appointment is quite a triumph for Mr. Singer, since it was made on the basis of only two concerts with the orchestra this winter.

LOUIS DE ROCHEMONT, producer of the currently successful Twentieth CenturyFox drama, "Boomerang," now at the Roxy, and erstwhile producer of the March of Time series, shortly will enter the educational film field.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 15 -- To the surprise of hardly anyone -- and to the delight of several hundred lusty-lunged rooters who had followed their heroes here from Bethlehem, Pa. -- Lehigh University's talented team tonight ended Navy's four-year reign as champion of the Eastern Intercollegiate Wrestling Association.
TOKYO, March 15 -- The lists closed today for Japan's first important local election.

ORCHIDS are not an everyday flower, and the thousands that are displayed for the single week of the Flower Show are viewed not just with pleasure but with a touch of awe. No single blossom draws more spectators.

MIAMI BEACH -- Florida's winter season is over and the tourist tide has turned. But visitors are still coming to this resort city at the rate of two for every three leaving, and the entire State is working just as hard to build up its spring season as it did last fall to make the high winter season a success.

MOSCOW (By Wireless). AS counselor, guide and friend during the meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers in Moscow Secretary of State Marshall will have an old and trusted lieutenant. He is a stocky blond man with wintry blue eyes and an air of authority -- Walter Bedell Smith, United States Ambassador to Moscow and an expert at straight talk in dealing with the Russians.

KIRK ASKEW is undoubtedly quite right when he estimates that fifteenth-century German art represents "a whole field of painting little known in New York." THE sequence of events last week in connection with the proposed Broadcasters Advisory Council illustrates the extraordinary difficulties which lie ahead in any concerted effort to improve programming and curtail advertising excesses on the air.

READING this book is like examining a fine piece of needlework: the more closely you study it the greater the beauty, the finer the detail of it emerges. For Mr. McLaverty is a master of simple, telling prose and of the pungent, chaste phrase.

To the Holy Land More than 81,000 European Jews entered the Holy Land from Sept. 1, 1939, the day the war in Europe began, to Jan. 1, 1947 -- 28,000 since the end of the war. Many were held in detention camps in Palestine and the island of Cyprus as illegal immigrants; later some were permitted to enter Palestine under quotas.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 15 -- A soft patter of rain fell on this Sunshine City today. It washed out the scheduled exhibition game between the Yankees and the Reds and pretty soon enveloped the town in a vast silence.

Representatives of industry and of labor squared off yesterday in a discussion of labor unions at the National Republican Club, 54 West Fortieth Street. Agreeing upon the principle of the right of labor to organize, they disagreed upon almost every point of the methods and practices of labor unions, and the need for legislation.

Programs by youth organizations to counteract the gang spirit in large communities and also to contribute to the welfare of children abroad were recommended yesterday by pupils participating in the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast from the studio of WQXR.

A YEAR or so ago, when many people were saying that passenger flights at speeds of 500 miles an hour at altitudes of 25,000 to 30,000 feet "were just around the corner," Luke S. Hobbs, vice president in charge of engineering for United Aircraft Corporation, dared to question the prediction.

LIFE EXPECTANCY -- The expectation of life at birth reached an all-time high of 65.6 years in 1946 among American wage-earners and their families, the statisticians of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company report. This is a gain of more than a half-year over 1945, a gain of more than five years over the past decade, and of almost nineteen years since 1911.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 15 -- The United Nations Security Council referred the entire question of international atomic control back to the Atomic Energy Commission this week in a final effort to resolve the deadlock between the views of the United States and the Soviet Union.

DETROIT, March 15 (AP) -- Things have been moving faster for several weeks in the production division of the car industry; barring developments at present unforeseen they soon will begin to move faster on all other fronts of the industry.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 15 -- The third round of the $10,000 Jacksonville open golf tournament was played over a rain-sodden course today and, when the splashing was over, Ben Hogan had blown sky high and big Clayton Heafner was out in front by a stroke.

SOON after this article appears -- so says an official of the Treasury Department -- a lot of people are going to head for the nearest office of the Collector of Internal Revenue. SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 15 -- Led by Switzerland's Edi Rominger, nine skiers broke the Warm Springs Trail record today in the downhill phase of the seventh annual Harriman Cup International Ski Races. A brilliant sun had the temperature hovering in the 90's.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- A new stumbling block to agreement on how much President Truman's $37,500,000,000 budget should be cut was thrown up this week. It consisted of the President's enunciation of a new foreign policy involving the proposed expenditure of at least $400,000,000 which previously had not been taken into account.

Taking the position that "my political views are my private business," Jack Ryan, executive vice president of the New York Newspaper Guild, Congress of Industrial Organizations, refused yesterday to affirm or deny membership in the Communist party.

AS a newcomer to the somewhat overcrowded but wellpaying field of historical fiction, Lucile Finlay comes off very well indeed with her first novel. MARGARET TRUMAN, fully recovered from an attack of laryngitis which prevented her appearance with the Detroit Symphony Orchestra last week, is expected to make her debut tonight as soloist during the concert broadcast from 8 to 9 o'clock over WJZ and the American network.

A shakeup of subordinate commanders in the detective bureau, including the demotion of one man, was announced yesterday by Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander. Twenty men from Deputy Inspector to First Grade Detective were involved in the shifts that hit every borough.

Revival of the cruise of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club of Greenwich, Conn., was announced yesterday along with the schedule of distance races in Long Island Sound and to the eastward. The cruise will take the yachts to the Yale-Harvard regatta at New London.

THE Original Ballet Russe, with Alicia Markova, Anton Dolin and Andre Eglevsky as guest artists, will open its brief season of twelve performances at the Metropolitan Opera House on Thursday. RICHMOND, March 15 -- Enrollment of three white co-eds from Midwestern colleges at Hampton Institute has caused considerable off-the-record comment in Virginia. Much of it is adverse, but little or nothing has been said publicly on the subject.

BERLIN, March 15 (AP) -- Reliable informants said today that United States Military Government officials had recommended to the United States delegation in Moscow that coal-rich industrial Upper Silesia be awarded to Poland and Lower Silesia be left to Germany in a compromise solution on Germany's eastern border.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 15 -- Presidents of nineteen American universities joined today in a warning of the uncertain future of medical education, upon which medical care and public health are dependent. They called upon citizens of this country for "prompt and generous aid."
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The State Department tonight described the project for aiding Greece as a simple one of giving economic assistance in response to an appeal from Greece.

The lure of the city's Police Department yesterday drew 21,000 men between the ages of 21 and 34 to eleven high schools in the five boroughs, where they toiled over tests for admission to the department.

Following is a list of definitions, plucked from the news columns, which may or may not help to clarify the situation: OPTIMISM -- "The sublimation of inhibitions and emancipation of neuroses from the depressive and jealousy complexes."

TO say that Miss Nancy Bruff is concerned with the baser manifestations of sex will come as no great surprise to readers who dipped into "The Manatee." Her new novel explores the same domains, approximately -- heaping (with a minimum of thought, but with a fair share of lavish intuition) adultery on desertion, impotence on lust, madness on immorality, and so on.

WHILE the chief emphasis in the Whitney Museum's 1947 annual of sculpture, water-colors and drawings is firmly on modernism, the show exemplifies so many types of procedure within that general category that the over-all effect may well appear somewhat less "extreme" than was the case in the December painting annual.

ALBANY, March 15 -- Internal strife has broken out in both the Republican and Democratic leadership as a result of tensions, pressures and lacerated feelings at the current session of the Legislature. Some, it is believed, may have serious political consequences.
Greater selectivity among students and wider diversity in adult and higher education have become necessary in the United States, according to Dr. Katharine E. McBride, president of Bryn Mawr College.

PORTLAND, March 15 -- As the West Coast reads of the economy program talked about in Congress, it shows concern over the subject of water, whether the term covers flood control, reclamation, power or deeper channels.

HOW a band of theatrical troupers fared along the Erie Canal in the early part of the last century, how a lone female made her cheerful, eventful way there along with an adventurous young blood from Harvard, plus a wealth of local Americana -- all this is on tap in "Banner by the Wayside."

AS never before, this country has become education conscious. The post-war period has witnessed an unprecedented public interest in education. Our schools and colleges are crowded beyond their limits. For the first time the Government is subsidizing the higher education of over a million men and women.

WASHINGTON -- A good disposition will have to be one of the prerequisites for the 1947 automobile tourist, if the hopes of the nation's highway builders are even partly realized. Highway construction work probably will be as much of a bugaboo to the traveler in 1947 as finding overnight accommodations was in 1946.

OTTAWA, Marcn 15 -- A profound sensation has been created here by the charges leveled against the Communist party by J. A. (Pat) Sullivan, who resigned yesterday as president of the Canadian Seamen's Union.
PHILADELPHIA, March 15 -- Pennsylvania closed its regular basketball season by defeating Princeton tonight at the Palestra, 65 -- 43. A four-game trip to Cuba next month still remains.
GREAT progress has been made during recent years in perfecting exciting new varieties of garden chrysanthemums. This flower is the most popular of all perennials with home gardeners today.

THE subject of this study lived in the fourth century. Enough is known about him to supply a reasonably full portrait. The author, however, draws heavily on speculation in order to achieve the semblance of an exhaustive treatment.
ASPARAGUS is a true aristocrat among the vegetables. It is one of springtime's delicacies which is never so good as when freshly harvested and promptly cooked.

WORKING forward in time through the Revolutionary, Civil and Spanish-American Wars, Elswyth Thane has now arrived at Volume Four (and World War I) in her projected series of five American historical novels. To people who lived through that war it is only now assuming the firm outlines of history, and for them "The Light Heart" will have the charm of time remembered.
The construction industry is supporting the efforts of the Building Officials Conference of America to unify and modernize building codes throughout the nation.
The United Financial Employes, AFL, began organizing yesterday an industry-wide strike against the Stock, Curb and Cotton Exchanges and Wall Street brokerage houses.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 15 -- The morale of many United Nations employes, which was already low as a result of recent cuts to per diem allowances, appears to have dropped further following President Truman's decision last Wednesday to by-pass the United Nations in extending immediate aid to Greece and Turkey.

MANY "systems" are suggested for selecting perennials so that the garden will be beautiful all through spring, summer and fall. One way is to choose perennials that are attractive for nine to twelve months of the year, rather than just for their flowering period.

READERS of this column in the past ten weeks, when it comprised a review of the latest bidding developments, may have observed that there have been few changes in the methods that have been in general use for ten years or more.

After the New York Rovers had dissipated a 4-0 lead and yielded four goals to the invaders, the locals stormed back to hand the Washington Lions a 5-4 setback in an Amateur Hockey Association of the United States play-off battle featuring the hockey twin-bill at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

Headquarters of spring will be found this week in Grand Central Palace, where the International Flower Show opens at noon today. Greenhouses and gardens from New Jersey to Connecticut have yielded their finest flowers and plants to present for the next six days a panorama of bloom unrivaled in thirty - one years of flower show history.

President Truman was characterized yesterday as "a man sent from God" to play a leading role as a world democratic leader, by Archbishop H. G. Athenagoras of the Greek Orthodox Church of North and South America.
NEWARK, N. J., March 16 -- Ellis Arnall, former Governor of Georgia, spoke here today at the State convention of the American Jewish Congress in Temple B'nai Abraham.

With the Red Cross 1947 Fund for New York at the half-way mark, a little more than 10 per cent of the 19,000 concerns in which gifts are being collected from workers have completed their assignments, Mrs. George J. Harding, chairman of the employe gifts committee, reported yesterday.

BERLIN, March 16--An amazing story of counterfeiting, passport forgery and bribery in a German - administered internment camp was told by an inmate. A high Military Government official admitted at the same time that conditions in the camps were "unsatisfactory."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 16 --Twentieth Century-Fox announced today that Olivia De Havilland, who won the Academy Award Thursday for the best 1946 performance by a film actress, will play the leading role in the screen version of Mary Jane Ward's novel, "The Snake Pit." The story will be filmed next summer, with Antole Litvak directing, from a scenario by Frank Partos and Millen Brand. Robert Bassler will produce.

The twenty-fifth anniversary of the Jewish Institute of Religion was observed last night at a dinner in honor of Rabbi Stephen S. Wise, its founder and president. Four hundred educators, friends, alumni and others attended the event at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, which also commemorated the seventythird birthday of Dr. Wise, which is today.

CHICAGO, March 16--M. David Keefe, president of the United Financial Employes, AFL, said today that his union would not serve thirty-day strike notices on the Stock, Curb and Cotton Exchanges in New York for several days at least.
DETROIT, March 16--Margaret Truman, daughter of the President, made her formal debut as a vocalist at a concert given here tonight at the Detroit Music Hall.

The Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert, Bishop-elect of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, administered yesterday the apostolic rite to a confirmation class of twenty members at the Calvary Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street.

"The Wearing of the Green" will be the theme of song and story-- and the predominant fashion-- when an estimated 80,000 sons and daughters of Erin march up Fifth Avenue this afternoon in the traditional St. Patrick's Day parade.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 16-- Dr. Paul Kleinsorge, who has stirred national interest since his recent arbitration awards in two maritime disputes affecting both East and West Coast operators, firmly believes that wages should reflect the rising costs of living.

That the subject of public finance still has a considerable distance to traverse before it can be said to qualify as an exact science was illustrated last week (if any illustration were needed) at a Round Table Discussion broadcast under the auspices of a Midwest university.

PARIS, March 16--Foreign Minister Georges Bidault's proposal to the Big Four in Moscow of huge emigration to keep down the German population does not involve forced emigration. What is suggested is a voluntary movement of Germans, notably workers, to countries to which they may be persuaded to go and that are willing to receive them, officiate in close touch with the problem said tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 16--The Administration has called home the United States Ambassadors from Greece and Turkey to provide facts for Congressional examination of President Truman's...
LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 16 (AP) --Nine leaders of the CIO United Automobile Workers held a "harmony meeting" for nearly two hours here tonight in an attempt to patch up intra-union friction.

Deferred a night to March 26 is the premiere of James Mason's vehicle, "Bathsheba," at the Barrymore. In Philadelphia yesterday Coby Ruskin went to work in earnest as the latest director of the Jacques Deval play. At the request of the star, who had been making his own script and directorial changes since the original director, Robert H. Gordon, resigned on March 7, Mr. Ruskin is staging the biblical play to accentuate its comedy values.

ROME, March 16--Foreign Ministry circles today saw some contradiction as well as muddled thinking in President Truman's decision to create what they termed a "dollar dam" to stem Russian imperialism in the Mediterranean while leaving wide open the Adriatic back door.

The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation reported yesterday for 1946 a consolidated net income of $10,854,084 after charges and taxes. This was equal, after preferred dividend payments, to $3.79 each on the 2,476,502 common shares outstanding at the yearend.

The grandest mass riot in the local history of the National Hockey League took place at Madison Square Garden last night as the Canadiens of Montreal beat the New York Rangers 4 to 3. With only thirty seconds of play remaining, and with the Canadiens leading by what turned out to be the final score, the tense feeling that had existed between the teams all night broke out with sudden fierceness.

CHICAGO, March 16--The grain markets continued their sensational advance last week and all deliveries of the three major grains on the Chicago Board of Trade sold at new seasonal peaks. The advance, which got under way around Feb. 1, has lifted May wheat 69 1/2 cents and corn 41 1/2 cents a bushel, and March wheat sold yesterday at $2.89 3/4, a new high for any future of that grain since May, 1917.

LONDON, March 16--With a weather eye toward her long-range domestic coal market, Britain is moving cautiously during the present fuel crisis in promoting oil as a substitute fuel, officials conceded here today.

AMSTERDAM, March 16--Finance Minister Pieter Lieftinck, in an interview on Thursday, declared that heavy occupation damage and post-occupation difficulties barred the Netherlands from immediate recovery without acceptance of a substantial deficit in the balance of foreign trade.

Described as "a long step forward" in pediatric nursing, the first study of what makes good nursing care for children is now under way in the pediatric department of the New York Hospital, Sixty-eighth Street and the East River.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 16 (AP) --Delegates to the CIO-National Education Conference staged an eight-and-a-half-hour "sit-in" at the coffee shop of the Neil House today in protest against what they termed discrimination against Negro delegates.

The United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York announced yesterday that three fund-raising agencies here had closed independent drives and instead would become part of its 1947 campaign for $65,000,000.

A program to combat both intellectual and physical Jim Crow discrimination against the Negro in the fields of art and entertainment was discussed yesterday afternoon at a meeting at the Murray Hill Hotel. The meeting was called by the cultural division of the National Negro Congress.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 16--The pneumatic tube system now used by the New York Post Office in its underground mail service will be installed in the future world capital to provide the United Nations with special twominute mail service between office desks and main postal depots, according to present plans.

Appearing for the first time this season in a National Challenge Cup competition at Sterling Oval before a crowd of 3,000 fans, the Brookhattans of the American Soccer League gained a hard-fought victory, 2 to 1, over the visiting Hakoah eleven of the National League.

BOSTON, March 16 (U.P.)--Paced by Capt. Bobby Bauer, the Boston Bruins ran their unbeaten streak to nine games tonight as they humbled Toronto, 5 to 3, before 13,900 fans in one of the bitterest National Hockey League games staged on Boston Garden ice this year.

U.N.'s Food and Agriculture Organization comes into the Grecian picture this morning with what is, in the context of the news, a poignantly dramatic report. This is not because what it has to say is new. The FAO mission which produced the report went to Greece, at the invitation of the Greek Government, ten months ago.

Ernest H. Peabody, president of the New York City League for Less Noise, asserted yesterday that the police had made considerable progress in 1946 toward curbing unnecessary noises in home, street and factory. Statistics released by the Safety Bureau of the Department, he added, indicated the most extensive anti-noise enforcement program in several years.

The plan of reorganization for Portland Electric Power Company, recently approved by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Federal District Court of Oregon, is not "fair and equitable" in the opinion of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York.
LONDON, March 16--Britain entered the international field in watch manufacturing yesterday with the opening of the AngloCeltic watch factory at Ystradgynlais, South Wales.

BRUSSELS, March 16--No one knows how many Belgians remain in the hands of the Soviet Union. Repeated efforts to get information and even to have a mission visit Russian territory have yielded exactly nothing.

Although the return of large numbers of war veterans to the campus has caused Columbia University difficult adjustments and heavy expenses, the effort has beer extremely rewarding, Dr. Prank D. Fackenthal, acting president, declared in his annual report to the trustees, made public yesterday.

AT THE GREEK-ALBANIAN FRONTIER, March 15 (Delayed) --The rattle of machine-gun fire has replaced the tapping of typewriters and donkeys have taken the place of limousines as transport for a group of the United Nations Balkans inquiry commission, which found itself today in this rugged countryside.

The only part of the Potsdam agreement that has been promptly, even enthusiastically, carried out is the decision to transfer into Germany the population of the Sudetenland and the inhabitants of the large slice of eastern Germany "provisionally" awarded to Poland in compensation for the cession of eastern Poland to the Soviet Union.
LONDON, Ohio, March 16 (AP)-- Mel Shane, 37 years old, who made good as a business man in Detroit, surrendered today to State Prison Farm authorities on a twelve-yearold escape charge.

PARIS, March 16--In a resolution adopted tonight the national congress of the Popular Republican Movement, of which Foreign Minister Georges Bidault is the leader, "took note" of President Truman's message to Congress, bringing a "new guarantee to democratic institutions in the world."

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 16 (AP)--Hammering Hank Greenberg, cutting loose for the Pittsburgh Pirates for the first time, banged out two homers and a single while his new team-mates were overwhelming the Boston Braves, 13--1, in an exhibition game that was halted by rain after the seventh inning today.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 16--Dr. Herman Santa Cruz, permanent delegate of Chile to the United Nations, emphasized today that his Government was entirely behind international efforts to maintain political freedom and to safeguard the basic rights of the individual.

Poised long on the brink, China seems plunging head-on into full-scale civil war. Ever since they withdrew from the Nanking parleys the Communists have been preparing for it. Now at last Chiang Kai-shek, speaking from the tomb of Sun Yat-sen as though to dedicate himself and his Government at the national shrine, has drawn the naked sword.

The wholesale markets last week were generally quiet with only rayon piece goods business and the toy fair highlighting activity according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (U.P.) --The Foreign Policy Association said tonight, in support of the State Department's world-trade proposals, that the United States would lose its free enterprise system if it followed an "economic nationalism" policy of high tariffs.

LAKELAND, Fla., March 16--A year ago at this time the Detroit Tigers looked to have as much class and power as any team in baseball. They had pitching, hitting and fielding. What more could a manager want? But the Bengals were smitten hard by the "GI jitters," a disease which prevented returning veterans from climbing back to their pre-war heights.
Roger N. Baldwin, director of the American Civil Liberties Union, will leave next week for Japan and Korea for a two-month survey of civil liberties in those areas.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP)-- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Republican, of Michigan, has pigeonholed President Truman's appointment of Francis Biddle to the United Nations Economic and Social Council. The group's New York sessions probably will end before the Senate acts.

TOKYO, March 16--The unfortunate citizen of Tokyo who wishes merely to keep his virtually priceless clothing--one of the rarest and most expensive items on the flourishing black market--now faces a new hazard--bathhouse bandits.

Sending of relief to Greece will be good Christianity and wise strategy, but the United States must beware of a return to the old theory of balance of powers, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman declared yesterday in his sermon at Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., March 16 --Corny Shields left his dinghy Dainty ashore today at the Larchmont Yacht Club and took over me helm of Whimsy, the craft owned by his daughter, Aileen. The result was that he tied the outstanding leader of the season, Arthur Knapp Jr., who had won ten regattas with his boat Agony, Each scored 157 points over six races.

An audience of more than 3,500, including 130 in special seats in the orchestra pit, thronged the Metropolitan Opera House last night for the reunion of one of music's most famous brother and sister teams, Yehudi and Hephzibah Menuhin.

ST. LOUIS, March 16--The city of St. Louis, victor in a battle with the Federal Government for return of facilities at Lambert-St. Louis Municipal Airport, taken over as a wartime measure, is now negotiating with the McDonnell Aircraft Corporation for a long-term lease on a $9,500,000 building there.
The books and services of the New York Public Library were in far greater demand last year than they had been since the war began, according to its annual report, released yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 16--A pertinent report on the economic crisis in Greece, setting forth a twenty-five year plan for her recovery, was made public today by the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization.

Reduction of fire hazards in multiple dwellings not adequately protected was asked yesterday by Robert F. Wagner Jr., Commissioner of Housing and Buildings. He called upon the Legislature to enact legislation before adjourning this week.
LONDON, March 16--Lewis W. Douglas, new United States Ambassador to Great Britain, arrived in London today. One of the first things he heard was Left-Wing condemnation of President Truman's message.

LONDON, March 16--Flood conditions throughout the country became more serious tonight when winds that reached eighty and in some places 100 miles an hour, struck the southwest and south coasts of England. The storm, with severe downpours of rain in many places, smashed eastward in a path of destruction.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP)-- The staff of Frank R. Creedon, Housing Expediter, has told him that the estimate of 1,000,000 new homes to be started in 1947, mentioned by President Truman and predicted by other officials, is far too high.

LONDON, March 16 (U.P.)--For a few hours tonight, London firemen had their busiest time since blitz days. Engines answered at least fifty emergency calls as the howling winds blew in windows and knocked over at least three subway station entrances.

SALONIKA, Greece, March 16-- An armed band of nearly twenty men, dressed as Greek Regular Army soldiers, entered a cafe frequented habitually by Nationalists on the outskirts of Salonika late last night, killed two gendarmes off duty and wounded three others.
An unusual experiment in labor-management cooperation for better human relations is being made at the Botany Worsted Mills in Passaic, N. J.
DETROIT, March 16--Dr. Karl Krueger, conductor of the Detroit Symphony, was highly enthusiastic tonight over Margaret Truman's debut.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I ask for the privilege of space in your columns to explain the viewpoint of one American of Jewish faith on the painfully troublesome situation in Palestine. I do so particularly because I find more than one instance, in your newspaper and in others, of the acceptance of propaganda concepts that have no real basis in fact.

WASHINGTON, March 16-- Hastening to meet the recommendations of Herbert Hoover for German relief, the Army reported tonight that supplies for soupkitchen feeding were arriving there and that seeds were ready for shipment.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP)-- Top professional sports officials today endorsed a youth guidance program sponsored by sports writers and broadcasters in cooperation with Attorney General Tom Clark.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP)-- The Norwegian Embassy will not oppose Kirsten Flagstad's plans to become a United States citizen, Ambassador Wilhelm M. Morgenstierne said today. But when asked to comment on the Norwegian soprano's announcement of her plans in New York yesterday, Mr. Morgenstierne said that "we feel under obligation to give these facts to the American press":

PITTSBURGH, March 16 -- Although facing difficulties of production that usually are present at levels close to maximum output and also finding it hard to obtain supplies of scrap metal, the steel industry was able last week to advance its ingot rate one point to 95.5 per cent of rated capacity-- a new peacetime peak.

WASHINGTON, March 16--J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, reported tonight that crime increased 7.6 per cent last year to a ten-year peak and warned that there was evidence of "old gangs regrouping."

CHICAGO, March 16--A big increase in production of shoes and other leather goods in the next few months was predicted by stockyard sources today because of the large number of cattle and calves slaughtered since the meat industry was decontrolled last October.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., March 16--Victorious in four of the five events on Saturday, George Hinman in his craft Felix once again dominated the competition today as the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's two-day regatta for Class B dinghies was concluded. Hinman placed first in four of today's seven tests to register a two-day total of 111 points.

With Gallic realism, French Foreign Minister Bidault put his finger on one of the fundamental problems confronting France, Europe and the world when he declared at the Moscow conference that any peace based on the Yalta and Potsdam plans would further increase the population density and population pressure in Germany and would thereby also increase the German menace to France.

David Dubinsky's leadership of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL, was supported by a vote of nearly 6 to 1 in the Cutters Union, Local 10, it was announced last night after a tally of ballots cast on Saturday in Manhattan Center.

LAHORE, India, March 16 (AP)-- Stringent measures approaching imposition of martial law to deal with the situation in riot-torn areas of the Punjab were predicted tonight by Giani Kartar Singh, Sikh leader, after a conference with Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, Vice President of the Indian Interim Government.
The tremendous weights of the projected planes of tomorrow pose major technical problems which may eventually set optimum limits to aircraft size.

Although this country's tonnage left over from the wartime emergency is viewed by other nations as a challenge to their maritime future, the United States has no intention of retiring from the sea to satisfy these critics of our shipping policy, Arthur M. Tode, honorary president of the Propeller Club of the United States, declared yesterday.

Two men, one displaying a pistol, held up Gerald Moran, 30 years old, night cashier in the ground floor office of Post-Graduate Hospital, 301 East Twentieth Street, at 10 o'clock last night and escaped with $7,400 in cash and checks.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., March 16-- The old-fashioned theory that baseball is a young man's game was rather rudely jarred on Lane Field his afternoon, where, before a fathering of 7,099, the White Sox snapped a three-game winning streak of the Giants as a gesture of aloha before the National Leaguers took off in the great blue yonder for Hawaii. The score was 9 to 3.

CHICAGO, March 16--Handlers of cash grain are reported to have large Government contracts for corn to fill prior to May 1, and a leak in figures of the Department of Agriculture on May export allocations indicates that 22,000,000 bushels of corn will be wanted for shipment that month.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 16 --Barney McLean of the Denver Heipfelberger S.C., badly hurt a month ago when he crashed into a tree at Aspen, turned in two masterful performances today to win the international open slalom race held in conjunction with the Harriman Cup combined competition on Ruud Mountain.

WASHINGTON, March 16--An acceleration of the legislative wheels of Congress will be attempted by Republican leaders this week. The chief aim in this effort is to complete by March 31 consideration of President Truman's request for an authorization of $400,000,000 to aid Greece and Turkey.
MOSCOW, March 16--After the feverish opening days, the meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers has shaken down into a routine that is exacting but never boring.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, March 16 (U.P.)--President Higinio Morinigo announced today the Government had opened full-scale military operations against the rebels at Conception. He pledged the holding of national elections when order was restored.

The Frigidaire division of General Motors Corporation will beam 1,000,000,000 advertising messages to consumers during 1947 in what was described over the week-end by F.H. Peters, advertising manager, as "the most vigorous and comprehensive campaign in company history."

Domestic cotton prices last week backed and filled within a comparatively narrow trading range, and ended the period with mixed net change. At the close on Saturday active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 39 points to down 27 points on the preceding week, the gains being recorded in the nearer positions.

Enough music for three concerts, and much of it very interesting, was performed at the concert given by the American-Soviet Music Society last night in Town Hall. The concert was so long that not all of it could be heard by a reviewer with an edition to catch.

HONOLULU, March 16 (AP)--A new storm out of the northwest Pacific today threatened to swamp the stern section of the wrecked tanker Port Dearborn and made impossible any immediate rescue of the twenty-two men aboard.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 16 (AP)--Lew Worsham of Washington, D.C., came from behind with a sub-par 71 and a spectacular finish to tie Clayton Heafner of Charlotte, N.C., for first place in the $10,000 Jacksonville open golf tournament today.

In the face of widely conflicting predictions by industry spokesmen as to estimated 1947 production of FM-AM radio receivers and transmitters, the Radio Manufacturers Association last week took steps to arrive at a reliable estimate. It sent questionnaires to all member set producers asking for detailed information on actual and planned production on such models.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (U.P.) --Gen. Omar N. Bradley, chief of the Veterans Administration, believes that within ten years war veterans and their dependents will number almost half the population and thus will have to shoulder the major tax burden.

General Electric has overcome the old argument against electric cooking--that is, that it is slow-- in four new ranges that will go into distribution in two or three weeks. Top units, broilers and ovens have been overhauled, with the result that food preparation is speeded up.

Marriage and family life are disintegrating because moderns fail to realize that physical love is only "a means to en end, and that end is divine love," Msgr. Fulton J. Sheen, Professor of Philosophy at the Catholic University of America, declared yesterday in a Lenten sermon at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

The second half of the National Academy's annual exhibition--devoted to work by members--and the first of a projected series of annual print exhibitions, national in scope, at the Brooklyn Museum, open to the public Wednesday, are among some thirty group and one-man shows this week.

The Texas Company reported yesterday for 1946 a consolidated net profit, excluding European subsidiaries, of $71,089,267 after charges, taxes and reserves for depreciation, depletion and amortization. This was equal to $6.32 each on 11,244,660 capital shares outstanding.

ELIZABETH CITY, N. J., March 16 (AP)--Police Chief Walter Spence reported that Superior Court Judge C. Everett Thompson, 65, was shot and instantly killed tonight in his home by George Pritchard of Elizabeth City, who then killed himself with a shotgun.

Aided by foundation grants of $54,000 the New York Academy of Medicine in 1943 began a four-year inquiry to determine the changes in medical practice required in "whatever new social order may ultimately develop." Ten studies of special aspects of medical practice have thus far been published, two more are promised, and the whole serves as the basis of a final opinion now issued.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP)-- Farmers can expect costs to take a larger share of their income this year, the Department of Agriculture said tonight.

The fortieth anniversary of the Rev. Dr. Matthew F. Johnston's ministry of the Morrisania Presbyterian Church, Washington Avenue at 168th Street, the Bronx, was celebrated yesterday at the church's morning service.
JERUSALEM, March 16--The withdrawal of statutory martial law imposed on the Tel Aviv-Petah Tiqva area and a section of Jerusalem on March 2 was announced today.

The heaviest musical love potion in operatic history was served up yesterday at the Metropolitan Opera House without a single paying customer on hand for the treat. The occasion was the first operatic recording there under the auspices of the Columbia Recording Corporation.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Carroll Reece, chairman of the Republican National Committee, accused President Truman tonight of "sabotaging" the Republican legislative program and of insincerity in his proposal to "cooperate" with the Republican majority in Congress.

A colorful resident of Cochise County, Ariz., is fighting extradition to New York to face charges of engineering a $16,000 stock swindle, it was announced here yesterday by the State Attorney General's office.

MOSCOW, March 16--Secretary of State Marshall was reported tonight to have decided to submit tomorrow to the Council of Foreign Ministers a demand that all indigenous German resources be made available to Germany's entire national economy.
DETROIT, March 16--Miss Margaret Truman, the daughter of the President, made her professional debut as a singer tonight with the Detroit Symphony Orchestra playing under the baton of Karl Krueger.

The Young Men's Board of Trade of New York, 291 Broadway, acting is coordinator of the efforts of business and industry, lists the following free services to aid veterans in career-planning and employment.

ALBANY, March 16--Governor Dewey will recommend pay increases ranging up to $5,500 for heads of state departments in his supplemental budget, which is to be submitted to the Legislature tomorrow on the eve of the final adjournment of the present session, it was reported today.
LAKELAND, Fla., March 16-- The Yankees for a time today appeared finally to have caught up with their long lost winning touch.

CHICAGO, March 16 (U.P.)--The Detroit Red Wings smothered the Chicago Black Hawks under a barrage of goals tonight, 10--6, before 17,071 at Chicago Stadium. Roy Conacher made four tallies, three of them in the first twelve minutes of the game.

Much of the report of the acting president of Columbia University for 1946, which is published today, is a summing up of that substantial and varied contribution made by Columbia men to the winning of the war. Dr. Fackenthal's eloquent conclusion deals with the ways to peace and calls for new and needed emphasis on the social sciences which, he believes, must now come to the assistance of mankind, "and not too slowly."
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A large group of employes, who are being denied their rights by law, are the World War II veterans in the New York City Civil Service.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 16--Eastern Union County has gained 194 new industries since 1941, the total aggregating 689, compared with the 495 listed six years ago, the 1947 edition of the industrial directory of the Chamber of Commerce revealed today.

Eighty-five rabbis, graduates of Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary of Yeshiva University, were ordained at a "S'micha" convocation yesterday afternoon in the Nathan Lamport Auditorium, Amsterdam Avenue and 187th Street. Dr. Samuel Belkin, president of the university, presided, and Dr. Joseph B. Soloveitchik, Professor of Talmud and Jewish Philosophy, delivered the address.

A sharp recovery in airline patronage, both passenger and cargo, was reported from several sources yesterday, leading company executives to predict that all facilities, including Floyd Bennett Field, would be needed here to handle traffic within thirty to sixty days.

When the League of Composers presents a program of new music, you may be certain that there will be a lot of it and that it will be new. There was enough of it at last night's program of new chamber music at the Auditorium of Modern Art to satisfy the heartiest appetite, enough, in fact, to give some systems a touch of indigestion.
A diverse collection of articles, hand made by professional craftsmen and hobbyists, opened yesterday at the Pen and Brush Club, 16 East Tenth Street.
