The National Dairy Products Corporation transacted last year a record high volume of sales and increased earnings by $11,330,238 over 1945, L. A. Van Bomel, president, informed stockholders in the annual report being distributed today.

PARIS, March 16--Reverberations of President Truman's message throughout Europe have grown in the last few days, as a study of the text has revealed its full implications. The accumulating echoes have been accompanied by mental reservations in high places that may surprise Americans.
Sunny skies and a temperature that reached 41.4 degrees at 3:10 P.M. gave a semblance of spring to the city yesterday, luring thousands to parks and playgrounds and near-by beaches.

BALBOA, C.Z., March 16--The Dodgers celebrated the arrival of Branch Rickey today by winning another ball game, but it took them two and a half hours and eleven innings and the Mahatma didn't wait for the finish.

MEXICO CITY, March 16--After a disappointing week of "Young Woodley," with Roddy MacDowell, the Teatro Americano announced tonight it would close next week in the hope of reorganizing and of reopening a week from Tuesday.

Rapidly decreasing margins of net profit in 1947 are worrying many distributors of industrial machinery, equipment and supplies, spokesmen disclosed here over the week-end. Five major factors have contributed to their decreasing net profits, they said.

Although American shipping companies are forbidden to operate aircraft, the Government is allowing foreign airlines controlled by steamship companies to dominate international trade routes developed over a century by American lines, it was charged yesterday.

MOSCOW, March 16--British Foreign Secretary Bevin's principal aim in the meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers has been set forth as the achievement of an agreement on a four-power policy that will steer between two dangerous alternatives.

NEW DELHI, India, March 16 (Reuters)--Communal rioting continued the hill districts of the northwest Punjab today, where troops opened fire to disperse a crowd preparing to attack a village. Casualties in another village were officially described as heavy.

Seven hundred persons filled Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Wall Street, yesterday afternoon for a "service in celebration of the historic relationship between Trinity and its sister and daughter churches." The service was held as part of the church's 250th anniversary ceremonies.

The National Bureau of Casualty and Surety Underwriters announced yesterday a general revision of glass insurance rates and minimum premiums to be effective today in thirty-two States and the District of Columbia. Changes will become effective in the remaining States as soon as rate filings have been accepted by the States where filings must be made.
ATHENS, March 16 (AP)--Paul Porter, chief of the United States economic mission to Greece, left Athens by plane today for Washington.
HAIFA, Palestine, March 16-- Arab and Jewish workers are presenting a common front here in their sitdown strike against the Iraq Petroleum Company, which is 23 per cent American-owned.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 16--A Welsh terrier to whom the top prize came as no novelty was judged best in show tonight at the Saw Mill River Kennel Club's seventh all-breed event in the County Center. She was Champion Twin Ponds Belle, owned "by Mrs. Edward P. Alker of Great Neck.

Week Ended March 15, 1947 A fresh crop of rumors hinting that the Canadian free dollar was to be devalued--the mark-down was as vague, either 5 per cent or 10 per cent--struck down the open market rate for that currency late on Friday afternoon to 93.50 cents, a new low since the Canadian dollar was lifted to parity with the American dollar on July 5, 1946.

The University of Kentucky quintet, tabbed by many as the nation's No. 1 team since early in the season, makes its first appearance in the tenth annual invitation basketball tournament at Madison Square Garden tonight, against Long Island University.

"The Atomic Story," by John W. Campbell, a history of the 2,000 years of discovering that the atom existed, has been scheduled for publication by Henry Holt on April 10. Mr. Campbell, who has degrees in nuclear physics, is editor of Air Trails and Astounding Science Fiction.

ALBANY, March 16--Rejection of the proposed peace treaty with Italy was urged upon the United States Senate today in a resolution adopted unanimously by the State Executive Committee of the Columbian Republican League.
LONDON, March. 16--Although the financial markets were not pulled violently in any direction by the events of the past week it was an unsettling period with the general trend of prices downward.

CLEARWATER, Pla., March 17 -- The Philadelphia Phils will not win the National League pennant this season. If they do, Commissioner Happy Chandler should order a saliva test. But they've shaken loose completely from their last-place complex and now have the jaunty look that befits a fifth-place team. Admittedly, though, the Phils are a couple of years away from strong pennant contention, since they are rebuilding from the ground up.

ALBANY, March 17 -- Resistance to the state's anti-discrimination law has decreased to such an extent that "pre-employment discriminatory inquiries are now the rarity rather than the rule," the State Commission against Discrimination reported today to Governor Dewey.

CHICAGO, March 17 -- Directors of the Chicago Board of Trade, at a special meeting today, met in part a request by the Commodity Exchange Authority that initial margin requirements on new speculative trades in grain futures be set at 25 per cent of the current market price.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 17 -- The personnel of the United States men's and women's ski teams, with the exception of the jumpers, for the 1948 Olympic winter games at St. Moritz, Switzerland, next February was announced today by the Olympic ski games committee.

Three policies aimed at solving the urgent national problem of shortages of ores were recommended yesterday by J.A. Krug, Secretary of Interior, to more than 700 members of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Cotton Consumption Domestic consumption of all cottons in February fell 102,000 bales from the preceding month's total to 845,000 bales, according to the trade report service of the New York Cotton Exchange. The decline was about normal for the month, although on the daily rate basis--1.6 per cent from the January daily rate--it was slightly more than was expected.

BUDAPEST, March 16 (Delayed) -- The conclusion of a new Russian-Hungarian trade agreement that will make this country virtually an economic adjunct of the Soviet Union is expected soon, since it has been delayed only by the necessity of installing Russia's friends in positions of power.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today refused to rule on an employer's contention that the right of freedom of speech permitted him to express to his workers his personal views against a CIO union.

MOSCOW, March 17 -- The editors of Pravda, newspaper of the Communist party's central committee, invited this correspondent to their plant yesterday to talk over the meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers. Actually, it was also a courteous repayment of the hospitality shown to two of Pravda's diplomatic correspondents, Boris Izakov and Eugene Zhukov, by THE NEW YORK TIMES when they were reporting the United Nations meeting in New York.

TOKYO, March 17 (AP) -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur, granting his first formal press conference since early in the war, proposed a toast at the Tokyo Correspondents' Club today to "the friendship and goodwill of the Fourth Estate" and announced:

TOKYO, March 17 -- Further steps in its drive against the black market were announced today by occupation headquarters. Brig. Gen. F.S. Besson Jr., chief of the transportation section, said that, as of March 20, Japanese police would restrict railway passengers to a single bundle of specified size and weight.

CLEVELAND, March 17--The United Rubber Workers, CIO, called today a strike of 100,000 members employed by the "Big Four" rubber companies for midnight Sunday following a breakdown in wage negotiations.

It wasn't an interest in gardening that directed us to the Flower Show yesterday, but rather the fact that some of our favorite food manufacturers have set up booths for the week at Grand Central Palace.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson announced today that he had signed the Sanitary Agreement setting up the joint United States-Mexican campaign against the foot-and-mouth disease outbreak in Mexico.

BATAVIA, Java, March 17 (AP)-- Indonesian Premier Sutan Sjahrir demanded today that the Dutch halt their offensive in the Mojokerto area of eastern Java or risk all hope for a "peaceful settlement in Indonesia."

The National Hockey League's play-offs will open next Tuesday in Montreal between the champion Canadians and the third-place Boston Bruins, President Clarence Campbell announced yesterday after a meeting here of the board of governors, the Canadian Press reported.

After Saturday night's performance, "Parlor Story" will be withdrawn from the Biltmore Theatre, it was announced yesterday by Paul Streger. The comedy, headed by Walter Abel and Edith Atwater, opened on March 4 and will have registered twenty-three performances by closing time.
Offices of the Collectors of Internal Revenue in New York were flooded with last minute income tax returns containing checks and money orders running into the hundreds of millions of dollars.
WASHINGTON, March 17--The House Banking and Currency Committee, opening hearings on rent legislation, was urged today by a top Federal official to extend rent controls to June 30, 1948.

The National Collegiate A.A. cleared the decks for its Eastern tournament starting Thursday night in Madison Square Garden with a draw that matched Holy Cross against Navy and City College of New York against Wisconsin, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

Port Patrol officers under Harry M. Durning, Collector of Customs, yesterday uncovered and seized on the French freighter St. Tropez 459 ounces of pure heroin, valued in illicit markets at $1,147,500. This was said by authorities to be the largest seizure of narcotics ever made in the port of New York.

A banking group headed by Lehman Brothers submitted yesterday the highest bid for $1,300,000 of water works improvement bonds of Kansas City, Mo., maturing from March 1, 1948, to March 1, 1987. The Lehman bid was 100.10 for 1 1/2s, a net interest cost of 1.499 per cent.
Forty striking employes of the Young Women's Christian Association in Brooklyn were dropped from their jobs yesterday after they had ignored telegraphic warnings to return to work.

SHANGHAI, March 17--Street searches by the police and the disappearance of about 100 persons following night visits by gendarmes have produced uneasiness among Chinese liberals and intellectuals here.

Mel Hein, former New York Football Giants star, is returning to professional football. Hein, named eight times as All-National Football League center, will serve as assistant coach of the Los Angeles Dons of the All-America Conference this year.

TRENTON, N.J., March 17 -- Program legislation sought by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll received Assembly approval today at a meeting of the New Jersey Legislature, curtailed by honors to St. Patrick and the Irish.

PARIS, March 17 -- In a move to assure the continued existence of certain Paris newspapers hard hit by the strike just ended, the Government assumed control of part of the revenues of almost all Paris dailies today. It was generally conceded that this move gave the Government almost life-and-death control over certain papers in spite of the fact that it has repeatedly advocated a press not susceptible to Government control.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 17 (AP) -- Herbert M. Woolf's Delegate again indicated today that he might prove one of the horses to beat in the Kentucky Derby of May 3 when he captured the Magic City Handicap in impressive manner at Gulfstream Park.

The Friendly Sons of St. Patrick -- 2,300 of them -- overflowed the main ball room of the Hotel Astor last night for the dinner held annually in New York since 1784 to mark the feast day of the saint.

The business of creating homes is at the threshold of its greatest opportunity, T.H. Robsjohn-Gibbings, interior designer, told members of the Decorators Club last night at a dinner meeting in the Beekman Towers restaurant, 3 Mitchell Place.

CHICAGO, March 17 -- PullmanStandard Car Manufacturing Company has reduced the price of its box cars approximately 15 per cent through lower production costs, Champ Carry, president, said today. This means railroads will be able to purchase the cars for $3,400 to $3,500 instead of $4,000 to $4,200 as formerly, he explained.

KANSAS CITY, March 17 -- The Big Six champion Oklahoma Sooners won the right to represent District Five in the N.C.A.A. Western regional play-offs here this weekend by defeating the St. Louis University Billikens, Missouri Valley champion, 47 to 41, tonight.
PARIS, March 17 -- The existence of secret stores of arms, long discussed in political circles, was frankly conceded today by the Minister of the Interior, Edouard Depreux.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The zoning proposals placed before the City Planning Commission by a group of civic organizations call public attention again to the difficulties confronting the City of New York in making the surroundings of the United Nations headquarters site sufficiently attractive and the approaches impressive and safe.

How much chance does a team, trailing by 19 points with less than 15 minutes left to play, have in this modern era of streamlined basketball? Very little, one would say, especially if he or she were at Madison Square Garden last night, watching Kentucky's Wildcats romp to a 49-30 lead over L.I.U. at 5:30 in the second half of their national invitation quarter-final meeting.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 17 (AP) -- Clayton Heafner, 204pound ex-Army sergeant, today won the Jacksonville open golf championship and $2,000 cash when he beat Lew Worsham by three strokes in a play-off match that went twenty-one holes.

The city's efforts to extend its water supply system to areas in Brooklyn now served by the New York Water Service Corporation were checked temporarily yesterday by a ruling of the Appellate Division, Second Department.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Irish Republicans in the House-- or should it be Republican Irishmen --were in an expansive mood today, what with winning the election and having two pretenders to ancient Irish themes among them.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 17--The first reaction here to Gen. Douglas MacArthur's statement on ending the Japanese occupation was that it would be difficult for the United Nations to take over responsibility for the future guidance of Japan.

The Board of Estimate will meet in special session today to consider once again the problem of development and operation of the city's airports. An executive session called for 2:30 o'clock will be followed by an open meeting at 4 o'clock.

MOSCOW, March 17 -- Russia demanded today the annulment of the economic fusion of the United States and British zones of occuation in Germany and a share in the control of the Ruhr, Germany's industrial arsenal.

The largest spring advertising campaign in its thirty-eight years will be conducted by Oakite Products, Inc., for Oakite, grease-dissolving and general household cleaner, Frank A. Conolly, merchandising manager announced yesterday at a meeting in the Hotel Astor.
Accessories designed to give a lift to spring costumes abounded in the exhibit opened by Lord Taylor yesterday on the third floor.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 17 -- Representatives of the Arab States met tonight in the seventh general session of the Arab League council and found the agenda so confused that a special political committee was appointed to report Wednesday with clarification of the issues.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The World Bank assumed the form of an active peacetime lending agency today when John J. McCloy, the new president, picked up the reins of leadership with the assistance of a "team" brought at his request into the long-dormant organization.
George P. Wakefield who died at Monte Carlo, Monaco, on March 5, left the residue of his $800,000 estate for charitable purposes, it was learned yesterday in Surrogate's Court.

CHICAGO, March 17 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 6,500 head; total, 10,000; market slow; around 50 cents lower on all weights and sows; practical top $28: around one load, $28.25: bulk of good and choice 180 to 260

Two weeks from today Mayor O'Dwyer must submit to the Board of Estimate and the City Council an executive budget (for the fiscal year beginning July 1) which will near or pass one billion dollars. We think it is imperative for the good of the city that the Mayor do some realistic thinking about the more general aspects of New York's financial condition before he brings on this budget.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 17 -- The City Planning Commission of New York will reject largescale beautifying plans for the area surrounding the projected world capital on the East River and will insist instead on a "conservative" approach to any rezoning, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- The State Department published tonight the following text of the second protest addressed by Brig. Gen. George H. Weems, American representative in the Allied Control Commission far Hungary, to Lieut. Gen. V.P. Sviridov, Russian acting chairman of the commission:

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 17 -- With an effort born of despair the Yankees pushed two enormous runs across the plate in the eighth inning of their struggle with Steve O'Neill's Tigers today that tied the score at 2 -- all.

CHICAGO, March 17 -- Representative Francis Case, Republican, of South Dakota, today predicted that labor legislation including modification of the Wagner Act would be enacted in this session of Congress, whether President Truman signed the legislation or not.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- A former editorial associate of Douglas M. Stewart, once publisher of Scribner's Commentator, testified in Mr. Stewart's perjury trial today that Mr. Stewart had received sums of money from "anonymous donors" on at least four occasions.

A book on Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery by Alan Moorehead, entitled "Montgomery; A Biography," is scheduled for April publication by Coward-McCann. Mr. Moorehead, author of "Eclipse" and a British war correspondent, was with the general from Egypt to the Elbe.

Test cases aimed at relieving the plight of pleasure car owners who have been squeezed by steadily mounting garage rates, lack of off-street storage space and accelerated police action against illegal parking, have been started here, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Price Increases and a generally improved supply situation enabled wholesalers serving the merchant trade to pile up impressive sales of $5,137,000,000 in January, the Department of Commerce reported today.
MOSCOW, March 17 -- The BigFour powers agreed today that they would evacuate their troops from Austria within ninety days after a peace treaty with that country had come into force.
LONDON, March 17 -- Brokers were unable to report any expansion of business in the stock markets here today and the general tendency was dull.

The thirty-first International Flower Show opened at noon yesterday at Grand Central Palace. There was no ceremony at the main entrance, but none was needed, for the flower-minded people waiting there surged up the steps and fanned out into the aisles of the main floor on a trip of discovery through the gardens on display.

Another interlude in the draftevasion trial of Serge M. Rubinstein, international financier, occurred yesterday when Irving H. Saypol, chief assistant United States Attorney, informed Judge J.F.T. O'Connor that one of the spectators in the court room had made threats to Rubinstein.

Mr. and Mrs. Norman M. Cohen of 1075 Park Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Louise Janet, to Walter W. Hess Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hess of 40 Central Park South. The wedding will take place in May.

ROME, March 17 -- The Foreign Ministry today published the text of a note addressed to the Foreign Ministers of the Big Four in Moscow asking that Italy be allowed to express her viewpoint on the German problem.

Plans for a strike to tie up the Wall Street financial district went forward yesterday after the heads of the New York Curb Exchange and the Association of Stock Exchange Firms had refused to intervene in a dispute between the United Financial Employes, AFL, and the brokerage house of A.M. Kidder Co.

Alexander Borovsky plays the piano with professional competence from every point of view. His command of the mechanics of the piano is complete; he has at his disposal as wide an assortment of colors as any pianist can use, and as an interpreter he has an aptitude for enough composers of different periods and schools to satisfy the demands of customary program-making.

OTTAWA, March 17 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's Minister of Agriculture James Gardiner announced today in the House of Commons that price ceilings on barley and oats are being raised, effective tomorrow, to stimulate the production of these urgently needed feed grains.
Spring fashions in dresses, suits and furs were exhibited by Gunther yesterday noon in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis Hotel. The ensembling of furs with town fashions was excellent.

One man was missing and three others were rescued yesterday after they were thrown into the East River about 500 feet off Wall Street from the tugboat Invader, which capsized in a strong current while towing a float laden with fourteen railroad cars.
WASHINGTON, March 17--The Supreme Court today advanced by eleven days the period within which John L. Lewis and the United Mine Workers must obey its recent ruling pertaining to them.
The occupational hazards of city planning were described in detail yesterday by Park Commissioner Robert Moses, who holds numerous city and State public improvement jobs.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Refusal by the Supreme Court to interfere today in the case of Morton Friedman, New York lawyer, sustained in effect the power of the United States Civil Service Commission to discharge an employe on grounds of sympathy with communism.

DETROIT, March 17 (AP) -- The car industry's United States production of 1947 passenger cars and trucks will pass the 1,000,000 unit mark this week; barring a major assembly line tie-up the total for the year's first quarter will be in excess of 1,150,000.

BERLIN, March 17 -- For the next few days German political parties' activities will go into high gear here. Out of the spate of discussions, it is hoped, a joint statement by all four major units may emerge reflecting German policy and direction for the information of the Moscow conference of Foreign Ministers.

Lions and Lambs If it is true what they say about the British Empire tobogganing down to its fall, then there is one obvious difference between that long imperial record and the traditional month of March.

Director J. Edgar Hoover of the Federal Bureau of Investigation reports that 1946 was a record year for crime. There was an over-all increase of 7.6 per cent in arrests over 1945, a 25.4 per cent increase in arrests of males, a greater increase in rural than in urban areas, substantial increases in murder, manslaughter, robbery, assault and burglary.

WASHINGTON, March. 17 -- Whenever the United States is faced with a difficult decision, as it now is over the loans to Greece and Turkey, the popular tendency is to evade the decision if possible, and if not possible to toss it to some amenable scapegoat.

IN recent years several multiple biographies of distinguished American families have recorded the careers of Adamses, Lowells, Randolphs and Roosevelts. Russell Lord, a painstaking writer with long experience in agricultural journalism, believes that the three Henry Wallaces deserve similar respectful literary treatment and has not spared any effort to give it to them in his "The Wallaces of Iowa."*

ROME, March 17 -- The only way to establish permanent peace is to abandon might as an instrument of power politics and replace it with a sense of justice, Pope Pius XII today told Charles Helou, who holds the distinction of being the first Lebanese Minister ever accredited to the Holy See.

SALONIKA, Greece, March 17 -- The special field team of the United Nations Balkan Investigation Commission, which left here last Wednesday, returned last night without the Soviet and Polish members, who have remained in the Pindus Mountain region in an endeavor to consult with the Greek guerrilla leader, "General" Markos Vafthiadis.

BERLIN, March 17 -- A detailed analysis of denazification figures throughout Germany was made available today by Russian and other sources. They disclosed a tremendous stumbling-block in the path of any attempt at the uniform denazification procedure for all four zones advocated by Foreign Minister Molotov.
RICHMOND, Va., March 17 (AP) -- Lord Inverchapel, the British Ambassador, declared emphatically tonight that he rejected any suggestion that Britain was "finished as a world power."

East New York and Woodrow Wilson, co-holders of the BrooklynQueens divisional basketball title, advanced to the final round of the city vocational schools championships with victories over Samuel Gompers and Bronx Vocational, respectively, at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

Normal, competitive selling has returned in full measure to the textile and apparel markets and is marked by unprecedented sales activity by manufacturers and suppliers, a survey of the New York market indicated yesterday. Producers have crossed the threshold from the greatest sellers' market in the history of the industry into an era of solicitation and seeking out the buyer once again.

The American Water Works and Electric Company, Inc., reported yesterday that consolidated net income for 1946 was $7,205,326, or $4,561,997 more than in 1945. Common share earnings last year were $2.56 each, against 61 cents in 1945. In the report, Earle S. Thompson, president, explained that 1945 earnings were exclusive of a special tax adjustment of $3,877,938 in favor of the company.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- A plan to give tax cuts of 25 to 30 per cent to taxpayers in the lower brackets while those in the upper grades would get 20 per cent was considered today by the House Republican Steering Committee.

A veterans' organization so selective that it drew no members from World War II is planning its annual convention here, it was announced yesterday. The group, the American Balloon Corps Veterans, is made up of men from the "sausage service'" of World War I.
In keening wind that tore at their banners, 80,000 men, women and children marched up Fifth Avenue yesterday, from Forty-fourth to Ninety-sixth Street, in a four-hour procession to honor St. Patrick.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 17 -- Brazilian territory today was under fire from both the revolutionary Paraguayan forces and the troops of General Morinigo. Stray shots hit houses in the Brazilian township of Ponta Pora.
Steamship lines have asked the Treasury Department for a ruling on disposal of tax money as a result of the recent removal of a 15 per cent Federal levy on foreign travel, it was learned yesterday.

A city-wide committee to reduce accidents in the home, which caused 1,724 deaths in New York last year, is being organized, it was announced yesterday by Frank L. Jones, president of the Greater New York Safety Council.

Sharply increased costs offset the record operating revenues of United Air Lines last year, holding net income to $1,086,961, compared with $4,203,815 in 1945, W.A. Patterson, president, disclosed yesterday in the annual statement.

Under the new rules of golf, as revised recently by the United States Golf Association, youngsters will be able to serve as caddies up to the time they are 18 years old without impairing their amateur standing, according to an interpretation released yesterday by the game's governing body.

LONDON, March 17 -- Resisting heavy pressure from a hostile group of Left-Wing Labor Members of Parliament, the British Government today refused to give the House of Commons anything but a cautious and non-committal interim statement on President Truman's message about aid to Greece and Turkey until the United States Congress had reached its decision.

Representative Forand, Democrat, of Rhode Island, proposed yesterday that instead of the 20 per cent "across the board" reduction in the individual income tax provided for in the tax bill sponsored by Chairman Knutson of the Ways and Means Committee, exemption rates for taxpayers and their dependents be raised from the present $500 to $700.

The Moran Towing and Transportation Company of 17 Battery Place is now engaged in the longest single towing job ever undertaken by an American company-- 13,000 miles from Tampa, Fla., to Banka Island in the Netherlands East Indies.

Underwriting groups will place on the market here today a new issue of 70,000 shares of $4 cumulative preferred stock, series A, of American Potash and Chemical Corporation at $100 a share and 125,000 shares of Air Express International Agency 50 cents par value common stock at $6 a share.

Determined resistance by industrial buyers of fir plywood to speculators' prices ranging from 50 to 100 per cent above those in normal trade channels is the only effective means of combatting the situation, an industry spokesman declared yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 17 -- All members of the United Nations Security Council agreed readily and enthusiastically today that the United States should take over the Japanese-Mandated Islands in the Pacific under a "strategic trusteeship" pact.

The national council of the National Maritime Union, CIO, began a series of meetings here yesterday at which it is expected to appoint a special board to try Joseph Stack, suspended vice president of the union.
MOSCOW, March 17 -- The war against Germany and Japan cost the Soviet Union $357,000,000,000, Foreign Minister Molotov said at today's meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 17 --Universal-International today announced the purchase of screen rights to "Loom of Justice," an Austrian, novel by Ernst Lothar, and the engagement of Edward G. Robinson to play the leading role in the film version.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, March 17 (AP) -- The United States, renewing accusations of Russian interference in Hungary, declared today that Hungarian Communists were attempting to seize power from the freely elected Government.

PHILADELPHIA, March 17 (AP) -- A paper on which Thomas Alva Edison pencilled his disbelief in the internal energy of the atom was among 379 rare letters, documents and autographs offered at public auction here today.

HONOLULU, March 17 -- Twenty -two seamen who had been drifting on the severed stern half of the tanker Fort Dearborn since last Wednesday were rescued in a dramatic open-sea transfer to a lifeboat 800 miles north of Honolulu today after heavy seas had prevented their removal from the weakening stern half for fortyeight hours.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 17-- Linus Lindberg, treasurer of Local 248, United Automobile Workers, CIO, today was allowed until 10 A.M. tomorrow to produce the records of his union before the House Labor Sub-Committee, sitting here or face a contempt citation.

BOSTON, March 17 (U.P.) -- Tami Mauriello of New York, who claims to be the No. 1 heavyweight challenger, was suspended indefinitely today by the Massachusetts Boxing Commission for trying to slug it out with Johnny Shkor of Boston after their bout Friday ended in a technical knockout victory for Shkor.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- A review of the world wheat situation, issued today by the Food and Agriculture Organization, said that little if any increase in export supply in growing countries could be anticipated in the 1947-48 crop year.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 17 -- Social workers should help educate people for "family living" and not merely "jack up" families on the point of breaking up, Dr. Luther E. Woodward, field consultant of the National Committee for Mental Hygiene, told the Tennessee State Conference on Social Welfare today.

Early in January the National Academy opened the first part of its 1947 annual, and this evening, at 8:30 comes the preview of the second part, an exhibition opening to the public tomorrow and continuing through April 13.
Justice William O. Douglas of the United States Supreme Court said last night that the United States should assume a crusading leadership in the fight for world democracy.
BRADFORD, England, March 17 -- Even with good luck, it will be a very long time before this part of Britain recovers from the effects of this disastrous winter.

JERUSALEM, March 17 -- The average terrorist leader is a lower middle-class man about 31 years old, probably of Polish origin, who previously worked at a skilled occupation. But for his political convictions and activities, he would probably be an ordinary man working at an ordinary job and living on an ordinary street in the all-Jewish city of Tel Aviv.

ALBANY, March 17 -- Raymond A. Donovan, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association of New York City, today requested Governor Dewey and Republican legislative leaders to supplement the Condon-Wadlin Bill with a measure to provide for official machinery to adjust grievances of public employes.

Jean Borotra held forth before the American press yesterday for the first time in ten years and despite the afflictions and perils of his war experiences he was the same dynamic figure as in the days when the Four Musketeers raised the Tricolor to the top of the tennis ramparts.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., March 17 -- The American Gas and Electric Company, New York, filed a plan with the Securities and Exchange Commission today providing for the investment of 1,150,000 shares of the $10 par value common stock of its subsidiary, the Atlantic City Electric Company, Atlantic City, N.J.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The $400,000,000 program for implementing the anti-totalitarian "Truman Doctrine" through economic and military aid to Greece and Turkey was headed tonight toward a political battle that, as it now was shaping up, was described as having serious implications.

When the regular conductor of this column was laid low unexpectedly by a cold, as happened yesterday, the obvious course for the substitute was to make a short cast into the mail box to see what might be lurking there. Faith, and the haul wasn't bad at all, at all.

CHICAGO, March 17 -- March and May wheat closed 10 cents higher on the Board of Trade today, the permissible limit for one day, and July wheat and all deliveries of corn went to new seasonal peaks. March wheat set a new top since May, 1917, and March corn since 1920.

ALBANY, March 17 -- The Young Demo bill that would make possible rebates of $118,000,000 on unemployment insurance taxes on an experience rating basis received final legislative approval tonight as the Senate and Assembly moved to clear their calendars for adjournment of the session tomorrow.

Appeal of the case of Mrs. Genevieve Rivera, serving a year in prison for contributing to delinquency of her 14-year-old son, is being arranged by the Society for the Prevention of Crime, Edwin Lucas, the executive director, reported yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, March 17 (AP) -- Mohammed Ali Jinnah, president of the Moslem League, chief rival of the predominantly-Hindu Congress party, called upon Moslem Leaguers in the Punjab today to give their "unstinted, wholehearted cooperation to the Punjab Administration to restore immediately order in the province."
Dr. Alexander Loudon, the Netherlands Ambassador to the United States, called yesterday for a new approach to international law. It should be based, he said, on "the rights of man."

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 17-- Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, today urged, in his quarterly report, that the international executive board hold fast to its current demand for a wage increase of 23 1/2 cents an hour, plus "fringe" requests.

Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed steady, 5 to 21 points net higher than Saturday's final levels. The market started 15 points higher to 1 point lower, and then worked up to gains of 23 to 36 points on active months.

PANAMA CITY, March 17 -- Jackie Robinson was unveiled before the observing eyes of Branch Rickey and 6,000 Panamanian fans in Olympic Stadium today as a first baseman and did nothing to discourage the Mahatma as the Dodgers and Royals battled to a 1-to-1 tie in eight innings.

Dullness ruled yesterday in the stock market although prices received a slight lift in highly selective trading. International complications continued to exert a staying hand on activity and a few wide bulges in isolated instances accounted for a rise of about a point in the composite rate.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Formidable resistance appeared in the Senate today to the first labor bill brought to the floor by the Republican majority.

Whatever the date on the calendar, spring came to New York yesterday with the opening of the thirty-first International Flower Show at Grand Central Palace. It is a more varied spring, in bloom and in new classes of competition, than has ever marked the show before.

JERUSALEM, March 17--Just before noon today an Army officer blew his whistle and the people of the overcrowded Mea Shearim quarter in northern Jerusalem trampled down the barbed wire surrounding the area. Statutory martial law had ended in Palestine.

Additional taxation of cooperatives would be "not only unjust but also unconstitutional," Jerry Voorhis, former member of Congress From California, said yesterday. In in interview at the Hotel Biltmore, it which his election as executive secretary of the Cooperative League of the U.S.A. was announced, Mr. Voorhis also stressed the role which he said co-ops could play in averting business recessions, holding that consumer purchasing power is already falling below production.
PARIS, March 17 -- President Truman had a bad press in Paris today when the newspapers reappeared after a month's strike.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 17 -- No distinction should be made between countries that are members of the United Nations and those that are not when fluids for relief work are apportioned, the Social Committee of the United Nations Economic and Social Council decided today.

Within the next two weeks a seven-man committee of faculty members and alumni of Columbia Law School will begin drawing up final plans for creation of a new $5,500,000 law center on the Morningside Heights campus of the university, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Though leaders of the Republican majority in Congress, who have the responsibility for legislative action on the bill to initiate our new foreign policy, have declaimed that all the facts and implications must be "laid on the line," that may not be the end-product of the debate.

Four thousand four hundred dollars is the average cost of rehabilitating an apartment in a boardedup slum building, the New York City Housing Authority reported last night. Thus the $6,000,000 borrowed from the State by the Authority will provide only about 1,364 apartments, it was announced.

A total of 54.3 per cent, or 170 of the 313 commercial banks responding to the recent request of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York for information regarding Saturday closing plans, are preparing to adopt the closing schedule on a year-round basis, it was learned yesterday.

The estimated total monthly wage of the United States seaman, including such supplemental payments as overtime and penalties, exceeds that of his highest paid foreign counterpart by $95 and is 60 per cent higher than the composite average pay of eight other maritime countries, according to a survey released yesterday by the National Federation of American Shipping.

Plans for a seven-story apartment house to accommodate 107 families at 100 West Ninety-fifth Street and 99 West Ninety-fourth Street were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings. The Columbus Development Corporation of 349 East 149th Street, the Bronx, is the owner and Horace Ginsbern and Associates are the architects.

LONDON, March 17 -- Old motor boats and river craft that formed part of the nondescript fleet that evacuated Britain's army from Dunkerque in 1940 were in service again today, but this time they were rescuing families imperiled in the flooded Thames River area.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Watson B Miller, Federal Security Administrator, today urged the Aiken bill raising FSA to Cabinet status, as against the Taft-Fulbright bill creating a Department of Health, Education and Welfare with a professional Under-Secretary for each of the three fields.

MANCHESTER, England, March 17 (AP) -- Bruce Woodcock, British Empire heavyweight champion, had to go all out tonight to defeat Stephan Olek of France in a fifteen-round bout. Woodcock weighed 200 1/4 pounds, Olek 187 1/2.

TOKYO, March 17 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur today, in the first press conference he has given since the early days in Australia, urged a prompt initiation of negotiations for a peace treaty with Japan and preparations for the evacuation of Allied military occupation forces as soon as such an agreement was signed.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Edwin G. Nourse, chairman of President Truman's Economic Council, told a group of eastern business controllers today that it would take more than "removal of wartime controls" to restore sound wage, price and profits relationships.

ALBANY, March 17 -- Governor Thomas E. Dewey appointed Senator Alexander A. Falk of Manhattan tonight as a member of the State Civil Service Commission, an act that was praised warmly as the Senate moved immediate confirmation.

MADRID, March 17 -- A call for greater individual effort by Falange members and a warning that the Falange was in danger from "enemies " who call themselves friends" came from its vice secretary, Gen. Manuel Valdes, today.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, March 17 (AP) -- The Paraguayan Government acknowledged tonight that revolutionary forces in the north had captured Bella Vista, near the border of Brazil, capitan Bado and the upper Paraguay River stronghold of Pefia Hermosa.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- A Senate subcommittee studying newsprint scarcities sought vainly today to follow an elusive trail of reported cases of price gouging in sales of this kind of paper.

Robert Brereton, young California pianist, gave his second New York recital last night at Town Hall. It was another remarkable display of skill and musicianship, for the pianist has been blind since birth.

Joe Louis will fight again, on June 26. The heavyweight champion of the world was committed to a defense of his title yesterday by his representatives, John Roxborough and Marshall Miles. They conferred with Sol Strauss who, since the illness of Mike Jacobs, has been directing the activities of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club and Strauss announced that Joe would be seen in action at the Yankee Stadium against an opponent not yet selected.

A novel collective agreement under which granting of a union shop is conditioned on maintenance by the union of fixed production standards has been reached by union and management representatives at the RCA Victor plant in Indianapolis, Ind., it was learned yesterday.

The Inter-American Safety Council conferred yesterday its 1946 award on Pan American Airways for flying three-quarters of a billion passenger-miles throughout the world without a single accident during 1946.
LONDON, March 18 (U.P.) -- Prospects looked rosier today than ever before for those who favor some relaxation of the amateur rules to permit "broken-time" payments to amateur athletes.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 18 -- The State Division of Housing ruled today in a test case here that apartments developed by the State for veterans of World War II must not be opened to other persons no matter how desperate their plight and meritorious their claim.

Don't ask for an IQ for your child, Dr. L. Joseph Stone, assistant professor of child study at Vassar College and lecturer at the New School for Social Research, warned yesterday. He gave the final lecture in the seminar on child development sponsored by Ivriah in conjunction with its bicultural school, Beth Hayeled, at the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 18 -- Katharine Hepburn was named today by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for the leading role in the screen version of "B. F's Daughter," John Marquand's latest novel, which the studio bought for the screen last fall.
TRENTON, N.J., March 18 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll tonight broke a New Jersey political custom of nearly twenty years and replaced a Supreme Cuort justice.
NANKING, March 18 (U.P.)--Right wing members of the Kuomintang's central executive committee demanded today a strong policy toward Russia and the end of "appeasement" tactics.

CRISTOBAL, C.Z., March 18 -- Pete Reiser is out of action again before he had hardly returned to it. In batting practice, preceding today's Dodger game with the Canal Zone All-Stars, pain in the region of his right collar bone forced him to stop swinging.

Preparations for a national telephone strike on April 7 were intensified yesterday as union negotiators reported a breakdown in wage talks covering 20,000 longdistance telephone workers in forty-two States.

PHILADELPHIA, March 18 (AP) -- Second - seeded Donald Budge stroked his way into the quarterfinal round of the first Philadelphia Inquirer Charities $10,000 world professional indoor tennis tourney tonight by defeating George Seewagen, St. John's (Brooklyn, N.Y.) University coach, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 3.

PARIS, March 17 -- The French Government today refused to make overtures for a settlement in IndoChina with the Viet Nam Government of President Ho Chi Minh. It declared, however, that it would be ready to treat with any qualified representatives.

Operations of the International Business Machines Corporation last year resulted in a consolidated net profit of $18,766,433 after taxes and all charges, an increase of $7,872,727 over the $10,893,706 earned in 1945, the annual report showed yesterday.

ALBANY, March 18 -- Among the bills passed, defeated or allowed, to die by the Legislature in this session were the following: Taxation Continued 50 per cent rebate in personal income taxes for another year; incorporated so-called emergency levies on gasoline, cigarettes, utilities, estates, liquors and unincorporated businesses into permanent tax structure.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, March 18 (U.P.) -- The rebel radio in Concepcion said the crews of four Government planes, sent out Saturday to bomb the rebels in Concepcion, had landed and joined the revolutionary forces. The entire air force previously had been reported loyal to President Morinigo.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Representative Robert W. Kean, Republican of New Jersey, told the Controllers Institute of America today that the persons who determine future government spending will in effect write the new tax law.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Republican members of the Ways and Means Committee, convinced that a change of course was advisable, sought a method today of giving special relief to low-income taxpayers.

CHICAGO, March 18 -- Wheat and corn futures broke badly today on the Chicago Board of Trade after a higher opening. March wheat was up 8 1/2 cents a bushel at the start to $3.05, a new high since May 9, 1917. But the market turned reactionary later, the price breaking 18 1/2 cents from the top with the finish at $2.86 1/2, off 10 cents, the permissible limit, from Monday's closing level.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- President Truman told Congress last week that the aid to Greece and Turkey was only "one aspect" of the larger political problem of world communism and the larger economic problem of world reconstruction.
SCRANTON, Pa., March 18 (AP) -- Miss Mary B. Powers, who lived fifteen years in a New York hotel as a recluse, has decided that she wants $25,000 in dividends refused by her for many years.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 18 -- The superior training which the Yankees are confident they derived from their four-week tour of the tropics finally made its presence felt with great force today.
MIAMI, Fla., March 18 (AP) -- Jack Kramer of Los Angeles national singles champion, today swept past two foes to go into the third round of the University of Miami invitational tennis championships.

JERUSALEM, March 18 -- When a swarm of locusts recently darkened the sky over an Arab town in southern Palestine, a peasant in the street lifted his eyes and asked: "Is it not enough that we have the Jews?"

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- The text of the bill introduced in the House today to carry out President Truman's request for aid to Greece and Turkey follows: To provide for assistance to Greece and Turkey.
PEIPING, March 18 -- Central Government forces are still pursuing defeated Communist troops north of Changchun, reports to Peiping indicate.

The city of Los Angeles, Calif., announced yesterday that It would offer at competitive sale on April 3 an issue of $7,500,000 of airport bonds dated May 1, 1947, and due May 1 from 1948 to 1967. Interest must not exceed 2 1/2 per cent.

Marymount College of Tarrytown-on-Hudson will erect a fourstory school building at 532-34 West 215th Street, in the block between Park Terrace East and Park Terrace West, according to plans filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings by Eggers Higgins, architects.
ALBANY, Wednesday, March 19 -- The 170th session of the Legislature ended its labors early this morning. The Assembly adjourned sine die at 3:08 A.M. The Senate had adjourned at 1 A.M.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- The text of the prepared Senate speech by Senator Vandenberg on Gael Sullivan's proposal for a bipartisan statement on Greek and Turkish aid: I regret the necessity of making this statement at this critical moment, when partisan politics should be totally removed from foreign policy considerations.
TO THE EDlTOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: President Truman's address to the Congress asked for a good deal of money, $400,000,000.

ALBANY, March 18 -- The 170th regular session of the State Legislature, which has been grappling for two and a half months with problems resulting from inflationary forces loosed by war spending, sped toward a final adjournment tonight.

Columbia yesterday named three permanent assistant football coaches and a temporary one as aides to Head Coach Lou Little, according to an announcement by Ralph Furey, director of athletics. All four will begin activities on April 7, first day of the spring drills for the eleven.

LONDON, March 18 (Reuters) -- Toss, the Soviet news agency, distributed today the following text of the hitherto secret Yalta protocol on German reparations, as released in Moscow yesterday by Foreign Minister Molotov:

Local officials were elected without opposition today in thirty-three incorporated Nassau County villages, but there were contests in fourteen others. Sixteen additional villages will hold their elections in June. Mayors were elected in thirty-five villages; trustees in all forty-seven, and police justices in six of the villages that voted today.

TOKYO, March 18 -- A certain amount of quiet apprehension developed today among Japanese as Newspapers prominently displayed general MacArthur's statement made at a press conference yesterday that early negotiations should be begun for a peace treaty to be followed by the withdrawal of Allied occupation forces.

Gustav Metzman, president of the New York Central Railroad, announced last night that Robert R. Young and Robert J. Bowman had been invited to serve on the New York Central's board of directors to represent the Chesapeake Ohio Railway, subject to the necessary authorization by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended March 12: Increases of $193,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans and $196,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 18 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie supported a plea to forty-one United Nations today to give their backing and financial aid to the stalled International Refugee Organization.

Zino Francescatti was the soloist at the concert of the Philadelphia Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall playing the Beethoven violin concerto. The orchestral compositions were the overture to "Egmont," an Andante for solo oboe and small orchestra by Kent Kennan and the suite called "Nobilissima Visione," from the music of the ballet of St. Francis, by Paul Hindemith.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The Army Air Forces' new experimental bomber, the XB-45, which is powered with four jet engines, successfully completed its first test flight yesterday at Muroc Army Air Base, California. AAF headquarters said today that the bomber was aloft an hour and four minutes.

NANKING, March 18 (U.P.) -- Powerful Government mobile units have driven within thirteen miles of Yenan, capital of Communist China, it was reported today. High Chinese military sources predicted the mountain fortress would fall within two weeks.
WASHINGTON, March 18 --The War and Navy Departments and the Army Air Forces appeared in united front today as James Forrestal, Secretary of the Navy, testified as their first proponent...

Reporting on the work of the Refugee Economic Corporation in aiding in the resettlement of thousands of victims of persecution in Europe, Charles J. Liebman, president, voiced confidence in the solution of the problems of these helpless people.

A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Brendler of 18 East Seventy-third Street on March 3 in the Lying-in Hospital. Mrs. Brendler is the former Miss Sylvia Levison, daughter of Mrs. M. Lincoln Schuster and Jack J. Levison, both of this city.

Buyers' Total Lower Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,365, compared with 1,510 last week and 2,244 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Frederick G. Reinecke, Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, outlined last night plans to rehabilitate the harbor's facilities and return the port to the status of the "world's best." His speech was the climax of ceremonies marking "Port of New York Day," for which all vessels in the harbor "dressed" and blasted the air with their whistles at noon.

PARIS, March 18 -- The facts that Georges Bidault was the first visiting Foreign Minister to be received by Premier Stalin and that they talked for almost two hours led correspondents attached to the French delegation in Moscow to suggest today the possibility of a French-Russian rapprochement on Germany.

AMSTERDAM, March 18 (Aneta) -- Prices on the Stock Exchange moved higher in fairly active trading. The improvement was attributed to optimism following report that the Government had authorized the signing of the Linggadjati agreement.

The close cooperation of department stores and other retail establishments here in the field of education in retailing was hailed yesterday at the luncheon held in honor of the visiting delegation of French merchants given by the merchants' advisory committee of the New York University School of Retailing in the Hotel WaldorfAstoria.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., March 18 -- Elections were held today in eleven villages in Suffolk County. In four of them there were no contests, but in the seven others various local offices were contested. The results in contested elections available tonight were as follows:

Even if fans are convinced that nothing that follows in post-season basketball competition can match Monday night's spectacular comeback by Long Island University against Kentucky, it is a certainty that more than 18,000 persons will be at Madison Square Garden tonight for the semi-finals of the tenth annual national invitation tournament.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The Federal Government has decided to appeal the Mount Clemens portal - to - portal case directly to the Supreme Court, without previous intervention by the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals at Cincinnati.

The North American Company reported yesterday that net income for 1946 amounted to $21,878,611, the highest profit since 1931. Earnings on the common stock were $2.55 a share, compared with $1.77 in 1945, when net income was $15,152,370.

TEL AVIV, Palestine, March 18 -- Within thirty-six hours of the lifting of martial law, Tel Aviv is back to normal tonight. Its experience of fifteen days' ironclad military administration seems to have left it none the worse.

The goal of $3,000,000 sought for the Alfred E. Smith Memorial Hospital has been reached, it was made known yesterday by Cardinal Spellman, head of the Alfred E. Smith Memorial Foundation. The disclosure was made in a letter sent by the Cardinal to friends of the movement who had made contributions.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- The Senate Rules Committee today overrode the standing committee of newspaper correspondents and voted that Louis R. Lautier, correspondent of a Negro daily newspaper and Negro weeklies, be admitted to the Senate Press Gallery.

DENVER, March 18 (AP) -- Milwaukee and Dallas, two of the most highly regarded dark horses in the national A.A.U. basketball tournament, got through secondround play today, but neither could call the jlay's work a picnic.

MOSCOW, March 18 -- Following is the text of the political clauses proposed by the United States delegation to the Foreign Ministers' deputies for a peace treaty with Austria. It appears under the titles "Treaty for Re-establishment of an Independent and Democratic Austria; Draft Political Clauses; Proposal of United States Delegation."

HONOLULU, March 18 (U.P.) -- A fleet of twenty Navy vessels, with land-based Army and Navy planes shuttling overhead, began scouring the mid-Pacific today for twelve or thirteen men who took to the sea in an open boat when the tanker Fort Dearborn broke in half six days ago.
Questions of war and peace may befuddle the minds of the world's statesmen but the answers seem clear and simple to children.

BERLIN, March 18 -- The first post-war interparty conference of German political groups moved closer to realization today when Dr. Kurt Schumacher of Hanover, spokesman for the Social Democrats, announced his willingness to cooperate. The invitation for the session was extended by the Christian Democratic Union with special reference to the desirability of a German pronouncement of policy and sentiment during the Moscow conference.

The metropolitan sector's top indoor polo players ride tonight at the Squadron A Armory, where an 18-goal New York trio headed by Buddy Combs faces a 17-goal New Jersey side in the feature match of the American Red Cross Greater New York Fund benefit double-header.

Economic Reform Weapon for Peace To the editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES: "The recent recommendations of President Truman in relation to Greece and Turkey can spell success for the cause of world peace only if our Government makes it brilliantly clear by word and deed that we have not accepted war with Russia and communist domination as the only possible choices before us.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (U.P.) -- J. Parnell Thomas, chairman, announced today that the House Un-American Activities Committee would begin public hearings Monday on legislation to curb or outlaw the Communist party in the United States.

Anthony Ruopoli, "manager" of a two-man shoeshine stand in the Administration Building at La Guardia Field, announced yesterday a plan to compete "in these times of controlled economy." He said he would seek business not only among the thousands of air travelers who hurried through the airport daily, but would make a "dollar - a - month - for - as - many shines-as-you-need" offer, thus stabilizing his economic program.
The Garment Center Community House to be erected on the northwest corner of Fortieth Street and Seventh Avenue will be the first project of its kind in the city, its sponsors said yesterday.

STONINGTON ISLAND, Marguerite Bay, March 17 (Delayed) -- The hitherto academic issue of territorial rights in the Antarctic has materialized here in a dispute over raising the United States flag over this base, less than 200 yards from a long-established British, base camp.

HONOLULU, March 18 -- In the conviction Bob Thomson has the ability to justify a berth for him among the reconstructed 1947 Giants, manager Mel Ott today launched an intensive training grind for the Staten Island youth. The campaign is designed to develop Thomson as an outfielder.

MOSCOW, March 18 -- The fourpower committee that has been studying the financial situation of Trieste has recommended to the Council of Foreign Ministers that a short-term loan be granted to the new Free Territory, as otherwise it will be unable to get on its economic feet.

New Yorkers are not measuring up to the current Red Cross appeal "as promptly as the seriousness of the hour demands," James M. Cecil, general chairman of the Red Cross 1947 Fund of Greater New York, declared yesterday.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, March 19 (U.P.)-- Secretary of State Marshall, at a banquet for the Big Four Foreign Ministers given by Foreign Minister Molotov last night, offered a toast in which he expressed hope that the Allies would remain as united in peace as they had been in war.

LONDON, March 18 -- In a plea for a "sustained effort" by the British people to produce more and thus overcome their economic difficulties, Prime Minister Attlee appealed tonight for volunteers to leave their nonessential jobs and go into the basic industries of coal, agriculture, transport and iron and steel.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 18 -- The United Nations, its prestige shaken by President Truman's proposal for American aid to Greece and Turkey, may seek the cooperation of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, it was learned today.

Welcome back to Broadway, Tallulah Bankhead! An actress endowed with dynamic qualities and an idol of the public, she is returning in "The Eagle Has Two Heads," which opens tonight at the Plymouth. It was there during the 1942-43 season that she set the town on its ear as the jezebel of Thornton Wilder's "The Skin of Our Teeth."

When the Oregon had to round the Horn to join the fleet in Caribbean waters during the Spanish-American War it was obvious that the digging of the Panama Canal could no longer be deferred. But was it to be a sealevel or a lock canal? For many months the controversy raged.

MOSCOW, March 18--A fivepoint bill of rights to insure the operation of democracy as the United States understands it and as Secretary of State Marshall defined it here last week is the keystone of United States proposals for a treaty for Austria.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- A roll call for the powers to record their yea or nay before the world as to whether they are willing to disarm now and depend in full faith upon a newly sinewed United Nations was demanded today in the Senate.

MOSCOW, March 18 (AP) -- The text of Secretary of State Marshall's statement to the Council of Foreign Ministers on reparations: I wish to make completely clear the position the United States has consistently taken with regard to the relation of the Potsdam agreement on reparations to the Yalta protocol.

The American-built, British-flag passenger liner Empire Woodlark, laden with a cargo of gas bombs, has been scuttled in mid-Atlantic, ending a career that included service in two World Wars, it was announced by a spokesman for the American Merchant Marine Institute on the basis of information received yesterday from England.

The first comprehensive and detailed outline of street changes to improve the United Nations site and vicinity were disclosed yesterday in a report that City Construction Coordinator Robert Moses submitted to the Board of Estimate in executive session.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday fluctuated sharply on extraneous conditions and finally closed 5 points higher to 7 points lower than on Monday. Starting 2 to 7 points up, the market made early gains of 13 to 22 points on trade support.

CHICAGO. March 18 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 6.000 head, total 10,000; market mostly 25 cents lower but closed dull, 25 to 50 cents lower; top $27.75; bulk of good and choice 180-260 pounds $27.25 to $27.75; 260 to

A Bronx woman, 49 years old, was among eight stowaways who arrived here yesterday from Genoa on the transport Marine Perch. The ship, operated by American Export Lines, docked at Pier 84, North River, with 908 passengers, including 407 United States citizens.

A fashion show of misses' and women's dresses highlighted by French adaptations, bolero dresses, "little black dresses" and evening and bridal party gowns was presented yesterday by Oppenheim, Collins at its Brooklyn store.

CLEVELAND, March I8 -- Attacking communism as "an unwholesome element" seeking to destroy our form of government, the triennial convention of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers adopted a resolution today barring Communists from membership.

Considering the long record of Navy Department opposition to plans for a unification of the armed forces, it is a good omen to find Secretary Forrestal appearing yesterday before a Senate committee as the first witness in behalf of the Administration's new Unification Bill.

Sales of the General Foods Corporation last year reached a new high level for the ninth successive year, exceeding the 1945 volume by 14.1 per cent and resulting in an increase of $5,003,752 in earnings, Clarence Francis, board chairman, reported yesterday in the annual statement to stockholders.
CHICAGO, March 18 (AP) -- Thomas E. Wilson, chairman of Wilson Co., meat packers, said today "that the American people are backing off from high prices."

The passing of one more nation under Russian domination could well upset the balance of power that exists between the United States and Russia and start a landslide in Russia's favor that could "bury" the United States, Otto D. Tolischus, a member of the editorial staff of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared yesterday.
The Pressed Metal Institute has started a nation-wide drive against the "black market" in steel called "Operations Ingot," it was learned yesterday.

Random notes. The New Jersey striped bass legislation is now the basis for a political rather than conservation battle, and the Senator sponsoring the bill has appealed to the Governor to force the Senate Fish and Game Committee to follow the rules of politics

Capt. Granville Conway, president of the Cosmopolitan Shipping Company and former War Shipping Administrator, received the annual award of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York yesterday for his "distinguished contribution" to the development of maritime activities in the Port of New York.
BATAVIA, March 18 (Reuters) -- The Phrontis will sail for Liverpool shortly with part of the cargo of cinchona bark (used for making quinine) trans-shipped from the Martin Behrman, it was said today.

Consolidated Edison Company of New York executed the first step of a $290,000,000 bond refunding program yesterday by awarding at competitive sale an issue of $100,000,000 of thirty-five-year refunding mortgage bonds due in 1982 to a syndicate of seventy-eight underwriters headed by Morgan Stanley Co.

LOS ANGELES, March 18 -- Some 200 Los Angeles parents went to the Fremont High School today and, to get their suspended children reinstated, signed papers renouncing future race prejudice on the part of their children.

Councilman Michael J. Quill informed the City Council yesterday afternoon that the 32,000 transit workers employed by the city would seek another wage increase probably before July 1. Mr. Quill is also international president of the Transport Workers Union, CIO.

WASHINGTON, March 18--The Navy officially confirmed today that the U.S.S. Leyte, a 27,000ton aircraft carrier, would be sent to the Mediterranean and would visit, among other ports, Suda Bay on the Greek island of Crete and the Turkish port of Istanbul.

The Potsdam agreement, which put a quarter of Germany's arable land and her second industrial center under Polish administration, also provided that the rest of Germany should be treated as an economic unit, that Germany should retain an economy capable of feeding her people, and that reparations should be met by removals of unnecessary German industrial equipment and should be completed by Feb. 2, 1948.

Firmness in the price structure of drugs and health supplies was called an "outstanding example of free enterprise in action" in a survey report by Dr. E.L. Newcomb, executive vice president, National Wholesale Druggists Association, made public yesterday.

An accountant who advises his client on an income tax matter is not practicing law, Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag ruled yesterday in dismissing a suit brought by the New York County Lawyers Association against Bernard Bercu, a certified public accountant.

BOSTON, March 18 -- A plan intended to make for better management relations and to prevent strikes jeopardizing public health and safety was submitted today by Gov. Robert F. Bradford to the Massachusetts Legislature.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 18 -- "Hey, Joe, what goes on here?" said a very startled Ted Williams, as he backed smilingly away from the plate in his first Regular-Yannigan game a week or so ago. The Yannigan first baseman was glued to the baseline. The second baseman was playing a short right field and the shortstop was on the wrong side of the middle bag.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The dangers of being too clever and trying to turn everything to partisan advantage -- even including the gravest issue of foreign policy in the nation's history -- were not foreseen by the headquarters staff of the Democratic National Committee when it was decided that Gael Sullivan, the executive director, should send the letter to B. Carroll Reece, the Republican National Chairman, that was denounced in the Senate today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 18 -- Twenty villages in Westchester County held spring elections today, choosing Mayors, trustees and other local officials. Nine villages had contests and two voted on propositions. Pelham Manor faced the anomalous problem of running a last-minute write-in campaign to save an unwilling Mayoralty candidate from being elected.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 18 -- Col. Larry S. MacPhail, president of the New York Yankees, confirmed today the announcement that his club would sponsor a daily program of classical music, the works of the master composers.

The Board of Estimate received cautiously yesterday a strong report from its special three-man committee of legal, financial and engineering experts that recommended that the city continue to operate and improve its three airports and listed many legal objections to the plan under which the Port of New York Authority offered to take over the airports.

Export managers of top American industries were warned yesterday that prosperity of their business and future international trade depend on sound foreign loans that will permit other nations to rebuild their own domestic economies.
Angelo Maccarone, a former Seabee, was celebrating yesterday his personal solution of the housing shortage. He had bought a sixroom house and paid for it in cash -- $100.

Jean Carlton has everything in her favor for a career as a singer except an extraordinary voice. The fact that the voice is not extraordinary is not at all a fatal flaw. For Miss Carlton knows how to make it do. Her recital at Town Hall last night -- she made her debut there two years ago as a Naumburg Prize winner -- was an evening of tasteful, sensitive music-making.

Caught between retail demand for lower prices and higher labor and material costs, the coat and suit industry has no alternative but to hedge on its total volume output, it was pointed out last night by Joseph L. Dubow, executive director of the Merchants Ladies' Garment Association.
LONDON, March 18 -- Uncertainties concerning the forthcoming budget led to quieter conditions in the stock markets today.

MOSCOW, March 18 -- The Soviet Union has accused the United States of permitting the German territory of Bavaria to develop into "a sovereign and independent state" with the right of maintaining independent relations with foreign powers.

Safeguards Against Communism It is nothing new, of course, that two men will start out from the same general theorem and end up at opposite poles. On the same day, which was last Sunday, former Governor Arnall of Georgia and the heads of the American Veterans Committee publicly subscribed to what may be called substantially the same view on how best to combat the spread of communism in this country.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (UP) -- Carl Berreitter, publisher of the Trenton, N.J., Trentonian, alleged today that the tight newsprint situation threatened to destroy freedom of the press in the United States.

PHILADELPHIA, March 18 (AP) -- A 37-year-old accountant stepped up today to the presidency of the huge Sun Oil Company. The company's board of directors named Robert G. Dunlop of Drexel Hill, Pa., to the post to succeed J. Howard Pew, who retired as president after thirty-five years to turn over active executive responsibility to "younger, more vigorous men."

ALBANY, Wednesday, March 19 -- An extended floor fight in the Assembly over the Savings Bank Insurance Bill ended early today as the measure, approved earlier after hot discussion in the Senate, was defeated by a vote of 72 to 60.

LONDON, March 18 -- A Foreign Office spokesman confirmed tonight the authenticity of the text of the secret Yalta proctocol revealed in Moscow by Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov but contended that in effect it had been superseded by a later agreement reached in Potsdam.

Jonai had some nice - looking clothes in the fashion show which he held yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz. Above all, they were wearable. Skirts were definitely longer but without any exaggeration; fifteen inches from the floor was the rule for daytime woolens and silks.

John M. Hancock, former member of the United States delegation to the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission, told a large gathering of mining and metallurgical engineers attending the World Conference on Mineral Resources at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday that the American delegates "have at no time proposed any release of information regarding the bomb itself."

Frank J. Sampson, new leader of Tammany Hall, made his first appointment yesterday in the announced reorganization that he plans. It was the naming of George Gordon Battle, 78-year-old Tammany warhorse, as chairman of the law committee.

The second day of the International Flower Show's appearance in this city proved yesterday that flowers have a magnetic attraction for all kinds of people. When the doors opened at 10 A.M. at Grand Central Palace, the line extended from one entrance far around the corner along Forty-sixth Street.

MOSCOW, March 18 -- The United States "will not follow Mr. Molotov in a retreat from Potsdam to Yalta" and will not accept the Russian figure of $10,000,000,000 as a basis for German reparations to the Soviet Union, Secretary of State Marshall told the Council of Foreign Ministers today.

Six Metropolitan Opera singers will give a benefit concert for a cherished project of the nuns at the French Hospital, 324 West Thirtieth Street, because a patient there recently overheard a conversation.

SINGAPORE, March 18 -- Several factors, including labor difficulties and lawlessness in remote districts, have seriously hampered recovery in the Malayan tin industry, despite Government rehabilitation loans totaling several million Straits dollars, according to the 1946 report of A.A. Bean, chief inspector of mines for the Malayan Union, published today.

A couple of teen-aged boys named Hallahan and another by the name of McElvey probably will think twice in the future before they celebrate St. Patrick's Day in a boat. As it was, everything turned out all right except that they missed a meal.

The Brooklyn Museum opens to the public today the first of a projected series of annul print exhibitions, national in scope. It is a very ambitious undertaking, with 210 entries in all media within the scope of the print field -- etchings lithographs, engravings, aquatints cellocuts, drypoints, linoleum blocks, silk screens and woodcuts, work in black and white and examples in color.

The stock market moved ahead yesterday to the levels of last Thursday under the leadership of the heavier industrials, but a sharp break in wheat tended to restrict further gains. Peak additions of 1 to about 2 points were retained by some key units, while the price index rose 3/4 point.

A strike that left thirty-five families without heat, hot water or elevator service in the nine-story apartment building at 235 West Seventy-first Street was settled at 5:20 P.M. yesterday, thirty-one hours after it started. Elevators began to run again, furnaces were fired and, later in the evening, garbage was collected.
JERUSALEM, March 18 -- The legal struggle to save three of five members of terrorist organizations sentenced to death by a British military court ended another phase today.

TRENTON, N.J., March 18 (AP) -- A State take of up to 6 per cent on a sliding scale based on daily pari-mutuel betting at New Jersey's three race tracks, compared with the straight 4 per cent at present, was recommended in a new formula today by the Commission on State Administrative Reorganization.

On the aid-to-Greece issue, Americans are getting an intensive course in the intricacies of world politics. Most worried citizens of this country, like the President, are sincerely anxious to "do what's right" in the new and oppressive role destiny allots to them in the earthshaking shifts of post-war power.

The truth of an affidavit submitted by Serge M, Rubinstein, international financier, to Selective Service Board 44 was attacked by the Government in Federal Court yesterday through the testimony of an official of one of Rubinstein's former operating companies.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Senate leaders who are grappling with international problems served notice on party managers today to leave partisan politics out of Congressional action to implement the anti - totalitarian "Truman doctrine" in Greece and Turkey.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- The House acted today to help small business concerns use their priority rights for the purchase of surplus material and plants.
BRADFORD, England, March 18 -- The recruiting of labor has become one of the leading executive jobs in Britain's woolen industry.
