MONTREAL, March 18 (AP) -- Max Bentley, center of the Chicago Black Hawks, has wrested the National Hockey League's individual scoring lead from Montreal's Maurice Richard, league statistics disclosed today.
MOSCOW, March 18 -- A basic difference in the approach to the United States' treatment of Western Europe exists within the Amercan delegation to the Council of Foreign Ministers.

Three consumer-owned non-profit department stores are planned by the Consumer Distribution Corporation, subsidiary of the Filene Foundation, organized by the late Edward A. Filene, Boston merchant, to promote cooperatives and credit unions, it was announced here yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, March 18 -- At the request of the American Gas and Electric Company, the Securities and Exchange Commission handed down an order today declaring that the company has ceased to be a subsidiary of the Electric Bond and Share Company.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- Douglas M. Stewart, on trial charged with perjury, denied today any knowledge of the source of $39,000 which he received to finance the publications which the Government contends were German propaganda mediums.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 18 (AP) -- R.S. McLaughlin's Kingarvie today equaled the mile and a sixteenth Gulfstream Park record of 1:43 3/5 as he easily captured the Sunny Isles purse by two lengths before 11,016 racegoers who bet $817,484 on the eight events.

The New York Legislature has done in general a good, solid job in the session now completed. It acted with real courage on occasion. It indulged in no spending sprees, despite the assaults of various raiding parties. The members may go home, after a sometimes turbulent and always busy session, with a feeling of earned satisfaction.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March I8 -- A far-reaching decision to authorize the Commission General in Java to sign the now famous Cheribon Agreement on conditions approved by the Indonesian Republic was taken late yesterday, following a lengthy Cabinet meeting.

PESHAWAR, North-West Frontier Province, India, March 18 -- Between 1,500 and 2,000 "Redshirts," a uniformed auxiliary to the Congress party, camped on the edge of this frontier capital tonight preparatory to entering the city tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- A compromise plan for setting up a Cabinet post of Health, Education and Welfare was presented to the Sanate Committee on Expenditures in the Executive Departments today by a committee of twenty-one experts in those fields.

The New York Yankees Baseball Club will sponsor a program of symphonic music every afternoon during the regular baseball season over WQXR, the radio station of THE NEW YORK TIMES, it was announced yesterday. The program, to be known as "Symphonic Matinee," and running from 4:05 to 5 P.M., will be sponsored by the Yankees beginning April 14.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., March 18 -- Children's Court is the keystone in combating juvenile delinquency, Austin H. MacCormick, former New York City Commissioner of Correction, said here today in a Radio forum on the topic, "Do We Pamper Young Lawbreakers?"

Hand - made home accessories, ranging from neat silver serving utensils to a gray rag rug, are included in the forty-fourth annual exhibit of the New York Society of Craftsmen that had its preview yesterday. A background of simple wood furniture by Jens Risom indicates how the pieces can fit easily into contemporary interiors.

The first kosher products to enter the frozen food field, which is rapidly expanding to include almost everything that's edible, are being placed on the market now. They bear the seal of Kashruth of the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America, and are made by the Sanborn Foods Company of Cedarhurst.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- With facilities in the radio spectrum for only one system of color television, the Federal Communications Commission ruled today that further experimentation was essential and denied the petition of the Columbia Broadcasting System for approval of the standards proposed by CBS to permit commercial operation of color television stations on the basis of the sequential system developed by it.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Dr. Arnold P. Meiklejonn, United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration nutritionist, said today that the "most striking feature of public health in Europe today" is the absence of epidemics and vitamin-deficiency diseases.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Dean Acheson, Acting Secretary of State, made it clear today that practical circumstances were such that the United States could not respond to Gen. Douglas MacArthur's call in a speech before the Tokyo Correspondents Club for the prompt initiation of negotiations for a peace treaty with Japan.

PEIPING, China, March 19--A scathing attack on the Central Government of China on the ground of "rampant corruption" and also "low efficiency of administration" was published here yesterday in the leading editorial of the local newspaper Clung Shih Jih Pao.

BREMEN, Germany, March 19-- Thousands of citizens in this city lined up today along the banks of the Weser to see their lines of transport and communication fall into the river. This city was virtually split in two as the flood waters, carrying gigantic ice floes, destroyed the two main vehicular bridges.

The post-season basketball jamboree at Madison Square Garden continues tonight with the opening competition in the Eastern Regionals of the ninth annual National College Athletic Association championship tournament.

CONSIDER this a belated St. Patrick's Day review. For it is about "Life and the Dream,"* the memoirs of Mary Colum. And Mrs. Colum, as everyone knows, is a distinguished and penetrating critic of literature, life and manners who has lived as much in the New World as in the Old, but has always taken with her everywhere the spirit of Dublin.
MOSCOW, March 19--The Government of the Soviet Union today gave its first answer--an indirect one--to Secretary of State Marshall's definition of the word "democracy."

Alarm over the future of the American labor movement in the face of a universal campaign of reaction was expressed yesterday by Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, in a report to the union's national council. The council is in session at 346 West Seventeenth Street.
WASHINGTON, March 19--The Department of Commerce has suggested pointedly but politely that industry re-examine its prices with view toward reducing those which are now too high, it was closed today.

CHICAGO, March 19--Wheat prices plunged downward again on the Board of Trade today, reaching the 10-cent-a-bushel permissible daily limit for the second straight day as a result of an announcement that the Government would permit cash wheat handlers to substitute spring wheat in the Northwest for unobtainable hard winter in the Southwest in an effort to ease the market situation.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On March 4 you printed the letter of J. Raymond Walsh, in which he drew certain gloomy conclusions concerning one of the several so-called "Marches on Albany" which have occurred these past few weeks.

MILWAUKEE, March 19 -- "Falsehoods have been told here and we have proof of them," Representative Thomas Owens, Republican, of Illinois, said today as a House Labor subcommittee ended its perjury hearing today.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (U.P.) --Attorney General Tom C. Clark took steps today to prevent illegal industrial mergers which he warned must be checked or "the small businesses of America may disappear from the area of effective competition."

WICHITA, Kan., March 19-- Former Governor Alf M. Landon, Republican nominee for the Presidency in 1936, called tonight for complete support of the aid to Greece and Turkey proposed by President Truman as the basis of a new "big-stick" foreign policy.

The threatened further reduction of the New York Customs staff, which will be necessary if the cut in the Treasury and Postoffice Department appropriations recommended by the House Appropriations Committee is passed by Congress, was protested here yesterday by Port agencies.

CHICAGO, March 19 (AP)--Admiral Jonas H. Ingram, "sold" on professional football by watching the rival National League perform, today established a "deputy" to aid him as commissioner of the All-America conference. Ingram, at a news conference, announced appointment of an old Navy sidekick, Commodore A.A. (Scrappy) Kessing, to a newly created position of deputy commissioner.

VIENNA, March 19--The Russian occupation forces in Austria have paid over another 7,000,000 schillings to the Vacuum and Shell Oil Companies and simultaneously have proposed a long-term understanding with them based on the fact that "Russia is going to stay in the oil business in Austria."
ALBANY, March 19--Nine separate questions, six proposing amendments to the State Constitution and three public housing propositions, will be submitted to the voters at referendums this ...

WASHINGTON, March 19-- John L. Lewis yielded to the Supreme Court today and withdrew his contract termination notice of Nov. 15, 1946, which resulted in a coal strike last fall and threatened to bring another on April 1.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, March 19 (AP)--Russia tossed a charge of "interference" back at the United States today and rejected for the second time in two weeks an American demand for an investigation of Hungary's political affairs.

LONDON, March 19--The flood situation became more critical tonight as rain and thaw, spreading across England, raised the levels of rivers already swollen. Practically the whole country was affected and in the Midlands, the Thames Valley and the low-lying Fens district of East Anglia the situation was described as "catastrophic."
LONDON, March 19--Britain's crisis can be solved only by the application of moral and spiritual remedies, a British Cabinet Minister and a Catholic Cardinal agreed today.

PITTSBURGH, March 19--Bituminous miners in western Pennsylvania seemed inclined today to bow to the "stay-on-the-job" order from John L. Lewis, but there was some apprehension among several coal operators and a few United Mine Workers' aides over what might happen April 2.

Since Tallulah Bankhead is playing a tragic queen, "The Eagle Has Two Heads" gratifies the eye at the Plymouth Theatre, where Jean Cocteau's drama opened last evening. But on general principles there must be more to his play than meets the ear.
JERUSALEM, March 19--Palestine's Zionists are generally confident that relations with their Arab neighbors can be satisfactorily adjusted once the country's political status has been settled.

BUENOS AIRES, March 19 (U.P.) -- The official campaign against Opposition newspapers, personally inspired by President Juan D. Peron in a recent speech, was renewed today by the distribution of posters urging readers and advertisers to boycott the Prensa, leading daily of South America.
MIAMI, Fla., March 19 (AP)-- The sweep of favorites continued today in the fourth annual University of Miami invitational tennis tournament as all seeded stars came through their matches.
The Greater New York Hospital Association has agreed to support the request of nurses in this city for increased pay and shorter hours, it was learned yesterday.

The Five-Borough Carbonated Beverage Manufacturers Association and the Soft Drink Workers Local 812, International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, with whom they have a collective bargaining agreement, were absolved yesterday of conspiracy in their relations with independent peddlers of soft drink beverages.

TOKYO, March 19 -- Japanese labor must adopt a more responsible attitude, George Atcheson Jr, chairman of the Allied Council for Japan, warned that body in his report during his recent visit to the United States.

The National Audubon Society has just come forth with an argument for the elimination of a 1947 waterfowl shooting season, but the argument will impress only those completely unfamiliar with any of the factors influencing the increase or decrease of the waterfowl population.

A new company known as Commercial Forms Corporation, 50 West Fifty-seventh Street, has been organized for the national distribution of continuous forms for use in punched card accounting machines and forms-writing typewriters, it was announced yesterday.

The city "is not eager to take over the child placement problem lock, stock and barrel," Edward E. Rhatigan, Commissioner of Welfare, declared yesterday. If the city moves into the situation further, he said, it would be because of the complete breakdown of private agencies.

The number of juvenile arrests here last year was 21 per cent less than in 1945, Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander announced yesterday. He spoke at a luncheon in the Hotel Commodore opening a campaign for $1,000,000 by the Police Athletic League.
WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP)-- The United States Chamber of Commerce told Congress today a flat reduction of individual income taxes by "20 per cent or even more" was of "urgent importance."

Memorial Day floral wreaths for the graves of American service men who were buried abroad may be ordered in this country, it was announced yesterday by Edward J. McCarthy, president of the Florists Telegraph Delivery Association. The service will operate on a yearround basis.

Allocations of off-brand home freezers will terminate soon and substantial price reductions will go into effect because of rising production of standard brands, distributors and dealers said yesterday. They emphasized that many producers who have entered the field since the end of the war will be forced to suspend operations because of competition from long-established mass producers.

The Representative Assembly of the Newspaper Guild of New York, by a vote last night of 114 to 46, rebuked Milton Murray, president of the American Newspaper Guild, CIO, for having alleged at a hearing of the House Labor Committee that the local was virtually under communistic control.

Mrs. Malcolm Muir was chosen yesterday chairman of the women's division of the New York City Cancer Committee's drive for $1,300,000 and Mrs. Albert D. Lasker was named honorary chairman at a meeting in the Cosmopolitan Club, 129 East Sixty-fifth Street.

PARIS, March 19--In a motion voted by its central committee late tonight the Communist party came out for the end of hostilities in Indo-China and declared it would "not be possible to vote military credits for the pursuance of the war against Viet Nam."

Contributions to the Red Cross 1947 Fund of Greater New York through the commerce and industry committee are now being received at the rate of $107,000 a day, Charles De Wolf Gibson, chairman of that committee, announced yesterday.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, March 19 (U.P.)--Government planes bombed a rebel Army stronghold in northern Paraguay today as President Higinio Morinigo mobilized his forces for a showdown battle in Paraguay's spreading civil war.

Establishment of "private" exportimport banks, to assist commercial banking operations in the "twilight zone" of foreign trade financing, is being proposed by Washington officials. Leading commercial bankers here, it was learned yesterday, are being sounded out on the proposal, which is designed to increase their participation in the more risky foreign ventures.

HACKENSACK, N.J., March 19 --Columbia University eventually will receive an estate estimated unofficially at $1,000,000 under the will of Dr. Ludwig Schaefer, it became known today when the document was filed in the Bergen County Surrogate's office.

BOSTON, March 19 (AP)--Furious scoring drives by Joe Carveth and Woody Dumart gave the Boston Bruins a 7-3 National Hockey League victory over the Chicago Black Hawks tonight before a crowd of 13,900 at the Boston Garden.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The President's address to Congress has been described as a decisive departure from the main course of American diplomatic history.
Flower arrangements that carry out the feeling of period rooms are featured in the exhibit prepared by the Garden Club of America for the International Flower Show in Grand Central Palace.

WASHINGTON, March 19--Establishment of Federal Labor Courts to enforce collective bargaining agreements and to compel the settlement of many strikes was proposed today in a bill offered by two Republican Senators, Homer Ferguson of Michigan and H. Alexander Smith of New Jersey.

Insurance Bill's Defeat Savings bankers, although disappointed by the defeat in the State Legislature of the bill to increase the limit on savings bank life insurance from $3,000 to $5,000, indicated yesterday that they would continue their efforts to obtain such legislation at the next session of the Legislature.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 19-- Seventy - three per cent of the adults in this community, one of the wealthiest per capita in the United States, base their opinions about national and international events and issues on what they read in newspapers.
The summer picture, 1947, as envisaged by eight New York designers, was displayed yesterday by the Revlon Products Corporation at the luncheon hour in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Either today or tomorrow the Senate is expected to begin debate on the Lilienthal appointment. It is high time. For eleven weeks the affairs of the Atomic Energy Commission have been marking time. The result, regarded either from the point of view of national defense or of progress toward peacetime uses of atomic energy, has been expensive.
In a quiet market, cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday finished 7 to 11 points net lower.

Hats and coiffures, designed to go together, were presented yesterday by the Millinery Fashion Bureau and the American Hair Design Institute at the Hotel Pierre. The coiffures, the work of Mr. Leon of the institute, were inspired by current millinery silhouettes and featured a sleek, away-from-theface and close-to-the-head look.

Acute effects of the housing shortage in 1946 were felt in institutions for the aged and at residences for business girls, according to the annual report of the Rev. John J. Donovan, director of family service of Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York.

The buyer's market in steel has not arrived, but there are signs that buyers are obtaining more consideration from steel mills, industrial purchasing executives disclosed here yesterday. They said that the simplification of prices on extra cards and the aggregate reduction in prices announced by Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, a subsidiary of United States Steel Corporation, were important steps in helping to stabilize market conditions.

Good health is not a right of man but a privilege that must be earned by every individual and maintained as a social responsibility, Dr. Edward J. Stieglitz, one of the nation's foremost authorities on the diseases of old age, said yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, March 19 -- A Federal Grand Jury indicted Alfred W. Ingalls, Boston lawyer and former Massachusetts legislator, and his wife, Mira Elizabeth Kimball Ingalls today for violation of the Constitutional prohibition against slavery in their treatment of Dora Jones, 57, a Negro servant.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. of the Twenty-second (Harlem) District denied last night that he was a Communist and called for "not a rally of Communists, or Reds, but of the Negro people, speaking together against reaction."

Adoption of a sixteen-section code of standards, effective at its thirty-five member tracks on April 1 and designed to eliminate "undesirable practices and elements from the sport," was announced yesterday by the Thoroughbred Racing Associations of the United States.

The United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York will start its campaign for $65,000,000 on April 15 to finance a program of "relief, rehabilitation, reconstruction, resettlement, welfare and civic defense," it was announced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Jonah B. Wise, chairman of the board.

Plans for a sixteen-story office building to be erected at 55 to 59 East Thirty-fourth Street at an estimated cost of $1,000,000 were filed yesterday by Charles N. and Selig Whinston, architects, for the Hycourt Realty Corporation, 292 Madison Avenue.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 19 (AP)--The first of what may be a series of movies on the life of Franklin Delano Roosevelt will be based, Jay Richard Kennedy, producer, disclosed last night, on one of the late President's "four freedoms" --freedom from fear.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP)-- The housing industry set a new construction record in January by completing 59,300 permanent houses and apartments--the largest number of such dwellings finished in any month since the end of the war.

WASHINGTON, March 19--In a night session of Senate debate a fatigued Democratic minority fought with slight hope against a Republican bill to alter one of the basic labor policies of the Roosevelt era, the Wage-Hour Act.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 19 (AP) --Just before taking off for Washington this afternoon, President Truman shook hands with the naval officers who had been his hosts at the submarine base and expressed hope that he could come back in June.

American exporters must face the fact that most European Governments have moved a long way toward socializing basic industries, a process that has been part of the social revolution in Europe following the war, Thomas C. Blaisdell Jr., director of the Office of International Trade, Department of Commerce, said yesterday.

DETROIT, March 19 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings mathematically assured themselves the fourthplace play-off spot in the National Hockey League standings tonight by gaining a 2-0 victory over the New York Rangers before a crowd of 14,389 at the Olympia.
MOSCOW, March 19--The Foreign Ministers' deputies for the Austrian treaty got themselves deeply involved in technical arguments on political clauses today and actually advanced nowhere.

Jerome Rappaport, pianist, gave a recital last night at Carnegie Hall. The program included Beethoven's Sonata in D minor, Op. 31, No. 2; Brahms' "Variations and Fugue on a Theme of Handel"; Chopin's "Ballade" in F major, "Nocturne" in E minor and "Ballade" in G minor; Ravel's "Le Gibet" and Beryl Rubinstein's Sonatina in C sharp minor.

Communist party members and fellow travelers should be registered as agents of a foreign power and immigration laws should be enforced to prevent Communists from entering the country, Max H. Sorensen, national commander of the Catholic War Veterans, declared in an interview here yesterday.
With the supply increasing, department stores and specialty shops will begin offering nylon hosiery at reduced prices immediately after Easter, it was predicted yesterday in the trade.

A total of $624,000 of this year's goal of $1,000,000 for the Greater New York Councils, Boy Scouts of America, has been raised to date, it was announced yesterday at the organization's annual meeting, held at the Yale Club, Forty-fourth Street and Vanderbilt Avenue.

The stock market's effort yesterday to extend its advance by a major margin was thwarted by selling in the final hour. A few issues showed substantial increases but the list in general edged ahead only by small fractions and the closing levels were about even with the finish of the previous session.
One of the most exciting collections seen in New York was Adrian's, presented by Bonwit Teller yesterday afternoon at the St. Regis Hotel. It was daring, original, beautiful.

Kentucky and Utah moved into the final of the tenth annual national invitation college basketball tournament last night at Madison Square Garden. The top-seeded Wildcats advanced at the expense of North Carolina State, 60--42, after the Utes had upset West Virginia, 64--62.
WASHINGTON, March 19--For more than a year, Congress has been preoccupied in the field of foreign affairs with what would happen if the United States did not oppose the expansion of the Soviet Union.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 19--Byron Price, wartime director of the United States Office of Censorship, arrived here today to take over the United Nations' administrative and budgetary problems.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

If stable political conditions prevail in India the United States can look forward to a period of rapid development of trade with that country, Arthur B. Foye, president of the Far East-America Council of Commerce and Industry, said yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 19 --Universal - International today signed Ronald Colman for the leading role in "The Art of Murder" and borrowed George Cukor from Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to direct the film, which Michael Kanin will produce from a photoplay by Garson Kanin and Ruth Gordon.

MOSCOW, March 19 (AP)--Folowing is the text of Secretary of State Marshall's statement to the Council of Foreign Ministers today: I agree with Mr. Molotov as to the great value of Mr. Bevin's clear statement of the British position.

Seven members of a gang of at least twelve, who took pride in calling themselves the "Dead End Kids," were held in Brooklyn Police Headquarters last night for questioning about the theft of fifty to sixty motorcycles with a secondhand value of $40,000.

JERUSALEM, March 19 -- At the present rate, Palestine Government figures disclosed today, it will take fourteen months to transfer to Palestine all the unauthorized Jewish immigrants now detained on Cyprus.

More flowers continue to arrive daily at the International Flower Show and are judged faithfully on their merits promptly after their arrival. However, it is doubtful that the keen competition among the exhibitors means a great deal to those who have come to Grand Central Palace to admire the flowers there this week.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP)-- Josh L. Horne, publisher of the Rocky Mount (N.C.) Telegram, told the House Postoffice Committee today that "newspapers will be withdrawn from the mails" if postal rates go up 400 per cent.

JERUSALEM, March 19--Terrorist groups have warned twelve Jewish morning and afternoon newspapers against publishing a police reward offer for eighteen wanted terrorists. The warning was discussed at a meeting of editors today in Tel Aviv.

Assistant Secretary of State Spruille Braden, in an address last night before the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, declared that "only when totalitarianism of every color has been exterminated may civilization resume its upward march."

BROOKLINE, Mass., March 19 (AP)--Walter H. Langshaw, who began work as a mill-hand in Lawrence, Mass., at the age of 9 and rose to president of two New Bedford mills, died here today at the home of a daughter. His age was 88.

Members of the Long Island Real Estate Board will compete this year for a prize of $1,000 for "the most unusual, influential and ingenious traction." Announcement of the award was made yesterday at the monthly luncheon meeting of the board at the Forest Hills Inn, Forest Hills, Queens.

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company reported yesterday for 1946 a consolidated net income of $58,310,569 after charges and taxes, equal to $1.87 each on 31,708,452 capital shares outstanding. For 1945, it had reported a net income of $42,301,983, or $1.36 a share.

The New York City Housing Authority awarded yesterday to banking groups an issue of $13,285,000 of temporary loan notes dated April 17 and due on Oct. 16 at bids ranging from an interest rate of 0.78 per cent to one of 0.83 per cent plus dollar premiums.

SLA Granted Budget Increase The State Liquor Authority is reported to have received an additional appropriation of $113,000 out of a total of $132,000 requested in the supplemental budget, it was stated yesterday. Of the total $75,000 was requested for enforcement of fair trade agreements in the liquor industry.

LOS ANGELES, March 19 (AP)--With a new murder to cope with every day, police tonight were studying the statements of AnnaDiresio, 55 years old, bashed over the head and left to die early today in Elysian Park.

The board of governors of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms decided yesterday to recommend to the New York Stock Exchange a revision of the present commission schedule, which would base the rates on the amount of money involved in a transaction rather than on the number of shares.
MOSCOW, March 19--Secretary of State Marshall warned the Soviet Union and France today that the rebuilding of German industry to pay for reparations would endanger peace.

Short interest in stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange declined 31,466 shares from 1,046,797 on Feb. 14 to 1,015,331 on March 14, the Exchange announced yesterday. The short interest in the accounts of all odd-lot dealers was 70,111 shares, against 52,898 a month earlier.

Seven hundred elderly persons, in three homes for the aged operated by the Little Sisters of the Poor, were honored yesterday when Archbishop J. Francis A. McIntyre and two other members of the Catholic hierarchy in New York served luncheon for the inmates in celebration of the Feast of St. Joseph.

Reporting on operations last year, Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc., manufacturing chemists, informed stockholders in the annual statement being distributed today that sales and profits were the largest in the company's history. Net sales of $43,658,202 were 58.5 per cent above the 1945 volume of $27,538,047.

PELHAM, N.Y., March 19-- Ruffo, a big, reddish-brown dog of vague North African ancestry, rolled his eyes disinterestedly and fell into a snooze this afternoon when Supreme Court Justice Frederick G. Schmidt at White Plains granted him an extension of life.

MOSCOW, March 19--A plan for a provisional central German government which would be elected by the various German Laender and which would abolish the authority of the four zonal commanders to interfere was virtually completed today by the United States delegation to the Council of Foreign Ministers.

WASHINGTON, March 19--The low state of America's passengercarrying ocean fleet was emphasized today in a statement from the United States Maritime Commission which disclosed that only ninety-one passenger vessels are under American registry.

Net profit of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., and its subsidiaries last year amounted to $29,681,352 after all taxes and charges, equal to $1.90 a share of common stock, Robert C. Stanley, board chairman and president, reported to stockholders yesterday.

Mayor O'Dwyer went into a huddle yesterday with Thomas J. Patterson, Budget Director, about the fiscal budget for the year beginning July 1. Previously, Mr. Patterson and his aides had received requests from the heads of 109 city agencies.

The newly formed National Society of Art Directors will hold its first official meeting in their club at 115 East Fortieth Street on April 24, it was announced yesterday by Gordon Aymar, president. Executive members from Boston, Philadelphia and Chicago are expected to join the New York staff and map the groundwork for the society's program.
PHILADELPHIA, March 19-- The Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A., the Northern church, announced today that it had prepared a new plan for a union with the Southern church.
WASHINGTON, March 19-- President Truman, in a message to Congress today, requested extension of Government controls over exports for a year beyond the present expiration date of June 30.

A second official of a company formerly controlled by Serge M. Rubinstein testified in Federal court yesterday that the company was not engaged 100 per cent in war work. Rubinstein is on trial on charges of having made false statements to his Selective Service Board.

Modern sewage disposal plants as built by the city were described as eye-pleasing structures yesterday by members of the City Planning Commission when they heard objections to a proposed plant in the Rockaways in Queens.

CHICAGO, March 19--Three resolutions barring Communists from membership or from "attaining any place of trust or authority" in the Office Employes International Union, American Federation of Labor, were withdrawn at the union's convention today.

ALBANY, March 19--A proposal that the state and private capital go into a partnership to provide large-scale, white-collar housing, as distinguished from lowrent public housing, will be submitted to the Legislature next year, it became known today.

The action of John L. Lewis yesterday in withdrawing his notice of last Nov. 15 terminating the United Mine Workers contract with the Government is important in two respects. From the labor standpoint it means the final capitulation by the miners' leader in his four-months' legal battle with the Government over the latter's assertion of its right to injunctive relief in labor disputes involving its own employes.

DETROIT, March 19--The automobile industry faces a complete shutdown if a rubber strike is called. If the rubber workers walk out the major automobile factories will be forced to close within eight to twenty - one days afterward, spokesmen of the industry said tonight.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 19--A Soviet-American proposal to refer the unsolved disagreements on international atomic control to study by committees, rather than embark on a new round of public debate, was accepted unanimously today by the twelve members of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission.

MIAMI, March 19--Luke Sewell was feeling pretty despondent about the time of the last world series. The newly resigned manager of the St. Louis Browns had just come back from a fishing trip. But instead of being completely relieved by the termination of his grief over the benighted Brownies, Luke was still unhappy.

AMSTERDAM, March 19 (Aneta) --Prices on the Stock Exchange were firm in moderate trading, due to the expectation of a solution of the Indies situation. Industrials and banking shares were irregular, while Indies Plantations stocks moved higher.

BRUSSELS, March 19--Premier Paul-Henri Spaak announced a new Government today, just eight days after the former Left-Wing Cabinet resigned. But the speed with which the crisis was resolved is less remarkable than the fact that the incoming Government will be potentially strong enough to last possibly two years or longer.
HOLLANDALE, Fla., March 19 (AP)--Job Dean Jessop, idle since Friday, returned to the saddle at Gulfstream Park today and won the featured Indian Creek Purse astride T.A. Grisson's Knight's Gift.

PARIS, March 19--Leon Blum, former Premier and power behind the Ramadier Government, joined the critics of President Truman's speech on Greece and Turkey today. In an editorial in his Socialist newspaper Populaire, M. Blum wrote:

A dispatch to this newspaper from Moscow yesterday reported that the American delegation to the Council of Foreign Ministers has developed a basic difference of opinion, not in the goal it seeks, which is a durable peace, but in the approach toward a solution of the problem of Germany and Western Europe.

LONDON, March 19--Business in the stock markets today still was on the small side, as buyers held off pending the budget statement. Some British Government stocks were higher at the opening, but prices fell when selling developed.

Repudiation of international agreements with nine other nations and serious danger to air and surface navigation on the Atlantic and Pacific were said yesterday to be involved in a proposed cut of $36,000,000 in Coast Guard funds approved by the House Appropriations Committee.
LEEDS, March 19--Almost every important economic consequence of the war to Britain is exhibited in the current problems of the wool industry of the LeedsBradford district.

WASHINGTON, March 19--A fight in Congress on extension of food allocation and controls and of box car priorities under the Second War Powers Act, which is scheduled to expire March 31, may hold the fate of the $350,000,000 unilateral relief program and the $400,000,000 program of aid to Greece and Turkey.

W. Ross McCain was elected on Tuesday to the board of directors of the Reinsurance Corporation of New York. He is president and a director of the companies composing the Aetna Fire Insurance Group. He replaces Karl E. Pickett, who resigned.
ISTANBUL, March 19--There are growing indications here that the United States aid to Turkey will become a subject of controversy between the Government and the Opposition.

CRISTOBAL, C.Z., March 19-- Pouring it on with fervor and high glee the Dodgers today squared accounts with the dusky General Electrics by shellacking them, 7 to 0, before 2,500 fans in Mount Hope Stadium.
TOKYO, March 19 (AP)--If the United States expects to insure world peace, Americans must remain indefinitely in Japan after the Japanese peace treaty is signed, Premier Shigeru Yoshida said today.

Two systems of transmitting and receiving television are at present in laboratory competition. One is the "sequential," the other the "simultaneous." The names almost explain themselves. In the "sequential" system three primary colors are transmitted with flashlike rapidity, one after the other, in the form of appropriate electric impulses, picked up by a receiver and presented to the eye in the proper order--all so rapidly that it is impossible to detect the process.

The Home Insurance Company, leading underwriter of fire insurance, reported yesterday net premiums of $95,065,346 for 1946. Operating results, however, showed an underwriting loss of $4,236,150 for the year and a net decrease of $6,139,788 in surplus.

WASHINGTON, March 19-- Dear old Grandma may get her own commemorative day, by act of Congress, along with Mother, Pulaski, the Sentimental Heart, the Physiological Heart, the American Indian and Dear old Dad.

ATLANTA, March 19 -- The Georgia Supreme Court, in a 5-to-2 opinion, deposed Herman Talmadge today and declared Melvin E. Thompson the Acting Governor, ending a two-month-old controversy that divided the state's Democratic party into warring factions.

The Liberal party through Ben Davidson, executive director, criticized yesterday the regular session of the Legislature, just ended, as "woefully inadequate in the light of the needs of the people of New York State and the opportunities and resources that existed for meeting these needs."
WASHINGTON, March 19--The United States Atomic Energy Commission announced today its first regulations for strictly controlling the raw materials of the atomic bomb.

The second season of Carnegie Hall "Pop" Concerts will be presented, May 1-June 14, at Carnegie Hall, it was announced yesterday by Daniel Rybb, founder-director of the series, which attracted more than 100,000 persons during its initial seven-week season last spring.

Breaking loose with a 5-goal attack in the third period and then holding off a spirited bid by the losers in the last chukker, a 17goal New Jersey trio turned back a 16-goal New York side, 10 to 7, in an all-star match that featured the indoor polo double-header staged for the American Red Cross Greater New York Fund at the Squadron A Armory last night.

WASHINGTON, March 19--John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, called today upon the nation's banking system to participate in a "Bond-a-Month" plan for encouraging regular investment in United States Saving Bonds by bank depositors.

HONOLULU, March 19 -- The Giants awoke today to a transportation problem that snarled plans for return of the club to the mainland. The problem was how to get 110 baseball visitors back to the States in single trips of two fourmotored planes, each having a capacity of thirty-two passengers.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP)-- The text of the $350,000,000 foreign relief measure approved by the House Foreign Affairs Committee today: Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives of the United States of America, in Congress assembled, that there is hereby authorized to be appropriated to the President not to exceed $350,000,000 for the provision of relief assistance to the people of countries devastated by war, such relief assistance to be limited to the following:

WASHINGTON, March 19--John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, called today upon the nation's banking system to participate in a "Bond-a-Month" plan for encouraging regular investment in United States Saving Bonds by bank depositors.

HONOLULU, March 19 -- The Giants awoke today to a transportation problem that snarled plans for return of the club to the mainland. The problem was how to get 110 baseball visitors back to the States in single trips of two fourmotored planes, each having a capacity of thirty-two passengers.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP)-- The text of the $350,000,000 foreign relief measure approved by the House Foreign Affairs Committee today: Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives of the United States of America, in Congress assembled, that there is hereby authorized to be appropriated to the President not to exceed $350,000,000 for the provision of relief assistance to the people of countries devastated by war, such relief assistance to be limited to the following:

The Thomason brothers have the same first name and a comparison of their fingerprints by naked eye reveals a similarity in all except the index fingers. This curious circumstance was the basis yesterday of a case of mistaken identity that almest caused the revocation of one brother's parole.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, March 19--Prime Minister Jan Christian Smuts told the House of Assembly here today that the case for the incorporation of SouthWest Africa into the Union was juridically strong but he did not advocate by-passing the United Nations or appearing to challenge that organization.

PESHAWAR, North-West Frontier Province, India, March 19-- Bands of frontier "Redshirts," called into Peshawar to "restore confidence" among the people in the wake of religious and political clashes, circulated today in the bazaars.

The Walter Fried-Paul F. Moss production, "The Whole World Over," has won over several incoming attractions in the bidding for the tenancy of the Biltmore Theatre, to be vacated on Saturday by "Parlor Story." The Konstantin Simonov comedy about post-war life in Moscow, which Thelma Schnee has adapted into English, will make its debut at that playhouse on Thursday evening, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 19--The Administration's $350,000,000 program for American relief in liberated countries was released in modified form today to the House for its action after three weeks of deadlock in the Foreign Affairs Committee.

Some Early Cases On that well-known occasion when the Mother Goose customer went to market, to market to buy a fat pig it must have obviously been a buyers' market. Otherwise he would not have been going home again, home again dancing a jig.

NANKING, March 19--Chinese Government troops bivouacked today in Yenan, sprawling, dusty, one-time capital of Communist China. The remote little city that for eleven years has served as the headquarters of Chinese communism was captured this morning after a week's drive by a Government column thrusting northward from Lochwan, fifty miles away on the border of the Yenan area.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 19-- To stimulate the search for petroleum in California and to bring prices of California oil more nearly in line with prices prevailing in the Midwestern and Gulf oil fields, the Standard Oil Company of California announced today that it will pay 25 cents a barrel more for all crude oil it purchases of 20 degrees gravity and above, and 20 to 24 cents a barrel more for oil of lower gravities.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP)-- The Congressional Reorganization Act of 1946 reduced the number of standing House committees from forty-eight to nineteen, but there are 115 committee groups operating in the new House.

The charge that "psychological warfare" is being waged against the United States while Soviet Russian propaganda is efficiently spread throughout the world by many official agencies was made yesterday by William Benton, Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 19--Hiram M. Phillips, United Kingdom delegate to the United Nations Economic and Social Council, sharply criticized the work of the Commission on the Status of Women today as being largely superfluous and outside its jurisdiction.

LONDON, March 19--The British Government rejected today the suggestion made in both Houses of Parliament that it should resort to compulsory direction of labor as the only way out of Britain's economic difficulties.

Thirteen cash awards totaling $5,000 will be given by the Associated American Artists for outstanding work in the etching, lithography and wood-engraving media in the organization's second annual print club competition. The competition is open to any artist residing in the United States or its possessions.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 19--To the consternation of Al Lang and most all the other habitues of this city of eternal sunshine, a veritable cloudburst cracked down on this community today. So much of it, in fact, that it overflowed clear into neighboring Lakeland and washed out the scheduled game between the Yankees and Tigers.

A new double-decker car, making its first contribution toward easing passenger congestion on the Long Island Rail Road, dropped its control box on a third rail yesterday morning. The resulting short circuit brought a sizzle of sparks and disrupted traffic in both directions of the North Shore division.

The Navy, in the person of Rear Admiral Monroe Kelly, commandant of the Third Naval District, presented the highest award it makes to civilians, the Certificate of Achievement, to the Girl Scouts of America yesterday in recognition of outstanding services to Naval personnel during the war.

We went to a candy-tasting yesterday at the gay little confiserie known as La Reine at 601 Madison Avenue. John Heller, head of the Heller Candy Company, which makes the wares for the shop, greeted the guests, mostly from newspapers and broadcasting companies, and introduced to them his newest products, a variety of hard candies, chocolate-covered creams, fudge and solid chocolates.

Continuing its winning streak, Lincoln made its way into the final round of the P.S.A.L. basketball championship yesterday by defeating the Commerce five, 37 to 29, before a crowd of 8,000 at Madison Square Garden.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 19 --Dumping of quantities of frozen foods on the market was urged before 4,000 members of the frozen food industry here today as the Association of Frozen Food Packers opened its first national convention.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 20 (AP) -- A one-armed radio operator who finally ground out a prayerful distress signal on a makeshift set after four attempts had failed was acclaimed a hero today by ten survivors of the broken tanker Fort Dearborn.

The trial of three men indicted on charges of selling narcotics ended yesterday. They changed their plea to guilty after ten jurors had been picked. General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen set April 8 for sentencing. Three other men recently convicted of the same charge are also to be sentenced on that date.
LONDON, March 20 -- Fresh selling of British Government issues in the stock markets today brought about further declines. This was responsible for unsettled conditions in other sections.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The discussion of Foreign Minister Molotov's claims regarding Soviet war damage, appearing in THE TIMES, merits further elucidation.

The customs administrative service requires an increase of $1,000,000 for the fiscal year 1947-1948 to carry on its work effectively rather than a cut of $3,500,000 as now recommended by the Bureau of the Budget, according to a nation-wide survey just completed by the National Council of American Importers, Inc.

The substitute answer of the National Association of Blouse Manufacturers, admitting all questions of fact but making no admissions on questions of law, has now been filed with the Federal Trade Commission, it was disclosed yesterday at the hearing held at 1440 Broadway by the FTC into its charges that the association and other respondents had conspired in restraint of trade.
City Controller Lazarus Joseph announced yesterday the sale of $40,000,000 of 0.75 per cent tax anticipation notes dated March 21 and payable May 2. The notes were allotted to twenty-six local banks.

ANYONE who has ever had an operation, and that includes a great many of us, knows that his natural apprehension as a prospective victim of surgery was considerably mitigated by blind confidence in the surgeon. Frequently such confidence is completely justified, but surgeons are fallible men who make mistakes and have troubles of their own.

Though the housewife will see an abundance of such winter standbys as sweet potatoes, cabbage and onions when she does her week-end shopping today, she will find they are sharing space in fresh produce displays with more spring-like vegetables such as asparagus, radishes and green peas.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 20 -- Corinne Calvet, French film actress, will make her American screen debut in Paramount's "The Sealed Verdict," the studio announced today. Miss Calvet, who was signed to a term contract by Paramount in February, will arrive in New York tomorrow on the way from Paris to Hollywood, according to the studio.

Manufacturers' pricing should be directed at the medium bracket income group which represents their most profitable market, it was pointed out yesterday by Dr. Henry Bund, director of management methods of the Research Institute of America.

Irving H. Saypol, chief assistant United States Attorney, read yesterday into the record at the draft evasion trial of Serge M. Rubinstein a part of the 1943 report, of the Panhandle Producing and Refining Company in which Rubinstein said that the Panhandle Steel Products Company, a subsidiary, was engaged 45 per cent in war production in 1942.

Net sales and earnings of Best Co., Inc., for the twelve months ended last Jan. 31 were again the largest in its history, Philip LeBoutillier, president and general manager, reported to stockholders in the preliminary annual statement issued today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 20 -- A Soviet move to restrict the jurisdiction of the proposed Ecolomic Commission for Europe to nembers of the United Nations was rejected today by a committee of the United Nations Economic and Social Council.
Eight men of the crew of the United States Army transport Wilson Victory were taken from that vessel at the Army Base Pier in Brooklyn yesterday accused of possessing stolen post exchange supplies.
Hundreds of customs agents are scheduled to be discharged in the Port of New York after March 28, despite protests of shipping interests.

Two purchases of paintings for museums have been announced by New York galleries. The Betty Parsons Gallery disclosed that the Museum of Modern Art has accquired the painting, "Sounds in the Rock," by Theodore Stamos, and the Mortimer Levitt Gallery announced the sale of "Dark Mountains," by Everett Spruas, to be presented to the Nelson Gallery of Kansas City, Mo., through the Friends of Art, a Kansas City or ganization.

PANAMA. March 20 -- Getting away to a lucky lead on a wild throw by Jackie Robinson in the first inning, the Dodgers went on to trample their Montreal farm hands beneath a 10-to-3 score at Olympic Stadium today.

AIKEN, S.C., March 20 -- Several thousand persons watched today as the fourth annual public trials on the Aiken training track got under way a day late because of yesterday's heavy rain. This event, where big stables send their charges for silver cups instead of purses, annually features the end of winter training here.

A House judiciary subcommittee is soberly at work on the pressing problem of ways to increase the number of national holidays. The Congressional approach is a timid one, lacking in the imaginative daring needed. Our Washington correspondent, Anthony Leviero, who is apparently hanging anxiously over the subcommittee's shoulder, finds that there are only twenty-five bills already in the hopper for creating special days and weeks.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 20 (AP) -- Only horses with extreme partiality for muddy going were able to show to best advantage at Gulfstream Park today and one proved to be Alien and Strandlund's Bert in the Palm Beach Purse.
A campaign for more trees in the city's streets has been started by the Municipal Art Society, 119 East Nineteenth Street.
Five steps will be taken immediately to ease the critical shortages in iron and steel scrap, a group of large manufacturers decided here yesterday at a luncheon meeting at the Cloud Club.

His Dead Selves In reply to his little granddaughter's inquiry the old gentleman said, yes, his life has been blessed with many friendships. Looking back through the years, he saw their faces emerge out of the mists of time -- isolationists, interventionists, militarists, pacifists, warmongers, appeasers, imperialists, anti-imperialists friends of the people, enemies of the people. . . .

New table lamps and floor models to be made under the Certified Lamp Makers program Will give fifty to a hundred per cent more downward light for reading or close work, it Vas reported yesterday. Models incorporating the specifications, devised by authorities on residential lighting, will be tagged for consumer identification.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The United States has turned down on all counts Yugoslavia's requests for grain to relieve her food needs, the State Department announced today. Under the decision, Yugoslavia will get no relief from the $350,000,000 appropriation bill now before Congress.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 20 -- Acknowledging that British charges against Albania had not been proved 100 per cent, Sir Alexander Cadogan told the United Nations Security Council today that the "chain of events" demonstrated conclusively that the mines that damaged two British destroyers in Corfu Channel had been laid by the Albanian Government or with its connivance.

CHICAGO, March 20 -- Grain markets fluctuated nervously on the Board of Trade today. Old crop deliveries of wheat were under pressure, with cash interests selling May against purchases of July and at one time the May was off 10 cents a bushel, the permissible limit.

The program of the Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra, with Efrem Kurtz as guest conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall, began with Haydn's G-major symphony, B. and H. 88, and ended with the First symphony of Gustav Mahler. The soloist was John Corigliano; he played the Lalo "Symphonic Espagnole."

Speaking at a press luncheon in Hampshire House yesterday, Arthur Schwartz of Fredrica Furs, Inc., gave his interpretation of the fur highlights of the couture showings in Paris, whence he has just returned.

PORTLAND, Ore., March 20 -- New techniques in lumbering "to make a tree go farther," plus strides by the infant aluminum industry of the Pacific Northwest, are making this part of the country bullish on its industrial future.

Decontrol of Used Cars Seen Export controls soon will be removed from used but not new cars, according to reliable trade sources. Official announcement of decontrol is expected within the next few days. The decontrol order will probably apply to cars built before 1945, it was stated.

The first of a series of weekday prayers by radio for the success of the Foreign Ministers Conference in Moscow was started over Radio Station WRUL yesterday afternoon by the Laymen's Movement for a Christian World in cooperation with the World Wide Broadcasting Foundation.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 20 -- A policy of isolation applied to Greece and Turkey would inevitably bring war and world destruction, Secretary of Labor Lewis B. Schwellenbach said in an address before the Commonwealth Club here today.

JERUSALEM, March 20 -- The Executive of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, which has been in session here since last Friday to discuss and decide primarily the character and method of presenting the Zionists' claims to the United Nations, has so far not reached any definite line.

ROME, March 20 -- Pope Pius XII issued today an encyclical -- which will be known as "Fulgens Radiatur" ("Brilliantly Shines") -- in which he urged the peoples of the Christian world to pattern their lives upon the principles of religion.

Women who plan to go out on dates after work show fewer signs of fatigue than those who look forward only to "a quiet evening at home," Dr. Lillian M. Gilbreth, Professor of Management at Purdue University, said yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, March 20 -- The California District Court of Appeal In a unanimous three-judge decision declared today that public servants should not belong to labor unions because such membership divided an allegiance owed entirely to the people and jeopardized constitutional government.

PARIS, March 20 -- Premier Paul Ramadier threatened today to resign and demanded a vote of confidence by the National Assembly in a national crisis that, some leaders contended, had been precipitated by President Truman's anti-Communist message to Congress and Moscow's reaction to it.

The Selznick Releasing Organization has appointed Robert W. Orr and Associates, Inc., as advertising counsel for "Duel in the Sun" soon to be released in key cities throughout the country, it was announced yesterday by Paul MacNamara, director of advertising and publicity for David O. Selznick and Vanguard Films.

If the theatrical industry awarded Oscars for courage, Monte Proser, successful night club operator, undoubtedly would be admiring one on his mantelpiece. Undaunted by Several setbacks in bringing a show to Broadway, he intends to keep right on trying.

NANKING, March 20 (AP) -- The Chinese Communists will be defeated within three months, Gen. Chen Cheng, Government Army Chief of Staff, said today in discussing the capture of Yenan, Communist capital.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In our excitement about Greece and other far away parts of the world, there is a tendency to overlook important happenings on the American Continent. In a recent trip to Argentina, I was deeply impressed with the fundamental changes taking place in that astonishing country.

LONDON, March 20 -- Word was received here tonight of the death in Switzerland yesterday of Lady Cecilia Harington, niece of Queen Elizabeth. The elder daughter of the Earl of Strathmore, she was 34 years old.

Supreme Court Justice Bernard Botein upheld yesterday the right of Teachers College, Columbia University, to close the experimental Horace Mann-Lincoln School after June 30, 1948. His decision represented an unconditional victory for the college.

In the DP camps and special child centers of the American zone in Germany, there are 6,200 "unaccompanied children" -- war orphans or children whose parents have disappeared and cannot be traced. Representing more than fifteen nationalities and the three religions -- Protestant, Jewish and Catholic -- many look to America as their overriding hope.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 20 -- Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association, today told the press than an inevitable post-war attitude has produced "looseness" in certain recent films. He made the statement in answer to a question concerning "Duel in the Sun," which was recently attacked by the Roman Catholic Church in Los Angeles, but he declined to specify what other pictures belong in the category of "looseness."

MIAMI, Fla., March 20 (AP) -- Francisco (Pancho) Segura of Ecuador today became the first player to reach the semi-finals of the fourth annual University of Miami invitational tennis tournament when he routed Tony Vincent of the University of Miami, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 2.

PHILADELPHIA, March 20 -- The Public Service Company of New Hampshire applied today to the Securities and Exchange Commission for permission to increase its short-term debt to $4,400,000, including outstanding short-term obligations of $1,200,000.

For the first time in the city's history some restaurants have been "padlocked" by the Health Department on the grounds that the insanitary conditions in them were a menace to the public. This is a drastic action, but it cannot be said, that Health Commissioner Weinstein moved hastily.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 20 -- Governor M.E. Thompson said today that the State of Georgia would prosecute its charter revocation suit against the Ku Klux Klan and in his inaugural address before the General Assembly indicated that he would veto the white primary bill sponsored and signed by Herman Talmadge.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The United States has contributed approximately $435,500,000 to Greece since that country was liberated it was learned today.

A stable health program that will provide adequate nutrition for the hospitalized and "cleanliness in public places," was pledged yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer as the ultimate goal of his administration.

VIENNA, March 20 -- Russian occupation authorities have ordered Austria's Minister of the Interior, Oscar Helmer, to appoint eight Communists nominated by them to leading posts in the Austrian police.

A factual record of United States relations with France, from the French defeat in the last war to Darlan's assassination, has been written by William L. Langer, Coolidge Processor of History at Harvard University. Entitled "Our Vichy Gamble," the book will be published by Knopf on April 7.

The Original Ballet Russe had planned no novelty for the opening of its season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, but there was a major one on its program nevertheless. This was the unscheduled 'first appearance of Rosella Hightower in the title role of "Giselle," replacing Alicia Markova who was ill.

Appropriation of $1,559,734 by the American Cancer Society to expand its program of cancer research was announced yesterday. The allocation was from funds set aside for research from contributions to the society during its 1945 and 1946 campaigns.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Within the next week the Government will announce the convening of a conference of bituminous coal operators and United Mine Workers' officials to write a new wage contract. The success of this conference would mean restoration of the nation's coal mines to their owners.

Since it isn't precisely unusual for a movie to violate the integrity of a novel or a play from which it is drawn, we suppose we should not be too greatly surprised nor too bitterly shocked to find that "The Late George Apley" has been botched on the screen -- but good! That is a disappointment for which we might ordinarily have been prepared.

The first of a series of rooms that will be used for the display of new wallpapers as they appear, will open today at Katzenbach Warren's decorators' showroom at 49 East Fifty-third Street. It will be called "The Wallpaper Gallery."

There is still some hope that the Moose River Dam project, sanctioned by the Legislature over the protests of sportsmen and conservationists, may be halted as the result of action taken by the Governor, it was announced yesterday.

AMSTERDAM, March 20 (ANETA) -- Prices on the Stock Exchange showed little changes in moderately active trading. Indies plantation issues were higher, due to favorable market interpretation of the Indies situation. State bonds, shipping issues and banking shares were steady, while industrials were irregular.

MOSCOW, March 20 -- All Allied belligerent and former enemy states who joined the Allies' side and fought Germany will have a chance to express their views on the German peace settlement, the Council of Foreign Ministers' deputies decided today.

Billy Graham of the East Side will face the sternest test of his career when he opposes Tippy Larkin, veteran welterweight from Garfleld, N.J., at Madison Square Garden tonight. The clash is listed for ten rounds and promises to attract a crowd of 13,000 fans.
LONDON, March 20 -- The House of Lords passed a motion of censure on the Government's economic policy tonight by a vote of 119 to 30.

The problem of the British Labor party, it has been said many times by Labor party spokesmen, and has just been said again in a debate in the House of Commons which was reported in this newspaper yesterday, is "to find a solution between totalitarian methods and the method of unrestricted private enterprise."

Financial and industrial leaders were told last night by Shepard Morgan, vice president of the Chase National Bank, that they should have "no illusions" about the term of commitment for the financial aid sought by President Truman for Greece and Turkey.

In his testimony yesterday before the House Foreign Relations Committee, under-Secretary of State Acheson gave the first official answers to the major questions Congress and the country are asking about the proposed assistance to Greece and Turkey. He did not and could not give all the answers.

If architects, landscape architects, and decorators are ever to serve the small home market profitably, now is the time to do it, Mary Pentland, public relations counsel, told members of the Architectural League at a dinner meeting last night at the league clubhouse, 115 East Fortieth Street.

LONDON, March 20 -- Lewis W. Douglas, new United States Ambassador to Britain, told his first press conference today that he had "complete confidence and faith" that Britain would "recover much of the position which she had in the world."

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Department store sales in the week ended March 15 were 10 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1946:

ALBANY, March 20 -- An amendment to the Commercial Rent Control Law, included in the bill extending the operation of the law for another year, may open the door to a substantial number of rent increases for commercial and business space in New York City.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- Another bumper crop production year, topped by what may be the largest wheat crop ever harvested, was forecast today by the Department of Agriculture. The forecast was in a report showing farmers plan to plant slightly larger acreages than during the last two seasons.

President Truman's foreign policy in regard to aid for Greece and Turkey to combat communism was roundly booed and hissed last night when it was mentioned in a speech by Representative Vito Marcantonio at a meeting in Manhattan Center.

After a rather quiet session the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday unchanged to 6 points higher than the day before. Opening with losses of 2 to 10 points, the market sagged on the early weakness in grains, but recovered on price fixing and local covering.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Senate opponents of a Republican proposal to amend the Wage-Hour Act conceded tonight that their case appeared lost, and they were counting on a veto by President Truman.

ALBANY, March 20 -- The O'Dwyer Administration fared very well at the hands of the Republican-controlled Legislature for the second successive year, an analysis of New York City program bills now before Governor Dewey showed today.

Artistic work by young people from virtually every quarter of Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx was shown yesterday in a preview of an exhibition that opens to the public today in Education Hall of the Museum, of Natural History.

Tourists planning to visit Europe would be wise to wait a year if the trip is not a necessary trip abroad, according to Robert C. Lee, executive vice president of Moore-McCormack Lines, who returned from Scandinavia yesterday.

LONDON, March 20 (U.P.) -- Lord Burghley, chairman of the Olympic Organizing Committee and president of the International Amateur Athletic Federation, today gave the second official indication in two days that Britain is changing its position on the "broken-time" issue.

MOSCOW, March 20 -- French Foreign Minister Bidault told the Council of Foreign Ministers today that France would never agree to a solution of the German economic question unless it included guarantees of shipments of German coal to France and other European countries.

Robert Stevenson, pianist, presented a program of his own compositions yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. He was assisted by Eugenie Dengel, violist; Louise Lackland, contralto; Nena Williams, mezzo-soprano, and a chorus of thirty voices from the West-minster Choir College, conducted by Harold Hedgpeth.

Bricklayers are working at a lower rate of production today than before the war because the cost-plus contracts of wartime construction gave incentive to management to waste labor rather than economize it, Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, declared last night.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., March 20 -- Four major developments in the current plastic materials picture were outlined here today at the Pacific Coast meeting of the Society of the Plastics Industry. As outlined by F. A. Carman, general manager of the Plastic Materials Manufacturers Association, Inc., these developments were:

The stock market labored yesterday through the dullest session in seven months with prices generally easier, although some show of steadiness appeared near the close. Corporate developments inspired some major changes in a few issues and the composite rate declined 0.35.
Total buyer attendance at the American Toy Fair yesterday went above the 10,000 mark, setting an all-time high for the two-week exhibit, which closes here today.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 20 -- The gift by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Goelet of New York City of Ochre Court, their fifty-room villa on Cliff Walk at Newport, to the Catholic Diocese of Providence was announced here today after transfer of the deed took place in the office of the Most Rev. Francis P. Keough, D.D., Bishop of Providence.

Billy Rose, the little showman who does everything in a big way, is embarking on a large-scale humanitarian and personal venture, it was learned yesterday. He and his wife, the former Olympic swimmer Eleanor Holm, are planning to bring from Europe twenty-five displaced orphans and rear them here.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- A rapid examination and judgment of the lower court decision whereby workers in the Mount Clemens Pottery plant were denied portal-to-portal pay was asked of the Supreme Court by the Federal Government today.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 20 -- The prolonged strike at the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company, described by Walter Geist, president, as "the machinations of a Communist-dominated union," cut 1946 net income to $144,487 from $7,090,407 in 1945, the company's annual report disclosed today.

A variety of comparatively small borrowings sent commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System $23,000,000 higher last week, to a new record of $4,172,000,000.

MEXICO CITY, March 20 (AP) -- Nineteen United States baseball players who were lured to the Mexican League by jangling silver last year are not listed on the roster published by the six-team south of the border circuit today.

The Guidance Institute at 122 East Fifty-eighth Street will celebrate its twenty-fifth, birthday today, in the midst of the twenty-eighth annual fund raising campaign of New York Catholic Charities, under whose auspices this mental clinic for children was organized in 1922.

In cold print, the news that C.C.N.Y. defeated Wisconsin, big nine basketball champion, by 70 -- 56 before 18,473 fans at Madison Square Garden last night does not begin to tell the story of one of the most sensational comebacks of the campaign.
LONDON, March 20 -- Towns were isolated and communications cut tonight in large parts of central and southern England as flood waters rose beyond past record levels.

Directors of the Pennsylvania-Central Airlines Corporation at a meeting in Washington on Wednesday took no action on the payment of interest on its 3 1/2 per cent convertible income debentures, ordinarily due on April 1, it became known yesterday.

Jean Borotra, Marcel Bernard and Jacques Brugnon, members of the visiting French tennis team, left last night aboard the Montrealer to launch their tour of Canada and the United States. They are raising funds to rebuild the indoor courts at the Stade de Coubertin on the outskirts of Paris, bombed into ruins during the war.

Unless physicians use their knowledge and skills for improving the health of all the people, the medical profession faces a dark future, Dr. Dean A. Clark, medical director of the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York, said yesterday.
The soft-voiced man in the dark topcoat stared heavenward. He spoke like a man bemused, which he was.
HONOLULU, March 20 -- Manager Mel Ott had cause today for jubilation followed last night's 6-2 victory for the Giants in the opening brush with the San Francisco Seals.

Fire Losses While The Home Insurance Company is the country's largest fire underwriter, the article in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday on this company's annual report, certainly did not mean to convey that it alone paid the nation's entire fire losses in 1946, which amounted to $561,487,000.

Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., has abandoned temporarily its recent proposal that cooperating gas household heating equipment dealers quote flat prices covering all service and installation costs, Brig. Gen. E.T. Jeffee, vice president in charge of sales, disclosed yesterday.

The long-awaited itinerary of the Alcoa Steamship Company's new Alcoa Cavalier on its seventeen-day cruises to the Caribbean was announced yesterday. The Cavalier will make her maiden voyage from here on May 2, with a scheduled departure every three weeks thereafter.
CHICAGO, March 20 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:
Arbitration may be proposed by the National Federation of Telephone Workers as an alternative to the national strike it has called for April 7, it was indicated yesterday.

For the first time In many decades the American Bible Society has been able to make a shipment of Bibles and portions of the Scriptures to Russia, This was announced in the annual report of the organization, made public yesterday at Bible House, Park Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street, by the Rev. Dr. Eric M. North, general secretary.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- Following is the text of the State Department's announcement today on Yugoslavia's request for grain:

Gilbert Simon has acquired from Bros Realty the one-story taxpayer consisting of seven stores at 620-32 Caton Avenue and the corner of East Seventh Street, in Brooklyn, through Thomas G. Sarris and Timm Behrens, brokers. The property was sold for cash above two mortgages totaling 550,000.
Giant flying boats and so-called "flying LST's" may be one of the answers of the future to the problems presented by increasing aircraft size and large-scale airborne operations.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on March 15 were 841,147 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 35,358 cars or 4.4 per cent more than for the preceding week, 41,241 cars or 5.2 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year and 24,591 cars or 3.0 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

The unqualified support of the 7,500,000 members of the American Federation of Labor was pledged to the United Financial Employes yesterday in its threatened strike against Wall Street exchanges and brokerage houses.

SALONIKA, Greece, March 20 (AP) -- Three slug's from an, assassin's gun killed Jean Zevgos, 40, former Communist Minister of Agriculture, as he stood on a busy corner here today. Police said a man who claimed to be a member of the Communist party's "execution squad" had confessed the slaying.

The Westminster Choir, founded and conducted by John Finley Williamson, appeared in concert at the Town Hall last night, its first on its own in New York in thirteen years. Since 1936, however, it has been paying visits to this city to assist such organizations as the New York Philharmonic-Symphony and the NBC Symphony in the performance of major choral works.

As his first step toward the reorganization of Tammany, Frank J. Sampson, its leader yesterday appointed a Committee on Revision of the Rules of the Democratic County Committee, headed by George Gordon Battle, newly appointed chairman of the Tammany law committee.

LONDON, March 20 -- Charging that the Labor Government has proved a failure, both in its economic planning and its political leadership, Anthony Eden called on the British people tonight to reject "state regimentation" in favor of "free enterprise adapted by modern thought."

The board of trustees of the Police Pension Fund set a precedent yesterday when it voted to increase the pensions of three former deputy police commissioners who previously had held high posts in the department.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Robert P. Patterson, Secretary of War, said today that an over-all National Defense Establishment would curb "empire-building" practices by the armed services and would start saving money for the taxpayers within two years.

WASHINGTON. March 20 -- Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr. and the House Republican Steering Committee gave their blessing today to proposed revisions of the Knutson bill which would reduce the income taxes of more than 20,000,000 persons in the lowest income bracket by 30 per cent.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Prompt enactment of long-range housing legislation to check the critical housing shortage and its accompanying threat of social disorder and degeneration of health and family life was urged today by representatives of civil, veteran and labor organizations.

The securities business was described last night as the most essential prop of individual freedom in our economic system in an address by Francis Adams Truslow, new president of the New York Curb Exchange, at a dinner given in his honor in the Park Lane Hotel.

Discussion of plans for a multi-lingual international magazine was begun yesterday by publishers from nineteen countries. They met in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel at the invitation of the Crowell-Collier Publishing Company.
BREMEN, Germany, March 20 -- The dissemination of anti-occupation literature, edited to suit all tastes, is on the increase in this recently created fourth state of the American zone.

ALBANY, March 20 -- Governor Dewey signed today the Quinn-Steingut bill extending the time in which municipalities and housing authorities may start emergency housing projects. He also approved a law extending the life of the State Mortgage Commission which was set up during the depression to assist investors in real estate mortgages.

Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Rutherfurd of Allamuchy, N.J., told yesterday how they collected 550 mammals, representing 108 different forms, in a 1,400-mile journey by jeep from Bechuanaland to the Kenya border in Africa.

ALBANY, March 20 -- Governor Dewey signed today the Quinn-Steingut bill extending the time in which municipalities and housing authorities may start emergency housing projects. He also approved a law extending the life of the State Mortgage Commission which was set up during the depression to assist investors in real estate mortgages.
