The securities business was described last night as the most essential prop of individual freedom in our economic system in an address by Francis Adams Truslow, new president of the New York Curb Exchange, at a dinner given in his honor in the Park Lane Hotel.

LONDON, March 20 -- Despite demands in the House of Commons today that Britain reduce her armed forces to help solve the manpower shortage in industry, the Labor Government was firm in its refusal to cut the Army, Navy and Air Force below 1,OOO,OOO by March, 1948.

A simple Episcopal funeral service for William C. Durant, founder of the General Motors Corporation and a spectacular stock market speculator who made and lost several fortunes, was held yesterday in Calvary Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street.

Sales and earnings of Bond Stores, Inc., in 1946 were the largest in that clothing company's history "despite better competitive values resulting from lower gross markup," the annual statement reported to stockholders yesterday.

A wildcat strike of sandhogs and maintenance workers halted construction work last night on the $84,000,000 Brooklyn-Battery tunnel. The walkout began at 1 P.M. at the Brooklyn end of the tunnel and spread to the Manhattan end at 8 P.M.

Substantial progress was reported yesterday in negotiations between the city and the Port Authority on the latter's $191,000,000 plan to operate Idlewild and La Guardia Airports on a ninety-nine-year lease.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- After five weeks of steady advances, average primary market prices dropped 0.3 per cent because of lower prices for some foods during the week ended March 15, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the United States Department of Labor.

BERLIN, March 20 -- In the absence of any central government to represent the German people on either international or domestic issues, the next few weeks may develop a working merger of representatives of political parties as an interim substitute.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- An authentic report on the strength, tactics and objectives of the Communist bands operating along the northern Greek border was received in the capital today.

Discussion of plans for a multi-lingual international magazine was begun yesterday by publishers from nineteen countries. They met in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel at the invitation of the Crowell-Collier Publishing Company.
BREMEN, Germany, March 20 -- The dissemination of anti-occupation literature, edited to suit all tastes, is on the increase in this recently created fourth state of the American zone.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Warren C. Kendall, chairman of the car service division of the Association of American Railroads told the Interstate Commerce Commission today that the AAR has arranged to permit the loading in the East of empty cars suitable for grain, for points west of Chicago and St. Louis.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The statement made today by Acting Secretary of State Dean Acheson before the House Foreign Affairs Committee:

Reorganization of the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures to include representation for twenty-two national organizations was approved yesterday by delegates to the board's thirty-eighth anniversary conference, at the McAlpin Hotel.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 20 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie will make the opening address when the United Nations Trusteeship Council hold its first meeting Wednesday.
Blind war orphans in Poland soon will be reading selections of American literature translated into Polish braille as a result of the efforts of a group of New York City high school students.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- High flour exports under a general licensing system to the other American republics, some South Pacific islands and some parts of Africa were cut off today by the Department of Agriculture. The step was taken to channel full flour allocations to needy Europe.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 20 (AP) -- A record number of 186 swimmers from twenty-nine colleges and universities will compete for eleven individual titles in the two-day Eastern Intercollegiate League invitation meet in the Yale pool starting tomorrow.

A record number of 3,500 student journalists gathered at Columbia University yesterday to attend the opening session of the twenty-third annual convention of the Columbia Scholastic Press Association in the McMillin Academic Theatre.

JERUSALEM, March 20 -- If the Palestine Communist party's policy reflects Russian policy, as is usually the case in other countries, the Soviet Union's proposal for Palestine in the United Nations will be the evacuation of British troops and the establishment of an Arab-Jewish independent state.

Warning that Manhattan's midtown area is being forced into obsolescence through traffic congestion, Cleveland Rodgers, City Planning Commissioner, yesterday urged rapid improvement in physical facilities for the accommodation of business requirements.

The young Georgian who smashed his way into the Governor's offices in Atlanta last January, on a basis of 675 popular votes, has moved out of them in obedience to a 5-to-2 decision of the Georgia Supreme Court. Melvin E. Thompson, whom nobody denied was legitimately chosen Lieutenant Governor, moved in.

Raymond B. Fosdiek, presenting yesterday his annual review of the activities of the Rockefeller Foundation, of which he is president, stressed three major fields in which immediate further progress must be made.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The International Trade Organization expected to be created at the eighteen nation conference to open in Geneva April 10, would not be permitted to interfere in the domestic affairs of any member nation, under an authoritative interpretation handed down here today.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- John L. Lewis said today the choice of James Boyd to head the Bureau of Mines was "a political deal" and that the Government should have consulted "the men who are going to die in the mines" before naming Mr. Boyd to be in charge of their safety.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Those who are firm believers in the free enterprise system should read carefully Councilman Louis P. Goldberg's letter which appeared in your paper recently. It points the way to bring about socialism without the people realizing what is happening.
For the first time in New York, restaurants have been closed by the city authorities for insanitary conditions.

NEWARK, N.J., March 20 (AP) -- Yale defeated Cornell, 10 -- 9, in a sudden-death overtime chukker here tonight to earn the right to meet West Point in the final of the national intercollegiate polo tournament to be played at the Essex Troop Armory on Saturday night.

JERUSALEM, March 21 -- Ten members of the Executive of the Jewish Agency for Palestine left their conference room in the Hadassah University Hospital on Mount Scopus today to take turns at breaking ground for new hospital buildings.

A list of major obstacles that prevent understanding between the peoples of the Soviet Union and the United States, and a program designed to overcome these obstacles were outlined yesterday by Prof. George S. Counts of Teachers College, Columbia University.

GLEN COVE, L.I., March 21 -- The Russian owners of the former George Dupont Pratt estate are busy turning it into a recreation and entertainment center for diplomatic representatives and employes of Russian agencies in the United States.

KANSAS CITY, March 21 (AP) -- A long push shot by Slater Martin with less than half a minute remaining gave the University of Texas a 42-to-40 victory over Wyoming in the opening semi-final of the western regional National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball play-offs tonight.

After a rather poor start yesterday the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned strong and active in the late trading and closed at virtually the best levels of the day and at net gains of 20 to 46 points.

BREMEN, Germany, March 21 -- Six out of every ten Germans in the American zone of Germany are still "deeply imbued" with strong anti-Semitic feelings, according to an official American Military Government report.

MANILA, March 21 (AP) -- A fiveyear military assistance agreement integrating the Philippines in American defense plans for the Western Pacific was signed this afternoon by President Manuel A. Roxas and United States Ambassador Paul V. McNutt.

The record of the New York Public Library for 1946 as told in its annual report is a warm and human document. It has the essential statistics on reader use, which are startlingly impressive. The story is also told in pictures. One of these shows a little fellow with pen tightly clasped in hand writing his name in the Children's Room Register for the first time.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., March 21 -- The blackballing of a Negro from membership in Phi Omega Chi, a leading sorority at Upsala College here, resulted in formation of a new sorority that eliminates membership restrictions. The faculty social committee announced today that it would act on the proposed new charter May 12.

MADRID, March 21 -- Eleven members of the clandestivs national committee of the Anarchist National Confederation of Labor were tried for military rebellion today at the village of Alcala de Henares outside Madrid. Their Conviction, although not yet announced, is a foregone conclusion.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The Senate, ignoring Democratic threats of a Presidential veto, passed 64 to 24 today a bill reducing the legal privileges of workers under the minimum wage laws and quashing nearly $6,000,000,000 in portal-to-portal back pay claims.

Norma Kotler, 22 years old, clerk in a pajama factory, was garroted, apparently with fine wire, some time yesterday morning in her mother's fourth-floor apartment at 28-25 Thirty-fourth Street, in Astoria, Queens. The killer left no clue, not even the death instrument.

NEWARK, N.J., March 21 -- President Truman's announcement last Feb. 1 that an agreement between the Associated Contractors of America and the Building and Construction Trades Department of the AFL would settle disputes in the industry by voluntary arbitration and without strikes was characterized today as "obviously phony" by Representative George MacKinnon, Minnesota Republican.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- By a roll-call vote of 286 to 54, the House passed and sent to the Senate today a resolution extending government controls over the pricing and distribution of sugar until Oct. 31.

SANTA ANA, Calif., March 21 (AP) -- Murder accusations were signed tonight against Louise Overell, 17, and her fiance, George Gollum, 21, charging them with the slaying of her wealthy parents, Mr. and Mrs. Walter Overell, aboard the parents' yacht in nearby Newport Harbor Saturday night.

Convinced of the need for extensive script revisions, especially as they concern the third act, Irene M. Selznick has temporarily delayed the opening of her first Broadway production, "Heartsong." The Arthur Laurents work was to have had its premiere at the Booth Theatre on April 2, but Mrs. Selznick decided to surrender the booking to permit the author more time to make the necessary revisions.

After a nine-month road tour, nature's favorite production, spring, was back in town yesterday for a three-month stand. The curtain went up at 6:13 A.M., at which time assorted newspaper people and Boy Scouts began chasing around the metropolitan area.

Hardened by the rigors of war, six outstanding European soccer players stepped ashore from the Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth yesterday, eager to sample the United States variety of the pastime.

GREENSBORO, N.C., March 21 (AP) -- Big Vic Ghezzi of Kansas City, Kan., one-time national P.G. A. champion, turned in the only sub-par round, a two-under 33, 36 -- 69, to take a two-stroke lead in the first round of the $10,000 Greensboro open golf tournament today.

Charles W. Baker Jr., who was a director of the Taylorcraft Aviation Corporation in 1943, testified in Federal Court yesterday that he had no knowledge of any connection Serge M. Rubinstein had with the company in that year.

LONDON, March 21 (U.P.) -- Viscount Wavell, retiring Viceroy, said today in a farewell radio broadcast from New Delhi, India, that he believed the stability of the Indian Army would be a decisive factor in India's future.

New Capital Market Distributors of securities are getting set for their most active week of the year, beginning Monday. Topped by $200,000,000 of American Telephone and Telegraph Company new-money debentures, the week's slate calls for a dozen major marketings.

MOSCOW, March 21 -- One of the essential tasks of the Communist party in the western Ukraine is to strengthen the agricultural administration of the area and to explain the "advantages of a collective economy over an individual economy.

Easter Buying Improves Buying of ready-to-wear for Easter showed a firmer tone in retail trade here this week. Department store volume was estimated at about 8 to 10 per cent above the like week of last year. This is about the same rate of gain noted for the preceding week.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board approved today an agreement by sixteen of the country's major airlines to increase passenger rates by 10 per cent. The increase will take effect April 1, and the airlines have agreed to keep the boosted rate stable for at least ninety days after that date.

TRENTON, N.J., March 21 (AP) -- An adjustment in the proposed formula to increase the State's take from pari-mutuel betting at race tracks was said by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll today to appear desirable.

ROME, March 21 -- Two hundred thousand Italian workers will emigrate to France within, one year from today, going there at the rate of 17,000 a month, according to the Italo-French agreement signed today.

LONDON, March 21 -- The outstanding feature in generally dull stock markets here today was the weakness in shares of companies manufacturing bicycles as a result of the Board of Trade's drastic cut in steel supplies.Realization that all steel-consuming industries probably will have to accept further cuts affected the remainder of the industrial market, and provincial selling of motor shares was seen.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 21 -- "The Brothers Karamazov," Fyodor Dostoievsky's 1880 Russian novel about the violent, neurotic sons of a depraved, debauched father, will be brought to the screen this year by Metro-GoldwynMayer, the studio announced today.

The New York Stock Exchange had a net profit of $606,460 last year, compared with one of $856,026 in 1945, its annual report disclosed yesterday. Total income was $8,146,443, an increase of $636,593 over the preceding year.

Jerry Connolly of Fordham nipped favored Tommy Quinn of the New York A.C. in the last half-dozen strides to win the 1,000yard invitation event that featured the ninety-seventh games of the Seventh Regiment Athletic Association last night.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- Following is the text of the preamble Senators Arthur H. Vandenberg, and Tom Connally have proposed for the Greek-Turkish loan legislation: Whereas the Governments of Greece and Turkey have sought from the Government of the United States immediate financial and other assistance which is necessary for the maintenance of their survival as free nations;

SAN FRANCISCO, March 21 -- Stern warnings that the frozen food industry must improve its product or suffer severe setbacks were sounded before the convention of the National Association of Frozen Food Packers here today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 21 -- The importance of international atomic control in any disarmament scheme will be re-emphasized by the United States when the United Nations arms reduction talks begin on Monday, it was reported today.
The United Financial Employes, AFL, served notice yesterday on the New York Stock and Curb Exchanges that it was canceling its contracts effective April 21.

It will be C.C.N.Y. against Holy Cross in the final for the National Collegiate Athletic Association eastern regional championship at Madison Square Garden tonight as Gotham's annual postseason basketball program continues at its dizzy pace.

Adopting a middle course between contradictory proposals at the Moscow Conference, Secretary of State Marshall has warned both Russia and France against building up Germany's industry beyond her own needs in order to enable her to pay reparations, and then beggaring her either by excessive reparations or by economic strangulation.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In letters published by THE TIMES on the present federal tax policy with regard to cooperative enterprises, both proponents and opponents of special tax treatment have expressed their intense feelings but, for the most part, have clouded the real issues by the heat of their one-sided arguments.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth, with salt spray stains on her bridge structure ninety feet above the water line, docked at Pier 90, North River, yesterday, after the stormiest crossing of her Atlantic career.

"We are anxious to continue the custom that we inaugurated in Holy Cross of having only one collection at the masses on Sunday," Msgr. Joseph A. McCaffrey, the pastor, said in a letter this week to his parishoners at Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church, West Forty-second Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues.

President Truman has asked for an extension of government controls over exports for a year beyond the present expiration date of June 30. In a message to Congress he points out that immediate decontrol in the face of continuing domestic and world scarcities is "too dangerous to be undertaken at this time.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 21 -- Mrs. Adam Leroy Jones, civic leader here, who enjoyed a national reputation for her activities in educational, musical and cultural fields, died yesterday at her home, 71 South Mountain Avenue, after a long illness.

TAMPA, Fla., March 21 -- Clifford Mapes, the tall Californian who played every inning in centerfield in the days when this MacPhailian tour was barnstorming its way through Puerto Rico and Venezuela, returned to the Yankee line-up today and Manager Bucky Harris could not have timed the big fellow's re-entry to better advantage.
A "wildcat" strike of sandhogs and maintenance workers on the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel spread yesterday as other crafts joined the walkout in sympathy, making 1,200 workers idle.

GROTON, Conn., March 21 (AP) -- Rear Admiral John Wilkes, commander of the Atlantic Submarine Fleet said today that "very strenuous" mid-Atlantic fleet exercises, from which he had just returned, pointed up the "weakness" of our present-type submarines in contrast to a speedier vessel which the Germans developed just as the war ended.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The vote by which the Senate passed and returned to the House today a bill to outlaw portal pay suits was as follows:

ALBANY, March 21 -- Dr. Ruth Andrus, chief of the Bureau of Child Development and Parent Education, said today that one function of parent education is interpreting such family substitutes as the nursery school.

PHILADELPHIA, March 21 (AP) -- Seedings in the Philadelphia Inquirer Charities' $10,000 professional tennis tournament ran true tonight as two former rulers of the amateurs gained the final with straight-set victories.

PARIS, March 21 -- Sumner Welles, former United States Under -Secretary of State, has written a letter that will be read in defense of Camille Chautemps in the French High Court of Justice when the former Premier is tried in absentia at Versailles next Tuesday on charges of acts that impaired national defense.

HYAK, Wash., March 21 -- The foremost ski "riders" of this country, along with a brilliant array of Norwegian, Swedish and Canadian "cloudbusters" tonight were scanning the skies, hopeful that the unexpected and unwelcome downpour would cease in time to permit the holding of the Olympic jumping tryouts and exhibitions tomorrow and Sunday.

Consumer resistance to men's woolen suits has reached a point where many manufacturers have left them out of their lines for fall and are attempting to dispose of current stocks of woolen piece goods at a loss, a survey indicated yesterday.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 21 -- Three unrelated news dispatches in a Belgrade paper emphasized today the progress Marshal Tito's regime was making toward the liquidation of intellectual freedom, and the demoralizing effect it already had had on education standards, especially among the youngest students.

Unable to agree on a recommendation that enlisted men should not sit as members of courtsmartial in either the Army or Navy, the War Veterans Bar Association voted last night to poll its membership on the question.

Condemning saber-rattling and jingoism, Capt. William E. Haskell, assistant to the president of The New York Herald Tribune, predicted yesterday that there would be no war between Russia and the United States and Great Britain. He spoke at the morning session of the Columbia Scholastic Press Association convention in the McMillin Academic Theatre at Columbia.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 21 -- Outlawing of strikes in vital public utilities and government services was advocated here tonight by Charles P. Taft, president of the Federal Council of Churches and brother of the chairman of the Senate Labor Committee.

MOSCOW, March 21 (AP) -- The text of the statement on a provisional German government by United States Secretary of State Marshall before the foreign Ministers Conference today: As the result of the defeat of the German armed forces, the German Government and administrative machinery were completely destroyed.

August Ganzenmuller Jr. and Edward F. McGrath, the only seeded players to see action in the men's division, advanced to the second round as play started yesterday in the fourth annual Eastern indoor tennis championships at the Eighth Regiment Armory, the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- When stability is re-established in Greece, the United States will follow a moderate policy of trying to obtain what it regards as a just political and territorial settlement between Greece and her Communist neighbors, it was learned today.

Having begun at the bottom of the league a few weeks ago, The Associated Playwrights, Inc., have advanced several numbers with the production of Edmund B. Hennefeld's "The Deputy of Paris" at the Henry Street Playhouse last evening.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The House Appropriations Committee carved deeply today into the budget for labor activities of the Federal Government in the next fiscal year.

LONDON, March 21 -- While floods receded in some parts of England tonight, there was no easing of the critical situation in Yorkshire or in the low-lying eastern counties, where violent winds threatened further breaches in the dikes.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- H.T. Andrews, the Minister of South Africa, handed Dean Acheson, acting Secretary of State, today a check for $50,000,000 as the first of two payments on a $100,0OO,OOO settlement of the dominion's lend-lease account with the United States.

Norway, Sweden and Finland will be represented in the international racing on Long Island Sound off Oyster Bay for the Scandinavian Gold Cup. Each will send a six-meter sloop here for the competition, which is to open on Sept. 8.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your issue of March 3 you published an article entitled "Future of Free Enterprise Is Found Uncertain in Survey of Economic Trends," in which Russell Porter asserted that in Rumania "industry is being completely nationalized," and also that "private enterprise is fighting a losing battle there.

To attempt to stop communism internationally by "sheer power politics and domestically by witch hunts" will not provide a fundamental solution to Soviet-American relations, Dr.H. Scudder Mekeel, Professor of Anthropology at Wisconsin University, declared yesterday.

Spring, which arrived yesterday for a long stay, will have a difficult time surpassing the number of flowers which the International Flower Show has on display within the four walls of Grand Central Palace this week. The exhibits may still be seen until 10:30 o'clock tonight.

HONOLULU, March 21 -- Bob Carpenter's status as a starting pitcher for the Giants this year has become a matter of much speculation following the Polo Grounder's 12-to-6 victory over the San Francisco Seals here last night.

In spite of dust, smoke, exhaust gases and difficult soil conditions, experience has shown that several fine varieties of trees will live and thrive in New York City streets. In the blocks where they now grow, new beauty and graciousness have been brought by the pattern of their architecture in winter and the fresh green and shade of their summer foliage.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- An apparatus for melting ice and preventing ice formation in waterways, ports and harbors, which may find an eager market in the Soviet Union, has been developed by two Swedish inventors, Bengt Erik Persson of Enebyberg and Erik Forslind of Stockholm, to whom was awarded this week one of the 397 patents issued by the United States Patent Office.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 21 -- Evidence submitted by Great Britain to the United Nations Security Council has demonstrated that a Corfu Channel mine field, whose location had not been made public and that damaged two British destroyers and killed forty-four British sailors, was sown with the knowledge of the Albanian Government, the United States declared today.

A major advertising and promotion campaign will start soon for the ten models of the 1947 line of Olympic radios, it was announced yesterday by J.F. Crossin, vice president and director of sales of the Olympic Radio and Television Corporation.

The Rockefeller Foundation is the largest and most important philanthropic organization of its kind specifically devoted to the advancement of science. It spends its money for education and research in every country that boasts of a respectable university, a hospital or a research institute -- spends it only after an appraisal of needs.

MOSCOW, March 21 -- The Council of Foreign Ministers agreed this afternoon to invite the Austrian Government to send representatives here as soon as possible to present Vienna's views on the projected Austrian peace treaty.

CHICAGO, March 21 -- Grain markets turned strongly upward on the Board of Trade today. There was an absence of the liquidation that had been evident during the three preceding days, and enlarged commission and cash house buying caused prices to rise rapidly.

Quiet and Serious Prophecy is always a hazardous occupation, and no branch of the trade is beset with deeper pitfalls than the department which specializes in predictions about what young men will do when they come home from a world war.

The stone cast upon the waters by President Truman has stirred farspreading ripples. The place it was aimed at was the Moscow conference, and it is too soon yet to gauge the effects on the high-power sparring match of the Foreign Ministers. The white baize cover of the council table is loaded with questions -- also loaded -- on topics relevant to the German problem.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- President Truman today sent to Congress a proposed joint resolution for United States participation in the World Health Organization of the U.N.

The signs of spring are pushing at the snow and ice in Maine, and according to a number of the recognized as well as unrecognized prophets the ice will be out of almost every major lake in the state by May 1.

Importance of correlating all available data on sizing of textile yarns for the purpose of scientific research and conclusions was emphasized yesterday by Lewis Sanders, president of the Textile Research Institute. The study will take ten years, Mr. Sanders predicted, but substantial benefits to the industry should be realized in the next twelve months.

BERLIN, March 21 -- The United States and Britain suspended indefinitely today iron and steel shipments into the Russian zone of Germany on the ground that the Russians had failed to live up to a $21,000,000 trade agreement with the merged [economic] BritishAmerican zone.
A vice raid early yesterday by plainclothes patrolmen on two ornate East Side apartments resulted in the arrest of three women and four men.

LONDON, March 21 -- A final check on the effects of the February industrial crisis shows that 15 1/2 per cent of Great Britain's working population was unemployed at the low point. The number unemployed in the week following the general resumption of production was twice the precrisis figure.

An offer by a felon facing two and a half to five years on a charge of second-degree grand larceny to donate an eye to a totally blind 14-year-old girl raised a legal question in the mind of Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz in Kings County Court yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The world trade controls which President Truman has asked to have continued under the Second War Powers Act are as essential to American agriculture as to the feeding of Europe and the curbing of the spread of communism, several Administration speakers today told the Senate Agriculture Committee.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 21 -- The United Nations Press Division issued an official denial today of Greek charges that one of its members was sending biased accounts of the activities of the special commission investigating border strife in the Balkans.

LOS ANGELES, March 21 -- American business management must take the lead in the stabilization of our national economy by "raising its sights above the considerations of immediate profit and loss," Leon Keyserling, vice chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers to the President, said to night.

MOSCOW, March 21 -- The United States Government was accused today of seeking "world domination" and aspiring to the heritage of German, Italian and Japanese imperialism. The charge was made in a forthright article published in the magazine New Times.

The stock market made yesterday a technical comeback which encompassed a greater portion of the list and raised prices on the average a point. The strongest momentum was generated in the last few minutes of trading and produced some major gains in the pivotal issues.
San Leandro, Calif., announced yesterday that it would offer at competitive sale on April 8 an issue of $900,000 of sewer bonds dated June 15, 1947, and due on June 15 from 1948 to 1977.

ANYONE who has made the mistake of writing France off as finished had better take a look at her literature. It is still boiling with new movements, and far less insular than our own. In France, as John L. Brown suggested in last Sunday's issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES Book Review, the whole literary field can get into an uproar as to the merits of American writing.

LONDON, March 21 -- Charges of seriously curtailing the freedom of individuals were leveled against the British Government in the House of Commons today by both Laborites and Conservatives during the debate on a bill to abolish mid-week dog racing.

Operations of the Bendix Aviation Corporation and its wholly owned domestic subsidiaries in the fiscal year ended with last September resulted in a net income of $785,914 after all charges, but including special credits, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday.

AIKEN, S.C., March 21 -- Another set of trials for thoroughbreds trained in this sector was staged today, with the silver cups that take the place of purses, going to a record breaker in one race for 2-year-olds and to a good-looking son of the famous Whirlaway in another.

TRENTON, N.J., March 21 -- Thomas S. Holden, president of the F.W. Dodge Corporation, New York, predicted today before New Jersey real estate men that in the next three months it would be determined whether there would be "a leveling off" in new construction prices.
DETROIT, March 21 -- The United Automobile Workers of the Congress of Industrial Organizations submitted demands today to the General Motors Corporation for a reopening of wage contract provisions.
New York State has had a net gain of 78,000 businesses since V-J Day, most of them in the category of small business, the State Department of Commerce said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- Elisha Hanson, general counsel for the American Newspaper Publishers Association, told Congress today that the Postoffice Department should get its mail transportation "out of the horse-and-buggy age.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 21 (AP) -- Mighty Armed, seeking to return to familiar territory -- the winner's circle -- today was entered in tomorrow's $25,000 added Gulfstream Park Handicap, along with ten others.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The revised tax reduction bill of the Republicans was cleared by the Ways and Means Committee today, and Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr. predicted the House would pass it next week.

NEW HAVEN, March 21 -- Yale and Rutgers made a clean-up tonight in the Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League's individual championships, the Elis taking the first three finals and the lads from the banks of the old Raritan grabbing the other two.
FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, March 21 -- The United States Army in Europe will drink less, according to a European command directive effective April 1.

A vigorous protest to Governor Thomas E. Dewey against New York State promotion of private industrial research by tax-exempt institutions to the exclusion of commercial research laboratories was planned here yesterday, A.J. Nydick, general counsel of the American Council of Commercial Laboratories, announced.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Congress was urged today to put the United States squarely on record in favor of a United States of Europe organized within the structure of the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Senators Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan and Tom Connally of Texas set out tonight to insert in the Greek-Turkish assistance resolution a clause stating that the United Nations was not to be bypassed in the program.

Fortunately for us who like good food, the fact Mrs. Carrie Bertolotti had seven children did not interfere with her running a restaurant. She and her husband opened it on West Third Street about a half-century ago, appropriately naming it Mother Bertolotti's.

Negotiations for the sale of the Horace Mann-Lincoln School building to New York City by Teachers College, Columbia University, have been deferred pending action by the higher courts, it was learned yesterday.
The Port of New York will be "wide open" to smugglers after next Wednesday when 740 Customs patrol officers receive formal notice of severance from the service.

PATERSON, N.J., March 21 -- The body of the Most Rev. Thomas Henry McLaughlin, Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Paterson, was buried today on the grounds of the Cathedral of St. John the Baptist, where the Bishop became first head of the newly created diocese nine years ago.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- The War Assets Administration directed today that competitive bidders for surplus property henceforth put up deposits as "evidence of good faith."

Rebels in the Authors Guild who have sought to unseat executive officers in the interest of "economic reforms" received something of a setback yesterday when the Appellate Division voted three to two to reverse an order of the Supreme Court giving them the right to inspect the membership list.
Both the Greater New York CIO Council and the New York State Employment Service Issued employment surveys yesterday, showing that unemployment had increased lately in the New York City area.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board refused today to undertake an investigation to see whether nine steamship companies would be justified in operating air services along with their water routes.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 21 -- A committee of the United Nations Economic and Social Council today wrote the charter for a precedent -setting economic commission for Asia and the Far East. It will have the vast task of reconstructing those war-devastated areas and strengthening and coordinating their economy.
Both up-State and here, earnest but somewhat unorganized interest in home-building is evident, Herman T. Stichman reported yesterday.

AMSTERDAM, March 21 (Aneta) -- Prices on the Stock Exchange were mixed in quiet trading while the public was awaiting interpretation of the statement made in Parliament on the Indonesian question. Industrials were generally higher, with Indies Plantations issues, banking shares and shipping stocks showing both gains and losses.
Many old marks are expected to fall by the wayside tonight when the New York Athletic Club holds its third annual interscholastic track and field games at the Twenty-second Regiment Armory.
Homer Collyer was found dead yesterday in his decaying brownstone house at 2078 Fifth Avenue, but the legend of the two recluse Collyer brothers still lives on.

The property at Rockaway Beach, Queens, known as Eagan's Seaside Villas, comprising Dorothy and Eldsea Courts and consisting of fifty-five threeand-five-room bungalows and a market, have been sold by the Medlaw Realty Corporation to the Mardrell Realty Corporation.

LONDON, March 21 -- Delegates from twenty-three nations, including the United States, Britain and Canada, have expressed agreement on the desirability of the early conclusion of an international wheat agreement during the opening sessions of the International Wheat Conference in London.

A report released here yesterday by the Maritime Commission showed that 13,196,637 tons of coal and bulk grain had been moved from United States ports in the six-month period ended Feb. 28. The movement was accomplished through the berthing of 1,571 vessels, of which 473 were foreignflag controlled.

CHICAGO. March 21 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 5,000 head; total, 9,500; market moderately active on hogs under 260 pounds but 50 to 75 cents lower; heavier weights and sows slow, 75 cents to $1 lower; practical top,

Too many national organization in this country have "nice, pious inter-racial policies worked out on paper, but don't implement them," Edward S. Lewis, executive director of the Urban League of Greater New York, asserted yesterday. Taking part in a group conference on Intercultural and Inter-racial Programs in Recreation, sponsored by the Welfare Council of New York at the Y.M.C.A.'s Sloane House, 356 West Thirty-fourth Street, he declared that such policies must be pushed ahead.

ALBANY, March 21 -- Governor Thomas E. Dewey signed today the Quinn bill extending until July 1, 1948, the period within which housing authorities may postpone the issuance of long-term bonds in favor of financing projects by the use of temporary anticipation notes.

Rosella Hightower was again the star of the Original Ballet Russe in the second performance of its spring season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. She appeared in William Dollar's "Constantia," an abstract work demanding style and easy brilliance, and in Edward Caton's "Sebastian," a seventeenth century tale of necromancy and violence which depends chiefly upon her dancing for its excitement.

PANAMA, March 21 -- Joe Hatten and Harry Taylor collaborated to hand the General Electrics, Panama League champions, their second successive whitewashing by the Dodgers, 5 to 0. Scarcely more than 500 fans turned out for the Brooks' farewell appearance in the Isthmus, perhaps because they could not scent a victory.

Commodore Robert G. Tobin, port director of the Third Naval District, presented the Navy Reserve pennant and an accompanying warrant to Capt. John C. Scott, master of the Mormacwave, in a brief ceremony yesterday on the bridge of the ship, tied up at Pier 32, North River.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Sava N. Kosanovitch, the Yugoslav Ambassador, declared today that his country badly needed food from abroad, saying that "the ration in Yugoslavia today is a ration of hunger."

BADEN, Germany, March 19 (Delayed) -- The French zone of occupation in Germany has become self-supporting, Maurice Half, Director of Economics and Finance of the French Military Government, said today.

Swiss watch manufacturers are uraging an excessive expansion of the watch importing industries in the United States without giving due consideration to American importers, A.A. Harman, president, Harman Watch Company, importers of Swiss watch movements, stated yesterday.

Reduction in normal mark-ups on certain advertised merchandise to bolster lagging unit sales has been reinstituted by many independent furniture stores after a lapse of nearly five years, it was learned yesterday. Retailers emphasized that it bears little resemblance to outright clearance price reductions and will probably result in an increase in overall dollar volume.

NANKING, March 21 (AP) -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek was reported reliably to have told his party leaders today that he expected financial aid from the United States and that it would be spent for national reconstruction and not to fight the Communists.

PARIS, March 21 -- French Socialists hope for a peace bid from Viet Nam to provide a way out of the deadlock over Indo-China and to serve as an excuse for postponing the vote of confidence, scheduled for tomorrow.

Action yesterday by the Office of International Trade of the Department of Commerce in removing heavy cattle hides and leathers made from them from export control, effective April 1, met with a mixed reception in the shoe and leather trade here.

Tippy Larkin was again the master boxer in his ten-round bout with Billy Graham of the East Side at Madison Square Garden last night. The Garfield (N.J.) veteran, rebounding admirably after the surprise knockout suffered at the hands of Charley Fusari last month, hooked and jabbed his way to a convincing triumph over his New York foe before a crowd of 14,054 spectators.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Demands for changes in wages and working rules on the railroads, covering 1,400,000 employes, will be served on the carriers within the next few days, It was learned today.

Addressing a group of editors of the foreign-language press and leaders of foreign-language organizations last night, Lieut. Gen. Raymond S. McLain made a plea for support of universal military training. He spoke at an AllAmerica conference at the Seventyfirst Regiment Armory, Thirtythird Street and Park Avenue.

Lack of public health agencies will hamper the progress of voluntary agencies on a nation-wide scale, Dr. Haven Emerson, member of the Board of Health and an executive of the American Public Health Association, declared yesterday at the annual meeting of the National Health Council at the Hotel Barbizon-Plaza.

MOSCOW, March 21 -- Britain has received 350,000 tons of shipping among the reparations thus far received from Germany, Foreign Secretary Bevin announced today in the Council of Foreign Ministers' meeting.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The continuation of rent control through Feb. 29, 1948, without an "across-the-board" increase was unanimously favored today by a rent subcommittee of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Camille Gutt, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, sees little danger that any country will try to misuse the fund's exchange facilities, he said here today. Mr. Gutt prepared to leave tomorrow for a six-week tour of Western Europe, during which he will visit Britain, France, the Netherlands, Belgium, Denmark and Norway, all members of the fund.

PHILADELPHIA, March 21 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it has under consideration changes in the rules under the Investment Company Act and invited investment companies and other interested persons to submit comment prior to April 10.

ONE indication of the inflationary trend in some quarters is the price of dead cats. A bulletin issued recently by the College of the City of New York announced a boost of one dollar a semester in its biology laboratory fees -- what with the cost of dead cats for laboratory work up from $3 each to $6, and lobsters for the same purpose, once $65 a hundred, now up to $140.

Last September the Columbia Broadcasting System applied to the Federal Communications Commission for permission to erect and use a single station for the transmission of television images in color. A storm of protest arose from the Radio Corporation of America, Philco Corporation, DuMont Laboratories, Radio Manufacturers Association and the Television Broadcasters Association.

LONDON, March 22 (Reuters) -- The struggle for the championship of the English Football League grew closer today when the leaders, the Wolverhampton Wonderers, bowed to Sheffield United and second-place Blackpool moved within a single game of the top by defeating Grimsby.

THE world premieres of five ballets, all of them by young American choreographers, are on the agenda this week, with three producing organizations involved. To take them chronologically, Jerome Robbins has composed a "Pas de Trois" for Alicia Markova, Anton Dolin and Andre Eglevsky, which will have its first presentation tonight in the Original Ballet Russe's program at the Metropolitan.

NEW ORLEANS, March 22 (U.P.) -- CIO and AFL merchant seamen picketed offices of the United States Maritime Commission and the States Marine Corporation here today to protest "transfer of an American ship to foreign registry," which, it was said, would be manned by a crew of "shanghaied" Norwegian sailors.

LOS ANGELES, March 22 -- Col. Robert B. McCormick, editor and publisher of The Chicago Tribune, declared here that American participation in the affairs of Greece was the inevitable consequence of the cycle of war and peace.
DALLAS, March 22 -- That part of Texas sentiment which can be sounded on the President's proposed aid to Greece and Turkey regards it as interventionist, but seems to believe it justified.
Peter Jarrett, Hawaiian pianist, who made his New York debut yesterday afternoon at Town Hall, may be put down as a deeply musical young man with real gifts.

Brandishing a 3 1/2 -inch pocket knife, a burly chauffeur, 6 feet 3 inches tall and weighing 195 pounds, terrorized a hundred passengers in a crowded car of an IND subway train at the York Street station in Brooklyn last night.

There are two broad schools of opinion on how a budget surplus, should one emerge in fiscal 1948, could be utilized most effectively. One school places major emphasis on the importance of debt reduction; the other stresses tax relief.
Consumer purchases of spring ready-to-wear apparel and accessories improved here last week. Department store volume for the week ended March 22 was estimated as about 8 to 10 per cent over last year.

SHANGHAI, March 22 -- Back in Chungking, members of the American Nelson Mission, which helped establish the War Production Board there, termed Dr. Ruth Y.H. Feng the "George Washington Carver of China." If that characterization is valid, the 40year-old scientist remains a prophet without honor in her own country at a time when her textile process might be especially useful.

MOSCOW, March 22 -- The Council of Foreign Ministers completed the initial stage of its Moscow meeting this evening -- that of the individual presentation of national views on Germany's future. This phase was concluded in record time and in an atmosphere of broad generalized harmony, which exceeded some preliminary hopes.

BERLIN, March 22 -- United States officials flatly denied today a report that shipments of steel and iron from the economically merged American and British zones to the Russian zone had been either slowed down or cut off entirely.

Five youths and two juveniles were rounded up yesterday and charged with a series of armed hold-ups because an alert patrolman, three weeks on the force, followed through on a summons he had issued to a driver for passing a red light.

VANCOUVER, B.C. -- While snow still blankets the Canadian prairie, spring has unlocked the green valleys of British Columbia. The gentle Chinook winds in the Dominion come first of all to the vast Province which lies along the Pacific Ocean.

Material for 1,200 tons of paper for the publishing of literature on the rehabilitation program of the World Council of Churches in Europe has been bought in Sweden with American Protestant funds, it was learned here yesterday. The literature will be distributed principally in Germany.

Under a five-year plan for improving the working conditions, efficiency and standard of living of workers in India, "industrial undertakings which do not provide a decent standard of living for their workers can have no social claim to survival," according to Jagjivan Ram, Labor Member of the Interim Government of India.

Three hundred campaigns of this type, fifty of which are of major caliber, are being carried on in New York. As is the case with the National Society for Crippled Children and Adults, which is conducting its annual Easter seal sale, many contributors support the campaign but actually know little of the organization and its program.

PITTSBURGH, March 22 (AP) -- Irregular operations in steel at exorbitant prices are disturbing some sections of the nation's steel and scrap industries. Some big concerns deny the existence of such business, known in the trade here as the "gray market"; others admit its existence but say the tremendous tonnages that are being offered are non-existent, but another major basic steel producer admits that the problem is "serious."

Disclosure last week by the Consumer Distribution Corporation of its intention to open next year three streamlined co-operative department stores, community owned, brought into sharp focus the original plans conceived some ten years ago by the late E.A. Filene, Boston merchant.
MOSCOW, March 22 (U.P.) -- Yuri Zhukov, correspondent for Izvestia, Government newspaper, said today that sensational American newspapers were "perverting and crippling" the minds of readers.

CAMDEN, S.C., March 23 -- Clifton's Ruler, a gray gelding owned by Ernest Mahler of Chinquapin Farm, Tryon, N.C., captured the hunter championship of the thirty-fourth annual Camden horse show, held today in the Marion DuPont Scott show ring.

MEXICO CITY, March 22 (AP) -- The Mexican Baseball League, backed by the multi-millionaire sportsman, Jorge Pasquel, has ceased to be a get-rich-quick haven for United States players having contract difficulties with the Nationnal and American Leagues.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 22 (AP) -- Lashing out at "certain commercially controlled organizations in this "country and Canada that use the name amateur," Edward W. Stanley of Clinton, N.Y., speaking at a meeting of the United States Olympic Hockey Committee at Brown University today, declared that the ousting of the A.A. U. from the International Ice Hockey League now provided an opportunity for the organization of amateur hockey "free from professionalism."

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- An echo of last summer's outburst in the bitter feud between Supreme Court Justices Robert H. Jackson and Hugo L. Black rumbled out of the Senate Judiciary Committee today. The justices will not have to face a Congressional inquiry after all.

DETROIT, March 22 (U.P.) -- A one-man grand jury tonight climaxed an 18-month, search for the killer of Lydia Thompson, victim of one of Michigan's most savage mutilation slayings, by indicting her widower and his second wife on first degree murder charges.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The United States proposes to establish diplomatic relations with Nepal, the mountain kingdom of 7,000,000 inhabitants between Tibet and India, through negotiations to be conducted by a mission headed by Joseph C. Satterthwaite, Foreign Service officer now attached to the State Department.

One of the most dashing and popular figures in tennis in years gone by returns to action on the courts of New York this week for the first time in more than a decade.

AS further evidence of the vitality of the current theatre, take note of "Brigadoon," by Alan Jay Lerner and Frederick Loewe. In a fantasy about an imagined Scottish village it has fulfilled an old theatre ideal of weaving music, dancing and story into a single fabric of brightness and enchantment.

STUTTGART, Germany, March 22 (AP) -- Two masked gunmen broke into the bedroom of Rheinold Hub, 41 years old, a Communist, in Oehringen today and shot him to death in the first slaying of a German denazification official in the United States occupation zone.

AT the age of four a child takes everything in his life for granted. His home, his mother and father, his pets make up his small world and are accepted casually. At the age of five he begins to sense the differences and changes which go on directly around him.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: One of the vital sections of the proposed legislation for unification of the armed forces which President Truman has sent to Congress is that providing for the establishment of a Central Intelligence Agency.

PARIS, March 22 -- The Government crisis was surmounted today by agreement that the Communists in the Assembly might abstain from voting on military credits for the forces in Indo-China so long as their Ministers voted for those credits and remained in the Cabinet.

HYAK, Wash., March 22 -- A 22year-old Ishpeming, Mich., mountain trooper, Joey Perrault, won the opening-day honors of the Olympic ski jumping tryouts today on Olympian Hill in the Milwaukee Road Ski Bowl.

Eleven days after one of the most important foreign policy statements in our history there is an opportunity for another statement which will present American foreign policy not just in one aspect but in all its aspects. The Truman program, as originally announced, has won powerful support in both parties.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Senator Elbert D. Thomas, Democrat, of Utah, suggested in a broadcast tonight that the Ruhr as well as other disputed areas be placed under the trusteeship of the United Nations in the interests of world peace.

BRANCHING away from fiction, John Brophy, who is better known in his native England than in this country, has produced the first full-length, popular study of a fascinating subject. The only comparable treatise is "Apology for Beards," an allegory written by a twelfthcentury Cistercian abbot.

Accountancy is generally recognized as a skilled profession. In New York State the title of Certified Public Accountant was created by an act of Legislature in 1896. Since then accountancy has become a regular part of university and college curricula throughout the country, and the standard of academic requirements for eligibility ranks equal to that of other professions.

ASSIGNED the task of slaying the Lernaean hydra, Hercules found out that for each of its nine heads he cut off, two new ones would grow; so he resorted to a more "scientific" method: he burnt out the root of each head, and since the center one was immortal, he buried it beneath a great rock.

MILTON BERLE, an afterdark idol in Broadway social circles, again has transferred his brittle and impromptu patter to the airwaves, this time turning up as replacement for Rudy Vallee's ill-fated venture on Tuesday evenings (8 o'clock) over NBC.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 22 -- Armed, the greatest attraction ever offered at this young seaside course, set a new track record as he easily captured the $30,350 Gulfstream Park Handicap today. His Calumet Farm stable-mate, Pot o' Luck, was second, a length behind.

Debut and Encore concerts gave three more musicians a third of a chance late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. They were Olga Coelho, soprano-guitarist; Adrian Fisher, pianist, and Hugh Thompson, baritone.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The Corcoran Gold Medal and the first W.A. Clark prize of $2,000 was awarded today to Sigmund Menkes, New York artist, for his entry, "Day's End, 1946," in the Twentieth Biennial Exhibition of contemporary American oil paintings sponsored by the Corcoran Gallery of Art.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- John L. Lewis and the United Mine Workers face a double jeopardy in attempting to arrive at a working agreement with the soft coal operators by June 30.

ATHENS, March 22 (AP) -- The Greek Government imposed martial law tonight throughout the Prefecture of Laconia in the Peloponnesus at the southern tip of the Greek mainland. The Cabinet acted as a result of the tense situation created by the massacre by Rightists, of thirty-nine Leftist prisoners yesterday in a jail at Gythium.

Portraits of six American generals in occupied Germany, painted by the Polish artist Boleslaw Jan Czedekowski soon after their victories, were placed on exhibit last week at the Kosciusko Foundation House, 15 East Sixty-fifth Street.

How the crew of a helicopter, maneuvering their aircraft so close to rough Caribbean waters that the nose wheel dipped into the swell, succeeded in rescuing an injured naval airman was told here yesterday by the rescuers.

Established in 1929 to study the culture of Iran, Asia Institutes has expanded its original program and now offers the most extensive course of studies dealing with the Orient and the Far East in this country.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 22 -- A United States Army C-47 transport plane crashed in a mountainous, desolate area of Ethiopia on Thursday killing its six American occupants, including two State Department officials, according to word received here today.

The majority of the American people are in favor of President Truman's foreign and domestic policies and "overwhelmingly" in favor of his attitude toward Russia, William A. Lydgate, editor of the Gallup Poll, declared yesterday.

Replacement of the American Export Lines "Four Aces," which were well-known passenger vessels in pre-war days, drew one step closer with the announcement yesterday that bids will soon go out for the reconversion of five "Exporter" type vessels, four to be made passenger ships.

Airline operators believe that the industry has passed its crisis and that operating improvement is assured, provided the industry in prosperity does not lapse to its former foibles. All the dire predictions made at the beginning of the year concerning the revenues, traffic and earnings of the domestic airlines have materialized.

MOSCOW, March 22 -- British Foreign Secretary Bevin submitted to the Council of Foreign Ministers today a detailed plan designed to increase the level of German industry and to determine by Aug. 15 how many industrial units should be removed from the conquered nation.

IT is not often that a historian's first book shows the range of learning, psychological insight and balanced judgment that are abundantly in evidence in this contribution made by Professor Cecil Driver of Yale to the massive literature on the history of British social reform.

The Export-Import Bank is carving out a new niche for itself in the pattern of organizations already established and being established in the field of international lending, foreign traders pointed out last week. The bank's new role will be in the field of stimulating imports into the United States to fill the $7,000,000,000 gap between exports and imports.

TO THE EDITOR: Foster Hailey deals most superficially with a profound subject in "Too Many People on the Land." Specifically he says: "It is not surprising that the Chinese Communists' program for more equitable land distribution should be so appealing to the Chinese peasant."
CHICAGO, March 22 -- In this part of the country, once regarded as a hotbed of isolationism, a sharp cleavage of opinion marked the reaction to President Truman's message to Congress.

MOSCOW, March 22 -- The United States, Britain and Russiathree of four great powers gathered in this sprawling capital to settle Germany's future -- wish to fashion the Fourth Reich more or less in their own image. France is the only one of the Big Four to have escaped this national Narcissus complex.

BALTIMORE, March 22 (AP) -- C. Dorsey Warfield, publisher of The Baltimore News-Post, fell to his death from a twelfth-floor window in his apartment at the Warrington Apartments on fashionable North Charles Street early this morning, the police said.

ALBANY, March 22 -- Now that the 170th session of the State Legislature has adjourned sine die after eleven weeks of controversy, the question uppermost in many minds is the effect of its decisions on the political future of Governor Thomas E. Dewey.

BOSTON, March 22 -- New England is overwhelmingly in favor of President Truman's plan for checking Russian expansion by giving aid to Greece and Turkey. Sentiment in this sense is universal, crossing political party lines and without respect to the economic position of individuals.

Unleashing a powerful secondhalf attack that brought eight goals, the New York Athletic Club trio got off on the right foot in the national junior championship tournament last night by whipping the Turtles, 15 to 12, in the star match of the indoor polo twin-bill at the Squadron A Armory.

JEALOUSY, usually a state considered normal for lovers and crackpots, can be a terrible thing, as Dr. Sokoloff points out quite clearly in this psychiatric study. A practicing psychiatrist (and, presumably, a psychoanalyst, or one convinced of the truth of the Freudian concepts), the author illustrates his studies with case histories of patients whose lives have been warped by jealousy and not a few in which murder has been the end result.

DR. KNUDSON is dean emeritus of the Boston University School of Theology. He has traveled, studied, thought and written widely. His is no narrow field, his scope is not limited by any restrictive religious concept, and he does not divorce the material from the spiritual.

THERE is no happening in the world of books just like the advent of another Dard Hunter creation. The necessarily limited number of copies in each of the editions produced by the Mountain House Press alone cannot account for book lovers' enthusiasm.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- Any newsprint concern which plans to saw into Alaska's untouched forests must also process its logs there, Interior Secretary J.A. Krug has ordered.

NANKING, March 22 -- A resolution demanding the dismissal of Gen. Chen Yi, Governor General of Formosa, was adopted by an overwhelming majority by the Central Executive Committee of the Kuomintang [Government party] today.

RICHMOND, March 22 -- Opinion on President Truman's proposal for large-scale aid to Greece and Turkey has not jelled in this region, although such indices to public opinion as exist appear to indicate that sentiment is tentatively favorable.

SANTA ANA, Calif., March 22 (AP) -- Beulah Louise Overell, 17year-old heiress, and her fiance George R. Gollum, 21, were arraigned today on a charge of murdering her wealthy parents aboard their yacht, which was blown up in Newport harbor last Saturday night.

CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand, March 22 (Reuters) -- Walter Hammond, making his farewell test cricket appearance -- his eightyfifth test for England -- came to England's rescue today with a grand innings of 79 and helped in the fifth wicket partnership of 97 with John Ikin.

BOYS and girls of the fourth, fifth and sixth grades from P.S. 151, and from the near-by parochial school of Our Lady of Good Counsel, share the arts and crafts, music, games and class "clubs" at the public school's recreation center. Ninetyfirst Street and First Avenue.
The news of last week made it abundantly clear that the most important long-term issues involved in President Truman's new foreign policy are economic and social.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Senate Republicans failed today in an attempt to agree on a policy with respect to extension of controls over rents and sugar. President Truman said prompt Congressional action was "urgently needed."

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- One hundred and twenty-three years ago Daniel Webster rose in the House of Representatives and placed before its members the fundamental question that lay before the Congress this week.

ON May 11, 1792, Capt. Robert Gray conned a stubby little vessel across a perilous bar and entered a river whose existence had been suspected, rumored, disputed and denied for two centuries. Gray named the stream the Columbia for his ship.

The annual meeting of the marine section of the National Safety Council will be held in conjunction with the meeting's of the Greater New York Safety Council, opening on Tuesday at the Pennsylvania Hotel, it was announced yesterday.

THE cities visited by the Metropolitan Opera have a hand in selecting the operas they see. The repertoire of the tour, therefore, gives an indication of the country's operatic taste which seems to be changing "Madame Butterfly" will be done in eight cities.

Irregularly higher prices were posted again yesterday on the stock market with interest centered in the air transport division. A rise of 0.31 point was scored by the composite rate, with some wider additions in a few selected issues.

YOU can still borrow books from the library that once supplied John Adams, Aaron Burr, Washington living and De Witt Clinton with reading matter. You may not, like John Jay, borrow Plutarch, or Emmerich Vattel's "The Law of Nations" a tome perused by George Washington during a Congressional recess -- but whatever your interest, you are sure to satisfy it among the well-stacked shelves of the New York Society Library.

FORT WORTH, Tex., March 22 (U.P.) -- Texas A. and M. College, strong in all events, today swept to victory in the University Division of the twenty-fourth annual Southwest recreation track and field meet by defeating Texas University, 48 3/5 points to 46.

HOLLYWOOD. THE nineteenth annual presentation of awards by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences added up to a personal triumph for Samuel Goldwyn, but produced deep gloom at the major studios because Goldwyn's sweep left them only crumbs.

HAVANA, March 22 -- Aided by a couple of errors and one or two timely hits, the Dodgers today chalked up another victory, this time over the Cuban All-Stars, beating- them by 5 to 2 before a slim crowd in Gran Stadium.
SARASOTA, Fla., March 22 -- Organized baseball is getting set here this week-end to wash an accumulation of its soiled linen.

DUBLIN, March 22-- Ireland's celebration of St. Patrick's Day this week had little of the traditional gaiety associated with the national festival. This was mainly because of the grave plight of the agricultural industry and the worst floods in years both in Eire and Northern Ireland.

BADEN, Germany, March 20 (Delayed) -- The United States and Britain have exerted unfair economic pressure in retaliation for the French refusal to join them in the zonal economic merger, Maurice Half, the French zone's Director of Economics and Finance, said today in an interview.

Over 'Truman Doctrine' The "Truman Doctrine," enunciated by the President on March 12, had sharp repercussions last week: First, a broad debate began in Congress and in the nation on American foreign policy; second, the impact was felt in the Conference of Foreign Ministers in Moscow.

FIFTY centuries of man's effort to define graphically the world in which he lived may be seen, for the asking, in New York today. "It is not too much to say," thinks Francis Henry Taylor of the Metropolitan Museum, that this city "has come to be for the mid-twentieth century what London and Paris were to the nineteenth."

MOSCOW, March 22 -- The establishment of a German national council as the provisional government at an early date was advocated by United States Secretary of State Marshall in the Council of Foreign Ministers' meeting tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- Motorists' complaints over widespread increases in gasoline prices the last two weeks have started an inquiry by the justice department's anti-trust division. Two governors, Mon C. Wallgren of Washington and Earl Warren of California, joined in criticizing the increases and in asking an inquiry by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

Hopes of isolating the theoretical virus of the dread Hodgkins Disease are growing brighter, Dr. Herman A. Hoster, president of the newly formed Hodgkins Disease Research Foundation told a group of scientists yesterday. He addressed a meeting of the foundation in the Spellman wing of St. Vincent's Hospital.

In view of the new foreign policy charted by President Truman, THE NEW YORK TIMES asked its correspondents in ten sections of the country to report on the attitudes in their areas on the nation's role in world affairs.

WASHINGTON. WHITE HOUSE telephone service was handled exclusively by men from 1878, when the first instrument was put in, until the morning of March 7, 1933 -- just fourteen years ago -- when a brunette Brunhilde timidly took over.
MILWAUKEE, March 22 -- Bars to the counting of additional challenged ballots in the hotly contested bargaining election at the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company were dropped today.

THAT great thoroughbred Man o' War -- who retired from racing (though it is sometimes hard to realize) 'way back in 1921 -- is celebrating his thirtieth birthday this week and may well be on the way to another record, in the equine longevity stakes.

An appeal to Americans of foreign extraction to help the displaced peoples of Europe was voiced yesterday by George M. Mardikian, noted restaurateur and "United Nations chef" at the San Francisco Conference in 1945. Mr. Mardikian returned from Europe last week after a four and a half month survey of food conditions in the Army for the War Department.

FLOWERING plants from the indoor window garden can lead a double life if they are made ready for shifting to summer quarters now. Left to their own devices, only a few house plants have the stamina to go on producing blossoms outdoors.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 22 -- With perhaps the idea in mind that a habit formed early may in time become a fixture, the Yankees today gave the other half of last fall's World Series cast a goingover that was much on the lines of what they gave the Cardinals a few days ago.

ONE of the phenomena thrown up by World War II is an Armenian-born portrait photographer, Yousuf Karsh. Scarcely known beyond the confines of his adopted Ottawa, the 33-year-old Karsh became a dazzling camera luminary with his portrait of Winston Churchill.

WILLIAM BLAKE wanted to write a one-man Bible. He felt he had outdone Rousseau, Voltaire, Swedenborg, Milton, Shakespeare, Dante, Virgil and Homer. He thought some of his artistic productions outclassed Michelangelo and Raphael; certainly Reynolds, Rembrandt and Rubens.
ALBANY, March 22 -- More than 100 delegates to the Conference on Child Development and Parent Education brought their three-day conference to an end today with a series of informal discussions.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 22 -- All present signs point to the enactment by Congress of labor laws that will not be in the interest of industrial harmony, Senator Wayne Morse, Republican, of Oregon, told the first annual Public Affairs Conference of the Yale Law School Student Association here tonight.

Until recent years there seemed little need for a constitutional limit on the number of terms a President of the United States might serve. From time to time the issue of a third term was raised on behalf of some popular leader, but tradition and the advice of the Founding Fathers proved too strong to be overcome.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- A series of National Labor Relations Board decisions modifying its early doctrines provoked a sharp attack by the Congress of Industrial Organizations today.
The debate over the post-war money market that has accompanied the year's retirement of more than a quarter of a billion dollars of public debt is rising in intensity.

LOS ANGELES, March 22 -- The United States' stiffening policy toward Russia has evoked general, if somewhat perplexed, approval on the Pacific Coast and crystallized a new consciousness of America's involvement in world affairs.

MEXICO CITY. IT is said that when Fra Domingo de la Anunciacion arrived on burro-back in Tepoztlan late in the sixteenth century under orders from his Dominican superiors to Christianize the heathen, he was appalled by the moral laxity of the native Tepoztecos.

THOUGH it fails to live up to the promise of its title, which is too ambitious (and historically questionable as well), nevertheless this book contains much excellent story-telling and vividly presents many dramatic and significant scenes in the early history of Boston that are of perennial interest to all Americans.

Back in 1936 Mrs. Dorothy J. Manice of Augusta, Ga., was reading a golf magazine in which the women champions of that year were listed. Being a golfer of promience herself, Mrs. Manice suddenly decided that a tournament in which only champions competed would be a very excellent event.

Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., has completely recamped its system of distribution of appliance orders taken by company representatives as agents for manufacturers, distributors and 896 cooperating dealers, Brig. Gen. E.T. Jeffe, vice president in charge of sales, disclosed during an interview last week.

CAMDEN, N.J., March 22 -- Following the collapse of negotiations between the Campbell Soup Company and union officials for a new contract, the company informed its employes today that the existing contract would end at midnight tonight.

VIRGINIA CITY, Nevada, was a city state sprung up in a desert wilderness. It was wholly dependent on a mountain of precious metals and ruled by the ever-changing ups and downs of mineral production. For a time during the Eighteen Seventies it was fabulously prosperous.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The report by the President's Temporary Commission on Employe Loyalty, released by President Truman today, provides for the first time a systematic program for weighing loyalty to the United States Government with other qualifications in determining a person's eligibility for a Federal job.

JOHN STBUART CURRY is as American as a cornfield, as Midwestern as the Missouri River. Born a Kansan, he went away at the age of 19 to study art. He went back to Kansas periodically but, as the natives would say, he never settled down there. Eleven years ago he went to Wisconsin, and died there last year.

CHICAGO, March 22 (AP) -- Corn exhibited strength on the board of trade today following the overnight announcement of May export allocations. Corn exports will be increased in April, taking the place to some extent of wheat.

After four months of needless fighting around the Indonesian ports and a growing bitterness among the men who must work together if there is to be peace in the Netherlands Indies, it appears that the agreement negotiated at Linggajati, Java, last November is at last to be put into effect.

SALT LAKE CITY, March 22 (U.P.) -- Einar Fredbo, proclaimed by most ski enthusiasts as the foremost "ski jumping stylist" in the nation, was electrocuted tonight at Magna, Utah, where he was working as a lineman for the Salt Lake County line department.

TO THE EDITOR: The article, "Prescription for a New Kind of Opera," by Howard Taubman has been, I am sure, most encouraging to those who are looking forward to a progressive conception of opera in America.

THIS little book by Dr. Case, formerly dean of the University of Chicago Divinity School and now dean of the School of Religion at Lakewood, Fla, is written for a wide audience. In a simple, precise style, with a minimum of references or exhaustive analyses, Dr. Case argues against the importance of supernaturalism for the Christian faith.
LONDON, March 22 -- Calculations of the prospects for European economic recovery are being seriously upset by the long delay of the International Bank in beginning lending operations.

ANDRE BRETON, the father of Surrealism, has been living among us almost incognito in self-imposed exile for the past five years. As a farewell token to the American reading public he leaves behind a little volume containing a chronological sampling of his poems, old and new, representative of the movement he initiated some twenty-five years ago and of which he has remained the leading spokesman.

SAVE THE CHILDREN FEDERATION is making an appeal for flower and vegetable seeds to be used for school and home gardens in needy rural parts of the United States. Contributions of any kind of seeds can be sent to "Children, 8 Washington Place, New York 3."

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations submitted proposed changes in the Federal tax laws to the House Ways and Means Committee today. The suggestions call for a tax structure "which will promote full employment through giving complete encouragement to maximum purchasing power."
NOW here you have it: the National Academy, pristine, unbolstered by outside talent, decorously and impavidly keeping house all by itself.
LONDON, March 22 -- The British Government is opposed to any cession of Cyprus to Greece, it was learned authoritatively today.

IF you would cherish the memory of your wedding day, it can be arranged so that you will never forget a moment of it. A Newark, N.J., man has made a business of recording wedding rites. He puts the whole ceremony on unbreakable disks which will last long enough to be played on the family phonograph to celebrate the golden wedding anniversary.

The State Legislature before its adjournment last week, despite last-minute disapproval of the bill to increase the top limits of savings bank life insurance from $3,000 to $5,000, generally acted along the progressive lines regarding bank legislation, financial observers asserted yesterday.

ALBANY, March 22 -- Governor Dewey flatly supported today President Truman's request for a United States political loan to Greece. The Governor made his position clear in a proclamation designating Tuesday as Greek War Relief Day.

James P. Warburg, banker and former deputy director of the Office of War Information, said yesterday the people of the United States have the right to pass judgment on the recent proposal of President Truman to give immediate aid to Greece and Turkey.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The State Department was busy today preparing answers to more than 100 "very intelligent, fair and useful questions" from Congress on President Truman's Greek-Turkish aid program. The queries were assembled by Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, president pro tempore of the Senate.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Republicans presented the issue of how much President Truman's budget should be cut to a SenateHouse conference committee today, and a deadlock promptly resulted.

GREENSBORO, N.C., March 22 -- With what he termed "the best competitive round I ever played," amateur Frank Stranahan of Toledo today moved into the halfway lead of the $10,000 Greensboro 72-hole open golf tournament by one stroke with a total of 140.

SALONIKA, Greece, March 22 -- A tense uneasy quiet prevailed this week in the rugged mountain areas where the borders of Greece meet the frontiers of Yugoslavia, Bulgaria and Albania -- one of Europe's primary "zones of strain" -- while the United Nations Commission continued to hear evidence regarding responsibility for past incidents and attempted to find a formula to prevent new ones.

THE motion picture industry may have gone West, but it still induiges some of its well-known penchant for the colossal in New York City, which is why William Kelly is never out of work.
