Kelly is a camera man, or director of photography, and one of the five members of Local 644, I.A.T.S.E., who specialize in shooting New York sequences for Hollywood productions.

CLIFTON, N.J., March 22 -- Efforts to avert a strike of clerical and drafting employes of the Federal Telephone and Radio Corporation, manufacturing subsidiary of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, failed today, with each side to the dispute questioning the action of the other during the final hours of a truce agreement.

LONDON, March 22 (AP) -- Flood waters burst tonight through sandbagged dikes and spread ruin over 25,000 acres of fertile Norfolk Fenlands in the latest weather disaster to hit that section of agricultural England.

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 22 -- Champion Rip of Blue Bar, English setter owned by C.N. Myers of Hanover, Pa., won his sixth bestin-show trophy tonight at the twelfth annual dog show of the Harrisburg Kennel Club in the State Farm Show Building.

CHICAGO, March 22 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 500 head (estimated): total not elven. Compared with week ago: market $1 to S1.75 lower: most declines on hogs above 280 pounds and on sows.

FOR THIS WEEK: Sow sweet peas and garden peas as soon as the soil is dry enough. Larkspur also must be planted as soon as possible. . . . Prune roses whenever weather permits. Removing deadwood is the first step, then shortening canes according to the size and quantity of bloom desired. . . . Loosen the heaviest coverings around plants so that air can circulate, but do not remove them yet.

POLAND has inaugurated a "Famous Poles" series. A letter from the postal administration to Scott Publications, Inc., mentions last names only, but the Polish Press Agency in New York identifies the persons being recalled.

Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School, whose track prestige suffered two weeks ago when it lost the C.H.S.A.A. crown to Mount St. Michael, retrieved some of it last night by scoring 21 1/2 points for a narrow victory in the New York Athletic Club's third annual interscholastic track meet at the Twenty-second Regiment Armory.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial on "All Weather Flying" properly emphasizes a point overlooked by the public. The announcement that a striking new chemical has been discovered or a new process or machine has been invented is usually accompanied by extravagant claims which are sometimes made by the discoverer or the inventor, but more often by those who have little real understanding of science, technology or the problems of operation.

Gilbert Dodos may write a new indoor mile record into the books this week. The wind-up of the board-track campaign presents the Iron Deacon with three opportunities to level at the mark of 4:06.4 he set in Chicago in 1944. Conditions will be favorable for fast time in at least two of his engagements.

WILLIAM C. DURANT: On March 18, at New York City, age 85. Pioneer automobile manufacturer and founder of the General Motors Corporation, was for many years a spectacular stock market manipulator who won and lost more than one fortune. At one time his wealth was estimated at $120,000,000.

AMSTERDAM. MUSICAL Holland, where the Rodzinski-Judson explosion was heard as only a faint echo, is heading for its own show-down over the Mighty Manager. A foundation called "Stichting Nederlandsch Impresariaat" has just been formed, with offical support, which hopes to threaten the position of the established private managers.

TEL AVIV, March 22 -- Although breathing more freely in their first unrestricted week-end this month after the lifting of the martial law, more than 200,000 residents of the world's only all-Jewish city are wondering today what comes next. "Thank God that's over, but is it going to happen again soon?" is their attitude.

THE theatre, never exactly a dull institution, is about to add another feature to its continuous round of pleasures calculated to give surcease from contemplation of the international situation. Two weeks from tonight, Easter Sunday night to be exact, the first of an annual series of events will be given in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

JERUSALEM, March 22 -- A miniature arsenal was found by British troops today when, using the latest type of magnetic detectors, they searched the barren, rocky ground and olive groves of northern Jerusalem.

PHILADELPHIA, March 22 -- Bobby Riggs added the world indoor professional tennis championship to his outdoor title tonight when he defeated Don Budge, 6 -- 1, 8 -- 6, 6 -- 3, in the final of The Philadelphia Inquirer charities tournament before a capacity crowd of 6,400.
The colorful names given to Pullman cars is one of the profitable specialities for paint manufacturers who will participate in a $100,000,000 program for 737 domestic railroads.

POSTPONEMENT last week of plans for the staging of an all-star show at Madison Square Garden in behalf of the American National Theatre and Academy came as another blow at the already badly battered American Repertory Theatre.

THE story of Jesus of Nazareth as it was known to St. Thomas is the theme of Miss Malvern's sympathetic, straightforward narrative. From his prison cell, awaiting the martyrdom he does not fear, the venerable Apostle is imagined as sending forth this version of the Good News of the Son of God.

ALDEN BLAND, the Negro author of this short novel, has none of the power of a Richard Wright. His style is jerky, sometimes making it as difficult to follow his story as it is to discern what he is getting at. There is bitterness from the Negro viewpoint, and there is wisdom, too, when at the end one of the characters says, "Maybe it just happened."

Common Cause, Inc., 1775 Broadway, made public yesterday an appeal issued by prominent Yugoslavs to the American public to prevent forced repatriation of 35,000 Yugoslav ex-prisoners of war and refugees now in the British and American zones.
MOSCOW, March 22 -- A design for a planned economy for the Soviet zone of occupation in Germany, along lines similar to those prevailing here, was revealed today.

A PRELIMINARY report by the Chesapeake Ohio Railway on its charge-it-asyou-go plan, inaugurated Jan. 27, indicates such wide acceptance of the travel credit program as to offer "sufficient grounds to claim it already a success."

NEWARK, N.J., March 22 -- Two Republican and one Democratic Representative, who completed a two-day hearing here this afternoon, investigating the causes of jurisdictional strikes, returned to Washington tonight prepared to recommend new legislation or changes in existing measures as a solution for the problem.

NEWARK, N.J., March 22 -- Army captured the first National Intercollegiate Indoor Polo championship since pre-war days tonight by scoring a 10-8 victory over Yale before 2,000 spectators at Essex Troop Armory.

Nearly 3,300 delegates to the Columbia Scholastic Press Association convention were told yesterday to become "the builders of tomorrow's road" by Col. Hans Christian Adamson, author of "Eddie Rickenbacker," at the final convention luncheon in the Hotel Astor.

ABOARD MOUNT OLYMPUS, March 22 -- Within the next four weeks virtually all of the Navy's Antarctic explorers will have returned to East or West Coast ports, it was learned today as this vessel neared half-way in her three weeks' voyage from Wellington to Panama.

The New York Rangers bring the local season of the National Hockey League to a close tonight, when they skate against the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden. The game will be a meeting between the two teams in the circuit that are not going anywhere, but it is expected, nevertheless, that a near-capacity crowd of 15,000 fans will turn out to see it.

M.I. Behrens, vice president and general manager of Ludwig Baumann, was honored at a luncheon in the Hotel McAlpin tendered him by leaders in the home-furnishings industry. The event was marked by presentation of the 1946 Cavalier Award to Mr. Behrens as "the merchant who best served his industry, his country and his community in 1946."

The performance of Prokofieff's Violin Concerto, No. 1, with Isaac Stern as soloist, was the special feature of the concert given by the Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra, with Efrem Kurtz as guest conductor, last night at Carnegie Hall.

Developments during the past week affecting financial markets indicated that both Congress and the public were awakening to the economic problems confronting the country. There was less concern over foreign affairs, and some progress was made in tax legislation, but the labor situation again came to the fore for discussion.
The highly controversial question of a guaranteed annual wage for labor is coming in for serious study by people in government, business and labor, according to The Associated Press yesterday.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 22 (AP) -- Light air plagued the fleet of twenty-five boats in the St. Petersburg-Havana yacht race after entering the Gulf of Mexico tonight, but the yawl Gulfstream still hugged onto its scant lead.

ROME, March 22 -- After two full weeks of discussion the Constituent Assembly this evening approved Article I of the new Italian Constitution. It reads, "Italy is a democratic republic founded on labor. Sovereignty belongs to the people, who exercise it in the forms and within the limits laid down by the Constitution."

SWEET PEAS, whose wide range of colors almost runs the gamut of the spectrum and whose scent is so delicious, are flowers beloved by all but grown by few. This is the year to try them again. Success can be had by observing a few rules.

A READER of this column has contributed a most eloquent analysis of a bidding problem that frequently plagues the bridge player when a hand like this is held: The dealer has this hand and bids one spade.

WASHINGTON. WHEN the voters of the United States elected Republicans to the control of both the House and Senate last fall, party leaders were quick to take credit for this election victory. They assumed that their completely negative approach to national problems bad been endorsed by the American people.

OAXACA DE JUAREZ, Mexico -- This curious town jolts you with such surprises as elefante, the local liquor compounded of equal parts of vermouth and cognac, seasoned with a twist of lime. Mitla and Monte Alban, ruins of ball-playing Zapotec communities that throve a thousand years before the Brooklyn Dodgers.

With stores seeking to fill in their stocks for Easter selling there was a heavy rush of orders on coats and suits last week, according to a market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.

THIS story is more of a psychiatric case history than it is a novel. In the early part of the book there is a psychiatrist's formal report, in tiny print, and the volume ends with a second report. The disturbed love life of Louise de Faivres, Parisian aristocrat, is the subject.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- On several fronts there was evidence this week-end of a determination to do something positive against communism.

-- UTOPIA Every horse-sensible citizen has his opinion of Utopians, these dreamy idealists forever singing out of tune with practical folks. And yet, all of a sudden, large numbers of perfectly sound and hard-boiled people are shouting from the housetops, and even from some of the skyscraper towers, saying that the human race has got to turn Utopian p.d.q., or perish.

IN years gone by, this observes has not worked up too much regard for the annual awards of "Oscars," not because we've always disagreed with the muchadvertised selections but because we've just disliked the way they're picked.

Magnificent in its dramatic comeback against Wisconsin in last Thursday's opening round, the City College basketball team collapsed last night at a most unexpected moment and reached the end of the road in its quest for the N.C.A.A. court championship.

Fears that a substantial number of rent increases for commercial and business space in this city will result from a recent amendment to the State Commercial Rent Control Law were discounted yesterday by John J. Lamula, legislative representative of the Joint Rent Action Committee, who said a survey by his organization indicated that not more than one in a thousand tenants would be affected by the change.

THE visual testimony embodied in this portfolio is more conclusive than verbal disputations about the resilience of France. It is a tribute, a creative sampling in the form of sketches, designs, photographs (in black-and-white and full color), ranging over fashion, art, decoration, the theatre, ballet, sculpture and some dozen other fields including music, the cinema and the novel -- all testifying clamorously to France's liberal activities in spite of the Nazi occupation.

"A STALWART Puritan with a quiet sense of devilment"-- so the author calls Uncle Henry Wallace, first of the three famous Iowans bearing that name; and so he might call the other two. By quiet devilment Mr. Lord means an impulse toward experiment, a recurrent tendency to rebel against existing systems.

KLAGENFURT, Austria, March 22 -- Tito followers in Carinthia are following the pattern made familiar by Hitler's "German brothers beyond the frontiers." They are trying to build up a crisis here to support Belgrade's claims for Southern Carinthia.

TODAY'S column is merely a reflection of a bit of reading recently come upon, in which I found things that seem to have particular point just now. G.K. Chesterton's "Heretics" was published more than forty years ago, but some of the essays in that volume have even more edge today than when they were written.
IF somebody's a typical American in his food tastes, then we speak of him as a "meat, potatoes and pie" man. Pie looms up in our gastronomic scheme the way the phone does in our communication scheme.

THE end-of-the-world motif has been supplying an undercurrent of pleasurable excitement to millions of tall stories since Henny Penny first rushed the news to Cocky Locky that the sky was falling down. Writers have, throughout the years, embroidered the old theme with gloomy relish and great success -- even in the golden days when there was nothing to fear but total war followed by famine and pestilence.

THERE is, in Aline Bernstein's latest book, an atmosphere so richly, so skillfully and so implacably created as to cast a hypnotic spell over the five senses of both characters and reader and to make credible -- as a result -- a completely incredible tale.

Hopes for a match for the chess championship of the United States during 1947 have faded. Arnold S. Denker of Forest Hills, winner of the title in 1944, issued a challenge for a contest of twelve games to Samuel Reshevsky of Boston, the present champion.

The rapidity with which Brazil recovers from the current post-war inflation will depend to a large degree upon how much technical assistance and capital investment the United States is willing to bring to that country, Dr. Gastao Vidiqual, superintendent of the Banco Mercantil of Sao Paulo and former Minister of Finance, stated last week in an interview at the Brazilian Government Trade Bureau.

The policy of the United States toward Argentina should neither violate the pledge of non-interference with the internal affairs of the republics of Latin America nor permit any dictatorship to interfere with the progress of world peace, according to pupils who participated yesterday in the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast over WQXR.

Delegates from 185 plants of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, CIO, voted yesterday to support a program of unity among all labor organizations. They met in the head quarters of Local 475 of the union at 160 Montague Street, Brooklyn.

MAJOR developments on the television, FM and standard radio fronts made last week one of the more active in the industry for some time. The production curve for the television manufacturing industry is expected to show a sharp upward surge now that the FCC has ruled that color television transmissions have not yet reached the point where commercial standards can be approved.

NEW DELHI, India, March 22 -- Viscount Mountbatten, who on Monday will become the twentyninth and presumably the last British Viceroy of India, arrived today by special plane from London. He was accompanied by Lady Mountbatten, their daughter Pamela and members of his staff, including Gen. Lord Ismay and Sir Eric Mieville, senior staff members.

CORNELL -- Fewer Failures Despite widespread predictions at colleges and universities throughout the country of a sharp increase in the percentage of "flunks" because of swollen enrollments and readjustment problems of veterans, Cornell University reports that its percentage of academic failures showed a decrease for the recent term in comparison with pre-war years.

To the Drama Editor: I must take a few minutes from revisions of the first act of my first play to snort at Michael Blankfort's sneers at the theatre. * * * Mr. Blankfort only partially presented the dour picture facing the aspiring playwright.

In a thriller that had the crowd of 12,000 in a state of high excitement during the breath-taking final quarter, De Witt Clinton won the city school boy basketball crown at Madison Square Garden yesterday by defeating Abraham Lincoln, winner in Brooklyn Division 2, 49 to 44.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 22 -- The British Government has been asked by the United States to consider making one last try at solving the Palestine problem by presenting a final proposal to the Arabs and Zionists before handing the case to the United Nations, it was reported today.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 22 -- Efforts to solve causes of conflict between the Western and Near Eastern civilizations will be made at the twelfth Princeton University Bicentennial Conference, which will open on Tuesday. About seventy delegates, representing six countries of the Near East and the United States, Canada and England, will attend the three-day meeting.
MOFFETT FIELD, Calif., March 22 (U.P.) -- The Navy installed here today a lighting system designed to guide airplanes through the last few seconds of a landing.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., March 22 -- Consideration of the human feelings of workers was depicted as the outstanding challenge to American business today at the final session of the convention of the Society for Advancement of Management.

SIXTEEN years ago In this Review: If the boys around Tammany Hall had an eye for the handwriting on the wall, they should have been interested in Charles Willis Thompson's Page 1 review of "The Life of Richard Croker," by Lothrop Stoddard.

THIS novel concerns Powys and Margiad, children who live with their father and paternal relatives on the coast of Wales. The boy, Powys, is, at 7, fascinated, not too unhealthily, by his sister, who is four years older. Their mother in death is a soft fragmentary memory for Powys, an obsession for Margiad.
The New York City Cancer Committee announced yesterday the details of a program that it described as applying atomic bomb research methods to the problem of conquering cancer.

BOSTON, March 22 -- Hammond V. Hayes, retired inventor of marine signaling and navigational devices, died today at the age of 86. While president of the Submarine Signal Corporation of Boston, he helped develop the fathometer, an instrument for registering sea depths directly beneath vessels.

'Loyalty Test' Last Monday the United States Supreme Court refused to review the case of a Federal employe who had been dismissed because of his membership in a "Communist front" organization. The court's action grave legal backing to a practice followed by the United States Civil Service Commission since 1942.
ATLANTA, March 22 -- President Truman's new anti-Communist foreign policy appears to have tremendous public support in this area notwithstanding the many questions raised concerning its implications.

LIKE all his writings, Professor Fisher's latest book is so rigorously reasoned that he who runs may not read it with any particular profit. But reflective readers will find it immensely profitable. Essentially it is an effort to discover what international economic system will best serve the interests of Great Britain in the light of the fact that her Government is committed to a full employment policy.

CHARLOTTE, N.C. -- Peach and dogwood blossoms will soon be brightening the sandhills sections of North and South Carolina, and in old plantain gardens azaleas and camellias will be bursting into bloom.

THE partnership of color and drawing in the pictorial arts is an unequal one. Drawing can do without color much better than color can do without drawing. Behold Ingres, behold Raphael, behold Michelangelo -- behold the insufficiency of their color, which doesn't matter, because their draftsmanship and their grasp of dark-and-light values are enough of themselves.

THERE are thirty-seven communities within a hundred miles of New York in each of which from ten to fifteen people have reported that, if adequate seaplane facilities were available, they would be interested in the purchase of an amphibian or float plane for regular commuting into the city.

Unrealistic policies, budget cuts, friction or competition with other military or semi-military components, and in some areas of the country a reversion to pre-war fallacies, is hampering the development of the National Guard and the reserve components of the services.

PORTLAND, Ore., March 22 -- With obvious reluctance the people of the Pacific Northwest seem convinced that the United States should use its economic strength to resist Russian influence over other nations.

ARTERIAL SURGERY -- Dr. Norman E. Freeman (University of California Medical School) reports in The Annals of Surgery that damaged arteries can easily be repaired. He simply cuts away the damaged part and sutures healthy tissue crosswise rather than longitudinally.

AIKEN, S.C. MANY a Southern farmer still fortifies himself against the long, lonely nights of the winter season with what is, after more than a decade of repeal, his favorite beverage -- homemade moonshine whisky.

PARIS -- One of the indications that times are beginning to get back to normal is that more Americans are writing to friends here that they are coming to France this summer and asking, "What should I know in advance?" Travel here is quite different from what it was in the Thirties and there is a fat dossier of things the visiting American "should know in advance."

Following years of consideration, the Long Island Golf Association's tournament committee now has found what it regards as the most practical system for opening up the Long Island amateur championship to numerous players who have been excluded in the past.
OMAHA, Neb., March 22 -- Although mass opinion has not become settled completely, this "breadbasket" area shows no sign of shying away from the country's currently developing role in world affairs.

CELEBRATED figures and incidents in the history of the medical profession as depicted in prints of several centuries have been assembled at the gallery of Kennedy Co. Many of these are after paintings by Neagle, Zoffany, Lawrence and others.

To the Music Editor: BOTH as a concertgoer and as a former soldier I read with interest the interview with Kirsten Flagstad printed in last Sunday's TIMES. Because of the dynamic nature of the issues involved in her return to this country it hardly seems possible that Mme.

Rare historical musical and literary autographs collected by Thomas L. Shattuck, Mrs. Mary Sefton and Thomas Lux of New York will be auctioned on Tuesday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

New York garment manufacturers, with a $2,000,000,000 stake in the country's prosperity, are reconciled to a level of trade lower than the peak attained in 1946. However, they are confident that they will do a volume two and one-half times as great as that of 1939, it was asserted last week by industry leaders.

OVERNIGHT service on color transparencies and color prints is offered by William R. Whittaker Company of Hollywood in connection with their Micro 16 camera. A roll of ten 16-mm-size frames of Whittaker color film (Ansco Color daylight) is sent to the Whittaker factory after exposure.

Seven hundred and fifty delegates attending a conference at the Hotel Diplomat yesterday afternoon were exhorted by speakers to make this year's May Day parade a "fighting demonstration" of the unity of the labor movement.

Before the thirty-first International Flower Show closed its doors last night one of the several committees concerned with its management had scheduled a meeting for next week to start planning the spring exhibit of 1948. Eleven full months of planning and hard work are needed to create a show with as profuse floral displays as this one.

TORONTO, March 22 -- Toronto's Maple Leafs exploded for three goals in the third period tonight to come from behind and defeat the New York Rangers, 5 -- 3, before 12,984 fans in the last game of the regular National Hockey League season at Maple Leaf Gardens.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 22 -- Joseph Verdeur, 21-year-old freshman from La Salle College of Philadelphia, was the head man in tonight's final proceedings at the Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League championships.
A new experimental curriculum, the result of six years' research and planning, will be started at Amherst College next fall.

AT the flower shows held in Chicago, Philadelphia, Boston, Cleveland and New York during the past two weeks, flower arrangements were made, by the finest exhibitors in the country. Many of them inspire spectators to try enlivening their winter-weary homes with similar pictures of spring.

CHICAGO, March 22 -- The world shortage of raw materials from which are made hard fiber twines will likely continue through, the current year, "and possibly for several years more," a cordage industry representative predicted today.

The Very Rev. Dr. Edward J. Walsh, C.M., president emeritus of St. John's University in Brooklyn, died yesterday at Providence Hospital in Mobile, Ala., which he entered as a patient after the recurrence of a heart ailment on Feb. 23. His age was 69.

A catalyst is a substance that speeds up a chemical reaction without taking part of it. Thus a piece of spongy platinum will ignite gas in the kitchen stove by catalytic action. Oils are converted into hard fats by passing hydrogen through them in the presence of nickel, a catalyst.

NANKING, March 22 -- Dr. Carson Chang, leader of the Social Democratic party, has not been persuaded that his party should join the Cabinet, Gen. Wu Techen, Secretary of the Kuomintang, told the party's Central Executive Committee today.

HARD drinking and long poems are forms of dissipation in which the Japanese refuse to indulge. Those of us who have drunk sake with them from thimblelike cups used for toasting their ancestors and legendary demigods know by now that the Japanese put far more feeling into the offering of a poem than they do in a toast.

VERY little fiction gives as clear and crucial a sense of what it is like not only to live but to be in the modern world as the best of Mark Schorer's short stories. His people are sensitive and intelligent in a way that readers like to think of themselves as being.

Members of society will act as "salesladies" on Tuesday at Arnold Constable's, the occasion being the annual shopping day for the benefit of the Children's Village. In accordance with a nineteen-year-old tradition the store will contribute a generous percentage of all sales that day toward the support of the underprivileged boys at the village.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- President Truman, by executive decree, ordered into effect today an elaborate and unprecedented program of security and precautions against Federal employment of any person who, on "reasonable grounds," can be judged disloyal.

Starting 10 to 23 points net higher than the preceding close, the cotton futures market, on the New York Cotton Exchange turned strong and active again yesterday and closed near the best levels of the day, 25 to 43 points net higher.

DETROIT, Mar. 22 (U.P.) -- Used car dealers have raised their sights to aim at a banner business year in 1947 because of increasing demand, steady supply and continued high prices. A spot check of major used car markets across the country shows that 1940, 1941 and 1942 models in good condition generally sell at prices above the original cost.
To the Music Editor: The discussion of music and politics in THE TIMES Sunday music section poses an important question to which nobody has as yet given a satisfactory answer.

WITH Easter only two weeks away the test of consumer goods demand is nearing completion with results that are definitely on the disappointing side. The holiday comes two weeks earlier this year than last year and apparel volume is running under 1946 in spite of higher prices.

DENVER, March 22 -- In analyzing the attitudes of people of the Rocky Mountain area toward the present-day foreign policy of the United States, it is evident that a great majority of the people of this region have abandoned their prewar, die-hard isolationism.

NANKING, March 22 (AP) -- With the Communists retreating northeastward from their fallen capital of Yenan, the Government made new tentative peace overtures today but anticipated that they would be rejected.

THE memorial exhibition of work by Augo Steiner-Prag (1880-1945), installed at the Galerie St. Etienne, touches upon the various facets of an interesting and versatile talent. It is made up of oil temperas, water-colors, crayon drawings, pen drawings, lithographs and etchings.

Francis Adams Truslow, president of the New York Curb Exchange, told its employes yesterday that if they went on strike after April 21 as their union, the United Financial Employes, AFL, had threatened, it would not affect "the good relations now existing between us."

CLEVELAND, March 22 -- A strike against the "Big Four" of the rubber industry was averted at the eleventh hour tonight when union representatives agreed to accept a wage increase of about 11 1/2 cents an hour, or less than half of the 26 cents which comprised their original demand.

JERUSALEM, March 22 -- Normal everyday relationships that might exist between Jews and Arabs, as they exist among racial and religious groups in other countries, are made difficult if not impossible in Palestine by the superinduced political tension that is felt by nearly everyone in the country.
To the Drama Editor: THERE used to be a time when Michael Blankfort never imagined that he would write one day, "No more plays for me. I'm through."

DESPITE the post-war resurgence of the French film industry, Hollywood's attraction for Gallic filmmakers apparently is still strong. Next year, pending unforeseen changes in plan, Marcel Carne, director of the currently successful "Les Enfants du Paradis," will journey to the Coast, as have such other top-flight French directors as Rene Clair and Julien Duvivier.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Documents stressing the need for immediate aid to Greece because of an impending economic crisis were released for publication today. The material had been given earlier in the week to the House Foreign Affairs Committee for background material.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- Congressmen of both parties had praise tonight for President Truman's "loyalty in Government" order. Some added that it was long averdue and its worth, would have to be proved by strict enforcement.

The discovery that certain fruit juices, and chemicals contained in fruit juices, speed up the onset of infantile paralysis in infected experimental animals was reported at a recent medical meeting in Cleveland by Drs. John A. Toomey, William S. Takacs and P.P. Pirone, all of Western Reserve University.

MOSCOW (By Wireless). THE most important objective of Soviet policy for Germany is the ideological and political mastery of the country and its people. This is not a policy of the moment. It represents both the dream of Communist planners for the last eighty years and the apex of the new Russian nationalism.

ILYA EHRENBURG, because of his "The Tempering of Russia" and his writings and lectures in the United States, is probably the Soviet journalist best known to Americans. He is also, undoubtedly, one of the Soviet Union's ablest reporters, equipped for his task both by temperament and experience.

AIKEN, S.C., March 22 -- More than 1,000 racing fans watched the third and final day of the training trials today. The Greentree Stable of Manhasset, L.I., scored a triple in the seven trials contested over a fast strip.
A family friend who had known Norma Kotler since she was 3 years old was held yesterday on a charge of strangling the attractive 22-year-old girl early Friday.

Presidents and Pianists About piano-lovers, as about so many other things in life, you never can tell. If a President of the United States is discovered to be fond of the piano and a good amateur hand at it, a person would say offhand that it would be one of our Presidents from the effete East and from an old, well-to-do family.

MOSCOW, March 22 (AP) -- The text of Secretary of State Marshall's statement to the Council of Foreign Ministers on the form and scope of the provisional political organization of Germany follows: Without prejudice to any position the United States may take under 2-3 (B) of the agenda of the Council of Foreign Ministers, the United States delegate proposes the following directive:

Beset by what they describe as "continual assumption of unintended powers by the Federal Power Commission," members of the natural gas industry expressed satisfaction last week over the recent filing in the Senate and House of bills specifically designed to curb the powers of the Federal agency.

KANSAS CITY, March 22 -- A long jump shot by Ken Pryor in the last ten seconds of play gave the University of Oklahoma Sooners a 55-to-54 victory over Texas to win the Western Regional N.C.A.A. basketball championship here tonight.

THE attack on Pearl Harbor added urgency to a question frequently raised in the two decades preceding that fateful day: Would the 160,000 Japanese in Hawaii be loyal to the United States in the event of war with Japan?
INDIANAPOLIS, March 22 -- "We are making the same mistakes we did after World War I, We are stifling our aviation industry."

IT was John Galsworthy who saved himself from being a "promising" writer by throwing away everything he wrote until he reached the age of 30. Russell La Due (late of the United States Marines and now on the faculty at the University of Michigan) has unfortunately let himself be lured into print prematurely with a novel that is so exasperatingly promising that its basic failure is all the more glaring.
Alteration of subway stations to allow lengthening of platforms was halted in several parts of the city yesterday when construction workers staged a wildcat walkout.

SALONIKA, Greece, March 22 -- Alexis Grauer a Russian member of the United Nations Balkans Investigating Commission; Z. Gawrak of the Polish delegation, and liaison officers of Yugoslavia, Albania and Bulgaria returned to Salonika today, saying they had met and interviewed "General" Markos Vafthiadis, Greek guerrilla chief.
DETROIT (AP) -- A far-reaching reorganization program rapidly is nearing completion in the great family-owned Ford Motor Company.
The whereabouts of Langley Collyer, now sole heir to more than $100,000 since the death on Friday of his blind brother Homer, remained unknown yesterday.

MISS Warner is one of that handful of English and American women writers who manage to be by turns compassionate and scathing without their syntax becoming ruffled or their taste affected by the moral climate of which they write.

HOW to take a picture that will fit the requirements of a specific photography contest and win a prize is a problem that puzzles most amateurs. The Rev. Anthony W. Kieffer, father superior of St. John's University, Brooklyn, first solved the problem back in 1936 when he won a one-dollar prize in a newspaper camera contest.
HONOLULU, March 22 -- At outburst of minor league home-run hitting brought grief to the Giants today before 3,000 as the major leaguers sought their fourth in a row over the San Francisco Seals.

The earth's axis slowly heaves over, and spring arrives in the northern hemisphere. There's a new season, a new moon, and now the days lengthen beyond the nights. And in the human heart a tide begins to rise; somewhere in the pulse is response to change. There is a quickening of the bases for belief, for understanding; for spring is more than sap rising and buds bursting: it is life renewing itself in every aspect.

LIFE is just one false alarm after another for some firemen. In Philadelphia a record number of thirty such alarms were sounded within twenty-four hours. Thanks to a wide-awake milk-wagon driver, however, one of the culprits was captured in short order.

Two of the seeded players in the men's division of the fourth annual Eastern indoor tennis championship bowed out yesterday as the field entered the third round at the Eighth Regiment Armory in the Bronx. Elwood T. Cooke, veteran star who was rated No. 1, notified tournament officials that he would be unable to appear for a secondround match with Francis Montalbano because of illness.

THIS is an honest, entertaining and informative book about India in these days when good books about India are necessary. The world is being shaken by colossal forces and few things are more important than the approaching end of British rule in India.

PENNY CASCADE -- A smirking taxpayer walked into the Internal Revenue office at Missoula, Mont., one March 15 and dumped a sack containing 9,099 pennies -- his income tax for 1945 -- on a collector's desk.

CONDITIONING the car for spring and summer touring will be emphasized during the seventeenth annual safety convention and exposition sponsored by the Greater New York Safety Council, which will open Tuesday and continue through Friday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Today's Conflict WE are, in fact, in a period of conflict betwen cultures -- a conflict which finds the older cultures in a position of disadvantage: from lack of confidence in themselves, from divisions both internal and between each other, from the inheritance of old abuses from the past aggravated by abuses due to the hasty introduction of novelties.

Leo Schwarz, director of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee in the United States Zone in Germany, back after thirteen months of service, said yesterday that among the displaced Jews of Europe are vast reservoirs of talent that should prove of value to any nation.

ALBANY, March 22 -- Governor Dewey signed more than a score of bills today, ranging from measures requiring additional safety accessories on school buses to bills increasing the compensation of certain county judges and surrogates.

WESTWOOD, N.J., March 22 -- Gustave Meyer, owner of the Warner Brush Manufacturing Company at 171 Madison Avenue, New York, and former Councilman and Mayor of this community, died late last night in Atlantic City, where he was attending a brush manufacturers' convention with his wife.

Charles De Wolf Gibson, chairman of the Commerce and Industry Committee of the Red Cross 1947 Fund of Greater New York, urged yesterday that the tempo of canvassing by the ten sections which comprise the committee be speeded up.
EXQUISITE craftsmanship, a cool perfection of utterance have long been the enviable property of Janet Lewis.

THE first of a projected series of annual print exhibitions, national in scope, has opened at the Brooklyn Museum. Out of more than 600 submitted examples some 210 were passed by the jury, which acquitted itself well in its difficult task.

FRUIT trees and bushes on many places fit all too accurately an old gardener's description of "a scatterment of plants." They have been bought over a period of years, one or two trees or a half dozen bushes a season.

THERE'S a wonderful, relaxing feeling about spending the summer at the seashore, close to the ocean and hard under the sun. Mrs. Louise Field Cooper, who has doubtless idled away many an hour in just such a setting, has written a novel about a small and well-to-do colony on the eastern Connecticut -- or is it Rhode Island? -- coast.

THE: first edition of this textbook on baseball found great favor with high school and college coaches when it appeared in 1938. This revised edition should be just as popular. It is more complete than the original, with the most notable addition probably being a chapter on scoring.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 22 -- The battle within Georgia's Democratic party continues unabated. It merely entered a new phase as the result of this week's State Supreme Court decision invalidating the General Assembly election of Herman Talmadge and installing Melvin E. Thompson as the legal acting Governor.
DETROIT, March 22 -- It cannot be said with certainty that a definite public opinion has crystallized in Michigan on President Truman's message on March 12.
Early demise of the Puget Sound Power and Light Company, one of the largest utility operating systems in the Pacific Northwest, appears inevitable, Frank McLaughlin, its president, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Following is the text of a Presidential Executive Order "prescribing procedures for the administration of an employes' loyalty program in the Executive Branch of the Government": Whereas each employe of the Government of the United States is endowed with a measure of trusteeship over the democratic processes which are the heart and sinew of the United States; and

The recent proposal by the Audubon Society to eliminate a 1947 waterfowl shooting season has placed the United States Fish and Wildlife Service on the uncomfortably sharp horns of a dilemma, and it is quite apparent from the comments by the Service spokesman that the Audubon proposal was a bit premature.

LONDON, March 22 (AP) -- They're off next Tuesday in the seven-anda-half-month racing season -- saved from any serious interruption by the avowed necessity of maintaining the reputation of British bloodstock for profitable exports.

Inexperienced executives in top brackets, bidding against each other in spot metal markets for available supplies, have been responsible for recent sensational prices in many metal lines, purchasing officials disclosed here yesterday.

ALBANY, March 23 -- M. P. Catherwood, Commerce Commissioner, in a letter transmitting to Governor Dewey the 1946 report of his department, said today that New York State led the country last year in post-war reconversion.

Following is the text of Report No. 3 by Herbert Hoover on the President's economic mission to Germany and Austria: March 18, 1947 The President The White House Washington, D.C. Dear Mr. President: I am sending you herewith my conclusions upon the problems of reviving German industry and thus exports with which to relieve American and British taxpayers from their burden in preventing starvation in Germany.

The New York Rangers ended the National Hockey League season by defeating the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden last night. While a crowd of 15, 271 looked on, Frank Boucher's Blue Shirts carved out a 4-to-3 triumph over the Windy City crew.

In Thermic Ray's new version of the double boiler, that very practical kitchen utensil has a beautifully designed top pan that can be brought to the table as a casserole. Two black plastic handles, one on either side, replace the one long handle that's usual on such a pot, fitting it for dining-room appearances.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 23 -- Yugoslavia will spend $270,000,000 on national defense in the next fiscal year, an increase of 29 per cent over the figure for the last year.

The Washington debate over Greece has stolen the spotlight from the Moscow debate over Germany. The pivotal question is momentarily eclipsed by the peripheral question. The reason is that interest in both cases hinges on their bearing on Soviet-American, relations, and Greece has suddenly become the touchstone of a new approach on the part of the United States to the Soviet Union.

Supporters of Governor Dewey and of Thomas J. Curran, New York County Republican chairman, scored a substantial victory yesterday in the fight over the election of officers in the National Republican Club.

Some plain if unpalatable facts were placed before the American Legion's National Aeronautics Conference in Indianapolis by Gen. George C. Kenney, Senator Brewster of Maine and Major General Echols, who performed so great a service during the war in assuring the flow of our materiel

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 23 -- Dr. Seymour E. Harris, Professor of Economics at Harvard University, has completed a study of the New England economy and found that New England, like old England, though far from being a depressed area, is in an economic decline.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 23 (AP) -- A sweeping five-point program designed to solve the explosive Greek problem and ease Russian fears concerning' the role of Greece in international affairs has been proposed by Greece's Foreign Minister Constantin Tsaldaris, at Athens, John Leacacos, correspondent of The Cleveland Plain Dealer, reported today.

There should be plenty of excitement today at Broadway and Thirty-fourth Street and at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. This is the day that the Police Department will try the psychological approach to dissuade New Yorkers from jaywalking.

BERLIN, March 23 -- Apparently as the result of President Truman's request for loans for Greece and Turkey, the Russians have begun to re-investigate German politicians to discover if they have American connections. Recently the Russians have made numerous arrests.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Turkey was pictured today in authoritative documents as a nation being pounded by a Soviet war of nerves.

BOSTON, March 23 (U.P.) -- A small party of mountain climbers, including one woman, left here tonight on the first lap of a trip, the ultimate destination of which is the icy summit of 20,300-foot Mount McKinley, the tallest peak in North America.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There has been a surprising lack of comment upon the views of former Ambassador Kennedy.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., March 23 -- Over six races in the sailing dinghy regatta today at the Larchmont Yacht Club, Arthur Knapp Jr. renewed his wining way with his boat Agony.

Net income of the American Smelting and Refining Company and its subsidiaries last year amounted to $15,712,122, equal to $5.57 a share, compared with $11,468,677, or $3.64 a share earned in 1945, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

Parking conditions throughout the country apparently are not Improving generally and temporary expedients are utilized in attempts to cope with the rising volume of traffic congestion, accordiag to a survey conducted by THE new york times.

PITTSBURGH, March 23 -- It is a foregone conclusion here that the changes made last week in extra charges for steel by the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation will be followed by similar revisions in the extras charged by other steel companies.

Future contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange closed with net advances of 45 to 84 points last week, after moving irregularly during the period, In the preceding week the market had been up 39 to 27 points lower, with the only gains in the near-by deliveries.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 23 -- "Missouri Legend," the 1938 Broadway play by Elizabeth Beall Ginty, will be filmed by Eagle-Lion this season under the terms of an agreement concluded by the studio with Joseph Fields and Jerome Chodorov, who own the screen rights to the drama. Fields and Chodorov will write the screen adaptation, and will participate in the profits of the venture which will be listed as a Joseph Fields Production.

SALONIKA, Greece, March 23 (AP) -- An unofficial survey of the United Nations Balkans Investigating Commission disclosed today that a majority considered outside assistance a prime reason for internal fighting in Greece.
THE HAGUE, March 23 -- The International Court of Justice stands ready for business at the Peace Palace here but thus far no customers have appeared.

Warning that "war is not the answer to the problem of communism," Msgr. Fulton J. Sheen, Professor of Philosophy at the Catholic University of America, declared yesterday that "we must not hope for the extinction of the Communists but must pray for their conversion."
NEW DELHI, India, March 23 -- Serious trouble seems to lie ahead in "Pakistan," the projected Moslem state that may or may not come into existence when British power departs from India.
An increase in personality, behavior and habit disorders in children committed to the care of the New York Catholic Charities was reported yesterday by its department of child care.

SEABRIGHT, N. J., March 23 -- A $1,000,000 stone seawall will be built to save this North Jersey seashore resort from being washed tnto the sea. The State Department of Local Government in Trenton, acknowledging that such a danger exists, approved a $60,000 borough bond issue last week.

CHICAGO, March 23 (U.P.) -- Most State and local Republican leaders favor the foreign and domestic policy views of Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan, a survey in the magazine of the national party showed today.

ALBANY, March 23 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey signed today the budget bill providing overtime pay and a basic forty-hour week for all State employes. He said the measure marks an important step forward and removes many old injustices.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 23 -- Two new international organs of top importance, the Commission for Conventional Armaments and the Trusteeship Council, will convene for the first time here tomorrow and Wednesday. The meetings will highlight an anniversary week of the United Nations.

MILWAUKEE, March 23 -- Local 248, United Automobile Worker CIO, voted today 3 to 1 to end the bitter 329-day strike against the AllisChalmers Manufacturing Company here and return to work tomorrow without a contract.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., March 23 (AP) -- Scoring two quick goals early in the third period to break a 2-2 tie, the Hanover, N. H., Indians, composed of Dartmouth's international intercollegiate co-champion players, defeated the Boston Athletic Association, 6-2, tonight to win the National A.A.U. hockey championship at the Rhode Island Auditorium.

The week-end schedule of the Original Ballet Russe at the Metropolitan Opera House found Rosella Hightower, the newest star on the ballet horizon, in two performances of "Swan Lake," with, first Anton Dolin, and then, Andre Eglevsky as her partner.

Retailer's stocks last week appeared heavy and somewhat over-supplied, according to the reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Department stores hoped that there would be a spurt in the demand for Easter merchandise with the advent of milder weather which would help to make up for some recent losses in volume, the reports stated.
The Rev. Dr. George Arthur Buttrick, senior minister for twenty years of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Seventy-third Street, began yesterday his third decade of service.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- After a slow start, disappointing to its most ardent supporters, the Republican legislative program has overcome its first inertia and is going along at an accelerating pace.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 23 -- Delegates to the United Nations first subcommission on freedom of the press can be elected as "individuals" and not solely as Government-designated representatives, it was decided here today by the Social Committee of the Economic and Social Council.

LONDON, March 23 -- Charges voiced in the House of Commons recently that the British Broadcasting Corporation's staff accepted bribes from, dance band leaders and variety artists who sought broadcasting engagements were held today to be unfounded after a thoroughgoing investigation.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 23 -- The Yankees, who have been looking at some pretty good hurling this spring, got a look at some super-fine flinging today, but unfortunately it didn't come out of a New York uniform.

Red Cross volunteers in their gray uniforms and Chinese children in bright native dress canvassed Chinatown yesterday, collecting funds for the 1947 Red Cross drive. Teamed up in pairs they spread out through the section, stopping passers -by, appealing- to neighbors, entering the stores and collecting from shopkeepers and customers alike.

LONDON, March 23 (AP) -- British farmers estimated tonight that flood damage already had cost them $48,000,000 in drowned cattle and sheep in the continuing floods. It will be two weeks before damages can be calculated on growing crops.

HONOLULU, March 23 -- The San Francisco Seals said it with homers today by way of bidding aloha to the Hawaiian Islands as a training site in their finale with the Giants. Banking: two of MelOtt's pitchers for three four-masters, the minor leaguers trounced their major league rivals, 11 to 9, before 7,194 fans for their second straight victory.

Assistant Chief Inspector William P. O'Brien was one of 496 members of the Police Department who received citations for meritorious service in general orders made public yesterday by Commissioner Artbvur W. Wallander.

Sidney Scher has joined the Associated Merchandising Corporation as merchandise representative of luggage to succeed Nat Friedman, who has been named merchandise representative of boys' clothing and furnishings.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- The National Federation of Telephone Workers reported today that balloting was running 15 to 1 in favor of a country-wide strike.

The establishment of transatlantic service by the Maersk Line was announced here yesterday by M. M. Moller, president of the Moller Steamship Company, Inc., operator of the line. The service, which will operate on a semimonthly schedule, will include Antwerp, Rotterdam, Rouen, New York and Philadelphia.

Sidney Schwartz and William Lurie, seeded fourth and fifth respectively, and Nathan Goldstein, an unranked entry, paced the field into the quarter-final round of the men's singles division of the Eastern indoor tennis championships at the Eighth Regiment Armory yesterday. Each scored straight-set triumphs.

Large quantities of storage batteries are included in the fixed-price offerings of surplus materials by the War Assets Administration this week, Carl P. Malmstrom, regional director, announced over the weekend. More than 140 sales schedules of surplus property worth $160,000,000 in cost values were announced.

Accusing President Truman of using "Gestapo methods" to gag opponents of his policy of support for Greece and Turkey, Councilman Eugene P. Connolly of the American Labor party said yesterday that the President had placed the country on the road to war.

TOKYO, March 23 -- Considerable protest is developing in the Japanese press on the Government's new attempt to suppress the black market in foodstuffs by limiting railroad passengers' parcels to five pounds. This policy is being enforced by police raids on passenger trains, and the Japanese complain the raids often catch the wrong persons.

Victorious by wide margins in the third round for the championship of the Metropolitan Chess League, the two leading teams, the Manhattan and Marshall Chess Clubs, yesterday drew away from the Brooklyn Chess Club, which had a bye.
Miss Florence Schmitt of the home club annexed the junior national A. A. U. 220-yard breast-stroke title yesterday in 3:28.3 at the meet conducted in the Women's Swimming Association pool.

Subway improvements and a solution to the midtown parking problem were requested of Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday by the New York Board of Trade, which asked that provision be made in the next city budget for both problems.

New York has more Communists than any other comparable area in the world "outside Moscow," Assemblyman Owen McGivern, Democrat, of Manhattan told 4,500 members of the Police Department Holy Name Society yesterday at their twenty-ninth annual communion breakfast in the Hotel Astor.

The Rev. Dr. Horace W. B. Donegan, rector of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church at Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street, urged yesterday at the morning service that the parish give $40,000 of the $500,000 sought by the New York Protestant Episcopal City Mission Society to rebuild St. Barnabas House.

SHOUNEH, Trans - Jordan, March 22 (Delayed) -- King Abdullah of Trans-Jordan declared today that he opposed the partition of Palestine, but, if the British should evacuate any part of the country his forces would immediately occupy it.

It seems to be pretty generally agreed among serious students of the problem that whatever measures the present Congress enacts in the field of labor legislation, considerations of public interest should be paramount.

David Mannes, now 81, who has conducted the free orchestral concerts at the Metropolitan Museum of Art regularly since he founded them during the first World War, yesterday afternoon opened the thirtieth season.

Two hundred representatives of 35,000 public employes of New York, members of the United Public Workers of America, CIO, met yesterday in a State-wide conference in Manhattan Center and lashed out at Governor Dewey and the State Administration for "arrogantly misusing control of the legislative machinery."

BOSTON, March 23 (U.P.) -- The Montreal Canadiens, backed by the stellar goal-tending of Bill Durnan, stopped Boston's unbeaten streak at ten games tonight by edging the Bruins, 3 to 2, at Boston Garden before 13,900 fans in the regular-season finale for both teams.

MOUNT MISERY, N. J., March 23 -- The one-time Civilian Conservation Corps camp here is undergoing a transformation into an educational and recreational center for the New Jersey Conference of the Methodist Church, which recently purchased the 175-acre tract and its dozen buildings from the Government.

NEW DELHI, India, March 23 -- Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, long a spokesman of the Asiatic "subject countries" today hailed the end of "old imperialisms" and called upon the nations of Asia to help this vast continent to take its rightful place in world affairs.

DETROIT, March 23 -- The United Automobile Workers reacted strongly tonight to the news from Cleveland which, meant the knocking out of its demands, demands based upon a wage increase of 23 1/2 cents an hour with fringe concessions to bring the aggregate amount to more than 30 cents.

KLAGENFURT, Austria, March 23 -- A party here seeking annexation to Yugoslavia, is operating or the basis of a Slavic racial fanaticism equivalent to German racial fanaticism, still in evidence among former Carinthian National Socialists and many returned Carinthian soldiers who were in the German armies.

Music lovers at the Metropolitan Museum of Art yesterday afternoon celebrated an anniversary that warms one's heart to think about. In the last year of the First World War David Mannes opened a free series of museum concerts, with an initial audience of 781 persons.

ST. JOSEPH, Mo., March 23 (AP) -- The third-seeded Sports Arena team of Atlanta, Ga., made an impressive debut in the opening round of competition in the nineteenth women's national A. A. U. basketball tournament today, defeating the Dallas, Texas, Hornets, 49 to 10.
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., March 23 -- In a strong southerly which lightened during the afternoon, nine Class B dinghies and sixteen Penguins started off the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club today.
Joyce Ronelle, New York soprano, gave her first local recital last night at Town Hall. She was accompanied by Leonard Rudko, who has been her only teacher.
Net profit of Pullman, Inc., last year totaled $2,079,110, equal to 64 cents a share, compared with $13,890,226, or $ .30 a share, in 1945, it was announced yesterday.

NANKING, March 23 -- The conduct of China's foreign relations during the last year was accepted as satisfactory in a resolution adopted here today by the Kuomintang [Government party] central executive committee, now in session.

Criticisms leveled at the American shipping industry by maritime unions, for the alleged sale or transfer of American vessels to Panamanian and Honduran registry are dealt with in a report compiled and made public by the National Federation of American Shipping.

Arturo Toscanini, two days before his eightieth birthday, conducted a program entirely of Italian music with the NBC Symphony Orchestra yesterday afternoon in Radio City. It was as if the maestro, who detests birthday ceremonies, had elected on this occasion to make a special gesture toward the land that bore him and the sorely tried nation which first gave him his fame.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Miss Mary V. Robinson, chief of the public information division of the Womens' Bureau of the Department of Labor for more than seventeen years and a member of the staff for twenty-four years, has resigned, Miss Frieda S. Miller, director of the bureau, announced today.

Because of fire and safety hazards, the Imperial Hotel, Broadway and Thirty-first Street, will close its doors next Monday, it was announced yesterday by its owners, the heirs of the late Robert Walton Goelet.

MOSCOW, March 23 -- Charging that the United States and Britain wished to turn western Germany into an economic vassal, the Moscow press launched a violent attack today on the principle of a federation as proposed by the United States, British and French delegations to the Council of Foreign Ministers.

NANKING, March 23 -- More than a thousand Formosan soldiers in Southwest Shantung Province have deserted the Chinese Government forces and have gone over to the Communists, a Communist radio broadcast monitored here contends.

ZURICH, Switzerland, March 23 -- The Anglo-Swiss negotiations in Berne to adapt the terms of finance and payments in the agreement of March 12, 1946, to conditions that are expected to prevail during the second year of operation of the agreement have ended to the complete satisfaction of both sides.
LONDON, March 23 -- The stock markets have now drifted into a comparatively idle and rather depressed state from which no early relief appears likely.
JERUSALEM. March 23 -- The extremist Irgun Zvai Leumi was reported tonight to have issued a "cease-fire" order and decided to concentrate "until further notice" on political warfare only.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Bulgaria and Yugloslavia are teeming with concentration camps and prisons for political prisoners, offenders against the military and some minority groups, according to a confidential report received here. The report is based on information of observers, representing various nations, who were recently stationed in the Balkans.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 23 (AP) -- For the first time since they started slinging mud at each other several months ago Larry MacPhail of the New York Yankees and Manager Leo Durocher of the Brooklyn Dodgers will meet face to face when they appear here before Baseball Commissioner Chandler in an unprecedented hearing tomorrow that may produce some sensational results.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Representative William M. Colmer, Democrat of Mississippi, announced tonight that he would introduce in Congress tomorrow a resolution prohibiting any form of aid to Russia, and Communist-dominated countries while they continue "unfriendly" and violate their political commitments.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 23 -- Ending its long strike, Local 248 of the UAW-CIO win go back tomorrow in a last-ditch fight to hold its bargaining rights at the Allis-Chalmers manufacturing plant.

Speaking of Trees Announcement of a campaign by the Municipal Art. Society for planting more trees in our city streets has reminded us that the first printed description of Manhattan Island, written by Robert Juet, mate of Henry Hudson's ship, back in 1609, described it as a land of "goodly trees."

Prince George Chavchavadze presented his first New York piano recital in four years, last night at Carnegie Hall. His playing was, as always, individual, virile and alive. He applied coloring in a masterly way in all of his offerings, and if results proved uneven this was largely due to liberties taken to achieve effects which were sometimes foreign to the spirit of the music under consideration.

Ten youthful Bronx thugs who made secluded sections of Bronx Park on week-ends their base of operations were in police custody yesterday because of the vigilance of Patrolman John J. Sulger of the Bronx Park station.
Week Ended March 22, 1947 The Canadian free dollar suffered a fresh break in value on a recurrence of the devaluation rumors, selling down to 93.38 cents on Friday, a new low since last July.

STONINGTON ISLAND, Palmer Land, Antartica, March 21 (delayed) -- In the best flying weather that the Antarctic can offer, Capt. Harry Darlington, pilot, and Bill Latady, photographer, made a flight today to the entry of King George VI Sound.
The legend of the Collyer brothers drew a crowd of several thousand persons yesterday to the recluses' decaying brownstone bouse at 2078 Fifth Avenue.

CLEVELAND, March 23 (AP) -- Settlement of the year's first major strike threat early today -- involving the United Rubber Workers, CIO, and the industries' "Big Four" rubber companies -- will bring no price increase in rubber, and may be the first step toward cutting booming prices of other American products, an industry official asserted.

CHICAGO, March 23 -- One of the wildest grain markets in years developed last week, with a drastic decline following an early upturn that carried March wheat up to $3.05 a bushel, or within 20 cents of its high record, and put corn into new ground since 1920.

City institutions here are "forced to keep chronically ill aged person long after they are ready for dismissal, because they have no place to go," Miss Flora Fox, executive director of the Central Bureau for Jewish Aged, declared last week in a report to the Federation of Jewish Women's Organizations.

MOSCOW, March 23 -- The United States delegation to the Council of Foreign Ministers decided after a meeting this morning to submit two new papers to the secretariat clarifying the United States views on German democratization and on reparations.

An appeal to individual radio stations to adopt the financial safeguard of the 2 per cent cash discount, already in effect with the majority of other media was made last week by the American Association of Advertising Agencies. The request, in the form of a letter signed by Frederick R. Gamble, president, on behalf of member agencies, has been mailed to all stations that do not allow the discount.

HAVANA., March 23 -- Playing without pressure, the Dodgers ambled through to another victory over the Cuban All-Stars at Grand Stadium this afternoon, punishing three pitchers for eighteen assorted hits to win, 12 to 4. Not more than a thousand fans viewed the proceedings with an apathy from which they were stirred only once. That happened in the sixth, when Dick Whitman stole third.

DETROIT, March 23 (U.P.) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs and Detroit Red Wings closed out their National Hockey League schedules tonight with Toronto the victor, 5 to 3, in the wildest game played at Olympia Stadium in recent years.

A seismological observatory for recording earthquakes and tremors is scheduled for installation in City College's Finley Hall at 137th Street and Amsterdam Avenue early in May, Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of the college, announced yesterday.

A slowing up in the demand for whisky and record production from War-developed distilleries are beginning to exert bearish pressure on liquor prices, trade sources said over the week-end. They predicted, however, that the floor created by high State and Federal taxation would keep prices from dropping to pre-war levels.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 23 (AP) -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Auto Workers, CIO, lost out today in his effort to purge the union of Irving Richter, its national legislative representative, whom he accused of "disloyalty" to the UAW.
Lack of funds, variable policies and friction and competition between the various parts of the armed services have handicapped the post-war development of the "civilian components."

MEXICO CITY, March 31 -- A three-sided Mexican labor battle got under way last week with the launching of a new organization that claims to represent at least 350,000 workers opposed to Vicente Lombardo Toledano's Mexican Confederation of Labor.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- More than $2,000,000,000 worth of food was exported from this country in 1946, the Department of Commerce reported tonight.
The Baldwin Locomotive Works, In its annual report for 1946, being distributed to stockholders today, shows a net profit of $3,802,738, compared with $3,769,948 in 1945.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Deposits by individuals, partnerships and corporations in all banks covered by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation were at a new high record of $124,085,000,000 at the end of 1946. Chairman Maple T. Hart reported today that the gain was accompanied by a "substantial increase" in bank loans.

Marc Brown, 21-year-old violinist of this city, gave his first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Before he was 3 years old, articles concerning his ability to name seventy compositions when they were played on the piano for him, appeared in the local press.

In some quarters here there seems an odd tendency to construe the capture of Yenan by the Chinese Nationalists almost as though it were a government defeat. The "escape" of the Communists is emphasized rather than the loss of their capital city. One has only to reverse this picture to show its falsity.

PHILADELPHIA, March 23 (AP) -- Dr. Henry B. Alien, executive vice president and secretary of Franklin Institute, today annouced the winners of four medals that will be awarded on April 16 at the annual Medal Day ceremonies.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The Treasury Department is handing dismissal notices to 1,000 employes in the Customs Bureau, including many engaged in the Border Patrol, an official stated tonight. The notices, going out at once, will be effective March 28.

JERUSALEM, March 23 -- The executive of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, which has been planning Zionist tactics for the United Nations, ended its deliberations today with the adoption of resolutions.

Despite much, detafied criticism and inner conflict, the American business community as a whole strongly supports the principles and objectives of the Truman Administration's program for the Geneva Conference scheduled to open on April 10.
The Matson Lines are expediting reconstruction of three liners to meet increasing demands for passenger space between the Pacific Coast and Hawaii, S. G. Walton, vice president, reported yesterday.

MOSCOW, March 23 -- France has moved away from the policy of the Soviet Union and closer to that of the United States on almost every important point of the German settlement during the first two weeks of the Council of Foreign Ministers' meeting here.

A precedent has been shattered with the arrival of the Ronne Antarctic Expedition on Stonington Island on Palmer Land, Antarctica. Two women are in the group of twenty-four persons, one of them the wife of Commander Finn Ronne, leader of the expedition, and the other the wife of Harry Darlington, chief pilot, Both are attractive.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 23 (AP) -- Valkyrie, the great J. M. MacDonald ketch from Marble-head, Mass., rewarded her backers with a sprint which, carried her within hailing distance of the pace-setting Cuban sloop Ciclon shortly after night closed in on the twentyfive-ship fleet in the fourteenth annual St. Petersburg-to-Havana sailing classic.

HYAK, Wash., March 23 -- Sverre Fredheim, 38-year-old skier from St. Paul, and 22-year-old Joey Perrault, comparative newcomers to the sport, today stole the limelight in the concluding phase of the two-day Olympic ski-jumping tryouts in Hyak Bowl before 8,000.

The Continental Oil Company and its subsidiaries announced yesterday in the annual report for 1946 net earnings of $19,013,899, equal to $4.05 a share, compared with $15,142,870, or $3.23 a share, the year before.

The Moore - McCormack Lines, Inc., had a net profit in 1946 of $3,771,000 after Federal income taxes, compared with $1,580,000 adjusted profits in 1945, Albert V. Moore, president, reported in the annual statement being distributed today.

BOSTON, March 23 (AP) -- Lincoln MacVeagh, United Ambassador to Greece, declared today that "the preservation of democracy in the land of its birth [Greece] is undeniably linked with the defense of democracy throughout the world."

Formation of an Interfraternity Congress to deal with high school fraternity problems throughout the country, including scholarship, hazing, drinking, gambling, extracurricular activities and opposition from school authorities and the public, was announced here yesterday.

GREENSBORO, N. C., March 23 (AP) -- Vic Ghezzi, the 1941 P. G. A. champion, playing out of Kansas City, Kan., put together rounds of 72 and 73 today to win the $10,000 Greensboro open golf tournament with a 286 total, two over par for the seventy-two holes.

The problem President Truman had to face when he issued his executive order on Saturday was how to make sure of loyalty among government employes and yet not violate the democratic principles which are the deep undercurrent of all our national loyalties.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The reasoning that led the United States to propose unilateral assistance to Greece and Turkey was disclosed in a Government document made available today.

Mayor O'Dwyer extended the city's welcome yesterday to safety experts gathering from many parts of the nation for the four-day Safety Convention and Exposition that will start here tomorrow. At the same time he urged New Yorkers to be careful every day in the year to avoid accidents, which last year took 3,755 lives and caused property loss of $300,000,000 in this city.

The Radio Manufacturers Association has asked the Internal Revenue Bureau to exempt the operators of television receivers in public places, such as taverns, cocktail rooms and hotel lobbies, from the 20 per cent cabaret tax, it was announced yesterday.

The Y.M.C.A. will start in May its "greatest peacetime appeal" for funds for the restoration of 105 Y.M.C.A. buildings that have been reduced to rubble or severely damaged in twenty-two war-torn countries, it was announced yesterday by Harper Sibley, chairman of its international committee.

KLAGENFURT, Austria, March 24 -- It is feared everywhere here that Yugoslavia will invade Carinthia some time after the British occupation force leaves and Carinthia will become the United Nations' grave.

MIAMI, March 24 (AP) -- Armed, Calumet Farm's great gelding, has been, taken out of training because of a deep cut on the right hind ankle received in Saturday's $25,000 handicap at Gulfstream and will be on the shelf for at least two or three weeks.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 24 -- Approximately two and a half million more homes in this country will use some form of oil burners by the end of 1950, W.A. Matheson, executive vice president of the Eureka Williams Corporation, Bloomington, Ill., predicted today.

TOKYO, March 24 -- Great Britain's political representative today added his voice to those of the chairman of the Allied Council and a vice president of the American CIO in condemning political activities of Japan's labor unions. A. D.F. Gascoigne, chief of the United Kingdom liaison mission, asserted that some unions here "have turned more to politics than is perhaps good," adding:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 24 -- Mark Hellinger, independent producer, announced today that Humphrey Bogart had agreed to make one picture a year for him for an unspecified number of years. The terms of the contract were not disclosed, but it is understood that Bogart will participate in the profits on a percentage basis.
MONTREAL, March 24 (Canadian Press) -- Gill Dodds set his own pace tonight to win the International Invitation one-mile run at a Canadian Legion indoor track meet.

Charles P. Taft of Cincinnati, the first layman to serve as president of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, chided churches yesterday for having "missed the boat 100 per cent" in the field of human relations, especially on labor-management issues, which he termed "fundamentally religious."

BALTIMORE, March 24 (U.P.) -- The Maryland Federation of Telephone Workers issued strike ballots to 2,000 workers today in preparation for a walkout on April 7. The federation is one of five Maryland unions trying to negotiate new contracts with the Chesapeake and Potomac Telephone Company.

TORONTO, March 24 (Canadian Press) -- Abitibi Power and Paper Company, Ltd., reported today its profits for 1946 were $5,600,205, of which $1,453,652 was realized in the first four months of the year, while the company was under receivership. The latter amount was credited to deficit account at the termination of receivership on April 30.

It is a little remarkable that a pianist should have the degree of lent manifested and play as badas Tota Economou, a young and rsonable Greek pianist, played first night in Carnegie Hall. For iss Economou, who studied in exandropoulis with Geza Geuei d later in Salonika with Otto ufmann, has strong and fleet gers, and a good deal of temprament.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Following is the text of the agreements made at the Berlin (Potsdam) conference between President Truman, Prime Minister Attlee and Generalissimo Stalin, as released today by the State Department: Protocol of Proceedings of Berlin Conference

A large advertising campaign for a new line of Remington Blue Streak Electric Shavers will start in May in national magazines and trade papers with Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., as the agency. A substantial cooperative newspaper advertising campaign for Father's Day promotion is a feature of the campaign.

MOSCOW, March 24 -- Secretary of State Marshall pressed the Soviet Union, Britain and France today for the reduction of occupation forces and for guarantees against the rise of a totalitarian police state in Germany.

LONDON, March 24 -- The Monarch of Bermuda, known to thousands of American vacationers who traveled in her on trips from New York to Bermuda, lay a smoking hulk in a Tyneside drydock at Hebburn tonight.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., March 24 -- The quest for new sources of oil in the United States was pressed in seventeen States last year, with about 4,000 new wells drilled, reports to the national convention of the Association of Petroleum Geologists said today.

Battered but undamaged by rough weather that forced her to heave to for fourteen hours during her ten day trip from Goeteborg, the Swedish-American liner Drottningholm docked at Pier 97, North River, yesterday with 680 passengers.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- Franklyin D. Schurz, as spokesman for 407 daily newspapers of the Midwest and Rocky Mountain States, suggested today that the Postoffice Department revise its accounting methods.
