If it does, said Mr. Schurz, who is president of the Inland Daily Press Association and secretary-treasurer and business manager of The South Bend (Ind.) Tribune, it might find that it is not costing the department as much to handle newspapers as it thinks.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 24 -- The first step toward bringing former European enemy countries within the United Nations framework was taken today by the eighteen-nation Economic and Social Council.

American Airlines, Inc., operator of the largest commercial air transport system in the United States, sustained a net loss of $252,467 in 1946, contrasted with net profit of $4,339,458 the year before, according to the annual report to stockholders, issued for publication today.

Fewer than 1 per cent of the guaranteed loans made to veterans in New York State since the inception of the loan program by the Veterans Administration late in 1945 have been defaulted, it was announced yesterday by David P. Page, deputy administrator in charge of the New York branch office of Veterans Affairs in New York State.

Steeplechase and hurdle racing in the metropolitan area will have greater money values this season than ever before, according to a decision announced yesterday by the Westchester Racing Association, which operates Belmont Park, and the Queens County Jockey Club, operator of the Aqueduct track.

MADRID, March 24 -- Opposition activity of all types has risen to a new pitch of intensity in the past couple of weeks. On the part of the monarchists, this is part of a definite plan to force the issue and attempt to produce some decisive move against the Franco regime, according to a source in close touch with the monarchist group.

The Chicago Corporation, an investment company heavily committed to "enterprise financing," reported yesterday a net profit of $7,972,884, the largest in the corporation's history, for 1946. Net profit was $6,873,592 in the preceding year.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The text of the military and other conclusions reached at the Teheran conference, as announced today by the State Department: The conference: (1) Agreed that the partisans in Yugoslavia should be supported by supplies and equipment to the greatest possible extent, and also by Commando operations;

CAIRO, Egypt, March 24 -- The Arab League adopted a resolution tonight condemning the British Administration in Palestine for its "weakness" and declaring it would argue the case before the United Nations on the basis of complete independence for Palestine as an Arab state.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The Congressional debate over how to help Greece and Turkey is developing into an argument about how to help the United Nations.

TRENTON, N.J., March 24 -- A business receipts tax or $2 on each $1,000 and a levy on machinery and equipment at one-half of municipal tax rates were proposed today by the Commission on State Tax Policy to simplify New Jersey tax procedure and raise more revenue.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., March 24 -- Shortwave broadcasts to Greece and Turkey in their native languages are being planned by the State Department to help implement President Truman's new foreign policy, William Benton, Assistant Secretary of State, disclosed here today.

Reflecting buying by merchants in near months against export sales, prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 20 to 34 points yesterday, closing steady, with July relatively stronger than other months.

MOSCOW, March 24 -- British Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin saw Premier Stalin in the Kremlin tonight, and revision of the treaty of 1942 between the Soviet Union and Britain is believed to have been one of the topics of discussion.

Last minute notification of cancellation of the annual convention of the National Association of Personnel Directors, scheduled to begin yesterday in the Hotel WaldorfAstoria, was met with surprise, and, in one case, resentment, by leading personnel executives.

Retail unit stocks of men's separate wool coats and wool trousers showed a steady increase while unit sales declined slightly in the quarter ended Jan. 31, according to a report released yesterday by Dun Bradstreet and the National Credit Office, Inc. Manufacturers' cuttings exceeded shipments in both separate wool coats and men's wool trousers.

The British King is still by title Emperor of India. His representative in India is still a Viceroy. But everyone knew when the twenty-ninth Viceroy, Viscount Mountbatten, took the oath of office yesterday at New Delhi, replacing the twenty-eighth Viceroy, Field Marshal Viscount Wavell, that these titles were fading into the historical twilight.
LYNBROOK, L.I., March 24 -- A 4-year-old girl saved her mother's life here today by toddling to a telephone in her home and calling the police after the woman had attempted to commit suicide by gas.

The Association of the Bar of the City of New York put itself on record last night in opposition to legislation seeking to restrict industry -wide bargaining, but refused to be committed on the equally controversial matter of the closed shop.

CHICAGO, March 24 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 4,000 head, total 6,500; market active; 50 to mostly 75 cents higher on all weights and sows; top $28 sparingly; bulk of good and choice 180 to 260 pound kinds,

Random notes. Islamorada, down in the Florida Keys, seems to be holding its own as the spot for big bonefish as well as plenty of them, and has just produced the leading fish in the Miami fishing tournament. The ten-pound eleven-ounce bonefish taken by A.J. Peer of Short Hills, N.J., is not holding first place.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The text of the agreements reached at the Crimea (Yalta) Conference between President Roosevelt, Prime Minister Churchill and Generalissimo Stalin, as released by the State Department today, follows: Protocol of Proceedings of Crimea Conference

New Yorkers can be docile and obedient pedestrians -- if there are enough policemen on hand to keep them so. That seems to have been the major conclusion to emerge yesterday from the Police Department's first day in the campaign to curb jaywalking.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The proposed charter for the International Trade Organization, on which an eighteen-nation conference will meet in Geneva on April 10, ran a gantlet of questioning by the Senate Finance Committee today, questioning which indicated that the committee was far from satisfied with the program.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- "If Russia had the atomic bomb it would already have been dropped on the United States," William C. Bullitt, a former Ambassador to the Soviet Union, told a Congressional committee today.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Two officials of the American Medical Association, Dr. R.L. Sensenich, chairman of the board of trustees, and Dr. James Raglan Miller, a member of the board, told the Senate Committee on Expenditures in the Executive departments today that health should have a cabinet post of its own.
Three offerings of industrial stock priced at $631,400 will be made here today by underwriters as follows: Continental Car-Na-Var Corporation, maker of floor-treating
LONDON, March 24 -- Weakness prevailed in stock markets here today and in practically every section showed losses.
Maritime labor representatives are continuing to press for passage of a bill of rights for seamen who served during the war in the United States merchant marine, it became known yesterday.

Commissioner Ernest I. Pugmire, national commander of the Salvation Army, has been relieved of his additional duties as Eastern territorial commander in charge of eleven states, by Gen. Albert Orsborn, international commander. Commissioner Pugmire will devote his entire time to national affairs and his position as Eastern territorial commander will be taken by Commissioner Donald McMillan, now national secretary.
BERLIN, March 24 -- Harold E. Stassen believes that the most important problem in Germany is mutual understanding among the four occupying powers and their ability to get together.

BADEN, Germany, March 22 (Delayed) -- The French Military Government is concentrating heavily on the regeneration of the school system and the reorientation of young people to further the desire for security from future German aggression.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Turkey's entry into World War II against the Axis was considered "most desirable" at the time of the Teheran conference in 1943 by President Roosevelt, Prime Minister Churchill and Marshal Stalin, the State Department disclosed today.

TAMPA, Fla., March 24 (AP)-- The Reds pounced on Randy Gumpert, Yankee starting pitcher, for seven runs in the first two innings, a margin which Randy's mates never could quite make up despite sixteen hits, as the Bombers went down to their second consecutive defeat, 8 to 5, today at Plant Field.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Efforts toward the establishment of a unified government in Korea have been so completely blocked by Russia that Congress may expect an early Presidential request for funds to put the southern, American-occupied, section of that country on a solid economic footing.

WASHINGTON, March 24--William L. Clayton, Under-Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, said today that $250,000,000, or 62 1/2 per cent of the proposed $400,000,program to help Greece and Turkey, would be spent on equipment for the armed forces of the two countries.

As representatives of the city and the Port Authority sit down today in what may be the final conference before decision on the disposition of our airports problem it may be illuminating to glance at the record. Although the city appears to be in a more critical situation as to its budgets than it was six months ago, there is still considerable talk of trying to muddle along with continued city operation.

SALONIKA, Greece, March 24 -- Preparatory to a sweep of the entire mountain area of Verria, in Central Macedonia about fifty miles west of here, to rid it of rebels, the Greek Army and gendarmes have begun to evacuate a number of villages.

In the smallest turnover since last July, the stock market was unable yesterday to make any gain. Prices eased moderately and closed irregularly lower, with the index down 0.24 and a few wider vairiances in some of the pivotal issues. Transfers on the Stock Exchange were the lightest since July 5, last, at 580,000 shares, against 710,000 shares on last Friday.

The Theatre Guild, which annually supplies about six stage offerings to Washington, D.C., may omit the nation's capital from its subscription dates next season if the present policy of racial discrimination persists there, it was learned yesterday.

JERUSALEM, March 24 -- The Zionist movement will seek from the United Nations a solution of the Palestine problem "which will place the fate of the Jewish people in their own hands," the executive of the Jewish Agency for Palestine declared today in a statement issued at the conclusion of its tenday emergency meeting here.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., March 24 -- Mrs. Susan Hawley Davis, a leader in Connecticut musical circles and widow of Charles Davis, former president of Davis Hawley Company, Bridgeport jewelers, died here today in the home of her daughter, Mrs. Andrew R. Smith, after a long illness.
LONDON, March 24 -- Great Britain is confident that the forthcoming tariff negotiations with the United States and fifteen other countries can be a success.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., March 24 -- The Garden City Antiques Show opened this afternoon in the Garden City Hotel with forty-five dealers displaying their wares in the ballroom and three adjacent salons. The show, under the management of Mrs. Flora Campbell Koones, will be open dally from 1 to 10 P.M. through Friday.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, March 24 -- At mass meetings today in every displacedpersons camp in the United States zone of Germany, Jews shouted approval of resolutions asking the Big Four conference in Moscow to consider their problems.

Daniel W. Blumenthal, as trustee for the benefit of certificate holders, has entered into contracts for the sale of the property at 211-225 West Sixty-first Street to the Port Morris Sales Company, and that at 2047 First Avenue to the Sinclair Refining Company.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., March 24 -- Following are excerpts from statements by Sir Alexander Cadogan, the British representative, and Herschel V. Johnson, deputy representative of the United States, at the opening session of the Commission on Conventional Armaments:

Swedish fishing smacks, freed of wartime restrictions, have been able to haul in large catches of herring, sardines and other varieties that, to a Swede, are among the principal and most pleasing foods in his diet. These sizable catches have made it possible, too, for large canning concerns there, such as Ameln Brothers, Ltd., to export again the fish products so popular here before the war.

A survey of business opinion on President Truman's program for the Geneva Trade Conference, the results of which were published in this newspaper yesterday, reveals a spirit of friendliness and cooperation that is decidedly hopeful. It suggests, indeed, that there is more than a little substance to the point made by one of the industrialists consulted that the recent public hearings on the program tended to exaggerate the strength of the opposition to tariff cuts.

New War Loan Groups The Federal Reserve Bank of New York has revised its grouping of war loan depositaries, according to announcement yesterday by Allan Sproul, president. Effective immediately, it was stated, Group A will consist of all depositaries having war loan balances of $150,000 or less at the close of business of March 22.

Replying to the New York Board of Trade's criticism of the subway service and its demand for a higher Care to finance improvements, Mayor O'Dwyer cited yesterday $66,000,000 in improvements made since January, 1946, and $47,000,000 more soon to be contracted for.

President Truman and the Federal Board of Hospitalization yesterday approved a plan for the purchase of an entire block on Manhattan's East Side for a 1,000bed medical and surgical hospital to be built for the Veterans Administration.

Store Sales Here Up 11% Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week were 11 per cent higher than a year ago, according to the "flash report" yesterday of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the four weeks ended March 22 volume rose 12 per cent.

A large exhibition of paintings by the late John Steuart Curry opened yesterday in the galleries of the Associated American Artists, 711 Fifth Avenue, to continue for three weeks. They are calling it "Twenty Years of His Art" rather than a memorial exhibition, although, if less fully rounded than one could wish, it sums up Curry's career in a generally satisfactory manner.
MOSCOW, March 24 -- The French Government has proposed a Big Four conference in Paris before July 1 to organize German emigration.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Repudiation of David E. Lilienthal, chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, and his five colleagues "would be almost fatal" to the atomic-energy program, the Senate was told today.

A year ago today the United Nations Security Council held its twenty-fourth meeting, the significance of which for us is that it was the first held on American soil. Six hundred persons crowded into the renovated gymnasium at Hunter College. Dr. Quo Tai-chi of China presided.

This is the anniversary of modern Greek independence. In New York Governor Dewey has proclaimed it Greek War Relief Day. It is a happy combination, for this year Americans contributing to the $12,000,000 fund now being raised for the Greek people will also be helping them establish a new and firmer freedom.

Earl Bunting, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, accused the United States Department of Labor yesterday of having engaged in a program designed to promote labor philosophies in educational institutions throughout the country.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The Senate passed unanimously and without debate today a bill to continue until June 30 one of the most essential parts of the Selective Service System even though the power of conscription is expiring this month.

PEIPING, March 24 -- Rival Nationalist and Communist armies in north China are reported resting, regrouping their forces and preparing for a resumption of fullscale hostilities soon. A sort of uneasy armed truce, punctuated here and there by minor clashes, has descended over the civil war major spheres in China.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, March 24 (AP) -- President Higinio Morinigo said today that the rebels in the north had failed in their attempts to overthrow his Government, and that they were attempting now to negotiate a peace.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- Exports to Europe increased $75,000,000 during January over the previous month while those to Asia declined $54,000,000, the Census Bureau reported today.

HAVANA, March 24 (AP)--Ciclon, a 51-foot, Cuban-owned sloop, today won both the fleet handicap and Class A honors in the annual St. Petersburg-Havana yacht race, although an American boat was first of the 25 starters to cross the finish line.

Joseph C. Harsch, member of the Washington news staff of the Columbia Broadcasting System, has been chosen to succeed William L. Shirer as commentator on the network at 5:45 P.M. Sundays, it was announced yesterday by Edward R. Murrow, CBS vice president and director of public affairs.

Unless the split among Orthodox Jews here is healed immediately, the relief program, for Orthodox Jewish displaced persons abroad will be endangered, Rabbi Solomon P. Wohlgelernter warned yesterday. Recently returned from twenty months in Europe, Rabbi Wohlgelernter made his statement at Vaad Hatzala Rehabilitation Committee headquarters, 132 Nassau Street.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- President Truman discussed with Congressional leaders of both parties tonight problems of supplies of certain critical materials, which will be removed from Government control on March 31. They are tin, antimony, hemp fiber, sugar, rice, cinchona and streptomycin.

LONDON, March 24 -- Despite persistent pleas from members, the Speaker of the House of Commons refused tonight to permit discussion of the fantastic case of five Gold Coast Negroes convicted of a ritual murder, whose execution was temporarily postponed for the sixth time this morning.

The twenty-fifth annual report of the Shell Union Oil Corporation and its subsidiaries, to be issued to stockholders today by R.G.A. van der Woude, president, announced a net income of $32,880,417 for 1946, equal to $2.44 a share. The net income for 1945 was $28,712,328 or $2.13 a share.

With the admonition that "you can fool some of the people only some of the time," Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz in Kings County Court turned down yesterday the offer of a felon to donate an eye to a 14-year-old girl who is totally blind.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In his message to Congress requesting aid for Greece, President Truman showed that the United States is fully aware of its global responsibilities. We hope that a method may yet be found for the United Nations to deal with this situation, possibly with the United States acting as its agent and supplying the necessary funds.

NANKING, March 24 -- The third plenary session of the Kuomintang Central Executive Committee ended its nine-day meeting today by acting to pave the way for sharing governmental authority with non-Kuomintang political leaders.

Barons and Boyars By now it is probably too late to do anything about Magna Carta, which was signed on June 15, 1215, at Runnymede-on-the -Thames. Yet it is hard to get away altogether from certain doubts about that famous piece of writing.

CHICAGO, March 24 -- William L. Clayton, Under-Secretary of State and others in the State Department today were accused of being "more interested in giving American ships away to foreign countries than helping to build a powerful merchant marine."

NEW DELHI, India, March 24 -- Amid scenes of Viceregal splendor in the Palace and turbulence in the countryside, Viscount Mountbatten took office today as Governor-General and Viceroy to begin the task of liquidating the British political position in India.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- Carleton Putnam, president of Chicago and Southern Air Lines, Inc., said today "shotgun weddings" were not the best solution for money-losing air carriers.

CHICAGO, March 24 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, told Mayor Walter E. Miller of Elgin, Ill., today that he had not used his official position to further the interest of any importer of watches.

MOSCOW, March 24 -- Foreign Minister Molotov has extended invitations to the principal Council delegates and diplomats in Moscow to what is tantamount to a command performance of the Bolshoi Theatre ballet tomorrow night.

MILWAUKEE, March 24 (U.P.) -- About 500 members of Local 248, United Automobile Workers, CIO, returned to their jobs at the Allis-Chalmers farm equipment plant today, but the company barred ninety-four others because of "disruptive acts" during the 10 1/2-month strike which the union called off yesterday.

Smokeless household space heaters, burning low-cost bituminous coal for fuel, will soon be available in quantity to meet heating equipment shortages, T.A. Day, special representative of Bituminous Coal Research, Inc., told more than 400 coal merchants here yesterday, at Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- There is an underlying reason, as yet unexpressed, for the fact that some Republicans and some members of the bipartisan economy bloc in Congress would oppose the President's GreeceTurkey aid program, or tie it up in a tight package with a very specific label, if they knew how to do either without damaging the world position of the United States vis-a-vis Soviet Russia.

Another straw indicating increased world market activity in hides was the report in the leather trade here yesterday that Russia has purchased 100,000 hides in Argentina. While the report lacked confirmation, it was widely accepted here.

The Long Island Railroad promised yesterday to comply with the order of the Public Service Commission to submit a plan for the full utilization of all available equipment to provide for the maximum number of passengers not later than April 1.

ALBANY, March 24 -- Governor Dewey signed today a bill granting to counties and larger cities power to levy special taxes, the maximum yield of which has been estimated at $111,000,000 a year. Because of local financial and political conditions, it is unlikely that all the taxing power authorized will be used.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- President Truman spent forty minutes today with his Cabinet Food Committee reviewing the world food crisis.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- A critical Senate minority gave notice today that a sharp examination of the constitution of the International Refugee Organization would be demanded tomorrow in debate on a bill authorizing United States adherence to that association.

More than seventy medical research projects were under way in 1946 as an integrated effort of the College of Physicians and Surgeons and the Presbyterian Hospital at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, it was said yesterday in the annual report of the hospital, made public by Charles P. Cooper, its president.

HYAK, Wash., March 24 -- The United States Olympic ski team, expected to make a serious bid to the supremacy enjoyed by the Alpine and Scandinavian nations in these games next year at St. Moritz, Switzerland, was completed today with the official announcement of the addition of two more to the jumping squad.
Casual fabrics with a feminine touch provided the high spot of interest in a spring fashion showing by Russeks yesterday in the St. Regis Hotel.

LONDON, March 24 (AP) -- The odds on the leading contenders for Saturday's 103d running of the Grand National steeplechase at Aintree came in for a general reshuffling today, with last year's winner, John Morant's Lovely Cottage, dropping all the way to 50 to 1 because of reports he hasn't been training well.

Ralph Hollander gave his first solo recital last night at Town Hall. It was not his first appearance in the auditorium though. He was soloist there with the Harmony Guild of New York three years ago and earlier this season he led the Hollander Quartet at Ruth Freeman's concert.
The police searched the junkfilled home of the Collyer brothers at 2078 Fifth Avenue for three hours yesterday, but found no trace of Langley Collyer, missing since Thursday.

WITH both baseball and basketball fighting for the headlines in their overlapping seasons, the easiest, most appropriate and most timely double-play is to wrap them up in the same package for a twin killing. There is only one man now active in either sport who left his mark indelibly on both, Stanley Raymond Harris, the manager of the New York Yankees.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 24 -- A new international body designed to restore the power and prestige of Europe without recourse to politics was born here today. It is called the Independent League for European Cooperation and the pro tem head of it is Paul van Zeeland.

ST. LOUIS, March 24 (AP) -- Seven women and five men, all but one of them parents, were chosen today for the Juvenile Court jury which will try Mary Catherine Reardon, 14 years old, for the death of her father, a wealthy St. Louis paint manufacturer.

Analysis of conditions leading to increased cancellation of medium and higher priced women's apparel indicate a much lower rate of turnover in coat, suit and dress departments so far this year, according to trade sources yesterday. Such cancellations which are coming in large measure from specialty shops it was pointed out, are also indicative of overbuying by merchants who had their first opportunity to place volume orders after many seasons of hand to mouth buying.

AMSTERDAM, Mar. 24 (ANETA) -- Prices on the Stock Exchange moved upward in expectation of the signing of the Linggadjati agreement. Industrials, shipping and Indies plantation issues were higher. Bank stocks closed lower while State bonds were unchanged.

Forty years of fault-finding in every State in this country were recalled yesterday by Charles P. Berkey, Newberry Professor Emeritus of Geology at Columbia University, as a profitable and exciting career.

PHILADELPHIA, March 24 -- Registration statements covering $19,000,000 of first mortgage bonds and 100,000 shares of preferred stock were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by two companies.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 24 -- The United States and Great Britain joined today in declaring that they would accept general disarmament only on condition that compliance was guaranteed by a system of international inspection.

Midnight still was an hour away, but the clock was wrong -- as wrong as all the experts who predicted that Utah didn't have a chance against mighty Kentucky in the final of the tenth annual National Invitation college basketball tournament at Madison Square Garden last night.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 24-- Amid a bizarre setting of swaying palms and not far distant from the winter quarters of the Ringling circus, Commissioner A. B. (Happy) Chandler today conducted his extraordinary hearing to sift the charges fired broadside by Larry MacPhail, explosive president of the Yankees, into the ranks of the Dodgers family.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- A nation-wide strike of telephone workers was set for 6 o'clock on the morning of April 7 by the policy committee of the National Federation of Telephone Workers today.

With neary 200 mentors from various sections of the country in attendance at the Belvedere Hotel yesterday, the National Association of Basketball Coaches began its annual meeting and heard numerous proposals for rules changes. Of the lot, however, three suggestions will be passed on to the rules committee for immediate action.

CHICAGO, March 24 -- Heavy buying of May wheat and corn, attributed to cash interests and presumably representing export sales of corn and wheat flour to continental Europe, gave the grain markets a strong tone on the Board of Trade today.

With the curt declaration that he was not accustomed to having people tell him what subjects he can discuss, former Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia announced yesterday that he had canceled a scheduled Dr. Dowling Memorial Lecture at Birmingham-Southern College in Alabama.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The letter of Prof. Herbert R. Northrup, published in the times of March 12, on the matter of the National Labor Relations Board and professional employes requires refutation from someone with practical experience on the subject.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The writer of your editorial on President Truman's gracious gesture in decorating the monument (not the tomb) in Mexico City to "Los Ninos Heroes" justly pays tribute to the memory of the gallant lads who joined in the defense of Chapultepec against General Scott's troops on Sept. 13, 1847.

CHICAGO, March 24 -- Jack Johnston, 70 years old, a professional golfer, was shot below the heart in the British Consulate here today when he went to the aid of Patrick O'Reilly, 38 years old, a guard who was attempting to eject a ruffian.

One year ago at this time the United Mine Workers were about to go on strike; the longest and most costly strike in the history of the automobile industry had just ended, and a nationwide strike was threatened on the railways. By way of contrast, the first threat of a major strike to appear in 1947 has just been averted by an agreement in the rubber industry.

Holy Cross and Oklahoma University, having survived their respective regional preliminaries, will clash tonight at Madison Square Garden with the N.C.A.A. basketball championship at stake. This contest will follow the thirdplace play-off battle between C.C.N.Y. and Texas, starting at 7:45 P.M.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- While the bill appears bound to pass the House, storm signals are ahead in the Senate. Senator Walter P. George, Democrat, of

PARIS, March 24 -- Unless the civil war is ended in Greece, the economic aid proposed by President Truman will be useless, John Sophianopoulis, former Greek Foreign Minister, has told the Foreign Affairs Committee of the French National Assembly, it was disclosed today.

LONDON, March 24 -- The British Government is arranging for the publication within the next few days of the complete texts of the Yalta and Potsdam Agreements, Hector McNeil, Minister of State, announced in the House of Commons today.

Work on the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel, virtually at a standstill since Thursday because of a wildcat strike of 1,200 compressed air and maintenance workers, will resume as soon as the contractors agree to a six-hour day, strike leaders said yesterday.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, March 23 (Delayed) -- Dr. Eugen Kogon, who was a prisoner in Buchenwald for seven years and has since become known for a book called "The SS State," disclosed today that he had spent three days in the Darmstadt internment camp at the request of Greater Hesse's Denazification Ministry.
JERUSALEM, March 24 -- Armed men believed to be members of the Irgun Zvai Leumi robbed a Tel Aviv bank of $109,000 in daylight today.
Admiral Thomas C. Kinkaid, commander of the Eastern Sea Frontier, yesterday blamed American Communists and the Soviet Union for the warlike tensions existing in the world today.

EIGHTH ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Yokohama, Japan, March 24 -- More than 12,000 Japanese and a handful of Allied nationals have been tried before the occupation's Provost Courts established almost exactly a year ago, a survey showed today.

LONDON, March 24 -- As the melting of the unprecedented snow blanket spread floods to the whole of England today, Thomas Williams, Minister of Agriculture, described the situation as "a disaster of the first magnitude." The disaster will have a most serious effect on Britain's food production for this year, he said.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 24 -- An impressive funeral service was held in the Cathedral of St. John here this afternoon for the Right Rev. James De Wolf Perry, presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episeopal Church in America from 1930 to 1937, who died Thursday at the age of 75.

CHICAGO, March 24 -- The purchase price of new machine tools should be written off in one year. Herbert H. Pease, president of the National Machine Tool Builders Association, declared today in an address before the spring meeting of the National Machine Tool Distributors Association.

An understanding of each other's history and traditions by the East and West was urged yesterday by Dr. Raymond B. Fosdick, president of the Rockefeller Foundation, as vital to finding a basis for bridging the "ideological chasms" now dividing the world.

Work on the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel, virtually at a standstill since Thursday because of a wildcat strike of 1,200 compressed air and maintenance workers, will resume as soon as the contractors agree to a six-hour day, strike leaders said yesterday.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, March 23 (Delayed) -- Dr. Eugen Kogon, who was a prisoner in Buchenwald for seven years and has since become known for a book called "The SS State," disclosed today that he had spent three days in the Darmstadt internment camp at the request of Greater Hesse's Denazification Ministry.
JERUSALEM, March 24 -- Armed men believed to be members of the Irgun Zvai Leumi robbed a Tel Aviv bank of $109,000 in daylight today.
Admiral Thomas C. Kinkaid, commander of the Eastern Sea Frontier, yesterday blamed American Communists and the Soviet Union for the warlike tensions existing in the world today.

EIGHTH ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Yokohama, Japan, March 24 -- More than 12,000 Japanese and a handful of Allied nationals have been tried before the occupation's Provost Courts established almost exactly a year ago, a survey showed today.

MONTREAL, March 24 -- The failure of the democratic brand of socialism now being tried in Great Britain and of the totalitarian socialism of the Soviet Union is inevitable, Robert R. Wason, chairman of the board of the National Association of Manufacturers, told the Canadian Club of Montreal today.

The Jamaica Chamber of Commerce appealed yesterday to the Board of Estimate to approve at its meeting Thursday the proposal of Jamaica business men to ease traffic congestion in their Queens community, third largest retail shopping area in the city.

ROBERT NATHAN has been writing novels for twenty-eight years, long enough for most readers of current fiction to know just where they stand on the controversial matter of the Nathan brand of fiction. A considerable, loyal and discriminating group has found an unfailing source of pleasure in the ironic fantasy, the gentle wisdom and the delicate beauty of Mr. Nathan's writing.
Blind children who have been forced to use the subways and other public transportation to get to school will soon have special bus service sponsored by the Board of Education.

Loans by all commercial banks in the United States, in 1946, were more than $5,000,000,000 higher than in 1945 and stood at $32,000,000,000 on Dec. 31, according to the March Federal Reserve Bulletin, released here yesterday. The total outstanding was the greatest since 1930.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Controversy over the record of Edgar L. Warren, director of the Labor Department's Conciliation Service, who was attacked as a Communist sympathizer and defended as a brilliant administrator, was the highlight today in the House debate on appropriations for labor activities in the next fiscal year.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 24 -- Smooth operation of Westchester's $1,600,000-a-year Parkway toll plan, now scheduled to begin on June 1, would be delayed another six months if Governor Dewey failed to sign by next Monday the three latest toll-enabling acts passed recently by the Legislature, county officials said today.

New York spent more per capita for the education of its children last year than at any other time in its history, according to the thirty-sixth annual financial and statistical report of the Board of Education made public yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- House Republicans in a party conference today raised a front of unanimity among those present in support of the majority's tax reduction bill.

Akron, Ohio, announced yesterday that it would offer on April 14 an issue of $3,000,000 of City School District bonds dated May 1, 1947, due on each Dec. 1 from 1947 to 1969 and bearing interest of not more than 2 per cent.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- Senator C. Douglass Buck, Republican, of Delaware, chairman of the Senate rent subcommittee, said today that his group has approved a bill transferring rent controls from OPA to the Housing Expediter, Frank R. Creedon.

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 24 -- In the same court room over which he had presided for twenty years former Federal District Judge Albert Johnson, 74 years old, of Lewisburg, Pa., was acquitted today by a Federal court jury of charges of conspiring to obstruct justice and to defraud the United States in receivership, bankruptcy and criminal cases.

The Delman spring collection shown yesterday at the salon at 754 Fifth Avenue had many interesting new trends. One was every vestige of more practicality; the shoes were imaginatively and beautifully designed and there were over 100 styles from which to choose.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company rejected last night a union demand for industrywide bargaining, but held the door open for wage arbitration on a local basis.
Extension of the Greater New York Red Cross 1947 Fund Drive into April was indicated yesterday by campaign officials at a report luncheon in the Hotel Commodore.
BATAVIA, Java, March 25-- Representatives of the Netherlands and of the Indonesian Republic signed the "Cheribon Agreement" tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The Greek Government has filed with the World Bank a notice of intention to apply for a loan of an unspecified amount as soon as plans for rehabilitation are complete, the Bank announced here today.

The formation of an organization composed of 150 painters, sculptors and graphic artists for the protection and advancement of their economic interests was announced last night by its president, Yasuo Kuniyoshi.

The annual pamphlet report of the United States Steel Corporation can invariably be depended upon to provide more than its share of thoughtprovoking facts as to what is happening to American industry. The report covering Steel's forty-fifth year of operation is no exception in that respect.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The current Police Department campaign to educate pedestrians by means of admonitory leaflets ignores the basic cause of jaywalking: our improperly geared traffic light system.

The percentage of surplus machine tools to be scrapped by the War Assets Administration should now be Increased to 30 or 40 per cent of the total, machinery distributors disclosed here yesterday, Individually, they approved the five-point plan of accelerated disposal presented at the annual meeting of the American Machine Tool Distributors Association yesterday at Chicago by Robert L. Giebel, president of Giebel, Inc., of New York City.

WASHINGTON, March 25--The Korean Pacific Press Service, which has offices here, predicted today that an interim independent government would be established in south Korea, with United States support, within thirty to sixty days.

The executive committee of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America in monthly session yesterday adopted as an interim statement, a resolution calling on the Federal Government to clear the proposed aid to Greece and Turkey with the United Nations.

WARSAW, March 25--The Polish Government announced today that more than 50,000 persons in the Warsaw region had been made homeless by the rampaging waters of the Bug and Wkra Rivers where they tumble into the Vistula twenty -five miles north of this capital.

Old pieces of furniture that remind one member of the household of a lovely childhood do not necessarily contribute to a sound home for our children, Kim Hoffmann, interior designer, cautioned homemakers yesterday. "Besides, just because grandmother owned that piece of furniture, we have no guarantee that her taste did not slip," he added.
Led by the strength in May, the cotton futures market yesterday closed steady, 6 to 19 points higher.

WASHINGTON, March 25--The United States has "strongly protested" to Sweden her imposition of the general import prohibition that went into effect on March 15 as a protection for her foreign exchange position because it made exceptions in favor of Russia and other European countries.

PITTSBURGH, March 25--The Pittsburgh Consolidation Coal Company said today that it plans to switch a vast western Pennsylvania soft coal tract over to the manufacture of gas, high-octane gasoline and alcohol through a process still under development.

WASHINGTON, March 25--General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, urging passage of the Army-Navy Unification Bill, eloquently affirmed today his belief that a citizen can be found in the United States who can fill the position of Secretary of National Defense and treat all the services fairly and decently.

WASHINGTON, March 25--The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended March 19: Decreases of $615,000,000 in holdings of Treasury notes and $308,000,000 in United States Government deposits, reflecting the redemption of maturing notes and Treasury calls on war loan deposits: and an increase of $219,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted.

During the last fifteen years, the Cities Service Company has reduced its consolidated debt by more than $211,000,000, W. Alton Jones, president, disclosed in his 1946 report, which will be distributed to stockholders today. The annual meeting is scheduled for April 29 in Dover, Del.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (U.P.) --The staff of the House Labor Committee has drafted a sweeping labor control bill which would deny rights under the Wagner Act to Communist-dominated unions, it was learned today. The tentative draft of the measure called the "Labor-Management Peace Act of 1947," was prepared for committee discussion under the direction of its chairman, Representative Fred A. Hartley Jr., Republican, of New Jersey.

HERSHEY, Pa., March 25 (AP)-- Percy Alexander Staples, who says he is "just a New England Yankee taking things in stride," today took over the presidency of the Hershey Chocolate Corporation, succeeding William F. R. Murrie.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Thoughtful Americans, properly interested in the welfare and future of China, are much disturbed over the current bad relations between the Chinese Communists, who control large areas in northern China, and the recognized National Government, headed by ChiangKai-shek.

Sweden will impose further restrictions on her industries to bring about an increased exportation of wood pulp, Ivar Rooth, governor, State Bank of Sweden, declared yesterday. Lack of coal and coke has forced the use of wood as fuel, he pointed out, and reduced pulp exports were in part responsible for the unfavorable trade balance which brought about, the embargo on luxury goods instituted eleven days ago.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP)-- Charles A. Heiss, a Post Office Department consultant, today described as "bunk" the contentions of some publishers that they should be given a cheaper mail rate because what they publish is educational, scientific or cultural.

PARIS, March 25--France's nationalized gas and electrical industries will require a subsidy of 18,000,000,000 francs for the coming year, it was learned today. This is about $151,000,000 at the legal exchange rate.

MOSCOW, March 25 (AP)--The text of Secretary of State Marshall's statement to the Council of Foreign Ministers on a German peace conference: The American deputy refrained from taking a positive position on the peace conference.

WASHINGTON, March 25-- Counsel for the United Mine Yorkers asked Justice T. Alan Goldsborough of the Federal District Court of the District of Columbia today to write "finis" to the contempt of court convictions of the union and its president, John L. Lewis.

Mayor O'Dwyer was able to report some progress toward rehabilitating our subway system in reply to the Board of Trade's sharp criticisms. He cited $66,000,000 in improvements since January, 1946, when he came into office, and $47,000,000 more soon to be contracted for.

Removal of red tape in foreign trade would save manufacturers, importers and exporters many millions of dollars, according to a report released yesterday by the United States Associates of the International Chamber of Commerce.

Ten persons, including the 64year-old mother of a police sergeant who was being taken to the French Hospital, suffered minor injuries early last night in the rush-hour crash of a southbound Broadway bus and a westbound Police Department ambulance at Broadway and Twenty-third Street.

Capturing the renowned British film star, James Mason, for a play on this side must have fired the ambition of Broadway producers on every rung of the ladder. Oftentimes the least expected happens in the theatre, and that's just what occurred in this instance.

Impi Spreads Terror Graybeards in the population, who have wondered now and then about the time spent by their small grandsons on the masked bandits and gallant rangers of radio and the comics, may have had their thoughts sent back a good many years by a recent brief dispatch from South Africa.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE TIMES of March 22 reports that the House Appropriations Committee has recommended a substantial reduction in the appropriations for the United States Conciliation Service.
QUINCY, Mass., March 25 (AP)-- The 100th ship built at the Quincy yard of the Bethlehem Steel Company since Pearl Harbor--the airconditioned cruiser Salem -- was launched today.

In his annual statistical survey released yesterday, Harry L. Lourie, executive vice president of the National Association of Alcoholic Beverage Importers, Inc., warned that the alcoholic beverage industry in the United States is now faced with a period of liquidation of its excess inventories.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 25-- While world diplomats concerned themselves with the enigmatic mosaic of the Near East and bordering states, scholars discussed here today how East and West might live in harmony.

Holland, despite its war damage, will be ready for all the tourists that planes and ships can bring to her this spring, Dr. Albert Plesman, president of Royal Dutch Airlines, KLM, said yesterday. Dr. Plesman, a vigorous advocate of freedom of the air, was interviewed in the Wings Club in the Biltmore Hotel.

Much of the chaos and misery in Greece could be lifted if Premier Stalin were to give the word, former President Herbert Hoover declared last night as he appealed for greater private relief for Greece.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 25-- As an aftermath of the New York City investigation of attempts to "fix" the New York Giant-Chicago Bear professional football championship, the Union County Grand Jury here indicted today ten persons. The report handed up to Judge Walter L. Hetfield by the January jury also criticized the Elizabeth Police Department for laxity and indifference.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (U.P.) --The text of the letter of resignation of Arthur Bliss Lane as Ambassador to Poland: March 21, 1947. My Dear Mr. President: I have the honor to request you to be good enough to accept my resignation as American Ambassador to Poland on the termination of my present period of consultation with the Department of State, that is, on March 31, 1947.

Wood pulp for export has been freed from price control by the Swedish Government, it was learned yesterday from New York pulp importers. The pulp industry in Sweden will exercise its own controls to limit price rises to $25 per ton over current levels, according to private cable advices.

The United Gas Improvement Company reported yesterday that operations in 1946 resulted in a balance for the capital stock of $2,388,013, compared with $1,268,877 in 1945. Earnings per share last year amounted to $1.52 for each of the 1,566,378 shares outstanding, compared with 55 cents for each of the 2,315,985 shares at the close of 1945.

This city has some of the country's best health services but not nearly enough to take good care of its children, Dr. C.-E.A. Winslow, Professor Emeritus of Public Health, Yale University, declared yesterday.

MOSCOW, March 25 (AP)--Greek Ambassador Athanasios Politis, with a row of medals on his chest and a beaming smile on his face, listened to poppingchampagne corks and the gay laughter of his guests tonight and thoughtfullydecided the day had been saved for Greece.

The rustle of spring was heard at the Ritz-Carlton yesterday when Macy's presented a show starring crisp fabrics that swished gently as the models came down the runway. Black taffeta made the bodice that tied in a sash at one side of a black and white dotted print.

Although receipts of the United States Steel Corporation from the sale of steel and other products in 1946 were the highest for any peace-time year in the company's history, earnings were the lowest per dollar of sales for any peacetime year of comparable volume, according to Irving S. Olds, chairman, in the annual statement to stockholders, released for publication today.

Traditionally rasping March winds, ranging up to sixty miles an hour, tore at everything movable in New York yesterday, giving residents in exposed areas the impression that their city was being blown down piecemeal by successive gusts.

WASHINGTON, March 25--William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, today termed legislation proposing to outlaw the Communist party "tantamount to a declaration of voluntary bankruptcy of the ideas and ideals of American democracy."

The second day of the police search through the Collyer home at 2078 Fifth Avenue produced five tons of assorted junk and a sick cat yesterday, but no sign of Langley Collyer, missing' since Thursday.

WASHINGTON, March 25--The Senate approved today a bill to put the United States into the International Refugee Organization, but with the most sharp and positive qualification that no softening of American immigration policy was to be implied.

A banking group headed by Kidder, Peabody Co. received yesterday the award of an issue of $5,100,000 of bonds of Allegheny County, Pa., maturing April 1 from 1948 to 1977 on a bid of 100.96 for 1 3/4s. Other bids for the same interest rate ranged from 100.87 to 100.279.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., March 25 -- The Soviet Union vetoed a move today by the United Nations Security Council to accuse Albania of indirect responsibility for the laying of a Corfu Channel minefield that tore apart two British destroyers and killed forty-four sailors.

Buyers' Total Lower Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 880, against 1,365 last week and 1,884 in the corresponding week of 1946, according to listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES.
Back from Canada and Boston, Jean Borotra worked out yesterday in preparation for the benefit tennis matches tomorrow evening at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

ALBANY, March 25--Restaurants, bars and grills can sell liquor on credit by obtaining a special permit from the State Liquor Authority, under the terms of a bill that became law today with the signature of Governor Dewey.

For the Oratorio Society of New York, now in its seventy-fourth season, Bach's B minor Mass has become a ritual. It is performed with joy and affection but one never forgets that basically the approach is devotional. Since last night's performance at Carnegie Hall of Bach's towering score was the twenty-first complete presentation by the society, it is not surprising that certain procedures have become ritualized and perhaps standardized.

WASHINGTON, March 25-- George D. Aiken, chairman of the Senate Committee on Expenditures in the Executive Departments, today told witnesses that persons wanting a Cabinet post of health, education and welfare "will have to find a meeting place before legislation is enacted."

WASHINGTON, March 25--Very quietly, as befits his office and his duty, Fleet Admiral William D. Leahy is playing an important part in the projection of the new foreign policy, known as the Truman Doctrine, which he had a considerable share in formulating.

WASHINGTON, March 25--The proposed international trade organization came under new Senatorial fire today with development of the thesis in Finance Committee hearings that its power may be greater than that of the Social and Economic Council of the United Nations, under which it would function.
LONDON, March 25--The British Government has no intention of withdrawing completely from Greece and Turkey and leaving everything to the United States, it was made clear here today.

A large loan exhibition of oils and water-colors by Paul Cezanne will open with a preview this evening at Wildenstein's, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street. The show was arranged as a benefit for the New York Infirmary. For the gala preview tonight the admission fee is $6, tax included, and thereafter it will be 60 cents.

BERLIN, March 25--The first four German trustees appointed to handle I.G. Farbenindustrie's plants in conformity with the Allied Control Council's directive dissolving the vast cartel were appointed today in Stuttgart.

BERLIN, March 25--Maj. Gen. Frank A. Keating, deputy military governor, agreed today to permit a trainload of 700 Poles, including women and children, to pass through the American zone en route from France to Poland following the detention of the train two weeks ago.
No proper evaluation of the news today can be made without the atomic bomb as the frame of reference, William L. Laurence, science reporter of THE NEW YORK TIMES, told 500 teachers yesterday.

BRUSSELS, March 25--Premier Paul-Henri Spaak, in a statement of the new Government's policy, forecast in parliament today that taxation would be reduced to encourage private industry. He added that the Government opposed all general salary increases.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 25 (AP)--One of the biggest upsets of the Florida racing season developed today when Mrs. Alfred Roberts' War Watch, at 1 to 4, ran third while Battlefire, a 14-to-1 shot, captured the Fort Pierce Purse before 10,486 fans who bet $706,862 at Gulfstream Park.

PARIS, March 25--Camilla Chautemps, pre-war Premier who has lived in Washington since 1940, was condemned in absentia today by the High Court of Justice to five years' labor, national degradation for life and the confiscation of his property.

JERUSALEM, March 25--Since Palestine's civil governor and military commander are in London for important political and military talks, speculation has started here on Britain's prospects of retaining strategic bases here under the United Nations' new dispensation.

For greater efficiency in removing debris from New York Harbor, a new catamaran-type drift collector has been designed recently and will be constructed in the near future, the District Engineers Office, Corps of Engineers, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Douglas MacCollum Stewart, former publisher of Scribner's Commentator, was acquitted by a Federal district court jury today of a perjury charge. The Government had accused him of falsehood in testifying to a grand jury in 1943 regarding the source of $15,000 he admitted receiving in 1941.

MOSCOW, March 25--The Foreign Ministers' deputies for the Austrian treaty made distinct advances in the direction of a treaty draft this morning. Not only did they agree on a final figure limiting Austria's future army, but Fedor T. Gusev of Russia dropped his opposition to use of the word "Nazi" in defining banned political movements.

Although it lacks the thrill of salmon or tuna fishing, it has one advantage these two forms of sport lack--you can do it now. So load the family in the car and see how much of a dent you can make in the flounder population of Peconic or Great South Bay.

Mrs. Elisha Walker will give a tea this afternoon at her home, 33 East Sixty-ninth Street, for members of the Social Service Department of Memorial Hospital Center for Cancer and Allied Diseases. Each guest has been requested to bring packages of useful and decorative articles suitable for resale later at the Stuyvesant Square Thrift Shop, from which the Social Service Department derives part of its support.
LONDON, March 25--Britain and Northern Ireland produced more than half the world total of merchant ships built during 1946, according to Lloyd's Register, being published tomorrow.
The field in the men's division of the Eastern indoor tennis championships at the Eighth Regiment Armory, Bronx, was narrowed down to eight yesterday as the quarter-final bracket was completed.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP)-- The rise in the value of manufacturers' inventories was greater than that of their shipments into trade channels in January, and the increase in shipments was greater than that in new orders, the Commerce Department reported today.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 25-- The shortcomings revealed by his pitching staff in Honolulu command Mel Ott's fullest attention these days and the hurlers are sure to be under the most critical observation during the second half of the series, to be resumed with the San Francisco Seals tomorrow.

BERLIN, March 25--At least 17,000 Germans were homeless and several were known to be dead as the Oder River burst its banks today near Kuestrin, about fifty miles due east of Berlin. The rapidly rising waters already had covered more than 600 square kilometers [about 148,263 acres].

TOKYO, March 25--An extension of the present Diet session appeared inevitable this evening as Opposition parties, in a determined filibuster, continued to block consideration of the Government's proposed revision of the voting law for the general election next month.
A uniform labor relations policy or all city departments and agencies under him was announced yeserday by Mayor O'Dwyer.

American womanhood "in many respects has become the model for Chinese women," Mrs. Henry Lin, president of the National Committee of the Y.W.C.A. in China and wife of the president of Shanghai University, declared yesterday at National Board Y.W.C.A. headquarters, 600 Lexington Avenue.

MOSCOW, March 25--Secretary of State Marshall urged today that the Council of Foreign Ministers, including China as well as the Big Four, summon a general peace conference of all the states that were at war with Germany to consider the draft of a peace settlement.

CHICAGO, March 25 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows HOGS Salable hogs, 2,000 head, total 4,000: most hogs 270 pounds and under, 25 to 50 cents higher; weights over 270 pounds slow and very uneven, steady to 50 cents higher; market

MOSCOW, March 25 -- The United States has received less than $275,000,000 in German reparations, according to a statement circulated in the Council of Foreign Ministers by the United States delegation today.

The Monsanto Chemical Company of St. Louis has inaugurated engineering plans for construction involving $50,000,000 for facilities to produce new post-war products, and has already started its previously announced $22,000,000 construction program, Edgar M. Queeny, chairman, informed stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday in St. Louis.

NEVIL SHUTE, the British aeronautical engineer who is known to much of the world as a popular novelist, is not a subtle literary craftsman. He always has more than a spot of trouble with the mechanical construction of his books. He is not much of a hand at characterization either, and ia particularly inept when it comes to heroines.

Finch Junior College of 52 East Seventy-eighth Street filed plans yesterday through W. Stuart Thompson and Phelps Barnum, architects, for an eleven-story and penthouse building which will be used as a college dormitory.

WASHINGTON, March 25--In an unscheduled outbreak, the $400,000,000 Greek-Turkish antitotalitarian aid program today went under attack in the Senate by Senator Claude Pepper, Democrat, of Florida. With his assault Senator Pepper precipitated debate and reaction that appeared to foreshadow bitterness and high controversy when the legislation to implement the so-called Truman Doctrine reaches the floor for a decision.

STEPHENVILLE, Nfld., March 25 (AP)--Nine crewmen of a United States Army C-54 transport which crash-landed in rugged country twenty-five miles south of here Sunday rested safely at Harmon Field tonight after being flown out of the wilderness by a helicopter rescue plane.

The trustees of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad yesterday told the security holders in the road's report for 1946 that the record year of peacetime gross revenues produced a return of only 1/4 of 1 per cent on the company's depreciated investment.

Representatives of the city and the Port of New York Authority spent three hours yesterday afternoon discussing the authority's proposal to operate La Guardia Field and Idlewild Airport, and if they came to any agreement it was not apparent when they finished their session in the office of Controller Lazarus Joseph.

The new group of interiors presented by Herman Miller shows what a home can look like when all the decorative elements are of contemporary design and are put together by one who understands modern home planning. The display was opened yesterday at the concern's showroom for achitects, decorators and their clients at 1 Park Avenue.

LONDON, March 25 (AP)--The field for Saturday's 103d Grand National Steeplechase at Aintree was cut to sixty-two horses today with withdrawal of M.J. Anderson's Great Patrick, 50-to-1 outsider that had won one of his last two starts and finished second in the other.

BERLIN, March 25--Standing room only remained today for the first reappearance in Berlin of Walter Gieseking, Germany's topranking pianist, who is scheduled to fill four professional engagements here during the next fortnight. Until recent weeks he had been banned from giving concerts in the American zone of occupation on the basis of his record of performances under Nazi auspices during the Hitler regime and the munificence of fees he had collected from these programs.

WASHINGTON, March 25--The policy committee of the National Federation of Telephone Workers rejected today the proposal by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company that wage negotiations be carried on locally.

The Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert yesterday became Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of New York, it was learned last night. He succeeds the Right Rev. William T. Manning, for the last twenty-five years the bishop, who is now retired.

AMSTERDAM, March 25 (Aneta) --Prices on the Stock Exchange rose sharply as a result of the signing of the Linggadjati agreement. Oils, industrials, Indies plantation issues and bank stocks were higher. Shipping shares were firm while State bonds closed lower.

CHICAGO, March 25--Harry Lundeberg, president of the Sea farers International Union, American Federation of Labor, today called on members of the Canadian Seamen's Union to take the initiative to clean the union of Communists. The CSU was ousted from the AFL-SIU in 1944 for refusing to repudiate the Communist party.
A resolution calling upon Congress to investigate the "all-time high" level of food prices was adopted unanimously yesterday by the City Council.
WASHINGTON, March 25--Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower told a National Press Club audience today that no nation in the world at the present time "would deliberately provoke war."

No living Englishman recalls any such series of natural disasters as Britain has suffered this year. Having dug itself at last out of the heaviest snowfall on record, the nation is now swept by unprecedented floods, only just beginning to subside. The damage already counted is immense.

LONDON, March 25--A sharp recovery in British Government stocks was a cheering influence in the stock markets today. Jobbers reported a fairly big volume of buying orders from the public and gains of as much as three-quarters were recorded.

As inmates of an adjoining tier of cells watched, a convicted slayer of two men savagely attacked a prison guard with a penknife and a metal mop wringer in a desperate and futile attempt to escape from a steel-barred detention room on the seventh floor of the Tombs, it became known yesterday.

Amateur Athletic Union basketball teams in the United States and all quintets in numerous foreign countries will play next season under the same set of rules adopted by American colleges, it was disclosed yesterday as the National Rules Committee opened a two-day session.

MADRID, March 25--The body of the late dictator Miguel Primo de Rivera left Madrid tonight on a special train for final burial at his birthplace, Jerez, after receiving every honor that the Spanish Government could bestow.

Dun Bradstreet has assembled the blockfront on the east side of Church Street, from Park Place to Barclay Street, next to the Woolworth Building, as the site for an imposing office structure, it became known last night.

ALBANY, March 25--Governor Dewey approved today a bill by Assemblyman William Mackenzie incorporating into the State Insurance Law the major recommendations of the so-called Guertin report. It provides for use of a new mortality table in computing premiums and changes the method of computing cash surrender and nonforfeiture values on future life policies.

ROME, Wednesday, March 26-- The Lateran Agreement of 1929 between Italy and the Holy See was made an integral part of the Constitution today by a vote of 350 to 149 in the Constituent Assembly. As a result, the Constitution will recognize Catholicism, as "the only state religion" and Vatican City as an independent state, with the Pope as its temporal ruler.

PHILADELPHIA, March 25-- Revision of school textbooks, to eliminate nationalistic bias and stress the importance of world understanding, was advocated today by educators attending the American National Conference on the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

PARIS, March 25 -- The rearrest of Col. Rene Hardy, former Resistance leader who was acquitted in a sensational trial in January of charges of treason, has produced a new element in the numerous scandals, plots and arms discoveries that the political parties are now exploiting against one another in the disturbed situation in France.

On the authority of the State Department, the complete texts of all the secret agreements made at Teheran, at Yalta and at Potsdam have now been made public. (They were printed in full in this newspaper yesterday.) Nothing, says the State Department, has been held back.

Trading on the stock market continued at a slow pace yesterday with prices declining moderately, although the pressure was absent. The steel and motor shares were off fractions to a point or more at the lows of the session. Turnover was 660,000 shares, compared with 580,000 on Monday, the final hour accounting for 260,000 shares of the total.
A warning of new kinds of accident hazards to come in the age of jet propulsion and atomic energy marked the opening day, yesterday, of New York's seventeenth annual Safety Convention and Exposition.

CENTRALIA, Ill., Wednesday, March 26--A total of 118 coal miners trapped 540 feet underground by an explosion yesterday afternoon were still in the mine with little or no hope of survival early today.

At the first "working" session of the Foreign Ministers Council yesterday in Moscow--as distinguished from its previous "expository" meetings--Secretary Marshall proposed the calling of a general peace conference in which all nations which have been at war with Germany would participate on the basis of equal rights.

ROME, March 25--Believing that Ivan Matteo Lombardo, head of the Italian economic mission that is scheduled to go to the United States next month, is a pro-Communist, the State Department is understood to have suggested to the Italian Government that his trip be postponed.
HAVANA, March 25--The fourteenth St. Petersburg-to-Havana yacht race ended today as the last of the competing craft reached Havana Harbor.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 25--Dr. Charles Malik, delegate of Lebanon to the United Nations Economic and Social Council, will ask the Council to create an economic commission for the Near East, it was learned today. His request will be submitted for the next session of the Council, scheduled for July.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Five Senators introduced a bill today that would torpedo the present United States Atomic Energy Commission, replacing it with a board headed by Secretary of State Marshall.

In his testimony before the House Foreign Affairs Committee UnderSecretary of State Acheson stressed the difference in the situation of Greece and Turkey. The difference is quite evident in the hitherto "secret" reports circulated in Washington and now widely published to acquaint the public with conditions in the two countries we are asked to build up into a kind of breakwater against the tide of Soviet expansion.
A campaign is in progress to prosecute all veterans who are collecting the $20 weekly GI readjustment allowances--tantamount to unemployment insurance--while holding jobs, it became known yesterday.

MONTREAL, March 25 (AP)--Official National Hockey League statistics released today confirmed the fact that Chicago's Max Bentley is the circuit's individual scoring champion for the second straight season.

WASHINGTON, March 25-- Arthur Bliss Lane has resigned as Ambassador to Poland and President Truman has accepted the resignation, acording to letters made public today by the White House. In his letter to the President, Mr. Lane charged the Polish Government with "cynical disregard of its international obligations."

MONTREAL, March 25 (AP)-- The Montreal Canadiens, defending champions, defeated the Boston Bruins, 3--1, tonight in the opening game of their best-of-seven Stanley Cup semi-final series. The Canadiens went on top with two third-period goals after the game had been deadlocked at 1--1 since early in the first frame.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- House Republicans completed the preliminaries today for pushing their income tax reduction bill through the lower chamber without change, with two days of debate beginning tomorrow.

The Right Rev. James P. DeWolfe, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island, urged yesterday that the Young Women's Christian Association in Brooklyn take prompt action to settle a twenty-six-day-old strike of maintenance employes at two Y.W.C.A. buildings.

A 15 per cent increase in sugar allocations to candy manufacturers beginning April 1 for the second quarter will result in improvement in quality in nearly all brands and a straight 15 per cent output increase in the case of a few, Harry Lustig, executive secretary of the Association of Manufacturers of Confectionery and Chocolates, said yesterday.

A "grave misunderstanding" regarding expenditures for customs personnel on the part of the House subcommittee on appropriations for Treasury and Postoffice is apparent in a statement made recently by Representative Gordon Canfield, Republican, of New Jersey, according to a telegram sent to the Representative yesterday by the National Council of American Importers, Inc.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP)-- Pointing to cuts voted by the House in his agency's funds, William R. Johnson, Customs Commissioner, said today that he would put 1,410 men on furlough Friday, suspend Canadian border patrols and cut back waterfront patrol activities in United States ports.

Perhaps you've noticed, as we have, the comparatively low price at which mushrooms have been selling recently. Two fine groceries we know offered them for 45 cents a pound over the weekend. The City Department of Markets reported 59 cents a pound the average city-wide cost; a year ago at this time the range was 78 cents to $1.05 a pound.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 25 --Frank Sinatra will play the role of Father Paul, a Roman Catholic priest, in the screen version of "The Miracle of the Bells," it was announced today by Jesse Lasky and Walter MacEwen, who will produce the film for RKO release.
LONDON, March 25--The British Government has been advised by a special committee of experts to abandon the present cost-of-living index.
BERLIN, March 25 -- Seven thousand Soviet Army deserters are confined in a camp in Guestrow, in eastern Mecklenburg and patrols are scouring the forests and villages for others.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 25--With a supreme effort born of deep despair, the Yankees scored two runs in the ninth inning today after the first two batters in that round had been retired.

To patrolmen on the midnight-toeight tour, who sometimes chatted with Langley Collyer on his nocturnal strolls, he seemed, for all his shabbiness, a well-mannered and cultured old gentleman. They probably never thought that some day the entire Police Department would be on the lookout for him.

American Foreign Investing Stockholders of the American Foreign Investing Corporation voted at the annual meeting yesterday to change its name to Bowling Green Fund, Inc. Francis G. Goodale, William H. Schubart, T. Graydon Upton and Ira Jewell Williams Jr. were added to the board of directors.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 25 -- Jonathan Daniels, former White House press secretary, was elected today to a twelve-member international body that will study problems of discrimination and the treatment of minorities.

Scrap Prices The first decline in the price of scrap metal since the lapse of controls last November was reported yesterday from Pittsburgh. A leading dealer there announced that sales of heavy melting scrap steel to steel companies were made at $43.50 a ton, a decrease of 50 cents a ton from the level that prevailed since March 17.

WASHINGTON, March 25--The Congress of Industrial Organizations appealed today to Attorney General Tom C. Clark to take anti-trust action against "the bread baking monopoly" as a result of recent price increases of one to three cents per loaf.

Admiral Jonas Ingram, the skipper, was confined to his quarters with grippe, so Commodore Owen O. Kessing, the exective officer, took the deck yesterday at the local launching of the All-America Football Conference's new high command.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 25--Behind closed doors the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission began today its job of working out a detailed control plan and was faced immediately with the Soviet Union's complaint that its proposals for swift outlawing of the atomic bomb were being bypassed.

Every so often the Bronx Zoo turns up with a new headliner for its show. This time it is a bird known as the Guatemalan junco. Ornithologists have known about juncos for some time. A few had even heard of the Guatemalan junco. Today they can see it.

The East River site for the future world capital was formally turned over here yesterday to the United Nations and dedicated by its donor, John D. Rockefeller Jr., to the "hope of the people of the world."

A syndicate of 201 underwriting houses headed by the First Boston Corporation and Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., yesterday bought at competitive sale and redistributed to investors $200,000,000 of thirty-five year debentures of the American Telephone Telegraph Company.

For the nineteenth consecutive year, The Children's Village at Dobbs Ferry, New York, held its annual spring "shopping day" benefit yesterday at Arnold Constable, Fifth Avenue and Fortieth Street. Ten of the 400 Children's Village youngsters were selected to serve as floorwalkers when the home cottage colony, a project designed to give guidance to young boys, received a "generous share" of the store's profits.

TRENTON, N.J., March 25-- The New Jersey Legislature adjourned tonight for the week without filling the $16,500-a-year position of state alcoholic beverage commissioner, as planned by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll.

Retailers are clamoring for sound merchandising assistance and leadership from manufacturers, and the producer who gives the retailer a program to meet the current inventory problem will forge ahead in the impending competitive battle, Philip J. Kelly, vice president of Lennen Mitchell, Inc., said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 25--The House passed today a $1,585,586,780 supply bill for the Labor Department, the Federal Security Agency and related activities after smothering by resounding majorities all attempts to restore cuts recommended by its Appropriations Committee.

CHICAGO, March 25 -- Grain markets continued on the upgrade again today on the Board of Trade. While the gains were not as large as on the previous day, all deliveries of corn sold at new seasonal high prices, with May the highest since 1920.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: No one will dispute the New York Public Library's claim, and your editorial approval, that increased appropriations are needed to meet the present and the growing needs of the reading public. May I, however, carry the point still a little further?

SOMETIMES you can't even see the forest for the trees. This reporter spent the better part of a week in Tampa, using that town as his base of operations on the West Coast of Florida. It was a rather disconcerting discovery to find that he'd departed for the North without squeezing in a column on the Cincinnati Reds, who are training in Tampa and whom he saw practically every day.

The Original Ballet Russe at the Metropolitan Opera House last night gave its first performance of Bronislava Nijinska's "Pictures at an Exhibition," set to Mussorgsky's music and with costumes and setting by Boris Aronson. The work was created for the Ballet International in 1944 and has not been seen hereabouts since then.

Helen Kwalwasser, who gave a violin recital last night at Town Hall, made her debut at the age of 6 at the University of Syracuse, where her father, Dr. Jacob Kwalwasser, was a professor. But her career was not forced and this was her first New York appearance.

WASHINGTON, March 25--Warren R. Austin, United States representative to the United Nations, will explain this country's plans for aiding Greece and Turkey to the Security Council on Friday, he said at the White House today. He made the announcement after having conferred for more than an hour with President Truman.
HAVANA, March 25--Pistol Pete Reiser will be firing accurately and often at opposing pitchers this season instead of gathering rust on the sidelines as had been feared recently.

Newspaper advertising in fiftytwo cities during February totaled 279,886,603 lines, compared with 236,922,247 in the same period last year, or a gain of 18.1 per cent, according to Media Records. All classifications showed gains except financial, which dropped 11.2 per cent.
