To Holy Cross went the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship last night at Madison Square Garden, as the smartly drilled Crusaders from Worcester, Mass., running away from the opposition in the last three minutes, fashioned a 58-47 victory over the University of Oklahoma in the East-West playoff before 18,445 persons.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., March 25-- Representatives of education and labor split here today with spokesmen for the American Legion and the Citizens Committee for Military Training on the issue: "Must We Have Universal Military Training?"
WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP)-- The Commerce Department announced today that hereafter there will be a subscription rate for eight industry information reports it has been distributing free.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 25 -- Mr. Austin will be the first speaker recognized when the Security Council meets Friday at 3 P.M. to hear his statement on President Truman's program.

WASHINGTON, March 25--The Soviet Government has notified the State Department that it is prepared to fulfill its agreement with China and turn over to the Nanking Government the administration of the port of Dairen, Manchuria, the State Department announced today.

LONDON, March 26 -- Closer political and economic ties with Russia and a corresponding withdrawal from the United States was urged in resolutions prepared by various units of the Labor party for submission to its annual conference in Margate in May.
WASHINGTON, March 26--Officials of the executive branch of the Government are confronted with more dilemmas in the GreekTurkish debate than they have been in any other debate in recent history.

WASHINGTON, March 26--The Senate considered today the nomination of David E. Lilienthal as chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission only long enough to hear an opposition speech by Senator Homer Ferguson, Republican, of Michigan.

TOKYO, March 26--A new political leadership for Japan--long sought both by Allied Headquarters and the Japanese voters themselves --today appeared to be in the making. The lists closed for the general election to be held next month.

WASHINGTON, March 26--Fleet Admiral Chester W. Nimitz told Congress bluntly today that the country's military leaders were making "substantial progress" on plans for "the military operations which might have to be carried on in the event of another national emergency."
Official severance notices were issued by local district Customs authorities yesterday to the first of 740 port patrol officers slated to go in the Congressional economy wave.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 26-- The General Assembly today approved a new city charter for Hartford, providing a Government by a city manager and an elected city council of nine men. The measure spells the end of a mayor-commission form of government that had grown out of three centuries of gradual change and development.
NANKING, March 26--The Supreme Court has commuted to life imprisonment the death sentence passed recently on Chou Fu-hai, one of the chief wartime collaborators with the Japanese.

Although the number of traffic deaths in this State was 14 per cent higher last year than in 1945, the fatality rate was the lowest in New York history on the basis of motor travel mileage, Commissioner of the Motor Vehicle Bureau Clifford J. Fletcher reported yesterday.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, March 26--The arrest of four high-ranking Stormtroopers, who had begun "a large-scale organization" to sabotage occupying powers and overthrow the present German civil government, was disclosed today by the United States European Command headquarters.

The nation's gasoline stocks last week declined 287,000 barrels, according to the weekly figures of the American Petroleum Institute. This was the first decrease in gasoline stocks in several months and brought supplies at the week-end to 106,526,000 barrels, compared with 106,813,000 a week earlier and 104,330,000 a year ago.

LONDON, March 26--Announcing in the House of Commons today the names of seventeen members of a Royal Commission of Inquiry into the British press, Prime Minister Attlee defined its object as that of "furthering the free expression of opinion through the press and the greatest practicable accuracy in the presentation of news."

CHICAGO, March 26 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 3,500 head, total 8,000; weights under 270 pounds fairly active, around 25 cents higher; heavier weights and sows steady to 25 cents higher; market closed slow, very uneven

AMERICANS who knew Italy before, during and/or after the war are going to have a fine time identifying the Dario Duvolti of Percy Winner's "fictitious reminiscence"-- "Dario"*--published today. Dario starts as a Fascist. Midway in life's Dantean road he is briefly helpful to the Allies. When last seen he has gone totalitarian again, and is still going strong.

CANTON, China, March 25 (Delayed) --The treacherous Himalayan "hump," over which the United States Air Transport Command carried war supplies to blockaded China, is being explored on foot by members of the American Graves Registration Service.

Industrial training for the American Negro, especially in the South, presents a more dismal picture today than it did at the close of the war, Lester B. Granger, executive secretary of the National Urban League, said yesterday. He found the situation facing the Negro veteran "critical with no sign of improvement."

ALBANY, March 26--Bills appropriating $5,000,000 additional for emergency housing at colleges and removing the statutory ceilings on rents in new limited-dividend housing projects were approved today by Governor Dewey. Both were part of the Administration's legislative program.
Moderate-income car owners, squeezed between inflexible parking regulations and a shortage of off-the-street parking space, lost the first round of their legal battle for relief yesterday.

New York's junior high schools are creating better understanding among children of varying racial and cultural backgrounds, Dr. Elias Lieberman, associate superintendent in charge of the junior high school division, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 26--Tracy S. Voorhees, New York attorney, who accompanied Herbert Hoover on the recent food mission to Germany, has been appointed by Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson to the newly created post of War Department Food Administrator for Occupied Areas.

The House of Representatives has slashed by substantial amounts the appropriations for the various labor agencies. In the case of the Bureau of Labor Statistics the cut has been so deep that it threatens to impair the effective functioning of that agency. The House has approved an appropriation of only $2,373,000 as compared with a request for $6,700,000 by the BLS.

A total of 11,000,000 yards of Japanese cotton goods will be shipped to Sweden before the end of May, it was reported yesterday by J.H. Lippmann, vice president of Wells Fabrics Company, Inc., who returned recently from Europe. The goods are of the type purchased in large quantities before the war and will be bleached, dyed and printed in Sweden, he said.

Lew Hahn, president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, agreeing "wholeheartedly" yesterday with President Truman's stand on high prices, was quoted by The Associated Press as saying that if they go higher "the public will stop buying and we will have to sell goods at any price we can get for them."

TONKERS, N.Y., March 26-- Sol Gelb, former New York City rackets investigator, was chosen by a special committee of the Yonkers Common Council today to investigate possible official corruption in connection with gambling in the former Labor Temple here.
MOSCOW, March 26--The Council of Foreign Ministers agreed this afternoon to have a trial run with the Austrian treaty tomorrow, when the key subject of German assets in Austria will be examined.

Adoption of a governmental interest rate policy sufficiently flexible "to curb inflation and resist deflation" was recommended by the Committee on Public Debt Policy in a report on a study issued yesterday. It asserted that rates should recognize interest not only as a cost to society but also as an important part if its income.

Two additional skyscrapers, each having thirty-five or more stories, may be included with the forty-story Secretariat building and nine major meeting chambers being planned for the East River world capital, it was disclosed here yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, March 26 -- Registration statements covering $11,077,800 of debentures, 135,000 shares of preferred stock and 448,000 shares of common stock were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by four companies.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development will open an office here in the Federal Reserve Bank Building on April 15, and E. Fleetwood Dunstan has been appointed director of marketing, to head the new office, it was announced yesterday.

Dr. Selig Brodetsky, deputy chairman of the Board of Governors of the Hebrew University in Jerusalem, asserted last night that disquiet in Palestine will not halt the development of that country. "New settlements are being established by Jewish colonists at this very moment," he added.

Two-thirds of this nation's wage earners perform their daily tasks in plants having no organized safety program, John Gibson, Assistant Secretary of Labor, told the seventeenth annual Safety Convention yesterday in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., March 26 (AP)--Four CIO unionists in sympathy with strikers at four Springfield daily newspapers were fined a total of $80 today in District Court in charges based on demonstrating outside the building of The Morning Union and Evening News.
WASHINGTON, March 26--The National Federation of Telephone Workers pledged itself today to maintain emergency service in the event of a strike of 325,000 telephone employes April 7.
WASHINGTON, March 26 (U.P.) --A Federal grand jury in New York City has issued subpoenas for records and officials of some newsprint companies, it was learned today.

The American Academy in Rome has announced the Prix de Rome Fellowship for mature students in musical composition, painting, sculpture, architecture and landscape architecture are open to any citizen of the United States for one year, beginning Oct. 1.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Drew Middleton reported from Moscow, in the times of March 12, that Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov has denounced the demilitarization of Germany as carried out in the America and British zones. Mr. Molotov charge the British with keeping 81,350 and the Americans with keeping 9,000 Germans in military organizations.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 26-- After the hold-over squad arrived from Hawaii this morning, the Giants ran into fresh difficulty with the San Francisco minor leaguers when they renewed hostilities in the Seals' stadium today before a gathering of 5,064.

TRENTON, N.J., March 26-- Many policemen, firemen and other public employes in New Jersey eligible for retirement but still active at their jobs may be compelled to go on pension under a bill that has been slipped quietly through the New Jersey Senate.
WASHINGTON, March 26--Dr. E.S. Bagnall of the Massachusetts Medical Society today told the House Committee on Expenditures that his State tried combining health and welfare and it didn't work.

An extensive drive to improve sanitary conditions in the baking industry is being started by a school for production managers under the auspices of the American Institute of Baking, Dr. Edward L. Holmes, director of the Department of Sanitation of the Institute, said yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, March 26--An integrated oil policy for the Western Hemisphere, including a halt to oil exportation, was urged today by Arthur A. Curtice, one of the country's leading petroleum extraction experts.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, March 26-- The Soviet Union's representatives on the United Nations Balkans Inquiry Commission fought stubbornly today to prevent a detailed discussion on whether Bulgaria and Yugoslavia have territorial designs on Greece and whether this motivates their alleged aid to the Greek insurgents opposing the present Government.

MOSCOW, March 26 (AP)--The text of Secretary of State Marshall's statement today to the Council of Foreign Ministers on participation of small nations in the peace conference: I should like to refer at this time to what I said yesterday-- that the Allied states should specifically include all states at war with Germany.

Freedom of the press is definitely in danger, largely because of the failure of the press to meet the needs of our society. That is the judgment of the Commission of Freedom of the Press, which is publishing today in book form the results of a four-year study of the subject.

The Standard Oil Company of Indiana reported yesterday for 1946 a consolidated net income of $67,649,785 after charges, taxes and reserves, equal to $4.43 each on the 15,284,830 capital shares. This compares with $50,340,476, or $3.29 a share, in 1945.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP)-- The Senate voted today to investigate the Centralia, Ill., mine disaster after sharp debate in which Senator Styles Bridges, Republican, of New Hampshire, said that Secretary of the Interior J.A. Krug was "the man directly responsible."

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 26--Total United States demand for all petroleum products for 1947, including exports, will be about 5,500,000 barrels daily, an increase of 3 1/2 per cent over 1946, and 26 per cent over 1941, the last prewar year.

WASHINGTON, March 26-- President Truman voiced sincere hope today that Congress would approve the entire $400,000,000 Greek-Turkish aid program in time to avert a necessity for stopgap action when British support is withdrawn March 31.

The Federal Reserve Board will seek cancellation of the executive order with which Regulation W is authorized, should Congress fail to give that credit control permanent status, it was learned yesterday.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 26--The Soviet Union demanded today that countries giving technical, financial or "other" assistance to needy nations must not exploit this aid for their own ends.
Frank J. Sampson, new leader of Tammanny Hall, superseded Bert Stand and Clarence H. Neal, the powers behind the throne in the old Loughlin regime, yesterday with appointees of his own selection.

Dr. Victor Moritz Goldschmidt, leading Norwegian geochemist and a pioneer worker in the field of crystal chemistry, died in Oslo last Thursday, according to word received by colleagues here yesterday.
CENTRALIA, Ill., March 26-- Hope dimmed tonight for 104 miners trapped in a gas-filled mine since an explosion at 3 P.M. yesterday. A state official said it might take more than a week to reach them.
WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP)-- Once rebuffed, Yugoslavia renewed a plea to the United States today for 250,000 tons of grain and potatoes to tide the nation over until the summer harvest.

FORT WORTH, March 26 (AP)-- The Army Air Forces' B-36, world's largest land-based bomber, made a safe emergency landing at 6:20 P.M. (Central Standard Time) today, on a grassy strip at Fort Worth Army Air Field, after landing gear trouble had caused twelve of the fourteen men on board to parachute.

Jennie Tourel, mezzo-soprano, joined with the New York Chamber Orchestra, conducted by F. Charles Adler, at Carnegie Hall last night in a program of uncommon quality. Not an item of this program was trite or a replica of what most other concerts offer.

Announcement of plans for a 700-apartment limited-dividend project in the Bronx followed immediately yesterday Governor Dewey's approval of a law to permit higher rentals on such buildings. The $6,500,000 Bronx project is to be built by the Amalgamated Housing Corporation adjoining that concern's existing housing near Van Cortlandt Park.

PHILADELPHIA, March 26--A challenge to the educators of this country to help remove the tensions that now exist between the United States and the Soviet Union was made today at the closing session of the American National Conference on the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.
A consolidated net profit of $31,179,048 was reported yesterday for 1946 by the International Paper Company and its subsidiaries, compared with $8,546,078 earned the year before.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 26 (AP)--Head Smart, in the brown and ivory racing livery of Max Slifkin, drove to her first triumph in nine 1947 attempts when she captured the $5,000 added mile and a sixteenth Singing Tower Handicap by a neck at Gulf stream Park today.

A banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., won yesterday an issue of $2,000,000 of road bonds of the State of West Virginia at an interest cost of 1.428 per cent for maturities extending from 1947 to 1971. Other bids, each representing an interest cost of 1.476 per cent, were submitted by syndicates headed by Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., and National City Bank.

ALBANY, March 26--Accountants who are more than 40 years old and have had fifteen years' experience may be licensed as certified public accountants without examination, under a bill that became law today with Governor Dewey's approval.

WASHINGTON, March 26-- President Truman announced today that Richard C. Patterson Jr. would not return to his post as Ambassador to Yugoslavia. He said he did not know whether Mr. Patterson intended to drop out of the diplomatic service and that the decision would be up to him.

At his press conference yesterday President Truman expressed concern over rising prices and voiced the hope that industry will cooperate in preventing a spiral of inflation. Certainly orderly price reductions would provide a solution for many of our present problems.
Dr. John F. Erdmann, the famed surgeon, will be 83 years old today. For the sixtieth consecutive year he will mark his birthday by performing at least one major operation.

WASHINGTON, March 26--In a move to help meet the newsprint needs of small publications, a voluntary committee of publishers exploring possible steps to ease the newsprint insufficiency recommended today that their group be expanded to include representatives of manufacturers, paper jobbers and magazines.

Despite the snow yesterday, the calendar proclaims it's spring, and that being so, we assume your menus need to be rescued from a bad case of winter weariness. Accordingly, consideration is begged for the herb that's considered a vegetable, the globe artichoke, which is enjoying one of its seasons of plenty at the moment.

Thanks to Jacques Deval's "Bathsheba," acted at the Ethel Barrymore last evening, the ancient chroniclers seem more masterly than ever this morning. In a few terse paragraphs they could tell a story that M. Deval spreads through a long and diffuse evening.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 26 (AP)--Mr. Ely was born in Elyria, Ohio. He attended public schools there and studied at Phillips Academy, Andover, Mass., before enrolling in the Sheffield Scientific School of Yale. He received his college degree in 1894.

The Radio Corporation of America soon will introduce its first post-war console television set and has completed extensive production changes designed to materially increase output of all types of television receivers, an official of the RCA-Victor division disclosed yesterday.

The twice-postponed premiere of Jerome Robbins "Pas de Trois" finally took place last night in the program of the Original Ballet Russe at the Metropolitan Opera House, but with Rosella Hightower in the role created by Mr. Robbins for Alicia Markova.

BALTIMORE, March 26 (AP)-- Joe DiMaggio limped out of Johns Hopkins Hospital today with a big bandage still on his left heel and only slight hope that he would be in center field for the Yankees' opening American League game next month.

Bias Binding Prices Down Bias binding used by garment manufacturers has come down in price to a point where it is now selling at former ceilings or less, according to trade sources yesterday. Shortages had forced the price up to $15 per 1,000 yards, but current quotations by Jobbers are new in the neighborhood of $9.

LONDON, March 25 (Reuters) --The British housewife now can choose from the largest supplies of fruit seen since 1939, but prices, except for oranges, apples and bananas, which are under official control, have soared.

Price stabilization in durable goods is quite general now, durable goods manufacturers here disclosed yesterday in commenting on news reports that President Truman had suggested price reductions following the pattern of the Ford Motor Company and the International Harvester Company.

BOWIE, Md., March 26 (AP)-- Spokesmen for three of Maryland's four major race tracks reported tonight that work contract demands of the newly formed Mutuel Employes Protective Association, which claims 300 members, would be rejected.

MOSCOW, March 26--Foreign Minister Molotov of Russia has agreed to an exchange of information by the Big Three on implementation of their 1945 agreement on China. He stated his position in letters to Secretary of State Marshall of the United States and Foreign Secretary Bevin of Britain.

WASHINGTON, March 26--The Senate today debated without conclusion a bill to continue sugar controls until March 31, 1948, but defeated a motion to table an amendment allowing housewives thirty-five to fifty pounds of sugar each this year.

Competition between the civilian components for funds and priorities and friction between each of the components and between them and the regular forces handicap the development of the National Guard and Reserves.

MEXICO CITY, March 26 (AP)-- With nine former major-leaguers still unsigned, the six-club Mexican Baseball League will open its season here tomorrow with President Miguel Aleman scheduled to throw out the first ball at the VeracruzMexico City game.

WASHINGTON, March 26--An inquiry into telegram delivery methods of the Western Union Telegraph Company will be made a part of the projected comprehensive investigation of the telegraph industry, Federal Communications Commission officials said today.

American-Marietta At their annual meeting, in Chicago on Tuesday stockholders of the American-Marietta Company voted to increase the paint company's capitalization. Preferred shares will be increased from 20,000 to 35,000 shares and 100,000 Class A common shares will be supplemented by 900,000 common shares.

CHICAGO, March 26 -- May corn sold at a new twenty-seven-year peak of $1.88 1/4 a bushel, up 6 1/2 cents, at one time on the Board of Trade today. Other deliveries of corn were at a new seasonal high, while wheat and oats went into new ground on the current upturn.
WASHINGTON, March 26 (UP)-- A Senate Banking subcommittee today agreed on a bill to continue Federal rent controls until March 1, 1948, with any rent increase granted on a local or "home-town" basis.

WONALANCET, N.H., March 26 (AP)--Arthur T. Walden, 76, chief dog driver of Admiral Richard E. Byrd's first Antarctic expedition, died today in saving his wife from a fire which destroyed their farm home.

An old favorite of tennis galleries from overseas makes his first appearance in New York in years this evening when Jean Borotra leads a French team into action at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixtysixth Street.

AMSTERDAM, March 26 (Aneta) --Prices on the Stock Exchange were firm in moderate trading. Shipping, oil and bank stocks closed higher. Industrials were irregular while state bonds and Indies plantation issues were steady.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 26-- Three vessels carrying UNRRA supplies have struck mine fields in the vicinity of Trieste, but in each case it was established that they were off their course and had wandered into unswept mine fields, naval authorities said today.

William M. Holmes, president of Bonwit Teller, announced yesterday his retirement from active business. He said that he would present his resignation today at a meeting of the board of directors. He intends to continue, however, as a director of the corporation and as a company adviser.

TORONTO, March 26 (AP)--The Toronto Maple Leafs defeated the Detroit Red Wings, 3-2, tonight in the first game of their best-ofseven Stanley Cup semi-final series after the contest was extended to a "sudden death" overtime period. The attendance was 12,749, lower than the average National Hockey League crowd here.

Two overtime periods were needed to decide the Basketball Association of America contest between the New York Knickerbockers and the Providence Steamrollers at Madison Square Garden last night. The Knicks, after gaining a 74-74 tie in regulation time, rallied again to even matters at 80-80 in the first five-minute extra session and triumphed with a belated outburst in the second overtime stanza, 91-84.

Thelma Schnee's adaptation of Konstantine Simonov's comedy of life in post-war Moscow, "The Whole World Over," will make its debut this evening at 8:15 at the Biltmore Theatre. Walter Fried and Paul F. Moss are the sponsors and the principal players in the cast are Stephan Bekassy, Uta Hagen, Joseph Buloff and Sanford Meisner.

PARIS, March 26--Former President de Gaulle's speech in Bruneval, near Le Havre, on Sunday is expected to be the first of a series that will mark his second re-entry into public life since his resignation in January, 1946. His purpose will be to counsel his country on the course it should take in the world crisis of peace-making and American-Russian rivalry.

Margaret Maddison, English pianist, gave her first New York recital last night at Town Hall. Her program contained Beethoven's Thirty-two Variations in C minor and Sonata in E flat, Op. 31, No. 3; two "Intermezzi" of Brahms; Schumann's "Papillons," and six Etudes and the Scherzo in C sharp minor of Chopin.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, March 25 (Delayed)-- Hundreds of workmen today dug into the rubble within the oval shell of St. Paul's Church in Frankfort and began a concerted effort to rebuild it by May 18, 1948. It is to be finished in time to celebrate a meeting there of Germany's short-lived first democratic National Parliament 100 years ago.

Fragments of rubble from the British House of Commons will be presented to Governors of the forty-eight states in the near future, it was announced yesterday. The project, sponsored by the American and British Commonwealth Association, is intended as a symbol of Anglo-American solidarity.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 6--Some stout pitching by Big Hill Bevens, coupled with some even more robust clouting, served to put the Yankees back on the victory beam today with a noisy detonation as the New Yorkers attened the Cardinals, 10 to 1, in the fifth encounter of their spring exhibition series.

Macy's "Summer Colony" will open today with enough hot weather furniture to take care of any domicile from a palace by the ocean to a lakeside shack. The difference between this season's offerings and those of last year is more a matter of detail than of radically new design.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 26 (U.P.) -- Frank Reynolds, an American stoker, was killed yesterday when the United States ship St. Lawrence Victory sailed into a "known" mine field off the Adriatic port of Ragusa and struck a mine, a spokesman for the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration said today.

Out of a doll's house, large enough for children, paraded young fry in spring fashions yesterday in the showing presented by Arnold Constable at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Carrying toys by Anne Farrell, the models, who ranged from tiny children to teen agers, showed party clothes, playtime togs, spring suits and coats.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed at virtually the beat levels of the day, 13 to 27 points higher after starting 7 points lower to 3 points higher. Shortly after the opening, the market eased, then quickly recovered to the previous closing levels on small price-fixing orders.

WASHINGTON, March 26--A casual newspaper reader might suppose, what indeed Chairman Brooks and his fellow members of the Senate Rules Committee have by inference conveyed, that the committee intervened recently to prevent discrimination in the Senate press gallery against a newspaper reporter because he is a Negro.

Fiberglas and flame-proof cotton yarns have been combined into a new type of fire-resistant drapery and decorative fabric, it was announced yesterday at a preview in the Hotel Gotham given by Turner Halsey Company, selling agents.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- President Truman and the Secretary of the Treasury, John W. Snyder, expressed almost simultaneously today their concern with the trend of prices to rise, and both indicated that industry would be wise to do something about it.

NANKING, March 26 -- The broadcast of President Truman's speech advocating aid to Greece and Turkey was called "no bombshell, but a lament" in a Communist Emancipation Daily News editorial broadcast today from the Communist radio station in North Shensi.
Broadway loft buildings figured in two realty purchases reported yesterday. Henry Goelet, the operator, was one of the buyers.

Chills without fever became epidemic in New York yesterday as the earlier high winds dropped the temperature to a record low average for the date of 28 degress. The previous low average of 30 degrees had stood since 1937.

Although their approval is only "preliminary," the governing officials of this city in ordering a definitive agreement drawn up for Port Authority development and operation of our airports have set a course that if followed through will assure a great aviation future for New York.

Total advertising volume in 1946 was at a new peak of $3,116,600,000, a 17.2 per cent gain over the $2,659,900,000 in 1945, Dr. Hans Zeisel, manager of research development of McCann-Erickson, Inc., estimated yesterday in Printers' Ink.

BOSTON, March 26 (AP)--Civil action in Federal court charging the Grinding Wheel Manufacturers Association and five corporations allegedly producing most of the nation's abrasives, with price fixing in violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Laws, was reported today by the Department of Justice.

Gerald Light has been appointed assistant director of sales and advertising of the Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation. He formerly was head of technical publications and service manager of the company.

Two Harlem real estate operators were fined and sentenced to jail for six months each yesterday by Federal Judge John W. Clancy after they pleaded guilty to two criminal informations charging them with violation of rent ceilings in 1,011 instances between March and October last year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 26 --Beatrice Lillie, stage star, will return to the screen this summer to appear in "Texas, Heaven and Brooklyn," Robert S. Golden, producer, announced today. Lewis Meltzer has written the photoplay from "Eddie and the Archangel 'Mike," a 1943 novel by Barry Benefield, and filming is scheduled to start in July.

THE most extraordinary of all basketball seasons will come to a close in Madison Square Garden on Saturday night with the staging of the East-West game for the benefit of the Tribune Fresh Air Fund. This will be the final flourish to a remarkable year since it will send the total attendance rocketing above the 650,000 mark.

Failure to move sizable amounts of dresses in the hands of manufacturers and retailers in the next two weeks will result in widespread off-price selling at all levels shortly after Easter, it was predicted yesterday in the trade.

WASHINGTON, March 26--J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, branded today the American Communist party as a "fifth column if there ever was one" and declared that its "goal is the overthrow of our Government."

Within twenty-four hours it has been announced at the White House that two American Ambassadors will not return to important posts in Europe. One is Arthur Bliss Lane, Ambassador to Poland; the other, Richard C. Patterson Jr., Ambassador to Yugoslavia. Each was appointed to his post at a time when relations between the United States and the country to which he was sent as our envoy were confident and cordial.

ROME, March 26--While the Vatican newspaper I'Osservatore Romano expresses gratification today over the action taken by the Constituent Assembly yesterday in making the Lateran agreements of 1929 between the Holy See and Italy an integral part of the new Italian Constitution, most other newspapers voice doubts.

CHICAGO, March 26--Stockholders of Pullman, Inc., will vote on April 16 on a plan to authorize their directors to use up to $50,000,000 of company funds to purchase and retire capital stock, the company announced today. Under the plan the amount of capital represented by the company's stock could be reduced from $132,116,880 to a minimum of $90,000,000.

Harold Gottfried of 4671 Fieldston Road, Riverdale, the Bronx, and the Pure Rock Mineral Springs Corporation of Ellenville, N.Y., were found guilty by a Federal Court jury yesterday afternoon of having made to the Office of Price Administration false statements that enabled the corporation to acquire illegally 1800,000 pounds of sugar.

LONDON, March 26--Britain's highest judicial body, the Privy Council, blocked today a "despairing effort" to prevent the execution of Dov Bela Gruner, terrorist who seeks martyrdom for his cause in Palestine.

WASHINGTON, March 26-- House and Senate Republican leaders disagreed today over the effect in lost revenues of a personal income tax cut retroactive to Jan. 1. This question has considerable bearing on prospects of a Senate drive to change the effective date to July 1.
JERUSALEM, March 26--All British army and air-force personnel in Palestine were confined to barracks tonight if not on duty.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 26--Secretary General Trygve Lie conceded today that during the last eight months of controversy and crisis the United Nations had made little progress toward capturing the enthusiasm and harnessing the imagination of the peoples of the world.
Support of the insurgent strike of sandhogs on the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel was voted yesterday at an official meeting of the Compressed Air Workers Union, Local 147, AFL.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The editorial and letter carried on your editorial page on March 6 concerning the plight of probation officers and the importance of their work will, I hope, help to bring further community support for the request for adequate salaries for these important public officials.

Mrs. Rich W. Hollaman, president of the East Side Settlement, and Mrs. John P. Maguire Jr., chairman of the Winifred Wheeler Day Nursery Committee, will give a cocktail and tea party on Tuesday at the Hotel Drake for a group of debutantes and others who are actively interested in the settlement's coming theatre benefit, at the evening performance of "The Chocolate Soldier" on April 15, at the Century Theatre.

When the fifty-four nations represented in the General Assembly of the United Nations unanimously adopted on Dec. 14 a resolution calling for world-wide reduction of armaments they stirred hopes that gave the international skies their brightest hue since the war ended.
LONDON March 26--Although business in the stock markets today was on a comparatively small scale, moat sections were cheerful.

The Gillette Safety Razor Company yesterday reported that earnings last year were $5,608,580 larger than in 1945 and declared an increased quarterly dividend of 62 1/2 cents a share on the common stock, which compared with the 50-cent rate paid previously.

The news that Mr. Austin, after consultation with the President, will explain our program of assistance to Greece to the Security Council tomorrow will be received with satisfaction by many supporters of the Administration policy who believe our position would be stronger if the United Nations had been notified formally in advance of our proposed action.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: John P. Fox's letter in your March 18 issue, pointing out obstacles to any comprehensive planning of a large area around the United Nations site and to the effort to hold the existing situation in the neighborhood pending the formulation of big plans, suggests someone's recent remark: "For every It-can't-bedone there are 1,000 It-can't-be-doners."
Against Perfect Order Obviously the hermit Collyer brothers overdid things in the quantity and nature of the contents in their "junk-filled" private residence.

HAVANA, March 26--Opening of Dr. Durocher's clinic at Gran Stadium tonight had a monkey wrench thrown into the proceedings when Jackie Robinson, billed as the central figure, suffered an ailment that prevented him from appearing in Montreal's starting line-up as the Dodgers blanked the Royals, 6-0.

LONDON, March 26--A strong effort to profit by the present world shortages to establish a permanent market abroad for high quality British clothing was urged today by a joint industry Government group that had been investigating the clothing industry.
The Musicians Emergency Fund last night started a drive for $500,000 to expand its work in service hospitals throughout New York.

Producers in the luggage field are trying to appraise the size of the vacation and travel "boom" this year. Spokesmen here yesterday said that any strong revival of travel will prove a marked stimulant to luggage volume, which had been running behind last year.

On the Button When a market commentary hits the market on the head, it can be sheer coincidence, psychic phenomena, or a logical arrangement of causes and effects. When the timing measures up, it is always fortuitous.

The Board of Estimate advanced a cautious step yesterday toward solution of its airport problem by directing Corporation Counsel Charles E. Murphy to draw up a "definitive agreement" between the city and the Port Authority looking toward eventual Port Authority operation of city airports.

Declaring that "strikes against the Board of Transportation and the city cannot be tolerated," Mayor O'Dwyer recommended a formula for a sound labor relations policy yesterday to the Board of Transportation with the aim of stabilizing labor relations in the field of municipal transit.

NEW DELHI, India, March 26-- The Viceroy, Viscount Mountbatten, has invited Mohandas K. Gandhi, "patron saint" of the predominantly Hindu Congress party, and Mohammed Ali Jinnah, president of the Moslem League, to New Delhi for discussions on the Indian political impasse, it was announced today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 26--The United Nations Trusteeship Council, which is intended to supervise the development of territories that are not yet capable of governing themselves, got off to an unencouraging start today when the Soviet Union boycotted the first meeting.

LINCOLN, England, March 26 (AP)--The mud, a rodeo-size field, and a 100-to-1 shot beat back American hopes in the Lincolnshire Handicap today, as a rank outsider, Jockey Treble, raced home by a neck. The New York favorite, Whistling Wind, finished far out of the money.

PHILADELPHIA, March 26 -- Geographic integration and corporate simplification proceedings were instituted today against Eastern Utilities Associates and its four subsidiaries by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which set May 6 for a hearing.

Two Vincent Astors doing business on West Forty-second Street was one too many for Vincent Astor, prominent realty operator and one of New York's first families. He brought suit yesterday in Supreme Court to restrain Vincent Astor Williams, 35-year-old war veteran, from operating an export business under the name of the Vincent Astor Purchasing Company at 11 West Forty-second Street.

ST. LOUIS, March 26 (AP)--The defense opened its case in the trial of 14-year-old Mary Catherine Reardon today with a statement that her father, with whose death she is charged, was shot by Michael D'Arcy, 13, the girl's runaway companion, and that Mary was wounded while trying to protect her father.

The four-minute rule that basketball coaches had termed unsatisfactory was changed yesterday by the National Basketball Rules Committee, which concluded its two-day meeting at the Hotel Astor. Hereafter, only during the final three minutes, instead of four, will the clock be stopped with each whistle.

Sidney Edwards and Ward Davenny, head of the 'Cello Department and director of the Hartford School of Music, respectively, gave an evening of fine chamber music for the 'cello and piano last night at Times Hall.
The missing 61-year-old recluse, Langley Collyer, is believed dead, the police said yesterday in an affidavit to Francis J. Mulligan, Public Administrator for New York County.

MOSCOW, March 26--The Council of Foreign Ministers split today over the question of German signature of the peace settlement in a long, hectic session that saw Russia and Britain aligned against the United States.
AMITE, La., March 26 (AP)--A teamsters' boycott was ordered tonight, backing up a dairy farmers' strike to stop the flow of milk into New Orleans.

Underwriting managers here will offer today to investors three issues of senior securities amounting to $15,150,000, as follows: Baltimore Ohio Railroad Company--$5,650,000 of ten-year serial equipment trust certificates at prices to yield 1.10 per cent to 2.15 per cent, by Halsey, Stuart Co.

CHICAGO, March 26 (AP)--Following is the text of an inspection notice found posted at the Centralia Coal Company, mine No. 5, near Centralia, Ill., where a disastrous explosion occurred yesterday. The notice was dated March 18 and 19, 1947, and was signed by Driscoll O. Scanlon, Illinois state mine inspector.

WASHINGTON, March 26--The Republican majority of the Senate Rules Committee approved today a bill to put the Speaker of the House, at present Joseph W. Martin Jr., a Republican, at the top of the line of succession to the Presidency after a Vice President. The latter office is now vacant.

The 17,383-ton Warwick Castle, second Union Castle passenger liner to return to peacetime service, is on her first post-war voyage between England and South Africa, according to advice from abroad received by the Cunard White Star Line here.

BREMEN, Germany, March 26-- Despite the lack of textbooks and school buildings, United States ideas on education are infiltrating into the German school system, it was learned today. For the first time since the pre-Hitler days coeducation will be reintroduced here after Easter in thoroughly revamped elementary schools.

Stock prices turned strong in late dealings yesterday, with leading issues closing at net gains of 1 to 3 points. Reflecting the activity in the last hour, trading on the Stock Exchange was the heaviest since March 12. Turnover was 940,000 shares, of which approximately 340,000 changed hands in the final hour.

WASHINGTON, March 26--William L. Clayton, Under-Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, said today that the foreign policy of the United States must recognize the thesis that international economic stability is essential for political stability.

With the telephone strike threat no nearer solution, the Federal Government explored yesterday the possibility of working out a settlement through the same approach that succeeded in averting a nation -wide phone tie-up last March.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 26-- Whether the West can exploit the oil fields of the Near East and develop commerce without encroaching "on the interests of the people" was a question raised today at the second day's sessions of the Princeton University Bicentennial Conference on Near Eastern Culture and Society.
Reduced air passenger fares for vacation travel between North and South America, and a new low rate for flights between New York and Hawaii were announced here yesterday by two American airlines.

Strong winds along the eastern seaboard delayed the arrival of eleven New York bound passenger and cargo vessels yesterday. Heavy seas extended from Eastport, Me., to northern Florida, according to the Weather Bureau's marine division.

Ways women can help prevent both industrial and home accidents were outlined to representatives of women's organizations at special sessions held yesterday during the seventeenth annual Safety Convention and Exposition at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
DETROIT, March 26--The United Automobile Workers moved ahead today in its quest of an increase of 23 1/2 cents an hour, plus fringe demands, bringing the total to more than 30 cents.

Curtailed production as a result of strikes and shortages of material and inadequate ceiling prices on cars last year are reflected in the sharp reduction in net profits of the General Motors Corporation for 1946, C.E. Wilson, president, and Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman, declare in the annual statement to stockholders, issued for publication today.

WASHINGTON, March 26--The State Department asked Congress today to create a public corporation to take charge of its international short-wave broadcasting throughout the world. It submitted drafts of proposed legislation to accomplish this purpose.
A few of the hardy Maine trout fishermen, who are willing to bite the ice from the tip guide at every other cast, have been trying Somerset County streams and have found some reward.

WASHINGTON, March 26--The Maritime Commission expressed confidence today that "at least minimum, requirements" of shipping service on domestic routes would be met when the merchant marine was returned to private operators on July 1, the expiration date for Government operation.

Formal approval of the immediate cash sale of thirty merchant vessels to the British Government and 107 to ship operators in the United Kingdom was announced here last night by the Maritime Commission.

JERUSALEM, March 26--By a secret decision communicated to Zionist quarters here, the Iraqi Parliament has reportedly asked its Government to take the initiative in assembling a conference of Jews of all Arab countries to adopt resolutions condemning Zionism.

CHICAGO, March 26--The refusal of officials of three Congress of Industrial Organizations unions to disavow Communists makes it impossible for American Federation of Labor unions to try to cooperate with CIO unions on a common program for seamen, said a report submitted today to the AFL Seafarers International Union.

BRUSSELS, March 27 -- Capital industrial equipment from twentyfour German plants, valued at roughly 18,000,000 Reichsmarks, has been approved for allocation among member nations by the Assembly of the Inter-Allied Reparations Agency. Its eighth session closed today.
CHICAGO, March 27 -- Grain prices plunged downward on the Board of Trade today after having made straight advances of 29 1/2 cents on wheat and 28 cents on corn from the low of a week ago.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- American Communists were denounced today as foreign conspirators who "owe their loyalties and allegiance to Russia" by Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America.

PARIS, March 27 -- The three largest parties in France are engaged in a sharp contest, pitting their star orators against one another in a campaign for the runoff next Sunday of the election for Assembly seats annulled last fall because of irregularities in voting.
The receipt of petitions from eight railroads for permission to increase commutation rates in New York State was announced yesterday by the Public Service Commission.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Representative Charles A. Eaton, Republican, of New Jersey, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, will be 79 years of age tomorrow.

Municipal operation on twentyseven Queens bus routes was ordered by the Board of Estimate yesterday after the North Shore Bus Company, private operator, had announced it would suspend operations at midnight tomorrow because of financial difficulties.

PHILADELPHIA, March 27 -- More than 300 pioneers in the development of the helicopter gathered at the Franklin Institute today for the opening of the third annual forum of the American Helicopter Society.

The economic situation of the country calls for drastic revision of pricing and production methods to avert a serious business recession, Jay D. Runkle, chairman of the board of the National Retail Dry Goods Association and general manager of Crowley, Milner Co., Detroit, declared last night.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Richard C. Patterson Jr. tendered his resignation as Ambassador to Yugoslavia today during a long conversation with President Truman. He pleaded the necessity of looking after his private affairs after the diplomatic intermission of two and one-half years.

PEIPING, March 27 -- A decided increase in Nationalist military activity along the Great Wall from Ningsia in northwest China through northern Shensi into the vicinity of Tatung, major military base in northern Shansi, has been reported.

Cluett, Peabody Co. has begun licensing of its new method of stabilizing viscose rayon, it was announced yesterday at a press luncheon at the Hotel Ritz-Carlton. To date, eight finishing plants can offer textile mills and converters the benefits of the process, which has resulted from research since before World War II, according to John C. Turrell, managing director of the Sanforset division of the company.
SARASOTA, Fla., March 27 -- The Yankees were within two outs of scoring a neat two-run victory over their arch pennant rivals, the Red Sox, today, when something slipped.

A warm note rich with an overtone of spring sounded above the chill March winds yesterday. A long man with a sad face came to town bringing a vision of dainty damsels and prancing pachyderms, and the promise: "The Greatest Show on Earth unfolds on April 9 in Madison Square Garden."

BOMBAY, India, March 27 (Reuters) -- As Calcutta reports tonight told of at least six dead, forty-six injured and 200 arrested in the second successive day of communal rioting there, Mohammed All Jinnah, leader of the Moslem League, called for a truce with the "great Hindu community" on the basis of an India divided between Moslem and Hindu.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The House will be asked to pass before the end of next week a "drastic" temporary measure arming the Government with power to stop by injunction a national telephone strike threatened for April 7.
A collection of rare Guatemalan birds is making its first appearance at the Bronx Zoo now. Caught in the deserts, jungles and mountaintops, some have never been exhibited anywhere before.
NANKING, March 27 -- There has been a favorable reaction to the announcement of the Government's new attempt to cope with the economic crisis by offering $400,000,000 worth of new bonds.

Standardized directional signs, pedestrian control and limiting of left-hand turns by vehicles during city traffic rush hours were urged yesterday at the Greater New York Safety Council convention and exposition at the Pennsylvania Hotel.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Changes in the structure of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development to make its board of directors a supervisory body rather than a day-to-day operating group are still under discussion, it was learned today. The suggestion may be presented at the annual meeting of the bank's board of governors which is scheduled to be held in London in September.

In "The Whole World Over," which was acted at the Biltmore last evening, Konstantine Simonov, the Soviet litterateur, endorses love. With the assistance of Joseph Buloff, the well-known dramatic buffoon, Mr. Simonov's comedy appears here in an adaptation by Thelma Schnee.

After a partial survey indicated that leaking plumbing fixtures in the city caused an estimated water loss of 220,000,000 gallons daily, John M. Cannella, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, sent out a second warning yesterday to owners and tenants to do their utmost to conserve the city's water supply.
WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- Real estate spokesmen, assailed the Wagner-Ellender-Taft housing bill today as "dangerous" and "Communist."

HAVANA, March 27 -- Aside from the first base problem, which may or may not be resolved before opening day, an obvious need of the Dodgers is a gentleman of southpaw swinging power who car belt balls into right field stands and over right field barriers.

ATLANTA, March 27 -- Gov. M.E. Thompsor vetoed Georgia's white-primary bill today and approved two anti-labor measures outlawing the closed shop, the involuntary check-off of union dues, and mass picketing.

BERLIN, March 27 -- Agitation over the recent series of arrests of German students in the Soviet sector precipitated a vigorous debate this afternoon in the Berlin City Assembly, culminating in a request to a magistrate to seek the assistance of the Allied Kommandatura in investigating the matter.

ALBANY, March 27 -- Governor Dewey signed today the CondonWadlin bill which outlaws strikes by public employes and fixes dismissal as a penalty for violations. In doing so he declared that such strikes could paralyze government and produce anarchy.

Continued strong demand for products of the paint industry, with every indication that 1947 will be the first billion dollar year, was forecast last night by Ernest T. Trigg, president of the National Paint, Varnish and Lacquer Association, at the sixtieth anniversary dinner of the association in the Waldorf-Astoria.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, March 27 (AP) -- Peter Rupeka, former United States Army sergeant from Hempstead, N.Y., married Fraulein Erika Schaefer today in the first officially approved American-German wedding in occupied Germany since the war.

"Wartime Correspondence Between President Roosevelt and Pope Pius XII" has been scheduled for publication by Macmillan on April 11. Containing twenty-nine messages, from December, 1939, to a telegram sent to Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt in April, 1945, the book has prefaces by President Truman and the Pope.
Mid-Manhattan Magistrate's Court witnessed yesterday a touching new version of the Scriptural story (St. Mark 12:42, 44) of the widow's mite.
DENVER, March 27 -- Max (Mottel) Cohen, 114-year-old resident of the Beth Israel Home for the Aged in Denver and one-time messenger of Czar Nicholas I, died yesterday.

Jerome Robbins' new divertissement, which he calls with both literal accuracy and barbed humor "Pas de Trois," had its second performance last night in the program of the Original Ballet Russe at the Metropolitan Opera House. It was designed for Alicia Markova, Anton Dolin and Andre Eglevsky, but because of Miss Markova's illness it has made its bow with Rosella Hightower in the feminine role.

In the first annual report of the General Public Utilities Corporation, successor to the Associated Gas and Electric Company and the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation, A.F. Tegen, president, announced yesterday that earnings last year amounted to $11,745,400.

PHILADELPHIA, March 27 -- The Potomac Electric Power Company, a subsidiary of the Washington Railway and Electric Company, received permission from the Securities and Exchange Commission today to borrow, during a twoyear period, $12,000,000 from twenty commercial banks.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Strike activity continued at a relatively low level in February, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

Asserting that the Hebrew University in Jerusalem "has great potentialities as a factor in the peaceful development of Palestine," President Truman in a message to its board of governors declared that the university is "a worthy embodiment of the striving of a people toward full selfexpression in the realm of science and scholarship."

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on March 22 were 844,041 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 2,894 cars or 0.3 per cent more than for the preceding week, 39,435 cars or 4.9 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 27,300 cars or 3.3 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.
MOSCOW, March 27 -- Britain promised today to dissolve the Dienstgruppen or German Service Corps in her zone occupation in Germany.
WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- New York had 400 murders last year, sixty-six more than in 1945. Of these 346 were in New York City.

Marcel Cerdan, French and European middleweight champion, will make his second start in an American ring when he faces Harold (Red) Green of Brownsville for ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. The match has "caught on" and the biggest crowd of the season is expected.
LONDON, March 27 -- Sir Edwin Plowden, a wartime chief executive in the Ministry of Aircraft Production, was named today "superplanner" for coordinating Britain's industrial economy.

Easter bonnets made from paper pie plates and doilies were introduced yesterday at a "small fry" spring fashion show at the Children's Aid Society's James Center, 154 Hester Street. The designers were the "midget" crafts class of the James Girls Club, 7 to 10 years old.
D.W. Stromenger has rejoined Callaway Mills, Inc., as sales manager for the Rockweave laundry textile division.

After an interview with Mr. Molotov following his arrival in Moscow yesterday, the Austrian Foreign Minister, Dr. Karl Gruber, was hopeful about the prospects of concluding the Austrian treaty at the present meeting. He said that the Russian attitude seemed favorable to an early settlement, and this is plausible if the Soviet Government, for reasons of prestige, is anxious to make a success of the first peace conference held in Moscow.

Fear of the United States exists throughout the rest of the world, Dr. George N. Shuster, president of Hunter College and a member of the United States Commission for the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, told delegates to the convention of the American Federation of International Institutes yesterday.

Plans for Farragut Houses in Brooklyn, a project of the New York City Housing Authority, were among new building sketches filed with the Department of Housing and Buildings yesterday. The cost of the Brooklyn project was put at $11,214,163.

No hotel operator has the moral right to investigate whether a fire report is true or false before sending an alarm for the city's engines, John J. McCarthy, former chief of the Fire Department, told a session yesterday of the Greater New York Safety Council's seventeenth annual convention.

Edward E. Rhatigan, City Welfare Commissioner, said last night it would cost the municipality "millions of dollars" to duplicate the capital investment of New York Catholic Charities in childcaring agencies alone. His radio talk from Station WNYC was followed by a review of progress made in all fields of Catholic Charities, broadcast by Coadjutor Archbishop J. Francis A. McIntyre over Station WMCA.

Ruth Rankin, soprano, and Nell Rankin, contralto, gave a joint recital last night at Town Hall before a sold-out house, with the overflow accommodated on the stage. For this local debut the youthful sisters from Alabama had prepared an unusual and interesting program, largely devoted to seldom presented duets, but also containing solo offerings, which consisted of operatic excerpts.

The Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert, since last Tuesday the Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of New York, announced last evening that he would ask for a suffragan Bishop. It is expected the election will take place at the 164th annual convention to be held May 13.

PHILADELPHIA, March 27 -- Individuals' savings in the United States during 1946 were $15,800,000,000, the lowest since 1941 and less than half of the amount saved during 1945, the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today in its quarterly analysis.

PARIS, March 27 -- Ambroise Croizat, Communist Minister of Labor, warned today that France would have a shortage of 580,000 workers at the end of this year. He indicated that the labor recruiting program would be pushed at home and abroad this year and next to meet the production goals set in the country's program for industrial, agricultural recovery and modernization.

Reflecting a wide variety of small repayments, commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System declined slightly last week. According to the weekly statement of the banks assets and liabilities, released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, these loans were reduced $15,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday to $4,157,000,000.

Seven hundred and forty Customs port patrol officers were scheduled to turn out today for their final tours of duty along the New York waterfront as the result of the failure of the new Congressional appropriation to cover current costs of the Customs service.

The Republican-sponsored tax reduction bill, under which, income taxes would be cut 30 per cent for 20,000,000 individuals in the lowest bracket and 20 per cent for those with incomes of $302,000 a year or less, passed the House yesterday by a vote of 273 to 137.

Current high costs of plywood to consumers are a source of embarrassment rather than profit to plywood manufacturers, Lawrence Ottinger, president of United States Plywood Corporation, declared yesterday. Manufacturers, he said would be disposed to follow President Truman's recommendation that prices be reduced, except that such action in the case of plywood would not benefit the consumer.

The possibility of safe placement of babies for adoption as early as the fourth month of life has been demonstrated by a twoyear program at the New York Foundling Hospital, 175 East Sixty-eighth Street.
A sports prize 102 years old is to be revived and raced for next August on the cruise of the New York Yacht Club.

An issue of $50,000,000 of refunding and new-money revenue bonds of the Puerto Rico Water Resources Authority will be placed on the market here today by an investment banking syndicate headed by the First Boston Corporation and B.J. Van Ingen Co., Inc. under an agreement with the Banco de Fomento de Puerto Rico, fiscal agency of the Territorial government.

The successful run of "O Mistress Mine," starring Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne, will come to an end May 31 at the Empire, according to a joint announcement made yesterday by the Theatre Guild and John C. Wilson, sponsors.

LONDON, March 27 -- Lewis Douglas, United States Ambassador to Britain, attended an informal reception in London today to celebrate the appearance of the first number of American Outlook, a new publication devoted to Anglo-American understanding.

MOSCOW, March 27 (AP) -- The text of United States Secretary of State Marshall's statement to the Council of Foreign Ministers on German assets in Austria: (1) Yesterday I indicated the United States delegation did not agree with the position Mr. Molotov has taken in his paper on German assets in Austria.

It is two months yesterday since the Senate section of the Atomic Energy Committee opened its hearings on the nominations of Chairman David E. Lilienthal and his colleagues on the United States Atomic Energy Commission. It is eighteen days today since the committee approved the nominations.
Surrogate James A. Delehanty failed yesterday to appoint Francis J. Mulligan, Public Administrator, as temporary administrator of the Collyer brothers' estate.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- A bill to attack racial discrimination in employment with a "minimum" of legal compulsions was introduced today by Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican, of New York, with bipartisan backing.

Columbia University will observe the 100th anniversary of Joseph Pulitzer's birth with centennial ceremonies April 10, at 4 P.M., in the university's Low Memorial Library, Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, acting president of Columbia, announced yesterday.
SHANGHAI, March 27 (U.P.) -- A giant pyramid in isolated mountains of Shensi Province in western China was reported today by Col. Maurice Sheahan, Far Eastern director for Trans World Airline.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned easier yesterday in sympathy with the weak grain markets and closed 21 to 47 points net lower.

OKLAHOMA CITY, March 27 (AP) -- Twelve years of research costing $1,000,000 has resulted in the development of a chemical process for use of agricultural by-products such as corncobs in the manufacture of nylon, Dr. Oliver W. Cass, research chemist for E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., announced today.

A banking group headed by the Chase National Bank yesterday was awarded issues of various bonds of Fulton County, Ga., aggregating $20,000,000 yesterday at a bid of 95.789 for 1 1/2s. Bonds maturing from 1948 to 1960 were reoffered at prices to yield from 0.65 per cent to 1.45 per cent.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The Republican majority in Congress is having the common experience of those who set out to reduce the costs of government. The way of the economizer is hard, but it has never been more rugged than that on which Senator Bridges and Representative Taber have ventured.

The concert of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Efrem Kurtz, guest conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall was not replete with excitement or with memorable feats of performance, interpretation or creative originality.
Twelve members of the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee sailed yesterday for Panama, accompanied by their wives, for a study of the operations of the Panama Canal.

Victor Vigotsky, a 23-year-old veteran who fought through nine battle campaigns and who killed his wife out of unreasoning jealousy, was sentenced yesterday in Bronx County Court to serve seven and a half to fifteen years for his crime.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 27 -- Orson Welles will produce, direct and star in a screen version of "Macbeth" for Republic Pictures this summer, the studio announced today. The picture will be made as a Charles K. Feldman group production under an extension of a recently announced deal involving John Steinbeck's "The Red Pony" and Ben Hecht's "The Shadow."

PRINCETON, N.J., March 27 -- The theme of ancient Islam's reawakening was studied today at the final sessions of a three-day meeting of leading Orientalists and gave rise to the question whether the East desired more than the mere externals of Western civilization.

AMSTERDAM, March 27 (Aneta) -- Trading on the Stock Exchange was fairly active, with prices up sharply and numerous stocks reaching new highs. Industrials, shipping, oil, Indies plantation issues and bank stocks were higher. State bonds were easier.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Department store sales for the week ended March 22 were 12 per cent above sales for the corresponding period a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Comparison of last week's sales in the respective Federal Reserve districts with sales a year ago follow:

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 27 -- Although the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization's report on Greece contains detailed recommendations for the rehabilitation of Greek economy through the action of the United Nations, it was learned today that it would not be taken up at the current session of the Economic and Social Council.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 27 -- In violation of the terms of the Swedo-Russian trade pact signed last fall Russia has demanded payment in United States dollars for deliveries to Sweden, it was announced officially today. The pact stipulated payment in Swedish crowns.

Federal Judge Harry E. Watkins sentenced Harold Gottfried, former Coast Guard lieutenant, yesterday to three years in Federal prison and imposed a fine of $5,000 on him for the filing of false statements to the Office of Price Administration in an application for sugar.
LONDON, March 27 -- Yugoslavia has asked Britain for substantial economic aid, the Foreign Office revealed tonight.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A.C. Sedgwick has just produced a "pact" of collaboration between the Elas and the Nazis. For those who read THE TIMES and follow Mr. Sedgwick's dispatches, this latest story could not come as a surprise. It was interesting, however, to note that you devoted almost a full column of your precious space to it.

WESTOVER FIELD, Mass., March 27 (AP) -- The Army C-54 transport that crashed on a Newfoundland plateau Sunday slid more than a mile to the edge of a 1,500-foot precipice, a rescued airman disclosed today.

The appointment of men with limited combat experience or inadequate military background to high command in the National Guard and to a far lesser extent in the Organized Reserve Corps is adversely affecting the efficiency of the Army's "civilian components," in the opinion of some observers.

The Standard Oil Company of California reported yesterday for 1946 a consolidated net income of $66,956,611 after charges, taxes and reserves, equal to $5.15 each on the 13,003,953 capital shares outstanding. This compares with $55,554,628, or $4.27 a share in 1945.

The Board of Estimate expressed its approval at City Hall yesterday of a three-year program for development of the United Nations site in east midtown at an estimated cost of $12,649,000 and directed all city officials to cooperate in the improvement.

See Lower Prices on Robes A price break in men's rayon and silk robes is imminent, according to market sources, and manufacturers are expected to offer high quality products to retail for less than $10. Manufacturing costs on some of the items to be liquidated are said to be two and three times the new wholesale prices, indicating the desire to cut down on inventories which have not been moving too well.

JERUSALEM, March 27 -- I have just returned from a visit into the strongholds of the underground, where I was permitted to meet secretly a group of confident young men who plot to carve with the sword a "Hebrew republic" on both sides of the Jordan River.

Three States that have enacted laws against racial and religious bias reported a "definite decline in discrimination," at a meeting called yesterday by the New York Council on Fair Employment Practice at 20 West Fortieth Street. The three States are New York, New Jersey and Massachusetts; they were represented by six enforcement officers.

George L. Noble Jr., director of the War Production Board for the Texas region in 1943, testified in Federal Court yesterday that he had recommended air travel priorities on numerous occasions for Serge M. Rubinstein, international financier, on his belief that Rubinstein was engaged in war work.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- A directive has been sent to Gen. Douglas MacArthur for a review of the new Japanese Constitution in one to two years on the basis of a policy decision reached by the Far Eastern Commission last October, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The House passed the income tax reduction bill today, 273 to 137, in the most emphatic demonstration of Republican solidarity in the lower chamber since the new Congress convened.

To several thousand New York anglers the opening of the trout season two weeks from tomorrow is more of an occasion than a fishing trip, and for most of those who turn out the day will be much more productive of pleasure than it will of trout.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 27 -- Receiving word that Governor Dewey had signed Westchester's three new toll bills, the County Board of Supervisors drafted this afternoon an eight-point program to put into operation on June 1 the collection of 10-cent tolls on the Hutchinson River and Saw Mill River Parkways and the discontinuance of existing tolls on the Cross County Parkway.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- After the preceding week's slight decline, average primary market prices rose 0.5 per cent during the week ended last Saturday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, United States Department of Labor.
JERUSALEM, March 27 -- An attempt to kill a British police sergeant, A.H. Weaghorn, expert on Jewish political affairs, was made today in the center of Tel Aviv.

In surveying the food markets this week-end, one is reminded of the old bromide that says no news is good news. Little has taken place since last Friday, but what is lacking in events is made up in stability. Though few prices have decreased, they haven't risen either, and most are holding the line.
LONDON, March 27 -- Although business again was on a small scale in the stock markets today, sentiment throughout was good.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The three Germans, in high places in this country before the war, who were brought here to testify in the recent perjury trial of Douglas MacCollum Stewart, will be returned to Germany on Saturday, it was learned at the Department of Justice today.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today directed the reorganization committee of the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad Company to carry out reorganization of the company under a plan the Supreme Court has twice approved.
AINTREE, England, March 27 (AP) -- Aintree opened its spring meeting today with a possible tipoff for Saturday's renewal of the Grand National Steeplechase: a race in which all sixteen starters fell.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- During the week ended March 26 member bank reserve balances decreased $285,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.
NANKING, March 27 (AP) -- Three Chinese Government armies are reported racing to cut off the retreat toward Manchuria of the Communists fleeing northeastward from fallen Yenan.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., March 27 (AP) -- Willie Goggin of White Plains, N.Y., who has spent 25 of his 41 years playing golf, scored a six under par 33, 33 -- 66 today to take the 18-hole lead in the $10,000 Charlotte Open Tournament. He was one stroke ahead of six 67 shooters who, in turn, were hotly pursued by five 68 performers.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (U.P.) -- The Navy said tonight that Great Britain, Mexico and Panama were the only countries to return any of the 4,795 naval units turned over to the allies under the lendlease program during the war.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The Senate voted tonight to continue sugar rationing until Oct. 31. A Republican Senator shouted treachery at the majority party for killing a provision to continue sugar controls for a whole year.

BIRTHDAY cards will be stacked high on the table on either side of his massive guest book tomorrow. Many of them will have been written in childish scrawls with such affectionate but unimaginative messages as "I think you are wonderful." The big fellow won't know about these mash notes, of course. Although he will be 30 years old on the morrow, he still hasn't learned to read.

The Hudson Guild must obtain $60,000 to expand its services for the benefit of 2,250 newcomers to the neighborhood, H. Daniel Carpenter, executive director, said yesterday. The Guild's neighborhood house is at 436 West Twentyseventh Street, in the midst of the new low-rent housing development, the John Lovejoy Elliott Houses.

MADISON, Wis., March 27 (AP) -- The University of Wisconsin, host to the tenth annual National Collegiate Athletic Association boxing championships, led the seventeen teams entered in the opening rounds today by qualifying seven men for the semi-finals.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 27 -- Leroy D. Stinebower, United States delegate to the United Nations Economic and Social Council, today hailed the Economic Commission for Europe as the "most significant" accomplishment of this current fourth session of the Council's "unglamorous but constructive" work for peace.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Senator Styles Bridges, Republican, of New Hampshire, called tonight for an explanation from the head of the Customs Bureau of what the Senator termed wholesale layoffs of patrol agents in a "brazen campaign" to force more money out of Congress.

The news got around Second Avenue and Forty-seventh Street yesterday that the church on the corner -- St. Boniface's Roman Catholic Church -- was to be torn down to make way for a sweeping approach to the United Nations site a couple of blocks away.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Oscar Cox, a lawyer who said he helped in the drafting of the TaftFulbright bill to create a Cabinet post for health, education, and welfare, told the House Committee on Expenditures in the Executive Departments today that the differences between it and the Aiken bill for such a post had been "unduly exaggerated."

CHICAGO, March 27 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 9,000 head, total 18,000; market very slow; weights under 250 pounds $1.00 to $1.50 lower; close $1.50 off; weights over 250 pounds $1.50 to $2.00 lower, close mostly $2.00

ATLANTA, March 27 -- Homer L. Loomis Jr., secretary-organizer of Columbians, Inc., the self-proclaimed anti-Jewish, anti-Negro organization, today was sentenced to thirty months' additional imprisonment following conviction in Superior Court on charges of usurpation of police powers.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The 500 delegates and alternates to the Women's Action Committee for Lasting Peace, representing all forty-eight states, were briefed today for a mass move on Capitol Hill tomorrow morning to urge support and strengthening of the United Nations.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Education of adults and the public responsibility for it have been ignore in THE TIMES' educational survey an the consequent public discussion. Always important, education of the adult is increasingly so now since it serve veterans, nurses, and the almost forgotten war workers as well as the student with a full-time job.

BATAVIA, Java, March 27 -- New economic arrangements between the Dutch and Indonesian Governments, quick return of nonIndonesians to their properties in the interior and gradual elimination of military perimeters were projected by Dr. Hubertus J. van Mook, acting Governor General of the Netherlands East Indies, in an interview following the signing of the Cheribon agreement this week.

Men Against Time On the same Sunday afternoon two orchestra conductors were busy at their regular employment here in town. One was Arturo Toscanini in the NBC studio; he was to celebrate his eightieth birthday two days later.
AUGUSTA, Ga., March 27 (AP) -- Three former winners were tied for the lead today at the end of the first day's play in the annual women titleholders' golf tournament today.

In the annual report of the Ogden Corporation for 1946, being sent to stockholders today, B. H. Brewster, president, said the indicated asset value of the company's stock was $1.47 a share at the close of 1946, compared with $1.53 a share at Dec. 31, 1945.
Governor Dewey was denounced last night by American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations unions for signing the Condon-Wadlin bill penalizing strikes of public employes.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The labor-management advisory committee of the United States Conciliation Service cautioned today against the threatened disorganization of the service and expressed confidence in the leadership and loyalty of the conciliation director Edgar L. Warren.

About 1,000 metal stamping manufacturers have been sent a copy of a letter from a Federal Trade Commission official in which the commission asked for information on steel trade practices, Tom J. Smith Jr., executive vice president of the Pressed Metal Institute disclosed through a local official of the institute here yesterday.
