VIENNA, March 27 -- A British military court in Voelkermarkt, Carinthia, sentenced the secretary general of the Yugoslav party, Karl Pruschnik, to four months in prison today.
YONKERS, N.Y., March 27 -- Sol Gelb, hired by a special committee of the Yonkers Common Council to investigate possible official corruption in connection with gambling, began his inquiry today.

BERLIN, March 27 -- A retired Wehrmacht officer with membership in several Nazi organizations dominates the Bavarian educational system despite all efforts of anti-Nazi Bavarians and of some members of the Military Government to have him removed.

A Bundles for Freedom drive, a program of direct relief by individual Americans to persons fighting against totalitarianism in Europe, has been started by Common Cause, Inc., 1775 Broadway, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Wales Latham, chairman of the organization.

A Church Planning Commission was authorized yesterday afternoon by the board of directors of the Protestant Council of the City of New York, which met at the Gramercy Park Hotel. The commission's purpose is "to plan for the coordination of the church life and the extension of the program and influence of the Protestant bodies of New York City," Dr. Earle F. Adams, executive director, said.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 27 -- Russia was absent from the United Nations Trusteeship Council for the second day today as the newly established organ spent most of its meeting in a drafting wrangle over proposed rules of procedure.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Proposed restrictions and conditions facing the $400,000,000 GreekTurkish aid program started taking clearer form today. Committees of both the Senate and the House indicated at the same time that they would continue their own studies through the March 31 "deadline" for Congressional action.

Encouraged by heavy buying at the opening, the stock market yesterday showed a marked improvement in prices and volume with advances in 763 issues. Chemical, motor and steel shares were the pacemakers, although numerous industrial specialties also were in good demand.

CHICAGO, March 27 -- Public resistance to present high merchandise prices is growing, but manufacturers are holding their price line and in some instances increasing prices, shareholders of Butler Brothers were told today at their annual meeting.

LONDON, March 27 -- Although persistent rumors of impending major changes in the British Cabinet were denied today by an authoritative Government spokesman, he did not rule out entirely the possibility that later in the year Ernest Bevin may leave the Foreign Office to take over the vital task of directing Britain's economic recovery.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, March 27 -- The Bulgarian Government denied today as "absolutely groundless" Greek charges before the United Nations Balkans Investigating Commission that it had fomented disorders inside Greece "with a view to severing Aegean Macedonia from Greece."

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Signs of flexibility appeared in the apparently deadlocked telephone wage situation today when the National Federation of Telephone Workers announced that it would not insist on system-wide collective bargaining conferences with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

Fate of the World Trade Corporation, a state-sponsored agency granted greatly expanded powers under a bill now before Governor Dewey for signature, will depend largely on the results of talks to be held within the next few weeks with Mayor O'Dwyer.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 27 -- Looking pale and drawn and walking with a limp as well as with the aid of a cane, Joe DiMaggio rejoined the Yankees today, but his return to active duty in center field was as much a matter of conjecture as ever.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- A Congressional source has revealed the Anti-Trust Division report which Attorney General Tom Clark disregarded when he approved the sale of the Government's giant steel plant at Geneva, Utah, to the United States Steel Corporation.

Although Mayor O'Dwyer two weeks ago strongly denounced the then-pending Condon-Wadlin bill to forbid strikes by public employes, saying such legislation was "hysterical," it is because the Mayor's hand is greatly strengthened by passage of that measure that he is able to announce now with calm assurance a set of principles for transit labor relations that fall far short of meeting the demands of the Transport Workers Union.

The New York Telephone Company estimated last night that demands for wage increases and other concessions presented by the company's unionized employes would increase the cost of providing telephone service in this State by $84,000,000 a year.

The use of recently developed plastic materials for interior decoration and architecture was demonstrated yesterday at the opening of the newly remodeled executive offices of the Bakelite Corporation, 30 East Forty-second Street. The interiors were designed by Walter Dorwin Teague.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 27 -- The identities of eight of the ten persons indicted by the Union County Grand Jury on Monday in connection with the gambling investigation that followed the Paris football "fix" in New York were disclosed today.

The Chesapeake Ohio Railway within a few days will file an application with the Interstate Commerce Commission for the release from a voting trustee of the 400,000 shares of New York Central Railroad stock that it now holds, Robert J. Bowman, president of the C. O., stated here yesterday.

MONTREAL, March 27 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadiens nosed out the Boston Bruins, 2 -- 1 in overtime tonight to take a 2-0 lead in their best-of-seven National Hockey League championship playoff series. Kenny Mosdell hammered in the pay-off counter at 5:38 of the "sudden death" overtime.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 27 (AP) -- With new track records established almost daily, it was not surprising when two more marks were smashed today at Gulfstream Park, including that for one mile and seventy yards when Allen Strandlund's Bert captured the Fulford Purse.

MOSCOW, March 27 -- After five weeks of broadcasting, the "Voice of America" program beamed to the Soviet Union from the United States is winning an increasing number of listeners not only in Moscow but also in the Ukraine, White Russia and several provincial cities of the Russian federation.
Players or France and the United States met on the tennis courts of the Seventh Regiment Armory in team competition for the first time in years last night.

Licensed bottlers of Spur, Canada Dry's cola beverage, have scheduled the heaviest campaign of twenty-four-sheet poster advertising in the history of this beverage, J.X. Kennelly, Canada Dry's assistant advertising manager, announced yesterday.

CANTON, March 27 -- Despite sporadic but growing Communist activity in the Kwangtung hinterland, Canton now lies in the backwash of Chinese politics and seems distantly remote from the civil war north of the Yangtze.

PARIS, March 27 -- Premier Paul Ramadier said today that he had received assurances from Washington that wheat shipments from the United States to France would be 553,000 tons this year and that the delivery schedule would be advanced by one month.

Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, left suddenly yesterday at 10:23 A.M. for Oslo, where he will testify before a commission of the Norwegian Parliament that is making a report on Norway's war-time activities. He said as he boarded a Scandinavian Airlines plane at La Guardia Field that he would probably return to New York next Tuesday.

MOSCOW, March 27 -- Following a forty-minute conversation with Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov, Dr. Kari Gruber, Austrian Foreign Minister, asserted tonight that his country would never sign a peace treaty that awarded Southern Carinthia to Yugoslavia.

Fordham's spring sports program has been returned to a regular basis for the first time since 1943, Graduate Athletic Manager Jack Coffey announced yesterday with the release of track, tennis and golf schedules.

Dissension between the Teachers Union, CIO, and other organizations composing the Teachers Salary Conference came into the open last night when the conference chairman accused "irresponsible groups" of having an "ulterior motive."

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Amid the debate over the Truman program to pledge American economic aid against totalitarianism in the Mediterranean, the Senate War Investigating Committee opened today a wide inquiry into American oil investments in the Near East.

Nathan Goldstein of Brooklyn advanced to the semi-final round of the Eastern indoor tennis championships last night at the Eighth Regiment Armory, the Bronx, by upsetting Sidney Schwartz, also of Brooklyn, 8 -- 6, 7 -- 5.

Warning of possible future trouble from current inflationary trends in real estate and of the danger of pricing veterans' homes "out of the market" was sounded by banking and insurance executives at the appraisal conference of the New fork State Society of Real Estate Appraisers yesterday in the Commodore Hotel.

PARIS, March 28 -- Admiral Jean de Laborde, who ordered the sinking and sabotage of the French Fleet at Toulon in 1942, was condemned to death for treason by the French High Court of Justice in Versailles today. The sentence carried with it national degradation and confiscation of his property.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The House Ways and Means Committee furnished today a graphic preview of the bitter debate and close division to be faced at some future date by the Administration's twin program involving new reciprocal trade treaties and an International Trade Organization to supervise international commerce.

Designating the midtown Manhattan parking ban as a permanent arrangement, James J. Sheeny, deputy commissioner, New York Police Department, emphasized yesterday the traffic benefits derived since it was put in force. There has been a great gain in the free movement of essential travel, and this will increase with more extensive enforcement, he told the seventeenth annual safety convention and exposition sponsored by the Greater New York Safety Council at the Pennsylvania Hotel.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The War Department announced today it would drop an additional 42,000 graded civilian employes and close another fifty-five posts and air fields to meet the requirements of its reduced 1948 budget.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Further efforts to reach an agreement on how much President Truman's $37,500,000,000 budget should be cut were advanced today as the Senate showed increased signs of balking on tax reduction until settlement of that issue.

Despite warnings that the city could not take over private bus lines and operate them profitably, the Board of Estimate in a special meeting last night completed arrangements to operate the North Shore Bus Company system in Queens beginning at midnight tonight.

MOSCOW, March 28 -- Participation of Turkey in the peace conference, as proposed by the United States, was violently attacked by Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov in a bitter statement before the Council of Foreign Ministers today.

An exhibition of thousand-yearold Chinese ceramics was opened yesterday afternoon with a preview at the C.T. Loo Gallery, 41 East Fifty-seventh Street. Beginning this morning the display will be open to the public daily except Sundays through April.

The Experimental Theatre, Inc., under the sponsorship of the American National Theatre and Academy, submits its fourth production of the season tomorrow evening at the Princess Theatre, 106 West Thirtyninth Street. It is Arnold Sundgaard's "The Great Campaign" which will be done for the customary five performances.

Doubleday will publish on April 10 a collection of writings by fiftythree veterans, entitled "The Purple Testament: Life Stories by Disabled Veterans," edited by Don M. Wolfe with a preface by John Dos Passos. The writings cover the authors' moods and experiences from Arizona sunsets to the worst shocks of battle experience.

Although failure crowned the efforts of many anglers who tried to take shad on a fly during the last season, the interest in this fishing is still running high, and many Connecticut anglers will give up the hope of trout to try the shad fishing at Enfield Dam on the opening day.

A letter from Harold A. Littledale printed on this page has called attention to a serious defect in library service in this city: the failure to provide for persons who, for one reason or another, cannot visit the public libraries. They are persons who most need the privilege of books.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Ohio's top political leaders held a privy council here tonight at the home of Senator Robert A. Taft, ostensibly to narrow down agreement as to whether Mr. Taft or the junior Senator from Ohio, John W. Bricker, will be the "favorite son" in the 1948 Presidential race.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Mayor William O'Dwyer accompanied Mayor George W. Welsh of Grand Rapids, Mich., to the White House today to urge President Truman to encourage the passage of housing legislation by Congress. Mr. Welsh is chairman of the Conference of Mayors.

AINTREE, England, March 28 (AP) -- A rodeo-sized field of fiftyeight jumpers -- barring last-minute scratches -- will go to the post tomorrow in the grueling Grand National Steeplechase, with an Irish horse the favorite and the lone American hope having only an outside chance.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., March 28 (AP) -- The four favorite teams -- Cornell College of Iowa, Oklahoma Aggies, Iowa State Teachers College and the University of Illinois -- remained primed for the showdown tomorrow in the N.C.A.A. wrestling tournament by advancing four men apiece through tonight's quarter-finals.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 27 -- Great Britain indicated today that she would challenge the right of German residents of Tanganyika to go to the Trusteeship Council with their protests against forced repatriation to Germany.
Union action delayed the departure of the Government-owned steamship Marine Perch with cargo and passengers yesterday.
NANKING, March 28 -- Foreigners who have just returned to China from Formosa corroborate reports of wholesale slaughter by Chinese troops and police during anti-Government demonstrations a month ago.

PHILADELPHIA, March 28 -- A tiny helicopter which can be strapped to the body of a paratrooper in place of a parachute, and a small, lightweight, one-place helicopter which eventually may be to flying what the motorcycle is to highway travel were disclosed here today at the third annual forum of the American Helicopter Society.

The annual report of Arnold Constable Corporation and its wholly owned subsidiaries, issued yesterday to stockholders by Isaac Liberman, president, shows an increase of 28.9 per cent in net sales to $21,240,026 for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, American Federation of Labor, charged today that J.A. Krug, Secretary of the Interior, "murdered" the victims of the Centralia mine disaster through "criminal negligence."

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Robert P. Patterson, Secretary of War, overruled Gen. Douglas MacArthur and gave permission to delegates of the World Federation of Trade Unions to visit Japan and Southern Korea after Gen. Douglas MacArthur had agreed to admit the delegation, it was learned today.

The approval during February of applications to purchase twelve war-built merchant vessels raised the total of such sales sanctioned by the Maritime Commission to 950, as of March 1, it was reported yesterday.
The Zarief quadruplets -- three girls and a boy -- gave a press preview party yesterday in anticipation of their third birthday anniversary today.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- William T. Faricy, newly elected president of the American Association of Railroads, described today as "half-truths" some of the criticisms of that organization by Robert R. Young, chairman of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway and organizer of the rival Federation for Railway Progress.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Senate-House conferees agreed today to extend rationing and price control of sugar until Oct. 31, with a specification that individuals receive at least twenty pounds each during the next seven months.

While the great majority in the sugar trade favor an extension of sugar controls beyond the Oct. 31 deadline proposed in Congress, they are seriously concerned over tin provision for a ten-pound increase to home users, sugar brokers stated yesterday.

AUGUSTA, Ga., March 28 (AP) -- Fighting off a sudden illness which almost caused her withdrawal, Miss Dorothy Kirby of Atlanta shot a 1-over-par 76 today to take a three-stroke lead in the annual women titleholders' golf tournament at the halfway point.

By a margin of more than seven to one, 8,000 students from twelve colleges in the New York area have indicated their belief that an effort to make the United Nations work now is preferable to a striving for a federal world government.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- Senators deluged with protests over the impending discharge of 1,576 port and border patrol men won a promise from W.R. Johnson, Customs Commissioner, today to reconsider the action.

The schools of this country should put greater emphasis on safety instruction, Dr. Herbert J. Stack, director of the New York University Center for Safety Education, told the seventeenth annual Safety Convention yesterday at the closing session of its four-day meeting in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Thirty-nine championship regattas on Long Island Sound, the largest number ever scheauiea, were announced last night by the Yaclit Racing Association for next summer. They will cover all Saturdays, Sundays and holidays starting May 24 and running through Sept. 21.

ALBANY, March 28 (AP) -- A supplemental budget of $6,801,996, including pay rises up to $4,500 for top State officials, was approved today by Governor Dewey. The appropriations augment the record $671,900,000 budget enacted earlier for the fiscal year beginning April 1.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- Standard Brands, Inc., notified the Federal Trade Commission today that it has discontinued advertising Fleischman's yeast for "direct human consumption and health purposes." The organization made the statement in reply to a commission charge of misrepresentation "concerning the therapeutic properties of the product," the commission said.
Surrogate James A. Delehanty flung a challenge to the new leadership of Tammany Hall yesterday when he asked that it ignore machine politics and designate him for another term.

Clothes for Easter We have been promptly and justly called to account for one bad piece of counsel in this column a few days ago. Writing on the sentimental value of a certain amount of "junk" in the home, we mentioned, along with superannuated sticks of furniture and outdated books, the contents of old clothes closets.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., March 28 -- Described as the plane that will change the whole pattern of air transport, the first two of a hundred and fifty Douglas DC-6 airplanes were turned over, one to United Air Lines and the other to American Airlines, in a brief ceremony here at noon.

Vladimir Horowitz gave the first performance of his new version, based upon the oldest manuscripts, of Mussorgsky's piano pieces, "Pictures at an Exposition," at his recital last night in Carnegie Hall, and it made an extraordinary impression.

The eleventh annual Three Choir Festival at Temple Emanu-El, which began with two programs yesterday and will end with a third this morning, has been dedicated to Arturo Toscanini, in honor of his eightieth birthday, which took place last Tuesday.

While the police were sorely tested yesterday tracking down endless tips on the enigmatic Langley Collyer, 61-year-old missing recluse, plans were announced for a funeral service for his older brother, Homer, found dead last Friday in their decayed brownstone home at 2078 Fifth Avenue.
LONDON, March 28 -- Britain has decided on a "get tough" policy on Palestine for the maintenance of order there on a long-term basis, it was learned authoritatively tonight.

LONDON, March 28 -- Despite a small turnover in the stock markets today, most of the leaders had small gains in price. Sentiment was helped by a further allround improvement of up to 3/8 point in British Government stocks.

MADRID, March 28 -- Circles close to Generalissimo Franco are studying the possibility of creating a Council of Regency first and trying to reach an agreement with Don Juan, the pretender, later, it was stated tonight by a person in close touch with those circles.

An exhibition made up of group portraits of American families will be held at Portraits, Inc., Gallery for the benefit of the Homemaker Service of The Children's Aid Society, from April 8 through April 30. Tickets for the preview on April 8 will be $5 and admission thereafter will be 50 cents.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 28 -- In the light of the latest developments in Turkish-United States relations, progressive individuals and newspapers are renewing their efforts to ease what is considered to be the difficult position of foreign press correspondents here.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- A personal flying equipment, reminiscent of the old-time "flying machines," having powers of elevation, propulsion and control to enable the wearer to fly from 125 to 350 miles at from 100 to 200 miles per hour and to land at will, with or without a parachute, is one of the 305 inventions for which patents were issued this week by the United States Patent Office.
Two men and a woman were arraigned yesterday in Federal Court on an indictment that accused them of selling morphine tablets stolen while in transit for the relief of wounded soldiers overseas.
LONDON, March 28 -- International action of some sort will be needed if trouble on the GreekBulgarian frontier is to be avoided, Hector McNeil, Minister of State, told the House of Commons today.

Out of China comes a strange and stirring story as the aftermath of one of the great feats of the war, the aerial blockade-running of the Air Transport Command over the Hump of the Himalayas. That superb performance in air logistics, which was to develop from a trickle to a huge and regular supply line across some of the most forbidding terrain on the earth, was a costly one.

New Capital Market The stepped-up pace of the market for new capital is shown by the fact that eleven bond issues aggregating $297,557,000 were marketed this week, on top of $112,720,000 last week. Moreover, five new-money issues of stock aggregating $10,894,900 were put out, a volume approximating that of last week.

TOKYO, March 28 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur has warned the Japanese Government that unless serious efforts are made to solve the country's economic problems and stamp out current abuses, United States support may be withdrawn.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Paul Porter, recently returned chief of President Truman's Economic Mission to Greece, urged Congress today, to make the proposed United States reconstruction aid to that country conditional on a maximum of self-help.

VIENNA, March 28 -- The Russian delegation to the Allied Council for Austria blocked today a proposal by the Western powers to permit the Austrian Government to begin planning now for the organization of the army of 53,000 agreed to this week in Moscow.

Only a month ago the city, meeting a crisis in Staten Island transportation, took over the privately operated bus lines which were failing to meet expenses under a five-cent fare. This, it was estimated, would add $350,000 to $700,000 a year to the city's present transit deficit of about $76,000,000 a year.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade state, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York state now offered by dealers.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: General Marshall came home with his report on the failure of a year' thankless effort to establish peace in China, and within hardly a month after his return the State Department announced our complete withdrawal from coaxing the two irreconcilable elements in China.

HOUSTON, March 28 -- Quiet, unassuming Houston multi-millionaire, Hugh Roy Cullen, who once was an oil field roustabout, stunned the city late today by announcing calmly that he was establishing a foundation for charitable purposes with a potential value of $160,000,000, rather than half this sum as previously announced.

The Army and Navy will purchase a minimum of 150,000,000 board feet of lumber before the end of 1947, R.E. Broderick, executive secretary of the Northeastern Lumber Manufacturers Association, predicted yesterday. He said the figure is only an estimate, but is supported by a revival of substantial purchases, backward since V-J Day.

In its drive to raise an annual fund of $100,000 to promote the sale of sweaters, bathing suits and other knitted sportswear, the knitted outerwear industry will stress the need of an all out effort to maintain sales at a point not too far under the $360,000,000 volume of 1946, it was pointed out yesterday by leaders in the industry.

MADISON, Wis., March 28 (AP) -- Six University of Wisconsin boxers registered victories tonight to lead eight other schools into the final round of the tenth annual National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament in the Badger ring before 11,000 fans.

HAVANA, March 28 -- The Dodgers continued their mastery over their Montreal farmhands tonight, downing the Royals under the lights of Gran Stadium by 5 -- 2. In the four meetings between the teams to date the best the Royals have registered was a tie.

DETROIT, March 28 (U.P.) -- Circuit Judge George B. Murphy today named a 33-year-old ex-convict as the hired killer of wealthy Mrs. Lydia Thompson, whose mutilated body was found in a lane near Pontiac, Mich., eighteen months ago.
Collections of fats have almost tripled since last October, but evidently it's owing to the fact there's more meat from which, to salvage fat, rather than that there are more women saving it.

CANTON, March 28 -- Forays by Communist-led irregulars on the Kwangtung mainland and on Hainan Island are growing in strength and frequency. The raids are giving the undermanned Nationalist forces considerable trouble.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Far from building up an "iron curtain" around industrial research laboratories, our patent system actually makes such secrecy unnecessary and promotes free interchange of scientific information, says Dr. Laurence A. Hawkins, consultant for the General Electric Research Laboratory, in Science, the weekly journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- Congress received a belated $1,751,894,500 bill today for World War II.

Adolf A. Berle Jr., former Under Secretary of State, called yesterday for an end of the kind of diplomacy that "wants to push populations out of one country for the benefit of another." He spoke at a luncheon of the American Federation of International Institutes in toe St. Moritz Hotel.

TIENTSIN, China, March 28 -- A heavily armed joint United States Army-Marine Corps convoy, escorted by tanks and aircraft, passed safely through Communistheld territory between Peiping and Tientsin today.

The demand for elevators and escalators that accumulated during the war years, plus sales for repairs and maintenance, resulted in booked orders of $88,241,550, the annual report of the Otis Elevator Company revealed yesterday. This record volume exceeds by $25,966,184 the previous maximum of $62,275,366 contracts established in 1929, and compares with $86,116,733 on the company's books at the close of 1945.

LONDON, March 28 -- Argentina will not accept the decisions of the international wheat conference now meeting in London. The chances of obtaining an effective world-wide purchase-andsale pact are therefore remote.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 28 (AP) -- Attendance dropped below 10,000 for the first time at the twenty-one-day-old Gulfstream Park meeting today when 9,858 fans visited the seaside track and saw the Edgehill Stable's He Rolls capture the featured sixth race by half a length.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, March 28 -- Two major developments in the drive to solve the displaced persons problem of the western zones of occupation this year were disclosed by the Intergovernmental Committee on Refugees and the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration today.

Real estate leaders who on Thursday attacked the WagnerEllender-Taft housing bill were criticized yesterday by Edmond Borgia Butler, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority. He suggested that they start building or stop talking.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, March 28 -- By an eight-to-two line-up without a vote, the United Nations Balkans investigating Commission decided here today that it had the right and duty to inquire whether Bulgaria and Yugoslavia are supporting a Macedonian autonomous movement.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 28 (AP) -- A three-run outburst in the eighth inning, engineered by a quintet of rookies, gave the New York Yankees a 5-to-2 victory over the Cincinnati Reds today. Kenny Polivka, Redleg rookie hurler, was the victim of the Bombers' assault.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 28 -- Argosy Pictures, the John FordMerian Cooper producing company, has signed Henry Fonda and John Wayne to play the leading roles in "War Party," a projected photoplay about the American Western frontier, which Ford will produce and direct for United Artists release.

In an action unprecedented in this State's legal history. Enix Bussey, 31 years old, strangler of two Chinese laundrymen, was sentenced twice yesterday to die in the electric chair for murders committed on different dates and localities.
Marcel Cerdan scored a tworound knockout victory over Harold (Red) Green of Brownsville in the scheduled ten-round star bout at Madison Square Garden last night.

TOKYO, March 28 -- Evidence is accumulating to show that the pendulum of Japanese labor, which swung hard toward communism and direct action during the first eighteen months of the occupation, has started on the return track.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 28 -- Recovering from a painful cheek injury, Larry Jansen, highly touted rookie right-hander, will rejoin the Giants here tomorrow. He will not be able to do any pitching for at least another fortnight but his presence should prove helpful to a mound staff which needs moral as well as physical encouragement.

ALBANY, March 28 -- Governor Dewey vetoed today a bill designed to end the system of substitute teachers in the New York City schools and said that when the administration bill on teachers' pay became law it would take care of the situation.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, March 28 -- More than 50,000 Germans staged today the largest protests witnessed since the war's end against food shortages. In a remarkable display organizations of workers in a dozen towns around this hub of the Ruhr stopped all but essential services and gave the first overt display of violence against the British Military Government.
After an irregular start yesterday, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned strong and buoyant in the afternoon and closed at net gains of 43 to 50 points on active months.

A three-way program of Federal, State and city aid to solve New York City's post-war development program was recommended yesterday by Newbold Morris, former president of the City Council, and Councilman Stanley M. Isaacs, Republican, of Manhattan.

College basketball, which added further to its stature as a major sports attraction through a season of exceptionally ambitious scope, will bow out of the picture tonight at Madison Square Garden with the East-West All-Star game. This contest is the feature of a program for the benefit of The Tribune Fresh Air Fund.

Fewer shoe manufacturers will use an escalator clause in pricing for summer and fall, while a majority will quote firm prices without qualification, according to a sampling survey made available here yesterday by the National Shoe Manufacturers Association.

As a part of its $290,000,000 bond refunding program, the Consolidated Edison Company of New York has obtained a mortgage loan of $100,000,000 from the National City Bank, as trustee, on 119 parcels of realty throughout the city. Loans on twenty-one of the parcels in the Bronx were recorded yesterday.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 8 -- In a session that endured for more than four and a half hours, (Baseball Commissioner Albert B. Happy) Chandler today sat as judge and jury in the final joust between Larry MacPhail and Branch Rickey over charges which the former had directed against he head of the Dodgers.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Policy Committee of the National Conference on the German Problem respectfully draws attention to the account of the conference published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on March 7.
A racket whereby Army officers paid fees to a port official at the New York Port of Embarkation in Brooklyn to obtain priority in the shipment overseas of personal automobiles became known yesterday.

The stock market drifted irregularly yesterday following the previous day's activity with closing prices moderately easier in slower trading. While transactions on the Stock Exchange dropped to make the smallest volume of the last three sessions, with a turnover of 830,000 shares, the tenor of the market was evidenced by the fact that the volume in the morning session about equaled that in the latter part of the day.

The leak in exports of irreplaceable resources of pig iron and scrap must be closed by Congressional action at an early date, Raymond L. Collier, executive vice president, the Gray Iron Founders Society, declared here yesterday in an interview.

ST. LOUIS, March 28 (AP) -- Mary Catherine Reardon, calmly shifting the blame for her father's death from herself to her 13-yearold runaway companion, Michael D'Arcy, stuck to her story today under more than two hours of cross-examination.

Sales in the better-grade jewelry field have been holding up better than was expected since the first of the year, trade reports indicated here yesterday. Volume has been aided by larger business in silverware, pent-up demand for American watches and other items which were in short supply a year ago.

CHICAGO, March 28 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hoes, 5,000 head: total, 9,500. Weights under 260 pounds fairly active and 50 to mostly 75 cents lower; heavier weights around 25 cents lower:

The population of persons 65 years and older has increased 57 per cent in this city and by 35 per cent throughout the country in the last twenty years, Harry Levine, director of the older persons' program for the City Department of Welfare, reported yesterday.

VIENNA, March 28 -- Soviet authorities in Austria have now arrested five members of Austrian national or provincial parliaments. The fifth seized was Josef Mayer, member of Austrian Upper House, who was arrested by Soviet guards Sunday on a bridge between Urfahr in the Soviet zone and Linz in the United States area.
Brownsville, Tex., announced yesterday the sale of $1,750,000 of revenue bonds due Feb. 1 from 1948 to 1977 to Crummer Co., Inc., and associates at a bid of 102.51 for 3s.

SEATTLE, March 28 (AP) -- Ohio State's National Collegiate Athletic Association defending swim champions qualified eight individuals and a relay team for the final events tonight, but other teams were challenging and the Buckeyes were squeezed out of the 50-yard free-style entirely.

Seventy-five working mothers in Harlem whose 100 children were about to be evicted from their daycare center won a delay of three months yesterday from the trustees of the Convent Avenue Baptist Church, 420 West 145th Street, in whose parish house the center is situated.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- A member of the Communist party, appearing as an emissary of Peter V. Cacchione, Communist Councilman of New York City, who stayed away, today flung defiance and denunciation at the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

MOSCOW, March 28 -- The Western powers rejected today Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov's latest proposed definition of German assets in Austria and a stalemate on this vital issue ensued. It was indicated that any progress on a basic solution of the draft treaty for Austria would now be deferred for some time until the subject of Austria arose once again at the end of the Council of Foreign Ministers' agenda.

AMSTERDAM, March 28 (ANETA) -- Trading on the Stock Exchange was fairly active, with prices continuing to move higher for the fourth successive day and many stock showing new highs. Indies plantation issues were up sharply, improving on the gains made after the signing of the Linggadjati agreement.

The Citizens Union appealed yesterday to Governor Dewey to sign the Schneider-Pakula bill extending the mortgage moratorium on a limited basis. It requested, however, that he call a special session of the Legislature to correct what it considers as obvious shortcomings of the legislation.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 28 -- Warren R. Austin formally notified the United Nations Security Council today of President Truman's $400,000,000 proposal to aid Greece and Turkey.

CLEVELAND, March 28 (AP) -- Gilbert H. Dodds, the flying parson of the Boston A.C., set a new meet record of 4:08.5 tonight in winning the Catholic Universe Bulletin mile from a classy field in the feature event of the seventh annual indoor Knights of Columbus track meet before 11,485 spectators at the Arena.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 27 -- The United States gave its approval today to a special United Nations General Assembly session on Palestine, clearing the way for Great Britain to make the formal proposal, probably tomorrow.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, March 28 (Aneta) -- John Davis Hatch, chairman of the Albany, Nijmegen Committee formed in Albany, N.Y., to aid in the reconstruction and relief of Nijmegen, the Netherlands, announced here tonight that agreement had been reached on a three-point program along which the aid would be directed.
A group of East Harlem boys, puzzled and angry at the bad name their community has gained in recent years, set out yesterday to prove their detractors wrong.

BERLIN, March 28 -- The Soviet Military Government spent hundreds of millions of marks buying "gold" here before it discovered much of the seemingly precious metal was a base alloy with a gold coating and was worth little.

Trade Holds Recent Gains The recent rate of gain in dollar sales in retail trade here continued this week. Eastern buying was a factor, but ready-to-wear turnover did not supply the sales increases. Department store sales were estimated at about 10 per cent ahead of last year.

BOSTON, March 28 (U.P.) -- Lee Savold of Paterson, N.J., spoiled the American debut of Italian heavyweight champion Duilio (The Great) Spagnolo of Milan tonight by scoring a technical knockout in the eighth round of their scheduled 10-round bout at Boston Garden before 9,718 bored fans.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- Copper fabricating interests urged the Senate Finance Committee today to suspend the 4-cents-a-pound import duty on copper for at least two years to help meet domestic shortages.

CHICAGO, March 28 -- General selling developed in the grain markets at the opening of the Board of Trade today, with wheat breaking as much as 8 3/4 cents a bushel and corn about 3 cents, continuing the downward movement of the previous day, when wheat dropped 10 cents and corn 8 cents.

These are the saddest of possible words -- Tinker to Evers to Chance. Trio of bearcubs -- and fleeter than birds -- Tinker and Evers and Chance. Pricking forever our gonfalon bubble, Forcing a Giant to hit into a double, Words that are heavy with nothing but trouble -- Tinker to Evers to Chance.

New procedure will be followed by the Federal Trade Commission in handling complaints of trade practice violations. Commissioner Lowell Mason told the annual meeting of the National Fiber Can and Tube Association at the Hotel Astor yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 28 -- The United Nations Economic Commission for Europe and a like commission for Asia and the Far East were created today in a marathon meeting of the Economic and Social Council. The Council is expected to end its work tomorrow.

Voluntary hospitals are experiencing the greatest operating deficits in their history, creating a situation that requires the most serious attention of everyone, Norman S. Goetz, president of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, said yesterday.

AMSTERDAM, March 28 (Aneta) -- Eventual liquidation of Dutch mortgage banks operating abroad, mostly in the United States, has been ordered by the Bank of the Netherlands in a ruling that these institutions might no longer reinvest United States and Canadian dollars paid them on mortgages and other investments.

In his comprehensive statement to the United Nations Security Council on American aid to Greece and Turkey, Mr. Warren Austin made a passing reference to the weather in the mountainous borderlands where the guerrillas are waging the strange little three-sided war -- civil, international ind ideological -- on which so many larger issues hang.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 27 -- New Zealand insisted today that approval by the United Nations of United States trusteeship proposals for Japanese mandated islands in the Pacific could not become final before the peace treaty with Tokyo was signed.

The Maritime Commission awarded eight former German ships yesterday to the highest responsive bidders. Bids on three others were rejected, with the sale of these to be readvertised. The sale brought a $1,932,650 return to the government.
Twenty-two-year-old Hans Kloosterman arrived here yesterday aboard the Holland America liner Leerdam "to take the place" of an American flier he buried three years ago near his Holland farmhouse.

PHILADELPHIA, March 28 -- Registration statements covering $5,100,000 of bonds, $1,750,000 of debentures, 120,000 shares of preferred stock and 963,954 shares of common stock were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by seven companies.

To those Americans who have been troubled by the charge that President Truman's program for aid to Greece and Turkey deliberately "by-passes" the United Nations, we believe that Senator Austin's address yesterday before the Security Council provides a straightforward and reassuring answer.

The eight-day-old "wildcat" walk-out that has tied up construction on the $84,000,000 Brooklyn -Battery Tunnel changed to the status of a union-authorized strike yesterday, with no immediate prospect of settlement.

The Transport Workers Union of Greater New York voted last night to ask the Board of Transportation for substantially higher wages, a work week of forty instead of forty-eight hours, increased vacations and an improved pension system for the fiscal year starting July 1.

ROME, March 28 -- After a meeting lasting more than six hours the Cabinet announced tonight various financial measures aimed at balancing the budget. The major decision is for a capital levy that will be paid by all persons possessing money, property or goods aggregating more than 3,000,000 lire, or about $7,500 at the official rate of exchange.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 28 -- The statement of Warren R. Austin, United States representative in the United Nations Security Council on the Greek case before the Council and on the United States program of aid to Greece and Turkey, follows:

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The closing, elimination or consolidation of numerous naval shore establishments, including some naval shipyards and airfields, may be the result of a thorough survey of the Navy's shore facilities now being conducted by the general board of the Navy Department.
JERUSALEM, March 28 -- Five youths dressed as Arabs, but assumed to be Jews, caused an explosion and fire at the Iraq oil pipeline near its terminal in the Haifa Bay area today.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The National Federation of Telephone Workers today suggested to Congress that its labor committees help to avert a strike of telephone workers on April 7 by conferring with spokesmen for the federation and the American Telephone Telegraph Company.

The ancient bell in the tower of the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, will be tolled thirty-three times on Good Friday, beginning at 3 P.M., the traditional hour of the death of Jesus Christ on the Cross of Calvary.

Steps to aid pedestrians crossing two of Manhattan's busiest intersections were announced yesterday by Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander. Effective Monday automobiles will be 'barred from making any turn at Forty-second Street and Fifth Avenue and at Herald Square. In addition traffic signals are being reset to allow 22 per cent tion time to cross the intersection of Broadway, Avenue of the Americas and Thirty - fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Mrs. Raymond Brown, campaign chairman of the Women's Action Committee for Lasting Peace, reported to its annual convention today that delegates had succeeded earlier in the day in seeing Senators "from all but three or four States" in behalf of United Nations objections.
ROME, March 28 -- Italy hopes in the near future to re-establish consular ties with Ethiopia as the first step toward resuming diplomatic relations, a Foreign Ministry spokesman announced today.

The United States Concilation Service stepped into the telephone wage situation yesterday and sought to reopen negotiations between the long lines department of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the American Union of Telephone Workers.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The question of confirming the members of the United States Atomic Energy Commission was threatened with indefinite suspension today when Senator John W. Bricker, Republican, of Ohio, moved to turn the whole issue back into committee.

"THE AMBOY DUKES,"* by Irving Shulman, is a somber novel of young Brooklyn gangsters, though it might be about the children of violence in many another city. It is told in the appropriate naturalistic manner, with the bark on, and few details left to the imagination. As a novel it suffers from a little too much plot.

A CHARGE-IT service for the purchase of rail and Pullman tickets on forty-five major railroads will go into effect on Tuesday. Under this plan travelers need only one credit card, which is issued by the Rail Travel Credit Agency, set up in Chicago's Union Station to administer the service.
MOSCOW, March 29--Heinrich Dinkelbach, head of the North German Iron and Steel Control group in the British zone will be retained in his post despite Soviet protests.

SEATTLE, March 29--Joe Verdeur of La Salle University bettered his own accepted world record tonight in the 200-yard breast-stroke final at the National Collegiate A.A. swimming meet, going the distance in 2 minutes 16.8 seconds.

ST. LOUIS, March 29--An architectural competition offering $125,000 in prizes to obtain a design for a $30,000,000 Federal memorial to Thomas Jefferson and the pioneers of the Western expansion of the United States was announced here today.

Dr. W.K. Kolff of Kampen, Holland, turned up by invitation at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York recently and there demonstrated an "artificial kidney" that he invented for the treatment of uremic poisoning. This form of poisoning follows damage to the kidney.

SYRACUSE--Speech Lab Films In one of the first projects of its kind in the country, the School of Speech at Syracuse University has initiated a system of filming speech classes to aid classroom teaching. Nearly 300 students have been filmed and their voices recorded in a specially designed pre-fabricated speech laboratory.

DUESSELDORF, March 29-- The food demonstrations in the British zone, which have involved more than 100,000 Ruhr workers this week, reached a new and possibly dangerous climax today when 4,000 miners refused to go down into the pits after a demonstration in Dortmund.

Quick action by a neighbor who knew that there was quicksand along that part of the Flushing Bay shoreline was credited by the police yesterday with saving the lives of Carole Consiglio, 8 years old, and her brother, Paul, 10, of 25-65 124th Street, College Point, Queens.

By the waters of Jerome Park Reservoir, deep in the Bronx, the United Nations made its American debut one year ago last Tuesday. Delegates to the Security Council gathered in the renovated gymnasium at Hunter College. There were speeches of welcome. In the audience a wounded sailor said: "Well, we've got it started; let's hope it works."

SAN FRANCISCO, March 29-- Jack (Lucky) Lohrke, the San Diego rookie who had been counted on as the Giants' third sacker, will be tried out at second in some of the exhibitions remaining on the schedule, Manager Mel Ott revealed today.

Approach of the iron ore-moving season on the Great Lakes, scheduled to begin about April 15, has again touched off discussion in steel circles on the vital question of the size of the nation's iron ore reserves and how soon the topgrade deposits of the mineral will be exhausted.

THE controversy over "excessive commercialism" in radio was renewed last week when the Commission on the Freedom of the Press made the unqualified recommendation that all advertising matter on the air should be separated entirely from program content.

CHICAGO, March 29 (AP)--Chicago's Golden Glovers, easily trouncing New York's finest squad in their twentieth intercity boxing rivalry, today were primed for their meeting May 28 with the allEuropean amateur championship team with seven gilt-edged prospects.

SOME of Mack Sennett's old silent comedies of happy memory are about to be reissued, completely refurbished with sound and appropriate comic narration, in a series generally titled "Nickelodeon Chuckles." J. J. Balaber, local film man and a profound admirer of Sennett's works, has collected some 150 Sennett two-reelers produced for Pathe between 1922 and 1928 out of which he has called twenty-six for presentation in his series.

PARIS (By Wireless). THE French delegation went to the Moscow conference in the hope that at last the great powers would be willing to face squarely the problem of Germany, which for France is the greatest single question mark hanging over a horizon that is full of question marks.

HOLLYWOOD. LAST June the famed Chaplin film studios on La Brea Avenue, Hollywood, birthplace of such movie milestones as "The Gold Rush," "The Kid" and "City Lights," were reactivated for the first time since 1940. Charles Spencer Chaplin was making another picture, his first since "The Great Dictator."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 29--Plans to hold in Washington this September the first World Statistical Congress to be held in almost eleven years were adopted today by the United Nations Economic and Social Council.

CHICAGO, March 29 -- Looselimbed Gil Dodds, the Flying Parson, tonight ran the fastest mile of the indoor track season, a 4:06.8 performance, which fell short by only four-tenths of a second of matching his accepted American mark set in the Chicago Relays same Bankers' Mile in 1944.

THIS book is the result of an effort made by a group of two college presidents, nine professors, a former Assistant Secretary of State and a banker to find out what is wrong with the newspapers, radio, motion pictures, magazines and books of the United States (referred to, for convenience, as "the Press") and to agree on a prescription.
DES MOINES, March 29 (AP)-- Attorney General Tom C. Clark predicted tonight that the stand taken by President Truman against communism "will go down in history as the Truman Doctrine."

MADISON, Wis., March 29 (AP) --Three former champions, Charles Davey of Michigan State, Cliff Lutz of Wisconsin and Laune Erickson of Idaho, won titles again in the renewal of the National Collegiate Athletic Association boxing tournament before 15,000 spectators tonight.

WHATEVER else may be said of post-war houses, they all seem to have one detail in common -- bigger windows. This current architectural convention may vary from the generous window walls of the solar house to the one "picture window" of the pseudoCape Cod cottage.
Supreme Court Justice James B.M. McNally upheld yesterday the right of the police to visit and inspect so-called social clubs if the purpose is to prevent crime and apprehend criminals.

TOKYO--The semi - official Japan Travel Bureau is sponsoring the development of a Japanese tourist industry that is expected to bring the first tourists to this country by the end of 1948 or early 1949. The plans envision a billion yen industry entertaining more than 100,000 visitors a year, at least fifty-thousand of them Americans, in the early stages of its development.

WHEN the Forty-niners landed in California Jed Blaine and his woman were there to greet them. Abetted by one of those well-timed accidents that make life exciting for people in historical novels. Jed and Keziah sailed through the Golden Gate in August, 1848, aboard the clipper Flying Star, five months out of New York.

Aside from the problem of city finance, the two biggest headaches that have plagued Mayor William O'Dwyer of New York for more than a year have been concerned with transportation -- first, the city airports problem; second, the transit labor problem.

PRYING-- A woman entered the office of the County Clerk in Tampa, Fla., and applied for a driver's license. A minute later she rose from her chair, glared angrily at the astonished clerk and departed in indignation.
Cosmic Bomb, winter-book favorite for the Kentucky Derby, stepped six furlongs in 1:16 on Belmont Park's training track yesterday and got a sweet reward from Owner William Helis--a lump of sugar.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Some opinions relating to the Communist party which have appeared in your columns betray confused thinking or writing, although they eventually reach a conclusion controverted by none, i.e., the right of free speech must be preserved to every citizen.

LONDON, March 29 -- Hints from United States security officials about the possibility of a leak of atomic bomb secrets prompted a British Military Intelligence unit this week to curb the activities of five persons in the civil service, it was reported tonight.

SEATTLE, March 29 -- As labor surpluses increase and prices continue to rise, the West Coast is becoming attracted by the peacetime application in the Portland industrial area of a wartime development, the Labor-Management Committee.
Charles Seymour Whitman, former Governor of New York, died last night at 7 o'clock in the University Club at 1 West Fiftyfourth Street, where he had resided for several years. His age was 78.

The 180 permanent guests and twenty-five commercial tenants of the Hotel Imperial started court action yesterday to restrain the Goelet Estate, owners of the property, from carrying out their announced plan to close the hotel Tuesday.

To the Drama Editor: The existence of the German story "Germelshausen" comes as no surprise to me at this time. It was not long after I had completed the first draft of "Brigadoon" that a friend informed me of it.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., March 29-- Herman Barron, 37 year-old White Plains, N.Y., professional, often around the top money but seldom a winner, took over the 36-hole lead in the $10,000 Charlotte open golf tournament today with his second 67 for a 134 halfway total,

Of the various health needs of the nation, none assumes more staggering proportions when measured by statistical evidence than dental diseases. They are among the most prevalent and the most neglected of the disabilities that affect man.

WINCHESTER, Va., March 29-- All grousp in the national economy will benefit if prices are reduced, it was asserted in a nation-wide radio address tonight by Earl Bunting, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, and president of the O'Sullivan Rubber Company, makers of rubber heels, of this city.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)-- A United Nations organization eventually will be developed with strength to maintain world peace, Representative Clarence Cannon, Democrat, of Missouri, said today in comment on the foreign policy program.

There is good reason to believe that the French National Assembly disregards history in voting additional millions for use in attempting to hold by force its colony of French Indo-China and its 25,000,000 people, who, quite obviously, do not wish to remain colonials.

PARIS, March 29--A critical political situation arose in France when the Communists balked at approving military credits for IndoChinese operations. It was widely attributed in part to the effect in France of President Truman's message to Congress urging loans to save Greece and Turkey from Communist pressure.

FOR thirty-five years the man called "Hankey" has lived a breathless life in Cabinets, conferences and committees, national, imperial and international. Experience in hundreds of such affairs has qualified him to be regarded as an authority on the inception and development of government and diplomacy by round table.

TO THE EDITOR: Re "Better Minds for Better Politics," by Arthur T. Vanderbilt: Total failure or uninformed participation in elections on the part of the legally qualified voter has long been recognized as a major obstacle to good government.

Some appointments to high commands in the National Guard have had an unfortunate psychological effect upon the veterans who might provide the backbone of the post-war Guard and Organized Reserve units.

SEATTLE, Wash., March 29-- In the face of assertions that the lumber capital of the Pacific Northwest has shifted from Tacoma, Wash., 250 miles southward to Eugene, Oregon, millions of dollars are being poured into expansion of timber products industries in this State.

TO THE EDITOR: I must differ with my friend Leonard Traube in his comment on your photo of Emmett Kelly. Mr. Traube states that Emmett Kelly is an "American pantomimist." Kelly, while a great buffoon and what was once called in the circus a funmaker (to distinguish his type of work from that of the whiteface clowns), is definitely not a pantomimist.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 29-- William Berryman Scott, who was Professor of Geology and Paleontology at Princeton University from 1884 until his retirement as Professor Emeritus in 1930, died today of a heart attack in the Princeton Hospital.

HOLLYWOOD SOME hope for settlement of Hollywood's six-month-old strike appeared last week in the form of a report made to Roman Catholic Archbishop John J. Cantwell by the Rev. John J. Devlin and the Rev. Thomas Coogan, whom the Archbishop, had appointed to investigate the problem.

WASHINGTON, March 29--The Truman doctrine of providing assistance for free nations that are in imminent danger of succumbing to Communist pressure has thrown into high relief our entire program of foreign assistance since the cessation of hostilities.

MOSCOW, March 29--The United States and Britain will be in an "extremely strong" position when the Big Four meet Monday and attempt to break the deadlock over Germany's economic unity, reparations and the level of industry.

Long Island Agricultural and Technical Institute MAGNOLIAS in bloom are among the highlights of spring. These trees and shrubs are, obligingly enough, among the few early flowering plants that need to be set in the ground at this season.

LOW-COST, low-alloy steels, developed during the war to ease the shortages of alloying metals, may prove to be effective in easing the steel bottleneck in the automobile industry, and eventually in reducing the cost of car manufacture.
Reflecting the unexpectedly sharp rise in the parity price for cotton, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange rose again yesterday, and closed 1 to 15 points net higher.

FATAL-- The Registrar, a publication of the National Office of Vital Statistics, reports the following notation on a death certificate: "Cause of death--Injury on neck with axe. Contributory cause--Lady friend."

WASHINGTON, March 29--The second chapter in the story of Navy oil-buying in the Middle East was told today in a fairy tale literary style. The Senate War Investigating Committee, however, engaged former Senator Burton K. Wheeler to rewrite the whole story in terms of American-British-Arabian high finance, diplomacy and power politics.

An 18-year-old boy and his 14year-old brother who allegedly had terrorized women in Central Park were captured yesterday by the crew of a radio patrol car. Two hold-ups had occurred within thirty minutes, with a hunting knife as the weapon.
A RADIATOR painted in aluminum or gold emits approximately 10 per cent less heat than one painted a reasonably modest color.

Our present democratic form of government may be succeeded by some totalitarian system unless greater numbers of able young men and women are trained for government careers, Arthur T. Vanderbilt, dean of the New York University School of Law, declared yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel New Yorker.

THERE are irony, compassion, and a true knowledge of both people and period in this brief novel about a woman and the two soldiers who have been in love with her. One of these soldiers, Tom Grail, is killed as a youth in that war which now, by current comparison, seems so small and so far away, the SpanishAmerican.

With only slightly more than half of New York's Red Cross 1947 goal of $6,153,600 raised in the month of March, James M. Cecil, general chairman of the fund, announced yesterday that the campaign would be extended into April. So far $3,153,428 has been subscribed.
PRETORIA, South Africa, March 29 -- Emotionally, King George's entry into Pretoria today was the climax of the royal tour of South Africa.

IN spite of Edgar Allan Poe's warning that the poet should not attempt a long poem, Jeanette Michael Haien has made the attempt--and has succeeded in fulfilling most of Poe's dire predictions. Miss Haien has taken the story of Rip Van Winkle, which has become a part of our authentic explore and has attempted to explore its symbolic possibilities.

Supreme Court Justice Frank E. Johnson denied yesterday a motion by the State Labor Relations Board to compel an apartment house owner to bargain with a building service employes union and to reinstate a discharged employe.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March 29--The Economic and Social Council of the United Nations ended its fourth session today. The Council's president, Sir Ramaswami Mudaliar of India, reviewing achievements, stressed that the past year had been devoted largely to organization.

The white-porticoed palace of the Governor General in the Rijswijk district of Batavia was the scene last week of a ceremony of historic importance to Indonesia's 80,000,000 people. There, representatives of the Netherlands and Indonesian Governments signed a document which extended formal recognition to the Indonesian Republic, consisting of the rich islands of Java, Sumatra and Madoera.

CHICAGO, March 29--A $2,000,000,000a-year program for the advancement of the country's schools and the teaching profession, the first country-wide campaign of its kind ever undertaken, was set in motion today. Members of the National Commission on Teacher Education and Professional Standards of the National Education Association outlined the far-reaching program at a press conference.
The next Federal fiscal year will end June 30, 1948--during the political season of national conventions, platforms and nominations for the Presidential election four months later.

MRS. KIBBE is probably as well-qualified a person as one could find to write a book on the Latin Americans of Texas. She has had broad, practical experience in the field, and at present serves as executive secretary of the Texas Good Neighbor Commission.

FORMERLY the New York concert season began to slacken in April. But not this year. Undoubtedly it will be the heaviest April for concerts the city has ever had. Already four halls have announced 119 musical events during the month.

A SHORT while after the end of World War II the venerable Burgtheater in Vienna performed "Jaakobs Traum" in order to honor the memory of its creator, the Austrian poet, Richard Beer-Hofmann who, a few weeks earlier, had died in his New York exile in his eightieth year.

Department store sales by reserve districts, as reported by the Federal Reserve Board, are listed in the following table, which gives percentage comparisons with a year ago: Federal Four Yr.to Reserve 1 Wk. Ended Wks.Ended Mar.

DAISIES have a simple charm which has made them garden favorites for generations. For many of us they carry with them into cultivation, in all their various forms, the freshness of open fields and the memory of June picnics.

ST. LOUIS, March 29 (AP)--Secretary of the Navy James Forrestal declared tonight that if Navy funds were cut below Budget Bureau figures the Navy's "program and our naval strength would be seriously endangered."
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., March, 29--The Truman program to supply military equipment for Greece and Turkey, and economic help for Greece, has had a marked effect upon the United Nations.

APRIL FOOLS' DAY--or All Fools' Day, as it was formerly known-- will be observed on Tuesday. For some, the day is unofficially observed throughout the year. Tradition, however, restricts the custom to one day of the 365 and the time-honored pranks, practical jokes and fool's errands associated with it occur then.

Commercial bankers here, caught between the millstones of increased costs of operation and the Government's fiscal operations, with the consequent depressing influences on interest rates, are anticipating marked declines in earnings for the quarter that will end this week.

There is a succession in the days, now, that quickens the human heart. Whether they are gusty days or days of calm, chill days or days of deepening warmth, they have the air of change. No two days are alike. Sometimes it seems as though the season were trying a variety of moods, play-acting in a dozen different parts, eager to be spring and reluctant to be no longer winter.

IN George Moore's "Hail and Farewell" there are two "candid camera" portraits of Lady Augusta Gregory, friend of W.B. Yeats, Standish O'Grady, Dr. Douglas Hyde, Sara Allgood, George Bernard Shaw, and Sean O'Casey--and wherever The Abbey Theatre of Dublin was known, she was known as one of its playwrights and directors.

"THE AUTHOR MEETS THE CRITICS" will move on May 25 to Station WNBC, where it is scheduled to be heard regularly on Sunday afternoons, according to an announcement by Martin Stone, originator-and producer of the program.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)-- The text of John L. Lewis's letter to all United Mine Workers, calling for a week's holiday in memorial to the victims of the Centralia, Ill., mine disaster follows: To the officers and members of the United Mine Workers of America in all bituminous districts in the United States, greetings:

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)-- Pay of production workers in manufacturing industries increased 14 per cent during 1946, while consumer prices were rising 18 per cent, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

ROME, March 29--The Italian Government has requested Great Britain to take steps for the total evacuation of some tens of thousands of former Chetniks and other Yugoslav political refugees who pursue political activities contrary to Marshal Tito.

JERUSALEM, March 29--A ship carrying 1,600 Jewish unauthorized refugees was intercepted tonight off the northern coast of Palestine by the Royal Navy. The ship bore the name Moledeth [Patria or Homeland]. She is now being escorted into Haifa.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., March 29 (AP) -- Fleetridge, strapping chestnut colt making only the seventh start of his career, staged a Garrison finish to win the $10,000added Arkansas Derby before a crowd of 11,118 that bet $595,290 on Oaklawn Park's closing program today.

AFTER World War I the novel about the girl in search of her freedom, economic and otherwise, was fairly common. This story of Rose Weber might be considered a follow-up. Covering three decades of Chicago at a gallop--up to 1950 for good measure --we learn how little this freedom meant to her and how little she made of it.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The difficulties now facing France are purely economic in nature. The country is stripped of her industrial and agricultural equipment, with the French people, industrious as they are, forced to remain idle. The Government, foreseeing with fear unemployment ahead, which may well harm the nation, is obliged to support a number of Government officials.
For the first time in history transcontinental air passengers saw the Pacific and the Atlantic under the light of the same day's sun yesterday.

COLLECTORS who can afford to buy recordings of full operas should be looking forward to the future with optimism. Victor and Columbia are busy making new recordings or reissuing old ones, and the competition, in this field is bound to be lively.

THIS book on "Psychiatry at the Fox-hole Level," was written at the direction of Gen. George C. Marshall, who terminated his briefing, after hearing the final report, with, "It would not be right to have that information forever buried in the files of the War Department.

Rare first editions, autographs and other literary material forming Fart Three of the library of the late Fred W. Allsopp of Little Rock, Ark., are on pre-sale exhibition at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

PITTSBURGH, March 29 -- The subject of smoke control had the 1,500,000 residents of Allegheny County, of which Pittsburgh is the hub, mentally smogbound as this week started. Suddenly the air cleared, and the State Legislature now has the green light to shake up a county-wide program.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 29--The world champion Cardinals got more than a little bit rough this afternoon. They ripped into one of Bucky Harris' younger pitchers, Frank Shea, for five runs in the first inning--four riding in on Marty Marion's grand-slam home run--and from there went on to down the Yankees, 8 to 4.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 29 --The study and development of atomic energy in Belgium are slowly gathering momentum. The immediate objective is to win approval of a state grant of 10,000,000 francs for the National Scientific Research Fund.

VIENNA, March 29--Parliament passed the Works Council Law yesterday. Under this measure, which was long and bitterly debated, the elected representatives of workers will be permitted to demand consultation in matters not only of labor relations but also of marketing, financing and other policies of management.

In the first meeting of its land ever held in this country, the National Conference on the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization brought together in Philadelphia last week 1,000 delegates representing 500 of the leading educational, professional, labor, civic, fraternal and religious groups in the nation.

TASSELFLOWER is an annual that receives little publicity in the seed catalogues. This is not because it is new, for it has been grown for generations, nor is it because it is difficult to grow. Perhaps it isn't spectacular enough to keep up with mammoth marigolds and fully double fluffy ruffled petunias.

The Knickerbockers will face an opportunity to grain a tie for second place in the Basketball Association of America race when they play the Philadelphia Warriors at Madison Square Garden tonight in the final regular game of the season. The Warriors, present occupants of the runner-up berth, lead the New Yorkers by a full game.

WARSAW, Poland, March 15 (By Mail) (AP) -- The American Joint Distribution Committee plans to spend more than $8,000,000 in Poland this year, "trying to rehabilitate every able-bodied Jew" and aid those in distress, whether they remain in Poland or leave this country," says William Bein of New York, director of the organization in Poland.

Banks are said to be insisting upon liquidation of excess inventories held by some borrowers, with commercial loans at a high mark, the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents reported in their monthly summary released yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Senator Robert A. Taft was still the leading contender today for Ohio's favorite son designation for the 1948 Presidential race, following last night's dinner-time caucus of Ohio political leaders in his home.
TWO viburnums deserve to be considered for placement in the garden this spring. They belong to a large, diverse family, and they have idiosyncrasies qualifying them for special uses.

When it comes to gaudy lures, the average surfcaster is very rapidly coming under the spell that has influenced fly fishermen for several centuries, and the good old days when a surfcaster walked the beach with a few block tin squids in his pocket are gone, perhaps forever.

The National Association of Manufacturers said yesterday that the American economic system could be preserved despite the recent world drift toward collectivism. This finding is announced in a two-volume book of 1,100 pages, "The American Individual Enterprise System," just published after a six-year study by the NAM's Economic Principles Commission.

HAVANA, March 29 -- One Dodger proved beyond doubt today that he is ready for the opening of the season. Even if he would say tonight, as he has said before, that he surely will win 30 games this year, nobody would argue with him.

The current rash of new import controls invoked by nations abroad is regarded in foreign-trade circles as one of the first signs of a return to a normal market, traders stated last week. Despite the fact that international trade is already heavily burdened with restrictions of every possible description and that the new controls are directed principally against the United States, trade experts found cause for considerable optimism.
MOSCOW, March 29--The Inter-Allied Reparations Agency told the Big Four deputies on Germany today that the present system of dealing with German reparations was unsatisfactory.

FAMAGUSTA, Cyprus, March 29 --In anticipation of a spring flood of refugees from Europe, accommodation for an additional 9,000 Jewish unauthorized immigrants-- making a total of 20,000--is being provided in British internment camps on the island of Cyprus.

Influenced by several favorable factors concerning labor and business, financial markets for the second successive week displayed an improved tone. Sentiment, which for many weeks has been hesitant and uncertain, veered to a more definite outlook following recent developments which already have been discounted.

Army Week will be observed throughout the country next week. In New York a program ending in the annual parade on Saturday, April 12, will be presented to stress the relationship between an adequate Army and national security.

Splitting up for the first time this season, Al Parsells and Del Carroll, Ramapo Polo Club stars, led different sides to triumph last night in the National junior indoor polo championship tournament at the Squadron A Armory.

Political figures of high and low degree fell victims to the lampooning of the Inner Circle, an organization of past and present political writers, before a dinner audience of 1,500 at the Hotel Astor last night.
NEW ORLEANS, March 29 -- Mississippi has two brand-new laws designed to protect the State's "white primary system," but the legislators who passed the laws are neither sure nor happy about them.

EDGAR BOHLMAN'S current show at the Ferargil is devoted entirely to ballet subjects. One group of water-colors has to do with S. Hurok's Original Ballet Russe. In a dozen or more papers he addresses himself to Ballet Theatre, and a couple of items relate to Katherine Dunham's "Tropical Revue."

A large site at the intersection of Raymond and Fulton Avenues opposite the gates of Vassar College and the Juliet Theatre, has been acquired by a syndicate of New York and Boston business men to be developed as a new shopping center for the Poughkeepsie area in Dutchess County, N.Y.

EVERY now and then there appears a regional anthology so well thought out, so coordinated, so imbued with deep love and intimate acquaintance with the section involved that it is a real gift both to knowledge and the imagination.

New chemicals from natural petroleum gases, used both as a raw material and as fuel, have been developed by Celanese Corporation of America, company officials announced here yesterday. Following their recent initial production of propionaldehyde, the third in a series of aldehydes, the company disclosed that expansion plans are now aimed at establishing its position as a leading producer of synthetic organic chemicals, comparable with its position as a producer of plastics and synthetic textiles.

ON the theory that a man is a chump to withdraw his hat from the jackpot while the nickels are still flowing, John Wildberg has been setting something of a producer's precedent by traveling around the country for the last six months as his own advance man for "Anna Lucasta."

Radiant heating--a system by which warmth is supplied by pipe coils buried or hidden in the walls, floors or ceilings of a building--is being used for the first time in residential buildings in New York now under construction on the East Side.

"OZARK FOLKSONGS," collected and edited by Vance Randolph, is a book which indicates the immense, amorphous oral literature of the folk ballad and song in America. Songs which were popular in Chaucer's England persist in the Ozarks, but with that fluidity of change which shows a constant creation going on, as each singer changes slightly each version.

ONE of the imponderable factors in bridge-playing skill, but no less an important one, is the ability to give up gracefully. The hardest thing for most bridge players to give up, apparently, is the prospect of a slam when they hold real powerhouse hands.

Radio Voice Control A nation-wide survey conducted by this department along original lines of its own yields in one important field much more impressive ratios than are usually recorded in such inquiries.

BOSTON, March 29 -- The political teakettle in Boston has boiled high over charges by war veterans and others that bribes have been demanded for city licenses. Some action to clean up the metropolitan situation now seems indicated.

HONOLULU, March 29 (AP)-- The missing lifeboat from the broken tanker Fort Dearborn was found last night by the steamship China Victory, but there was no sign of the twelve men who disappeared with it on the stormy night of March 12.
A new twelve-passenger bus for the transportation of disabled veterans, which was presented by an anonymous donor to the American Women's Voluntary Services, made its first official trip yesterday.

Ania Dorfmann, pianist, appeared as soloist in Beethoven's Concerto in C minor at last night's concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Efrem Kurtz, at Carnegie Hall. The program opened with the overture to Rossini's "La Gazza Ladra," and also contained two works which had been presented earlier in the week, namely, Shostakovich's First Symphony and Ravel's "Daphnis et Chloe" Suite, No. 2.
