CAMDEN, N.J., March 29-- The greatest number of commercial helicopters ever to be gathered at one place churned the air over Central Airport today in the world's first helicopter flying show.

FOR THIS WEEK: Rake and clean up branches after pruning. Burn any wood that harbors insects or disease and sort the remaining material into sizable pieces for the fireplace and brush for plant supports.... Remove evergreen branches from pansies transplanted last fall. Loosen other mulches.... Weed the flower borders, too.... Feed asparagus beds with commercial fertilizer and work any manure left from the winter covering into the soil.... Watch temperature in greenhouses.

AUGUSTA, Ga., March 29 (AP)-- Miss Dorothy Kirby of Atlanta held the lead by two strokes after fifty-four holes in the Augusta women's titleholders' golf tournament today with a total of 228, in the face of a strong challenge by Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Zaharias, who played the third round in a fourunder-par 71, a new record for the event.

Another college basketball season, this one the most successful of all, went into the archives last night. With it went a 66-58 victory by the West over the East in the second annual All-Star game and a turnout of 18,019 persons at Madison Square Garden agreed that the better squad had won.
The people of the Thirty-fourth Street section are pointing with pride to the continued high level of realty transactions in that area as a good omen for future stability and growth there.

DETROIT, March 29--A 1948 Packard super-eight convertible in six colors, with a 145-horsepower engine, was announced today by George H. Christopher, president and general manager of the Packard Motor Car Company.

Federal conciliators in an all-day session yesterday explored the positions of union and management in the key long lines telephone wage situation, seeking to bring about resumption of negotiations for a pattern agreement that would avert an industry - wide strike April 7.

WASHINGTON, March 29-- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, AFL, proclaimed today a Holy Week shutdown of the soft coal industry, beginning Tuesday, as a memorial and a protest against the Illinois mine accident which killed 111 workers.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 29--The Kasr el Nil barracks, which has been a symbol of the British occupation for sixty-four years was quietly and unceremoniously emptied of troops this morning as Britain completed the evacuation of Cairo two days ahead of schedule.

The formal signing at Batavia last Wednesday of the Linggadjati Agreement between the Dutch Government and the Indonesians marked a step on the long road from colonialism to democracy. Dr. Herbertus J. Van Mook, Lieutenant Governor General of the Netherlands Indies, has observed that the agreement "may not stop the shooting for a long time in Java, but we hope to get it on a more friendly basis."

An important deadline--Jan. 1, 1948--is looming for the insurance business. By that time, as specifically set forth in Public Law 15, the States must bring insurance legislation into conformity with what the Federal Government thinks it should be.

Tomorrow, March 31, is the deadline set by President Truman for Congressional approval of his $400,000,000 program of aid for Greece and Turkey--a program designed to initiate a new and broader foreign policy of supporting the free nations of the world against direct and indirect aggression.
EEK-- Detective Henry Darnell of Birmingham, Ala., snapped open the handbag of a woman suspected of shoplifting and came up with a dead mouse.

THIRTY years ago in this Review: Four books shared the honor of attention on Page 1, two of them being St. John Ervine's "Changing Winds" and Kathleen Norris' "Undertow." The first was judged "by all odds the biggest piece of work" its author had done.

AINTREE, England, March 29 --Eight-year-old Caughoo, Irish "bargain baby" who cost his owner a mere $200--and rewarded his backers at 100 to 1 in the books and a fantastic 200 to 1 in the mutuels--raced out of nowhere in the last killing yards today to win the 103d Grand National Steeplechase Handicap.

Retail store volume held up fairly well last week because business was on the pre-Easter level, according to the weekly market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc. However, it was pointed out, spending power would have to be maintained after Easter by a decrease in the cost of living.

LONDON, March 29--Sir Stafford Cripps, President of the Board of Trade, lived up to his reputation for plain talking today. He told workers that there was going to be a cut in the clothing ration, that food imports could not be increased, and that workers were not yet experienced enough to become managers.
Despite salary increases of $600 since 1945 and an additional $300 rise that will go into effect July 1, the resignation of teachers from the city's public schools have shown only a slight decrease.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 29--The demand by out-of-town people for summer rentals here, which in the past few years presented a windfall of high prices for local residents, appears to have passed its peak well in advance of the opening of the season here.

For the first time since pre-war days, a number of industrial plants in the New York area have been able to get all of their requirements of cold rolled steel on reasonably prompt deliveries, in the quantities actually ordered, spokesmen declared here last week.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The President's proposal to Congress that the United States inaugurate the "Truman Doctrine," which he enunciated at the same time, by making political loans or grants to Greece and Turkey to aid these Governments in resisting "armed minorities" or "outside pressure" that threaten their independence calls for a restatement of the various loaning functions of the Government in the foreign field.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)-- A 522,400,456 hospital being constructed at Peekskill, N.Y., has a thirty-seven-building plan which the Veterans Administration today termed unique in its current construction program.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president - emeritus of Columbia University, attacked "appeasement" of Soviet Russia yesterday as a course that "would lead only to friction and increase the possibility of war."

LONDON. THE Queen Elizabeth recently disembarked Paulette Goddard and Burgess Meredith to make pictures on this side, and at the time of writing these two were tying with John Strachey's press conference on food as top news.

AUSTIN Tex., March 29 (AP) --Three records fell, two others were tied and Tiny Jerry Thompson of Texas, who ran a 4:13 mile and 1:53.8 half-mile in anchoring two quartets to victory, was named outstanding performer today as the University of Texas dominated its own relays.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, March 29-- Liberal Judaism and the opportunity to serve mankind through cooperation with liberal Christianity are two great reasons for optimism in these discouraging years, Rabbi Allan Tarshish of Temple Beth Israel, Hazleton, Pa., said at the Hebrew Union College here this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)-- Frederick H. Osborn, United States Deputy on the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission, declared today in an address to the Women's Action Committee for Lasting Peace that efforts were being made to get an atomic treaty that was acceptable to all.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 29-- John M. Schmid, nationally known newspaper circulation executive and former circulation manager and business manager of The Indianapolis News, died in his home near Danville yesterday of a heart attack.

IN "Mid-Channel," the second volume of his autobiographic "Chronicle of America," Ludwig Lewisohn described the circumstances under which '"The Case of Mr. Crump" was written. After a stormy break with his first wife, which was made into a sensation by the yellow press, he sought refuge in Paris with Thelma Spear.

YELLOWSTONE, the first national park established in the United States, celebrated its seventy-fifth birthday this month. It was in March, 1872, that President Grant approved the act of Congress setting it aside is "a public park or pleasuring ground for the benefit and enjoyment of the people."
